title: Hanson Is Free to Buy More SCM Stock
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday cleared the way for Hanson Trust P.L.C. to resume purchases of the SCM Corporation's stock in the open market, and the action is likely to lead to a test of nerves on the part of the two companies.

title: Bengals Rip Apart Steelers' Defense
description: Boomer Esiason threw two touchdown passes to the tight end Rodney Holman and picked apart Pittsburgh's league-leading defense with short passes as the Cincinnati Bengals rallied for a 37-24 victory over the Steelers tonight.

title: Improving Employee Training
description: SEYMOUR LUSTERMAN, author of a new study for the Conference Board, ''Trends in Corporate Education and Training,'' has found what he considers to be important increases and changes in corporate training policies.

title: Gulfstream Land
description: The Gulfstream Land and Development Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by Kenneth M. Good, who already owns 24 percent of its 4.6 million common shares, for $37 a share. It said members of senior management would also own equity interests. Gulfstream, a land development and construction company, said the merger was subject to approval by institutional lenders and shareholders and may be terminated by either party if not completed by Feb. 1.

title: Producer's Body Found in Car
description: A retired movie executive's body was found Sunday after he was robbed, beaten and his car set afire in his suburban neighborhood, the police reported today.

title: 4 RUSSIAN MEN TAKEN HOSTAGE IN WEST BEIRUT
description: Four Soviet diplomats riding in official cars were kidnapped in West Beirut today, authorities said.

title: U.N. SPEAKERS DEAL WITH REGIONAL CONFLICTS
description: Many speakers at the General Assembly dealt today with the spread of regional conflicts, with some pointing to the continuing violence in South Africa as an example of these tensions.

title: FAME EVADES MARATHONER
description: Orlando Pizzolato has become a minor celebrity, the kind only a few people recognize.

title: 'Brigadoon' Will Open City Opera's Musicals
description: The New York City Opera's first musical comedy season will open Feb. 28 with ''Brigadoon,'' the company announced today.

title: PROGRAMS UNLIMITED reports earnings for Year to June 30
CORPORATE PROFIT DROP SEEN
description: Wall Street analysts have been cutting their estimates of third-quarter corporate earnings almost daily, and forecasters say that the actual reports, due out in the next two to three weeks, will be grim indeed.

title: Import Restraints Don't Help Industry
description: To understand the frustration that fuels the protectionist fervor in Congress, it is instructive to examine why voluntary restraints on imports favored by President Reagan do not help American industry. The case of steel producers is a good lesson.

title: CHINESE OFFICIAL ASKS END TO ARMS RACE IN SPACE
description: In a rebuke to both the Soviet Union and the United States, China's Foreign Minister called today for both countries to halt the arms race in outer space immediately.

title: KEY INFLUENCE OF GAMES IS SEEN IN NEW TRENDS
description: COMPUTER games are pretty much passe today, except perhaps among a small core of die-hard fanatics. All the same, their influence on personal computing has been tremendous, not merely because of the boost they gave to ''home'' computer sales, but also because of their profound effect on the direction of personal computing as a whole.

title: Topics;   Earned Interest Think Again
description: ''Think 12,'' reads the eye-catching ad implying that a New York bank offers 12 percent interest on three-year deposits. If you think 12 percent is too good to be true, you think right.

title: MICRON TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Net income.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Fathers and Sons Play Indian Music
description: South Indian musicians played a four-hour concert Saturday at the Borough of Manhattan Community College's Triplex Theater (199 Chambers Street) that was as brilliant as it was lengthy. It featured quartets led by the violinist Lalgudi Jayaraman and by the singer Maharajapuram Santhanam, both of whom trace their styles to disciples of the South Indian composer Thyagaraja (1767-1847).

title: Egypt Raises Price of Oil
description: Egypt is raising its oil price by 25 to 45 cents a barrel, for its second consecutive monthly increase. Egypt is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: 'MURDER: BY REASON OF INSANITY,' CBS DOCUDRAMA
description: MADE-FOR-TV dramas are notoriously partial to detailed portraits of psychopathic murderers, preferably based on a true story. The latest example, on CBS this evening at 9 o'clock, is ''Murder: By Reason of Insanity.'' For nearly two hours, a deranged man threatens and stalks his former wife until, as the title reveals, he gets to stab her to death in a brutish scene of violence. This is followed by some brief and unconvincing reassurances that minor changes in the law may help prevent similar situations in the future. Cut. Wrap. Take the money and run. As true-story treatments go on television, the script for ''Murder: By Reason of Insanity,'' written by Scott Swanton and Marjorie David, stays fairly close to the known facts. The film is based on a Newsday article, entitled ''Always a Victim,'' by Marilyn Goldstein. The case was also covered in a 1980 segment of CBS's ''60 Minutes'' series. And a note in the final credits, requiring a speed-reading degree to catch it, discloses: ''This motion picture is based in part on the interviews of Adam Berwid conducted by Lawrence Schiller.''

title: HEEKIN CAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 8
Pakistan-India Clash Is Reported in Kashmir
description: Indian and Pakistani troops battling for control of a border area in Kashmir exchanged heavy fire near a key frontier pass in the disputed territory, the Press Trust of India said today.

title: The Nose Knows
description: The United States Government has a word for it: In The FDA Consumer, the magazine of the Food and Drug Administration, a recent article noted that decomposi-tion in shellfish ''is detected by organoleptic analysis.''

title: U.S. PROSECUTOR CITES LOUISIANA GOVERNOR'S DEBT
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards of Louisiana was portrayed by a Federal prosecutor today as an debt-ridden fraud who betrayed the state in an illegal scheme to make millions of dollars.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CREW IN DALLAS SAW BAD WEATHER AHEAD
description: The crew of a Delta Air Lines plane talked of weather so severe it looked ''like a tornado or something'' two and a half minutes before another Delta plane crashed at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport Aug. 2, according to documents made public today.

title: UTILITIES EXPECT REPAIRS TO TAKE REST OF THE WEEK
description: Utility companies, still struggling to repair a record number of power failures inflicted Friday by Hurricane Gloria, said yesterday that it probably would take the rest of this week to restore electricity to most parts of Long Island and Connecticut.

title: CARROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
KOCH ORDERS ARTS SCHOOL INQUIRY AFTER NEW STUDY ON DESIGN FLAWS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday ordered an investigation of what he called possible ''incompetence or corruption'' in the construction of the most expensive public high school ever built in New York City. He acted after new disclosures of ''structural cracks'' and other design defects at the school.

title: MERCURY, PATRON OF THIEVES IS FOUND UNSUITABLE
description: The University of Rochester has decided that the doctors and dentists it trains ought not to be identified with Mercury, the Roman god of merchants, messengers and thieves. Accordingly, the university authorities have ruled that the caduceus, Mercury's stylized staff entwined with two snakes, may no longer be used in the institution's seal.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Bruce Benedict, catcher, to a three-year contract.

title: SMOKING TOLL SPURRING CURBS
description: ''NO SMOKING'' signs are proliferating in offices and factories now that managers are adapting the Surgeon General's health warnings to bottom-line concerns.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the Metropolitan Museum of Art's plans for a $35 million structure gave an incorrect date for the Landmarks Preservation Commission's consideration of the project. The plan will be considered in executive session ''sometime in the near future,'' according to Gene A. Norman, the commission's chairman.

title: Australian to Sell His Stake in Asarco
description: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier who has for the last year steadily built up his holdings in Asarco Inc., has agreed to sell his 14 percent stake in the New York mining company to M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an Australian metals producer, for $23 a share, or $97.6 million, Asarco said yesterday.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
'GENERATIONS' EXAMINES APARTHEID RESISTANCE
description: IN ''Generations of Resistance,'' an hourlong documentary film that can be seen at 11 o'clock tonight on Channel 13, the word ''African'' is heard more frequently than the word black. That is the underlying message emerging from this instructive historical survey of the resistance movement against apartheid in South Africa.

title: U.S. OFFERS GOAL TO END SPREAD OF DEADLY AIDS
description: The United States Public Health Service today unveiled a long-range plan to control the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, that acknowledges that no vaccine or cure is likely for at least five more years and that the disease would therefore continue to spread until the turn of the century.

title: COMPUTERLAND MOVES TO AVERT DEALER REVOLT
description: Edward E. Faber, the new president and chief executive of the Computerland Corporation, rushed today to forestall a revolt of the computer retailer's franchisees by promising a sweeping corporate reorganization and cuts in the fees the franchisees pay to corporate headquarters.

title: Kremlin's Way of Holding a Nation at Bay
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS reports earnings for Year to June 30
CORRECTION
description: A listing on Sunday of food establishments cited for violations included an incorrect mention, provided by the City Health Department, of the Box Tree restaurant at 250 East 49th Street. The restaurant corrected four earlier violations; it remains open.

title: Dodgers Stalled
description: Jerry Davis singled home Miguel Dilone with the tiebreaking run in the ninth inning tonight to lead the San Diego Padres to a 6-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: TRIAL OPENS IN DEATH AT TEXAS NURSING HOME
description: A corporation that runs nursing homes in Texas and its top management went on trial today on charges of murdering an 87-year-old woman by neglect.

title: Come In, Afghanistan
description: Radio Free Afghanistan is to begin broadcasting today, using the transmitting facilities of the United States anti-Communist stations, Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty.

title: PENTAGON REASSESSES SOVIET BOMBER
description: The Defense Intelligence Agency has significantly lowered its estimate of the range of a Soviet bomber that has figured in the Geneva arms talks, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Plea Entered by DeLorean
description: John Z. DeLorean pleaded not guilty today to defrauding investors in his car company of $8.9 million. He was released on a $1 million unsecured bond.

title: Superior Program for a Police Cadet Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. Not available* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Broken Hill to Lift Stakes in Concerns
description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company said that it would spend $700 million to increase its stakes in two Australian mining operations. The Australian company said that it would pay $280 million for the 25 percent interest in the Mount Newman iron ore joint venture held by Amax Inc., which is based in Greenwich, Conn.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS 7-NATION MEETING
description: President Reagan plans to meet next month in New York with the leaders of six industrialized nations to discuss his summit meeting in November with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the White House announced today.

title: Chief Executive Officer Appointed by Biogen
description: Biogen N.V., a biotechnology company that has been in the forefront of research for an anti-cancer drug, yesterday named James L. Vincent, the head of the health and scientific products unit of Allied-Signal Inc., to be chief executive officer.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY SOVIET ARMS PLAN IS NOT BALANCED
description: The Soviet Union formally proposed today that the United States reduce its long-range and medium-range nuclear weapons by 50 percent, while offering a reduction that would cover only Soviet long-range weapons, according to American officials here.

title: PROBLEMS AFTER MYOPIA SURGERY CITED IN STUDY
description: ONE-THIRD of patients undergoing a simple surgical procedure designed to correct nearsightedness have suffered fluctuations in the quality of their vision in the second year after the operation, according to a new report. Scientists said the finding was surprising and a cause for concern.

title: Judge in AIDS Hearing Asks About Quarantine for Adults
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens expressed incredulity yesterday that the City Health Department does not quarantine adults with advanced cases of AIDS.

title: The Arms Control Tangle
description: In their somewhat disingenuous presummit maneuvers, President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev have already framed the arms control issues they confront. They have not yet collided head on, but someone is going to have to veer off.

title: RANGERS, ISLANDERS DROP 26
description: The Rangers and the Islanders both made large reductions in their rosters yesterday. The Rangers cut 11 players, the Islanders 15.

title: TRADE IN SERVICES URGED AS PARLEY TOPIC
description: The major industrial nations today called for a rapid start of international trade-freeing negotiations that would seek, for the first time, to end obstacles to trade in services as well as goods.

title: RISING DEBT TO REPAY STUDENT LOANS IS CAUSING CONCERN
description: OVER the last 10 years, Jesse L. Smith has become more educated and more in debt.

title: Topics;   Earned Interest Manners
description: New Yorkers who are especially polite to out-of-towners this fall may get a pleasant surprise. The Association for a Better New York will award $1,000 each week for model behavior by citizens whose work puts them in contact with visitors.

title: BALLOON BARGAINS LURE SCIENTISTS
description: AS the costs of space vehicles, particle accelerators and telescopes soar out of sight, scientists are turning back to the humble balloon - little changed since its invention two centuries ago -as a cut-rate tool for exploring the origin and nature of the universe.

title: Canadian Auto Workers Vote To Authorize Chrysler Strike
description: Union employees of Chrysler Canada Ltd. voted today to authorize a strike if current contract talks with the company fail, a Canadian United Auto Workers union spokesman said.

title: COURIER DISPATCH GROUP reports earnings for Year to June 30
RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 1.

title: CHRISTIANA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $167,000 for the quarter and a gain of $430,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net income. Results for the year ended June 30, 1984, include gain of $2,724,000 on disposition of partnership interests.

title: REAGAN REQUESTS THAT HECKLER QUIT HER CABINET POST
description: President Reagan today asked Margaret M. Heckler to give up her post as the Secretary of Health and Human Services and to become Ambassador to Ireland.

title: METS NEED SWEEP IN ST. LOUIS
description: The task, Howard Johnson says, will be ''very tough, probably next to impossible.'' The task, Ron Darling acknowledges, will be ''very difficult but not impossible, definitely not impossible.''

title: Mom's Command Injured
description: Mom's Command will miss her scheduled showdown with Lady's Secret in the Rare Perfume Stakes at Belmont Park Saturday because she took a few bad steps after a workout Sunday. Her handlers are concerned enough to say her career may be over.

title: SIMONE SIGNORET DIES IN FRANCE AT 64
description: Simone Signoret, the Academy Award-winning French actress who starred in ''Diabolique,'' ''Room at the Top'' and ''Ship of Fools,'' died of cancer yesterday at her country house in Normandy. She was 64 years old and also lived in Paris.

title: U.S. Would Sell China A Munitions Factory
description: The Pentagon today notified Congress that it has offered to sell China plans and equipment for a munitions factory in what would be the first Government-to-Government arms sale between the two nations.

title: Jerome Robbins to Get Astaire Dance Award
description: The choreographer Jerome Robbins will receive an Astaire Award for lifetime achievement in dance at the fourth annual awards ceremony, to be presented by the Anglo-American Contemporary Dance Foundation, on Monday at 7 P.M. in the Rainbow Room of the RCA Building at Rockefeller Center. This will be the first time the foundation has honored a choreographer specifically for a lifetime contribution to dance.

title: Salvador Military Action Halted in Rebel Region
description: The Salvadoran armed forces have virtually halted their operations in the region where the kidnapped daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte may be held, according to military and civilian sources.

title: Alexander Services Inc. Names Unit Chairman
description: William M. Wilson, president and chief executive of the Reed Stenhouse Companies Ltd., has been named to head the international subsidiary of Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the insurance brokerage firm that acquired Reed Stenhouse earlier this year, the company said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Greer Expected To Plead Guilty
description: Shelby Greer, charged with distributing cocaine to major league baseball players, is expected to plead guilty to seven counts, his attorney said tonight.

title: LEADING INDICATORS UP BY 0.7%
description: The Government index devised to foretell broad moves in the economy rose a substantial seven-tenths of 1 percent in August, the fourth consecutive monthly gain, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Millen's Secret
description: Hugh Millen, the University of Washington quarterback, was hospitalized and was administered antibiotics intravenously the two days before the Huskies defeated U.C.L.A., 21-14, Saturday, team officials revealed yesterday.

title: Mitchell Quitting Congress
description: Representative Parren J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maryland, announced today that he is retiring and will not seek re-election in 1986. Mr. Mitchell, 62 years old, who has been a member of Congress since 1971, would only confirm that he is retiring and declined to elaborate on his plans. He ran unopposed in 1984 and has been a staunch supporter of civil rights and an equally vigorous critic of President Reagan.

title: 'SUGARBABY,' FROM WEST GERMANY
description: IN the West German film ''Sugarbaby,'' directed by Percy Adlon, a big, brawny mortuary worker named Marianne (Marianne Sagebrecht) develops a mad crush on a good-looking Munich subway conductor many years her junior. Mad isn't really the word for it, since Mr. Adlon's film retains a cool, stylish reserve that would not seem conducive to strong passions. However, the unexpected element here is humor, and ''Sugarbaby'' has quite a lot of dry, measured wit. Neither this drollness nor the pathos surrounding Marianne is in the least bit obscured by Mr. Adlon's predilection for understatement.

title: KNICKS SIGN CARTWRIGHT TO 6-YEAR PACT
description: Slowly, the Knicks' intriguing picture is beginning to take form. This afternoon, between the fifth and sixth practice sessions of camp, the team announced the signing of the free-agent center Bill Cartwright to a contract that will pay him an average of $1.2 million annually over the next six seasons.

title: NAVAL ACADEMY MIDSHIPMAN SENTENCED TO PRISON FOR THEFT
description: A midshipman at the United States Naval Academy who pleaded guilty to stealing $5,000 in merchandise from an Academy store was sentenced at a court-martial today to three years in military prison and dismissed from the school.

title: Hepatitis Vaccine Proves Effective
description: A new genetically engineered hepatitis B vaccine appears as safe as the current vaccine made from human blood and may be more effective, the Government reported today.

title: OVERHAUL OF THE APPLE II: IT'S MORE LIKE A MACINTOSH
description: APPLE has just introduced a bushel of new peripherals that make the Apple II more like a Macintosh.

title: Merrill Lynch Fills Key Financial Post
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the parent of the nation's largest brokerage concern, yesterday named Courtney F. Jones, the treasurer of the General Motors Corporation, to be chief financial officer. He will be responsible for all the firm's treasury and credit operations.

title: Where Norfolk Southern/Conrail's New Traffic Would Come From
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1985
description: International

title: COLD WEATHER HELPS DRIVE OFF DULUTH BEARS
description: An early cold snap has led some of Minnesota's black bears to prepare to hibernate, helping to end a search for food that saw as many as 70 of them wander into this city each day.

title: JETS HANGING ON THIS YEAR
description: The Jets, who turned the ball over 34 times last season, have apparently learned to hold on to the ball.

title: Bridge: When Good-Looking Hand Deteriorates in the Bidding
description: Some superb-looking hands decline rapidly in value as the auction develops. On the diagramed deal, South was looking forward to exploring slam possibilities when North opened two spades with a hand that had one fewer spade than one would expect.

title: Offerings Of Equities Show Rise
description: While the stock and bond markets struggled in much of the third quarter, which ended yesterday, business was strong for securities underwriters.

title: Big Return
description: Under Casey Stengel the Yankees won nine pennants from 1949 to 1958 with clubs that, for all their strengths, usually sought ''pennant insurance'' in each season's late stages. They went after veteran players like Johnny Mize (1949), Johnny Hopp (1950), Johnny Sain (1951), Ewell Blackwell and Ray Scarborough (1952), Enos Slaughter (1956), Sal Maglie (1957) and Murray Dickson (1958) to provide seasoned assistance during stretch drives.

title: KOCH FIGHTS FOES OF S.I. NAVY BASE
description: Mayor Koch began a campaign yesterday against a referendum designed to block a Navy base on Staten Island for ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons.

title: Arco Assets Sale
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said it had completed the sale of its Philadelphia refinery, the Fort Mufflin marine terminal and its Pennsylvania marketing and distribution networks to the Atlantic Petroleum Corporation for about $420 million.

title: Judge Orders U.S. To Hold Population Aid
description: A Federal judge ordered the State Department tonight to wait to grant to other agencies or foreign countries $10 million originally intended by Congress for the United Nations Fund for Population Activities.

title: SALUTE TO THE ART OF BALENCIAGA
description: ''Homage to Balenciaga,'' a luminously installed retrospective exhibition of the work of one of the fashion giants of this century, drew crowds to its opening at the Museum of Historic Textiles over the weekend. Many designers, including those who trained with Balenciaga, came from Paris to pay their respects and to learn.

title: AFGHAN REBELS REPORT U.S. DEATH
description: Afghan rebels said today that an American journalist, Charles Thornton, was killed in Afghanistan when the jeep in which he was riding was destroyed by a land mine on Wednesday.

title: WILLIAM JAMES: STATURE RAISED IN NEW APPRAISAL
description: WILLIAM JAMES, one of the great psychologists of the turn-of-the-century, is being restored to what some see as his rightful place of prominence. Although James is widely acknowledged these days for his ability to draw others into the fledgling field of psychology and for his influence as a popularizer, today's historians point to what they see as his under-appreciated strength as an experimental scientist. They also say that he deserves credit for creating a early coherent theory of the unconscious.

title: Quick Fix
description: Armed with a 42-3-1 record as football coach at little Wabash College, Stan Parrish went looking for a Division I-A job after the 1982 season, but no one would give him a chance. He was turned down by Indiana and others, and became the quarterback coach at Purdue.

title: WEST GERMAN BACKS PARTICIPATION IN 'STAR WARS'
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's national security adviser called today for a governmental agreement with the United States to coordinate the participation of West German industry in the Reagan Administration's research program for an antimissile shield.

title: Books and Suzanne Mubarak
description: WHEN the late Anwar el-Sadat was President of Egypt, his wife, Jihan, became something of an international star. She spoke out on controversial issues on which Egyptian women were usually silent, lectured at home and abroad, appeared on television and traveled the world on behalf of her causes, opening exhibits and visiting rehabilitation centers.

title: The Electoral College Fits Our Republic Well
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1985
description: The Economy

title: CUTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: HERBERT BAYER, 85, A DESIGNER AND ARTIST OF BAUHAUS SCHOOL
description: Herbert Bayer, a painter, architect, graphic and industrial designer and one of the last ''masters'' of the Bauhaus, the influential design school founded by Walter Gropius in 1919 at Weimar, Germany, died yesterday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 85 years old and had been in poor health for some time.

title: INTERFERON IS USED FOR GENITAL WARTS
description: Injections of the germ-fighting hormone interferon appear to be a promising new treatment for genital warts, one of the nation's most common venereal disease problems, researchers said today.

title: THEFT CASE INCLUDES THE PURPORTED CHIEF OF GAMBINO GROUP
description: The man accused of heading the Gambino crime organization went on trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, with the judge telling potential jurors that their identities would be kept secret.

title: Digital Research To Modify GEM
description: Digital Research Inc. of Monterey, Calif., said that it would modify its GEM operating systems programs to avoid claims by Apple Computer Inc. that the programs violate Apple's copyrights.

title: MILITARY CONTRACTS
description: The Defense Department ended its fiscal year today by awarding 132 contracts worth almost $1.1 billion, including $104 million it would have lost had it not been obligated. Most of the awards were for fairly small amounts and less than 10 percent of the money obligated would have actually lapsed had it not been dispensed. The biggest single contract announced today was an Army contract for $70. million, which went to the Lycoming division of the Avco Corporation for 143 gas turbine engines.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE INMAN DIARY. A Public and Private Confession. Edited by Daniel Aaron. Two volumes. 1,661 pages. Illustrated. Harvard. $39.95 until Dec. 31, $50 thereafter. WITH the appearance of this huge slab of self-revelation, space will have to be found for a new entry in the annals of American literature: Arthur Crew Inman (1895-1963). It is not the entry that Inman himself would ideally have chosen; he first set out to win fame as a poet, paid for the publication of several volumes of mediocre verse and clung to the conviction that although he was never mentioned by the critics who ''pedestalized'' Robert Frost, Carl Sandburg and the like, his time would eventually come. (''I am superbly patient in big things.'') But at some point in the 1920's he decided that his best chance of achieving immortality lay in the diary that he had begun keeping in 1919 - a personal record intended to be the most candid and inclusive ever written.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary net gain of $55,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary net loss of $951,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,178,000. Results for the latest quarter and year reflect LIFO accounting. Year- ago results are based on FIFO accounting.

title: U.S. LEASE LAPSES AT PACIFIC ATOLL
description: The United States lease on a missile testing range at Kwajalein atoll in the Marshall Islands was to expire at midnight tonight, and a spokesman for the native owners of the land said today that they would demand a substantial increase in their present compensation of about $12 million a year in cash and services.

title: Shelton Out
description: Lonnie Shelton, the Cavaliers' veteran forward, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee today. Shelton injured the knee Saturday in a collision with the guard Johnny Davis during practice, said Bob Price, a Cavalier spokesman. The extent of the injury will be learned during the surgery, Price said.

title: PHILIP MORRIS MERGER LOANS CAME MOSTLY FROM ABROAD
description: The Philip Morris Companies' $6 billion takeover of the General Foods Corporation is being financed by a carefully crafted package involving loans from 46 banks - 17 domestic banks and 29 international institutions. And this package, the financial underpinnings of the largest merger outside the energy industry, was put together in less than a week by two Philip Morris executives calling scores of banks.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OFFICER ARRESTS COOK
description: A manager and a district supervisor of a fast-food chain were shot and killed in the company's Westbury, L.I., restaurant shortly before opening time yesterday by a man who escaped with more than $4,000 in weekend receipts, the police reported.

title: Science Isn't George
description: The Russians have delivered their new arms-control proposal in Geneva, the first time they have offered substantial reductions and not just ceilings on existing arsenals. At last, there is a start on real negotiations.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: JOANN BERMAN, Parsons School of Design class of '87, says she feels she has been a student forever. She did indeed go to college and to art school in London before entering Parsons, and is, she says, the oldest person in her class at the age of 28.

title: OFFICIALS TO LEVY $100 FINES
description: Beginning today, city inspectors are authorized to levy $100 fines for any shower head that does not comply with the new flow limit of three gallons of water a minute. To comply, the shower head must be fitted with a restrictor, or be on a list of acceptable shower heads compiled by New York State.

title: Hayes Hospitalized
description: The hospitalization of Woody Hayes, the former Ohio State football coach, is apparently for more serious reasons than physicians first believed. Dr. Robert Murphy, Ohio State's team physician, said yesterday that test results indicated Hayes suffered a mild heart attack instead of what was initially thought to be a case of congestive heart failure.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of Andree's Mediterranean Cuisine in Weekend on Friday, incorrectly described the preparation of a seafood couscous. The dish is prepared in the Jewish style, which omits shellfish.

title: SABERHAGEN'S 20TH TIES RACE IN WEST
description: Reggie Jackson made his reputation on these kinds of confrontations, but tonight he simply stood motionless at the plate. Bret Saberhagen, whose value to the Kansas City Royals is no less than Dwight Gooden's is to the Mets, fired three straight fastballs. Jackson watched them all, then walked quietly back to the dugout.

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss from disposal of discontinued operations of $107,000 and an extraordinary tax credit of $462,000. c-After a loss from disposal of discontinued operations of $356,000.

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $328,296 for the quarter and year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $170,991 for the quarter and year.

title: General Foods Helps Dow Post Gain
description: A sharp rise in the price of the General Foods Corporation's stock helped the Dow Jones industrial average record a sizable gain yesterday, but the market over all was little changed on only moderately heavy volume.

title: More Trials Are Due On Organized Crime
description: The ''pizza connection'' and Paul Castellano trials are the first of several major organized-crime cases scheduled for trial in New York in coming months.

title: QUEBEC'S NEW LEADER: PIERRE MARC JOHNSON
description: Less than a decade ago, a young doctor quit his residency at a hospital in East Montreal to try his hand at politics, reasoning that he could help more people as a politician than as a physician. On Sunday night, Pierre Marc Johnson was elected the new leader of Quebec's governing Parti Quebecois, collecting the votes of 59,925 party members, or 58.5 percent of those casting ballots.

title: KOREAN DISSIDENT GOES HOME TO UNSEEN SHACKLES
description: Nearly eight months after returning from exile in the United States, Kim Dae Jung has yet to make it all the way back home.

title: Esta Gluck, a Plaintiff In Church-State Case
description: Esta Gluck, one of two plaintiffs in an unsuccessful suit to bar New York City from giving public-school children time off for religious instruction, died of cancer last Friday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 74 years old.

title: ALCOHOL ABUSE IS BECOMING A PUBLIC POLICY ISSUE
description: Across the nation, as cities ban happy hours, states raise the legal drinking age to 21 and various groups campaign against irresponsible drinking, the danger of alcohol abuse is a major topic of public discussion.

title: Fighting Tropical Diseases
description: The probability that researchers will be able to develop successful measures to control tropical diseases ''has never been greater than it is today,'' according to a report issued by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment. But the Federal Government is spending less than $100 million a year on tropical disease research, a tiny fraction of its total annual biomedical research budget of well over $4 billion, the Congressional agency estimates.

title: Bonds Are Priced For Health Care
description: A $165 million tax-exempt bond issue of the Mercy Health Care System of Providence, R.I., and Cincinnati was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9.83 percent for 9 3/4 percent bonds due in 2013 at a price of 99 1/4, according to underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Nets cut a pair of guards, Butch Graves of Yale and George Almones of Southwest Louisiana, reducing their roster to 15 players, excluding of Albert King and Mike Gminski, their unsigned free agents. . . . Fordham will hold a news conference today to introduce Frank McLaughlin as its new athletic director. . . . The Indiana Pacers, who reached a verbal agreement with Wayman Tisdale, their top draft choice, over the weekend, have run into a snag over several unspecified issues. ''We have encountered some issues with certain terms of the contract,'' said Bob Salyers, club president.

title: Cyprus at 25
description: The Republic of Cyprus is observing the 25th anniversary of the island's liberation from British colonial rule today, but Ambassador Andrew J. Jacovides of Cyprus says it is something less than a full celebration. For a small point, the real anniversary was Aug. 16 but was moved by Parliament to Oct. 1 because Cyprus, like Paris, pretty much closes down in August.

title: Universities that Divest Hurt Themselves
description: How tempting it is for universities to divest their endowment holdings in companies that do business in South Africa. It seems an opportunity finally to do something, to take a stand that might help halt the tragedy of apartheid.

title: CUOMO ANNOUNCES NEW DRIVE TO ENCOURAGE HIRING OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS
description: Governor Cuomo said today that his administration would begin a new drive to get private employers to hire welfare recipients in return for subsidies of part of their wages from the state.

title: DONALD MOFFAT, LISTENING IN 'ICEMAN'
description: Along with the audience at ''The Iceman Cometh,'' Donald Moffat spends most of the play's nearly five hours sitting down. He rises only three times during the performance of the critically acclaimed revival of the Eugene O'Neill drama - and a fourth time near midnight at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, to take a bow when most of the audience has risen to give him and the rest of the cast a standing ovation.

title: GURU'S BOOK IS BURNED AT OREGON COMMUNE
description: Followers of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh sang and danced around a bonfire tonight as they burned about 5,000 copies of the sect's former holy book and the robes of the guru's former secretary.

title: FOR LILCO, ONE MORE SETBACK
description: Even before Hurricane Gloria reduced much of its electric system to tangled and broken power lines last Friday, the Long Island Lighting Company was just about the financially weakest American utility, analysts widely agree.

title: FUEL IN SKYDIVERS' PLANE IS CALLED CONTAMINATED
description: A single-engine plane that crashed Sunday, killing the pilot and 16 skydivers, carried contaminated fuel and may have been overloaded, the chairman of the Federal investigating panel said today.

title: COPING WITHOUT THE MICROWAVE AND THE VCR
description: Since the hurricane, the Mead household here has been getting along without the microwave, the video recorder and the personal computer.

title: Congress;   Frustration, Resignation and the C.I.A.
description: After investigating Central Intelligence Agency abuses of recent decades, a Senate committee concluded in 1976 that ''Congress has failed to provide the necessary statutory guidelines to insure that intelligence agencies carry out their missions in accord with constitutional process.''

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   American and British New Piano Music
description: The pianist Eliza Garth's splendid Saturday evening recital at Merkin Concert Hall was devoted entirely to new music from Britain and the United States.

title: HINDERLITER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-No share earnings because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Bomb Scare Forces Landing Of a People Express Airliner
description: A People Express Airlines Boeing 747 made an unscheduled landing at a military airfield here this morning after airline officials received a bomb threat.

title: SECRECY TO SURROUND ATLANTIS'S FIRST FLIGHT
description: THE space shuttle Atlantis is to roar into space Thursday for the first time. The $1.2 billion Atlantis, the fourth and final addition to the nation's fleet of winged spaceships, will get little of the fanfare normally associated with a maiden voyage. Instead, the mission is to be wrapped in secrecy from start to finish.

title: No Apology for Stockman
description: Larry M. Speakes, the White House spokesman, didn't say so at the time, but he was apparently relieved when David Stockman left in July for job on Wall Street.

title: Mahaffey Wins
description: John Mahaffey made up four shots on the last four holes to tie Jodie Mudd at the end of regulation, then won the storm-delayed Texas Open on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff today.

title: Mergers' Impact on Campaigns
description: AS head of a corporation that is as dependent on communicating with the consumer as the Philip Morris Companies, then, be assured, Hamish Maxwell, its chief executive, is considering what effect any major corporate move will have on its advertising program.

title: Carbon Monoxide in Factory
description: Twenty-five people were taken to hospitals for treatment of nausea and breathing problems after inhaling carbon monoxide fumes at a fish processing plant Sunday night, officials said. In addition, 42 workers were treated at the scene after the fumes filled the Galletti Brothers Foods plant, according to a Fire Department spokesman.

title: INDEX OPTIONS TRADE WIDENS
description: Competition intensified yesterday in the crowded fields of stock index and foreign currency options as several exchanges either began trading new products or announced plans to do so within a few weeks.

title: 300 OLD MASTER PRINTS TO GO ON SALE IN LONDON
description: The Duke of Devonshire, owner of one of the largest art collections in the world, will sell 300 Old Master prints, including major works by Rembrandt, Mantegna, Durer, van Leyden and Castiglione, to raise money to maintain the art at Chatsworth, his sprawling 17th-century stone mansion in Devon.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,097,000 for the quarter and $2,980,000 for the year and a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $22,193,000 for the quarter and year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Co. has elected Michael P. Monaco comptroller. John R. Laird was elected senior vice president and treasurer.

title: I.B.M. to Make Announcement
description: The International Business Machines Corporation notified industry analysts yesterday to expect a ''significant'' announcement this morning, fueling speculation that the company was preparing to enter the supercomputer market.

title: AN OLD STANDBY WORKS
description: Ed Hughes laughed quietly, almost malevolently. He thinks he'll keep his Statue of Liberty play under wraps for a while.

title: Home-Buying Abililty
description: An index measuring the typical family's ability to buy a home rose in August, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: Well in Virginia Town Is Opened to Public
description: Excess salt in the city's water supply has led Chesapeake to provide free well water to residents, who must fill their own containers from one of eight faucets at the Civic Center here.

title: New Medical Chief
description: Samuel O. Thier, chairman of the department of internal medicine at Yale University's medical school, will become president of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences this month.

title: Hurwitz Planning a Bid For Pacific Lumber Co.
description: Maxxam Group Inc., led by Charles E. Hurwitz, the Texas financier and oilman, said today that it planned to start a tender offer for the Pacific Lumber Company at $36 a share, or a total of about $781 million.

title: Unhappy Fiscal New Year!
description: Another year, another $200 billion or so. Fiscal 1985 ended at midnight with another record Federal budget deficit. President Reagan has tried to reduce it without raising taxes. Congress has mostly done his bidding. Yet despite their determined efforts, the deficit rose. The message is clear.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HUNT FOR SIGNALS FROM SPACE
description: A giant antenna that astronomers will use to search for possible radio signals from space has been activated at the Oak Ridge Observatory in Harvard, a small town northwest of Boston.

title: 17 UTILITIES GIVING HELP TO LILCO IN REPAIRING HURRICANE DAMAGE
description: Wielding a chain saw in one hand and wire clippers in another, Carl Sorge approached his next objective - removing electric power lines from the branches of an oak tree toppled last Friday by Hurricane Gloria.

title: Analysts Favor Large H.M.O.'s
description: As hospital and medical costs soar and employers shift more of those costs back to employees, H.M.O.'s - health maintenance organizations - are enrolling new members at a brisk pace. Although many publicly owned H.M.O.'s have already surged in price, analysts say the stocks of the giants in the field may be headed for even better times as a shakeout in the industry develops.

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DID MAYANS COLLAPSE LATER THAN SCIENTISTS THOUGHT?
description: THE reason for the collapse of the ancient Maya civilization in Central America may not be as big a mystery as archeologists have thought. According to new excavations in Belize, the collapse seems to have come later than generally assumed, late enough to have been caused by massive epidemics of disease introduced by European conquerors.

title: NEW SHEPARD PLAY EVICTING OLD ONE
description: The acclaimed Off Broadway production of Sam Shepard's ''Curse of the Starving Class'' may be forced to close within two weeks.

title: F.T.C. Lawyer Joins Ad Group
description: Advertising certainly could not be as bad as some regulators suggest.

title: Fahlgren & Swink Gets Lottery Account
description: Fahlgren & Swink, which claims advertising dominance in the states of West Virginia and Ohio, has been tapped as the agency for the recently created West Virginia state lottery.

title: Warm Opening
description: It was just like in the movies.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.). Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis.

title: Anheuser-Busch
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said its 12th brewery would be built in Fort Collins at a cost of $300 million, with 1988 seen as the completion date.

title: Robinson Traded
description: The linebacker Jerry Robinson, who refused to report to the Philadelphia Eagles because of a salary dispute, has been traded to the Los Angeles Raiders for ''a high future draft choice,'' a Raiders spokesman said.

title: DANE RUDHYAR
description: Dane Rudhyar, a composer, writer and mystic, died Sept. 13 in San Francisco. He was 90 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Wanted: Arts Patron
description: ''The Royal Costumes of India,'' the winter exhibition of the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is due to open Dec. 20, but it still has no financial sponsor.

title: ANGOLA REPORTS SOUTH AFRICAN AIR ATTACK
description: Angola said South African airplanes attacked its forces in a southeastern province early today, killing more than 50 soldiers in an operation aimed at supporting South African ground troops helping Angolan rebels.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: YANKEES RALLY TO WIN AFTER NIEKRO QUEST FAILS
description: Where the gallant Phil Niekro failed, the triumvirate of Don Mattingly, Dave Winfield and Don Baylor succeeded, and the Yankees are still in a pennant race.

title: PATTERSON GAINS RESPECT
description: An hour after Elvis Patterson made his game-winning interception return against the Eagles Sunday, each member of the Giant defense was off in a different part of the locker room, recounting his version of the play.

title: Milwaukee to Pay Family After a Death in Custody
description: The city will pay $600,000 in a settlement reached today with the family of a man who died while in police custody for questioning about a rape it was later determined he did not commit.

title: CELLCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Results for year-ago 9-months are for the period Oct. 26, 1983 through June 30, 1984.

title: 11 Rebels Killed in Bogota
description: Policemen killed 11 leftist rebels, including three women, in the capital today, the police said.

title: Taiwan Rewards 2 Who Stole Chinese Boat and Weapons
description: A doctor and a soldier who commandeered a Chinese fishing boat and forced the crew to sail to Taiwan at gunpoint have been granted political asylum by the Nationalist Government, a spokesman said today.

title: HANNA-GRACE SPLIT
description: The M. A. Hanna Company and W. R. Grace and Company are changing their joint ownership of two coal companies to seperate ownership.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Swedish Group In Baroque Works
description: The Drottningholm Baroque Ensemble came to Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night bearing the name of the palace near Stockholm that is home to the king and queen of Sweden. There were six members, all using period instruments, and two guests - Andrew Dalton, a countertenor, and Clas Pehrsson, a recorder player.

title: POLISARIO'S DELEGATES TOLD TO LEAVE SPAIN OVER ATTACKS AT SEA
description: Spain today ordered representatives of the Polisario Front, the guerrillas fighting for the independence of Western Sahara, to leave within three days.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend paid July 17.

title: DWI CORP reports earnings for Year to June 28
A NEW SHANGHAI IS STIRRING
description: The horns of the ships still bray from the Huang-pu River, waking visitors in the night. Crowds still parade along the Bund, the riverfront boulevard, admiring the view. The buildings of the great banks and mercantile houses and hotels - the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank, the Bank of China, the Central Bank, the Communications Bank, the Farmers Bank, the Oriental, the Agra, the Mercantile and the huge Sassoon House - still line the quay.

title: SPY'S DEFECTION FUELS DEBATE IN GREECE
description: The newly confirmed defection of a senior Soviet military intelligence official who was based in Greece and the arrest of three purported Greek spies has fueled an intense political dispute here over the extent of Soviet spying in this NATO nation.

title: CITY SAYS RESERVOIR SYSTEM REAPED 2.31 INCHES OF RAIN
description: The heavy rainfall that accompanied Hurricane Gloria has helped raise water levels in reservoirs supplying New York City, but not as much as originally estimated, city officials said yesterday.

title: COCKPIT DIALOGUE BEFORE DELTA CRASH
description: Here are excerpts from the transcript of cockpit conversations and radio transmissions from Delta Airlines Flight 191, which crashed at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport on Aug. 2, killing 136 people. The transcript was released today by the National Transportation Safety Board, with some words deleted. 5:48:06 P.M. - Pilot: Getting kind of hot in the oven with this controller. See, that's what the lack of experience does. I'm glad we didn't have to go through that mess. I thought sure he was going to send us through it. 5:51:19 - Engineer: Looks like it's raining over Fort Worth. 5:51:23 - Co-pilot: Yeah. 5:53:41 - Controller: Delta 191 heavy, descend to 7,000. 5:53:44 - Pilot: Delta 191 out of nine for seven. 5:55:14 - Low-altitude warning buzzer. 5:55:46 - Controller: Delta 191 heavy, turn 10 degrees left, reduce speed to 180. 5:55:50 - Pilot: Delta 191, wilco. 5:57:19 - Engineer: Down to no smoking. (The pilot receives permission to go around a cloud buildup. Another low-altitude alert sounds.) 5:58:19 - Unidentified crew member: All that screwing around. 5:59:47 - Co-pilot: We're gonna get our airplane washed. 5:59:50 - Pilot: What? 5:59:51 - Co-pilot: We're gonna get our airplane washed. 6:00:36 - Approach controller: American 351, do you see the airport yet? 6:00:38 - American 351: As soon as we break out of this rain shower we will. 6:00:40 - Approach controller: O.K., 351, you're four from the marker.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS EXTENSION OF 16/-A-PACK TAX ON CIGARETTES
description: The House and the Senate, faced with fiscal-year deadlines at midnight, voted today to extend several programs, including a ceiling on dairy price supports and the 16-cent-a-pack cigarette tax.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You forget how spoiled you are by conveniences. Maybe it's good to have a storm like this every once in a while.''

title: NEW AFRICA-AID EFFORTS
description: New projects to bring in more money for African famine relief, and new disbursements for Live Aid funds, were announced yesterday by Bob Geldof, the Irish rock musician who organized the British benefit record by Band Aid and the internationally broadcast Live Aid rock concerts July 13.

title: BOTHA SETS OUT HIS 'AGENDA' FOR RACIAL CHANGES
description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa, facing his Government's deepest racial crisis, delivered a speech tonight in which he set out what he termed an agenda for racial reform.

title: WESTWAY FUNDS TRADE-IN WINS FEDERAL APPROVAL
description: The United States Transportation Secretary, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, today approved New York State's decision to abandon Westway and finance other highway and mass-transit projects with Federal funds that had been designated for the project.

title: KOCH ON PRONUNCIATION: STUDENTS NEED LESSONS
description: Mayor Koch, irked by teachers and students who say ''axed'' when they mean ''asked,'' called yesterday for a new effort to improve pronunciation in the city schools.

title: OZZIE SMITH HITS IT BIG
description: Some players let the big, new contract trip them up, shackle them, weigh them down. They strain to justify all that money being paid them, knowing the fans and the opponents and the press will never let them forget it.

title: Environmental Groups Join
description: Two environmental groups, the Conservation Foundation and the World Wildlife Fund-U.S., announced today that they would begin a formal affiliation that would leave their separate programs intact. William Reilly, the president of the Conservation Foundation, will also become president of the wildlife fund. Russell Train, the president of the wildlife fund, will become chairman of the board of both organizations.

title: HOROWITZ MAKING RECORD AND PLANNING RECITALS
description: A beaming Vladimir Horowitz announced yesterday that his career as a pianist was alive and healthy. To prove it, he made public news of a recording-to-be, now being taped in New York, and scheduled recitals next spring in Paris and Milan - his first public appearances in more than two years and the first in those cities in over 40.

title: FORECAST FOR TODAY: DIMINISHING SHOWERS IN CITY
description: New York's fight against the drought will be taken into the city's showers today and many occupants of those showers seem to think that is taking things one step too far.

title: S.I. FERRYBOAT LOSES POWER DURING A TRIP WITH 4,000 ABOARD
description: A Staten Island ferryboat with 4,000 rush-hour commuters aboard lost power and went adrift yesterday morning on her way to Manhattan.

title: Gimbels Officer May Resign
description: Thomas A. Brown, vice chairman of Gimbels East, is expected to resign shortly as the chief officer of the group, which includes the Gimbel stores in the New York and Philadelphia areas, according to retail trade sources.

title: TOUGH CHOICES AND DISCONTENT ON CAMPUSES
description: A CHARGE by students last week that administrators at Harvard University had censored a student-run course guide may sound like just another of the recurrent arguments over students' rights. However, behind this specific conflict lies a more general student discontent that is not confined to Harvard: the problem of choosing wisely from an extravagant bounty of courses.

title: Interest Rates Marking Time
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday, with credit market participants still waiting for the emergence of a clear trend in rates.

title: White Supremacist On Most-Wanted List
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today added to its list of the 10 most-wanted suspects a member of the Order, a white supremacist group.

title: Rocket Expert Regrets Giving Up Citizenship
description: Arthur Rudolph, a German-born rocket engineer who gave up his American citizenship and returned to West Germany, says he should have fought the Government's attempt to try him on the ground that he concealed purported Nazi war crimes in World War II.

title: VICKS IS SAID TO BE ON AUCTION BLOCK
description: Shares of Richardson-Vicks Inc. soared $10, to $63.50, in exceptionally heavy buying yesterday amid Wall Street rumors that the maker of Vicks cold remedies has put itself on the auction block.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corp., Pittsburgh, said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Gibbs Wire and Steel Corp. of Southington, Conn. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Prices Paid Farmers Dip
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in September and now stand 13 percent below the level of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Riches Didn't Elect Bill Green in 1980
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY WATCHES
description: A 43-year-old motorist was shot to death in upper Manhattan, possibly in a dispute over a parking space, as his wife, three children and brother-in-law looked on, the police said yesterday.

title: Fannie Mae Plans $1.85 Billion Sale
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to offer to investors this week $1.85 billion of debentures with various maturities and $200 million of mortgage pass-through securities backed by loans from its mortgage portfolio.

title: Defeat and Victory in Punjab
description: The Congress Party of India's Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, lost badly in last week's voting in Punjab. Yet it was a welcome victory for his effort to prevent more bloodshed over the grievances of the province's Sikh majority.

title: Melvin Belli Rejects Coast Murder Suspect
description: The lawyer Melvin Belli has turned down a request for legal assistance from Richard Ramirez, who has been charged with 15 murders in a series of assaults in northern and southern California.

title: HELEN MACINNES, 77, NOVELIST AND SPECIALIST IN SPY FICTION
description: Helen MacInnes, whose 21 novels established her as the queen of international espionage fiction, died yesterday at New York Hospital, from the effects of a stroke she suffered three weeks ago. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG INQUIRY
description: The police said today that they had arrested 15 people, including five from the military, after a three-month undercover investigation of drug trafficking at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.

title: WHAT FOOD TO DISCARD
description: Many people who lost electrical power because of Hurricane Gloria may be faced with considerable spoilage of the perishables stocked in freezers and refrigerators.

title: ENGLISH CHINA FOUND AT HOME OF LINCOLN
description: Abraham Lincoln might not have been the poor country lawyer depicted in folklore, according to two anthropologists who found English china among garbage at Lincoln's home.

title: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 6
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,713,000 for the quarter and $5,345,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $20,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Chip Makers Accuse Japan
description: Ad=vanced Micro Devices Inc., the Intel Corporation and the National Semiconductor Corporation charged today, as expected, that Japanese semiconductor companies are dumping computer memory chips known as Eproms on the United States market.

title: CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a provision of $814,000 for the closing of 12 unprofitable Godfather's Pizza restaurants. c-Net income.

title: Brock to End Backlog In Black Lung Claims
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock today announced a four-year plan to eliminate a backlog of 21,000 black lung benefit cases awaiting Federal review, saying ''intolerable delays'' had hurt some elderly claimants.

title: TRANSNET CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
Sears Seen Promoting Brennan
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has scheduled a news conference for Tuesday at which the retailer and financial services company is expected to announce that Edward A. Brennan will be its next chairman.

title: Japanese Speed Trade Changes
description: The Japanese Government, under American pressure to speed up its recently announced trade program, agreed today to put some measures in place ahead of schedule.

title: Unheralded Performance
description: Some remarkable feats of hitting by Wade Boggs of the Boston Red Sox this season have been overshadowed by the tightness of the division races and overlooked because of Boston's lackluster season.

title: Next Stop, Stockholm
description: President Reagan has chosen Robert L. Barry, a career diplomat, Soviet affairs specialist and former Ambassador to Bulgaria, as the head of the United States delegation to the East-West negotiations on security in Europe. The President is expected to ask the Senate to approve the rank of Ambassador for Mr. Barry for the post, which is in Stockholm.

title: CHARLES RICHTER, QUAKE EXPERT, DIES
description: Dr. Charles F. Richter, the pioneer in seismology for whom the Richter scale of earthquake magnitude is named, died of congestive heart failure yesterday in Pasadena, Calif. He was 85 years old and had suffered from heart disease for several years.

title: Rainbow Services Limited on Films
description: The MGM/UA Home Entertainment Group said yesterday that a Federal Court in New York had issued a temporary restraining order that prohibits the Rainbow Services Company from exhibiting motion pictures from the MGM/UA library on any basic cable television channel during October. But the court ruling will permit the films to be used on Rainbow's American Movie Classic pay TV services.

title: WORKERS START TO CLEAN UP OIL SPILL IN DELAWARE RIVER
description: While divers examined the hull of a damaged supertanker docked here, teams with truck-sized vacuum cleaners siphoned water today from the Delaware River, trying to skim off an inch-thick black sheen of oil.

title: TV RATINGS CONTAIN SURPRISES
description: Using the strongest artillery in their programming arsenals, the three commercial television networks went head to head over the weekend, and preliminary ratings in 10 major cities came up with a number of surprising results.

title: NEW LIFE FOR A FAVORITE YIDDISH PLAY
description: Omus Hirshbein was the beloved and only child of Peretz Hirshbein, the celebrated Yiddish playwright, novelist, poet and globe-circling journalist who died in 1948. The son's apartment high above Riverside Drive is crammed with mementos of the father, including a huge black bust that dominates the living room and photographs showing Omus as a child, a tiny replica of Peretz, with the same pale eagle eyes and knife-edged nose.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: NATIONAL BIRTHDAYS - Today is the national day of three countries - China, Cyprus and Nigeria. The Chinese will mark the 36th anniversary of their nation with the second reception in two days at their mission on West 66th Street. The food promises to be one of the highlights of the circuit. The Nigerians had planned an early celebration on Friday, but the party was canceled, a mission spokesman said, when ''Gloria came to town.'' In keeping with past years and in light of continuing political troubles in Cyprus, that nation's mission plans no special celebration, a spokesman said.

title: U.S. TO ASK BANKS' AID FOR DEBTORS
description: The Treasury Department has invited senior officers of commercial banks to a briefing in Washington on Tuesday where they will be urged to make new loans to third world debtor countries, Administration officials said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL INFORMATION NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-In the year-ago periods the company broke even. Year-ago results are pro-forma.

title: Weathering the Crisis
description: ''It is a meteorological metaphor for the decade.''

title: Ametek to Buy Bausch Division
description: Ametek Inc. said that Bausch & Lomb Inc. had agreed to sell its Houston Instrument division to Ametek for $46 million.

title: Ford Will Offer Options Discount
description: The Ford Motor Company, which raised its car prices 2.9 percent for 1986, said that it would offer some discounts on optional equipment to lure buyers.

title: ISRAELI OFFICIALS SPLIT OVER SPEECH BY HUSSEIN
description: The reaction of Israeli officials to a speech last week by King Hussein of Jordan has highlighted the many divisions within Israel's coalition Government on the issue of direct peace talks between Israel and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation.

title: REAGAN SAYS ISRAEL-JORDAN TALKS COULD START BEFORE END OF THE YEAR
description: President Reagan met today with King Hussein of Jordan and said afterward that he believed direct negotiations for peace between Israel and Jordan could be started by the end of December.

title: Second Chance
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation is leaning toward the reinstatement of Renaldo Nehemiah, according to Primo Nebiolo, the president of track and field's governing body. Nehemiah, the world-record holder in the 110-meter hurdles, was banned from the sport after signing a pro football contract with the San Franciso 49ers. Nebiolo said Nehemiah's case would be discussed at an I.A.A.F. executive council meeting in Canberra, Australia, later this week.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of the photographer Andre Kertesz in late editions on Sunday and in some copies yesterday misidentified Olga Kertesz of Buenos Aires.

title: U.S. Ordered to Spend Funds for Refugee Aid
description: A Federal district judge ordered the Reagan Administration today to release $11.5 million approved by Congress for counties with large numbers of refugees needing social services.

title: Merger Parties' Rating Review
description: The proposed acquisition of the General Foods Corporation by the Philip Morris Companies may have an adverse effect on the debt ratings of both companies, officials at the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: READING ALOUD The fourth year of free programs sponsored by Free Theater Productions, in which well-known actors and actresses read from their favorite writers, begins today at St. Thomas Church. Past programs have included Roscoe Lee Brown, Betty Comden, Colleen Dewhurst, Jeremy Irons, Anne Jackson, Raul Julia, Michael Moriarty, Geraldine Page, Jason Robards, Eli Wallach and Hattie Winston.

title: Library of Congress;   The Answer People of Capitol Hill
description: In memoriam for Harvey Baugh, there are a few weeping filbert trees growing outside the Library of Congress, plaintive and firm-rooted as the curiosity of the lamented reference librarian who long served the capital's most demanding readership, its lawmakers.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Montreal dispatch in some copies yesterday, about the new Premier of Quebec, Pierre Marc Johnson, referred incorrectly to the policies of the Parti Quebecois. Critics of Mr. Johnson's predecessor, Rene Levesque, asserted that the party's zeal in promoting French language and culture had alienated English-speaking Quebecers, not French-speakers.

title: D'ye Ken Henry IX?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tune for a Traffic Jam
description: Where Atlantic meets Flatbush is not so much an intersection as a stranglehold. The best efforts over the years to control traffic have merely reduced total chaos to simple anarchy.

title: Telephone Rate Changes Set
description: Sweeping changes in the rates local telephone companies charge long-distance companies for access to local lines were approved by the Federal Communications Commission today, but the impact on individual telephone users will be small because many increases are offset by decreases in other areas.

title: $618 Million Bond Issue From County in Texas
description: Harris County, Tex., and the Port of Houston Authority situated in that county are revamping their finances with a new $618 million bond issue that will be used to refund all their previously issued bonds.

title: Syracuse Change
description: Don McPherson, a redshirted Syracuse sophomore from West Hempstead (L.I.) High School, will replace Mike Kmetz, a junior, as the starting quarterback in Saturday's game against Louisville at the Carrier Dome. The Orangemen were 1-2 with Kmetz, who has completed only 26 of 66 passes for 373 yards and two touchdowns.

title: GENERAL VESSEY BIDS FAREWELL WITH 'THANKS' TO HIS TROOPS
description: General John W. Vessey Jr. closed out 46 years of military service today by turning to an honor guard and saying, with a gentle wave of his hand, ''Thanks, troops, thanks.''

title: Denim News
description: What'll they think of next, these breathless lobbyists and creative publicists who seem so busy around Capitol Hill these days? Well, this week's made-for-television-news events include the unfolding on Thursday of a pair of blue jeans to dramatize legislation to reduce textile imports. The pants are 54 feet long and 35 feet wide and are being displayed by Representative Howard Coble, Republican of North Carolina, who could easily fit into the hip pocket of the jeans with several other adults, according to a press release from his office.

title: CHARGES FACED BY 22 IN DRUG CASE CALLED 'PIZZA CONNECTION'
description: Jury selection began yesterday for a major narcotics trial - called the ''pizza connection'' case - involving charges that a Mafia ring smuggled $1.6 billion of heroin into this country.

title: Pipeline Deal For China Gas
description: Units of the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Santa Fe International Corporation have signed a $500 million contract with China to build a distribution network for natural gas discovered in the South China Sea.

title: The Strategic Value Of Arming Hussein
description: In the wake of President Reagan's decision to go forward with a package of defensive arms for Jordan, searching questions are being raised in Congress about Jordan's readiness to make peace with Israel, about its trustworthiness with advanced technologies and about its need for new American arms in the years ahead. Lobbyists for Israel, Jordan and the American defense industries alike are pressing partisan arguments on behalf of their respective special interests.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avant-Garde Computing Inc., Mount Laurel, N.J., which makes communications network management products, has named Michael L. Sanyour president and chief operating officer.

title: NICHOLS INSTITUTE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Sierra Leone Election
description: Voting began early today in Sierra Leone's first democratic presidential election. Nearly three million voters are expected to turn out to elect Maj. Gen. Joseph Momoh, 48 years old, of the All People's Congress.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Monday about American companies that are weeding out operations misstated General Electric's involvement in the production of its CAT scanners. The company's Japanese joint venture makes 25 percent of them; G.E. manufactures the rest itself in the United States.

title: More's New in China Than Meets the Western Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   Lampoon Plan To Cut Base
description: The 15-year-old National Lampoon, whose circulation in the 1970's was around one million, will cut its rate base to 300,000, from 450,000, with the January issue. And that's nothing to laugh about.

title: FILM: JESSICA LANGE IN 'SWWET DREAMS'
description: THE legendary country-and-western singer Patsy Cline, as played by Beverly D'Angelo in ''Coal Miner's Daughter,'' the biographical film about Loretta Lynn, cut such an extravagant figure that she very nearly stole the movie. Now Miss Cline is the subject of ''Sweet Dreams,'' a full-fledged screen biography of her own.

title: Reds to Retain Ticket Prices
description: The Cincinnati Reds have decided to leave their single-game ticket prices unchanged for 1986 home games at Riverfront Stadium.

title: SCHOOL BOARD WINS A DELAY IN CHURCH-STATE CASE
description: New York City's Board of Education can continue for one year a remedial-education program in which public-school teachers are sent into parochial schools, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: CANCER RISK CITED IN SUBSTANCE USED TO MAKE PACIFIERS
description: A chemical used in millions of pacifiers and other plastic products for babies causes cancer in animals and might cause cancer in people, a scientific panel told the Consumer Product Safety Commission today.

title: Fear No Forecasts
description: The editor and publisher of The Old Farmers Almanac are coming to Washington from Dublin, N.H., tomorrow, laden with copies of all 194 editions of the almanac that have appeared since 1792. With the 1986 version out this week, the two, Jud Hale and Rob Trowbridge, are to present this accumulation of Americana to the Smithsonian's Museum of American History.

title: Dancing Rush Hour Away
description: Following on the heels of music in the subway comes dance.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 7
description: b-Including tax credits of $8,500,000 for the 12 weeks and $18,500,000 for the 28 weeks. c-Including tax credits of $7,680,000 for the 12 weeks and 12,930,000 for the 28 weeks and an extraordinary credit from pension surplus of $135,000,000 for the 28 weeks.

title: COLD WATER DAMPENS DANCE GALA
description: Because of a water-heating problem, the opening event of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival began an hour and a half behind schedule last night.

title: Mexico Death Toll Is Raised to 5,526
description: The official death toll from the two earthquakes last month rose to 5,526 today, and the United States said its rescue workers were ending the search.

title: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $459,000 for the quarter and $2,772,000 for the year. Year-ago results have been restated to apply new accounting methods retroactively.

title: Transway Accepts $331.2 Million Bid
description: The Transway International Corporation, a freight forwarder based in White Plains, said its board of directors had entered into a merger agreement with a subsidiary of the International Controls Corporation for a package of $24 a share in cash and subordinated debentures that the company said were worth another $24 a share. The deal was valued at around $331.2 million.

title: Guard for Becker
description: Teen-age girls keep a vigil in front of his hotel and erupt into a screaming frenzy whenever he appears outside. It is, of course, a familiar peril for major rock stars, and anyone who doubts that Boris Becker, the 17-year-old Wimbledon champion, has the same luster can check with Willy Beyer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1985
description: International

title: THE FOOD OF LOVE: GENEROUS SERVINGS
description: SOME years ago a woman I worked with married for the third time. The single state made her jumpy - she called it ''being at loose ends'' -so for her, marriage was not only a commitment to someone else but a concession to a rotten nervous system. Then she started making lists.

title: BUILDING S.I. NAVAL BASE: CAN CITY REFUSE TO HELP?
description: If the Navy wants to build a base on Staten Island for ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons, it is pretty much free to do so.

title: Wyoming Governor Stricken
description: Gov. Ed Herschler was hospitalized this morning after complaining of chest pains and is being held at Memorial Hospital in Cheyenne for observation. Dick Skinner, an aide to Mr. Herschler, said tests would be performed on the 66-year-old Governor to determine if he had had a heart attack. Mr. Herschler, a Democrat who last month became the first Governor of Wyoming to declare personal bankruptcy, has announced that he will not seek a fourth term next year.

title: ERROR BY KARPOV LEADS TO KASPAROV CHESS VICTORY
description: Gary Kasparov capitalized on an error by the world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, and won his second victory in their championship match after only 25 moves in the 11th game today.

title: PLAYER TESTING TRANSFER RULE
description: Tom McHale, Cornell's defensive left end plays football for fun, and he has gone to court so he can continue to do just that.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
Reagan Revises Dirksen
description: Mrs. S.K. of Trenton notes that the national debt is approaching $2 trillion, says she doesn't know what $1 trillion looks like, much less $2 trillion, and asks for help.

title: A Craving for Decent New York Subways Doomed Westway
description: To the Editor:

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MEXICAN DEBT DELAY AGREED ON
description: Major international banks agreed yesterday to postpone nearly $1 billion in loan repayments from Mexico, averting what could have been one of the largest defaults since the debt crisis began in August 1982.

title: A & M FOOD SERVICES reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 3
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain from the sale of two Oklahoma restaurants of $385,000 for the quarter and nine months. Results for the latest periods reflect the acquisition of 49 restaurants on June 5, 1985.

title: STANFORD PRESIDENT UPHOLDS DOCTORAL STUDENT'S EXPULSION
description: Donald Kennedy, president of Stanford University, yesterday upheld a earlier faculty decision to expel a graduate student who had done research in China and accused the student of lying to him.

title: SOFT JEANS AND BRIGHT SOCKS
description: Jeans in Style The people who make Lee jeans have added a stylish new line, V-F jeans for men and women. Made of soft cotton, they have classic five-pocket styling and copper buttons and rivets that will not tarnish.

title: VOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $626,000. c-Net income, after an extraordinary net loss of $56,729.

title: POWER STILL OFF FOR 266,000 AS UTILITIES REPORT PROGRESS
description: Four days after the onslaught of Hurricane Gloria, utilities reported slow but continuing progress yesterday in restoring electricity and telephone service to Long Island and Connecticut.

title: PLAYING PENNANT POKER
description: For the Mets, it was perhaps the tingling triumph in their history.
