description: The displays have taken place more frequently lately as Jesse Orosco's business has become more and more important. When Orosco leaves the Met bullpen to go about that business, he does it with an even disposition. When his work is done, he discusses it quietly.

title: Coast Guard Takes Over Some Work on Oil Spill
description: The Coast Guard has taken control of efforts to clean up a 400,000-gallon oil spill threatening wetlands in New Jersey and Delaware because of fears the spill could reach Chesapeake Bay, the authorities say.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOUSE. By Tracy Kidder. 341 pages.

title: Unilever to Pursue A U.S. Acquisition
description: Unilever, thwarted in its effort to buy Richardson-Vicks Inc., still hopes to make a major acquisition in the United States, a spokesman said.

title: WORLD'S FAIRGOERS TO GET REFUNDS
description: Visitors to the 1982 World's Fair who arrived in Knoxville to find shabby or nonexistent accommodations may soon receive refunds of 62 cents on the dollar, a state attorney says.

title: FINAL ARGUMENTS IN SAN DIEGO MAYOR'S TRIAL
description: The prosecutor in the conspiracy and perjury trial of Mayor Roger Hedgecock told the jury in his summation today that the Mayor had engaged in a ''systematic cover-up'' to conceal illegal campaign contributions that totaled hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: AVANT-GARDE CELEBRATION IN BROOKLYN
description: WATER, water everywhere was the theme of the opening-night celebration Tuesday of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The evening, for which Bianca Jagger was chairman, began at 6 P.M. with a cocktail reception prior to the 7 P.M. performance of ''Arien,'' a piece by Pina Bausch's Tanztheater Wuppertal, the avant-garde German dance and theater company. The performance was delayed for an hour and a half because of problems in heating the water used to flood the stage floor.

title: LUSTERWARE SHOWN BY CALIFORNIA POTTER
description: The luster glazes of Beatrice Wood's ceramics evoke images of peacock feathers and abalone shells. While her forms are influenced by Etruscan ceramics and Indian jewelry, each of the 14 pieces currently on display at the Garth Clark Gallery is personal and original.

title: Mother and Baby Slain
description: A 20-year-old woman, Vicky Black, and her 18-month-old son, Richard Duane Mitchell, were found slain last night in their third-floor apartment at 2031 Webster Avenue in the Tremont section of the Bronx. The police said her throat had been cut and the child had been drowned. Richard Mitchell, who lived with the woman, told the police he found the bodies at 8 P.M. He was being questioned early today.

title: INFODATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $133,853 for the quarter and $273,414 for the six months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $14,800 for the quarter and $130,322 for the six months.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement 71.

title: PHOTOS HELP REDO VICTORIAN GARDEN
description: IN the late 1870's, a well-bred young American named Alice Austen started experimenting with the new medium of photography. Among her subjects was her family's residence overlooking the Narrows in Staten Island; a former 17th-century Dutch farmhouse, it had been transformed by her grandfather into a stylish Victorian cottage and grounds.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Bulgarian Denies Role In Attempt to Kill Pope
description: A Bulgarian defendant, Sergei Antonov, today denied involvement in the attempt to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981 and told the court he never knew the Turkish gunman, Mehmet Ali Agca.

title: SIHANOUK, AT U.N., SAYS REBELS AREN'T LOSING
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk told the General Assembly today that his rebel forces were holding their own against the Hanoi-backed Government in Phnom Penh.

title: NUCLEAR REACTOR TO BE RESTARTED
description: The Supreme Court refused today to block the restarting of the undamaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island, which was shut down six years ago in the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident.

title: J. Irwin Shapiro Dies; A Retired State Judge
description: J. Irwin Shapiro, a former associate justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, died Tuesday at the Peninsula Hospital Center in Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 80 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

title: The R.S.V.P. Affair
description: Some State Department officials say they feel that the White House has mishandled the invitation of leaders of six major industrial democracies to meet in New York with President Reagan in advance of the American-Soviet summit meeting.

title: TIE FOR LEAD
description: One more day went by, and there are still no takers for the American League West title. So California and Kansas City, tied for the eighth time in 14 days and staggering toward the finish, will take their series to its final game.

title: Heckler and Silence
description: The Irish Embassy said yesterday, a day after Margaret M. Heckler said she had accepted President Reagan's offer to become Ambassador to Dublin, that Ireland had still not been officially informed of the appointment by the Reagan Administration. Therefore, a spokesman said, the Irish Government would have no comment on the reassignment of the Cabinet officer and the hassling it involved.

title: MODERN MUSEUM NAMES A GALLERY FOR DONOR
description: In a ceremony at the Museum of Modern Art last night, the businessman Meshulam Riklis put the final touches on the gifts of $1.75 million and part of his corporate art collection to the museum, and acknowledged the naming of a museum gallery in his honor.

title: MORE BLOWS TO CHIP INDUSTRY
description: Only days after its trade association predicted that business would soon improve, the semiconductor industry is demonstrating again this week the effects of a relentless yearlong depression.

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1985
description: International

title: NEW-HOME SALES OFF BY 5.6%
description: Sales of new homes fell 5.6 percent in August from their July peak, the Government said today, but analysts shrugged off the decline, saying that attractive mortgage rates should keep demand strong.

title: Judge Drops Charges Against Presser's Uncle
description: Judge Sam H. Bell of Federal District Court today granted the Government's motion to dismiss embezzlement charges against an uncle of Jackie Presser, the teamsters' president.

title: An Agency Resettles in Jersey City
description: WHAT happens when an ad agency joins the others that have made a frantic dash southbound away from high rents and toward lower Manhattan, and it skids? Jersey City.

title: SOVIET BOY TO BE 'A FREE MAN' TODAY
description: On Thursday, Walter Polovchak becomes 18 years old, and on that day the boy who refused to return to the Soviet Union with his parents five years ago will be, in the words of his attorney, ''a free man.''

title: Foes of S.I. Navy Base Lose A Round in Appellate Court
description: A state appeals court yesterday ordered a lower court to determine the validity of signatures on petitions for a Nov. 5 referendum designed to block a naval base on Staten Island.

title: Books: Eyewitnesses in a Changing India
description: VENGEANCE. India After the Assassination of Indira Gandhi. By Pranay Gupte. 368 pages. W. W. Norton. $16.95. PRANAY GUPTE'S ''Vengeance: India After the Assassination of Indira Gandhi'' reads more like a series of news dispatches than it does the big book on India Mr. Gupte thought he might write. A journalist with a Brandeis degree and 14 years at The New York Times behind him, Mr. Gupte was in India visiting his ailing father in Bombay when Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was assassinated. Foreign journalists had been barred from the Punjab, where terrorism had led to a military assault on the Golden Temple, the Sikhs' principal shrine, and army rule. Mr. Gupte, an Indian national, was asked to cover the most severe test since independence in 1947 of Indian unity and democracy.

title: Crowdless Competition
description: Juventus of Italy and Atletico Madrid of Spain, playing in stadiums barred to spectators, posted victories yesterday in European club soccer competitions.

title: GOV. EDWARDS'S FEE CALLED UNEARNED
description: A hospital corporation official testified today that she knew of no work Gov. Edwin W. Edwards had done to earn the more than $700,000 the prosecution charges he received fraudulently in a hospital transaction in 1982.

title: YANKS FAIL TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF BLUE JAYS' LOSS
description: After Ted Higuera stopped the Yankees' 11-game winning streak by pitching a six-hitter against them in Milwaukee, Billy Martin gave the rookie credit for pitching well but proclaimed the Yankees would beat on him ''like a drum'' in New York.

title: The Elements of White
description: E.B. White not only wrote well but inspired good writing. He revised and amplified ''The Elements of Style,'' a first-rate handbook by William Strunk Jr., his English professor at Cornell. Here are some of its rules: Do not overstate . . . Write with nouns and verbs . . . Work from a suitable design . . . Do not explain too much . . . Avoid the use of qualifiers. Alas, students know that just going by the book won't give their prose the elements of grace that distinguished Mr. White's.

title: NEW ICM ARTISTS HEAD
description: Lee Lamont has been named president of ICM Artists Ltd., it was announced yesterday. Miss Lamont and Marvin Schofer have been serving over the summer months as executive vice presidents, sharing the duties previously held by Sheldon Gold, who died last May.

title: TUNISIA'S LEADER BITTER AT THE U.S.
description: The Israeli air strike near here, and the initial United States reaction to it, stirred bitter criticism from the President of this north African Arab nation.

title: IRAQ AND IRAN CLASH ON OPEC OUTPUT
description: Iraq and Iran, enemies on the battlefield since 1980 but still partners in OPEC, clashed today over an Iraqi demand for a bigger share of the organization's oil production.

title: HURRICANE'S PAST, WINTER'S SOON TO COME
description: THE hurricane cleanup continues. Twigs and blown-down leaves can be used as mulch under shrubs. Big limbs should be sawed up; use a power saw to make fire logs of fallen trees.

title: New Formula In EPIC Case
description: A new proposal to work out the financial problems of the EPIC group of real estate and mortgage companies has been submitted by large investors in EPIC mortgages.

title: Tennessee Bonds
description: The metropolitan government of Nashville and Davidson County, Tenn., is offering $163.5 million of general obligation bonds with yields ranging from 5 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 8 1/4 percent in 1995, 9.30 percent in 2005 and 9.40 percent in 2010 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's.

title: Vacant President's Post Filled at Jim Johnston
description: Steven R. Seiter, 41, has filled the vacant president's post at Jim Johnston Advertising, which puts him between Mr. Johnston, the chairman and chief executive, and Pat Johnston, wife and executive vice president.

title: MERRILL JOINS GIANTS AFTER LONG HOLDOUT
description: Casey Merrill was sitting at his ranch last Thursday in Borrego Springs, Calif. At a time when he normally would be playing football, he had just planted a few hundred citrus trees - oranges, tangerines, tangelos, red grapefruit and Mexican limes.

title: Maxxam Raises Bid for Pacific
description: Maxxam Group Inc., a New York investment partnership led by Charles E. Hurwitz, said today that it had begun its tender offer for the Pacific Lumber Company at $38.50 a share, or about $798 million.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY SHULTZ TO POLICY GROUP
description: Following are excerpts from a speech given by Secretary of State George P. Shultz in New York last night to the National Committee on American Foreign Policy:

title: DANCE: 'TRIADIC BALLET,' A LA BAUHAUS
description: IT'S not often that one sees a ballerina partnered by a cavalier in an armless diving suit adorned with tassels. Nor, for that matter, does one often see ballerinas made of golden wires.

title: HERS
description: I HAVE been reading ''The Norton Anthology of Literature by Women'' and pronounce it a treasure. It will befriend me on my travels, my awake nights and those procrastinating mornings when I would rather read then write. Already I have had the benefit of such diverse and potent minds as Queen Elizabeth I and Alice Munro. The book abounds with heroines - noble heroines, scatty heroines, screaming heroines, fornicating heroines, all kinds except an unforgettably great heroine, a creature who passes into the idiom and into the consciousness as completely as Emma Bovary, Anna Karenina or Becky Sharp.

title: ESIASON LEADING BENGALS' TRANSITION
description: ''Everything happens to me,'' moaned Boomer Esiason today, with the trace of a laugh.

title: REAGAN SELECTS TRADE 'STRIKE FORCE'
description: President Reagan today announced the makeup of the trade ''strike force'' that he has devised to ferret out unfair practices by foreign competitors and create strategies to overcome them.

title: Dodgers Clinch In West
description: Even before Orel Hershiser won his 11th consecutive game tonight, a 9-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves, the Los Angeles Dodgers became the first major league team to capture a division title this season.

title: Unacademic Campus Tactics
description: Something is odd about the movement on campuses to organize opposition among scientists to research on the Strategic Defense Initiative. On some campuses, this opposition extends to all defense-related projects.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption of a front-page picture grouping by Reuters yesterday, showing the four Soviet Embassy employees taken captive in Lebanon, reversed two of their identities. Valery K. Mirkov was at the upper left, Dr. Nikolai Versky at the lower right.

title: CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: Sales figures represent net sales. Sales for the year-ago periods have been restated.

title: Freddie Mac Gives Certificate Results
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday announced results of a $250 million sale of 15-year mortgage participation certificates, and said it plans to begin offering the certificates daily rather than every two weeks.

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 8
STAGE: 'LIVING LEG-ENDS' BRITISH MUSIC HALL SHOW
description: THE Bloolips are back in town, and this troupe of British music hall merrymakers is as disarming a company of cross-dressed clowns as one is likely to encounter. With no diminution of their parodistic amplitude, they are almost tasteful.

title: Stocks End Mixed; Volume Climbs
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday after a wave of selling of hospital-management issues erased a strong advance.

title: ELECTRIC HOT-GLUE GUNS; DISPENSERS FOR EPOXY
description: HOT-MELT glue guns are handy for such tasks as repairing sports gear - the grips on tennis rackets, for example - for fixing leather goods, furniture and plastic-laminate table tops, and for assembling crafts. Because the glue sets quickly, the guns are especially good for fastening things too fragile to clamp. They cannot, however, be used on nonporous surfaces such as metal and glass.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif, said it had purchased Anclote Manor Hospital, a long-term psychiatric hospital, near Tampa, Fla., for $25 million.

title: CITY PLAN WOULD EVICT WELFARE HOTEL HOLDOUTS
description: The Koch administration has drafted a new plan to evict homeless people living in welfare hotels if they refuse to look at or accept a city-owned apartment.

title: Local Group Will Buy Pirates
description: In an unusual move, a public-private coalition committed to keeping the struggling Pirates in Pittsburgh reached an agreement today to buy the team from the Galbreath family and Warner Communications Inc. for $22 million. The coalition also would assume $7 million in debts owed mainly to players who signed deferred contracts.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Revenue figures represent gross revenues. Results for the year ending Aug. 31, 1984, exclude non-recurring net merger costs of approximately $18.1 million.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 21
Nisson Weighs U.S. Price Rise
description: Officials of the Nissan Motor Company say they are considering raising prices on their cars in the United States if the yen continues to gain in value against the dollar.

title: Bears Don't Hibernate
description: To the Editor:

title: THREE 8-YEAR-OLD PUPILS SEXUALLY ASSAULTED
description: Three 8-year-old girls were sexually assaulted by an intruder who accosted them in bathrooms in their schools in the South Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: An American Promise Made to Shcharansky
description: To the Editor:

title: The Little That Went a Long Way
description: To the Editor:

title: DRUG REPORT CITES COWBOYS
description: The National Football League is looking into an allegation made in a 1982 F.B.I. report that five members of the Dallas Cowboys agreed to shave points in games in exchange for cocaine in the early 1980's. At the same time, the F.B.I. has begun investigating why its agents did not act on the allegation when it was first made.

title: P.&G. Leader Again In National Advertising
description: Let's hope the Philip Morris Companies enjoyed its brief moment in the sun as the country's largest national advertiser, because it didn't last long.

title: Cocaine Seller Planning Appeal
description: Shelby Greer, who has admitted selling cocaine to major-league baseball players, will appeal as ''unjust'' the 12-year prison term he received Tuesday after signing a plea-bargain agreement that included extended cooperation with the Federal government, his attorney said.

title: U.S. SHIFT ON LATIN DEBT SEEN AS A TURNING POINT IN CRISIS
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to promote a new strategy to deal with Latin America's debt marks a turning point in the region's three-year-old financial crisis, foreign bankers and Government officials said here today.

title: Bowery Sale Completed
description: An investor group led by Richard Ravitch, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, said yesterday that it had completed the previously announced acquisition of the troubled Bowery Savings Bank. Mr. Ravitch and state and Federal regulators said that none of the institution's accounts would be affected. Mr. Ravitch also said that there were no plans to close any of the $5.3 billion bank's 26 branches throughout the city.

title: Factory Orders Up 0.9%, Led by Durable Goods
description: Factory orders rose a modest nine-tenths of 1 percent in August as strong demand for autos and airplanes was offset by a slump in demand for food products, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Costly Scuffle
description: According to Nelson Burton Jr., a member of the Bowling Hall of Fame, it was just one of those bowler-to-bowler scuffles that began when he tried to collect a $6,250 debt from a fellow professional, Greg Shields. As a result of the dispute at a tournament in Overland Park, Kan., last March, it is going to cost Burton a lot more than that.

title: Bridge: A Top Player-Writer Shows The Way to Establish Losers
description: Every beginner is taught how to establish winners, but the technique of establishing losers is little understood. It may indeed have been invented by Eddie Kantar of Los Angeles, one of the world's great player-writers, on the diagramed deal.

title: BELGIANS AND DUTCH ANGRY WITH REAGAN
description: Belgium and the Netherlands are angry that they were not among the nations invited by by President Reagan to a meeting for consultations before his summit talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and they called today for a special North Atlantic Treaty Organization Foreign Ministers' meeting.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Ron Guidry, the American League's top-winning pitcher, seeks his 22d victory of the season.

title: Average 2.7% Rise In Chrysler Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced that its 1986 cars would, on average, cost 2.7 percent more than the 1985 models. Chrysler was the last of the Big Three auto makers to make its pricing move and its increase was in the same range as those announced by General Motors and Ford.

title: IN BLACKED-OUT HOUSE, NEIGHBORS LEND A HAND
description: This morning, shortly after sunrise, Alex Romanitch, 5 years old, and his brother Jonah, 4, jumped out of their bunk beds and ran for the TV room.

title: TURNER AND MGM/UA ALTER DEAL
description: The Turner Broadcasting Company and the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, apparently reacting to snags in the broadcaster's plans to acquire the film studio, said yesterday that they had agreed to revised merger terms that analysts valued at slightly less than the original deal.

title: ISRAELI VIEW OF ARAFAT: UNCHANGING CONDEMNATION
description: For much of the world, Yasir Arafat has become something of a benign figure in recent years, welcomed everywhere from the United Nations to the Vatican, but the Israeli public and Government continue to regard him as a vicious killer and nothing more.

title: HARLYN PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $87,000 from insurance recovery. Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid March 15.

title: U.S. WINS TRADE TALK GO-AHEAD
description: The Reagan Administration won unanimous agreement tonight from 90 countries to open a new round of formal negotiations to liberalize world trade.

title: Poland Reports Arrest Of a Solidarity Leader
description: The police have arrested a fugitive leader of the Solidarity underground, Andrzej Michalowski, for organizing ''illegal actions'' in the seaport of Gdansk, the official press agency announced today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim McMahon, the Chicago quarterback who threw nine touchdown passes while leading the Bears to a 4-0 record in September, has been named the National Football League player of the month by the Professional Football Writers of America. . . . Lynn Dickey, the Green Bay Packer quarterback who had been expected to retire after relinquishing his starting role for last Sunday's game against the St. Louis Cardinals, has had a change of heart, according to Coach Forrest Gregg, who said Dickey had agreed to start Sunday's game against the Detroit Lions. Dickey, who had asked not to start the St. Louis game, came off the bench in the third quarter to relieve the substitute starter, Randy Wright.

title: Role of World Bank Seen as Enhanced
description: In proposing its new approach to developing-country loans, in Seoul next week, the Reagan Administration is expected to urge a strategy that greatly enhances the role of the World Bank, shifting its emphasis from dedicated financing to more general purpose loans.

title: ETHIOPIAN JEWS REACH ACCORD WITH ISRAELI RABBIS ON STATUS
description: A monthlong strike and sit-in by hundreds of Ethiopian Jews against Israel's Chief Rabbinate ended today with an agreement between the protesters and the rabbis over how to determine whether individual Ethiopian immigrants are Jewish.

title: Piedmont-Empire
description: Piedmont Aviation Inc. said that it had agreed to acquire Empire Airlines, a regional carrier with a hub in Syracuse, for $15 a share in cash, or about $41.6 million.

title: Moderate Quake in California
description: A moderate earthquake registering 5.0 on the open-ended Richter scale jolted much of southern California this afternoon, swaying skyscrapers in Los Angeles and causing minor damage in some suburban areas. Scientists at the Caltech Seismology Laboratory in Pasadena said the quake, which struck at 4:44 P.M., was centered six miles southeast of San Bernardino, about 65 miles east of Los Angeles, on the San Jacinto fault. A spokesman for Caltech said the quake was probably not connected to the disastrous Mexico earthquake last month.

title: T I M E-DC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income of $250,000 for the quarter and a loss of $283,000 for the year from discontinued special commodities trucking operations. c-Net income, after a loss from discontinued operations of $40,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $62,000 for the year, and including an extraordinary gain of $10,196,000 for the quarter and year related to a reversion of pension plan assets and tax credits.

title: Women in Engineering
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Prague Says Plane Warned Off U.S. Copter
description: Czechoslovakia today said that one of its planes had fired on an American helicopter that was over West Germany Saturday but denied it was an attack on the aircraft.

title: Topics;   Foreign Fare Revalued Currency
description: Perusing one of the Christmas catalogues already starting to arrive, one discovers: ''Sunken treasure from the Andrea Doria . . . sculpted by the sea.'' A breathless blurb tells of the proud liner's sinking one foggy night off Nantucket in 1956 and how, ''risking the fury of the Atlantic,'' divers recovered her ''treasure'' a quarter-century later.

title: 2 Bombs Go Off in Chile
description: Two bombs exploded here today, causing panic but no casualties, shortly before President Augusto Pinochet visited this copper mining community, the police said.

title: Derailment Kills 13 in Sudan
description: A train carrying famine relief supplies and troops derailed in the southwest Sudan, killing 13 people and wounding 15 others, a daily newspaper, Al Ayam, reported today. A railway official said the accident in the Bahr al-Ghazal region was caused by faulty maintenance of tracks.

title: 22 Die in Hailstorm in Brazil
description: At least 22 people were killed and more than 1,000 injured when a hailstorm lashed the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais on Monday, a civil defense spokesman said today. Most of the deaths were caused by houses collapsing under the weight of hailstones. In some areas three feet of ice built up on roads, the spokesman said.

title: ROCK HUDSON, SCREEN IDOL, DIES AT 59
description: Rock Hudson, the actor whose handsome looks and flair for comedy made him a romantic idol of the 1950's and 60's, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 59 years old and had been suffering for more than a year from AIDS.

title: SWITCHING SIDES: REPORTER JOINS U.S. MISSION
description: After 25 years as the CBS News correspondent at the United Nations, Richard C. Hottelet is leaving the network to take a job across the street with the United States Mission.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Do we want to see the country become so unstable that there is a violent revolution? History teaches that the black majority might likely wind up exchanging one set of oppressors for another, and yes, could be worse off.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz, on South Africa. [A16:2.]

title: GOODEN HELPS METS SHRINK CARDS' LEAD TO A GAME
description: The Mets lurched one giant stride closer to first place tonight when Dwight Gooden pitched them to a 5-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Suddenly, after two straight nights of bristling pitching and defense, there they stood -only one game back with four to play in a pennant race whirling toward some grand and melodramatic finish.

title: IRISH WANT TO SEE SOMEONE RAISE THE FLAG AGAIN AT U.S. EMBASSY
description: Dublin has not been thrilled by the designation of Margaret M. Heckler, who reluctantly yielded her Cabinet post as Secretary of Health and Human Services, to be Ambassador to Ireland. But then the nomination has not come as a great shock, either. In the last few years, according to diplomats, journalists and those on the social circuit, American ambassadors have changed frequently and been out of town a lot.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 15
description: b-Including a tax credit of $425,000 for the 12 weeks and the 36 weeks.

title: State Tax Amnesty: How to Qualify for It
description: New York State tax amnesty applications and the tax forms for both the state and New York City can be obtained by writing to Amnesty, State Department of Taxation and Finance, Albany, N.Y. 12227.

title: Giving Thanks
description: There was no turkey and no cranberry sauce, and the greeting, everyone agreed, was premature. ''Happy Thanksgiving,'' said Rabbi Barry Freundel.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1985
description: International

title: Coast Thrift Unit Plans $500 Million Financing
description: The California Federal Savings and Loan Association announced plans yesterday to sell up to $500 million of fixed-rate medium-term notes backed by fixed-rate home mortgages.

title: WHEN A MARRIAGE IS LONG-DISTANCE
description: FOR 10 years, Natalie Zemon Davis, a professor of history at Princeton University, and her husband, Chandler, a professor of mathematics at the University of Toronto, have been living near work during the week and with each other on weekends.

title: HURRICANE'S PAST, WINTER'S SOON TO COME
description: THIS is a bittersweet time in the city garden: falling leaves signal an end to summer's dappled days, yet some gardeners can't help looking forward to their winter rest, although many chores remain.

title: Inflation Rises in Chile
description: Chile's cost of living rose 1.2 percent in September, putting prices up 21 percent since Jan. 1, the Government said today. It said that in 1984, the cost of living held steady in September and that prices for the year at that point were up 11.5 percent.

title: Rates Close Little Changed
description: After a day of sometimes hectic trading and unusually wide gyrations in Treasury bond prices, interest rates ended little changed yesterday.

title: Justice Department;   Reynolds: Not Gone And Not Forgotten
description: Every weekday morning, sometimes as early as 7, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d calls together his three closest advisers to discuss the day's strategy. Always at the meeting are the Deputy Attorney General, D. Lowell Jensen, and Mr. Meese's personal counselor, T. Kenneth Cribb Jr. The other participant is a man who some had thought, and some had hoped, would be gone from the Justice Department by now: William Bradford Reynolds, the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: Shares outstanding reflect the five- for-four split effective July 31.

title: Jockey Fee Plan Rejected
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday rejected the proposal by New York jockeys to raise minimum riding fees beyond the so-called California Scale that was implemented on an emergency basis July 30 to avert a possible job action by the jockeys.

title: BONN ADDING 3 MONTHS TO DRAFT TO MAINTAIN STRENGTH OF MILITARY
description: The West German Government, struggling to maintain manpower levels in the armed forces despite sagging birth rates, has agreed to extend compulsory military service to 18 months from the present 15 months, officials said today.

title: Let Us Wage War on Preventable Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: LIEBERMAN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a three-for- two stock split paid June 28.

title: LET A MILLION BUSINESSES BLOOM, THE CHINESE CRY
description: As a boy growing up amid the rice paddies of Jiangsu Province, Zhu Bingrong read the tracts of Karl Marx and Mao Zedong.

title: More Tests for Bailey
description: James Bailey, who fainted during a Knicks practice last Saturday and was hospitalized, will undergo another series of tests today and will be released from Lenox Hill Hospital tomorrow. According to the team physician, Dr. Norman Scott, the forward will work out independently for two days, and then possibly join the team in Charleston, S.C., Sunday for their exhibtion game against Atlanta. . . . Ron Ginker, the agent for the free-agent holdout Louis Orr, and the Knick vice president, Dave DeBusschere, spoke Tuesday for the first time in more than a week.

title: Carolina Power Bond Offering
description: The Wake County Industrial Facilities and Pollution Control Finance Authority, in North Carolina, is offering $97 million of pollution control revenue bonds on behalf of the Carolina Power and Light Company, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: John P. Humes Dies; Former Envoy Was 64
description: John P. Humes, the former United States Ambassador to Austria, died Monday of a stroke in the Community Hospital at Glen Cove, L.I.. He was 64 years old.

title: Continental Air
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled today that striking Continental Airlines pilots and flight attendants were not wrongfully discharged, and he dismissed $1.4 billion in claims against the carrier. Judge R. Glover Roberts granted the airline's motion for summary judgment on claims by the Air Line Pilots Association and the Union of Flight Attendants. Telephone calls to offices of both unions went unanswered yesterday evening.

title: Lust For Power
description: Jeane Kirkpatrick has just performed a valuable service for American democracy. She has given us a glimpse of the authoritarian mentality that lies beneath the genial surface of the Reagan Administration: its lust for power without accountability.

title: Yields on C.D.'s Level; Money Funds Fall a Bit
description: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were level for the week ended yesterday, while money market mutual funds recorded a slight decline.

title: RECORD MILLION ADVANCE FOR BANTAM FIRST NOVEL
description: In a highly contested auction involving seven New York publishing houses, Bantam Books has agreed to pay a record advance of more than $1 million for a first novel by a relatively unknown writer of fiction.

title: DANCE: PINA BAUSCH LOOKS AT HUMAN NATURE
description: IN Pina Bausch's ''Arien,'' a persuasive-looking hippopotamus - portrayed by two men in hippo's clothing - seems rejected by a laughing woman. And as the lumbering beast turns around and makes a solitary, dejected trek to the rear of a stage filling up with water, a pool of loneliness wells up before our eyes.

title: Agency Gets Thrift Proposal
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today it had received an application, as expected, from the thrift industry to establish an institution that would acquire the troubled assets of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation and liquidate them over time.

title: HEALTH CHIEF TO FACE TOUGH PROBLEMS
description: The next Secretary of Health and Human Services faces difficult problems and policy decisions involving unfilled personnel vacancies, the prospect of budget cuts and the task of devising a new method for paying doctors under Medicare.

title: HERR, CARDS REFLECT ON LOSS
description: Not long after his line drive to the second baseman ended a ninth-inning rally, Tommy Herr sat back in his corner of the Cardinal clubhouse and thought of a way to describe his team's growing predicament.

title: JAZZ: NU, QUINTET, IN DEBUT
description: NU, a quintet featuring the trumpeter Don Cherry, made a polished American debut Tuesday evening at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street. With a repertory of Ornette Coleman-flavored jazz tunes, African melodies and Afro-Caribbean vamps, Nu suggests an earthier version of Old and New Dreams, the band of ex-Coleman sidemen that includes Mr. Cherry and Nu's drummer, Ed Blackwell.

title: JUDGE IN SUFFOLK HOLDS COURT IN A PARKING LOT
description: ''All rise,'' a court officer sang out to a cluster of lawyers this morning outside the darkened State Supreme Court building here.

title: 22...R/1-Q1 -- KARPOV'S FATAL MOVE
description: Anatoly Karpov made one of the worst blunders ever to occur in a world championship chess match in dropping the 11th game of the current series in Moscow to the challenger, Gary Kasparov.

title: THE DANCE: FROM CHINA
description: ''AN AFTERNOON OF CHINESE DANCE,'' which the Young People's Chinese Cultural Center presented Saturday afternoon at Pace University, featured choreography by dancers from China who are now living and studying in New York City. In addition to reflecting folk traditions of several regions of China, the varied program showed the influence of classical ballet on Chinese dance.

title: NEW BID, AS REVLON HINTS AT BUYOUT
description: Revlon Inc. confirmed yesterday that it was looking at the possibility of going private in a leveraged buyout, but the cosmetics company said it had also been approached by a ''major American corporation'' that might be interested in acquiring it.

title: CONTRACT UNDER INQUIRY
description: The state is spending $160,000 a month on overtime as it tries to end a backlog in recording motor-vehicle registrations that state officials say has been caused by problems with a new computer system.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL PITTSBURGH (NL) - Announced an agreement in principle to sell the club for $22 million to a coalition of private and public investors.

title: Benjamin in Accord
description: Benoit Benjamin, the third player chosen in last June's college draft, has reached an agreement in principle with the Los Angeles Clippers, the team announced yesterday. ''It's all agreed upon verbally and in principle, it just has to be drawn up,'' said the Clippers' vice president and general manager, Carl Scheer. Scheer added that there was a possibility the contract could be completed today.

title: PBS SHOW EXAMINES APARTHEID
description: PERHAPS almost everything that should be said and observed about South Africa's apartheid system is being aired this week on WNET/Channel 13 with its own programs and those made by the Public Broadcasting Service. One of the most eloquent of these is a half-hour show, ''Allan Boesak,'' that, at 8:30 tonight, focuses on the religious and moral forces and explain how they have drawn him into the struggle.

title: Topics;   Foreign Fare Watch This Space
description: For 12 years, turning the cable TV dial to channel A in Manhattan was like falling into a vacuum. Except for sporadic special programs, the viewer saw the same motionless message on red and blue announcing this to be the educational television channel of the City University of New York.

title: RENOVATING FOUR CO-OPS AS ONE JOB: A MONEY-SAVING SOLUTION
description: IT began with the typical cry of the New York City apartment dweller: ''I need more space!''

title: DEMOCRATS CALL TRADE TOP ISSUE
description: The Democratic Leadership Council, a group of elected officials trying to invigorate their party with new ideas, today joined the political debate on trade policy. It charged that President Reagan's economic policies, and not foreign trade barriers, were the primary cause of the decline in American competitiveness in world markets.

title: New Acquisition Target For Houston Investor
description: Charles E. Hurwitz, the Houston investor who has built an empire with interests in everything from oil and gas to real estate and savings and loans, is on the acquisition path again.

title: FOR SUSHI AND SASHIMI
description: EVERY piece of Ikuzi Teraki's pottery is handmade, and just the thing for serving sushi and sashimi at home. Mr. Teraki works in white porcelain.

title: Topics;   Foreign Fare A Golden Balance
description: A resident of a small offshore island reports that the top of the lighthouse light blew off, but otherwise the most visible casualty of Hurricane Gloria was the goldenrod. The winds, coming across the ocean, had filled with salt spray.

title: HOUSE PASSES $104 BILLION BILL FOR 3 DEPARTMENTS
description: The House of Representatives today approved a $104.9 billion appropriation bill for the Departments of Labor, Education, and Health and Human Services, including a near doubling of money for research into acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS. The vote was 322 to 107.

title: Imaging Gains For Computers
description: AT the Smithsonian Institution's cavernous National Air and Space Museum, many of Orville and Wilbur Wright's aircraft drawings are crumbling. So are thousands of other brittle design sketches from the early days of flight, kept in a warehouse six miles from the museum floor where throngs of visitors each day gaze at the Kitty Hawk and the Apollo 11 space capsule.

title: WORK ON TAX BILL PUSHED, BUT AIMS VARY WIDELY
description: Congressional leaders of both parties vowed today to press ahead with legislation to rewrite the Federal tax law.

title: Survivor Found Alive In Mexico City Rubble
description: Rescue workers today found a survivor trapped but alive in the rubble of a building that collapsed 14 days ago when the first of two major earthquakes struck Mexico.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
RESTORING THE SPLENDOR OF VERSAILLES
description: Seven years of labor at the chateau of Versailles have restored the former splendor of some 50 rooms, including Marie Antoinette's dressing room and the rooms where the children of Louis XV played. In addition, the magnificent ceremonial staircase designed by Gabriel and begun in 1722 but never completed has been built according to the original design.

title: Diplomacy's Unfair Burden on Communities
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: NINTH DAY OF DEBATE - The Foreign Ministers of Libya and Iran are scheduled to speak during the ninth day of debate in the General Assembly this morning. Other nations scheduled to speak include Laos, Honduras, Ghana, Morocco, Guatemala and Barbados.

title: Headline Confusion
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: STATE, CITING TAX AMNESTY, TELLS CHEATS: GET TO US BEFORE WE GET TO YOU'
description: New York tax evaders were told in detail yesterday how to turn themselves in and avoid penalties under the state's three-month amnesty program. They were also told, in a series of television commercials, ''We know who you are.''

title: A Lawyer in 10 Cases Is Termed an Impostor
description: A Manhattan man was charged yesterday with falsely representing himself as a lawyer in 10 Federal criminal cases.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE PALESTINIAN-ISRAELI FIGHT: ARAB LANDS NOW SPECTATORS
description: The Israeli air strike Tuesday against the P.L.O. headquarters near Tunis underscored the degree to which the Arab-Israel conflict has been transformed in the last year. It has gone from a conflict primarily between Israel and the surrounding Arab countries to a struggle almost exclusively between Israel and the Palestinians, with the Arab countries as spectators.

title: ASTRONAUTS PREPARE FOR SECRET MISSION TODAY
description: The countdown proceeded today for five military officers set to ride the space shuttle Atlantis into space Thursday on a secret Defense Department mission, officials said.

title: Falkland Islanders Will Vote For a New Legislature Today
description: Voters in the Falklands, the islands Britain and Argentina fought over in 1982, will elect a new legislative council Thursday.

title: TENTATIVE PACT IN SHIPYARD STRIKE
description: After a 20-hour session, negotiators reached tentative agreement today on a contract to end a three-month strike of 4,500 shipbuilders at Bath Iron Works.

title: SWITCHCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LILCO HEAD CRITICIZED BY OFFICIALS FOR STYING EUROPEAN VACATION
description: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company has been vacationing in Europe since before Hurricane Gloria struck last week, and today some of the state's political leaders sharply criticized him for his continuing absence.

title: GORBACHEV WARNS ABOUT 'STAR WARS'
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in France today on his first visit to the West since becoming Soviet leader, and warned tonight of ''a tough time'' ahead if the United States kept to its plans to develop a space-based missile defense system.

title: RIOTS CONTINUE IN BRITISH CITIES
description: Youths in Liverpool attacked policemen with stones today as violence flared for a second straight day after a night of violence in that city and in Peckham, an area of south London.

title: Stone Plans to Buy Parts of Champion
description: The Stone Container Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy most of the Champion International Corporation's packaging business for about $457 million.

title: NEO-NAZIS SHARED GAINS WITH OTHERS, U.S. SAYS
description: More than $750,000 in money said to have been stolen in bank and armored-car robberies by the neo-Nazi group the Order was given to leaders of white-supremicist organizations around the country to further their work, according to Federal investigators.

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Latest year results reflect one year of Omega Enterprises operations plus six months of Omega and Gaming & Technology operations combined. 1984 figures reflect only Omega operations. Omega acquired Gaming & Technology in a reverse acquisition on Jan. 1, 1985.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
IMEX MEDICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to June 30
DUEL OF WORDS FOR BRITISH LABOR PARTY'S SOUL
description: The two verbal gladiators had been heading for this fight for more than a year.

title: MUSIC: CONCERTGEBOUW
description: IN an increasingly homogenized and standardized world, major symphony orchestras are hard pressed to maintain distinct, easily distinguishable characters. It is not as easy as it once was, for instance, to identify a Philadelphia Orchestra or a Chicago Symphony or a Berlin Philharmonic. There are still differences in musical schooling and instrumental techniques from country to country, but the effects of worldwide touring and interchangeable conductors has tended to smooth out idiosyncrasies and override national characteristics. One ensemble that continues to show a great deal of individuality, however, is the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, which gave the first of three concerts Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A 2D HOSTAGE IS REPORTED DEAD, AND NEW THREATS ARE MADE
description: One of four Soviet officials kidnapped by gunmen here Monday was found shot dead in West Beirut today, and there were unconfirmed reports that a second hostage had been killed.

title: People
description: Irwin Warren has been elected executive vice president and to the board of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.

title: From Gary Carter's View
description: When the Mets arrived at their Busch Stadium clubhouse, they had to lock up the memory of Tuesday night's tingling 1-0 triumph along with their money and jewelry. But with their deficit down to two games in the National League East, the Mets had the first-place Cardinals precisely where they wanted them last night - swinging against Dwight Gooden, their 20-year-old prodigy who had lost only once since May in compiling a 23-4 record with a 1.51 earned-run average and 250 strikeouts.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL DEBATES AIR RAID
description: Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzak Shamir, appeared before the General Assembly today and strongly defended the Israeli bombing of the Palestinian Liberation Organization headquarters near Tunis.

title: U.S. TOXIC MISHAPS IN CHEMICALS PUT AT 6,298 IN 5 YEARS
description: At least 6,928 accidents involving toxic chemicals have occurred in the United States in the last five years, killing more than 135 people and injuring nearly 1,500, according to a Government report not yet released.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LEAN-TO'S There has been a spate of construction around town lately, most of it put up last week and most of it soon coming down. It is the season for Succoth, or Tabernacles, the Jewish festival of pilgrimage, and it celebrates the late Harvest and God's protection of the Jews when they wandered in the wilderness. The observant Jew builds a succah, a leafy wooden booth that symbolizes the huts Jews lived in during those times.

title: DREXEL AND THE MIDCON SURGE
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., deeply concerned over its rumored role in the Midcon Corporation's stock run-up, has said that it has played no role in the stock rise, sources close to the investment house said yesterday.

title: CLINI-THERM CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CATHOLICS WARNED ON ABORTION ISSUE
description: The American hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church issued a stern warning yesterday to Catholics who dissent from the church's opposition to abortion, declaring that they were going against higher moral laws as well as church doctrine.

title: Mets Sweep Awards
description: Gary Carter was named the National League's player of the month for September and Dwight Gooden the pitcher of the month of September.

title: Soviet Subway
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro would agree with that assessment.

title: Tax Reform, Rostenkowski-Style
description: Dan Rostenkowski, the Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has issued his redesign of the Reagan tax reform. Since no reform is likely without his strong support, it has to be taken seriously.

title: Gun Sellers Liable, Court Says
description: People who make or sell small, cheap handguns should know that they are used mainly by criminals, and therefore the makers or sellers can be sued by victims shot in criminal attacks with them, Maryland's highest court ruled today.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES TO BAR SPACE TEST
description: A House subcommittee voted today to block future tests of the Air Force's new antisatellite weapon as long as the Soviet Union continued a moratorium on similar testing.

title: STUDY REPORTS SHORTCOMINGS IN VOTER REGISTRATION DRIVE
description: A study of nonpartisan voter registration drives held in 1984 concludes that they emphasized registering large numbers of voters at the expense of voter education and other follow-up work.

title: AIDS FEARS FORCED PUPILS OUT
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that three children had been removed from classes by community school district superintendents this term because of suspicions that boyfriends of the students' mothers had AIDS.

title: Brandt Packs His Bags
description: When President Reagan went to Bonn last May for the economic summit meeting, he violated the full diplomatic niceties by not scheduling a meeting with former Chancellor Willy Brandt, chairman of the Social Democratic Party. Not even a photo-opportunity handshake was held, and the West German opposition leader, applying European standards, regarded this as a snub.

title: THREE MILE ISLAND: WHERE IT STANDS
description: The Accident In the early hours of March 28, 1979, things began to go wrong at the Unit 2 nuclear reactor on Three Mile Island in the Susquehanna River near Harrisburg, Pa. Before the trouble was corrected the plant came close to a disastrous meltdown in the worst accident in the history of commercial nuclear power.

title: AIDS Education Drive Is Planned by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo plans a major education effort by the state to inform New Yorkers about AIDS and combat possible panic from misinformation about the disease, a spokesman for the Governor said last night.

title: NBC WINS TV RIGHTS FOR OLYMPICS
description: NBC, using a formula that for the first time links the price paid for broadcast rights to the amount of money taken in from advertising, yesterday won the right to televise the 1988 Summer Olympic Games from Seoul, South Korea.

title: BOOK PUBLISHER NAMED
description: Dan Green, a 23-year veteran of Simon & Schuster, has been named publisher of Weidenfeld & Nicolson New York, the book publishing house recently started by George Weidenfeld and Ann Getty. Mr. Green will also be chief executive officer of the Wheatland Corporation, consisting of Weidenfeld & Nicolson New York and Grove Press, the 33-year-old house that was purchased by Wheatland last March.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE VICTIM'S SONG. By Alice R. Kaminsky. 268 pages. Illustrated. Prometheus Books. $19.95.

title: NEW PROVISIONS FOR CHILD CARE
description: Toddler power now has a place in San Francisco's politics, as the growing need for child care begins pressing its way into the pages of city law.

title: TUNISIAN DISSATISFIED WITH U.S. STAND ON ATTACK
description: The Foreign Minister of Tunisia said today that his country was not satisfied with the American response to a proposed draft resolution in the Security Council condemning Israel's bombing of the Palestine Liberation Organization headquarters.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Klan and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including tax credits of $1,264,000 for the quarter and $2,350,000 for the nine months, and a provision for plant closing of $1,500,000 for the quarter and the nine months. d-Including a provision for plant closings of $6,600,000 in the first quarter. The company and its major subsidiaries filed petitions for relief under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code on Feb. 22, 1985.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: WINDING DOWN - The second week of the General Assembly's general debate winds down today with speeches by representatives from 10 nations. The morning lineup features Ethiopia, the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, Turkey and Malaysia.

title: Mr. Gorbachev's Challenge
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's visit to Paris, deliberately set before his meeting with President Reagan next month, is both a dress rehearsal and an effort to enlist support for Soviet proposals from America's allies in Europe.

title: Dart Debentures
description: The Dart Group Corporation, a retailer, is offering $250 million of 14 percent subordinated debentures at a price of 99, to yield 14.19 percent, through E. F. Hutton & Company as sole underwriter. Proceeds from the sale of the debentures, which carry a speculative grade rating of B-1 from Moody's and B+ from S.&P., will be used for acquisitions or to start new businesses.

title: Nerve Injury Worries Lendl
description: Ivan Lendl is worried - so worried that the United States Open champion is having trouble sleeping. Just when his career has taken a turn for the best, the Czechoslovak star finds himself threatened by a serious inflammation of a nerve in his right arm.

title: Dutton Chief Quits
description: Joseph A. Kanon is resigning as president and publisher of E. P. Dutton, effective Nov. 1.

title: Of Dollars and Doormats
description: Senator William Proxmire calls it a doormat. A Navy spokesman calls it a floor covering. But on one thing they do agree: The item, whatever it is, cost $792.

title: Jimmy Riley at Beacon
description: The singer Jimmy Riley will perform with the rhythm section of the Wailers tonight at 8 at the Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway at 75th Street (874-1717). Opening the show will be the reggae composer-producer Augustus Pablo. Tickets are $15.50 and $17.50.

title: Longer Longest Span
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   'So Easy' Is Theme For Avis
description: IN some markets, the business customers of Avis Inc. are as much as one-third women, according to its marketing executives.

title: BLISS, 'AUSTRALIAN EVERYMAN TALE'
description: EVEN in its moments of wildest and darkest comedy -which are sometimes difficult to distinguish from other intervals - ''Bliss,'' an Australian movie to be shown at the New York Film Festival today at 6:15 P.M. and tomorrow at 6, is deadly serious. If it caused controversy Down Under, according to reports, it may cause more in the way of bewilderment here.

title: Status Studied On Peru Loans
description: Loans made by American banks to Peru will probably be classified as ''value impaired'' when Washington bank regulators meet this month, bankers said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1985
description: International

title: Music at Bronx Zoo
description: Visitors to Wild Asia at the Bronx Zoo on the next four Saturdays will be treated to free performances of Asian music, dance and storytelling in celebration of the Jungle World exhibition.

title: CERBERONICS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
CITY MOVING HOMELESS INTO SHELTER AT BELLEVUE
description: City officials moved beds and cribs into an abandoned psychiatric ward at the Bellevue Hospital Center and opened it last night as a shelter for homeless families.

title: Reagan and the Italians
description: How does a relatively small 10-year-old ethnic organization persuade President Reagan to attend its anniversary gala? Well, the National Italian American Foundation decided last month to present its Life Achievement Award to Frank Sinatra at a dinner at the Washington Hilton Oct. 19, and a few weeks after the decision, White House sources say, the affair quietly found its way onto the President's schedule.

title: Extension for Computerland
description: The Computerland Corporation today reached an agreement giving it 30 extra days to come up with a $25 million cash bond to appeal a court decision that granted an outside investor group a 20 percent stake in the company and $141 million in damages and fees. The bond had been due next Monday, and, although officials of the privately held computer retailer have said they could raise the amount, they apparently were having trouble.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: THIS is the year the Lower East Side has flowered into the bustling art shopping market that, despite its early Bohemian appearance, it always seemed destined to become.

title: DR. G. JARVIS COFFIN
description: Dr. G. Jarvis Coffin, a former medical director of St. Luke's Hospital, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90 years old. Dr. Coffin, who went to St. Luke's as an intern in 1921, was a member of the hospital's staff for 64 years, serving as its director of medicine from 1954 to 1957.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Hugh Green, Tampa Bay's star linebacker, rejoined the Buccaneers after an unexplained one-day walkout. . . . Kurt Becker, the Chicago Bears' offensive guard who hurt his knee in a game against the Minnesota Vikings, underwent surgery and will be out for up to four weeks, the club announced. . . . Ron Tabb, the fifth-fastest American marathoner, has entered the New York City Marathon Oct. 27. . . . Alan R. Fields, an executive for Gulf and Western Industries, which owns Madison Square Garden, was named executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Garden.

title: COLTS WILL FACE THE NEWEST HEAD COACH
description: And so Kay Stephenson was the first to go this season, dismissed this week as coach of the Buffalo Bills, leaving a rather inglorious mark with records of 8-8 in 1983, 2-14 last season and 0-4 this season.

title: MITRAL MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: PRINCEVILLE DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: No year-ago figures are available because the company was spun off in November 1984 from Consolidated Oil & Gas.

title: Fairchild Units May Be Sold
description: Fairchild Industries said yesterday that it might sell or find partners for two of its subsidiaries, the Fairchild Republic Company and the Fairchild Aircraft Corporation, in an effort to reduce its $115 million short-term debt by the end of the year.

title: TROUBLES AT CANADIAN BANKS
description: Until last month, Canada's highly concentrated banking industry had gone 62 years without a bank failure. But since Sept. 1, two of the country's 14 banks have collapsed, leaving behind a potential Government loss of more than $3 billion (Canadian) and the likelihood of major regulatory changes.

title: Ugly Duckling, of Sorts, Is Now a Swan Contest
description: The Federal Government's only art competition, a simple enough citizens' contest to paint the annual decorative duck stamp, has quietly evolved into a competition for one of the richest prizes in painting: a payoff of $2 million or more in related print sales to hunting buffs and collectors.

title: LAW FIRM DROPS SOUTH AFRICA CLIENT
description: The largest law firm in Washington, D.C., Covington & Burling, dropped South African Airways as a client last week, only days after a boycott of the firm by law students at Harvard, Yale, New York University and a number of other schools cut into its efforts to recruit new associates.

title: Courier-Journal Proposal Rejected
description: Sallie Bingham has turned down a $25 million cash offer from the Bingham family for her 15 percent interest in the Courier-Journal and the Louisville Times Company and two other family-owned companies. Instead, she asked the family to respond as soon as possible to a counterproposal she had made.

title: Controllers Defended In Jet Crash at Dallas
description: Officials of the Federal Aviation Administration are defending air traffic controllers who were criticized by the captain of a Delta Air Lines jet just before it crashed in a thunderstorm Aug. 2, killing 137 people.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS SOVIET WAS FIRST TO DROP RELIANCE ON DETERRENCE
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger charged today that the Soviet Union had abandoned the idea of ''mutual assured destruction'' that had long been the basis of nuclear deterrence, and had raced ahead with its own antimissile defense program, even as it denounced President Reagan for doing the same.

title: British Coal Chief Chosen
description: Ian MacGregor, the 73-year-old Scottish-born American who led Britain's National Coal Board during the bitter yearlong strike that ended in March, will be succeeded when his appointment ends next September by Sir Robert Haslam, Energy Secretary Peter Walker said today.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for 16 wks to Sept 22
description: b-Net income, including an extraordinary tax credit of $3.9 million.

title: GORBACHEV URGES ARMS AGREEMENT WITH EUROPEANS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev laid out a formal arms proposal to the United States today and offered to make a ''separate agreement'' with France and Britain to halt what he called the ''infernal train'' of the arms race.

title: GORBACHEV OFFENSIVE: SPLITTING ALLIES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today carried a Soviet diplomatic offensive into what he called ''the heart of Western Europe'' by announcing a series of arms initiatives crafted to split Washington from its NATO allies.

title: Miners in Bolivia Decide To End 4-Week Strike
description: Representatives of more than 27,000 striking miners agreed today to end a monthlong walkout and return to work at Bolivia's largest silver and tin mines, union officials said.

title: PINA BAUSCH DANCE: KEY IS EMOTION
description: LIKE the Pied Piper, Pina Bausch is literally followed by followers - in this case, young dancers pleading to join her West German company. The impact left by the 1984 United States debut of the Pina Bausch Tanztheater Wuppertal, which is appearing at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in a return engagement, has been deeply felt.

title: Faraway Undergrounds
description: Poring over the maps as if one could somehow get from 42d Street to Blackfriar's, Tuileries, Pushkinskaya or Cleveland Park, New Yorkers are taking in an unusual new show underground.

title: Textile Bill: Floor Is Next
description: Legislation to aid the textile industry, which has been hurt by competition from imports, cleared its final committee hurdle in the House today.

title: Baker Packs His Bags
description: Former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. is said to be reluctant to activate his campaign for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination so early that it might interfere with Republicans running in 1986 for various governorships and seats in Congress. But his supporters are concerned that if he seems inactive he may already be losing ground to Vice President Bush, Senator Bob Dole and Representative Jack F. Kemp, so the former majority leader is beginning to hit the road.

title: The Folly in Throwing Tax Dollars at PAC's
description: To the Editor:

title: Vibraphone and Piano
description: The vibraphonist Karl Berger and the pianist George Schutz will play duets tonight at 8 at Carnegie Recital Hall, 154 West 57th Street (247-7800). Tickets are $10.

title: PANEL DISAGREES OVER AIDS RISK FOR PUBLIC
description: The dean of the Harvard School of Public Health warned today that AIDS was spreading through sexual activity into the general population. At the same time, a leading Harvard researcher expressed the opinion that recent assertions about the safety of the nation's blood supply had been ''grossly exaggerated.''

title: First Chicago's Stake in Brazil
description: The First Chicago Corporation said today that the Federal Reserve Board had approved the request of the First Chicago International Finance Corporation to make a capital investment in Banco Denasa de Investimento S.A., a Brazilian bank in which First Chicago has held a minority interest.

title: APPEAL OF VERDICT AGAINST WASHINGTON POST HEARD
description: The United States Court of Appeals considered William P. Tavoulareas's libel case against The Washington Post today, hearing animated arguments about how much weight an appellate court should give to a jury's libel verdict.

title: Benign Nuclear Plants
description: To the Editor:

title: JAEGER OF CANADA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
A Trade Gap Made in America, Not Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: DINOSAURS DIED AFTER A FIRE SWEPT EARTH, SCIENTISTS SAY
description: Scientists say they have discovered the first direct evidence, 65-million-year-old soot, that fire once swept the world and contributed to the mass extinction of dinosaurs and many other forms of life.

title: ART: KEITH SONNIER, MEDIA-ORIENTED SCULPTOR, GOES OWN WAY
description: UNNOTICED by this reviewer, the ''process'' and art and technology movements of the 1960's merged and gave birth to artists who are ''media-oriented.'' A dubious term, this, for while it denotes a preoccupation with up-to-date materials, it also has connotations of the deceptive and the disposable - in other words, the wicked ways of commercial promotion. Art being more the mirror than the conscience of society, it may be obliged to follow these ways more consistently. But in the meantime, one media-oriented sculptor, Keith Sonnier, seems to be balking.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bechtel Group Inc., San Francisco, said its Bechtel Constructors Corp. unit had been selected for the $157 million first-phase expansion of the Palm Beach, Fla., airport.

title: G.A.O. REPORT QUESTIONS QUALITY OF SOME FOREIGN MEDICAL SCHOOLS
description: A report issued today by the General Accounting Office says Government agencies have done little or nothing to deal with the problem of unqualified graduates of foreign medical schools who come to the United States to practice.

title:
TV WEEKEND;

NBC OFFERS PREMIERE OF 'MISFITS OF SCIENCE'
description: SLATED to go up weekly against CBS's ''Dallas'' on Fridays at 9 P.M., NBC's ''Misfits of Science'' is being given a special two-hour premiere on Channel 4 this evening at 8. ''Dallas'' needn't fret.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $2,600,000 for the quarter and $5,000,000 for the nine months. c-Including extraordinary tax credit of $2,800,000.

title: RAIN SETS BACK EFFORTS TO RESTORE ELECTRICITY
description: The widespread effort to restore electricity to parts of Long Island and Connecticut blacked out since Friday by Hurricane Gloria was hobbled yesterday by a steady rain.

title: NEW U.S. VIEW ON DEBT LEAVES 3D WORLD WARY
description: As finance ministers from 149 countries start to gather here for the 40th annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, the major topic of conversation is the revised American strategy for fighting the world debt crisis.

title: Jazz Doctors to Perform
description: The Jazz Doctors - Billy Bang on violin, Frank Lowe on tenor saxophone, Thurman Barker on drums and Wilber Morris on bass - will perform Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Prospect Park Picnic House, near Fifth Street and Prospect Park West. The concert is sponsored by the Musicians of Brooklyn Initiative and Celebrate Brooklyn, and tickets are $5 or a Theater Development Fund voucher. Information: (718) 788-0055.

title: Burroughs Sees Drop In Earnings
description: The Burrroughs Corporation, a leading producer of data-processing equipment based in Detroit, said yesterday that it expected to report ''substantially lower'' earnings in the third quarter.

title: Antique Decoy Show
description: More than 60 dealers of antique decoys will take part in a show this weekend sponsored by the Long Island Decoy Collectors Association at the American Legion Hall on Park Avenue in Amityville, L.I. The decoys will be on display tomorrow from 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday from 9:30 to 4; there will be an auction on Sunday at 2. Admission is $2.50 (free for those under 12). Information: (516) 922-0939.

title: LOUISIANA GOVERNOR'S TRIAL HEARS CO-DEFENDANT SAW A 'GRAVY TRAIN'
description: A Government witness in the racketeering trial of Gov. Edwin Edwards testified today she had been told by an associate of Mr. Edwards that his re-election would bring ''a gravy train.''

title: BEHIND LILY TOMLIN, ANOTHER STAR
description: When the standing ovations started on the opening night of Lily Tomlin's new Broadway show, ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe,'' the star took her curtain calls - and then the shouts began: ''Author! Author!''

title: EAST SIDE HISTORY
description: A display photographs, garments and other items that detail the growth of the Upper East Side from the 17th century to the present, will be on view through Nov 17 at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. Among the prints on view are a 1909 photograph of St. Patrick's Cathedral and a 1935 shot of the Lexington Candy Shop.

title: U.S. SUMMIT STANCE: NUCLEAR TESTING WILL GO ON
description: For the foreseeable future, the United States will not agree to join a July 30 Soviet moratorium on all nuclear testing or agree to a total test ban treaty, according to senior Reagan Administration officials.

title: Jury Begins Deliberating Case of San Diego Mayor
description: The two-month trial of this city's Mayor, Roger Hedgecock, who is charged with criminal conspiracy and perjury in connection with his campaign financing, went to the jury at 11:46 A.M. today.

title: Argentine Officer Defends Anti-Terror Role
description: One of the nine Argentine armed forces officers on trial for large-scale human-rights abuses addressed the court today for the first time.

title: Martha Graham Gets Gingrich Award
description: Martha Graham yesterday received the Arnold Gingrich Memorial Award, presented by the Arts and Business Council for extrardinary achievements in the arts.

title: SANFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $396,000 for the quarter and the 9 months for early extinguishment of debt. Year-ago 9 months results are pro- forma reflecting an acquisition as if it took place on Dec. 1, 1983.

title: Lady Wright, Model
description: A number of prominent Washingtonians will serve as models in a luncheon fashion show to be held today at the Sheraton Washington Hotel for the benefit of the Capital Childrens Museum, but the morning-line favorite for outstanding attraction is Lady Wright, wife of the British Ambassador, Sir Oliver Wright.

title: FILM: GLENN CLOSE AS ATTORNEY IN 'JAGGED EDGE'
description: POURING rain, flashing lightning, scary music: ''Jagged Edge'' begins with all this and more at a lonely beach house, and seems to be signaling at least a hint of irony in the midst of all this crashing melodrama. However, the sequence is in deadly earnest, and it proves to be no less graceful for the rest of the movie. ''Jagged Edge'' has harsh lighting, blunt performances, and artless, no-nonsense dialogue relieved by the occasional bit of excess color. For instance, a judge addressing trial lawyers: ''I'll tell you now, I see this trial degenerating and I'll hit you like a freight train coming down the High Sierra!''

title: IRAN DENOUNCES U.N. AS 'FEEBLE'
description: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran denounced the United Nations today as a post-war alliance of victors that ''does not represent the shared values of the majority'' of its members.

title: Wyoming Policewoman In Beverly Hills
description: If a combination of the old television series ''McCloud'' and the motion picture ''Beverly Hills Cop'' underwent a sex change operation, the result would resemble ''Beverly Hills Cowgirl Blues,'' the attraction on ''The CBS Saturday Night Movies'' on Channel 2 tomorrow from 9 to 11 P.M.

title: Official Pledges Plant Checks
description: Nearly 10 months after at least 2,000 people died from a leak of a poisonous gas in India, Federal officials have not conducted broad inspections of chemical plants in the United States, the acting head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration said Wednesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about Hydro-Quebec utility crews providing help to storm-damaged Connecticut was omitted from some copies and another article, on restoration of electric power to Long Island and Connecticut, appeared twice. Readers wishing copies of the missing article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: KASPAROV, AS BLACK, FORCES A QUICK DRAW
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov played to a draw in only 18 moves today in the 12th game of their world championship chess match.

title: JERSEY'S G.O.P. ENJOYS BIG EDGE IN FUND-RAISING
description: When President Reagan comes to New Jersey Friday to help raise money for state Republicans, his visit will underscore a shift in political power and affluence in the state.

title: 20-Year Streak Has Photo Finish
description: With a burst of effort late in the afternoon four days ago, Rod Forester of Chambersburg (Pa.) High School sprinted past Mike Clark and Drew Sanders of State College High and beat them to the finish line by two seconds, giving his cross-country team a 27-28 dual-meet victory. So what? Well, Forester's last-minute push brought to an end the longest winning streak in the history of American high school sports, State College's string of 189 dual-meet triumphs that dated from Oct. 1, 1965 - two decades before, almost to the day.

title: METS' LAMENT: 'IT'S NOT OVER'
description: And so, like elephants, the Mets are coming home to die.

title: 3 From U.S. Reported Alive in Afghanistan
description: Two American doctors and a photographer, traveling with a journalist who was killed in Afghanistan last week, are believed to be still alive, a private American group aiding the Afghan resistance said today.

title: Economic Scene;   Where China Is Booming
description: THIS Special Economic Zone, an area marked out to attract foreign investment through special tax programs and other incentives, is the most spectacular success story of China's open door policy.

title: Delaware Oil Spill Contained
description: Only a few heavy pockets of oil remained today from a big oil spill in the Delaware River, but the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal was kept closed as a precaution, the Coast Guard said. The tanker Grand Eagle ran aground off Claymont late Saturday night, spilling 435,000 gallons.

title: AMERICAN IS REPORTED HELD BY RIGHTISTS IN BEIRUT
description: A British writer, reported yesterday to have been abducted in Beirut by a Christian rightist group, turned up last night in London saying that he had been released but that an American associate was still being held by the armed group.

title: Another Loss
description: No, it has not been the happiest of seasons for the Chicago Cubs. So when the justices of the Illinois Supreme Court dealt the team another kind of setback yesterday by upholding state and local laws that keep lights out of Wrigley Field, General Manager Dallas Green had this reaction: ''I was surprised it took seven guys to figure out that we were going to get beat again.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1985
description: Companies

title: Yesteryear's Grand Canyon Uranium Mine
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Rohm & Haas Making Top Management Shifts
description: The Rohm & Haas Company yesterday announced several top management changes that a spokesman acknowledged would set up a two-man race to succeed Vincent L. Gregory Jr. when he retires as chairman and chief executive in 1988.

title: FILM: 'DREAMCHILD,' ABOUT LEWIS CARROL'S ALICE
description: THE collision of fading Victorianism with the rough-and-tumble world of American enterprise is a running theme throughout Gavin Millar's ''Dreamchild,'' a small sentimental gem of a movie that is at heart a cinematic memory play.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KOCH BARS EASING OF SYRINGE SALES IN AIDS FIGHT
description: Mayor Koch yesterday rejected a recommendation that the sale of hypodermic needles and syringes be made easier to curb the spread of AIDS among drug users who share dirty needles.

title: Fraud Charged to Doctor In Pacemaker Implants
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a Rhode Island cardiologist, charging him with defrauding the Government by taking nearly $250,000 from pacemaker manufacturers to implant their products in his patients, the Justice Department announced.

title: JACO ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Soviet Hostage Crisis: Very Un-Washingtonlike
description: Compared to the crisis atmosphere and collective angst that usually grip Washington when Americans are held hostage or killed abroad, Moscow has maintained a stony stoicism this week as terrorists in Lebanon kidnapped four Russians and killed one of them.

title: Fannie Mae Certificates Priced to Yield 11.25%
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $200 million of 11 percent mortgage-backed securities at a price of 97 22/32 to yield 11.25 percent through various securities dealers.

title: Adieu Mata Hari, Cloak and Dagger
