description: This has been a season of defections and mishaps for the secret services in Europe, raising perturbing questions for spy masters in the West and even more so in the East.

title: FOR SOVIET ROLE IN LEBANON, KIDNAPPINGS ARE A HEAVY BLOW
description: Lebanese officials and commmentators say the kidnapping of four Russians connected with the Soviet Embassy in Moslem West Beirut has dealt a heavy blow to Soviet diplomacy at a time when Lebanon was moving closer to Moscow and away from Washington.

title: WRIGLEY LIGHTS BAN IS UPHELD
description: The Illinois Supreme Court upheld today a ban on night baseball at Wrigley Field, prompting renewed threats by the Chicago Cubs that they would play elsewhere.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IT may not have gleaming brass samovars or waiters in bright red jackets like those at the Russian Tea Room, but its food evokes the flavors of Russia all the same. Kalinka, a sunny little year-old restaurant at 1067 Madison Avenue, between 80th and 81st Streets, offers a fresh and colorful array of soups, salads and entrees at reasonable prices. It is a good spot to keep in mind for a quick lunch or casual dinner in this neighborhood. Kalinka also has a take-out service.

title: Multinational Clients Challenge the Industry
description: One of the chores of international agencies these days is to prepare for the expected increase of multinational clients by making sure that the agency's network of offices, which might previously have operated fairly autonomously, can now work together smoothly as a team and that there are enough offices in the right places to serve the multinationals.

title: LONG WAIT FOR HOME REPAIR AFTER STORM
description: Ever since a flying sugar maple slammed against the house, taking a bite out of the roof, Audrey Lamborn has been searching for a building contractor and an insurance agent.

title: Ruling Extended
description: Tom McHale, the defensive end who transferred from Maryland to Cornell so he could study at Cornell's school of hotel management, has won another round in his legal fight against the National Collegiate Athletic Association rule that requires transfer students to sit out a year before resuming collegiate eligibility.

title: AFTER THE QUAKES: POLITICAL RUMBLINGS
description: The earthquakes that struck Mexico are likely to provide a critical test in coming months of whether the damage went beyond the physical structures of the Government to rattle its political foundations as well.

title: CBS CORRESPONDENT WAS 68
description: Charles Collingwood, a CBS News correspondent who covered World War II, the Vietnam War and a host of other major events in a career that spanned more than four decades, died of cancer yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $308,000 from tax reversals.

title: YANKS WIN, ARE 3 GAMES OUT
description: Playing out their pennant pursuit in relative privacy and misty rain, the Yankees heard three significant roars and one interesting round of applause from their tiny corps of hardcore fans last night.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BY MAKING WAVES, NEW ZEALAND GETS ON THE MAP
description: For this small South Pacific nation more or less in between Australia and the South Pole, the sudden limelight from its diplomatic battle with France has been dazzling.

title: Former Salesman Is Sperry President
description: The Sperry Corporation yesterday named Joseph J. Kroger, a 51-year-old former computer salesman who is credited with revamping its major computer operations, to be president and chief operating officer.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss, after losses from discontinued operations of $1,671,000 for the quarter and $1,939,000 for the nine months, and a nonrecurring net loss of $929,000 for the quarter and the nine months.

title: U.S. Steel Plans Plate Mill Closing
description: The closing of the last plate mill still in production at the United States Steel Corporation's plant here will cost 450 jobs, leaving fewer than 2,000 working in a plant that employed 20,000 during its peak in World War II.

title: NEW BUILDING IN OLD GREENWICH VILLAGE
description: In the lexicon of real estate, few words are more overused and misused than ''unique.'' Its constant and sometimes hyperbolic appearance in advertisements and promotions for new residential developments can confuse even the most hardened housing shopper as to what really is and is not new.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Restructuring At RCA Units
description: The RCA Corporation said it would restructure some of its electronics and communications businesses and take a charge of $140 million before taxes, or $81 million after taxes, against its third-quarter earnings. The company said that, including an after-tax gain of $92.6 million from the sale of the Hertz Corporation, net income for the period was expected to be higher than in the same quarter last year, when it reported earnings of $78 million, or 74 cents a share.

title: PRETORIA LINKS CUBANS TO ANGOLA WITHDRAWAL
description: The Security Council, which was convened today to consider an Angolan complaint against South Africa, heard a proposal from the Pretoria Government for a resolution demanding the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Angola.

title: AUTO INDUSTRY'S BEST YEAR
description: The automobile industry closed the books today on the most successful model sales year in its history. Auto companies sold a total of 15.6 million domestic and imported 1985 model cars and trucks in the year that ended on Sept. 30, nearly 300,000 more than the previous record set seven years ago.

title: THREE HOMERS GIVE ROYALS WEST LEAD
description: On the fourth day of their four-game series with the California Angels, the Kansas City Royals finally regained first place in the American League West, winning, 4-1, tonight and placing their immediate future in their own hands.

title: People
description: * R. Patrick McCarthy has been appointed senior vice president, director of communications and human resources, at D'Arcy MacManus Masius/Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: CUOMO REVIEWS STROM RECOVERY ON LONG ISLAND
description: Charles Stroh was more than a little surprised this morning when he opened his front door and found Governor Cuomo and more than a dozen news reporters and cameramen on his front porch.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Edge Up
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday as many potential buyers remained on the sidelines waiting for the Treasury to auction new issues later this month.

title: Coast Utility Offers Bonds at 11.61%
description: The Southern California Edison Company is offering $200 million of 11 1/2 percent, 30-year first and refunding mortgage bonds at a price of 99.08 to, yield 11.61 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: William Speer Is Dead at 74; A Dean at M.I.T. for 22 Years
description: William Speer, former associate dean for student counseling at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died Sunday of respiratory failure in a nursing home in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: David Murray Octet
description: The David Murray Octet - with Hugh Ragin on trumpet, Craig Harris on trombone, John Purcell on clarinet and saxophones and Wilber Morris on bass - performs tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; 10, 11:30 and 1 A.M. Sunday. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: A Rating Review For Ohio Utilities
description: The ratings on $3.5 billion in debt securities of four Ohio utilities connected to the Zimmer power plant project have been placed under review for possible upgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of 3H Industries on May 31, 1985.

title: Airlines Are Told to Inspect Bulkheads on Boeing 727's
description: Federal Aviation Administration has ordered domestic airlines to inspect older Boeing 727 airplanes for cracks.

title: CITY OPERA: 'KISMET' MAKES SEASON DEBUT
description: FROM one standpoint, ''Kismet'' might seem to belong in an opera company's repertory more legitimately than most musicals. Much of the score of this 1953 Broadway hit was begged, borrowed or stolen from Borodin's ''Prince Igor,'' and that opera occasionally peers out at us through the cotton candy spun by the team of Robert Wright and George Forrest. Such logic, however, proved to be very shaky in the New York City Opera's new production, which had its first performance last night. Of this rather aimless show it may only be said - to resort to an ancient critical dodge -that if this is the sort of thing you like, you will like this ''Kismet.''

title: 3 PRISONERS SAID TO BE FREED IN A BID FOR DUARTE DAUGHTER
description: The Salvadoran Government has freed three political prisoners and is preparing to hand over others in its bid to obtain the release of the kidnapped daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, according to a Salvadoran close to the case.

title: Spot Silver Prices Jump On Rports of Hunt Sale
description: Silver prices jumped a sharp 5.5 percent yesterday on reports that the Hunt family of Texas had completed selling about 59 million ounces of the silver it acquired on a speculative binge in the late 1970's.

title: Cable TV Pirate Sentenced
description: Frank Cardamone, 25 years old, was sentenced today to five years probation for running what the authorities said was the nation's largest cable television piracy operation. He was convicted in February 1984 of criminal conspiracy, theft and possessing equipment for the theft of telecommunications services. The Judge, James Munley of Lackawanna County Court, said imprisonment ''would not be appropriate under the circumstances.'' Mr. Cardamone could have been sentenced to 14 years in prison and fines totaling $30,000.

title: PHYSIO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to June 30
EX-C.I.A. AIDE MAY HAVE TOLD OF SPY METHODS
description: A missing former C.I.A. officer is believed to have given the Soviet Union significant secret information about the methods the United States uses to gather intelligence in Moscow, Congressional sources said tonight.

title: Police in Paris Thwart Anti-Soviet Protesters
description: Policemen today hustled a French Jewish war veteran from the scene of a wreath-laying at the Arc de Triomphe by the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: AMR May Sell Food Service Unit
description: Robert L. Crandall, chairman and chief executive of the AMR Corporation, said the company had discussed selling its food service subsidiary, Flagship International Inc., which operates as Sky Chefs. Mr. Crandall also said at an analysts meeting that AMR, parent of American Airlines, would look at Avis to see whether the subsidiary of the Beatrice Companies would want to acquire Sky Chefs.

title: Clippers Sign Williams
description: The Boston Celtics said that they had given up rights to the veteran guard Ray Williams, who had signed a free-agent offer sheet with the Los Angeles Clippers. The Celtics said that in exchange for surrendering their right of first refusal to match the Clippers' offer to Williams, they would receive some form of compensation in the future, possibly a draft pick. . . . Spencer Haywood, the 35-year-old former star who had been trying for a comeback with the Detroit Pistons after two years of retirement, was waived by the club yesterday along with a rookie guard, Kenny Patterson. . . . Daryl Lloyd, a rookie forward who was cut by the Philadelphia 76ers Wednesday night, found himself back on the team yesterday after the club decided it needed him to fill in for Andrew Toney, a guard who reinjured his left ankle in a practice.

title: 2 New Dance Works By Laura Dean
description: Excerpts from two new dance pieces, ''Impact'' and ''Transformer,'' will be performed by the Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians this weekend as part of the Works and Process series at the Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue at 89th Street.

title: ART: JAN HAFSTROM OPENS SEASON OF NEW NAMES
description: IT is a promising season that brings us, straight off, a slew of new names we shall be glad to remember. One of them is Jan Hafstrom, a Swedish artist whose work can be seen at the Jack Tilton Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, through Monday.

title: 74 PLAY OCTOBERFEST IN SWING
description: ''Here's one of my favorites,'' said Curt Dempster, looking over the schedule of the Ensemble Studio Theater's Octoberfest. ''A play called 'Plato's Republic.' I have no idea what it's about.''

title: RAX RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-After pre-tax charges of $1,374,000 and $1,299,000 for the quarter and the year. c-Net income.

title: JOINT BID IS SEEN FOR GROUP W
description: Three of the nation's largest cable operators - Time Inc., Tele-Communications Inc. and the Comcast Corporation - are expected to form a group to bid jointly for Group W Cable Inc., according to sources close to those companies.

title: Market Place;   New Optimism On Oil Issues
description: OIL stocks are back in favor.

title: Bridge: New York Area Team Finds A Silver Lining in Its Cloud
description: When one door closes, another opens: those eliminated in the early rounds of the Spingold Knockout in Las Vegas, Nev., in August were able to shoot for the national men's and women's Swiss team events, which were scheduled for the final weekend of the Summer Nationals.

title: Ford Credit Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Corporation is offering $200 million of floating-rate notes due in 1992 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Interest on the notes, rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P., will be adjusted and paid semiannually at 1/8 percentage point above the offered rate for interbank deposits in London.

title: DE LAURENTIIS TO MARKET OWN FILMS
description: Dino de Laurentiis, who purchased Embassy Pictures from Coca-Cola last week, said today that he had bought the company so he could distribute his own films instead of having to go through a major studio.

title: WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 18
Keep Bilingualism
description: Bilingual education programs in public schools are under attack by the Government official who should be their strongest defender.

title: Musical Ruling
description: Willie Banks, holder of the world record in the triple jump, apparently will be able to listen to his musical tapes on the field today during the World Cup track and field meet, after all. The International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world governing body of track and field, had ruled yesterday that Banks would not be permitted to bring his stereo headphones onto the field.

title: President of U.P.I. Resigns; News Agency Silent on Why
description: Ray Wechsler, president of United Press International, is resigning, the news agency said today. It did not disclose the reasons.

title: The Balanced Baloney Act of 1985
description: Frustrated by the failure to reduce the breathtaking Federal deficit, Congress and the President are ready to fasten onto a fantasy. Dreamed up by Senators Rudman of New Hampshire and Gramm of Texas, both Republicans, it promises to balance the budget by 1991. The idea is appealing but this approach is perilously unbalanced.

title: Rival Zimbabwe Parties Agree on a Merger
description: Zimbabwe's two major political parties reached a broad agreement to merge at a meeting between Prime Minister Robert Mugabe and the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo, it was announced here today.

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a two-for-one stock split in June 1985.

title: Classical Hindu Dance
description: Bharata Natyam, a classical Hindu dance drama of India, will be performed by Shusheela Mehta tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a debate between Governor Kean and Peter Shapiro, the Essex County Executive, misstated the county's tax rate. It is $1.05 for each $100 of assessed valuation, down from $1.45 in 1978.

title: CARDS' SPEED CREATES VICTORY
description: They did not add any stolen bases to the total that has become an important part of their trademark, and they did not have an extra base hit.

title: U.S. Official Offers to Meet Allies Before Summit Talks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has offered to fly to Brussels for talks with foreign ministers of North Atlantic Treaty Organization members on the November summit meeting, the State Department said today.

title: MEXICANS TRY TO SAVE BOY, 9, IN RUBBLE
description: Rescuers digging with shovels and their bare hands fought today to reach a 9-year-old boy thought to be still alive in the rubble of an apartment building wrecked two weeks ago in the earthquake disaster. It was unclear tonight whether they could reach him in time.

title: MUTUAL REAL ESTATE INVESTENT TRUST reports earnings for Year to June 30
AUCTIONS
description: AUCTIONGOERS have a rare opportunity this weekend to view two dramatically different antiques collections assembled by wealthy families over more than a half century. Curiosities dominate in one, while the other is filled with handsome though more predictable furnishings. Both contain offerings that are expected to sell for moderate prices when they are auctioned next week at New York's two largest auction houses.

title: Addendum
description: * USA Today is raising its advertising rates 7.7 percent on Nov. 1.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,000 for the quarter and $75,000 for the nine months, and extraordinary credits of $48,000 for the quarter and $78,000 for the nine months. c-Net loss, after losses from discontinued operations of $1,482,000 for the quarter and $2,159,000 for the nine months.

title: Judging a Judge Buckley
description: On the advice of the Justice Department, former Senator James Buckley declined to talk to New York City's bar association about his qualifications for the Federal appeals court in Manhattan. The association's judiciary committee responded by issuing a public rating of ''not approved'' for the nomination, which the department has not yet recommended to the White House.

title: FARM REFERENDUM PLAN DEFEATED IN HOUSE VOTE
description: The House of Representatives today bowed to pressure from the Reagan Administration and the nation's food processors by defeating a section of the new farm bill that could have led to severely restricted production of wheat and corn and to higher prices for consumers.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Mellon Bank Corp. has named Joseph Linn president and chief executive of Mellon Securities Trust Co., Pittsburgh.

title: GROSS TESTIFIES ABOUT AUTOPSY AT STEWART TRIAL
description: The city's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, began his testimony yesterday on the findings of his autopsy of Michael Stewart.

title: Sun Oil Plans Restructuring
description: The Sun Company, the nation's 10th-largest oil company, said yesterday that it would restructure its operations and take a $275 million charge against third-quarter earnings.

title: ON THE OPERABILL, FROM THE GRAND TO THE INTIMATE
description: GRANDNESS is a relative term in the world of grand opera, and New Yorkers get to measure this art form in a variety of sizes and shapes. From its earliest years, opera has leaned toward the spectacular, but it has also made small spaces and limited resources work in its favor. Both these sides will be seen this weekend.

title: FILM: BODY SNATCHING IN 'DOCTOR AND THE DEVILS'
description: WITH the current New York Film Festival going in so heavily for cinema art, it's a pleasure to come upon a regular - though not exactly old-fashioned - commercial movie designed to appeal to the timid beast in all of us. It's Freddie Francis's ''Doctor and the Devils,'' yet another grisly fiction inspired by the infamous William Burke and Willian Hare who, in the 1820's, were arrested for supplying all-too-fresh bodies to the celebrated Edinburgh anatomist Dr. Robert Knox.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Synthetic Fuels Cuts
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington has suggested that the Administration would support Congressional efforts to abolish or further curtail the Synthetic Fuels Corporation.

title: RICH AND STAKES-FILLED CARD AT BELMONT
description: The top 3-year-old colts and fillies are missing and the 2-year-olds ran last weekend, but the rich card at Belmont Park tomorrow has a little of just about everything else, with a New York-record five graded stakes races on the program.

title: WTC INTERNATIONAL N V reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
STOCKS CLOSE MIXED IN SLOWER TRADING
description: Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday as the debilitating effects of Wednesday's selling in hospital management equities began to wear off.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. URGED TUNIS TO TAKE P.L.O.
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said yesterday that the United States urged Tunisia to absorb some Palestine Liberation Organization personnel when they were forced to leave Beirut in 1982.

title: ELECTRO SCIENTIFIC INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday

title: BUDGET OFFICE ATTACKED OVER RULES FOR ASBESTOS
description: A Congressional report issued today asserted that the White House Office of Management and Budget, in an ''unlawful abuse of power,'' had for more than a year blocked measures to protect the public from asbestos.

title: BLACKS AND JEWS IN NEW YORK CONDEMN FARRAKHAN'S VIEWS
description: A broad range of New York's civic, religious and political leaders, black and white, yesterday repudiated the racial and religious views of Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim minister.

title: Threat to Kill Hostage In Lebanon Reported
description: The newspaper An Nahar reported today that the terrorist group known as Islamic Holy War said in a statement that it was about to execute William Buckley, a United States Embassy official who is one of six Americans missing in Lebanon.

title: STUDENT, 15, SEIZED IN SEXUAL ASSAULTS ON 8-YEAR-OLD GIRLS
description: A 15-year-old high school student has been arrested on charges that he sexually assaulted two 8-year-old girls in the bathroom of a South Bronx elementary school on Tuesday.

title: Lloyd's Move
description: Lloyd's has suspended a record 199 members from underwriting with the world's biggest insurance market after they failed to meet solvency requirements. The suspended members belong to syndicates that have record underwriting losses of about $185 million. As a result of the suspensions, Lloyd's, whose total membership is about 26,000, is setting aside a record $80 million from its central fund to insure that all claims on policies underwritten by the suspended members are met.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
OPEC FAILS TO REACH ACCORD ON QUOTAS
description: Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries failed today to resolve demands for higher production quotas by six of the group's 13 members, and put off further discussions of the matter until their next meeting in Geneva in December.

title: SHULTZ SUGGESTS THAT SOUTH AFRICA RELEASE MANDELA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said yesterday that the South African Government could ''signal'' its willingness to search for a political compromise with the black majority by freeing Nelson Mandela, the prominent black political prisoner, and agreeing to negotiations with him and the outlawed African National Congress.

title: George Savalas Dead; A Movie and TV Actor
description: George Savalas, who played the role of Detective Stavros on the ''Kojak'' television show, which starred his brother Telly Savalas, died of leukemia Wednesday at the University of California Los Angeles Medical Center in Westwood. He was 58 years old.

title: LARRY ADLER 'SINGS' MOUTH ORGAN AT BALLROOM
description: ONE of the fondest memories of Larry Adler, the world-famous mouth organist, is of the time in Chicago when he and Duke Ellington gave an impromptu performance at the Grand Terrace, a South Side nightclub run by Earl Hines. ''Afterward,'' Mr. Adler recalled in his autobiography, ''Duke said, 'I want you to meet somebody,' and took me to a ringside table where a lady was sitting alone.''

title: Accounts
description: * Ohrbach's to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: Remembering Boulanger
description: More than a dozen former pupils of Nadia Boulanger showed up at the French Embassy's Cultural Services headquarters at 972 Fifth Avenue, at 78th Street, to reminisce about the celebrated music teacher.

title: Another Record
description: WOR-TV, the Mets' flagship station, is now riding a two-game winning streak that has been built in record-breaking fashion.

title: GIANTS' HAYNES WANTS TO LEAVE;   RECEIVER SAYS KNEE IS FINE
description: Wesley Walker, the Jets' most accomplished and dangerous receiver, but also one of the most injured, said today he was ready to return Sunday for the first time this season.

title: PLAN TO END DEFICIT IN 1991 GAINING WIDE SUPPORT
description: The Republican leadership in the House and the Senate today endorsed a proposal aimed at forcing the Government to balance the budget by 1991.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We see what attempts are now being made to find a way out - by using new arms in the so-called Star Wars. This is an illusion and an extremely dangerous one at that.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from the settlement of a lawsuit of $702,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: Regents Board to Get Charges in Gross Case
description: The State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, decided today to have the State Board of Regents make the final decision on whether the state should proceed with medical misconduct charges against the New York City Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot Gross.

title: Outdoor Outfitters Publication Acquired
description: Burke Communications Industries of Chicago, already the owner of Outside magazine, a consumer publication, has acquired the National Outdoor Outfitters News, a trade publication and a leader in its limited field.

title: MOBILE HOME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income. In December 1984 the company filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Lawyer Fighting 30-Day Sentence
description: A Federal judge has scheduled a hearing for Oct. 10 on the 30-day jail sentence he imposed on the attorney Adam O. Renfroe Jr. at the conclusion of the cocaine distribution trial of Curtis Strong.

title: MOTHERS AGAINST DRUNK DRIVING STRIPS FOUNDER OF 2 MAJOR POSTS
description: Candy Lightner, who founded Mothers Against Drunk Driving after a drunken driver killed her daughter in 1980, was stripped of two posts and much of her authority yesterday in an apparent power struggle within the organization.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: REPORTING GRAND JURY DATA IN PREPARING CASE IS BANNED
description: A Brooklyn judge yesterday ordered a reporter from The Daily News not to write stories about a former baseball player, Joe Pepitone, that were based on grand-jury testimony.

title: Duets at Roulette
description: The saxophonist John Zorn and Michihiro Sato, who plays the shamisen (a banjo-like stringed instrument), will perform duets tonight at 9 at Roulette, 228 West Broadway at White Street (431-1022). Tickets are $5.

title: SUBWAY ANTICRIME TV TEST ABANDONED
description: Four years after the start of an experiment to place more than 200 closed-circuit television cameras in two high-crime subway stations, the program is being discontinued.

title: METS STUMBLE ON THE THRESHOLD OF FIRST PLACE
description: After two rousing nights of classic baseball, the Mets took a noble but mighty tumble at the gates to first place tonight when they lost to the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3, and fell two games behind with three to go.

title: Wrong Number?
description: Coach Mack Brown, whose Tulane football team is 0-4, describes the dearth of respect being afforded him: ''I called Dial-a-Prayer, and they hung up on me.''

title: Like Little Buzz Saws
description: In the 50's, movies like ''Blackboard Jungle'' made the switchblade knife an object of such adolescent fascination that localities banned its sale and Washington forbade sending it through the mails.

title: RATIFICATION TO TAKE 3 TO 4 WEEKS
description: For the second time in little more than three months, the United Transportation Union and a bargaining group representing most of the nation's major railroads have reached a tentative agreement with substantial raises for 68,000 railroad workers.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. The final home stand and the first of three final regular-season games for the Mets. (Television -Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto. Opener of a series that has been sold out for at least a week. If the Yankees can move a game behind the first-place Blue Jays by the final scheduled game Sunday, then both teams will have to play makeup games on Monday to try to decide the American League East championship, the Yankees against the Tigers at Yankee Stadium, and the Blue Jays against the Orioles in Toronto. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at George Mason University, Fairfax, Va., 8:30 P.M. Exhibition opener and the debut of Patrick Ewing in a Knicks uniform. (Television - MSG, 8:30 P.M.) Tennis Davis Cup Semifinals, West Germany vs. Czechoslovakia, at Frankfurt, and Sweden vs. Australia, at Malmo, Sweden. Opening-round singles in the three-of-five competition. The West Germans, led by Boris Becker, knocked the United States out in the quarterfinal round in August. Sweden, the defending champion after beating the United States in the final last year, is led by Joakim Nystrom, who knocked Becker out of the United States Open this year. Australia is playing without the injured Paul McNamee. Eastern Tennis Association Nyack Classic for women and men 60 and over and 70 and over, at the Nyack Field Club, Nyack, N.Y., 9 A.M., women's finals.

title: CORRECTION
description: A movie review of ''Colonel Redl'' on Wednesday attributed a scene to the film incorrectly. The scene, in which the protagonist is blackmailed by Czarist agents, is from John Osborne's play ''Patriot for Me,'' which was a source for the film.

title: Philippe Petit
description: Philippe Petit, who walked a high-wire strung between the towers of the World Trade Center 11 years ago, will take to the wire tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street.

title: FILM: SCHWARZENGGER, 'COMMANDO'
description: ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER is a delicate talent to work with. If a director tries to make the personality of a character he portrays too complex, the result will be confusion or, at best, unintended hilarity. Mr. Schwarzenegger first appears in ''Commando'' in parts - one huge bicep and then another; when the camera pulls back he is seen to be carrying an ax and the trunk of a large tree down a mountainside to his house. And the early scenes in which Mr. Schwarzenegger, as Col. John Matrix, a retired commando, is at home with his daughter (Alyssa Milano) have an underlying current of humor - it is clear the child would be as comfortable cuddling up to a polar bear.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''IT'S a play that was living somewhere inside me,'' said John Pielmeier, the author of ''The Boys of Winter,'' a drama about Vietnam that will open at the Biltmore Theater Nov. 17.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES PRAYER PROPOSAL
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow setting aside a moment for silent prayer or meditation in public schools.

title: Informing the People
description: President Reagan's last news conference was not one of the Great Communicator's most instructive performances. For example: 1. He declared that ''the United States is still well behind the Soviet Union in literally every kind of offensive weapon, both conventional and in the strategic weapons.'' That earned the President this remarkable rebuke from Sam Nunn of Georgia, one of the Senate's most informed men on military matters:

title: NESTOR INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
A Trade Gap Made in America, Not Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME CAMBODIANS HIDING IN THAI REFUGEE CAMP
description: At least 7,100 Cambodians, many of whom had fled what they considered dangerous camps on the Thailand-Cambodian border, have been found illegally hiding in a major Thai refugee center, according to officials who conducted a census of the camp last weekend.

title: FORSTMANN IN BUYOUT OF REVLON
description: Revlon, one of the best-known names in cosmetics, agreed yesterday to a complicated buyout proposal from the New York investment firm of Forstmann Little & Company that involves breaking the company into three parts.

title: THEATER: THREE BY SAM SHEPARD
description: BENEATH their often rambunctious surface, Sam Shepard's early one-act plays deal with the collision of the inner self and the threatening world at large. As the characters go through behavioral rituals - eating, drinking, pairing off - they are shadowed by apocalyptical events beyond their comprehension.

title: EVEN FUN IS WORK AT U.N. PARTIES
description: Surveying the roomful of drinking diplomats Monday night at a dinner given by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Richard A. Woolcott, Australia's chief delegate to the United Nations, joked about the social demands of his occupation. ''Apart from a good mind,'' he said, ''the two most important assets for a U.N. diplomat are a good tailor and a strong liver.''

title: 4-Day Layoff At Control Data
description: The Control Data Corporation, which has been battered by the weak market for computers and peripherals, said that its entire domestic work force would be required to take four days off without pay by Nov. 30 in an effort to reduce expenses. About 40,000 employees will be affected.

title: Islanders Demote King
description: Derek King, the 18-year-old left wing who was the Islanders' first-round draft choice this year, was sent back to his junior team in Canada yesterday as the club trimmed its roster to 32 players. King, who lost a week of practice with a knee injury, was the 13th player selected in the June draft.

title: 4TH SPACE SHUTTLE STARTS SECRET MISSION
description: Five military officers flew into space today aboard the new space shuttle Atlantis on a secret mission for the Defense Department.

title: GIANTS' HAYNES WANTS TO LEAVE;   HOLDOUT SEEKS TRADE
description: Mark Haynes, the Giants' unsigned All-Pro cornerback, asked today to be traded, saying he had lost respect for the Giants' management and coaches. He did not know if he could play again for the Giants, Haynes said, and ''it would be a very tough situation'' if he did.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $101.6 million, to $208.11 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the first weekly increase after five weeks of declines, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: REAGAN SEES TAX LEGISLATION THIS YEAR
description: President Reagan said today that, despite skepticism in Congress about the popularity of tax revision, his plan to overhaul the Federal income tax system will be passed before the end of 1985.

title: ACCORD ON TRUCE SEEN IN LEBANON
description: Syria and a Sunni Moslem militia chief agreed today on a draft accord aimed at halting fighting in Tripoli, a move that some officials believed raised hopes for three surviving Soviet Embassy men held hostage in Lebanon under threat of death. One Soviet diplomat was found slain on Wednesday.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 7
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $34.9 million for the 12 weeks and the 36 weeks on the sale of the company's Australian operating subsidiaries.

title: XEROX RESHAPES CRUM & FORSTER
description: The Xerox Corporation took steps yesterday to reposition its Crum & Forster insurance subsidiary, a move that will have an adverse impact of $160 million after taxes on third-quarter earnings.

title: Hutton Auditor Defends Role
description: Documents released today by Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, showed that even when E. F. Hutton & Company's illegal overdrafting scheme was coming unraveled in early 1982, members of top management assured auditors that no illegalities were involved and that the brokerage firm might face ''negative publicity'' but no monetary damages from the situation.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY GORBACHEV ON ARMS
description: Following are excerpts from an address today by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to about 50 members of the French National Assembly at the official residence of its Speaker, as translated by Mr. Gorbachev's aides:

title: WAYS AND MEANS UNIT BEGINS VOTING ON TAX PLAN
description: After three days of wrangling over procedural matters, the House Ways and Means Committee today took its first votes on substantive tax issues.

title: HINDERLITER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE EVENING HOURS
description: HELEN HAYES, looking too sprightly for the part, was the guest of honor at an 85th birthday party Wednesday night at Tavern on the Green. Her birthday will actually take place next Thursday, but Miss Hayes celebrated early with a benefit for Citymeals-on-Wheels, a nutritional lifeline for more than 6,000 homebound elderly.

title: Apology to a Deserving Dog
description: I have been taken to task - with considerable justification, it appears - by a passionate beagler from Nebraska.

title: Dining Out Guide: After the Theater
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Cocaine Trial Faces New Delay
description: The trial of a bartender accused of selling cocaine to the former Pittsburgh Pirates outfielder John Milner was further delayed today as a Federal appeals court decided whether to allow two former Pirates to testify.

title: AFTER 6 YEARS, UNDAMAGED REACTOR AT 3 MILE ISLAND IS RESTARTED
description: Six and a half years after the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident, the undamaged Unit 1 reactor was restarted today on Three Mile Island.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''Charles Dodgson has been locked up in the nursery far too long,'' says Dennis Potter of the man who - under the name of Lewis Carroll - wrote ''Alice in Wonderland'' and ''Through the Looking Glass.''

title: Don King's Trial to Open
description: The tax-evasion trial of the boxing promoter Don King is scheduled to begin today in United States District Court in Manhattan.

title: Woman Wanted to Die, Facility's Attorney Says
description: An elderly woman's health was rapidly deteriorating and she wanted to die months before entering a Texas nursing home, defense attorneys said today in the trial of the nursing home company and its employees on murder charges in the woman's death.

title: EWING MAKING A GOOD IMPRESSION
description: The initial reviews are in, and, to the surprise of no one, Patrick Ewing is a hit.

title: REAGAN SEES SHIFT ON ARMS BY SOVIET
description: President Reagan said today that the Soviet Union had substantially altered its arms control proposals and that he had no objection to an offer today by Mikhail S. Gorbachev for separate negotiations between Moscow and Britain and France to reduce nuclear arsenals.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WHEN the Gotham Bar and Grill was born a year and a half ago, it had a pedigree that seemed to assure success. One of the owners, Jerome Kretchmer, who was a member of the Lindsay Administration, had the kind of heavy-hitting friends whose presence would add a luster to the stunning post-modern setting. The cookbook author Barbara Kafka was hired as a consultant and devised an eclectic, au courant menu that attracted much buzzing among food writers. Shortly after its celebrated opening, however, reports from the front were dismaying. Like Hurricane Gloria, Gotham turned out to be 80 percent anticipation. The food wasn't very good.

title: FILM: FROM NEW ZEALAND, 'CAME A HOT FRIDAY'
description: NEW ZEALAND is not often represented in American film showplaces and the newest movie from that far-off country, ''Came a Hot Friday,'' which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street 2, is not likely to elevate it to the pantheon of cinema. But hold on a second, the film is a mildly diverting comedy about two amusing scamps that will pass the time decently enough, if not memorably.

title: UTILITIES REPORT GAINS IN GETTING POWER BACK ON
description: Utilities said yesterday that nearly all Connecticut customers blacked out a week ago by Hurricane Gloria should have electricity restored by tonight. They said that most blacked-out customers on Long Island would have power by Sunday but that some restoration work would go on until early next week.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Mohawk Data Set To Sell Five Units
description: The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation, which has strived unsuccessfully for months to sell many of its operations, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell five units to a newly formed private company for about $180 million.

title: PLEXUS RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ALASKAN OIL EXPORTS LET 'EVERYONE' WIN
description: To the Editor:

title: House Unit Backs Some Tax Shifts
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, continuing to work slowly through a comprehensive tax-revision bill, set aside some controversial items for the time being and voted today on several relatively minor matters.

title: 2 Workers Die in Acid Spill
description: Two pipefitters at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation died today after they were accidentally doused with acid used to mill metal parts for high-performance airplanes. About five gallons of the hydrofluoric acid spilled on them when a pressure valve at the top of a tank truck they were unloading ruptured.

title: SALVATION ARMY SUES 2 OVER KICKBACK SCHEME
description: The Salvation Army has accused a father and son of tainting the charity's reputation by involving its employees in a kickback scheme.

title: GETTING THUMBS OFF THE TRADE SCALE
description: Under pressure from the Reagan Administration, 90 nations have agreed to talk about reducing a variety of non-tariff trade restrictions, including barriers to trade in services.

title: G TECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
BIG QUAKE HITS TOKYO BUT DAMAGE IS MINOR
description: Tokyo was rocked Friday night by its most severe earthquake in 62 years, a sudden jolt that halted trains and caused skyscrapers to sway.

title: Hit-Run Driver Kills 2 Bronx Men
description: A hit-and-run driver struck two men walking their dogs in the Bronx yesterday, killing both men, the police said.

title: CUOMO AND KOCH RECONSIDERING THEIR OPPOSITION TO CLOSING OF BATHHOUSES
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch indicated yesterday that they were reconsidering their opposition to the closing of bathhouses catering to homosexuals as a way of reducing the spread of AIDS.

title: Censure of Civil Court Judge Voted by State Commission
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct has recommended censure for a New York City judge who ordered a convicted teen-age prostitute to sit beside him on the bench for a few hours last year.

title: 'HOME AS PRISON' FITS YOUNG OFFENDERS, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: 30 SAID TO DIE IN PERU PRISON RIOT
description: Thirty inmates died tonight in a riot at Lurigancho Prison on the outskirts of Lima, an official reported.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air One, St. Louis, said it had completed its plan of reorganization and has emerged from protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws.

title: What's the Latin for B.O. Smash?
description: Now of course we know Hollywood should have cashed in big by producing ''Casablanca II'' in 1944. I tried to tell them, but they didn't know what I was talking about because in those days nobody in Hollywood had heard of Roman numerals.

title: FROM AN AMERICAN IN PARIS, CUSTOM-MADE JEWELRY
description: Women coming here to shop for clothes are passing around the name of a jewelry designer the same way women once told their best friends the name of a treasured ''little dressmaker.'' The jeweler is Joel Arthur Rosenthal - he calls his business JAR's - and he has occupied a small, cozy shop in the arcade at 7 Place Vendome for just seven years. He has never run an ad or given an interview, he says, because he simply is not equipped to handle a large business.

title: Back Seeks Draft
description: Kenneth Davis, the all-America running back from Texas Christian University who was suspended along with six other players after it was discovered they were being paid by T.C.U. boosters, wants to finish the season in the National Football League. But although several teams, including the Chicago Bears, the Buffalo Bills and the Los Angeles Raiders, are reportedly interested in signing him, they have been blocked by an N.F.L. rule prohibiting athletes from playing in the league in the same season they have played at the college level.

title: PENN IS TOLD TO REVIEW LABS AND END ABUSES TO ANIMALS
description: The Government today ordered the University of Pennsylvania to review all its research laboratories for animal cruelty and open its laboratories to Federal inspectors to verify that abuses have been corrected.

title: BRITISH LABOR PARTY ASSAILS U.S. LATIN POLICY
description: The opposition Labor Party passed a resolution today that condemned United States policy in Central America and said a future Labor government might supply Nicaragua with military aid.

title: Fed Panel Voted No Changes
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve Board voted in August to make no changes that would alter the current level of interest rates, although they expressed concern about a continued surge in growth of the nation's money supply.

title: POFTRAITS OF RENOIR AND COCTEAU
description: Two giants of the French cinema are each the subject of a splendid documentary that will be shown on a double-bill in the New York Film Festival today at 3 P.M. and next Saturday at 6 P.M. They are ''Jean Renoir, the Boss,'' directed by Jacques Rivette and Andre S. Labarthe, and ''Jean Cocteau: Self-Portrait of a Man Unknown,'' directed by Edgardo Cozarinsky, the Argentine-born director who's lived in France since 1974.

title: Hanson Lifts Stake In SCM to 32.1%
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C., a British conglomerate that is attempting to take over the SCM Corporation, said late yesterday that it had raised its purchases of SCM stock by 545,000 shares in the three days ended yesterday. Hanson said it now held 3,961,600 SCM shares, or 32.1 percent of SCM's 12.34 million shares.

title: It's Still This Year
description: It was the scruffiest, trashiest two-run rally you could imagine - the only hit was a 65-foot chopper by Gary Carter - but it was as if the echoes of Johnny Podres and Gil Hodges and Sandy Amoros were blowing the ball around for the Mets on the 30th anniversary of another big game in the city.

title: Common Interests
description: We have a lot in common,'' Alair A. Townsend, New York's Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said of Han Boping, Deputy Mayor of Peking. ''Housing problems, transportation problems and having two working spouses.''

title: AFGHAN REBELS REPORT CAPTURE OF ARMY BASE
description: Moslem rebels fighting the Soviet-backed regime in Afghanistan have captured an army headquarters base and a Government official, rebel spokesmen in Peshawar said today.

title: On Making It In the Hispanic Community
description: When Mayor Koch named a commission of 16 Hispanic New Yorkers to study poverty in their community, he turned the occasion into the retelling of a success story.

title: Fiat-Ford Talks
description: Talks over merging Italy's Fiat and Ford's European subsidiary have run into trouble but are continuing despite the snags, a Fiat spokesman said.

title: NEW YORK JOBLESS RATE RISES AS SUMMER ENDS
description: The unemployment rates for New York City, New York State and New Jersey edged up slightly last month as summer jobs ended for many of the region's residents, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: STANFORD ASSERTS CHINA RESEARCHER IS EXPELLED LIED ABOUT HIS USE OF GRANT FUNDS
description: In the spring of 1980 someone purchased a truck in Hong Kong and donated it to a Chinese village near Canton where a graduate student from Stanford University was doing research.

title: S.I. HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Net loss.

title: FEDERAL AGENTS TO INVESTIGATE AIRPLANE CRASH
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has assigned almost two dozen agents to investigate the apparent sabotage of an airplane that crashed shortly after takeoff near here last Sunday, killing the pilot and 16 skydivers aboard the plane.

title: EX-AGENT DECLINES TO TESTIFY AT HIS SPY TRIAL
description: The defense in the case of the first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigtion charged with espionage rested today without calling the former agent to testify.

title: LONDON AND PARIS SPURN ARMS OFFER FROM GORBACHEV
description: President Francois Mitterrand, appearing at a news conference with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, today rejected the Soviet leader's proposal for separate arms negotiations with France.

title: KIRKPATRICK RULES OUT RACE FOR SENATE FROM MARYLAND
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, says she will not run for the Senate from Maryland.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 2:20 P.M. (Television - WHT and SportsChannel, 2:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 2:15 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto. (Television -Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Chicago Cubs, at St. Louis. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.) Royals vs. Oakland A's, at Kansas City. (Radio -WCBS 880, 8:20 P.M.). Football South Carolina at Pittsburgh (Television - USA Network, noon.); North Carolina at Georgia Tech (Television - MSG, noon); Princeton at Brown (Television - Channel 13, 1 P.M.); New Hampshire at Connecticut, 1 P.M.; Penn at Columbia, 1:30 P.M. (Radio -WKCR-FM 89.9, 1:30 P.M.); Rutgers vs. Boston College, at Giants Stadium, 12:20 P.M., live (Television - MSG, 10:30 P.M., tape. Radio - WRSU-FM 88.7, 12:15 P.M., and WCTC 1450, 12:15 P.M.); R.P.I. at Iona, 1 P.M.; St. John's at Fordham, 1 P.M. (Radio -WFUV-FM 90.7, 1 P.M.); Catholic U. at Hofstra, 1:30 P.M.; Wagner at Cortland State, 1:30 P.M.; Pace at Villanova, 1:30 P.M.; Fairleigh Dickisnson-Madison at Marist, 1:30 P.M.; Yale at Army, 2 P.M.; Michigan State at Iowa (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.); Notre Dame at Air Force (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.; New York Maritime at Fairfield, 7:30 P.M.; Mississippi at Auburn (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.); Purdue at Minnesota (Television -WTBS, 8 P.M.); Prarie View vs. Grambling, at Dallas. (Television - WTBS 8 P.M.); Ohio State at Illinois (Television - Satellite Program Network, 1:30 A.M., tape).

title: LOTHAR W. NORDHEIM
description: Lothar W. Nordheim, a physicist who helped make the atomic bomb in World War II and later played a major role in the development of the hydrogen bomb, died Tuesday at St. Paul's Health Care Center here. He was 85 years old.

title: PLAN TO BALANCE U.S. BUDGET BY '91 DELAYED IN SENATE
description: Senators critical of a proposal to balance the Federal budget by 1991 blocked a vote on the plan today as members of Congress were torn between its political attraction and its possible flaws, both constitutional and fiscal.

title: Stations Battle Down to Wire
description: It was one hectic day of television negotiations yesterday for the Yankees. And by the time everybody finished talking, WPIX-TV (Channel 11), whose final baseball telecast of the season was to have been last Sunday, had received permission to show today's game at Toronto - if the Yankees remained in the race against the Blue Jays - and tomorrow's game there as well, when Phil Niekro tries again to nail down career victory No. 300. Last night's game might also have been a part of the agreement, but the length of the discussions simply left too liitle time.

title: CONTEXT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Dr. Simon Silverman, Ex-Head Of School Guidance Division
description: Dr. Simon S. Silverman, retired head of the Bureau of Child Guidance of the New York City Board of Education, died Sept. 21 in Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens, and Singer Island, Fla.

title: EWING IMPRESSIVE IN DEBUT AS A PRO
description: If Patrick Ewing goes on to have a long and storied career, as everyone seems to predict he will, it will be noted that it began - unofficially, at least - in a proud fashion. The 7-foot center was not spectacular tonight, but he was effective. And he did make mistakes. Yet in 24 minutes, he overcame opening-night jitters and scored 10 points, grabbed 15 rebounds, blocked one shot and committed five fouls against the Washington Bullets in the Knicks' first exhibition game of the new season.

title: Bridge;   A New Yorker Forms Half Of Partnership in Shanghai
description: Maintaining a bridge partnership with someone half a world away is not easy, but it can be done.

title: A POROUS NUCLEAR PACT
description: The agreement for United States nuclear cooperation with China, before Congress, is a porous document that fails to meet requirements of the Atomic Energy Act. Congress seems inclined to overlook this awkward problem.

title: ACRONYM OF THE WEEK
description: Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of Queens, has come up with the term ''BOBO.'' He says it stands for ''Big Oil Bail Out,'' his description of a toxic waste cleanup bill passed by the House last week.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the reported abduction of a British writer and an American associate in Beirut included an erroneous reference to a New York murder case about which the Briton, Anthony Haden-Guest, had written in a book. The murder victim was John Tupper, Howard Jacobson's rival for the affections of a model, Melanie Cain.

title: BERGERAC'S SUDDEN REVERSAL
description: What gives with Michel Bergerac?

title: NORTHROP'S F-20 HOPES DEALT A BLOW BY REPORT
description: Congressional analysts this week challenged the Northrop Corporation's contentions that its F-20 Tigershark is a better plane and a better buy than a stripped-down General Dynamics F-16 Falcon.

title: COMPUTER STOCKS LEAD MARKET DOWN
description: Stocks declined broadly yesterday, after a forecast by the Burroughs Corporation of ''substantially lower'' third-quarter earnings sent many computer stocks tumbling.

title:
Patents;

Fingerprint Processor Eliminates Distortion
description: Fingermatrix Inc. of North White Plains, N.Y., received a patent this week on a fingerprint-processing apparatus.

title: Cavaliers Sign Lee
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers yesterday announced the signing of Keith Lee, a rookie forward, to a multiyear contract. The signing came after a one-week holdout. the former Memphis State star's agent, Peter Johnson of the International Management Group in Cleveland, would not disclose the length of the pact, believed to be for three years, but he did say that it was worth between $800,000 and $1.2 million, with no incentive clauses. . . . Darrell Griffith, a free-agent guard who has not signed with the Utah Jazz for this season, broke his left little toe while playing basketball yesterday in his native Louisville, Ky. Team physicians were awaiting X-rays to assess the injury.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REMARKS OF GORBACHEV AND MITTERRAND TO THE PRESS IN PARIS
description: Following are excerpts from the news conference in Paris today by President Francois Mitterrand and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, as translated by Cable News Network:

title: LEBANESE INVESTIGATE REPORT ON HOSTAGE
description: The Lebanese authorities began an investigation today to try to verify an assertion by the underground group Islamic Holy War that it had killed William Buckley, one of six Americans it said it was holding hostage.

title: YANKEES AND METS TRIUMPH AND STAY ALIVE
description: Two games out with two to go: That's where the Mets stood last night in their forlorn and fading pennant race after they beat the Montreal Expos, 9-4, and won a game but lost a day.

title: TAX UNCERTAINTY AFFECTING DECISIONS
description: The protracted Congressional debate over President Reagan's sweeping proposals to overhaul the tax law has thrown investment decisions out of kilter for large parts of the American economy.

title: SAD, SWEET TRAMP
description: CHAPLIN. HIS LIFE AND ART. By David Robinson. 792 pages. McGraw-Hill Book Company. $24.95. CHARLIE CHAPLIN. By Maurice Bessy. 438 pages. Harper & Row. $50 ''All my pictures,'' Charles Spencer Chaplin once observed, ''are built around the idea of getting me in trouble and so giving me the chance to be desperately serious in my attempt to appear as a normal little gentleman. That is why, no matter how desperate the predicament is, I am always very much in earnest about clutching my cane, straightening my derby hat and fixing my tie, even though I have just landed on my head.''

title: A REVIVING COSMETICS LINE
description: Although Revlon's beauty products may have lost some of their gloss in recent years, industry experts say the company still has one of the strongest brand names in a bottle. They say the biggest challenge the company's new owners will face is to nuture what has been a budding turnaround.

title: CITY COLLEGE'S STAKE IN AN AUDUBON SET'S AUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT RISES A BIT, TO 7%
description: The nation's unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a point in September, to 7 percent, as the number of manufacturing jobs showed its sharpest decline in nearly three years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: London Stock Changes Set
description: The London Stock Exchange said today that it would allow outsiders such as banks to own outright member firms from March as part of its program to modernize centuries-old trading systems.

title: STUDY SEES BROAD SHIFTS IN AUTO SUPPLIER FIELD
description: The automobile supplier industry, under pressure from the Big Three car makers, will undergo a major restructuring over the next seven years, according to a study conducted for the State of Michigan.

title: MODERATE SAUDI OIL RISE SEEN
description: The Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, indicated today that his country would moderate planned increases in oil production to prevent them from undermining the world oil market.

title: ON KEEPING THE ELDERLY OUT OF NURSING HOMES
description: To the Editor:

title: Pratt Hotel Plans
description: The Pratt Hotel Corporation is ''actively working'' on plans for building its second Atlantic City casino-hotel, the company's president, William P. Weidner, said. He said Pratt also expects to announce soon casino projects in three Caribbean nations and that it is considering the establishment of casinos in various Latin American, Middle Eastern and Far Eastern countries. Pratt owns and operates the Sands Hotel and Casino, and has interests in other casino and hotel properties. Mr. Weidner would not say where the new hotel would be built.

title: IN PRAISE OF MEMORY
description: Memory, and memorization, have earned undeservedly bad publicity.

title: RPM, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Westfield Coatings in January 1985. Share earnings have been restated to reflect the effect of a 25 percent Common Share Dividend on November 30, 1984.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1985
description: International

title: BULGARIAN MAINTAINS INNOCENCE IN ROME TRIAL
description: A Bulgarian airline official accused of being an accomplice of the Turk who tried to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981 had his days in court this week, and he denied having anything to do with the attempt on the Pope's life.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The longer something hangs around here, it gets stale. People start reading it.''

title: Water Limits Removed For 93 Towns in Jersey
description: Water restrictions in 93 towns in northeastern New Jersey were lifted today because of heavy rainfall in recent weeks, officials announced.

title: CELLIST FOR BUDAPEST QUARTET
description: Mischa Schneider, the cellist with the Budapest String Quartet for 38 years, died Thursday at his home in Buffalo. He was 81 years old. Mr. Schneider was born in Vilna, Lithuania, and as a teen-ager went to Leipzig, Germany, to study at the conservatory there with Julius Klengel. Mr. Schneider continued his education in Paris, where he attended the Ecole Normale de Musique. In 1930, at the age of 26, he became the cellist with the Budapest Quartet.

title: DRACULA
description: Children of the night, what music they could make on Nov. 2 at the end of the Smithsonian Institution's day long seminar on Dracula.

title: 600 SIGN PETITION AGAINST WHITNEY DESIGN
description: A petition signed by more than 600 people, including architects, artists and writers - among them Edward Larabee Barnes, I. M. Pei, Isamu Noguchi and Arthur Miller - has asked the trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art to abandon their plan to build a structure designed by the architect Michael Graves.

title: PROTESTS FAIL TO STOP DIVING MULES
description: The Aqua Mules did their show as scheduled today at the Alabama State Fair in Birmingham, despite protests by animal welfare groups who say it is cruel to make mules dive off a 30-foot-high platform into a six-foot-deep tank of water.

title: Goodrich Backed On Acquisition
description: A Federal Trade Commission complaint challenging the B.F. Goodrich Company's acquisition of two Diamond Shamrock Plastics Corporation plants was dismissed by an F.T.C. administrative law judge, officials said. The 1982 F.T.C. complaint had charged that the acquisition could reduce competition in the production of polyvinyl chloride in vinyl chloride monomer materials used in plastics.

title: Gun Sellers Liable, Court Says
description: People who make or sell small, cheap pistols should know that they are used mainly by criminals, and therefore the makers or sellers can be sued by victims shot in criminal attacks with them, Maryland's highest court ruled Thursday.

title: BUDGET DIRECTOR IS CONFIRMED
description: The Senate confirmed James C. Miller 3d today to succeed David A. Stockman as director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: AUTUMN RAINS DELAY A WORRIED FARMER'S HARVEST
description: As Shorty Gladbach trudged between rows of tall corn, rain-soaked soil sucked at his boots. A few steps behind came his son Johnny, trying to match his father's long strides with 5-year-old legs.

title: ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF LEARNING ENGLISH
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 SENTENCED IN BOMB PLOT
description: Three suspected members of a Puerto Rican nationalist group were sentenced in Federal District Court today to 35-year prison terms for plotting Fourth of July bombings of two military installations in 1983.

title: AFFIRMATIVE COMFORT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD ON TRADING TV PROGRAMS
description: American public television executives said today that they had reached agreement in principle with Soviet broadcast authorities for a major exchange of American and Russian television programs.

title: JOY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SOVIET PLAN: U.S. REACTS
description: The Soviet leadership's new arms-control proposals have produced somewhat contradictory responses from the Reagan Administration, which seems pleased to have the proposals but unhappy with much of their content.

title: BEHIND THE ALBANIAN CURTAIN, NEW CHIEF SETTLES IN
description: The President of Albania delivered a long speech on domestic and foreign policy recently, and hardly anyone outside the country noticed.

title: SOVIET ANTIMISSILE EFFORTS LISTED
description: Reagan Administration officials renewed charges today that for decades the Soviet Union had devoted more effort and money than the United States to devising ways to defend against nuclear attack.

title: JAMAICA ENVOY NAMED
description: President Reagan has nominated a loyal political supporter, Michael Sotirhos, to fill one of the most sensitive diplomatic posts in the Caribbean, Ambassador to Jamaica. The nomination is now in the Senate, but a hearing date has not been set for Mr. Sotirhos, who heads Ariston Interior Designers Inc., in New York.

title: THEATER: BELGIAN TROUPE PRESENTS 'LE LIVRE'
description: Belgium's Theatre de Banlieue has impressive theatrical credentials. For many years, the director, A. Mebirouk, was a member of the Theatre Laboratoire Vicinal and the company he founded has performed at many international festivals.

title: AN INNOVATION BY KASPAROV
description: A sparkling innovative gambit by Gary Kasparov enabled him to obtain an effortless draw in the 12th game of his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov in the Tchaikovsky Concert Hall in Moscow on Thursday.

title:
Patents;

Furnace Tests Metal In Space
description: A FURNACE to be used in space shuttles to conduct metallurgical experiments that are only possible in zero gravity was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PROCESSION OF ANIMALS
description: Sunday will be a special day for animals during a celebration of the feast of St. Francis at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. The day begins at 11 A.M. with a mass featuring music by the Paul Winter Consort and performances by the cathedral choirs and the Omega Liturgical Dance Company. A procession of animals, including an elephant, llama, horse, cow and monkey, is planned at 1:15 P.M. An afternoon of activities, including plays, dance performances, films and the blessing of parishoners' pets begins at 2 P.M. Information: 678-6962.

title:
Patents;

11% Rise in Fees
description: Because Congress has taken no action to alter the scale, increases in fees proposed by the Patent and Trademark Office that were to be instituted today have gone into effect. The average increase is reported to be 11 percent above previous rates. The charge for one copy of a printed patent has gone up to $1.50, from $1.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HARD-PRESSED FARMER REAPS HELPERS FROM CITY
description: As far as any of his neighbors can tell, Vince D'Attolico is just about the cagiest guy in the valley. He has all of these city slickers from Manhattan out harvesting his crops, doing stoop labor for nothing and smiling about it.

title: FOOTBALL TEAM RIGHTS COURSE
description: The Merchant Marine Academy's football team is undefeated after four games, in first place in the new Liberty Conference, ranked first in the East among Division III teams and second in the nation.

title: DIVERSITY OF BLACKS DENOTES NO SCHISMS
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING WELFARE, AND WORK, PAY OFF
description: Support for big-budget social welfare programs has faded in these conservative times. But when such programs deliver a large return on the investment, fiscal and social, they deserve support from right and left.

title: U.S. Investing Plans Abroad
description: American companies plan to increase capital investment in their overseas subsidiaries by 2.5 percent in 1986, far below the 15 percent increase expected for this year, the Government said today.

title: U.S. DECLARES KAHANE IS NO LONGER A CITIZEN
description: The State Department said today that it had deprived Rabbi Meir Kahane, the Israeli political leader, of his United States citizenship.

title: Parochial Interest
description: Exotic attire'' was specified on the invitation to an ''exotic bazaar'' after the opening of ''Kismet'' at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center Thursday.

title: HELEN OF TROY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income. The company has changed its year- end to the end of February instead of Dec. 31.

title: S.M.U. Applies Brakes
description: Southern Methodist University, which was hit with a series of stiff sanctions after the National Collegiate Athletic Association found it guilty of football-recruiting violations, largely by boosters who reportedly provided money and cars to S.M.U. players, has moved to head off further problems. According to Bob Hitch, the athletic director, all student-athletes have been required to register their cars with the athletic department.

title: SOVIET EMBASSY SENDS 60 HOME FROM LEBANON
description: The Soviet Union today evacuated nonessential staff members and families of diplomats from its embassy in Moslem West Beirut.

title: College Games at a Glance
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses.

title: IN FIRST JOINT APPEARANCE, KOCH AND McGRATH BACK PROPOSED NAVY BASE ON S.I.
description: In their first joint appearance of the mayoral campaign, Mayor Koch and his Republican opponent, Diane McGrath, agreed yesterday that they would not oppose the stationing of nuclear-armed warships at a base proposed for New York Harbor.

title: SIDNEY CLUTE
description: Sidney Clute, the actor who played Detective Paul LaGuardia on the ''Cagney & Lacey'' television series, died of cancer Wednesday at St. George Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: BURROUGHS'S SURPRISE SETBACK
description: Until a few days ago, the Burroughs Corporation looked like one of the few American computer makers that would make it through the industry's worst year in two decades relatively unscathed.

title: Rangers Win
description: Steve Patrick's goal 2 minutes 27 seconds into overtime lifted the Rangers to a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in an exhibition tonight. Grant Ledyard and Mike Allison each assisted on the goal.

title: THE UPWARDLY MOBILE IN CLASS BY THEMSELVES
description: Friday night alone in the big city. No messages on the answering machine. No place to go.

title: RETIRING TO SOMETHING
description: I have a sad memory of my father after he retired in his mid-60's, still in good health. He spent every morning poring over his newspaper and reading his mail, much of it junk mail. He even examined each coupon before throwing the lot away. Following lunch, he took a long nap. Then he went grocery shopping. He spent hours in the supermarket in the small town where he lived, comparing prices, examining new products, reading the fine print on labels - anything to spend time. Late every afternoon, he watched television, like a child watches it - staring with dull eyes. In the evenings, he would watch more television, sometimes falling asleep by its flickering light. Retirement for him meant that time had to be endured rather than used. He died five years after he retired.

title: Farewell for Sipe
description: He had an outstanding career in two leagues, but after two shoulder operations, Brian Sipe, the 36-year-old Jacksonville Bull quarterback, has been told that his playing days are over. ''It's time to move on,'' he said after learning that he had failed a recent medical examination and would be waived by the Bulls within a few days. Sipe stopped short of announcing his retirement, but he made clear he had little hope of resuming his career.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about Canadian banks incorrectly described the loan loss reserves listed in the final column. The figures were derived from a five-year moving average of the individual banks' loan loss experiences, rather than reflecting the actual level from Oct. 31, 1984, to July 31, 1985. Figures for 1985 have not yet been propared by the banks.

title: HOLDING UP COMMUNICATIONS COSTS
description: In a recent boost for free markets, Washington wisely gave the green light to three private companies to compete with Intelsat, the 110-nation consortium that owns most of the world's telecommunications satellites. Now Intelsat asks for the right to lower its prices for television signals, high-speed data transmission and other business services to meet the new competition. But the State Department is balking.

title: Murray Latimer, 84; U.S. Pension Architect
description: Murray Webb Latimer, an architect of the Social Security Act and an expert on pensions, died Tuesday at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: BERMUDA FAULTS PRETORIA
description: Bermuda adopted economic sanctions against South Africa today and called for the elimination of apartheid. Prime Minister John Swan announced the sanctions after months of protests by local anti-apartheid groups that had urged the Government of this British colony to sever all links with South Africa. The sanctions banned all commercial imports from South Africa including the sale of gold krugerrands. Mr. Swan also reiterated Bermuda's policy of not investing in South African companies.

title: NEW YORK CITY OPERA: SEASON'S FIRST 'KISMET'
description: From one standpoint, ''Kismet'' might seem to belong in an opera company's repertory more legitimately than most musicals. Much of the score of this 1953 Broadway hit was begged, borrowed or stolen from Borodin's ''Prince Igor,'' and that opera occasionally peers out at us through the cotton candy spun by the team of Robert Wright and George Forrest. Such logic, however, proved to be very shaky in the New York City Opera's new production, which had its first performance last night. Of this rather aimless show it may only be said - to resort to an ancient critical dodge -that if this is the sort of thing you like, you will like this ''Kismet.''

title: FOR 'RADIO'S BAD BOY,' THIS ISN'T PRIME TIME
description: Howard Stern's foot is swollen and bandaged and he hobbles through his split-level house in Manhasset Hills, L.I., on a pair of crutches.

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results for latest periods include unusual nonrecurring expenses of about $4.2 million.

title: RESCUERS IN MEXICO TUNNEL TOWARD BOY
description: Rescue workers today continued to tunnel in the rubble of an apartment building destroyed by the earthquake last month, seeking a 9-year-old boy they think has been trapped alive for 16 days.

title: Late Rally Eases Sharp Drop in Oil
description: The inconclusive end of the two-day OPEC meeting sparked a broad slide in prices of crude oil and petroleum products in Europe and the United States in morning trading yesterday.

title: Idle Wild Foods
description: Idle Wild Foods Inc. said it had agreed to be acquired by Bennet S. Le Bow, an investor, for $32.50 a share, or a total of $62 million. The meat processing, food and trucking company will be a private concern after the transaction, but it is expected to continue as currently operated. Mr. Le Bow also owns MAI Basic Four Inc. Idle Wild's stock was bid at $29 a share in over-the-counter trading today.

title: Your Money;   Tax Swapping By Year's End
description: YEAR-END tax swapping is a traditional way to generate paper losses as a means of sheltering real income from taxes. But this year the technique can be even more useful because of the possibility that President Reagan's tax proposals will be enacted.

title: TEACHER STRIKES END; 44,000 STUDENTS STILL OUT
description: Two teacher strikes in Pennsylvania were settled yesterday and another was suspended, but more than 12,000 public school pupils remained out of class elsewhere in the state.

title: CARDINALS WIN ON 6-HITTER TO CLINCH TIE
description: With their 100th victory, the St. Louis Cardinals tonight clinched at least a tie for the National League East title. Bob Forsch combined with Todd Worrell to stop the Chicago Cubs, 4-2, on a six-hitter while Andy Van Slyke hit his 13th home run.

title: GORBACHEV MEETS THE PRESS: A BANTERING STYLE AND AN ECHO OF KHRUSHCHEV
description: The spectacle of Mikhail S. Gorbachev tangling with the press in the ruthless forum of a Western-style news conference marked a Soviet leadership finally arrived in the television age.

title: Bell Resources, Broken Hill Tie
description: Bell Resources Ltd. said today that it held an interest in 103 million Broken Hill Proprietary Company shares at the close of trading on Wednesday, or about 10 percent of Broken Hill's 1.03 billion shares. The interest comprised 19.6 million ordinary shares and the balance by way of contracts in share options traded on the Australian stock exchanges, Bell said in a brief statement to the Perth Stock Exchange.

title: WHAT PRICE FOR A PRICELESS MUSEUM?
description: It is hard to believe that a resurgent New York cannot provide a proper home for the Museum of the American Indian and its priceless ethnological collection. Yet all paths seem blocked. And with an open-ended offer to move to Dallas, the museum's trustees are preparing to ask the courts to release them from their obligation to remain in New York.

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including special credits of $58,000 for the quarter and a gain of $2.9 million for the 9 months and a tax credit of $1.3 million for the nine months. d-Including a gain of $336,000 on sale of investments and a tax credit of $149,000.

title: SHUTTLE ON SECRET MISSION DEPLOYS 2 SATELLITES
description: The military crew of the space shuttle Atlantis deployed two $100 million communication satellites for the Department of Defense today, according to reliable sources.

title: U.N. BODY ASSAILS ISRAELI AIR STRIKE
description: The Security Council tonight condemned Israel's raid on the Palestine Liberation Organization's headquarters in Tunisia.
