title: E. Harold Hugo Is Dead at 85; Headed Meriden Gravure Co.
description: E. Harold Hugo, the retired president of the Meriden Gravure Company, died Sept. 9 at St. Francis Hospital in Hartford. He was 85 years old and lived in Meriden, Conn.

title: DATEBOOKS: A STAMPEDE TO GET ORGANIZED
description: Allison Hudnut Clarkson can tell you what she had for dinner on her honeymoon. Or who she called each day last week. Or which of her friends have birthdays in September.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CLEVELAND TEAMSTER AIDE MAY RETRACT GUILTY PLEA
description: Jack Nardi, who pleaded guilty in a payroll scheme involving a local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in Cleveland, now wants to retract his plea, an attorney says.

title: PRESIDENT URGES VOTES FOR G.O.P. IN JERSEY RACES
description: President Reagan, calling New Jersey ''a bellwether for the national recovery,'' urged voters today to re-elect Governor Kean and to give Republicans control of the State Assembly for the first time in a dozen years.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a provision for relocation cost of $2,516,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Year to July 27
description: b-Including a tax credit of $511,000

title: A SUPREME CELEBRATION
description: On Monday, as is traditional for the first Monday in October, the Supreme Court will start its new session. But Monday will be a special day for another reason as the Justices mark the 50th anniversary of the Court's installation in its present building.

title: On Making It In Brooklyn
description: Made in Brooklyn'' is not one of your best-known labels, whether it be on clothing, soda vending machines, pens or forklifts.

title: 'NO MAN'S LAND,' DRAMA OF FRENCH - SWISS BORDER
description: Each of the four principal characters in Alain Tanner's ''No Man's Land'' wants to be some place else.

title: ABC MONROE-REPORT CANCELLATION IS ARGUED
description: A decision by Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, to kill a 13-minute report about Marilyn Monroe for last Thursday night's ''20/20'' has drawn criticism from the co-anchors of the program, Hugh Downs and Barbara Walters, and the executive producer, Av Westin.

title: Interest Rates Advance a Bit
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday, as securities dealers and investors awaited Congressional action to increase the Federal debt ceiling and allow the Treasury to proceed with a huge amount of postponed auctions.

title: Challenge to Election Barred
description: The House has rejected former Representative George Hansen's challenge to his 170-vote loss last November to Richard H. Stallings. Mr. Hansen, a Republican, said that registration and other procedures had been handled improperly in the election, in which more than 200,000 votes were cast. Mr. Hansen's challenge was dismissed Wednesday by a vote of 247 to 4, with 169 Republicans voting ''present'' in protest.

title: SUDBURY HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: b-Including a tax credit of $885,000. c-Including a tax credit of $378,000.

title: RESTARTED NUCLEAR UNIT RUNS WELL, OFFICIALS SAY
description: The Unit 1 nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island ran smoothly today, its first full day of operation in the six and a half years since its twin, Unit 2, was damaged in the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident, plant officials said.

title: YOU CAN BANK ON RUDENESS
description: Many people don't like automatic teller machines in banks because they're so impersonal. But I prefer them to the flesh-and-blood tellers precisely because they don't talk back. They respond politely to my requests. They're not abusive or disrespectful. In short, they are my friends at the bank.

title: Gallows Humor
description: Coach Don Morton of Tulsa's 1-3 football team assesses today's opponent, who is 3-0: ''I don't think Oklahoma State is any better than fourth in the nation - right behind the Dallas Cowboys, the Denver Broncos and the Chicago Bears.''

title: WIFE ACCUSED OF CONTRACT KILLING
description: A Staten Island woman was charged with murder yesterday, accused of having paid $10,000 to have her husband killed at his appliance store last March, the police said.

title: Sweep for WOR
description: While the Yankees were trying to put an end to vituperation, the mood at WOR-TV was one of bliss.

title: F.C.C. ACTS TO EASE DISTANCE RATE COSTS
description: The Federal Communications Commission adopted a new policy today that will make it easier for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to offer selective discounts on long-distance service to compete with smaller long-distance companies.

title:
Patents;

Devices Paired to Pick Bills in Bank Machines
description: A multi-picker mechanism for automatic banking machines has been invented by staff members of Diebold Inc., a manufacturer of such equipment in Canton, Ohio.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday about a meeting of the United Nations Security Council misidentified Venancio de Moura, an Angolan official. He is Deputy Foreign Minister.

title: Top Choice Signed
description: The Islanders signed Brad Dalgarno, their No. 1 draft selection this year, to his first professional contract and returned him to his junior team in Hamilton. No terms of the multiyear contract were revealed. In six preseason games with the Islanders, the 18-year-old Dalgarno scored one goal. . . . Tim Bothwell, a St. Louis Blues defenseman who once played for the Rangers, has been traded to the Hartford Whalers for unspecified future considerations.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 28. 1. According to scientists, the 65-million-year-old soot, whose presence appears to be worldwide, is the first direct evidence of a global fire that may have contributed to the mass extinction of dinosaurs and many other forms of life. 2. He proposed that the Soviet Union hold separate arms talks with France and Britain. 3. Second. 4. A referendum to block the Navy from establishing a base on Staten Island for ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons. 5. Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, was named Ambassador to Ireland. 6. The soccer clubs Juventus of Turin, Italy, and Glasgow Celtic of Scotland played in the European Cup and the Cup Winners' Cup before empty stands. The teams were forced to play without crowds as punishment for past incidents of violence. 7. Businessmen. 8. As a water conservation effort in New York City, a law prohibits any showerhead that uses up more than three gallons of water a minute. 9. The legal battles for his return ended with his 18th birthday, when his parents' custody automatically expired. 14.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1985
description: International

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $5,345,000 relating to a damage award from Sharon Steel Corp.

title: PARSIPPANY TAKES THE PRESIDENT'S APPEARANCE INSTRIDE
description: Jellybeans in glass jars were placed on the tables. White House security men - crisp white shirts, trousers with yellow stripes down the legs, pistols on their hips - prowled the halls. And Samir Shafei sat back in his office this morning and calmly smoked a cigarette.

title: REAGAN CHOICE FOR POST IN PEKING IS BLOCKED
description: The nomination of Winston Lord as Ambassador to China has been stalled in the Senate, a Republican leadership aide said.

title: FREE RIDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. SAYS EX-C.I.A. AGENT WENT TO AUSTRIA IN '84 TO BETRAY SECRETS
description: Edward L. Howard, a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, traveled to Austria in 1984 and sold Soviet intelligence agents highly secret information about American intelligence sources and methods, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: KREMLIN CHIC: PARIS WOMEN TAKE A LOOK
description: Raisa Gorbachev may have electrified many Westerners and Russians with her elegance, but her first official appearance here in the world fashion capital has drawn mixed reviews.

title: Jury Is Chosen
description: A jury of eight women and four men was selected yesterday to hear testimony in the tax-evasion trial of the boxing promoter Don King, which will begin Monday in United States District Court in Manhattan.

title: BRASH COLEMAN GETS A BIG HIT
description: He had not planned on getting here quite this fast. When the St. Louis Cardinals chose Vince Coleman in the June 1982 draft, he considered the realistic possibilities for a 10th-round selection and thought that a spot on the major league roster was, at best, five years away. But then, Coleman has always possessed the ability to move quickly from one place to another.

title: Armstrong Tire May Shut a Plant
description: The Armstrong Tire Company said that it may close its plant in Hanford, Calif., on April 1.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday about a court ruling that lets the Board of Education continue, for a year, a special program to send teachers into parochial schools misidentified a lawyer in the case. It was Stanley Geller, the lawyer for the Committee for Public Education and Religious Liberty, who successfully brought suit against the board to halt the program.

title: ROYALS GO TWO UP AND CLINCH A TIE
description: The message board kept flashing the scores from Texas, and each time the ovation from the crowd at Royals Stadium built slowly into a joyful roar. The California Angels folded quietly under a Texas sky tonight, and the Kansas City Royals moved one game closer to their sixth division title in the last 10 years.

title: OPEN AIR MARKETS reports earnings for 12 wks to Aug 25
Key Rates
description: n.a. Not available.* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Dresser Plans Income Charge
description: Dresser Industries, the Dallas-based manufacturer of products for the energy and natural resources industries, said yesterday that it would take a $270 million fourth-quarter charge to reflect a write-down and the disposal of certain assets. The action will result in a loss for the fiscal year 1985, the first loss in Dresser's 106-year history, the company said.

title: Edgcomb Steel
description: Edgcomb Steel of New England Inc. said a group of investors led by the company's chairman and chief executive, Michael J. Scharf, had proposed a leveraged buyout at $25 a share, which would make the company's value about $150 million.

title: L.I.U. Reaches a Settlement With Striking Faculty Union
description: A tentative settlement was reached last night between Long Island University and a union representing 240 striking faculty members at the university's Brooklyn campus, according to an L.I.U. spokesman.

title: Gulf Canada
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. said it will continue to operate its Montreal East Refinery, which was scheduled to close Oct. 21, for another two months beyond the scheduled shutdown date. The company said the extension allows more time for any potential buyer of the refinery to come forward. Gulf Canada is currently trying to find a buyer for the refinery and its marketing operations in Quebec and the Atlantic Provinces.

title: Records Ordered Sealed
description: A personal injury lawsuit filed by Susan Hernandez, the estranged wife of the Mets' first baseman Keith Hernandez, has been ordered sealed and kept under special guard by a St. Louis County Circuit Court Judge, Robert L. Campbell, according to a report in today's St. Louis Post-Dispatch. At the request of Walter M. Clark, Mrs. Hernandez's attorney, the documents were sealed, according to the newspaper, immediately after they were filed last Wednesday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OUT ON STATEN The first building designed as a performance space on the developing Snug Harbor Cultural Center opens tonight at 8 o'clock. The Cultural Center is a 80-acre tract which, before 1976, when the center moved in, was a home for retired merchant seamen. Its 26 buildings share one address, 914 Richmond Terrace, at Tysen Street on Staten Island's north shore, two miles west of the ferry terminal.

title: Florida Lawmaker Assigned To Flight on Space Shuttle
description: Representative Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat, has been assigned to the crew of the space shuttle Columbia, which is scheduled to begin a five-day flight Dec. 20.

title: CRIME PANEL FINDS ASIAN GANG THREAT
description: A Presidential commission said today that Asian organized crime groups threatened to become ''fixtures in America's mainstream economy in much the same fashion as the Mafia has become.''

title: I.M.F. LOAN TO MEXICO IS EXPECTED
description: Mexico, which suffered devastating earthquakes two weeks ago that took more than 3,500 lives, is expected to receive $300 million from the International Monetary Fund under a 25-year-old program of disaster relief.

title: INTERPOL, AKA 'STRAIT-LACED GUYS'
description: The international supersleuths are in town, nosing about the capital and gathering in secret meetings to discuss their trade.

title: A CHEROKEE IS CHOSEN
description: The highest-ranking Indian affairs job in the Government is to go to Ross O. Swimmer, now principal chief of the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma. President Reagan is to ask the Senate to approve Mr. Swimmer as an Assistant Secretary of the Interior and head of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

title: SCHACHER, GREENTREE & CO reports earnings for Year to May 31
SIGMUND WAHRSAGER
description: Sigmund Wahrsager, a former partner of Bear, Stearns & Company, the Wall Street brokerage firm, died of cancer Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ACTORS EQUITY OPPOSES MARRIOTT BENEFIT
description: Leaders of Actors Equity have asked the Actors Fund of America to cancel a benefit cocktail party Oct. 7 at the Marriott Marquis Hotel because two Broadway theaters were demolished in 1982 to make room for the hotel.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, TRUTH AND CYNICISM
description: In any other country, a renowned South African novelist was saying the other day, people would have resigned.

title: DR. GROSS, AT TRIAL, AGAIN REVISES VIEW ON CAUSE OF STEWART'S DEATH
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, testified yesterday that he has changed his opinion again on the cause of Michael Stewart's death and that he no longer supports his final autopsy report.

title: PHONING ABOUT BIRTH CONTROL
description: PLANNED PARENTHOOD of New York City is advising users of the 1985-86 Manhattan Consumer Yellow Pages that a listing for the ''Pregnancy Hot Line'' beneath the one for Planned Parenthood has no connection with that organization.

title: THE CHOCOLATE CHIP COOKIE THAT MONEY CAN'T BUY
description: Anyone under the age of 10 might find it difficult to believe, but chocolate chip cookies were not always available on every street corner. It was usually necessary to bake them. At home. Washington was an exception. From 1946 until a few years ago, when the Y.W.C.A. moved from K Street Northwest, it sold freshly baked chocolate chip cookies every day. The lines used to snake down the corridor and out the door as cookie lovers lined up for the Y's large, warm, soft, chewy version. But the Y, now on G Street Northwest, is no longer so centrally located and it has no baking ovens. The cookie making has been farmed out to someone who guards the recipe as closely as the Y once did. The cookies are still available at the Y and at Neiman-Marcus, but a lot of the ritual's charm has been lost.

title: STATE OPENS AN ALZHEIMER'S CENTER
description: A DIAGNOSTIC and resource center for Alzheimer's disease opened at Rutgers Medical School here last week, the first step in a statewide effort to coordinate and improve services for about 200,000 New Jerseyans who suffer from the fatal, degenerative brain disorder.

title: DR. MARIA LOPEZ WEDS IN DANBURY
description: Dr. Maria Victoria Lopez, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Francisco Lopez of Danbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to Dr. Michael Henry Bresnahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Bresnahan of Peabody, Mass. The Rev. Eugene Tully performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church.

title: BEDFELLOWS;   Pardon His French
description: A French journalist, with more pluck than finesse, put this question to Mikhail Gorbachev on television last week: ''Is it true that there are four million political prisoners in the Soviet Union?'' The nettled Soviet leader, unused to such challenges, fired back: ''It is absurd! It calls to mind, you know, Goebbels's propaganda. I am amazed, that you, Mr. Marousi, an educated and up-to-date man, could ask such a question.

title: Toddlers on The Fast Track
description: Parents can make their children smarter by getting smarter about their children - and the earlier the better. That finding was announced last week in Missouri, where a study of four school districts has offered some of the strongest evidence to date of the value of programs that teach parents how to rear children.

title: LAWMAKER POSED AS DERELICT IN AN ILLINOIS INQUIRY
description: On the streets of a Chicago uptown neighborhood, he was known as Donald Crenshaw, a grizzled, unemployed worker who haunted storefront clinics and pharmacies in search of powerful narcotic cough syrups.

title: PUBLICATION CLEARED FOR MENCKEN DIARIES
description: The State Attorney General today cleared the way for publication of H. L. Mencken's diaries, ruling that a 1954 memorandum by the writer does not block their release.

title: IN A CABINET UNDER NEW MANAGEMENT, AGGRESSIVE ADVOCACY IS A HIGH PRIORITY
description: By all accounts, it was both a clash of personalities and a desire on the part of some influential Presidential lieutenants - Donald T. Regan chief among them - to see a more aggressive enforcement of Administration policies that led to Margaret M. Heckler's being asked to give up her Cabinet post last week.

title: In the Woods: 97 Homes, 54 Acres
description: A 54-acre forested area less than four miles from downtown White Plains is the site for a $40 million residential community that will have 97 attached and free-standing homes.

title: A RICH AND TRAGIC LEGACY
description: The elderly man who stopped me on the street in the old Jewish quarter early one evening in 1968, before the cold blast of the Soviet-led invasion blighted the Prague Spring, hesitated before he put his question. Finally, in German, he blurted, ''Are you a Jew?'' Then, pleased at my answer, he led me off into the Altneuschul, the Old-New Synagogue, where I would complete the necessary round of 10 men to give validity to prayer.

title: HIGHLAND OF THE CONQUISTADORS
description: I first went to Spain more than 30 years ago. It was then a forbidding and, if you had a strong liberal conscience, a forbidden land. Many of those who loved it had sworn they would never return while Franco remained in power; they had a long wait before the accession of King Juan Carlos in 1975 restored his country to the European community and to democracy.

title: ARAFAT SAYS U.S. WAS PARTNER IN ISRAELI RAID
description: Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, accused President Reagan today of complicity in what he said was a plot to assassinate him, and he warned that United States policy in the Middle East, with ''its arrogance of power,'' would lead not to peace but to ''more oppression, more terrorism and more assassinations.''

title: Appraising 'At Freddie's'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: CIBA-GEIGY and other New Jersey pharmaceutical companies should be angrier at us, says Steven Adubato Jr., a Democratic Assemblyman from Montclair.

title: 50 YEARS OF LAWN BOWLING IN THE COUNTY
description: DEVOTED ''hustlers of stone'' were scheduled to gather last night at the Coveleigh Country Club in Rye to celebrate the 50th anniversary in this county of one of the world's oldest sports.

title: FINE IN WAREHAM FOR ANIMAL LOVER
description: DOROTHY Checchi-O'Brien, 4 feet 11 inches tall and weighing 110 pounds, has been a familiar figure around the statehouse in Boston for a decade as a lobbyist for animal rights and around Plymouth for caring for stray and injured animals in her home.

title: KATHARINE HOBLITZELLE WED IN MISSOURI
description: Katharine Laughlin Hoblitzelle, director of communications for Affiliate Artists Inc. in New York, and William English Walling 3d, a management consultant in New York, were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Ladue, Mo. The Rev. Richard Schmidt performed the ceremony.

title: ROADSIDE CROSSES A REIMINDER OF FATAL WRECKS
description: When Mark O'Keefe drives over the bridge that spans the St. Mary River near Glacier National Park, he is reminded of a friend who was killed there when a bus plunged down the embankment in 1977. The spot is marked by a solitary white metal cross.

title: POPE ADDRESSES UKRAINIANS
description: Pope John Paul II said today that he was saddened by what he called the persecution of Ukrainian Catholics in the Soviet Union and shared their grief as a Slav. Addressing leaders of the Ukrainian Catholic Church in exile, who have held a two-week synod in the Vatican, the Pope said the Holy See had repeatedly called on the Kremlin to let Catholics practice their faith in the Soviet republic.

title: NO HURRY II
description: Among the more unhurried operations in the Federal contraption is the work of the Oliver Wendell Holmes Devise. This devise began 50 years ago with the death of the Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and son of the poet.

title: HOW HUMANS GOT FLIPPERS AND BEAKS
description: GALAPAGOS By Kurt Vonnegut. 295 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/ Delacorte Press. $16.95. YES, American culture is more smart than wise. But Kurt Vonnegut, that clown-poet of homesickness and Armageddon, might be the rare American writer who is both. He dances the witty and informed dances of the literary smart, but while he does, he casts a wide eye about, and he sees. He is a postmodern Mark Twain: grumpy and sentimental, antic and religious. He is that paradoxical guy who goes to church both to pray fervently and to blow loud, snappy gum bubbles at the choir.

title: A Ticket With Cachet
description: Correspondents from The New York Times report on their local subways, from the chandeliers of Moscow to the Aztec temple of Mexico.

title: New Mexico's Sangre de Cristos
description: Artists and writers recall high points -- from ski school in Japan to a sacred crater in Hawaii, from the Montana Rockies to a novice climb in the French Alps.

title: TEEN-AGE REBELLIION LIMNED IN NOVEL
description: FOR many youngsters, growing up suburban is just fine.

title: Connecticut: History Gives Developers a Boost In Meeting Local Resistance
description: TRADITIONALLY resistant to multifamily housing of any kind, Connecticut towns have long struggled against those who seek to impose 20th century urban concepts on Colonial streets. But the New England passion for preserving buildings has proven to be a convenient hook on which to hang several hundred more condominiums throughout the state.

title: ROYAL TREASURES GLOW AT THE MET
description: The Metropolitan Museum never hesitates to think big, as we all know.

title: LOCAL NEEDS VS. LOCAL WANTS
description: AS legendary as our magnificent beaches and shorelines is our overcrowded transportation system. Long Island has the highest level of deficiency or shortfall in carrying capacity on its highways and roads of any area in the state of New York.

title: FLIGHT TO CITY SHOWS SIGNS OF BOOMERANG
description: THEY fled the world of manicured lawns, country clubs and station wagons vowing never to return. But some recent college graduates, expressing disillusionment with urban living, are returning to their suburban nests for more than financial reasons.

title: VERMONT DISPUTE GROWS OVER EFFLUENT FOR SKI SNOWMAKING
description: A proposal to use treated effluent to make snow for skiing here has stirred a dispute pitting environmentalists against resort owners.

title: NO SYMPATHY FOR HERNANDEZ
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHY MUST GARBAGE COLLECTING BE SUCH A NOISY BUSINESS?
description: EVERY Wednesday morning at about 6 A.M. I hear it. It begins faintly from a distance of a few blocks away: a strange but familiar symphonic pattern of sounds.

title: Perspectives: Land Divestitures;   Disposing of City-Owned Property
description: ONCE, long ago, there was to be a Verrazano Street in Greenwich Village. City maps show it curving gracefully through existing parcels of developed land from Seventh Avenue across Downing Street to the foot of Bedford Street at the Avenue of the Americas, snipping off a backyard here and a piece of a building there.

title: HOME-STYLE MAYHEM
description: FAMILY LINEN By Lee Smith. 272 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JEALOUSY. By Nancy Friday. (Morrow, $19.95.) How I envy Theseus. In his contest with the Minotaur and escape from the labyrinth he needed only a broadsword and single thread.

title: Storm Kills 2 In South Korea
description: A typhoon killed at least two people today, bringing the death toll to four, as it battered southern South Korea before heading north over the Sea of Japan. A police spokesman said the latest to die were a child swept away by a flood on the southern island of Cheju and a man hit by a falling roof at a factory in the port of Pusan.

title: IT NEVER WAS EASY
description: IN THE COMPANY OF EDUCATED WOMEN A History of Women and Higher Education in America. By Barbara Miller Solomon. Illustrated. 298 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25. WOMEN IN COLLEGE Shaping New Feminine Identities. By Mirra Komarovsky. 355 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: TOPICS
description: AT noon, two simultaneous sounds strike my ear.

title: UNDER NEW MANAGEMENT
description: Candy Lightner, who founded Mothers Against Drunk Driving after a drunken motorist killed her daughter in 1980, was stripped of two posts in the organization last week and lost much of her authority. MADD's executive committee removed Mrs. Lightner as chairman and chief executive officer, leaving her with the titles of president and chief spokesman.

title: ROAD MEETING: A 'BOND' FOR NEIGHBORS
description: TEN minutes into the State Department of Transportation's presentation on expanding the Long Island Expressway service roads, Harris Davis decided he had had enough.

title: AT HARVARD LAW, STUDENTS ARE GIVEN AN INFORMAL BRIEFING ON THE REALITIES
description: Shakespeare's facetious cure for society's ills - ''The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers,'' Dick the Butcher declares in Henry VI, Part 2 - is often quoted but rarelyanalyzed. Tonight, a group of Harvard Law professors gathered to discuss whether Dick was right.

title: THE NEVER-ENDING TOMATO PLANT
description: EVEN when we lived on many acres in the outer reaches of exurbia, my husband and I could never properly be called gardeners. To be sure, we installed two or three tomato plants each spring, fostered various other vegetables from time to time, but never went in for the professional routines such as compost heaps, fertilizing or, for that matter, the reaping of large harvests.

title: A NEIGHBOR'S VOICE
description: The Canadians, our best and closest friends, have a quiet way of coming up the back porch with sensible and practical suggestions in times of trouble, and they did it the other day when President Reagan needed a helping hand.

title: IN BOSTON, A RENOIR EXHIBITION THAT SPANS THE MANY STAGES OF HIS CAREER
description: A LIFETIME of paintings by Pierre Auguste Renoir - a founder of Impressionism, chronicler of Paris at leisure and painter of robust nudes -will go on exhibit Wednesday at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, where they will be shown through Jan. 5.

title: THE 'GOETZ CAR'
description: FEW cars in New York City's graffiti-streaked subway fleet achieve notoriety. One that did was IRT Car 7657, ''the Goetz car'' - the one in which Bernhard H. Goetz shot four teen-agers after one of them, he said, demanded money from him on Dec. 22, 1984.

title: CATALOGUE TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;

PICTURE IN NEW HOPE IS BRIGHTER
description: NEW HOPE, Pa., has the reputation of having wonderful restaurants. Although they are frequently both interesting and fun, I have often found the food to be disappointing.

title: UNSUNG HEROES OF THE STAGE
description: ONE might think that The Theater League of Westchester - having produced tributes to stage musicals, movie musicals, composers, hit songs (decade by decade) and even orchestrators - would be running out of themes.

title: STEEL TOWNS DISCHARGE POLICE AND REDUCE SERVICES SHARPLY
description: Deeply in debt and with less than $1,000 in its bank accounts, this steel city laid off its entire 14-member police force and 10-member fire department in early September.

title: THE STAGE: 'GREEN FIELDS'
description: IN 1923, Peretz Hirshbein, the great Yiddish writer, wrote ''Green Fields,'' about a little-remembered segment of Jewish existence in Eastern Europe: farm life. It has clicked sweetly in its revivals, in Yiddish and in English, ever since then, and it is continuing to do so even more delightfully, it seems, in the new English-language production by the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y. The simple, bucolic atmosphere has been carried over the language barrier serenely in this version, translated by Joseph Landis and directed by Stanley Brechner. Of course, as those who loved it in Yiddish will realize, you can't extract all the flavor of the mother tongue (even opera buffs who see their favorites in translation know that), but to those who know only English or do not remember the Yiddish, ''Green Fields'' as done here is a happy theater piece.

title: A CITY OF ILLUSIONS
description: We flew to Prague, looking for Rabbi Loew. The Jews of the city had always been known for their brilliance and wisdom. Jehuda Loew ben Bezalel, or Rabbi Loew, a cabalist, scientist and alchemist of the Renaissance, died in 1609. So famous were his experiments that he was credited with the creation of the Golem, the clay giant of folklore who rises to defend the ghetto from its persecutors, then turns on its creators because it is not soon reduced back to clay.

title: Summing Up a Poet
description: To the Editor:

title: HERMANN PREY IS SINGING A LOT OF SHUBERT
description: Hermann Prey is clearly a singer who thrives on big-scale, long-range challenges. Three years into a Viennese Schubertiad that has nine years to go before completing a chronological survey of more than 1,000 Schubert compositions, a quarter of the way through a video-disk project that will encompass 24 hours of performances (documenting ''everything I've sung,'' as he puts it), and ready to begin a series of six Schubert recitals at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday, the German baritone seemed not only at ease but eager as he discussed all these projects and more one day early last week. He had arrived in the United States less than 24 hours earlier but had already had his first rehearsals with the New York Philharmonic of orchestrated Schubert songs they were to perform together Thursday night, Friday night and last night.

title: The Episcopalians
description: In ''The Episcopalians: A Church in Search of Itself'' (Sept. 1), Paul Wilkes begins by saying that ''It is indeed a strange fellowship of believers that can, if not boast of, at least tolerate'' the diverse liturgical activities of the six parishes he lists. But that is where he is exactly wrong -we should boast of this inclusiveness.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: STAYING AFLOAT. By Muriel Spanier. (Random House, $17.95.) In her often eloquent first novel, Muriel Spanier convincingly portrays a woman's grief.

title: THE DEBTORS MAKE THEIR POINT
description: Three years ago, Mexico set off an earthquake that shocked the financial world - the debt crisis. Now a natural earthquake reminds the world the crisis isn't over. The good news is that Washington is now willing to consider new remedies for debtor countries, and to turn its emphasis from austerity to growth.

title: NANCY MCCONAUGHY WED
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Albany yesterday Nancy McConaughy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Francis McConaughy of Loudonville and Silver Bay, N.Y., was married to Shawn Damien McLoughlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Anthony McLoughlin of Babylon, L.I. The Rev. Robert Lamar performed the ceremony. The bride is sales services manager for Perry Ellis America in New York, where Mr. McLoughlin is a government securities broker for the R .M. J. Securities Corporation.

title: A CASE FOR THE RIGHTS OF LATE SLEEPERS
description: A GASOLINE-powered lawn mower growls into action, and the stillness of a summer morning is suddenly lost. Then a chain saw revs up in a tiny patch of woods down the street. The flag is now down: early rising gardeners and their restless mowers take off all over the neighborhod. I am in bed trying to sleep, but the machines raise twisted dreams. The irritating whine of a weed whacker hovers at ear like a mosquito. Too tired to get up, too annoyed to sleep, I lay in bed cursing and writhing. It is 8:15 on a Saturday morning and my neighborhood resounds with the din of mechanized gardening.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an item in last Sunday's Westchester Journal gave incorrectly the name of the director of a bus-safety program conducted by the Putnam/Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services. He is Noel Kaiser.

title:
TREKS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: MAGIC MOUNTAINS;

A Landscape to Soothe the Heart
description: Artists and writers recall high points -- from ski school in Japan to a sacred crater in Hawaii, from the Montana Rockies to a novice climb in the French Alps.

title: DANCE
description: There may be lots of choreographic huggings on stage this week. Some of them are those of the tempestuous Argentine tango dancers appearing in Tango Argentino.

title: DEMOCRATIC CHIEFS LAUD BUDGET MOVE
description: Democratic leaders in the Senate and the House of Representatives today endorsed the goal of balancing the Federal budget by 1991 but insisted that they needed more time to consider and write a specific proposal.

title: LESLIE FEDER HAS WEDDING
description: Leslie Margaret Feder, an associate fellow at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, and Garrick Hillman Leonard, a third-year student at the Harvard Medical School, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. Rabbi David Posner perfomed the ceremony.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Miller High Life 500, at Charlotte, N.C. (Television -MSG, 12:30 P.M.) Cart Laguna Seca 300, at Laguna Seca, Calif. (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M. live). Formula I Grand Prix of Europe, at Brands Hatch, England (Television - ESPN, 9 A.M. live). Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto. This will be Phil Niekro's final chance this year to win his 300th career game. (Television - Channel 11, and SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks, at The Citadel, Charleston, S.C. 2 P.M. Exhibition game. Football Jets vs. Bengals, at Cincinnati. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 4 P.M.) Giants vs. Dallas Cowboys, at Giants Stadium, 9 P.M. The Giants have not lost to Dallas at home since 1979. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 9 P.M.) Falcons vs. San Francisco 49ers, at Atlanta. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Hockey Devils vs. Rangers, at New Haven, 8 P.M. Exhibition game. Islanders vs. Bruins, at Boston, 7:05 P.M. This is the final exhibition game for the Islanders. Other Events BIATHLON: Big Apple Series, Queens Biathlon starts at 8 A.M. with a three-mile run in Alley Pond Park at the intersection of the Grand Central and Cross Island Parkways, followed by an 18-mile bicycle race on the northbound lanes of the Cross Island Parkway and another three-mile run over the same course in Alley Pond Park.

title: FOR SOWETEO'S HORATIO ALGERS, SUCCESS CAN TURN OUT TO BE A DEAD END
description: Nestled amid the bleak dwellings and thick smog that serve as vivid characteristics of this black township are pockets of finely furnished homes, some with swimming pools in the back and expensive automobiles in the driveways.

title: The Episcopalians
description: The six parishes cited by Mr. Wilkes in his opening paragraphs reflect the fragmentation and the ''trendier than thou'' atmosphere of the denomination in which I grew up. There was a sizable group of bishops, clergy and laity who wanted the Episcopal Church to abandon its traditional spiritual role and become a kind of political movement led by men - and women - in the pulpit.

title: THE PLAY MOZART DIDN'T WRITE
description: When Circle in the Square opens its 35th season Thursday with Andrei Serban's production of Pierre-Augustin Caron de Beaumarchais's ''Marriage of Figaro,'' an acknowledged classic of world drama will receive one of its rare outings on the New York stage. For ''Figaro,'' a tapestry of farce and polemic that alternately satirizes and condemns the privileged state of 18th-century France's ancien regime, has not been seen here in a major production since it was peformed at the City Center in 1964 by Jean-Louis Barrault, Madeleine Renaud and the Theatre de France.

title: DEBATE IN NEWTOWN RECALLS FORMER ERA
description: IT may not have been the Lincoln-Douglas debate, but a 19th-century atmosphere prevailed at the ice-cream social held by the League of Women Voters in Newtown last Sunday. Top hats, frilly blouses and long skirts were in evidence among those awaiting the speakers on the lawn of Main Street's most prominent Victorian mansion, which is owned by John and Kathy Haverkamp, antique dealers in New Milford and Kent.

title: DOROTHY WILSON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Dorothy E. Wilson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jordan Wilson of Alpine, N.J., was married last evening to Peter Brandell Galant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Galant of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Burt Siegel officiated at the Edgewood Country Club in River Vale, N.J.

title: DICK CAVETT RETURNS TO THE WARS
description: The more things change, the more ''The Dick Cavett Show'' stays the same. Its length may vary, its scheduling may shift, its network may decide to pull the plug, but its quick-tongued talk-show format persists.

title: TRYING FOR A COMEBACK AS A UNION HERO
description: IT was almost a year ago that Ray Rogers, the union organizer, first came to this town, 100 miles south of Minneapolis, and a meatpacking center for nearly a century. Angered by a 23 percent wage cut, local members of the United Food and Commercial Workers believed they might strike George A. Hormel & Company in August, when their contract would expire. They called the 41-year-old Mr. Rogers to organize the battle.

title: OPERA TO ZARZUELA, WEEKEND OF VARIETY
description: A GUITAR recital, chamber and symphonic concerts, grand opera, a Broadway musical and even a fully staged zarzuela are among next weekend's attractions.

title: WHEN A CATASTROPHE STRIKES
description: HERE am I, a computer columnist on the leading edge of today's information technology, furiously scribbling away at my desk with a ballpoint pen on narrow-lined yellow paper - by candlelight. Admittedly, the ballpoint and the yellow narrow-lined paper are part and parcel of my normal writing habit. Only the final editing of copy do I undertake on a personal computer packed with word processing software. However, the candlelight is not typical of my usual routine. Then again, neither are hurricanes.

title: Ski School In Japan's Shigas
description: Artists and writers recall high points -- from ski school in Japan to a sacred crater in Hawaii, from the Montana Rockies to a novice climb in the French Alps.

title: WHITE SOX HIRE DARK
description: Alvin Dark, a former major league manager who guided the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland A's to pennants, was named director of minor leagues and player development of the Chicago White Sox.

title: ITALY'S COMMUNISTS HAVE LOST THEIR GRIP ON CITY HALLS
description: On walls all over this city of canals, the Communist Party has slapped up angry manifestos next to the posters for a de Chirico show and a grappa convention. The posters denounce the new city government as ''weak and inadequate'' and promise that the Communists, as the largest party in town, will fight to restore good government to Venice.

title: A BUSY DAY FOR THE 'WATER RATS'
description: A WORKER with a garden hose was rinsing soap from a Buick when County Police Officer Ronald W. Harbolic walked into a car wash on Nepperhan Avenue here last week.

title: TO THE CLASS OF '36: LETS GO TO COLLEGE
description: TO THE high school graduates of 1936 - to those Great Depression children who dreamed the impossible dream of going away to college, but whose families couldn't afford it: Your time has come.

title: MCKINNEY, SOLDATOVA TAKE ARCHERY TITLES
description: Richard McKinney of the United States retained the men's title today and Irina Soldatova of the Soviet Union took the women's individual crown at the 33d world archery championships.

title: ANNE NELMS HUKILL AN EDITOR, WEDS W. DEWEES YEAGER 3D, BOND BROKER
description: The Winchester Center (Conn.) Congregational Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Nelms Hukill, an associate editor at Doubleday & Company, and W. Dewees Yeager 3d, a corporate bond broker with Mabon, Nugent & Company, both in New York.

title:
AROUND THE NATION;

Atlanta: A 37-Story Tower Is Fulfilling The Promise of Peachtree Road
description: AFTER almost two decades of predictions that Atlanta's version of Park Avenue was destined to develop along Peachtree Road in the Buckhead area, the promise is gaining tangibility as construction progresses there on Park Place, a 37-story condominium tower that will be the city's tallest residential structure.

title: More Rioting In England
description: With economic hardship dragging on and the population becoming less and less homogeneous, Britain's reputation as a well-mannered society respectful of its polite, largely unarmed bobbies has faded into what seems like legend. Last week, the image paled further as English cities were again rocked by rioting in which black and white youths confronted tough-minded, gun-toting police officers.

title: ABDUS SATTAR, EX-LEADER OF BANGLADESH, DIES
description: Abdus Sattar, the only elected civilian president in Bangladesh's 13-year history, died yesterday in the Suhrawardy Hospital in Dhaka. He was 79 years old and was admitted to the hospital last month with heart and kidney problems.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Housing Finally Starts Housing starts have been a disappointment this year. With mortgage interest rates down, housing activity should be up. Instead, housing starts soared to an encouraging 1.9 million unit annual rate in April and never hit that level again. But Rosanne Cahn, of Goldman Sachs Economics, says that housing may still wind up the year on the strong side of the ledger. She expects starts of single and multifamily housing units to total 1.85 million for 1985, solidly ahead of last year's 1.75 million units. The September number, due out next week, will show the housing sector's growing strength, said Mrs. Cahn. She expects a 6 percent jump in starts over the August level, the second strong monthly rise in a row. Michael Carey, of Citicorp Investment Bank, is also optimistic about this key sector. ''We expect housing starts to continue to rise through the fourth quarter,'' he said, as lower mortgage rates and gains in real personal income encourage home building and buying.

title: PHOEBE M. RENTSCHLER WED TO CHARLES D. COLE JR.
description: Phoebe Mason Rentschler and Charles Dodd Cole Jr. were married yesterday at the Old Whaling Church in Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. William Eddy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SOME VERY RECENT OILS For anyone who has never bought a painting ''hot off the easel,'' and even for those who have, the Garrison Art Center has an interesting Saturday afternoon in store Oct. 12. Prospective purchasers may take one hour, from 5 to 6 P.M., to sip cocktails and study 50 newly executed paintings before they are auctioned promptly at 6 P.M.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

THE OTHER VICTIMS
description: THERE are six in the room, and one unwanted guest.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cliffside Park $314,000 *2* 300 Windsor Drive *2* 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 11-year-old high-rise condominium; *2* terrace, wall-to-wall carpeting, *2* $276 monthly charges; taxes $3,486. Landing $98,000 *2* 41 Salmon Road *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old bilevel; *2* new furnace, garage workshop; *2* taxes $2,139. Millburn $160,000 *2* 416 Wyoming Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old brickfront colonial; *2* center hall, basement rec room; *2* taxes $3,090. Newfoundland $140,000 *2* 16 Meadowview Court *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; *2* pool, hot tub, central air-conditioning; *2* taxes $2,400. Oak Ridge $107,000 *2* 371 Oak Ridge Road *2* 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old split-level; *2* 3-zone heat, fenced yard, *2* fireplace in family room; taxes $2,205. Rockaway $121,900 *2* 199 West Lakeshore Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; *2* brick patio, lake view, wood stove, *2* family room; taxes $2,309. OTHER AREAS White Plains, N.Y. $173,500 *2* 41 Prospect Street *2* 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 85-year-old Victorian; *2* library, basement, 1-car garage; *2* taxes $1,690. Wallingford, Conn. $103,000 *2* 32 Stillwood Road *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; *2* close to town and schools; *2* taxes $1,656. Plainview, L.I. $154,000 *2* 6 Harold Court *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2* basement, 1-car garage; *2* taxes $2,900.

title: AIR FORCE BEATS NOTRE DAME
description: Unbeaten Air Force beat Notre Dame today for the fourth straight time and the biggest play of the game was painfully familiar to Coach Gerry Faust and the Irish, sending them to their third defeat in four games.

title: MAN JOINS WOMAN'S PARTY
description: It took 72 years, but the Woman's Party founded by the suffragist Alice Paul has accepted a male member. ''I am a true believer in equal rights for women,'' said the newcomer, Gerald R. Gereau, who paid his dues this week. Mr. Gereau is chief investigator for the Senate Rules Committee and president of the Senate Staff Club. A revision in the bylaws last weekend opened the membership to men.

title: DR. SARAH MCGRATH IS ENGAGED TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Terence J. McGrath of Chappaqua, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Dr. Sarah Marie McGrath to Dr. William Tobin McGee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. McGee of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: RENAISSANCE SCHOOL in Tuckerton, Ocean County, keeps young people in class by sending them out to work under a program financed by the state's Department of Education and through the county's Private Industry Council (local businesses that dispense Federal Job Training and Partnership Act funds to projects).

title: RULING DELAYS REMEDIAL CLASSES
description: Officials of big-city schools in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have not been able to start remedial classes as scheduled this year for thousands of low-income parochial-school students. Education officials say it could be weeks before the children get the help they need in reading and mathematics.

title: SUZANNE FINLEY ROBINSON IS MARRIED
description: Suzanne Finley Robinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot F. Robinson of Old Bennington, Vt., and Osprey, Fla., and Andrew David Buchsbaum, a son of Dr. Robert B. Buchsbaum of Boulder, Colo., and the late Harriet Heller Buchsbaum, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Charles Fox performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Vermont home of the bride's parents.

title: BEDFELLOWS;   The Klan Connection
description: As if it weren't already clear, more evidence has now surfaced as to the nature of Louis Farrakhan. The black nationalist leader of the Nation of Islam, it turns out, has accepted support from the former head of the California Ku Klux Klan, who now runs something called the White People's Political Association.

title: A Gift to Carnegie Hall
description: There is a gap in the Carnegie Hall story that I feel anyone interested in the hall's history would want filled (''The Glory of Carnegie Hall,'' by Samuel G. Freedman, May 19).

title: THE GRIDLOCK BRIGADE
description: ALSO on duty this week will be 241 newly appointed traffic-enforcement agents, those men and women in brown uniforms who try to keep the grids from locking on the city streets.

title: Good Design
description: To the Editor:

title: Staten I. Man Is Slain Investigating Robbery
description: A 26-year-old Staten Island man was fatally shot when he apparently stumbled into robbers in his twin brother's apartment building, the police said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK HOSPITALS STEPPING UP REPORTS ON PERILS TO PATIENTS
description: Hospitals have been directed to expand sharply their reports to the State Health Department on incidents threatening or potentially threatening patients, according to the Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod.

title: WILL TIMES SQUARE BECOME A GRAND CANYON
description: When the plans were first announced back in 1973 for what is now the Marriott Marquis Hotel, it was spoken of as the crucial link in the city's program to rehabilitate Times Square. So, too, are such claims being made today for the massive four-tower complex that has been proposed for the south end of Times Square at 42d Street. And similar words were offered years ago by private developers in justification of such projects as the immense 1515 Broadway office tower, which replaced the glorious Astor Hotel, or the 1500 Broadway office tower, which replaced the almost-as-fine Claridge Hotel, or the 1633 Broadway office tower, a black box that may be the worst tower in midtown Manhattan.

title: RURAL JACKSON GETTING HOUSING SPILLOVER
description: COVERING a total of 100 square miles, Jackson Township is one of the largest municipalities in New Jersey.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE BEATS RUTGERS
description: The memory of their remarkable season-opening tie against Florida may have vanished for Rutgers today as it lost, 20-10, to Boston College at Giants Stadium.

title: MICHIGAN TROUNCES WISCONSIN BY 33-6
description: Jim Harbaugh passed for three touchdowns and the Michigan defense forced seven turnovers today as the Wolverines routed Wisconsin, 33-6, in the Big Ten opener for both teams.

title: TOM WAITS: POP'S MINSTREL OF THE DOWNTRODEN
description: For the last 12 years, Tom Waits, the gravelly-voiced, 35-year-old singer-songwriter from Pomona, Calif., has played American pop's self-appointed spokesman for a segment of society that hardly knows he exists. The would-be poet laureate of urban lowlife, Mr. Waits has peopled his albums with desperate derelict characters who carry their lives in rickety suitcases, live in fleabag hotels or on the street, and dream in blurry Technicolor.

title:
GARDENING;

LOOKING TO THE EAST FOR FALL COLOR
description: WITH the exception of food plants such as corn and squash, the early European settlers in the Northeast tended to ignore the native plants in favor of those from their homelands. This is understandable, for they were familiar with their characteristics and uses. It is also understandable that they looked upon the native plants more as enemies to be conquered than friends, since they had to clear them away, acre after acre, to make land available for cultivation.

title: RENATA CIOTH MARRIED TO RANDOLPH MULDER
description: Renata Barbara Cioth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Boguslaw Cioth of Rolling Hills Estates, Calif., was married yesterday to Randolph Daniel Mulder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daantje Mulder of Indio, Calif. The Rev. William D. Larkin performed the ceremony with the Rev. Paul J. Ilecki at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: MALARIA ADVANCE
description: THE last big hurdle to development of the world's first vaccine against malaria was reported cleared last year.

title: HALFTIME REPORT FROM THE FESTIVAL
description: At this juncture, which is the midpoint of the 23d New York Film Festival, it's time to take stock, to pick up loose ends, to put things in perspective, to throw one's hat into the air or, if the situation calls for it, to step on some toes. The following was made possible through the cooperation of an inquiring reporter from an unidentified land and the magic of a tape recorder.

title: GORBACHEV OPENS IN PARIS TO MIXED REVIEWS
description: WITH a blitz of diplomacy last week, Mikhail S. Gorbachev attempted to set the agenda for an arms control dialogue with the United States and its NATO allies. The Soviet leader met a response that was wary but intrigued, as Americans and Western Europeans sifted between the imposing Gorbachev style - risk-taking, energetic, even flamboyant - and the rather familiar content of his offer.

title: BALTIMOREANS MOUNTING DRIVE TO FIGHT VIOLENCE
description: In the past six months a 16-year-old high school basketball star was shot on the street for no apparent reason, a 20-year-old mother of two was killed on her back porch by a stray bullet from a nearby shootout, and an 83-year-old school bus driver was shot by two teen-agers who were trying to rob him in a downtown parking lot.

title: Karpov Takes a Timeout
description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, called for a timeout today in his title series against Gary Kasparov, postponing the 13th game until Tuesday, the news agency Tass reported. Each player is entitled to one timeout every 8 games in the 24-game series, which is tied at 6 points apiece.

title: STUDY SAYS POLICE ERRED IN BLAMING BUS DRIVER
description: An enginerring report says a bus driver was wrongly accused of reckless homicide in a fatal August crash because the police misidentfied the tire tracks.

title: PARK AVE. ABUZZ OVER PLAN TO REFURBISH TRAIN TUNNELS
description: THE refurbishing of the century-old Park Avenue train tunnels may not be under way yet, but talk in the community about the project has certainly begun.

title: KAREN SCHUSTER WEDS R. R. BARCE
description: The marriage of Karen April Schuster to Robert R. Brace, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Brace of Westwood, Mass., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Schuster, in Dayton, Ohio. Rabbi Robert Barr and the Rev. William Privette, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: VALERIE COUFOS MARRIES
description: Valerie Coufos, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis P. Coufos of Queens, was married yesterday to Burton Richard Bachrach, the son of Jean Bachrach of Miami Beach, and the late Louis Bachrach. Justice Yorka C. Linakis of New York State Supreme Court officiated at the Park Lane Hotel in New York. Mrs. Bachrach is an assistant vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: MAKING SIZE 22 POSH AND PROFITABLE
description: IT is midday at the Forgotten Woman shop on New York's Upper East Side.

title: NEW STRAIN OF CITRUS CANKER FOUND IN FLORIDA LIME TREES
description: A new strain of citrus canker has been found among lime trees grown by the owner of a Gainesville restaurant, and officials say it could prompt tougher import restrictions on all citrus products, including a lime leaf popular as a seasoning in Asian cuisine.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two fashion picture captions in The Times Magazine today, with the preview of the Milan collections, are reversed. The dress on page 84 is by Luciano Soprani, the one on page 86 by Franco Moschino.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE WORLD OF BEDS
description: KING LOUIS XIV addressed the public and hosted receptions from his bed.

title: UPDATE ON CRIME
description: CRIME reported on the subways has been decreasing, according to figures from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: LEHIGH OVERCOME BY COLGATE, 32-14
description: Kenney Gamble rushed for two touchdowns and 93 yards today while Mike Powers kicked three field goals to give Colgate a 32-14 victory over Lehigh.

title: Watch Out For Old Ladies
description: Correspondents from The New York Times report on their local subways, from the chandeliers of Moscow to the Aztec temple of Mexico.

title: DEBORAH HARTIOGAN IS WED TO R.L. WYSOCKI IN JERSEY
description: Deborah J. Hartigan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Hartigan Jr. of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., and Richard L. Wysocki, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley S. Wysocki of Farmington, Conn., were married yesterday.

title: GOING SOLO
description: To the Editor: Traveling alone is certainly more expensive than traveling as a couple (Practical Traveler, Sept. 15), but it need not be as exorbitant as it is at present. Hotels and tour operators as well as cruise lines have not yet awakened to the fact that ''single households'' are on the increase, that people living alone are hardly ever prepared to share cabins or rooms while on vacation, don't necessarily need a room large enough for two but do expect the same comfort, conveniences and amenities that couples expect.

title: HARVARD IS DEFEATED
description: Stan Yagiello combined with Harry Meahre for a 44-yard touchdown pass with just over two minutes left today as William & Mary beat Harvard, 21-14, in the rain.

title: HOTEL ROOMS
description: To the Editor: One aspect of travel I have not seen written about is the response of travelers to accommodations that are heralded as luxury -but that really are not luxurious.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE TO JOIN NEW YORK LAW FIRM
description: Judge Frederick B. Lacey of Federal District Court here has announced that he will leave the bench to join a New York City law firm.

title: OIL SUPPLIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Misarranged Coronets
description: To the Editor:

title: PLEASURES AND PALACES
description: I like to think of the Loire Valley as France's well-bred region. Everything here - the architecture, the food, the scenery, even the character of the people - has a well-mannered, self-assured quality. The Loire has little in common with the rusticity and remoteness of the Pyrenees in the southwest, the folkloric playfulness of Alsace, the heady aromas and fierce sunshine of Provence. It's a region that makes you feel secure, even a bit pampered.

title: AN '82 SLAYING STIRS POLITICS IN BRAZIL
description: Almost two years before his body was found on a beach near here in late 1982, a magazine publisher noted in his personal papers that ''my physical extinction has been decided by the National Information Service,'' Brazil's main intelligence agency.

title: BEGINNER'S LUCK?
description: Sally Beauman's first novel, entitled ''Destiny,'' is still in progress, but her financial fate appears assured. Bantam Books agreed last week to pay more than $1 million for the novel, which is thought to be the highest advance ever offered for a first novel by a relatively unknown writer.

title: LET'S GET PERFECT
description: Excerpts from remarks by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, in Senate debate over an immigration bill, Sept. 18:

title: O'NEILL'S 'ICEMAN' RETAINS ITS RIVETING POWER
description: Jose Quintero's 1956 production of ''The Iceman Cometh'' was an act of dramatic reclamation. In its Broadway premiere 10 years earlier, the play had apparently been victimized by a flawed performance and by postwar euphoria. The bleakness of Eugene O'Neill's message - that illusions, pipe dreams, were essential to man's survival - met with resistance. Ten years later, there was enough disillusion in the air to give the play a biting relevance, and Jason Robards's personification of Hickey, the truth-teller, was itself a performance of magnitude. As jaunty as his salesman's straw hat, Mr. Robards was a hollow messiah hellbent on removing the blinders from the eyes of his disciples.

title: EVICTION DISPUTE SPLITS COMMUNITY OF MEDIUMS
description: For 106 years, the Lily Dale Assembly here has been a gathering place for psychic mediums who believe they can help people communicate with the dead.

title: RAISE HIGH THE ROOF BEAM
description: HOUSE By Tracy Kidder. Illustrated. 341 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: U. of Illinois Gets a Gift For $50 Million Institute
description: The University of Illinois said today that it had received a huge gift of money and would build a $50 million research institute where scientists from many fields would focus on the processes of the human brain and how the processes might apply to computers.

title: O'BRIEN SYMBOLIZES RESILIENCY OF JETS
description: There is a sense of optimism among the Jets that the team has turned an important emotional corner.

title: LILCO EXPECTS 98% TO HAVE POWER BY TONIGHT
description: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company predicted yesterday that power would be restored to 98 percent of Lilco's customers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties by midnight tonight.

title: FOR FRESHMEN, SURVIVAL 101
description: BEING a freshman is no easy task. This occurred to me as I sat on the curb of College Street in New Haven, wondering how I was going to get my stereo, my trunk of clothes and my box of Rolling Stone magazines dating back to 1977 up to my fourth-floor suite. With all that is written telling you how to get into college, there is nothing telling you what to do once you get there.

title: Polish Echoes -- And Ironies
description: Michael Kaufman's article was both fascinating and touching. However, he doesn't mention the language in which his father and Ozjasz Szechter sang the song ''A Letter to Mother,'' by the Russian poet Sergei Yesenin. Unless they sang it in Russian, it was probably in Yiddish: ''A Brievele der Mamen.'' ARTHUR J. MORGAN New York City

title: NEWARK TO REDEVELOP 1,000 ACRES DOWNTOWN
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson has outlined a plan to redevelop a 1,000-acre site in the central part of the city, including some areas devastated during the riots and looting of 1967.

title: GUY A. LONGOBARDO WEDS LISA YOKANA
description: Diane Elisabeth Yokana, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Yokana of Princeton, N.J., and Greensboro, Vt., and Guy Alfred Longobardo, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Guy S. Longobardo of Bronxville, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. James A. Carpenter, professor of theology at the General Theological Seminary in New York, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: TOP SPOT IN POLL DRAWS REWARDS
description: WHEN the University of Iowa rose to No. 1 in The Associated Press and the United Press International college football rankings last week, it was reason for elation across the state. ''We're No. 1'' is the familiar cry, as well as the goal for many of the nation's teams.

title: LACEY LEAVING BENCH
description: JUDGE Frederick B. Lacey, who rose to prominence as the United States Attorney for New Jersey and who directed the prosecution of corrupt political figures in Newark and Hudson County, announced last week that he intended to resign from the Federal District Court early next year to resume private practice.

title: NEW FLORIDA LAW OUTLAWS DRIVING ON BEACH
description: Driving on the beach has been a pastime at this tourist town since 1903, when the automobile pioneer Alexander Winton raced a vehicle over the wide-open, hard-packed sand at the then-unbelievable speed of 69 miles an hour.

title: HE'S A TRIPLE-THREAT WRITER
description: ''OUR apartment in Manhattan and our house in East Hampton are filled with pig memorabilia,'' said Roger Swaybill. ''We have stuffed pigs, wooden pigs, ceramic pigs, pig salt-and-pepper shakers, an inflatable pig, pigs on wheels.''

title: 101 VIEWS OF THIS 'FAR FORM PERFECT' WAR
description: Ten days of general debate have brought 101 kings, presidents, prime ministers, foreign ministers and other officials to the podium of the General Assembly to offer their views of the world. About half a million words have been uttered, exclaimed and shouted.

title: TOLLS TO END WEDNESDAY ON CONNECITCUT TURNPIKE
description: Toll collections on the Connecticut Turnpike will cease Wednesday at 11 P.M., Gov. William A. O'Neill announced yesterday.

title: FROM POLICING THE STREETS TO ADVISING THE STARS
description: There are those who understand the New York City Police Department to be a crime-fighting organization, but people in the entertainment industry know better. In truth, the department is an idea factory.

title: FACILITIES ARE LISTED
description: Based on a survey of hospitals in New Jersey, the state's Department of Health has identified four additional centers that offer comprehensive diagnostic services for Alzheimer's disease and related disorders. They are:

title: A Second Chance For Tax Evaders
description: All is forgiven - for a while, at least - Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch told tax evaders last week. The officials announced that, beginning Nov. 1, they would offer a 90-day amnesty for people and companies that have failed to pay city or state taxes.

description: PRECISELY a quarter of a century ago, Vincent Thomas Lombardi -of Brooklyn and Fordham University, of St. Cecilia High School in Englewood, N.J., and the United States Military Academy at West Point - won his first professional title, the 1960 championship of the Western Conference of the National Football League.

title: Constitutional Scholarship
description: To the Editor:

title: RETURNOF STREET IN PHILADELPHIA
description: A 36-year-old-Philadelphia man went into Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas last Monday and was given an odd order by the judge: Replace 6,700 square feet of a street in South Philadelphia or face jail.

title: REPORT ON HOMELESS UNVEILED
description: TERMING homelessness in Westchester ''a disaster,'' the Homeless Crisis Action Group, a blue-ribbon panel named last April by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, issued a report last week, criticizing the municipalities for failing to address the issue and stressing the need for them to assume more responsibility if solutions are to be found. It says that, ''The county has a right to expect each unit of government in Westchester, in concert with not-for-profit organizations, to develop options that provide housing for families and individuals in various homeless situations.''

title: Some Competition For the Bicycle
description: Correspondents from The New York Times report on their local subways, from the chandeliers of Moscow to the Aztec temple of Mexico.

title: Counting Up Some of the Toxic Accidents
description: Before the disaster at Bhopal, India, last year, the United States had never systematically collected information on accidents involving toxic chemicals. However, a still-incomplete study commissioned by the Environmental Protection Agency was reported last week to show that since early 1980 American companies large and small have experienced an average of five accidents a day in which toxic chemicals were released.

title:
ANTIQUES;

TOWNWIDE FAIR IN SALISBURY
description: THERE are towns where, now and again, the residents prove that they understand the true meaning of community. Salisbury, tucked away in the northwest corner of Connecticut, where the Taconic Mountains rise west of the Housatonic, is one of those.

title: SPY SUSPECT SEEN AS A HARD WORKER
description: There were some odd things about Edward L. Howard, a 34-year-old financial forecaster for the State of New Mexico, but to the people he worked with he was the quintessential bureaucrat, a bit laconic, perhaps, but smart, wise in government affairs and hard-working.

title: BUILDER OF BRIDGES BETWEEN THE LIVING AND THE DEAD
description: When Alfred Jarry, the turn-of-the-century literary genius and enfant terrible, wrote the first version of his outrageous political cartoon, ''Ubu Rex,'' he entitled it ''Les Polonais'' (''The Poles'') because he felt that a country partitioned out of existence provided an appropriate symbolic setting for an image of unbridled tyranny. As he explained in a speech on ''Ubu's'' opening night, ''The action takes place in Poland, that is to say: Nowhere.''

title:
GARDENING;

LOOKING TO THE EAST FOR FALL COLOR
description: WITH the exception of food plants such as corn and squash, the early European settlers in the Northeast tended to ignore the native plants in favor of those from their homelands. This is understandable, for they were familiar with their characteristics and uses. It is also understandable that they looked upon the native plants more as enemies to be conquered than friends, since they had to clear them away, acre after acre, to make land available for cultivation.

title: BRITISH-IRISH TALKS ON ULSTER REACH A CRITICAL STAGE
description: Negotiations between the British and Irish Governments to try to find a political solution to the problems of Northern Ireland have reached a critical stage, according to British Government sources.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Dave Tipton, the Arizona Outlaw defensive tackle who led the United States Football League in quarterback sacks last season, has been traded to the Denver Gold in exchange for Steve Hathaway, a linebacker. . . . Tim Kerr, the Philadelphia Flyer who was hospitalized with a brain infection last week, has been released from the hospital and told he can resume skating in about a week and should be ready to rejoin the team two weeks after that. . . . Jimmy Connors and Ivan Lendl, who were rained off the court after reaching the final of the Executone Hamlet Cup Aug. 25, will play their final Thursday night, according to the tournament organizers, who said the match would be preceded by one between Molly Van Nostrand and Terry Phelps. They are the first women to play in the tournament, which is usually a tune-up for the United States Open.

title: A HARPSICHORDIST WHO DARES TO BUCK THE TIDE
description: DAVID STEVENS

title: PROTECTOR OF THE AMERICAN FLEET
description: CAPT. RAYMOND WALSH IS AT THE command post of the U.S.S. Ticonderoga, at sea off the Atlantic coast. In another era, he would have been up on the cruiser's bridge with a clear view out over the ocean; in this age of electronic warfare, he sits in a dark, low-ceilinged room without portholes, facing a set of battle display screens. All through the room, crew members hunch over other screens and consoles. There is a slight pitch as the Ticonderoga, one of the world's most formidable naval vessels, cuts through the water at 11 knots.

title: S.M.U. STUNNED
description: Alfred Jenkins, the Arizona quarterback, threw three touchdown passes tonight as the Wildcats shocked unbeaten Southern Methodist, 28-6.

title: NATIONWIDE CRUSADE TO END WORLD HUNGER
description: The United States Postal Service has shown the design for a Help End Hunger stamp which is scheduled for release Oct. 15 in Washington, D.C. The 22-cent commemorative depicts the debilitated faces of two young boys and an elderly woman. Designer Jerry Pinkney's previous credits include the annual Black Heritage stamps.

title: INSURANCE CRISIS: LET GOVERNMENT INSURE ITSELF
description: LAST year, taxpayers in the upstate village of Brownville spent $8,200 for liability insurance. This year, they are paying $245,300 for the same coverage.

title: JILL E. KESTER MARRIES BARNABUS HUGH KELLEY
description: Jill Earlene Kester and Barnabus Hugh Kelley were married yesterday at the Wilton (Conn.) Congregational Church by the Rev. Carl Becker. Mrs. Kelley is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl M. Kester of Dundee, Ill., and Sarasota, Fla. Mr. Kelley is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Kelley of West Redding, Conn.

title: ARMY CRUSHES YALE BY 59-16 TO GO 4-0
description: Army routed Yale today, 59-16, and became the first Cadet team since 1958 to win its first four games. Never has a Yale team allowed so many points.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1985
description: International

title: SCIENCE AND FLIP OF COIN VIE IN CALLING WEATHER
description: Thanks to new mathematical models and increasingly powerful computers, scientists seem to be having a little more luck than they did a generation ago in predicting weather trends a month or more in advance. But meteorologists acknowledge that their 30-day forecasts are still only slightly more accurate than flipping a coin.

title: PASSAIC SWAMPS TEANECK
description: Sterling Henton threw two touchdown passes and the Passaic defense held Teaneck to minus 26 yards in a 36-0 victory yesterday at Teaneck.

title: SALVADORAN SAID TO DEAL FOR DAUGHTER'S LIFE
description: El Salvador has apparently informed leftist rebels that it is willing to free 23 prisoners in exchange for the abducted daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, her companion and 20 mayors.

title: William Shakespeare's Not-Ready-for-Prime-Time Sonnet
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAGGING ON BROCCOLI
description: IF I WERE TO PROPOSE the vegetable with the most interesting name, it would probably turn out to be broccoli. When I was a child, I was told that the name derived from that of an Italian gardener who developed it. Later, I was informed that the name is actually an acronym, a word made by blending the first few letters of the vegetable's scientific name: Brassica oleracea italica.

title: A 'Mud Soldier' Retires
description: In 1939, John W. Vessey Jr., then a 17-year-old boy from Crow Wing County, Minn., lied about his age so he could enlist in the National Guard. In 1982, after a long march through Army ranks, he was appointed Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: MAKING ALL THE RIGHT MOVES BEFORE THE VAN PULLS UP
description: PEOPLE planning a move within the city face a panoply of choices on how to haul their goods across town, ranging from do-it-yourself methods to the use of cut-rate moving companies to full-service haulers who may charge as much as $80 an hour even on a trip of a few blocks.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AN EVENING PERFORMANCE. By George Garrett. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Though best known for his historical novels - ''Death of the Fox'' and ''The Succession'' - George Garrett has also produced a large body of short fiction encompassing the American experience of the last 30 years. The stories collected here describe the conflicts of adolescence, romantic and domestic turmoil, life in small Southern towns, academic life and wartime experiences, and they range in manner from the naturalistic to the near-farcical. Never less than workmanlike, solidly traditional in form, Mr. Garrett's stories frequently sound the theme of human cruelty. ''Human beings are the foulest things in all creation,'' says a character in ''Wounded Soldier,'' while the boy-narrator of ''The Last of the Spanish Blood'' is made to confront his own potential for evil and violence. ''What's the Purpose of the Bayonet?,'' a powerful story of wartime, ends by indicting ''the whole inhuman race.'' This abiding misanthropy does, however, allow for the saving grace of humor. ''Bread From Stones,'' an amusing tale of a feckless gigolo, also forms a tiny critique of the American dream. Perhaps the best story in the volume, ''Texarkana Was a Crazy Town,'' tells of a likable former soldier who finds ''real life'' much more fearsome and wondrous than anything he had encountered in the military. With few exceptions, the stories seem defiantly ''unfashionable'' in style. In our age of pared-down realism, Mr. Garrett's flaws as a writer - a fondness for elaborate similes, an occasional straining after poetic effects and a general prolixity -are particularly noticeable.

title: FACES IN THE CROWD
description: In the beginning comes the audition. When Westco Productions, a professional theater company based in White Plains, announced a casting call for this season's productions, dozens of hopeful actors of all ages arrived at the Galleria with pictures, resumes and well-rehearsed solos.

title: DANCE: EDOUARD LOCK'S PUNK STYLE
description: ''HUMAN SEX'' is a lot of fun.

title: OLD BLACK CEMETARY IS BEING RESTORED
description: Unlike many cemeteries, the one known around here as Sand Hill is not a peaceful place. Tractor-trailers rumble along nearby Route 46, sending vibrations through the soil.

title: Los Angeles: Giving Up Some Square Feet In Return for Architectural Flair
description: THEIR relatives repeatedly cautioned Richard and Lorienne Shaw against buying a condominium for their first home. Yet, after an 18-month search that ranged across 400 square miles of metropolitan Los Angeles and Orange County, they settled on a $93,950 condominium in Le Parc, a 246-unit development in Simi Valley, 45 miles northwest of Los Angeles.

title: High and Low Ends Firm In Vacation Condo Sales
description: JUST south of the resort hotels, amusement rides and crowded beaches that typify the bustling New Jersey seaside resorts of Wildwood and Wildwood Crest, a 128-acre parcel of formerly undeveloped land - including a 320-foot windswept beachfront - is being developed into a planned recreational community called Diamond Beach.

title: ALMAGRO
description: To the Editor: After an eight-hour, sun-baked, winding drive from the Costa del Sol toward Madrid, my husband and I pulled our dusty car and our dustier bodies into the breezy front stone courtyard of the Parador Nacional de Almagro (Travel, Sept. 1).

title: COALITION ASSERTS CITY IS UNPREPARED FOR SURGE IN HOMELESS THIS WINTER
description: The number of homeless single men and women in New York City next winter will approach the peak levels of the Great Depression, but the city is less prepared than ever to shelter them, the Coalition for the Homeless charged yesterday.

title: TAX PROPOSALS CAST A SHADOW OF UNCERTAINTY
description: ECONOMISTS and Congressmen are still guessing about the impact President Reagan's tax-reform proposals would have on the market for condominiums and cooperatives, but the complex measure has already clouded the marketplace.

NATURE WATCH;

SKIPJACK TUNA
description: Euthynnus pelamis Size: To 45 pounds; averages 4 to 8 pounds.

description: To the Editor:

title: SARAH ROSSBACH, A WRITER, IS MARRIED TO DOUGLAS M. FLEMING, AN EXECUTIVE
description: Sarah Rossbach, a daughter of Mrs. J. Howard Rossbach of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Saranac Lake, N.Y., and the late Judge Rossbach of New York City Criminal Court, was married yesterday at Edgehill Church in Riverdale to Douglas Morrison Fleming, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Elliot Fleming of Chatham, N.J. The Very Rev. James P. Morton, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, performed the ceremony.

title: Verbatim;   Explaining Stockman
