description: 'For a good while now, both political parties have been faking on the No. 1 problem of governance in this country, and that is paying our bills as a national household. We just can't live with these massive deficits without traumatic economic dislocations.' David A. Stockman former director, Office of Management and Budget rr'I've explained David Stockman for four and half years, and I'm not obligated to explain him now.' Larry Speakes White House spokesman

title: WIFE OF EX-SENATOR WAS 79
description: Elizabeth Williams Fulbright, wife of former Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas, died today at her home here. She was 79 years old. Mrs. Fulbright had been ill for some time, according to her daughter, Roberta Fulbright Foote.

title: New Jersey: A Canalled City in the Harbor To Evoke the Era of the Dutch
description: AT the lip of New York Bay, where ocean water laps against reed grass and tankers pass in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty, a Frenchman, a German, a Swiss architect and an all-American hero intend to give back to the Hudson what was taken from the river years ago.

title: CHILD SUPPORTERS
description: THOSE who fail to pay child support in the state should beware. Courts statewide, including those in Westchester, are interviewing candidates interested in becoming hearing examiners in the state's Family Court system. Applicants must be lawyers willing to give up their law practice to serve full-time in a quasi-judicial capacity to hear and decide all cases relating to support and uncontested paternity.

title: THE CARDS' SAVE COMMITTEE
description: AS soon as Bruce Sutter accepted Ted Turner's millions and defected to the Atlanta Braves last winter, the St. Louis Cardinals were suspect as contenders. Without their bullpen savior with the split-fingered fastball, the Cardinals were dismissed as also-rans in the National League East behind the Mets and the Cubs, but they didn't dismiss themselves, especially the bullpen pitchers Bruce Sutter had left behind. And now the pitchers in the Cardinal bullpen are known among themselves as the Save committee.

title: SPACE SCIENTIST ADMITTED ROLE IN NAZI CAMP
description: A former space scientist accused of war crimes has told the Justice Department he was aware that slave laborers he had forced to build Nazi rockets in World War II were dying of poor treatment, transcripts of an interrogation show.

title: Grapevine
description: To the Editor:

title: 'AND WHAT ARE THE NEIGHBORS LIKE?'
description: THE decision to move was a difficult one. For two years we drove through different neighborhoods with real-estate brokers and researched our alternatives. Even after we finally signed the contract for our new house, my husband and I continued to agonize over our decision.

title: Hospital Consortium Focuses on Costs
description: The subject of health-care costs has captured the attention of the American public. Television news programs, newspaper headlines and magazine cover stories have relayed the message that health-care costs are rising, and are doing so at a rapid rate. The Federal Government has publicized its concerns over health-care cost increases and has announced its plans to reduce its spending for health-care services.

title: MODERNS IN RED SNEAKERS
description: ''Contemporary composers ride the same subways and react to the same headlines that the rest of us do,'' Allan Miller, who is, with Isaiah Sheffer, one of the two artistic directors of Symphony Space, said recently. ''I'm interested in what they have to say -whether they can tell me something new about the world we live in.''

title: CHAMBERMUSIC: LOCKENHAUS FESTIVAL
description: LOCKENHAUS is a small town in eastern Austria where, for the past five summers, Gidon Kremer and a number of musicians have been playing chamber music for small audiences and for one another. Mr. Kremer, who may be the most complete musician now playing the violin, is obviously troubled by the pressures and burdens of high-powered musical careers - like the one he now pursues for himself. With the Lockenhaus Chamber Music Festival, he seems to be making earnest protestations for a less commercial, more collegial and relaxed tone in the world of music.

title: IT'S MORRISTOWN CRAFTMARKET TIME
description: THE Morristown CraftMarket, which has an established reputation as a quality event scaled for retail shoppers, will take place at the National Guard Armory here next weekend.

title: PARIS
description: The heart of Paris continues to drift eastward. Visitors are finding that the city's center of gravity is slipping, slowly but visibly, away from the Champs-Elysees, the Place de la Concorde and the broad, straight avenues that Haussman, the 19th-century city planner, carved out of the city's western half. The new destination for visitors: the narrow, twisting 17th-century streets in the eastern section with potbellied houses that evaded the earlier planners.

title: More in the Meadowlands: Office-Hotel Complex
description: Once regarded as an unproductive wasteland, New Jersey's 32-square-mile Meadowlands district across the Hudson River from Manhattan in recent years has attracted more than $1 billion worth of industrial, commercial and residential development.

title: MORE UNITS BEING RENTED AS OVERSUPPLY GROWS
description: THE rise of the condominium as a key form of primary housing in metropolitan centers across the country is producing a growing inventory of apartments for renters, according to real-estate professionals in many regions.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IN his 13th year, Michael not only has become a man in our religion, he has moved away from home. Well, at least down to the basement.

title: SHOPPING SERVICE FOR ELDERLY
description: THE elderly residents at the Home for the Aged Blind in Yonkers line up outside the auditorium even before the doors are opened.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

HIRING THE HANDICAPPED
description: Like many other liberal-arts graduates, Richard Manley recalled his search for employment as being an ''extremely frustrating experience.''

title: Don't Handicap Imports: Handicap the Buyer of U.S. Assets
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHECK-WRITING NATION IGNORES THE DEBIT CARD
description: TWENTY years ago, it seemed just a matter of time before a consumer of anything, from groceries to TV sets, would brandish a plastic ''debit'' card, and in seconds money would be zinging from the buyer's account to the merchant's.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEGAL DAISY SPACING: The Build-a-Planet Manual of Official World Improvements. By Christopher Winn. (Random House, $7.95.) With each passing year, roads become wider and straighter.

title: STENGEL'S GREAT LESSON: LOSE, BUT CHARM 'EM
description: LOSING with style, grace and class, or with creativity, is as difficult and admirable an art as winning without those elements, and surely it is more endearing.

title: IN THE IMAGINATION'S TRUE COUNTRY
description: THE ENVOY FROM MIRROR CITY An Autobiography: Volume Three. By Janet Frame. 176 pp. New York: George Braziller. $14.95.

title: DRUG TEST NOT WIDESPREAD
description: A week after baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth proclaimed that a mandatory testing program had brought about a ''dramatic decrease'' in drug use by minor-league players and nonplaying baseball personnel, his office has disclosed that less than 20 percent of the minor-league players and other personnel were actually tested in the program.

title: COUNTY'S FALL FILM FESTIVALS BEGIN
description: THERE are sad ones and glad ones, there are tough ones and there are soft ones, there are unusual as well as esoteric ones, criminals as well as monsters, beauties and beasts - all sorts of them. They make up Westchester's fall film festivals, some of which continue into the winter and the spring.

title: YOUTHS SEND ABUSE MESSAGE
description: THE room was filled with colorful balloons, streamers, plates of chocolate-chip cookies, a large blue-and-white cake and 17 children, laughing and playing. They had come to celebrate their work in combating a growing problem: child abuse.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MEMORIES OF RUSSIA Peter the Great, Catherine the Great, and some personal memories of the Russian Revolution by a Greenwich resident are the subjects of three lectures on Russian history at the Greenwich Library, 101 West Putnam Avenue.

title: SEARCH IS ENDED FOR MEXICAN BOY
description: Rescuers working in the earthquake rubble of a small apartment building here abandoned today their attempt to rescue a 9-year-old boy believed trapped in the bedroom where he was sleeping when the earthquake struck 17 days ago.

title: AFRICA'S MEN IN KHAKI ARE OFTEN A LAW UNTO THEMSELVES
description: At a crowded concert in the Mozambican capital one recent night, a girl in a canary yellow dress offered to help some latecomers find their seats. Before she could move very far through the throng, a police dog, its leash still in a soldier's hand, sunk its teeth deep into her right leg.

title: SURREALISM IN 'CITY OF PIRATES
description: THE Chilean-born fabulist Raul Ruiz makes surrealist films that are entirely self-contained; for ''intriguingly enigmatic,'' as the New York Film Festival literature describes Mr. Ruiz's ''City of Pirates,'' you might just as well read impenetrable. However, this film, like Mr. Ruiz's ''Three Crowns of the Sailor'' (which was shown at last year's festival), has the strong imagery and confident, if solipsistic, visual style that make Mr. Ruiz's work notable.

title: NO HURRY I
description: The Brookings Institution is a generally serious and deliberate place, but there seems to be some room there for unbridled optimism, too. Starting there today and requiring a total of only six days is a conference titled ''Understanding Federal Government Operations.''

title: CANDY SHOP TO GIVE SAMPLES
description: IN what sounds like the answer to every sweet tooth, Munson's Candy Kitchen on Route 6 in Bolton will turn thousands of people loose in its store today to partake of free samples and a tour of the candy plant.

title: A New Life
description: To the Editor:

title: LOTTERY AID TO JERSEY A RECORD
description: The New Jersey Lottery produced a record $390.5 million for aid to education and state institutions in the last fiscal year and set sales and prize records, according to state lottery officials.

title: THE GREENING OF KUALA LUMPUR
description: From the air, the city seems almost lost in white mists.

title: Summerfare: Its Future Is Called in Doubt
description: Your recent interviews with the organizers of the 1985 Summerfare Festival [''Summerfare to Retain Hunt,'' Sept. 8] raise serious questions that should be addressed by Westchester County residents.

title: VIDEOTAPED CONFESSIONS GROW
description: JOSEPH ROSS sat with his feet up on a chair, calmly talking with two other men in the room. Seemingly relaxed, he answered numerous questions from the men. As he talked, his pre-recorded image appeared on a television screen.

title: EARTH MOTHER KNOWS BEST
description: DWELLERS IN THE LAND The Bioregional Vision. By Kirkpatrick Sale. 217 pp. San Francisco: Sierra Club Books. $14.95.

title: PRO-SYRIANS POINT TO ARAFART ALLIES IN SOVIET KILLING
description: A delegation from a Syrian-based Palestinian guerrilla group has reportedly told the Soviet Union that Moslem extremists who kidnapped four Soviet Embassy men here and killed one of them are allies of Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Fallen Idol Starring Ralph Richardson, Bobby Henrey, Michele Morgan; directed by Carol Reed, 1949 Prism Entertainment 96 minutes, $19.95 Anyone who thinks Alfred Hitchcock held a monopoly on urbane suspense - and anyone who savors the fruits of collaboration among first-rate talents - will profit by making the acquaintance of this splendid thriller.

title: STALKING MARYLAND
description: Since Senator Charles McC.

title: COMPANY RECALLS NUT MIXES TO RELABEL FOR SULFITE CONTENT
description: An Illinois candy company is recalling fruit and nut mixes distributed nationwide because the products contain sulfite preservatives but do not carry a required warning label, the Food and Drug Administration said Friday.

title: KATHRYN C. BAXER MARRIES R.E. EDEN IN CONNECTICUT
description: The marriage of Kathryn Caroline Baxer, a flight attendant with the international division of American Airlines, to Robert E. Eden, a student at the Boston University School of Medicine, took place yesterday at the Stonehenge Inn in Ridgefield, Conn. Justice of the Peace David D. Huntoon performed the ceremony.

title: In Montana, Unisex Insurance
description: In 1917, feminists pointed with pride to Montana, which sent Jeanette Rankin to the House of Representatives. Last week, women's rights groups were pointing to Montana again as a law went into effect that prohibits discrimination by sex or marital status in insurance premiums or policy benefits.

title: Mormon Leader Warns Members on Criticism
description: A Mormon official warned church members today not to criticize the faith's leaders or its doctrines, and said there would always be attacks by outside critics.

title: TEXT OF U.N. RESOLUTION ON ISRAELI AIR STRIKE
description: Following is the text of a resolution on the Israeli raid on the Palestine Liberation Organization's headquarters in Tunisia, adopted Friday night by the Security Council by a vote of 14 to 0, with the United States abstaining:

title: Closing in on The Rockies
description: Artists and writers recall high points -- from ski school in Japan to a sacred crater in Hawaii, from the Montana Rockies to a novice climb in the French Alps.

title: TOPICS
description: I'M glad to report that many ageless traditions still flourish among our children despite the sophistication they exhibit these days. For example, it is a well-known fact that the Tooth Fairy still lives, undaunted by the computer era.

title: NEW REVIEW STARTED FOR SMALL PRESSES
description: IN the book business, small publishing houses often suffer second-class status, struggling under the shadow of the large and profitable publishers.

title: NEW MUSIC
description: New York is the nation's musical capital in a variety of ways, and one of them is this city's centricity as a forum for contemporary music. All kinds of new music will be on display this week.

title: Former C.I.A. Agent Goes Out in the Cold
description: Although Edward L. Howard left the Central Intelligence Agency in 1983, he apparently remembered a few tricks of the trade. The weekend before last, he managed to slip away from his small stucco house outside Santa Fe, N.M., eluding agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation assigned to watch him. Last week, the bureau said it had issued a warrant for Mr. Howard's arrest charging him with conspiring to deliver ''national defense informaton'' to a foreign government.

title: THE MUNROS: DREAMS OF GLORY
description: People climb Everest because it's there. But the heights of Scotland are here, and I haven't stirred myself.

title: WATERBEDS FOR JUST PLAIN FOLKS
description: THEY were a 1960's counterculture fad at first. Along with ripped, faded bluejeans, bandannas and long hair, water beds were yet another way to make the statement: We're against convention. ''Really, the water bed is about the only symbol of that era that's lingered,'' said Jerry Long, director of sales and marketing at Wavecrest, a California-based waterbed manufacturer.

title: DEMOCRAT OUTLINES CAMPUS PROGRAM
description: THE new president of the College Young Democrats of America, Mark M. Elliott of White Plains, is eager to take the message of the Democratic Party to young college Americans. ''That message,'' Mr. Elliott said, ''is that we are the party of opportunity, the party of upward social mobility.''

title: The Improbability Of Kilimanjaro
description: Artists and writers recall high points -- from ski school in Japan to a sacred crater in Hawaii, from the Montana Rockies to a novice climb in the French Alps.

title: MINERS PREPARE FOR SECOND WINTER IN BITTER STRIKE
description: As chilly autumn rains fall on the hills of southern West Virginia and eastern Kentucky, members of the United Mine Workers prepare for another winter in their prolonged strike against seven subsidiaries of the A. T. Massey Coal Company.

title: CRIME
description: Surprising, the number of college professors who have written mystery novels. The latest to join the crowd is Peter Levi, with GRAVE WITNESS (St. Martin's, $11.95). Mr. Levi is the Professor of Poetry at Oxford University.

title: CARIN G. GENDELL MARRIED IN OHIO
description: Carin Gaye Gendell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald S. Gendell of Cincinnati, and Steven John Benjamin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Benjamin of Larchmont, N.Y., were married yesterday in Wyoming, Ohio. Rabbi Solomon Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Valley Temple.

title: BOUTIQUES FOR THE DISCERNING SLEEPER
description: FURNITURE and department stores have long been the most popular places to buy beds. But ''sleep shops'' - stores that carry only beds and bedding accessories - are gaining fast. And manufacturers increasingly prefer them as outlets for their beds.

title: Balancing Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Mismanagement Is Charged At Nine-Mile 2 Nuclear Plant
description: The staff of the Public Service Commission says there has been ''extensive mismanagement'' in building the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant on Lake Ontario.

title: LIMIT ON CIRCULARS EYED
description: A CIVIL suit challenging the delivery of a newspaper supplement to a Rockville Centre resident has revived a proposal by village officials to limit the unsolicited delivery of printed circulars and advertising materials.

title: LONG ISLANDERS SEE RED IN THE DARK
description: STORMS, like other natural disasters, often bring communities together, but the legacy of Hurricane Gloria did not include solidarity. Last week, as hundreds of thousands of people in the region waited for the restoration of electricity, many residents - and not a few politicians - took out their frustrations on a convenient target: the utilities.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Serebrier Conducts Kultur 134 minutes, $59.95 Since classical music discovered the video cassette all sorts of film clips and videotapes have been boxed and launched by hopeful merchandisers. In this instance, Jose Serebrier conducts two Australian orchestras in concerts documented by the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I told them next year I expect to drink champagne instead of beer.''

title: 1938 STORM: A VIVID MEMORY
description: THIS time there was nothing left to lose, no need as the storm approached to flee from Fire Island or, if we were not there when it came, to rush out to Fire Island when the storm had passed to see what it had done to the house.

title: VULNERABILITY IS ASSESSED
description: HURRICANE Gloria provided a quick reminder to Long Islanders of how vulnerable they are to the costly, destructive and sometimes deadly whims of nature.

title: MEREDITH BRITZ IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Meredith Ann Britz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Frank Britz Jr. of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., to James Christopher Shelley, a vice president of the Philadelphia National Bank, took place yesterday at the Croton Valley Meeting of Friends in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. William S. Shillady, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Frederick Morris Shelley 3d of Stamford, Conn., and Virginia Shaw Shelley of Solebury, Pa.

title: Learning the Meaning of Fear
description: Artists and writers recall high points -- from ski school in Japan to a sacred crater in Hawaii, from the Montana Rockies to a novice climb in the French Alps.

title: NEW YORKERS HONOR SOUTH AFRICAN VICTIMS
description: Nearly two thousand people, including the Rev. Benjamin J. Hooks, John Cardinal O'Connor, Mayor Koch and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato gathered in Saint Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning for a memorial service commemorating black South Africans who died in the last year during racial violence.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Oct. 6, 1985 Fiction

title: Cats Still Made The Same Way
description: In reply to the article, ''Cats Just Aren't Up to Snuff Any More'' [Opinion Page, Sept. 22] : Yes, Mrs. Derman, they still make cats the way they used to - of flesh and bones. It apparently didn't occur to you or your daughter that the cat's injury might have been caused not by a mouse bite, but rather by being flung against the wall.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: VANLANDINGHAM WINS THE GOLD CUP BY 2 1/2 LENGHTS
description: Vanlandingham capitalized on an easy lead, a perfect ride and a speed-favoring muddy track to score a front-running 2 1/2-length victory over Gate Dancer in the $861,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: CROP DAMAGES FROM GLORIA RUN INTO THE MILLIONS
description: LOSSES continued to mount throughout last week for Connecticut farmers in the wake of Hurricane Gloria, with crop and building damage estimated at more than $6 million by midweek.

title: CONCERT: HAITINK AND THE CONCERTGEBOUW
description: THE second of the two Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam programs at Carnegie Hall, on Thursday evening, was perhaps the best suited of the three to bring out the special qualities that distinguish this great ensemble and its music director, Bernard Haitink.

title: INDECISION IN THE DESERT
description: SAUDI ARABIA The Ceaseless Quest for Security. By Nadav Safran. 524 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $25.

title: STUDENTS PAINTING SUBWAY MURALS
description: Fourteen murals designed by two New York artists and painted by local high school students are being installed in subway stations in upper Manhattan as part of a program that invites community groups to help improve the subways.

title: WATCHES, WARNINGS AND, NOW, SECOND-GUESSING TIME
description: With the guessing about Hurricane Gloria now past, its path completed and its damage done, the second-guessing has begun, with questions about the way the National Weather Service, emergency officials and the electric companies handled the emergency.

title: OLD FRIENDS HIKE TRAILS TOGETHER
description: FOR the Keyarts Klamberers, the lure of the trail never seems to diminish.

title: ANOTHER CONFLICT OVER SEABROOK
description: THE way consultants were selected to help update an emergency evacuation plan for the Seabrook nuclear plant has been raising questions about possible conflict of interest.

title: THE SPLIT AT HARVARD LAW GOES DOWN TO ITS FOUNDATION
description: At Harvard Law School, one speaker contended, it is considered a ''symptom of right-wing extremism'' to favor rigorous standards of scholarly excellence. Its distinguished professors are a ''wasting asset,'' he said, and replacements are hard to find because most scholars are not attracted to ''an institution devoted to guerrilla warfare.''

title: RALSTON'S PERILOUS 'MIDDLE INNINGS'
description: WILLIAM P. STIRITZ, with his soft voice, distant eyes and reflective manner, seems more like a philosophy professor than a reckless gambler. But gamble he did when he became president of the Ralston Purina Company in 1981 and chairman a year later.

title: WAITING FOR THE R-62A
description: TO the cognoscenti they are known as R-62A's. To the riders of the Seventh Avenue IRT local, they are known as the new subway cars that appeared briefly last summer and have never been seen again.

title: THOSE IN THE DRIVER'S SEAT
description: THE LONG NIGHT OF FRANCISCO SANCTIS By Humberto Costantini. Translated by Norman Thomas di Giovanni. 184 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95. OTHER WEAPONS By Luisa Valenzuela. Translated by Deborah Bonner. 135 pp. New York: Ediciones del Norte/ Persea Books. Paper, $8.50.

title: THE EAST VILLAGE
description: PROSPECTIVE buyers of city-owned properties are swarming over the East Village, looking for bargains in hundreds of dilapidated buildings and vacant lots.

title: IN THE REALM OF OSIRIS
description: FOUR HUNDRED MILES SOUTH OF CAIRO and across the Nile from the town of Luxor, the Theban hills lie like a clenched fist in the dust, with narrow ravines between the knuckles. One of these ravines, winding and branching back into the red rock, is the Valley of the Kings. There, in tunnels sometimes hundreds of yards long, the Pharaohs of the 18th, 19th and 20th Dynasties were buried. Like the Pharaohs, the landscape itself is dead, enlivened only by the tourists who lend some movement and color to a barren and mortuary area. Though in this part of Egypt you occasionally meet a young couple doing the country on a shoestring, the majority of the tourists are middle-aged, while a sizable minority are like me, dour totterers, pensioners, blotched and indomitable.

title: Easing Mexico's Money Problems
description: Mexico, still reeling after a series of devastating earthquakes, got some respite from its debt problems last week and an offer of disaster relief. Its largest creditors agreed to a six-month delay on interest payments of $950 million. The move by leading commercial banks coincided with efforts by the Reagan Administration to encourage more help to foster growth in the third world. The International Monetary Fund said it was ready to extend $300 million in credits to help cover the costs of the earthquake emergency.

title: MEDIATION IS TAUGHT AS ALTERNATIVE TO COURTS
description: With court calendars crowded and litigation increasingly costly, a movement is growing in law and business schools to teach the use of negotiation and mediation as alternatives to courts.

title: INVASION OF THE VERBS
description: THE FACT IS I THINK I am a verb,'' wrote the dying Ulysses S. Grant to his doctor, ''instead of a personal pronoun. A verb is anything that signifies to be; to do; or to suffer. I signify all three.''

title: FANS THANK CARTER FOR MEMORIES
description: Last October, three days after the end of his season, Gary Carter underwent arthroscopic surgery to remove cartilage from his right knee. Afterward, Carter remembered yesterday, he was told the knee was healthy enough for him to catch for 10 more seasons.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Briefing column of the Washington Talk page last Sunday misstated the date of the Washington Senators' last home game. It was Sept. 30, 1971.

title: FORCING BULBS IS EASY WITH POTS AND A REFIGERATOR
description: Last winter, my first daffodil bloomed on one of the coldest days in January - Super Bowl Sunday. I remember returning home late in the day, struggling to light the fire in the wood stove, wondering how I'd manage to get through two more months of winter.

title:
GARDENING;

LOOKING TO THE EAST FOR FALL COLOR
description: WITH the exception of food plants such as corn and squash, the early European settlers in the Northeast tended to ignore the native plants in favor of those from their homelands. This is understandable, for they were familiar with their characteristics and uses. It is also understandable that they looked upon the native plants more as enemies to be conquered than friends, since they had to clear them away, acre after acre, to make land available for cultivation.

title: BRENDA DALLAS GRIFFIN IS WED IN CONNECTICUT
description: Brenda Dallas Griffin, an investment officer in the personal trust department at the Bank of New York, and Bernard Henri Jose Lirola, a vice president of the First Boston Corporation in New York, were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Edwin Lincoln performed the ceremony.

title: PLAYERS LEARN TO PREVENT CARREER - THREATENING INJURIES
description: Fieldston's second football game of the season was probably John Schapiro's last. Two weeks ago, the senior linebacker dislocated his left elbow when he tackled a Dwight Englewood ball carrier and caught his arm between two other players' bodies.

title: INDIAN POINT 3 IS RESTARTED
description: The Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant began generating electricity Friday for the first time since spring, the State Power Authority announced today. The plant was taken out of service June 7 for refueling, maintenance and equipment changes.

title: DOWNHILL ON EUROPE'S LONGEST RUN
description: Klosters has changed, of course. it's no longer the unspoiled village, two hours from Zurich and buried in snow, that Irwin Shaw found when he first drove down from Paris one winter in the 1950's. That paradise with its farmers, open fields and absolute jewel of a hotel has almost disappeared. Its perfection doomed it. The crowds arrived. Buildings sprang up. But the skiing is still excellent, some of the best in Switzerland; the small hotel has lost none of its charm; there is at least one exceptional restaurant that deserves a couple of stars and from the highest summit you can still ski a long, beautiful run, the longest in Europe.

title: HUMANITIES ENDOWMENT SPURS CONTROVERSY AGAIN
description: In the Federal Government, where spending is generally reckoned in the billions, the National Endowment for the Humanities is a modest undertaking, with a budget of $140 million a year.

title: Westchester: Old Police Barracks 'Chateau' Becomes 56 Condo Apartments
description: A REPLICA of a French chateau, with a turret, slate roof, huge interior courtyard and portals tall enough to admit a horse and rider, is being converted to condominiums in Hawthorne, at the center of Westchester County.

title: PENN OVERPOWERS COLUMBIA BY 46-14
description: Pennsylvania, crushed by Army last week, got back on track in the Ivy League yesterday, scoring five first-half touchdowns in an easy 46-14 victory over Columbia yesterday before 4,272 fans at Baker Field.

title: GREELEY TOPS GORTON
description: The quarterback Doug Sweeney rolled up 122 yards rushing while scoring two touchdowns, one on a 90-yard run, to lead Horace Greeley to a 26-0 victory over Gorton.

title: EXPOS POST 8-3 VICTORY
description: The great chase finally came to an end for the Mets yesterday afternoon in two cities nearly 900 miles apart, and it came to an end with 45,404 people rising in Shea Stadium and roaring a standing ovation to the team that finished second.

title: Martyrs for Human Dignity Left Nameless
description: To the Editor:

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;

LIVELY, LOVELY LONDON
description: TWENTY YEARS AGO, LONDON was the spot to find the fashionable and new. It was Mary Quant and the mini-look; it was Carnaby Street. Now, in the mid-1980's, London is again a center of fashion inspiration. The chic costume jewelry of Butler & Wilson adorns collections around the world, as do the madcap millinery of Stephen Jones and the elegantly seductive shoes of Manolo Blahnik. The designer names today are Body Map and Betty Jackson, Joseph Ettedgui and Crolla, Wendy Dagworthy and Rifat Ozbek - the forward look of fashion, but, oddly, firmly anchored to the heritage of the 60's.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: My Side of the Mountain Paramount Home Video 100 minutes. $29.95 Reading, and daydreaming about, ''My Side of the Mountain'' has been one of the great treats of childhood since 1959, when Jean George's award-winning tale about a modern-day Thoreau first appeared.

title: DOWN THE DRAIN
description: There is nothing so discouraging for one's overall result in a tournament as to play a good game early and later have the point taken away from you. That happens when an opponent gets sick and cannot finish the competition. Under the rules of the International Chess Federation, if a player must drop out before completing half his schedule, none of his games count.

title: EKING OUT A VICTORY
description: In 35 years only two women, Helen Sobel Smith and Dorothy Hayden Truscott, have represented the United States in Bermuda Bowl world championship competition. Victories by women in open national championships are rare. The pattern is similar in other parts of the world and the World Bridge Federation recognizes the reality by organizing separate women's world championships.

title: Planning the Battle on AIDS
description: While the actor Rock Hudson was mourned last week, public health officials and experts offered an uncertain prognosis for AIDS, the disease that killed him.

title: TWO FOR THE TEA LEAVES
description: When Russo Watts & Associates, a political and governmental affairs concern in Sacramento, opened a Washington office last week, it actually opened two.

title: Man, 77, Killed His Wife Out of Love, Judge Rules
description: A 77-year-old man strangled his wife out of love for her and is innocent of murder because he is insane, a county judge has ruled.

title: THE PARTI QUEBECOIS LOWERS IT S VOICE
description: Even before Pierre Marc Johnson was sworn in as Premier of Quebec last week, many Canadians were expressing a sense of relief that he had replaced Rene Levesque as the leader of the Parti Quebecois.

title: NEW YORK PARK OFFICIALS COPING WITH WATER RULES
description: Flower beds were irrigated with water from Van Cortlandt Park Lake. Golf course fairways browned in the summer sun. Saplings went unwatered and graffiti unwashed. Wading pools remained dry.

title: LYNN M. SARAJIAN BECOMES BRIDE OF RAY PRICE 3d
description: At the United Methodist Church in Stroudsburg, Pa., yesterday Lynn M. Sarajian and Ray Price 3d were married in a Presbyterian ceremony performed by the Rev. Harold Rosenburger. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Robert M. Ahnert of Bushkill, Pa., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Steven M. Sarajian of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Mr. Price is a son of Mrs. Price Jr. of Stroudsburg and the late Mr. Price.

title: Peru's Main Prison Rocked By a Second Day of Violence
description: About 6,000 inmates rioted at Peru's biggest prison today, one day after 30 people died and at least 69 were wounded in a mutiny by jailed guerrillas, the police said.

title: INDIAN UPDATE
description: VENGEANCE India After the Assassination of Indira Gandhi. By Pranay Gupte. 368 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: Life-and-Death Decisions
description: With increasing urgency, our society is forced to confront difficult questions concerning a person's legal and moral right to refuse life-saving medical treatment. Challenged by a constantly evolving conception of life, we must ponder the extent to which our legal system can and should intervene in these very private decisions.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE ANTHROPOLOGY OF EVIL. Edited by David Parkin. (Basil Blackwell, $34.95.) In this idiosyncratic collection of essays, 14 anthropologists consider the nature of evil, reviewing general religious concepts of it and revealing obscure cultural ones.

title: LINKING TWO CRISIS
description: To imply the possibility of some political linkage between the crises in Afghanistan and Nicaragua is not the same as to equate morally the roles that the two superpowers are playing in these crises.

title: TOPICSuf9010>;   BEDFELLOWS;   Unhired Gun
description: Covington & Burling, Washington's largest law firm, has dropped South African Airways as a client. The firm denied that student boycotts of recruitment sessions prompted the decision.

title: HILDEGARD BEHRENS WITH ST. LUKE'S GROUP
description: The German soprano Hildegard Behrens will sing works by Beethoven and Wagner, as guest soloist with the Orchestra of St. Luke's, Sunday, Oct. 15, at Carnegie Hall.

title: BALLOON MILEAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: LIVE ART IN ELMIRA An elegant woman in a bustled dress and sable muff will mingle with the crowd at a grand opening Saturday through Monday of the renovated and expanded Arnot Art Museum in Elmira, N.Y. So will a barefoot woman in a peasant blouse, a bride's mother in dark headdress and a barrel-shaped burgher's wife in an opulent outfit of many layers.

title: GETTING A BETTER DEAL FOR CONRAIL
description: FOUR years ago, Congress decided it had lost enough money on rail service in the Northeast and Middle West. It passed a law telling Conrail, the Government-owned freight railroad, to make money or face a liquidation sale.

title: RUMANIA LEADER PUTS HIS IMPRINT ON CAPITAL
description: More than 10 churches, including some of historical and architectural importance, at least three synagogues and many other buildings have been bulldozed or dynamited in the center of Bucharest to make way for new buildings to house offices of the Communist Party and the Government, a project ordered by President Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: PENGUIN REPERTORY ACCENTS THE BRITISH
description: NOW that Michael Frayn's ''Two of Us'' is over at the Penguin Repertory Company, the theater's fourth and final play of the season - Christopher Hampton's ''Treats,'' which runs through next Sunday - could be aptly called ''The Three of Us'' just for the sake of continuity.

title: ISTANBUL'S MIASMA
description: THE SEA-CROSSED FISHERMAN By Yashar Kemal. Translated by Thilda Kemal. 288 pp. New York: George Braziller. $16.95.

title: NEW HAVEN OFFICIAL SEEKS RADIO BAN
description: A NEW HAVEN alderman is following the lead of Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York City in trying to take the ''boom'' out of ''boom boxes'' in city parks.

title:
AROUND THE REGION;

Long Island: 6 Victorian Waterfront 'Houses' Conceal 28 Clustered Residences
description: CONSTRUCTION starts this month on Timber Ridge at Amityville, a homeowners'-association development on the waterfront with an innovative feature - although there are 28 attached units, the project will look like six large Victorian single-family houses.

title: ELIZABETH BOATWRIGHT WEDS R.J. CROWLEY JR.
description: St. James' Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Brownley Boatwright, the daughter of Col. Charles C. Boatwright, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Boatwright of Alexandria, Va., to Robert James Crowley Jr., a son of Mrs. Crowley of Milton, Mass., and the late Mr. Crowley. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony.

title: REAL ESTATE REPORT: CO-OPS AND CONDOMINIUMS

AROUND THE NATION;

Denver: A Grand Mansion Renovation Opens in a Slumping Market
description: AFTER more than a decade of neglect - and in the face of a slump in the Denver condominium market - the 73-year-old Bonfils mansion has been converted into three grand condominiums while preserving its French Mediterranean architecture and given a matching wing with 23 smaller units.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

MICROECONOMICS AND SPORTS TICKETS
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S tax reform bill would prohibit companies from deducting the cost of seats at sporting events as a business expense. This action is part of a broader proposal to limit generally the deductibility of all business entertainment expenses, including business meals and theater tickets.

title: Sonny Mae Loans: 5 Days To Apply
description: Begining tomorrow, home buyers trying to get a share of the $179 million the State of New York Mortgage Agency will soon make available for low-interest home loans, will have only five working days to apply.

title: CALLS FOR RADON DETECTORS INCREASING
description: RECENT public focus on the radon-gas problem in New Jersey has led to a booming new industry for the manufacturers and sellers of radon detectors.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;

30 DISCOUNT STORES ALL IN A CLUSTER
description: The nationwide pattern of manufacturer-run outlets in a totally discount shopping area is found closest to this county in East Norwalk, Conn., well-marked along I-95 as south of Exit 16 with a right turn immediately after the railroad underpass. There are 30 stores in the area.

title: FRUSTRATING THE SPECTATOR
description: THE FORMS OF VIOLENCE Narrative in Assyrian Art and Modern Culture. By Leo Bersani and Ulysse Dutoit. Illustrated. 136 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $19.95.

title: WRONG AGAIN
description: ONE DAY I AM PRUN-ing hydrangeas the way Comstock, who understood flowers, showed me years ago. Silliman walks by with his dog, looks over my shoulder. ''That's not the way to prune a hydrangea,'' he says.

title: ENGLAND'S WILDEST WEST
description: Cornwall is the most westerly of the British counties and West Penwith is its westernmost tip, the slightly cocked toe on the leg of England that sticks out into the Atlantic. (Penwith means Land's End in Cornish.) Even now, with fast trains and relatively decent roads, Cornwall feels remote from the rest of the country, older, more romantic and with a different kind of beauty - wilder and bleaker. Where Devon, its neighbor to the east, has deep lanes, lush pastures, spreading trees and thatched cottages, the western part of Cornwall is mostly moorland broken by dry-stone walls and scattered with reminders of the people who lived there millenniums before the Romans arrived in Britain.

title: TOUR CANCELED. WHAT HAPPENS NOW?
description: A lot has been written about penalties that travelers sometimes must pay if they cancel a prepaid trip shortly before departure or if they interrupt it en route to return home early. But what happens if a cruise line or tour operator cancels a trip that you had eagerly awaited?

title: THE MIND OF THE PRESIDENT
description: RONALD REAGAN IS unique in the history of American Presidents. He is alone in possessing the mind of both an ideologue and a politician.

title: MEDICAL EXPERTS STRESS MONITORING 'HIGH RISKS' TO AVERT HOMICIDES
description: Medical experts urged public health officials and the medical community last week to recognize that homicide was more than a law-enforcement problem and that ''high risk'' individuals and groups required better identification and monitoring.

title: LAURIE STAUHS IS WED
description: At the Riverside Church in New York yesterday Laurie Catherine Stauhs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Stauhs of Maplewood, N.J., was married to Steven Robert Howard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Howard of Richmond. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr. performed the ceremony. The bride is advertising, promotion and public relations director for the Hayden Book Company in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. Mr. Howard is an associate with the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton.

title: MAKING THAT DREAM HOUSE AFFORDABLE
description: KENNETH N. RASHBAUM and his wife, Vicki H. Kaplan, recently bought the dream house they thought they could never afford. After a lengthy search, the couple found a 102-year-old Federal townhouse in Brooklyn's Park Slope with marble mantels, a large backyard - and a ready-made rental apartment that helps pay the mortgage. The carrying costs for the three-story house are less than the payments on the small co-op apartment they just sold.

title: ULTIMATUM FOR SPINKS
description: Just two weeks after he upset Larry Holmes to become the first light- heavyweight champion to win a heavyweight title, Michael Spinks has been told that he must give up one of his crowns by Tuesday. The deadline was set by Jose Sulaiman, the president of the World Boxing Council, who said that if Spinks did not renounce his newly won International Boxing Federation heavyweight title by then he would be stripped of his W.B.C. light-heavyweight crown.

title: STEPHEN HOWARD WED TO ELIZABETH M. HINZ
description: The wedding of Elizabeth Marie Hinz, a consultant with Channing, Weinberg & Company, a health-care consulting concern in New York, to Stephen Edward Howard, an associate with Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, took place yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Lewis Towler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Why Dinosaurs Went Away Forever
description: Scientists have come up with intriguing new evidence that may help explain why the dinosaurs became extinct and how, perhaps, we might follow them. Examining clay samples from Denmark, Spain and New Zealand, researchers at the University of Chicago's Enrico Fermi Institute discovered substantial amounts of graphitic carbon, or soot.

title: ISLANDERS EARLY GOALS DOWN RANGERS BY 4-0
description: It was preseason hockey at its most typical, meaning it was a very boring evening at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: U.S. UNCERTAIN OF DIPLOMAT'S FATE Uncertain
description: The State Department said today that it still has ''no independent confirmation'' of reports from Beirut that William Buckley, an American diplomat, had been executed.

title: WINFIELD CONVINCES HIS CHIEF DOUBTER
description: George Steinbrenner, in a long-repressed verbal swipe at some of his players not long ago, said he saw Dave Winfield as Mr. May, but if the Yankee owner were to trade Winfield, as some people thought he wanted to do, he would eventually view the move with dismay.

title: EYGPTIAN POLICEMAN IS SAID TO KILL 8 IN SINAI
description: An Egyptian policeman fired his automatic weapon at a group of Israeli tourists and at fellow officers today in the Sinai Peninsula, killing eight people and wounding four, officials reported.

title: ELIZABETH HARPER PLANS TO BE WED
description: The Rev. and Mrs. John C. Harper of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Warren Harper to Daniel Francis Danello, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Danello of Cleveland.

title: HOW TO CHOOSE THE RIGHT VCR FROM A BEWILDERING PROFUSION
description: The autumn nip in the air calls the imagination indoors. Domesticity revives.

title: BOTH PARTIES RECRUITING CANDIDATES IN KEY STATES
description: When Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr. suddenly announced last month that he was retiring from the Senate next year, the Republican lawmaker touched off a political uproar in Maryland, his home state, that has yet to subside. Donald P. Hutchinson, the Baltimore County executive, jumped into the race for the Democratic nomination; Gov. Harry Hughes said he would announce after the legislative session next year. Representative Michael D. Barnes, who represents this heavily Democratic area in the Washington suburbs, will enter the fray tomorrow, and Representative Barbara A. Mikulski of Baltimore is also eager to run.

title: THE WEEDEND PARADE IN SOHO
description: If the East side is the place for well-tailored dressers and the West Side for ever-so-rumpled tweedy types, the SoHo is New York's mecca for the sartorially free-spirited.

title: OUTDOOR GRILLING GOES YEAR-ROUND
description: NOW that the passion for grilling food has spread from California across the country, this method of cooking is no longer confined to summer barbecues in the Northeast. Even on chilly evenings, people are cooking on their outdoor grills - but bringing the food indoors to eat.

title: AFLOAT ON JAPAN'S INLAND SEA
description: No region of Japan gives more immediate pleasure than the Inland Sea. From the deck of the ferry or speedboat, patterns of islands change kaleidoscopically, now linking together to form a single serrated island, now standing apart as if to allow fishing boats and tankers to pass. If you are lucky with the weather, the brilliant green of the islands is set off by the sparkling blue of the sea and the softer blue of the sky, but even if it is raining, the varied shapes of the islands, dimly visible through the mist, claim your entire attention.

title: '7 UP'/'28,' BRITISH DOCUMENTARIES
description: THE twin documentaries ''7 Up'' and ''28 Up,'' which were shown last night at the New York Film Festival (and which open at the Film Forum 1 on Oct. 16), constitute as fascinating a work of popular sociology as you may ever see. ''7 Up,'' which was first shown on British television in 1963, collected a group of 7-year-olds from different class strata and let them describe their values, their prejudices and their hopes for the future. The same project takes on tremendous poignancy and a great deal more breadth in ''28 Up,'' a follow-up study consisting of much longer profiles of the same people, revealing how their dreams and aspirations have changed with time.

title: PLAN TO SIMPLIFY NEW YORK TRIAL COURTS HIT SNAGS
description: A plan to simplify New York State's trial court system - thought to be close to consensus in the last session of the Legislature - has started to unravel.

title: THE BIG BANK RUSH IS ON
description: Sooner or later it was bound to happen. The nation's money-center banks have discovered Washington. Led by the ever-aggressive Citicorp, the big banks are pushing not so quietly to get in the door.

title: THE GENSIS OF 'STAR WARS'
description: THE MILITARIZATION OF SPACE U.S. Policy, 1945-1984. By Paul B. Stares. 334 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $25.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THE story of D.B. Cooper, the hijacker who parachuted from a Boeing 727 as it flew over the Pacific Northwest in 1971, receives the full treatment in ''D.B. Cooper: What Really Happened,'' by Max Gunther (Contemporary Books, Chicago, $14.95).

title: THE CITY BENEATH ROME
description: In 1956, the pastor of San Pietro in Vincoli, the Roman church that houses Michelangelo's ''Moses,'' decided that the basilica needed a new pavement. So he ordered the old floor taken up, to be replaced by the polished travertine marble found there today. Before the digging had gone very far, the workmen came upon some ancient remains; and the simple replacement of the floor turned into a complex project of excavation that went on for several years. Like almost every building in the heart of Rome, San Pietro in Vincoli was built over layers of other constructions. Somewhat to his dismay, the pastor found a cross section of Roman history beneath his feet.

title: BASHFUL PHILADELPHIA CHNAGING WITH NEWCOMERS WHO WANT TO STAND OUT
description: Proper Philadelphians, the novelist Owen Wister said earlier in this century, ''seem to distrust our own power to do anything out of the common; and when a young man tries to, our minds close against him with a civic instinct of disparagement.''

title: TOPICS
description: WHILE the town fathers of my community ponder the interminable problem of trash disposal, I have been wrestling with a dilemma of my own: what to do with my garbage cans. I have three of them. One has been with me since I first moved here 25 years ago. The others are of slightly more recent vintage.

title: A CRASH COURSE IN ACADEMIC FREEDOM
description: Depending on the year and the government, high school students in Argentina have been taught to look favorably upon the military, Peronism or freely elected leaders. Alternatively, all have been portrayed in unflattering ways at one time or another during the last 55 years and 24 governments.

title: BEDS THAT BEND, FOLD OR INFLATE
description: WATER beds are enjoying the limelight, but other non-traditional beds are inching their way into stores these days, too.

title: ABOUT THOSE MATURE WOMEN -- AND MATURE MEN, TOO
description: IN HIS Sept. 8 ''Personally Speaking'' article, Marvin H. Burton wrote of his experiences with group-hopping mature women, who, it seemed to him, had ''real fun'' in ''socially acceptable'' twosomes and threesomes. He said that cash was the only entree into their self-sufficient world.

title: Never Call It The Subway
description: Correspondents from The New York Times report on their local subways, from the chandeliers of Moscow to the Aztec temple of Mexico.

title: FRENCH LESSON
description: To the Editor: Several decades ago when I first visited France I winced somewhat at having to address a dignified, elderly waiter as ''garcon'' but quickly adopted the custom.

title: JAZZ/FOLK
description: Musicians of Brooklyn Initiative is determined to get good jazz heard in Brooklyn. Sunday at 3 P.M., the collective and Celebrate Brooklyn open a month of Sunday concerts at the Prospect Park Picnic House near Prospect Park West and Fifth Street. The performers will be the Jazz Doctors, featuring two wide-ranging soloists - Billy Bang on violin and Frank Lowe on tenor saxophone.

title: SIMPSON, 13 UNDER PAR, LEADS SOUTHERN OPEN
description: Tim Simpson shot a one-under-par 69 today to hold off the charges of Bob Tway and Clarence Rose and maintain a two-shot lead after three rounds of the $350,000 Southern Open golf tournament.

title: 8 Food Outlets Listed By New York Officials
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of eight food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: BALANCING TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: PUPIL SEAT-BELT LAW FOUGHT
description: THREE Long Island school districts are seeking to overturn a Suffolk County law mandating the use of seat belts on school buses beginning Jan. 1, 1986, before a proposed state law can become effective.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;

A NEW U.S. TACK TO EASE LATIN DEBT
description: Latin nations would be encouraged to grow instead of tighten their belts under a policy shift that Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d will present to the conference of the I.M.F. and World Bank. The plan in effect accepts the argument of such debtors as Brazil and Argentina that austerity measures imposed by the I.M.F. prevent them from earning enough hard currency to repay their foreign debts. The American plan envisions the World Bank taking a lead role, making development loans in concert with American and foreign banks to stimulate growth.

title: GORBACHEV MAKES A TRIUMPHAL RETURN TO MOSOW
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev returned today from a four-day visit to Paris that seemed as striking to the Russians as it did to the West Europeans.

title: SEAT-BELT USE DROPS IN NEW YOPRK AND NEW JERSEY
description: The use of seat belts by motorists in New York and New Jersey, the first two states in the country to adopt mandatory seat-belt laws, went up immediately after the laws were enacted but has begun to slip, an insurance-industry group has reported.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: BRAINS, NOT BRAWN SHE is not comfortable with her newfound celebrity status. Jacquelyn Sumell of Oakdale shies away from having her picture taken because, she said, she doesn't like being singled out from her teammates.

title: HERE COMES NEW JERSEY!
description: IN ROOM NO. 2458 OF THE RAYBURN BUILDING IN WASHINGTON, the champagne was flowing. Representative Frank J. Guarini, Democrat of Hudson County, and his staff were congratulating themselves on a job well done. Earlier in the day, the House had voted on an amendment, co-sponsored by Guarini, that prohibited funding for Westway, a massive highway project designed to bring development to Manhattan's West Side.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FIELD OF BLOOD. By Gerald Seymour. (Norton, $14.95.) ''An oath's an oath. An oath's a lifetime.'' Exactly what kind of havoc our oaths can wreak, and how perilous and abbreviated a lifetime in Belfast, Northern Ireland, can be, preoccupies this relentlessly grim suspense novel, Gerald Seymour's eighth in 10 years.

title: Investors' Luxury Units Becoming Harder to Rent
description: EVER since the condominium phenomenon took hold in Manhattan a few years ago, an increasing number of the buyers of these units have been investors who rent out their apartments rather than occupy them. Realty professionals say that about 30 percent of the units in newly constructed condominium projects in Manhattan have been bought by investors, who have been attracted by the tax write-offs and appreciation offered by this form of residential ownership.

title: DODGER VERITIES SPAN THE SEASONS
description: AT the very center, in the tabernacle so to speak, of the most successful and efficient baseball organization on earth, you find not a computer but a shoe box. It is cardboard, blue and white, and somewhat battered. Al Campanis, the old N.Y.U. second baseman, who is the Los Angeles Dodgers' vice president for player personnel, removed the shoe box from the drawer beside his desk and looked for an instant as archeologists must have looked when they first uncovered artifacts from Troy. He smiled, worked off some rubber bands, opened the box and said quietly: ''The Branch Rickey Tapes.''

title: Kansas City: Cautiously Entering the Market
description: AS it is everywhere else, location is the key to condominium development in Kansas City, says James J. Nicholson, who heads condominium sales for J. C. Nichols Company, the area's largest residential developer.

title: Don't Blame the Cats For What's Wrong
description: In thinking about Martha Derman's article, I have come to believe it's wrong to blame the cats for their loss of independence. Let us fault their benefactors. It appears that cats have now become the poor victims of the nouveau cat lovers who give them strange names and cater to their luxuriant life styles.

title:
TREKS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: MAGIC MOUNTAINS;

Clouds in The Living Room
description: Artists and writers recall high points -- from ski school in Japan to a sacred crater in Hawaii, from the Montana Rockies to a novice climb in the French Alps.

title: PLANS FOR FUND TO AID BEACHES ARE PRESSED
description: ALTHOUGH Hurricane Gloria ripped up boardwalks and knocked down trees and power lines on its way up the coast, it also breathed new life into moves to find some stable source of funds for shore-protection projects.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page caption in the Business section on Sept. 22 incorrectly dated a photograph of John Sculley, chief executive of Apple Computer, and Steven P. Jobs. The photo was taken last January.

title: CORNELIA BESHAR BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Somers, N.Y., yesterday Cornelia Anne Beshar, who is with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, was married to Robert Emmett Spring, an associate with the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;

MESSAGES FROM MILAN
description: MILAN IS THE FIRST place to spot new spring and summer fashions. And the 1986 season there, opening today, offers two basic themes - both, let it be said at the outset, subject to wide interpretation. There is the Orient, notably in the form of clean kimono shapes by Gianfranco Ferre and translations of handmade Japanese papers into exquisite silks and linens by Gianni Versace. Then there is something that might be loosely gathered under the heading ''safari cum military'' - jackets that includes a subtle cut by Giorgio Armani, a skirted look by Laura Biagiotti and the complicated patterning of a Complice outfit by Claude Montana that manages a camouflaged look via a photojournalistic collage. Throughout, there is also a renewed emphasis on legs through above-the-knee skirts, Bermuda shorts and pants that fit second-skin tight. Shoulders, though still emphasized, are evoluting. Designers have been walking about with clouds of shoulder pads - sticking them into jackets, pulling them out, snipping at them with scissors or, even, tossing them away. ''Shoulders still have to be important,'' as Armani put it, ''but somehow smaller.'' For sheer luxury, there are light, beaded jumpsuits by Versace, adorned with variations on the Japanese symbol for happiness. Ferre drops his restructured kimonos over what he calls his ''energy dress'' - a tank-topped slink of black leather pulled even tighter with a suede obi. At Krizia, Mariuccia Mandelli has paired down her signature big-shoulder shapes and shortened her skirts. ''The mood perhaps is military - but by that I mean the rigorousness and cleanness of uniforms emphasized with touches of white,'' she says.

title: SPRAY PAINT SALES CURBED IN GRAFFITI WAR
description: Legislation banning the sale of spray paint to minors has been approved by Westchester County in an effort to curb an increase of graffiti.

title: EVERYBODY'S MUSIC TEACHER
description: MADEMOISELLE Conversations With Nadia Boulanger. By Bruno Monsaingeon. Translated by Robyn Marsack. Illustrated. 141 pp. New York: Carcanet. $14.95.

title: BOSCO NETS 417 IN $-& VICTORY
description: Robbie Bosco passed for 417 yards and hit the wide receiver Mark Bellini for three touchdowns as Brigham Young routed Colorado State, 42-7, today in a Western Athletic Conference game. B.Y.U. is 4-1 over all and 1-0 in the W.A.C. Colorado State fell to 1-4 and 1-2.

title: IRONY IN 'CHAIN LETTERS'
description: NEW YORK FILM FESTIVAL patrons who decided to see Mark Rappaport's ''Chain Letters'' must have done so on the basis of an advertisement describing the film as ''funny-peculiar'' and declaring, ''You'll have fun trying to trace the convolutions of a plot worthy of Dickens, or Borges, or a weird dream.'' So audiences, particularly those fluent in the euphemistic language that is Festivalese, undoubtedly know what they're in for.

title:
DINING OUT;

THREE-STAR FRENCH DINING IN RYE
description: THE overhead beams may be recent arrivals, but they give the intended southern French provincial feel to an essentially clean-lined dining room that is otherwise sophisticated with French antiques, lavish floral displays repeated in microcosm on each table, bright bird and flower panel draperies with sconce-shades echoing the motif, lovingly appointed tables, heavy ''silver,'' proper wine glasses and discreetly floral, exquisite Austrian china.

title: LIBRARY USES ITS OWN STUDIO TO ADD MORE BOOKS FOR BLIND
description: The New York Public Library has installed a new recording booth to increase its selection of books for blind and other handicapped patrons in the New York area.

title: Secret Flight Of the Atlantis
description: The Atlantis joined the nation's fleet of space shuttles last week, but no brass bands or champagne bottles were on hand to celebrate the maiden voyage. The fourth and final shuttle is on a classified mission for the Defense Department, and even the time of Thursday's launch -11:15 A.M., it turned out - was kept secret ''to deny our adversaries'' information about the craft's payload, an Air Force spokesman said.

title: THAI ARMY SEEKS TO STOP RUMORS ON FAILED COUP
description: The Thai Army issued a report Friday intended to quash rumors that high-ranking officers on active duty were involved in an abortive coup Sept. 9.

title: BATTLE LINES DRAWN AT LAKE MINNEWASKA
description: WHEN Kenneth Phillips Sr. stands on the terrace of his house and looks across Lake Minnewaska at a sprawling 98-year-old Victorian hotel, he envisions replacing the aging structure with a major new resort facility and several hundred condominiums.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

NEW MEDAL WILL HONOR ADOLPH S. OCHS
description: A new medal has been issued in honor of Adolph S. Ochs, pioneering publisher of The New York Times. It marks his selection as 1985 honoree of the Jewish-American Hall of Fame at the Judah L. Magnes Memorial Museum in Berkeley, Calif.

title: COMING OF AGE
description: In the eyes of the law, Walter Polovchak became a man last week - and a free man at that. The high school senior from Chicago, who refused to return to the Soviet Union with his parents five years ago, turned 18 and formally applied for citizenship.

title: 'Global Knowledge' Called 'Globaldegook'
description: In the late 1940's, Clare Booth Luce called it ''globaloney.'' Sophisticates called her unsubtle. But was she wrong?

title: Bonn Proves That It's a Capital
description: Correspondents from The New York Times report on their local subways, from the chandeliers of Moscow to the Aztec temple of Mexico.

title: GOP's McGrath Opens Campaign; Koch Ignores It
description: Diane McGrath presented details of the major issue in her campaign for mayor of New York last week, a proposal to fight the spread of AIDS by restricting the social lives of homosexuals and testing for signs of AIDS in many professional people.

title: SHAPIRO HAS TWO OPPONENTS: KEAN AND PROSPERITYTHE GOVERNOR BANKS ON HIS ENDORSEMENTS
description: FOUR years after winning the closest gubernatorial race in New Jersey history, Governor Kean has a chance to gain re-election in the state's biggest landslide.

title: NEW ZEALAND DISPUTE: LANGE DRAWS THE LINE
description: Prime Minister David Lange has suggested in a major speech that New Zealand's antinuclear policy will take precedence over its military alliance with the United States.

title: STEATE PLAYS MAJOR ROLE IN U.S. SPACE PROGRAM
description: WHEN people in New Jersey see the launching of the latest United States space venture from Cape Canaveral or listen to communications from Mission Control in Houston, they probably do not realize the role of their own state.

title: PATRICIA DEMPSEY WED TO PHILIP W. LANGGUTH
description: Patricia A. Dempsey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Dempsey of New York, was married yesterday to Philip W. Langguth, a son of the late Col. Paul O. Langguth, U.S.A., and the late Mrs. Langguth of Henley-on-Thames, England. The Rev. Thomas Joyce performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: HOLY LAND: MILESTONES OF THREE FAITHS
description: There has rarely been a time in history when the narrow strip of earth that lies between the Mediterranean and the Jordan River, forming the geopolitical seesaw connecting Egypt with Turkey, the unique land bridge between Europe, Africa and Asia, has not been scarred by battles, tramped by armies, inhabited by opposing peoples.

title:
ART;

BECKONED BY L.I.'S WATERS
description: Long Island's water settings would seem to be such an appealing exhibition theme that some may wonder why the current ''Waterworks,''' at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, is the first institutional attempt at the topic. Recent preferences for exhibitions that help define the newest movements offer at least a partial explanation.

title: JUMPING OUT OF THE SKY: THRILL, RISKS, DISPUTES
description: In 1797 a Frenchman, R. J. Garnerin, leaped from a balloon while he was harnessed to a big silk canopy he called a ''para-chute,'' which can be translated roughly as ''prevent-fall.''

title: Polish Echoes -- And Ironies
description: In Michael T. Kaufman's article ''Polish Echoes - and Ironies'' (Aug. 25), I empathized with the elder Kaufman's ''nostalgic visits and sentimental wanderings'' -his arduous walk in the rain on the Via Dolorosa at Auschwitz; the emotional highs and lows released by returning to see familiar places and former acquaintances in the changed socio-political climate of a new Poland.

title: ONE OF INDIA'S EARLY AMBASSADORS
description: The Festival of India, a year-long celebration in the United States that will incorporate a number of dance performances in addition to other cultural events, comes too late in time to include the dancer who, more than anyone else, forged the strongest link between India's dance traditions and the West. I refer, of course, to the great Uday Shankar, who died in 1977 and whose dance company from India crisscrossed the country for decades until his final tour here in 1968. It goes without saying that Ravi Shankar, the sitarist, is better known today than his brother - for reasons that cannot be entirely divorced from the Beatles' discovery of his art. It is not surprising that Zubin Mehta, conductor of the New York Philharmonic and Indian-born himself, invited Ravi Shankar to perform with the orchestra when the Festival of India launched its opening week in New York last month (the official nationwide starting date was in June in Washington).

title: DOWN EAST ALMANAC
description: About Maine we are all romantics.

title: ARKANSAS ROUTS T.C.U., 41-0
description: Carl Miller scored on the last Arkansas possession of the second quarter and its first possession of the third period to lead the Razorbacks to a 41-0 rout of Texas Christian today.

title: BEYOND REALITY: DEATH VALLEY
description: It is a little hard to believe in the reality of what we are seeing. In spite of the hardness and the brilliant opacity of the scene before our eyes, it gives the impression of a setting for a movie, a landscape seen through the eyes of a skilled Italian cineaste. We are seated in a building with heavy stone walls, looking out across a valley floor of sterile salt to a high black mountain wall buttressed with reddish-brown foothills. There is no other settlement or town of any size for 140 miles in any direction. If your car breaks down at certain places within sight of this room, you can die of thirst before anyone comes along to find you. The mountains across the valley are over 11,000 feet high. Only a short distance from here the valley floor is almost 300 feet below sea level, the lowest point in the United States.

title: LOCUST VALLEY WINS, 40-6
description: Locust Valley has emerged as the team to beat in Nassau's Conference IV. Yesterday, the Falcons overwhelmed favored Cold Spring Harbor (2-1), 40-6.

title: REAGAN TRIES TO MEND FENCES WITH TUNISIA AFTER THE ISRAEL RAID
description: President Reagan expressed regret today that Tunisia had been ''swept up'' in Middle East violence, and he praised that country's efforts to encourage a peaceful settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: 70 Shops on the Harbor: A High-Style Mall for Roslyn
description: With major retail names like Lord & Taylor, Jaeger and Charles Jourdan, the strip of stores on Northern Boulevard in Manhasset known as the Miracle Mile has long offered some of the finest shopping on Long Island.

title: MIDEAST WEEK: FROM OPTIMISM TO ANGER TO ANGUISH
description: WITH the Middle East again caught up in a wave of killings and reprisals, Secretary of State George P. Shultz last week expressed the American frustration: ''I say, it is time to say, 'Enough. Enough to violence in the Middle East.' '' But with the killing of a Soviet diplomat in Beirut and reports that a Moslem group had executed William Buckley, a diplomat who is one of six American hostages in Lebanon, there was no sign that anyone was paying heed to the Secretary's appeal.

title: ANDOVER BEATS CHOATE
description: Choate (2-1) fumbled the opening kickoff, and Andover (1-2) scored two plays later on a 9-yard run by the halfback Peter Burgess on the way to a 20-0 win yesterday over its divisional rival.

title: October 6, 1985
COWBOY DEFENSE A CHALLENGE
description: Twelve weeks remain in the National Football League season, so it hardly seems appropriate to call Sunday's 9 P.M. game here between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys crucial.

title: PERSONALITIES KEY TO PORTUGUESE VOTING
description: Portuguese will vote Sunday in parliamentary elections that will turn more on personalities than policies.

title: ROYALS DEFEAT A's AND CAPTURE TITLE
description: The Kansas City Royals, saving their biggest comeback of the season for their biggest night, clinched their sixth Western Division championship in the last 10 years tonight with a 5-4 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: Round 2 for Unit 1 at TMI
description: For proponents of nuclear power, one of the victims of the March 1979 accident in Unit 2 of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant was its twin neighbor, the reactor in Unit 1. Shut down for routine refueling at the time of the accident, the worst in the history of commercial nuclear power, Unit 1 had been shut ever since.

title: 22 ORCHESTRAS SEEK A FULL HOUSE
description: AUDIENCE-BUILDING is a major occupation in the county. In the field of music, no fewer than 22 orchestras vie for the public's attention in concerts throughout the year. Of these, three are fully professional, four include a mixture of professional and avocational players, and the rest are strictly avocational.

title: TERRORISM DEFEATS REAGAN
description: The United States position on international terrorism has just turned to mush. All of George Shultz's fine oratory about ''the ethics of power'' in striking back at vipers' nests that can be shown to be the source of hostage taking and murder stands revealed as so much hot air.

title: The Economy: A Modest Gain
description: Many experts see the Government's grab-bag index of leading economic indicators as a far-from-perfect measure of things to come. Still, the Commerce Department's figures for August, released last week, were widely regarded as a sign that the economy may be slowly recovering from its year-long doldrums.

title: THE THINGS THAT MAKE A DAD A HERO
description: IT was a week before I had the nerve to go back out and check for casualties. I opened the lid of the propane gas-fired grill, removed the grate and bed of lava rock, pulled up the lower grate and found it there in a corner - an intact but partially charred nest.

title: ROYAL MEANDER ALONG THE LOIRE
description: In 1669, Moliere introduced his play ''Monsieur de Pourceaugnac'' at a command performance at Chambord castle. The guidebooks tell of a bored Louis XIV, of royal fidgets and of a king who never smiled. Midway through opening night, Jean Baptiste Lully, who had written music for the play and was also acting in it, sensed gathering disaster and jumped off the stage onto a harpsichord, smashing it to bits. Big yuks from the king; a triumphant play, and a major precedent for Harpo Marx and Mel Brooks.

title: SUSAN P. AMBROSE WED TO DANIEL JEFFREY PLAINE
description: Susan Patricia Ambrose and Daniel Jeffrey Plaine were married in an interfaith ceremony yesterday at the Bradley Hills Presbyterian Church-Bethesda Jewish Congregation in Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Mark Ramsey and Rabbi Siegfried Rowe officiated.

title:
AROUND THE MARKET;

What Boards Should Ask
description: PERHAPS the only thing former President Richard M. Nixon and the rock star Madonna have in common is that both were rejected as buyers by the boards of directors of elegant Manhattan cooperatives.

title: EATING FOR PLEASURE
description: IS SALAMI AND EGGS BETTER THAN SEX? Memoirs of a Happy Eater. By Alan King and Mimi Sheraton. 218 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $15.95.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: BREAKFAST TIME, ERNEST AND CELESTINE. Written and illustrated by Gabrielle Vincent. Greenwillow. $5.25. (Ages 3 to 6) Those enchanting companions, Ernest, the very large gentle bear, and Celestine, the very small and curious mouse, are back.

title: EFFECT OF OIL SPILL ON WILDLIFE STUDIED
description: DOZENS of biologists left their laboratories and offices last week to begin assessing the potential long-term effects on fish and wildlife of the 435,000 gallons of crude oil that spilled into the Delaware River last weekend.

title: TRAUTMANN WINS 5,000 METERS
description: John Trautmann, who last weekend won the high school section of the Fifth Avenue Mile, was victorious yesterday over the cross-country trails at Sunken Meadow State Park in Kings Park, L. I. Running through a steady rainfall and on a muddy course, Trautmann, a senior at Monroe-Woodbury High School in Central Valley, N.Y., was clocked in 16 minutes 17.9 seconds over 5,000 meters to win the third of five varsity races at the St. Anthony's High School Invitational. His time was the fastest of the meet, which brought together runners from 130 schools and three states.

title: MEDICARE
description: To the Editor:

title: ELIZABETH CULLEN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Grace Cullen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cullen of Garden City, L.I., and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., to Martin Johnson Remsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Remsen of Locust Valley, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., took place yesterday. The Rev. Paul McKeever performed the ceremony in the Convent Chapel at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City.

title: EXECUTIVE SEARCH
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonevict Plans: Co-ops With Split Personalities
description: UNTIL two or three years ago, most people who bought cooperative apartments in New York City were joining a community in which almost all the other residents were also tenant-shareholders and thus tended to have compatable goals.

title: FLORIDA DOMINATES LOUISIANA STATE, 20-0
description: The back Neal Anderson passed 51 yards for a touchdown and broke the school's career rushing mark, leading Florida to a 20-0 rout of Louisiana State tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: CONNECTICUT SWEARS IN 27 MAGISTRATES TO EASE COURT BACKLOG
description: Connecticut's magistrate program, which allows lawyers rather than judges to hear minor cases, was expanded this week when Chief Justice Ellen A. Peters swore in 27 men and women as magistrates to ease the state's backlog of court cases.

title:
ART;

MONTCLAIR: FOCUS IS ON INDIANS
description: THE Montclair Museum possesses a rich collection of American Indian art, and its holdings of more than 4,000 items have just been examined by Dr. Frederick Dockstader, former director of the Museum of the American Indian in Manhattan.

title: Appreciating Strindberg
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Hurricanes;   Insuring Against the Next One
description: AS homeowners dug their way out of the debris of Hurricane Gloria last week, many of them learned that traditional insurance policies did not adequately cover some of their losses, among them spoiled food from the freezer, the cost of removing fallen trees and damage from basement flooding.

title: RETRACING HISTORY AT 10 M.P.H.
description: For people who race through cities all week long, the Housatonic Railroad offers a weekend amble through lush greenery and 19th-century history at speeds guaranteed not to break 10 miles an hour. At that pace, passengers have time to contemplate stone walls coursing through dense woods, flowers tumbling down river banks and canoeists negotiating Housatonic River rapids.

title: POLISH CHURCH KEEPS ITS DISTANCE FROM THE STATE
description: Over the last four decades attempts to define and establish a golden mean in Polish politics have proven elusive in this divided land. Now, with parliamentary elections scheduled for Oct. 18, the impending failure to again attract a moderate middle is generating active and often vituperative debate.

title: TRADITION CONTINUES AT AN OUTPOST OF BRITAIN
description: HURRICANE GLORIA and its wind and rain had hit the gentle hills and valleys here only a day earlier. But, charitably, it did not leave a sticky wicket for the Mendham Cricket Club's monthly match last weekend.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ORGANIZED FOR PROHIBITION: A New History of the Anti-Saloon League. By K. Austin Kerr. (Yale University, $25.) If any institution deserves credit for the enactment of Prohibition in 1919, it is the Anti-Saloon League.

title: ALEXANDER TRIUMPHS, 5-1
description: Shrugging off their stunning loss 17 hours earlier and holding off the Yankees' third charge in the last three months, the Toronto Blue Jays sent an entire nation soaring into ecstasy today by winning the American League East championship for the first time in their nine-year history.

title: FOOTBALL, COMMUTER-STYLE
description: CONNECTICUT is famous for the Charter Oak, mountain laurel, Enfield prison, Yale University and the Coast Guard Academy. But it is most famous for that hardy perennial, the commuter.

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: AS SHUTTLE ORBITS, A DEBATE GROWS OVER MILITARY'S ROLE
description: As five military officers on the space shuttle Atlantis orbit the earth on a secret mission, a debate is growing in the United States over how much secrecy is necessary in the civilian-run space program and what the military's role in it should be.
