title: FAST-DRAW SHERRIFF AIMS AT MORE PISTOL RECORDS l>By BOB NESOFF
description: DIRTY HARRY could have made Joe Walsh's day, but he didn't.

title: THE LONG QUEST FOR CHIEF WARAMAUG
description: THE long-lost grave of Chief Waramaug, the powerful Indian sachem of the turn of the 18th century, may now have been found.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MARSALIS CONCERTS Wynton Marsalis, the trumpeter who last year became the first musician to win Grammy Awards for best instrumental soloist in both jazz and classical categories, will give two concerts in Lawrenceville Saturday evening.

title: CHAMBER GROUP IS OFF TO GOOD START
description: THE New World Consort was born at Wesleyan University only last month, but already the ensemble has some of the most fascinating chamber programming in the state.

title: JANICE LISA BLOCH AND DR. MALCOLM Z. ROTH WED
description: Janice Lisa Bloch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald C. Bloch of New York and Belmont, Vt., and Dr. Malcolm Zachary Roth, the son of Mrs. Emanuel Salzberg of Hewlett, L.I., and the late Morton Roth, were married yesterday. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at Hampshire House in Manhattan.

title: MILWAUKEE POLICE SUIT ENDS
description: Mayor Henry Maier has approved the payment of $600,000 to the family of Ernest Lacy, who died while being held for questioning about a rape he did not commit. The payment, approved earlier by the Common Council, settles a lawsuit against the city by his parents. The agreement was approved Monday by Federal Magistrate Robert Bittner.

title: NO. 304 FOR SEAVER
description: He was a 40-year-old pitcher on a damp, cold night, and for a while he considered just snuggling up in his warm-up jacket and letting someone else take on the Seattle Mariners. But who knows? At his age he might not have many more chances.

title: PHILIPPINES REPORTSKILLING 30 REBELS
description: Military officials said today that special anti-insurgency forces had killed 30 rebels and seized several weapons in an ambush on the southern island of Mindanao.

title: WHAT THE COUNTRY STANDS TO WIN - AND LOSETHOMAS A LUKEN: A POPULAR WAY TO RAISE MONEY
description: CALIFORNIA rrbecame the 20th state with a lottery last week. Potentially, at least, the nation's largest state may have its richest lottery, with gross revenue expected to hit $1.4 billion in the first year. As in many other states, part of the profit will go to public schools. Some members of Congress, looking with envy upon the states' revenue jackpot, have pushed for a national lottery, and a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs held a hearing on lotteries last year. Robert Pear of The Times Washington bureau asked Representative Thomas A. Luken, an Ohio Democrat who supports a national lottery, and Senator Dave Durenberger, a Minnesota Republican who opposes it, to discuss the idea.

title: TARQUINIA
description: To the Editor: Travelers to Italy, and especially Rome, who are interested in Etruscan artifacts and civilization might like to know more about Tarquinia, the chief city of ancient Etruria whose extensive necropolises supplied two of the illustrations for Nancy Jenkins's article, ''Exploring the Etruscan Mystery'' (Travel, Sept. 1).

title: MAN FINED IN MASSACHUSETTS FOR RACIAL SLUR IN RESTAURANT
description: A man has been fined for shouting racial slurs in a restaurant in what the prosecutor said he believed was the first conviction of a restaurant customer under a 1964 state law.

title: Social Events;   Partying Around Town
description: Evening of Dance Oct. 7 - An evening of dance celebration to honor Jerome Robbins will feature performances as well as cocktails starting at 7 P.M. and dining and dancing for guests at the Fourth Annual Astaire Awards. The benefit at the Rainbow Room atop Rockefeller Center is for the Anglo-American Contemporary Dance Foundation, which provides exchanges of dance companies and individuals dancers between Britain and the United States. White tie preferred. Tickets, $200, from 212-247-7575. 'A Night in Spain' Oct. 9 - El Morao, the Spanish Flamenco dance company, will be whirling at the Pierre for the 33d annual benefit dinner for the Children's Blood Foundation, which supports the division of pediatric hematology and oncology at New York Hospital. While advances have been made in some childhood cancers and blood disorders, a new threat, acquired immune deficiency syndrome, has erupted to demand new research efforts. Tickets for the black-tie event, starting with cocktails at 7:30 P.M., are $200 from 212-644-5790. At the Jockey Club Oct. 9 - The junior committee of the Friends of 13 will be partying at the Jockey Club at 112 Central Park South to benefit the local public television station. Cocktails at 7:30 P.M. followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets, $150, from 212-560-2800. For Mothers and Babies Oct. 10 - The credo of the Maternity Center Association, one of New York's oldest health care agencies for women, is that ''every baby born will be wanted and welcomed.'' A benefit for the center's extensive services will start at 5:45 P.M. with a cocktail buffet at the headquarters of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, 1285 Avenue of the Americas at 51st Street, followed by a performance of ''Song & Dance'' at 8 P.M. at the Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street.

title: SUSAN ANDERSON AND C. H. HEALEY EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Susan Grace Anderson, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Richard Anderson Jr. of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, was married at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York yesterday to Christopher Hughes Healey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Joseph Healey of Newtown Square, Pa. The Rev. Susan Harris performed the ceremony.

title: MUSIC: BADINAGE ENSEMBLE
description: THE early-music group Badinage's Thursday night concert at the Merkin Concert Hall was an uneven one, but its best moments made the evening worthwhile.

title: MISS WHITMAN BECOMES BRIDE OF MARK SWANK
description: Cynthia Graham Whitman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Cutler Whitman 3d of Katonah, N.Y., was married at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday to Mark Frederick Swank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bruce Swank of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. William E. Foley, rector of the church, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Arthur Hargate, rector emeritus.

title: SPELLERS OF THE WORLD, UNITE! YOU HAVE NOTHING TO LOSE BUT YOUR CACOGRAPHY
description: THE immigration officer at Gatwick Airport this summer asked the purpose of my trip to England. ''To attend the International Conference on Spelling Reform, in Southampton,'' I said. The officer looked surprised: ''I haven't seen anyone else come through for that.'' I assured him that great hordes were expected from all over the world.

title: NEW RULES NEAR ON FIRE SAFETY
description: THE state's Fire Safety Commission is expected to enact into law, effective Nov. 27, new rules and regulations requiring high-occupancy structures built before 1977 to meet certain minimum safety requirements.

title: CURRICULUM ON SUICIDE AT MIDDLE SCHOOLS
description: IN addition to reading, writing and arithmetic, middle-school students in some districts in the county this year will receive lessons in coping with crisis and loss and will learn what to do if they or someone they know is thinking of suicide.

title: MAGIC, GOD AND QUANTUM PHYSICS
description: MASKS OF THE UNIVERSE By Edward Harrison. Illustrated. 306 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: TALKING SPORTS
description: DURING THE LAST TWO DEC-ades, the job of major league sports commissioner has grown from a comfortable figurehead post to one of the nation's most visible and demanding executive positions. It involves not only the scheduling of hundreds of professional games each season, but also dealing with complex governmental regulation and the negotiation of television and other revenues that amount to hundreds of millions of dollars a year for football and baseball alone.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's four-year-old program to raise money for nongame and endangered wildlife is in trouble, and officials of the Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife have started cutting back.

title: BLACKS FAULT FARRAKHAN, BUT THEY ALSO FIND MUCH TO PRAISE
description: Posters announcing the arrival tomorrow night of Louis Farrakhan cover walls, bus stops and subway stations in predominantly black neighborhoods of Harlem, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH SUPERTITLES?
description: The other evening at the opera I found myself leaning forward and straining for some hint of what words the singers were trying to communicate to one another. This, of course, is not an unusual posture for anyone who goes to the opera with even a hope of understanding what is supposed to be taking place onstage. However, on the evening in question the opera, Janacek's ''Jenufa,'' was being sung at the Metropolitan in a new English translation rather than in the original Czech, so why should there have been any problem of comprehension?

title: A Freeze for Owner-Renters
description: Question: My building is owned by a corporation that has 10 owners who occupy apartments. Can they freeze the rents on these 10 apartments at current levels while continuing to raise rents of rent-regulated apartments? . . . R.G.A., Manhattan Answer: The owners can continue raising tenants' rent and not their own, says Thomas Viola, assistant commissioner for public information for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. If an owner were to move and rerent the apartment, he would be entitled to a guideline increase and a vacancy increase, but could not recapture the past guideline increases. The Sumptuous Vanderbilt Question: How old is the building I live in - 4 Park Avenue - and what details can you supply on its former life as the Vanderbilt Hotel? . . . M.O., Manhattan Answer: The Hotel Vanderbilt opened Jan. 11, 1912, and was praised as the ''last thing in hotels'' in news accounts of the day. Among its novel features were a bath with each of the 585 rooms and the inclusion of dressing rooms with maid and valet service on the mezzanine for use of out-of-town people who did not want a room, but wanted to dress for dinner.

title: Madame Esquire
description: I read with interest, not to say delight, William Safire's item entitled ''Madame Esquire'' (''Arcane Brown Bag,'' On Language, Sept. 15). How fascinating to find this arcane corner of English snobbery alive and well in these United States.

title: GARRETT'S EXAMPLE A DISTURBING ONE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AFOOT IN JERUSLEM
description: The khamsin was blow-ing and the view from my window in the King David Hotel was hazy. I had to intuit the Dead Sea, lying to the southeast, and across it the mountains of Moab, in Jordan - on clear days they are a visible soft blue. Even the pale golden walls of the Old City of Jerusalem, just a few blocks beyond the hotel, looked gritty in the hot, insinuating wind. In this always seething city, the khamsin creates an extra atmospheric layer of suspense.

title:
AROUND THE NATION;

Chicago: The Disguised Condo Flourishes As Apartments Lose Appeal
description: AT Lakewood Commons on the north side of Chicago, all 30 town houses were sold before the first shovelful of earth was turned this summer on the project. At Picardy Circle in north suburban Northbrook, more than half the 83 town houses were under contract before the builder started construction on a model that will now get very little use.

title:
GARDENING;

LOOKING TO THE EAST FOR FALL COLOR
description: WITH the exception of food plants such as corn and squash, the early European settlers in the Northeast tended to ignore the native plants in favor of those from their homelands. This is understandable, for they were familiar with their characteristics and uses. It is also understandable that they looked upon the native plants more as enemies to be conquered than friends, since they had to clear them away, acre after acre, to make land available for cultivation.

title: U.S. JURY TRIAL ORDERED IN SCHIAVONE LIBEL SUIT
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a jury must decide whether Time magazine had libeled a former employer of Raymond J. Donovan, who resigned last March as Labor Secretary.

title: 2 KEY SENATORS JOIN IN ASSAULT ON THE MILITARY
description: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and its senior Democrat have begun a concerted assault on the way the American military is run, calling the current system wasteful and dangerous.

title: HUNGER PROJECT AIMING AT GLOBAL COMMITMENT
description: Last month, a woman in Mexico became the four millionth person to sign a pledge declaring that the end of hunger ''is an idea whose time has come.''

title: DESIGNER SETS THE STAGE FOR A ROYAL VISIT
description: PAUL LEONARD, an interior designer from Washington Depot, likes to think of his work as quiet, countrified and understated, but the 25-year progression of his career reads like the script for a jet-set adventure.

title: Quiet, Please, We're at the Opera
description: Correspondents from The New York Times report on their local subways, from the chandeliers of Moscow to the Aztec temple of Mexico.

title: JANE SHEAHAN IS WED
description: Jane Ann Sheahan, a vice president in the money-market department at Paine Webber Inc., and Raymond McLaughlin, a first vice president of E. F. Hutton & Company, were married yesterday at Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Joseph Zorawick. The parents of the couple are Mrs. Michael Patrick Sheahan of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Mr. Sheahan, and Mrs. William McLaughlin of Cocoa Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. McLaughlin.

title: ONE OF ITALY'S BEST
description: A FEW MILES SOUTHWEST OF Alba, in the Piedmont region of northern Italy, is a small wine-growing region - about 5,000 acres - that produces one of the great wines of the world: Barolo. There is a problem with Barolo, however, and it is this:

title: SHAPIRO HAS TWO OPPONENTS: KEAN AND PROSPERITYDEMOCRAT CONCENTRATES ON ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES
description: IN one of the television commercials that he hopes will beam him into office, Peter Shapiro, the Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, says he is ready to replace Thomas Kean, one of the most popular incumbents in the state's history. ''What do you say?'' he asks the television audience.

title: DEBORAH BARNETT TO BECOME BRIDE OF ROBERT BRANDT
description: Deborah Elizabeth Barnett, a senior designer in the school textbook division of MacMillan Inc. in New York, and Robert Brandt, a member of the Brandt Organization, a real-estate investment and development company in New York, plan to be married Nov. 2.

title: FRANKFURT POLICE CHARGE CROWD AT BANNED PROTEST Crowd
description: Riot policemen charged a crowd in Frankfurt's busy shopping district today at a banned protest against the death of an anti-Nazi demonstrator who was run over by a police vehicle.

title: MARTIN'S CONDUCT WAS DISGRACEFUL
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fire at Petroleum Plant
description: A fire at a petroleum distribution plant today seriously injured one man and threatened huge tanks containing 80,000 gallons of gasoline, prompting the evacuation of 200 people within a half-mile radius, authorities said. Sgt. Peter Matonis of the state police said the fire at the Belasco Petroleum plant, about a mile north of the Fort Dix Military Reservation, was declared under control at 9:30 P.M., about 40 minutes after it was reported. The burning building contained 55-gallon drums of motor oil and kerosene.

title: IRAQ SAYS ITS PLANES HIT PORT AGAIN
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes had hit Kharg Island for the third time in three days, the 21st raid since Iraq began a drive Aug. 15 to close the vital Iranian oil terminal.

title: GAIL LINDSEY WED IN NORTH CARONLINA
description: The marriage of Gail Ann Lindsey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Lindsey of New York, to Michael William Cox, a son of Ralph Cox of West Chicago, Ill., and Jody Cox of New Orleans, took place yesterday in Wake Forest, N.C. The Revs. Jill Auman and Timothy Auman, sister and brother-in-law of the bride and Methodist ministers, performed the ceremony at the couple's future home.

title: ROUND 2 BEGINS IN THE BUDGET DEBATE
description: With startling suddenness, a proposal designed to balance the Government's budget by 1991 began attracting legions of supporters last week and was soon Topic No. 1 in Capitol Hill's rekindled debate over Federal red ink.

title: AMERICAN TO SAIL IN SOLO TRIP
description: Dodge Morgan is a New England entrepreneur who intends to spend the next year climbing down the corporate ladder. Morgan sold his multimillion-dollar electronics firm in 1983 to give himself the time. Now, at age 53, he is ready for an attempt to become the first American to sail alone round the world nonstop.

title: PHOTOGRAPHS BY PAINTERS AT THE ALDRICH
description: PHOTOGRAPHERS, as a rule, do not diversify into painting and sculpture, but plenty of painters and sculptors take photographs and 34 of them stand revealed in the new show at the Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield.

title: TOWARD WILDER PRECINTS
description: THE SECRETS OF HARRY BRIGHT By Joseph Wambaugh. 345 pp. New York: A Perigord Press Book/ William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: IRRADIATED FOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY NATURE PRESERVE GROWS BY 1,270 ACRES
description: A total of 1,270 acres have been added to the Mad Horse Creek Wildlife Management Area near the Salem nuclear power plant here.

title: COUNTY EXECUTIVE CANDIDATES BEGIN OUTLINING THE ISSUES
description: THE election campaign for County Executive started to take shape last week in the aftermath of the first debates between the Republican incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, and his Democratic challenger, Arthur H. Goodman.

title: TOBACCO COMPANIES ARE FACING MANY DAYS IN COURT
description: Slowly but steadily, public awareness of the dangers posed by smoking has begun to assert itself in American society. Liability suits are reaching the courts in growing numbers, people are winning unemployment compensation because they say they cannot work where smoking is permitted and legislators seem increasingly willing to back antismoking measures.

title: CLASSES ADDED TO DORM
description: TEN students were at the semester's first seminar on human development at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. The aroma of new carpet and fresh paint mixed curiously with the scent of a pot of spaghetti and cheese that one student brought to class.

title: CONTRARY CREATORS FAVOR SIMPLICITY IN DESIGN
description: Down on Wall Street they talk about ''contrary thinking.'' Basically, this means watching where the crowd goes and then heading the other way. It doesn't always work, but once a while it turns up a winner.

title: THE I.M.F. COMES TO DINNER
description: The Republic of Korea - one of the success stories of international lending - is showing off this week to the economic and financial leaders of the world.

title: DWIGHT GOODEN: BY THE NUMBERS
description: Dwight Gooden's season compares well with the most productive years of all but a handful of pitchers, all of whom are in the Hall of Fame. The Earned Runs Prevented statistic, used by The New York Times for the last two seasons, permits comparisons across different baseball eras - dead ball or lively ball, seasons with a wealth of good hitters or weak hitters - by rating a pitcher against the average earned-run average for the league.

title: TECH LOSES BY 18-8
description: Port Richmond lost its bid for a shutout but evened its record at 2-2 (2-1 in the Public School Athletic League), defeating Brooklyn Tech, 18-8, yesterday at New Dorp.

title: ATLAS OF A WRITER'S WORLD
description: The air lane is the highest road. It is Ariel's view. If the clouds have parted, and it is night, there is moonlight clearer than we have ever seen on earth, or a depth of ice-bright stars, huge in the sky. If it is day, or we are flying low, below us is a contoured panorama of the world that our ancestors would have thought miraculous. It is. There is, if we look, a glimpse of the low roads - a cart, a ship, a river - through the rifts of clouds.

title: STARTED RADIO STATIONS
description: William H. Reumann, who started radio station WWRL-AM in his living room in Woodside, Queens, in 1926 and went on to own three other stations as well, died Thursday at his home in Amityville, L.I. He was 89 years old and had lived in Amityville for 45 years.

title: DETOURS ON THE INDIAN ROAD
description: WHETHER HIGH, LOW, OR SOMEWHERE IN BETWEEN, THE open road is fundamental to Indian life. Much gets done there that in our countries is done indoors - and, quite apart from that, the road in India is in continual and multifarious use. It serves as theater and nursery, barber shop and botanical garden, menagerie and employment exchange. No one knows India who has not spent time on the open road.

title: GLASSBORO STATE TOPE TRENTON STATE
description: Larry Lewis hit Marty Regan on an 11-yard scoring pass with 11 seconds remaining in the first period as Glassboro State defeated Trenton State, 10-2, yesterday in a New Jersey Conference game before a Homecoming Day crowd of 3,408 at John Page Field in Glassboro.

title: A WALK IN THE CINQUE TERRE
description: A walk in the Cinque Terre, an area encompassing five towns of medieval origin on Italy's rugged Ligurian coastline, offers three magic travel ingredients: splendid scenery, varied landscape and a sense of discovery. The combination is mesmerizing.

title: MAKING HISTORY WHOLE AGAIN
description: OVER the course of perhaps 20 years, the writing of American history by professional historians has been transformed. The direction of this scholarship, as Frances FitzGerald remarked in ''America Revised'' (1979), her study of high school textbooks, had eclipsed the notion of a national past, replacing it with many pasts, the history of many groups in America with little suggestion of how, or whether, they make up a nation or a society. Historians, to whom we once confidently entrusted the custody of our public memory of ourselves as a nation, have been unable to pull together the vast mountain of scholarship produced in the past quarter century and make of it a coherent and explanatory account of American life. Both readers and writers have been drawn or directed, by a variety of social and cultural mechanisms, to histories of their chosen or inherited group. It is a phenomenon that may represent a disintegration of the civic sense as much as purely intellectual trends in historiography.

title: SLOUCHING TOWARDS DUBLIN
description: Crosswinds and low clouds made Dublin Airport impossible to reach, so it was down to Shannon and a choice of identical-tasting turkey or spareribs, plus a glass of chilled white wine from the land of Spain, from where the galleons came and perished along with thousands of men and from where altar wine is still dispatched.

title: ANDERSON PLAY IN STAMFORD SERIES
description: FOR more than 30 years, the name of the prolific playwright Maxwell Anderson brightened Broadway marquees. He spanned styles from the historical (''Elizabeth the Queen'' in 1930) to the psychopathological (''Bad Seed'' in 1955) with forays into writing lyrics (''Knickerbocker Holiday'' of 1938, which contained the classic, ''September Song''). He died of a cerebral embolism in 1959 at Stamford Hospital at the age of 70.

title: DECISION AWAITED ON TRAINS TO RESORT
description: AFTER three years of delays and false starts, the future of the proposed Philadelphia-Atlantic City rail line may be determined soon.

title: INN WHERE DESSERTS ARE SPECIAL
description: LIKE many other inns throughout the state, Under Mountain Inn in Salisbury has had its share of revolving-door owners since it opened in 1950. The new owners, Margaret and Peter Higginson, double as hostess and chef, respectively. They are obviously trying so hard, one wishes them well.

title: SAINTS AND SERENDIPITY IN PRAGUE
description: ''Times keep changing,'' says the brochure we read sitting in our taxi outside a yellow Renaissance building in the Mala Strana, or Little City, quarter of Prague, ''but the powerful stride on the legs of the three ostriches has been set on the facade of this house once and for all, reminding us of history more ancient than the painting itself.''

title: LYRIC WORLD OF AN ANCIENT PAINTER
description: For 2,500 years, we are told, the Amasis Painter never had a one-man show. Now that oversight has been corrected by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in ''The Amasis Painter and his World: Vase Painting in Sixth Century B.C. Athens,'' a retrospective, comprising 65 skillfully decorated black-figure Greek vases and fragments, dating from 560 to 515 B.C. The museum describes the show, remaining through Oct. 27, as the largest exhibition of terracotta vessels by a single ancient Greek artist and the first to document the evolution of one artisan's oevre.

title: THE NEW WAY TO WIN AT BUSINESS
description: Excerpted from the book ''The Winning Performance: How America's High-Growth Midsize Companies Succeed,'' by Donald K. Clifford Jr. and Richard E. Cavanagh. By permission of Bantam Books Inc. THIS is a study about what's right with American business.The companies whose stories it tells are the nation's midsized growth companies - those with sales between $25 million and $1 billion - that constitute perhaps the least known but the most successful sector of the economy. These winning performers have succeeded by overturning the conventional business wisdom of the 1970's and developing strategies and management practices of their own.

title: MAKING HIGH-WHEEL BICYCLES IS A TRUE LABOR OF LOVE
description: THEY are large, unwieldy contraptions that, even in their heyday, stayed in fashion for only 10 years. They can be difficult to get the hang of, expensive to purchase and costly to repair, but James F. Spillane does not care. He is in love with high-wheel bicycles.

title: KASSEBAUM BILL HAS U.N. WORRIED
description: The name Kassebaum is causing anxiety in the corridors and committee rooms of the United Nations.

title: LASTING EPHEMERA
description: TQ 20 Twenty Years of the Best Contemporary Writing and Graphics From TriQuarterly Magazine. Edited by Reginald Gibbons and Susan Hahn. Illustrated. 668 pp. Wainscott, N.Y.: Pushcart Press. $28.

title: THE FELD BALLET STAGES A LEGENDARY RUSSIAN WORK
description: When the Feld Ballet opens Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, the program will include the company's first performance of a legendary work, ''Les Noces'' as choreographed by Bronislava Nijinska. Depicting a Russian peasant wedding and set to a score by Stravinsky for chorus, four pianists and percussion, ''Les Noces'' has amazed audiences since 1923 when it received its premiere in Paris by Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes.

title: NIGERIANS DEBATE A PROPOSED LOAN
description: Barely five weeks after seizing power in a coup, Nigeria's head of state, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, has catapulted this country of nearly 100 million people into an enormous town meeting.

title: GERMAN OPERAS STIR INTEREST DESPITE FLAWS
description: Sometimes you win; sometimes you lose. When this writer sat down to listen to five new German opera recordings, he had high hopes that at least some, if not all, would be rewarding. As it happens, all five are flawed, if not without interest; certainly none leaps to the fore for especially extensive consideration. So here they are, in chronological order of composition:

title: MISS MURRAY HAS WEDDING
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Marie Barbara Murray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Murray of New Canaan, Conn., was married to Roger Stephen Lane, a son of State Assemblyman and Mrs. Clarence D. Lane of Windham, N.Y. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: CULLING TEACHERS
description: WITH a goal of making New Jersey's public schools ''competitive with prep schools,'' the state's Education Department began last year to recruit teachers at what it considered 21 of the ''most prestigious'' colleges in the Northeast.

title: JAN JACOBI, A BANKER, WEDS DAVID STEWART
description: Jan Ellen Jacobi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce A. Jacobi of New York, was married at the Pierre yesterday to David Hutchison Stewart, a son of Margery W. Stewart of Montreal and the late William T. Stewart. Justice Richard W. Wallach of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: FINISHING TOUCHES FOR WALLBOARD
description: JOINTS in gypsum board or wallboard are finished by filling with a joint compound (also referred to as joint cement) that is reinforced with a special paper tape.

title: EBB TIDE FOR THE KOREAN MIRACLE
description: THE Korean economy is a miracle. In a little more than 20 dizzying years, a country torn apart by war has become an emerging economic power - another Japan of sorts.

title: SHAKING OFF THE 60's
description: THE FABULOUS ENGLISHMAN By Robert McCrum. 274 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $14.95.

title: PIANISTS, A COLORATURA AND A GUITARIST
description: Orrett Rhoden THE advance publicity for Orrett Rhoden's debut recital not only promised a long, hefty solo program and two major concertos with full orchestra, but suggested he might wear ''a 19th-century black doeskin military jacket or a swish black embroidered Victorian cape'' while playing them. One went expecting the worst; Mr. Rhoden probably did the shrewdest possible thing by dressing in perfectly conventional fashion and playing only the solo program - parts of it quite impressively.

title:
ANTIQUES;

CAPE MAY TO RECALL VICTORIAN ERA
description: ''VICTORIAN WEEK,'' a 10-day extravaganza showcasing many of this resort's historic attractions, is expected to lure a large influx of visitors.

title: Thomas Jefferson, Man of the Enlightenment
description: To the Editor:

title: STORM UNEARTHS OLD BONES
description: Archeologists have been examining a skull and several bones unearthed here when Hurricane Gloria knocked down an old tree.

title: CARING FOR ILL: A STRUGGLE FOR AGED
description: A 76-YEAR-OLD man from Tallahassee, Fla., faces life in prison for shooting to death his terminally ill wife after she begged him to do so. A 76-year-old doctor from Rochester committed suicide after administering a lethal dose of insulin to a lifelong friend rather than watch the man die slowly. The doctor had been charged with murder.

title: JUDITH MARENUS IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Marenus of Valley Stream, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Judith Ellen Marenus, to Mark Ryan, a son of Gerald Ryan of New York and the late Doris Ryan. The future bride's father is vice president of Gerald Magit Associates, magazine representatives in New York, and her mother, Faye Marenus, media director of Morton Advertising, also in New York. Mr. Ryan's father is an account supervisor with Doyle Dane Bernbach, the New York advertising agency.

title: MINE UNION BARS REWARD IN OFFICIAL'S KILLING
description: The United Mine Workers has decided not to pay the $50,000 reward it offered after the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski, a union official slain in his sleep shortly after his defeat in a bitterly contested attempt to wrest the union's presidency from W. A. Boyle.

title: VINEYARDS ASSESS STORM DAMAGE
description: SOME Long Island winemakers might be tempted to label the 1985 vintage ''Chateau Gloria.'' Predictions of an excellent, bountiful harvest, after a season of near-perfect weather, are now being revised in the aftermath of the hurricane that blew across Suffolk County.

title: Unions and Churches Join in Brooklyn Condo Project
description: EAGER to improve the image of the labor movement, the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. has joined hands with Brooklyn Ecumenical Cooperatives, a coalition of 35 churches and religious organizations, to convert 24 abandoned city-owned buildings in the Crown Heights section into middle-income condominiums.

title: SHUANA REDFORD MARRIED IN UTAH
description: Shauna Jean Redford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Redford, and Eric Matthew Schlosser were married yesterday on the lawn of her parents' home in Provo, Utah. The ceremony was performed by Justice Michael D. Zimmerman of the Utah State Supreme Court, who was assisted by Ted Wilson, the former Mayor of Salt Lake City.

title: A License to Drive
description: I WAS SPEAKING WITH MY SON JESSE OVER THE telephone. He's 15 and lives with his mother and her new husband 120 miles north, in the Catskills. It was Friday evening. I asked him what he'd done that afternoon.

title: THE FEELING OF BEING THERE
description: On Nov. 23, 1936, Life magazine was introduced, and with it a new kind of photography called photojournalism. With its cinema verite look of realism, this new technique soon attracted a tremendous audience.

title: ON THE OUTSIDE, LOOKING FOR AN IN
description: FOR many years now, my husband and I, two longtime New Yorkers, have been infiltrating the city of New Rochelle. The place we picked out as our more or less permanent special spot is Hudson Park, a lovely beachfront area with a view of the many boats sailing Long Island Sound.

title: COLLINGWOOD SERVICE IS SET
description: A private memorial service for the CBS News correspondent Charles Collingwood, who died of cancer Thursday, is to be held at 3 P.M. Wednesday at Saint Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, at 109 East 50th Street, network officials said. Mr. Collingwood, who was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan, died at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: GREENPEACE SHIP REACHES TEST SITE
description: The Greenpeace flagship has arrived off the coast of the French nuclear test site in the South Pacific, where it joined another protest ship from the organization.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'EXPO '85'

title: FAMILY MARKETING SAIL CRAFT
description: ON recent weekends, the first Essex 14, a new 14-foot sailing dinghy, has shared a tiny section of the limelight with her larger, more luxurious and far more expensive sisters at boat shows in Newport, R.I., and Stamford.

title: WAVE OF ARAB MIGRATION ENDING WITH OIL BOOM
description: More than a million migrant Arabs working in countries throughout the Middle East are being forced to return home, in large part because of the end of the decadelong oil boom.

title: What Buyers Should Ask
description: THE prospective buyer of a cooperative apartment should investigate the co-op thoroughly before signing a purchase agreement. The co-op's finances, operational policies and physical facilities will have a significant impact on the value of the apartment investment and its use and enjoyment for the purchaser.

title: BEAUTIFUL WOOD, FUNCTIONAL FORMS
description: THE objects created by Laurence Hendricks, a wood designer and craftsman from Warren, point out that the saying ''form follows function'' is not always true. For the 47-year-old designer, what a thing does and what it looks like are inseparable. His art is functional; you can sit on it, read from it, play games on its surfaces, rock your children in it, entertain friends from it and even lean on it in your old age - without sacrificing esthetics.

title: DISASTER RELIEF: MANY QUESTIONS
description: THE initial damage assessments from Hurricane Gloria's encounter with Long Island last week -which downed power lines, trees and caused massive power failures - are now pouring into Washington. Governor Cuomo has told the White House he would ask President Reagan to declare all or part of Long Island a disaster area, making local residents, businesses and municipalities eligible for Federal relief funds.

title: TOKYO STEPS UP EFFORTS TO PLACATE CONGRESS
description: A delegation of senior ruling-party members left for the United States this weekend carrying the latest list of proposed Japanese actions intended to fend off protectionist legislation in Washington.

title: NEW YORK CITY S.A.T. SCORES RISE BUT TRAIL STATE AVERAGES
description: The average scores of New York City public high school students taking the Scholastic Aptitude Test rose slightly last year, but both the rate of increase and the scores themselves lagged behind the national and state averages.

title: The Episcopalians
description: Mr. Wilkes did his homework on ''A Church in Search of Itself,'' but by describing A Christian Ministry Among Jewish People (C.M.J.) as ''a fundamentalist group bent on converting Jews to Christianity,'' he oversimplified a historic work in the Anglican communion with 176 years of ministry worldwide.

title: CABLE TV
description: One of the joys of cable is the reappearance of a good, shelved movie. The new week offers quite a few.

title: WHAT THE COUNTRY STANDS TO WIN - AND LOSEDAVE DURENBERGER: 'FAIRNESS WOULD GO OUT THE WINDOW'
description: CALIFORNIA rrbecame the 20th state with a lottery last week. Potentially, at least, the nation's largest state may have its richest lottery, with gross revenue expected to hit $1.4 billion in the first year. As in many other states, part of the profit will go to public schools. Some members of Congress, looking with envy upon the states' revenue jackpot, have pushed for a national lottery, and a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs held a hearing on lotteries last year. Robert Pear of The Times Washington bCALIFORNIA rrbecame the 20th state with a lottery last week. Potentially, at least, the nation's largest state may have its richest lottery, with gross revenue expected to hit $1.4 billion in the first year. As in many other states, part of the profit will go to public schools. Some members of Congress, looking with envy upon the states' revenue jackpot, have pushed for a national lottery, and a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs held a hearing on lotteries last year. Robert Pear of The Times Washington b Question. Why do you think a national lottery is unwise?

title: Sherman Beychok, 54; Columbia Biochemist
description: Dr. Sherman Beychok, a Columbia University biochemist active in research on the principal blood protein hemoglobin, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MARC P. GOODRICH IS WED TO KATHRYN ANNE MARIANI
description: At St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, L.I., yesterday Kathryn Anne Mariani and Marc P. Goodrich, graduates of the University of Dayton, were married by Msgr.

title:
AROUND THE NATION;

Philadelphia: Living at Downtown Crossroads
description: A DISTINCTIVE landmark in city living for a fortunate few'' is the line being used to sell Abbotts Square, and the developers of the 162-unit condominium on the border of Philadelphia's exclusive Society Hill neighborhood are trying hard to bring that spirit to life in their building.

title: Triumphs of Socialist Realism
description: Correspondents from The New York Times report on their local subways, from the chandeliers of Moscow to the Aztec temple of Mexico.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: TALK to Anne Meara about diets and all she can think about is eating. In fact, it doesn't take much to separate Miss Meara and her good intentions, just good pasta, some bread to sop up the sauce, white or dark chocolate and maybe some hot fudge sauce over ice cream with a dollop of butterscotch thrown in.

title: Jerusalem Pair Slain; Palestinians Suspected
description: Two Israelis, missing since Wednesday, were found shot dead today near Jerusalem, a police spokesman said.

title: BEST SELLER
description: Oct. 6, 1985 Fiction

title: KNICKS' CARTWRIGHT TO MISS 2 WEEKS
description: While Patrick Ewing was the center of attention Friday night in his professional debut with the Knicks, Bill Cartwright became the center of concern.

title: 13 Reported Killed in Clashes Between 2 Main Ghana Tribes
description: Weeklong tribal fighting has left 13 dead and many wounded in northeastern Ghana, according to radio reports today from Accra, the capital.

title: MISS ORESMAN, BANKER, IS WED
description: Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Wilton, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Deborah Ann Oresman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Oresman of Darien, Conn., and Captiva Island, Fla., to Dr. Edward K. Kasper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kasper of Wilton. The Rev. Michael C. Palmer performed the ceremony.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

ANSWERS ON INFANTS
description: ''We call it the 'warm line' - it kind of connotes something comforting,'' said Swee Tay-Maurizio, the head nurse at the obstetrics and gynecology department at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, which along with the nursery department provides a telephone line, 24 hours a day, to help answer questions that parents might have regarding their infants as well as their own status as new parents.

title:
TV VIEW;

DIPPING A TOE IN FAULKNER COUNTRY WITH A BOW TO SOAP OPERA
description: When commercial television executives start talking about a ''literary event,'' duck. That is the kind of project NBC supposedly had in mind when it decided to remake ''The Long Hot Summer,'' a 1958 movie starring Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward, which was very loosely based on the William Faulkner novel, ''The Hamlet.'' The new four-hour version, being broadcast tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M., carefully notes that it, too, is based on the Faulkner work but also discloses another, more influential source: the 1958 screenplay by Irving Ravetch and Harriet Frank Jr. In the process, as might be expected, any traces of William Faulkner have just about vanished.

title: SAMANTHA SMITH FOUNDATION
description: A nonprofit foundation has been set up in Washington in honor of Samantha Smith, the Maine schoolgirl who traveled to the Soviet Union at its leader's invitation in 1983.

title: ISRAEL'S LONG PURSUIT
description: Israel's precise strike at a P.L.O. base in distant Tunis proved only that its technology is more sophisticated than its diplomacy. The raid killed about 50 Palestinians, which may avenge the murder of 20 Israelis in recent months. But the raid also took a toll in Washington, where American leaders were left sputtering both to condone and to condemn. Such humiliation of the United States does not seem to matter much in Israel's calculations, but it should.

title: VOTE SET ON PORNOGRAPHY
description: Voters of Cambridge will decide next month whether pornography is a form of sex discrimination. The Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled this week that the question must be placed on the Nov. 5 ballot. The measure was proposed by the Women's Alliance Against Pornography, which called pornography ''a systematic practice of exploitation and subordination based on sex which differentially harms women.''

title: DOCTOR IS SHIFTED BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: Dr. Wendy Orr, a district surgeon who revealed widespread police brutality against political detainees, has been given ''other duties'' so that she may no longer enter prisons to see people held under South Africa's state of emergency, according to her father.

title: LOS ANGELES MAYOR ALTERING IMAGE TO RUN FOR GOVERNOR
description: At a Bruce Springsteen concert here a few days ago, who showed up among the rock star's fans but Tom Bradley. It was a novel appearance for the reserved Mayor of Los Angeles, who turned up in his customary business suit.

title: AUDITING APPEALS TO ELDERLY
description: TWICE a week, 67-year-old Mary E. Moore takes a bus from her home in Princeton to New Brunswick, where she walks a block and then boards a second bus to attend a Rutgers University class in jazz theory.

title: PHILHARMONIC: PREY SINGS SCHUBERT
description: THOSE who complain about the predictability of symphony programs in general and those of the New York Philharmonic in particular found solace last week. The Philharmonic's subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday through last night - heard Friday afternoon - consisted of a Schubert-and-Schuman pairing. Not Robert Schumann, mind you, but William Schuman. And not Schubert's ''Unfinished'' Symphony, but versions of some of his best-known songs orchstrated by Reger, Britten, Brahms, Liszt, Webern and Felix Mottl.

title: IN TORONTO, NICE GUYS FINISH FIRST
description: The hand-printed sign in the Blue Jays' clubhouse seemed to tell everything: ''This team was counted out several times by many people, but we did not hear the bell.''

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;

FRESH SAUERKRAUT FROM MAINE
description: It is an institution, one that has been growing slowly but steadily for more than 50 years. No one remembers exactly when Virgil Morse began selling the German-style sauerkraut made on the family farm in Waldoboro in southeastern Maine, but when he was invited to supply the local general store, it turned out to be the start of a thriving small company that is now sauerkraut supplier for nearly the whole state, and mail-order house for sauerkraut addicts from as far away as Florida and California.

title: ANN HERKNESS MARRIES ANTHONY VILLA
description: Ann Morris Herkness, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Herkness of Rydal, Pa., and Anthony Gambrill Villa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Lippencott Villa of Peapack, N.J., were married in Peapack yesterday. The Rev. Michael Alliegro, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Thomas Oates, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Vernon Manor, the home of the bridegroom's grandmother, Mrs. Richard Van Nest Gambrill.

title: REAGAN THE RECITER
description: From time to time, President Reagan has entertained friends and admirers by reciting from memory two of the turn-of-the-century Yukon ballads of Robert W. Service: ''The Shooting of Dan McGrew'' (112 lines) and ''The Cremation of Sam McGee'' (115 lines). Now he has learned with pleasure that two Britons are making a movie based on the McGrew story.

title: REPUBLICANS IN RHODE ISLAND ACTING TO OUST CHIEF JUSTICE
description: Republicans in the Legislature say they will try to oust the censured Chief Justice of the state when the Legislature convenes next year.

title: BRYANT'S RECORD BROKEN
description: The pressure that had been building inside Eddie Robinson was finally released here last night when the 66-year-old head coach, surrounded by hordes of photographers, became the winningest coach in the history of college football.

title: ABRIDGED FROM 17 MILLION WORDS
description: THE INMAN DIARY A Public and Private Confession. Edited by Daniel Aaron. Illustrated. Two volumes. 1,661 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $39.95 until Dec. 31; $50 thereafter.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A REVOLUTIONARY WOMAN. By Sheila Fugard. (Braziller, $14.95.) ''The Coloureds are tainted by the sin of the Europeans, because our ancestors took their women in lust.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BADGER ON THE BARGE And Other Stories. By Janni Howker. 201 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $10.25. (Ages 10 and up) OCTOBER smelled of bonfires, even in Alfred Street. Down by the canal the yellow leaves of the big conker trees flickered and rustled like burning newspapers. In the still canal water black leaves floated on Helen's reflection.'' These evocative words begin Janni Howker's first book, a collection of five stories, set in England, each one a memorable encounter between a young person and an old one.

title: Ticketing The Baron
description: I'm delighted that the world still contains a unique, titled individual who can reply to a police officer's request for his driver's license: ''Don't have one.

title: The Episcopalians
description: As a former Roman Catholic who chose the Episcopal Church as a new spiritual home in the 1970's, I read with interest the article on that church. The Episcopal Church epitomizes, to my mind, the contradictory nature inherent in Christianity and in being human.

title: PROSTITUTION IS BACK, AND PEKING ISN'T HAPPY
description: More than 30 years after the Communist Party claimed to have eradicated prostitution in China, the revival of the practice is causing concern at high levels in Peking.

title: Women's Proletarian Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST GERMANY GAINS DAVIS FINAL
description: When the Festhalle was opened here in 1909, it quickly became a center for exhibitions, trade fairs and entertainment of all kind. Today, it was the scene of controlled but ecstatic jubilation as West Germany clinched a Davis Cup victory over favored Czechoslovakia, and advanced to the final for only the second time in international tennis competition.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: V . . . - MAIL: Letters of a World War II Combat Medic. By Keith Winston. Edited by Sarah Winston. (Algonquin Books, $14.95.) When Pvt. Keith Winston, an elderly soldier at 32, wrote home to his wife during the last year of World War II, he tried to hide the danger and despair he had endured.

title: HOAXER ON PROBATION
description: The Los Angeles policeman who hid a pipe bomb on an Olympic bus during the 1984 Summer Games and then removed it to make him appear to be a hero has been fined $10,000, sentenced to five years' probation and ordered to undergo counseling and to provide 1,500 hours of community service. The defendant, Jimmy Pearson, who resigned from the force after admitting the hoax, had entered a guilty plea in July to a charge of possession of explosives, a felony in California. He could have been sentenced to as long as four years in prison, but in imposing the lighter sentence, Judge Gerald Levie of Superior Court in Los Angeles said that Pearson had had an exemplary nine-year record on the force.

title: U.S. SAID TO URGE MORE ASSITANCE FOR THIRD WORLD
description: The United States today reportedly urged the creation of a $5 billion lending pool to help third world countries. The proposal came at a meeting here of representatives of five major industrialized nations.

title: LAST-MINUTE SCORE GIVES IOWA VICTORY
description: Iowa, the nation's top-ranked team for the first time in 24 years, played exactly like a No. 1 team when put to the test in the final four minutes today against Michigan State.

title: CARDS CLINCH AS TUDOR WINS
description: The scenes were not particularly different from those of other championships in other cities. The champagne was on ice by the sixth inning, and when the game finally ended this afternoon, a normally sedate Midwestern city erupted joyfully. Fans streamed onto the field, music filled the streets and the celebrants toasted themselves in a crowded clubhouse.

title: From Brooklyn to Jersey, an Abundance of Units
description: THE word, in the 1985 New York-area condominium and cooperative apartment market, is supply.

title: Cavour's Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BOYCOTTS BRING CAUTIOUS CONTACTS
description: The bougainvillea has blossomed, sudden and violent. And in the Sundays River valley, around a small, torn town in the Eastern Cape, the orange groves march like legions, somber and green. But there is no peace here, not really. Across the region, where ridges of scrub fall on one another, offering long vistas, a traveler might drive through myriad small towns and say, well, things are quiet enough here. But that would be deceptive.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:When is the best time to visit the Canary Islands for warm and sunny weather? Which island would be more suitable for those who enjoy shopping, night life and restaurants, and are there any casinos? Are passports and immunizations required? - S. M. S., Pittsburgh Answer:The Spanish Canary Islands, which are in the Atlantic off the northwest coast of Africa, have a mild climate the year round with little seasonal change. But November through March, when many vacationers from Northern Europe flock to the islands to escape winter, is the high season. In January the average daily maximum temperature in Santa Cruz on the island of Tenerife is 69 degrees Fahrenheit; the average minimum is 58. In August the corresponding temperatures are 85 and 70. Most of the winter rain, according to an official of the National Tourist Office of Spain, falls in the mountainous interior of the islands and the coasts remain sunny.

title: RESCUING A TUSCAN GARDEN IN BERKSHIRES
description: In 1903, shortly after Edith Wharton wrote her classic, ''Italian Villas and Their Gardens,'' the New York writer turned to adapting what she had learned during six months spent visiting gardens in the Tuscan Hills to her new estate in the Berkshire Hills.

title: A TABLE IN THE FRENCH PROVINCES
description: LA SORBONNE, a sliver of a restaurant recently added to Huntington's dining scene, is a far cry from a student cafeteria, even a French one. It is a serious place drafted along fairly traditional lines that resembles many of the comfortable little French restaurants that dot Manhattan's West Side in the theater district.

title: CATHLEEN HALKO AND U.S. JUDGE EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Cathleen Marie Halko, an associate with the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, and Judge Gregory Wright Carman of the United States Court of International Trade in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Albert Palmer, assisted by the Rev. Bruce Forbes, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: THE RICHES OF MOGUL INDIA BRING A DYNASTY TO LIFE
description: Some years ago, while at high school in Shillong, a hill town in India's remote northeast, I became fascinated by the Mogul Emperor Akbar, arguably the greatest member of the dynasty that ruled the Indian subcontinent from the 16th to the 18th centuries.

title: CATALOGUE TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title:
INVESTING;

THE GROWTH STOCK FUNDS GROW WARY
description: THE managers of many of the nation's growth stock mutual funds are in a bind. They are becoming wary in the face of so many divergent economic indicators, and are finding it harder and harder to uncover the kind of companies whose surging stocks fueled the record-breaking mutual fund performance of the last few years.

title: Boston: As Land Values Soar, The Lure Of the Condo Is No Longer Price
description: ALONG with ease of maintenance, lower cost has always been a selling point for condominiums. When town-house units first became popular about 15 years ago, boosters sold them as a lower-cost alternative for buyers priced out of the single-family-house market by the high costs of land and construction.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE REMARKABLE EXPEDITION: The Story of Stanley's Rescue of Emin Pasha From Equatorial Africa. By Olivia Manning. (Atheneum, $12.95.) In 1887, H. M. Stanley started across Africa from Zanzibar to rescue Emin Pasha, a German appointed by Gen. Charles George (Chinese) Gordon as Governor of Equatoria, a territory near the upper reaches of the White Nile plagued by the the Mahdist uprising, a messianic movement that had isolated the province. The privately financed expedition consisted of ''eight white officers, 623 Zanzibaris, sixty Soudanese armed as soldiers, four Syrians, 13 Somalis . . . stores supplied . . . as an advertisement by different manufacturers . . . and Stanley's Madeira.'' Emin Pasha wished to be left where he was. But Stanley, ambitious for another triumph after finding David Livingstone in 1870 and inspired by the press's fanciful portrayal of Emin Pasha's heroism, was determined to take the man to Cairo, where he feared an obscure end as a pensioned-off civil servant. In the end, Emin Pasha went, no match for the imperious egotist Stanley. He returned in service to the Germans, and was beheaded in the Congo in 1892. In the course of the two-and-a-half-year expedition, 655 people were abandoned along the way, and more than 80 died. After a dense scene-setting introduction, the novelist Olivia Manning launches her wry comedy of imperialism, a complicated tale of frustration, waste and boldness in which she distributes blame and praise evenhandedly, showing each character's absurdities and capacities. Manning, who died in 1980, worked on this book during World War II while undergoing many of the experiences she used to brilliant effect in her books about the Balkans and the Levant.

title: DENG SKEPTICAL ON SOVIET OFFER
description: The Chinese leader, Deng Xiaoping, said today that Mr. Gorbachev's proposal that the United States and the Soviet Union cut their nuclear arsenals by half did not mean substantial change, officials in a West German delegation said.

title: JESSICA LANGE TRIES ON ANOTHER LIFE
description: In ''Sweet Dreams,'' Jessica Lange plays the part of the late Patsy Cline, an ebullient, freewheeling, country-and-western singer, who struts around in calf-high cowboy boots and is unabashedly chunky.

title: THE GLORIOUS WILD RIVERS
description: RIVERS possess people in various ways. To some, a river is a challenge to one's ability as a white-water enthusiast. To others, it is a place where magnificent Atlantic salmon may be caught, or a thoroughfare through the wilderness where one may paddle for days without encountering another human.

title: Business Turns On Apartheid
description: ''There is a better way,'' read the headline on full-page ads in South African newspapers last week. The ads called for an end to apartheid and a beginning of negotiations between the Government and ''acknowledged black leaders.''

title: If St. Ambrose Had a Subway ...
description: Correspondents from The New York Times report on their local subways, from the chandeliers of Moscow to the Aztec temple of Mexico.

title: And in West Germany
description: Frankfurt and more than a dozen other West German cities also suffered last week at the hands of rioters whose main connection appeared to be their youth and, according to the police, their anarchist beliefs.

title:
ART;

4 WINNERS IN A JURIED ART SHOW
description: THE Fine Arts Museum of Long Island in Hempstead credits itself as treating its annual juried exhibition with ''great panache.'' Such hyperbole aside, the show does have features that set it apart from similar offerings by the region's other museums.

title: Man Unearths Male Skeleton While Digging in Queens Yard
description: A man unearthed the skeleton of a young man in the backyard of his mother's Queens home while he was transplanting a stand of rhododendrons, the police said yesterday.

title: House of the Hawaiian Sun
description: Artists and writers recall high points -- from ski school in Japan to a sacred crater in Hawaii, from the Montana Rockies to a novice climb in the French Alps.

title:
GLORIA: THE AFTERMATH OF A HURRICANE;

OFFICIALS SPLIT ON LILCO ROLE
description: AS the Long Island Lighting Company struggled to wire 750,000 customers back into its grid after a hurricane that will be remembered more for its aftermath than for its brief landfall on Long Island, there was wide disagreement among officials last week about how well the utility handled the crisis.

title: 'AS LONG AS SHE SMILES...'
description: ALZHEIMER'S disease, the fourth leading cause of death in America, affects whole families, leaving them with financial, legal and emotional burdens.

title: ANNE MOORE IS MARRIED TO HARRY MASON DENT 3d
description: Anne Moore and Harry Mason Dent 3d were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by the Rev. Ward Patrick Moore, a Roman Catholic priest and cousin of the bride.

title: WHY NOT SET YOUR HAIR ON FIRE?
description: OCTOBER BLOOD By Francine du Plessix Gray. 253 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95. THE peculiar world of high fashion is satirized in Francine du Plessix Gray's new novel, ''October Blood.'' It also sounds a lot like the literal truth.

title: F.B.I. AGENT KILLED IN SHOOTOUT
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, wounded Friday night in a shootout with a robbery suspect, died today.

title: MARY GILLESPIE IS MARRIED TO STUART L. BELL, SALESMAN
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday Mary Virginia Gillespie, a daughter of Virginia Gillespie of Harrison, N.Y., and Peter T. Gillespie of Rye, N.Y., was married to Stuart L. Bell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Bell of Larchmont. The Rev. George Zabriskie performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr.

title: ONE GENE AT A TIME
description: VAULTING AMBITION Sociobiology and the Quest for Human Nature. By Philip Kitcher. 456 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $25.

title: AAGUN I. FONBOE WED TO HERVEY A. CONNELL
description: Aagun Ingrid Fonboe, the daughter of Mrs. Sverre Fonboe of West Islip, L.I., and the late Mr. Fonboe, was married yesterday to Hervey Andre Connell, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. George W. Connell of New York and Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. John O'Leary performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: CONSUMER RATES
New & Noteworthy
description: ON THE BORDER: Portraits of America's Southwestern Frontier, by Tom Miller. (University of Arizona, $7.95.) For Tom Miller the area on both sides of the border between Mexico and the United States is ''a third country,'' with its own customs and its own unwritten laws. He drove along the frontier for four months, reporting for this book. In 1981 our reviewer, Tamar Jacoby, called ''On the Border'' ''a sometimes arch but deftly written book, concerned less with the political issues it raises than with ordinary people's lives. . . . a lively sketch of this unruly, unpredictable place.''

title: NO SAD SONGS
description: THEY are different teams, with different fans and different managements, but never have the New York Mets and the New York Yankees had more in common than in the past week.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Of course there are bloody battles ahead, but the debate is no longer over procedure - it is over the substance of the negotiation.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Failure as a Vocation As Harold Rosenberg said about the painter Barnett Newman, Samuel Beckett works with nothingness as if it were a substance; he makes nothingness exclaim itself. Beckett's remarks on nothingness in art are quoted in ''Dialogue in the Void: Beckett and Giacometti,'' by Matti Megged (Lumen Books).

title: 3 States Warned of Aid Loss Over Speeding by Motorists
description: The Transportation Department has advised three states that they may lose up to 10 percent of their Federal highway money for non-Interstate construction because too many drivers are violating the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit, officials say.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE ELEVENTH SUMMER. By Carlo Gebler. (Dutton, $13.95.) At his grandfather's burial site, Paul guiltily overhears two gravediggers talk: '' 'There's nothing in that coffin that just went down, only a handful of cinders.'

title: KODAK VIDEOTAPE SERIES IS A TEACHING TOOL
description: THE Eastman Kodak Company, which not only makes film and cameras but publishes books and instructional materials about them, has now entered the home-video market with a variety of photographic how-to programs plus a video-tape ''magazine'' about making pictures.

title: Oil Shake-Up In Nigeria
description: Festus Marinho, a two-term managing director of the National Petroleum Corporation of Nigeria, has been retired in a shake-up of the Government organization.

title: Mrs. Heckler Sees 'Vendetta'
description: Margaret M. Heckler said in an interview published Saturday that she had been ousted from her post as Secretary of Health and Human Services because of ''a long-term vendetta by one individual in the White House.''

title: Philippine Army Kills 14 Communist Guerrillas
description: An army anti-insurgency patrol killed at least 14 Communist guerrillas in a gun battle on the southern island of Mindanao, the official Philippine news agency said today.

title: STEVIE WONDER'S MESSAGE
description: ''I am in love,'' said the singsong voice of Stevie Wonder's talking computer.

title: RAISES ARE WELCOME, BUT TEACHERS IN A POOR JERSEY TOWN LONG FOR RESPECT
description: Barbara Shannon measures New Jersey's new $18,500 minimum teacher salary in plates of spaghetti.

title: Datapoint Studies Offer
description: The Datapoint Corporation has retained L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, the investment banking concern, to review a $6-a-share, $100 million leveraged-buyout offer from a management group led by Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier who gained control of the financially troubled computer company last March. Datapoint said its board would not take a position on the offer until the review is completed.

title: Nuclear Plant to Close For Alteration in Jersey
description: The Oyster Creek nuclear generating station will shut down Oct. 18 for electrical modifications to meet new Federal requirements designed to make the industry more accident-resistant, the plant's operator announced.

title: EFFORT TO SAVE A SPECIES: BRIEF CHEER, THEN GLOOM
description: A last-ditch attempt to save the dusky seaside sparrow from extinction has achieved a measure of success in a third generation of cross-breeding, although a director of the project says it is now aimed mostly at educating the public.

title: HOUSTON'S VISION SHIFTS FROM OIL TOWARD ARTS
description: Construction workers topped off a new building on the edge of downtown Houston the other day. That building, more than anything else, represents Houston's new vision of itself, a statement that gives the lie to its image elsewhere as a burly, uncultured oil town.

title: P.R. With Caskets, Bears and Socks
description: Distinguishing oneself from the crowd of attention seekers in this city is a tall order.

title: Legless Samaritan Subdues Would-Be Thief
description: A man who lost both legs when he stepped on a mine in the Vietnam War vaulted from a truck Friday and made his way several hundred feet on his hands to help capture a man who tried to grab an elderly woman's purse.

title: New Strategies For Currency
description: PLAYING the dollar is not what it used to be.

title: THRIVING SEATTLE FINDS FEW ISSUES IN MAYORAL RACE
description: Mayor Charles Royer is seeking election to a third term here in a race against the City Council President, Norman B. Rice, that has centered on the quality of the Mayor's leadership.

title: Save Our Greenmarket
description: To the Editor:

title: Rays of Hope For Computers
description: IT seems to happen every quarter to technology stocks. One company will report disappointing earnings, and investors will take it out on the whole group of high-technology stocks.

title: The Devil and Taxes
description: Should organizations that consider themselves churches but whose members believe in Satanism and witchcraft enjoy the same tax exemption as more widely accepted forms of worship? Some members of Congress have been shocked by the possibility, but Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has confirmed that such exemptions exist and has defended them as consistent with the constitutional right to freedom of speech and religion.

title: Rainbow Quest Wins After Foul
description: Rainbow Quest won the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe today after favored Sagace, who finished first by a neck, was disqualified from first to second for bumping in the last one and a half furlongs.

title: RALLY BY DOLPHINS TOPS STEELERS, 24-20
description: Dan Marino, held in check most of the day by the Steelers, engineered a last-quarter drive that was capped by Lorenzo Hampton's 2-yard touchdown run with 47 seconds left today to give the Miami Dolphins a 24-20 victory over Pittsburgh.

title: Nets Still Hoping For 'New' Dawkins
description: For 10 seasons there have been repeated hopes for the emergence of a ''new'' and ''more productive'' Darryl Dawkins. But after having played for five coaches, the high-spirited center, with a quirky mixture of ferocious talent and irrepressible good humor, has failed to meet expectations.

title: WHY DEBT LIMIT BECOMES VECHICLE FOR LEGISLATION
description: The balanced budget proposal that has kept the Senate in session this weekend is attached to a bill that would increase the nation's debt ceiling by more than $250 billion.

title: 100 Lost in Bangladesh As Two Ships Collide
description: A ferry carrying 200 passengers broke in half and sank after hitting a fishing trawler, and as many as 100 people were missing and feared drowned, a newspaper reported today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 7, 1985: *2*MONDAY *2*None Reported *2*TUESDAY AAR Corp Loral Corp Bank of NY Co Inc Procter & Gamble CBI Indus Inc Standard Motor Chesapeake Corp United Telecom Inc Diversified Energies Weyerhaeuser Co ITT Corp White Consol Indus LeaRonal Inc *2*WEDNESDAY Dayton-Hudson Tokheim Corp PacifiCorp USLife Income Fund Safeway Stores Walgreen Company TECO Energy Inc Woolworth (FW) *2*THURSDAY Centel Corp Owens-Illinois Inc Fleet Fin'l Group Inc Puget Sound Pwr&Lt Ford Motor Co Wisconsin Pub Serv NERCO Inc *2*FRIDAY Aluminum Co Amer Kaufman & Broad Inc

title: Ally Is Back in Shoes As Frye Leaves Bozell
description: In August Ally & Gargano lost the Timberland Shoes account for which it had done some award-winning advertising.

title: CONCERT: WAILERS AND RILEY
description: BOB MARLEY'S band, the Wailers, have reunited to tour with the reggae singer Jimmy Riley. Their concert Friday at the Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 76th Street, reminded listeners how well Marley chose musicians, and how much his songwriting and stage presence are missed.

title: FREE TRADE STIRS DOUBT IN ONTARIO
description: Ontario, Canada's most populous and economically powerful province, is emerging as perhaps the biggest stumbling block to a free trade deal between Washington and Ottawa.

title: SENATORS DECIDE TO POSTPONE VOTE ON BUDGET MOVE
description: The Senate, meeting in an unusual Sunday session, today failed to shut off debate on a proposal to balance the Federal budget by 1991. But the Republican leadership said the vote showed that a bipartisan majority supported the legislation.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Redskins vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Washington, D.C. This is the Cardinals' first appearance on the Monday night game since a boring 20-20 tie with the Giants in 1983. The Cards had a 26-0 lead over Green Bay in the third quarter in their last game and then hung on to win, 43-28.

title: 6 Firebombs Explode In West German Stores
description: Six incendiary bombs exploded in department stores today, the ninth straight day of street battles and violence against the police in West German cities.

title: FILM SHOWS U.S. AFTER TAKEOVER
description: Early next year ABC is scheduled to begin rolling the cameras for a movie that will show United States-Soviet relations through a potentially controversial prism: life in the United States 10 years after a Soviet takeover of the country.

title: SOLITUDE VS. TIME TOGETHER
description: CONFLICTS over how to spend free time are common among successful, career-oriented couples, who may find it difficult to juggle job and home responsibilities, mental-health professionals say. Such couples often end up exhausted and depressed because they feel they do not have enough time for themselves or their mates.

title: Bears, Now 5-0, Top Bucs
description: Walter Payton scored twice today to become the sixth man in National Football League history to score 100 career touchdowns as the Chicago Bears rallied from a 9-point halftime deficit today to beat the Tampa Bay Buccaneers by 27-19.

title: Let Congressmen Earn All They Want
description: To the Editor:

title: REACHING OUT TO UNWED TEEN-AGE FATHERS
description: Being an unmarried teen-age father who is going to school and holding a job has not been easy, says Bryant McCullough, but he looks to the future with confidence and has dreams for his daughter.

title: Bridge: World Championship Book Is 32d in the Annual Series
description: The most valuable source of information about international play is now considerably older than many of the players. The 32d in the annual series of world championship books is now available for $13.95 from the publisher: the American Contract Bridge League, P.O. Box 161192, Memphis, Tenn. 38186.

title: In 2 Days, Coast Lottery Sells 30 Million Tickets
description: California has sold 30 million tickets in the first two days of its new lottery, officials say.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1985
description: International

title: Patricia A. Tine Wed To Philippe C. Dordai
description: Patricia Ann Tine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Tine of Westmont, N.J., was married yesterday to Philippe Charles Dordai, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Augustine Dordai of Phoenix, Md. The Rev. Lawrence Shulmeister, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Maryvale Chapel in Baltimore.

title: 7 DIE AS SMOKE BLINDS MOTORISTS
description: Smoke from a roadside brush fire suddenly blew across Interstate 5 today, causing collisions of 31 vehicles in which seven people were killed and 43 taken to hospitals, the police said.

title: A SEASON OF YOUTH AND CHANGES
description: The following preview was prepared and written by Craig Wolff.

title: Washington Watch;   Natural Gas and 'Block Billing'
description: After sifting some 6,000 pages of comment since it proposed, in May, a major overhaul of its regulations governing the natural gas industry, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is set to vote on Wednesday to put the measures in place.

title: OFFICIALS WHO JOINED G.O.P. LOSE RECALL VOTE IN HONOLULU
description: Despite a radio and television campaign that included President Reagan, Hawaii Republicans lost their brief control of the nine-member Honolulu City Council Saturday when voters recalled three councilmen who had switched parties.

title: Misguided Tampering With Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bullish Showing By City Universities
description: Turning to business news, the S.& P. index of 545 leading academic institutions shows three local names among the dozen most active: N.Y.U. at 2,522, Columbia at 1,883 and C.U.N.Y. at 1,462.

title: ROCK: TEARS FOR FEARS, AT RADIO CITY
description: ''IT'S been on the radio all bloody summer,'' moaned Roland Orzabal, lead singer of the English rock group Tears for Fears. ''We're sick to death of it.'' And with that cheery fanfare, the band launched into a performance of its hit-single pop dirge, ''Shout'' -to rapturous, adulatory applause.

title: RIGHTS COMMITTEE URGES NEW STRATEGIES ON GOALS
description: The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., re-evaluating civil rights strategies for the rest of this decade, has concluded in a report that top priority must be given to ''the urgent plight of underclass blacks.''

title: 'PARK IS MINE,' ON HBO
description: EVEN Home Box Office doesn't seem to be terribly enthusiastic about ''The Park Is Mine,'' this month's new ''premiere film.'' The made-for-cable movie, which had its premiere last night, is being quickly shunted to limbo on the pay-channel's schedule. It can also be seen at 5:10 this morning, 4:15 A.M. Wednesday and 11:30 P.M. next Monday. HBO knows what it is doing. ''The Park Is Mine'' is one of its more pompously silly concoctions.

title: College Editor Ousted Over Ads for Military
description: The editor of Wayne State University's student newspaper has been dismissed for refusing to allow the paper to publish military recruiting advertisements.

title: PURCHASERS SEE UPTURN IN ACTIVITY
description: For the first time in eight months, the economy showed signs of improvement in September, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in a report prepared for release today.

title: A Site for Chrysler-Mitsubishi Seen
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation have called a press conference for Monday, at which they are expected to announce a site for a plant that will produce automobiles in the United States for sale by both companies.

title: OPERA: IN TORONTO, 'HAMLET' FEATURES SUTHERLAND
description: Divas must have their vehicles, and Joan Sutherland picked an unusual one Friday night - ''Hamlet,'' by Ambroise Thomas, a period piece composed in 1868. She had recorded it last year but had never sung it in public. It was the first staged presentation in Canada, and one of the very few anywhere in the last 50 years or so.

title: U.S. DEFENDS ACTION IN U.N. ON RAID
description: The Reagan Administration decided not to veto a Security Council resolution condemning Israel's attack on the P.L.O. in Tunisia after Washington received intelligence warnings that an American veto might lead to the overthrow of the pro-Western Tunisian Government by Libyan-backed mobs, Administration officials said today.

title: De-average Natural Gas Prices
description: Federal regulators propose a bold new pricing plan for natural gas that would reduce waste, create efficient incentives for production and save consumers $5 billion a year. It's in everyone's interest - except the producers, who stand to lose the $5 billion and are lobbying hard against it. Will Congress resist them?

title: NEW YORK SEEKS COMPUTER'S HELP FOR FAST FINGERPRINT INDENTIFICATION
description: As the man forced the woman into a passageway before raping her, he removed a light bulb. In doing so, he left behind a valuable clue - a clear, left thumbprint - that should have quickly resulted in his identification.

title: Judicial Exercise
description: This week marks the fifth anniversary of Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor at the Supreme Court and, concurrently, of the exercise and aerobics classes for women she initiated there.

title: SORROW, AND HINT OF FEAR, AT TRIBUTE TO SKY DIVERS
description: As the late afternoon softened into dusk Saturday, Ted Schobert stood with mixed emotions amid a quiet drift of parked cars and clustered families, facing the little yellow clubhouse of the Georgia Tech Sports Parachute Club and its flag, flying at half staff.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday by United Press International incorrectly reported arrangements for a memorial service for Charles Collingwood, the CBS News correspondent who died Thursday. The 3 P.M. service Wednesday, at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, 109 East 50th Street, is public.

title: CITY REVIEWING ABUSE REPORTS ON FOSTER CARE
description: The Koch administration is reviewing reports of child abuse at five foster-care agencies to determine whether the agencies are adequately protecting children in their care, city officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. PLANS TO QUIT THE WORLD COURT IN POLITICAL CASES
description: President Reagan is moving toward a decision to formally end United States recognition of the World Court's authority in political cases, Administration officials said today.

title: CRIME RATE IS LOWEST IN 12 YEARS
description: The estimated number of crimes in the United States dropped to the lowest level in 12 years in 1984, but the number of rapes, robberies and assaults remained about the same, the Justice Department reported today.

title: AFTER STORM, POWER PLANT IS PRIDE OF A VILLAGE ON L.I.
