description: While Long Island Lighting Company crews were completing the job of restoring electricity to scattered areas of eastern Long Island, workers at the municipal power plant here were basking in the glow of popularity.

title: ADDABBO'S ABSENCE IS SEEN AS DIMINISHING STATE'S INFLUENCE ON CAPITOL HILL
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, the senior member of New York City's Congressional delegation, has been in the hospital since August, and his absence has left a void that some of his colleagues say could affect both New York's influence on Capitol Hill and the course of national defense policy.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising Column on Sept. 23 misstated the single-copy sales of People magazine. They averaged 1.6 million weekly in the first half of this year.

title: Farrakhan Is Not the Voice of Black America
description: To the Editor:

title: 'HONEYMOONERS' ANNIVERSARY SHOW
description: ''THE HONEYMOONERS'

title: The Tests Go On
description: On Oct. 7, l963, little more than a month before his death, President Kennedy signed the Limited Test Ban (L.T.B.) Treaty ending nuclear tests in the atmosphere. Observing the anniversary, a number of officials of the Kennedy Administration have issued a call for President Reagan to join the Soviet Union in its moratorium on underground nuclear testing during the last months of 1985.

title: Jane Sklar Marries
description: Jane Taylor Sklar, a manager of marketing automation for Pan American World Airways, and Dr. Daniel D. Schube, an oral surgeon, were married yesterday at their Manhattan home by Justice Burton B. Roberts of State Supreme Court. The bride is a daughter of Maude Klaber of Rockledge, Fla. Dr. Schube, the son of Lydia Schube of New York and the late Morris Schube, practices in New York and is a clinical associate professor at the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery. Previous marriages for both bride and bridegroom ended in divorce.

title: P.&G. Line of Credit
description: The Procter and & Gamble Company said Friday in a fling with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had obtained commitments for a $1.5 billion line of credit to finance its proposed acquisition of Richardson-Vicks Inc. Procter said a group of six banks, led by Citibank, agreed to lend it the funds on an unsecured basis. Other participating banks are Union Bank of Switzerland, Toronto Dominion Bank, Bankers Trust, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Chemical Bank.

title: 6 FOULS ON EWING, THEN AN OUTBURST
description: No one ever said it was going to be easy for Patrick Ewing to adjust to his new life as a pro. But this afternoon, in the hot and humid gymnasium on the campus of The Citadel, some of the frustrations of that indoctrination caused him to explode.

title: A Birthday Roast
description: Edward P. Morgan, the veteran broadcaster and newsman, will be toasted and roasted at a dinner at the Hotel Pierre in New York Tuesday evening, in observance of his 75th birthday, which actually came June 23. Mr. Morgan worked for United Press, the Chicago Daily News, CBS News and ABC News and is now chief correspondent of ''In the Public Interest,'' a daily 15-minute commentary broadcast on 450 radio stations.

title: Washington Watch;   Selling a Supply Sider
description: Look who has a press agent.

title: The Language Of Foreign Trade
description: The debate rages over United States foreign-trade difficulties. But nobody is talking about the one issue that is more disturbing and far more revealing about the underlying problem than our overvalued dollar, closed foreign markets and the other obvious causes of our stunning trade deficit.

title: Nancy Feins Wed To Dr. D. S. Adler
description: The marriage of Nancy Joy Feins to Dr. Dale Steven Adler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Adler of Beechwood, Ohio, and Hollywood, Fla., took place yesterday at the home in New London, N.H., of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Feins of New London and New York. Rabbi Daniel Epstein officiated.

title: Ex-Steel Chief In Pay Accord
description: Allen E. Paulson, who assumed control of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation last month, has disclosed that he agreed to pay Dennis J. Carney, Wheeling's former chairman, nearly $1.4 million in 15 annual payments beginning next year. Mr. Carney would forfeit the amount if he goes back to work for Wheeling or for ''any business in direct competition,'' Mr. Paulson said. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, Mr. Paulson also said that he would make a $73,710 retirement payment to Mr. Carney and buy about $34,000 in Wheeling stock with an option to buy additional shares before year-end. Mr. Paulson will also indemnify Mr. Carney up to $300,000 for any claims resulting from his employment at Wheeling.

title: THE HOMELESS OF EUROPE: A SCOURGE OF OUR TIME
description: Margaret lives with her husband and six children in a London bed-and-breakfast hotel, not the quaint sort, with chintz in the sitting room, but damp and bug-infested, with the dining room a block away.

title: Rebels Refuse to Resume Talks With Sri Lanka
description: Tamil groups told India today at a meeting in New Delhi that until the lives of Tamils were safe, there was no chance that Sri Lanka peace talks would resume, an Indian news agency said.

title: Flurry of U.S. Sales Expected Soon
description: The only scheduled Treasury financing this week is today's auction of new three- and six-month bills. But government securities dealers expect a flurry of Treasury auctions to be announced as soon as Congress raises the Federal debt ceiling above its current limit of about $1.8 trillion.

title: SYRIANS IN LEBANESE CITY TO GUARD TRUCE
description: Syrian troops entered the northern Lebanese port city of Tripoli today to enforce a cease-fire arranged after 19 days of fighting between rival Moslem militia groups.

title: THE LEGACY OF WESTWAY: LESSONS FROM ITS DEMISE
description: When Westway was declared legally dead last Monday, many of the eulogies also mourned the loss of New York's will to conceive and build great public works. But many planners, officials and urban experts are challenging the perception that the project's demise, by itself, signals a fundamental change in government's capacity to achieve grand projects.

title: OCEAN LIFE, AVIAN LOVE AND REPATTERNED PLATES
description: As South Florida grew, so did its problems. Most were visible as the urban population swelled and crowded the world-famous beaches. Others, like the destruction of offshore reefs, were not.

title: CARDS PROVED SUPERIOR
description: ''From the opening day of the season,'' Dave Johnson was saying, with a mixture of wonder and regret, ''the Cardinals and Mets have been that close: photo finish.

title: YANKS' NIEKRO CHANGES STYLE AND WINS 300TH
description: Having failed four times to reach the elite 300-victory level, Phil Niekro decided for his final attempt of the season today to pursue his goal differently. In an astounding switch in strategy and style, the Yankees' 46-year-old right-hander pitched virtually the entire game without throwing his knuckleball, the pitch for which he is famous.

title: Relearning The Sculptor's Craft
description: Willard Boepple is having his first one-man show at the Acquavella Contemporary Art gallery since December 1981. In between shows, he had to learn how to be a sculptor all over again.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1985
description: International

title: $60 Million Given For Bridge Repairs
description: New York City has been awarded nearly $60 million in Federal funds for the upgrading of three East River bridges.

title: Kimberly Buonato Is Wed To David Harold Friedberg
description: Kimberly Anne Buonato, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Buonato of Weston and New Seabury, Mass., was married yesterday to David Harold Friedberg, a son of A. Alan Friedberg of Boston and Chilmark, Mass., and Natalie Cohen Miller of Wayland and Westport Point, Mass. The ceremony at the Ritz Carlton in Boston was performed by Rabbi Benjamin Z. Rudavsky and witnessed by the Rev. Michael M. Ferrarro, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Mets Lose and Say Goodbye
description: The Mets ended their best season in 16 years yesterday with a 2-1 loss to the Montreal Expos, and with cascades of cheers from the 31,890 fans who went to Shea Stadium for the team's farewell appearance.

title: GOALIE SEARCH
description: DEPTH at forward with the offseason acquisitions of Mark Johnson, Peter McNab and Perry Anderson will be the most noticeable improvement for the Devils in their fourth season in New Jersey.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Mike Rozier played for Nebraska, did he set an N.C.A.A. Division I record for the most touchdowns scored in a career?

title: CBS Names Head Of Record Division
description: Alvin N. Teller has been named president of the CBS Records Division, which is the United States operation of CBS Inc.'s worldwide record business.

title: Kathleen Lynn, a Reporter, Married to Ben Nathanson
description: Kathleen Lynn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lynn of Kings Park, L.I., was married yesterday to Ben Nathanson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Nathanson of Brooklyn. The Rev. T. Peter Ryan, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Elizabeth Williams Fulbright; Wife of Ex-Senator Was 79
description: Elizabeth Williams Fulbright, wife of former Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas, died Saturday at her home here. She was 79 years old. Mrs. Fulbright had been ill for some time, according to her daughter, Roberta Fulbright Foote.

title: ADMINISTRATION IS ADOPTING ASSERTIVE ECONOMIC STANCE
description: Driven by the slowdown in the United States economy and the protectionist movement in Congress, the Reagan Administration has abandoned its international economic policies of more than four years, economists, diplomats and members of the Administration itself report.

title: OUTDOORS: GROUSE AND WOODCOCK ARE IN SEASON
description: FOR the upland bird hunter who is also an angler, this is the time of year in the Northeast that triggers an agony of indecision. In lakes and ponds, trout have stirred from their summer lethargy. Along the coast, some of the season's best fishing for bluefish and striped bass is about to begin. And at the same time, the hunting seasons for ruffed grouse and woodcock are under way or about to start.

title: Mosques to Remove Khomeini's Picture
description: Iran's religious and political leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, has ordered his picture removed from all mosques, the Yugoslav press agency reported today.

title: JAL Crash Agreement
description: Japan Air Lines and the Boeing Company of Seattle will split compensation payments to relatives of the 520 people killed in the worst single plane crash in history, JAL said Saturday.

title: Washington Watch;   Unloading TV Stations
description: There is no hard and fast rule at the Federal Communications Commission on the time purchasers in mergers have to divest themselves of properties in accordance with ownership rules. But some experts feel that the commission may have offered a hint of its current thinking last Friday.

title: POLICE CHIEF DETAILS DEATH BY SHOOTING OF AN F.B.I. AGENT
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who died Saturday was apparently shot by two fellow agents who thought she was the girlfriend of a robbery suspect, Police Chief Ruben Ortega said today.

title: DANCE: BLACK TROUPES
description: THE Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center celebrated an impressive 10th anniversary this past weekend with performances at the Klitgord Auditorium in Brooklyn. Under the direction of Larry Phillips, the tireless impresario of black dance, the center has brought a wide variety of affordable black music and dance programs to the public eye.

title: Too Little Toxic-Waste Data
description: Despite two decades of environmental regulation of toxic substances and thousands of files accumulated about them, Government agencies still cannot answer basic questions about even the most common toxic chemicals used at industrial plants throughout the United States.

title: Empire Chairman Sees Key Role at Piedmont
description: When Paul Quackenbush, the chairman and president of Empire Airlines Inc., was in the Navy as a diver he used the extra hazard pay he received to pay for flying lessons off base. ''I was always interested in flying,'' the 49-year-old founder of Empire said in an interview.

title: How Manila Mocks American Law
description: Affronts to justice in the Philippines have deepened the despair of democrats over the murder of their champion, Benigno Aquino, two years ago. They confirm the cynicism that greeted President Marcos's pledge to pursue and punish the perpetrators. It seems unlikely that those on trial, especially the top general accused of covering up the crime, will be convicted of anything. The Marcos tyranny appears determined to radicalize its opposition.

title: TEAMWORK
description: IT was after another of the Rangers' sorry nights last year that Barry Beck slumped against a wall in a locker room and said, ''No one's helping out each other out there. No one's sticking up for each other. I keep banging my head, but nothing's happening.''

title: ISRAELIS QUESTIONING ACCOUNT OFFERED BY EGYPT IN KILLINGS
description: Israel raised doubts today about Egypt's assertion that a demented policeman was responsible for shooting to death seven Israeli vacationers at a beach on the Sinai coast Saturday. Officials said the gunman may have been an Egyptian soldier, whose presence in the area would violate the 1979 peace treaty.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STAR-STRUCK The American Museum-Hayden Planetarium opened its indoor heavens to the public for the first time just 50 years ago this month. New Yorkers, whose own real sky sights are more often than not obscured by city lights and smog, crowded into the building at 81st Street and Central Park West, on the north side of the American Museum of Natural History. On a clear - or unclear - day or evening, you could see, it seemed, forever, a pristine universe twinkling on the underside of the big dome.

title: EAST ASIA: THE FACE OF ECONOMIC OPTIMISM
description: Cheung Oi Kwan remembers her childhood in a one-room farmhouse in the New Territories of Hong Kong. If you wanted to take a bath, she recalls, you had to trek to a distant public faucet, fill a pail and carry it back.

title: BROWN'S POTKUL GAINS PRAISE
description: In the wind and rain at Providence, Jamie Potkul kept going play after play. When the game was over the 170-pound halfback from Green Brook, N.J., had rushed for 156 yards on 32 carries for Brown in its 17-0 victory over Princeton and once more had earned the praise of Coach John Rosenberg.

title: AFTER PAUSE, SEOUL RENEWS CRACKDOWN ON DISSENT
description: The authoritarian Government of President Chun Doo Hwan has begun a new crackdown on dissidents, with a long string of political arrests, indictments, dismissals and even beatings in the last few months.

title: King Is Victor In British Golf
description: Betsy King of the United States birdied four of the last five holes today to win the $84,000 British Women's Open golf championship by two strokes.

title: Musical Chairs
description: One of Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.'s favorite political mottoes is ''Loyalty is everything,'' and he is expected to exemplify it once more himself when Christine Sullivan, his appointments director and adviser on women's issues for the past nine years, runs for the Massachusetts State Senate in 1986, her first bid for elective office.

title: U.S. MAY BACK HIGHER LENDING BY WORLD BANK
description: The United States told other leading industrial powers today that it might support an increase in funds provided to the World Bank, according to an official at the closed-door meeting. The official asked not to be named.

title: Ecumenical Installation For Boston Bishop
description: The country's largest Episcopal diocese ordained a new Bishop Coadjutor Saturday in an ecumenical ceremony attended by Roman Catholic, Protestant and Greek Orthodox leaders.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Miss Armour Marries Jerome Mandelbaum
description: At Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J., yesterday Deborah Anne Armour, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Armour of Springfield, N.J., was married to Jerome Mandelbaum, the son of Boris Mandelbaum of New York and the late Margery Mandelbaum. Rabbi Israel S. Dresner performed the ceremony.

title: Delaware Marijuana Seizure
description: The police here say they have seized three-quarters of a ton of marijuana from a plane that was forced to land at Greater Wilmington Airport when it began to run out of fuel. Four men who came to unload the drugs were arrested early Saturday by New Castle County officers and Federal agents.

title: ILLEGAL ENTRY BY NON-MEXICANS ON RISE AT BORDER
description: Federal officials say that growing numbers of immigrants from Central and South America, China, Korea, India, Poland and other countries are entering the country illegally across the Mexican border.

title: New Magazine to Go To Physicians at First
description: There is no more popular magazine audience than persons of affluence, which is to be expected. And publications hoping to give advertisers access to big spenders frequently come onto the scene.

title: OSCAR WINNER NOW STARS AS A TEACHER AT BROOKLYN COLLEGE
description: Like all junior faculty members at Brooklyn College, F. Murray Abraham shares an office. And like almost all of them, he leaves his desk littered with letters and manuscripts.

title: Washington Watch;   BANKING BILLS WILT AGAIN
description: BANKING legislation, the perennial hopeful that everyone agrees is needed, has, for all practical purposes, died for this session of Congress.

title: FOR SABERHAGEN, LOOKS ARE DECEIVING
description: He is so young, and so young looking, that the wisp of a blond mustache seems almost deceitful, as if he has grown it to make himself appear more mature, even more imposing. But the ruse doesn't pass. Bret Saberhagen still looks like the kid down the block, not like one of the best starting pitchers in the American League this season.

title: BISHOPS REITERATE CONCERN FOR POOR BUT ADD EMPHASIS ON MIDDLE CLASS
description: In a second draft of a pastoral letter on the United States economy, a committee of Roman Catholic bishops today reaffirmed the conviction that American society must alter its values and act more generously toward the poor.

title: Aspin Sees Little Gain In Buildup of Military
description: President Reagan's military buildup can claim only tiny improvements in United States security, a key Congressman asserted today.

title: MARTIN COMPLAINS ABOUT HIS CONTRACT
description: Billy Martin, manager, became Billy Martin, assistant to the president, after the final game of the season, Billy Martin said today.

title: BLUE JAYS PROVED ELUSIVE
description: BEFORE they arrived in New York to play the Yankees in a possibly pivotal four-game series last month, the Toronto Blue Jays read a newspaper article that quoted Tommy John talking about the problems they would face at Yankee Stadium.

title: SUPREME COURT TACKLES IMPORT AND BANK ISSUES
description: A private antitrust suit charging most of the biggest Japanese color television manufacturers with conspiring to dump products at artificially low prices in the United States will be before the Supreme Court when it begins its new term Monday.

title: Brief Encounter
description: ''Are you going to 93d Street?'' said the voice.

title: AIDS and the New Apartheid
description: Diane McGrath, the Republican candidate for Mayor of New York, has a plan for controlling the spread of AIDS. She would require all doctors, nurses, teachers, food handlers and prostitutes to take the blood test that detects antibody to the AIDS virus, and would bar those testing positive from contact with the public. Their loss of livelihood would be regrettable, Mrs. McGrath says, but people exposed to AIDS are ''a clear and evident menace to the health of their patrons.''

title: Norway Conservatives Have Four More Years
description: To the Editor:

title: New Deputy Governor At Bank of England
description: The announcement last week by the British Government naming George Blunden as future deputy governor of the Bank of England came as a surprise to many in the City. In an unusual move, Mr. Blunden, who is 62, has been brought back from semiretirement to fill the vacancy created when Christopher McMahon decided to become Midland Bank P.L.C.'s chief executive last month.

title: Catching Up
description: Dwight Gooden's season of superlatives made him, among other things, the first Met to lead the National League in earned run average since Craig Swan posted a 2.43 e.r.a. in 1978. Whatever happened to Swan? Well, having struggled with a series of arm problems that proved to be career-shortening, and having been waived by the Mets in May last year, he finished the season with the California Angels but failed to make their roster this spring.

title: Seaver: '86 Met or Yank
description: ONE way or another, Tom Seaver will be wearing a New York baseball uniform next season. But now that his age finally will match his number when he turns 41 next month, will he be a Met again, or a Yankee?

title: CUP CLASSIC LOOMS AS CHAMPION TEST
description: Critics who complain that the rich, new Breeders' Cup races harm the sport by detracting from traditional major events were proved both right and wrong at Belmont Park this weekend.

title: WHY NOT DO AS WE SAY?
description: ''They should deal with the African National Congress.''

title: 'PRIVATE CONVERSATIONS,' ON FILMING OF 'SALESMAN'
description: CHRISTIAN BLACKWOOD'S ''Private Conversations,'' which will be shown in the New York Film Festival today at 6:15 P.M. and next Saturday at 9 P.M., has something of the manner of an authorized biography to it. The movie is an on-set record of the filming (for television) of the hit Broadway revival of Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman'' starring Dustin Hoffman.

title: Joan B. Munves Becomes a Bride
description: Joan Barbara Munves, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Munves Jr. of New York, and Philip George Boening, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence P. Boening of Valley Stream, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner performed the ceremony at 1A East 77th Street.

title: Koch Sets Mark For 400 Meters
description: Marita Koch of East Germany shattered the 400-meter record with a clocking of 47.60 seconds today, and her country's 400-meter relay team set a world record in the World Cup track and field meet.

title: BANKERS HAIL MONETARY SHIFT BY U.S.
description: Bankers attending the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund here are expressing enthusiastic support for the more active and pragmatic role they see the United States playing in the administration of the international monetary system.

title: LATIN DEBT STRATEGY ASSESSED
description: When Argentina's new Government decided last year that growth rather than recession was the answer to its debt crisis, the International Monetary Fund, commercial banks and even other regional debtor nations warned sternly that it was mistaken.

title: Thrift Plan In Maryland
description: A plan to allow out-of-state banks to buy Maryland savings and loan associations and convert them to commercial banks will be presented to the legislature later this month, Gov. Harry R. Hughes said Friday. Two New York banks, Chase Manhattan and Citicorp, are negotiating to purchase four Maryland thrift units, but a final agreement has not been reached in either case.

title: 'Signals Mixed' for Rates
description: A heavier-than-normal supply of Treasury notes and bonds over the next month could cause interest rates to rise, but credit market analysts are deeply divided about whether an increase in rates could be sustained in coming months.

title: Yarborough Wins
description: Cale Yarborough came from one lap down to take the lead with 45 laps left and won the Miller 500 at Charlotte Motor Speedway today, while Bill Elliott finished second and gained some ground in the national championship battle.

title: EDWARD SCHNEIDER
description: Edward Schneider, a vice president and former director of international relations for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, died of a heart attack last Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

title: COMPUTERS BRIDGING GAP FOR SCHOOLS IN MICHIGAN
description: Children in parochial schools in Grand Rapids, Mich., who need extra help in reading and mathematics are getting it this year from personal computers hooked to their home television sets.

title: KENNEDY CENTER HONORS STEVENS
description: Leonard Bernstein read a poem he had written, and Mstislav Rostropovich gulped a tumbler of vodka in a toast as the political, musical and business communities of Washington and New York celebrated the 75th birthday of Roger L. Stevens, chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: CUOMO SAYS FARRAKHAN ADVOCATES 'UGLY' IDEAS
description: Governor Cuomo condemned the Black Muslim minister Louis Farrakhan yesterday as an advocate of ideas that are ''ugly and divisive and wrong and hateful.'' He said he was gratified that black leaders and many people in the black community had rejected Mr. Farrakhan's message.

title: Nuclear Plants' Operating Cost
description: The cost of operating and maintaining a nuclear power plant jumped 22 percent last year, according to a study by a consulting group based here. Over all, it found, running a reactor now costs roughly the same as running a coal plant.

title: Deborah Coward and Alexius Goschl Are Married
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday Deborah Albrecht Coward, a daughter of Editha Albrecht Coward of Bedford and the late Howard S. Coward, was married to Alexius Peter Carl Goschl, a son of Melanie Goschl of Vienna and the late Carl Peter Goschl. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley and the Rev. Dr. Arthur W. Hargate performed the ceremony.

title: FOR BUSTLING NEWARK AIRPORT, EXPANSION AND CONGESTION
description: George E. Roberts, chief of terminal services at Newark International Airport, scanned the network of roads threading the fast-growing air hub.

title: 3 Are Lost as Boat Capsizes in Sound
description: One New York City man drowned and two others were missing and presumed dead after their 19-foot light motorboat capsized in the Long Island Sound, the Coast Guard said today.

title: Peru Bans 217 Import Items
description: Peru's two-month-old Government has announced an import ban on 217 types of products in a bid to conserve foreign reserves and has stated that it would adopt fresh policies to tackle inflation.

title: POLICEMAN KILLED IN LONDON BATTLE WITH RIOTING MOB
description: Hundreds of rioters armed with shotguns, gasoline bombs and bricks fought with 500 police officers in north London on Sunday night. One officer was killed and at least 72 people, including 54 police officers, were wounded.

title: BANK HEAD PUSHED POLICY OF GROWTH
description: Should stockholders of the World Bank accept new ideas from the United States for a bigger role in the debt crisis, they will find themselves leaning on an open door.

title: SEARS, AT 99 PLUS, IS TAKING STOCK
description: When Edward A. Brennan becomes chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company on Jan. 1, he will preside over one of the nation's largest birthday parties.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from San Antonio on Tuesday, about the trial of a nursing home corporation and its top management on charges arising from the death of a patient, misidentified the courthouse involved. It is the John H. Wood Jr. Courthouse.

title: GODARD'S 'HAIL MARY'
description: OTHER people can decide -each according to his or her beliefs - if Jean-Luc Godard's ''Hail Mary'' is blasphemous, as has been charged by a number of people, including a number of people who haven't seen it. This much is certain: The controversy will probably sell a lot more tickets than is warranted by the comparatively solemn, unsensational nature of the film itself.

title: Prost Takes Title
description: A hard-fought fourth place in the European Grand Prix today gave Alain Prost the 1985 world driving championship after two years as runner-up. A crowd of 80,000 at the Brands Hatch circuit near London cheered Prost as loudly as they did their hometown favorite, Nigel Mansell, who got his first Grand Prix victory in 72 starts.

title: EVEN PROGRESS
description: With the exception of two Finnish newcomers whose roles are so uncertain they might not even make the team, the Islanders have virtually the same personnel as last season. But they are experiencing some difficulty at left wing.

title: COMPUTERS RESHAPE MARKETS
description: A Wall Street lunch, five years from now, may consist of soup, steak, a 5,000-share trade and dessert, in that order.

title: UNDER MOSCOW SUN, GIRLS TRY SASHA'S SKATEBOARD
description: It was an Indian summer Sunday in Moscow. After weeks of unusually cold, rainy weather, even by Moscow standards, the sun took charge today. The gentle, warm breeze seemed to soften the hard edges of the Soviet capital.

title: Misguided Tampering With Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MASTERS OF ATLANTIS. By Charles Portis. 248 pages. Knopf. $15.95.

title: 2 STUDIES SHOW GROWTH IN CLERICAL JOBS SLOWING
description: The growth rate for clerical jobs, the largest segment of the work force, is beginning to slow down for the first time in more than two decades, according to an unpublished study by the Labor Department.

title: MCFARLANE CONTENDS SOVIET PLAN INCREASES 'FIRST STRIKE' THREAT
description: The Soviet Union's proposal for a 50 percent cut in strategic nuclear weapons would increase Moscow's ability to launch a ''first strike'' on American missiles, Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser, said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline of a chart in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly described the sales trend for Harley-Davidson motorcycles. Sales improved in 1984, a year after tariffs on imported large motorcycles were imposed.

title: ROBINSON THANKS HIS PLAYERS
description: The deed had finally been done. His players had delivered the torch, and with a mighty effort, had helped their coach fulfill an ambition that he had had before any of them were born.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I would trade this in for a game today that meant something in the pennant race.'' - Phil Niekro, Yankee pitcher, after winning 300th game. [C4:4.]

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRATS WIN IN PORTUGAL
description: The Socialist Party of Prime Minister Mario Soares was defeated in parliamentary elections on Sunday by its former partners, the centrist Social Democrats.

title: INSURER SCREENING UNMARRIED MALES
description: An insurance company has told its underwriters to examine applicants' personal lives and use marital status, age and residence in an attempt to screen out possible AIDS victims.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Culture Shock
description: Georgi Glouchkov, a solidly built 6-foot-8-inch forward from Bulgaria whom the Phoenix Suns drafted on the seventh round this year, has been in training camp for a week now, and although the Suns are sure of his skills, they are not always sure that he understands what they are saying. And vice versa.

title: REMOVAL OF CONVICTS' BRAINS AFTER EXECUTIONS IS STUDIED
description: An investigation is under way into allegations that medical examiners removed parts of brains from executed prisoners and gave them to a researcher without permission of the inmates or their families, the Governor's office said today.

title: Deborah Bell Is Married to Neil Pickett
description: Deborah A. Bell and Neil C. Pickett were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Duggan, her grandparents, in Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. Robinson officiated.

title: AIDS HOT LINE IS BUSY IN CITY
description: What has been the aftermath of the recent barrage of news about AIDS? ''The clear pattern we're seeing is that people are being exposed to this information and seem to be selectively picking out the worrisome news,'' said Susan J. Rosenthal, director of the New York City Health Department's AIDS Hotline.

title: PEN READING STARS WALKER AND MILLER
description: Isaac Bashevis Singer was unable to keep his scheduled appearance on Broadway last night, but the second PEN Celebration went off flawlessly with Arthur Miller and Alice Walker. In separate appearances at the Booth Theater, the playwright and the novelist read from their works and answered questions from an audience that seemed well satisfied with the pairing.

title: COMPOSER-ARRANGER FOR STARS
description: Nelson Riddle, the Oscar-winning composer and arranger who was famed for his work with such stars as Frank Sinatra and Linda Ronstadt died today. He was 64 years old.

title: Double Vision
description: If Paul O'Connor, the first-year football coach at North Central College in Naperville, Ill., has been seeing double this season, it's mostly his fault. There are four and a half sets of twins on his team, and O'Connor recruited three of them himself.

title: Waitz Wins Race For the 10th Year
description: Grete Waitz, the Olympic marathon silver medalist, easily beat a fellow-Norwegian, Grete Kirkeberg, by 1 minute 38 seconds today to win a women's 15-kilometer race in Lidingo Island outside Stockholm for the 10th consecutive year.

title: Misguided Tampering With Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Dueling Arenas
description: Rival basketball teams in the region have long tried, of course, to keep up with the University of North Carolina. By all appearances, three cities within the state are trying to do likewise.

title: Dissident Teamsters Press For Vote on Union Officers
description: Amid a chorus of songs, speeches and jibes at the current leadership, a group of dissident teamsters has started a national campaign aimed at giving rank-and-file members the right to elect the union's officers.

title: JETS IMPROVE TO 4-1;   COWBOYS WIN, 30-29
description: The bottom line was that the Dallas Cowboys defeated the Giants, 30-29, tonight in a rare Sunday night National Football League game. In truth, it was more a case of the Giants losing than the Cowboys winning.

title: GOODEN IS BEST IN 3 CATEGORIES
description: Dwight Gooden of the Mets and Don Mattingly of the Yankees ended the baseball season yesterday as the major league leaders in several categories.

title: BOOM AIDS PROVIDERS OF DATA
description: The boom in real-time information has been a bonanza for some companies that provide data, and it has sparked an influx into the business from other kinds of companies.

title: Medieval Historian Becomes President of Williams College
description: Francis C. Oakley, a medieval historian who has taught at Williams College for 24 years, was installed Saturday as president of the 193-year-old liberal arts school.

title: THE WORLD COURT: SNUBBED BY MANY NATIONS
description: By withdrawing from proceedings of the World Court except when it considers them nonpolitical, the Reagan Administration would further weaken the authority of a judicial panel already lacking clear enforcement powers.

title: PHILADELPHIANS' CAREERS AT STAKE AS HEARINGS APPROACH ON POLICE BOMBING
description: With the careers of several senior city officials at stake, a mayoral commission begins public hearings this week into the confrontation in May with the radical group Move.

title: METS HEAR THE WIND
description: THE sound of the applause was still ringing in the Mets' ears Saturday afternoon, minutes after they had been eliminated from the race. They sat around the clubhouse, after one of the most enjoyable nonchampionship seasons a New York team has ever produced, and the realization began to sink in: This team was one day away from being history.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: END OF GENERAL DEBATE -The third and final week of the general debate begins today with speeches by eight nations. Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe was originally scheduled to lead-off the session, but he has postponed his visit to New York until later this month, a spokesman said Friday. Foreign Minister Witness Mangwende will substitute for Mr. Mugabe. The morning lineup also includes the Foreign Ministers of Mongolia, Bahrain and the Dominican Republic. In the afternoon, delegates will hear speeches by representatives of Angola, Southern Yemen, Benin and Sao Tome and Principe.

title: PRESSURE MOUNTING FOR FAUST
description: Notre Dame, having enough problems trying to win while fans and alumni clamor for Coach Gerry Faust to step down, was beaten Saturday on a 77-yard runback of a blocked field-goal attempt just when it appeared the Irish were going to win for a change.

title: Miller Barber Wins by 3 Shots
description: Miller Barber shot a 1-under-par 71 today for a three-stroke victory in the $230,000 Coca-Cola Grandslam golf championship.

title: Detroit's Pressure On Rates
description: PARADE magazine, the Sunday newspaper supplement with 30 million circulation, has gotten a 25-page order from Chevrolet. And that is the best automotive order the publication has ever gotten.

title: Soviet Has No AIDS, Russian Official Says
description: A Soviet Deputy Health Minister said today that there were no recorded cases of the disease AIDS in the Soviet Union and attributed its incidence in the West to dissolute and unnatural sex lives.

title: OPERA: PREMIERE OF 'ANGEL LEVINE'
description: POOR Nathan Manischevitz!

title: FOR WHOM THE BELL TOLLS
description: A Baptist minister, tired of preaching to the converted and getting excuses from the rest of his congregation for not showing up in church, decided to bring in a packed house by directly answering those excuses.

title: 4 SHOT AS MAN RESISTS HOLDUP
description: A man shot four bystanders when he pulled a gun on a group of men trying who were trying to rob him yesterday in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: JETS IMPROVE TO 4-1;   BENGALS ARE BEATEN, 29-20
description: In one of the strangest and sloppiest games of the young season, the Jets continued their winning ways today, defeating the Cincinnati Bengals, 29-20, to stay even with the Miami Dolphins in the division, each with a 4-1 record.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE LANDING IS DUE TODAY ON COAST
description: Officials of the space agency, breaking three days of silence, announced today that the space shuttle Atlantis and its crew of five military officers would land Monday, ending a secret mission for the Department of Defense.

title: HOW TO GAUGE TAX PANEL'S ACTIONS
description: Now that the House Ways and Means Committee has finally begun to vote on specific provisions of tax legislation, dozens of lobbyists are hanging around daily outside the meeting room to pick up the latest scraps of information. When word gets around that the committee has approved some tax break or rejected another, the lobbyists rush to the pay phones to fill in their clients or home offices.

title: OPERA: 'KISMET' CAST CHANGES
description: THE New York City Opera is offering ''Kismet'' six times over four days, making alternating casts somewhat of a necessity. Friday, there were wholesale changes in the major roles. Theodore Baerg, a Canadian baritone, sang the part of Hajj, while Michele McBride, a soprano, became Marsinah, his daughter.

title: Nursing Home Fire Kills 6 in Missouri Town
description: Six residents of a nursing home, ranging in age from 72 to 90, died in a fire that apparently started in a mobile trailer unit and spread to the main facility, the authorities said today.

title: AT U.N. BLACK TIE AND POLITICAL TIES
description: It has been called everything from the greatest party in the world to the world's hardest job. The truth, according to people who have done it and observed it, is that being a United States delegate to the United Nations is really both.

title: People
description: William A. Catlin, Rick C. Evans and Donald B. Lenehan promoted to senior vice presidents at SSC&B: New York.

title: POPULAR FLEA MARKET ORDERED CLOSED
description: For four or five years now, customers have been flocking to the Canal Street Flea Market on weekends, rummaging through old-fashioned jewelry, trying on vintage clothing and playing xylophones.

title: COUNTRY-HOUSE BACKDROP FOR ART SHOW
description: It is a rare entertainment - the architectural equivalent of a play-within-a-play. It is a building-within-a-building, and one is now going up inside the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: REWRITING NATION'S CIVIL RIGHTS POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration, in intensifying its legal attack on affirmative action programs that give preference to blacks, has altered the Government's definition of racial discrimination.

title: Flag Flurries
description: The Jets' game at Cincinnati on Sunday almost drowned in a sea of yellow flags, but the clubs' combined total of being penalized 29 times did not approach the National Football league record. These were the games with the most penalties in N.F.L. history: 37 penalties - Chicago (16) at Cleveland (21), Nov. 25, 1951. 35 - Seattle (15) at Tampa Bay (20), Oct. 17, 1976. 33 - Brooklyn (22) at Green Bay (11), Sept. 17, 1944.

title: Congress;   Of Women and Women's Issues
description: After Representative Mary Rose Oakar of Ohio was elected secretary of the Democratic caucus in the House earlier this year, she received a call from her predecessor, Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: KEAN AND SHAPIRO OFFER A SHARP CONTRAST ON TV
description: Bold, black typeface fills the television screen, flashing three- and four-letter words: Rip Off, Bull, Now. Those words come at the beginning or end of the television commercials for Peter Shapiro, the Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey.

title: MCA REJECTS LYRICS RATINGS
description: MCA Records has announced that none of its albums would carry the ''Parental Guidance: Explicit Lyrics'' stickers that were recommended by the Recording Industry Association of America, the record-business trade organization. It is the first major label to join a coalition of smaller labels that have refused the labeling, including A&M, Geffen, Island, Gold Mountain and I.R.S. Records.

title: STARS TAKE LANGEVIN
description: Dave Langevin, a member of the Islanders' four Stanley Cup championship teams, yesterday became a former Islander.

title: SCORING OF FIREFIGHTERS' TEST IS ORDERED EASED FOR WOMEN
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday ordered the city to devise a new formula for scoring physical tests for firefighter applicants, saying the present system virtually assures that no women would be selected for the department.

title: Thermal Commercials
description: Polar bears have not been sighted. Snowplows are not on the streets. Ice has not formed along the Lake Ontario shore, only in Maple Leaf Gardens, where the hockey season opens later this week. But tonight the Toronto Blue Jays will be on display against the Kansas City Royals in the opener of the American League championship series. Welcome to baseball's three-hour television commercials for thermal underwear.

title: PUBLISH: CALM REACTION TO DISPUTED AMIS BOOK
description: SIX months after Kingsley Amis's ''Stanley and the Women'' was published to wide praise in Britain, John Gross last January called attention in The New York Times Book Review to the irony that the novel had not been picked up in the United States, when ''in the normal course of events any novel by him would automatically be expected to find an American publisher.'' And Jonathan Clowes, Mr. Amis's literary agent, charged that at least two American houses turned the book down because of feminist pressures within those houses over its unflattering depiction of women.

title: NIGERIA LEADER WARY ON I.M.F. LOAN
description: Nigeria's military leader said today that even though his country needed financial help, he would not accept a $2.4 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund if the Nigerian people opposed it.

title: Essays on Suburbia
description: A collection of 88 short, humorous essays about suburban life by William E. Geist, many of which were first published in The New York Times in the ''About New York'' column, is entitled ''Toward a Safe and Sane Halloween and Other Tales of Suburbia.'' The collection, published by Times Books, covers such subjects as plastic pink flamingos, local government and subdivisions, garage sales, shopping malls, car pools, Tupperware parties and hardware stores.

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in October 1985.

title: Human Contributions To Suffering in Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: ZIMBABWE SAYS IT CAN BEAR JOLT OF PRETORIA CURBS
description: The Foreign Minister of Zimbabwe told the General Assembly today that his country was prepared to accept the consequences that economic sanctions against South Africa would have on Zimbabwe.

title: Smaller Design Of Artificial Heart
description: Researchers at the University of Utah have begun a two-year study of an artificial heart smaller than the Jarvik-7 for implanting in animals weighing as little as 110 pounds, officials said.

title: Easy Way Out
description: How poorly did the Buffalo Bills play in Hank Bullough's debut as head coach? Hear it from the man himself after the 49-17 loss to Indianapolis: ''If I had known it was going to be this bad, we wouldn't have shown up. I'd rather take a fine than a game like this.''

title: 'NOVA' BEGINS WITH A SCIENCE TEST
description: NOVA, the science series on Channel 13, begins this year's programming tonight at 9 with ''The National Science Test II,'' its second try with a game-show format in which ''celebrity panelists'' answer questions and television viewers are invited to do so too. The show has been given some of the gushy patina of a daytime contest. Art Fleming, the host, comes bouncing out, throwing kisses, as the audience applauds. He happily introduces each of the panelists: Edwin Newman, the televison newsman; Alvin Poussaint, a psychiatrist; David Attenborough, the author and naturalist, and Michelle Johnson, an Air Force Captain and Rhodes scholar.

title: DANCE: MAHARAJ TROUPE AT THE ASIA SOCIETY
description: THE evening was billed as a special performance of Kathak from North India. But it could just as well have been called ''the art of Birju Maharaj,'' when Mr. Maharaj and his company of 12 dancers and musicians appeared on Thursday at the Asia Society in a program sponsored by the society and Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, a New York-based cultural organization.

title: A Boy About 10 and 2 Others Rob L.I. Restaurant of $150
description: Three boys, one about 10 years old, held up a fast-food restaurant here today and escaped with $150, the police said.

title: ROSHAN SETH, A STAR DESPITE HIMSELF
description: With the resignation of one who knows his efforts are hopeless, an ineffectual young Englishman has been trying to get a waiter; no one responds to his shouts. Suddenly a famous author strides into the room and - pleasantly but with the authority of a man who cannot imagine his command going unmet - says, ''Waiter.'' Instantly three waiters appear. Such is the audience's introduction to Victor Mehta, the celebrated Indian writer in David Hare's new play, ''A Map of the World.'' Brilliant, sophisticated and so charming his arrogance seems irresistible rather than insufferable, Mehta is an expatriate Indian who has returned to Bombay for a Unesco conference on poverty at which he - despite his controversial right-wing views - is the keynote speaker.

title: King's Explanation
description: The lawyer for the boxing promoter Don King and his secretary, both accused of tax evasion, acknowledged yesterday that not enough taxes were paid but said the underpayment was not the fault of King or his secretary. King, 54 years old, and Constance Harper, 52, vice president of Don King Productions, are accused of taking $1 million in boxing revenues without reporting it to the Internal Revenue Service. In opening arguments in United States District Court in Manhattan, Assistant United States Attorney Roanne Mann said that King and Miss Harper deliberately did not report advances, some as high as $70,000, on prize-fight contracts, reporting only a single lump sum after a fight.

title: RETICENCE AND FOREIGN POLICY
description: One year ago Secretary of State George P. Shultz was unabashedly recommending that the Reagan Administration take lessons from Israel in using force to strike back at terrorism.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN STUDENTS RIOT
description: Mixed-race youths hurled gasoline bombs and stones and set fire to barricades of tires today as a school boycott in Cape Province gained new momentum.

title: JAILED PALESTINIANS: HUNDREDS HELD
description: Despite the release of 1,150 convicted Palestinian guerrillas and other prisoners by Israel in May as part of an exchange for three Israeli prisoners of war captured in Lebanon, hundreds of Palestinians remain in Israeli jails.

title: FARRAKHAN SAYS HIS CRITICS ADD 'FUEL TO THE FIRE'
description: Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim minister, electrified an overflow crowd of 25,000 at Madison Square Garden last night with a message of economic and spiritual renewal coupled with a ringing denunciation of his critics.

title: Redskins Defeat Cardinals by 27-10
description: Faced with the prospect of falling into the far reaches of their division with another loss, the Washington Redskins returned to the familiar form of more successful times tonight.

title: MISKITO SAYS U.S. BLOCKS UNITY
description: Brooklyn Rivera, a member of Nicaragua's splintered Miskito Indian leadership, said today that the Reagan Administration was blocking Miskito unity because it wanted a group it could control.

title: ROCK: YANKOVIC
description: TOP 40 rock songs are pretty funny in themselves, but the accordionist-singer Weird Al Yankovic pushes them even further, writing parody lyrics and, now, making parody video clips. His concert Saturday at the Beacon Theater spoofed hits, from Madonna to reggae; even the souvenir T-shirts announced tour dates at bar mitzvahs and truck stops.

title: APPLE GIVES ITS MACINTOSH A HARD DISK
description: APPLE has finally introduced its own hard disk drive for the Macintosh, the aptly named Hard Disk 20 (it holds 20 megabytes - 20 million characters - of data, roughly the equivalent of 12,000 double-spaced, typewritten pages). That may seem a lot, but hard disks work just like attics: as more space becomes available, more junk materializes to fill it.

title: HIGH COURT AGREES TO REVIEW AFFIRMATIVE ACTION CASES AS IT BEGINS TERM
description: The Supreme Court, opening its new term, set the stage today for a broad review of court-ordered affirmative action plans that the Reagan Administration contends discriminate against whites.

title: CLUES TO SUICIDE: A BRAIN CHEMICAL IS IMPLICATED
description: THE anguish that leads to suicide seems to follow no set path. But researchers believe they are making important progress toward understanding that painful process.

title: Writer Wins Delay in Term
description: A freelance writer today won a delay in starting a 10-day jail term imposed last month after he refused to surrender a tape at a hearing in connection with the death of John Belushi. The writer, Christopher Van Ness, is said to have tape-recorded an interview with Cathy Evelyn Smith, who is charged with second-degree murder, in which she admitted injecting the comedian with heroin and cocaine. Mr. Van Ness appealed a contempt order and Judge Robert R. Devich of Superior Court delayed the jail sentence until at least Wednesday.

title: All 53 Finalists Named Opera Contest Winners
description: All 53 finalists at the second Opera Company of Philadelphia-Luciano Pavarotti International Voice Competition have been named winners and will be asked to perform with the Philadelphia company.

title: Son in New Jersey Awaiting Word From Parents on Cruise
description: Robert Kantor waited anxiously by his telephone early today, hoping his parents would call to say they were safe ashore in Cairo and not aboard a hijacked Italian ocean liner.

title: Swimming Without Tails
description: Bacteria that swim swiftly with no visible means of locomotion have been identified in a number of marine environments. They belong to the class of organisms known as cyanobacteria or blue-green algae.

title: Tackling Apartheid From the Inside
description: Defenders of the status quo in South Africa have resorted to the convenient fiction that the unyielding resistance of the white electorate prevents Pretoria from abolishing apartheid. In fact, the Government actually trails white opinion rather than being constrained by it. Public opinion polls indicate that roughly 70 percent of English-speaking whites and 40 percent of Afrikaners - or a slight majority of the white population - would support a unified South Africa with a universal franchise and a multiracial parliament. They would also back the elimination of such essential elements of apartheid as pass laws and influx controls, which separate blacks from their families.

title: Dickey's Return Seen
description: The Packers received good news yesterday when X-rays disclosed that the injured thumb of the quarterback Lynn Dickey was not broken. Coach Forrest Gregg said the thumb on his passing hand that Dickey injured Sunday while leading the Packers to a 43-10 victory over the Lions was tender, but there was no swelling. Gregg said he expected Dickey to play next Sunday against the Vikings.

title: 11 ARE ACCUSED IN FATAL BLAZES AT BETTING SITES
description: Eleven men have been arrested and accused of setting 20 fires in rival betting parlors that killed eight people and injured six others, authorities announced yesterday. They said the crimes had been ordered by a group of Cuban-American racketeers.

title: 'UNFINISHED BUSINESS,' ABOUT JAPANESE-AMERICAN INTERNMENT
description: MORE than 110,000 American citizens of Japanese ancestry were uprooted from their homes, farms, professions and businesses in the spring of 1942 and placed behind barbed wire in relocation camps in a half-dozen Western states. Without hearings or trials, men, women and children were evacuated under Executive Order 9066 because they were considered possible spies or saboteurs in wartime. After the surprise bombing of Pearl Harbor, Government officials and military commanders thought that California itself might be vulnerable to attack.

title: PEACE CORPS: 25 YEARS' CARE FOR A WORLD
description: At the University of Michigan, where John F. Kennedy asked students 25 years ago if they would be willing to dedicate a part of their lives to serving their country abroad, the anniversary of the idea that grew into the Peace Corps was celebrated today.

title: ROYALS AND JAYS SEEM EVENLY MATCHED
description: On occasional moments, Dick Howser will allow himself to smile at the unfortunate realization that he has been a manager three times in the postseason but has never won a game.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ, ETC.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: NEW ARRIVALS - The second wave of the parade of world leaders begins early today with the arrival of the Prime Minister of the southwest Pacific island nation of Vanuatu, the Rev. Walter H. Lini. Father Lini was scheduled to arrive at about 6 A.M., after a 28-hour trip that took him from Vanuatu to New York, with stops in Fiji, Honolulu and Los Angeles.

title: WHITE, MCCARVER BIG PLUS FOR VIEWERS
description: Yes, it's true that the St. Louis Cardinals kept New York from a division championship this year, but it's not as though St. Louis only takes. After all, New York baseball fans can thank the Cardinals for Bill White and Tim McCarver.

title: NATO CHIEF WELCOMES SOVIET PROPOSALS
description: Lord Carrington, the Secretary General of NATO, said today that the latest Soviet arms control plan was ''greatly to be welcomed'' even though he said the specific proposals were clearly unacceptable.

title: ORCHESTRATED SINATRA SONGS
description: Nelson Riddle, a composer and arranger best known for his song orchestrations for Frank Sinatra and Linda Ronstadt, among others, died of cardiac and kidney failure Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 64 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: BERNARD BECKERMAN, 64, SHAKESPEARE SCHOLAR
description: Bernard Beckerman, the Brander Matthews Professor of Dramatic Literature at Columbia University and a noted Shakespeare scholar, died of a heart attack yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: Ship Carrying 400 Seized
description: ROME, Tuesday, Oct. 8 - Heavily armed men hijacked an Italian cruise ship with more than 400 people aboard in the Mediterranean on Monday and demanded the release of 50 Palestinians from Israeli prisons.

title: OREGON PAPER CITED BY JUDGE
description: A judge today cited The Oregonian for contempt for its refusal to turn over subpoenaed photographs, and ordered the newspaper's executive editor, William Hilliard, jailed unless an appeal is filed.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Kansas City at Toronto, Game One of the four-of-seven-game American League championship series. This is the first year that the championship series will be expanded in both leagues.

title: GROSS OFFERS NO OPINION ON WHAT KILLED STEWART
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, testified yesterday that, based on his autopsy findings, he now has no opinion on the cause of Michael Stewart's death.

title: PIRATES WILL REPLACE TANNER
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates today dismissed Manager Chuck Tanner, who had been with the club for nine years, as part of a shakeup that will put a partnership of local government and private business in control of the team.

title: U.S. SET TO SHIP NUCLEAR WASTES IN CITY'S STREETS
description: The Brookhaven National Laboratory will resume trucking spent nuclear fuel from its Long Island research reactor through New York City later this week, Federal officials told members of New York's Congressional delegation today.

title: Bridge: Weak Two-Bid Has Power To Confuse the Opponents
description: A major advantage of the weak two-bid is that the opponents may have trouble in gauging their combined strength, especially when the next player doubles for takeout. A suit response at the three-level has a wide range, and the doubler often has to guess when to continue.

title: Housing Aid Program Is Proposed by O'Neill
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today outlined a $183 million housing program to provide low-interest mortgages and new housing for low-income residents.

title: OHIOAN'S 'MEA CUPA' IS FIRST ON THE DOCKET
description: Christopher D. Stanley arrived from Cleveland, checked into the Quality Inn and got through Sunday night anxiety on the strength of ''massive denial'' that he faced the burden of arising on this first Monday in October and arguing before the United States Supreme Court.

title: Rehnquist's Share In a Meese Position
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Books: On Apartheid
description: MOVE YOUR SHADOW. By Joseph Lelyveld. 389 pages. Times Books. $18.95. THE other day I was crossing Harvard Yard with the esteemed botanist Richard Evans Schultes, a vigorous man in his seventies who has spent years collecting plant specimens in the jungles of South America. When we came upon a group of undergraduate specimens carrying banners that said ''Divest Now,'' Mr. Schultes gave them a stare that stopped them in their tracks and boomed out five words: ''Why don't you grow up?''

title: EAGLES NAME JAWORSKI AS STARTER AGAIN
description: The Philadelphia Eagles, whose 1-4 record clearly reflects their offensive ineptitude, took two steps yesterday in an attempt to change the pattern.

title: Ex-Legislator Guilty in Killing
description: A former state Representative, Gregory Reed, of St. Johnsbury, pleaded guilty today to charges stemming from the 1984 killing of Rene Savage Jr. Mr. Reed, 32 years old, had previously pleaded not guilty to first-degree murder and arson. He and James Rivers, 22, were accused of killing Mr. Savage, 20, to keep him from talking to the police about an arson in St. Johnsbury. o

title: P.L.O. AIDE DESCRIBES THE HIJACKERS
description: A senior member of the Palestine Liberation Organization said yesterday that the gunmen who hijacked the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro belonged to a new, small Palestinian guerrilla group composed of residents of the Sabra and Shatila refugee districts in Lebanon.

title: COLUMBIA PLANS TO SELL BY '87 STOCK LINKED TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: Columbia University's board of trustees voted yesterday to sell, ''in an orderly way'' over the next two years, virtually all of the university's $39 million in stock in American companies doing business in South Africa.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Elusive Lenin
description: President Reagan was asked the other day if he still thought the Soviet Union was an evil empire. Yes, he told Ted Koppel of ABC, because of things like the downing of a South Korean airliner in Soviet airspace. Moreover, he said, Soviet leaders repeatedly proclaimed their global ambition, which is why ''I have often quoted'' Lenin's statement that:

title: Judge Chooses a Jury in Crime-Family Trial
description: A jury of five women and seven men was selected yesterday for the Federal trial of the reputed head of the Gambino organized-crime family and nine others on charges of murder and operating a car-theft ring.

title: CHIEF OF U.N. AGENCY FOR REFUGEES ASKS DONORS TO GIVE MORE MONEY
description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees appealed today for $74 million to help his agency meet a severe budget shortfall.

title: JETS ARE TURNING TIGERS ON DEFENSE
description: The Jets are coming of age. The losing opponent is claiming foul play - and the New Yorkers today seemed to be enjoying the reputation of playing to the edge of the rules - or beyond.

title: HIJACKERS DEMAND RELEASE OF 50 PALESTINIANS IN ISRAEL
description: Heavily armed men hijacked an Italian cruise ship with more than 400 people aboard in the Mediterranean on Monday and demanded the release of 50 Palestinians from Israeli prisons.

title: Giants Get Berenguer
description: The Detroit Tigers traded the pitcher Juan Berenguer and two other players to the San Francisco Giants in a six-player deal. In exchange for Berenguer, a right-handed pitcher, Bob Melvin, a catcher, and a player to be named later, the Tigers obtained the pitcher Dave LaPoint; Matt Nokes, a catcher, and Eric King, a minor league pitcher. The 30-year-old Berenguer had a 5-6 record with an earned run average of 5.59 this season.

title: At Least 25 Horses Die After a Trailer Collapses
description: The floor of a trailer carrying 42 horses collapsed beneath their weight today, and at least 25 horses died after being crushed or dragged beneath the vehicle, the authorities said.

title: ABORTED FETUSES BURIED WITH REAGAN EULOGY
description: A three-year legal dispute over how to dispose of 16,433 aborted fetuses found in a steel bin ended Sunday as the fetuses were given a nonreligious burial with a eulogy written by President Reagan.

title: HOUSE TURNS BACK CUTS IN FOOD STAMP PROGRAM
description: The House of Representatives today defeated several attempts to cut back the cost of the food stamp program and require more recipients of the stamps to go to work.

title: CARLA PEKELIS SEITZ
description: Carla Pekelis Seitz, professor emeritus of Italian at Sarah Lawrence College, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan.

title: MILAN SHOWS BEGIN AFTER PARTIES BY FENDIS
description: The first act of the Italian spring ready-to-wear openings was played in Rome over the weekend. The five sisters who run the Fendi fashion business -Anna, Alda, Carla, Franca and Paola -staged an extravagant celebration there for about 500 guests. It included a museum exhibition, a tour of their fur workrooms, gala lunches and black-tie dinners.

title: Syrian Troops Disarm Moslems in Tripoli
description: Syrian troops moved through Tripoli today, disarming rival Moslem militiamen, and the focus of Lebanon's factional war shifted to a Shiite-Palestinian battle in Beirut's refugee quarters.

title: 122 Years of Emotion
description: With the stroke of a pen yesterday, the name ''Long Island'' was being crossed out on letters sent from the Long Island Historical Society. And the name ''Brooklyn'' was replacing it.

title: U.S. LIMITS ITS ROLE AT COURT IN HAGUE
description: The United States announced today that it was ending its policy of automatic compliance with the decisions of the World Court.

title: U.S. ARGUES FOR TEACHER SKILLS TESTS
description: The Justice Department argued today that a skills test used by the State of Texas for admission to teaching programs was legal, despite a Federal judge's ruling that the test was probably designed to discriminate against members of minority groups.

title: Business Leaders Urge Talks in South Africa
description: South African business leaders today urged negotiations between the Government and black leaders to prevent an intensification of violence.

title: LILCO IS PRAISED BY ITS CHAIRMAN FOR STORM EFFORT
description: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company, Dr. William J. Catacosinos, today praised as ''outstanding'' the utility's performance in preparing for Hurricane Gloria and its response to the damage that knocked out power to 750,000 customers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1985
description: International

title: Colts Drop Schlichter
description: Art Schlichter, who opened the season as the starting quarterback for the Indianapolis Colts, was waived today and Coach Rod Dowhower elevated Matt Kofler to the backup position behind Mike Pagel.

title: Men Won't Be Denied Coverage, Insurer Says
description: An insurance company whose underwriters were asked to identify potential AIDS victims will not automatically deny coverage to men in the high-risk group, a spokesman said today.

title: Naming the Best Of the Best
description: On six occasions during the last two decades, Golf Digest has set out to rank the nation's top courses, but for this year's survey the magazine added a few new wrinkles, the most notable of which is the designation of a single course as the very greatest in the 50 states. And the winner, it turns out, is a venue that is virtually in New York's backyard: Pine Valley Golf Club in Clementon, N.J.

title: BID TO DELAY HEARINGS DENIED
description: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court denied a police union's last-minute request today to postpone hearings scheduled to start Tuesday into the siege of a house occupied by members of the radical group Move that left 11 people dead and 61 homes destroyed. The Fraternal Order of Police argued that the televised hearings before a special city commission could violate the constitutional rights of officers called to testify. The court, however, agreed with an attorney for the commission, who argued that the panel was created as a fact-finding body to advise Mayor W. Wilson Goode and not to accuse individuals of wrongdoing.

title: RITA LAVELLE APPEAL TO HIGH COURT FAILS
description: Rita M. Lavelle, the former Assistant Administratrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in charge of the toxic waste-disposal fund, failed today in an attempt to have the Supreme Court overturn her conviction for lying to Congress.

title: BRITISH RIOT POLICE WILL BE ARMED WITH PLASTIC BULLETS AND TEAR GAS
description: In the aftermath of rioting in the north London district of Tottenham in which a constable was killed, the police warned today that they would be prepared to use plastic bullets and tear gas in future confrontations with rioters.

title: West German Cities Hit By Bomb Blasts
description: Bombs exploded today at a car dealership and a botanical research station in Cologne and a fire bomb went off in a store in Hamburg, the police said. There were no injuries in the attacks.

title: A QUESTION OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS ON S.I.
description: The 34-acre site on Staten Island -strewn with rubble, its piers rotting -hardly seems the center of a controversy involving talk of war and peace and nuclear missiles.

title: A CIRCUMCISION METHOD DRAWS NEW CONCERN
description: Two accidents involving infants who suffered disfiguring burns while undergoing circumcisions at an Atlanta hospital have focused concern on a traumatic modern complication of an ancient surgical procedure.

title: GENETIC MARKER MAY IDENTIFY HEART DISEASE
description: SCIENTISTS in California have discovered a genetic ''marker'' that they believe may help identify people who have a greater than normal risk of developing heart disease.

title: Proposals to Reform the U.N., 'Limping' in its 40th Year
description: For all the champagne and fine words, it should be obvious to friends and foes alike that the United Nations is in trouble and has fallen far short of what its founders dreamed of 40 years ago.

title: BLUE RIDGE REAL ESTATE CO- BIG BOULDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LEONARD SPOOF OF SHERLOCK
description: A new play by Hugh Leonard, ''The Mask of Moriarty,'' a spoof on Sherlock Holmes, has opened at the Dublin Theater Festival to generally favorable reviews.

title: M.T.A. Opposing Tax-Lease Change
description: A proposed change in a Federal tax-leasing program would cause the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to lose $180 million in its major improvement program for buses and subways, the authority's chairman, Robert R. Kiley, warned yesterday.

title: ORGANIC FARMING MOVES TOWARD MAINSTREAM AMERICA
description: To many people, organic farming means overpriced, anemic-looking fruits and vegetables sold in health food stores. But to the staff of the Rodale Research Center here, it is an economic and environmental necessity - a means of assuring the continued production of an adequate food supply at the lowest possible cost to farmers and their land.

title: Alaska's Daring Senators
description: Everyone understands that members of Congress pursue special or local interests that sometimes may not lie wholly within the national interest. But there's a line beyond which a little regional favor-seeking becomes a brazen trial of public patience. Take the case of the Alaska Lumber and Pulp Mill in Sitka, Alaska.

title: NORMAN J. PHILION
description: Norman J. Philion, president of the Air Transport Association, died late Friday of a heart attack, association officials said Saturday. He was 60 years old.

title: MAINE SHIPBUILDERS VOTE TO ACCEPT 3-YEAR CONTRACT AND END STRIKE
description: Some 4,500 shipbuilders at the Bath Iron Works today ended their walkout on its 99th day, accepting a three-year contract that freezes wages but provides bonuses of $2,000 for each worker.

title: Tribute to a Teacher
description: Exceptional teachers touch students' lives. In this case, the imprint has remained for 25 years.

title: ONE MORE THING FOR MEXICANS TO REBUILD: TOURISM
description: There are rows and rows of empty lounge chairs around the swimming pools in the resort hotels here on Mexico's Pacific coast. The tennis courts are empty; no appointment is needed to tee off on the golf course.

title: STAGE: 'FILTHY RICH,' A SLEUTH SPOOF
description: THE plot of ''Filthy Rich,'' being presented by the Double Image Repertory Company at the 47th Street Theater, is sometimes a tangled mess, but there enough laughs, at least in the first act of this sendup of private-eye films of the 1940's that much of the time the plot doesn't get in the way at all.

title: METS SEE NEED FOR PITCHING
description: This is Day One for Frank Cashen, the man who runs the Mets; the day he begins to put the season of 1985 into the time capsule, the day he starts to do his homework for the decisions on who plays where in 1986.

title: ASTRONAUTS RETURN FROM SECRET
description: Under crisp blue skies, a pale crescent moon and with only a handful of spectators as witness, the space shuttle Atlantis landed safely here this morning after its maiden voyage to space.

title: MARTHA SCHLAMME, SINGER, 60
description: Martha Schlamme, the smoky-voiced soprano whose Kurt Weill interpretations were internationally acclaimed, died Sunday in Jamestown, N.Y., two months after suffering a stroke on stage. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TREASURY WARNS CONGRESS TO ACT IN BUDGET FIGHT
description: The Treasury Department, trying to put pressure on Congress to raise the Government's debt ceiling and pass a companion bill calling for a balanced budget by 1991, said today that as early as Tuesday the Government would order banks not to honor its own checks.

title: MCNICHOL IN 'MARY' ON CBS
description: TONIGHT'S inspirational television movie, inevitably ''based on true events,'' is ''Love, Mary,'' starring Kristy McNichol as the heroine triumphing over awesome odds. On CBS at 9 o'clock, the film is about Mary Groda-Lewis, who is now a resident physician in Youngstown, Ohio, and who indeed fought a hard fight to get where she is. Her achievement remains laudable. It is only this television biography that is downright irritating.

title: DANCE: THE LEVY GROUP
description: THE titles of three of the four mixed-media dances that the Monica Levy Performance Group offered Sunday night in St. Mark's Church contained the word ''life.'' One soon suspected that Miss Levy wished to emphasize that ''life'' rhymed with ''strife.'' But, thanks to her satiric wit, the evening involved more than brawling.

title: U.N. COUNCIL CONDEMNS SOUTH AFRICANS FOR RAID
description: The Security Council unanimously condemned South Africa today for its air raid on a southeastern province of Angola a week ago, calling the raid ''premeditated and unprovoked.'' The Angolan Government said the raid killed more than 65 people.

title: Shoals for France
description: There is a peculiar rhythm to the troubles of France's Socialist Government, like a square dance of a step or two forward and several steps back.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was horrible. The water came through and it took my father, my mother, my four brothers and my niece.''

title: Highway Industry Imperiled by Insurance Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK OF NEW HAMPSHIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split paid Oct. 1, 1985.

title: YOUNG IS EXPECTED TO WIN IN ATLANTA
description: Mayor Andrew J. Young is expected to win easy re-election to a second term Tuesday.

title: Futile Pursuits
description: Yes, some people do consider him a baseball genius, but Gene Mauch's failure to win a league title with the California Angels this year made him 0 for 24 seasons as a major league manager. Here is a list of the leaders when it comes to such futile pursuits since the turn of the century:

title: Malpractice Measure For Military Advances
description: The House passed legislation today that would give military personnel the right to sue the Government in medical malpractice cases.

title: Give Farmers a Fair Market, Not a Free One
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTRIST WINNER IN PORTUGALS: ANIBAL CAVACO SILVA
description: Anibal Cavaco Silva, who appears all but certain to be Portugal's next Prime Minister, rose politically by being inflexible, a paradoxical trait for a man who may now have to be flexible to survive. The centrist party Mr. Cavaco Silva leads, the Social Democrats, won parliamentary elections Sunday with nearly 30 percent of the vote. That gave him at least 85 of the Parliament's 250 seats - 8 seats remain to be decided - but still far short of a majority.

title: Ex-Dean of Arts and Sciences To Join Harvard Corporation
description: Henry Rosovsky, former dean of Harvard University's Faculty of Arts and Sciences, has been named to the Harvard Corporation, one of the Ivy League university's two governing boards, the school announced today.

title: SCIENTISTS SEEK 4,600-YEAR-OLD AIR AT EGYPTIAN BOAT SITE
description: Egyptian and American scientists are combining space-age technology and archeology to try to preserve an artifact potentially as precious as the rarest of Egypt's antiquities: a sample of 4,600-year-old air.

title: 'DIRTY, LITTLE SECRET' OF UNLICENSED TEACHERS
description: IN discussing the need for school reform, Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said recently that New York City's classrooms were staffed with thousands of ''temporary per diem substitutes.'' He added, ''They are neither temporary, nor per diem, nor substitutes.'' They are, in fact, teaching classes regularly, on a long-term basis, whether or not they have been trained for the particular assignment.

title: AIDS Spreading in Europe
description: Western European nations are experiencing a sharp increase in cases of AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, comparable to the rapid rise in cases experienced in the United States, the World Health Organization has reported.

title: Faulting Tennis
description: John McEnroe said his resistance was down, which was why a severe stomach virus forced him to default in the semifinals of a tournament last month in Los Angeles. Jimmy Connors said that his ankle, the one he injured on the day of his semifinal match with Ivan Lendl in the United States Open last month, was still less than 100 percent.

title: On Heckler's Agenda
description: The Irish Embassy says there will be a meeting in Washington soon between Margaret M. Heckler, the newly designated Ambassador to Ireland, and Padriac MacKernan, Ireland's new Ambassador to the United States.

title: On Smoking
description: The air is to be particularly clear tomorrow night in the dining room of the Four Seasons Hotel in Georgetown, as the Prime Minister of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew, presides at a dinner for Vice President Bush and Mrs. Bush.

title: Indian Relocation in Arizona: 'The Worst Possible Solution'
description: To the Editor:

title: Female Globetrotter
description: Lynette Woodard, captain of the United States Olympic basketball team, was selected to be the first woman to play for the Harlem Globetrotters. The 26-year-old Miss Woodard, a 5-foot-11-inch guard from Lawrence, Kan., attended the University of Kansas and is the top career scorer in the history of the school, male or female. Miss Woodard edged out nine other women who had been trying out for the Globetrotters.

title: Israelis Kill 4 Gunmen Linked to Five Deaths
description: The Israeli Army announced tonight that it had killed four Arabs who it said were responsible for killing two Jewish couples and a shopper in an Arab market.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
