description: AT long last, fall seems to have really arrived. The women who go to charity lunches are all back in town. They've packed up their summer clothes and are all decked out in their new fall suits. Many of those suits, as ever, carry an Adolfo label. Among the Adolfo fans at last Thursday's fashion show in Saks Fifth Avenue for the Kips Bay Boys' Club were Eileen Roosevelt, Mimi Thorne, June Harrison, Jean Remmel, Diantha Nype, Tommie Ridder and Glady Solomon. In fact, Mrs. Ridder's blue and black suit was exactly the same as Mrs. Solomon's red and black, a not uncommon coincidence in those circles. But Mrs. Solomon had draped hers with all manner of Chanel jewelry.

title: AFTER THE HURRICANE, COLD, SILENT MACHINES
description: I WAS in Florida when Hurricane Gloria struck the Northeast. On returning home, I found trees strewn all over the power lines, but fortunately they had fallen on only a few houses.

title: SERGE JAROFF
description: Serge Jaroff, founder and director of the Don Cossack Chorus, died Saturday in the Paul Kimball Medical Center in Lakewood, N.J. He was 89 years old and lived in Lakewood.

title: SPY CHARGE SPURS QUESTIONS ON C.I.A.
description: Members of the Senate and House intelligence committees say espionage allegations against a former Central Intelligence Agency officer raise serious questions about the agency's procedures for dealing with disgruntled employees.

title: A Raise at UNESCO
description: When the United States decided last year to pull out of UNESCO, one of the reasons it cited was profligate management. Some 80 percent of the $374 million biennial budget, for example, was still being spent at the Paris headquarters of the agency, formally the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: A Party for Hart
description: Former Gov. W. Averell Harriman of New York and his wife, Pamela, are to hold a fund-raising party at their Georgetown home tomorrow night to help Senator Gary Hart pay off the Presidential primary campaign debt he acquired in 1984. Expected at the formal dinner and dance are eight or nine Democratic Senators, including Edward M. Kennedy and Bill Bradley.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DICTIONARY OF AMERICAN REGIONAL ENGLISH: Volume I - Introduction and A-C. Chief editor: Frederic G. Cassidy. 903 pages. Belknap/ Harvard. $49.95 until Dec. 31; $60 thereafter.

title: GIANTS ARE FOILED BY BASICS
description: Bart Oates, the Giants' new center, snaps the ball hundreds of times a week to Phil Simms, the quarterback. They do it in practice, they do it after practice and they do it in games.

title: ROME INQUIRY: WAS AGCA COACHED?
description: An Italian magistrate has begun investigating accusations that the gunman who tried to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981 was later coached in jail to implicate the Bulgarian secret service in the attack.

title: SCIENTIFIC SPLIT BLOCKS DIET RULES
description: In an unusual move, the National Academy of Sciences announced today that some of the nation's most eminent scientists were in an irreconcilable conflict over proposals to alter the recommended levels of certain vitamins and minerals in the human diet.

title: RULES PROPOSED BY WACHTLER ON NAMING OF CONSERVATORS
description: New York State's Chief Judge yesterday proposed new guidelines intended to curb favoritism, political influence and a longtime perception of such evils in the appointment of conservators and guardians by judges in the state.

title: Deregulation's Air Crash Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: Bilingual Shortcut
description: To the Editor:

title: MOMENTUM A LOSING PATTERN
description: Louis Breeden's coverage on Wesley Walker was perfect. Walker, the Jet receiver, was running a post pattern, and Breeden, the Cincinnati Bengals' cornerback, was running at his shoulder, synchronized, as if he were Walker's shadow.

title: Quinones Faults AIDS Planning
description: School Chancellor Nathan Quinones said in court yesterday that he and other city officials had been ''regrettably tardy'' in not devising a plan earlier to deal with pupils with AIDS.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dwight Gooden, the Mets' ace pitcher, received the Seagrams award as the baseball player of the year with an 89.8 computer ranking compiled by the Elias Sports Bureau. Don Mattingly, the first baseman of the Yankees, came in second with 75.93 points, and Rickey Henderson, the center fielder of the Yankees, was fourth with 72.94. . . . The Utah Jazz guard Darrell Griffith, who suffered a foot injury last week, will probably not be able to play until January, team officials said. . . . Jim Rice, the Red Sox outfielder, underwent arthroscopic surgery to remove torn cartilage from his left knee. . . . Kirk Muller, a forward for the Devils, the youngest player in the All-Star Game last season, signed a three-year contract that also includes an option year.

title: Portuguese Rebel Trial
description: The trial of 73 suspected left-wing urban guerrillas reopened in Lisbon today after a long adjournment and with almost a third of the defendants on the run. The accused are charged with belonging to a guerrilla group named after the April 25, 1974, revolution.

title: MANY FILED, FEW CHOSEN AT HIGH COURT
description: Unlike most other courts, the Supreme Court hears and decides only a small fraction of the cases that are brought to it.

title: THEATER: DALY'S 'FLASH OF LIGHTENING
description: IN the Equity Library Theater's spirited revival of Augustin Daly's 19th-century melodrama, ''A Flash of Lightning,'' the ''noises off'' are on stage in full view of the audience. A thunder sheet claps on cue, a wind machine simulates a howling gale, a ship is engulfed in flames and sinks at sea -and one of the characters rows his way to safety across mock waves. The loudest sound that we hear, however, is that of the play creaking.

title: YANKEES SEEKING ANOTHER STARTER
description: The Yankees have now gone longer without winning a division championship than in any other period in the 13-year ownership of George Steinbrenner. The result of that negative achievement could mean another winter of hectic activity for the Yankees. Or could it?

title: DR. GLYNN ISSAC, ANTHROPOLOGIST
description: Glynn Llywelyn Isaac, a professor of anthropology at Harvard University who was known for his study of human origins and his archeological work in East Africa, died of unknown causes, the university said today. He was 47 years old.

title: Authentic Fauna
description: Kate Gordon had a problem that most New Yorkers only dream of: no cockroaches.

title: Verdict Now, Trial Later
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese has a vision of justice that would eliminate court backlogs and facilitate the cumbersome process of deciding guilt and innocence. It would even end argument about innovative versus strict-constructionist judges - by eliminating judges altogether. Let the police adjudicate, Mr. Meese says. Consider this exchange in the current U.S. News & World Report:

title: MIDDLE EAST AND VIOLENCE: SUMMARY OF ONE YEAR'S TOLL
description: Jan. 14 - In Beirut, an anonymous caller claiming to represent Islamic Holy War says five Americans kidnapped in separate incidents in the previous year will go on trial as spies. The caller also takes responsibility for the deaths of two French soldiers killed with machine-gun fire in a jeep in Burj al Brajneh, a mostly Shiite Moslem area. March 8 - A car bombing in a Beirut suburb kills more than 80 people and reports in Washington say it was carried out by a Lebanese counterterrorism unit that had been working with the Central Intelligence Agency. March 10 - A suicide bomber drives a car packed with explosives into an Israeli Army convoy in southern Lebanon, killing 12 soldiers and wounding 14. March 11 - Israeli troops cross new defense line in southern Lebanon and kill at least 24 people in a village. The raid comes after a suicide bomber crashes into an Israeli Army convoy. April 20 - An Israeli gunboat sinks what Israeli officials call an Arab ''terrorist vessel'' with 28 people aboard off Israel. Eight Arabs are captured, one body is recovered and 19 people are missing and presumed drowned. May 25 - A suicide bomber drives a car filled with explosives into the motorcade of the Kuwaiti leader in Kuwait, killing himself, two bodyguards and a passer-by but failing to kill his apparent target, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Emir of Kuwait. A caller identifying himself as a member of Islamic Holy War takes responsibility.

title: The Gregarious Ann Getty
description: LIFE in Ann Getty's New York hotel suite is never serene.

title: Cartwright's Problem
description: The Knicks' anxiety is growing over the status of Bill Cartwright's injured left foot. Heavy swelling has not subsided and has prevented an accurate diagnosis of the injury to the same foot Cartwright broke twice last season.

title: NEW THEORY ON READING GOES AWRY
description: Somewhere along the way, a good theory seemed to have been poorly executed, and the result: a reading program for elementary school students in Chicago that failed to include an essential ingredient -reading.

title: Drilling for Oil Money in Congress
description: Congress: Please reduce the deficit by raising it. That's the solemn urging of a handful of states with offshore oil wells. They greedily propose an accounting trick that would credit the Treasury with $4 billion it has already received in return for a commitment to give away as much as $6 billion. They should be quickly rebuffed by the House.

title: ELMER S. GROO
description: Elmer S. Groo, a former executive of the International Business Machines Corporation and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, died of Alzheimer's disease Sept. 24 at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 68 years old. Mr. Groo, a graduate of the Drexel Institute of Technology, joined the International Business Machines Corporation in 1941. He served in the Navy from 1942 to 1946, then returned to I.B.M., leaving in 1973 as vice president of the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation, the company's overseas marketing arm.

title: A SAD NIGHT FOR A FILL-IN KICKER
description: The information above the cubicles in the Giants' dressing room identifies most of the inhabitants by uniform number and surname, but some of the stalls reveal a little more about an individual's station in life within Giants Stadium.

title: ON DAY 11, SPIRITS SOAR AS POWER IS RESTORED
description: For the last handful of Connecticut residents still without power after Hurricane Gloria's knock-out blow, the darkness vanished today.

title: INTERFERON USED IN TREATMENT OF RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS PAIN
description: ONE form of the natural virus-fighting substance interferon has shown promise in treating the pain and inflammation of rheumatoid arthritis, according to the biotechnology company, Biogen Inc.

title: Rampage Is Reported After Battle in Uganda
description: Hundreds of Government troops went on a rampage of killing and looting in western Uganda after hours of fierce fighting with rebels, witnesses said today.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
Article 062961 -- No Title
description: Financial leaders from around the world have agreed to set aside $2.7 billion from the International Monetary Fund for a special lending pool to help the poorest countries promote economic growth.

title: South Korea Says North Seized Fishing Boat
description: Seoul said today that a North Korean patrol boat seized an 86-ton South Korean fishing vessel with 12 crewmen aboard while the ship was operating in international waters in the Yellow Sea.

title: Priest Gets 3-Year Term In Sexual Abuse Case
description: A state judge ordered Roman Catholic priest to serve three years in prison for sexually abusing four teen-age boys.

title: FELD SEASON INCLUDES FOUR NON-FELD DANCES
description: Over its 11-year history, the Eliot Feld Ballet has come to be seen as its founder's choreographic instrument. The ballets performed by the company, which opens a four-week season tonight at the Joyce Theater, have been almost exclusively Mr. Feld's. This season, the company will perform 12 Feld ballets, including a revival of ''At Midnight,'' a brooding, poignant classic. And Mr. Feld has created three new ballets to music by Steve Reich, one of them a tour de force for James Sewell, a trampoline and a set of ramps.

title: Bridge: In a Rare Turn of Events, 3 Couples Form Top Team
description: In tournament bridge, married couples have one substantial advantage: They have virtually unlimited opportunity to practice their bidding methods and refine their partnership understandings. Few of them, apparently, take advantage of the opportunity, for husband-and-wife successes in open events are rather rare.

title: Marines Disclaim Role In Burial of Fetuses
description: Marine Corps officials say they were duped into sending a color guard to a burial service for more than 16,000 fetuses that was staged Sunday by an organization opposed to abortion.

title: MEETING ON POOR AND HEALTH CARE
description: In a two-day period this year, in just one of the five emergency rooms at Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta, 15 doctors and their six physician's assistants cared for more than 600 people.

title: DISCOVERIES
To Make the Rich Richer
description: To the Editor:

title: Gloom on the Summit
description: Most of the speculation about next month's U.S.-U.S.S.R. summit meeting in Geneva has been negative if not downright pessimistic - and it's easy to understand why - but an argument can be made for a little patience if not for optimism.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CITY'S HEALTH CHIEF DEFENDS THE DELAYS ON AIDS GUIDELINES
description: New York City's Health Commissioner said yesterday that it would have been ''advantageous'' if the city had announced a policy by last spring on admitting children with AIDS to public schools, but he said it would have been ''inappropriate'' for the city to have done so then.

title: All Generic Equivalents Are Not Created Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: Calling All MoZo's
description: Somehow losing national political campaigns seem to produce more lasting nostalgia among participants than the winning ones, or maybe they have more time for it. The hardy travelers of the 1964 Vice-Presidential campaign of William E. Miller continued to hold regular reunions until the New York Republican's death in 1983.

title: Evidence Ends in Spy Trial
description: Both sides in the trial of Richard W. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who is accused of espionage, rested their cases today after jurors trooped to a Little League ballpark for the reenactment of a scene in the prosecution's account of the case.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports World Specials column on Monday incorrectly reported Benson Huggard's accomplishment last month. Mr. Huggard, who had set out to swim once around Manhattan on each of eight consecutive days with his legs tied, completed the act on only four of those days. On the other occasions, the swims were completed by other members of his team.

title: All Generic Equivalents Are Not Created Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes non-operating charges and credits including a gain on the sale of three hospitals of about $3 million, or 3 cents a share. c-Including a gain from the sale of two hospitals of about $3 million, or 3 cents a share.

title: MET MUSEUM ARMOR SALE
description: David Cosby just kept raising his hand as the bidding rose higher and higher on his favorite lot, and in the end, for $2,600, he beat his competition and took home an egg dolly, a blowhorn stake and a square-bench anvil with tang.

title: Spinks Asks Delay
description: Michael Spinks, who has been ordered to give up one of his two world boxing titles, has asked for a postponement of the directive in order to give him time to win a third. Spinks, the World Boxing Council's light heavyweight champion, won the International Boxing Federation's heavyweight crown by defeating Larry Holmes last month.

title: Rolls Aircraft Picks U.S. Unit President
description: Rolls-Royce Inc., the United States subsidiary of the big British aircraft engine maker, has named Alan D. F. Smith president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: IP TIMBERLANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Year-ago figures are not available because the company commenced operations on March 14, 1985.

title: To Moscow, Then Mars
description: Seven members of the House of Representatives, two former astronauts and assorted other Government people will take off on a flying trip to Moscow tomorrow. One of their goals will be to interest Soviet officials and scientists in a joint, manned mission to Mars sometime in the future.

title: Tackle the U.S. Deficit By Splitting It in Two
description: To the Editor:

title: Putnam's High School Drops Dungeons and Dragons Game
description: The fantasy game Dungeons and Dragons will be dropped at Putnam High School after a six-month controversy, according to the school.

title: BRITISH TIME OF VIOLENCE
description: Early this year, the Princess of Wales ventured from her apartment in Kensington Palace to dedicate a youth center in a housing project in Tottenham, a racially mixed working-class area of north London.

title: All in the Same Boat
description: The terror this time is different. For one thing, it involves a ship instead of an embassy or a plane. The more important difference is that this time, the terror is truly international.

title: A MEETING ON HELSINKI CULTURAL PACT
description: The Helsinki accords signed in 1975 by 35 nations from both East and West bound those countries to agreements that are widely known, if not always adhered to, in such areas as human rights and economic affairs. Another aspect, not so well known, calls for the free exercise of cultural activities, and the signatories to the Helsinki document are to gather in Budapest beginning next Tuesday to determine how it is being carried out.

title: Divorce and the Deficit
description: With so many crucial issues facing Congress, humor has been largely absent these days in both the Senate and the House.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXTENSION REQUESTED ON STAGEHAND CONTRACT
description: An organization of independent and predominantly young producers yesterday asked both sides in the crucial contract negotiations for Broadway's stagehands to extend the old accord by a year and to study far-reaching changes in Broadway labor relations.

title: Hanson Raises Its Offer For SCM to $75 a Share
description: A takeover battle for the SCM Corporation heated up again yesterday as Hanson Trust P.L.C., a British conglomerate that has spent $280 million for about a third of the food and paint company, raised its offer for the rest to $75 a share, or $628.5 million.

title: LANDMARKS PANEL STAFF URGES REJECTION OF EAST SIDE TOWERS
description: The staff of the Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday urged the commissioners to reject a proposal for a 19-story residential tower above the facades of three Queen Anne-style brownstones on East 79th Street.

title: KARPOV AND KASPAROV DRAW 13TH CHESS GAME
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to draw the 13th game of their world championship chess match today after 24 moves. ----An analysis of the 13th game by Robert Byrne will appear tomorrow.

title: HONEYMOON ENDS FOR MULRONEY GOVERNMENT
description: After sailing through a year in office nearly unscathed, the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has mired down over the last few weeks in scandals, contradictions and challenges to its credibility and competence.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: OCTOBER 9, 1985
description: International

title: Astray in the Mails
description: Witches, goblins and evil spirits are on the program tonight of the Opera Ensemble of New York. But gremlins seem to have struck first.

title: U.S. WARSHIP CUTS ISRAEL VISIT SHORT TO MONITOR ITALIAN VESSEL
description: The Pentagon said this afternoon that it had ordered an American destroyer to cut short a port visit at Haifa, Israel, and to monitor a hijacked Italian cruise ship in the Eastern Mediterranean.

title: Hodsoll Renominated
description: The White House has announced the nomination of Frank Hodsoll to a second four-year term as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. The appointment of Mr. Hodsoll, who is 47, is subject to confirmation by the Senate, which is expected to give it.

title: Trevino Retires
description: Lee Trevino says this time he is really ready to ease off the Professional Golf Association Tour.

title: Our Unfree Dollars in a Free Market
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR SALVADORANS, CITY HALL IS WHERE YOU FIND IT
description: In the thin morning light, the Mayor of Lolotique stooped to pick the town records off the ground, made a slight bow at his colleague from Chirilagua and sat down. Five other mayors were also present, sitting behind borrowed desks in an open yard here.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Carney Joins G.O.P. Formally
description: Representative William Carney, a member of New York's Conservative Party who has been elected to Congress four times as a Republican, has joined the Republican Party. His change of enrollment was filed Monday at the Suffolk County Board of Election in Yaphank, L.I., according to a spokesman, Tim Kelly.

title: 5 DIE IN SOUTH AFRICAN VIOLENCE
description: The police said today that five more blacks were killed in anti-apartheid violence, and Bishop Desmond M. Tutu said he wondered if advocates of peaceful change should ''sit down and shut up'' and let the rioters prevail.

title: REPUBLIC BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $6.2 million from the sale of assets and $1.1 million from investment securities transactions. c-Includes $14.4 million of after-tax gains from the sale of assets and $4.8 million after-tax benefit from the refund of capital shares taxes.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Royals vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto. Second game of the four-of-seven-game American League championship series (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M. Radio -WCBS, 3 P.M.) Cardinals vs.

title: RESCUE OPERATION CALLED POSSIBLE BUT DANGEROUS
description: A rescue operation to retake the hijacked cruise liner Achille Lauro might be possible, but would risk the lives of some hostages or even the sinking of the ship, several experts said today.

title: JAMES BUCKLEY TO BE WASHINGTON COURT NOMINEE
description: The Reagan Administration will nominate James L. Buckley to the United States Court of Appeals, but officials have changed their minds about which circuit court the former New York Senator would sit on, Administration officials said today.

title: Valid Local Voices on Nuclear Arms Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKERS AT I.M.F. TALKS CAUTIOUS ON BAKER PLAN
description: As Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d returned to Washington, bankers reacted cautiously today to his third world lending plan.

title: ISRAEL FIRM ON TERROR POLICY, BUT SEEMS WILLING TO HELP
description: An Israeli Cabinet spokesman, asked whether the Government would consider the Mediterranean hijackers' demands to free 50 Palestinian prisoners, said today that Israel opposes negotiations with terrorists as a matter of principle.

title: TV Savvy
description: A ''new'' Elizabeth Holtzman was unveiled yesterday, as the Brooklyn District Attorney's media consultants previewed for reporters four television commercials that will go on the air this week.

title: New Zealand Criticized For Anti-Nuclear Policy
description: Former New Zealand military chiefs criticized the Government's anti-nuclear policies today and said a ban on visits by nuclear ships could lead to a complete breakdown in relations with the United States.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary after- tax gain on the sale of Alliance Mortgage Co. of $41,313,000.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: PACIFIC AND AFRICAN DAY -Pacific and African representatives dominate the General Assembly's debate agenda today. The morning schedule includes a speech by the Prime Minister of Vanuatu, the Rev. Walter H. Lini, who is expected to offer his views on nuclear weapons testing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Please, please, please, don't try anything.'' - Gerardo de Rosa, captain of the Achille Lauro. [A1:6.]

title: A BOOMLET IN WINERIES ON THE BANKS OF THE HUDSON
description: CALL them 914 wines. Call some of the couples who grow grapes and run the wineries part-timers. Call the drive to visit them fast and easy. And call the dog that dashes around Louis J. Fiore's West Park Vineyards this way: ''Here, Rhine!'' Next year, Mr. Fiore says, Rhine is ''marrying'' a dog named Moselle.

title: NEW TARGET, NEW WORRIES FOR HIJACKERS
description: Psychologists and other specialists have written many volumes on the human aspects of hijackings, hostage-takings and related events, but they have devoted little attention to the specific environment of ships.

title: Two Officials Named To the Smithsonian
description: Tom L. Freudenheim, director of the Worcester Art Museum in Massachusetts, today was named assistant secretary for museums of the Smithsonian Institution and Dr. David Challinor was named assistant secretary for research.

title: A ROYAL PREVIEW FOR THE PRINCELY COLLECTIONS OF LIECHTENSTEIN
description: FOUR horns played atop the Metropolitan Museum's grand staircase, welcoming guests to the first preview of ''Liechtenstein: The Princely Collections,'' the only major art collection of its kind that remains in private hands. In a gallery modeled after the reception hall of the Liechtenstein Garden Palace in Vienna, 400 luminaries stood in line to shake those hands and greet the tiny European nation's reigning Prince, Franz Josef II von und zu Liechtenstein, his wife, Princess Gina, and Crown Princess Marie.

title: HEAVY LIMITED EDITION
description: THE limited edition has long been a practically foolproof way of making sure a work of art, a book or a recording will rapidly appreciate in value -and a favorite ploy for enabling the artist or publisher to sell his work at a price far above what it would fetch as a mass-produced item. There have not been many limited editions in the world of pop music, and for a good reason: many dedicated fans exist on modest incomes and have enough trouble saving up to buy a new album at regular or discount prices.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: The Fish of Fall The fall run of fish is starting to quicken, according to Richard Lord of the Fulton Fish Market. Mackerel, bluefish and porgies are plentiful, and excellent striped bass are in good supply, from Massachusetts, Rhode Island and eastern Long Island.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ATLANTIC BANCORP INC (READING, PA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHINA HAND In 1979, Isaac Stern and violin, his family and David Golub, pianist, were invited to visit China, to perform, to handle a few master classes, to meet fellow musicians. This trip abroad resulted in a 1981 movie, ''From Mao to Mozart: Isaac Stern in China,'' which created such a joyous stir that it won an Oscar for best documentary.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alberto-Culver Co., Melrose Park, Ill., a maker of personal care products, has promoted Howard Bernick to executive vice president.

title: Tunisian Officer Fires Into Crowd, Killing 3
description: A Tunisian security officer fired into a group of people on the Tunisian island of Djerba, killing three people and wounding several, the official Tunisian news agency said today.

title: Koch Denounces Farrakhan Speech
description: Mayor Koch, responding to a speech by Louis Farrakhan at Madison Square Garden, yesterday compared the Black Muslim minister to Hitler and his supporters to Nazi brown shirts.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect the 3-for-2 stock split made Feb. 19, 1985.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $29 million for the quarter and the 9 months for the company's voluntary retirement program. vuf92c-Includes a $1.6 million restatement for the cumulative effect, to Dec. 31, 1984, of a change in accounting for cost of timber harvested.

title: NEW FOODS: SMALL, FANCY, U.S.-MADE
description: IN an era when real people make real food in real kitchens and sell it in small quantitites under their own names, Betty Crocker, Ann Pillsbury and Aunt Jemima may have to reckon with the likes of Duggan Peak, Claudine and Juliana.

title: TO HOSTAGE FAMILIES, WAITING BACK HOME IS ALSO A NIGHTMARE
description: There are 11 of them in the group, devoted friends from New York and New Jersey who for many years have spent weekends together at the Jersey shore.

title: POP: TASTE OF ZYDECO AT TRAMPS
description: FERNEST and the Thunders brought the casual swagger of zydeco (Cajun blues) to Tramps, 125 East 15th Street, on Monday and Tuesday. The six-piece band from Lafayette, La., features Fernest Arceneaux on button accordion and his brother Ashby Arceneaux on frottoir (metal washboard).

title: EVEN WITH A NAME, IT'S HARD TO KNOW WHO THE HIJACKERS ARE
description: The hijackers of an Italian cruise ship have said in radio transmissions that they are members of a group called the Palestine Liberation Front, but even if that identification is accurate it may not do much to clear up their motives and allegiances.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SOME foods depend almost wholly for their own identity on the flavors with which they are allied. The list includes rice, snails and almost any form of pasta.

title: MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES INC (ST LOUIS, MO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Connecticut Will End Turnpike Tolls Today
description: Tollgates on the Connecticut Turnpike are scheduled to go up tonight at 11 o'clock, ending toll collection after 27 years.

title: CONCERT: PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA OFFERS 'RIGOLETTO'
description: A CONCERT version of ''Rigoletto'' in New York? Who needs it, you might say.

title: Easy Pickings
description: Coach Mack Brown, whose Tulane football team is now 0-5, reminds the New Orleans Quarterback Club of his prediction that many opponents would want to schedule the Green Wave for homecoming games: ''We've started working on our float.''

title: Graham Greene, How Do You Do It?
description: Greene is in town, a most subtle tourist bearing the gifts and burdens of imagination.

title: 'An Urban Delight'
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CAMEOS FROM THE FILM FESTIVAL
description: ''For 15 days, this turf is cinema turf,'' said Paula Gibbs, an usher at the New York Film Festival, pointing to the inside of Alice Tully Hall. ''And these people, coming and going day after day - it is their turf.''

title: STAGE: COMEDY TROUPE
description: THE First Amendment, the downtown improvisational company with its own cellar theater at 2 Bond Street, is proudly celebrating its 10th anniversary this month. Long-running revues, even by improvisational troupes that have to invent new material on the spot, tend to sag as they rely on proven formulas.

title: Parents of Septuplets Sue Doctor and Clinic
description: The parents of three surviving septuplets filed a malpractice and wrongful death suit today seeking more than $2.2 million from the doctor and clinic that gave the mother fertility drugs.

title: G.A.O. FINDS LAG IN ENFORCING OVERTIME AND MINIMUM PAY LAWS
description: The General Accounting Office has criticized the Departments of Labor and Justice as failing to penalize employers who violate Federal minimum wage and overtime pay laws.

title: P.& G. Forecasts Better Earnings
description: The Procter & Gamble Company's earnings should improve throughout this year compared with last year, P.&G.'s president, John G. Smale, told company shareholders today at their annual meeting.

title: Spousal Support
description: Representative Jack Kemp has come up with a new fund-raising wrinkle - having his wife, Joanne, sign computer-written invitations to a belated 50th birthday party.

title: CITY RESERVOIR LEVELS HIGHEST SINCE AUGUST
description: Recent rainstorms and the runoff from Hurricane Gloria have filled New York City's upstate water reservoirs to their highest levels since August, although they remain far below normal, city officials said yesterday.

title: HOUSE, IN REBUFF FOR REAGAN, PASSES $141 BILLION FARM BILL
description: The House of Representatives tonight overwhelmingly adopted a new farm bill that would cost $141 billion over the next five years. Most of the money would go toward propping up prices paid to farmers and feeding the nation's poor through the food stamp program.

title: 'WE ARE LOSING PATIENCE'
description: Following is a transcript of radio communications today between hijackers of the Italian liner Achille Lauro and the Syrian port of Tartus, as provided by shipping sources in the eastern Mediterranean. All times are local. 2:32 P.M. HIJACKER: What about the negotiators? 2:42 P.M. HIJACKER: Negotiators? We will start killing at 1500. 2:58 P.M. HIJACKER: We cannot wait any longer.

title: RELIEF FUND IS SET UP IN NEW YORK FOR VICTIMS OF PUERTO RICO FLOOD
description: As Puerto Ricans in New York scrambled for information yesterday about relatives and friends caught in the floods and mud slides that struck the island, community leaders and civic organizations began mounting a relief effort.

title: WINE TALK
description: A friend back from Burgundy reports that the tonneliers - barrel makers to the rest of us -are working overtime these days. It seems that demand for barrels in which to store the new vintage is fierce; not because of an unexpectedly huge harvest, but because no one really expected an appreciable harvest at all.

title: Price Tag of Corporate Generosity in Pennsylvania
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican's Body Recovered
description: Rescue workers today found the body of a 55-year-old man in the rubble of a building destroyed by last month's earthquakes. But there was no sign of his 9-year-old grandson, who had been believed alive but was given up for dead.

title: A SHAKEOUT IN EAST'S REFINERS
description: A Dutch oil trader could soon be one of the biggest gasoline dealers in the East.

title: Blaze in Brooklyn Kills Couple and Injures Son
description: A couple died and their son was critically burned last night in a fire of unknown origin that swept a two-family house in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a headline in Business Day on Sept. 25 about Steven P. Jobs, former chairman of Apple Computer, erroneously punctuated a description of Mr. Jobs's reaction to a suit filed against him by Apple. He expressed shock but did not use the word and it should not have appeared in quotation marks.

title: Spiting the World Court
description: Some of the Reagan Administration's laments about the World Court are surely sound. The tribunal sitting at The Hague has indeed been used as a ''political weapon'' by Nicaragua in its current charges of aggression. And American hopes that other nations would submit to the Court's compulsory jurisdiction have been disappointed; the majority go to The Hague when they think they can win. But by joining that majority, the United States makes a good point in a wrong-headed way.

title: STAGE: FOUR ONE-ACT MUSICALS AT SOUTH STREET
description: IN ''Leo,'' the first of four new one-act musicals at the South Street Theater, a man spends 15 minutes chasing angrily after a cat. The cat has smashed a prized vase, and the man wants to exact revenge. ''Am I man or mouse?/Who's the master of this house?,'' he sings to the elusive pet, later adding, ''If I blow my stack/I'll give you such a whack.'' By that point, a theatergoer can't be blamed for wondering if the whole exercise is a put-on. Have a composer (Michael Ching) and lyricist (Fernando Fonseca) really written an entire musical - or, as they label it, ''opera'' - about a man punishing his cat? And, if so, why? We never do find out.

title: A Big Flap
description: Speaking of flying and space, the National Air and Space Museum is planning to give a glimpse tomorrow of the model of a prehistoric flying reptile that is scheduled to rise over the Mall next June, flapping as the original did 65 million years ago.

title: 'THE LUCKY ONES,' LODGED IN CAIRO, WAIT GRIMLY FOR WORD OF THE OTHERS
description: Frank Hodes, an insurance broker from Springfield, N.J., was one of more than 600 passengers who left the cruise ship Achille Lauro Monday afternoon in the Egyptian port of Alexandria, to go sightseeing and do some shopping with friends. His wife, Mildred, stayed on board.

title: 'CINDY ELLER,' ON ABC, 'A MODERN FAIRY TALE'
description: ABC's Afterschool Special series is going pleasantly fey today, at 4 P.M., with ''Cindy Eller,'' which, if you haven't already guessed, is ''A Modern Fairy Tale.'' Cindy is a sweet, unaffected girl who has grown up in Maine and now, following the death of her mother, has come to live with her father and stepmother in New York City. She has two silly stepsisters who look like Madonna clones raised in a mod boutique.

title: CHRYSLER BUYING BANK AMERICA UNIT
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell FinanceAmerica, its consumer finance subsidiary, to the Chrysler Corporation for $405 million.

title: CENTRAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. 'PATIENT AND STUBBORN' IN GENEVA, AIDE SAYS
description: The chief American negotiator at the arms talks here has been quoted as saying that the United States will be both ''patient and stubborn'' in dealing with the Soviet Union, but will not be lulled by Soviet declarations of ''peaceful intentions.''

title: MILAN DESIGNERS' FREE AND EASY SPRING FASHIONS
description: Gianfranco Ferre's spring and summer fashion show had been under way for some time when a samurai warrior appeared alone, made some passes with his sword, then slashed the curtain with it, from stage right to stage left. The entire lower portion of the canvas fell away. Standing right behind it were 50 models, neat in navy, red and white outfits. The applause started up, gaining momentum as each model walked down the runway, albeit rapidly, then followed by the designer, wearing a navy blue suit. Everyone is now talking about the electrifying finale and is wondering whether anyone will devise a way to top it.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MANVILLE TO TAKE A CHARGE
description: The Manville Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $180 million pretax charge against earnings that will result in a loss for the third quarter and the year. The move is part of a program to withdraw from several businesses, including residential roofing and some industrial insulation lines, that are losing money or are only marginally profitable.

title: Congress Rushes to Unfairness
description: Melodrama surrounds Congress, where members are plenty touchy about approving a new borrowing limit of two trillion dollars. Will the Government grind to a halt while legislators dawdle? Would the Treasury really dare tell banks to bounce Federal checks? Will a so-called balanced-budget bill emerge as law?

title: ZANUSSI'S HAUNTED LOVERS
description: KRZYSZTOF ZANUSSI'S ''Year of the Quiet Sun'' is set in 1946, in a Polish town that has been ravaged by war. The setting reflects the shell-shocked weariness of both the heroine, a recent widow named Emilia (Maja Komorowska), and the hero, an American ex-P.O.W. named Norman (Scott Wilson) who still dreams of the terror he felt at being captured by the Germans.

title: BOLIVIA OFFERS PLAN ON DRUGS
description: The sale of cocaine could be curtailed if an international economic fund was set up to purchase the coca leaves from peasants, the Vice President of Bolivia told the General Assembly today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TEXAS. By James A. Michener. 1,096 pages. Random House. $21.95. BY now, James Michener has pretty much found his formula for the novel: whether the setting is Hawaii (''Hawaii''), Afghanistan (''Caravans''), South Africa (''The Covenant''), the eastern shore of the United States (''Chesapeake'') or, as now, the sprawling plains of Texas, the result is always a huge book, crammed to overflowing with facts, ideas and sociology - a sort of Baedeker to local civilization. This time, Texas seems the ideal subject: vast, sprawling, and eclectic in population and geography, the state has just the sort of larger-than-life history that lends itself to Mr. Michener's taste for multi-generational epics; and the story of its emergence - from frontier outpost to proud flagship of the New South - personifies the sort of old-fashioned American values that the author likes to examine in his fiction.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September 1985.

title: HUNDREDS FEARED KILLED BY PUERTO RICO MUD SLIDE
description: Hundreds of people apparently died in a mud slide that buried a hillside shantytown north of this city Monday after a three-day rainstorm, the authorities said today.

title: F.B.I. Says Other Agents Killed Agent in Shootout
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation confirmed today that an agent who died Saturday after an exchange of gunfire Friday was shot by other agents at the scene of the arrest of a Las Vegas robbery suspect.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big One Gets Away
description: The famous Westway case in Manhattan left most people, probably including most New Yorkers, baffled and bored. This is a pity because at the end it was like those Frank Capra fables about Mr. Deeds going to town and Mr. Smith going to Washington, in which innocent small-town boys with a civics-book faith in democracy challenged the big shots and won.

title: PANEL GOAL: FINDING CAUSE
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode appointed the Philadelphia Special Investigation Commission after his administration was criticized for its handling of the May 13 confrontation with the radical group called Move, in which 11 people died and 61 houses were destroyed.

title: Wine Regulations
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Viacom Shares Up $5.75, to $52.25
description: Viacom International Inc.'s stock soared $5.75 a share yesterday to close at $52.25 in heavy trading, amid rumors that the Gannett Company was planning a takeover.

title: STRAWBERRY FIELDS 'GARDEN OF PEACE' OPENS TODAY
description: At times, Bruce Kelly concedes, the construction of Strawberry Fields seemed to be taking forever. And it was hard for Mr. Kelly, the landscape architect in charge of the Central Park project, to imagine clearing all the obstacles involved in creating Yoko Ono's ''International Garden of Peace'' honoring her late husband, John Lennon.

title: ENEMY BLOCKED, ANGOLAN REBEL SAYS
description: The leader of a South African-backed rebellion in this country appealed today for United States aid to help him fight what he said was a Soviet-directed Angolan offensive against him.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $3.5 million for the quarter and after a loss of $3.8 million for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $1.3 million for the quarter and $400,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations and a $25.7 million pre-tax gain from the sale of land and air rights for the quarter.

title: KOCH IS ENDORSED BY MARCHI AND OTHER CITY REPUBLICANS
description: State Senator John J. Marchi and William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, led a group of Republican and independent politicians, lawyers and business leaders in endorsing Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: Warning by Pyongyang
description: North Korea warned the International Olympic Committee today that many Communist and other nations would boycott the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, unless the Games were organized jointly by both North and South Korea. Korea's two Olympic committees met today at the invitation of Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the I.O.C., to consider North Korea's demand to be co-host of the Games and to merge athletes from both north and south into a single team.

title: U.S. ASKS PORTS TO DENY HAVEN TO CRUISE LINER
description: The Reagan Administration has undertaken a worldwide effort to deny the hijackers of the Italian cruise ship a sanctuary in any port, high-ranking Administration officials said today.

title: BALTIMORE ESPIONAGE TRIAL BEGINS
description: The espionage trial of a former naval intelligence analyst began here today with prosecutors arguing that he had passed classified information to a British military journal to gain a job on its staff.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $175,000 for the quarter and $576,000 for the 9 months.

title: A Confident South Korea
description: DUCK WOO NAM, at the relatively early age of 61, is regarded here as the gray eminence of Korean politics and economics.

title: UNITED STATES HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCARSDALE MAN, MISSING 5 YEARS, DECLARED DEAD
description: A retired oil-company executive from Scarsdale, who has been missing since 1980 when he and his wife disappeared from a Georgia motel, has been declared dead by a Westchester County surrogate.

title: BANPONCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $6,741,671. Per share figures reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in August.

title: HARVARD OMITS HONORARY DEGREES, ENDING REAGAN DISPUTE
description: Harvard University has decided to grant no honorary degrees at its 350th anniversary celebration next year, cutting short a heated debate among its faculty and alumni over the prospect that President Reagan would be among the degree recipients.

title: SUNTRUST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1985
description: Companies

title: Politics;   The Loneliness of The Front-Runner
description: The psychological warfare of the 1988 Republican Presidential campaign has begun, and its main target seems to be Vice President Bush.

title: NEW TV TECHNOLOGIES ALTER VIEWING HABITS
description: Communications experts say that the number of television viewing options now available and the ability to control how and when programs are watched have led to significant changes in the way the medium affects viewers.

title: Ponderosa Chairman Is Doing Battle Again
description: Gerald S. Office Jr., chairman and chief executive of Ponderosa Inc., the budget steakhouse chain, is fighting the second unwanted approach by outsiders on his company in five years.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics;   Forms of Nurture Coordinated Diets
description: During a recent visit to Down East Maine, a friend who loves salads was dismayed to find only iceberg lettuce in the stores. She therefore turned to nasturtiums, which her hosts had planted like a necklace around their lawn.

title: Calling All Horsers
description: Ordinarily at this time of year, Farragut Square tends to be full of outdoor lunchers taking the autumn sun. But today they will be sharing it with two champion entries in the Washington International Horse Show, a pack of foxhounds and a 7-foot-6 jumping barrier.

title: MAN THE HIJACKERS WANT
description: The hijackers of the Achille Lauro were said to have mentioned only one name in demanding the release of 50 Palestinian guerrillas held here in Israel. He is Samir al-Qantari, whom they describe as ''a hero of Operation Nahariya.''

title: OF WRESTLERS, POLITICIANS AND SHOWMANSHIP
description: ''And is it not true,'' the witness was asked solemnly, ''that the woman in question was stir-frying vegetables at the time?''

title: NONPROFIT GROUPS' ANSWER TO HIGH MANHATTAN RENTS
description: Perhaps there are no users of office space in Manhattan more vulnerable to rising commercial rents than nonprofit organizations.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS ACQUIRING FRONTIER
description: People Express agreed yesterday to buy Frontier Holdings, the owner of Frontier Airlines, in a deal the companies described as binding. The merger would catapult People from its position as the nation's 12th-largest airline, in terms of passengers carried, to No. 5.

title: GROSS CALLS STEWART INJURIES INCONSISTENT WITH ACCOUNTS
description: The city's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, testified yesterday that the injuries suffered by Michael Stewart were not consistent with the actions of transit police officers as described in their grand jury testimony.

title: Mellon to Acquire Commonwealth
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said that it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire the Commonwealth National Financial Corporation of Harrisburg, Pa., in a deal valued at $119 million.

title: A Monetary Pact Is Overdue
description: The agreement by the ''Group of Five'' industrial nations to lower the value of the dollar is a decisive and welcome departure in policy - not only for the Reagan Administration but also for our industrial trading partners, who met in Tokyo just four months ago to declare that freely floating rates were working just fine.

title: Ward Closings
description: As part of a previously announced plan to phase out its 113-year-old catalogue operation, Montgomery Ward & Company said it would close two of its six merchandise distribution centers, effective Jan. 1.

title: THEATER: 'CABBAGEHEAD'
description: HEAVY is the hex that hangs over ''The Cabbagehead,'' a doleful tale about the poor and the superstitious among the Pennsylvania Dutch in the 1920's. The author, Oliver Goldstick, has apparently based his play on actual events, but, in this case, truth is no assurance of credibility.

title: Cruise Ship Security Check
description: A Congressional panel announced today that it plans to examine security on cruise ships as a result of the hijacking of the Italian liner Achille Lauro in the Mediterranean. Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, said a House Merchant Marine subcommittee, of which he is chairman, will conduct a public hearing Oct. 22. He also called for improved communications between cruise ships and the United States Navy and merchant marine.

title: Ex-Dean of Arts and Sciences To Join Harvard Corporation
description: Henry Rosovsky, former dean of Harvard University's Faculty of Arts and Sciences, has been named to the Harvard Corporation, one of the Ivy League university's two governing boards, the school announced Monday.

title: Ford and Fiat Call Off Merger
description: The Ford Motor Company and Fiat S.p.A., the giant Italian auto maker, said today that they could not reach an agreement on a merger or a joint venture to build cars. However, the companies will continue to discuss other business arrangements such as joint production of parts, Ford said.

title: EXEMPTION PLAN LOSES IN TAX VOTE
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today rejected President Reagan's proposal that would nearly double the personal exemption taxpayers are allowed to claim, but the panel did not reach agreement on an alternative.

title: Paris and Brussels Hit By Bomb Blasts
description: Bombs exploded overnight in Brussels and Paris, slightly wounding one passer-by in Paris but causing no casualties in Brussels, the police said.

title: SMALL-SCHOOL MATCHUP LOOMS AS A BIG ATTRACTION
description: This week's meetings between unbeaten teams will feature the Alabama-Penn State and Texas-Oklahoma games. The Tennessee-Florida and Nebraska-Oklahoma State games will also pit some of the best of the big teams in the land against each other.

title: CHAMPAGNE HOUSE TRIES OUT SPARKLING LIQUEUR
description: A French count steeped in the traditions of a centuries-old Champagne house has developed the concern's first new product in 50 years: a sparkling liqueur aimed at the most discriminating young professional palate.

title: POLICEMAN KILLS A MERCHANT WHO WAS PURSING YOUTHS
description: A liquor store owner, armed with a pistol, was shot to death by a police officer yesterday in Brooklyn as the merchant chased a group of youths who had fought with him in the store, the police said.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in April 1985.

title: Disputed Conversation
description: After a 75-minute meeting with Kenneth Davis, the suspended T.C.U. star, and his agent, Mike Trope, the commissioner of the National Football League, Pete Rozelle, said he hoped to decide within a few days whether Davis would be allowed to play in the N.F.L. this season. At issue is the so-called ''Red Grange'' rule that prohibits an athlete from playing at the college level and in the N.F.L. the same season.

title: SEARLE BACKS MEDICAL DEVICE
description: G.D. Searle & Company is finding itself on the defensive over charges and lawsuits involving its Cu-7 intrauterine device.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $73,000 for the quarter and $260,000 for the year. c-Including net income from discontinued operations of $88,000 for the quarter and $93,000 for the year. Results are restated to include the results of operations of Montevideo Technology acquired on July 30, 1985, and accounted for as a pooling of interests. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the disposal of the SL Homalite Corp. and the SL Modern Creative division in 1985.

title: AN EXAMINATION OF ABSCAM INQUIRY ON CHANNEL 13
description: NO one has ever objected much when petty criminals are lured by the police into committing crimes they would have committed anyway. But five years after details of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam inquiry into political corruption first broke, the debate over the tactics used in the case continues.

title: PHILADELPHIA PANEL PLEDGES IMPARTIAL BOMBING INQUIRY
description: A panel appointed to conduct an inquiry into the police bombing of the radical group Move opened hearings today that its chairman said would determine the facts ''without regard to personal interests.'' Eleven people were killed in the group's house and a neighborhood was destroyed in the resulting fire.

title: FINANCIAL CORP.'S CLIMB BACK
description: Since William J. Popejoy succeeded Charles W. Knapp as chairman of the troubled Financial Corporation of America in August 1984, the company has benefited from a three-percentage-point drop in short-term interest rates. That decline has brought record profits to many of Mr. Popejoy's large competitors in California. However, for the Financial Corporation and its main subsidiary, the American Savings and Loan Association - the nation's largest thrift institution - it has not been enough.

title: BIG CASES FOCUS ATTENTION ON JURY SELECTION
description: Thousands of prospective jurors have been summoned to the Federal courthouse in Manhattan in recent days for numerous trials, including two major cases involving organized crime.

title: Low Numbers
description: Coach Tom Landry of the Cowboys, unhappy with his defensive backs in Dallas's victory over the Giants, when asked to rate the secondary on a scale of 1 to 10: ''Do we have to start at 1?''

title: Ex-Rep. Hance to Run For Governor of Texas
description: Kent Hance, a former Democratic member of Congress who switched parties in May after losing a bid last year for the United States Senate, has announced that he would enter the Republican primary for Governor next year.

title: HANOVER CUTS CREDIT CARD RATE
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest bank, said yesterday that it would lower its interest rate on credit cards and other revolving credit products to 17.8 percent, from 19.8 percent. It was the first such reduction by a major bank in four years.

title: CP Air, Nordair Planning to Merge
description: CP Air, which is wholly owned by Canadian Pacific Ltd., and Nordair Ltd. said that they had agreed in principle to merge for a $43 million exchange of stock. Under the proposal, Nordair's outstanding common shares would be exchanged for CP Air preferred shares valued at $43 million, or $17.57 a share, the companies said.

title: FIRE KILLS BOY, 3, AT PRINCE GEORGE HOTEL NOW USED BY CITY AS SHELTER
description: A 3-year-old boy died early yesterday in a fire at the Prince George Hotel, which has become one of New York City's largest shelters for homeless families.

title: Unesco Meeting Opens; U.S. Is Urged to Rejoin
description: A conference that could determine the future of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization opened here today with an appeal to the United States to rejoin the agency.

title: J.A.L. Insurance
description: The Japan Air Lines Company Ltd. said that it had received $35 million as hull insurance for the fuselage of the Boeing 747 that crashed on a mountain on Aug. 12, killing all but four of the 524 passengers aboard. J.A.L. had contracts with 19 insurance compaines in Japan for hull insurance, which is automatically paid unless the airline is solely responsible for an accident, J.A.L. said. Japan Air Lines and the Boeing Company of America have agreed to share the cost of compensating relatives of the victims, leaving a decision on how much each should pay until the end of the official investigation into the cause of the crash.

title: Jersey Officers Named In Assault Indictment
description: Four Elizabeth police officers have been indicted on charges of misconduct in connection with the alleged beating of a robbery suspect, Attorney General Irwin Kimmelman said today.

title: NOT JUST GARNISH, PARSLEY CAN PLAY A LEADING ROLE
description: LIKE a talented actor who has been typecast, parsley appears destined for the perpetual role of garnish. Dropped onto meats and fish chiefly to provide a touch of green, unceremoniously removed to the bread plate, if not the ashtray, by fully half the diners in America, is it any wonder, then, that parsley so often comes to work in limp dejection?

title: Comings and Goings
description: Graig Nettles, a former Yankee, signed a new contract with the San Diego Padres. The 41-year-old third baseman will reportedly be paid about $800,000 in 1986, his 18th major league season. . . . D. J. Dozier, the Penn State tailback who missed two games with a pulled groin muscle, is expected to play against Alabama on Saturday. . . . Kellen Winslow, the San Diego tight end who has been out with a knee injury since early last season, will start working out with the Chargers today and may play against the Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday. . . . A judge yesteday declined to dismiss narcotics and weapons charges against Joe Pepitone, the former Yankee first baseman. . . . Dick Balderson, director of player development for the Kansas City Royals, has joined the Seattle Mariners as vice president in charge of baseball operations. . . . John T. Landry, a breeder and Philip Morris vice president who helped develop the Marlboro Cup, and John C. Mabee, a California breeder who serves as president of Del Mar race track, have been elected to membership in the Jockey Club. . . . Bob Lurie, the owner of the San Francisco Giants, indicated yesterday that the team was turned down in its bid to share the Oakland Coliseum with the A's for a few years until a new stadium can be built in downtown San Francisco. ''It was clear to me that the A's may not support this proposal at all,'' he said after a lengthy meeting between the two teams.

title: HURRICANE THREAT POSED AS STORM NEARS FLORIDA
description: The storm that deluged Puerto Rico with torrential rains over the weekend appears well on the way toward becoming a full-fledged hurricane and presents a serious threat to the Florida and Georgia coasts, the Hurricane Warning Center in Coral Gables, Fla., said yesterday.

title: RIGHTS UNIT REVIEWS 123 NATIONS
description: Almost half the governments of the world held political prisoners in 1984, and many tortured inmates as an instrument of state policy or jailed citizens without charge or trial, according the annual report of a worldwide human rights monitoring group.

title: FIRE AT PATERSON CHEMICAL PLANT FORCES 200 TO FLEE THEIR HOMES
description: A three-alarm fire raged out of control for several hours in a chemical plant in Paterson, N.J., last night, forcing 200 residents from their nearby homes.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Named Roland Johnson scouting director and expanded the responsibilities of Joe McIlvaine, the director of player personnel.

title: BRITAIN ADRIFT: ARE THE OLD VALUES A HANDICAP, OR THE SAVING GRACE?
description: Six years after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took office determined to promote recovery, proud old Britain - birthplace of the Industrial Revolution, master of a third of the world in the 19th century, a Great Power only four decades ago - remains a nation in decline.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SOUNDS of chirp, chirp, chirp are heard on the Lexington Avenue IRT from Brooklyn to Manhattan. None of the passengers bother to look up. It's probably some joker with a plastic birdy tweeter. As the chirps grow louder, however, the eyes of Lisa Thiesing and others move slowly, suspiciously, along the length of the car, settling at last on a burly man with a hard hat on one knee and a big green sack on the other. Here is the source of the chirps.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IF a tree falls in the forest and no one is around to hear it, does it make any noise? The answer to this perennial puzzle is yes. Sound is generated when molecules of air are displaced, setting up a gradually widening series of ripples that resembles a wedge cut from the ripples on a lake after a fish jumps.

title: MAINE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE ACHILLE LAURO: OVER HALF A CENTURY, A SERIES OF CRISES AND MISHAPS
description: Collisions, fires, a sinking and governmental seizure - the Achille Lauro had a turbulent history even before her hijacking off the Egyptian coast on Monday.

title: PROGRESS IS SLIGHT IN CHRYSLER TALKS
description: The contract between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers expires Tuesday, and both sides report that little progress has been made in the talks that got under way Aug. 15.

title: LEADERS IN SENATE REACH COMPROMISE ON U.S. DEBT LIMIT
description: Republican and Democratic leaders in the Senate, after a day of partisan and sometimes testy wrangling, reached an agreement early today that was expected to open the way to approval later today of a short-term extension of the ceiling on the Government's debt.

title: The Israeli Air Raid Cannot Be Condoned
description: I am troubled about the idea that a nation whose citizens are victimized by terrorists has the right to hunt and kill anyone it believes to be responsible anywhere he can be found. That is Israel's justification for its air raid on the Palestine Liberation Organization headquarters in Tunisia. While the Administration has reserved judgment on the Tunisian facts, it sometimes supports the principle the Israelis have invoked.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET OFFER COULD BE A BEGINNING
description: The Reagan Administration, in its first full response to the recent Soviet arms proposals, said today that the measures could be the start of a ''successful process'' in the effort to reduce the nuclear weaponry of the two sides.

title: ORION PICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: HIJACKERS OF SHIP VOW AGAIN TO KILL 400 HELD HOSTAGE
description: The hijacking of an Italian cruise ship with more than 400 people aboard went into its second day today with the hijackers repeating their vow to kill the passengers and crew unless Israel frees 50 Palestinian prisoners.

title: REAGAN CURBS ENTRY OF CUBAN OFFICALS
description: President Reagan today imposed restrictions on the entry into the United States of Cuban officials.

title: USEFUL ITEM FOR BAKING
description: A KITCHEN sifter is vital for baking and sauce making. It separates fine particles from coarser ones or blends dry ingredients.

title: Dowsing, West Side Style
description: Zabar's is not fishing for sturgeon from that hole on West 80th Street. It is prospecting for water.

title: OFFICIAL OF FIRM TELLS OF BUYING G.O.P. TICKETS
description: A partner in the accounting firm that installed New Jersey's motor-vehicles computer system testified today that a top state official told him two weeks after the $6.5 million contract was awarded that it would be ''good business'' to buy tickets to the annual Governor's Ball.

title: CRUISE SHIP LINES REASSESS SECURITY
description: Shipowners and shipping industry analysts said yesterday that cruise ships were reassessing their security precautions as a result of the hijacking Monday of an Italian cruise ship.

title: Topics;   Forms of Nurture Winner
description: For all his adult life, Eddie Robinson has been a football coach, a darned good one. How good? On Saturday, his Grambling College team defeated Prairie View A. & M. to give him his 324th victory, more than any other coach in the history of college football.

title: Mexican Coast Is Hit by Hurricane
description: Hurricane Waldo washed onto Mexico's northwestern coast today behind heavy rain and high winds that drove 10,000 people from their homes and toppled a communications tower in Sinaloa state.

title: A DRAMA ON ROLE OF JOURNALISTS
description: THERE is no dearth of learned essays, seminars and panel discussions on the perceived role and responsibility of television news in reporting events. The singular achievement of ''Accepted Levels,'' a highly unusual drama on WNET at 11 o'clock tonight, is that it takes several of the issues involved and uses them to powerful effect. The 1983 film was made in Northern Ireland by Frontroom and the Belfast Film Workshop, with financial assistance from Britain's Channel Four.

title: FRONTIER BID SEEN AS BARGAIN
description: People Express Airlines will get a bargain if its agreement to acquire Frontier Airlines goes through, Robert McAdoo, the chief financial officer of People, said in an interview yesterday. He said People would have to put up only about $85 million of the $300 million cost.

title: AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF (COLO) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an after-tax gain of $201,528 from the sale of securities.

title: MAMEYES SURVIVORS RECALL FIRST MOMENTS
description: Some people recall hearing a thunderous crack and seeing a flash of light that momentarily set the hillside aglow. Others recall only the driving rain. Some felt their frail houses shudder.

title: ARMANI: SPARKLE, CHARM FOR EVENING
description: The spring collections peaked here with the showing Tuesday night of the Giorgio Armani collection in the theater of his headquarters on the Via Durini. Not a seam was out of place as the master tailor brought out his now-classic daytime look based on a precision-made broad-shouldered jacket. But there was a surprise. Using spangled fabrics that glittered as they caught the light and some prints, he reinterpreted his jackets and shirts for evening. His evening separates were applauded last season; this year they overshadowed the daytime clothes.

title: Ford, AMC to Cut Some Loan Rates
description: The Ford Motor Company and the American Motors Corporation said today that they would offer financing at below-market rates on some vehicles, in response to a similar plan announced earlier this week by the General Motors Corporation.

title: Soviet Trade Outlook
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that he thought the United States could increase trade with the Soviet Union without jeopardizing national security. However, Mr. Baldrige told the congressional Joint Economic Committee, ''Over all, the Soviet market is likely to remain a modest one for U.S. manufacturers.'' Last year the United States exported $3.3 billion worth of goods to the Soviet Union and had $600 million of imports. Mr. Baldrige said shipments to the Soviet Union could reach $5 billion within a few years.

title: STATE DEPT. ANGRY AT SPEEDY ACCORD WITH GUNMEN
description: The United States tonight assailed ''the brutal killing'' of an American aboard the hijacked Italian cruise ship, and it criticized Italy and Egypt for failing so far to announce that the hijackers would be prosecuted.

title: DECLINE FOUND IN PROPORTION OF BLACKS IN MEDICAL SCHOOLS
description: The proportion of entering medical students who are black has declined over the past decade, according to a new study, even though blacks have made up a larger part of the applicants and their admission test scores have increased.

title: PASSENGER SLAIN, 400 ARE SAFE; U.S. ASSAILS DEAL WITH CAPTORS
description: Four men identified as the hijackers of an Italian cruise ship surrendered in Egypt on Wednesday after a two-day drama in the eastern Mediterranean.

title: DINKINS GETS A POLICE GUARD AFTER REMARKS BY FARRAKHAN
description: Police protection was ordered yesterday for City Clerk David N. Dinkins in the aftermath of a speech at Madison Square Garden Monday by the Black Muslim minister Louis Farrakhan.

title: Jersey Woman Named As the Next to Be Slain
description: A New Jersey woman aboard the hijacked cruise ship Achille Lauro was reportedly singled out by terrorists to be the second hostage killed, and was spared only when she pleaded for her life, the American Ambassador to Egypt was quoted as saying.

title: 2 Plead Guilty To Killing Writer
description: A drifter and the victim's adopted son pleaded guilty yesterday to the murder last year of Paul T. Rogers, a writer who won the 1982 Editors' Book Award for his first novel, about the life of a male prostitute on Times Square.

title: Coors Forecast
description: The Adolph Coors Company expects a decline of about 20 percent in its third-quarter earnings, to 45 to 50 cents a share, compared with 58 cents a share a year ago, the company's president, Jeffrey Coors, told securities analysts. Mr. Coors said that earnings before taxes for the third quarter, ended Oct. 6, were higher than in the 1984 period, but net income declined because of a ''significant increase in the company's tax rate.'' Mr. Coors also said sales in several subsidiary operations were lower than expected.

title: FIRST NEW HAMPSHIRE BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 25 percent stock dividend payable Nov. 1.

title: SUMMIT ARMS PROSPECTS: SOVIET HOPE AND PESSIMISM
description: Interviews with a wide range of Soviet officials and foreign policy and scientific experts have revealed a mixture of hopefulness and pessimism over the prospects for progress on arms control at the summit meeting in Geneva next month.

title: PANEL VOTES TO END POLITICAL TAX CREDIT
description: Continuing to skip the most difficult tax issues, the House Ways and Means Committee moved today to abolish the credit taxpayers may now claim for political contributions and to tighten some enforcement procedures.

title: STAGEHAND HURT
description: Followers of Louis Farrakhan brawled with a group of stagehands early Tuesday morning after the Black Muslim minister's speech at Madison Square Garden, the police said yesterday. At least one stagehand was injured.

title: QUILTERS MAKING AN APPEAL FOR PEACE
description: THE inspiration for the Boise Peace Quilt Project, says Anne Hausrath, came one Sunday morning in 1981 when she and her friend, Diane Jones, heard a Utah woman describe the devastating effects of desert nuclear tests near her town in the 1950's. Hundreds of people have sued the Federal Government over the effects of fallout from the tests, which the woman said had caused her brother and several of her friends to die of cancer.

title: A CRUSIE LINE IS DROPPING SOME PORT CALLS IN EGYPT AND ISRAEL
description: A cruise line said yesterday that it was dropping scheduled port calls in Egypt and Israel after the two-day hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro that left one American passenger dead.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: U.S. GAS REGULATION OVERHAULED
description: The Government today overhauled its regulation of the natural gas industry in a move likely to increase competition and thus lower prices for residential, business and industrial consumers.

title: KOCH FACING IMPATIENCE OVER SERVICES
description: Mayor Koch still has a campaign to wage and a general election to win. But with his comfortable primary victory behind him and an equivalent mandate likely to greet him in November, the focus is on the future now at City Hall.

title: Rights Group's Accusations Called 'Groundless' by China
description: China dismissed as ''groundless'' today a report by the human rights group Amnesty International that criticized what it said were widespread executions and human rights violations in China.

title: POP: LATIN SONGS BY ROY BROWN
description: The Latin American ''nueva cancion'' (''new song'') movement has encouraged songwriters to place modern messages in songs that mix local traditions with international pop. Roy Brown, one of Puerto Rico's leading nueva cancion singers, opened a series of songwriters' performances Monday and Tuesday at Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street.

title: Talks Fail on 1988 Games
description: North and South Korea failed today after two days of talks to find a way of sharing the 1988 Olympic Summer Games, but the countries agreed to meet again next January.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: I NEVER PLAYED THE GAME. By Howard Cosell with Peter Bonventre. 380 pages. Morrow. $18.95. DISTANT REPLAY. By Jerry Kramer with Dick Schaap. 236 pages. Putnam. $16.95. DESPITE the loud noise it has already made with its disparaging remarks about other members of the sportscasting profession, Howard Cosell's latest book, ''I Never Played the Game,'' is not a pig's bladder full of hot and poisonous air.

title: SATOR CONFIDENT AS RANGERS BEGIN ANEW
description: A day after one of the most hectic days around the Rangers and a day before the opening of the season, the coach went home early.

title: AGENT SUGGESTS PATRIOTIC MOTIVE IN ESPIONAGE TRIAL
description: A naval analyst indicated to Government agents that he had given classified photographs to the press because he wanted the American people to know the extent of the Soviet military buildup, a Navy investigator testified today in Federal court.

title: Green Traded To Dolphins
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers traded Hugh Green, twice a Pro Bowl linebacker, to the Miami Dolphins yesterday for first- and second-round selections in the 1986 draft.

title: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * John L. Kelly is retiring from Avtex Fibers to run Kelhan Ltd., communications consultants.

title: Klosterman Sues Express, U.S.F.L.
description: Don Klosterman, the former president and general manager of the Los Angeles Express, filed suit Tuesday, alleging breach of contract against the team and the United States Football League.

title: North America Needs a Common Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Emilio Medici, a Brazil Leader
description: Gen. Emilio Garrastazu Medici, President of Brazil from 1969 to 1974, died today in a hospital after being ill for months, doctors said. He was 79 years old.

title: ARABS RENOUNCING SEIZURE OF VESSEL
description: The hijacking of the Italian cruise liner Achille Lauro has emerged as the most unpopular event in the Arab world in the history of the Palestinian guerrilla movement against Israel.

title: CLARK, J L MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Transactions
description: FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Reactivated David Frye, linebacker. Waived Roy Harris, defensive lineman.

title: Compudyne Stake
description: The Compudyne Corporation said Frank J. Kelley, its chairman and president, and members of his family are negotiating for the sale of their stake in the company, which amounts to about 43 percent of the voting rights.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL CONDEMNS SEIZURE OF SHIP AS UNJUSTIFIABLE AND CRIMINAL
description: The Security Council today unanimously condemned the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro by assailants identified as Palestinians.

title: CRAXI REGRETS DEATH, BUT SAYS CRISIS ENDED 'HAPPILY'
description: Italy's Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, was told of the slaying of an American passenger aboard the hijacked cruise liner just as he was about to announce the peaceful conclusion of the incident.

title: DEVILS FORWARDS BRING NEW HOPE
description: With the addition of the forwards Mark Johnson, Peter McNab and Perry Anderson, the Devils expect to be more productive this season, which they open in Philadelphia against the Flyers Thursday night.

title: NEW LIFE FOR THE BROWNSTONES OF BEDFORD-STUYVESANT
description: IT is a mansion, or nearly a mansion, that Arthur and Esther Bramwell did not know they wanted. ''A friend introduced me to the house three years ago,'' said Mr. Bramwell, a deputy county clerk in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. ''I told him I already had a house nearby that was paid for, that I didn't need it. He said I had to see it.''

title: CONCERN OVER CHARGES ON CREDIT CARDS GROWS
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company's action on Tuesday to lower the interest it charges on its Visa and Mastercard accounts comes amid growing concern in Congress and among consumer groups about those charges.

title: SENATE SEEKS BAR TO DEFICITS BY '91 IN BIPARTISAN VOTE
description: Ending a weeklong deadlock, the Senate gave overwhelming bipartisan approval today to a plan to require a balanced budget by 1991.

title: GIANTS AND BENGALS: OLD BUT NEW RIVALS
description: The game Sunday in Cincinnati between the Giants and the Bengals will be like a blind date.

title: S.E.C. CITES KIDDER, PEABODY
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company mishandled ''at least $145 million of its customers' fully paid-for securities,'' according to an administrative complaint issued yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Horse Racing;   ALL 13 IN YOUNG AMERICA GIVEN A CHANCE
description: What a good year to have 2-year-olds who can run a little bit. The Meadowlands is giving away $500,000 tonight in the Young America Stakes, and virtually every one of the 13 moderate juveniles in the field has some kind of chance.

title: MURDOCH TO UNITE FOX, METROMEDIA
