description: In a sweeping restructuring, Rupert Murdoch plans to consolidate his recently purchased 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation with his six Metromedia Inc. television stations to form Fox Inc., which will include a planned Fox Television Network.

title: Dangerous Shortage Of Hospital Beds
description: To the Editor:

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a provision for plant closings of $14,725,000.

title: COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Writer in Belushi Case Is Jailed for Contempt
description: A freelance writer today was ordered jailed on contempt charges for refusing to either answer questions about his interview with the woman accused of killing the comedian John Belushi or surrender a tape of the conversation.

title: Two Kidnapped Britons Are Freed in Lebanon
description: Two British women abducted two weeks ago in West Beirut have been released unharmed.

title: CONGRESS IS SAID TO APPROVE MORE AID TO AFGHAN REBELS
description: Congress was reported today to have secretly approved about $250 million in further covert military aid to rebels fighting the Soviet-backed Government in Afghanistan.

title: E.P.A. Administrator Is Out of Step on Acid Rain
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INDIA Perhaps the next-best place to learn about India these days, outside of India itself, is New York. The city is playing a focal role in our country's nationwide Festival of India, a yearlong event distinguished by a profusion of performance and exhibition. The newest event in the schedule is the exhibition ''Akbar's India: Art from the Moghul City of Victory,'' which opens today at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 71st Street (288-6400).

title: Iraq Reports New Raid On Iranian Oil Terminal
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes had raided the Kharg Island oil terminal in Iran for the second time in 24 hours and had attacked a ''large'' naval target near the Iranian coast.

title: CHARGES DROPPED IN TEAMSTER CASE
description: A Federal judge today dismissed bribery and embezzlement charges against a former teamsters union official after prosecutors said they would rather have the case dropped than confirm or deny whether the teamsters president, Jackie Presser, was an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Farm Credit Banks Unit In $512 Million Offering
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation, which sells bonds to finance agricultural loans of the Farm Credit System, is offering $512 million of 10 1/4 percent bonds due April 20, 1988, at a price of 100 through various securities dealers.

title: WILTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Advertising;   CBS Seeks Magazine 'Culture'
description: ''It's been a hell of a year. The best of years and the worst of years,'' said Peter G. Diamandis, president of CBS Magazines. He was telling his peers about the difficulties of meshing two companies after a major acquisition while the parent company is being bombarded by a series of takeover bids.

title: Temblor Off Alaska Hits Vulnerable Area
description: A moderately severe earthquake struck the sea floor south of the Shumagin Islands and the Alaska Peninsula yesterday. While it was felt in nearby communities, no damage was reported.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: PUMPKIN CARVING
description: Harvest Weekend, New York Botanical Garden, Bronx; 212-220-8700.

title: A PARED-DOWN OLIVEIRA
description: THE eagerness of the New York Film Festival's selection committee to represent Manoel de Oliveira in this year's schedule is understandable: This 77-year-old Portuguese director has lately been emerging as a significant and greatly underrated figure in world cinema, and almost none of his work has been seen by American audiences.

title: EX-HUSBAND OF ONE IS CHARGED
description: Two sisters were shot to death and a passer-by was critically wounded yesterday when one sister's former husband opened fire on a busy commercial block in Jamaica, Queens, the police said.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Clare Drake, the hockey coach at Alberta College in Edmonton, became the most victorious coach in North American collegiate hockey when the Alberta Golden Bears defeated the Red Deer College Kings, 7-6. That brought Drake's 25-season record to 556-240-34, or one victory more than the 555-295-39 record turned in by the late John MacInnes of Michigan Tech over 26 seasons. . . . Sulaiman Nyambui of Tanzania, who specialized in the mile in his years on the Texas-El Paso championship track team, will move up a bit in distance Oct. 27 when he takes part in the New York City Marathon. . . . Roberto Medina, the escaped felon who was recognized and then seized in July after he appeared in a nationally televised bout with Meldrick Taylor, was sentenced to two extra years in prison after he fought 14 professional bouts as a fugitive.

title: Cosell Benches Himself
description: For Howard Cosell, it was either work in the broadcast booth or not work the World Series at all, judging from a statement released by ABC Sports yesterday. ''ABC Sports offered Howard the pre-game show, with the feeling he would be excellent in the role of pre-game anchorman, but Howard refused that position and suggested that he not work the World Series at all,'' the statement said. Al Michaels will do the play-by-play, with Jim Palmer and Tim McCarver offering commentary, and Michaels and Reggie Jackson will anchor the pre-game show.

title: Gloria Safier, Agent For Writers and Actors
description: Gloria Safier, a longtime theatrical and literary agent, died yesterday at her apartment in Manhattan. She was 63 years old.

title: Landmark Collaboration On the West Side
description: Neighbors of the Universalist Church on Central Park West wanted to help fix the steps. Now, they are about to embark on an unusual experiment in the governance of a landmark building.

title: Bridge: Outstanding Defensive Play Is Made in a Quebec Match
description: Brilliant defensive plays are quite rare, and when they do occur they attract a great deal of attention. The diagramed deal, played last month in Quebec, is likely to find its way into many books.

title: Mortgage Auction
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation auctioned $200 million of 11 percent, 15-year mortgage participation certificates yesterday at an average price of 99 14/32, to yield 10.83 percent. The certificates, which are backed by a pool of 15-year fixed-rate home mortgages, are offered at various prices through securities dealers.

title: S.& P. Lowers Its Ticor Rating
description: The claims-paying ability rating of the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company has been lowered to CCC from AA, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Israel's Economy Is Recuperating Nicely
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Argentine Junta Faces Military Trial
description: The military junta that led Argentina to defeat in its 1982 conflict with Britain over the Falkland Islands will face a public court-martial next month, a spokesman for the Supreme Military Tribunal said today.

title: Robbery Suspect Seized At Bush's Residence
description: A man accused of holding up a taxicab at gunpoint jumped a security fence at Vice President Bush's residence today but was cornered by police dogs and arrested, the authorities said.

title: The Rambo Doctrine
description: ''This is not an invasion of Cambodia.'' - President Nixon, announcing the U.S. invasion of Cambodia, April 30, 1970.

title: Hanson Seeks Court Order
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British company trying to take over the SCM Corporation, asked the Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday to order the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company not to help Merrill Lynch Capital Markets get control of two key SCM businesses.

title: CALIFORNIAN SPENT $1.1 MILLION ON ILLINOIS RACE
description: Michael R. Goland, the largest independent spender in the history of elections, according to new Federal Election Commission figures, is a publicity-shy California entrepreneur, He spent $1.1 million last year in a personal campaign, not organized or coordinated with any candidate, to bring about the defeat of Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois, according to late filings and tabulations, the commission said. Earlier reports filed by Mr. Goland stated that he had spent $419,573 toward defeating Mr. Percy. However, late reports and delayed tabulations brought the total to $1.1 million ''sometime in September,'' a commission spokesman said.

title: SOUTHEAST COAST POISED FOR STORM
description: Tropical storm Isabel, with winds near 65 miles an hour, headed toward Florida today, prompting gale warnings from Cape Canaveral to Savannah, Ga.

title: Beatty Makes Settlement In Suit Over 'Reds' Data
description: A retired copy editor for the Tacoma News Tribune has reached an out-of-court settlement in his suit against Warren Beatty over the Oscar-winning movie ''Reds.'' The former copy editor, William M. Greene, 88 years old, declined yesterday to disclose the terms.

title: RAIDS AND TERROR: VIOLENT PAST OF THE PALESTINIAN FACTIONS
description: The Palestine Liberation Front, the organization to which the hijackers of the Italian cruise ship claim they belong, conducted several novel, stunt-like terrorist raids into Israel in 1981, some using hang gliders and hot-air balloons.

title: CONSUMER DEBT ROSE IN AUGUST
description: Americans took on $6.31 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in August, only slightly more than the July level, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1985
description: International

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PROMISES REPORTED AT EDWARDS TRIAL
description: Two state workers have testified that they were told their careers would be advanced if they helped approve a hospital project in which Edwin Edwards, who is now the Governor of Louisiana, had an interest.

title: Statements Set Today In the Gambino Trial
description: Opening statements are scheduled to start today in the trial of the reputed head of the Gambino organized-crime group and nine others on charges of operating a car-theft ring and conspiring to commit several murders.

title: CONCERT: A SINOPOLI PREMIERE
description: THE roll call of composers who have turned to conducting and done well at that craft is long. Try Liszt, Wagner, Berlioz and Mahler for a start. In our time, Leonard Bernstein and Pierre Boulez are prominent among those who have pursued the double career with some success. The latest composer to achieve a degree of fame on the podium is Giuseppe Sinopoli, who appeared in both guises last night when he led the New York Philharmonic in a suite from his opera, ''Lou Salome.''

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Avalon Corp. said it intends to begin a tender offer for all outstanding common shares of Maynard Oil Co. for $6 a share, or a total of about $42 million.

title: Moseby Loses Call, But Wins the Game
description: There was so much indecision around him that Lloyd Moseby seemed lost, the ball still sitting precariously in the top of his mitt, his hand still held aloft as he waited for some kind of signal. When it finally came, Moseby was a mixture of confusion and frustration, his afternoon of apparent triumph suddenly gone bad.

title: KINARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $313,000 from the sale of real estate for the quarter and a tax credit of $245,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: Choosing the U.N.'s Next Refugee Commissioner
description: The hoopla and high protocol surrounding the current session of the General Assembly cannot obscure the fact that the United Nations at 40 is increasingly on trial in the United States. U.N.-bashing in Congress has become as prevalent as U.S.-bashing in the United Nations, and both sides need to look for confidence-building measures to halt the trend.

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: On Aug. 30, 1985 the company was acquired by members of its founding families in a leveraged buyout. The company's third quarter reporting period was extended by one week.

title: STAGE: 'TANGO ARGENTINO' AT THE MARK HELLINGER
description: FORGET about the deficit. Stop brooding over the state of the New York subway system.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-earlier per share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 28, 1985. The 1984 amounts do not include the results of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Kearny which was acquired on Oct. 1, 1984.

title: TEACHER GROUP BACKS AIDS TESTS FOR SOME
description: The National Education Association said today that schools ought to be able to require tests to screen for exposure to AIDS in students or teachers when there was ''reasonable cause'' to believe they had been infected.

title: OCE-VAN DER GRINTEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MT BAKER BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. The year-ago 9 months per share figure is not shown because the company went public in September 1984.

title: CONCERT: PHILADELPHIANS PERFORM 'RIGOLETTO'
description: A CONCERT version of ''Rigoletto'' in New York? Who needs it, you might say.

title: FIRST COLONIAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SITE OF PUERTO RICAN DISASTER MAY BE SEALED AS MASS GRAVE
description: Health officials today asked the Government to consider sealing a valley north of here as a mass grave for landslide victims.

title: To Make New York a Better Place (Contd.)
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET LEADING BID TO DISMISS UNESCO'S AMERICANS
description: The second day of a Unesco conference here was dominated today by a Soviet-led effort to dismiss all American nationals working for the agency, from which the United States resigned in protest at the end of last year.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $3,652,000 gain from the sale of the company's leasehold interest in an office building, the sale of its interest in London Interstate Bank Ltd., and a change in reporting trust fees.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a non-recurring after- tax gain from the sale of land of $570,000 for the quarter and the year. c-Including a gain from a reduction of income tax expense due to changes in tax law of $850,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: By Acclamation Of Manhattan Democrats
description: The three main attractions at the annual Manhattan Democratic fund-raising cocktail party last night at Tavern on the Green illustrated one of the ways of forgiveness among politicians.

title: Arguments End in Vote Trial
description: The prosecution and defense completed closing arguments today in the vote-fraud trial of the two defendants, and the jury in Federal District Court was expected to begin deliberating Thursday. The Government has alleged in the two-and-a-half-week trial that Spiver Gordon, 46 years old, and Frederick Daniels, 37, defrauded citizens through conspiracy, mail fraud, furnishing false information to an election official and voting more than once in the September 1984 Democratic primary and runoff in Greene County.

title: FIRST EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ex-Councilman Loses Arms Case
description: A former City Councilman, Joseph Savino Jr. of the Bronx, was convicted yesterday of illegally obtaining a machine gun and three pistols with silencers.

title: Bruce-Marcade
description: Robert Bruce Industries said it had signed a letter of intent to buy a 51 percent stake in Marcade Group Inc., a financially troubled maker of women's apparel.

title: ROCK LYRICS IRK REAGAN
description: President Reagan complained today that the music industry and newspapers and magazines are providing children with ''glorification of drugs, violence and perversity,'' and that pornographers have more rights than parents.

title: RESEARCHERS REPORT PROGRESS IN FIGHT AGAINST AIDS VIRUS
description: Federal health officials today reported some progress toward developing drugs to combat AIDS but warned that the quest for a cure was an ''almost impossible task.''

title: 3 Philippine Convicts Slain
description: Three prisoners were shot dead and eight escaped in two jailbreaks in the Philippines today, the police said. The three were shot by policemen after they fled at dawn from a jail in Manila's suburban district of Quezon City, a spokeman said. Eight men escaped in a dawn jailbreak in Baguio, 125 miles north of Manila, by drilling a hole in a bathroom wall, the Philippine News Agency said.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $9.7 million.

title: Boston to Try Again On City Hall Guidebook
description: A guidebook for City Hall employees has been sent back to the drawing board after drawing snickers for such sections as ''Other fun things to do on my lunch hour'' and ''How do I get to City Hall?''

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including after-tax closing costs of the company's Canadian lumber/ chip mill of $2,334,000.

title: Understudy In Department Store
description: A woman called B. Altman & Company and asked for Linens.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Dodgers vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Los Angeles, Game No. 2 of the four-of-seven-game National League championship series. Joaquin Andujar, 2-0 against the Dodgers this season, is scheduled to start for the Cardinals against Orel Hershiser, 1-1 against St. Louis this season. (Television - Channel 4, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:30 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Knicks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M., exhibition. Patrick Ewing of the Knicks faces Darryl Dawkins of the Nets in a matchup of two physical centers. Ewing, the No. 1 draft choice of the Knicks, has fouled out and been ejected on technicals in his two previous exhibition games, both defeats. This will be the first exhibition for the Nets and the debut as coach for Dave Wohl, former assistant with the Los Angeles Lakers. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Washington Capitals, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M., season opener. The Rangers start their 60th season with a new coach, Ted Sator, former assistant with the Philadelphia Flyers, and without several well-known players from last season, among them Pierre Larouche, Glen Hanlon, Nick Fotiu and Mike Rogers. Washington won five games from the Rangers last season, but both teams were eliminated by Philadelphia in the playoffs. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.) Devils vs. Flyers, at Philadelphia, season opener, 7:35 P.M. Craig Wolanin, an 18-year-old defenseman from Grosse Pointe, Mich., the Devils' No. 1 draft choice and No. 3 over all in the league, makes his pro debut.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including an unusual after-tax investment gain of $4,344,000.

title: Odd Team Engineered Telepictures' Success
description: On the surface, Michael Jay Solomon and Michael Garin might not seem to have much in common. Mr. Solomon, 47, is a college dropout who spent his early career in the movie business, while Mr. Garin, 39, is a Harvard philosophy graduate who started in publishing at Time Inc.

title: CHILE CHALLENGED ON MILITARY RULE
description: An agency of the Organization of American States, in a new report that the Chilean Government tried to block, has called on the military Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet to restore representative democracy.

title: Hunter's Gun Kills Him
description: State Representative Daniel DeBonis, a Vermont legislator for 20 years, died Tuesday in a hunting accident. The New York state police said Mr. DeBonis, a 70-year-old Democrat, was bird hunting on his farm, which straddles the Vermont-New York border, when he tripped over a cornstalk and his 12-gauge shotgun fired, striking him in the head. His body was found by an employee, the police said.

title: CAESARS ORDERED TO CLOSE FOR DAY FOR VIOLATIONS OF GAMBLING RULES
description: The Casino Control Commission today ordered Caesars to close its Atlantic City casino for a day as a penalty for violating credit, deposit and reporting regulations to cater to a heavy gambler.

title: Panel Votes Toxic Waste Bill
description: The effort to renew and expand the stalled program to clean up abandoned toxic waste dumps cleared a hurdle today when a House subcommittee approved a bill requiring that cleanups be started at 600 sites through 1990.

title: Genetic Test Is Discovered For Common Kidney Disease
description: Researchers have developed a genetic test for a kidney disease that afflicts 400,000 Americans and is responsible for one in 10 kidney dialysis patients.

title: KARPOV PARRIES KASPAROV'S GAMBIT
description: Prudent defense by Anatoly Karpov threw cold water on a gambit attempt to gain the upper hand by his 22-year-old challenger, Gary Kasparov, in the 13th game of the world championship chess match in Moscow on Tuesday.

title: EQK REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-No year-ago results are available because the company began operations on March 13, 1985.

title: A SPINNING WHEEL FOR MOZAMBIQUE
description: A RARE early-19th-century American vertical spinning wheel is being used as a prototype in a project to develop spinning and weaving industries for women in rural areas of Mozambique.

title: Dow Up by 1.23 as Volume Gains
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday for their first gain in nearly a week, buoyed by special-situation issues.

title: Workfare Doesn't Work
description: Maimonides, the 12th century Jewish scholar, defined eight ascending levels of charity. At the lowest level is charity given grudgingly, where donor and recipient know each other. The levels ascend according to willingness to give and anonymity. At the highest level, a donor gladly helps a stranger until he can break free of the need of assistance. Legislators in California aspire to the highest virtue by helping the poor in that state find jobs so they will not need charity.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * David Eick has been appointed senior vice president and management supervisor at Campbell-Ewald Co., Warren, Mich.

title: Wyoming Bonds
description: The Wyoming Community Development Authority is offering $75 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: CHEERS, THEN HEARTBREAK, AT APARTMENT ON 10TH STREET
description: At the home of Leon and Marilyn Klinghoffer, the celebration was just beginning. Giddy with joy and relief, the two Klinghoffer daughters, joined by relatives and close friends, held their champagne glasses aloft, about to toast their parents' deliverance.

title: E.P.A. Administrator Is Out of Step on Acid Rain
description: To the Editor:

title: Trevino Not Retiring
description: Lee Trevino has been a cutup on the golf course for far too long to be taken seriously every time he opens his mouth, but that, according to Trevino, is just what happened when me made a little joke in El Paso, Tex., earlier this week, after someone asked if he planned to cut back on his tournament play. ''Vaguely,'' Trevino said yesterday, ''I threw an answer at them in jest: 'Ah, hell, I'm retired.'

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-earlier nets were restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1985.

title: E.P.A. PROPOSES 5-YEAR PROGRAM AIMED AT RADIOACTIVE RADON GAS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed a national program to lessen the threat to public health from radon, a naturally occurring radioactive gas that can cause lung cancer.

title: The Magnolia Twins
description: Back in the summer of 1944, just after the Democratic Party had nominated President Roosevelt to run for a fourth term and had chosen Senator Harry S. Truman as his running mate, the two men met for lunch, al fresco, under the Jackson magnolia on the South Lawn of the White House. The table was set with crystal and silver from the Coolidge Administration.

title: Market Place;   A New View Of Polaroid
description: IN an age of camcorders and other sophisticated video equipment, the technology of the Polaroid Corporation's brand of instant photography may seem a little tame. This public image problem, often aggravated by pictures of less-than-professional quality, did not end with the consumers, and the treatment received by the company from investors in recent years has been equally harsh.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,908,000.

title: YUL BRYNNER, THEATER'S 'KING,' DIES
description: Yul Brynner, the actor who this past summer completed a triumphal return engagement of his hit musical, ''The King and I,'' died early this morning at New York Hospital after a long bout with cancer. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AID SEEN FOR BANK IN CANADA
description: Canada's big six banks are quietly aiding the Mercantile Bank of Canada, in an effort to avoid a repeat of the federal Government's forced closings of two small Alberta banks last month.

title: MCENROE PLANNING TO SHAPE UP AT LAST
description: Someday, when John McEnroe reveals the secrets of his success, the physiologists, nutritionists and workout specialists who are so prevalent in sports will be shocked. For among McEnroe's revelations will be no special hints about dieting, no strenuous physical regimen, and no sit-ups.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
REAGAN TAX STUMPING FOUND TO FALL SHORT
description: As President Reagan's campaign to overhaul the Federal income tax system draws to a close, some aides and Congressional leaders agree that he has failed to generate public enthusiasm behind the plan.

title: CARTER UNDERGOES SURGERY
description: Three days after the end of the season, Gary Carter of the Mets underwent arthroscopic surgery at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday to repair torn cartilage in his right knee, and he went home afterward saying he would be ''100 percent for next season.''

title: Bandits Rob Toronto Bank
description: Two armed bandits stole nearly $730,000 in cash in a daylight robbery of a Brink's guard in an office building in the city's financial center Tuesday afternoon, the Toronto police said today. They said the thieves made off with bags of money in American, Swiss and West German currency after pouncing on a lone guard on a regular pickup.

title: EL BARRIO RESIDENTS WORRY AND WAIT
description: All along East 116th Street, the commercial heart of New York City's Puerto Rican Barrio, people were talking yesterday of almost nothing but ''la tragedia'' - the devastating tropical storm that struck Puerto Rico this week, leaving several hundred people dead and thousands homeless.

title: TALES OF GRACE UNDER CRITICISM
description: ONE finds amusing literary anecdotes in the oddest places. One of these odd places is Philip McFarland's recently published ''Sea Dangers: The Affair of the Somers,'' a compelling account of an incident that occurred in 1842 involving the execution aboard ship of three suspected mutineers.

title: Sencer Testifies Adults Are Main AIDS Threat
description: The city's Health Commissioner said yesterday that AIDS was more likely to be spread by the more than 400,000 adults who carry the virus in the city than by a 7-year-old girl afflicted with the disease.

title: Net Progress
description: Last month a group of tennis-playing American tourists went to the Soviet Union for a series of friendship matches with ordinary Soviet citizens (Sports World Specials, Sept. 9). Now they have returned to the United States, and according to Alan Boltin, the California pro who organized the trip, it was a great success - even if the Soviet players turned out to be not so ordinary.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THIS week, as occasionally in the past, the Home Improvement column will be devoted to questions and answers about some of the problems most frequently encountered by do-it-yourselfers. Q. We are having a problem with several window shades in our living room. About half the time they roll up and down fine and the shades stay put. At other times, after we have pulled the shade down to the position desired, there is a sudden loud noise as though the spring has unwound, then the shade loses all its tension and I have to take it down and rewind it. The shade then works fine for a while before it acts up again. The shades are expensive, so I don't want to get new ones. Is there any way to repair these? A. The first thing to check is the slotted bracket that holds the shade up at one end (one bracket has a slot for the flat pin; the other has a round hole for the pin at the other end of the shade).

title: Shultz to Go to Europe For Summit Briefings
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will fly to Brussels on Tuesday to brief allied foreign ministers and diplomats on the Administration's plans for the meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, scheduled for Nov. 19-20 in Geneva, State Department officials said today.

title: UNION CALLS FIRST CHRYSLER OFFER 'INADEQUATE'
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers said today that the first economic proposal made by the Chrysler Corporation in the current contract talks was ''woefully inadequate.''

title: All the Better to Write By
description: The reporters who cover Vice President Bush know that when they fly with him, they can't all have window seats. But when they learned that for Mr. Bush's trip to China most of them would be sitting in a converted cargo plane with no windows at all, well, that was a bit much, and there was whining.

title: SHOW OF ITALIAN LAMP DESIGN
description: SOME of the most innovative lighting designs produced since World War II are to be seen in ''The Italian Lamp, 1945-1985, a Collection,'' an exhibition that opens today and runs through Nov. 15 at Furniture of the 20th Century, 227 West 17th Street.

title: State Cautions Schools In Jersey AIDS Dispute
description: The New Jersey Education Department said today that two local school boards would face state sanctions if they did not allow children exposed to AIDS into their classrooms.

title: A NEW PHONE BOOK IS FAMILY-ORIENTED
description: WHERE can parents find a listing of entertainment ticket services, or a youngster find ice-skating rinks or comic book stores?

title: E.E.C. Backs Steel Bid
description: The executive commission of the European Economic Community said today that it had authorized the British Steel Corporation to buy the steel coils business of Alphasteel Ltd. of Britain. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Rates Steady in a Slow Day
description: The uncertain outlook for interest rates and questions about the timing of the Treasury's huge offerings continue to keep rates little changed in light activity.

title: UGANDA AIDE ASSERTS REBELS CAN HAVE GOVERNMENT ROLE
description: The Justice Minister of Uganda told the General Assembly today that his country was prepared to include a rebel group in the newly formed Government, which came to power after a military coup last July.

title: Genex Sues G. D. Searle
description: G. D. Searle & Company was accused today of fraud and securities laws violations by the Genex Corporation, which for two years has supplied Searle with a key ingredient for the production of aspartame, the sugar-substitute Searle markets as Nutrasweet and Equal.

title: SOHN CATCHING PASSES, PRAISE
description: When the Jets opened camp in July, the wide receiver Kurt Sohn, who had shown promise two summers earlier, seemed to be on his way out.

title: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan to Jennings & Carmichael.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have made it clear to all concerned that we will do everything possible to see that those responsible are brought to justice.'' - Statement by the White House and the State Department. [A11:6.]

title: 2 Liberal Leaders Back Koch in Race
description: Two state Liberal Party leaders split with their own party nominee yesterday and endorsed Mayor Koch, whom they had vehemently criticized in recent years.

title: BOOK FAIR IN FRANKFURT
description: The Frankfurt Book Fair, widely regarded as the most important annual event in the international book trade, officially opened today with the attendance of fewer countries than last year but with more publishers represented than ever before in its 37-year history.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $9.8 million.

title: A.T.& T. Offers A New Computer
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company expanded its line of computer offerings again yesterday, announcing a new personal computer, an addition to its line of minicomputers, new printers and circuit boards that enhance existing machines.

title: Letter: On Bilingual Education;   Learning Better in a Native Tongue
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex On a Platter
description: ''We should listen more carefully to popular music,'' said a public figure 15 years ago, ''because at its best it is worthy of more serious appreciation, and at its worst it is blatant drug-culture propaganda.''

title: LITTLE COMMENT FROM UTILITIES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Utility companies serving the three-state region around New York City generally declined to comment yesterday on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's revisions of rules governing the transportation of natural gas, saying they have not seen the new rules.

title:
GARDENING;

STREET-TOUGH TREES FOR URBAN DESERTS
description: ON New York City streets, sometimes even the fittest barely survive. This year, because of heavy applications of de-icing salts followed by a drought, street trees are being severely tested. Indeed, two of the most successful and widely planted trees, the little-leaf linden and Bradford Callery pear, showed significant leaf damage alarmingly early this year.

title: CAPTAIN: 'THEY SAID, WE'VE KILLED A MAN'
description: Following is a transcript of a telephone interview by the Italian television with Capt. Gerardo de Rosa of the Achille Lauro, as recorded and translated by The New York Times:

title: INTERVIEW WITH EGYPT'S AMBASSADOR TO U.S.
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of an interview last night with el-Sayed Abdel Raouf el-Reedy, the Egyptian Ambassador to the United States, on the ABC News program ''Nightline,'' as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BANK MONEY ACCOUNTS AND C.D.'S GAIN A BIT
description: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market accounts made minor advances for the week ended yesterday, while money market mutual funds moved slightly lower for the second week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1985
description: The Economy

title: NEW YORK PANEL PROPOSES A CUT IN NEW DOCTORS
description: A New York State commission has recommended a plan that would cut by 30 percent the number of doctor-training programs in hospitals, and has won the support of the state's top health and education officials. The plan would also prevent graduates of foreign medical schools from entering the remaining programs.

title: U.S. BORROWS $5 BILLION, BUT STAYS BELOW CEILING
description: The Treasury Department, refusing to wait further while Congress debated raising the ceiling on the Federal debt, today borrowed $5 billion to cover Government checks already issued.

title: Spinks Loses a Crown
description: Michael Spinks, the two-division boxing champion, lost his bid to hold on to his World Boxing Council light-heavyweight crown long enough to add a third title to his string. Citing a rule prohibiting a champion from holding titles in more than one division, the W.B.C., meeting in Bangkok, Thailand, voted unanimously to strip Spinks of his light-heavyweight title, noting that W.B.C. rules require a dual champion to relinquish one of his titles within seven days of winning another.

title: VW's New Model
description: Volkswagen of America said that it would introduce an inexpensive new car built in Brazil to the United States market beginning in late 1986. Noel Phillips, president of Volkswagen of America, described the car as an ''entry'' model, cheaper than the company's Golf model, currently its lowest-priced car, at $6,900. Mr. Phillips said the new car would be made at existing Volkswagen plants in Brazil.

title: ONE DESIGNER'S FLIGHTS OF FANCY
description: THE fact that he was born in Cairo and lived in Paris is only a hint in understanding Patrick Naggar's work.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PACWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August 1985.

title: Westinghouse Net Up 13.8%
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation today reported that third-quarter net income rose 13.8 percent, to $148.6 million, or 85 cents a share, compared with $130.6 million, or 75 cents a share, in the 1984 quarter. Sales edged up 2.4 percent, to $2.61 billion, from $2.55 billion last year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ernst & Whinney, the accounting and consulting firm, has appointed Ronald S. Cooper managing partner of its Long Island office.

title: Politics;   Gary Hart: Stumped, and Not Yet Stumping
description: Senator Gary Hart is a frustrated man these days, recognized but unheard.

title: Rumsfeld to Be Blair Adviser
description: Donald H. Rumsfeld, who stepped down Sept. 30 after eight years as chairman and chief executive of G. D. Searle & Company, said today that he would serve on a part-time basis as a senior adviser to William Blair & Company, a Chicago investment banking firm.

title: ARAFAT ASKS THAT GUNMEN BE TURNED OVER TO P.L.O.
description: The head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, said at a news conference here tonight that he had asked Egypt to hand over to the P.L.O. the four hijackers of an Italian liner for trial if the four are indeed Palestinians.

title: HOUSE BACKS STUDY OF PAY EQUITY
description: The House today approved a bill authorizing a study of whether women and members of minorities in the Federal work force were victims of pay discrimination.

title: CULLEN/FROST BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOORE FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about computerized financial information and the companies that provide it omitted Bunker Ramo Information Systems. Bunker Ramo provides real-time information on equities, options, commodities and currencies and other financial instruments.

title: ONE THAT GOT AWAY REPLAYED BY SMITH
description: In between bites of a meatball, Ozzie Smith spoke about a ground ball, one that he didn't quite handle and which might have made the difference in tonight's playoff game.

title: VAIN EFFORT TO FREE SHCHARANSKY IS DESCRIBED
description: A leader of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry said today that efforts have been made for several years to involve a prominent East German lawyer in an effort to free Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet Jewish activist, but that so far there was no sign of a breakthrough.

title: KRUEGER, W A CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE CREATOR OF RICK'S CAFE SEEKS RIGHTS TO 'CASABLANCA' CHARACTERS
description: To Murray Burnett, it is as much a custody battle as a contractual dispute. He is fighting Warner Brothers for control of his children, who include Rick, an expatriate American cafe owner in Casablanca, a piano player named Sam and a host of others, with names like Victor Laszlo, Ugarte and Strasser.

title: REPAIRING DRAWERS IN OLD FURNITURE
description: IF early cabinetmakers had foreseen that the drawers they made would be so hard working, perhaps they would have made them differently. They made most drawer runners for chests of soft and poor-wearing woods.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: He found the second baseman on a soccer field. He knew the shortstop from the time the boy was 10 years old. He urged that the left fielder be chosen despite a bad back. And now 43-year-old Epy Guerrero, the Blue Jays' chief scout in the Dominican Republic and once a minor league third baseman, is watching Damaso Garcia, Tony Fernandez and George Bell help lift the Toronto Blue Jays into a 2-0 lead in the American League championship series that resumes tomorrow night in Kansas City.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $174,000 from discontinued operations.

title: GLORIA'S WINDFALL: FUEL FOR THE FIRE
description: IN the aftermath of Hurricane Gloria many owners of suburban and country homes are faced with fallen trees and branches. For those who have fireplaces or wood-burning stoves, this can be something of a bonanza -plenty of free firewood.

title: COLUMBUS MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHAPIRO SEEKS 'DEPOSIT' FUND FOR TOXIC WASTE
description: Peter Shapiro, the Democratic candidate for Governor, said today that if elected he would require companies that use toxic chemicals to deposit money with the state to pay for disposal of their toxic wastes.

title: SHELBY WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Summoned for the Summit
description: The White House has summoned two highly respected and trusted former Presidential aides, Kenneth L. Khachigian and Michael K. Deaver, to help President Reagan prepare for his visit to the United Nations later this month and his meeting in Geneva next month with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: WHERE TO GET DISASTER FACTS
description: For information about casualties in the Puerto Rican landslide, the extent of the damage and where the emergency zones are, call the Office of Civil Defense in Ponce, P.R., (809) 842-2323 or the Civil Defense office in San Juan (809) 724-0124.

title: To Make New York a Better Place (Contd.)
description: To the Editor:

title: Washburn Reinstated
description: Saying he has learned from his mistakes, Chris Washburn has been reinstated by the North Carolina State basketball team after completing his court-ordered community service in connection with charges stemming from the theft of a stereo at a dormitory last December that led to his suspension from the team. Washburn, a 6-foot-11-inch native of Hickory, N.C., not only finished 320 hours of community work, but also has made sufficient academic progress to return to the team, according to Coach Jim Valvano.

title: Horn & Hardart President Quits
description: The Horn & Hardart Company said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, John T. Gerlach, had resigned ''for personal reasons,'' effective Oct. 31.

title: Criminal's Offenses in Israel Backed as Basis for Sentence
description: A state appeals court ruled today that a judge acted properly when he took an Israeli citizen's criminal record abroad into account and sentenced him to extra prison time as a persistent offender under New Jersey law.

title: WEINBERGER DESCRIBES U.S. STARTEGY FOR 90'S
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Reagan Administration had abandoned past American military strategies as ''obsolete'' and devised ''a new defense strategy for the 1990's.''

title: LANDSLIDE TOLL TERMED WORST IN U.S. HISTORY
description: The landslide in Puerto Rico Monday appears to have been the most lethal in United States history, a landslide specialist at the United States Geological Survey in Reston, Va., said yesterday.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of 12 cents a share resulting from the sale of leasehold rights in Southeast's former headquarters. The gain was partially offset by a loss on the sale of lower-yielding investment securities.

title: KEAN HAS BIG EDGE IN FUND-RAISING
description: Less than a month before the election, Governor Kean's re-election campaign committee has received twice the amount of money as his Democratic opponent, Peter Shapiro, according to public records released here today.

title: CARTER LIBRARY RISES DESPITE PROBLEMS WITH MONEY AND ROAD
description: Driven by a lot of Coca-Cola money, the determination of a former President of the United States and the ambitions of the wealthiest private university in the Southeast, the newest Presidential library complex rises amid strain and controversy from a raw cut of red clay on a hilltop here.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $96,852,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ABRAMS GRANTED HIS CHOICE IN MOVE TO LOWER BROADWAY
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams has won the fight to move his office into one of lower Manhattan's most eye-catching buildings.

title: TURNOUT LOW AS SOUTH AFRICANS HOLD PEACE VIGILS
description: Thousands of South Africans of all races attended church services today in response to a call by a wide cross section of clergymen, including Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, for a national day of prayer for peace.

title: THE ARCHITECT OR THE DECORATOR: WHICH TO CHOOSE?
description: TRADITION has it that in a renovation project the architect shapes the structure, the walls, doors, windows and other elements that create the space, while the decorator applies the icing, the furniture, fabrics and colors for the interiors. But this is changing, especially in New York, where the lines between the professions are beginning to blur, with architects decorating and decorators and interior designers handling structural commissions.

title: MAYOR OF SAN DIEGO GUILTY OF CONSPIRACY AND PERJURY
description: Roger Hedgecock, one of San Diego's most popular and innovative Mayors, was found guilty today of conspiring to funnel more than $360,000 into his 1983 campaign and of lying about it.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
TWO DOCUMENTARIES
description: TWO very different, equally ambitious and ultimately unsatisfactory documentaries make up the program that will be shown in the New York Film Festival today at 6:15 P.M. They are Pierre Beuchot's ''Le Temps Detruit'' (Time Destroyed), 73 minutes, and ''Harvest of Despair,'' 55 minutes, produced and directed by Slavko Nowytski for the Ukrainian Famine Research Committee in Canada, with the assistance of the National Film Board of Canada.

title: Navy Finds a Defect In McDonnell Fighters
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation will be required to repair hundreds of F-18 fighter planes and fix the design of future planes because a critical part of the fuselage cracked in stress tests, a Navy officer said today.

title: LED U.S. STEEL FOR 13 YEARS
description: Roger M. Blough, who in 1962 locked horns with President Kennedy over a price increase by the United States Steel Corporation, died Tuesday at the family home in Hawley, Pa. He was 81 years old.

title: SCRAMBLING TV SIGNALS FROM SPACE
description: Around the nation, the 1.5 million Americans who own satellite dishes have been turning them on during certain hours and getting squiggly, incomprehensible pictures. Nothing is wrong with their antennas; rather, the deliberately scrambled signals are the result of a bitter confrontation between programmers and satellite dish owners.

title: DRIVE TO END DEFICITS: ODD BEDFELLOWS
description: Legislation that would mandate a balanced budget within the next five years has hit Capitol Hill like a hurricane, and the issue has been pushed ahead by a curious coalition of conservatives and liberals who are acting out of widely different, and even contradictory motives.

title: A TORY PLOT: CAN LIFE INITATE JEFFREY ARCHER'S ART?
description: In Jeffrey Archer's latest best seller, a novel about the ambitions that drive British politicians and the temptations fate casts in their way, there is an immensely successful woman who displays perfect self-discipline and wisdom in her walk-on role. The novelist calls his character Margaret Thatcher.

title: ELIZABETH KAPLAN
description: Elizabeth Kaplan, a leading figure in contract bridge, died of cancer Tuesday at her home in Manhattan.

title: Massachusetts
description: The Massachusetts Convention Center Authority is offering $100 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 9 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2005 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 5.25 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7 percent in 1990, 8.10 percent in 1995 and 9 percent in 2001. The bonds, which underwriters expect to be rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by Standard & Poor's, will finance the Hynes Convention Center in Boston.

title: GROSS OFFERS THEORY IN STEWART'S DEATH
description: The city's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, testified yesterday that a ''combination of factors,'' including acute intoxication, the effects of physical restraints and the infliction of ''blunt force trauma'' could have caused Michael Stewart's death.

title: Service for David Golden
description: The Directors Guild of America will hold a memorial service Oct. 17 for David Golden, the motion picture producer, who died in an automobile accident Aug. 7 in Oregon. The service will take place at the Martin Luther King High School, Amsterdam Avenue and 65th Street, from 7 to 9 P.M. Representatives of the guild, the motion picture industry and New York University's Tisch School of Arts, where Mr. Golden taught, are scheduled to participate. Mr. Golden was executive producer of ''Love Story'' and production manager of ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' and ''Fame.''

title: Farm and Home
description: The Farm and Home Savings Association said that its board had signed a merger agreement with the Guaranty Federal Savings and Loan Association of Dallas. The agreement, subject to certain conditions, provides for holders of Farm and Home common stock to receive $31 a share. Guaranty is owned by the Pacific Realty Corporation, Paul Cheng and Simon Edward Heath, and Pacific in turn is owned by Mr. Cheng and Mr. Heath.

title: Officials Said to Agree On Contractors' Policy
description: Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds said Tuesday that he had reached agreement with Labor Secretary Bill Brock on a proposed revision of affirmative action requirements for hiring by Federal contractors.

title: UNILEVER ALTERS ITS GAME PLAN
description: When Unilever lost the costly bidding war for Richardson-Vicks Inc. last week, the failed effort by the British-Dutch consumer products giant fit two patterns - an old one and a new one.

title: PROTEST SHIPS NEAR NUCLEAR ATOLL
description: The protest ship Greenpeace raised the stakes in a battle of nerves with French warships today by sailing to within 200 yards of a forbidden zone around France's nuclear test site in the South Pacific.

title: All Over Again
description: When Army and Navy Academy of Carlsbad, Calif., attempted a sweep of left end last Saturday against Coronado High, the halfback burst 76 yards for a touchdown. And why not? The ballcarrier - Jason Simpson, a 5-foot-11-inch, 167-pound sophomore who was making his first starting appearance for the Warriors - was following in the steps of not only his blockers but also his dad, O. J. Simpson, who had a few long scoring runs of his own.

title: TEXTILE INDUSTRY IMPORTS, TOO
description: When it comes to waving the flag for American-made goods, Sam M. Walton, the retail executive who runs more than 800 Wal-Mart discount stores, is as patriotic as they come. But at a recent apparel industry dinner in his honor Mr. Walton said that even he had to compromise and sell clothes that were made in this country with imported materials.

title: Gillette Unit's Head Is Going to Diasonics
description: Diasonics Inc., a leader in sophisticated medical technology, named Martin Koffel president and chief operating officer.

title: NAKASONE, GIVING IN, WILL SHUN SHRINE
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, yielding to sharp Chinese criticism, apparently intends to cancel a planned visit next week to a Shinto shrine dedicated to Japan's war dead.

title: CANADA TRUSTCO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Pro Basketball;   TISDALE REACHES PACT WITH PACERS
description: When the Indiana Pacers announced last night that they had agreed to contract terms with Wayman Tisdale, it left Chris Mullin, the Golden State Warriors' pick, as the only No. 1 selection from last spring's draft still unsigned in the National Basketball Association.

title: HERS
description: THE health plan doctor suggests I have a D and C on his office table. A mini-D and C is what he calls it. I jump at the chance. Off the table. Fast. I suggest you do likewise when offered this opportunity. It's an efficient little operation. It will save him time. It will save you missed days at work. Only minutes as compared to a hospital stint. It will cause you great pain. They say that you forget pain. You will remember these minutes even if you've managed to forget childbirth.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: ANNUAL RECEPTION - Diplomats will gather tonight at the annual reception for the chairmen of delegations to the General Assembly, which will be held 6:30-8:30 P.M. in the Delegates' Lounge. The sponsors of the gathering, which is expected to attract several hundred people, are Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Jaime de Pinies, President of the General Assembly.

title: ISRAEL URGES EGYPTIANS TO PROSECUTE HIJACKERS
description: Israel today condemned the reported killing of an American tourist aboard the hijacked Italian cruise liner and called on Egypt to prosecute the hijackers.

title: Technology;   The Return Of Propellers
description: WHEN jet planes replaced propeller-driven planes in the 1950's, it was considered a great leap forward in aviation. Now, the next major advance in aircraft engine design is a surprising one: a return to propellers.

title: OCILLA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of GDG Services of $68,000 for the quarter and $166,000 for the 6 months.

title: Congress's Way With Words
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings has come to the conclusion that a stint in Congress is one way to improve one's vocabulary.

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BAKER OVERTURES WIN RESPECT
description: Although it is unclear how cooperative all the key parties will be, a growing number of bankers and finance officials say they are convinced that the United States has presented a plan for a promising solution to easing the debt crisis that has plagued the world for the past three years. On Tuesday United States Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d spoke at the annual meeting here of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund of his three-pronged plan to improve the economies of debtor nations and step up lending to those most in need.

title: Xerox Unit Chief Has Resigned Post
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that John Lundberg, the chairman and chief executive of its Crum & Forster insurance unit, had resigned. Xerox said that Melvin Howard, a Xerox executive vice president and chairman of its financial services organization, would fill both positions.

title: ARCHITECTURE: A DESIGN FOR GUGGENHEIM TOWER
description: It was last February that the Guggenheim Museum announced plans to build an 11-story tower just behind the northern half of its Frank Lloyd Wright-designed building. But except for showing a model of the museum with a stark box behind it, the museum said little back then about what the new building, designed by Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, would actually look like.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

TV REVIEW;

PIANO TEAM HONORS ITS FORERUNNERS
description: CABLE television's Arts & Entertainment Network uses its Thursday schedule to showcase ''serious music'' productions but, as can be seen tonight, it still might not hurt to have a gimmick.

title: U.S. Advances In Federation Cup
description: The second-seeded United States took two singles and one doubles match against unseeded China today and advanced into the quarterfinals of the Federation Cup, the international tennis team championships for women.

title: Thousands Attend Funeral Of West German Anti-Fascist
description: Thousands of people, some raising clenched fists in salute, attended the funeral today of an anti-fascist protester whose death touched off violence, arson and bombings in 16 cities.

title: DANCE: PINA BAUSCH PRESENTS 'MOUNTAIN'
description: EMOTIONAL mugging is what concerns Pina Bausch in ''On the Mountain a Cry Was Heard,'' a dance-theater piece that she created last year and that had its American premiere Tuesday night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Next Wave'' Festival.

title: Credit Charges Vary Widely
description: There is enormous diversity among the 50 states on what consumers can be charged for use of credit and charge cards and a bewildering variety of formulas for calculating those charges. Thirty-eight states have statutory limits on credit card interest rates and 12 do not.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MORTGAGE RATES SHOW ONLY SLIGHT VARIATIONS
description: Interest levels on fixed-rate home mortgages rose slightly while adjustable rates fell between early August and early September, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: NEIGHBORS TELL HEARING OF FEAR OF RADICAL GROUP
description: While the radical group Move fortified its house, the city ignored pleas for help from the neighborhood, residents said today.

title: Middle East Optimism
description: A key adviser to Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel is visiting Washington, and he says he is optimistic about the possibilities for peace negotiations involving Israel, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Advanced Micro To Curb Output
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said that it would close most of its domestic plants for two weeks during the Christmas-New Year holidays. The computer chip maker, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said most of its 7,600 domestic employees would be asked to take six paid vacation days, combined with four previously scheduled paid holidays, to allow closing most plants from Dec. 23 through Jan. 5.

title: FILTERING SYSTEMS FOR CLEANER WATER
description: CONCERN about the quality of drinking water has led many people to consider installing water filters. A number of varieties are available.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dr. Baker, Take Your Medicine
description: Dipping generously into other people's pockets, Treasury Secretary James Baker has nonetheless shown a welcome new concern for the huge debt of the world's developing nations.

title: Quality, Not Just Quantity, at the Polls
description: The 1984 Presidential election generated the most feverish voter registration activity in 20 years, much of it the result of foundation-funded effort. The result: more than 11 million new registrants. Voter turnout increased for the first time since 1960. Yet of 174 million eligible voters, only about 127 million were registered and only about 92 million actually voted. A new study of voter registration efforts last year confirms the important link between voter education and participation. In registration, as elsewhere, quality counts.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: TONELLI GOES BACK TO WORK
description: Three years from now, Alex Tonelli of Milton, Ontario, will retire after nearly 40 years in the steel business. He has advanced to a supervisory role, in charge of machine operators, but only after years of hard labor. Not so long ago - a little more than 10 years - when Alex Tonelli finished his shift at the steel plant, his work day was not nearly done.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $230.6 million on the sale of investments and a gain of $83.9 million from a distribution from Litton Industries Inc. debentures. c-Including a gain of $276.8 million from the sale of investments and a tax credit of $42.2 million.

title: HOW SENATE VOTED ON BUDGET PLAN
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate approved a plan today to require a balanced budget by 1991, attaching it to a bill to raise the national debt limit:

title: U.S. to Plan Next Fighter
description: The Air Force is seeking proposals for a fighter plane that would enter the nation's arsenal in the mid-1990's and eventually replace the F-15 Eagle and the F-16 Fighting Falcon.

title: The Battles of Britain
description: The Britain we know from novels, films and television serials was, for all its class divisions, a law-abiding, relatively homogeneous society. The Britain that now erupts on front pages and news shows is sharply transformed, struggling with the effects of decades of decline, including a decline of respect for its civil institutions.

title: Three Mile Island Plant Producing Power Again
description: The Unit 1 reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near here reached 15 percent power today and began generating electricity for the first time since nuclear fuel melted in 1979 at adjacent Unit 2, the plant's operator said.

title: Dollar's Rise Continues Despite Intervention
description: The dollar fluctuated widely yesterday and finished generally stronger, despite efforts by several central banks to weaken it both by words and financial muscle.

title: G.M. Landmark
description: The General Motors Corporation's elaborate 15-story world headquarters building here has been dedicated as a national historic landmark by Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel. ''This building is important to the development of Detroit, to the nation and, in fact, because of the company it has housed, to the world,'' Mr. Hodel declared before unveiling a plaque on Tuesday.

title: FELD BALLET: 'LES NOCES'
description: THE Feld Ballet opened its fall season at the Joyce Theater last night with a new production of one of the most remarkable ballets of our century: ''Les Noces,'' as choreographed by Bronislava Nijinska in 1923 to a score by Igor Stravinsky for chorus, four pianists and percussion. Staged by Irina Nijinska, the choreographer's daughter, the revival, danced to a recording, demonstrated that this work about a Russian peasant wedding has not lost its power to amaze.

title: SLOPPY ROYALS TRAIL; 2-0
description: The renowned ''rabbits'' of St. Louis did no running tonight because they did no hitting. And so, the St. Louis Cardinals got nowhere against Fernando Valenzuela and Tom Niedenfuer, who pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 4-1 victory in the opening game of the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: Top White House Aide Serving Without Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Workers Strike
description: Eighteen million Italian workers staged a two-hour nationwide strike today to protest a Government decision to cut some benefits as part of its economy drive. The general strike, called by Italy's three major trade unions, affected work in the largest industrial groups and stopped public transportation. Some flights were canceled at the international airports of Milan and Rome.

title: Surprise Ending For Yale Band
description: Ivy League marching bands have long made the spoof a cornerstone of presentations that they offer during the football intermission. But if there is a time and a place for everything, then the time was not last Saturday and the place was most decidedly not West Point. While Yale was taking a 59-16 shellacking from Army, the Elis' band was being completely shut out, barred from its scheduled halftime appearance on the Michie Stadium turf.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of equity in Mexican operations, in August 1984, of $3,598,000 for the quarter and the year, and equity in net earnings of Mexican operations of $222,000 for the quarter and $1,205,000 for the year. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected in the form of a stock dividend distributed to shareholders on May 8, 1985.

title: TESTING COMPLETED AT SHOREHAM
description: Electricity has been restored to the last of 750,000 Long Island residents who lost power during Hurricane Gloria, the Long Island Lighting Company reported today.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,289,000.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF STATEMENT BY SPEAKES
description: Following is a transcript of a statement by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, at a meeting with reporters in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times from the Cable News Network:

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOR REAGAN, A TRIP TO ILLINOIS, AN ORDER ON MIDEAST
description: President Reagan, en route to Washington from two appearances in the Chicago area, approved a plan today for American planes to intercept an Egyptian commercial jet carrying four hijackers, the White House said tonight.

title: APARTHEID DIE-HARDS RELIVE DAYS OF BLAZING GUNS
description: On a stretch of arid scrub beneath a harsh sun, 2,000 whites assembled today to celebrate the memory of a hero of their history and to commit themselves anew to white separatism and Afrikaner nationalism.

title: SALE OF SARDI'S TO 2 PRODUCERS IS SET
description: Harvey Klaris was one of the producers of ''Cloud Nine,'' ''Nine'' and ''The Tap Dance Kid.'' Ivan Bloch is one of the producers of John Pielmeier's forthcoming Broadway play, ''The Boys of Winter.'' Their first co-production is scheduled to be Sardi's Restaurant.

title: G.E. Net Increases 2%
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 2 percent in the third quarter, when market conditions were ''generally sluggish and uneven.''

title: FOOTBALL SATURDAYS AT SERVICE ACADEMIES A JOY AGAIN
description: Football at the service academies - Air Force, Army and Navy - is fashionable this fall not only for the athletes who play the games but also for the spectators who attend them.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $2,857,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for investment tax credits. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $844,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Right Pell, Wrong Pew
description: In one room of the Dirksen Senate Office Building yesterday morning, the Foreign Relations Committee, of which Senator Claiborne Pell is the ranking Democrat, was quizzing Secretary of State George P. Shultz on proposed arms sales to Jordan. Down the hall, the Labor Committee, on which the Rhode Island Senator is the No. 2 Democrat, was holding a hearing on requiring manufacturers to list salt content on food labels.

title: America in the Ranks Of Debtor Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR THE GIANTS, SHIFTING ROLES
description: After one-third of the National Football League season, the Giants are becoming a team in transition. Witness these personnel changes and uncertainties today:

title: THE SUBURBAN SPIRIT CHAFES AT SEAT-BELT LAW
description: According to uncontested testimony, on July 21 at 7:19 A.M., Cheektowaga Patrolman Ken Rusin spotted the Town Supervisor, Daniel Weber, driving north on Union Road, not wearing a seat belt.

title: G.A.O. Inquiry Urged On Law Center Funds
description: The General Accounting Office has been asked to investigate expenditures of Government money by a conservative legal group that has received nearly $400,000 to assist poor people, Congressional officials say.

title: 12 DAY-TRIPS TO THE COUNTRY: AUTUMN LEAVES AND LOTS MORE
description: ALONG with the baseball playoffs, football and the new season's television situation comedies, starting this weekend nature is offering its own season special - the annual spectacular display of fall foliage sweeping down from the north toward metropolitan New York.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: ARAFAT ON AGENDA - The General Assembly considers a resolution today to invite Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to address the assembly during the 10-day period marking its 40th anniversary, which begins Monday. The resolution, introduced by six of the nations espousing nonalignment, is opposed by the United States.

title: Lendl Defeats Connors
description: Ivan Lendl, who defeated Jimmy Connors in the semifinals of the United States Open nearly five weeks ago, defeated Connors again tonight in a tournament final that was supposed to be a tuneup for the Open. Shaking off an arm injury that has bothered him since the summer, Lendl was a 6-1, 6-3 winner in a match that was postponed because of rain from last Aug. 25.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JESUS THROUGH THE CENTURIES.

title: DEVILS TOP FLYERS ON 4 LATE GOALS
description: The Devils stunned the Flyers with four goals - three by Paul Gagne - in 8 minutes 30 seconds of the final period and defeated the 1985 Stanley Cup finalists, 6-5, tonight in the season opener at the Spectrum.

title: 5 More Reported Dead In South Africa Unrest
description: The authorities said today that five people, including a 3-week-old baby, had been killed in new violence in South Africa.

title: G.M. to Expand Its Plant Upstate
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was planning a $340 million expansion program to make two new kinds of car engines at the Tonawanda engine plant. Officials, however, said they could not immediately tell how many new jobs it would create.

title: PORT OF ISRAEL DESCRIBED AS TARGET OF TERRORISTS WHO SEIZED VESSEL
description: The four Palestinians aboard the Achille Lauro intended to stay aboard as passengers until the cruise liner reached Ashdod, Israel, and then planned either to shoot up the harbor or take Israelis hostage, according to Israeli, Palestinian and other Arab informants. The Israelis were to be held to bargain for the release of 50 Palestinians held in Israeli jails.

title: One Family's Loss Of E. B. White
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITALS FIGHT BID TO CUT BACK DOCTOR TRAINING
description: Officials of several financially strapped hospitals serving poor neighborhoods in New York City warned yesterday that a proposal to bar graduates of foreign medical schools from doctor-training programs could have a devastating effect on the services they provide.

title: Endangered Ballroom
description: The wreckers' ball is probably headed toward the Audubon Ballroom on Broadway, between 165th and 166th Streets, where the black leader Malcolm X was shot to death 20 years ago.

title: CARIBBEAN FESTIVAL: A MELTING POT FULL OF SONG AND DANCE
description: FROM a demographic viewpoint, the Caribbean basin might well extend north to New York City. With its well-defined, self-conscious communities of Puerto Ricans, Dominicans, Trinidadians, Haitians, Jamaicans, Cubans and others, the city is firmly tied to the islands, by culture if not by climate.

title: Prison Inmates' Beards Ruled Threat to Security
description: A Federal appellate court said today that beards worn by prisoners could threaten security at the Missouri State Penitentiary.

title: Attorneys' Contingency Fees: Not Guilty
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Cites Audit Firm
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured the New York-based accounting firm of Seidman & Seidman for failure to properly conduct an audit of the Chronar Corporation's 1983 financial statement, a subsequent stock registration statement and a preliminary prospectus.

title: KEYCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $788,000, or 9 cents per share.

title: STAGE: SERBAN'S 'FIGARO,' WITH SKATES AND RADIO
description: TAKE three of New York's most stylish comic actors, mate them with a classic play that's ideally suited to their talents, and what is the result? Not necessarily what you might hope or think. The Circle in the Square's new production of ''The Marriage of Figaro'' is the barely living proof, if any were needed, that even performers as fetching as Anthony Heald, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and Dana Ivey - or a playwright of the caliber of Pierre Augustin Caron de Beaumarchais - stand little chance against a director with his own set of self-aggrandizing priorities. As staged by Andrei Serban, this ''Figaro'' is first and last the Andrei Serban show; its subject is the director's artifice rather than that of Beaumarchais's civilization. The evening is most likely to be enjoyed by audiences with an undying nostalgia for avant-garde gimmicks of 10, even 20, years ago, as well as by those who prefer a ''Figaro'' more suggestive of the Three Stooges than Mozart.

title: Prize for 'Civil Wars'
description: Rosellen Brown has been named winner of the $1,000 Janet Heidinger Kafka prize for fiction by an American woman for her third novel, ''Civil Wars'' (Knopf, 1984). The award, administered by the University of Rochester, is named after the late author. It will be presented at the university on Monday.

title: FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Liberian Opposition Threatens Vote Boycott
description: Opposition parties are threatening to boycott the first multiparty election in more than 130 years in this West African nation.

title: BUOYANT CAPITAL HAILS THE ACTION
description: Reagan Administration officials and legislators reacted exuberantly tonight to the news that American warplanes had seized the four hijackers who apparently killed an elderly American aboard an Italian cruise ship.

title: TREASURY SAYS U.S. DEBT STAYED BELOW LIMIT
description: The Treasury Department insisted today that a novel financing technique it used Wednesday to borrow $5 billion did not lift the Federal debt above the statutory ceiling.

title: 'Out of the Darkness,' On Son of Sam Case
description: More than a few manufacturers of police dramas for television could take some lessons from ''Out of the Darkness,'' a story of the solution of the Son of Sam murders scheduled for broadcast tomorrow from 9 to 11 on ''The CBS Saturday Night Movies'' on Channel 2.

title: Two Hats, And Both Fit
description: ''I'm just a workingman,'' says David Corley, ''trying to do two jobs.''

title: P.L.O. AIDE DISPUTES REPORT OF KILLING
description: A Palestinian leader, Farouk Kaddoumi, said today that the killing of an American aboard the hijacked Italian cruise ship was ''a big lie fabricated by the intelligence service of the United States.''

title: PANEL SET TO PROPOSE MAJOR OVERHAUL FOR PENTAGON
description: A Presidential commission has concluded that ''fundamental'' changes should be made in the organization of the Pentagon to correct weapon problems involving poor quality, high prices and long delays in purchasing, the panel's chairman said today.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Readings by Columnists
description: Russell Baker and Tom Wicker, Pulitzer Prize-winning columnists for The New York Times and best-selling authors, will read from their works tonight at 8 o'clock at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street. Gay Talese, the author and a former reporter for The Times, is host for the reading, which starts the Writer's Voice series at the Y.M.C.A. Admission is $7. Information: 787-6557.

title: SAN DIEGANS GET IN LINE TO SEEK MAYOR'S OFFICE
description: The political season began anew in this city today as candidates lined up to succeed Mayor Roger Hedgecock, who was found guilty of criminal conspiracy and perjury Wednesday.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: DAVID HARE, who has become a busy commuter between the worlds of theater and film, is preparing for another excursion to a movie set. Next spring he will go behind the camera for the filming of ''The Butter Mountain,'' which will have his name on the credits as both author and director.

title: BAKER, FENTRESS & CO reports earnings for As of Sept 30
New Position For Executive
description: J. P. Morgan & Company and its principal subsidiary, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, yesterday named John F. Ruffle to be vice chairman of both organizations.

title: PUERTO RICO CITES PERIL OF SHANTYTOWNS
description: Tens of thousands of poor Puerto Ricans are living in unhealthy and dangerously situated shantytowns like the one that was struck by a landslide here four days ago, Government officials and housing experts said today.

title: Judge in Belushi Case Drops Contempt Charge
description: A 10-day sentence and $1,000 fine against a freelance writer was dropped today after he gave a judge his tape-recorded interview with Cathy Evelyn Smith, who is accused of killing the comedian John Belushi.

title: Lewis's Version
description: Carl Lewis, who was dismissed from the United States track team before the World Cup Games in Australia last weekend, says that Coach Russ Rogers didn't tell it right when he announced that Lewis's teammates in the 400-meter relay, Kirk Baptiste, Calvin Smith and Harvey Glance, had voted for the dismissal because Lewis had failed to attend practice.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Oriole Shuffle
description: After nine seasons and more than 1,000 games with the Baltimore Orioles, Rich Dauer found himself a free agent yesterday when he and two other Oriole veterans were given their releases. The other victims of the postseason house cleaning were Lenn Sakata, a 32-year-old infielder, and Joe Nolan, a 34-year-old catcher who had been on the disabled list with chronic knee problems since July. Dauer, who has a .257 career batting average, hit only .202 this season.

title: FOR 56 AMERICANS WAITING IN ITALY, SOBERING NEWS
description: They hung around Leonardo da Vinci Airport early today, gleaning snatches of news from reporters and trying to decide what to do.
