title: GREAT LAKES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1.3 million for the quarter and $2.5 million for the 9 months and losses from the early extinguishment of debt of $600,000 for the quarter and $1.8 million for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $200,000 for the quarter and $1.1 million for the 9 months.

title: PLANE DIVERSION RAISES LEGAL ISSUES
description: The four hijackers aboard an Egyptian plane that was diverted by United States jet fighters to Italy today could probably be prosecuted either in Italy or the United States, and perhaps in both countries.

title: Jurors Hear Testimony On Louisiana Official
description: Prosecutors in the trial of Gov. Edwin Edwards today introduced evidence indicating that the Governor ordered the appointment of an associate of one of his co-defendants as the state hearing officer for approving new hospital construction.

title: P.L.O. SAYS TUNISIANS REFUSED ENTRY TO EGYPTIAN PLANE BEFORE IT LEFT CAIRO
description: Palestine Liberation Organization officials said here early this morning that Tunisia refused entry Thursday night to an Egyptian airplane before the plane left Cairo.

title: RAMS ARE GAINING WITHOUT DICKERSON
description: Clearly, it is not necessarily because of Eric Dickerson.

title: Nippon Project
description: Japan's top petroleum distributor, the Nippon Oil Company, will introduce a $100 million project to develop oilfields in the United States, the company's president, Yasuoki Takeuchi, said. The project would be the first for American oil development by a Japanese oil company. Mr. Takeuchi said that his company had obtained oilfields from Texaco Inc. in five areas, including California, North Dakota and Colorado.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
Peru Shuns I.M.F. Deals
description: Peru's Finance Minister, Luis Alva Castro, said today that his country would refuse to work with the International Monetary Fund because it was an ''accomplice'' of the United States in the debt crisis but would try to negotiate arrangements with its commercial bank creditors.

title: DODGERS, BEHIND HERSHISER, ROLL TO 2-0 PLAYOFF LEAD
description: The scenario was probably fixed in the first inning: Vince Coleman and Willie McGee, the whippets of the St. Louis Cardinals, got on base for the first time in the National League playoff. Both were thrown out trying to steal second base.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures are fully diluted. The earnings include the results of the Heritage Bancorporation since the acquisition on May 1, 1985.

title: DANCE: HOUSTON BALLET'S 'SWAN LAKE'
description: IN the Houston Ballet's new version of ''Swan Lake,'' as Prince Siegfried betrays his true love, Odette, and is seduced by the imposter, Odile, he learns of his mistake in a novel manner.

title: AS TOLLS CEASE, CONNECTICUT REJOICES
description: Bound by 11 years of commuting habits, Maureen Gorman approached a turnpike toll booth here this morning and reached for a token.

title: ASPIRIN CALLED AID AGAINST 2 HEART ATTACK
description: Federal health officials said today that heart attack victims and certain others who suffered heart pains could reduce the likelihood of dying from further heart attacks by taking an aspirin a day. They suggested that such aspirin treatments might save 30,000 to 50,000 lives a year.

title: Corn Harvest Record Seen
description: The 1985 corn crop is estimated at a record 8.6 billion bushels, 12 percent more than last year's harvest of 7.66 billion bushels, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: LIBERAL PARTY SUFFERING A SEVERE MONEY CRISIS
description: The Liberal Party, already torn by dissension, now confronts what a party official says are the most serious financial problems in its 41-year-history.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Per share figures are after capital gains distributions of $1.20 a share in February 1985 and $1.33 a share in February 1984.

title: Hello Moscow, Get Me Rewrite
description: The pleasant, slightly accented voice on the other end of the line says, ''Good morning, embassy press section,'' and offers to take a message for the requested spokesman, who is ''unfortunately not available.''

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC IN SINOPOLI PREMIERE
description: THE roll call of composers who have turned to conducting and done well at that craft is long. Try Liszt, Wagner, Berlioz and Mahler for a start. In our time, Leonard Bernstein and Pierre Boulez are prominent among those who have pursued the double career with some success. The latest composer to achieve a degree of fame on the podium is Giuseppe Sinopoli, who appeared in both guises Wednesday night when he led the New York Philharmonic in a suite from his opera, ''Lou Salome.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ponce's Grief
description: ''The houses are stacked up on the hill like cards, and when the rock cracked, they just peeled off and all fell down to the bottom in a heap,'' said one rescue worker of the mudslide that may have killed as many as 500 in the Mameyes section of Ponce, P.R.

title: John Ashbery's 'Wave' Winner of Poetry Prize
description: John Ashbery's ''Wave,'' published by the Viking Press, has been named the winner of the Lenore Marshall/ Nation prize for poetry.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $1.47 billion, to $209.58 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an after-tax gain of $5 million for the quarter and $24 million for the 9 months attributable to the cancellation of a subsidiary's contracts to supply special glass fiber reinforcements and a charge of $2 million for the quarter and the 9 months from the temporary shutdown of the company's subsidiary, American Borate.

title: Who Has the Power to Appoint?
description: ''The President is deeply displeased'' with Senate Democrats for holding up 70 appointments to executive and judicial posts, says a spokesman. Well, Robert Byrd, the minority leader, is displeased too. He's blocking some Senate confirmations because the President keeps ignoring his plea to stop making appointments when Congress is in brief recess.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Chief Named At News America
description: Martin Singerman has been named president and chief executive officer of News America Publishing Inc., Rupert Murdoch's American publishing operations, the company said yesterday.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Royals vs Toronto Blue Jays, at Kansas City, Game 3 of the four-of-seven American League Championship Series. Bret Saberhagen (20-6) starts for the Royals, who lost the first two games of the series in Toronto.

title: FAUROT CUT BY JETS IN SURPRISE
description: In one of their more dramatic roster moves, the Jets announced today that they had released Ron Faurot, their first-round draft choice in 1984.

title: BOARD OF ESTIMATE, IN REVERSAL, REJECTS BUS GARAGE IN BRONX
description: The Board of Estimate, in a reversal, voted early today to revoke the approval it gave four years ago for the construction of a Transit Authority bus garage near Co-op City in the Bronx.

title: The Duty of Nations
description: The murder of an ailing American passenger nullified any deal to free the hijackers of the Achille Lauro. They have to be brought to trial, and the United States, Italy and Egypt were bound in law and decency to see that they are.

title: Braves Hire Tanner
description: He was originally signed by the Boston Braves, made his major league debut as an outfielder with the Milwaukee Braves, and now Chuck Tanner will be the manager of the Atlanta Braves. That became official yesterday when Ted Turner, the Atlanta owner, signed Tanner to a five-year contract just three days after Tanner was let go by the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Scott & Fetzer Bid Made by Investors
description: Two Washington investors, Steven and Michael Rales, said they have offered to buy the Scott & Fetzer Company for $60 a share, or a total of about $396 million.

title: The Decline Of Communism
description: What will be at issue when Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev sit down at the summit meeting next month? Not just the specific deals that will or will not be made and later kept or not kept. The meeting will take the measure of the two leaders' societies as well as of international power. Just as President Reagan represents the liberal democracies, so General Secretary Gorbachev will speak for Communism at the summit.

title: TWO PARTIES, TWO BOOKS AND TWO WORLDS
description: The world of Dr. Armand Hammer could have been something of a menacing place last night, but joviality triumphed, to everyone's relief. The menace, of course, was all in the setting: the arms and armor gallery of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with its collection of lances, maces and knights on horseback. But joy was inherent in the occasion: a champagne celebration of the publication of ''The World of Armand Hammer,'' a volume portraying the ceaseless travels of Dr. Hammer, the industrial patriarch, art patron and navigator of the corridors of power.

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a non-recurring gain of $70 million from the sale of the company's interest in a building.

title: OPERA: 'X,' A PRE-DEBUT
description: ''X,'' a new opera about Malcolm X by the family team of Anthony Davis (music), Thulani Davis (libretto) and Christopher Davis (story), received its semi/sort-of world premiere Wednesday night at Walnut Street Theater here, part of the American Music Theater Festival.

title: PROSECUTOR IN SEX CASE TO STAY IN OFFICE
description: A Minnesota prosecutor who charged 24 adults with sexually abusing dozens of children and then abruptly dropped most of the charges should not be removed from office, Gov. Rudy Perpich said today.

title: CHELSEA TOUR TO RECALL POETS OF PAST
description: The Bohemian past of the Chelsea district will be retold tomorrow in an unusual tour spiced with readings of poets who lived there.

title: GAMBINO AUTO THEFT RING TRIAL OPENS
description: The prosecutor in the Federal trial of the reputed head of the Gambino crime group and nine other men said yesterday that the defendants ran a ''highly sophisticated'' stolen-car ring whose members killed people who ''threatened the smooth flow of their operation.''

title: ACTION AGAINST TERRORISTS: 4 INCIDENTS IN DECADE
description: The interception by United States aircraft yesterday of an Egyptian plane carrying four hijackers was not the first time in which a Western government has taken military action against terrorists.

title: Loyalty by Kodak
description: Vice President Bush's loyalty to President Reagan has rarely been questioned in their five years together at the pinnacle of American government.

title: Cabinet Change in Fiji
description: Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara today appointed the veteran minister Semesa Sikivou to handle the Government's foreign affairs. Mr. Sikivou had been in charge of communications and transport.

title: Schramm's Pet
description: Tex Schramm, the envied major-domo of the Dallas Cowboys, when asked about the chances of getting other teams' approval to use instant replays in the playoffs: ''I thought we had a good chance to pass it until I read a story somewhere that this is my pet project.''

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Risky Abracadabra
description: Those most responsible for $200 billion annual Federal deficits and for doubling the national debt to $2 trillion in the last four years are President Reagan, the Senate Republican majority and those Congressional Democrats who helped them push through the 1981 tax cuts and a bloated military buildup.

title: $1 Billion Line Of Credit for PHH
description: The PHH Group Inc. of Hunt Valley, Md., said yesterday that it had signed a $1 billion, 5-year revolving credit facility with 25 commercial banks led by the Bankers Trust Company.

title: OFFICIALS SAY C.I.A. DID NOT TELL F.B.I. OF SPY CASE MOVES
description: The Central Intelligence Agency failed to notify the Federal Bureau of Investigation after it learned more than a year ago that Edward L. Howard was considering becoming a Soviet spy, Government officials said today.

title: DAVIS'S AGENT TELLS OF OFFERS
description: Kenneth Davis, the Texas Christian University running back who was suspended from the team for accepting improper payments from T.C.U. boosters, has told his agent that he was offered money and other inducements from Nebraska and Oklahoma before he was persuaded that he would make more money at T.C.U.

title: Lorimar Saves Two Accounts
description: BY spinning off a new agency, Lorimar Inc. will be able to save about $30 million in billings from conflicting accounts resulting from its latest agency acquisition.

title: Merrill Seeks Buyout Respect
description: A FEW weeks ago, in the middle of Merrill Lynch & Company's struggle to keep a leveraged buyout deal with the SCM Corporation alive, whispers started coming out of the investment firm's camp that it was determined not to let this one slip away.

title: BROADWAY
description: AFTER lots of talk and a year of touring, ''Jerry's Girls'' is finally scheduled for Broadway's St. James Theater Dec. 4.

title: NEW ECKARD TACK: A BUYOUT
description: For the management of the Jack Eckerd Corporation, the last few months have been spent either actively warding off takeover efforts or conceiving strategies to discourage any potential suitors. Now, it has taken a step that its managers hope will put those matters behind it.

title: MASON AND BATES IN 'FISCHER'
description: PUBLIC television's ''Great Performances'' begins its 13th season tonight at 9 on Channel 13 with the kind of quality production that has become the hallmark of the distinguished series. Alan Bates and James Mason star in ''Dr. Fischer of Geneva,'' an adaptation of Graham Greene's 1980 novel.

title: DUTCH EXPECTED TO APPROVE CRUISE MISSILES
description: Early next month, the Dutch Government will approve the deployment of American ground-launched cruise missiles despite an unusual high-level Soviet move to sway it from its decision, according to senior Government officials.

title: The Septet Ekaya
description: The pianist Abdullah Ibrahim (Dollar Brand) will lead his septet Ekaya - including the saxophonists Carlos Ward, Ricky Ford and Charles Davis, and the drummer Ben Riley - tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; 10, 11:30 and 1 A.M. Sunday. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: SUBSIDIZED FOR-SALE HOUSING IN QUEENS
description: The urban evolution has come full circle on Christie Avenue in Corona, Queens. Nearly 20 years ago school authorities thought the land between 99th Street and 101st Street would be part of the site for a new Corona High School. They condemned houses there and on nearby blocks for the school.

title: Fluor May Sell Oil, Gas Units
description: The Fluor Corporation, in another step of its financial restructuring, has signed a letter of intent to sell its remaining onshore and offshore oil and gas operations to Primary Fuels Inc., a subsidiary of Houston Industries, for about $190 million.

title: GLATFELTER, P H CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $24,574,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of a Carrollton, Ohio, paper mill on Sept. 10, 1984.

title: FORD TO PURCHASE SPERRY FARM UNIT
description: While Henry Ford, the founder of the Ford Motor Company, was still alive, he made sure that his company kept ''one foot in industry and the other in the soil.'' Today, true to tradition, Ford Motor planted its foot deeper into the soil by acquiring the New Holland farm equipment operation from the Sperry Corporation.

title: INTRUDER STABS STUDENT IN COLUMBIA DORMITORY
description: A 21-year-old engineering student was stabbed in the face, chest, abdomen and legs before dawn yesterday in her bedroom at a Columbia University dormitory. A suspect was arrested hours later.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $2.1 million on the sale of land.

title: INNOVATOR OF FILM AND STAGE
description: Orson Welles, the Hollywood ''boy wonder'' who created the film classic ''Citizen Kane,'' scared tens of thousands of Americans with a realistic radio report of a Martian invasion of New Jersey and changed the face of film and theater with his daring new ideas, died yesterday in Los Angeles, apparently of a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Debt and the Democrats
description: The Democratic National Committee has been living on pretty thin gruel ever since the national Republican landslide last November, but the worst of the famine may be over. Its $1,000-a-plate gala fund-raising dinner at the Washington Hilton Wednesday night drew 1,800 contributors, grossed $1.3 million and may net as much as $1 million after all the bills are paid.

title: Morgan Fed Proposal
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that it would apply to the Federal Reserve Board for permission to underwrite and deal in commercial paper, certain municipal revenue bonds and specific mortgage-related securities. It proposed forming separate subsidiaries that would handle the new functions as well as other activities.

title: Chambers Quartet
description: The drummer Joe Chambers will lead a quartet - with Gary Bartz on alto saxophone, Ted Dunbar on guitar and Lonnie Smith on organ - Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Prospect Park Picnic House, near Fifth Street and Prospect Park West. The concert is co-sponsored by Celebrate Brooklyn (718) 788-0055, and by the Musicians of Brooklyn Initiative; tickets are $5.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN PRESIDENT COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
INTERNATIONAL LEASE FIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $980,000 for the quarter and $2,894,000 for the year and a charge of $6.5 million for the quarter and year from litigation. c-Net income including extraordinary credits of $1,023,000 for the quarter and $1,764,000 for the year.

title: FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share net adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in April.

title: Baldwin Sponsoring Jazz Piano Festival
description: The Baldwin piano company and the Burgundy Cafe on the Upper West Side are sponsoring the cafe's first jazz piano festival, starting this week.

title: Stocks Up Slightly In Listless Trading
description: Stock prices plodded higher yesterday in dull trading.

title: U.S. MOVES TO REDUCE EFFECT OF QUOTAS ON HIRING
description: The Justice Department has proposed to relax requirements that Federal contractors set numerical goals to remedy possible job discrimination against women and members of minority groups.

title: GIORGIO SANTELLI, 87, EX-FENCING COACH OF U.S. OLYMPIANS
description: Giorgio Santelli, a former United States Olympic fencing team coach and one of the most respected fencing masters in the world, died Tuesday in Teaneck, N.J. He was 87 years old.

title: Preservation Fights to Preserve Itself
description: The National Trust for Historic Preservation, created by Congress to foster the preservation of historic sites, has worked for more than 35 years to educate the public and encourage particiation in the preservation of America's history and culture.

title: M.A.C. in Bond Offering
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation of the City of New York is offering $125 million of bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: United Telecom
description: United Telecommunications Inc. said that it now planned to spend $1.5 billion on its fiber optic network construction in the 1985-87 period, $600 million less than previously projected. The company, whose businesses include telecommunications systems and equipment and computer network services, said that its route-sharing agreements were helping to cut anticipated construction costs. Construction of its fiber optic network is ''progressing well,'' with more than 2,800 miles of fiber in place.

title: WITNESS OF ESPIONAGE TRIAL CITES POSSIBLE HARM TO U.S.
description: A naval intelligence expert testified today that secret information found in the home of Samuel Loring Morison could have provided the Soviet Union with ''a window on the naval intelligence process.''

title: Bridge: The Death of Betty Kaplan Will Be Deep Loss to Many
description: The death of Betty Kaplan on Tuesday will be deeply felt around the world of bridge, by the thousands who found her a friendly opponent in her active playing days, when she won four national titles, and by the hundreds who met her in many countries, as the Boswell of the commentating performances of her husband, Edgar, at a score of world championships.

title: Bonn Holds Rightist On Suspicion of Spying
description: A 34-year-old businessman and right-wing activist has been arrested on suspicion of spying for East Germany, the chief West German federal prosecutor said today.

title: 9.60% Is Top Yield On Idaho Offering
description: The Boise-Kuna Irrigation District of Idaho is offering $140 million of refunding revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of 9.60 percent for bonds due in 2008, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: AMERICAN HOSPITAL SUPPLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The hijackers pushed him in his chair and dragged him to the side of the boat where - in cold blood - they fired a shot to the forehead.

title: EXCERPTS FROM WHITE HOUSE NEWS CONFERENCE ON HIJACKERS
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference last night by the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday Barnard Film Festival Several critically acclaimed films and their creators are on the agenda for Barnard College's ninth annual film and video festival, ''Works by Women,'' which begins today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: WHEN wine bars start appearing in department stores, it is a clear sign that New Yorkers have come a long way from the old Scotch and water days. Both Macy's at Herald Square and Bloomingdale's on Third Avenue and 59th Street have relaxing little bars where weary customers can take a breather and taste wines by the glass.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including nonrecurring after-tax credits applicable to prior-year tax refunds of $1,040,000. Year-ago results have been restated to include the accounts of Citizens Bank in South Hill, Va., which was acquired on Aug. 1, 1985.

title: Sales Tax-Plus
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAN FOR A FOX NETWORK INTRIGUES TV INDUSTRY
description: The television industry yesterday was by turns intrigued, skeptical and sympathetic to the announcement that Rupert Murdoch would attempt to start a television network of affiliated stations. Many industry insiders said that while they believed he faced a difficult challenge he stood a reasonably good chance of succeeding.

title: 40 SALVADOR SOLDIERS KILLED BY REBELS
description: Leftist rebels killed at least 40 Salvadoran soldiers and wounded 68 in a lightning raid before dawn today on the main training base for Government recruits near this coastal town.

title: AIR FORCE AND ARMY MAKE A WISHBONE FOR SUCCESS
description: It may be coincidental that the Air Force and Army football teams are undefeated, but it is no coincidence that both use the wishbone offense.

title: EWING: ANOTHER BLOWY
description: Patrick Ewing continues to have a difficult time adjusting to the National Basketball Association. Tonight, in his first appearance as a pro in the New York metropolitan area, the 7-foot Knick center not only fouled out of his second straight exhibition game but also got into a fourth-period shoving match with Buck Williams, the Nets' power forward.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIGHTERS DIVERT IT TO NATO BASE IN ITALY; GUNMEN FACE TRIAL IN SLAYING OF HOSTAGE
description: An Egyptian plane carrying the hijackers of an Italian cruise ship was intercepted by American Navy jets as it flew toward Tunisia Thursday night and was forced to land in Italy, the White House announced. A spokesman said the four terrorists had been taken into custody by Italian authorities.

title: Acme Head Promoted By American Stores
description: The American Stores Company, the nation's third-largest supermarket chain, yesterday named Thomas W. King, the head of its Acme supermarket division, president and chief operating officer, effective next Feb. 2.

title: Restaurants' Stake in Tougher Drinking Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including net gains from the sale of land of $160,000 for the latest year and $550,000 for the previous year.

title: INACTION ON WARNINGS IS ASSERTED IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Despite warnings that a crisis was brewing with the radical group Move, the city took no action to resolve the problem or to arrest a member of the group who was wanted, officials said today.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company issued cash dividends of 51 cents for the latest quarter, $1.53 for the latest nine months, 46 cents for the year-ago quarter and $1.38 for the year-ago nine months.

title: Turner Outlines MGM/UA Plans
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. says a joint film-distribution venture between Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and United Artists studios is planned, even after the companies are split.

title: Dining Out Guide: Connecticut
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. FINE BOUCHE, Main Street, Centerbrook (203-767-1277) -

title: U.S. DOG RESCUE TEAMS SEEKING SURVIVORS AT LANDSLIDE SITE
description: Rescue teams with dogs, sent from the United States mainland, today traversed the hillside of Mameyes today to determine if there was hope for finding any more residents of the shantytown alive after a rain-driven landslide swept down on them Monday.

title: ITALIAN OFFICIALS SAY MOVEMENT OF THE HIJACKERS CAME AFTER A WIDE ACCORD
description: Senior Italian officials asserted early today that the transport to Italy of the hijackers of an Italian cruise liner was a result of a wide-reaching accord between the United States, Italy, Egypt and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: On Heckler's Successor
description: The Administration that argued a reluctant Margaret M. Heckler into resigning as Secretary of Health and Human Services now seems to be having some trouble making up its mind who is going to be her successor. Currently at the top of the list of potential appointees, Administration sources say, are Dr. Tirso del Junco, former chairman of the California Board of Medical Examiners; David B. Swoap, a former H.H.S. official who is stepping down as secretary of the California Health and Welfare Agency, and Otis R. Bowen, a former Governor of Indiana who is a physician.

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Chief Executive Foreseen at Doremus
description: Steve Kahler, 46-year-old chairman and chief executive of Doremus & Company, will be seeking new horizons after the first of the year.

title: Procter & Gamble Sets Its Mr. Clean Campaign
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the Cincinnati-based consumer products giant, has taken to the streets to promote its Mr. Clean brand liquid cleaning solvent.

title: A Gunman Wounds 2 Yale Police Officers
description: Two Yale University police officers were shot early this morning by a man using one of the officers' revolver, the New Haven police said.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENERS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $853,198. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $512,053. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: TORIES PLEDGE TO CRACK DOWN ON RIOTERS
description: The Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher promised its supporters today that it would stiffen criminal penalties on rioting and ''hooliganism'' and maintain firm control on immigration.

title: Entertainment Agency Of Della Femina Grows
description: Della Femina, Travisano, Sherman & Olken, the Della Femina agency's entertainment and communications advertising subsidiary, is reporting on two pieces of new business, each of which bills about $1 million.

title: IT'S BOOK COUNTRY FOR SMALL PRESSES, TOO
description: THE New York Book Fair has moved from the old Huntington Hartford Museum at Columbus Circle to the parking garage at Lincoln Center to the Exposition Rotunda at the Madison Square Garden Center, where the fair is taking place today through Sunday.

title: President Ends Tax Road Trips
description: President Reagan wound up his tax-revision road show today with speeches blaming the ''national media'' and Congress for his failure to create a groundswell for his plan to overhaul the Federal tax system.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Crying Over Crushed Eggs
description: It would be only mildly hyperbolic to say that Representative Robert Lindsay Thomas ended up with egg on his face.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
HOSTAGE'S DEATH: 'A SHOT TO FOREHEAD'
description: Passengers from the hijacked Italian cruise liner were quoted today as describing how the terrorists had dragged an elderly American tourist from his wheelchair and shot him in cold blood.

title: Reagan Rejects Offer On Some Nominations
description: President Reagan rejected an offer today by the Senate Democratic leader, Robert Byrd, to allow confirmation of some nominees Mr. Byrd has blocked in a dispute involving appointments Mr. Reagan made while Congress was in recess.

title: SENATE WON'T GET SPECIFIC ON DEFICIT
description: A day after overwhelmingly approving a measure requiring a balanced budget by 1991, the Senate showed today, just as overwhelmingly, how fragile and political is its devotion to this goal.

title: PAN AMERICAN BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a net gain of $4,509,000, or 94 cents per share, from the sale of a unit bank. c-Includes a securities gain of $1.3 million, or 27 cents per share.

title: MCI and GTE Settle
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said today that it had agreed to an out-of-court settlement with the GTE Corporation over an long-distance antitrust suit it had filed in 1979. Terms were not disclosed.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Net income.

title: STORM CAT WINS
description: Storm Cat and Danzig Connection, who finished one-two in a prep race here Sept. 28, repeated that finish for a lot more money tonight in the $500,000 Young America Stakes for 2-year-olds at the Meadowlands.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., said it had completed the acquisition of PSL Health Care Corp, a Denver-based hospital system, for about $178 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Middle South Unit Rate Rise
description: A state judge, overruling the state's Public Service Commission, ordered a $113.9 million rate increase today for the Louisiana Power and Light Company to help pay for the Grand Gulf nuclear power plant, effective immediately.

title: Maxxam's Offer Rejected by Pacific
description: The Pacific Lumber Company said today that its board had unanimously rejected the Maxxam Group's unsolicited offer to buy Pacific for $38.50 a share, or a total of about $781 million. Pacific called the price inadequate. The company, however, left the door open for a friendly suitor, asking its financial adviser, Salomon Brothers Inc., to seek other offers.

title: U.S. Opposes Omaha Bid To Add Blacks to Police
description: The Justice Department is trying to stop the City of Omaha from adding 27 to 35 blacks to the list of candidates for a police recruit class, a city official says.

title: NEW SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1985
description: After the Hijacking The four hijackers arrived in Italy, according to the Reagan Administration and Congressional sources. They said that an Egyptian plane carrying the hijackers of an Italian cruise ship had been intercepted by United States Navy planes and forced to land at a United States-NATO air base in Sicily. [Page A1, Columns 1-6.] The four Palestinian hijackers had not intended to seize the cruise liner but did so in desperation after the crew uncovered their weapons, according to Israeli and Arab sources. They said the four had boarded the Achille Lauro for the purpose of getting into Israel at Ashdod, the next port-of-call. [A1:3-4.] Passengers from the Achille Lauro were quoted as describing how the hijackers had dragged an elderly American tourist from his wheelchair and fatally shot him in cold blood. The Italian Ambassador, Giovanni Migliudo, put together his account of the killing of Leon Klinghoffer, a 69-year-old resident of Manhattan, after six hours of interviews with some of the former hostages. [A1:4-6.] International A Salvadoran leftist unit killed at least 40 soldiers and wounded 68 in a lightning raid before dawn at the main training base for Government recruits. [A3:1-3.] National Pentagon arms policy is inadequate, according to a Presidential commission that is preparing to recommend a major overhaul. David R. Packard, who was named chairman of the commission in June, said the panel had concluded that fundamental changes should be made in the Defense Department's organization to correct weapons problems involving poor quality, high prices and long delays in purchasing.

title: ISLANDERS RETURN TO BASICS
description: The Islanders have gone back to reach for their future.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: American Restaurants Corp., Ventura, Calif., which operates Wendy's and Pizza Time Theater restaurant franchises, said Robert W. Moses had joined the company as chief financial officer.

title: Ticor Replaces Most of Its Board
description: Ticor, the nation's third-largest home loan insurer, which stands to lose as much as $166 million on delinquent home loans underwritten for the Equity Programs Investment Corporation, said it has replaced most of the 15-member board for the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company, a subsidiary.

title: GENETIC MARKER FOR CYSTIC FIBROSIS REPORTED FOUND
description: Scientists in Canada and Massachusetts yesterday reported discovering the first genetic marker for the widespread and devastating hereditary disease cystic fibrosis.

title: THE FALL FOLIAGE SHOW IN NEW YORK BOROUGHS
description: While the fall foliage display is already reaching its peak a little to the north of the city, New Yorkers soon won't have to venture more than a subway or bus ride away for the annual autumnal show.

title: 'Fidelio' at Fisher Hall
description: The Beethoven Society, to mark its 10th birthday, is presenting a concert version of ''Fidelio,'' Beethoven's only opera, at 3 P.M. tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Income Rises for Chemical, 4 Others
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, the first major bank to report third-quarter earnings, said yesterday that its net income rose 23.9 percent, to $95.6 million, or $1.80 a share, from the $77.2 million, or $1.42 a share, in the 1984 quarter.

title: FOUR TOP WOMEN SINGERS AT CABARETS IN TOWN
description: THE singers Cleo Laine, Julie Wilson, Carol Fredette and Kaye Ballard are about as different from one another as four singers can be. Yet the four, who are appearing in New York cabarets this weekend, all draw from the wellspring of American pop standards.

title: The New Ideas At Seoul Talks
description: THE key idea coming out of the International Monetary Fund/World Bank meeting here is that nations should free up their economies for more efficient use of resources and that austerity alone, important as it may be for nations with budgetary and debt problems, cannot solve the world's overall debt problem. What is needed is an environment of overall growth, especially in the industrial countries.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $11,693,000 for the quarter and $10,902,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: Warsaw Said to Detain 5 Urging Election Boycott
description: The police detained five men in Warsaw today who tried to broadcast a Radio Solidarity appeal to boycott general elections next week, witnesses said.

title: FILM: 'REMO WILLIAMS,' FROM ADVENTURE NOVELS
description: ''REMO WILLIAMS: THE ADVENTURE BEGINS,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is a live-action comic book of a movie. It's about an ordinary New York cop who, through an intense course in martial arts and something like Zen, is physically and spiritually reconstituted to become an invincible, top-secret United States agent, the sort who murders freely on behalf of good government and honesty in business.

title: Piped-In Board of Estimate
description: The five Borough Presidents, who rarely attend Board of Estimate meetings in person, may soon be able to monitor the proceedings in the comfort of their borough offices.

title: AIR FORCE RELAXES ITS SECRECY ON CARGO FOR A POLAR SHUTTLE
description: The Air Force today made public the military cargo for the first space shuttle flight from California, citing as its reason public interest in the mission, which will place the shuttle in a polar orbit.

title: PLANNING AUTUMN HUNTING
description: Although the current spell of halcyon weather tends to set an outdoorsman thinking of angling rather than hunting, small-game seasons are under way in most of New York State, and deer and black bear are being pursued in the North Country.

title: DeJoseph Name Added To Eisenman & Enock
description: Eisenman & Enock, a New York agency for a quarter century, has merged with nine-month-old Golden Eye Advertising, which allows Jeff DeJoseph of the latter to find his way into the new name, Eisenman, Enock, DeJoseph Advertising.

title: Bad for Lawyers, Bad for Lawyering
description: For more than 10 years, Covington and Burling, the largest and most prestigious law firm in Washington, represented South African Airways. A few days ago, the firm ''fired'' its client, ending a protest by law students who insisted that big firms behave like ''moral actors in a political universe'' and who had, in consequence, been boycotting Covington and Burling's recruiters.

title: TRADE CURBS IMPERIL THE POORER NATIONS, WORLD BODY IS TOLD
description: Protectionist trade policies pose more of a threat to developing countries than the possibility of a space-based defense program, the acting Foreign Minister of the Philippines told the General Assembly today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Caldwell Jones, a 12-year veteran who spent last season with the Chicago Bulls, will be playing for the Portland Trail Blazers this one. The Trail Blazers have worked out a deal in which the Bulls agreed not to match Portland's offer for the free agent in exchange for a second round draft choice in 1987. . . . Doug Smith, a former Auburn star defensive lineman who played last season for the Birmingham Stallions of the United States Football League, has signed a contract with the Houston Oilers, the National Football League team that picked him in the second round of the 1984 draft.

title: FARM CREDIT SYSTEM PLANS BIG AID REQUEST
description: Officials of the troubled Federal Farm Credit System, the largest single source of financing for the nation's farmers, are planning to ask Congress next week for Government assistance that could total as much as $10 billion.

title: Boy, Bystander in a Dispute, Shot to Death on His Bicycle
description: A 14-year-old boy, an innocent bystander in a dispute between four men and four members of his family, was shot to death last night in the Bronx.

title: REAGAN NOMINATES 2 FOR FED
description: The White House tonight announced the nomination of two new members of the Federal Reserve Board: Wayne D. Angell, a Kansas professor, banker and farmer, and Manuel H. Johnson Jr. of the Treasury Department.

title: ENDS RAM LINE
description: The Intel Corporation, suffering from the severe slump in the semiconductor industry, today reported a loss for the third quarter of 1985, its first since 1971. It predicted an even larger loss for the fourth quarter.

title: SCREEN: 'SILVER BULLET'
description: ''STEPHEN KING'S SILVER BULLET,'' Mr. King's own adaptation of his novelette, ''Cycle of the Werewolf,'' tells us how plucky little Marty Coslaw (Corey Haim) almost single-handedly rids the small town of Tarker's Mills of its own, live-in werewolf.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: START WAS PERILOUS, FINISH WAS SWEET
description: It was a long night for Orel Hershiser, and, it turned out after some perilous moments, a sweet one.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INDIA REPORTS TRUCE IN SRI LANKA
description: India announced tonight that a new cease-fire agreement had been negotiated between the Government of Sri Lanka and leaders of one of the main guerrilla groups on the island.

title: Rumanian Cheered in China
description: Thousands of cheering people lined the rain-soaked streets of the industrial city of Wuhan today to greet President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania. A commentator on the state-run television said 5,000 people were at the Wuhan airport to greet Mr. Ceausescu, who arrived from Peking.

title: THREE GROUPS ARE SAID TO BID FOR GROUP W CABLE
description: At least three groups, including ones headed by Time Inc. and Viacom International Inc., have made preliminary bids for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's Group W cable unit, sources close to the bidders said yesterday.

title: Comet Exhibition
description: Halley's Comet, which will be visible in our skies beginning in December, is the subject of a free exhibition at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street.

title: MARTIN INVESTIGATION FINISHED
description: The investigation that George Steinbrenner ordered into two bar incidents last month involving Billy Martin placed no blame on the Yankee manager for starting the fights, but showed that he did ''things he shouldn't be doing,'' a Yankee source familiar with the investigation said today.

title: FIRST CITY BANCORPORATION OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: 'BOY MEETS GIRL,' A TALE OF LOVE BY LEOS CARAX
description: ''BOY MEETS GIRL'' is an intermittently charming first feature by Leos Carax, a young French director who seems to have seen and remembered every film made during the early years of the New Wave. Mr. Carax is 24, but ''Boy Meets Girl'' looks like the work of a talented 18-year-old, someone who still spends more time inside the Cinematheque Francaise than outside it. Even the film's weightily ironic title is a reference to movies - the Hollywood movies that fascinated the New Wave film makers, whose own films were something else entirely.

title: TEXTILES CURB VOTED BY HOUSE
description: Despite the threat of a veto by President Reagan, the House of Representatives today decisively approved legislation that would reduce textile and apparel imports from a dozen nations by as much as 40 percent.

title: In Mexico, an Urgent Need to Decentralize
description: To the Editor:

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WELLES: TOUCH OF GENIUS
description: ''The Magnificent Ambersons'' was not Orson Welles's first film, but it was the first Welles film I ever saw and it, as well as ''Citizen Kane,'' forever changed the way I - and millions of other people around the world -looked at movies.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bloom Quartet
description: The soprano saxophonist Jane Ira Bloom will lead a quartet - with Fred Hersch on piano, Ratzo Harris on bass and Tom Rainey on drums -today at 10:30 P.M. at the West Bank Cafe, 407 West 42d Street (695-6909). There is a $5 cover.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tour of 'Village'
description: The pre-World War I days of artistic life in Greenwich Village will be explored Sunday in a walking tour sponsored by Sculpture and Arts Research.

title: PANEL HEADED BY CHIEF JUSTICE IS SUED OVER CLOSED MEETINGS
description: A national advisory commission on the bicentennial of the Constitution, headed by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, was accused in Federal District Court today of violating a law requiring such groups to hold public meetings.

title: Venezuela Petroleum
description: Ten years after nationalizing its oil industry, Venezuela is now eager to find international partners to help sell its petroleum products. The energy minister, Arturo Hernandez Grisanti, said Wednesday night that the Venezuelan Government wants to amend the oil nationalization law, which reserves all petroleum dealings to the Government.

title: ART: AN ABSTRACT SHOW, SORT OF, AT THE MODERN MUSEUM
description: ''CONTRASTS OF FORM'' at the Museum of Modern Art is an exhibition subtitled ''Geometric Abstract Art 1910-1980.'' It is made up primarily of 75 paintings, 48 works on paper, 16 sculptures and 19 relief constructions that have been presented to the museum by the Riklis Collection of McCrory Corporation. (In all, the gift includes 249 works, chosen by the museum from a possible 800 or more.) Though largely dictated by the tastes of Celia Ascher, curator of the McCrory Corporation, the show is reinforced by a number of irreplaceable masterpieces from the museum's other holdings.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets. Per share figures are after a capital gain distribution of $2.34 per share paid in February 1985.

title: THE MANY FACETS OF ROSTROPOVICH
description: On Sunday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall, Washington's National Symphony Orchestra will appear for a concert. That's not unusual; the orchestra plays here every year, more than once. But Sunday's concert is special in that it will offer four facets of Mstislav Rostropovich - cellist, conductor, champion of Russian music and concerned advocate of human rights.

title: SABERHAGEN MUST STOP JAYS
description: Nothing much is on Bret Saberhagen's mind these days. When he next goes to work Friday evening, he will only have to worry about his team, the Kansas City Royals, being down two games to none in the American League pennant playoff and his wife, Janeane, expecting a baby at any moment.

title: Money Supply Up $5.3 Billion
description: The Federal Reserve late yesterday afternoon announced a $5.3 billion rise in the nation's basic money supply, but the larger than expected gain had little impact on interest rates, which were mixed during the day, with no major changes.

title: WIFE CALLS VICTIM OF HIJACKERS A HERO
description: ''Your father was a hero,'' Marilyn Klinghoffer told her two daughters yesterday morning in her first telephone call home since the the ship hijacking that ended with the murder of her 69-year-old husband, Leon.

title: House Panel Backs Measure On Uniform Poll Closing Time
description: A House subcommittee, in a move to nullify the effects of television projections of election results , today approved a bill calling for all polls in the continental United States to close at the same hour.

title: Hospital at Bethesda Stops Surgery of Heart
description: The Bethesda Naval Medical Center has temporarily stopped scheduling heart surgery because the new head of its cardiothoracic unit has left, a Pentagon official said today.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend payable Oct. 16.

title: OILERS AND GRETZKY START WELL
description: Wayne Gretzky scored two goals tonight, and Craig MacTavish returned to the National Hockey League by scoring the winning goal as the Edmonton Oilers won their season opener from the Winnipeg Jets, 4-3.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $1,150,000, or 12 cents per share; the results of the Centran Corp. which was merged into Society on Sept. 3, and is after the effects of certain previously announced sales of subsidiary banks which are expected to be completed on Oct. 31.

title: Valiant Lighthouse
description: The Little Red Lighthouse has been under a Great Gray Cloud.

title: THEATER: SAM SHIKAZE, PRIVATE EYE, IS BACK
description: THE escapades of Sam Shikaze, Japanese-Canadian private eye, continue with ''Once Is Never Enough'' at the Pan Asian Repertory Theater. Hat brim permanently shading his eyes against the neon glare, cigarette smoke clouding his face, Sam contemplates the death by urban renewal of Vancouver's Powell Street, where he does his lonely Sam Spade-work.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of about $6 million from the redeployment of certain assets.

title: ART: RALSTON CRAWFORD IN SURVEY AT WHITNEY
description: RALSTON CRAWFORD is up for reconsideration by way of a retrospective at the Whitney Museum. Made up of 155 works, this first comprehensive survey of Crawford's art suggests that a better word than ''reconsideration'' would be ''consideration'' -something that he seems never to have had.

title: SCM Adds a Wrinkle to Bidding War
description: The SCM Corporation, in a move apparently intended to put pressure on a British company trying to take it over against its will, said yesterday that its directors had authorized it to pay $74 a share, or $610 million in cash and securities, for two-thirds of the company's stock.

title: PLAN FOR SKYSCRAPER IN BROOKLYN HTS. PITS LIVABILITY GAGINST DEVELOPEMENT
description: The decision by one of the city's leading investment-banking companies to move its back-office departments into an unusual new building planned for Brooklyn has provoked one of the city's sharpest zoning controversies in some time.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Where Scales of Justice Tilt
description: Was there ever a time in America when rich and poor and corporations and white-collar criminals were prosecuted and punished with equal fervor? Senator Howard Metzenbaum, calling for an investigation of the Reagan Administration's Justice Department, implies that this noble norm has been suddenly betrayed.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WEST SIDERS are a hardened and skeptical lot when it comes to restaurants in their neighborhood. And understandably so. Countless times they have seen a bodega or dry cleaner leveled only to resurface as a splashy new restaurant with a cute name, enigmatic menu and advance publicity touting it as the greatest boon to the area since the subway. The curious will rush in while price tags are still on the chairs, slurp a Margarita, chomp on some unidentifiable substance slathered with hot sauce, and disconsolately head home. Fooled again.

title: Telling the Sources
description: One angry contributor to my abundant ration of hate mail denounces the presumption of trying to tell Americans about other people's views of the world. In rasping terms, he asks a reasonable question, in effect: How can you know what Europeans think?

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RANGERS TRIUMPH BY BEING INTENSE
description: The Rangers came flying back into Madison Square Garden last night, shooting hard from everywhere. They skated gracefully, threw their bodies and looked daring. This was the new edition of the Rangers and they won, 4-2, from the Washington Capitals on opening night.

title: FILM: 'BETTER OFF DEAD'
description: SAVAGE STEVE HOLLAND, who is 25 and grew up in Greenwich, Conn., isn't as funny as his name. But he does seem to have a genuinely anarchic sense of humor, and ''Better Off Dead,'' which Mr. Holland wrote and directed, has its moments.

title: Sports of The Times;   New Life For Madlock
description: When Bill Madlock was traded to the Dodgers in the final hours before the postseason rosters would freeze, it was cause for Dodger-haters to gnash their teeth and mutter ''Johnny Mize'' and ''Johnny Sain'' under their breath, all in the same motion. The Dodgers always come up with somebody at closing time, just the way the Yankees used to do.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL HOUSTON (AFC) - Signed Doug Smith, defensive lineman.

title: GENE TIED TO BIRTH PROBLEMS
description: A single gene has been linked to miscarriages, premature births and possibly spinal defects in newborns, according to a study that examined 1,101 couples and their children in the Cleveland area.

title: Afghan Rebels Search For Journalist's Body
description: Afghan rebels are trying to recover the body of an American journalist killed in southern Afghanistan but fear Communist forces have mined the area to prevent them from reaching it, three Americans who traveled with him said today.

title: 2 ISRAELI SAILORS REPORTED KILLED IN BARCELONA
description: Two bodies believed to be those of missing Israeli sailors have been found in this Mediterranean port, and today an anonymous telephone caller said they had been killed by a Palestinian group.

title: Engravings by Audubon.
description: JOHN JAMES AUDUBON was blind and dying in 1850 when the City of New York bought for $1,000 a set of ''The Birds of America,'' the last copy sold of the illustrator's masterpiece before his death the next year. Audubon's son Victor negotiated the sale of the 435 hand-colored engravings to the city, which will auction its copy next weekend at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. Proceeds of the sale, which Sotheby's expects will bring as much as $1.2 million, will be used by the city's Department of Records and Information Services for a variety of programs including public exhibitions of materials in the municipal archives.

title: 14TH CHESS GAME IS DRAWN
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov played to a draw today after 32 moves in the 14th game of their world championship match.

title: YUL BRYNNER, 65, KNOWN FOR ROLE IN 'KING AND I'
description: Yul Brynner, who became identified with his role as the Siamese monarch in ''The King and I'' in a way that few performers ever have been linked with a character, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a long bout with cancer. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Altschiller Is Agency For Lambert's Pasta
description: Altschiller Reitzfeld Solin is getting in on the ground floor of the pasta boom, It has been appointed agency for Lambert's Pasta and Cheese, a New York company that makes pasta products, operates seven retail stores and four cafes in the metropolitan area, and is also moving into distribution in gourmet shops and supermarkets in both this area and California, where it plans to open a second production facility.

title: Tall Tale
description: Yang Jun of the Chinese national basketball team has a listed height of 2.2 meters (about 7 feet 2 inches), which makes him a couple of inches taller than Patrick Ewing. But in a scrimmage against the Knicks last week, Yang had as rough a physical encounter as he could handle.

title: DESIGN CENTER CELEBRATES
description: Heeding instructions to ''follow the red glitter,'' more than 900 guests - including designers, architects and furniture manufacturers and importers -made their way along construction site sidewalks strewn with scarlet sparkles in Long Island City, Queens.

title: EGYPT SAYS IT GAVE GUNMEN TO P.L.O.
description: The departure of the four Palestinian hijackers from Egypt came after a day of confusion over their whereabouts and denials by Egypt that they were still in the country.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: PARTIES in honor of Jerome Robbins, Luciano Pavarotti, the Houston Ballet and Regine made this a very musical week on the social circuit. The first chord was struck Monday night when some 300 devotees of the dance filled the Rainbow Room to pay tribute to Mr. Robbins at a party given by the Anglo-American Dance Foundation. Twyla Tharp, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Donald Saddler were on hand to congratulate the choreographer on winning the Astaire Award for a lifetime of achievement.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: SECRECY BACKED IN EPIC CASE
description: In a ruling with Constitutional implications, a Federal bankruptcy judge ruled here today that the names of financial institutions that lent money to the troubled Equity Programs Investment Corporation be withheld from the public.

title: GOING DOWNTOWN WITH ED
WHEN DRIVERS ARE UNINSURED
description: WHAT happens if you are involved in an automobile accident with a driver of an uninsured or underinsured car? Unless your auto insurance policy provides specific protection against this type of occurrence, the cost could be substantial.

title: The Polls Moscow Won
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Generally, the White House picks veteran professional diplomats to serve as ambassadors in sensitive posts in the Middle East. But our new man in Qatar, an oil-wealthy Persian Gulf nation, is to be Joseph Ghougassian. Mr. Ghougassian, who is not a career diplomat, is to replace Charles Franklin Dunbar, who is.

title: NORTH AMERICAN COAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MANY IN U.S. PROTEST ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Thousands of protesters demonstrated at the White House and on college campuses around the country yesterday, demanding that universities, corporations and the Government break their ties with South Africa.

title: SUSPECT IS SOUGHT IN YALE SHOOTING
description: The city police were searching today for a man who shot and wounded two Yale University police officers on campus.

title: Catholic College Backs Polish Vote Boycott
description: Students at a Roman Catholic university in Lublin, the only Catholic university in Eastern Europe, announced today that they would support a boycott of parliamentary elections on Sunday.

title: COMPUTER TASK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HERMES DEAL MAY BE SPLIT
description: France's two leading aerospace companies are expected to share the $1.7 billion contract to design and build the Hermes, the European space mini-shuttle, industry sources said today.

title: ROONEY, PACE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $550,000 and an extraordinary gain of $5,469,000 on debt restructuring. c-Net loss including a tax credit of $4,018,000.

title: Drug Seller Loses Bid for Freedom
description: A Federal appeals court panel today refused to release Curtis Strong from jail while he awaits sentencing for selling cocaine to major league baseball players.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1985

title: SIX DESIGNERS IN THEIR 20's GET A CHANCE
description: Six designers in their 20's had a chance to show their clothes on the last day of the Italian spring and summer fashion openings. None had ever had a full-scale presentation before. More than 600 people filled the big salon at the Milan Fair, eager to discover new talent.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including special gains of $2,010,000 for the quarter and $13,101,000 for the year. Share earnings reflect a recent 2-for-1 stock split.

title: HEARING ON KAHANE IS SET
description: A Federal district judge in Brooklyn, I. Leo Glasser, yesterday set a hearing for Friday on a petition by Rabbi Meir Kahane, the Israeli political leader, to cancel a decision by the State Department to deprive him of his United States citizenship. The department on Oct. 2 issued a certificate of loss of nationality for Rabbi Kahane, stating that he had withdrawn himself from citizenship in August 1984 by assuming his seat in the Israeli Parliament. Rabbi Kahane, 54 years old, had held dual citizenship.

title: TEMPLE-INLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PHOENIX FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The decrease in the number of shares outstanding resulted from the repurchase of 13,670,588 shares by the company. All shares have been restated.

title: U.S. MILITARY'S PERFORMANCE IS PRAISED
description: Pentagon officials said today that the aerial operation that thwarted the escape of four hijackers over the Mediterranean was a firm rebuttal to critics of recent military budgets and organization.

title: CONCeRT: JAMES TAYLOW
description: Fifteen years ago, when James Taylor became a star at the age of 22, the singer-songwriter from North Carolina had already developed a full-blown personal style. Since then most of his peers have left behind acoustic-oriented folk music to follow newer pop fashions, but Mr. Taylor has remained essentially the same. He has just got better at what he has always done very well.

title: HOSPITAL STAFFING SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $60,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net losses.

title: AGED VICTIM, PORTRAYED AS HELPLESS, IS RECALLED AS A STRONG, HAPPY MAN
description: Leon Klinghoffer has become known around the world as the frail, elderly American shot to death in his wheelchair and thrown overboard from an Italian cruise ship in the Mediterranean. But yesterday, as they awaited the arrival of his widow in the Manhattan apartment where so much had been shared, his daughters and other relatives talked about the Leon Klinghoffer who was most of all a strong family man.

title: ECUADOR BREAKS WITH NICARAGUA
description: Ecuador severed diplomatic relations with Nicaragua today, accusing its President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, of ''gross, inadmissible attacks on the dignity, sovereignty and independence'' of Ecuador.

title: LADD FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
BOMB KILLS LEADER OF U.S. ARAB GROUP
description: A bomb demolished the offices of the Arab-American Anti-Discrimination Committee today, killing the organization's regional executive director and injuring seven other people.

title: TRIANGLE MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
UNITED BANCORP OF ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures reflect a 3-for- 2 stock split paid in May.

title: Piece of Her Mind
description: This week's Good Sportsmanship Award goes to Mary Brown, wife of General Manager Paul Brown of the Bengals, who were beaten by the Jets last Sunday in a game punctuated by 29 penalties, 16 of them called against Cincinnati. Afterward, Mrs. Brown stood at the entrance to the zebras' locker room and addressed them thus: ''You guys stink! You stink! You dirty officials, you stink!''

title: AMERICAN MCGAW
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation said that it has signed a letter of intent to sell its American McGaw division to a purchaser identified only as ''a major health care subsidiary of a multinational Fortune 100 company.'' Terms were not disclosed, but Larry N. Feinberg, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, said the price was probably between $150 million and $175 million. American McGaw makes and sells intravenous solutions.

title: ENTREPRENEUR GROUP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $540,500 for the latest year and $438,482 for the previous year.

title: EXPERT CHALLENGES U.S. VIEWON STOLEN PHOTOS AT SPY TRIAL
description: An expert on intelligence-gathering today disputed the Government's assertion that three photographs given to a British publication last year could have provided important information for the Soviet Union.

title: FIRST CHICAGO POSTS PROFIT IN QUARTER
description: The First Chicago Corporation today reported a healthy rebound in third-quarter net income, to $56.6 million, or $1.01 a share, in contrast to a loss of $71.8 million in the 1984 period.

title: SUNCOAST SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because Suncoast Savings opened for business on May 31, 1985.

title: DAVIED VAN ALSTYNE, REPUBLICAN LEADER IN JERSEY IN THE 40'S
description: David Van Alstyne, a Republican leader in New Jersey in the 1940's and 50's, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 88 years old.

title: GROSS SAYS HE LET AUTOPSY ERROR STAND
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, testified yesterday that he had let stand an incorrect cause of death on his autopsy report on Michael Stewart because he was concerned about how his office would be perceived.

title: DELOREAN TRIAL IS POSTPONED
description: John Z. DeLorean's trial on charges that he defrauded investors in his defunct sports car company has been postponed until next April at the earliest, Judge Julian Cook said today.

title: ROWE FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain of $297,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of surplus property.

title: AN ACTRESS AND AGENT
description: Edith L. Van Cleve, an actress and theatrical agent who is credited with having helped discover Marlon Brando, died at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston Thursday following complications from a blood clot in her leg. She was 90 years old and had been living for the last eight years on Martha's Vineyard.

title: TINY AGENCY BATTLES SECRETARY OF EDUCATION ON INNOVATIVE GRANTS
description: A small agency of the Federal Education Department that has been praised for innovative grants to colleges is waging an unusual battle against its nominal chief, Education Secretary William J. Bennett.

title: 3D INDICTMENT IN NAVY SPH CASE
description: A third indictment was handed up today against Jerry A. Whitworth, a defendant in the Navy spy case, and it had no reference to a communication system that earlier indictments said he used in divulging military secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: STATUS GAME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a benefit of $5,775 from state tax loss carryforward. c-Including benefits totaling $20,342 from research and development and investment tax credits and state tax loss carryforward.

title:
PATENTS;

LOW-ENERGY SWITHC FOR OPTICAL COMPUTERS
description: An optical device patented this week for AT&T; Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., has encouraged the company's expectation of the development of optical computers.

title: Trio at Vanguard
description: The pianist Tommy Flanagan, the bassist George Mraz and the drummer Al Foster will perform through tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 88 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: CRUISE SHIP IS HELD IN EGYPTIAN PORT
description: Egypt today condemned the American interception of an Egyptian jetliner carrying the hijackers of an Italian cruise ship to Tunisia.

title: A HEALTHY 3-YEAR OLD WHO 'JUST LOVES TO EAT'
description: Nuka, which means ''little sister'' in the Yukon Indian language, weighed in at 840 pounds yesterday during her annual physical.

title: TWO ARE KILLED AS POLICE TRUCK AND CAR CRASH
description: A man and woman from Missouri were killed yesterday when the car they were in collided with a Police Department truck at 30th Street and 12th Avenue, the police said.

title: DOW GAINS 11.87 AS STOCKS RALLY
description: Economic news propelled stocks strongly ahead yesterday, providing an upbeat conclusion to a lethargic trading week.

title: FRIES ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WESTAMERICA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANK OF DELAWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONSERVATIONISTS VS. NATIONAL-PARK VISITORS
description: A cruel hoax is about to be played on those of us who believe that national parks are for people. Ironically, the perpetrators of this deception are none other than the self-proclaimed protectors of the parks - the conservation organizations. Strange as it may seem, if we do not want to lose the use and enjoyment of our national parks, we had better take note of what these groups are lobbying for and put a stop to it.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 7, 1985.

title: CHIP INDUSTRY INDICATOR UP
description: The Semiconductor Industry Association reported today a slight improvement in a key semiconductor business index and said it was a sign that a recovery had begun.

title: SATURDAY NEX QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Today Is the Last Day Of Voter Registration
description: Today is the final day to register to vote in the Nov. 5 mayoral election, according to Betty Dolen, executive director of the Board of Elections. Neighborhood polling places will be open from 1 to 9 P.M.

title: MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: HYTEK MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED CAROLINA BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Photo Is Said to Show U.S. Diplomat's Body
description: A photograph purportedly showing the body of an American diplomat, William Buckley, was published today by a Beirut newspaper.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR BACKS HIS POLICY AT BOMB INQUIRY
description: Despite an official warning that an armed confrontation with the radical group Move was inevitable, Mayor W. Wilson Goode told an inquiry today that the city was right to follow a hands-off policy that allowed the group to turn its house into a fortress.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MAHINES CORP (IBM) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue figures represent gross income.

title: DEFENSEMATCHES OFFENSE TO BRING DRAW IN TITLE CHESS
description: Lively play by each player was countered in turn by the other to bring about a draw in the 14th game of the world championship chess match in the Tchaikovsky Concert Hall in Moscow on Thursday. Thus, the champion, 34-year-old Anatoly Karpov, and his 22-year-old challenger, Gary Kasparov, upped the score in their tie match to 7-all.

title: INDIAN PERFORMERS RETURN TO SQUALOR
description: Last summer they were the toast of America. At the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, they enchanted audiences and mingled with Nancy Reagan and other dignitaries. Their pictures were on television and in all the magazines.

title: THE MAN AT RADIO MARTi
description: When the Cuban revolutionary movement led by Fidel Castro began commanding international attention in the late 1950's, it recruited Ernesto Francisco Betancourt to be its public relations and contact man here.

title: 'WE HAVE DONE A FINE JOB,' CARTER SAYS
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said yesterday that he supported the American action that forced the Palestinian hijackers of the Achille Lauro to land in Italy, declaring that he would probably have done the same thing as President.

title: SAY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a reduction of $116,000 as a result of a preferred stock transaction.

title: BRETT SPARKLES AS ROYALS TRIUMPH OVER BLUE JAYS
description: George Brett, the heart, soul, breath and blood of the Royals, singlehandedly resuscitated the withering Western Division champions tonight in the Americam League pennant playoff.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Moseka Quintet
description: The singer Abbey Lincoln Aminata Moseka will bring a quintet to Small's Paradise, 2294 Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard, at 145th Street, (234-6330) for two shows today at 10 P.M. and midnight. Admission is $10.

title: STATE TO ADOPT ONE-CASE, ONE-JUDGE SYSTEM
description: A ''one case, one judge'' system of assigning criminal and civil cases will be put into effect in New York State in January under guidelines just drafted by a court-appointed panel, officials said yesterday.

title: BALBONI, HOWSER END 0-FOR-11 STREAKS
description: The ball just kept fading away, its trajectory carrying it farther from the outstretched gloves of the three fielders who frantically pursued it. When it fell, Steve Balboni and Dick Howser must have felt some kind of personal relief, perhaps even vindication. They had waited too long for this moment.

title: HANSON TRUST IN CREDIT ACCORD
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C. obtained commitments from a group of banks for $775 million in credit, it said today in a filing with the Securites and Exchange Commission.

title: Blast in Israeli Cafe
description: A booby-trapped soft-drink bottle exploded in a small cafe here today, slightly wounding the owner, the police said. In Tunis, the Palestine Liberation Organization said P.L.O. commandos were responsible for the blast, in which it said ''many Israeli security agents were injured.''

title: CB & T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. Phil Niekro became the 18th player to win 300 baseball games and he pitched virtually the entire game without throwing his knuckleball, the pitch for which he is famous. 2. China. 3. 1991. 4. The Peace Corps, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary this month. 5. 30 percent. 6. A sample of 4,600-year-old air. 7. The university decided to grant no honorary degrees at the celebration. 8. They will not be accompanied by short-time payment requirements or austerity measures that would restrict economic potential. 9. Because of harsh criticism, the Government withdrew the measure, but officials say the proposal is not dead and will be reintroduced if students protest again this fall. 10. The screening of Jean-Luc Godard's film ''Hail Mary'' at the New York Film Festival. 11. Even coastal resorts far from the devastation of the earthquakes last month are deserted. Tourism, the nation's second-largest industry, is facing its worst crisis since World War II. 12. Eddie Robinson, head coach at Grambling College since 1941. His teams have won 324 games. 13. The Atlantis. 21. This mission was operated under strict military secrecy. 14. Roger Hedgecock of San Diego. 15. True. 16. He is the co-author of the play ''Everybody Comes to Rick's,'' on which the movie ''Casablanca'' was based. He is suing Warner's, with little success so far, to regain rights to the characters. 17. The committee chairman, Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the committee's senior Democrat. 18.

title: AS NIGHT FALLS, CRIME MOVES INTO STUYVESANT SQUARE
description: In recent months Stuyvesant Square, between 15th and 17th Streets on the East Side and considered one of the city's most handsome parks, has become a late-night sexual meeting place for young homosexual men and a locus for drug dealers.

title: G.M. AND FIAT HOLD TALKS ON VENTURE
description: The General Motors Corporation and Fiat S.p.A., the big Italian auto company, are conducting negotiations on a possible combined venture, a spokesman for G.M. said today. He added that the talks, however, did not involve joint production of automobiles.

title: DANCE: 'MEDIUM' BY FELD
description: One dancer, eight small ramps and a trampoline add up to a new ballet by Eliot Feld with a score by the contemporary and minimalist composer Steve Reich.

title: VECTOR GRAPHIC INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including various nonrecurring charges totaling $2.7 million mainly related to restructuring of the company's operations in the fourth quarter.

title: PHONE AID FOR POOR ADVANCES
description: A panel of seven Federal and state utility regulators today adopted a plan to transfer millions of dollars of local telephone service costs from low-income households to the states and long-distance callers.

title: S.E.C. POST FOR LAWYER
description: The White House announced today that, as expected, it had nominated Edward H. Fleischman, a prominent New York securities lawyer, to a vacant seat on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Phil Niekro Misses Out
description: Phil Niekro, whose hope to become manager of the Atlanta Braves has dissolved again, said yesterday that he had ''no problem'' with the club's decision to hire Chuck Tanner and that he hoped to begin negotiations with the Yankees on another contract. Niekro, who won 16 games this season for the Yankees, said he did not speak with Ted Turner, the owner of the Braves, about the possibility of being named the successor to Bobby Wine, who served as the interim manager last season when Turner dismissed Eddie Haas.

title: 'HANG UP AND DIAL AGAIN' IS JUST THE START
description: It used to be so simple. ''We're sorry,'' the voice on the other end of the telephone would say, ''your call cannot be completed as dialed. Please check the number and dial again or ask your operator for assistance.''

title: UNIBANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ITEL SET OFFERING
description: The Itel Corporation said that it would offer $60 a share in cash, or a total of $124.6 million, for the 73 percent of Great Lakes International Inc. that it does not already own. Itel, a container leasing company based in San Francisco, said that it had made the offer in the form of a merger proposal, but that it would also consider a tender offer to Great Lakes shareholders. Great Lakes, a dredging company based in Chicago, termed the offer ''unsolicited'' and said its board would consider the offer and ''other options'' next week.

title: All Hail Long
description: It takes the retirement of an institution like Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana to inspire a bipartisan social coalition between Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and Robert S. Strauss, the former Democratic national chairman.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY CAIRO ON THE INTERCEPTION
description: Following is the text of a statement by the Egyptian Foreign Ministry today, as translated by The Associated Press from the Arabic:
