title: TWO DOCTORS WHO FEAR THE BOMB: BERNARD LOWN
description: Friends of Dr. Bernard Lown, a cardiologist and co-founder of a Boston-based group that won the Nobel Peace Prize, said today that he is an energetic man who has withstood the barbs of conservative peers to pursue his vision of a world free of nuclear weapons.

title: SECURITY BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 P.L.O. OFFICERS TAKEN TO ROME
description: A public prosecutor in Italy was reported tonight to have charged four Palestinians with murder and kidnapping in the hijacking of the cruise liner Achille Lauro.

title: Cribbs Back With Bills
description: Two years after he jumped from the Buffalo Bills to the Birmingham Stallions of the United States Football League, Joe Cribbs jumped back to the Bills yesterday and signed a series of one-year contracts, reportedly worth $2 million for four years, plus a $500,000 signing bonus. The Bills promptly applied for a two-week exemption to allow the 27-year-old running back to learn the club's offense before adding him to the active roster.

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF N.Y.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THATCHER AFFIRMS ECONOMIC POLICIES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in the face of doubts within her party, today reaffirmed the economic policies that have guided her Government.

title: COLUMBUS DAY, 1935: TENSION IN NEW YORK
description: New York City's worst celebration of Columbus Day may well have occurred 50 years ago today.

title: BUSINESS ECONOMISTS SEE A SLUGGISH '86
description: Economists for the nation's biggest companies today predicted slightly better but still lackluster prospects for the rest of this year and 1986.

title: NEW CONFIDENCE HELPS KEAN'S IMAGE
description: When President Reagan visited New Jersey last week to stump for Republican candidates in the Nov. 5 elections, he called Governor Kean ''the single most popular governor in the history of the state.''

title: A Man for Meese
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has appointed Allan Gerson to what Mr. Meese described as ''one of the most important offices in the executive branch.'' Mr. Gerson, who was special counsel to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick when she was chief delegate to the United Nations, will have the title Deputy Assistant Attorney General in the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel. The job pays $70,500 a year.

title: INFANT MORTALITY RATE IN U.S. AT RECORD LOW
description: Infant mortality in the United States fell to its lowest rate in the nation's history last year even as the number of births was rising to the highest point since 1970, new Government statistics show.

title: CARDS BACK ON 'MAGIC CARPET'
description: To the St. Louis Cardinals, it is home, and it has all the comforts of home: the carpet, the pool-table green, the true bounce, the high hop, the fast lane.

title: TWO DOCTORS WHO FEAR THE BOMB: YEVGENY CHAZOV
description: Yevgeny I. Chazov, the Soviet co-chairman of International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, is most popularly known in Moscow as ''the Kremlin Doctor.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: John McEnroe has withdrawn from the Australian indoor tennis championships next week, saying he aggravated a shoulder injury during an exhibition match against Ivan Lendl in East Rutherford, N.J., Wednesday night. He missed the 1984 event because of shoulder and elbow injuries. . . . Jackie Moore, the Oakland A's manager, has been rehired for next season. . . . Ken Oberkfell, the Atlanta infielder, signed a four-year contract with the Braves. . . . Walker Russell, who was cut by the Atlanta Hawks after 21 games last season and again during training camp this year, signed a multiyear contract with the Detroit Pistons, the club that cut him after 16 games in 1983.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an after-tax gain of $4.3 million from a contract settlement and an increase in net earnings of $2.2 million from a decrease in the provision for depreciation of certain assets. c-Including an after-tax gain of $6.3 million for an exchange of the company's common stock and cash for certain of its debentures and a gain of $7.5 million that resulted from provisions in the 1984 tax reform act.

title: HOLIDAY CLOSINGS
description: Stock and commodity markets will be open as usual Monday, but Government offices, banks and some businesses will close in observance of Columbus Day.

title: HIJACKING REKINDLES DEBATE OVER ITALIAN RELATIONS WITH ARAB WORLD
description: The American diversion to Italy of an aircraft carrying the cruise ship hijackers has put strains on Italy's Socialist-led coalition Government and its carefully cultivated relationship with the Arab world.

title: CREST-FOAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid July 15, 1985.

title: U.S. Supplies Are Sent To Nicaraguan Rebels
description: The United States has sent Nicaraguan rebels the first shipment of supplies from the $27 million in nonlethal aid approved by Congress last summer, the head of a special State Department office said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Armco Inc.'s Eastern Steel division and C. Itoh & Co. of Japan said they planned to build their previously announced joint venture steel processing plant in Tipp City, Ohio. * Adolph Coors Co., Golden, Colo., has licensed Molson Breweries of Canada Ltd. to produce and distribute Coors beer in Canada. * Deltaus Corp., Tyler, Tex., said it sold most of its oil and gas properties to the Kerr-McGee Corp. for about $140 million, to reduce its bank debt. Included in the sale are pipelines and two gas processing plants. * DSC Communications Corp., Dallas, said a qualified auditor's opinion of its 1984 financial results has caused a technical default under the company's line of credit with six banks and other lenders in connection with borrowings totaling $45 million. * Early California Industries, Los Angeles, said it completed the sale of its domestic olive business to Early California Foods Inc., a newly formed subsidiary of Specialty Brands Inc., and its Seville, Spain, olive operation to UB Investments Ltd., Specialty Brands' sister corporation, for about $86 million. * GCA Corp., Bedford, Mass., citing poor conditions in the semiconductor market, said it expects to lose more than $27 million in the third quarter on sales of about $52 million. The company said it will lay off about 500 employees. * GTE Corp., Stamford, said it plans to eliminate as many as 50 jobs among corporate and support staff at its Stamford headquarters and in nearby facilities. * Honeywell Inc. has been notified that the Army has exercised its option to buy 362,000 of the Swedish-design AT-4 shoulder-fired recoil-less weapons in a $272.8 million contract. * Kaypro Corp., Solana Beach, Calif., a maker of portable computers, introduced its first desktop computer at a suggested retail price of $1,595. * Martin-Marietta Corp.'s Martin Marietta Data Systems unit said it received an $18.5 million five-year contract from the Energy Department. * People Express Airlines Inc., Newark, said that effective Monday it will cut its one-way fares between Newark and San Francisco to $99 off-peak, and $149 peak, from $149 and $199, respectively. * Piezo Electric Products Inc., Cambridge, Mass., said it will not pay the 27.5 cents quarterly dividend for the cumulative convertible preferred stock, for the quarter ending Oct. 31. * Sony Corp., Tokyo, said it will start production of industrial videotape recorders this month at a plant in Florida. * Yamaha Motor Co. Ltd. said it will resume paying dividends with a 6 yen payment in the year ending April 30, 1986, after no dividend payments in the last two years.

title: SCHOLARS STILL DEBATING COLUMBUS LANDING SITE
description: After a westward voyage of 33 days, Christopher Columbus made landfall on Oct. 12, 1492, but to this day, the 493d anniversary of the discovery of America, scholars are not sure exactly where he first set foot in the New World. It was at a small island in the Bahamas, far from the Asian mainland Columbus was seeking, but which one?

title: ASTROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to June 30 from Aug. 31. Latest year results are for the 10 months to June 30, 1985. Year-ago results are for the 12 months to Aug. 31, 1984.

title: CUOMO PLACES STORM DAMAGE AT $285 Million
description: Hurricane Gloria, which struck the metropolitan area two weeks ago, caused at least $285.2 million in damage to New York, primarily on Long Island, Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

title: He May Take Payton's Place
description: One September afternoon three years ago, in a controlled scrimmage against the University of Lowell, Joe Dudek of Plymouth (N.H.) State took a handoff, sliced off tackle and sprinted 66 yards for a touchdown. Dudek, a freshman tailback, had never before touched the ball for Plymouth State, and if he was conveying a good first impression, he was also delivering a portent. In the season opener against Norwich the following week he scored four touchdowns, and in the next three games he scored nine.

title: EDITOR ON COAST SPARED JAIL OVER A CONTEMPT CONVICTION
description: A judge today held up the jailing of the executive editor of The Oregonian while the newspaper appealed a contempt citation.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
A SET BACK TO TERRORISM AND MORE: REAGAN'S PROGRAMS STAND TO BENEFIT
description: In a single stroke, President Reagan has altered the impression held by many, including some within the White House, that the American Government is virtually helpless in the face of terrorism, aides and political analysts asserted today.

title: NOW, JAPAN'S STROLLER INVASION
description: A small Japanese company has come up with a product that perfectly suits the temper of the times and a new group of eager, anxious and affluent parents: an upscale baby stroller.

title: SOUTHERN MINERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MANY U.S. ALLIES APPLAUD MOVE, BUT SOME QUESTION ITS LEGALITY
description: Many American allies yesterday applauded United States actions that led to the capture of the four Palestinian hijackers of the Achille Lauro, but some countries reacted cautiously or withheld judgment on the legality of intercepting the Egyptian jet that was carrying the hijackers.

title: CANADIAN JOBLESS RATE
description: The Canadian unemployment rate fell to a seasonally adjusted 10.1 percent in September, from 10.3 percent in August, the Government said today. The rate is now at its lowest in three and one-half years. The number of unemployed, not adjusted for seasonal variations, was 1,183,000 in September, 70,000 fewer than in August and 13.2 percent lower than a year earlier.

title:
PATENTS;

WATER TREATED TO AID PLANTS
description: IMPROVED ways to use drops of water for the protection and improvement of plant life were disclosed this week in patents granted to experienced inventors.

title:
PATENTS;

HALOGENATION PROCESS MAKES USE OF ENZYMES
description: The Cetus Corporation, a large genetic engineering company in Emeryville, Calif., received a patent for the manufacture of halogenated ketones and aldehydes.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain of $58,000 for the quarter and the year on the sale of land and a hotel in Columbia, Mo. c-Including a gain of $212,000 for the quarter and $456,000 for the year on the sale of land.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING & CERTIFICATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $422,000 for the quarter and $1,115,000 for the 9 months.

title: THE WHIFFLEBALL BROTHERS
description: As if ordained by the color, the Iorg brothers grew up in Blue Lake, Calif., a lumber town of about 1,000 population up near the Oregon border. Now they are wearing different blue-trimmed uniforms as the only brothers ever to compete in a league-championship series on opposing teams - Garth, a platoon third baseman for the Toronto Blue Jays and Dane, a pinch-hitter and reserve outfielder for the Kansas City Royals.

title: DASH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GENEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, including a payment of $6.9 million from Allied/Bendix, releasing them from their obligations to support the company's protein engineering program.

title: TRANS-NATIONAL LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NOBEL PEACE PRIZE CITATION
description: Following is the official text of the Norwegian Nobel Committee's citation today awarding the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize to International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War:

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FOODS THAT GRANDMA DID (AND DIDN'T) COOK
description: The fall crop of cooking-related books is beginning to pile up on the desk and spill onto the floor. Two stand out for reasons that have almost nothing to do with cooking. One because it is an enchanting memoir, the other because of its breathtaking photographs.

title:
PATENTS;

ALLERGIC REACTIONS TO POLLENS BLOCKED
description: Substances that block allergic reactions in the body to the pollen of timothy and other grasses are described in patent 4,545,986. The inventor of the compounds is Arthur Malley, an immunologist with the Oregon Regional Primate Research Center, Beaverton, Ore.

title: REAGAN REPORTS 'MINOR' SURGERY FOR SKIN CANCER
description: President Reagan said today that a White House doctor removed additional skin cancer cells from his nose in a ''minor operation'' on Thursday. He said he had now been assured that ''my nose is clean.''

title: Belfast Court Orders Fugitive Extradited to Dublin for Trial
description: A Belfast court today ordered Dominic McGlinchey, the first republican guerrilla extradited from the Irish Republic to Northern Ireland, to be returned to the south.

title: UNIFI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of 21 cents a share on the sale of auto texturing machines. c-Net loss. The latest quarter included 13 weeks while the year-ago quarter included 14 weeks.

title: BUSINESS SOURING ON TAX PLAN
description: Support for President Reagan's proposed overhaul of the tax system is fast eroding among many of the nation's leading business executives.

title: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,135,000.

title: CONSULTANT OPPOSED BID WAIVER ON JOB WON BY PRICE WATERHOUSE
description: An outside consultant hired by top officials in the Kean administration argued against awarding Price Waterhouse & Company a contract to overhaul the state's motor-vehicle computer system without competitive bidding, according to testimony today before an State Assembly committee.

title: UNITED BANCORP ALASKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $238,193, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $578,071, or 17 cents a share, for the 9 months and income of $2 million for the quarter and 9 months from the settlement of litigation. Per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK & TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AUTO RISE IS CHIEF SPUR
description: Retail sales rose at the strongest clip in five months in September as heavy demand for new cars overshadowed disappointing department store sales, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: LTV TO SELL PART OF OILFIELD UNIT
description: The cash-short LTV Corporation said yesterday that it is attempting to sell portions of its oilfield equipment division. The sales are part of a $500 million divestiture plan announced by the Dallas-based company last May. The units include Fibercast, a maker of fiberglass-reinforced piping for oil refineries and chemical plants; Oil States Industries, a maker of rubber and plastic parts for oil and gas production; the automated fluid systems division, and the tubular services division.

title: ALABAMA ACTIVIST IS ACQUITTED
description: Federal jurors today acquitted one of two black political activists accused of voting fraud, but they said that they were deadlocked in the case against his co-defendant.

title: Two Convicted In Player's Death
description: Two teen-agers were convicted today in the shooting death of a nationally recruited high school basketball star outside a South Side video games arcade last November.

title: HOW TO AID PUERTO RICE
description: Banco Popular de Puerto Rico is organizing a relief fund. People who wish to contribute may send checks and money orders to the bank's main branch at 7 West 51st Street in Manhattan.

title: P.L.O. PONDERS NEXT MOVE
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization made no mention today of what effect it thought the hijackers' apprehension might have on proposed Middle East peace talks involving Jordan and the United States.

title: Textile Union Rejected At North Carolina Mills
description: Employees at Cannon Mills, the nation's largest towel manufacturer, have rejected representation by the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union by a vote of 5,982 to 3,530, officials of the National Labor Relations Board say.

title: Davis Request Denied
description: The National Football League yesterday told Kenneth Davis, the former Texas Christian University running back, that it would not hold a supplemental draft for him and that he would not be allowed to join the league this season. And the league responded to a threatened lawsuit by Mike Trope, Davis's agent, that would challenge the rule prohibiting athletes from playing both in college and the N.F.L. in the same season.

title: READICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MUNSINGWEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Including tax credits of $33,000 for the quarter and $1,430,000 for the 9 months and a nonrecurring expense of $638,000 for the quarter and 9 months related to the replacement of the company's computer system which is expected to be completed by the middle of 1986. c-After a reversal of a tax credit of $59,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $993,000 for the 9 months.

title: QADDAFI IN MOSCOW: LITTLE OF SUBSTANCE EXPECTED FROM VISIT
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, spent a day meeting and dining with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other top Soviet leaders today, but diplomats saw no signs that the two sides were prepared to sign a friendship treaty announced two years ago.

title: INDEPENDENCE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
2 Killers Hanged in Guyana
description: Guyana has hanged two murderers in the first executions in the South American country in 15 years, the official Guyana News Agency said.

title: BALTIMORE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-No per share earnings shown because the company went public in November 1984.

title: FOSTER TO ACQUIRE FIVE KIDDE UNITS
description: The L. B. Foster Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire five units from Kidde Inc. for about $300 million.

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include the acquisition of Heritage Wisconsin Corp. on July 9, which was accounted for as a purchase.

title: SHL SYSTEMHOUSE reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a $4.8 million pre-tax gain on the sale of subsidiaries and a $3.2 million tax credit.

title: MORRIS HAS GIANTS ON THE RUN
description: When the Giants drafted George Adams on the first round this year, it seemed inevitable that he would soon become their starting halfback. But not yet. For now, the job belongs to Joe Morris, and he could tell Adams about the often-rocky path from college star to pro starter.

title: Let Art Subsidies Go Directly to Artists
description: To the Editor:

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PANTRY PRIDE
description: Pantry Pride Inc. said it has obtained commitments for the purchase of half the $700 million in notes it has said it would have to sell to finance its porposed purchase of Revlon Inc. It added that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., dealer manager for the offer, remained highly confident it could find buyers for the remaining notes required if its $56.25-a-share-offer succeeds. Revlon's management and Forstmann Little & Company have offered $56 a share for the company.

title: USLICO SETS BID
description: The USLico Corporation said the International Bank of Washington's board agreed to be acquired by USLico in an exchange of stock valued at $15.15 a share, or $129 million. USLico, an insurance company based in New York, said it also acquired the 38 percent stake owned by Aegon N.B. Thursday for $57.3 million, raising the total purchase price to $189 million.

title: WRITER ADMITS DECEPTION IN INTERVIEW ON BELUSHI
description: A freelance writer admitted today that he used subterfuge to obtain an interview in which Cathy Evelyn Smith said she injected the comedian John Belushi with heroin and cocaine about 20 times the day before he died.

title: NEW BROADWAY HOTEL GETS THE ONCE OVER
description: A hotel that has been in the works here for 13 years - and a design that has been playing to great acclaim in smaller cities for two decades - finally opened on Broadway this week to mixed reviews.

title: SLOW SEARCH FOR BODIES ON PUERTO RICO HILLSIDE
description: Working under a scorching sun, National Guardsmen and other rescue teams picked their way cautiously through a ruined shantytown today in a search for bodies. One senior officer said the search might drag on for a month.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $365,000 for the quarter and the 9 months for shutdown and disposition of the company's Huntsville facility and consolidation of its operation in Cullman.

title: STANDOFF REPORTED BETWEEN ITALY AND EGYPT ON P.L.O. ESCORTS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that an angry standoff had taken place at the Sicily air base between Italian and Egyptian officials over the fate of two senior Palestinian representatives who had accompanied the four hijackers out of Egypt.

title: REAGAN MAY BOYCOTT FETE AT U.N. IF ARAFAT SHOWS UP
description: President Reagan may boycott ceremonies marking the 40th anniversary of the United Nations if Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, takes part, a spokesman at the United States Mission said today.

title: TEXAS COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPEARHEAD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WHITE SUPREMACISTS VOICE SUPPORT OF FARRAKHAN
description: Leaders of neo-Nazi and other white supremacist groups met in a gesture of solidarity against Jews last weekend and talked of an accommodation with Louis Farrakhan, leader of a Black Muslim group who has been accused of anti-Semitism.

title: UNITED AIR GAINS IN BID TO GET PAN AM ROUTES
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, yesterday gave preliminary approval for United Airlines to acquire the Pacific routes of Pan American World Airways. But she also called for a hearing to determine whether another carrier should take over United's routes between Seattle and Tokyo.

title: SOUND WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company was formed in a reorganization of three entities under common control in May 1985 and went public on Aug 20, 1985. Year-ago earnings are pro-forma, reflecting the results of operations as if the reorganization occured at the beginning of fiscal 1985.

title: San Diego Mayor Quits; Deputy to Take Over
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock, convicted of conspiring to accept illegal campaign contributions and perjury, resigned today ''in the best interests of the city.''

title: 4 FOUND DEAD IN ATLANTA FIRE
description: The bodies of four men believed to have been transients were found Friday by firefighters searching through the rubble of a boarded-up building that burned Thursday. A spokesman for the city's Public Safety Department said the men were believed to have been transients who entered the building to sleep on old mattresses.

title: NATIONAL GUARD OUSTS SPOKESMAN
description: The New York National Guard announced today that it had dismissed its top spokesman.

title: LA POINTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $230,523.

title: 4th Whole Life Expo, Yoga, Music and Dance
description: Yoga workshops, seminars on health and music and dancing are being offered this weekend at the Fourth Whole Life Expo, in the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue and 45th Street.

title: VIDEO DISPLAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COMES THE MILLENNIUM The millennium, at least the first millennium, has arrived in the history of Spanish arts and letters and it is being celebrated nowhere more appropriately than in the aptly named exhibition ''Tesoros de Espana: Ten Centuries of Spanish Books,'' which opens today at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: REBELS ASSERT U.S. ADVISERS WERE TARGET OF SCHOOL RAID
description: In one of its strongest threats so far against American military advisers here, the Salvadoran rebel high command said today that the chief goal of a punishing guerrilla raid Thursday on the Salvadoran Army's basic training school was to kill or capture American soldiers serving there.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY TO CHALLENGE BRONX BUS GARAGE REVERSAL
description: The Transit Authority vowed yesterday to press ahead with the construction of a $100 million bus garage in the Bronx, despite a Board of Estimate vote to withdraw its support for the project.

title: POLAROID GETS CURB ON KODAK
description: The Polaroid Corporation said late yesterday that it had received a permanent injunction from the United States District Court in Massachusetts barring the Eastman Kodak Company from manufacturing or selling instant cameras and films after Jan. 9, 1986.

title: BOND PRICES NARROWLY MIXED
description: Prices of Treasury and other fixed-income securities meandered in a narrow range yesterday. Trading was dull as dealers largely confined their activities to balancing their books for the three-day holiday weekend. Most banks and Treasury securities dealers will be closed Monday in observance of Columbus Day.

title: AVON REPURCHASE
description: Avon Products Inc. said that it would commence its previously announced share repurchase program through an agreement with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. Under terms of the agreement, the brokerage firm would purchase up to 10 million, or 12.5 percent, of Avon's shares for its own account.

title: The Criminals for Whom We Must Have Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: PAROLE OFFICER IS SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: A state parole officer was shot to death in his car in Queens Thursday evening and the police said yesterday that they were investigating the possibility that he might have been killed because of his job.

title: GOODRICH CLOSING
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said today that it will begin shutting down its tire plant in Oaks, Pa., starting in April 1986.

description: b-Net loss. The company went public on June 3, 1985. Results for latest nine months include a benefit of $1.5 million caused by a change in the structure of a deferred compensation plan for key executives which resulted from the company becoming publicly owned.

West Germans Make Another Spying Arrest
description: Officials announced another espionage-related arrest today, bringing to 11 the number of suspects identified since August in West Germany's spying scandal.

title: DEFICIT SHOWN BY MOROROLA
description: Motorola Inc., in the throes of a depressed market for semiconductors, reported a third-quarter loss of $39 million today, in contrast to net income of $86 million in the same period a year ago. Sales for the quarter declined 5.8 percent, to $1.30 billion, from $1.38 billion a year ago.

title: DREYFUS ACTS ON APARTHEID
description: The directors of the Dreyfus Third Century Fund have voted to sell all their stock in companies that have South African operations, a spokesman said yesterday. The shift affects $27.8 million of the total $150 million portfolio.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. NEGOTIATORS OF ABM TREATY SAY REAGAN IS 'HARPOONING' PACT
description: Former Government officials who negotiated the 1972 treaty that limits United States and Soviet defenses against ballistic missiles said today that the Reagan Administration seemed to be misinterpreting and repudiating the treaty.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $545,000 from early extinguishment of debt less a penalty on prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: Talking Beisbol
description: The hardest-working broadcaster on the New York sports scene may well be the man almost nobody knows.

title: MORE GROUP W BIDDERS
description: Burton Stanier, president of Group W Cable Inc., and Warburg Pincus & Company, an investment concern, are among the groups that have submitted preliminary bids for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's Group W cable unit, sources close to the situation said yesterday. They join at least three other groups that have made offers for Group W, the nation's third-largest operator of cable systems. Sources said the other bidders included a group with Time Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc.; a group headed by Communications Equity Associates, a cable broker, and a group headed by Viacom International Inc.

title: JUBILANT JUSTICE
description: The best measure of Thursday's exhilarating triumph over terrorism is to consider where the world would be if it hadn't happened.

title: 3 CUSTOMS OFFICIALS INDICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE DRUGS
description: Three United States Customs Service supervisors were indicted Friday in a scheme to smuggle $17 million worth of marijuana from Colombia, according to the Federal authorities.

title: Exchange of Centers
description: In a trade of centers, the Toronto Maple Leafs sent Bill Derlago to the Boston Bruins in exchange for Tom Fergus. The trade was announced after the Bruins defeated the visiting Leafs, 3-1, in their season opener Thursday night.

title: DR. HOWARD T. BEHRMAN
description: Dr. Howard T. Behrman, a dermatologist and a benefactor of Princeton University, died Wednesday at the Princeton Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in New York and Princeton.

title: PRETORIA PARTY WILL MEET REBELS
description: A delegation from South Africa's official white opposition party has arrived in Lusaka for discussions with the outlawed African National Congress, diplomats in the Zambian capital said today.

title: CALLER SAYS U.S. WILL PAY IF HARM COMES TO HIJACKERS
description: An anonymous caller told a Western news agency here today that the United States would ''pay dearly'' if the hijackers in Italian custody were harmed.

title: HIJACKERS AND THE LAW: A TANGLE OF QUESTIONS
description: Officials here and in Italy said today that the four hijackers who apparently killed an American hostage on an Italian cruise ship would most likely be tried in Italy, rather than the United States.

title: ROSS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAELIS PRAISE U.S. ACT AS BIG ANTITERROR STEP
description: Israelis from all walks of life today hailed the swift capture by the United States of the hijackers of the Italian cruise ship.

title: Tackle Suspended
description: A starting Texas offensive tackle, John Stuart, has been charged with drunken driving and suspended from the game against Oklahoma today. Stuart, a senior, was arrested at about 1:45 A.M. Thursday, police said, after driving erratically in a pickup truck in the athletic-dormitory parking lot at the Texas campus. Stuart was released in his own recognizance.

title: CHECKING BARGAIN AIR FARES
description: IF some prices advertised in newspapers these days for flights to Europe - London for $189 or Paris for $199 - seem too good to be true, it may be because they are, according to the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York.

title: HARVARD ALLOWS PROFESSOR TO USE $50,000 GRANT FROM C.I.A. FOR CONFERENCE ON ISLAM
description: A Harvard University professor who accepted a $50,000 grant from the Central Intelligence Agency for a conference on Islamic fundamentalism without informing the school will not be disciplined and the meeting will be allowed to proceed, the university announced today.

title: Liberia Warns Soldiers On Conduct in Election
description: A special elections commission threatened today to dismiss or execute any soldier caught behaving in an unruly manner or ''engaging in acts of atrocity'' during a general election scheduled Tuesday.

description: Gov. William Sheffield of Alaska underwent a surgical procedure to clear a blocked coronary artery today at Providence Medical Center here. His spokesman said the procedure was successful.

title: Rolling on the River
description: Washington alumni of Oxford and Cambridge, lacking a Thames or Cam, will be out on the Potomac tomorrow afternoon for a local version of The Boat Race, wearing the dark blue and light blue colors, respectively, of those venerable institutions. Stroking the Cambridge eight will be Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. against an Oxford contingent that includes George A. Carver Jr., former deputy to the Director of Central Intelligence. Oxford won a comparable race between New York area alumni last spring, and tension is running high.

FAMILY BONDS
description: FAMILY AND FRIENDS. By Anita Brookner. 187 pages. Pantheon. $13.95. In the British writer Anita Brookner's four previous novels, a recognizable vision of society, of the interactions between men and women, has been elegantly mapped out. It's a vision of the world as a dangerous, predatory place, peopled by two sorts of individuals - sophisticates and innocents. And while Miss Brookner always sides with her naifs - in each case, a Pym-like spinster, diligent, correct and impeccably earnest -she also makes it clear that she regards them as losers in society's hypocritical games. It's the careless, tempestuous people who get ahead and who win the love of others - not her discreet little heroines, who seem doomed by their own good intentions.

Basketball Knicks vs. Rockets at Houston, exhibition game. 8:30 P.M. Nets vs. Utah Jazz, at Knight Center, Miami, 8 P.M., exhibition game. (Radio -WNBC 660, 8 P.M.) Boxing Azumah Nelson, champion, vs. Pat Cowdell, 12 rounds for World Boxing Council featherweight championship, at Birmingham, England. Nelson, 21-1 with 16 knockouts, from Ghana; Cowdell, 30-3 with 14 knockouts, is the hometown favorite. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Football Virginia at Clemson (Television -MSG, noon); Florida State at Auburn (Television - WTBS, 12:30 P.M.); Brown at Penn, 1 P.M.; Columbia at Princeton (Television -Channel 13, 1 P.M. live. Radio -WKCR-FM 89.9, 1 P.M.); North Carolina State at Pittsburgh (Television - Channel 11 and USA Network, noon.); Rutgers at Temple, 12:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 10:30 P.M. tape. Radio - WCTC 1450, 12:30 P.M.); Delaware State at Connecticut, 1 P.M.; Kean at Stony Brook, 1 P.M.; Fordham at Georgetown, 1 P.M. (Radio -WFUV-FM 90.7, 1 P.M.); Gettysburg at U.S. Merchant Marine, 1:30 P.M.; Wagner at Hofstra, 1:30 P.M.; Rutgers-Newark at Brooklyn, 1:30 P.M.; Worcester State at William Paterson, 1:30 P.M.; Holy Cross at Yale, 1:30 P.M.; U.S. Coast Guard at New York Maritime, 1:30 P.M.; Ramapo at Jersey City State, 1:30 P.M.; Air Force at Navy 2 P.M.; Pace vs. St. John's at Pleasantville, N.Y., 2 P.M.; Iona at Marist, 2:30 P.M.; Michigan at Michigan State (Television -Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.); Oklahoma vs.

title: Greenpeace Says Ships Will Continue Protest
description: Five Greenpeace ships in the South Pacific are prepared to continue their protest against French nuclear testing indefinitely, a Greenpeace official said today.

title: 'COPACABANA,' A MUSICAL FOR TV WITH MANILOW
description: The pirates crack their whips, the harem girls scream in terror, and Annette O'Toole sings defiantly of the man who is sure to rescue her, the legendary hero ''El Bravo.'' This gaudy, campy production number recently staged at the Coconut Grove nightclub in Los Angeles calls to mind ''The Pirate'' and other big-budget M.G.M. musicals of the 1940's.

title: EGYPTIAN AIRLINER HEADS FOR ROME
description: The Egyptian airliner forced by American fighter planes to land at this Italian-American air base shortly after last midnight took off tonight, almost 24 hours after it landed, bound for Rome.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: TOFU TIME reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 9, 1985.

title: SOLOMON ISLANDS PRIMIER, AT U.N., ASSAILS FRANCE
description: The Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands accused the French Government today of pursuing ''imperialistic'' policies in the South Pacific at the expense of the countries in that region.

title: TIME TO GET TOUGH ON CHILD-SUPPORT PAYMENTS
description: A new Federal law encouraging state governments to get tough with parents (mostly fathers) who cheat on their child-support obligations is now on the books. The only question is whether state judges and enforcement agencies will have the guts to use this new authority conscientiously.

title: NOBEL PEACE PRIZE GIVEN TO DOCTORS OPPOSED TO WAR
description: The 1985 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded today to the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, a five-year-old Boston-based group that was jointly founded by American and Soviet doctors.

title: FLATTERER IS VICTOR
description: Jonathan Sheppard sent out Storm Cat to win $300,000 at the Meadowlands Thursday night and Flatterer to win $30,000 at Belmont Park yesterday. Even though the Young America Stakes gave the trainer his first legitimate Triple Crown candidate and almost 10 times as much purse money, yesterday's cheaper victory was just as satisfying.

title: CITICORP ENDS MARYLAND THRIFT TALKS
description: Citicorp has notified Maryland officials that it has halted negotiations to buy First Maryland Savings and Loan Association, one of four Maryland thrift institutions where depositors cannot withdraw money.

title: HIJACKERS IN CUSTODY: A SPECIAL SATISIFACTION FOR ISRAEL AND U.S.
description: The affair of the Achille Lauro was only the latest in the cycle of revenge between Palestinians and Israelis.

title: BRENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $226,000.

title: TRANSTECTOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income. The company went public in July 1984.

title: SPERRY TO MOVE EXECUTIVE OFFICES
description: The Sperry Corporation said yesterday that it plans to move its executive offices from New York City to Blue Bell, Pa., in the next year or so. In a letter sent to employees last week, Gerald G. Probst, Sperry's chairman and chief executive, said that most of the executive office functions would be transferred to the Pennsylvania location as part of a plan to ''increase organizational efficiency and productivity.''

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN (FNMA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Toward a U.S. Judiciary Free of Political Passions
description: To the Editor:

title: A CENTURY OF OPERATIC GLORIES POURS FORTH
description: America's foremost opera house, now well-launched on its second century, is issuing a splendid history in sound of its first. ''One Hundred Years of Great Artists at the Met,'' compiled by the critic David Hamilton from recordings reaching from early acoustical 78's to modern stereo, brings the tantalizing pages of the Metropolitan Opera Annals to vibrant life. Nothing at once so broad and so rigorously specific has been attempted before, and the final impact is to suggest that the Met's achievement over the years has been, if anything, underestimated.

title: FOR YEAR-ROUND RESIDENTS, NANTUCKET IS NO OASIS
description: The moors and beaches of Nantucket Island are an oasis for vacationers seeking refuge from the stress of city life. But for many of Nantucket's 6,000 year-round residents, the stress of daily life is never left behind. The high cost of living on the island, the lack of a major industry offering good, steady wages, and the scarcity of year-round rental housing make survival on the island a constant struggle.

title: Clare D. Powell Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. David G. Powell of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Clare Davis Powell to Douglas Philip Pitney, a son of Philip Hill Pitney of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Julie Crystie Webster of Ithaca, N.Y.

title: STAGE: 'TWELFTH NIGHT,' DIRECTED BY MARK LAMOS
description: In Mark Lamos's intoxicating production of ''Twelfth Night'' at the Hartford Stage Company, life is a perpetual New Year's Eve party at an exclusive after-hours club. The revels are not ended until the last glass of champagne is consumed and the last prank has been played. Present mirth is matched by present laughter, and romance unites true lovers with tears of happiness, but melancholy also permeates the air. There is payment on demand for duplicity, and even as the fool sings his farewell ''hey, ho,'' we hear an echo of Malvolio's vow of vengeance.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE LITTLE VIRTUES. By Natalia Ginzburg. Translated by Dick Davis. (Carcanet/Harper & Row, $14.95.) ''When I sit down to write I feel extraordinarily at ease, . . . I use tools that are familiar to me and they fit snugly in my hands.''

title: Pamela Congdon Becomes a Bride
description: Pamela Lemle Congdon and Nicholas Anthony Blair were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York in an interfaith ceremony performed by the Rev. Richard Leonard and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel.

title: FIRST IMPRESSIONS CAN HAVE A LASTING EFFECT
description: CLOTHES make the man,'' Mark Twain observed. ''Naked men have had little or no influence in society.''

title:
DANCE;

HARMS PLAZA: FOCUS ON DANCE
description: JOHN HARMS ENGLEWOOD PLAZA, long perceived as one of the state's top presenters of classical music, is focusing the spotlight on dance this season, offering classes, performances and a four-part series, the first in its 10-year history.

title: RENAISSANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: DECADE'S TOP JOBS
description: NEED A JOB? Or a new one that might last a few years? Planning your business and wondering what occupations you can count on hiring in the future? Economists at the Bureau of Labor Statistics in the United States Department of Labor have prepared a list of 20 occupations expected to grow the fastest in the next 10 years. These range from technical positions such as computer analysts and injection-mold-machine operators to legal assistants and mechanical engineers.

title: Buildings Without Souls
description: Since Vincent Scully is one of the gray eminences of architectural criticism, it is surprising that he mistakenly assumes that Rockefeller Center's slabs were made thin and tall as ''pure symbol'' and for ''visual effect.'' In those pre-air-conditioning days, the perimeter walls of the Rockefeller Center towers were set a modest distance from the central service cores of the structures to give all the office space the benefit of fresh air entering through the operable perimeter windows. Mechanical air-conditioning frees the modern developer from this restriction. ANDREW ALPERN New York City

title: INSTITUTE ACTS TO AID LEARNING DISABLED
description: IN A small room at the Institute for Child Development here, four smiling adults maneuvered themselves around 4-month-old Frankie L., who lay on a mat.

title: NEIGHBORS FORM TRUST TO SAVE LAND AROUND NATIONAL PRESERVE
description: THE entrance to Turkey Mountain Park, a 124-acre nature preserve in Yorktown, is marked by an unobtrusive wooden sign.

title: FOR SCIENTISTS, THE IMPASSE ON VITAMINS IS A BITTER PILL
description: When the National Academy of Sciences first issued guidelines for a nutritious diet in 1941, it lamented ''the lack of sufficient experimental evidence.'' Since then, scientists have amassed huge amounts of information about the role of vitamins, minerals and other nutrients in maintaining health.

title: ALCOHOL PROBLEMS GROW FOR ELDERLY
description: PHYSICIANS who advise their elderly patients to have a glass of wine to calm their nerves may not realize how vulnerable those patients are to alcohol abuse. Likewise, family members who offer elderly relatives alcohol - even in moderation -should be mindful that the drug is especially dangerous for this age group.

title: In Richmond, Miss Breslin Is Married to Robert Heine
description: The marriage of Mary Grace Breslin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Breslin of Richmond, to Robert M. Heine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Heine of Spring Lake, N.J., took place yesterday in Richmond. Msgr.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: VIDA. By Delacorta. Translated by Victoria Reiter. (Summit, $12.95.) Delacorta's slight, brightly colored mystery - the fifth in the Swiss novelist Daniel Odier's pseudonymous series featuring the Parisian pair of Gorodish, a fortyish musician, and his 14-year-old companion, the barely virginal Alba - has the manic, surreal feel of a music video (another book in the series, ''Diva,'' was made into a movie with some of that quality).

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SIDEWALK FAIR IN NYACK More than 25,000 people are expected to stroll the streets of Nyack, N.Y., today, the attraction being the merchandise-laden tables set up by 300 crafts and antiques dealers for the town's semi-annual Street Fair. The seven-hour event gets under way, rain or shine, at 10 A.M.

title: FOR MILITARY SUPPLIERS, GROWTH UNCERTAINTIES
description: The sprawling General Dynamics shipyard complex on the Fore River in Quincy, Mass., was humming last winter as its 6,300 employees went about their jobs filling Defense Department contracts. But soon the 101-year-old yard will look like a ghost town. The company announced recently that a lack of Navy orders would force it to lay off all its workers and padlock the yard's 180 acres at year's end.

title: Recent Sales
description: Elmwood Park $137,000 *2* 18 Maplewood Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 45-year-old ranch; 4-zone heat, pool, deck; *2* taxes $1,956. Glen Rock $210,000 *2* 18 Wadsworth Road *2* 4 bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2* 2-car garage, new kitchen, porch; *2* taxes $3,404. New Vernon $475,000 *2* Mary Knoll Road *2* 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 27-year-old colonial; *2* pool, 2-stall barn, 3 acres; *2* taxes $3,196. Short Hills $210,000 *2* 34 Kilmer Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; *2* recessed radiators, den, basement workshop; *2* taxes $3,193. Wayne $239,000 *2* 1 Blackfoot Circle *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new town-house condominium; *2* central air-conditioning, garage; *2* $128 monthly maintenance charges; *2* taxes to be assessed. Warren $208,000 *2* 9 Wilderness Trail *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; *2* bow window, fireplace, hardwood floors; *2* taxes $3,064. OTHER AREAS Hicksville, L.I. $133,000 *2* 8 Frances Lane *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2* eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; *2* taxes $2,200. West Hartford, Conn. $115,000 *2* 34 Pleasant Street *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 71-year-old colonial; *2* veranda in front, 80- by 200-foot lot; *2* taxes $2,135. Goldens Bridge, N.Y. $213,500 *2* Waccabuc Road *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old frame contemporary; *2* 2-story entry, den, 2d-floor loft, 2 acres; *2* taxes $3,794.

title: ARTFUL STONEWORK FOR THE ROCK GARDEN
description: So much has been said about the intricacies of growing finicky, but lovely, alpine plants in rocky screes that many gardeners look upon rock gardening as an art beyond their grasp. This is a false impression easily dispelled.

title: DRAMA IN A QUONSET HUT
description: OFTEN, when you hear that someone from your deep past is dead, the big news is not so much the death but that the person had still been alive. Mary Lou Plugge had lived out not only a full threescore and 10 but missed fourscore by only one year; still, her death was a jolt. ''Seventy-what?'' I said into the phone. ''Seventy-nine,'' June Deakins Moffat said from her home in Roslyn. ''It's in the Adelphi publication they send all of us; didn't you get yours?''

title: THE 'BIG ONE,' A 3-TRAILER RIG, RULES MAINE LOGGING ROADS
description: Motorists cruising along the Golden Road often gape in awe when the logging rig known as the ''Big One'' rolls by.

title: Reagan's High Card At the Summit
description: President Reagan enters the most critical meeting of his Presidential career next month with what poker players would call a very strong though not necessarily unbeatable hand.

title: PURLOINED CLASSICS HAVE FALLEN OUT OF FAVOR
description: Throughout most of the history of what we call classical music - an imprecise term, but you know what I mean - learned composers did not hesitate to borrow melodies and other material from folk or popular music. How could they not? And why would they not? The popular music of any period is an inexhaustible reservoir that any composer would be a fool to ignore. However, at times the current also has run the other way and for a while in our own century the flow from classical to popular became a veritable flood.

title: DAY-CARE OFFICES SHIFT
description: THE State Department of Human Resources is restructuring its administration of day care.

title: THEATERS PLAN A BOUNTIFUL NEW SEASON
description: TO ANYONE who asks, ''What's new?'' this coming theater season, the answer is, ''Plenty.'' New Jersey and adjacent Rockland County will suffer no paucity of premieres. Some plays, although first seen elsewhere, will be new to audiences in both areas.

title: Physician Is Wed To Dr. Guilfoyle
description: Dr. Elizabeth Todd Guilfoyle, a resident in internal medicine at the Georgetown University Hospital, was married at her home in Bethesda, Md., yesterday to Lieut. Stephen Marc Trehu, U.S.N.R., Medical Corps, a resident in surgery at the Naval Hospital in Bethesda.

title: THE TESTING OF PETER WALLENBERG
description: BY the time the legendary Marcus Wallenberg died three years ago, at the age of 82, hailed here as a model capitalist and patriot, he had pieced together an industrial and financial empire of unprecedented scope.

title: NEW ENGLAND
description: FOR a decade the economy of the six-state New England region has been growing faster than the national average, creating strong job opportunities in many fields, and even spot shortages. In the Boston area, for example, opportunities for relatively well-paid, higher level jobs are now so strong that to fill lower-level positions like stock clerks and shipping-room workers, major companies have resorted to radio advertisements that stress health plans, tuition-reimbursement programs and even retirement benefits.

title: NEW CASSETTES: SIMMERING DRAMA TO SOULFUL ROCK
description: A Dog of Flanders Starring David Ladd, Donald Crisp and Theodore Bikel; directed by James B. Clark, 1959 Paramount Home Video 96 minutes. $29.95 ''A Dog of Flanders'' is more than a good boy-and-his-dog yarn.

title: BENGALS' STATISTICS DECEPTIVE
description: In last Sunday night's 30-29 loss to the Dallas Cowboys, Phil Simms of the Giants passed for 432 yards, a career high. This Sunday, against the Bengals in Cincinnati, he will face the National Football League's lowest-rated pass defense, a unit that often has given up big yardage.

title: Dr. M. C. Bennett And Miss Linton Exchange Vows
description: The marriage of Roberta Helen Linton to Dr. Mark Cohen Bennett took place last evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Linton, parents of the bride, in Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the ceremony.

title: BIG 'LITTLE BITES'
description: IF I WERE ENCOURAGED TO name the single category of food that most appeals to my palate, it would almost certainly be appetizers. These are the treats known in Italy as antipasti, in France as hors d'oeuvres, in Russia as zakuska and so on. That is why I consider the Spanish tradition of tapas one of the greatest gastronomic inventions of all time.

title: REAL RUNNERS DON'T LOOK AT QUICHE
description: THEY are out in force now, the whole tiresome troupe.

title: October 13, 1985
NELSON TRIUMPHS ON EARLY KNOCKOUT
description: Azumah Nelson of Ghana unleashed a bonecrushing left uppercut today to knock out Pat Cowdell of Britain at 2 minutes 24 seconds of the first round and retain his World Boxing Council featherweight title.

title: BROADCAST TV
description: Following are excerpts from John Corry's review of ''The Brain'' when it was originally shown last October. The eight-part series will be rebroadcast beginning Tuesday evening at 10 on Channel 13.

title: ARMY AN EASY WINNER, 45-14
description: Tonight was the time for Army to prove that it could do more than demolish Ivy League opponents and that it belonged in the top rank of Eastern football this season.

title: STEPFATHER LOSES ON CHILD SUPPORT
description: A man who accepted an 8-year-old girl as his daughter during his marriage must pay child support although a post-divorce blood test showed he was not the biological father, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today.

title: WELCOME TO PARRIS ISLAND
description: When the first United States marine was recruited at Tun Tavern in 1775, he was told to report to a ship in the Philadelphia Navy Yard where the busy officer of the day pointed to a bulkhead and said, ''You sit there until I have time to deal with you.'' A few minutes later the second marine reported to the O.D., who told him to wait with the other fellow. When the second marine sat down by the first, the first marine growled at him:

title: Barbara Connor Wed To Stephen R. Powell
description: The marriage of Barbara Sugar Connor, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James H. Connor of Columbus, Ohio, to Stephen Robert Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. F. Powell of New Canaan, Conn., and New York, took place yesterday. The Rev. J. Lawrence Reichert performed the ceremony at St. Catharine Roman Catholic Church in Columbus.

title: SOME LEGALLANDMARKS ARE FACING RECONSTRUCTION
description: The Supreme Court began its new term last week facing, among other contentious issues, abortion and religion, affirmative action and the most determined Administration effort in decades to change the course of constitutional law. While calling for an end to ''judicial activism,'' an activist Justice Department and an outspoken Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d are laying the groundwork to undo much of what the Court has done in the last 30 years.

title: FIT TO BE TIED
description: For years, men have been knotting pieces of fabric to fit smartly under a variety of shirt collars.

title: AT MACY'S, A CHIEF AND HIS TROUBLES
description: THREE years ago, Edward S. Finkelstein was riding high. As chairman and chief executive of a resurgent R. H. Macy & Company, he was heralded widely for transforming a drab and sluggish company into the nation's most dramatically successful department store chain.

title: ZONING: THE DELICATE BALANCE
description: IT PROBABLY happens every day all across America: A piece of undeveloped land catches the eye of a real-estate developer, who sees the opportunity to construct an office building and rent the space at some profit.

title: WHAT KIND OF TOURNEY?
description: Ppen tournaments differ less from round-robin competitions than they used to, even though the basic differences remain. At one time, the opens were cheaper to sponsor - sometimes even costless - because they were supported by entry fees, and board, lodging and transportation for the players did not have to be supplied. However, this difference is diminishing now, since some opens have become more glamorous, offering large prize funds or paying expenses and fees to notable players.

title:
GARDENING;

NOW IS THE TIME TO PLANT SPRING BULBS
description: THE mere mention now of spring is enough to conjure up visions of drifts of flowering bulbs spread across the landscape. If those visions are to come true in your garden, this is the time to plant the bulbs, unless they are already in place from previous years' plantings. Even so, no garden is so full of spring bulbs that it does not have room for a few more.

title: U.S. COURT REFECTS BONANNO'S APPEAL
description: Joseph Bonanno, who went to prison last month for refusing to testify about his role as a former Mafia leader, has lost an appeal for his freedom.

title: A 'SPRING' CHORE DONE BETTER IN FALL
description: ALTHOUGH spring would seem to be the most sensible time to give your aluminum outdoor furniture an annual sprucing up, more often than not this really does not happen. When spring arrives after a long, dreary winter, most homeowners get so busy with other chores -gardening, painting, landscaping and so on -that they do not have time to spend on their outdoor furniture. Instead, they pull the furniture out of the garage and simply dust it off or wash it before they start using it.

title: CONFERENCE WILL STUDY ROLE OF YIDDISH WRITERS
description: S TUDIES of American literature often ignore the important role played by immigrant authors who write in a foreign language - a situation that a first-of-a-kind international conference today and tomorrow, featuring such writers as Isaac Bashevis Singer and Irving Howe, hopes to begin to change.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE Alliance for Action, a statewide coalition of business, labor, professional and governmental organizations dedicated to improving New Jersey's economy and creating jobs, presented ''Eagle Awards'' to four people at its annual dinner in New Bruswick last Wednesday.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE FATEFUL ALLIANCE: France, Russia, and the Coming of the First World War, by George F. Kennan. (Pantheon, $8.95.) The author plans three volumes devoted to the birth and development of pre-World War I military blocs; this is the second. (The first was ''The Decline of Bismarck's European Order.'') ''The Fateful Alliance'' examines the years from 1890 to 1894, when France and Russia became allies. Last year Paul Kennedy wrote here that Mr. Kennan's analysis illuminates the forces that led ''ineluctably'' to World War I and could also lead to World War III. He termed the work ''a good read'' and ''a plea for the great powers to conduct their external policies in as wise, cautious and unprejudiced a manner as humanly possible.'' THE ALBANY CYCLE, by William Kennedy. (Penguin, $17.85.) The cycle is three novels presented as a boxed set - ''Legs'' (1975), ''Billy Phelan's Greatest Game'' (1978) and the Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Ironweed'' (1983). The hero of the first book is Legs Diamond, the gangster; the second features a gambler and pool shark and the third the gambler's father.

title: The New Threat to American Civilian Research
description: To the Editor:

title: PANNING FOR COMEDIC GOLD IN TV'S EARLY 'HONEYMOORNERS'
description: Ralph Kramden read, or at least bought, The New York Herald-Tribune. He and his wife, Alice, previously thought to have been childless for their entire 15-year marriage, once adopted a baby girl. Edward L. Norton survived as an ''engineer of subterranean sanitation'' in part because he had no sense of smell, and, though he tried to hide it, his middle name was ''Lillywhite.''

title: AIR FORCE DOWNS NAVY FOR 6 IN A ROW
description: The unbeaten Falcons of the Air Force Academy were unable to blow the Naval Academy off the football field today, but they had enough to beat their service rivals, 24-7.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE APPRENTICESHIP OF BEATRICE WEBB. By Deborah Epstein Nord. (University of Massachusetts, $25.) Beatrice Webb (1858-1943) and her husband, Sidney, dominated the Fabian socialists (a group that included George Bernard Shaw, H. G. Wells and Leonard Woolf), helped establish the London School of Economics and did much to inform their fellow Victorians about the victims of the era's rabid capitalism.

title: A Harvard Bridal For Miss Traynor
description: Elizabeth Ann Traynor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Michael Traynor of Berkeley, Calif., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Nicholas Priest Holder, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richmond Holder of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. John W. Rick 3d performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard University.

title: NOW IS THE SEASON WHEN THE CABBAGE FMAILY IS KING
description: IF you drive into the countryside and go past farms, you may notice that the crops in the fields at this time of year have acquired a steely, gray-green cast. Replacing the lush green of mid-summer's zucchini patches and cornfields are members of the cabbage family with their stiff, rounded leaves framing clusters, bunches and heads of the vegetables.

title: THE MERGER GAME, FOR SMALLER PLAYERS
description: More consolidations swept the corporate world. But unlike the multibillion-dollar mergers that were all the rage earlier in the year, the latest wave involves few mega-deals. But analysts say the new combinations, albeit smaller, could have big impacts on their various industries.

title: LAWYER IN QUEENS SUIT SAYS CITY DID NOT FOLLOW U.S. AIDS POLICY
description: The lawyer for two Queens community school boards sought to show in court Friday that New York City officials were failing to follow Federal guidelines for dealing with school-children with AIDS.

title: THE U.S. SIMPLY NEEDS FEWER FARMS
description: BUYING votes is the only farm policy most Congressmen understand. With existing farm programs, costs to taxpayers have soared, food prices have in some cases doubled or tripled, crop exports have nosedived and farm income has fallen. Yet, as the debate in Washington this last month has made painfully clear, most Congressmen favor perpetuating the tangle of failed and contradictory programs or making them even worse, by imposing manadatory production controls over millions of farmers.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE ROMANESQUE SCULPTURE OF MOISSAC. By Meyer Schapiro. (Braziller, $35.) On the face of it, ''The Romanesque Sculpture of Moissac,'' originally pre-sented as Meyer Schapiro's Columbia University doctoral dissertation in 1929, is a dry scholarly exercise.

title: RENTERS IN A NONEVICT CO-OP UPHELD
description: TWO West Virginia investors who bought a block of occupied apartments in a cooperative building in Elmhurst, Queens, last year have been barred by the New York State Attorney General's Office from selling any of the apartments until maintenance and services in the building are improved.

title:
NEW JERSEYANS;

INNER-CITY SUCCESS STORY
description: A DOZEN years ago, Ralph Gomez put his theater education to work for troubled youngsters at a youth center operated by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson.

title: DODGER LEAD DOWN TO 2-1
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 - Back home on their slick green carpet after two straight losses, back home in the fast lane, the St. Louis Cardinals finally flashed their speed today and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-2, for their first victory in the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Royals vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Kansas City, Game 5 of the American League Championship Series. (Television - Channel 4, 4:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 4:20 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at St. Louis, Game 4 of the National League Championship Series. (Television - Channel 4, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 8 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Spurs, at San Antonio, 8:30 P.M. Nets vs. Boston Celtics, at Portland, Me., 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WNBC 660, approximately 10:30 P.M., tape after the Ranger-Devil game.) Cross Country New York Masters 10K Championships, 30 and over men and women, at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, 11 A.M. Hunter College Invitational, at Van Cortlandt Park, women's five-kilometer (3.1 miles) at 11:30 A.M. and men's five-mile at noon. Hunter is the defending champion in both the men's and women's races. Football Giants vs. Bengals, at Cincinnati. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 1 P.M.) #49ers vs. Chicago Bears, at San Francisco. The Bears, one of two unbeaten teams, are still smarting from the shutout they suffered at the hands of the 49ers in the National Conference championship last season while San Francisco was marching to the Super Bowl. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) Dallas Cowboys vs. Pittsburgh Steelers, at Irving Tex. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Devils, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Devils managed only two victories in seven meetings with the Rangers last season but both came at Madison Square Garden.

title: A SLIDING DOLLAR
description: FOR most of this year, professional expectations for the American economy had a certain serene look: it would be slower this year and next, as it settled down from the boom of the last two years. Prospects weren't rosy, but they weren't the grim sort that spell recessions and rising unemployment either.

title: JUSTICE ARGUES FOR TEACHER TEST
description: The Justice Department entered its first case on the legality of teacher competency tests last week, but it was on familiar philosophical ground.

title: FOR POTATO FARMERS, HARD TIMES
description: IT is harvest time on Long Island, and for potato farmers, it looks like a dismal year. Potato yields are up, and prices paid to farmers are way down, $1.75 to $2 for 100 pounds. Moreover, prices usually decrease as the harvest progresses.

title: MOSCOW: A RARE DISPLAY OF SOLIDARITY
description: THE Soviet Union, which differs with the United States on the Middle East situation as on most others, gave Washington startling support for its handling of the latest hijacking. Tass, the official press agency, said: ''The Americans' anger at the hijackers' crime aboard a cruise liner is understandable and just.

title: Assignment: Disasters
description: The next director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency is to be a retired Army general, Julius W. Becton Jr., replacing Louis O. Giuffrida, who quit last month to return to private business.

title: ROYALS NEAR ELIMINATION
description: George Brett, who single-handedly destroyed the Toronto Blue Jays with his bat 24 hours earlier, nearly beat them by merely standing in the batter's box tonight. However, the Blue Jays overcame a losing gamble by their manager, Bobby Cox, and moved one victory away from bringing Canada its first major league pennant.

title: On Language;   Prexy Isn't Sexy Anymore
description: I READ IN THE HOLLYWOOD Reporter that a ''restructuring'' - we used to call it a shake-up - of a division of Paramount Pictures has taken place, ''with Barry London and Buffy Shutt being promoted to president of distribution and marketing and president of marketing respectively.''

title: WHY HENRY SWITCHED HIS SEX
description: THE BRANDON PAPERS By Quentin Bell. 214 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: CABLE TV
description: There's a cluster of interesting offbeat film fare this cable week, starting with - of all things - ''The Jerk'' (1979), a broad but original comedy with a sweet, quirky philosophy and a kind of mysterious charm. It's Steve Martin's first feature, with much help from a kewpie-doll Bernadette Peters, now enthroned on Broadway and it's easy to see why. The picture's showing Sunday at 8 P.M. and Thursday at 12:35 A.M. on Showtime and Friday at 8 P.M. on Cinemax.

title: STATE OPENS PARKS TO GAME HUNTERS
description: THE small-game hunting season opens Saturday, and two state parks will be open for the first time to hunters with guns.

title: MIDDLE WEST
description: DESPITE its Rust Bowl image, the Middle West still has a wealth of career opportunities, job experts say. Even if there are fewer blue-collar jobs in the region's once-robust manufacturing plants, there are opportunities to work with robotics and computers in those same factories. In Chicago, the region's financial center, there are jobs in banking, insurance and accounting. And there are opportunities in much of the region for math, science and computer teachers, sales trainees and geriatric nurses.

title: Dr. Siderides Wed To a Pediatrician
description: The Greek Orthodox Church of Archangels in Stamford, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Dr. Elizabeth Siderides, a daughter of Drs. Lambros and Cleo Siderides of Stamford, to Dr. Stelios Theophanides, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Theophanides of Nicosia, Cyprus.

title: MUSIC: RAFAEL PUYANA
description: R AFAEL PUYANA, the Colombian harpsichordist who gave the first of three recitals devoted to Bach and Domenico Scarlatti Thursday night at the Metropolitan Museum, has long bucked the prevailing tides. But the trouble with his Thursday recital, his first in New York since 1971, was not that the playing was different but that it was problematic on strictly musical and technical grounds.

title: Pamela Land Lynch, Fashion Model, Marries Mark B. Silverman, an Editor
description: At St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Stamford, Conn., yesterday Pamela Land Lynch, a daughter of Mrs. Melvus George Furney of Rowayton, Conn., and Robert Franklin Lynch of Paget, Bermuda, was married to Mark Bartholomew Silverman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Syd Silverman of White Plains. The Rev. Mark Anthony DeWolf of St. Andrew's performed the ceremony.

title: AFTER STORM, BLUEFISH TEEM
description: FOR a while it seemed as if Hurricane Gloria had spoiled the October fishing trip my grandson Morgan and I had planned for this year, but its ultimate effect was to give us a shot at larger quarry than the snapper blues we had originally planned to catch.

title: RAILIROAD BUFF FINDS NEW ROLE FOR AN OLD CABOOSE
description: JIM CLARKE'S little gray caboose is on the track, but it's going nowhere. Well, not exactly nowhere, according to his neighbors. And it is really not that little.

title: NEW CASSETTES: SIMMERING DRAMA TO SOULFUL ROCK
description: Verdi's 'Trovatore' An Australian Opera production, featuring Joan Sutherland, Kenneth Collins, Lauris Elms and Jonathan Summers; Richard Bonynge conducts the Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra, 1985 Sony Video 138 minutes. $79.95 In ''Il Trovatore,'' improbable people doing improbable things surge along on the wave of Verdi's powerful music.

title: HISTORIC FLATBUSH: A NEW FRONTIER FOR HOUSE-HUNTING
description: IN their widening search for value and space, many New York City house-hunters are turning to the middle of Brooklyn, to an oasis of large one-family houses, wide oak- and maple-lined streets, a small-town sense of community and reasonable prices.

title: JERSEY ENDS A SURCHARGE ON BUSINESS
description: New Jersey has improved its business climate by paying off a 10-year-old Federal loan that cost employers about $100 million a year, Governor Kean has announced.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: TWO bills that are said to be among the most important and controversial pieces of environmental legislation to come before the Legislature in recent years have prompted much debate in Trenton. However, there probably will be no definitive action on them until after next month's elections.

title: Shakespeare on Faust
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW DO YOU PITCH TO BRETT?
description: TO appreciate George Brett's artistry with his 34 1/2-inch, 32-ounce wooden wand, consider that when the Toronto Blue Jays were assessing the batting skills of the Kansas City Royals' third baseman prior to the American League championship series, their five scouts disagreed on how to pitch to him.

title: BRITAIN WORRIES ABOUT AN ARMS RACE BETWEEN POLICE AND CRIMINALS
description: A basic precept of the British police is that they are safer without guns. If they were to carry firearms, the thinking goes, so would criminals. Last weekend, however, that theory was put to a severe test when rioters in North London opened fire on police officers armed only with nightsticks and shields. The rioters were later able to overwhelm an officer and hack him to death with knives.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

MEDICINE IN THE 30's
description: From 1935 to 1942, Farm Security Administration photographers - including such then unknowns as Walker Evans, Dorothea Lange and Arthur Rothstein - crossed America and produced a chronicle of life during the Depression. Some 2,000 of the agency's more than 250,000 photographs recorded encounters between doctors and patients, and PLAIN PICTURES OF PLAIN DOCTORING: Vernacular Expression in New Deal Medicine and Photography (MIT Press, $19.95) - by John D. Stoeckle, a doctor who teaches at the Harvard Medical School, and George Abbott White, a clinical psychologist in Boston - contains 80 of the best of the pictures with an explanatory narrative.

title: MOVING IN ON MONEY MANAGEMENT
description: AS one of this country's largest pension fund managers, the Jennison Associates Capital Corporation has a reputation for what Wall Street professionals call ''bagging'' the brokers - that is, unloading their clients' stocks shortly before bad news drives down the price.

title: CALIFORNIA BUSES
description: Jim Lehrer's article, ''To Buses, With Love'' (Travel, Aug. 4) pays due respect to the vaished glamour of old-time bus lines and to their present-day successors. The images and feelings he describes, however, are not entirely lost to the past or tucked away in the Midwest.

title:
DINING OUT;

FLAVOR OF CHINATOWN IN YONKERS
description: ALTHOUGH quite a few Chinese restaurants fancier than The Golden Wok have opened in the county since the Shue family set up its modest operation seven years ago, for quality and value it can't be beat. It brings to the county not only the bustle found in Manhattan's Chinatown restaurants but the prices as well. Since our first visit in 1979, prices at The Golden Wok have increased, on average, a mere 50 cents an item. The $2.95 special lunch that the restaurant opens with has gone up only recently to $3.70 and includes soup, a choice of 38 entrees, rice and tea.

title: A Father's Anger
description: Frederick Kaufman writes in a nostalgic fashion about the legacy of his father's righteous anger (''A Father's Anger,'' About Men, Sept. 15).

title: Losing a Victory
description: A FTER a magazine circulated by the Flynt Distributing Company had published a nude photo and had incorrectly identified the nude as the author Jackie Collins, she sued Flynt for invasion of privacy. Her lawyer said the photo had been republished twice despite a court order against this.

title: THE STAGE: 'SEEHEAR' A SOUND/IMAGE STUDY
description: How strange it is that pictures and music share a common descriptive vocabulary but occupy such separate worlds. Words like symmetry, resonance, color and rhythm fly back and forth between the two, but how many of us hear blue and how many see counterpoint?

title: Derailments En Route to the Supreme Court
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PUMPKINS NEAR BUFFALO After trimming vines, fertilizing and otherwise coaxing their pumpkins to impressive girths, contestants in the third annual World Pumpkin Weigh-off will pick the best at the last moment to minimize weight loss, then haul them in trucks and trailers tomorrow to the parking lot of Waterman's Restaurant in Collins, N.Y., south of Buffalo. Last year the winning entry was a 612-pounder. The event will be held simultaneously at six other sites, from California to Nova Scotia. New Zealand will be represented, too, although its contest was held six months ago, when fall came to the Southern Hemisphere. All the sites announce their top weights in a joint telephone call. If the ''world'' winner breaks the 700-pound barrier, the prize will be $5,000. WITCHES IN CONNECTICUT While pumpkins ride wheelbarrows to the scales in a different event - a weigh-off at the Inn on Lake Waramaug in New Preston, Conn., on Oct. 27 - two other competitions will be held. Children dressed as witches will each ''cast a spell'' - spelling Halloween-related words drawn from a jack-o'-lantern. Youngsters will carve jack-o'-lanterns, scary or otherwise (pumpkins provided, but not tools). The events are free. Winners get meals at the inn. Information: (203) 868-0563. OLD HOUSES IN HOPE, N.J. A 1778 farmhouse, a grist mill and a distillery are among a dozen old homes and buildings to be seen on foot and by bus Saturday in the Moravian Village of Hope, N.J. Costumed guides will lead tours of a Moravian place of worship, lunches will be available and a bake sale will be held in the original kitchen of an 1830 stone home. The event, ''A Day in the Country,'' is a fund-raiser for preservation efforts and costs $10. Reservations: (201) 459-5381. APPLES IN BALTIMORE The Baltimore Farmers Market will concentrate on apples next Sunday. Homemade pies, cakes and other apple concoctions will be judged, cider will be pressed and offered free, apple cooking will be demonsrated and apple butter and pastries will be sold. The occasion is the fifth annual Fall Apple Festival, 8 A.M. to 3 P.M. at Holliday and Saratoga Streets. There will also be scarecrow-making, bluegrass music and such crafts as handwoven baskets and stoneware oil lamps. Information: (301) 837-4636. DUTCH IN WESTCHESTER What was real and what was fantasy in Washington Irving's tales of old Dutch life will be the topic Oct. 27 of a bus tour along the Hudson River from Prospect Park, Brooklyn, to southern Westchester. On the program are Philipsburg Manor (a Dutch homestead), Irving's Sunnyside villa and the graveyard where his horseman hurled his head at poor Ichabod Crane. The trip is sponsored by the Prospect Park Environmental Center. The fee: $30. Reservations: (718) 788-8500. GARDENS IN NEW YORK City dwellers with green thumbs or with goals of improving their neighborhoods will gather at the Vanderbilt Y.M.C.A. at 224 East 47th Street Tuesday through Friday for the sixth annual conference of the American Community Gardening Association. Workshops will deal with such subjects as horticulural therapy, community organizing, urban forestry, ecological planning and gardening with children. Wednesday's fare will be bus and walking tours of gardens in New York. Each day's session costs $15. Information: 755-2410.

title:
ART;

THE BIG AND LITTLE OF SCULPTURE
