description: IF the art world has a pendulum, there are more than a few signs that attention is shifting away from painting and toward sculpture. A smart exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich elucidates a specific sculptural issue, scale.

title: A BELATED APPLE OR TWO FOR THE TEACHER
description: I RETIRED from teaching this past summer, and not because I'm 65 or 62. I'm not even close to retirement age.

title: BERTOLUCCI'S UNCUT '1900' GETS A SECOND CHANCE
description: ''I now take the whole affair with some philosophy,'' Bernardo Bertolucci, the Italian film director, said last week. ''At the time, I thought I was going mad.''

title: CHARACTERSTUDY
description: When Murray Burnett sold his first play to Warner Brothers 43 years ago, he received $20,000, the most a movie studio had ever paid for the rights to a script. His play, ''Everybody Comes to Rick's,'' was made into the movie ''Casablanca.''

title: THIS TIME, REAGAN LET ACTIONS DO HIS THINKIN
description: ''IT'S morning again in America,'' President Reagan told the nation and the world a year ago, but the terrorists in the Middle East paid no attention.

title: IN BIG TEN, THE WHOLE CAST GOES AFTER TOP BILLING
description: IT would be fitting if remembrances of Bo Schembechler's coaching career were eventually put on display at the Kelsey Museum of Archaeology on the University of Michigan campus in Ann Arbor, instead of in the athletic complex trophy case. Perhaps a discarded game plan - circa 1971 - would be among the museum's artifacts, evidence of what will be remembered as the Stone Age in Big Ten football, beginning in the late 1960's and lasting 13 years.

title: Lincoln Jackson Wed To Catherine C. Nolen
description: Catherine Chapin Nolen, a daughter of Chapin Nolen of Bedford, N.Y., and Barbara Nolen of Tamworth, N.H., was married yesterday to Lincoln Cable Jackson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William C. Jackson of Denver. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: SAFETY IN THE WORKPLACE MEANS MORE SPECIALISTS
description: IN the slums of Bhopal, India, a leak of toxic methyl isocyanate kills 2,000 and injures hundreds more. A gas leak from a pesticide plant in Institute, W. Va., sends 135 people to the hospital. And in a Mexico City shantytown, an explosion in a liquefied-gas storage tank leaves nearly 400 dead.

title: SEPIA PHOTOGRAPHS AND JAZZ SOLOS
description: LOVING A WOMAN IN TWO WORLDS By Robert Bly. 78 pp. New York: The Dial Press/ Doubleday & Company. $12.95. HEALING SONG FOR THE INNER EAR By Michael S. Harper. 97 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $6.95. A POET who fashions an extreme individual style, as Robert Bly surely has done, may find he has forged his own manacles to a limited means of expression. Whatever his subject or emotions, his poems may melt together in a monochrome haze. The ostensible subject of ''Loving a Woman in Two Worlds'' is romantic love, but many of the poems - even those containing the phrase ''man and woman'' - are hard to distinguish from Mr. Bly's other poems of landscape and mystic reverie. The verses become creatures of a habit not necessarily their own. The problem is aggravated by the kind of idiom Mr. Bly has fabricated. So many lines weighted with reverent pauses, stolid with monosyllables, muffled by end stops, can make poems not suggestive but stonily incommunicative. There is too much easy Orientalism, as in ''The Turtle'': Rain lifts the lake level, washing the reeds. Slowly the milkweed pods open, the yellow lily pads. Through the mist man and woman see the far shore. The turtle's head rises out over the water. In ''The Roots'' and ''The Hawk,'' he is still playing Tarzan; and he still takes flying leaps - ''I float in the current, calm and mad as a sleepy cork.''

title: Susan Garwood Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Susan Clayton Garwood to Christopher Lykes Knapp, an investment associate with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company in New York, took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Houston. The Rev. Everett Cain performed the ceremony.

title: ALBANY G.O.P. ACTS TO AID LOCALITIES
description: Republicans in the State Assembly have recommended that the Legislature approve in November a plan to aid school districts and local governments hit by skyrocketing insurance rates.

title: STUDIO THEATER POISED FOR NEW ERA
description: THE silver anniversary season of the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst may mark a new era of recognition for a resourceful company - and the resurgence of a playwright's reputation.

title: A NEW LITTLE CARNEGIE
description: Much to the disappointment of those who had been patrons throughout the 50-year history of the Little Carnegie Theater, its operators abruptly closed it down after the last screening on April 4, 1982. The building at 144 West 57th Street that housed it was among a cluster of four- and five-story midblock structures that were demolished to make way for Metropolitan Tower, the 78-story mixed-use development project now rising near Seventh Avenue.

title:
ART;

DEITIES EVOKED IN MEXICAN MASKS
description: TODAY'S interest in magical objects and forceful artistic expression has helped to develop a keener appreciation for the art forms of tribal cultures. Such art has emotional qualities inspired by religious, social and supernatural beliefs, and its meaning is inseparable from the actual lives of its audience. This kind of powerful spiritual content has no parallel in modern Western art.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTIONS SPREAD THROUGH THE CITY
description: The voices that have been answering the morning roll call at police stations, fire houses and other outposts of New York City's uniformed services have been almost entirely male for generations. But over the last decade, an increasing number of women have donned city uniforms, at times facing harassment, isolation or merely grudging acceptance.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: ''I T brings tears to your eyes,'' the cemetery owner said, referring to a memorial plaque inscribed ''Someone Remembers, Someone Cares.''

title: The Betrayal Of Dodger Fans
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: USING PHOTOS TO LEARN PHOTOGRAPHY
description: W HEN the photographer Michael O'Brien was a student at college he would spend a good deal of time studying past issues of Life magazine. He would ask questions about the pictures, such as what problems they posed for the photographer and how they were solved. Today, Mr. O'Brien is shooting great pictures for Life.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE CULTURAL SEASON
description: Following is a report on highlights of the European cultural season and activities of special interest - from London's Lord Mayor's procession (a tradition since 1192) to a wine-tasting at the 14th-century Palais des Papes in Avignon. It was compiled by Carol Plum based on reports from New York Times bureaus in London, Paris, Rome and Bonn. ENGLAND All theaters and a number of ticket agencies take direct credit card bookings. Two of the agencies, both in London, are Ticket Master (telephone 011-44-1-379-6212 when dialing from the United States) and First Call (011-44-1-240-7200). It is advisable, when booking through an agency, to check how much service charge is being added. There is no law limiting it. Two principal British ticket agencies that have offices in New York will book tickets in advance. They are Keith Prowse (212-398-1430) and Edwards & Edwards (212-944-0290). In addition, there is the Group Sales Box Office for buying 20 or more tickets. It has numbers in New York (212-398-8383) and London (011-44-1-930-6123). It is frequently possible to get tickets to shows that seem to be sold out. In this, as in other ways, hotel concierges have been known to work magic. A booth in Leicester Square sells half-price tickets on the day of performance (open matinee days from noon to 6:30 P.M. and Monday to Saturday from 2:30 to 6:30). Otherwise, for performances at the National Theater, the Royal Opera House and the Coliseum, you can get in line before 10 A.M. and try to get one - they sell only one to a customer - of the small number of tickets held back each day.

title: MUSIC: COMPOSERS IN RED SNEAKERS
description: B OSTON'S Composers in Red Sneakers padded their way down the eastern corridor to New York on Thursday night, offering new music and comedy routines to a good-sized audience at Symphony Space. Composers in Red Sneakers is a communal group - in which performers write and writers perform. It is also trying to show that confrontations with the avant-garde need not be the grim affair they often are.

title: MIDDLE ATLANTIC
description: WHEN Pennsylvania's Secretary of Commerce, James O. Pickard, fantasizes about reliving his life, he imagines starting his own business while in his 20's. ''If I were young, I would get technical training and start my own company,'' said the 52-year-old Mr. Packard, who started York Saw Company when he was 35. ''The opportunities for entrepreneurship are much greater than when I was young.''

title: Nancy Porwick Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morton Porwick of Mamaroneck, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Nancy Kay Porwick to Edward S. Weiser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth D. Weiser of Scarsdale, N.Y. Miss Porwick and her fiance both graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. She is a department manager with Macy's in New York and he a student at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: ATLANTIC CITY LOOKS TO A 'RENAISSANCE'
description: RENAISSANCE II, the code name for plans to restore this resort as a convention city, appears to be assured of success, its principals say.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: STILL FAIR WEATHER While the venerable Long Island Fair continues to hold sway at the Old Bethpage Village Restoration (it runs through tomorrow), farther east on the Island, devotees of fall fairs can have their fun, too. Today, the 10th Riverhead Country Fair will run from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. along the Peconic River. The emphasis is on all things agricultural - with produce and food competitions and a pumpkin- and vegetable-carving contest. There will also be crafts exhibitions and entertainment.

title: PRODDING FOR AN EPIPHANY
description: INTERVIEWS By Djuna Barnes. Edited by Alyce Barry. Foreword and commentary by Douglas Messerli. Illustrated. 396 pp. Washington, D.C.: Sun & Moon Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: LESSON IN HUMANITY FROM THE HURRICANE
description: AS I make my way down the winding thoroughfares and back roads of Dix Hills and Melville on my daily round of errands and car pooling, I see that most of the visible signs of Hurricane Gloria's aftermath are gone. The tree limbs and debris that lined every street have been carted away or ground up into bark mulch. Fallen telephone poles have been hoisted back up.

title: KEAN OPENS A 2D FRONT IN HIS RACE
description: WHILE his Democratic challenger, Peter Shapiro, the Essex County Executive, continued to criticize his toxic-waste cleanup program last week, Governor Kean opened a second front in his re-election campaign. He began attacking an older foe, Alan J. Karcher, the Assembly Speaker, Mr. Kean did not mention Mr. Shapiro by name or refer to ''my opponent'' as he campaigned, but he did talk of Mr. Karcher and blamed him, - and, by inference, the Democratic majority in the Assembly - for blocking a number of the Governor's programs, including changes in the state's automobile-insurance laws and the Civil Service system.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Fine Arts and Antiques At Free Synagogue The Gala Art Showcase of the Free Synagogue of Westchester today from 1 to 5 P.M. and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. includes fine arts, antiques, Oriental art objects and antique Judaica. The admission is $5, deductible from any purchase.

title: BID FOR A ''CULTURAL LANDSCAPE''
description: GUILFORD, a town that is proud of its history and scenic areas, is developing a plan to insure that its special, visual image will be preserved.

title: 88 CONDOS FOR SUFFOLK
description: The commercial expansion in western Suffkolk County in the late 1970's and early 1980's not only added about 12 million square feet of high-technology research and development space but also created a demand for housing in that part of Long Island.

title: Buildings Without Souls
description: In his article ''Buildings Without Souls'' (Sept. 8), Vincent Scully points to the responsibility shared by architects and monied interests for the deplorable forms scattered about our cities.

title: Choice Words
description: AT AGE 12 OR SO I first heard the lyrics to what then seemed to me a dirty song about Columbus. Nowadays I would call it a bawdy song, but, bawdy or dirty, the lyrics will not be set forth here. In these matters I follow the principles suggested by the notorious beer baron and arbiter of taste, Dutch Schultz.

title: TWO PIANISTS AND A FLUTIST IN RECITALS
description: Jeffrey Marcus T WO pianists and one flutist made debuts in New York last week. Jeffrey Marcus, who played piano music by Mozart, Schubert, Liszt and Rachmaninoff at Merkin Concert Hall last Saturday, seemed the most complete musician among them.

title: BRIDGEPORT
description: FOR years, the image of Bridgeport has been that of a grimy blue-collar city riddled with crime and corruption, and until recently, it had been bypassed by the economic boom enjoyed by its more affluent Fairfield County neighbors. Now, however, it is in the midst of an upsurge in new construction and trying to shuck its old image.

title: 'ORDERLY DIVESTITURE'
description: The Government of South Africa seems to have succeeded where protesting Columbia students failed, persuading the university to join the growing list of institutions ''divesting'' themselves of stock in companies doing business in the white-ruled nation. After a private meeting last week, Columbia's trustees said that over the next two years the university would sell ''in an orderly way'' nearly $40 million worth of stock in its $900 million portfolio.

title: On the Carpet
description: Pulling the rug out from under someone is an acceptable practice almost anywhere in Washington, but not at the Textile Museum and especially not at the museum's next event, which it calls ''the first major exhibition of Armenian carpets in North America.'' The exhibition, which opens Friday, will run until Jan. 5, overlapping the museum's 11th annual rug convention, Oct. 25-27.

title: Reagan Picks Nominee For Judgeship in Jersey
description: Robert E. Cowen, a Princeton resident and United States magistrate here since 1978, has been proposed by President Reagan for elevation to a Federal judgeship, the White House said this week.

title: Breaking Ground
description: The ground-breaking for the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum is going to be somewhat different from conventional building starts.

title: THE TRUTH BEHIND THOSE HOUSING ADS
description: PREJUDICE in housing used to be aimed primarily at people with children or 18 cats. In the suburban share-a-house, rent-a-room set, the self-employed older woman now seems targeted for that dubious distinction.

title: Fran Warner Is Wed
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York last night Fran Joy Warner, a broadcast standards and practices editor for the American Broadcasting Companies, was married to Jonathan Michael Cohen, vice president of the U.S. Mattress Corporation in Irvington, N.J., and of International Furniture Rentals in Pine Brook, N.J. Rabbi Judah Nadich officiated. The bride, a daughter of Mrs. Marvin S. Mord of New York, and the bridegroom, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Cohen of South Orange, N.J., both graduated from Syracuse University.

title: NEW YORK AREA HUNTERS ASSAIL NEW DUCK RULES
description: Duck hunters are taking to the woods and waterways this month under new restrictions imposed by the Federal Government that are under attack by sportsmen's groups and state game management experts in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut.

title: AUBURN INTERCEPTS FLORIDA STATE, 59-27
description: Bo Jackson had touchdown runs of 53 and 35 yards, and Auburn turned two interceptions into fourth-quarter scores to rout Florida State, 59-27, today.

title: PORTUGAL TRIES ANOTHER CABINET AFTER ELECTION
description: The Government about to take office in Portugal may be no more stable than its 15 predecessors since democracy was restored in 1974. Hurt by a 10 percent unemployment rate and 17 percent inflation, voters turned away from Prime Minister Mario Soares and his Socialists in droves last Sunday, but the group they favored the most, the Social Democrats, won considerably less than a majority in Parliament and will need to strike deals.

title: RANGERS AR UNRAVELED BY WHALERS, 8-2
description: A credo of hockey defense is that when a puck is stopped, it should stay stopped. No one should have two chances to slam it home, or three chances. No goaltender should have to deal with that.

title: DISORDER IN THE WORLD COURT
description: The hijacking of the Achille Lauro was not the only dispute involving international law last week. The other involved the forum that administers it. In theory at least, the World Court is the ultimate international legal authority, and its 15 judges sit in suitably impressive chambers in The Hague. But in practice, it lacks the clout to make many of its rulings stick. Some countries - France, Italy, China and the Soviet Union among them - refuse to accept the Court's jurisdiction. Now the United States has decided that it, too, will no longer do so automatically.

title: HUNGARY'S VERSAILLES
description: Few visitors to Budapest these days realize that just two hours' drive away by car lies ''Hungary's Versailles,'' a Baroque palace once famous throughout Europe, that has just been splendidly restored.

title: Miss Savage Wed To Kevin Lichten
description: Sarah Jane Savage, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Savage of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday to Kevin Philip Lichten, a son of Mrs. Alfred Lichten of Centerville, Mass., and the late Mr. Lichten. The Rev. Beatrice Blair performed the ceremony in the Chapel of the Beloved Disciple at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: WEST SIDE MART
description: The city's Oriental rug dealers, who for decades were congregated in the Midtown area between 28th and 34th Streets from Lexington to Fifth Avenues, are among the most recent Manhattan-based merchants to be driven from their traditional neighborhoods by rising rents and the demand for office and residential space.

title: COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY REPLACES THE BRUSH OF THE ARTIST
description: MARK WILSON is an artist. But there are no easels or sketch pads, brushes or tubes of paint in the West Cornwall barn that serves as his studio.

title: BOXER HAS COLLEGE CHEERING HIM ON
description: WHEN the University of Hartford pep band strikes up the school's fight song, ''Hartford On to Victory,'' Friday night at the Hartford Civic Center, it will be more appropriate than ever, since it will be played at an actual fight.

title: JETS' GUILBEAU A ZEALOUS HITTER
description: A few minutes before Friday's practice, a group of Jet linebackers stood near their lockers attempting to get a consensus: Were they supposed to go out in full gear, in preparation for a stiff workout, or would partial pads do?

title: OLD SUNKEN FRIGATE STIRS BERGEN OFFICER
description: WHEN salvage experts announced last month that they had discovered the wreckage of the H.M.S Hussar in New York's East River, little was known about the three-masted, 26-gun frigate other than that she carried a British payroll in gold.

title: NEW ARTS CENTER FOR MASSACHUSETTS
description: The Pittsburgh Symphony has found a summer home amid the red cedar, white pine and maples of southeastern Massachusetts. It will be the resident orchestra and heart of a summer music festival at the Great Woods Performing Arts Center, a privately financed $12 million entertainment complex going up in the town of Mansfield, the symphony's manager, Marshall Turkin, announced this week.

title: 3D GENERATION RUNS STORE
description: WHEN Abe Horwitz was 13 years old, he and his parents left Poland and sailed to the United States. Settling in Connecticut, he used a horse-drawn wagon to earn his living by selling anything he could get his hands on. Several years later, in 1920, he opened a small dry-goods store in West Haven.

title: MORE CANCER ON REAGAN'S NOSE
description: The unexpected disclosure that President Reagan last week underwent his third surgical procedure for cancer in three months was deemed by experts to be of little significance to his health. There is almost certainly no connection between Mr. Reagan's colon cancer, a life-threatening growth that was removed July 13, and the relatively benign basal cell cancer of the skin removed from President Reagan's nose on July 30 and apparently again on Thursday.

title: Topics;   Long Runs The King
description: Yul Brynner created a character that will long live in memory because it embodied an enduring puzzle of the modern world. How can the real differences between peoples based on race, culture and gender be bridged without losing the human values those differences embody?

title: JOB POSSIBILITIES SOARING IN THE AVIATION INDUSTRY
description: YOU COULD be in your 40's or 50's and a college dropout, wear eyeglasses and carry a paunch; but if you are a licensed pilot or yearn to fly, the airlines may be looking for you. Threatened by a shortage of qualified pilots, airline companies have been easing some of their criteria - though not safety qualifications - to open opportunities for once-excluded candidates at salaries that can reach $174,000 a year for a senior captain. This year, in fact, will mark a record in the number of new airline pilots hired: about 8,000, nearly double the previous high of 4,600 set 20 years ago.

title: SOFTWARE SHIFTS
description: LOOKING ACROSS the Charles River from downtown Boston into Cambridge, it seems at first as if the software revolution has finally arrived.

title: THAT'S USING YOUR HEAD
description: THE MIND'S NEW SCIENCE A History of the Cognitive Revolution. By Howard Gardner. 423 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.50.

title: THE STATES LEARN TO RELY ON THEIR OWN DEVICES
description: A few years ago, Illinois, like most other states, was a passive actor in the post-New Deal Federal system. But last week, Illinois provided a measure of the intensity of a major shift in which the states have become significant innovators of social and economic change.

title: CITY OPERA: 'CARMEN'
description: T HE most successful member of the City Opera's new ''Carmen'' cast (not exactly new, since its members have gone into their roles at various times over the season, but all together for the first time Friday night) is the dramatic tenor John Absalom, who made his debut with the company earlier this season and is one of its more valuable recent acquisitions.

title: NEW INSTITUTE TO ASSIST FAMILY BUSINESS
description: FAMILY conflicts have existed ''since Cain slew Abel,'' said Neal Wehr, chairman and president of the New Haven-based Family Business Institute. The problems may be old, he said, but focusing on their effects on business is new.

title: KIDNEY STONES: MACHNE OBVIATES SURGERY
description: A SOPHISTICATED new device that uses pressure waves to pulverize kidney stones is being operated in southern New Jersey, offering a less costly, nearly painless alternative to patients who otherwise would need extensive surgery.

title: CONCEPTUAL ART, ITALIAN STYLE, MAKES A STATEMENT AT P.S. 1
description: Germano Celant has a phrase for the current neo-Expressionist trend.

title: BALLET: NEW 'SWAN' CAST
description: S INCE practice can help make perfect in the performing arts, it was pleasant to see the members of the Houston Ballet dance lucidly in Ben Stevenson's production of ''Swan Lake'' on Thursday night at the City Center, when a new cast appeared in some of the leading roles.

title: COLEMAN CREATES TURMOIL
description: Uneasy rest the heads of the opposition when Vince Coleman is lurking on base.

title: Quoting Orson Welles
description: To the Editor:

title: FORD PRIZES WILL HONOR GOVERNMENT PROGRAMS
description: T HE Ford Foundation plans to give $2.25 million in prize money to 30 state or city government agencies that have devised innovative programs to improve job training, curb health-care costs, attract new businesses to declining neighborhoods or meet other pressing social needs.

title: Leslie Shaw Minton Becomes Bride Of Salvatore Toscano in Greenwich
description: The Dingletown Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Leslie Shaw Minton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Minton 3d of Cos Cob, Conn., and Salvatore Toscano, a son of Air Marshal and Mrs. Gennaro Toscano of Rome. The Rev. Harry B. Adams performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

KEEPING THE FAITH
description: ARTICULATE, attractive, many of them involved in rewarding careers, the parishioners in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church one recent Saturday did not appear to be missing much from their lives. On the surface, they might not appear to be the sort to engage in spiritual searching.

title: PAVILIONS OF HARMONY
description: BUILDINGS FOR MUSIC The Architect, the Musician, and the Listener from the Seventeenth Century to the Present Day. By Michael Forsyth. Illustrated. 371 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $30. MICHAEL FORSYTH'S ''Buildings for Music'' is a superbly illustrated and absorbing study of concert halls and opera houses built or conceived since the 17th century. It starts with the first rooms constructed in London particularly for the pleasure of ''lovers of musick'' and ends with 20th-century world's fair pavilions specially devised to house works by Edgard Varese and Karlheinz Stockhausen. In between it delivers a feast of revelations, like Friedrich Gilly's project for the Berlin Schauspielhaus, Ernst Haiger's Symphoniehaus or Harvey Lonsdale Elmes's titanic St. George's Hall in Liverpool, England, and of pleasures, like its thorough documentation of the Neues Gewandhaus in Leipzig, East Germany. Throughout it is sustained by an intelligent, engaging narrative remarkable for its knowledge of the history of musical composition and its command of the acoustical implications of design. Since Leo Beranek's ''Music, Acoustics and Architecture'' (1962) there are few books in its class.

title: COLUMBUS DAY NEEDS WIDER SCOPE
description: IT happens every October: school kids get the day off, merchants have ''Columbus Day'' sales, and the Italian-Americans hoist a few in memory of a Genoese navigator who got no respect at home and had to sail under the Spanish flag.

title: CAMPAIGN FOR COUNTY CLERK QUICKENS
description: WITH less than a month to go in the race for County Clerk between the Democratic incumbent, Andrew J. Spano, and his Republican challenger, Guy Parisi, the contest seems to be getting sharper and more expensive.

title: Treasury Plays Strip Poker
description: In its annual challenge to Congress over the national debt limit, the Treasury Department threatened to take off all its clothes: Unless the Senate quickly raised the limit, Treasury said darkly, it might stop payment on all Government checks.

title: Buildings Without Souls
description: The demon of modern architecture in cities is neither ''money making'' nor the International Style, as Vincent Scully seems to imply, but a failure to face today's urban design challenge. The facade architecture of mannerists like Michael Graves is simply the wrong approach for cities like New York where a broader context must be addressed.

title: A GRIDIRON RIVALRY DASHED BY HURRICANE GLORIA
description: WHEN the UConn Club sent a 1986 Chevrolet back to the dealer last week, the action marked a halt in a 36-year tradition. The car was to have been first prize in a half-time raffle at the Yale-University of Connecticut football game.

title: Honors for Marguerite Yourcenar
description: To the Editor:

title: YUGOSLAVIA UNVEILS A BARGAIN BEAUTY
description: YUGOSLAVIA rolled into New York on Wednesday with a blitz of beautiful girls, red, white and blue balloons and the car that has America talking.

title: 'All By Our Little Selves'
description: The aerial arrest of the Mediterranean terrorists satisfied Americans at many levels. Finally, a President did more than deplore the murder of innocents. For once, American might was adroitly deployed in an effective police action. Score one for our side, for tourist safety, for international order.

title: Adrift?
description: Excerpts of remarks by Representative George C. Wortley, Republican of upstate New York, in the House, Oct. 2:

title: W. V. Connors 2d And Miss Gelats Exchange Vows
description: Margarita Maria Gelats, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Narciso Gelats of Palm Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday to William Vincent Connors 2d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Mann Connors of Potomac and Ocean City, Md. The Rev. Walter Hartnett performed the ceremony at St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Burn Center Support
description: I spent over a month in the Burn Center at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Dr. Cleon Goodwin and all the staff there took care of me, so, of course, I read your article with the greatest feeling of gratitude.

title: UNCOMMONLY NICE PIONEERS
description: TABLE OF CONTENTS By John McPhee. 293 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: MOUNTAIN
description: GROWTH in the advanced-technology sector has so far not met expectations in the Rocky Mountain West, even in Utah and Colorado, where it is most firmly established. Meanwhile, employment prospects in Idaho, Wyoming and Montana remain dismal because of the continued slump in key industries such as mining, oil and gas drilling and logging.

title: NEW YORK CHOOSES ITS 'SCENIC ROADS'
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation, which deals daily with toxic waste, hunting, fishing and forest preserves, has just embarked on a new function - that of designating scenic roads throughout the state.

title: Architectural Critic Is Criticized
description: Pity poor Howard Mansfield. In his Sept. 15 Opinion article ''Why We Build Fortresses,'' he has no love for these ''speculators' buildings'' and therefore the rest of us must be consigned to the ''architectural equivalent[s] of the Muzak piped inside'' and go through our life ''ignoring our neighbor.''

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening.

title: COMPANY OFFERS FARMING TO THE INVESTOR
description: TWO years ago, Austin D. Barney 2d purchased the ramshackle, 233-acre Folly Farm on Route 185 in Simsbury, and there were many who thought the farm was indeed Mr. Barney's folly.

title: SYMPHONY BEGINNING ITS 24TH
description: WHEN the White Plains Symphony begins its 24th season on Oct. 26, it will be ''New York Philharmonic Night,'' and therein lies a fascinating and heartwarming story.

title: 49ERS SEEK WAYS TO STOP MCMAHON
description: In the opinion of most experts, Joe Montana remains the best quarterback in the National Football League, and that's precisely why the Chicago Bears worry the San Francisco 49ers, who play them Sunday in Candlestick Park.

title: Wine;   THE LATER, THE BETTER
description: PRODUCERS OF THE WORLD'S FINEST SWEET wines, like avid poker players, thrive on the gamble. The longer the grapes linger on the vine, soaking up sun and producing sugar, the richer and sweeter they become. If grapes are picked at the critical moment - when their sugar concentration is high but they retain sufficient acid to make a lively wine - the result can be extraordinarily appealing. The most notable examples include the great Sauternes of France and the Beerenausleses and Trockenbeerenausleses of Germany. Because of the risks involved in producing superior sweet wines - a sudden frost can kill a year's crop - they are not made every year. Hence, they are scarce and priced accordingly. But to those who appreciate their sun-drenched nectar, they are worth seeking out.

title: PEKING IS CLOSER TO BOSCOW, BUT ONLY BY A BIT
description: A few years ago, a visiting American official asked Deng Xiaoping to name the Soviet leader he liked most among those he met on his visits to Moscow in the 1950's. When Mr. Deng named Lazar M. Kaganovich, the American objected that he had been one of the Soviet figures most intimately linked with Stalin's consolidation of power. ''He did what he had to do,'' Mr. Deng replied.

title: Despair: A Trigger Of Jail Rioting
description: This has been a bad year for prison disturbances. Every month headlines report violence in yet another state. And each time a governor appoints an investigative panel, which blames everything on overcrowding, poor facilities or mismanagement. The corrections commissioner is then fired and the cycle begins again. But during a visit to a Western penitentiary, site of two recent riots, I discovered what I think could be a root cause.

title: ''BUDDY CALLS'' KEEP CHILDREN IN TOUCH
description: STUDENTS at Eastern Junior High School in Greenwich were assigned buddies at the beginning of the school year and told that they had to call their buddy if they were going to be absent.

title: WIDE JERSEY GAINS
description: THE old industrial smokestacks no longer dominate the skyline of New Jersey's economy. The new silhouette is of the modern office building, standing either alone or clustered in campuses, sleek and shiny. Since the late 1970's, this silhouette has been stretching farther and farther from the faded riverbank manufacturing centers of Paterson, Newark, Jersey City and Camden, and into the open land that a generation ago knew only the farmer and the fawn. This land will be increasingly through the year 2000 the work place of the service industries and high technology, the new bastions of the state's economy, according to labor-market analysts in Trenton.

title: COLUMBIA ROUTED BY PRINCETON, 31-0
description: Princeton held Columbia without a first down for 54 minutes and broke one of Dick Kazmaier's longstanding offensive records today as it shut down the Lions, 31-0, before 7,080 fans at Palmer Stadium.

title: OKLAHOMA THWARTS SLUGGISH TEXAS
description: Patrick Collins, a second-string halfback, broke a long spell of defensive play and a tie with a fourth-quarter touchdown today that gave undefeated Oklahoma a 14-7 triumph over Texas before 75,587 fans in the Cotton Bowl.

title:
NATURE WATCH;

GREEN TURTLE
description: Chelonia mydas Size: Carapace to five feet long. Weighs up to 600 pounds.

title: HEARING IT ALL FROM OUR HEROES
description: ITHINK I'm like most sports fans, even knowledgeable sports fans, in that I need and often enjoy the commentary of play-by-play announcers and color analysts. That's why the quite daring announcerless pro football telecast a few years ago drew test-pattern ratings.

title: PROTESTS GROW ON TENURE DENIAL AT STONY BROOK
description: PROTESTS have been increasing in the last two weeks over the decision last summer to deny tenure to a lecturer who equated Zionism with racism in his course at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: RUNS OF LUCK, GOOD AND BAD
description: RECENTLY William Kennedy, the author of ''Ironweed,'' had a great run of luck. In less time than it takes to say, ''I can't believe it,'' and believe it, he had won a National Book Critics Circle Award, a Pulitzer Prize, a MacArthur grant, movie contracts for his novels and a hitch as a writer on the movie ''The Cotton Club,'' sharing the credits with Francis Ford Coppola. ''Ironweed'' is a fine novel, but the author may owe his run of luck and all the brouhaha to the fact that it had been repeatedly rejected. Now, among writers that is not news. But it proves to be news to ''60 Minutes'' and the prime time public.

title: JANE E. RICHARDS MARRIED
description: Jane E. Richards, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Andrew J. Frank Jr. of Shawnee, Okla., was married yesterday to Lee R. Carlson, a son of Judith L. Flynn of Plandome, L.I., and Eric G. Carlson of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Dr. David Thomas performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Tulsa, Okla. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce. Her father is pastor of the Assembly of God Church in Shawnee.

title: WRITERS AND THE NOSTALGIC FALLACY
description: AMERICAN writers criticize themselves, and are criticized, for lacking a sense of history, and for failing to achieve what is called political seriousness. Both Robert Dunn and E. L. Doctorow have argued to this effect in recent essays in these pages. These criticisms mean that writers judge what they do by standards they continually fail to satisfy - as if, with the best will in the world, their works cannot lead them to that dreamed-of grace. The idea is that, like Tolstoy (or his inspiration, Harriet Beecher Stowe), we could effect good things and momentous things by the use of our pens, if only we could break out of preoccupations we scourge as indulgent, trivial or safe. I think it is the tired assumptions we try to build on and the cumbered and self-referential language we use that keep us in a narrow space, lamenting.

title: CLASSES FOR GIFTED: MORE VIEWS
description: Special classes in certain areas of learning for gifted and talented pupils should not cause alarm. What this article failed to mention was the fact that special high schools are now being considered for gifted and talented pupils who live on Long Island. This is a giant step, and I don't think it is a very good idea.

title:
REGIONAL JOB ROUNDUP;

SOUTHWEST
description: THE slump in the oil business continues to affect employment opportunities in Texas, Louisiana and Oklahoma. Louisiana, which has the nation's second-highest unemployment rate, at 11.6 percent, lost 35,000 jobs this year. Lake Charles, with its many petrochemical plants, has an unemployment rate of 14.2 percent and New Orleans, 11.7 percent.

title: REFORMS OFFEREDFOR CONSERVATORS
description: New York State's chief judge proposed last week new rules to govern the appointment of guardians and conservators who oversee the financial affairs of incapacitated people and settle estates. The guidelines would attempt to curb favoritism and political influence, though judges would continue to exercise broad discretion over the selection of conservators.

title: DANCE THAT STARTLES AND CHALLENGES IS COMING FROM ABROAD
description: The human condition - or an examination thereof - is back in vogue in contemporary dance, and nowhere is man's fate being considered more intensely by choreographers than in West Germany, France and Japan. Ten years ago, the idea that these countries would provide the leading new and unexpected dance currents that have begun spilling over to these shores would have seemed inconceivable. Modern dance appeared to be an American preserve, willingly farmed out abroad but unable to take root even in Western Europe before the 1970's. And then it was apparently based upon American models.

title: LILCO AND GLORIA: WHO WILL PAY FOR THE STORM'S DESTRUCTION
description: AS Long Island finally shakes off the effects of Hurricane Gloria, another storm is brewing: Will the Long Island Lighting Company, its stockholders or its customers have to pay the millions of dollars it cost to restore power to tens of thousands of homes?

title: DISCOUNTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Julie Ero Gaughran Is Married to Garth Anderson
description: Julie Ero Gaughran, a daughter of Dr. Barbara A. Ehrlich of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Bernard D. Gaughran of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Garth William Anderson were married yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Anderson of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: SHOCKS DISSIPATED IN ''TOBACCO ROAD''
description: WHEN Jack Kirkland's adaptation of ''Tobacco Road,'' Erskine Caldwell's searing novel of the Depression-sapped rural South, opened in 1933, it stunned America with its graphic depiction of the seamier side of human nature.

title: WHERE MUSIC LIVES IN LONDON
description: This is an adventure we always enjoy.

title: FAMILY TIES, FAMILY PERILS
description: ALL SET ABOUT WITH FEVER TREES And Other Stories. By Pam Durban. 211 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $15.95.

title: On the Dollar
description: One former President and two probable Presidential hopefuls are expected to participate in the United States Congressional Summit on Exchange Rates and the Dollar, Nov. 11-13. The hopefuls, co-sponsors of the conference, are Representative Jack F. Kemp, the New York Republican, and Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat. The former President is Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who held that office in France from 1974-1981 and was Finance Minister before that.

title: PALESTINIAN GUERRILL: MAN OF MANY FACTIONS
description: Mohammed Abbas, the Palestinian guerrilla leader sought by the United States in conneciton with the cruise ship hijacking, is a man in his early 40's who has been a key strategist within the faction-ridden Palestinian guerrilla forces.

title: Jane Farrell Weds Peter Smagorinsky
description: Jane Elizabeth Farrell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard James Farrell of Glenview, Ill., and Tucson, Ariz., and Peter Smagorinsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Smagorinsky of Princeton, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Douglas Schwert performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in Glenview.

title: G.N.P. GROWTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Suzanne Benson Wed To Robert E. Robotti
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday Suzanne Martin Benson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Benson of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married to Robert Edward Robotti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Robotti of Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. William McGowan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: GAIN FOR PARENTS IN AUTISM DISPUTE
description: Parents and officials fighting a state agency's attempt to close seven homes that use punishment as therapy for young people with severe mental disorders have won a brief reprieve.

title: AMERICA LEANS TO A HEALTHIER DIET
description: JIMMY JOHNSON USED to wake up to the smell of bacon in the pan and coffee in the pot. ''And,'' his wife, Laura, recalls, ''I'd save the bacon grease to fry the eggs.''

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL;

BETWEEN CLASSES, TEAM REBUILDS ON PAST GLORY
description: DESPITE a cold and unrelenting rain, the new Monsters of the Midway took the practice field last Tuesday. Off to their best start in years, the team with perhaps the grandest football tradition in the land was not about to be beaten by Mother Nature. On the sideline the man who has brought winning back to Chicago exhorted his charges, and for a moment a spectator sensed the presence of the new coach's legendary forebearer, the crusty competitor responsible for the creation of the modern game.

title: CAIRO: SORROW, AND ANGER FOR A FRIEND
description: EGYPT, walking a tightrope between the Arab world and the United States, criticized the American interception of an Egyptian airliner carrying the Achille Lauro's four hijackers, but in terms that struck diplomats in Cairo as extremely mild. ''The Arab Republic of Egypt, with utmost regret, was surprised by the interception by American planes,'' the Foreign Ministry said. ''Such actions do not serve the cause of peace.''

title: HANDMADE LACE FROM NORMANDY
description: Bayeux, the town in Norman France best known for a monumental tapestry illustrating the invasion of England by William the Conqueror, is also renowned as a center of lace making. It was the capital for bobbin lace, a kind of lace made by manipulating numerous threads, each attached to a bobbin. In the 19th century, some 5,000 artisans centered in Bayeux and neighboring villages were involved in the craft.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: WELLS IN ETHIOPIA FOCUS OF CIVIC DRIVE
description: IN an effort to help Ethiopians suffering from drought, a West Hartford group is trying to raise money for a well digger.

title: THERE'S NEW PASSION IN MUSIC-MAKING
description: Sometimes conventional wisdom turns out not to be so wise, after all. Cliches codify what everyone knows, to the point of banality, but sometimes cliched assumptions become outmoded; they aren't even trivially true any more. Take the widespread notion that young instrumental virtuosos these days, while technically proficient, are bland, conservative and utterly lacking in individuality, ''soul'' or ''heart.''

title: COURT HEARING SET IN 1974 SLAYING
description: THREE suspects in one of Connecticut's longest-running unresolved murder cases are scheduled to appear in court this week, more than 11 years after the body of the 16-year-old boy they are accused of killing was discovered in a rural area of Enfield.

title: IDEAS AND IDEALS POPULATE THE WORLD OF DAVID HARE
description: As a playwright, David Hare is a surgeon who operates on the body politic. Watching his plays, theatergoers are stimulated by Shavian cross-currents of opinions, ideas and sardonic assessments of mankind's peril. Despite Mr. Hare's position as a dramatist with a confirmed left-wing political consciousness, in his plays it is not immediately evident which side he supports. He places his characters in conflict and encourages us to decide who is our spokesman while subtly nudging us in what he considers to be the morally responsible direction.

title: A REVISED OPINION ON THE DEATH OF MICHAEL STEWART
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's chief medical examiner, offered a third opinion last week on why Michael Stewart died in 1983, 13 days after falling into coma while in police custody.

title: COMPUTERS THAT RESPOND TO STUDENTS, AND VICE VERSA
description: At Shallow Intermediate School in Brooklyn, 11-year-old Alfred Macaluso ''shoots down'' the missing word in a sentence as part of a vocabulary exercise. ''I try to get 12 in a row with no misses,'' he explained. In the science room at Joan of Arc Junior High School in Manhattan, there are no correct answers to shoot down. Instead, students use computers to design clocks or judge the aerodynamic properties of toy cars they have built out of blocks. ''We see the computer as a tool,'' George Franz, a science teacher, said.

title: AN OBSESSION IN VERMONT: HAWK CENSUS
description: The sharp-shinned hawk appeared so suddenly and closely that Bill Barnard and the two other hawk watchers on Paine Mountain were startled.

title: A WALTZ FOR ATLANTA'S MAYOR
description: Four years ago Andrew J. Young won his first term as Mayor of Atlanta in a bitter contest that split mostly along racial lines.

title: The Curse Of the Cubs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: HOT-LINE SERVICE FOR MEN OFFERED
description: ALAN was talking about the way men usually choose to confide in each other when they have problems. ''It's a long process, to come out with emotions,'' he said. ''Generally the man is half drunk at a party or a professional gathering. Or maybe he's in the locker room of the golf course. Whatever, men are often conditioned not to be forthcoming, not to be willing to discuss their feelings, especially over the telephone.''

title: JERUSALEM: ELATION AT ENEMY'S SETBACK
description: ISRAELIS were savoring a rare setback for terrorism and its Palestinian practitioners. The interception by American jets of the airliner carrying the hijackers from the scene of their crime was proof, they said, that such actions could be combated effectively, without massive loss of life.

title:
GARDENING;

NOW IS THE TIME TO PLANT SPRING BULBS
description: THE mere mention now of spring is enough to conjure up visions of drifts of flowering bulbs spread across the landscape. If those visions are to come true in your garden, this is the time to plant the bulbs, unless they are already in place from previous years' plantings. Even so, no garden is so full of spring bulbs that it does not have room for a few more.

title: DRIVING TO WORK: OTHER VIEWS
description: In response to Irene Barrett's article, I would like to offer her a new solution to Long Island traffic.

title: ALLENDE AND ARTURO
description: I DREAMT THE SNOW WAS BURNING By Antonio Skarmeta. Translated by Malcolm Coad. 220 pp. New York: Readers International. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95. IT is 1973. Chile is in turmoil, reeling toward the military coup of Sept. 11, when young Arturo arrives in Santiago determined to become a soccer star and lose his virginity. ''He pictured himself as an animal that had grown up caged in a zoo, and now at twenty was released into the jungle.''

title: THE NEWEST GLOBETROTTER
description: ''Our newest Harlem Globetrotter holds the career scoring record at the University of Kansas, eclipsing the records of Wilt Chamberlain and Jo Jo White. At 5 feet 11 inches tall, ladies and gentlemen, meet Lynette Woodard.''

title: No Headline
description: ON FEB. 6, 1934, MY uncle Andre Monestier joined my father and 40,000 other Frenchmen at the barricades to preserve the honor of France and overthrow a government which they thought inept and corrupt. Like most other patriots of their time, they looked on their nation as supreme unto all others in the glory of its culture and its political and military might, ''Mother of arms, of arts and of laws'' (a phrase drummed into them since infancy). And in the winter of 1934 that image was being sullied by a number of political scandals which had culminated in the Stavisky affair, a heist brought off by a foreign adventurer who had robbed France of billions of francs, implicating some of the country's most prominent men.

title: FORSS WORKS SHOW ARTFUL SINCERITY
description: GEORGE FORSS speaks for artists and fantasists alike when he rounds off a statement for his show at the Pelham Art Center by saying: ''I just want to be accepted for myself and appreciated for my talent.'' A cry from the heart, it is nevertheless voiced by one who has already been accepted and appreciated and in the most romantic possible way.

title: Whitney Wright, Designer, Is Wed
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Gwynedd, Pa., yesterday Margaretta Whitney Wright, a daughter of Mrs. Beaumont W. Wright of Gwynedd Valley, Pa., and the late Mr. Wright, was married to Randolph Harrison Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison of Mill Neck, L.I. The Rev. Vincent Liddle, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Oates, performed the ceremony.

title: WINNING THE 'WAR' ON DRIVING DRUNK
description: A STATE of war exists on Connecticut's roads and highways. It is a war that can claim your life or that of a loved one or friend, without warning.

title: Holocaust Studies Termed Insufficient
description: In his Sept. 8 Opinion Page article [''Ignorance Breeds Anti-Semitism''] , Jeffrey Maas described racist and anti-Semitic violence among the ignorant youth of Monmouth County and elsewhere in the state. No part of our country - or the world -is proof against such violence, from outside or within a community.

title: Topics;   Long Runs The Shadow
description: ''The Life of Orson Welles,'' a drama that played for 70 years, closed Thursday in Los Angeles with the death of the title character.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Where there is so much smoke, one tends to think there is some fire.'' xhThomas Thomson Chief economist, Crocker National Bank, on recurring rumors that Paul A. Volcker will quit as Fed chairman

title: NEW AT HIGH POINT
description: FOR THE LAST TWO years, much of the news at the Southern Furniture Market Center in High Point, N.C., revolved around pieces inspired by the Italian-based group of international designers who call themselves Memphis. Their pieces were brash, overblown, hard-edged shapes with futuristic finishes.

title: A KEYNESIAN WHO REFUSES TO QUIT
description: When Nobel Prize-winning economist James Tobin was a sophomore at an Illinois high school in 1932, his class took a straw poll for the Presidency. The verdict: 30 votes for Herbert Hoover, one for the Socialist Norman Thomas and one lone vote -young Mr. Tobin's - for the Democratic contender, Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: SHOULD ROCK LYRICS BE SANITIZED?
description: Lowell George of the 1970's rock band Little Feat was probably kidding when he sang, ''Some contend that rock and roll/is bad for the body and bad for the soul/bad for the heart, bad for the mind/bad for the deaf and bad for the blind.'' Yet with an elaborate media campaign that culminated last month in a day of Senate hearings and stern, if vague, admonitions from Commerce Committee members to America's record companies, some parents have upset the record business.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Rear-Guard Bard While Shakespeare's imagery was radical, his tastes were conservative. In ''Shakespeare: An Illustrated Biography'' (Peter Bedrick), Martin Fido analyzes the Bard's social attitudes.

title: A TRADITION OF LUXURY ENDURES
description: I've been pondering the impact of a 19th-century Swiss cowherd on the life of our time.

title: SAFETY BOARD'S BRAIN DRAIN
description: A Federal agency that investigates aviation accidents along with an array of other transportation mishaps and recommends steps to avoid their recurrence is experiencing some turbulence of its own these days.

title: WHEN CONSCIENCE RULES ON INVESTMENTS
description: * The Pax World Fund will not invest in military contractors, liquor, tobacco, gambling and most companies doing business in South Africa. It shuns the International Business Machines Corporation because of its military contracts and its South African presence. Yet companies that make or sell food and drugs in South Africa are acceptable to the New Hampshire-based mutual fund. ''We didn't feel that things available to us on the drugstore shelf should not be available to blacks in South Africa,'' said the fund's spokesman, Jack Corbett, a Methodist clergyman.

title: Q AND A
description: The Oldest Apartments Question: What can you tell me about the red-brick building at 400-406 West 57th Street? . . . J. B., Manhattan Answer: You are referring to the Windmere, which was built in 1881. Christopher Gray, an architectural historian, says he believes it is the oldest large apartment house in New York City, predating the Gramercy (1883) and the Dakota (1884).

title: AHEARN SETS MARK ON 2.5-MILE COURSE
description: Karen Ahearn, a 17-year-old senior from Bernards High School in Bernardsville, N.J., broke the girls record for the 2.5-mile course yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: THE NEW YORK RECOVERY: CAN IT BE SUSTAINED
description: IN 1978, when New York City was at its lowest economic ebb since the Great Depression, a group of economists from the metropolitan region joined together to assess the bleak prospects around them.

title: AT STUYVESANT, FOOTBALL PROVIDES SOME LESSONS AND TESTS
description: It's 5:15 P.M. and Stuyvesant High School's football practice has just ended. After a six-hour day of classes and a gruelling 90-minute workout, the 115 players quickly file to the buses waiting to take them from their rock-strewn practice field on the F.D.R. Drive back to the school building on East 15th Street in lower Manhattan. The players shower and make the long trek home, some traveling as much as one and a half hours to sections of Brooklyn and Staten Island. They arrive home to face the most challenging part of their day: homework. Lots of it.

title: MEETING ESTEE LAUDER
description: THE WRAPS are being taken off Estee Lauder, the enigmatic founder of the privately owned, billion-dollar beauty business that bears her name. At least, some of them.

title: HELP FOR PIN OAKS
description: WHEN Deputy Mayor Deborah Miller of Munsey Park visits Copley Pond, her eyes search out more than just the view of ducks and geese waddling about.

title: New Hampshire High Court To Rule on State Vodka Ban
description: The New Hampshire Supreme Court has agreed to decide whether the State Liquor Commission can continue to keep vodka made in the Soviet Union off the shelves of 72 state-run liquor stores.

title: Classes for Gifted: More Views
description: In a recent article [''Classes for Gifted Provoke Debate''] a number of difficulties concerning the Three Village Schools' Elementary Honors Program were discussed. While both selection procedures and grouping were examined, the former issue is the pivotal one. Until a district can decide what its definition of ''gifted/ talented'' is, it cannot design a curriculum.

title: WHAT SHOULD ISRAEL BE
description: THE TRAGEDY OF ZIONISM Revolution and Democracy in the Land of Israel. By Bernard Avishai. 389 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: SUCCESS BREEDS FOURTH NEWARK GATEWAY
description: FIRST there was Gateway I, a 26-story office tower and 250-room hotel across the street from the Pennsylvania Railroad Station in Newark. When it opened in 1970, it stood alone at the edge of a 20-acre urban-renewal tract, a quarter-mile from Broad Street and, to observers who doubted the viability of any commercial developments in Newark, far from the path to success.

title: Elizabeth Kisken, A Banker, Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Ann Kisken, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Kisken of Riverside, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard M. Solazzo, a son of Mrs. Michael Ferris of North Castle, N.Y., and Henry A. Solazzo of Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Amato performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church.

title: ANOUILH'S 'WALTZ' GIVES ITS CAST FOOD FOR THOUGHT
description: There's a rumor around town that ''The Waltz of the Toreadors'' is a comedy.

title: WHAT TO DO ONCE THE PARCELS HAVE BEEN PUT TOGETHER
description: DAVID GIBBONS, a former Prime Minister of Bermuda and now chairman of the Bermuda Monetary Authority, is no stranger to New York City. His father opened the Bermuda Shop, selling women's sportswear, on Madison Avenue in 1936, and he has been a regular vistor for business over the years.

title: MURDER CASE RESOLVED
description: FOR the second time, Jacqueline Williams and her brother John have been sentenced to life imprisonment for a 1976 murder in a $56 holdup. As in their first trial, a third person was sentenced with them, but that third person was different this time.

title: FAMILY TRADITION
description: It is now 60 years since contract bridge was introduced by Harold Sterling Vanderbilt, so those who played the predecessor game of auction are a rapidly dwindling band. In the first quarter of the century a highly professional group, headed by such towering figures as Joseph Elwell, Sidney Lenz and Milton Work, wrote books and newspaper articles on auction for a wide audience.

title: CONTROLLING SPREADSHEET SPRAWL
description: EVER since the first computer software was written, the people using the programs have been complaining about poor documentation. The object of their criticism is not documentation in the sense in which the word is used today, to refer to an instruction manual. The criticism uses the word in its original sense of elucidating the underlying assumptions and methods employed by a writer in developing a program.

title: EASTCHESTER DOWNS WESTLAKE TIGHT RACE IN QUEENS August Martin moved into a tie with John Adams, Bayside and Andrew Jackson for first place in the Queens division of the Public School Athletic League, topping previously undefeated Bayside by 34-6 yesterday at August Martin.   John Leitzsey scored three of August Martin's five touchdowns and gained 140 yards in 16 carries.   The senior halfback scored his team's first points on a 4-yard run, and the senior quarterback Gaurdi Gilles then completed a pass to the junior split end Robin Callander for the conversion. Martin Flowers, a senior defensive back, set up the play with the first of his two interceptions, on his own 30-yard line.   In the second quarter, Leitzsey scored from 3 yards out and before the half, Gilles put August Martin ahead, 20-0, with a 47-yard pass to Garrick Faide.   Gilles, who completed all 7 of his passes for 111 yards, completed an 18-yard pass to Callander in the third period for another touchdown. Leitzsey finished the scoring in the fourth quarter with a 5-yard run.      BRIDGEWATER SHUT OUT   Hunterdon Central, stripped of two victories earlier this week by the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association for using two ineligible players in its first two games, rebounded to score a 14-0 victory over Bridgewater East in Bridgewater.   If not for the forfeits, Hunterdon Central (2-2) would be unbeaten, untied and unscored upon this season.   All the scoring yesterday occurred late in the final quarter, when Tom Bill hit Tim Apgar with a 23-yard touchdown pass and when Kendall Williams ran in from the 16 to complete a short drive set up by a fumble recovery by Ken Puttlitz.
description: Undefeated Eastchester (3-0) watched its 14-0 lead evaporate in the second half but held on to defeat visiting Westlake, 22-15, in a see-saw battle yesterday. Eastchester's backup quarterback, Brian Cade, connected with Doug Esposito, the wide receiver, for a 20-yard touchdown pass to secure the victory for the Eagles.

title: DANCE
description: There will be a foreign invasion of sorts this week, as three visitors from other countries present their work in New York theaters. The Kibbutz Dance Company of Israel, which performs Sunday afternoon at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, will offer a view of Israeli modern dance choreography in three works on its program, which also includes a dance by Jiri Kylian.

title: About Men;   The Thirsty Animal
description: I WAS VERY YOUNG, BUT I STILL VIVIDLY REMEMBER how my father fascinated my brothers and me at the dinner table by running his finger around the rim of his wine glass. He sent a wonderful, crystal tone wafting through the room, and we loved it. When we laughed too raucously, he would stop, swirl the red liquid in his glass and take a sip.

title: WATER-RATE REQUEST FOUGHT
description: New Jersey's Public Advocate says that the state's largest privately owned water utility is in sound financial condition and that it should be denied a $22 million rate-increase request.

title: NEW OPTIONS IN ROUND-THE-WORLD FLIGHTS
description: If you ask Pan American World Airways to sell you an unrestricted economy-class ticket from New York to Hong Kong and back, you will, at this writing, be quoted a price of $2,246. But a creative travel agent can arrange, for those willing to spend about $800 more, flights not just to Hong Kong and back but around the world with unlimited stopovers - all in first class.

title: BANDING TOGETHER
description: PARROTS' WOOD By Erma J. Fisk. 240 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. 5.95.

title: PIRANDELLO TALES IN THE TRAVIANNI BROTHERS' 'KAOS'
description: ''K AOS,'' the Greek word for ''Chaos,'' is a curious title for the new film by Paolo and Vittorio Taviani, a film with a profound and stirring sense of natural order. Adapted loosely from stories by Luigi Pirandello (the title in fact comes from a Pirandello quotation about the derivation of ''Cavusu,'' the name of a forest near his native village), ''Kaos'' tells four separate tales of Sicilian life. These fables, plus an epilogue about the author himself, are united by their shared imagery, their strong sense of community, their final ironies and the clear, graceful way in which they are told.

title: THE HISH COST OF CREDIT CARD CREDIT
description: The millions of Americans who use bank credit cards might have wondered why they were not sharing in the benefits of declining interest rates over the last few years. The barometers that reflect the banks' costs, such as the interest paid on savings accounts, are at their lowest levels in four years, while the interest they charge credit card holders has remained high.

title: RADON BECOMING A TOP ISSUE
description: THE potential dangers from naturally occurring radon, a gas that has been found trapped in many homes in northern New Jersey, have stirred as much public concern as, if not more than, that surrounding the worst chemical waste dumps in the state.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ARK FOR THE UNCALLED. By Vladimir Maximov. Translated by Julian Graffy. (Quartet, $14.95.) Although this novel by a Soviet emigre is set in the postwar Stalin era, it is hardly conventional historical fic-tion, for biblical parallels are at least as important to the author as verisimilitude.

title: SAVING 'THE LAST SUPPER'
description: SOMETIME NEXT YEAR, PERHAPS by Easter, the face of Jesus will be altered in a painting that has become as fixed and familiar as Scripture in the minds of millions of people - Leonardo da Vinci's centuries-old mural, ''The Last Supper.''

title: PORTRAITS COME TO LIFE AT NIGHT
description: IT was the 19th century, and the wife of a Parisian banker posed for the artist John Singer Sargent in a Worth gown with a heart-shaped bodice that was, for that time, alarmingly low-cut.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE JOURNALS OF THORNTON WILDER 1939-1961. Selected and edited by Donald Gallup. (Yale University, $25.) It is difficult to know just where to place the novelist and playwright Thornton Wilder (1897-1975) in American letters.

title: SMITHTOWN AND DEVELOPMENT: A COMMUNITY THRIVING, NOT DYING
description: IT should not come as a surprise that, as Supervisor of the Town of Smithtown, I strongly disagree with Anne Fauvell's article ''Smithtown Is Dying'' [Opinion Page, Sept. 29] . After all, one of my functions is to initiate and defend public policy.

title: COUNTY PUSHES TO END ILLEGAL SEWERS
description: THREATENED with the loss of several million dollars in Federal grant money, county officials are pressuring municipalities to crack down on homeowners with illegal sewer connections.

title: MANIPULATIVE, SECRETIVE AND GREAT
description: FDR By Ted Morgan. Illustrated. 830 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: CHRISTMAS IN THE OUTBACK
description: IN HER OWN IMAGE By Anna Murdoch. 225 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: SPICY RIBS AT A ROADSIDE STAND
description: WHEN yet another New York friend recommended the barbecued ribs at a roadside stand in Connecticut called Stick to Your Ribs, it seemed time to give the place a whirl. As insurance, we took with us the family barbecue expert, wise in the ways of mesquite versus applewood, Piggy Park sauce and incendiary home experiments of his own.

title: HIS HONOR IS GUILTY
description: Near the end of his first conspiracy trial, Roger Hedgecock took to the witness stand in defense of his good name; after the trial ended in a hung jury, he and his lawyers concluded that many jurors had not believed him.

title: CONSUMER RATES
SOME CHILD-ABUSE CHARGES HELD FALSE
description: IN THE living room of a home in nearby Verona recently, three men sat looking at photographs of the smiling faces of three little girls - their natural and foster children.

title: MICHAEL APTED: HE'LL BE CALLING AGAIN IN 1991
description: Michael Apted has learned that he can no longer knock on the same 14 doors every seven years and simply say, ''It's me again.'' The last time he knocked, two of the doors were slammed on his melancholy face, his camera crew, his everlasting questions. He fears he may be shut out next time by the remaining 12 in a collection of subjects he chose as children in London. His frank and revealing films of their lives at ages 7, 14, 21 and 28 have appeared so often on British television that people in pubs gossip about ''Suzi, the posh girl,'' ''Tony, the tear-away jockey boy'' and the others, as though they were characters in a soap opera.

title: COLONEL REDL: THE MAN BEHIND THE SCREEN MYTH
description: In the opening battles of World War I, the Austro-Hungarian Empire lost half a million men. It is almost universally thought that tens of thousands of these men died because of the treachery of Alfred Redl, a colonel of the Austrian General Staff and a top-level intelligence officer. Chroniclers of the last days of the Hapsburg Empire, as well as historians of espionage ranging from the Central Intelligence Agency's Allen Dulles to the Soviet Union's Gen. Mikhail Milstein, concur in calling Redl an arch-traitor.

title: FROM LYCEUM'S STAGE, A DISCUSSION ON AIDS
description: The public almost never gets the chance to meet an actor offstage to discuss his thoughts about a particular play.

title: CRIME
description: There have been many mysteries and suspense novels in which classical music plays a major part. (Remember Helen Traubel's ''Metropolitan Opera Murders''?) But there doesn't seem to have been one set at an international music competition. In THE MUSIC WARS (Beaufort, $15.95), Gordon Pape and Tony Aspler tell the story of a brilliantly talented American violinist at the Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow.

title: NEBRASKA SUBDUES OKLAHOMA ST., 34-24
description: McCathorn Clayton ran for two touchdowns and passed for another to lead Nebraska to a 34-24 victory over Oklahoma State in their Big Eight Conference opener. Both teams are 4-1. Doug DuBose led Nebraska with 134 yards on 16 carries. Oklahoma State's Thurman Thomas, who was second in rushing nationally, carried 22 times for 71 yards. His touchdown was the Oklahoma State's first by rushing against the Cornhuskers since 1978.

title: ROME: FEELING THE HEAT FROM ALL SIDES
description: AS the Rome daily Il Messagero hailed the release of the Achille Lauro's 400 hostages, calling it a ''triumph of Italian diplomacy,'' Prime Minister Bettino Craxi and his aides were trying to figure out what went wrong. They were mystified that a ship under their flag would be singled out by the P.L.O., whose cause they had supported, and embarrassed that poor communications had led Italian officials to praise their close work with the P.L.O. in ending the hijacking without violence only minutes before Mr. Craxi announced the murder of the American.

title: Writer-Architects
description: To the Editor:

title: EFFICIENT WAYS TO STAY WARM
description: EVER since the prices of home-heating fuels began to rise sharply in the 70's, homeowners have been seeking ways to control energy costs.

title: ALLURE OF HOME-EQUITY LOANS RETURNS
description: INTEREST rates have fallen to a level where second mortgages and home-equity loans are again practical options for homeowners looking for a relatively low-cost source of credit to pay for home renovations, college expenses, a second home or new investments.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

THE READ SANCTUARY
description: LAST weekend's downpours did little to dampen the enthusiasm of the more than 100 people who gathered at Playland, the county-owned park in Rye, to witness the dedication of 170 acres of land as a wildlife preserve. The new sanctuary encompasses Playland Lake and its seven islands, surrounding land and an expanse of Long Island Sound shoreline. It becomes the seventh area set aside by the county for the preservation of local flora and fauna.

title: BISHOPS REVISE ECONOMIC LETTER
description: When a panel of Roman Catholic bishops issued a draft of a pastoral letter on the American economy a year ago, some Catholics complained that it slighted the middle class and put too much faith in government's ability to help the poor. Last weekend, the committee conceded that the critics had a point.

title: NEWER INGREDIENTS SOUGHT FOR INVESTMENT BANKERS
description: INVESTMENT BANKING used to be a business where clients were loyal, the markets were predictable and the skills required to make it as a fat cat on Wall Street were minimal. Nowadays the financial rewards are still alluring, but stock and bond issues and corporate takeovers take place in an arena that pits one investment banking firm against another as never before. And the successful deal-makers are men and women who must possess the creativity of an artist, the fortitude of an athlete and the timing of a trader.

title: Miss Sherry To Be Wed
description: Vivien Gail Sherry, a staff analyst for personnel policy for the City of New York, and Andrew Paul Greenberg, a partner in Advance Realty Associates in New York, plan to be married Nov. 30.

title: 'BELLS AND WHISTLES' MARK A BORDER IN AUDIO DESIGN
description: The unrelenting quest for novelty sometimes inspires dubious achievements. Lately, for example, the fancier cassette decks have been sporting something called ''Music Scan.'' Hit the scan button and the deck will play the first few seconds of each selection on the tape and then skip to the next - unless the listener signals that he wants to hear the whole piece.

title: PLUCKY LOTTIE JAY
description: WALKING AFTER MIDNIGHT By Maureen McCoy. 223 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $14.95.

title: FATHER-IN-LAW, AT 85, MUST LEARN HOW TO GIVE UP DRIVING
description: MY father-in-law, George, was 85 the year he came to live with our family. The most difficult thing I had to do that year was to persuade him to give up driving.

title: STUDY SEEKS WAYS TO UNCLOG ROADS
description: ENDING toll collections on the Connecticut Turnpike last Wednesday was just the first step in an effort to relieve traffic problems in southwestern Connecticut, according to several government officials in the area.

title: SUMMER MEMORY OF AN UNCOMMON LABOR OF LOVE
description: WHEN children go back to school in the fall, they are often asked to write an essay on ''What I Did Last Summer.'' If I were to give myself that assignment, I could describe a summer unlike any I have experienced before. Last summer I helped my town build a new library.

title: District Lines Upheld For State Legislature
description: New York's highest court has upheld the way the Legislature redrew its members' district lines in 1982.

title: WESTPORT WEIGHS CURB ON GROWTH
description: THE latest effort in Westport to control commercial growth will come next month, when the Planning and Zoning Commission holds a public hearing on whether to impose a nine-month moratorium on commercial building applications.

title: Breaking Barriers
description: A delegation of 15 Soviet women will arrive in Washington tomorrow as part of an exchange program sponsored by Peace Links. After three days, they will break up into four groups and spend a week in different American communities, living with families and participating in a wide variety of events.

title: J. S. Richards Weds Rosemary Quigley
description: Rosemary Cannon Quigley, a daughter of Constance Vaughan Quigley of New York and the late Joseph Bernard Quigley, was married yesterday to James Shannon Richards, a son of Dr. Robert Charles Richards of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Claire Shannon Richards. The Rev. Damian Halligan performed the ceremony at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title:
DINING OUT;

WEST ORANGE: A NICHE IS FILLED
description: A MODERN office building across the road from St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston is the unlikely setting for a sophisticated-looking new restaurant. The Metropolitan Cafe, which opened five months ago in the spacious ground floor of the Atkins-Kent Building, fills a niche for the kind of informal place where one can drop in for anything from a drink to an omelet to a four-course meal.

title: ART
description: Mabel Dodge was one of New York's best known salonkeepers in the years between 1913 and 1917, conducting soirees in her apartment on lower Fifth Avenue where artists, writers and political activists held forth on the state of the world. (Later she was to settle in Taos, N. M., and establish an art colony there.) The lively mix included such diverse personalities as Marsden Hartley, Charles Demuth, Emma Goldman, Max Eastman, the psychoanalyst A. A. Brill, Carl Van Vechten and Margaret Sanger.

title: Tax Income Equally
description: Re: ''Preserve the Tax Deductions,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 8:

title: WHEN DOUGLAS BROKE THE WATER FOUNTAIN
description: NOTES FROM A SCHOOLTEACHER By James Herndon. 169 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: NORTHWEST
description: THE Pacific Northwest's economy has undergone euphoric turns in recent months in the major cities and technology corridors. But out in the hinterlands of Washington and Oregon, where traditional industries such as forestry products, aluminum and agriculture are depressed and more plant closings are expected, the outlook is somber. Overall, the unemployment rate hovers nearly a point and a half above the national average in Washington, at 8.3 percent, and is worse in Oregon, where the 9.9 percent jobless rate is expected to climb above l0 percent next year.

title: FOR L.I. COMPOSER, AN ESKIMO EVENT
description: IN a way, Judith Lang Zaimont's career as a composer has been marked by irony. Take Friday evening, for example, when her song cycle based on Eskimo poems, ''From the Great Land: Woman's Songs,'' is to receive its Long Island premiere during the American Chamber Ensemble's season opener at Hofstra University.

title: Namath a Father
description: Two days before his number is due to be retired and two days before his wife was due to give birth, Joe Namath became a father yesterday.

title: Quake Near Wilmington
description: Officials say a minor earthquake north of Wilmington did not lead to any reports of damage. Kenneth Woodruff, associate director of the Delaware Geological Survey in Newark, said Friday that the earthquake came at 9:40 Thursday night and registered about 1.9 on the Richter scale. Residents of the Alapocas Woods housing development felt the tremor and called the police and radio stations.

title: INDIANS RECLAIM LAND SEIZED A CENTURY AGO
description: In a ceremony evoking both pride and bitterness, the remaining members of the Narragansett Indian Tribe received 900 acres of land from the state Friday, 105 years after it was taken from their ancestors by Rhode Island lawmakers.

title: COMMUNITIES ACT TO SLOW BUILDING
description: WESTCHESTER is having its biggest building boom in 15 years - and half a dozen communities are trying to find some way to slow it down.

title: THE FORCES BEHIND WHITE-COLLAR LAYOFFS
description: THE recent announcements of large-scale, white-collar layoffs at the Ford Motor Company, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Union Carbide Corporation and CBS Inc. reveal both fault-lines and trend-lines in American business. They indicate how prior mismanagement allowed layers of excess staff - and hence costs - to grow, and how companies are belatedly though necessarily reducing their ''corpocracies.''

title: FOR THE SWISS, WHAT ELSE BUT CHOCOLATE?
description: For the chocolate connoisseur, a trip to Switzerland is like a pilgrimage to Mecca. From the moment of arrival, one notices - at airports, train stations, food stores and countless confiseries and konditoreien - the huge chocolate displays, which stand out as prominently as the Alps. In Switzerland, in fact, truffles and pralines (bonbons) are second only to the less perishable chocolate bar. Even diabetics are indulged. Signs in many confiseries proclaim diabetiker truffles and chocolate tortes made without sugar.

title: IMPORT PRICES
description: To the Editor:

title: WANAQUE SOUTH: A CORNERSTONE
