description: WHEN it comes to water-supply issues, it is easy to drown in the shallows and lose sight of the depths.

title: THE CHINA CLIPPER REMEMBERED, BORNEO EXPLORED
description: 50 Years of Pacific Service On Nov. 22, 1935, as 20,000 spectators looked on from the shores of Alameda Bay, a Pan American Martin 130 flying boat named the China Clipper, with the airline's chief pilot, Edwin C. Musick, at the controls, lifted off on a pioneering flight. Powered by Pratt & Whitney WASP 3,320-horsepower engines, the China Clipper's flight from San Francisco to Manila inaugurated commercial air service across the Pacific Ocean.

title: An Age of Fanatics
description: Here at the United Nations, as elsewhere, there was admiration for the U.S. political decision and technical skill that plucked the Palestinian terrorists from the sky over the Mediterranean. But the capture of a few demolition thugs obviously is no answer to the problem of international anarchy.

title: TROUPE PLAYS 'ON LOCATION'
description: A PLAY about a historic trial will be performed in a courtroom. A mystery about a vanished sculpture will be played in a gallery, with the audience wandering from room to room, as they choose. A rock opera will be sung in a rock-and-roll club.

title: CAR ENTHUSISASTS PREPARE FOR AUTOFEST
description: Vincent R. Pasquale of Mount Vernon does not recall exactly where he stopped his 1965 Corvair a few years ago to search for orange turkeys. He thinks it might have been Cortlandt. ''Or maybe it was Peekskill,'' he said. ''It was somewhere around there.'' He does, however, know where he stopped one night to look for pink bunnies with a flashlight. ''That was in Bedford,'' he said. He's certain because that's where he had to try and explain to a policeman exactly what he was doing. What he was doing was rallying. That means he and a navigator were traversing 50 or so miles of terrain in a car, following a set of instructions ''so precise, they're confusing,'' and attempting to get to a certain checkpoint at a certain time.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: OXFORD BLOOD. By Antonia Fraser. (Norton, $13.95.) The next time you're laid up after breaking a leg skiing, you could do worse than curl up with Jemima Shore.

title: PENN STATE EDGES ALABAMA
description: Watching intently from the sideline, dressed in a dark Penn State sweater and wearing horn-rimmed glasses, Joe Paterno cut a reassuring figure to the hometown fans. But many of them may have been surprised to know how often the coach grappled with his better judgment today, acting more on impulse than adhering to the playbook that he has followed for 20 years. This time, the gambler in Paterno was paid off with a victory.

title: INSECURITY IN SECURITY
description: His Presidential commission has been in business only since August, but David R. Packard has heard enough to conclude that Pentagon machinery for buying and testing weapons is ''worse than it was 15 years ago.''

title: NESTING: A DRAMA IN THE WILD
description: THE wind is high tonight, a wild, wanton westerly, sweeping unseasonable chill upon us, rushing rain across our inlet, pushing high moon-tide waters too close to them. We are out here in the dark, leaning into the storm, watching. There must be something we can do to help her.

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: ''ISSUES of medical ethics touch us at every point in our lives, from birth to death,'' said Dr. Bruce Grob, a medical ethicist at Drew University in Madison.

title: SURPRISES AT THE MORRIS MUSEUM
description: THE good news about ''Clay and Glass,'' the first exhibition in the new series of annual competitions for New Jersey artists, is that it does not look like a New Jersey show.

title: Deborah Cary Rubin Weds Douglas Casper Szlompek
description: Deborah Cary Rubin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Rubin of Brookville, L.I., was married at the Hampshire House in New York yesterday to Douglas Casper Szlompek, the son of Jeanne Govero of Pinebrook, N.J., and the late Edwin Szlompek.

title: LOVE ON LOCATION
description: WHAT THE MOVIES MADE ME DO By Susan Braudy. 233 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Susan Barba Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Susan Schill Barba, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Barba of Short Hills, N.J., and Stowe, Vt., to James O. Welch 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Welch Jr. of Short Hills and Manchester, Mass., took place yesterday. The Rev. Douglas Tompkins, assisted by the Rev. George MacCrae, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: A BEAUTY EXPERT SHARES HER SECRETS
description: WHEN Alicia Kornitzer Karpati fled Hungary during the 1956 Revolution, she took along the formulas of her Budapest cosmetics business.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: BROTHERS: A Hebrew Legend. By Florence B. Freedman. Illustrated by Robert Andrew Parker. $9.95. (Ages 5 to 8) A handsomely illustrated retelling of the Hebrew legend of Seth's sons, the two farming brothers, Dan and Joel, who lived in exemplary friendship and whose land underlies the Temple in Jerusalem.

title: CHINA'S 'WESTERN' SILVER EXPORTS
description: Many of the 450 tankards and tureens in the Chait Collection of Chinese Export Silver have been mistaken for Western-made wares for more than a century. There are, however, major differences between Western wares and the Chinese copies which were made for export, as can be seen in an exhibition of China-trade silver, opening Oct. 25, and remaining through Nov. 16, at Ralph M. Chait Galleries, 12 East 56th Street.

title: FORUM ON STUDENT VOLUNTEERS
description: ''SHOULD community service be required for high school graduation?'' This will be one of the topics discussed at the first meeting of the School Community Service Council at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry on the morning of Oct. 16. Representative teachers, guidance counselors, principals, school board members and other personnel from schools throughout the county are expected to attend.

title: No Headline
description: Roger Miles Blough, who died at the age of 81, was chewed out by President Kennedy in 1962 for raising steel prices.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening. Excerpts are from reviews by Times critics.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Can you supply the names of travel companies that can arrange a trip to Israel for eight people, touring by minibus or van with a driver-guide, and with accommodations in first-class hotels in the main cities? The time would be spring or summer next year. - E. K., Randallstown, Md. Answer:Several wholesale tour companies that specialize in Israel have long experience of arranging this kind of trip, which is sold through travel agents. Generally, they don't deal directly with the public. Among such companies are: Unitours (60 East 42d Street, New York, N.Y. 10165; 212-949-9500), Isram (630 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; 212-661-1193) and Foreign Tours (5 Penn Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10001; 212-947-9595 and 800-223-7500). A tour by minibus, larger bus or limousine usually starts in Tel Aviv and stops for overnights in Haifa, Tiberias and Jerusalem, with accommodations in first-class hotels. Most Israeli hotels provide a full buffet breakfast that is included in the rate. Company representatives said the land cost of an escorted tour would be about $100 to $150 a day a person, depending on the hotels used, and would include sightseeing. They said that while the current round-trip, New York-Tel Aviv air fare was $799, fares varied according to season. Fares are higher during Passover (April 24 to May 1 next year) and from the middle of June to the middle of July. Some flights are nonstop. Question:We plan to attend the Salzburg Festival in Austria next summer.

title: FOR R&D; ENTERPRISES, A REMARKABLE GROWTH
description: FOUR YEARS AGO, David Evans and William Sharp, two research scientists with the Campbell Soup Company in Camden, N.J., left their jobs to found the DNA Plant Technology Corporation in nearby Cinnaminson. Today, after watching their staff grow from 20 to 60 and their assets from zero to $20 million they are confident that they made the right choice.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Larry Nance, the Phoenix Suns' all-star forward, has been given until Friday to end his holdout and accept a revised contract. The 6-foot-10-inch Nance, the Suns' top scorer last season, is seeking to renegotiate the six-year, $1.3 million contract he signed in December 1983, and has refused to report to training camp. . . . The Houston Oilers have placed Dean Steinkuhler, an offensive guard, who won both the Outland and Lombardi Trophies as a collegian, on the injured reserve list.

title: A VERY SPECIAL TIME FOR MARKETING SPECIALISTS
description: ONE can hardly pick up a business publication these days without reading about another great marketing coup. Consider, for instance, Aspartame. A few years ago, few Americans would have recognized the name of this low-calorie artificial sweetener. But ever since the company that makes it, the G.D. Searle Company, began calling its substance Nutrasweet and spending hundreds of millions of dollars to promote it, Aspartame has been a top seller.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT KINGS IN OVERTIME
description: Bryan Trottier blasted a 35-foot shot from the left wing at 48 seconds into the overtime period to give the Islanders a 5-4 victory in their season opener.

title: REPORT SHOWS RISE IN RETAIL REVENUE
description: A NEW County Planning Department report released late last month shows that Westchester's retail economy has reversed its downward trend and has begun to grow. While not dramatic, the increase enabled Westchester to move up a notch to sixth place when its total sales are compared to those of the state's 61 other counties.

title: STARTING POINT
description: 'It's been a very long time since there've been any concrete proposals by the Soviet Union which go into details that those proposals have gone into.

title: A PLAN FOR FEWER DOCTORS
description: A New York State commission on medical education has recommended that major teaching hospitals and medical schools sharply curtail their graduate training programs and concentrate more on basic medical care. The proposals call for greater emphasis on such specialties as pediatrics, obstetrics, family practice, geriatrics and basic internal medicine at the expense of more sophisticated training programs favored by most major teaching hospitals.

title: Alexandra Garbers Is Wed
description: At the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Alexandra Devlin Garbers, a daughter of Virginia Garbers of Boston and Frederick James Garbers of New York, was married to David Randall Pruner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pruner of Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Thomas Stiers. The bride is a corporate communications associate with Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. Mr. Pruner is director of marketing for Bridgewater Associates, economic consultants in Wilton, Conn.

title: STEINBRENNER PURSUING TRADE AS PRESCRIPTION FOR YANKS' ILLS
description: THE experience is a first for George Steinbrenner, and he doesn't like it. That's why he's trying to move quickly to rectify the problem. The Yankees have played for four years now without winning even a division championship; that's the longest drought in Steinbrenner's reign as the Yankee owner. So, he said, he is working on one or two moves. ''One thing I've developed,'' Steinbrenner added, ''may cure a multitude of ills.''

title: WHAT'SNEW IN EXECUTIVE ETIQUETTE
description: LETITIA BALDRIGE remembers them well.

title: NOTRE DAME'S SAD FALL RECALLS SUNNIER HARVESTS
description: THIS has not been a good fall for me.

title: Of Mites and Bees
description: A MITE that lodges in the windpipes of honeybees and saps their strength by sucking out body fluids was threatening the multibillion-dollar bee industry in the United States.

title: TWO MEN DIE IN CONNECTICUT IN A CRASH INVOLVING SIX CARS
description: Two men were killed in a wrong-way crash involving six cars on Route 8 today, the State police said.

title: THE IMPORT BUSINESS ALSO CREATES JOBS
description: ON lower Broadway Frank Spadero, a customs-house broker, makes half a dozen phone calls to advise trucking companies and warehouses that a shipment of Brazilian lemons can be released through the Port of New York. In Midtown Manhattan an international trade attorney, Robert Eisen of Coudert Brothers, spends the better part of the day trying to obtain a customs exemption for an import manufacturer. Across the Hudson in Lodi, N.J., Michael Assile, vice president of Nuage Flowers Inc., designs artificial flowers for the bridal industry, which will be manufactured in a South Korean factory. Mr. Spadero, Mr. Eisen and Mr. Assile are among the thousands of people whose jobs depend heavily upon the nation's current import boom.

title: HOTEL OUTLOOK 'NEVER BETTER'
description: IT'S a familiar sight in New Jersey: flat, empty land one week, a hotel or corporate headquarters going up on it a week or so later. Big signs announce occupancy dates and give rental and employment telephone numbers. These sudden landscape changes have led to New Jersey's rise in ranking to second nationally in hotel-motel construction.

title: MAPPING SUCCESS
description: IT is no surprise that talent, self-discipline, personal sacrifice and a willingness to work long and hard hours are parts of the longstanding formula for getting ahead in the business world and carrying out career ambitions.

title: WHEN THE METROPOLITAN OPERA MOUNTS A LAVISH PRODUCTION
description: On a steamy August day, when the doors of the Metropolitan Opera House were closed to the public, a small group of people gathered in the darkness of the giant hall. For four days they talked, argued amiably, and walked up and down the aisles and onto to the stage. And when they were finished, a new production of Mussorgsky's rarely-performed epic opera, ''Khovanshchina'' - which opens tomorrow night conducted by Neeme Jarvi -took a major step toward completion.

title: 'Solar' Selling And Pressure
description: Your article on Sept. 22 about the energy tax credits expiring on Dec. 31, 1985 [''Warnings on 'Solar' Rooms''] and the companies that are waiving these tax credits in the face of consumers as a sales gimmick, most of whom will not receive these credits anyway, was very accurate.

title: THESE DAYS, THE BALKANS SEEM EVERY BIT AS BALKANIZED
description: Who would be want to place Rumania's territorial integrity in question, asked an official, raising his index finger and eyebrows as if to suggest a sinister secret. ''Our neighbor,'' he answered, making clear by indirection that he meant the Soviet Union. Complaints over purported restrictions on Rumania's Hungarian minority, he suggested, have been inspired by Moscow in an elaborate plot to undermine Bucharest's foreign policy, which is sometimes not fully in line with Moscow's.

title: A 'CABARET' THAT FAILS TO STARTLE
description: IS there a musical theater aficianado who hasn't dreamed up a season's ideal repertory of revivals? In real life, it isn't so easy. Some musicals are overexposed; others are unfamiliar. Some are durable no matter what - but not all that do-able.

title: MERCHANT MARINE DROPS FIRST
description: Paul Martin ran 68 yards for a second-quarter touchdown and Brian Barr sprinted 68 yards on a pass interception in the final period as undefeated Gettysburg handed the Merchant Marine Academy its first loss, 23-2, yesterday at Tomb Memorial Field, Kings Point, L.I.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Oct. 13, 1985 Fiction

title: THE OPPOSITION TAKES COVER IN PANAMA
description: When American officials and foreign policy specialists speak of the crisis in Central America, they usually leave Panama out of their concerns about teetering regimes and guerrilla wars. Somehow, the angular little country, divided by one of the world's most important canals, has always seemed to avoid the worst excesses of its neighbors. Now, however, there are indications that those quiet days may be coming to an end.

title: A Father's Anger
description: Frederick Kaufman's article is terrific. Anybody who can write a fascinating real-life story on one page is bound to be a successful writer like his father.

title: THE PROSECUTOR-LEGISLATOR STALKING E.F. HUTTON
description: Representative William J. Hughes was a Federal attorney for 10 years in Cape May County, N.J., and sometimes it seems as if he is still in the courtroom.

title: COUPLES CAUGHT IN ADOPTION MAZE
description: LAST December, Anne and Mel Siegel, who wanted to adopt a healthy American baby, put this advertisement in four upstate weekly newspapers: ''Warm, loving couple seeks white infant to make our life complete. Will provide wonderful home and financial security. Call collect.''

title: THE THIRD WORLD HAS NEW RESPECT FOR REAGANOMICS
description: Four years ago, when President Reagan spoke of the ''magic of the marketplace'' as the key to global economic growth and higher living standards, many third world countries greeted the idea with skepticism and derision. No one is laughing now.

title: BEYOND ACUPUNCTURE
description: ENCOUNTERS WITH QI Exploring Chinese Medicine. By David Eisenberg with Thomas Lee Wright. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: A RUTGERS PROFESSOR 'JOINS' FEMALE GANGS IN NEW YORK
description: SIX years ago, Anne Campbell, fresh from England, found herself treading on new territory - literally and sociologically - in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: BLACK-ASIAN TENSION STUDIED
description: Urban areas need to establish education and anticrime programs to ease tensions between Asians and blacks and to help fearful immigrants shed their distrust, according to a report by the Philadelphia Human Relations Commission.

title: PENALTY IS KEY AS TEMPLE TOPS RUTGERS
description: A costly personal foul, the only penalty of the game against Rutgers, enabled Temple to score with 1 minute 57 seconds remaining and salvage a 14-13 victory before a homecoming crowd of 25,286 at Veterans Stadium.

title: HOLIDAY ISSUES TO BE RELEASED
description: The marketing efforts of the Postal Service and the return to traditional hobbies have aroused renewed interest in collecting modern United States stamps. This year's holiday issues follow a pattern that has prevailed since 1970. Mailers have their choice of a traditional or a contemporary design. The first Christmas issue, released in 1963, reflected sensitivity to criticism of a religious theme on our nation's stamps. A holiday wreath was used.

title: MICHIGAN, NOW 5-0, STOPS MICHIGAN ST.
description: Michigan, which has given up only one touchdown this season, gave up nothing today and raised its record to 5-0 with a 31-0 victory over Michigan State before 78,235 spectators at Spartan Stadium.

title: VIEWS FOR ALL
description: More than one seaside community has had the unfortunate experience of Malibu, Calif., where dense development along the ocean forms a continuous wall, shutting off beach access and water views for all except property owners. To prevent this from happening in Long Beach, L.I., which is experiencing a revival, the city's building code mandates open space along the sides of oceanfront structures by prohibiting the filling of a lot's entire beach frontage.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Great Britain and Ireland A Phaidon Cultural Guide Illustrated; 638 pages; Prentice-Hall $16.95 Greece A Phaidon Cultural Guide Illustrated; 554 pages; Prentice-Hall $16.95 The emphasis in the fine Phaidon Cultural Guide series on the countries of Europe is on cultural. It is by no means limiting because the word encompasses history, philosophy, geography, art, armor, architecture, religion, theater and even the dreams and glories of civilization. These are among the visual and cerebral ''sights'' that travelers find last longest in memory. In this colorful series, one sees the paintings in museums head-on, without the crowds in front, and the landscapes and monuments, shining in splendor under perennial blue skies that are not always there for visitors and their cameras.

title: THE CAT AND I: SISTERS OF A SORT
description: MY black and white cat, 9 inches high, is about 11 years old.

title: THE BEAR WATCHERS MAKE A BULLISH CASE
description: NERVOUSNESS and pessimism seem to have become dominant states of mind in the stock market, and the gloom is encouraging some analysts who closely watch investor psychology to hope that a bottom may be near.

title: HOUSTON BALLE: GROWING FAST AND FLOURISHING
description: ''This is a good time for audiences to step on our bandwagon,'' says the artistic director of the Houston Ballet, Ben Stevenson. ''It's not just that we progressed since we were last in New York four years ago; we're ready for a new phase.''

title: STATE IS SEEKING ''HOME-GROWN'' POET
description: A SEARCH will soon get under way to find ''the finest poet in the land'' - or at least in the state.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

THE HARTFORDS
description: Once, the Tudor-style mansion was the site of a nine-hole golf course, a blacksmith shop, a riding ring and a pond filled with trout fed on shredded meat. Now the former home of John Augustine Hartford, son of George Huntington Hartford, founder of A.&P.;, serves as the administration building of Westchester Community College in Valhalla. But through Nov. 14, the grand house will once again be filled with artifacts and memorabilia of the family and the famous supermarket chain.

title: MOVIES DON'T ALWAYS LUMINATE THE ART OF FILM
description: Though film making appears to be the most public of the arts, and the most collaborative, it is no less private and personal than any of the others, which is one of the reasons why on-set documentaries about the production of a film tend to be about as revealing as fan magazine interviews, which, essentially, they are. Potentially far more rewarding are documentaries with or about film makers - at least they are if the people who make the documentaries are up to the standards of the artists whose work they are examining.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Oct. 13, 1985 Fiction

title:
ANTIQUES;

4 EXHIBITS REVEAL STATE'S PAST
description: FOUR new exhibits planned to recapture scenes from life in Connecticut from the Puritan 17th century through the years of 19th-century Victorian Hartford will open with a reception Wednesday evening at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

title: TOLLBOOTHS' CLOSING ENDS JOBS
description: WILLIAM ROLAND recalled getting medical help for motorists with chest pains, and being greeted with friendly ''good mornings.'' He also remembered people dumping garbage in automatic toll baskets.

title: MEDICAL INSURANCE: HIGH COSTS IN NEW YORK
description: Malpractice insurance is consuming about 10 percent of the average New York physician's gross income, leaving the doctor with an annual net income of about $95,000, according to the State Medical Society.

title: ONCE AGAIN, OLIVER PREVAILS
description: They had faced each other just three days earlier, and Al Oliver had prevailed with a dramatic single in the 10th inning. Now, they stood on the field again, Dan Quisenberry on the pitcher's mound at Royals Stadium and Oliver at the plate.

title: RACE TO NEW YORK TO START TODAY
description: Mike Birch lives a glamorous life by most standards, traveling round the world entering one international yacht race after another. But the job, if one can call it that, takes its toll. For example, Birch, a 53-year-old Canadian by birth, doesn't know where to call home these days. For the last few years it was England and then France, where his boat was docked most recently. Now his plans call for a trip to New York.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: KING BIDGOOD'S IN THE BATHTUB By Audrey Wood. Illustrated by Don Wood. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8) AUDREY and Don Wood seem to enjoy their work. In their book ''The Napping House'' and in this latest creation they express an exuberance that is quite infectious. ''King Bidgood's in the Bathtub'' is a short farce about a Renaissance King who one day refuses to leave his bathtub. Members of his royal staff (including the Queen) attempt to persuade him to perform his kingly duties. One by one they fail. As this dilemma builds to a tumultuous and bubbly climax, a clever Page, in a surprise gesture, finds an apt solution.

title: Up From Rock Bottom
description: A week ago, I thought the Reagan policy toward terrorism had sunk to rock bottom. In a display of moral cowardice and legal ineptitude, our State Department enabled the U.N. to brand Israel an ''aggressor'' - because Israel had the will and means to strike back at the P.L.O. terrorism center in Tunisia.

title: NEW JERSEY CROSS TALK
description: Two weeks after his company won a $6.5 million state contract without competitive bidding, a partner in an accounting firm said last week, a New Jersey official suggested that it would be ''good business'' to buy tickets to the annual Governor's Ball. The executive, William J. Driscoll of Price Waterhouse, said he took the advice and bought 30 tickets at a cost of $15,000.

title: Tickets on Sale For Joffrey Season
description: Tickets are now on sale for the Joffrey Ballet's fall season at City Center, where the company will perform from Oct. 22 to Nov. 10. Three premieres and three revivals will be the highlights of a repertory that includes 19 ballets by 9 choreographers.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Unpredictable Consumers ''Never before have economists been so uncertain,'' says Robert J. Eggert. When his forecasting concern, Eggert Economic Enterprises of Sedona, Ariz., polled 51 leading economists this month, the average forecast for the third quarter was a 3.1 percent rise in real gross national product at an annual rate. But the average hides an unusually wide range.

title: SAILING AWAY
description: To the Editor: With regard to the letter from a New Jersey reader (Letters, travel, Aug. 4) concerning sailing resorts, I believe that our Cape Cod waterfront inn has one of the most complete sailing programs anywhere. Wequassett inn, on Cape Cod, is on Pleasant Bay, the ''sea behind the dunes,'' which recently was the site of the National Daysailer Championships and is well-known for its sailing conditions.

title: ISTANBUL
description: The Bosporus continues to flow between green hills studded with mansions, separating not only the halves of a city but also two continents. This gives, as it has done for generations of travelers on its powerful currents, an altogether exceptional sense of immersion in the civilizations that have crossed back and forth between Europe and Asia, altering and enriching one another.

title: Ruth Cheney Streeter to Wed
description: A January wedding is planned by Ruth Cheney Streeter, a documentary producer for CBS News in New York, and John Brimelow, a director of international research at Keane Securities, a New York Stock Exchange member firm. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Streeter of New York and Darien, Conn., parents of the future bride. Mr. Brimelow is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Brimelow of Birkenhead, Merseyside, England.

title: Nancy E. Cohen Becomes Bride Of Marc Roberts
description: Nancy Ellen Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman G. Cohen of West Palm Beach, Fla., was married last evening to Marc Roberts, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Roberts of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Rabbi Joshua Haberman officiated at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington.

title: PAIRS IN BLUE AND GRAY
description: AMERICAN FALLS By John Calvin Batchelor. Illustrated. 570 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: ALBANY AUDIT FAULTS STATE U. ON SABBATICALS
description: The State University of New York's sabbatical leave program and financial controls at one of its colleges in Syracuse have been criticized in audits issued by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: Anne Fitzpatrick Becomes a Bride
description: Anne Tower Fitzpatrick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Fitzpatrick of Summit, N.J., was married at Christ Church there yesterday to David Charles Hargrave, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Hargrave of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Allen Tinker, senior minister of the church, performed the interdenominational ceremony.

title: NEW YORKERS
description: I T'S true that some people consider them strange, even eccentric. But they don't care. Their position is that if other people want to run around constantly searching and shopping, let them. They know better. When they see something they like, they not only grab it, they grab them. They are the men and women who buy in quantity when they find a style they like.

title: John Meegan Married To Caroline Jane Smith
description: Caroline Jane Smith, a second vice president with the Chase Manhattan Bank, and John Edward Meegan, a financial consultant with Shearson Lehman Brothers, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Lourdes in Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Gerald Lewis performed the ceremony.

title: IT'S A BAD TIME TO ABANDON SUPPORTS
description: AS Congress prepares a new farm bill, critics of our farm programs are as plentiful as the nation's corn crop. Farm income is so low that hundreds of thousands of farmers face financial doom, the strong prey on the weak and fragile land is abused. Many people understandably wonder if these results justify farm programs expected to cost $38.8 billion over the next three years.

title: ONCE FIT FOR A KING AND NOW FIT FOR PICASSO
description: Anyone who has lately walked the corridors of one or more of the grander hotels of the Western world is likely to have heard from time to time a mysterious thudding. This is the sound of eminent men and women banging their heads together in the course of a round-the-world search for the ideal architect, the predestined one-and-only who will design their upcoming major museum.

title: PROSECUTOR RACES: ISSUES VS. POLITICS
description: ALTHOUGH Nassau County District Attorney Denis E. Dillon, a Democrat on heavily Republican Long Island, is unopposed for a third term, his Republican neighbor, Suffolk County District Attorney Patrick Henry, faces a Democratic challenge in his bid for a third term.

title:
REGIONAL JOB ROUNDUP;

FAR WEST
description: LAST year's brisk rise in employment for most job sectors in the West has eased off to a more gradual improvement for industries, with the service- and technology-related fields continuing the strong expansion they have enjoyed over the last few years. Unemployment rates in California, Arizona and Nevada, which last year dropped to pre-recession levels, have generally remained low, and state labor officials say the increase in the number of jobs in the three states indicates the general good health of the labor market.

title: AS THR COMPUTER SPREADS, CONSULTANTS SURE TO FOLLOW
description: ANDREW ANDRETA wanted to make more money than the $25,000 a year he earned as a senior systems analyst at the American Can Company. After evaluating his skills and marketability, he made the difficult decision to give up the security of his staff job and pursue a career as an independent computer consultant. The decision turned out to be a profitable one for Mr. Andreta. ''In my first year as an independent consultant,'' he said, ''I doubled my salary.''

title: OFFICER CHARGED IN FATAL HIT RUN IS SEIZED AGAIN
description: A police sergeant charged in a fatal hit-and-run accident on Park Avenue last March was arrested in Westchester County early yesterday and charged with drunken driving.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;

SPRING'S CONTOURS IN PARIS
description: HIPS ARE HERE, OR WILL BE NEXT SPRING. YVES Saint Laurent talks of ''capturing'' them - he describes his new silhouette as ''tight.'' For Karl Lagerfeld, both in his own collection and his designs for Chanel, the key words are ''body molding.'' Sonia Rykiel and Claude Montana call their collections ''clinging.'' Adds Rykiel, ''very, very.'' And so it goes this week, as Paris designers unveil their new ready-to-wear collections for spring and summer.

title: MORE CUBANS ARE UNWELCOME
description: Fidel Castro impressed some Americans who saw him early this year as being ''in a new mood for accommodation,'' according to one Congressman. But far from looking for opportunities to warm the diplomatic atmosphere, Cuba and the United States have been taking pot shots at one another.

title: DANCE: 'HUGGINGS' BY ROBERT SMALL
description: R OBERT SMALL called his new dance ''Huggings and Hangings,'' and the neat apposition of that title was reflected in the piece, performed on Friday at St. Mark's Church. Approach-withdrawal was the order of the evening, evenly apportioned and wrought with deadening care to a coolly cacophonous score by Ron Anderson.

title: WHEN WALKING PAPERSLEAD TO COURT
description: Can a defense manufacturer discharge a worker who marches in a peaceful demonstration protesting one of its war-fighting products? Must an employer warn a worker that his job is in jeopardy before dismissing him?

title: Deborah Lee Berliner To Wed David Roberts
description: Deborah Lee Berliner, who is with the foreign exchange department at Banco Di Roma in New York, and David Nathan Roberts, an associate in the corporate finance department of L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, plan to be married Nov. 9.

title: A 'SPRING' CHORE BETTER DONE IN FALL
description: ALTHOUGH spring would seem to be the most sensible time to give your aluminum outdoor furniture an annual sprucing up, more often than not this really does not happen. When spring arrives after a long, dreary winter, most homeowners get so busy with other chores -gardening, painting, landscaping and so on -that they do not have time to spend on their outdoor furniture. Instead, they pull the furniture out of the garage and simply dust it off or wash it before they start using it.

title: A PAINFUL NEW RULING ON ISRAELI BONDS
description: Below are answers to recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance Column. Q. I've loyally purchased Israeli bonds for years, even though they pay only 4 percent interest. But I've just heard that because of a tax law change, I may owe taxes on bond interest income I've never received. Can this be possible? A. Surprisingly, yes. The reason: a provision in the 1984 tax act that was designed to crack down on interest-free loans from parents to children and from closely held corporations to major stockholders. Congress felt such loans were a tax-avoidance device, and decided that a market rate of interest should be imputed to them.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on page 1 of the Travel section last Sunday incorrectly described a sculpture in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The god depicted was Shiva.

title: Burn Center Support
description: Few witness more of the devastation that fire is capable of inflicting on the human body (or see more of the horror of severe burn injuries) than firefighters do (''Saving Burn Victims,'' by Douglas Hand, Sept. 15). And no one supports the Burn Center at New York Hospital more than firefighters do.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

CHILDREN AND SEX
description: The theme of the Oct. 26 Y.W.C.A. Family Life Education Conference - ''Let Them Know Before You Let Them Go'' - is particularly relevant in light of the growing number of teen-age pregnancies, according to Mary Alice Warner, chairman of the Y.W.C.A. public-affairs committee and one of the coordinators of the conference.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RELUCTANT FAREWELL. By Andrew Nagorski. (New Republic/Holt, $16.95.) Before taking up his Newsweek assignment to Moscow, Andrew Nagorski talked to some of the reigning experts and was surprised, he says, by the dearth of empirical evidence for their theories about the Soviet Union.

title: WOOD CHIPS GENERATE ELECTRICITY AND DEBATE
description: When a ''moral equivalent of war'' was declared on the energy crisis in 1978 by President Carter, gasoline prices were soaring and sales of woodstoves were booming in northern New England.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BLOODCURDLERS AT WORK When the White Plains Library schedules an afternoon of ''Really Scary Stories'' it does not fool around. Parents are advised to leave children under the age of 8 at home today. The staff in the Children's Room warns that the stories, to be told at 2:30 P.M. as an overture to Halloween, are bloodcurdling and that actual human skulls are among the props.

title: THE FROEBEL GIFT TAKES FORM AGAIN
description: ''T HE maplewood blocks are all in my fingers to this day,'' said Frank Lloyd Wright when he was 88 years old. The architect was referring to the elaborate set of children's building blocks designed in 1830 by the German educator Friedrich Froebel, the originator of the kindergarten system. He was among the first educators to recognize that play is the work of the child.

title: PRESCRIPTION FOR THE PEACE PRIZE
description: IF overshadowed by tales of terrorism and retaliation, the award last week of the Nobel Peace Prize nonetheless achieved a full measure of surprise, not the least among its recipients. The International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, founded in December 1980 by Soviet and American doctors, won $224,000 and considerable help in overcoming the neglect it suffers from.

title: SEASON IN FULL SWING
description: Cellar Dance Oct. 16 - The catacomblike cellar beneath St. Paul the Apostle Church on Ninth Avenue at 59th Street will be the unusual setting for a black-tie dinner-dance at the end of a busy evening to benefit the Dwelling Place, a shelter for homeless women. At 6:30 P.M., cocktails at Avery Fisher Hall followed by the American premiere of winners of the International Advertising Film Festival and then on to the 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. party at St. Paul's. Sponsors are the Advertising Women of New York and the Screenvision Cinema Network. Tickets, $35 for reception and screening or $225 to include dinner-dance, from 212-593-1950. Irish Medicine Oct. 16 - Dublin's Rotunda Hospital, for two centuries a leader in the field of teaching obstetrics, gynecology and neonatal pediatrics, will benefit from a black-tie dinner-dance at Tavern on the Green. More then $500,000 has been raised in Ireland for a new teaching center and a group of New York doctors are trying to bring the amount closer to the needed $1 million. Cocktails at 7:30 P.M. followed by dinner and entertainment. Tickets, $150, from 212-807-6896. A Christian Cause Oct. 17 - Founded in 1816, the Women's Bible Society of New York operates children's summer camps and brings a Christian message into homes and institutions. A concert at the Brick Church, 62 East 92d Street, by the New York Grand Opera Singers will benefit the society. Tea follows the 3:30 P.M. performance.

title: Jane R. Wallace and Nathan W. Pearson Jr. Wed
description: Jane R. Wallace, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Franklin Wallace of New York, and Nathan W. Pearson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pearson of Sewickley, Pa., were married yesterday at the Pearson family farm in Ledyard, Conn. Justice of the Peace Edgar J. Wood performed the ceremony.

title: SOUTHEAST
description: IN Atlanta, the economic throne of the New South, the cool air of early fall is crisp with opportunity. It is the common idiom of conversation here, with cab drivers or economists. There is the driver who will tell a new arrival, plucked from the airport baggage line, that he came here from Kenya, and began to drive a cab. Now he owns several in partnership with others, and is starting a little depot business, where cab drivers can stop to have their taxis cleaned and fueled and their stomachs filled with fried chicken before swinging back to the airport to fetch more businessmen.

title: IN PEEKSKILL RACE, FOCUS ON ECONOMY
description: MAYOR Richard E. Jackson Jr., the Republican incumbent and a candidate for re-election, is the first to acknowledge that this city, where he was born 40 years ago, is not all that it could be economically. But Mr. Jackson quickly adds that Peekskill is a ''far cry'' from where it was a few short years ago.

title: BACKROOM POLITICS ENTERS THE TOY SHOP
description: TO cynics, politics has always been a dirty little game played by the greedy and the ambitious. Now, for $15, it's a game anyone can play.

title: DISPUTE OVER EAST RIVER ESPLANADE RESOLVED
description: The city and the developer Harry Macklowe have resolved a dispute over the extent of his obligation to make improvements to the East River esplanade, both sides said yesterday.

title: TRUFFLES AND FLOURISHES
description: It is in fall that the New Year starts in Europe. Vacationers return to their homes after the summer holidays and take full possession of their cities' streets and squares. Life for most takes a new turn: for students, teachers and parents, schools and universities reopen to a new year; for others, fresh projects and programs are launched. Parliaments reassemble; the political season spins off. Next year's novelties and trends make their first appearance.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

'MOM, I'LL SEE YOU TOMORROW'
description: MY electric clothes dryer is broken and the service man won't get to me for three days. As I stood in the backyard hanging my clothes on a rope that I had attached from the maple tree to the oak tree, my thoughts drifted back to my mother.

title: VARIETIES OF CONTEMPT
description: MAN DESCENDING Selected Stories. By Guy Vanderhaeghe. 230 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. Paper, $7.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AT HER AGE. By Marian Novick. (Scribner's, $15.95.) Much of the charm of Marian Novick's first novel belongs to New York City, whose landmarks play so prominent a role in her heroine's story.

title: JOBS IN INSURANCE NOW OFFER A PREMIUM
description: WHILE a senior in college, Alan Hobbs knew that he wanted to be an actuary so he wrote to a number of insurance companies seeking employment. When the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company offered him a job six years ago at its Milwaukee headquarters, he happily accepted it.

title: Fernando A. Lacayo Jr. Married to Miss Muller
description: Katherine Davidson Muller and Fernando Alfredo Lacayo Jr. were married yesterday at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Frederick G. Hill, an Episcopal priest, and Msgr.

title: GROUP 'MARKETING' THE HARD TO PLACE
description: ''GO AHEAD, make my life,'' reads the caption on a poster showing a pensive child. The poster was developed recently by Greenstone and Rabasca, a public relations agency based in Melville, for the Long Island Coalition for Adoption of Children with Special Needs.

title: Mary Reynolds Is Wed To Dr. Richard L. Page
description: Mary Jean Reynolds, a daughter of Grace Blue Reynolds of Troy, N.C., and the late Hubert Alderman Reynolds, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Leighton Page, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ellis Batten Page of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Marion Parker, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony in which Brother Martin Curtin, a Capuchin friar, participated, at the First Baptist Church in Troy.

title: To the Edge Of the Universe
description: While Darwinists wallow in primeval soup and creationists claim supreme intervention, cosmologists have now taken a refreshing break from the big-bang/steady-state debate to indulge in a bit of cosmic hairsplitting: Is the universe open or closed? (''To the Edge of the Universe: The New Age of Astronomy,'' by John Noble Wilford, Sept. 15.) Does intergalactic space extend to infinity or do boundaries mark its final limits at some inscrutably distant point? And if so, what lies beyond the ''edge''? In fact, what is ''space''? Is it a circumstantial realm with no intrinsic dimension, no reality of its own? Does it prevail solely as a byproduct of human consciousness, just as time, which is seen as ''passing,'' stays where (when) it is?

title: RIDES WITH THE REVENOOER
description: MOONSHINE A Life in Pursuit of White Liquor. By Alec Wilkinson. 153 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE TIGER. By Lisa St Aubin de Teran. (Franklin Watts, $16.95.) The third novel by this prize-winning young British author is her most ambitious and most imaginative. Like her first book, ''Keepers of the House'' (first published in the United States as ''The Long Way Home''), ''The Tiger'' unfolds against the decay and drought of an unforgiving Venezuelan landscape. But whereas ''Keepers'' and its successor, ''The Slow Train to Milan,'' dealt with a young Englishwoman married to a Venezuelan (as the author once was), ''The Tiger'' partakes less of autobiography and more of the mysticism and legend that are popular symbols of South America. Its protagonist, a German family scion born in 1911 and known simply as Lucien, grows up under the tutelage of his grandmother, Misia Schmutter, a despot who rules her Venezuelan estate as if she were a spider who spins a web not so much for killing (although she does this too) but for the fascination of power. She molds Lucien to her will, and after dying becomes a supernatural presence clinging to his back like the predatory tiger the boy once killed. But while her creed seems vaguely fascist, it is transmuted by Lucien's somewhat gentler spirit into a kind of existential obsession with pure action. This is, in fact, a story of obsession: Misia's for order and the will; Lucien's for architecture, gardens and gambling, and those of other characters, whose feelings range from love to bitterness.

title: Driving to Work: Other Views
description: Irene Barrett in ''Driving to Work: One Tough Job'' [Opinion Page] raises the lament of many who find themselves at the mercy of seemingly capricious road repairers. The torn-up roadway, detour or lanes closed for resurfacing are not a Long Island phenomenon - they exist throughout the country, but in the Northeast and other established urban areas, the age of the infrastructure makes the commuter's penance more severe.

title:
GARDENING;

NOW IS THE TIME TO PLANT SPRING BULBS
description: THE mere mention now of spring is enough to conjure up visions of drifts of flowering bulbs spread across the landscape. If those visions are to come true in your garden, this is the time to plant the bulbs, unless they are already in place from previous years' plantings. Even so, no garden is so full of spring bulbs that it does not have room for a few more.

title: IN WHITE PLAINS, GROWTH IS DEBATED
description: IN the 10 years Alfred Del Vecchio has served as Mayor of White Plains, the city has experienced a remarkable building boom that transformed it from a tired and slightly run-down county seat to a major office and commerical complex for Westchester and surrounding Rockland and Fairfield Counties.

title: CASTLE COMBE
description: The recent article on Bath (Travel, Aug. 18) delighted us. My husband and I were stationed at R.A.F. Uxbridgbe, near London from 1979 to 1982, and we went back for a visit in the fall of 1983.

title: To the Edge Of the Universe
description: Following a survey of current thought and techniques involved in the search for extraterrestrial life, Richard Flaste writes, in reference to the sought-for signal, that ''much of current thought says it will be the signal of a benign rather than a malevolent civilization.''(''Listening for Life Among the Stars,'' Sept. 15.)

title: Church-State Separators
description: To the Editor:

title: Books From The Times
description: THE BEST BUYS IN COLLEGE EDUCATION. By Edward B. Fiske and Joseph M. Michalak.

title: TWO KNICKS HURT, EWING FOULS OUT IN LOSS TO ROCKETS
description: The Knicks, already facing the possibility of the extended absence of Bernard King and the absence for a few weeks of Bill Cartwright, were stung by two more injuries tonight.

title: VICTORIANA COMING INTO ITS OWN
description: HER HOME in New Canaan is featured on the cover of this month's Connecticut magazine. Her stature in historic preservation has long been recognized in her home state with a number of responsible positions and awards, and she is listed in the ninth edition of Who's Who of American Women.

title: 200 UNEASY YEARS
description: THE PRESS AND THE PRESIDENCY From George Washington to Ronald Reagan. By John Tebbel and Sarah Miles Watts. 583 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: DAY BY DAY IN THE MEDITERRANEAN
description: Monday, Oct. 7 rrThe Achille Lauro, an Italian cruise ship carrying 400 passengers, is seized between Alexandria and Port Said, off the Egyptian coast, by four Arab gunmen who threaten to shoot their hostages unless Israel releases 50 Palestinian prisoners. Tuesday rrAfter steaming toward Syria and then toward Cyprus, the Achille Lauro drops anchor off Port Said, where the hijackers begin negotiating with Egyptian authorities. There are reports that one or more passengers have been killed. Wednesday rrThe hijackers surrender the ship and themselves.

title: PENN EDGES BROWN ON LATE FIELD GOAL
description: Penn's winning streak in the Ivy League continued today because a newcomer and a kicker who quit varsity football two years ago made big plays near the end of the game as the Quakers beat Brown, 17-14.

title: Barbara Lanahan Wed in Maryland
description: The marriage of Barbara Lake Lanahan, a vice president of the Maryland National Bank in Greenbelt, to James George Mauro Jr., associate general counsel of the International Union of Electrical Workers, A.F.L.-C.I.O., in Washington, took place yesterday in Ruxton, Md. The Rev. John Powell performed the Protestant ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Wallace Lanahan Jr.

title: Ruth Cobrinik, Lawyer, Weds
description: Ruth Cobrinik, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Cobrinik of New York, and Peter Schuyler Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Williams of Short Hills, N.J., and Bridgehampton, L.I., were married yesterday. Mayor Peter Palmer of Bernardsville, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Somerset Hills Country Club.

title: Surgery for Salazar
description: The future of Luis Salazar, the Chicago White Sox infielder-outfielder, was ''undetermined'' after he underwent surgery on his left knee. According to Tim Clodjeaux, a team spokesman, Salazar's knee will be put in a brace for two months, after which he faces a long period of rehabilitation. Salazar, who hit .245 with 10 homers and 45 runs batted in, injured the knee two weeks ago fielding a grounder in a game against the California Angels in Anaheim, Calif. . . . Meanwhile, the Minnesota Twins have formally released John Castino, who spent last season and most of the 1984 season on the injured reserve list with back problems.

title:
ART;

MAKING CLOTH THE FABRIC OF ART
description: ALTHOUGH cloth, in the form of cotton or linen canvas, has been a traditional art material for centuries, its role as the support for paintings forces it literally into the background. When fabric does assume a primary role in creativity, it is more often in the fields of fashion and decoration than in fine art.

title: Elizabeth Bradford Rogow Wed to Nathaniel C. Nash
description: Elizabeth Bradford Rogow, until recently the supervisor of an English language program for children in Cali, Colombia, and Nathaniel Cushing Nash, an economics correspondent for The New York Times in Washington, were married in New York yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. The Rev. Calvin Burrows of the New Testament Missionary Fellowship officiated.

title: O.A.S. Court Is More Than a Rights Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S LOBBYISTS
description: SUDDENLY, SOUTH Africa is on the minds of Americans. Only a year ago an issue that was primarily the concern of foreign policy specialists, college activists and a few corporate executives, the crisis of the apartheid system is now a major story on network television news, a cover subject for the news magazines, and a regular presence on the front page of most American newspapers.

title: IN APARTHEID'S GRIP
description: MOVE YOUR SHADOW South Africa, Black and White. By Joseph Lelyveld. 390 pp. New York: Times Books. $18.95.

title: NEW CASSETTES: SIMMERING DRAMA TO SOULFUL ROCK
description: Red Dust Starring Clark Gable, Jean Harlow, Mary Astor and Gene Raymond; directed by Victor Fleming, 1932 MGM/UA Home Video 83 minutes. $24.95 This is a briskly engrossing drama of sexual tensions on an Indonesian rubber plantation.

title: THE PHOTOGRAPHER ROBERT CAPA IS FOCUS OF EXHIBITION AND 2 BOOKS
description: A T the International Center of Photography's current exhibition of Robert Capa photographs, an elegantly attired, gray-haired gentleman stopped in front of a black-and-white picture of a platoon of riflemen dug in at El Guettar during the Tunisian campaign in 1943. He peered closely at the helmeted figures in the desert landscape.

title: 2 Held on Cocaine Charges
description: Two city residents have been arrested on charges of supplying cocaine to employees at the main post office here. Hazel Morrison, 40 years old, and William Ballard, 49, were held Thursday on $150,000 bail and $100,000 bail after their arrest Monday night at Miss Morrison's home, said Deputy District Attorney Roy DeCaro Early last month, nine postal workers were arrested on drug charges after a loansharking investigation of Mr. Ballard turned up evidence of drug dealing, Mr. DeCaro said. The nine are free on bail.

title: BEYOND A TRENCH COAT IMAGE
description: SOMEONE was dead. And his family wanted to know why.

title: WIN CAPTURES THE MAN O'WAR
description: Win, the popular and gritty New York-bred gelding, rallied from off the pace and wore down two blueblooded European imports to win the $306,000 Man o'War Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: India: A Guide for the Quality-Conscious Traveler By Louise Nicholson 270 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press $19.95 Few visitors are neutral about India. They are either captivated by the contrasts in scenery, people and ways of life or repelled by the intense heat that blankets much of the country much of the year or by the crowds and noise in the cities, the dust and dirt, the political vituperation and the pervasive poverty. Some first-time visitors vow never to return, but others eagerly await opportunities to see India again and again and again.

title: E.P.A. PLANS A CAMPAIGN TO FIGHT RADON
description: Nature is to blame for radon, a cancer-causing gas produced by the decay of uranium in the ground. But many members of Congress, particularly those who represent areas where radon is a problem, say someone has to take the initiative for protecting the residents of the roughly one million homes that may have been contaminated by the odorless, colorless gas.

title: A MATTER OF DEGREE
description: It has come to be a tradition that whenever Harvard, the nation's oldest university, clicks off another 50 years, the President of the United States is asked to join in the festivities, which are usually peaceable affairs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was on hand for the 300th anniversary in 1936, and Grover Cleveland helped ring in the 250th, in 1886.

title: Catherine Howard Weds
description: Catherine Pratt Howard, a daughter of Carol Hamann Howard of Brooklyn Heights and George Pratt Howard of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Richard Drudi 3d, a son of Mary Jane Hilliker of East Haddam, Conn., and Mr. Drudi Jr. of Winter Park, Fla.

title: Polly Bennett, a Designer of Jewelry, To Wed Clifton Truman Daniel in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. K. K. Grubbs of Winston-Salem, N.C., of the engagement of her daughter Polly Bennett to Clifton Truman Daniel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Clifton Daniel Jr. of New York and a grandson of President Harry S. Truman. A June wedding is planned.

title: PASSAIC MAKING PLANS TO REBUILD
description: PEOPLE who live in this city's Lower Dundee area and public officials are beginning to talk about a phoenix rising from the rubble of the devasting fire that swept the Passaic River waterfront on Labor Day.

title: NOW IS THE SEASON WHEN THE CABBAGE FAMILY IS KING
description: IF you drive into the countryside and go past farms, you may notice that the crops in the fields at this time of year have acquired a steely, gray-green cast. Replacing the lush green of mid-summer's zucchini patches and cornfields are members of the cabbage family with their stiff, rounded leaves framing clusters, bunches and heads of the vegetables.

title:
GARDENING;

NOW IS THE TIME TO PLANT SPRING BULBS
description: THE mere mention now of spring is enough to conjure up visions of drifts of flowering bulbs spread across the landscape. If those visions are to come true in your garden, this is the time to plant the bulbs, unless they are already in place from previous years' plantings. Even so, no garden is so full of spring bulbs that it does not have room for a few more.

title: COUNTY INITIATES BID TO ATTRACT BUSINESS
description: IN an atmosphere of celebration, Westchester officials last week began an ambitious plan to promote economic development in the county, using about $30,000 donated by private corporations already here.

title: COUNTRY HOMES, BRITISH STYLE
description: Taking its lead from the ''Treasure Houses of Britain'' exhibition opening in Washington next month, Christie's auction house will sponsor tours to many of the homes on which the exhibition is based.

title: EX-POWER CHIEF TURNS TO VINICULTURE
description: Three months after stepping down as chairman of the New York State Power Authority, John S. Dyson stood the other day in his vineyard, clipping ripe grapes from the vine as the first commercial harvest started in his new career as a wine maker.

title: FOUR CENTURIES OF TEX ARCANA
description: TEXAS By James A. Michener. Maps. 1,096 pp. New York: Random House. $21.95.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

CONFERENCE ON PAPER MONEY
description: Paper money enthusiasts often are overshadowed by their coin-collecting brethren. The situation will be reversed later this month, when the American Numismatic Society holds a three-day conference on ''America's Currency, 1789-1866.''

title: ART NOUVEAU
description: ''YOU CAN FOOL ALL OF THE PEOPLE ALL THE TIME'' By Art Buchwald. Illustrated by Steve Mendelson. 332 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $16.95. MY aunt Emma called me from Sioux City, Iowa, to ask how Art Buchwald's new book, '' 'You Can Fool All of the People All the Time,' '' was doing in the nation's capital, so I went to a Washington cocktail party to check it out.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MANO A MANO ON THE LAWN EGYPTIAN royalty enjoyed the game over 5,000 years ago, and it has been a sport favored by aristocrats the world over ever since. But perhaps because the United States has no official royalty of its own, lawn bowling has never been that popular in this country.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening.

title: KIM PHILBY AND THE ALBANIAN MISSION
description: BETRAYED By Nicholas Bethell. Illustrated. 206 pp. New York: Times Books. $15.95.

title: SENTIMENTALITY WATERS DOWN A WELL-MEANT MESSAGE
description: Do your own thing, young people were being told in the permissive 1960's. Watch out, parents are people too, they are being warned in the conservative 1980's. That, at least, is the message being spelled out, rather laboriously, in ''Toughlove,'' tonight's ABC Theater presentation at 9 o'clock. Just a few years ago, a TV movie could show - as one starring Martin Sheen did - an overly strict father being taught a lesson when his troublesome teen-age son attempted suicide after Dad decided not to bail him out of jail. Toughness was no solution in those days. Today, apparently, it is becoming almost fashionable, endorsed at press conferences by movie stars like Lee Remick and Bruce Dern, who happen to be the stars of ''Toughlove.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: SIMMERING DRAMA TO SOULFUL ROCK
description: Joe Cocker: Mad Dogs and Englishmen With Joe Cocker, Leon Russell, Claudia Lennear, Rita Coolidge and others; directed by Pierre Adidge RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video 117 minutes. $29.95 Joe Cocker, an Englishman who sings like Ray Charles and twitches distinctively while doing so, had his first American hits in the late 1960's.

title: MASSACHUSETTS IN 10-YEAR TEST OF PROGRAM AGAINST ACID RAIN
description: The effectiveness of protective measures against the industrial precipitation called acid rain will be considered in a 10-year study by the University of Massachusetts that is to begin next Sunday.

title: JERSEY COURT SETS SENTENCING RULES
description: Defendants who engage in a pattern of behavior constituting a series of separate offenses should not be sentenced as if they had committed only a single crime, the New Jersey Supreme Court has ruled unanimously.

title: Congress: Support Your Local Police
description: Congress has a chance to help every police officer in America without spending a cent. All it need do is enact a ban on ''cop killer'' bullets. Pro-gun die-hards stand in the way, but they can be overcome - if protecting police means enough to House Speaker O'Neill and Senate Majority Leader Dole.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HISTORY IN THE AIR Pratt & Whitney Aircraft, one of Hartford's major industries for 60 years, will stage a free air show from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. today.

title: VICTIMS OF REFORM
description: THE DIVORCE REVOLUTION The Unexpected Social and Economic Consequences for Women and Children in America. By Lenore J. Weitzman. 504 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95. ''UNEXPECTED'' is the crucial word in Lenore J. Weitzman's subtitle. It goes along with its mates - ''unintended'' and ''unfortunate'' - to describe the results of the new divorce laws. The laws, which began in 1970 with California's no-fault, no-consent statute and which every state but Illinois and South Dakota have since adopted in some form, were the work of people of good will. These men and women believed they were correcting an outmoded legal code that was degrading and humiliating to all parties involved in the process and often unfair to one party in the outcome. The new laws were intended to reduce accusation and acrimony, to remove marital misconduct (often manufactured) as the necessary grounds for divorce and to base monetary awards on need and ability to pay, rather than treating them as rewards for virtue or punishments for sin.

title: Relievers Honored
description: Dan Quisenberry of the Kansas City Royals and Jeff Reardon of the Montreal Expos have been named winners of the relief pitching awards in the American and National Leagues. The awards are decided on a point basis in which each victory or save counts 2 points, with 1 point subtracted for each relief loss. It was the fourth straight year that Quisenberry has won the award.

title: YALE RALLIES TO WIN
description: Kelly Ryan threw an 8-yard touchdown pass to Mike Stewart with 28 seconds left today to give Yale a 19-15, come-from-behind victory over Holy Cross.

title: DETECTORS: ADVICE OFFERED
description: RADON in the home can be accurately, although not quickly, measured, and experts advise caution in hiring someone to do the tests or in buying a measuring device.

title: MONTENEGRO'S LEGENDS, COVES AND MOUNTAINS
description: From pebbly shores to jagged ranks of mountains, Montenegro fills the eye at every azimuth - some of its vistas almost frightening, such as the plunges of rockface beneath narrow serpentine roads or sudden tornado-like waterspouts sweeping in from the Adriatic.

title: AMIXED VERDICT ON ANONYMOUS JURORS
description: When his lawyer rose in United States District Court in Manhattan last week to defend Paul Castellano against charges of leading a car-theft ring, he presented his opening statement to a jury he knew only by numbers. The presiding judge, Kevin Thomas Duffy, had ordered the names of the seven men and five women concealed, producing an anonymous jury.

title: INNOVATIONS ON A JAPANESE MENU
description: DARUMA OF TOKYO has replaced Suma, but for Great Neck the bottom line remains the same: a dependable Japanese restaurant still occupies the premises.

title: 3 Are Indicted in Death Of Narcotics Informer
description: Three men, including a meat dealer who had been convicted of selling tainted beef in four states, have been indicted on murder charges in the death by shooting of a Federal narcotics informer whose body was found buried behind a shopping center.

title: BAYMEN SEEK TO MOVE JAMAICA BAY CLAMS
description: AS shellfish continue to decline dramatically in New York State waters, Jamaica Bay -which is brimming with shellfish because it has been closed to clammers for half a century on account of pollution - has become a key element in a plan to restock Long Island's clam beds.

title: FOR PERSONNEL, BIGGER ROLE PLUS A FANCIER NAME
description: ONCE relegated to the bottom of the corporate barrel, human resources - the business of managing a company's work force - is gaining in importance. ''It used to be that the people in charge of personnel hired you, fired you and made sure the watermelon and beer was kept cold at the company picnic,'' said Cate Bower, vice president of communications at the American Society for Personnel Administration. ''Now the human-resource field is far more complex and sophisticated.''

title: DEVILS TRIUMPH, 4-1, DESPITE PENALTIES
description: The Devils, playing effectively all over the ice and getting two goals from John MacLean, defeated the Washington Capitals, 4-1, in their home opener tonight.

title: Un-Reasonable
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERBURDENED BY HIS VIRTUE
description: HONORABLE MEN By Louis Auchincloss. 278 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95.

title: STATE TRAINS DISABLED DRIVERS
description: LOUISE AND GEORGE FISHER of Bloomfield own two specially equipped vans that enable them to drive to work. Mrs. Fisher, a quadriplegic with limited use of her arms, commutes to her job with the Xerox Corporation in Hartford, while her husband, a paraplegic, drives to the Cigna Corporation in Bloomfield.

title: Amy W. Troxell Wed To Gregory W. Powell
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday Amy Wentworth Troxell and Gregory Wilcox Powell were married by the Rev. David Earnest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Chase Troxell of Short Hills and her husband is the son of Dr. Kershaw E. Powell of Waterville, Me., and Judith Monroe of Hallowell, Me.

title: 14 OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 14 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: SPECIAL STATE GRANT WINERS SET THEIR ARTS GOALS FOR 1986
description: FOUR New Jersey arts organizations will share $1,142,840 in State Council on the Arts ''Artistic Focus Grants'' for fiscal 1986.

title: 'STARPEACE' LETS YOKO ONO HAVE HER CAKE AND EAT IT
description: Yoko Ono, whose splended new album, ''Starpeace,'' (PolyGram) was released this week, has become a familiar and even admired public figure since the tragic death of her husband, John Lennon. But among rock fans, she is still burdened with her earlier reputation as an abrasive, pretentious and possibly specious conceptual artist, and as the ''pushy'' intruder who is often blamed for the breakup of the Beatles.

title: 'Chief Architect' Of the 1% Case
description: Amid all the comment on the 1 percent kickback case, I am surprised to have seen no mention of the man who was its chief architect: Norman Blankman, president of a group called AWARE (Action Where Action Requires the Electorate).

title: BALANCING THE BUDGET AND POLITICS
description: As Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat, noted, most of the 75 of his colleagues who voted last week for a plan requiring a balanced budget by 1991 had ''overlapping motives.''

title: MEMORIAL MUSEUM TO HONOR STATE POLICE
description: NEAR the front gate of the State Police headquarters here stands a log cabin built in 1934 as a barracks for troopers undergoing recruit training.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DANCING IN THE LIGHT. By Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $17.95.) In the best-selling ''Out on a Limb,'' the Academy Award-winning actress Shirley MacLaine discussed her awakening spirituality.

title: O'CASEY CLASIC AT DREW UNIVERSITY
description: WHETHER or not one cares about the concerns of Sean O'Casey's plays concerning Irish rebellions, the fact is that O'Casey wrote beautifully, lyrically, boisterously and lovingly.

title: U.S. ISSUES WARRANT FOR ONE; HOSTAGES TELL OF 'DEATH LIST';   ACCOUNT OF ORDEAL
description: The hijackers of the Achille Lauro selected a group of Americans and other passengers and then shuffled their passports to compose a ''death list'' of those who would be executed, returning passengers have disclosed.

title: Low Profile, High Praise
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: 'CABARET' MIXTURE DIFFICULT TO GET RIGHT
description: IS there a musical theater aficianado who hasn't dreamed up a season's ideal repertory of revivals? In real life, it isn't so easy. Some musicals are overexposed; others are unfamiliar. Some are durable no matter what - but not all that do-able.

title: OF MINDS, MOTORISTS AND MEALS
description: The debate over the cost of the Seabrook nuclear reactor in New Hampshire has become so bitter that the chairman of the Maine Public Utilities Commission has turned to psychology to explain it.

title: L.I. Man Arrested In Theft of a Bus
description: A man angry about losing his job hit his former employer with a board and then stole a bus to escape, according to the Nassau County police.

title: CITY STARTS TALKS WITH DEVELOPER ON QUEENS PLAN
description: New York City has begun negotiations with a consortium that includes the Zeckendorf Company to build a $100 million development in the heart of Flushing, Queens.

title: Don't Arm the Arabs
description: Despite overwhelming Congressional disapproval - 73 Senators have co-sponsored a resolution opposing the sale of arms to Jordan and 64 have co-signed a letter objecting to the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia -the Administration has proposed a $1.9 billion package of advanced weaponry for immediate sale to Jordan and is seriously considering a similar sale to Saudi Arabia.

title: CONCERT: BEHRENS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: HILDEGARD BEHRENS is an incomplete singer, technically, who by her ability to commit herself to every piece of music she takes in hand consistently manages to persuade the listener that she is a complete artist. Best known for her Wagnerian performances, in which her gleaming high notes and fervent declamation of the text can carry the day, the soprano has been broadening her outlook in recent years. Last season, you may recall, she made a brave try at Tosca with the Metropolitan Opera, a venture that exposed her lack of an Italianate legato, among other vocal necessities. She also gave the Metropolitan a memorably strong and touching Marie in ''Wozzeck,'' an ideal role for her voice and temperament.

title: Palestinian Thanks Rome
description: Mohammed Abbas expressed thanks to Italy today for allowing him and a bodyguard to leave Rome for Belgrade.

title: FOOD INDUSTRY'S BIG MERGERS
description: Mary L. Balestra, a 33-year-old working mother of three who lives in Pelham, N.Y., is aware of Philip Morris Inc.'s recent agreement to buy the General Foods Corporation. She also knows that the nearly $5.8 billion deal is only the latest of many takeovers that have occurred in the food industry in recent years.

title: Conservatively, a Gala
description: The National Conservative Foundation will hold a $1,000-a-ticket gala in Las Vegas Oct. 26, according to a letter from Senator Chic Hecht, Republican of Nevada. Invitations are out to enlist about 200 co-chairmen, each of whom would contribute $10,000 or, for the same price, buy a table for 10.

title: ACCOUNTS OF THE TURNOUT FOR POLISH VOTING VARY
description: The Government announced tonight that more than two-thirds of all eligible voters had cast ballots seven hours before the polling places closed in Poland's first parliamentary election since the Solidarity movement was outlawed.

title: Balloon Implants in Stomach Help Patients to Lose Weight
description: More than 100 obese patients shed an average of nearly 40 pounds over six months by having a balloon implanted in the stomach, according to a report to the American College of Gastroenterology.

title: Soviet Jews Who Meet Gorbachev Exit Criteria
description: To the Editor:

title: MUBARAK REACTION REFLECTS EGYPT'S POLITICAL CLIMATE
description: Diplomats and Egyptian officials said today that President Hosni Mubarak's harsh condemnation of the United States was a response not merely to the American diversion of an Egyptian airliner but also to an American assault on Egyptian pride and dignity.

title: Bridge: Steve Becker Finds Solution In Playing Unusual Contract
description: Unusual contracts may require unusual plays. On the diagramed deal North-South could not consider three no-trump with clubs wide open, so they were forced to choose between a 4-3 fit in one of the major suits and game in diamonds.

title: For Lonnie Smith, Good and Bad Mix
description: All around him, teammates spoke glowingly of Lonnie Smith and of the role he had played on an afternoon of renewed hope for the Kansas City Royals. But Smith seemed distant from everyone else, brushing past reporters and dressing quickly in a room away from the clubhouse. And then he left. Quickly, quietly. The day had not been one of complete triumph for Smith, but his ability to get on base in the first inning and his subsequent steal of third had given the Royals their first run in a 2-0 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays that sent the American League playoffs back to Canada.

title: ESCAPING THE GUILLOTINE
description: His blue cap had been tossed into his locker, but otherwise Dick Howser was still in full uniform as he sat behind the desk in his manager's office. And for one of the few times since the American League championship series started, the Royals' manager was smiling.

title: EMIGRATION WORRIES ISRAEL AS ECONOMY SAGS
description: With the Israeli economy heading into a recession, and with unemployment rising, Government officials say they are concerned that they may be faced with a new wave of emigration, particularly of young people.

title: Irish Are Looking In
description: A dozen members of the Social Democratic and Labor Party of Northern Ireland are spending 10 days in Washington studying American political techniques at the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs.

title: U.S. IS PESSIMISTIC OVER EXTRADITING OFFICIAL OF P.L.O.
description: The Administration virtually gave up hope today of seizing a Palestinian guerrilla leader who fled to Yugoslavia from Rome as the United States sought to extradite him for planning the hijacking of an Italian cruise ship.

title: Weinberger and Geneva
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger strongly believes he should be a leading member of the team President Reagan takes with him to the arms control conference with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva next month, but it is not clear that he will be included.

title: BEARS, 6-0, AFTER BEATING 49ER'S
description: The ''last time'' was never out of their minds. Not before today's game, and certainly not after it.

title: DANCE: BALLET TOUSSAINT HAS DEBUT AT LEHMAN
description: THE Ballet Eddy Toussaint de Montreal, which made its New York debut on Saturday at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, is a likable company of well-trained, attractive young dancers. A pupil of the Lavinia Williams in his native Haiti, Mr. Toussaint founded the company under another name in 1974 in Montreal. The repertory includes works by Oscar Araiz, Salvatore Aiello, Domy Reiter-Soffer and Vassili Sulich, but the Lehman program served as a showcase for Mr. Toussaint's ballet choreography.

title: Shelling of Afghan Town Is Laid to Pakistan
description: The official Kabul radio reported today that Pakistani forces recently shelled the Barikot garrison town in eastern Afghanistan, killing 14 Afghan civilians and wounding 11.

title: Pronounced Speech Improvement If Fiscal Ax Doesn't Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: Grenade Said to Kill 10 At Philippine Cockfight
description: A hand grenade exploded in a crowded cockfighting arena in the southern Philippines today, killing at least 10 people and wounding 39, a church-run radio station said.

title: SOCIALIST PARTY FACTIONS IN FRANCE AGREE ON PLATFORM FOR '86 ELECTION
description: Leaders of France's governing Socialist Party emerged early this morning from an all-night meeting and announced in the predawn gloom that they had agreed on a unified party platform for key legislative elections next year.

title: KARPOV BLUNTS GAMBIT, AND THE PLAYERS DRAW
description: ''So, you're not that great with gambits after all.'' This was the taunt sent by Anatoly Karpov to his challenger, Gary Kasparov, in the 15th game of their world championship chess match in the Tchaikovsky Concert Hall in Moscow on Saturday.

title: ROYALS WIN;   LEG INJURED BY TARPAULIN
description: The first shock of the evening came two hours before game time tonight when the St. Louis Cardinals lost their base-stealing champion, Vince Coleman, in a bizarre accident: His left leg was trapped and bruised under a 1,200-pound tarpaulin cylinder before the fourth game of the National League playoff.

title: FINANCIAL EXECUTIVE PROMOTED AT FORD
description: Allan D. Gilmour has been named an executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company, succeeding Will M. Caldwell, who has announced that he will retire at the end of this year.

title: Shadow on the Summit
description: It is only a matter of words - a Washington word game, you might say. But the players are after very large stakes. If their gambit works, it will sabotage next month's Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting. And they have an even more ambitious goal: to remove all constraints on the nuclear arms race.

title: Fetchick Winner On 63d Birthday
description: Mike Fetchick won his first Senior PGA Tour event on his 63d birthday today, shooting an even-par 72 for a 6-under total of 210 in the $200,000 Hilton Head Seniors Invitational.

title: BELGIAN CENTER-RIGHT GROUP RETAINS MAJORITY IN ELECTION
description: The center-right coalition of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens appeared certain of retaining power after today's Belgian general elections, according to computer projections.

title: AIRLINES SEEK GROWTH THROUGH ACQUISITIONS
description: The nation's airline industry, which has struggled to adapt to deregulation for six years, has entered a new phase by turning to quick growth through acquisition.

title: Catching Up
description: Gordon Wood has reached his special plateau (Scouting, Sept. 26). Mark Ellis's off-tackle plunge with 4 minutes to play on Oct. 4 lifted Brownwood (Tex.)

title: A YEAR AFTER TALKS, SALVADOR PEACE RECEDES
