description: A year ago, Salvadoran leftist guerrillas and President Jose Napoleon Duarte met for the first time in the mountain village of La Palma and raised the hopes of their countrymen that peace might come after five years of civil war.

title: 3 Sri Lanka Soldiers Hurt By Rebel Land Mine
description: Three soldiers were wounded when separatist guerrillas set off a land mine under their jeep in Northern Province today, security officials said.

title: Independence on the Economic Court
description: They are not, like appointments to the Supreme Court, for life, but it's close to that. One of the two men President Reagan has nominated to the Federal Reserve Board could serve until the year 2000, the other until 1994. That semi-permanence defines the board's separation from transient politics, and the basis of its power. One may not consider these to be distinguished choices and yet recognize that most of the talk about them is speculation.

title: THE LAST DAYS OF ILL CHILDREN: BEST AT HOME?
description: Increasingly, children with terminal cancer and, to a lesser extent, those with other incurable cardiac, respiratory and renal illnesses are living out their final days or months at home rather than in a hospital.

title: Unser Edges Son In Phoenix Race
description: Al Unser Sr. beat the fastest field in the history of Phoenix International Raceway today in winning the Dana 150 Indy-car race and moving past his son into the season point lead.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch from Santa Ana, Calif., in some copies yesterday on the investigation of a fatal bombing misstated the name of the group whose office was bombed. It was the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee.

title: Another Fight On Phone Fees
description: IT appears that another telephone deregulation battle on costs is headed for Capitol Hill, and could prove as politically lively as the fight over monthly customer access charges. This one focuses on the extent to which the Government should help low-income Americans keep their telephones in the face of steadily increasing prices for basic local service.

title: O'NEILL, 10-YEAR 'WATCHDOG,' STILL SNAPPING AWAY
description: The shadows are starting to fall around Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. At the end of the Congressional term next year he will retire from the House and complete 10 years as Speaker of the House, the longest political tenure in the nation's history. But he is going out growling.

title: FOLK: SCOTTISH-IRISH BAND
description: TWO countries, two bands and two families are represented in Relativity, the Scottish-Irish folk band that made its New York debut Saturday at the Triplex, 199 Chambers Street. Genealogy aside, the group achieves a fine balance of old and new instruments in traditional and traditionalist songs.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS AGENCY SPLITS IN DEBATE ON NARROWING DEFINITION OF EQUALITY
description: In the two years since it was reconstituted by Congress, the United States Commission on Civil Rights has been deeply split by an internal debate over fundamental principles of civil rights and the meaning of equality.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1985
description: Hostages and Hijackers

title: NEWFOUNDLAND FISHERMEN: NOTHING BUT ILL WINDS
description: With his son Glenn and a half-dozen other sturdy Newfoundlanders, Lester G. Petten used to sail out to catch the cod on the Grand Banks with baited hooks.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Baseball Cardinals vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at St. Louis, Game 5 of the four-of-seven National League Championship series, 3 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 2:50 P.M.) Cross Country 59th Annual Met Intercollegiate Championships, at Van Cortlandt Park, women's 5 K, 3.1 miles at 3 P.M. and men's varsity 5 miles at 3:30 P.M. Fairleigh Dickinson has won the men's varsity for the past three years, and has five top runners from East Africa again this year, led by Steven Kogo. Iona has five top runners from Ireland, led by Kieran Stack, who finished second in this race last year. They are expected to give the Knights the strongest battle for the team title. The meet record of 24:05.4 was set by Jama Aden of Fairleigh Dickinson in 1983. In the inaugural women's competition, it looks like a four-team race among Rutgers, St. John, Fordham and Manhattan. Desiree Scott, a Rutgers senior from White Plains High School, should lead the pack. Fordham has Patti Nelson, an outstanding freshman from Richmond Hill High School in Queens. Football Jets vs. Miami Dolphins, at Giants Stadium. A battle for first place in the American Conference's Eastern Division. The Jets and the Dolphins are tied with 4-1 records. Joe Namath, the color commentator for ABC-TV, wilhave his No. 12 Jets' number retired at halftime ceremonies. Hugh Green, an all-pro linebacker and a teammate of Dan Marino at Pitt, has been acquired by the Dolphins from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to bolster the defense.

title: MCGRATH WOULD LIMIT USE OF FEMALE OFFICERS
description: Diane McGrath, the Republican candidate for Mayor of New York, proposed yesterday that women on the police force be barred from street patrols and that the Police Department establish height and weight standards for officers.

title: COLGATE PROVES TOUGH TO STOP
description: Steve Calabria was so dominant in as Colgate's quarterback, setting 19 school passing records, that Tom Burgess, his understudy, seldom got into games. Now, as co-captain in his senior season and with Calabria graduated, Burgess is playing and enjoying every moment.

title: OFFICER DRAGGED 500 FEET BY CAR
description: A police officer was injured yesterday when he was dragged 500 feet by an automobile in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, a police spokesman said.

title: Pronounced Speech Improvement If Fiscal Ax Doesn't Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: COWBOYS WIN AS DORSETT RUNS BY 10,000
description: Tony Dorsett today became the sixth player in National Football League history to rush for 10,000 yards as the Dallas Cowboys beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 27-13.

title: Treasury Head Defends Plan for Ending Deficit
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker said today that legislation approved by the Senate last week could lead to a balanced budget in five years without a tax increase.

title: EFFORTS UNDER WAY TO PLUG GAPS IN LAW PERMITTING USE OF LOSTS AS HOMES
description: Like thousands of other artists seeking low rent and lots of workspace, Barry Feuerstein moved illegally into an industrial loft several years ago.

title: The Hazardous Workplace
description: For some years now, the Surgeon General of the United States has issued an annual report on smoking and health, usually in the spring.

title: Shanker Supports U.S.Bilingual Plan
description: Albert Shanker, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, said yesterday that he supported Secretary of Education William J. Bennett's call for local autonomy and more flexibility in bilingual-education programs.

title: Still a Success
description: Inexplicably, the Government of Italy has released Mohammed Abbas, one of the major figures in international terrorism, apparently in violation of its extradition treaty with the U.S. and despite Prime Minister Craxi's personal pledge to President Reagan that Mr. Abbas would be held with the hijackers of the Achille Lauro.

title: Bicycle Brunch
description: Lured out of bed by the promise of warm knishes and the ''urban archeology of the Jews in New York,'' 20 cyclists set forth from Columbus Circle early one recent morning to explore Jewish neighborhoods.

title: Martin's Job May Be in Perilous Position
description: Billy Martin's fourth tenure as Yankee manager moved perilously close to termination today when George Steinbrenner said he was assigning the decision on next season's manager to Clyde King and Woody Woodward, the club's top two baseball executives.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1985
description: Companies

title: RUSSIAN-CHINESE SKIRMISH: TALE OF 2 TEA ROOMS
description: A new skirmish has broken out between the Russians and the Chinese. This time, however, the fight is over food, and the battle front is slightly to the left - and right - of Carnegie Hall.

title: ''It's Vince Coleman!''
description: IT happened so fast. Suddenly someone was screaming in pain. Suddenly the ballplayers, coming off the field during batting practice since it had just begun to rain, turned to see where the cries were coming from. Quickly they rushed to the scene, along the first-base line.

title: CONFLICTING CURRENTS
description: The Reagan Administration's frustration over the failure of Egypt, Italy and Yugoslavia to follow Washington's lead in the aftermath of the Achille Lauro affair has underscored the difficulty of trying to persuade other nations to join in actions that they regard as contrary to their interests.

title: Dogs Aiding in Search At Puerto Rico Site
description: Specially trained dogs that had been searching for people and bodies buried in a mud slide last Monday near Ponce were taken to another site today to help search for bodies where a bridge collapsed in the same heavy rains.

title: Felons in a Survey Say They Get Guns Illegally
description: Only about one in five convicted felons said they obtained their guns through legitimate channels such as retail stores, according to a Justice Department study released today.

title: U.S. REPORTED TO HAVE EVIDENCE LINKING P.L.O. AIDE TO HIJACKING
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they had transcripts of radio conversations that took place during the hijacking of an Italian cruise ship between the hijackers and a Palestinian guerrilla leader who was later freed by the Italian Government.

title: ADJUSTING AFTER YEARS ABROAD
description: IT usually happens about a month after the American who has been working abroad for several years returns to the United States. He and his family fall prey to a curious affliction: culture shock.

title: ITALIANS ATTEMPT TO REASSURE U.S.
description: The Government of Prime Minister Bettino Craxi struggled today to limit the damage to its relationship with the United States by portraying its decision to release a Palestinian leader, against Washington's wishes, as necessary to avert a collapse of its ties with the Arab world.

title: ARAB PAPERS ASSERT U.S. EMBARRASSED ITS FRIENDS
description: The United States interception of an Egyptian airliner carrying the four Palestinian hijackers of the Achille Lauro cruise ship has angered Washington's conservative allies in the Arab world, according to newspapers in the region.

title: CITY OPERA: 'I PURITANI' CAST CHANGES
description: FOR a brief fall reprise of Bellini's ''I Puritani,'' which was revived a few months back as part of the ''Bel Canto Festival,'' the New York City Opera has assembled a group of unusually fine voices. Two of them were new at Saturday's matinee performance: the tenor John Aler made his first appearance of the season, and the Greek soprano Jenny Drivala made her company debut as Elvira.

title: OUTSIDE ADVICE HELPS PATERNO
description: Bo Schembechler opened the wooden box in his office last week and displayed a Michigan blue vase sent to him as a gift by a college football coach and admirer in Japan. The coach also enclosed an article from a Japanese newspaper, listing the active major college coaches with the best records. Schembechler was first and Joe Paterno of Penn State, third. Second on the list was Mikio Shintake Nihon, whose teams have never been ranked by the wire services or invited to a bowl game.

title: THEATER: 'YOURS, ANNE' STAGED AT PLAYHOUSE 91
description: YOU don't have to fear the worst about ''Yours, Anne,'' the new musical adapted from Anne Frank's diary. The show at Playhouse 91 is not, at least, a Mel Brooks burlesque along the lines of ''Springtime for Hitler.'' Then again, after about 20 minutes of this soporific evening, you may find yourself wishing that it were. Always tasteful and just as consistently inert, ''Yours, Anne'' misrepresents the spirit of Anne Frank as woefully as any vulgar song-and-dance treatment might.

title: PALESTINIAN SAYS HIJACKERS TOLD HIM THEY DIDN'T KILL ANYONE
description: Mohammed Abbas, the Palestinian leader wanted by the Reagan Administration on charges of organizing the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro, said today that the hijackers had told him they did not kill anyone.

title: ITALIAN-AMERICANS URGED TO CREATE CLOSE NEW LINKS TO ITALY
description: Italians and Italian-Americans should recognize the strength and depth of their shared heritage and should create attitudes and organizations that would closely link the two groups culturally and politically, speakers at a conference here urged this weekend.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TAX DATA ON THOSE RECEIVING U.S. AID
description: The Reagan Administration plans to ask Congress for the legal authority to expand greatly the Government's use of confidential tax data and give Federal agencies direct access to information about the private insurance coverage of anyone in the United States.

title: REWRITING TAX CODE: SLOW GOING
description: On Sept. 8, after the members of his House Ways and Means Committee returned from a weekend retreat to prepare for drafting tax-revision legislation, Representative Dan Rostenkowski warned that the lawmakers would have to ''live in a foxhole for two or three weeks'' to produce a tax bill.

title: PROPP SCORES TWO AS FLYERS WIN, 4-2
description: Brian Propp scored two goals and Pelle Lindbergh made 31 saves, as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Washington Capitals tonight, 4-2.

title: LAW BUSINESS? THAT'S ENTERTAINMENT
description: F. Keith Adkinson, a Washington lawyer, tried a few years ago to sell an idea for a television series about a Senate investigator, which he once was. The idea got nowhere in the entertainment industry but it got him in touch with some people who work in the industry.

title: ROYALS WIN;   TRAIL JAYS BY 3-2
description: If the Toronto Blue Jays are to bring the World Series to Canada for the first time, they will have to win one more game on Canadian soil.

title: NEW CHAIRMAN QUITS AT COMPUTER MEMORIES
description: Finis F. Conner, who joined Computer Memories Inc. as its chairman and chief executive officer less than a month ago, has resigned for ''personal reasons,'' according to a company announcement.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''One of the terrorists shot the man in the chest. Then the other man, with a mustache, directed him to shoot Mr. Klinghoffer again.

title: DEVILS, IN OVERTIME, DEFEAT RANGERS, 3-2
description: It was a night filled with 2-on-1 breakaways, 3-on-1 breakaways and even a 3-on-0 breakaway. It was a night of manic shot-taking and a desperate finish: The Rangers tied the Devils with 2 minutes 13 seconds remaining in the third period, and then were beaten, 3-2, on a goal 3:41 into overtime.

title: THE DANCE: ANNA WYMAN TROUPE
description: THE Anna Wyman Dance Theater from Vancouver made its New York debut Saturday night as part of the Metropolitan Life Foundation Dance Canada Festival at Brooklyn College. Miss Wyman's company is the second of five dance troupes that the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts will be presenting as a selective overview of Canadian dance.

title: CHINA GREETS BUSH WITH A WARNING
description: Vice President Bush had barely begun a six-day visit to China today when one of the country's top leaders issued an unusually direct warning about the state of relations between the two countries.

title: CLASS OF '35 RECALLS GLORY DAYS AT JAMES MADISON
description: ''Stanley Kaplan,'' the gray-haired woman called as she rushed across the mezzanine of the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A&M Food Services Inc. of Tulsa, Okla., which operates 150 Pizza Hut franchises, has named Mike Staten corporate treasurer and chief financial officer.

title: M.T.A. Managers Faulted by Regan
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan yesterday blamed poor management and poor planning for extensive delays and cost overruns in the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's rebuilding program.

title: 3 MITHCHUMS STARRING IN A NEW CBS MOVIE
description: He seems to be playing Robert Mitchum - not surprisingly, considering the fact that he is Robert Mitchum. His hotel key sticks in the lock; he contemplates the door and observes conversationally, ''I could kick it in.'' He has just returned from cocktails and lunch, but when an aide asks whether he wants anything he says, ''A pitcher of martinis.'' He refers to his ''general outlook,'' and when asked what that is, he replies, ''Bloodshot.''

title: JUDGE SAYS SHIP'S BARTENDER SAW HIJACKERS KILL AMERICAN
description: A Philadelphia judge who was a hostage aboard the cruise ship Achille Lauro said yesterday that the ship's chief bartender had told him that he saw two terrorists shoot and kill Leon Klinghoffer last Tuesday.

title: White House: 'Who' or 'It'?
description: Sol M. Linowitz shows in his memoir, ''The Making of a Public Man,'' that the political learning process never ends. When he was about to go to work for President Johnson as a delegate to the Organization of American States in 1966, he was weekending in Nice.

title: KEAN WAGES A WEEKEND CAMPAIGN
description: The experts might be wrong. The pitfalls on the campaign trail are not errant remarks, staff scandals or advance men who get lost. No, the real danger comes from dogs and small children, especially small children.

title: P.L.O. LONDON VISIT ASSAILED
description: Representatives of Britain's 400,000 Jews said Sunday they strongly oppose the Government's decision to meet a joint Palestinian-Jordanian delegation that includes two officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: The Right's Attack on the Courts
description: If the constitutional vision of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the far right is ever realized, we are in for a radical restructuring of our governmental framework. The Federal courts' role in protecting individual rights would be severely diminished, while the job of safeguarding those rights would be left to the legislative and executive branches.

title: 'SEARCH FOR MENGELE' DOCUMENTS NAZI'S LIFE
description: WATCHING Rolf Mengele talk about his father in ''The Search for Mengele,'' a one-hour documentary film on Home Box Office at 8 tonight, the viewer hangs on to every word - spoken and unspoken - to find out what the son, who is a lawyer in Germany, really thinks about the Auschwitz doctor whose victims knew him as the ''angel of death.''

title: HELPING OLDER NEW YORKERS WHO ARE TRYING TO FIND JOBS
description: Henry Levy, 62 years old, has been looking for work since April. ''I can tell you, it hasn't been easy,'' said the former merchandise manager.

title: CHATTANOOGA REVITALIZES SYMPHONY
description: All because of an old popular song, Choo-Choo is a dignified word in Chattanooga: V.I.P. guests are put up in the Choo-Choo Hilton; the town's historic Market Street now bears the supplementary name of Choo-Choo Boulevard, and it was from the Chattanooga Choo-Choo itself, the tourist trolley at the restored 1909 railroad terminal, that Vakhtang Jordania stepped last March 29 for the press conference announcing his appointment as artistic director of the newly merged Chattanooga Symphony and Opera Association.

title: Housing Cash, Housing Questions
description: No one doubts New York City's urgent need for housing, and the housing finance plan sketched out and then refined by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch deserves support. Now is the time, however, for supporters to help refine it further.

title: New Top Dog?
description: Women are so often the owners of racing's champions that the sight of a female blueblood leading a regally bred animal into the winner's circle has become a rather familiar one: Penny Chenery with Secretariat, Allaire DuPont with Kelso, Martha Gerry with Forego. In the case of Irene Jenkins of Tucson, Ariz., the pedigrees involved may not be quite so classic, but winning is still the name of the game.

title: 4 Killed and 26 Injured After Bus Hits a Train
description: A chartered bus carrying a church choir rammed a freight train at a railroad crossing today, killing at least four people and injuring 26 of the 32 passengers, the authorities said.

title: REAGAN MESSAGE SENT TO MUBARAK
description: A conciliatory letter from President Reagan was delivered today to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt by the American Ambassador here in what a senior United States diplomat described as an effort ''to heal the breach'' caused by the interception of an Egyptian airliner carrying four Palestinian hijackers.

title: SINAI SLAYINGS: DETAILS PROMISED
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres told the Cabinet today that he had received a message from President Hosni Mubarak promising all the facts surrounding the killing of seven Israelis at a Sinai resort Oct. 5 by an Egyptian policeman or soldier.

title: RICE MAY SWAP ATHLETIC BIG LEAGUE FOR ACADEMIC
description: One of the biggest bargains and best-kept secrets in American private education lies behind a double perimeter of gnarled live oaks on the south side of Houston.

title: JETS APPLYING TO EXCLUSIVE CLUB
description: ARE the Jets, at 4-1, again ready to take their place among pro football's fine teams, the ones that win when they're supposed to?

title: KNICKS ROUT SPURS FOR FIRST VICTORY
description: The Knicks finally met a team that is in just as chaotic a state as they are. And they vented more than seven months of frustration upon their opponent.

title: TEXT OF U.S. STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a statement early today by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, in response to Italy's decision to free Mohammed Abbas:

title: TACOMA TRIES TO CHANGE GRITTY INDUSTRIAL IMAGE
description: From the 12th-floor terrace outside the Mayor's office, Mount Rainier looms gleaming in the sun, wearing the season's first snowfall. Steam from the industrial plants rimming the harbor rises in the nippy air after autumn's first frost.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TREE OF LIFE. By Hugh Nissenson. 159 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95. AT first, Hugh Nissenson's extraordinary new novel, ''The Tree of Life,'' appears to be a tour de force of realism, as well as a radical departure from the Jewish themes that have preoccupied him in his story collections, ''A Pile of Stones'' and ''In the Reign of Peace,'' and in his previous novel, ''My Own Ground.'' Taking the form of a diary or ''Waste Book'' written by an educated 43-year-old New Englander named Thomas Keene, ''The Tree of Life'' seems to be a documentary collage recreating life in the frontier community of Mansfield, Ohio, from July of 1811 until October of the following year.

title: While Bobby Short Marks His 61st
description: U ptown went downtown the other night to celebrate Bobby Short's 61st birthday.

title: ISLANDERS SURVIVE PRESSURE OF OVERTIME
description: As he stood outside the jubilant Islander dressing room Saturday night, Coach Al Arbour loosened his tie, took a long, satisfying sip of a half-empty beer, and grinned.

title: Nine Yachts Race
description: The first Monaco-New York trans-Atlantic yacht race started in brilliant sunshine today, with nine boats competing for about $125,000 prize money for the fastest crossing.

title: Fort Tryon Park Turns 50. . .
description: U ndaunted by drizzle and dressed in the first gilding of autumn, Fort Tryon Park celebrated its 50th birthday yesterday. And at least one of the 200 celebrators recalled the original dedication of the park, a green crown on the northern tip of Manhattan.

title: 10-HOUR PARIS CONCERT RAISES FAMINE AID
description: French pop singers staged a 10-hour concert today at Courneuve, north of Paris, to raise money for Ethiopian famine aid.

title: Headlines Again
description: In March 1983, Clarence Harmon was arrested in Texarkana, Tex., and charged with cocaine possession. That was ho-hum news in Texarkana, and most other places, but it was a headline happening in Washington, where Harmon was a spare running back for the Super Bowl-champion Redskins.

title: C.I.A. AID FOR MEETING PROTESTED
description: Several scholars said today that they planned to withdraw from a conference on Islamic fundamentalism at Harvard University after learning that the Central Intelligence Agency was one of its sponsors.

title: Pronounced Speech Improvement If Fiscal Ax Doesn't Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: ECONOMY GIVES ALTERNATING SIGNALS
description: The economy rebounded smartly during the third quarter, and there are no signs that the nearly four-year-old expansion is about to expire, statistics to be published this week are expected to show.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BACKSTAGE The events surrounding a theatrical event are sometimes as dramatic as what the audience sees onstage. The drudgery of working toward curtain time is accompanied, sometimes, by idyllic teamwork that results in a first-rate production - or, sometimes, by discord that tears a unit almost asunder as financing and artistry debate their proper roles. Tonight at 8 o'clock, Theaterscope, which returns for its third season at the West Side Y Little Theater, 5 West 63d Street, is going to tackle the big picture.

title: RAMS RALLY TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: LeRoy Irvin intercepted a Steve DeBerg pass and returned it 34 yards for a touchdown with 5 minutes 58 seconds remaining today to give the unbeaten Rams a 31-27 triumph over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: IN SEARCHING FOR 'ICEMAN'S' JOE MOTT, ACTOR FINDS HIS FATHER
description: When the conversation changed from the general to the personal, Roger Robinson looked away. He gazed out the window at the rain. Then he turned back, and behind his glasses there were tears.

title: TURF AIDS CARDS
description: The first thing Tom Lasorda did when he heard about Vince Coleman's bizarre leg injury from being run over by a tarpaulin roller was to visit the stricken player in the Cardinal training room.

title: When a University Must Take a Political Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BATTLE OF 2 AD MAGAZINES
description: Advertising Age is feeling threatened, says Adweek.

title: BENGALS TRIUMPH ON GIANT MISTAKES
description: Phil Simms had the best day ever by a Giant passer, the second-best in National Football League history. Mark Bavaro had the best day ever by a Giant receiver.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many times has a pitcher hit a home run in a World Series game, and who was the last one to do it?

title: CONCERT: SONG CYCLE
description: WHEN music has a story to tell, sheer beauty of sound can both mask and illuminate it. Thus there are two kinds of effective Lieder singers - those whose roughnesses and vocal frailty are turned to advantage, serving as metaphors for the drama at hand, and those who use purity of technique as their narrative voice.

title: Disney Classic Won by Wadkins
description: Lanny Wadkins birdied six of the last nine holes and tied the course record with a nine-under-par 63 today to win the $400,000 Walt Disney World Classic by one stroke.

title: WHEN WEST MET EAST (HEAD ON)
description: There have been many highly publicized confrontations through the years in Soviet-American relations, such as Berlin, Cuba and the Middle East. But until now nothing was known about the modest Soviet-American crisis over flunked driver's tests.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page caption in some editions yesterday with articles about the hijacking of the Achille Lauro misidentified a man with Marilyn Klinghoffer, whose husband was killed, as she talked with members of Congress. The man was not Jay Fischer, a family friend: his identity is not known. Another front-page caption in some editions incorrectly described the situation of Neil and June Kantor, passengers from Metuchen, N.J.; they were not on the ship when it was seized.

title: THE OPERA: 'FIDELIO'
description: ''FIDELIO'' in concert form is never a bad idea. Beethoven's only opera can be ungainly as stagecraft, but it remains a musical, emotional - indeed a moral - triumph. The Collegiate Chorale and Orchestra under Robert Bass brought something of the kind to the Beethoven Society's afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday, and it was instructive to have Beethoven's orchestra - from which so much of the visceral and intellectual power of this great work derives - before our eyes.

title: FARMS' CRISIS ENDANGERING RURAL TOWNS
description: As small farmers struggle against a continuing economic crisis, the rural towns that dot the Middle West are trying to keep going themselves.

title: NBC'S 'SILENT WITNESS' INSPIRED BY TRUE STORY
description: Although not billed as a ''based on fact'' TV-movie, ''Silent Witness'' -on NBC at 9 this evening - was clearly inspired in part by a true story. The plot revolves around the rape of a woman by several men in an ethnic neighborhood bar and the subsequent conspiracy of silence when the victim presses charges. A trial involving a similar case was actually televised and generated national headlines.

title: CONCERT: WESTERN WIND ENSEMBLE
description: THE avant-garde composer Charlie Morrow created his ''Birth of the War God'' by improvising and superimposing layers of chant and other self-expressive noises into a four-track tape recorder, and then taking down the result in normal notation. This notation in turn was set before the six adventurous vocalists of the Western Wind ensemble, who sang, spoke, shouted, chanted, clapped, wailed and croaked the work Saturday as part of the ''Great Music in a Great Space'' series at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: OUTDOORS: SIGHTING A RIFLE
description: THE Northeast's seasons for deer hunting with modern firearms are only a few weeks away and this is the time to make sure your rifle shoots where you aim it.

title: A GREAT DAY WASN'T ENOUGH
description: It should have been a glorious day for Phil Simms. He had just completed 40 of 62 passes for 513 yards, all Giant one-game records.

title: Shultz's Means Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Prime Minister Nominated for 2d Term
description: The Iranian Parliament today approved the nomination of Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi for a second term in a vote that indicated a slight increase in opposition to his policies.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATION - The 10 days of activities to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the United Nations officially begin today. More than 80 presidents, prime ministers and special envoys are expected to visit headquarters. Speeches are scheduled for two half-days and one full day this week. Three days of speeches are scheduled for early next week. Ceremonies on October 24, United Nations Day, will end the commemoration.

title: ISRAELIS DESCRIBE HEARING MESSAGES OF DIVERTED JET
description: Two Israeli airline pilots said today that they picked up radio messages from the pilot of an Egyptian airliner with four Palestinian hijackers aboard as the airliner was being intercepted by American Navy jets.

title: SPRINGS CHIEF PREDICTS DEAL WILL AID INDUSTRY
description: Walter Y. Elisha is bullish on American textiles. That is hardly surprising since, as chairman and chief executive officer of Springs Industries, he heads one of the country's largest textile concerns.

title: NOT QUITE AWESOME, BUT STILL IMPRESSIVE
description: ''We're awesome, we're awesome, please write that,'' two Devils players kept repeating in the locker room after last night's 3-2 overtime victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

title: FORSTMANN RAISES BID FOR REVLON
description: Forstmann Little & Company yesterday raised its buyout offer for Revlon Inc. And, in an unexpected move, Revlon's chairman, Michel C. Bergerac, withdrew his plan to invest in the deal.

title: REBELS HOLD OUT ON TALKS WITH PRETORIA
description: The African National Congress, the most prominent of exiled groups fighting white rule in South Africa, said today that it was not yet ready to negotiate a peaceful settlement in this divided nation.

title: KOLLEK GETS FRANKFURT PRIZE
description: Teddy Kollek, the Mayor of Jerusalem, received the Peace Prize of the Association of German Publishers today in recognition of his efforts to reconcile Arabs and Jews.

title: BATHHOUSES REFLECT AIDS CONCERNS
description: Attendance has declined at the 10 homosexual bathhouses in New York since the onset of the AIDS epidemic, according to the city's Department of Health. But some of the owners report that business remains profitable despite mounting public pressure that the baths be closed.

title: Doublespeak From the Dairy Lobby
description: To the Editor:

title: The Defense Malaise
description: After six years of sharply increasing military budgets, those who demanded the buildup should have solid ground for contentment. Yet some of them are more uneasy than ever. The extra money has in no way cured the underlying problems of defense organization. A trillion dollars seems to have bought pitifully little.

title: SHAPIRO AIMS FOR NEWS COVERAGE
description: For 12 hours Peter Shapiro campaigned tirelessly, rushing up and down the New Jersey Turnpike, emerging from his car six times during the course of a recent day to deliver his message.

title: ENVOYS LOST FOR WORDS? NOT AT U.N.
description: If the United Nations is a country unto itself, then the commodity it exports most is words.

title: Freedom Chain Rejects Offer
description: The shareholders of Freedom Newspapers Inc. rejected a second offer by Harry H. Hoiles, who owns one-third of Freedom's stock, to purchase the remaining shares of the family-owned newspaper and broadcasting chain. He offered $98 a share, or about $920 million.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Short-Sighted
description: Over the years, the International Amateur Athletic Federation has passed a number of rules that abetted the record-breaking quests of the world's top track and field competitors. History has reversed course, though, with I.A.A.F.-imposed modifications in the design of the men's javelin, which are due to take effect April 1 and are aimed at limiting the distances that the best throwers achieve.

title: BURST OF ENERGY PRODUCED AT GIANT ATOM-SMASHER
description: Physicists switched on the world's largest atom-smasher today, producing energy levels three times higher than had previously been achieved and thrusting the United States to the forefront of high-energy physics, scientists said.

title: ARMY ENLISTS NEBRASKA VEER
description: Between 1949 and 1950, Coach Earl Blaik's Army teams won 17 consecutive games, a streak that ended with a loss to Navy at the end of the 1950 season. Between 1947 and that loss, Blaik's teams went 28 games without a defeat, being tied twice.

title: LADY'S SECRET CAPTURES BELDAME STAKES
description: The nation's two leading 3-year-olds continued their late-season surges to divisional honors yesterday when Lady's Secret won her eighth straight stakes race in the $223,000 Beldame Stakes and Chief's Crown scored a useful victory in an allowance race at Belmont Park.

title: DISPUTE IN DENVER PITS PINSTRIPES AGAINST JEANS
description: Last year when Brooks Brothers accepted Mayor Federico Pena's invitation to open an outlet in Denver, a few letters to local newspapers complained that the Mayor only wanted the store so that Denver would seem more like New York.

title: GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: A Cairo dispatch yesterday about Egypt's reaction to the American interception of an Egyptian airliner incorrectly characterized what is known of Israel's role in the 1982 mass slayings of civilians at two Palestinian refugee quarters in Lebanon. An official Israeli inquiry concluded that Israel's top civilian and military leaders bore ''indirect responsibility'' for the killings, but were not directly involved.

title: Bergerac Quit Deal to End Criticism, Insider Says
description: Michel C. Bergerac, chairman and chief executive of Revlon Inc., decided not to put any money into a group trying to buy the company, an insider said yesterday, ''to put an end to criticism in the media'' that the executive was ''having his cake and eating it, too.''

title: The 20th-Century Justice
description: From his Supreme Court perch, Justice William Brennan has flung an answer at Attorney General Edwin Meese and other conservative critics of the Court. Mr. Meese complains of rulings that he says spring from the justices' preferences, not constitutional principle. To which the Justice now replies, with considerable justice: Stop posing as the sole champion of principle and admit that your arguments veil a program hostile to civil rights and civil liberties.

title: Goodrich Officer To Buy Tire Stores
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said that it had agreed to sell most of its tire retail stores to a corporation headed by one of the Akron, Ohio, company's executives. Terms were not disclosed, but analysts placed the price at about $100 million.

title: U.S. PLANS WERE MADE ON OPEN LINE
description: President Reagan and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger laid plans to intercept an Egyptian airliner last week over an open radio line that would have been audible to ham radio operators over a wide area, Pentagon and White House officials said today.

title: HARTWELL GROWTH FUND reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: KAISER CEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $2,098,000 for the quarter and $3,763,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses including tax credits of $7,847,000 for the quarter and $10,371,000 for the 9 months.

title: DANCE: KIBBUTZ GROUP
description: THE Kibbutz Dance Company, an Israeli modern-dance group that appeared Sunday afternoon at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, proved unusual in several respects.

title: FILES TELL OF CONTACTS BETWEEN HOOVER AND DISNEY
description: After J. Edgar Hoover objected that a 1962 Walt Disney Productions film depicted agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as bumblers, the film company changed their designation to ''Federal security agents,'' The Arizona Republic reported today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Shot-Putter Banned For Refusing Test
description: August Wolf of Dallas, who finished fourth in the 1984 Olympic shotput, was suspended yesterday by the International Amateur Athletic Federation because he refused to take a drug test after a meet. Wolf said Norway's ranking track official had told him he did not have to take the test.

title: Trilogy Merger
description: Trilogy Ltd. and Elxsi said they had received final approvals for their previously announced merger.

title: SOUTHTRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share figures reflect a 5-for-3 stock split paid in June.

title: HEALTH AGENCY URGES THAT MEDICARE PAY FOR NEW DIAGNOSTIC TOOL
description: The Public Health Service has recommended that Medicare pay for a popular but expensive new diagnostic technique that could eventually replace many uses of the X-ray.

title: Espionage Trial of Ghanaian In U.S. Put Off Until Nov. 12
description: The espionage trial of a Ghanaian on charges of obtaining classified information from a Central Intelligence Agency clerk on duty in the African nation has been postponed until Nov. 12,, legal sources said today.

title: 77 Years of Joy
description: ''Scat singing, all that hi-de-hoing, those zoot suits and wide-brimmed hats, they were a way of communicating joy to the people,'' Cab Calloway wrote in his autobiography, ''Of Minnie the Moocher and Me.''

title: HOME FEDERAL BANK OF FLORDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a state income tax credit of $115,000. c-After a state income tax credit of $54,000.

title: BURST AGRITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REPORT VIEWS SHOREHAM AS BURDEN TO PUBLIC
description: Long Island Lighting Company customers would pay $450 million more in rates if the Shoreham nuclear power plant opened, according to a report for the State Consumer Protection Board.

title: ASSET SALE WEIGHED BY RESORTS
description: Resorts International Inc., which opened the first legalized gambling casino in Atlantic City, disclosed yesterday that it was considering selling a major asset or conducting a refinancing of the company.

title: BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income There were no per share figures for the latest and year-earlier quarters because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: Leak in Reactor Steam Tube
description: A tube that drains nonradioactive steam from the turbine system at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant sprang leaks Sunday and today, Gordon Tomb, a spokesman for the plant, said today.

title: FOR NIGERIAN DOCTORS, THE HEALING IS THE EASY PART
description: Dodging a battered yellow bus hurtling up Obalende Road past his clinic, Dr. Doyin Okupe hurried across the stretch of pavement, past women crouched in the shadow of a concrete underpass selling oranges.

title: Two Guards Held Hostage
description: Six inmates were holding two guards as hostages tonight in a cellblock at Ohio's only maximum security prison. A third guard was injured in the the incident, which began about 1 P.M., the authorities said. A prison negotiator was called in to talk with the inmates at the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility shortly after the disturbance began, said Terry Morris, the prison superintendent.

title: Judge Lets Rhode Island Reopen Police Academy
description: A Federal judge rejected a request today to halt the start of classes at the Rhode Island State Police Academy, where an all-white class prompted charges of racism and nepotism.

title: CONCERT: DALLAS SYMPHONY AND LEES
description: The nation's capital becomes a ghost town on long Federal holiday weekends, and so the Kennedy Center Concert Hall here was half-empty for the visit of the Dallas Symphony under Eduardo Mata on Sunday evening. That is a pity, because the orchestra gave the East Coast premiere of Benjamin Lees's Symphony No. 4, ''Memorial Candles,'' a moving observance of the Holocaust's anniversary and a heartening new contribution to the symphonic repertory. It is a long work (over an hour) in three movements, with vocal solos based on the poems of Nelly Sachs, the German writer who survived the war in Sweden and found her voice as a poet and a Jew in mourning its victims. The Israeli mezzo-soprano Zehava Gal was the soloist.

title: MORTON THIOKOL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discont9inued operations of $4,535,000.

title: Paul B. Johnson Jr. Dies at 69
description: Former Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr., who campaigned as a segregationist but guided Mississippi into desegregation after taking office, died today apparently of a heart attack today at Forrest General Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include results of Turbomach, which was acquired in July. The company announced stock dividends of 45 cents a share for the latest and year-ago quarters and $1.35 a share for the latest and year-ago 9 months.

title: MITCHUMS IN 'PROMISES'
description: THE most interesting thing about ''Promises to Keep,'' the television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock tonight, is the album of family photographs woven into the production. They, at least, are believable, or as believable as snapshots of a famous Hollywood family are likely to get. ''Promises to Keep'' stars Robert Mitchum as Jack Palmer, a roustabout who left his family 30 years earlier; his son Chris Mitchum as Tom Palmer, Jack's still resentful son, and Chris's son Bentley Mitchum as Jack's grandson, Johnny.

title: Giants Proving Statistics Are Deceiving
description: Football coaches preach that statistics are for losers. Certainly, the Giants' performance in Sunday's 35-30 loss to the Bengals in Cincinnati supports that thinking.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
SYRIA APOLOGIZES FOR FIRING MISSILE AT ISRAELI PLANE
description: Syrian soldiers near the Golan Heights recently fired a shoulder-held missile at an Israeli Air Force plane and the Damascus Government then apologized for the cease-fire violation, military sources said today. The missile missed the plane.

title: YUGOSLAVS APPEAR TO BE ILL AT EASE
description: There were signs today that Yugoslavia was embarrassed at having become unwillingly involved in a controversy with the United States growing out of the cruise ship hijacking.

title: For Accountability In Political Ads
description: Every year at this time, I used to look forward to the political season just as I look forward to the World Series and the symphony opening. Thank goodness for baseball and good music. American political campaigning is sick.

title: SCULLY'S TEAM THE WINNER IN PLAYOFFS
description: The baseball playoffs have so far failed to produce a team that is clearly superior to the competition, but the 10 games have given television viewers a fair chance to compare NBC's two broadcast teams. Parity, it would seem, has not yet arrived in the broadcast booth.

title: Tarkenton Buys In
description: Fran Tarkenton, the former Minnesota Vikings quarterback, is one of three persons who have bought a minority interest in the Vikings, according to The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, which identified the others as Carl Pohlad, a part owner of the Minnesota Twins, and Irwin Jacobs, a Minneapolis financier. The newspaper reported in a story yesterday that Max Winter, the president and founder of the team, who owned one-third of the Vikings stock, was ''in the process of selling my financial interest.''

title: Trade Officials Meeting
description: Senior officials of the world's leading trading nations met today to discuss topics and procedure for a proposed new round of negotiations on opening up markets and heading off fresh curbs on commerce.

title: Italian Output Off 5.6%
description: Italy's industrial production in August was down 5.6 percent from the same month last year, after a 56.3 percent drop from July to August, the state statistical institute, Istat, said today. Italy's unadjusted industrial output generally falls dramatically during the August vacation period, when many plants are closed.

title: LITTLE PROGRESS IN AUTO TALKS AS CHRYSLER NEARS DEADLINE
description: Negotiators reported little progress today in contract talks between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, with the strike deadline little more than a day away.

title: SCIENTIFIC LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Canucks Endure Islander Rally, 4-2
description: Jean-Marc Lanthier's power-play goal at 5 minutes 43 seconds of the third period tonight proved to be the game-winner, and solid play by Vancouver's goaltender, Richard Brodeur, gave the Canucks a 4-2 victory over the Islanders.

title: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Helen Clay Frick Left Estate Worth More Than $15 Million
description: The late Helen Clay Frick, daughter of the industrialist Henry Clay Frick, left a personal estate worth $15.4 million, according to an inventory filed with the register of wills.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from the disposition of discontinued operations of $3.5 million. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.8 million for the quarter and $6.3 million for the 9 months and a loss of $60.7 million from the disposition of discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3.3 million and a loss from the disposition of discontinued operations of $3.5 million.

title: U.S. SENDS LAXALT TO TALK TO MARCOS
description: President Reagan has sent Senator Paul Laxalt to the Philippines to discuss the worsening military, political and economic situation there, Administration officials said today.

title: PHONE RATES LIFT COST OF LIVE REMOTE RADIO
description: For more than 25 years, radio station WMSA, in Massena, N.Y., has broadcast the annual Firemen Field Days activities of volunteer fire departments in its region as part of its contribution to the firefighters' fund-raising efforts. After two broadcasts this summer, however, such programs were dropped.

title: People
description: * Diane Flynn has been promoted to senior vice president at Young & Rubicam, New York.

title: Bridge: 3 Pairs Win Trips to Oregon For the Spring National Meet
description: The district final of the Grand National Pairs Championship was played Sunday at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., and the top three pairs won the right to play in the national final, scheduled for next March in Portland Ore.

title: CALI COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to May 31
OWNERS TO DECIDE ON USE OF REPLAYS
description: Owners and executives from the 28 National Football League teams begin two days of meetings in New York today. Judging from their agenda, none of their decisions will likely affect the season in progress.

title: VM SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public on May 29, 1985.

title: Topics;   Round and Round Recycling
description: There's new-old news from London about ''Les Miserables,'' Victor Hugo's rambling novel about crime, punishment and the Paris sewers. Last year it was reborn on the Paris stage, improbably, as a musical.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. - Not available due to Columbus Day holiday.

title: Hormel and Workers To Resume Negotiations
description: Meatpackers and officials at Geo. A. Hormel & Company resumed talks today for the first time since 1,500 workers began a strike Aug. 17 in a wage dispute, a union spokesman said.

title: 2 AMERICANS WIN NOBEL MEDICINE PRIZE
description: Two Americans, Michael S. Brown and Joseph L. Goldstein, won the 1985 Nobel Prize in medicine yesterday for discoveries the Nobel committee in Stockholm said had ''revolutionized our knowledge'' of cholesterol metabolism and the treatment of cholesterol-related diseases.

title: COMPUSAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
G.O.P. RIFT WIDENS FOLLOWING CRITICISM OF MAYOR NOMINEE
description: A rift among the Republican Party's candidates for citywide office widened yesterday as the nominee for comptroller accused the nominee for City Council president of being ''immature'' and having ''an ego that has been inflated by reading your own press releases.''

title: BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DORSEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A DAY TO REAFFIRM U.S.-ITALIAN TIES
description: City and state political leaders used the Columbus Day festivities yesterday to reaffirm relations between the Italian and United States Governments at a time of strain growing out of the hijacking of a cruise liner.

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RIOTERS KILL WHITE SOUTH AFRICA SOLDIER
description: Rioters have killed a white soldier in the Eastern Cape, the authorities said today. He was the first soldier to be killed on riot patrol in the township violence that has claimed more than 750 lives in 13 months.

title: MOVE IS FADING AS TOP PHILADELPHIA ISSUE
description: The cause may lie in tolerance that is a Philadelphia tradition, or in what some see as civic complacency.

title: Syria Discovers Body; It May Be Hostage's
description: The State Department said today that the body of a man had washed ashore near the Syrian port of Tartus and that the Syrians had told the United States they believed it might be that of Leon Klinghoffer, the American slain by hijackers of the cruise ship Achille Lauro last week.

title: NEW CENTURY BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: CPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Purchase by Itel
description: The Itel Corporation said it had entered into a definitive agreement to buy the shares of Great Lakes International Inc. that it does not already own for $62.50 each, or a total of $129.8 million.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FRANK AND MAISIE. A Memoir With Parents. By Wilfrid Sheed. 296 pages.

title: Belgian King Asks Martens to Stay in Office
description: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens today appeared certain to be asked to form another center-right coalition Government committed to economic austerity and the deployment of United States cruise missiles.

title: Accountant Will Head The Midwest Exchange
description: Charles V. Doherty has been elected president of the Midwest Stock Exchange, the nation's second largest after the New York Stock Exchange in both volume and the value of shares traded.

title: Official at Ohio State Named to Head Clemson
description: Clemson University today selected Max Lennon, an administrator at Ohio State University, as its new president, Clemson officials said. Mr Lennon replaces Bill Atchley, who resigned almost four months ago amid controversy over the role of athletics at the university.

title: APPROVAL RATING OF REAGAN BY BLACKS HAS RISEN SIGNIFICANTLY, POLLS SHOW
description: President Reagan's approval rating among blacks has increased significantly since he took office, although most still disapprove of the way he is handling his job, according to polls conducted by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: How to Balance the U.S. Budget by 1991
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1985
description: International

title: CARDINALS REVEL IN SMITH'S HOMER
description: Shortly after this afternoon's fifth game of the National League championship series -a delicious affair that ended with a dramatic home run in the bottom of the ninth inning to break a 2-2 tie - a man noted that ''sometimes, the most unlikely hero emerges, even with all the big names in the game. Maybe that was the case today.''

title: KEAN AND SHAPIRO CLASH ON TOXIC-WASTE CLEANUP
description: Governor Kean and Peter Shapiro, the Democratic candidate for Governor, clashed yesterday over the pace of toxic-waste cleanup in New Jersey.

title: CONVERGING ON A NOBEL PRIZE
description: FROM the time when they were both interns at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston from 1966 to 1968 the careers of Dr. Michael S. Brown and Joseph L. Goldstein have complemented one another, leading to the discoveries for which they were yesterday named to receive the Nobel Prize in Medicine and Physiology.

title: F.C.C. Phone Aims Cited
description: Lowering long-distance telephone charges is a top priority for Federal regulators, Mark S. Fowler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told telephone executives today.

title: Norman Lear In New Effort
description: Norman Lear, who with his partner sold TV production holdings to the Coca-Cola Company for $485 million earlier this year, said today that he had formed a new company, Act III Communications, to create or buy new entertainment and communications businesses.

title: CHINESE, IN TALKS WITH BUSH, SAID TO DWELL ON TAIWAN RIFT
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang conferred for three hours today with Vice President Bush, and much of the session was reported to have been devoted to denunciations by Mr. Zhao of United States policy toward Taiwan.

title: A WARNING TO ORATORS: TIME IS OF THE ESSENCE
description: The United Nations' 40th anniversary commemorative period officially began today with all five speakers exceeding their 15-minute time limits.

title: U.S. STAYS ITS BID TO FORCE EXILE BACK TO IRAN
description: An Iranian alien seeking political asylum in the United States won an 11th-hour reprieve today from being deported for the third time in three weeks.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PROFESSIONALS BACKS IN CLASS
description: WHAT is the best way to assure the public that the professional people who serve them - physicians, lawyers, architects, pharmacists, veterinarians and others - are competent?

title: CALLER IN BEIRUT MENACES RUSSIANS
description: An anonymous caller told a radio station here today that unless the Soviet Union closed its embassy in Beirut, three kidnapped Soviet diplomats would be killed within 30 minutes of the call and the embassy destroyed.

title: LOW ROLLER'S HIGH STAKES BET
description: Showboat Inc. is moving East. The veteran Las Vegas gambling operator is building a $200 million casino - the 12th in this city, and one of the biggest on the Boardwalk. It is an ambitious project for a modest Las Vegas player and Showboat's hopes are high. But many fear the project is so huge that the end result could be a corporate tale of broken dreams.

title: PLOT THICKENS IN LONG SERIES
description: If this were last year, Dick Howser would be back home in Tallahassee, grimacing when well-meaning friends said, ''At least you finally won a game,'' and Tom Lasorda would be home lining up speaking engagements while Whitey Herzog would be delayed from decimating the bass population of southern Illinois.

title: T.W.A. Sets Salary, Job Cuts
description: The new president of Trans World Airlines yesterday announced layoffs and salary cuts for nonunion employees aimed at saving the carrier $100 million a year.

title: P.L.O. AIDE BIDS U.S. PRODUCE EVIDENCE ON HIJACKING LINK
description: Mohammed Abbas, the Palestinian official sought by the United States in connection with the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro, challenged Washington today to produce evidence showing that he was involved in the seizure.

title: Tired-of-Memorials Day
description: Leif Ericsson Day was officially observed Oct. 9, by White House Proclamation pursuant to a Congressional resolution approved in 1964. And yesterday was not only Columbus Day, but the beginning of National School Lunch Week, also approved by the President and Congress.

title: BRITAIN CALLS OFF A MEETING WITH JORDAN-PALESTINE UNIT
description: At the last minute, Britain today called off a meeting with a Palestinian-Jordanian delegation on the situation in the Middle East.

title: KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 21
description: b-Including a tax credit of $270,000. c-Net income.

title: INDIAN VIEWS EXPLORED
description: IN ''Home of the Brave,'' an exploration of the threat to Indian life in North and South America (the one-hour documentary is broadcast at 11 o'clock tonight on Channel 13), several important notions are advanced that may have been heard before but that are, nevertheless, worth retelling. There can be no statute of limitations on human rights.

title: SHULTZ FAULTS MOSCOW ARMS PLAN BUT CALLS 'REAL PROGRESS' POSSIBLE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that although the Soviet Union's new arms-control proposals were ''deeply flawed,'' there could be ''real progress'' in the Geneva negotiations if the Soviet side is serious.

title: Whither the Museum Of America's Indian?
description: To the Editor:

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Latest year results include an after- tax writeoff of about $18 million related to the re-evaluation and realignment of the company's TRE Semiconductor Equipment Corp. product line.

title: SOCIOBIOLOGY YIELDS FRESH INSIGHTS INTO THE BEHAVIOR OF ANIMALS
description: IN little more than a decade the new discipline of sociobiology has transformed the study of animal behavior and brought a blossoming of insights into why animals act the way they do. Its relevance to humans, however, remains hotly disputed.

title: FOURTH FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics;   Round and Round Profitable Punishment
description: When Brian Molony showed up at Caesars in Atlantic City with an evident desire to lose a lot of money, the casino went out of its way to accommodate him. Against state gaming rules, he was allowed to bet with money on deposit outside the state.

title: Protector of the Signs
description: It is against the law to steal parking signs. But is it illegal to take them overnight, as long as you return them to their rightful place the next morning?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE CONCERT Among the most attractive free attractions of the sort that underscore the richness of New York's cultural resources are the concerts offered by the Juilliard School, one of the world's leading shapers of musicianship, now observing its 80th year. During the year, faculty members who are noted professionals perform, as do experienced student ensembles.

title: HOOVER DAM WAS TEST OF ENGINEERS' THEORIES
description: HOOVER DAM on the Colorado River is 50 years old this year, and the American Society of Civil Engineers has designated it a National Historic Civil Engineering Landmark for the contribution it made to the design and construction of extra-large structures.

title: ROOSEVELT MEMO LEADS TO DISPUTE
description: Was Franklin D. Roosevelt well in 1944, when he ran for re-election as President? Or did doctors who treated him that year cover up a grave illness, perhaps a tumor or stomach cancer?

title: SUPERMARKET BAR CODES ARE APPLIED TO SOFTWARE
description: EVER since microcomputers slid off the hobbyist workbench into the life of the public at large, the question of how programs and data for them should be dispersed has been open to much debate among manufacturers. Originally, the disk drives were too expensive for floppy disks to be considered practical vehicles for software, with a single unit costing more than a basic personal computer itself.

title: AXELROD CITED AS POSSIBLE CUOMO RUNNING MATE
description: Governor Cuomo, all but certain to seek re-election in 1986 and among those mentioned as a Democratic candidate for President in 1988, has started looking for a running mate with the credentials to succeed him as governor.

title: Tears From Mickey
description: Mickey Mantle said he couldn't stop crying after the Yankees lost the last game of the 1960 World Series to the Pittsburgh Pirates. After the loss to the Pirates on Bill Mazeroski's home run in the final inning, the Yankees ''walked off the field like zombies,'' Mantle said in article he wrote for the Oct. 19 issue of TV Guide magazine.

title: WESTERN-WORLD TELEVISION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Whither the Museum Of America's Indian?
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue Jays Anxious To Get to the Series
description: Lloyd Moseby, who has driven in the tying runs, then scored the winning runs in two of Toronto's three victories, arrived for the Blue Jays' light workout today ready to wrap up the American League pennant playoff ''as soon as possible.''

title: How to Balance the U.S. Budget by 1991
description: To the Editor:

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Comparison of earnings for the 9-month periods is affected by the company's acquisition of Nederlandse Credit Bank and the Lincoln First Bank in the third quarter of 1984.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Malaysia Fines Journalist Under Secrecy Law
description: The head of The Far Eastern Economic Review, was convicted today on two counts of publishing secret information and fined the equivalent of $4,166.

title: Bozell & Jacobs
description: Bozell & Jacobs has become agency for the American International Group, a global insurance organization. The previous agency was Needham, Harper & Steers, which got the account in 1979, when the billings were estimated at $2 million. B. & J. is being acquired by Lorimar and merged with its Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: WAYNE ANGELL
description: The Federal Reserve Board is not bursting with farmers or small bankers. In Wayne D. Angell, who was nominated last week to be a member of the Federal Reserve Board, the central bank will now have someone with first-hand experience in dealing with the consequences of Fed policy on both troubled areas.

title: FROM WALL STREET TO JERSEY SUBURBS: A SECOND HOME FOR MERRILL LYNCH
description: In his 11 years as an industrial psychologist with Merrill Lynch & Company, George P. Hollenbeck has become a keen observer of life in the world's largest, fastest-moving and most important financial disrict.

title: AMERICAN LIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
POLISH AIDE SAYS TURNOUT WAS 78%
description: A Government spokesman said today that election figures from Sunday indicated that voters had ''boycotted the boycott'' called for by the Solidarity opposition.

title: GROPING FOR THE BIG PICTURE
description: A few dozen times each year, a group of senior Pentagon officials file into a conference room down the hall from the office of Deputy Defense Secretary William H. Taft 4th, take assigned seats at a horseshoe table and become, in the words of one member, ''the board of directors of the Defense Department.''

title: BIG SOVIET ASIA QUAKE CLAIMS LIVES
description: A powerful earthquake struck Soviet Central Asia on Sunday night, toppling adobe homes, sweeping away roads and taking an undisclosed toll in human lives, the Soviet press reported today.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
YOUNG TEXAS TRANSPLANT PATIENT IS AMONG MANY AIDED BY NOBEL RESEARCH
description: The discoveries made by Dr. Joseph L. Goldstein and Dr. Michael S. Brown, for which they were awarded the 1985 Nobel Prize for Medicine, helped save a Texas girl who had her first heart attack at age 6 and could assist hundreds of thousands more.

title: GRIM NEW RAVAGE OF AIDS: BRAIN DAMAGE
description: EVIDENCE is mounting rapidly of a grim new dimension to acquired immune deficiency syndrome: The fatal disease can devastate the victims' brains as well as their immune defense systems. According to doctors' estimates, 30 percent of AIDS patients also show symptoms of brain disease or damage to the spinal cord.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Excluding a tax credit of $4,715,000.

title: Times to Add Printing Site
description: The New York Times will start satellite production of its national edition by the middle of next year at an eighth site, the plant of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution.

title: EXCERPTS FROM A SPEECH BY SHULTZ AT NORTH ATLANTIC ASSEMBLY MEETING
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to the 31st annual meeting of the North Atlantic Assembly in San Francisco:

title: EPSILON DATA MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a one-time charge of $750,000 for costs associated with the move of the company's headquarters.

title: FINGERMATRIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BLAZES DESTROY HOMES ON COAST
description: Wind-driven brushfires blackened thousands of acres in Southern California today, leaving one man dead and at least five homes destroyed in the Malibu area, officials said.

title: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,504,000 for the quarter and $5,496,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ITALY AND U.S. SEEK TO EASE STRAINS; CRAXI'S ROLE CAUSES RIFT IN CABINET
description: Italy and the United States sought today to ease the strains caused by the Italian Government's decision Saturday to allow a Palestinian leader wanted by the United States in the hijacking of an Italian cruise liner to flee to Yugoslavia.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Michael S. Brown and Joseph L. Goldstein have through their discoveries revolutionized our knowledge about the regulation of cholesterol metabolism and the treatment of diseases caused by abnormally elevated cholesterol levels in the blood.'' -Nobel Prize Committee. [C3:2.]

title: RESULTS OF RAT TESTS STIR CONCERN FOR ASTRONAUTS
description: The 24 rats that traveled in space aboard the shuttle Challenger last April suffered significant reductions in the release of growth hormone, a finding that could signal a serious problem for astronauts, a researcher said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Bell Atlantic Corp., Basking Ridge, N.J., said it received Federal Communications Commission approval to expand its cellular mobile telephone system in the Wilmington, Del., area by building new cell sites in Newark, Del., and northeast Maryland.

title: LONG-TERM TAX-FREE BONDS RISE
description: The total of long-term tax-exempt bonds issued in the first nine months of 1985 leaped to a record $98 billion, the Securities Data Company reported yesterday. That compared with $55.9 billion in the comparable period a year ago and the $95.1 billion sold in all of 1984, the company said, The huge rise in long-term borrowings reflected aggressive efforts to take advantage of the decline in interest rates this year by refunding costlier issues sold previously.

title: OPERA: 'KHOVANSHCHINA' AT MET AFTER 35 YEARS
description: MUSSORGSKY'S ''Khovanshchina'' lacks some of the sonic splendor of his ''Boris Godunov,'' but it is a powerful work that ought to be better known in this country. Like ''Boris,'' it deals with actual events in Russian history, bent here and there to meet the composer's theatrical needs. Its plot is extremely convoluted even for Russian opera, with tangled political alliances and crisscrossing personal loyalties as confusing as anything to be found in modern Beirut. But it is a score that can work on one's imagination, and when imaginatively staged, as it was last night at the Metropolitan Opera by August Everding, ''Khovanshchina'' overcomes all obstacles.

title: INTERGRAPH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTRAWEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEHIGH PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST NATIONAL BANCORP (GAINESVILLE, GA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split paid in May.

title: SURPRISING HOMER BY SMITH GIVES CARDS A 3-2 EDGE
description: Ozzie Smith, who makes $2 million a year with his Gold Glove, is a switch-hitter of no great renown. He has been to bat left-handed 2,967 times in his eight years in the big leagues, and he never hit a home run left-handed - until today.

title: Viadent Tooth Care Campaign
description: THESE days one of the most desirable qualities in an advertised product is a distinct consumer benefit, something that its ad agency can enthusiastically advertise.

title: Bridging the Abyss
description: BOBBIE HANDMAN is a handsome woman in her 50's. Her gray hair is naturally wavy. She wears no make-up, no jewelry but a wedding ring and a watch, and lots of lavender because ''I'm a Pisces and Pisces people love lavender.'' She considers herself a liberal.

title: Lobsang Samden, 53, Brother of Dalai Lama
description: Lobsang Samden, an elder brother of the Dalai Lama of Tibet, died Sept. 28 at a hospital in New Delhi. He was 53 years old and since 1978 had been director of the Tibetan Medical Institute in Dharamsala, India, where the Dalai Lama lives in exile.

title: NEW ENGLAND WILL BUY ELECTRICITY FROM QUEBEC UNDER BIG CONTRACT
description: Quebec's electric company and a consortium of 92 New England utilities signed an agreement here this evening for the Americans to import hydroelectric power in the 1990's, at an expected saving to consumers of about $1 billion.

title: Hewlett-Packard, Bechtel in Venture
description: The Bechtel Group Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company said they were teaming up to enter the business of building electronics plants for other companies.

title: Fiat Still Invites Discussions on an Auto Merger
description: Despite the breakdown of its talks with the Ford Motor Company, Fiat S.p.A. remains interested in finding a merger partner for its automobile operations, Giovanni Agnelli, the chairman of the Italian conglomerate, said today.

title: Low-Cost Skeleton
description: An inexpensive full-size model of the complete human skeleton that can be manipulated to duplicate every human position has been designed in England and is being sold in the United States. Henry Robinson, director of the science outreach program at the Boston Museum of Science, says the $50 cardboard skeleton is anatomically accurate and has good mechanical features. Assembly of the skeleton, distributed in this country by Albion Import Export, 65 Main Street, Watertown, Mass. 02172, is said to take six to eight hours.

title: TINSLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 22
EGYPT SECOND BIGGEST U.S. AID RECIPIENT
description: Since the Egyptians loosened their ties with the Soviet Union in 1972, they have become the second largest beneficiary of American aid, with a total of $17.5 billion from 1974 to 1985.

title: For New York Child-Care Agencies, a Catch 22
description: To the Editor:

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated for accounting purposes.

title: Family Style Takes Frizette
description: Family Style rescrambled the 2-year-old filly division ysterday with a 1 1/2-length victory over Funistrada, Guadery and Musical Lark in the $222,000 Frizette Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: Russians Are Angola Target
description: A rebel group said today that at least 12 Russians were killed when bombs planted by its forces exploded in Soviet officers' quarters in Huambo several days ago. The group, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, also said that its guerrillas killed 17 Angolan Government soldiers in an attack last Thursday on the town of Que in southern Huila Province.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE talk among many young designers these days is about something they call the New Couture. What they mean by that is a more formal, dressier style of clothing, a looking back to the soigne suits and dresses of the 1950's rather than the sweaters and pants of the more casual 60's and 70's. These designers seem to be addressing themselves to the needs of the working woman who wants something more feminine than a mannish suit for the office.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIME INC. PLANS TO CUTS COSTS
description: Time Inc., in a departure from its customary generosity, has announced plans to reduce its operating costs.

title: East Side Aids Homeless
description: Outside, the red brick is grimy with age, and there is little to distinguish the six-story building at 211 East 81st Street from its neighbors.

title: SECOND NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mideast Terror - The Peace Process Is Again Periled
description: The recent round of terror and reprisals in the Middle East is threatening to nip the peace process in the bud.

title: Swedish Transport Workers Declare South Africa Boycott
description: Sweden's transport workers today declared a one-month boycott of trade with South Africa, the latest in a series of anti-apartheid protests by Nordic trade unions.

title: Management Buyout Sought for Thorn Unit
description: Gary Dartnall was delighted by the announcement last Thursday from the big British consumer electrical company, Thorn EMI, that it is trying to sell its movie production and distribution division, even though Mr. Dartnall runs that business for Thorn. His attitude is explained by the fact that a group of investors he heads is the leading candidate to buy the unit, which also includes a chain of movie theaters, a large distribution operation handling prerecorded video cassettes, and a 46 percent stake in a London television station.

title: I.B.M. ADDS 10 MEGABYTES TO NEW AT
description: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES has rolled out a new model of its most powerful personal computer, the AT. The new version comes with a 30-megabyte hard disk, able to store 30 million characters of information, 10 million more than previous models. This means the new AT can store the equivalent of a few more James Michener novels than the 20-megabyte (20-MB) version. In addition, a second 30-MB hard disk can be installed in the new AT for users with truly Texas-sized storage needs.

title: Top Soviet Planner Replaced
description: Nikolai K. Baibakov, the longtime chairman of the state planning committee and a key figure in the management of the Soviet economy, was replaced today.

title: CANAL LOCK MISHAP BLOCKS SHIP TRAFFIC IN THE GREAT LAKES
description: The wall of a lock collapsed today on the St. Lawrence Seaway, pinning a ship for much of the day and blocking traffic at a busy time of the year for the heavily traveled waterway, which connects the Great Lakes to the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The defenseman Mark Hardy of the Los Angeles Kings will undergo surgery this week to repair tendon damage in his right wrist, the National Hockey League club announced. . . . With four N.H.L.-caliber golatenders in their organization, the Quebec Nordiques traded 34-year-old Daniel Bouchard to the Winnipeg Jets for a seventh-round draft choice and undisclosed monetary considerations. . . . The Phoenix Suns announced that Alvin Scott, the eight-year veteran forward, had been waived. . . . The San Antonio Spurs signed Marc Iavaroni, the free-agent holdout who was traded to the Spurs last December by the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEWORLD BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $491,000 for the quarter and $1,005,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: COMSERV CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $12,833,000 for the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Instant Camera Plans at Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it would keep selling instant cameras and film while it appealed an injunction obtained by the Polaroid Corporation barring Kodak from the instant photography market starting Jan. 9.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1985
description: International

title: Humanism Speaks
description: While everybody else was absorbed with the backlash of terrorism in the never-ending Arab-Israeli conflict, a poignant ceremony took place here Sunday morning.

title: Hanging On At the Top
description: For Mary Lou Retton, success isn't all wonderful. Being famous is hard work. And all the attention, she says, can get to her at times.

title: LIBBEY-OWENS-FORD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: On Sept. 16, 1985, the company purchased nearly 10.8 million shares of its common stock.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: DAY TWO - On the second day of the 10-day commemorative period, delegates in the General Assembly will hear from six speakers. President Spyros Kyprianou of Cyprus, an island nation that is the focus of much United Nations activity, leads off the proceedings. An African viewpoint will then be offered by the President of Gambia, Sir Dawda K. Jawara. Attention then shifts to the Caribbean, with remarks by Prime Minister Eugenia Charles of Dominica, and back to Africa with a speech by Prime Minister el-Gizouli Dafalla of the Sudan.
