Prime Minister Herbert A. Blaize of Grenada will speak next, followed by a special envoy from Guatemala.

title: INTERCHANGE STATE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ATOM COLLIDER PUT TO WORK
description: THE world's most powerful atom-smasher, a four-mile-long underground accelerator that slams beams of matter into counterrotating beams of antimatter, was put into action Sunday at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., and it has already produced energy levels of 1.6 trillion electron volts, three times higher than achieved before, physicists report.

title: Pakistani Leader Delays Trip to West Germany
description: Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq called off a scheduled visit to West Germany today as opposition mounted to a bill meant to pardon him for the last eight years of martial law rule.

title: The Background;   An Unfinished Mussorgsky Work
description: Mussorgsky left ''Khovanshchina'' unfinished at his death in 1881, along with another opera, ''The Fair at Sorochintsy.'' Like several other Mussorgsky works, ''Khovanshchina'' was completed and orchestrated by his Russian colleague Rimsky-Korsakov.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include FirstGulf Bancorp from the date of acquisition.

title: THEATER: 'A MIDNIGHT'S STRIPPING'
description: STRANGE are the lengths to which a playwright will go in search of verisimilitude.

title: God and Boy in Scouting
description: The leaders of the Boy Scouts of America could have dug in their heels and insisted that Paul Trout subscribe to a theology he didn't believe or else give up Scouting. Instead, after mishandling the case at first, they have behaved with enlightened good sense. The result is an accommodation that respects the principles of both the boy and the Boy Scouts.

title: OFFICERS SEEK OWNER OF CAR THAT DRAGGED POLICEMAN 500 FEET
description: Detectives were trying yesterday to trace the owner of an unregistered car involved in an incident Sunday that seriously injured a police officer in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section.

title: Byars Will Play
description: Team physicians at Ohio State have given Keith Byars permission to play against Purdue this week. The tailback, who led the nation in rushing and scoring a year ago, has missed the first five games after suffering a broken bone in his right foot. The cast was taken off his foot Sept. 30, and he was able to jog around the practice field last week.

title: SUFFIELD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Not available because the company went public in June 1984.

title: Columbia Pictures Fills Post at Domestic Group
description: Columbia Pictures, which has suffered a string of box-office disappointments this year, named Peter S. Sealey president of its domestic marketing and distribution group, in charge of all advertising, promotion and distribution for its films in this country.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After a reversal of deferred taxes on DISC income of $1 million for the quarter and 9 months.

title: QMAX TECHNOLOGY GROUP reports earnings for Year to June 30
Ditka Charged
description: Mike Ditka, the coach of the Chicago Bears, was charged with driving under the influence of alcohol in Chicago early yesterday, shortly after he had got off a plane from San Francisco, where the Bears defeated the 49ers Sunday. Sgt. Charles Roth of the Illinois State Police said Ditka was stopped by a trooper who saw him speeding and driving in an irregular manner. He said Ditka posted a $100 bond and surrendered his driver's license before being released.

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company declared stock dividends of 14 cents per share for the latest quarter, 42 cents per share for the latest 9 months, 12.5 cents a share for the year-ago quarter and 37.5 cents a share for the year-ago 9 months.

title: ROTATING CREWS SEEN FOR SOVIET SPACECRAFT
description: Soviet space officials said today that they expect to have a permanently manned space station by 1990, but that the Salyut-7 orbital laboratory will not be the spacecraft that hosts the rotating crews.

title: Chilean Diplomat Slain By Panamanian Soldier
description: A Panamanian soldier assigned to guard the Chilean Embassy today shot to death one diplomat and seriously wounded another, then shot himself in the head, Government sources and news agencies reported.

title: Walton Heads List Of Richest in U. S.
description: For Sam M. Walton, this has been a very good year. For Gordon Peter Getty it has been comparatively poorer, but all things considered he still has little to complain about.

title: ROBOT WITH LASER EYES TAKES LUMBERING FIRST STEP
description: WITH a blast of exhaust smoke and an ear-splitting howl, a three-ton robot came to life in a workshop at Ohio State University last week, tentatively flexing the hydraulic muscles of one of its six elephantine legs and practicing the movements that will eventually enable it to walk.

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GENERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Fleet Holdings Accepts United Newspapers Bid
description: One of Britain's most bitterly fought takeover battles ended today when the newspaper empire of Fleet Holdings P.L.C., which includes the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star, agreed to be acquired by United Newspapers P.L.C..

title: Paper Makers Post Declines
description: Two major paper companies, the Boise Cascade Corporation and the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, yesterday reported sharp drops in their third-quarter earnings.

title: 14.79 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,354.73
description: Stock prices rose sharply on Wall Street for the second consecutive session yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to within 5 points of its record.

title: MUBARAK, FURIOUS AT U.S., DEMANDS A PUBLIC APOLOGY
description: President Hosni Mubarak demanded today that the United States apologize publicly for its diversion of an Egyptian airliner to Italy. The plane was carrying the four hijackers of the cruise ship Achille Lauro.

title: ARCHER DANIELS MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JAPAN IS ADOPTING MEASURES TO SPUR ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: Japan's Government today adopted a variety of incentives to stimulate the nation's economic growth rate.

title: JETS STOP MARINO AND RUSH PAST DOLPHINS INTO FIRST
description: Confidently, easily, the Jets produced a bruising 23-7 victory over the Miami Dolphins tonight to take sole possession of first place in the American Football Conference East.

title: LSI LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
METRO-NORTH SPEEDS UP PLAN TO REPAIR PARK AVE. TUNNELS
description: Two sections of the Metro-North railroad tunnels under Park Avenue have deteriorated more rapidly than expected and will be repaired this winter rather than in 1987, when the entire aging tunnel is scheduled for a $75 million rehabilitation.

title: EQUINOX SOLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 1-for-4 reverse stock split effective Sept. 24, 1985.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because most Federal Government offices, the Federal Reserve offices in New York and Washington and many banks were closed yesterday for Columbus Day, tables were not available for foreign currency exchange rates, government and government-agency securities and money rates. In addition, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York was closed.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. Revenue figures represent net sales and other income.

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income, including a tax credit of $266,603.

title: MANUEL JOHNSON JR.
description: Jude Wanniski, the supply-side pamphleteer, calls Manuel H. Johnson Jr. a diplomat: ''He's civil. He doesn't attempt to put other people down. He doesn't ridicule their views.''

title: GRADCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $200,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including net income from discontinued operations of $338,000 for the quarter and $119,000 for the 6 months.

title: RAI RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $72,059. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of the company's RAICOUP Metal Recovery Systems activity of $8,777 and including a tax credit of $267,000.

title: Czechs Win Cup
description: The Czechoslovak women's tennis team, led by Hana Mandlikova, completed a rain-delayed victory over the United States today and won the Federation Cup for the third consecutive year. Miss Mandlikova, leading Kathy Jordan, 7-5, 3-0, when rain halted their singles match Sunday, needed only 10 minutes and 4 games to nail down a 6-1 victory in the second set, clinching the cup for her team.

title: Bears Do Hibernate
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Stock Choices
description: THE stocks of several high-technology companies, particularly those with specialized products, continue to stir enthusiasm among members of the investment community.

title: New Job: Software Engineer
description: COMPUTER software engineering is not a profession yet, but it will be if John H. Manley has his way. A former Air Force expert, he has just become the director of the Software Engineering Institute, financed by the Government.

title: The Sounds of the City
description: The little girls sometimes wax Chaucerian about little boys in performing their street cheers, clapping and stomping in rapid rhythm, cartwheeling and dancing for fun these cool evenings.

title: BIOSENSOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NBSC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 13 wks to Sept 28
description: b-After a nonrecurring pre-tax charge of $4.1 million relating to a special early retirement program and a tax credit of $105,000. c-Including a tax credit of $233,000. The company announced stock dividends of 38 cents a share for the latest and year-ago quarters and $1.14 a share for the latest and year-ago 9 months.

title: When Due Process Is at the End of a Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Reagan Ran
description: From time to time, President Reagan gives short, exclusive interviews to foreign correspondents based in Washington, and they sometimes produce rare Presidential reflections.

title: Utah Heard From
description: Former Gov. Scott M. Matheson of Utah, a Democrat, has told friends that he is planning to run for the Senate in 1988, challenging Orrin G. Hatch, a Republican, for his seat. The friends say Mr. Matheson sees some vulnerability in Mr. Hatch but decided not to run next year against the state's other Senator, Jake Garn, also a Republican, figuring that the extremely popular Mr. Garn would be much tougher to beat.

title: LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After charges of $76,000 for the quarter and $431,000 for the 9 months related to alleged improper waste storage and disposal matters.

title: WATER AND GAS CUT OFF TO 2,000 IN BROOKLYN
description: A water-main break caused damage that left almost 2,000 homes in Brooklyn without gas, water or phone service yesterday.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for 16 wks to Oct 6
description: b-Including tax credits of $900,000 for the 16 weeks and $4.7 million for the 40 weeks and a credit of $20.1 million for the 40 weeks represent the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting. c-Including tax credits of $2.5 million for the 16 weeks and $9 million for the 40 weeks.

title: Chemical Spill Injures 7
description: Acid leaked from a truck parked in a depot near here tonight, injuring seven persons and forcing crews clad in protective gear and wearing breathing apparatus to evacuate at least 400 people living nearby, officials said. M. E. Turner, a rescue squad worker, said the leaking substance was nitrosysulfuric acid, which can burn skin and eyes and may be harmful if inhaled. He said workers did not know how much had leaked.

title: IN BOOK, TEACHERS TELL 'WHO WE ARE'
description: AMERICANS tend to regard teachers either as saints or servants. When new demands are made to run schools differently, teachers are often the last to find out what their employers want. A new book, ''The Teacher's Voice: A Sense of Who We Are'' (Heinemann Educational Books, $10), lets teachers speak out.

title: ITALIANS REPORT A BROADER PLOT IN THE HIJACKING
description: Italian magistrates said today that their investigation of four Arab militants charged with hijacking the cruise ship Achille Lauro had disclosed the possible involvement of accomplices and possible links to other recent terrorism in Italy.

title: STEELMAKER'S CONFIDENT PLAN
description: In the face of flat demand for specialty steel products, the Carpenter Technology Corporation, one of the sector's biggest manufacturers, is going ahead with an ambitious expansion program intended to increase its steelmaking capacity by 50 percent.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORP (SPOKANE, WASH) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A PITCHER SEES DREAM COME TRUE
description: For five years, at least, the moments have been locked inside Mark Gubicza's head, waiting for the chance to escape. From the time he was a senior in high school, Gubicza began to envision his magic game, the decisive game for a championship.

title: WITNESSES AT NEO-NAZI TRIAL DESCRIBE DISSENSION IN GROUP
description: The Nazi-like group called the Order, which plotted and waged a racist war, was racked by internal dissension and members who talked too much, according to testimony in the trial of members of the group on racketeering charges.

title: FROM LONDON, A NEW ACCENT ON SIMPLICITY
description: Designers here are startling their audiences in a most unexpected way: they have cleaned up their act. There may still be pockets of slightly mad, looped and puffed clothes that recall Dickensian ragpickers. It was such outrageous designs that brought foreign retailers here in increasing numbers in recent years. But now that they have achieved a measure of success, some of the best-known British designers are choosing simplicity.

title: Alumni Corps
description: There was a time when a varsity emblem from Penn State was a respected letter of introduction for linebackers entering the National Football League. Through the last decade, the Nittany Lions boasted as many as 10 linebackers on N.F.L. rosters at one time, including such former stars as the Steelers' Jack Ham and the Jets' Greg Buttle.

title: BIO-LOGIC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $11,300 for the quarter and the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $30,000 for the quarter. d-Net loss. Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock distribution effective June 1985.

title: Hospital Releases Alaskan
description: Gov. Bill Sheffield of Alaska has left a Seattle hospital after undergoing an operation to correct a heart problem.

title: Coca-Cola Test Of Plastic Cans
description: Coca-Cola U.S.A. said today that it will begin testing a plastic soft-drink can this week in Columbus, Ga.

title: BAXTER NET ROSE 18.4% IN 3D PERIOD
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. announced today that its third-quarter net income rose 18.4 percent, to $47 million, or 32 cents a share, from $39.7 million, or 28 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Baxter, on the verge of completing its acquisition of the American Hospital Supply Corporation, said that sales for the quarter rose 11.4 percent, to $519.1 million, from $465.9 million in the 1984 quarter.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Blue Jays vs. Kansas City Royals, at Toronto. Game 6 of the American League Championship series. The Jays, leading by 3 games to 2, try to wrap up the pennant.

title: Kaypro President Succeeded by Son
description: The Kaypro Corporation, the California computer maker, said yesterday that its founder, Andrew F. Kay, would step down as president and be replaced by his son David.

title: Control Data Unit Sells 2 Companies
description: The Commercial Credit Company, a subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, said that it had sold two units as part of a restructuring. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CRAWFORD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sinclair Vehicles
description: The electrical vehicle company owned by Sir Clive Sinclair was placed in receivership.

title: PRESS COVERAGE CRITICIZED IN DISASTER IN PUERTO RICO
description: Some Puerto Ricans and others on the mainland have expressed frustration, disappointment and bitterness over news coverage of the mud slide last week that the authorities say may have killed more than 500 people.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 1
JOSEPH S. LINDEMANN
description: Joseph S. Lindemann, a retired cosmetics and pharmaceuticals manufacturer and a philanthropist, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: A FRESH VIEW OF DAYAN IN BOOK BY DAUGHTER
description: Like many historical figures, Moshe Dayan has been examined from a number of angles -from his autobiography to biographies, from fawning magazine cover stories to racy inside scoops in the Israeli scandal sheets. It is testimony to the complexity of his personality and the diversity of his political-military career that he has spun off more than enough grist for all of these mills.

title: Early Glaucoma Detection
description: A specially designed ophthalmoscope at the Yale Eye Center is being used for early detection of glaucoma, a buildup of pressure in the eyeball that can damage the optic nerve. Glaucoma has caused partial or total blindness in 2 million Americans.

title: Loss Narrows For Kaiser
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said today that its losses for the third quarter had narrowed by 76 percent, to $17.7 million, from $73.2 million a year ago. Sales slipped 4.1 percent, to $526.4 million, from $548.8 million.

title: MIRIAM MORTON
description: Miriam Morton, a former social worker in the Bureau of Child Welfare in New York who became an editor and translator of Russian and French stories, died of cancer Sept. 22 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington.

title: Downward Slide
description: Bob Grim has some advice for Tom Browning, the Cincinnati left-hander who last month became the first rookie pitcher in 31 years to win 20 major league games.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring tax credit of $30.6 million for the quarter and the 9 months.

title: IT TAKES TWO WHO TANGO
description: As they sail across the floor with locked limbs and perfect posture, Juan Carlos Copes and Maria Nieves look as if they have been dancing together most of their lives. They have. Theirs is a storybook partnership that began in a working class dance hall in Buenos Aires when Miss Nieves was only 12 years old and Mr. Copes was 18.

title: Sidney Rabb, 84, Dies; Supermarket Executive
description: Sidney R. Rabb, a philanthropist and chairman of a company that operates supermarkets throughout the Northeast, died at his home Sunday. He was 84 years old.

title: Yes, We Take No Opinions
description: Speaking of Columbus Day, people who called the White House yesterday to offer the President advice and opinions were told there was nobody to listen to them because of the holiday.

title: U.N., FACING BOYCOTT THREAT, DROPS EFFORT TO INVITE ARAFAT
description: Threatened by a boycott by the United States, the General Assembly averted a potentially bitter confrontation today by dropping a resolution to invite the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, to the 40th anniversary commemoration.

title: COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Chase Net Up 60.6% In Quarter
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that earnings rose 60.6 percent in the third quarter, to $149.4 million, from $93 million in the 1984 quarter, but some analysts said the results were less than met the eye, partly because last year's quarter was poor.

title: A TURK IN PAPAL TRIAL IS DEAD
description: A Turk who was being tried in absentia in the Rome trial of eight men accused of conspiring to kill Pope John Paul II died here today of a heart attack, the Anatolia news agency reported.

title: EX-PASTOR GIVEN 20-YEAR SENTENCE
description: A defrocked Roman Catholic priest who had admitted having sex with dozens of boys pleaded guilty today to pornography involving children and other charges and was sentenced to 20 years at hard labor.

title: At Other End of the Phone
description: The marble corridors of City Hall were dim and silent yesterday, as most of the government closed down for the day to honor Christopher Columbus.

title: PALESTINIAN AIDE REPORTED TO QUIT YUGOSLAV CAPITAL
description: A Palestinian official sought by the United States in connection with a cruise ship hijacking was reported by associates tonight to have left Yugoslavia, possibly on his way to Southern Yemen.

title: Monsanto Offers Early Retirement
description: The Monsanto Company made an early-retirement offer to 3,880 salaried workers, somewhat more than 10 percent of its United states work force.

title: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SQUARE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include operations of one location for the period from April 17 to May 31, 1985, excluded from the first quarter's operations as a result of a dispute resolved in September 1985. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in August 1984.

title: Spanish Trawler Off Sahara Is Rammed by Soviet Vessel
description: A Soviet merchant ship rammed a Spanish trawler off Western Sahara early today, sinking the boat and killing at least three crew members, officials said.

title: American McGaw
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said its Kendall Company subsidiary is the intended buyer for American McGaw Lab of Irvine, Calif., an American Hospital Supply Corporation unit. American Hospital said last week it had signed a letter of intent for the sale, but did not identify the buyer. Colgate did not disclose the price, but analysts estimate that Boston-based American McGaw, which makes intravenous solutions, is worth $150 million to $175 million.

title: SCM in Plea On Hanson
description: The SCM Corporation said yesterday that it had asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for a full-court review of a decision last month by a three-judge panel involving the takeover battle with Hanson Trust P.L.C. The panel had ruled that Hanson had acted lawfully when it abandoned an offer to all stockholders and then bought 25 percent of SCM from just six shareholders.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Elektra/Asylum Records has named Mike Bone senior vice president of marketing and promotion, succeeding Lou Maglia, who resigned.

title: Ralph G. Albrecht, 89, Counsel at Nuremberg
description: Ralph G. Albrecht, a Manhattan lawyer who was an associate United States counsel at the Nuremberg war crime trials from 1945 to 1947, died Sept. 27 at a nursing home in Watertown, Mass. He was 89 years old. Mr. Albrecht was one of a panel of nine American lawyers serving under Robert G. Storey of Dallas, who was executive counsel.

title: The Choices of Care Our Elderly Deserve
description: To the Editor:

title: OUTSIDE TAX COMMITTEE, UNEASY LOBBYISTS WAIT
description: Outside the high-ceilinged committee room where House tax writers have been grappling with a wholesale revision of the nation's tax laws for the last two weeks stands a crowd of anxious people - probably the best-paid loiterers in the United States. They represent virtually every thread of America's social and economic fabric, from the Girl Scouts and the Commissioner of Baseball to A.T.&T. and the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: APPLIED DATA RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to give effect to a 5 percent stock dividend declared May 16, 1985.

title: CCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-The company did not have sales for the year-ago periods because it was engaged in the start-up of a now- discontinued medical products business. c-Including extraordinary credits of $37,861 for the quarter and $521,778 for the 9 months. d-Net loss.

title: Abusing the War on Welfare Abuse
description: At President Reagan's behest, Congress four years ago ordered fines against states that permitted too much fraud or abuse in their management of the Federal program of Aid to Families With Dependent Children. Now it appears that the Administration wants the fines not just to make the program more efficient but to make it smaller. Such sanctions deserve a closer look.

title: HEILEMAN, G BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Sales figures exclude excise taxes.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Slayer Barring Efforts To Block His Execution
description: A convicted murderer, William Vandiver, refuses to appeal his execution set for Wednesday and is frustrating civil rights groups that need his consent to fight for a reprieve, a lawyer said today.

title: Daimler Set to Buy Big Stake in AEG
description: The auto maker Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that it plans to buy a majority stake in AEG A.G., an electronics maker, in a deal that would make Daimler-Benz the largest industrial concern in West Germany. The price and size of the proposed stake were not disclosed.

title: The Argument Against RICO
description: IN recent weeks, the National Association of Manufacturers, the United States Chamber of Commerce and several insurance and banking groups have been pushing Congress to overturn part of a 15-year-old law that aims to crack down on organized crime.

title: DUARTE SENDS RELATIVES TO THE U.S. AFTER NEW KIDNAPPING THREAT
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte sent three of his daughters and their four children out of the country today on a United States Air Force plane.

title: STAGE: KANTOR'S 'LET THE ARTISTS DIE'
description: IN ''Let the Artists Die,'' the new theater piece from the Cricot 2 company of Cracow, a half-dozen ragtag traveling players trudge in a circle in a black void, clutching their threadbare props as if they had been touring Europe since the beginning of time. Suddenly a gray wooden door opens in the darkness behind them to admit a regiment of generals wearing rubbery silver uniforms. The men's faces are caked with slime; their limbs move jerkily to booming martial music. They seem to have tottered, half-awakened, from their graves, much as a hero among their ranks rides a horse whose flesh has rotted away to reveal the yellowed skeleton within.

title: KEAN AND SHAPIRO ON KEY ISSUES IN GUBERNATORIAL CAMPAIGN
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between Governor Kean of New Jersey, a Republican seeking election to his second term, and Peter Shapiro, the Essex County Executive and his challenger from the Democratic Party.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the De Gustibus column on the Style page on Saturday incorrectly described the contribution of Eileen Yin-Fei Lo to the book ''China's Food.'' She provided the recipes.

title: HON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Real Estate;   Mixed-Use Growth in Manhattan
description: WHEN zoning regulations encouraging offices and apartments in the same buildings were loosened in 1982, the districts where the mixed-use projects could be built were extended from the original areas along 57th Street and down Fifth Avenue to most of midtown Manhattan.

title: THEATER: PHIL STEIN VAUDVILLE
description: IN the lobby at the Westbeth Theater Center, there are photographs on the wall of the entertainers who appear in ''The Phil Stein Vaudeville Show.'' All of the pictures are identical portraits of Phil Stein. He is his own opening act and all of his guest stars and in his finale, he plays both a waiter and a diner. Guess which Stein has food flung in his face.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Sept 29
description: Results for the year-ago fourth quarter reflect the forgiveness of tax on accumulated DISC earnings.

title: Some 8.8% Jeep Financing
description: The American Motors Corporation said today that it had extended its 8.8 percent financing to some of its 1986 Jeep line of trucks.

title: DRESHER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Up and Coming
description: Yogi Hightower was flattered to be one of the 10 athletes chosen by the Women's Sports Foundation last May for its inaugural Up and Coming Awards. She won in the team-sports category, and you might say that her sport - field hockey - deserves the same Up and Coming label. Although it has been played in this country since 1920, American women have just begun to establish themselves as international powers.

title: REAGAN SAYS 'STAR WARS' WILL AID EFFORTS FOR ARMS-CONTROL ACCORD
description: President Reagan said today that the Administration viewed a United States space shield against nuclear weapons as a ''moral'' obligation that would improve the prospects for an arms agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: Lots of Respect
description: Coach Bill Curry of Georgia Tech, whose next opponent is Auburn, applies the old soft soap not merely to the War Eagles as a group but specifically to Bo Jackson, Brent Fullwood and Tommie Agee: ''They resemble a National Football League team, except that they have better backs.''

title: ZURN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2.7 million for the quarter and the six months.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: YEAR FOR ANNIVERSARIES -This year marks not only the 40th anniversary of the United Nations, but the 25th anniversary of the adoption by the General Assembly of the ''Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples'' as well. The declaration was officially adopted on Dec. 14, 1960 but the Assembly has set aside today to commemorate the occasion. Although the United Nations lists some 19 global territories still to be decolonized, the talk is expected to focus on South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. Speakers scheduled to address the delegates include Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, the President of the General Assembly, Jaime de Pinies, and representatives of various United Nations committees and the regional groups of states.

title: TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $3.1 million nonrecurring write off for the quarter and the nine months.

title: WASHINGTON WATER POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company paid dividends of 62 cents per share each quarter.

title: Face Up to the P.L.O.'s True Nature
description: If nothing else, the Achille Lauro incident should have opened the West's eyes to the true nature of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: FIRST AMENDMENT KEY IN COURT CASE
description: School prayer came before the Supreme Court once again today, with a push from Congress and the Reagan Administration, as the Justices heard a case of concern to religious groups and educators.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of property of $480,000 for the quarter and a gain of $972,000 on the sale of property and the company's home health care operations for the nine months. c-Including a gain of $2,133,000 from the sale of investment and a charge of $1,091,000 relating to prepublication expenses and inventory writeoff.

title: DEFENSE ATTORNEYS IN STEWART CASE SAY GROSS FEARED FOR JOB
description: Defense attorneys in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart sought to show yesterday that the city's Chief Medical Examiner had altered his opinion on the cause of Mr. Stewart's death because he feared for his job.

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Honeywell Income Off
description: Honeywell Inc. today reported a 40.3 percent decline in third-quarter net income, to $55.7 million, or $1.24 a share, from $93.3 million, or $1.99 a share, in the same quarter a year ago. However, in the year-earlier quarter, the Minneapolis-based manufacturer of information and control systems and products received a credit of $40 million, or 85 cents a share, on the reversal of tax obligations. Third-quarter sales this year totaled $1.57 billon, up 4.7 percent, from $1.50 billion in the same period last year.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WHILE trundling socialites from gala to gala, limousine drivers experience a fair amount of downtime during which they are wont to work the streets, picking up the common folk. The negotiated fare is usually higher than the fare for a cab (assuming one can find a cab), but so much lower than the going rate for a limo that some people who have never been known to ride in such style say, ''What the heck?'' and hop in.

title: WINE
description: FIVE or six years ago, the wine business in this country had nowhere to go but up. And it seemed to be doing that at an astonishing rate. Consumption had doubled - tripled over 1950's figures - and the breathless trade press saw it doubling and doubling again. Wine shops were expanding like accordions and new wineries were opening as fast as the schools could turn out new wine makers. The wine-drinking nation was only a matter of time.

title: Tennis Upset
description: The way the organizers of the 1985 Australian indoor tennis championships figured it, Anders Jarryd, the Swedish sensation who won the 1984 tournament, would be meeting Ivan Lendl in the final of the 1985 event.

title: TIME INC. POSTS 3.9% DECLINE
description: Time Inc. reported yesterday that its net income for the third quarter fell 3.9 percent, to $44.2 million, or 70 cents a share, from $46 million, or 72 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DOWN TO THE SEA New York Harbor and the sea constantly influence the New York scene, cultural and commercial, and this phenomenon at our front door gives the big exhibition that opens today in the Museum of Brooklyn at Brooklyn College its theme and its name: ''From Brooklyn to the Sea: Ships, Seafarers and New York Harbor.''

title: PLANES USED TO FIGHT FIRES ON COAST
description: Firefighters used chemical-laden air tankers today to battle wind-driven brushfires in Southern California that had burned at least 43,000 acres and 22 houses.

title: State Delays Plant Of Louisville Gas
description: The Louisville Gas and Electric Company said that the expected service date for one of its coal-fired units has been delayed until at least 1991, from 1988, by the Public Service Commission of Kentucky.

title: Prices of Bonds Inch Ahead
description: The Treasury, tax-exempt and corporate bond markets drifted through a sleepy session yesterday as investors and dealers continued to wait for Congress to lift the Federal debt ceiling. Once the $1.8 trillion ceiling is raised, the credit market expects a torrent of Treasury borrowings that should set the tone for all fixed-income bond markets.

title: A 'SELF-PORTRAIT' MARKS COPLAND'S 85TH BIRTHDAY
description: ON Nov. 14, Aaron Copland will be 85 years old, an occasion being marked with richly deserved tributes, including a ''Live From Lincoln Center'' broadcast on public television. It seems like only yesterday that television was busy celebrating Mr. Copland's 80th birthday. Much of what should be said, obviously, has been said before, but Mr. Copland's story, like his music, still wears remarkably well.

title: COURT TO RULE PRESS ACCESS TO CRIMINAL HEARINGS
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the First Amendment gives the public and press a right to attend preliminary hearings in criminal cases.

title: RECITAL: MEIRELLES IN BEETHOVEN SERIES
description: DEBUT concerts tend to be timid affairs. The artist usually trots out an hour or two of sure-fire material, carefully calculated to dazzle the balcony and impress the critics. The emphasis is on making a secure first impression, and few chances are taken.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income including a gain of $1.6 million from an insurance claim for a fire.

title: U.S. TESTS FOR TAINTED WINES CONTINUE
description: IN the nearly three months since the Austrian wine scandal came to light, Federal testing of about 1,000 imported wines in the United States has turned up 58 containing poisonous diethylene glycol used as a sweetener, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said yesterday.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Chase Accord In Maryland
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank has agreed with Maryland officials to buy three troubled Maryland thrift institutions and turn them into commercial banks. Today Gov. Harry R. Hughes called a special session of the Legislature, which will meet Thursday to authorize the move.

title: A GOOD LIFE IN A GARDEN OF PLENTY
description: UP in the Catskills on Lookout Farm in Napanoch, N.Y., a deer nibbles on fallen apples. A wild turkey disappears into the bush. Roses, first cultivated in 17th-century France, bloom in unlikely shades of lilac, peach and blood red. The scene is bucolic but hardly a still life - for here, Eugene and Beverly Gregan transform everything that grows into a feast for the senses.

title: Self-Defeating Strategic Defense Initiative
description: To the Editor:

title: PACIFIC TELESIS NET UP
description: The GTE Corporation, plagued by heavy losses in its Sprint long-distance telephone unit, yesterday reported a 1 percent increase in third-quarter net income, to $290 million, from $287 million in the period a year earlier. Earnings per share, however, fell to $1.33, from $1.40, because of an increase in the number of shares outstanding.

title: BEARS ARE UNABLE TO TRADE HOLDOUT
description: Owners and executives of the 28 National Football League teams spent hours in meetings at a hotel in New York yesterday, discussing a wide range of matters. But the most significant development might have been one that didn't happen.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Wine Auction What is being billed as the first major wine auction in New York City in a number of years will take place at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. on Saturday, Oct. 26, at Morrell & Company, 307 East 53d Street. The auction, occasioned by the wine shop's move the following Monday to smaller space at 535 Madison Avenue (54th Street), will feature items from the company's own collection of fine and rare wines accumulated over the past 30 years, including 19th- and 20th-century Bordeaux and Burgundies, fine estate-bottled Champagnes and Champagnes roses, very old Sauternes and vintage Ports dating from 1830 on. The 765 lots to be auctioned have an estimated value of $500,000.

title: 31 KILLED IN COLLAPSE OF ROOF AT UNIVERSITY IN BANGLADESH
description: The roof of a university dormitory collapsed on hundreds of students during heavy rain tonight. Officials said 31 people had been killed, and other reports said more than 100 were dead.

title: ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Davis Sues N.F.L.
description: Kenneth Davis, the former Texas Christian University running back, sued the National Football League for $13 million yesterday because the league barred him from joining any of its teams in the same season he played college football. Davis became available to play after T.C.U. suspended him after he acknowledged that he accepted money from boosters.

title: SMITH, A O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $399,000 for the quarter and $8,027,000 for the nine months. c-Net loss. d-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,063,000 for the quarter and $10,744,000 for the nine months.

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ST. LAWRENCE SEAWAY SHUT AFTER A LOCK COLLAPSES
description: Ore carriers, grain carriers, oil tankers and other ships bearing hundreds of thousands of tons of cargo backed up at the ends of the Welland Canal today after the St. Lawrence Seaway was closed Monday by the collapse of a lock's concrete wall.

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Maine Unit Bonds Total $50.5 Million
description: The Maine State Housing Authority is offering $50.5 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bonds Is Caught Way Off Base
description: The number 461 sits at the bottom of a column of statistics in the baseball reference books. It is an impressive enough figure - the total of bases that Bobby Bonds stole during a 14-year major league career - but it is not quite so impressive as 681. And Bonds's somewhat confused understanding of the difference, combined with an advertising agency's embarrassing lapse in fact-checking, caused the Miller Brewing Company yesterday to suspend the televising of a commercial in which Bonds is a star. The suspension is effective today.

title: FALLING BEER SALES A CONCERN
description: Distributors at the National Beer Wholesalers Convention, concerned because sales are down, say that they must re-examine marketing strategies or rely more heavily on imports and nonalcoholic brands.

title: NOTHIN' UNTIL THE REPLAY
description: The best teams in the American League's two divisions are in its championship series. But some of the best umpires aren't in it - as instant replay has shown. And because baseball selects its postseason arbiters on rotation rather than merit, the umpiring could tarnish the World Series as it has the A.L. playoff.

title: Topics;   Carrying On; Heir and Parent
description: ''Dear Friend,'' said a letter we received in 1982 from Pyongyang, North Korea. ''We are sending you immortal classics of the Dear Leader Comrade KIM JONG IL.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page picture caption in some editions on Sunday, about the Achille Lauro hijacking, misidentified a man shown with Marilyn Klinghoffer, and a correction in this space on Monday specified the error incompletely. In early editions, which pictured Mrs. Klinghoffer at the bottom of the page, an unidentified man stood beside her. In late editions, showing her at the top of the page, the man alongside her was correctly identified as Jay Fischer, a lawyer and family friend.

title: FLAGLER BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Eased Capital Rule Proposed
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed easing restrictions today on brokerage firms' use of corporate debt securities to hedge their positions in other corporate bonds.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All figures restated to reflect the acquisition of Arltru Bancorp in August.

title: Congress and Dangerfield
description: For members of Congress who worry about their legislative image, the words of Nicholas Longworth might provide a bit of comfort.

title: HUNGARIANS ABRUPTLY CANCEL PRIVATE HELSINKI REVIEW UNIT
description: The first Helsinki treaty review to be held in a Soviet-bloc country opened with a dispute here today.

title: A Busy Initiation For Itel President
description: Rod Dammeyer joined the Itel Corporation as president and chief operating officer only two weeks ago, but he has already negotiated a deal the company had been mulling for months: the acquisition of Great Lakes International Inc., the nation's largest dredging and harbor improvement concern.

title: A VERSATILE GIFT AND TARGET TIME
House Tax Panel Backs Charitable Deductions
description: The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to permit some taxpayers to take deductions for their charitable contributions even if they do not file itemized returns.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: STONES' LATEST PROJECT: 635 PAGES ON PISSARO
description: ''In our household, The Book is God,'' says Jean Stone, wife, chief editor and business manager to Irving Stone, the writer. She is not speaking of the Bible, but explaining that whatever book the couple happen to be working on together - he writing, she editing - is one they take very, very seriously.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
High-Rollers Among the Thrifts
description: Hundreds of savings and loan associations are going broke, and the Federal agency that insures them doesn't have nearly enough money to cover their losses. Depositors, who are insured up to $100,000 per account, have nothing to worry about. Congress has pledged to cover the liabilities. Nonetheless, regulatory reforms are urgently needed to minimize the cost to the taxpayers.

title: Cable TV Bid
description: Communications Systems Inc. said that it had received an offer of about $35 million in cash and notes for its cable television assets. The company said that its board would consider the bid at its next meeting, scheduled for Oct. 30. It did not identify the bidder.

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EFFORTS TO SETTLE EL AL STRIKE REVIVED AS PERES VISIT NEARS
description: On the eve of a visit to the United States by the Israeli Prime Minister, officals of El Al Israel Airlines, the Israeli state airline, said today that they had made a renewed effort to end the 19-month-old strike by ground crews against the airline's operations in New York.

title: AMERICAN FLETCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Right-Wing Party Gains In Geneva Election
description: A right-wing group that wants to reduce the number of foreigners in Switzerland has emerged as one of the two strongest parties in Geneva's cantonal Parliament, according to election results published today.

title: All Together Now: Group Meditation
description: The woman was smiling and had her eyes closed, as did the other 70 or so people in the library of Maharishi International University College of Natural Law just five blocks from the White House, and she looked relaxed, her hands folded in her lap. Behind her, in the professional-looking crowd, somebody sighed loudly, and a man's head nodded precariously toward his necktie.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EMIL GILELS, SOVIET PIANIST, DIES AT 68
description: Emil Gilels, one of the world's great pianists and, in 1955, the first Soviet musician to perform in the United States since Sergei Prokofiev in 1921, died in a Moscow hospital Monday, apparently of kidney failure. Mr. Gilels also had a history of heart trouble, and the exact cause of death was not reported. He was 68 years old, and had been scheduled to embark on a concert tour of Switzerland next week.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $3,935,000 for the quarter and $5,850,000 for the nine months. c-After capital losses of $4,160,000 for the quarter and including capital gains of $10,000 for the nine months. Year-ago per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a two-for-one stock split paid in September 1985. Per share figures assume conversion of convertible debt.

title: PACIFIC TELESIS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMMERCIAL BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July.

title: BERNDT PUTS SOME FIGHT IN QUAKERS
description: A golfing companion of Jerry Berndt, the Penn football coach, says that Berndt always sinks his 3-foot putts and never doubts that he will. ''That says a lot about Jerry,'' commented Herb Hartnett, the Penn sports information director. ''He has so much confidence in everything he does, and it rubs off on everybody he's around.''

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After charges totalling approximately $3.0 million from discontinued operations of Plystran at Lewiston, Idaho, and the termination of a portion of the company's federal timber purchase contracts in Idaho.

title: Bars to Parochial Pupils' Remedial Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Sales Fell 10.1% In Early October Period
description: New-car sales fell 10.1 percent in the first 10 days of October, the nation's major manufacturers reported here today. The decline followed the end of a highly successful round of incentive programs that pushed sales to record levels in September and cleaned out dealer stocks.

title: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALASKA AIR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IGGY, our desert iguana, had never been much of a pet, least of all to my husband, who resented the 100-watt bulb the lizard needed to simulate the heat of its natural environment. But rather than rejoice at Iggy's demise, my husband cried throughout the shoebox burial in the backyard. He was crying, he said, for every pet he had ever loved and lost.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Tokyo yesterday on Japanese economic changes misstated the time it would take for the changes to produce extra growth in Japan's gross national product. According to Japanese economic officials, they should generate extra growth by October 1986.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm here; I'm staying; nothing is forever, but that's where things stand at the moment.'' - Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.[D1:1.]

title: VW-Fiat Denial
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. is not engaged in talks with the Fiat S.p.A. on forming a joint venture to make cars, a company spokeman said. The spokesman was reacting to a statement from Giovanni Agnelli, Fiat's chairman, that Fiat considered Volkswagen, the General Motors Corporation and Peugeot S.A. as possible partners for such a venture.

title: FUR VAULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GRACE, W R & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Decision to Sell Martin Processing
description: Martin Processing Inc., the subject of takeover rumors, said that its board had made no decision to sell the company, which designs custom machinery.

title: NIELSON TO TRY NEW AUDIENCE-SURVEY DEVICE
description: The A.C. Nielsen Company, whose ratings are the single most powerful factor in television advertising and programming, announced yesterday that it would begin experimenting with a new instrument designed to gather almost instantaneously more data from a larger survey group.

title: An Insurance Crisis Not Just for Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AVIALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place;   Jersey's Banks Still Gaining
description: THE passage of an interstate banking law in New Jersey, viewed by Wall Street analysts as a distinct possiblility in the coming months, is proving a boon to the shares of numerous banks in the Garden State.

title: DOMINICA'S FINALLY GETS U.N.'S ATTENTION
description: When the Prime Minister of the Caribbean island nation of Dominica addressed the General Assembly this morning, she startled many listeners because she did exactly what the organizers of the 40th anniversary celebrations had asked of world leaders.

title: MAYOR GOODE SAYS AIDES MISSED HIM
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode said today for the first time that his subordinates had misled, misinformed and disobeyed him in the city's confrontation with the radical group Move.

title: IN BUFFALO, A LIVELY CONTEST FOR MAYOR
description: If George K. Arthur can duplicate his victory in the Democratic primary, he will become the first black mayor of a major New York city.

title: Denver Voters Reject New Convention Center
description: Voters today sharply rejected a proposal to build a new convention center near the city's railroad terminal, a development that proponents had hoped would turn the city into a major convention site.

title: FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A LARGE segment of the public seem to believe that food professionals live on diets that consist mainly of truffle-studded pates, caviar and lobsters washed down with vintage wines and champagnes. To my amusement, I am often asked if I would ever dine on the likes of hamburgers and chili con carne. The truth is that I am quite fond of preparations such as these, my feeling being that good food is anything made with quality ingredients and imagination tempered with good taste.

title: American Medical Stake for Basses
description: Members of the Bass family of Fort Worth said that they had purchased more than 7.4 million shares of American Medical International Inc., or 8.7 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $575,000 on the early extinguishment of debt.

description: Conde Nast's Glamour breaks a new trade campaign by David Deutsch Associates next week.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Named Terry Logan director of scouting.

description: b-Including a gain of $1,559,000 from property transactions.

JETS CAUTIOUSLY JUBILANT
description: Joe Walton, the only 5-1 coach in the American Football Conference, was being wary.

description: By Yakov Pectoh - From Soviet Embassy, Washington, to General Secretary Gorbachev:

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Kill Lawyers' Is Not Shakespeare's Line
description: To the Editor:

title: ROYALS HOLD OFF BLUE JAYS AND FORCE SERIES LIMIT
description: No team had done it for almost five months, but someone finally has caught Toronto - and at the worst possible time for the Blue Jays.

title: OKLAHOMA TOPS TIME'S RANKING
description: Oklahoma, third last week, moved past Michigan as the nation's No. 1 college football team in this week's New York Times computer ranking. Florida, Army and Air Force round out the top five. Page B12.

title: Ogygian Is Out Until Next Year
description: Ogygian, the undefeated 2-year-old colt who would have been heavily favored in the Champagne Stakes at Belmont on Saturday and in the Breeder's Cup juvenile at Aqueduct Nov. 2, is out for the year with bucked shins, his handlers said yesterday.

title: FUTURE M.B.A.'S LEARN VALUE OF A HOME LIFE
description: ''But how could Willy Loman be the family's leader, if he was the sick one?'' asked Dr. Abraham Zaleznik, a Harvard Business School professor whose class had just studied Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman'' as a homework assignment.

title: GTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHEELING -PITTSBURGH NEARS AN ACCORD WITH STEEL UNION
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America reached a tentative contract agreement today that could end an 87-day strike, the steel industry's biggest shutdown in a quarter-century.

title: SECURITY PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $115 million pre-tax gain from sale of the bank's headquarters building and a $150 million special provision for credit losses. Year-ago per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a 2wo-for-1 stock split effected in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend effective Jan. 24, 1985.

title: Not-So-Free Wheeling
description: At the corner of the Avenue of the Americas and 37th Street, two police officers were halting bicyclists and checking their identification.

title: TRAILBLAZER AND TEAM PLAYER
description: The choice of Franco Modigliani as winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science is a popular one among economists, a tribe often given to highly refined and sometimes vocal dispute. Yesterday congratulatory telephone calls and laudatory telegrams poured in to his office at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: AMERICAN CYANAMID CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $3.8 million for the quarter and $13.4 million for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $5.9 million and a gain of $3 million on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: PEPSICO INCOME UP 14.4% IN 3D QUARTER
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that its third-quarter net income increased by 14.4 percent while sales increased 10.5 percent. Analysts said the figures were in line with expectations.

title: CNW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,409,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the defeasance of $23.5 million of the company's most senior mortgage bonds and nonrecurring costs of $2,641,000 for the quarter and $3,576,000 for the 9 months incurred for a continuing program to eliminate 1,500 jobs. c-Net income.

title: BEST BUY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A DOUBLE BLOW TO ARAFAT
description: Yasir Arafat's international standing has been greatly damaged by the Achille Lauro affair, according to both Arab and Israeli Middle East political analysts.

title: FIRST ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said all per share earnings were restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock splits distributed May 25 and Oct. 15.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Soviet Women's Group Arrives for U.S. Visits
description: A delegation of 13 Soviet women began a two-week national tour of the United States here today with the declared mission, shared by their American hosts, of improving Soviet-American relations at the individual level.

title: Felony Charges Dropped As Judge Cites Goetz
description: Comparing the defendant to Bernhard Goetz, who shot four young men on a New York City subway when they asked him for money, a judge dropped felony charges against a man who shot two youths he believed had thrown a brick through his car window.

title: CIVIL WAR INTRODUCTION FOR YOUNG VIEWERS
description: HOW do you present a program that purports to be an introduction to the Civil War - even for young viewers - without once mentioning the reason why the war was fought; without using the words secession, rebellion, Constitution, Union, emancipation or slavery; without showing one black face among the hundreds that fill the screen?

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Friday about the surrender of the jeweler Nicola Bulgari in a tax case included an incorrect description, from the office of Attorney General Robert Abrams, on the sequence of events surrounding the indictment. Mr. Bulgari was already out of the country on Aug. 7 when the indictment was unsealed. He was considered a fugitive by the Attorney General's office until his surrender last week.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Blount Inc., Montgomery, Ala., said one of its construction units had received a $21.3 million contract to build a Navy training equipment center near Orlando, Fla.

title: GAMBINO TRIAL HEARS CAR THIEF DESCRIBE WORK
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday presented vivid police testimony about two 1977 murders that they said they would tie to the conspiracy and car-theft charges against the reputed head of the Gambino crime organization and nine others on trial in Manhattan.

title: BUSH ENDS CHINA VISIT ON HIGH NOTE
description: Vice President Bush today completed three days of talks with Chinese leaders. He said relations between the two countries were ''strong, both economically and strategically,'' and not at risk over the renewed Chinese pressures on the Taiwan issue.

title: TIMES FIBER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MEXICO'S ENTOMBED BABIES WIN THE FIGHT FOR LIFE
description: The Nunez baby isn't very old; she was born just a short time before two earthquakes devastated parts of this capital, including the hospital where she first came into the world.

title: MUSIC: SHANKAR RECITAL IS PART OF INDIA FESTIVAL
description: RAVI SHANKAR'S recital Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum followed a lecture-demonstration there the previous evening; both were presented in conjunction with the museum's ''India!'' exhibition, in turn part of the nationwide Festival of India.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GORBACHEV GIVES NEW GUIDELINES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented drafts of new political and economic programs today that he said were free of the ''groundless fantasies'' of past blueprints yet would almost double national income within 15 years.

title: CORESTATES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $8,050,000 on the sale of long-term assets, a special loan loss provision of $10,800,000 and including income from discontinued operations of $360,000 and a gain on the sale of a subsidiary of $95.8 million. c-After income from discontinued operations of $2.4 million. Per share figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 common stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend declared Aug. 20, 1985, effective Oct. 15, 1985.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlas Copco Roctec Inc., Wayne, N.J., the mining and construction subsidiary of Atlas Copco North America Inc., has named Thomas M. Martinsen president, succeeding Donald M. Ulbrich, who resigned.

title: KENYA OFFERS 2 NEW WINES
description: Kenya released its first locally made grape wine Tuesday, and the producers say that some of the first bottles will go to the United States.

title: New Financing By Sallie Mae
description: For the second time in two months, the Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering a yen-denominated dual-currency issue in the Eurobond market.

title: WOOD PULP AS FIBER IN BREAD
description: THE source of fiber in a number of high-fiber breads is nonnutritional wood pulp, according to a Washington-based consumer group. The group, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, listed nine such breads on the market: Less; Roman Lite; Lite Loaf; Lite'n Up; Merita Lite; Tasty Lite; Sunbeam Lite; Vim, and 40.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REDMEN LOOK FOR THE SILVER LINING
description: Lacking the fanfare but none of the enthusiasm from a year ago, St. John's previewed its 1985-86 basketball season yesterday with a practice session at Madison Square Garden.

title: SAGA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: The company announced stock dividends of 13 cents per share for the latest period and 11 cents per share for the year-ago period.

title: 15 MARINES DIE IN COPTER CRASH OFF NORTH CAROLINA
description: A helicopter carrying 19 marines plunged into the ocean while taking off from a ship on maneuvers in pre-dawn darkness today, and officials said 15 marines were killed and four rescued.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: LANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reversal for an End
description: Tom McHale, the Cornell transfer student who had been allowed to play defensive end for the Big Red despite a National Collegiate Athletic Association rule requiring him to sit out a year, lost his legal shield yesterday with the expiration of the restraining order that had prohibited enforcement of the rule. Unless the Federal judge who issued the order issues a new one by Saturday, or rules in McHale's favor on the merits of the case, he will not be allowed to play against Brown.

title: POP: STOCKTON'S WING BAND
description: THE Irish band Stockton's Wing merges a three-piece folk group - fiddle, flute and mandolin or banjo - with a four-piece rock band. It is a self-consciously hybrid lineup, and its early set Monday at the Bottom Line (15 West Fourth Street) was a mixture of traditional tunes, modern folk-rock and material that was a little of each.

title: INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books: Today's Weapon-Makers
description: STAR WARRIORS. By William J. Broad. 245 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Advertising;   Charting A Drop in Rate Base
description: THERE is no more competitive environment in magazineland than among the leading women's magazines, known familiarly as the Seven Sisters. And among their number there is particularly hot blood between Good Housekeeping, The Ladies' Home Journal and McCall's. Three scrappy old gals, with Good Housekeeping, the youngest, celebrating its centennial this year.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,146,000 from the disposition of options.

title: NATIONAL GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the three-for-two stock split paid Oct. 1, 1985.

title: PROGRESS IN NEWSPAPER STRIKE
description: The two Philadelphia newspapers and nine striking newspaper unions appeared close to a settlement tonight in a six-week strike that has idled 4,500 workers and cost the city millions of dollars in revenue.

title: INVENTORIES DOWN 0.4% IN AUGUST
description: Business inventories fell four-tenths of 1 percent in August, the biggest decline in more than two years, the Commerce Department said today. Consumer demand, especially for automobiles, outdistanced the ability of companies to restock.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures reflect a 3-for- 2 stock split effective Sept. 25, 1985.

title: 2 BOMB EXPLOSIONS IN UTAH KILL BROKER AND EX-ASSOCIATE'S WIFE
description: Two booby-trap bombs exploded three hours apart today, killing a stockbroker outside his downtown office and a woman at the suburban home of the stockbroker's former business associate, the police said.

title: Stargell Joins Tanner
description: Willie Stargell, the slugger who was regarded as the soul of the Pittsburgh Pirates during his 20 years as a player and three as a minor league instructor and major league coach, has decided to follow his former manager, Chuck Tanner, to Atlanta to become a coach for the Braves. ''I have the chance to be with someone I admire and respect,'' Stargell told The Atlanta Constitution. Stargell, who spent his entire major league career in Pittsburgh and became the team's first-base coach at midseason, is expected to sign a Braves contract this week and to work as a batting instructor and first-base coach.

title: MYLAN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split on Feb. 15, 1985.

title: 4 LIBERIANS RUN FOR PRESIDENT IN NATION'S FIRST MULTIPARTY ELECTION
description: Gen. Samuel K. Doe ran for President against three other candidates today in the first multiparty election since this West African nation was founded by freed American slaves in 1847.

title: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge: Deals From Championships To Be Replayed in New York
description: While 10 countries fight a two-week battle for the world team championship in Brazil starting Sunday, some New York players will be able to compete in a more relaxed ''Bermuda Bowl'' event.

title: U.S. TELLS TROOPS: ''DON'T BE OBVIOUS''
description: To protect American military personnel from terrorists, the United States armed forces have instructed members to conceal their identities as much as possible when traveling abroad in areas of high risk.

title: CHARGES ARE DISMISSED IN BUILDING OCCUPATION
description: All charges filed against a State Senator and 14 other demonstrators in the illegal occupation of a vacant city-owned building last summer were dropped yesterday at the request of District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn.

title: NET RISES BY 13.5% AT CITICORP
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank-holding company, said yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter increased 13.5 percent, somewhat less than analysts had expected.

title: CONCERT: BACH GROUP
description: THE New England Bach Festival, where Blanche Honegger Moyse presides over the Thomaskantor's great choral works with priestlike devotion and authority, brought its chorus and orchestra to Symphony Space Monday to join a group of nationally known soloists for the St. John Passion.

title: Winning Alumni
description: Consecutive victories over South Carolina and North Carolina State hint that the Pitt football team, now 3-2-1, has turned its season around. But the Panthers cannot yet match the success of three prominent alumni, each of whom is now a head coach in the National Football League and each of whom is in first place in his division: Joe Walton of the Jets, Mike Ditka of Chicago and Marty Schottenheimer of Cleveland.

title: VOLCKER REJECTS MOVE TO WORLD BANK POST
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he had turned down an offer of the presidency of the World Bank, which the Reagan Administration wants to make its principal agent in helping the developing world deal with its debts.

title: CONSOLIDATED CAPITAL REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Big Blitz on Campus
description: As Representative Richard J. Durbin of Illinois watched college students cheer at Ronald Reagan's re-election in 1984, he realized the Democratic Party was in trouble. ''It struck me that perhaps we've been taking the campuses for granted too long,'' he said.

title: JEFFERSON BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STUDIED MARKET SHIFTS AND SAVING
description: Franco Modigliani, a 67-year-old professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, today won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for his pioneering work in analyzing the behavior of household savers and the functioning of financial markets.

title: Article 083054 -- No Title
description: Cluett, Peabody & Company, the nation's fifth-largest apparel company, said yesterday that a group of investors led by the California businessman Paul A. Bilzerian had begun a cash tender offer for the common and preferred shares not already owned by the group. The offer was valued at $258.9 million.

title: CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $13,000 for the quarter and $38,000 for the 9 months from the early retirement of debt. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $139,000 and an extraordinary gain of $53,000 from the early retirement of debt. d-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $109,000, an extraordinary loss of $150,000 from the early retirement of debt and a pretax gain of $27.5 million from the sale of property.

title: No Cause for Regret
description: Hurt feelings, not broken bones, account for those cries of anguish from Egypt and Italy. America's swift action in the Achille Lauro episode exposed the hypocrisies with which they tried to resolve their diplomatic dilemmas. But that is no reason to let their politics take precedence over ours. No American has to regret seizing the hijackers and fuming about the P.L.O. chieftain who got away.

title: TEACHERS STRIKE AS NEGOTIATIONS FAIL IN PATERSON
description: The 1,800 teachers of Paterson's 25,000-student school system struck tonight over salaries and the length of the school day, their union president said.

title: REISCHAUER IS FETED IN CAPITAL
description: Academics and political leaders gathered here today to pay tribute to Edwin O. Reischauer, America's foremost expert on Japan, and to celebrate the opening of the new Reischauer Center for East Asian Studies at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies.

title: E-Z-M INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
VYQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $22,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SHIPPING OFFICIALS WEIGHING IMPACT OF A BLOCKED SEAWAY
description: The impact on shipping from the blocked Welland Canal on the St. Lawrence Seaway could be serious if the disruption lasts longer than a month, shipping officials said yesterday.

title: SHULTZ ASSURES NATO ON ABM PACT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz assured NATO foreign ministers here today that President Reagan intended to adhere to a relatively narrow interpretation of the 1972 treaty with the Soviet Union limiting antiballistic missiles.

title: Deneuve's New Role: Symbol of All France
description: Parisians began voting today on which statuette of the film star Catherine Deneuve - traditional or modern, clothed or naked - they want as the new symbol of the French Republic.

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SYRIA REPORTS ACCORD AMONG LEBANESE
description: Three of the most powerful Lebanese militias agreed today to a Syrian-sponsored plan aimed at ending the 10-year-old civil war that has claimed more than 100,000 lives, Syrian officials said.

title: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a special pretax charge of $159.2 million. c-Net income.

title: Visa Meets in China
description: Visa International Inc.'s board met today in China, where capitalist conveniences like credit cards were unheard of until a few years ago. The official New China News Agency quoted Bu Ming, director of the Bank of China, as saying the Peking meeting would promote business cooperation between the state-run bank and Visa, which is one of the world's largest credit card systems, with about 104 million card holders. Visa cards have been used in China since 1981, and now 70 branches and sub-branches of the Bank of China and 300 hotels and businesses honor the credit cards.

title: MERIDIAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Include after-tax income of $897,000 from American Title Insurance Co., which was acquired in June 1985.

title: Topics;   Carrying On; Surprise Party?
description: The President's Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution has met twice, in secrecy. When asked why the celebration of an open society's charter should be planned behind closed doors, Chief Justice Burger, the chairman, explained: ''We are following the precedent of the original meeting of the Constitutional Convention of 1787.

title: U.S. and Soviet Open Talks on Airline Link
description: The United States and the Soviet Union opened talks here today on resuming a direct airline connection.

title: 4 Frontier Unions Vote
description: Four of Frontier Airlines' five unions have begun ratifying the People Express proposal to buy the Denver-based carrier for $300 million. ''We hope to have ratification completed by the end of the month,'' a Frontier spokesman, Sandra Allen, said today.

title: ART BOOM SEEKS NEW CURATORS

title: JONI MITCHELL TAKES UP TOPICALITY

For on ''Dog Eat Dog,'' the most probing confessional singer-songwriter of the 1970's has largely forsworn autobiographical self-examination in favor of blunt topical commentary.

But the Administration has decided to turn down the Indian Government's request for an even more advanced supercomputer, the official said, because of worries about its possible use in nuclear research.

Statoil said the 547-mile pipeline, which has cost $2.34 billion, will ultimately deliver about 280 billion cubic feet of gas a year to Western European utilities.

title: THE ART OF BRINGING A CAFE BACK TO LIFE
description: TO anyone else, the Cafe des Artistes appears shipshape in every detail. But not to its owner, George Lang. ''That tablecloth is not properly pressed,'' Mr. Lang tells his dinner companion, looking at the table directly in his line of vision. ''The flatware is not properly set,'' he says pointing to one on the other side of the room. ''That party - I'm not going to point them out - is not properly dressed and they are seated in too prominent a place.''

title: One Navigator to Another
description: Dr. Daniel J. Boorstin, the Librarian of Congress, will be officially made a Grand Officer of the Order of Prince Henry the Navigator today in a ceremony at the Portuguese Embassy. The order is named after the 15th-century prince of Portugal who was responsible, through encouraging mapmaking and exploration, for much of his country's colonial empire as well as its seagoing reputation. At a dinner Ambassador Leonardo Mathias will present the new Grand Officer with a certificate and a medal, a red and white Maltese cross suspended on a blue and white ribbon, in recognition of Dr. Boorstin's authorship of ''The Discoverers,'' an account of innovators, geographical and otherwise, down through history.

title: KLA INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PRIDE. By William Wharton. 288 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. ''THERE is all kinds of pride, Dickie,'' says a character midway through William Wharton's new novel. ''There's real pride, like being proud of good work, like when we do a good job building a porch. Then there's false pride like when you think you're better than somebody else for no good reason; that's the sin one. Then there's the lion's pride, his family.'' Those disparate definitions of the word pride - which, not incidentally, happens to be the title of this novel -pretty much summarize what the book's about, and they're also about the only thing that ties its jumpy, hodgepodge narrative together.

title: TABLE MANNERS: A CASUALTY OF CHANGING TIMES
description: COMPARED with the table manners of peasants and kings in the Middle Ages -people who mistrusted forks and other eating equipment - those of today's young people represent a period of high manners.

Hormel & Company and the union representing 1,500 meatpackers on strike at the company's flagship plant have been broken off indefinitely, a company official said today. A union official said talks Monday failed to resolve a wage dispute and other issues. The talks were the first since the walkout began Aug. 17.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Blue Jays vs. Kansas City Royals, at Toronto, seventh game of the four-of-seven-game American League championship series. (Television - Channel 4, 8:15 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 8:15 P.M.) Dodgers vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Los Angeles, sixth game of the four-of-seven-game National League championship series.
