Boxing Meldrick Taylor vs. Carlos Santana, eight rounds, lightweights, at Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8 P.M. This is the first eight-rounder for Taylor, the Olympic gold medalist. Hockey Rangers vs. Los Angeles Kings, at Inglewood, Calif., 10:35 P.M. Marcel Dionne had two goals and two assists to lead Los Angeles to victories in two of the three meetings with the Rangers last season. (Television -MSG Network, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 10:20 P.M.) Islanders vs. Oilers, at Edmonton, Alberta, 9:35 P.M. The Islanders face the defending Stanley Cup champions for the first time this season. title: SUMMATIONS ARE PRESENTED IN SPY TRIAL OF F.B.I. AGENT
description: A Government prosecutor today portrayed Richard W. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as the man who ''turned over the playbook of American intelligence operations worldwide'' to the Soviet Union.

title: OPERA: 'KHOVANSHCHINA' AT MET AFTER 35 YEARS
description: MUSSORGSKY'S ''Khovanshchina'' lacks some of the sonic splendor of his ''Boris Godunov,'' but it is a powerful work that ought to be better known in this country. Like ''Boris,'' it deals with actual events in Russian history, bent here and there to meet the composer's theatrical needs. Its plot is extremely convoluted even for Russian opera, with tangled political alliances and crisscrossing personal loyalties as confusing as anything to be found in modern Beirut. But it is a score that can work on one's imagination, and when imaginatively staged, as it was last night at the Metropolitan Opera by August Everding, ''Khovanshchina'' overcomes all obstacles.

title: UTENSILS FOR MAKING DESSERT OF THE YEAR
description: IF there were a New York dessert of the year award, the 1985 ribbon would go to creme brulee, or burnt cream, which has appeared on countless menus in both French and American restaurants. I am not sure how a dish that has been consumed for centuries in Europe without great fanfare - it is believed to be of English origin although many countries have their own versions - has suddenly achieved such fame in America, but it has.

title: Reagan's World-Court Error
description: The worst decisions are made in anger. President Reagan's decision to withdraw from the compulsory jurisdiction of the World Court was a lamentable overreaction to the impending negative ruling in the case of our clearly illegal mining of Nicaragua's harbors. The action may give us some fleeting satisfaction. But in the long term it will damage our foreign policy interests, undermine our legitimacy as a voice for morality and erode the rule of law in international relations.

title: 'STAR WARS' DISPUTE
description: For more than a week, Reagan Administration officials have been at odds over the extent to which a 13-year-old arms treaty with the Soviet Union limits President Reagan's plan to develop a space-based missile defense. title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: TIME FOR BUSINESS - For the first time in 19 days of regular sessions, the General Assembly takes a day off from the stream of world leaders to transact a little business. Routine approval is expected for the election of five new temporary members of the Security Council: Bulgaria, Congo, Liberia, United Arab Emirates and Venezuela. If elected, the five nations, selected by their regional groups of states, will serve two year-terms on the 15-member Council beginning Jan. 1. Burkina Faso, Egypt, India, Peru and the Ukraine will step down from the Council. In the afternoon, the Assembly will elect new members to the Economic and Social Council.

description: William E. Vandiver, convicted of killing his father-in-law, was electrocuted here today. He was the first prisoner executed outside the South since 1981.

title: BOTH SIDES OPTIMISTIC ON SOLUTION
description: More than 80,000 Chrysler workers in the United States and Canada went on strike today, seeking wages and benefits parallel to those at General Motors and Ford. Union talks with the Chrysler Corporation, the nation's third-largest automaker failed to produce agreement before the contract expired at midnight.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Higher
description: Treasury bond prices continued to edge higher yesterday in light trading, despite some late selling based on predictions by the Reagan Administration that the economy will strengthen in the coming months. Meanwhile, the tax-exempt and corporate-bond markets turned moderately bullish because of the good receptions accorded several major new issues yesterday.

title: Meese on Courts And the Constitution
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has a vivid vision of the Constitution, one that his critics call a nightmare that would question rights and principles established long ago.

title: Hoover Suitor Discussed Offer
description: The Chicago Pacific Corporation disclosed today that it was in touch with the Hoover Company almost a year before it bid $40 a share for the vacuum cleaner manufacturer. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Chicago Pacific said that in late 1984 and early 1985, representatives of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, acting on behalf of Chicago Pacific, got in touch with Joseph S. Hoover, vice president of the company's board, ''to discuss the possible acquisition'' of Hoover.

title: Heroin Seized in Austria
description: The Austrian police have seized 133 pounds of heroin and arrested 21 people in what they say is the largest seizure of the drug ever in Europe. Interior Minister Karl Blecha said at a news conference today that most of those arrested were Iranians or Turks. The heroin, brought here in trucks and destined for the West Coast of the United States, was worth $8.1 million, Mr. Blecha said.

title: ART: 'AKBAR'S INDIA,' AT ASIA SOCIETY
description: OF the many exhibitions that are part of the Festival of India, ''Akbar's India: Art From the Mughal City of Victory'' is one of the most unusual and accessible. Its subject is the Emperor Jalal ad-Din Akbar and his effect on Mughal culture. The particular focus of the 80 paintings and manuscripts in the show - at the Asia Society, 70th Street and Park Avenue, through Jan. 5 - is Fatehpur-Sikri, Akbar's capital city from 1571 to 1585.

FILM: SCOTTISH GANGSTER
description: ''A SENSE OF FREEDOM'' is based on an autobiographical novel of the same name by Jimmy Boyle, an inveterate Glasgow gangster whose activities bring him a life sentence on a murder charge, and whose violent behavior hardly abated once he found himself behind bars. Filmed for Scottish television by John Mackenzie, whose tough, flamboyant underworld thriller ''The Long Good Friday'' was so memorable, ''A Sense of Freedom'' catalogues the frequent and vicious scuffles that characterized Mr. Boyle's prison career.

title: 'Inner-German' Ties And U.S. Interests
description: When Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany comes to New York next week for consultation on the summit meeting, he hopes also to meet privately with President Reagan. For far too long, Washington and Bonn have failed to discuss the consequences for their alliance of these developing ''inner-German'' ties.

description: Among the graffiti splattered on much of a D train the other day was the word ''zone'' in large white letters across a window.

title: PUERTO RICO OFFICIALS LOWER ESTIMATE OF LANDSLIDE'S TOLL
description: City officials said today that the landslide that buried the shantytown of Mameyes may have killed far fewer people than originally estimated.

title: TYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net loss from discontinued operations of $798,000 and including a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $9,359,000.

title: GREAT AMERICAN FIRST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mexican Debt Proposal
description: Leftist opposition parties have called for an 18-month halt in repaying Mexico's $97 billion debt because of last month's earthquake damage. ''We demand that the Government take this measure immediately and encourage other indebted countries to do the same,'' they said in a statement Wednesday.

title: Eye Care
description: Eye Care has one of the simplest names, the lowest overhead and the most directly related fund-raising event of any nonprofit organization in Washington. Although it was established by two Americans in 1978 and its financing base is here, Eye Care is of Haitians, by Haitians and for Haitians.

title: S.E.C. Asks Position Limits
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked five stock exchanges and the National Association of Securites Dealers today to consider voluntarily ''telescoping'' their existing limits on the number of stock index option contracts that can be held by a single trader as the contracts near their expiration.

title: PATERSON TEACHERS DEFY BACK-TO-WORK ORDER
description: Most of this city's 1,800 striking teachers today defied a judge's back-to-work order, disrupting classes for a second day in the state's third-largest school district.

title: CALTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Inland Has a Loss; Dow's Profits Drop
description: The Inland Steel Company, the nation's fourth-largest steelmaker, today reported a loss of $52 million in the third quarter. The loss, its worst since industry demand plummeted in 1982, compared with a loss of $39.7 million in the third quarter of 1984.

title: Israel Jails 4 Arabs for a Plot To Attack the U.S. Embassy
description: Four Arabs were jailed for up to seven years today for plotting a grenade attack on the United States Embassy here last year.

title: LETTER OF UNSURE ORIGIN MAY VARY FROM MORMON VERSION ON TABLETS
description: Ever since Joseph Smith said he was led by an angel in upstate New York to golden tablets from which he translated the Book of Mormon, there have been critics who contend that his account of the Mormon faith's distinctive scripture was a fiction concocted by a man obsessed with the occult and buried treasure.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CARDS WILL RELY ON PROLIFIC OFFENSE
description: For the last month or so, the St. Louis Cardinals have struck people as a team with a chip on its shoulder. Ozzie Smith tells why: ''Nobody picked us to win in spring training. We had to convince people we could beat the Mets. We had to beat everybody in our division. It was very competitive, and very tough, and we never got credit for what we were doing.''

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH ROSE TO 3.3% RATE IN THIRD QUARTER
description: The nation's economy expanded at a 3.3 percent annual rate during the third quarter, somewhat faster than earlier estimated, the Commerce Department said today.

title: ARGOSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Including a nonrecurring tax credit of $400,000 due to a change in the tax laws.

title: WYETH FAMILY'S WORKS ON VIEW AND FOR SALE
description: If there is a first family of contemporary American art, the Wyeths of Pennsylvania would seem to have clear title.

title: Fats Domino to Play
description: The New Orleans rock pianist Fats Domino will perform at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues (254-2800), at about 1 A.M. Saturday. Tickets are $14.50.

title: Ad Director Resigns Post at New Yorker
description: Robert F. Young, with 25 years -or half of his lifetime - at The New Yorker has resigned from the position of vice president and advertising director. Steven T. Florio, the new publisher, said that negotiations with a potential replacement from the outsidewere nearing completion.

title: MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. AID TO NICARAGUA REBELS RUNS INTO SNAGS IN HONDURAS
description: The transfer of $27 million in United States aid to the guerrillas seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government has run into trouble, according to State Department officials.

title: Divestment Injures No One but the Divestor
description: To the Editor:

title: This Voting Thicket Is Thicker
description: The Supreme Court, peering at a map of legislative districts in Indiana, has spotted the odd contours of some gerrymanders, those amphibian shapes of districts drawn for partisan advantage. The justices may be moved, in the name of reform, to clear the amphibians from the swamp. The Court would do better to let them alone.

title: MUSIC: CECILIA GASDIA, SOPRANO, IN RECITAL DEBUT
description: THE ''Italy on Stage'' series at the Vivian Beaumont Theater opened last night before an elegant audience with what was, for all practical purposes, the New York debut recital of the much-talked-about, 25-year-old Italian soprano Cecilia Gasdia.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTMES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ESI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Austrian Who Doctored Wine Given Suspended Sentenced
description: A 24-year-old Austrian was given a 15-month suspended jail sentence today for doctoring thousands of bottles of wine with a toxic chemical used in antifreeze.

title: CAR-THEFT CASE WITNESS MISIDENTIFIES A SUSPECT
description: A witness against 10 accused members of a car-theft ring yesterday wrongly identified the defendant who prosecutors say sought the witness's help in a murder.

title: Miller Recovering
description: Marvin Miller, the 68-year-old retired executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association who suffered a heart attack Saturday, was listed in satisfactory condition at New York Hospital yesterday after being transferred from intensive care.

title: FIRST SOUTHERN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOSTEK, BIG CHIP MAKER, SHUT
description: The crisis affecting the United States semiconductor industry claimed its first major victim yesterday, when the United Technologies Corporation announced the closing of its Mostek Corporation subsidiary. The move would take effect immediately, United Technologies said.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $7.4 million.

title: METROBANC FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOATMEN'S BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THEATER: LIPSHULTZ IN READING
description: THERE are some good lines and interesting stories in ''Once Upon the Present Time,'' Geri Lipschultz's dramatic reading of her own poems at the New Federal Theater. But what stays with one is the music of Lawrence (Butch) Morris that accompanies the performance.

title: UNITED FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Septet Ekaya
description: The pianist Abdullah Ibrahim (Dollar Brand) will lead his septet Ekaya - including the saxophonists Carlos Ward, Ricky Ford and Charles Davis, and the drummer Ben Riley - in a performance tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; 10, 11:30 and 1 A.M. Sunday. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: LIBERIA'S ELECTION TO THE SECURITY COUNCIL IS BLOCKED IN ASSEMBLY
description: In an unexpected development, Liberia was blocked today from becoming a nonpermanent member of the Security Council. The General Assembly chose Ghana instead.

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Illinois Bonds Yield Up to 8 7/8%
description: A $90 million issue of Cook County, Ill., general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.40 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7.10 percent in 1990, 8.30 percent in 1995 and 8 7/8 percent in 1999 through underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest 9 months include a nonrecurring pretax gain of $24 million from the sale of the Hill Store Equipment group in June.

title: SCREEN: TOUGH COMEDY
description: PAUL MORRISSEY continues to be a cinema original and his ''Mixed Blood,'' a most unorthodox look at life in the drug trade on New York's Lower East Side, is successively comic, brutal, primitive and sophisticated - a comedy with the manners of a live-action cartoon for jaded adults.

title: Whale in Coast River Still Won't Head to Sea
description: A humpback whale whose instincts scientists say have gone awry was still in a central California waterway today, a Coast Guard official said.

title: CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $22,830,000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1985
description: International

title: Futures Units Set Merger
description: In two votes today, each more than 7 to 1 in favor, members of the Chicago Board of Trade and the MidAmerica Commodity Exchange approved the merger of the two Chicago-based futures exchanges.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE SAVINGS BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a net tax credit of $24,311,000 for the quarter and $10,627,000 for the nine months. c-Including a net tax credit of $15,713,000 for the quarter and $4,426,000 for the nine months.

title: Parker Family Member To Focus on Pens Again
description: Nearly a decade ago, George Parker, chairman of the Parker Pen Company, made a decision that was to change the shape of the company his grandfather had founded in 1888. Two days ago, Parker Pen made another move, one that will make Mr. Parker a pen maker again.

title: Book Fair in New City
description: Thousands of new and used books for adults and children will be on sale tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the annual book fair sponsored by the New City Library, 220 North Main Street, New City, N.Y. Prices range from 25 cents to $1. Information: (914) 634-4997.

title: FARM FRESH INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 7
HAYNES ARRIVES AT PRACTICE
description: Mark Haynes returned to the Giants today, still bitter over his long contract battle, but promising that ''there will be no lack of effort when I play.'' How soon he will play remained unclear.

title: PENN CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $7.7 million for the quarter and the nine months from the sale of a subsidiary. c-Including a gain of $6 million for the quarter and the nine months from the settlement of claims and litigation, and sales of $48 million and operating income of $2.5 million from shore drilling subsidiaries and related operations and three manufacturing businesses that were sold in July 1985.

title: You've Come A Long Way, Scribe
description: After a century or so of reporting mostly about Washington weddings, First Ladies and White House teas, the women's contingent in the capital press corps in recent years has begun taking leading and highly visible roles covering the White House, Congress, the Supreme Court and economic affairs.

title: CAPACITY USE DECLINED TO 80.2% IN SEPTEMBER
description: Factories, mines and utilities operated at 80.2 percent of capacity in September, compared with 80.5 percent in August and 80.2 percent in July, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Chicago Board Trading Plan
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it planned to begin trading options on the Standard & Poor's 250 over-the-counter index on Oct. 25.

title: AHMANSON, H F & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEVIL STREAK ENDS IN OVERTIME LOSS
description: The Devils' undefeated season ended abruptly in overtime tonight when the Hartford Whalers continued their dominance over New Jersey with a 4-3 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: INDEPENDENT BANK CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SAVINGS BANK OF PUGET SOUND reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures are fully diluted and reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: AFTER REAGAN, WHAT?
description: The movers are moving, the shakers are shaking, and the 1988 Presidential campaign is therefore upon us. But whatever else you hear, see or read, remember that only two facts about 1988 now exist: (1) an election will be held that year; and (2) Ronald Reagan will not be in it.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SNAP-ON TOOLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIBETAN ART, ON A STATEN ISLAND HILL
description: Forty years ago, a Manhattan gallery owner named Jacqueline Klauber created a museum for Tibetan art that she had collected since childhood. She looked all over New York City for a site and finally chose a remote spot high on a wooded hill that, she said, somehow fit her image of the land known as the ''roof of the world.'' The site was Staten Island.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1985.

title: RCA HAS LOSS
description: The American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that net income for the third quarter declined 38.1 percent, while the RCA Corporation reported an operating loss, beause of the costs of a restructuring.

title: On a Crusade For a Revolution
description: Concord, Mass., where some person fired a shot that was heard round the world, is not far down the road from Worcester, where some other people have issued a cry for a new Colonial revolt. This one will not be so successful.

title: Passengers Injured As Train is Sideswiped
description: One car of a freight train derailed and tipped into Amtrak's California Zephyr tonight, smashing windows aboard the 13-car double-decker passenger train and injuring 60 people, at least one critically, the authorities said.

title: NYNEX AND US WEST EXPAND PHONE PROFITS
description: The Nynex Corporation, which owns the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company, yesterday reported a profit increase of 12.5 percent, while earnings at Colorado-based U S West Inc. rose 10.8 percent, closing out a strong third quarter for the telephone industry as a whole.

title: Zellerbach in Talks With James River
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said today that it was discussing possible transactions with the James River Corporation, another big paper concern.

title: G.M. and Isuzu
description: The General Motors Corporation has increased its stake in Isuzu Motors Ltd. to 38.6 percent, from 34.2 percent, by converting half the $200 million in convertible bonds it held in the Japanese auto maker, an Isuzu spokesman said. The deadline for converting the remaining $100 million portion is June 1988, but G.M. has made no decision on whether it will convert, he said. Separately, G.M. said in Cairo that it had signed a $59 million finance deal for a new truck factory with a consortium of banks led by Chase National Bank (Egypt) and Misr International Bank.

title: THIRD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-earlier results were restated for pooling of interest acquisition. The per share figures were restated for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Sept. 12.

title: PAINTERS TO THE KING, THE FRENCH TASTE
description: ''THE FIRST PAINTERS OF THE KING,'' at Stair Sainty Matthiesen, 141 East 69th Street, is subtitled ''French Royal Taste From Louis XIV to the Revolution.'' Neither phrase, in itself, is likely to draw a crowd, yet the exhibition is one that does us all a service. It is full, moreover, of works of art that are both learned and voluptuous, majestic and highly energized.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: The Victory Was Brief
description: The aftermath of the capture of the Achille Lauro hijackers is proving a lot trickier and perhaps more dangerous than the bold, successful military operation. The public story of what happened is peculiar. There are so many unanswered questions and contradictions by various leaders that the more we are told, the less we know.

title: Fairchild Quits Saab Venture
description: Fairchild Industries said today that it was pulling out of a joint venture with Saab-Scania A.B. of Sweden for production of 340 turbocraft airplanes for the commuter airline market.

title: WYMAN-GORDON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELECTRO-BIOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $141,000 for the quarter and $360,000 for the 9 months. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $99,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: FOSTER, L B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REPUBLIC AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $14,220,000 for the quarter and $35,047,000 for the nine months and a gain on a pension plan termination of $62,175,000 for the nine months. c-Including a tax credit of $8,437,000 for the quarter and $20,167,000 for the nine months.

title: British Girls Can Get Pill Without Consent
description: Doctors can legally prescribe contraceptives to girls under 16 without parental consent, Britain's highest court ruled today in a case that has stirred a national debate over teen-agers and the pill.

title: D'Arcy Masius Benton Gets Managing Director
description: Thomas H. Carey, 41 years old, and a former executive of Benton & Bowles, has been named managing director of the New York office of the merged D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, at 909 Third Avenue, the D'Arcy crowd having bid a sad farewell to 360 Madison Avenue, the refurbished headquarters of Abercrombie & Fitch of sainted memory.

title: NIAGARA SHARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: SCREEN: 'CEASE FIRE'
description: DON JOHNSON and the City of Miami appeared together in ''Cease Fire'' well before either of them had developed a reputation for glamour. The release of this film hasn't been speedy, and it undoubtedly would have been less so without Mr. Johnson's current celebrity in his ''Miami Vice'' role. Since runaway success has a way of coaxing cinematic skeletons out of the closet, ''Cease Fire'' might be expected to be the usual pre-stardom embarrassment, but it's not. Even in a middling and predictable drama, Mr. Johnson is affecting enough to suggest that his new renown has at least as much to do with authentic acting talent as with good looks.

title: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WORLD SERIES: SHOWING THE WAY TO MISSOURI
description: Marvella Smith's son, Osborne Earl, says that when he was growing up in the Watts section of Los Angeles, his mother gave him the most important piece of advice in his life. ''Son,'' she said, ''always put your heart in whatever you do.''

title: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $7,307,000, or 41 cents a share, for the quarter and $22,097,000, or $1.31 a share, for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $1,487,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $10,838,000, or 75 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: LANDMARK BANCSHARES CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mack Truck Plant
description: Mack Trucks Inc. said that it would replace its nearly 60-year-old Allentown assembly plant, which employs more than 1,800 people.

title: FIRST FIDELITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $4,176,000 from the sale of branches for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Caudill Gets Message
description: Bill Caudill, Toronto's million-dollar relief pitcher, did not make a single appearance in the seven-game American League championship series, and in the hushed locker room following the Blue Jays' final defeat by the Kansas City Royals Wednesday night, the right-hander indicated that he had gotten the message. ''Judging by the way things went this season,'' he said, ''I honestly don't think I'll be back.'' Signed as a free agent during the offseason, Caudill compiled a 4-6 record and a 2.99 earned-run average after a shaky start, but clearly lost the confidence of the Toronto manager, Bobby Cox.

title: ELDERLY AT A STATE HEARING REJECT IMAGE OF FEEBLENESS
description: Forget the image of the elderly as frail and frightened. Sylvia Bassoff is on the prowl.

title: GORMAN-RUPP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a credit of $700,000 for the quarter and 9 months for deferred income taxes of the domestic international sales corporation that were no longer considered a tax liability. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective May 2, 1985.

title: ONE CLASS, THREE NOBEL WINNERS, AT CITY COLLEGE
description: City College has produced seven Nobel Prize winners, more than any other public institution. And now, after the announcement of this year's two laureates in chemistry, the college is celebrating an even more extraordinary record - three winners from the same class, the class of 1937.

title: ITALIANS DOUBT VIEW THAT HIJACKING WAS IMPROVISED
description: Italian prosecutors said today that they were leaning toward a theory that four Palestinians who boarded the liner Achille Lauro here hijacked it to force the freedom of jailed comrades, and never intended to stage a terrorist raid in Israel.

title: Scare for Red Wings
description: One of two engines on a jetliner carrying 88 people, including the Detroit Red Wings hockey team, failed shortly after takeoff yesterday from Detroit Metropolitan Airport, forcing an emergency landing. No injuries were reported.

title: CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1.2 million.

title: Quotron Silent On Possible Suitor
description: Quotron Systems Inc., which provides stock quotations and other business data electronically, rose $1.625 a share today, to $15.375, in over-the-counter trading.

title: COLUMBIA FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Aug. 15, 1985.

title: LeGeros Is Sentenced To 25 Years in Prison
description: A judge today sentenced Bernard LeGeros to the maximum term of 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a Norwegian fashion student.

title: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JEFFERIES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $308.3 million, to $209.25 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: 7 RADICALS MUST DO COMMUNITY SERVICE IN 'INTERIM SENTENCE'
description: A judge yesterday imposed an unusual ''interim sentence'' on seven black revolutionaries, ordering them to do community service for three months before he decides whether to put them in prison.

title: Times Co. Gains 10.8%
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 10.8 percent, to $22.6 million, or 56 cents a share, from $20.4 million, or 51 cents a share, in the 1984 quarter. The earnings were a record for the quarter.

title: CLUETT, PEABODY & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a special charge of $2.5 million for restructuring plant and distribution functions.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
ISOMEDIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PREMIER OF ITALY, SCORNING U.S. ACTS, QUITS OVER FUROR
description: The Prime Minister of Italy resigned today after a speech to Parliament in which he spoke of his ''bitterness'' over actions by the United States in the aftermath of the hijacking of the liner Achille Lauro.

title: CITY EXPECTS RISE IN AIDS CARE COSTS
description: New York City expects to spend up to $100 million this year to provide medical and social services to victims of AIDS, mainly for intensive care in municipal hospitals and clinics, city officials said yesterday.

title: SPECIAL THRIFT FUND IS URGED
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today proposed raising $8.5 billion from the savings and loan industry to shore up the beleaguered thrift institution insurance fund.

title: U S HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gross profits from the sale of land and lots of $1,107,000 for the quarter and $7,271,000 for the nine months. c-Net loss. d-After losses totalling $18,884,000 for the quarter and $15,423,000 for the nine months from the sale of land and lots and provisions for anticipated losses in the disposition of certain land and housing inventory and expected warranty and legal expenses.

COMMONWEALTH NATIONAL FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,624,000 from the sale of a branch bank.

description: b-Including a gain of $6.7 million from the settlement of litigation, a charge of $5.1 million for a plant writedown and a charge of $1.7 million for the consolidation of manufacturing facilities.

title: UNION BANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IVB FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEKALB AGRESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FROM THE JAPANESE IN PARIS, SOFTER DESIGNS
description: Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garcons made new friends for Japanese fashion this morning with a collection that was soft and gentle and employed a lot of pale colors instead of the expected gray and black.

title: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BATTERY PROJECT REFLECTS CHANGING CITY PRIORITIES
description: The glittery commercial centerpiece of Battery Park City officially opened for business yesterday in ceremonies that were imbued with a sense that something more was involved than a cluster of office towers.

title: SAN DIEGO MAYOR CHARGES JURY TAMPERING AND ASKS RETRIAL
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock, charging that a court bailiff tampered with the jury that convicted him last week of violating the law on campaign contributions, asked today that his conviction be set aside and that he be granted a new trial.

title: INTEGRATED DEVICE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Sports of The Times;   'IT'S ALL ON ACCOUNT OF THE WATER'
description: In the month of September, much was made of a Subway World Series in the city of New York. Wheelbarrowfuls of copy were issued by the Eastern press about the wonders of an IRT Fall Classic - change at Grand Central for the third, fourth and fifth games.

title: MERCANTILE BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Velikovsky's Long-Ago World in Upheaval
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDEN WATCHES EWING GROW
description: A crowd of 17,448 came to Madison Square Garden last night flush with the anticipation that has been building since the Knicks won pro basketball's first lottery last spring and the rights to Patrick Ewing, the all-America shot-blocking center. By the time the crowd left, they were treated to a range of emotions.

title: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRIBECA, A GUIDE TO ITS OLD STYLES AND ITS NEW LIFE
description: TRIBECA is a swath of old New York, complete with food and textile wholesalers, gritty warehouses, ungentrified neighborhood bars, and century-old cast-iron buildings. At the same time, it is a swath of the very new New York, with all kinds of avant-garde art galleries and performance spaces from Franklin Furnace to the Puppet Loft.

title: U.S. HOPES TO KEEP CLOSE ITALIAN TIES
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it hoped to maintain ''close and friendly relations'' with Italy but had no regret for actions that led to the resignation of Prime Minister Bettino Craxi.

title: DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net charge of $1.1 million to establish a reserve for disposition of two subsidiaries.

title: Topics;   Shots Felt Round the World; We Are Driven
description: Put yourself in the position of Japan, whose turn to be host for the annual economic summit meeting comes up next spring. You want to put your best foot forward, but your guests think your feet are too big.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAPE TOWN DAY: JUST A SAMPLE OF A NATION'S PAIN
description: The armored truck drew to a halt in the midst of the crowd and the men inside opened fire with pump-action shotguns on youths who had thrown rocks at them.

title: SACKLER ART MUSEUM TO OPEN AT HARVARD
description: It was conceived more than a decade ago and nearly dropped at one point because of qualms about its financing. But the new $9 million Arthur M. Sackler Museum at Harvard University will open here on Monday to cheers all around.

title: Edinet Venture
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. and McDonnell Douglas Information Systems said that they had formed a venture, called Edinet, to provide and market the Electronic Data Interchange service, which supplies computer-to-computer exchange of business documents. Separately, a spokesman for the British company said it plans to cut 4,000 of the 197,000 jobs in its local communications services unit. He said the company hopes to make the cuts entirely through attrition.

title: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: On Giving Due Process To P.L.O. Combatants
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS SAY POLES WILL RESTORE LIMITED TIES
description: Israeli officials said today that Israel and Poland would soon restore limited diplomatic relations after a break of 18 years.

title: ATLANTIC SOUTHEAST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Including tax credits of $3,579,000 for the quarter and $18.7 million for the 9 months.

title: VAN DORN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOING ON A TRIP TO ITALY WITHOUT LEAVING TOWN
description: ''Italy on Stage,'' a two-week extravaganza of Italian theater and music, opened last night at Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater. The new Italian Consul-General, Francesco Corrias, called it ''the broadest cross-section of contemporary Italian culture ever exported to this country.''

title: ELDORADO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUDDING LAXALT FAREWELL, MANILA SEEMS TO BRISTLE
description: The office of President Ferdinand E. Marcos showed some irritation today at American criticism of his Government. The irritation became apparent after two meetings with Senator Paul Laxalt, who brought Mr. Marcos a message of concern from President Reagan.

title: POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net loss.

title: Salvadoran Reports Gain In Duarte Kidnapping
description: A Salvadoran Government official said today that while substantial progress had been made in negotiations for President Jose Napoleon Duarte's kidnapped daughter, ''at the most optimistic'' it would take three more days to gain her freedom.

title: USTINOV IN CHRISTIE TALE
description: PETER USTINOV has played the detective Hercule Poirot twice in the movies, in ''Death on the Nile'' and ''Evil Under the Sun,'' and is now bringing his fussy impersonation to television. His M. Poirot, complete with authentic Belgian accent, can be seen again, tomorrow on Channel 2 at 9 P.M., in a television movie formally titled ''Agatha Christie's '13 at Dinner.' '' Directed by Lou Antonio and written by Rod Browning, this is an updated version of ''Lord Edgware Dies,'' a mystery Miss Christie wrote in the 1930's.

RESTAURANTS
description: THE casual charm of a restaurant in rural Japan is evoked by the brick-and-wood interior of Omen, a four-year-old local favorite in SoHo that continues to turn out high-quality, distinctive fare at reasonable prices. In contrast to the sleek and Minimalist uptown sushi bars, which are designed for speed, Omen is a place for winding down with a sake and a steaming bowl of fish soup. Oriental lanterns hang from a timbered ceiling, spacey electronic music pulses from above and striking calligraphy adorns the walls.

Prosecutors have identified the customer, James V. McDonough, as the mastermind of a high-tech, high-volume sports betting operation. Mr. McDonough pleaded not guilty to related charges at a separate arraignment.

title: FAUST CONCEDES JOB IS IN JEOPARDY

title: '87 BUDGET TO MEET NEW DEFICIT GOAL
description: President Reagan will send a 1987 budget to Congress in January that will increase military spending, include no tax increases and meet the $144 billion deficit ceiling contained in the Senate proposal to require a balanced budget by 1991, the director of the Office of Management and Budget said today.

title: Development Bank Issue Set at 10.56%
description: The African Development Bank made its debut in the American public bond market yesterday with a $100 million issue of 10 1/2 percent notes due in 1995. The notes were offered at a price of 99.634 to yield 10.56 percent through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: FATHER OF MODERN JUJU TO PLAY AT TOWN HALL
description: TAKE half a dozen each of guitarists, singers and percussionists, and hook them up with riff upon interlocking riff. Add lyrics in the Yoruban language that tell parables and give gentle advice, underline both lyrics and melodies with the rhythmic language of talking drums, and perform them in a concert that, at home in Nigeria, might last up to nine hours. The result is juju, one of the definitive Nigerian pop styles. Tomorrow, the guitarist-singer-bandleader who is credited with inventing modern juju, Chief Commander Ebenezer Obey, will bring his 19-piece Inter-Reformers Band to Town Hall.

title: Catholics and Baptists
description: The Wanderer Forum Foundation, which describes itself as ''a Catholic laymen's grassroots organization,'' opens a two-day conference at the Shoreham Hotel today on an ecumenical note. Two principal speakers, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Marion G. (Pat) Robertson, the television evangelist, are Baptists. Mr. Robertson, son of former Senator A. Willis Robertson of Virginia, is described in the program as a ''potential Presidential candidate.'' The Wanderer, a Catholic weekly founded in 1867 that is parent of the foundation, endorses ''a traditional and conservative approach to Catholic doctrine and teachings,'' its editor says.

title: Bush Praises Canton For Its Prosperity
description: Vice President Bush sailed through the gorge of limestone peaks along the Li River in Guilin today, then flew to the bustling port city of Canton and praised its new prosperity.

title: Horse's Choice
description: Oh, if horses could only talk. What an endorsement the makers of Gatorade would get from Manfred Hanover. As it is, they'll have to make do with a testimonial from his owner and trainer, Walter Szczepanski.

title: Turkoman Bursts to Forefront
description: For most of last winter and spring, whenever the search for Kentucky Derby prospects turned to California, a colt who kept popping up as the hope amid a bad bunch was Turkoman. The stretch-running son of Alydar had a lot to learn, though. He was usually running greenly and getting himself into trouble, but was always closing ground down the stretch. His trainer, Gary Jones, came within an inch of sending him to Churchill Downs for the Derby, but decided that Turkoman still needed some time to grow up and kept him in the West.

title: BLACK REPUBLICANS HONOR NIXON

title: Role of P.L.O. Aide On Tape Is Clarified

Mr. Abbas was identified by the code name Abu Khaled and the hijackers were identified as Jayed and Majed.

title: Dailey Gets Treatment

According to Jerry Krause, the club's vice president for operations, Dailey called him Wednesday night before an exhibition game against the Indiana Pacers and said he needed help to overcome a drug dependency.

title: CLAUDE SIMON OF FRANCE WINS THE NOBEL PRIZE IN LITERATURE

title: BRITISH RESIST SANCTIONS AGAINST PRETORIA
description: The Commonwealth conference here, now in its second day, has developed into a lobbying session on South Africa, with Britain trying to persuade most of the other members that discussion is likely to be more effective than sanctions in eliminating apartheid Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher avoided the subject of South Africa when she opened today's closed-door meeting with a wide-ranging speech on world issues.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''TANGO ARGENTINO,'' one of the season's hits, has now been extended indefinitely - and the men behind it obviously believe that if at first you succeed, strike again as fast as you can. Claudio Segovia and Hector Orezzoli, who created ''Tango,'' and Mel Howard and Donald K. Donald, who produced it, are even at this moment rehearsing ''Black 'n' Blue,'' a jazz show with 41 American jazz singers, dancers and musicians, including Linda Hopkins and Buster Brown. It will play in Paris for 11 weeks, starting in mid-November, and come here early in the year.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Payments Supported
description: Wilt Chamberlain, recalling that he was secretly paid $4,000 to play basketball at the University of Kansas 30 years ago, said yesterday that a system of standardized payments for college athletes should be established to keep them from being corrupted by unscrupulous boosters. ''It's time to revamp the codes and be more honest,'' he said. ''These players need money to live and go to school and learn. And they shouldn't be forced to take money under the table and make them do illegal things at such an early age.'' Chamberlain, who played at Kansas from 1955 to 1958, said he had received the cash from Jayhawk boosters known as ''godfathers'' at the school. ''I had two or three godfathers,'' he said. ''That way I wasn't sure where the money was coming from. Everyone was assigned at least one godfather when I was at Kansas.'' Told of Chamberlain's remarks, Doug Vance, the director of sports information at Kansas, said, ''There's no such program in existence now.'' Chamberlain, who suggested a standardized system that would allow colleges to pay athletes a legal stipend of $300 to $400 a month, was reluctant at first to say just how much he had been paid at Kansas. ''It would make it look like I wasn't worth very much,'' he said. Actually, the figure is somewhat misleading. The $4,000 Chamberlain said he was paid in the late 1950's would be worth some $16,000 today, or close to the $18,000 that Kenneth Davis, the suspended Texas Christian running back, said he was paid by T.C.U. boosters. . . . Mike Trope, Davis's agent, said yesterday that a damage suit Davis had brought against the National Football League for refusing to allow him to join the N.F.L. this season had been filed by mistake and would be withdrawn.

title: AUCTIONS
description: MOST of the Peter Tillou collection of American folk paintings - including compelling portraits by Ammi Phillips, Erastus Salisbury Field and Robert Peckham - will be sold at Sotheby's next weekend in an auction that the house describes as the first major assemblage of 18th- and 19th-century American naive paintings to appear at public sale.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday A FESTIVAL OF CRAFTS The works of more than 150 artisans will be exhibited this weekend at ''Crafts on Park Avenue,'' a fair sponsored by Schrafft's Ice Cream in the Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street. On display will be stoneware and porcelain pottery, jewelry, art glass, hand-painted silks and floor cloths, custom-made shoes, folk toys, handwoven clothing, leather, quilts, furniture, wood sculptures, tapestries, folding screens, Christmas ornaments, clocks, and wooden copies of antique cars, among other items. The fair will be open today from 5 to 9 P.M., on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and on Sunday from 11 to 6. Admission is $4. Information: 302-4904.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NOTHING HAPPENS IN CARMINCROSS. By Benedict Kiely. 279 pages. David Godine. $16.95. CARMINCROSS, where nothing happens, is a small town in Ulster. Mervyn Kavanagh is a wandering son of Carmincross (Catholic as opposed to Protestant Carmincross) who has been teaching in America, at a women's college in ''the semi-Deep South'' - a well-cushioned exile in ''a never-never land of dogwood and forsythia and chipmunks and young people.'' He has also acquired and then lost an American wife, who has left him and gone to live in New York, with a boyfriend in fitful attendance.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nicaragua Bares the Nightstick
description: Nicaragua's Sandinista regime has now suspended by decree the few freedoms it had grudgingly accorded its domestic opponents. There is no reason to swallow President Ortega's claim that the crackdown is the fault of ''the brutal aggression by North America and its internal allies.'' A more likely explanation is an eruption of discontent over a crumbling economy and military conscription. But until now, despite the war with the U.S.-backed ''contra'' rebels based in Honduras and Costa Rica, the Sandinistas needed no new powers to crush or cow political and religious dissent.

description: To the Editor:

title: JETS DON'T INSPIRE CONFIDENCE
description: Although the Jets have a 5-1 record, a five-game winning streak and a clear victory over the Miami Dolphins on Monday Night Football, they apparently still have not convinced many people who follow the game with their wallets and not their hearts how good a team they are.

title: NAVAL ANALYST IS GUILTY OF ESPIONAGE
description: A former naval intelligence analyst was convicted today on charges of espionage and theft for giving secret photographs to a British military journal and having other secret information in his home.

title: MAXICARE HEALTH PLANS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Earthquake Jolts Tokyo
description: An earthquake jolted Tokyo and surrounding areas today, but the police said there were no reports of casualties or damage.

title: MAYTAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COAST BANK EARNINGS DROP 29%
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, reeling from mounting loan losses, yesterday reported a 29 percent drop in third-quarter net income, Bank analysts, seeing a substantial operating loss for the company in the quarter, called the results bleak.

title: KOCH MEMO DIRECTS CITY WORKERS NOT TO REPORT ILLEGAL ALIENS TO U.S.
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had ordered city employees not to report illegal immigrants living in the city to Federal authorities unless the alien ''appears to be engaged in some kind of criminal behavior.''

title: A TALE OF TWO MISSOURI CITIES, ENGULFED IN SERIES MADNESS
description: ''I-70! I-70! I-70!'' shouted the young throngs who poured from the bars of trendy Westport Square here Wednesday night.

title: 5 REPORTED DEAD IN A LEBANON RAID
description: Three men with explosives strapped to their bodies caused extensive damage to a radio station run by American missionaries in the Israeli-controlled part of southern Lebanon today, Lebanese authorities said. At least five people were reported killed, including the attackers.

title: DIGITAL TRANSERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Digital Transervice Corp. is in the development stage.

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ASTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADVANCED LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CONIFER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Coast Firefighters Guard Sanctuary for Wildlife
description: Ocean breezes and a damp fog today helped firefighters contain 2 more of the 19 brush fires that have charred 80,000 acres of southern California, but fear was expressed for a wildlife refuge.

title: BRIDGE COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $533,000 for the quarter and $1,303,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $15,000 for the quarter and $63,000 for the 9 months.

title: A QUIET, INFLUENTIAL IVESTOR
description: As the chairman of the Loews Corporation, Laurence A. Tisch has gained a reputation as an extremely savvy investor. And as chairman of New York University's board of trustees, a board member of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a driving force behind the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, Mr. Tisch has become a highly regarded member of the New York establishment.

title: CLERICAL WORKERS STRIKE COLUMBIA ON PAY ISSUES
description: Clerical workers struck Columbia University yesterday in a contract dispute over wages, health benefits and what their union leaders called pay inequities for women and nonwhite employees.

title: GRAINGER, W W INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: TEXT OF 1830 MORMON LETTER
description: Following is the text of the letter, dated Oct. 29, 1830, addressed to W. W. Phelps from Martin Harris, on the origin of the Mormon religion. It contains numerous spelling and grammatical errors and is written without paragraphs.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BARS ZAMBIA TRIP BY 8
description: The South African authorities today withdrew the passports of eight white university students who were to have traveled to Zambia later this month to meet representatives of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: JOHN AHEARN'S studio is filled with arms and legs, a torso tossed in a corner and a couch on which rests a row of disembodied heads. It seems fitting that Mr. Ahearn and his assistant, Rigoberto Torres, work in a space just above Charles's Auto Repair in the Bronx, since the two sculptors work for a living on body parts themselves.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * All American Life Insurance Co., a subsidiary of the USLife Corp., has elected William R. Strack president and chief executive.

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CBS Stock Off $2.75
description: CBS Inc.'s stock fell $2.75 yesterday, to $114.75 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange, primarily because Wall Street investors apparently believe that the alliance between CBS and the Loews Corporation will thwart any potential takeovers, at least in the near term.

title: U.S. OFFERS $250,000 REWARD FOR 3 JET HIJACKERS
description: The Justice Department said today that it had charged three men with murder and piracy for the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet in June and the shooting death of one of its passengers, a Navy seaman.

title: 5 Newspaper Unions to Vote Today in Philadelphia Strike
description: At least five of the nine unions that have been on strike against The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News since Sept. 7 have scheduled membership votes today on tentative contracts, with the Newspaper Guild early this morning being the latest union to approve terms.

title: VERMONT EX-GOVERNOR TO VIE FOR SENATE SEAT
description: Former Gov. Richard A. Snelling, a Republican, announced today that he would run for the Senate next year against Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat.

title: BROWNS SCRAMBLE THE LINEUP
description: They have a former tackle at right guard, a former tight end at right tackle and none of the Cleveland Browns' linemen has more than four years of experience in the National Football League.

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $7 million for the quarter and $21 million for the 9 months.

title: Lawmakers' Mother, 87, Dies
description: Bess Levin, mother of Senator Carl Levin and Representative Sander M. Levin, both Democrats of Michigan, died Thursday at the age of 87.

title: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCREEN: COMEDY FROM ITALY
description: ''ACQUA E SAPONE'' (Water and Soap), which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street Theater, is a sentimental little Italian comedy that self-destructs - it hangs itself by its own heartstrings.

title: PACIFIC FIRST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,114,000 from a prepayment penalty on borrowings for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: LOW-KEY ROYALS DEPEND ON PITCHING
description: They have not signed glamorous free agents for millions of dollars. They do not trade the cream of their minor league crop for established players. They certainly are not a mercurial organization.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Turner Offers Stake in Network
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc., which previously disclosed that it might sell part of its Cable News Network, said that it is trying to sell a 30 percent to 40 percent stake in the network and expects to net $200 million to $300 million from such a deal.

title: CHILTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split in November 1984.

title: Bookbinder's Bows
description: Although Hyman H. Bookbinder was briefly an economist for the Amalgamated Clothing Workers before he settled into a lifelong career as a lobbyist, that does not really explain his hobby of collecting, wearing and making bow ties. The Washington representative of the American Jewish Committee says his current collection of 200 bow ties evolved from the fact that his father, a shoemaker, taught him how to sew.

title: JWT Group Unit Wins Dean Witter Account
description: In a creative battle with two other agencies, Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, a subsidiary of the JWT Group, has won the account of the Dean Witter Reynolds brokerage with expected billings of $15 million.

title: USAIR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SIMMERING FEUD OF 2 ITALIAN PARTIES IS BROUGHT TO BOIL BY HIJACKING CRISIS
description: It was a bitter moment today when Prime Minister Bettino Craxi was forced to hand in his resignation. His Government was just 28 days shy of becoming Italy's longest-lasting administration since World War II.

title: U.S.-ITALIAN TEAMWORK BRINGING ORGANIZED-CRIME CHIEFS TO TRIAL
description: On a sunny morning in August 1984, Giuseppe Palazzolo met under the leafy portico of the Doney cafe on the Via Veneto in Rome with a bearded young American he had met several months earlier in New York.

title: INNOVATIVE SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Topics;   Shots Felt Round the World; Six Killers
description: If a child's life is worth $5, the world can cut in half an annual toll of five million lives. That's how many victims are claimed by six killers -measles, diphtheria, tetanus, whooping cough, tuberculosis and polio.

title: U.S. INDICATES EX-C.I.A. OFFICER HELPED SOVIET CAPTURE A RUSSIAN
description: An officer of the Central Intelligence Agency, now a fugitive, may have helped the Soviet Union apprehend a Soviet researcher who was providing American intelligence with valuable military information, Administration officials said today.

title: BANKEAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN BROADCASTING COMPANIES INC (ABC)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sybron Pulls Out Of Buyout Talks
description: The Sybron Corporation said negotiations for a proposed leveraged buyout by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., Hillside Capital Inc. and five members of Sybron senior managment had been terminated and the proposal withdrawn.

title: SCREEN: STUART GORDON DIRECTS 'RE-ANIMATOR'
description: ''RE-ANIMATOR'' has as much originality as it has gore, and that's really saying something. Stay away if you haven't a special fondness for severed body parts, or an unflinching curiosity about autopsy scenes; this one takes place mostly at the morgue, and it doesn't leave a thing to the imagination. But as directed by Stuart Gordon, a television and stage director making his feature debut, ''Re-Animator'' has a fast pace and a good deal of grisly vitality. It even has a sense of humor, albeit one that would be lost on 99.9 percent of any ordinary moviegoing crowd.

title: COMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $7 million for the quarter and 9 months.

title: HOGAN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WESTERN FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public Feb. 14, 1985.

title: P.L.O. AIDE AFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR BID WITH JORDAN
description: A senior aide to Yasir Arafat was quoted today as saying that the Palestine Liberation Organization remains committed to an agreement with Jordan on a common approach to a Middle East settlement despite the cancellation by Britain of talks with a joint Palestinian-Jordanian delegation.

title: Indian Folk Music
description: The Bengali singer Purna Das Baul will perform Indian folk music tonight at 8 o'clock at the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street, near West Street (618-1980). Tickets are $10 and $12.

title: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June 1985.

title: Old Coke Outselling the New in U.S.
description: Three months after it bowed to consumer pressure by bringing back the original formula of the world's best-selling soft drink, the Coca-Cola Company acknowledged yesterday that Coca-Cola Classic was outselling new Coke in the United States.

title: AFTER 2 YEARS AND LITTLE PROGRESS, WORK ON BROOKLYN IRT STOP IS HALTED
description: The $1.3 million renovation of the Clark Street subway station in Brooklyn, which has been frustrating riders for almost two years and was scheduled for completion last July, has been halted with 75 percent of the work still incomplete.

title: STERLING DRUG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $335,000 for the quarter and $2,487,000 for the nine months, and a pre-tax gain of $4.5 million for the quarter resulting from the sale of several proprietary products to another company.

title: Rolm British Plan
description: The Rolm Corporation, a unit of the International Business Machines Corporation, said it would market its 8000 automatic call distribution system in Britain through the Telecommunications Systems Business unit of I.B.M. United Kingdom Ltd. The system allows companies with a high volume of incoming calls to provide enhanced service to callers, Rolm said.

title: MARSH & MCLENNAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge: Jerry Silverman Made Mark In Wide Range of Positions
description: Jerry Silverman, one of the most respected and energetic bridge administrators ever to be active in the New York area, died recently in retirement in Mill Valley, Calif., at the age of 76.

title: Lockheed Rises 14.6%
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that net income in the third quarter rose 14.6 percent, to $102 million, or $1.54 a share, from $89 million, or $1.36 a share, in the 1984 quarter. Analysts said the earnings were in line with their expectations.

title: DANCE: 'AURORA' BALLETS BY ELIOT FELD
description: ELIOT FELD'S ''Aurora I'' opens with a dancer rising up in dark air. His back is washed with light, giving him the look of a flickering flame. His arms bloom up into the night, held like the catch of a breath, then fall with his disappearing body. It is a moment whose magic recalls that of the fugitive entrances of the Princess Aurora in productions of ''The Sleeping Beauty.''

title: GEODYNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net losses. There is no share earnings figure for the latest 6 months because net income did not cover preferred dividends.

title: SUSQUEHANNA BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. BANS ARMS IMPORTS
description: The United States today banned imports of firearms, ammunition and technical arms manuals from South Africa.

title: LOTUS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
U.S. AND AUSTRIAN TEAMS GET EDGE IN WORLD EVENT
description: The inside track for the world open team championships, which begin play in Sao Paolo, Brazil, tomorrow, is held by Austria and the United States.

title: FIRST OKLAHOMA BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ZENITH ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, including a nonrecurring tax credit of $10.4 million for the quarter and the nine months.

title: EXCEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRODIGAL MANAGER'S RETURN
description: At the 1979 All-Star Game party, Muriel Kauffman, the wife of the Royals' owner, was talking to some friends, one of whom asked about her husband Ewing.

title: SANDWICH CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SUPREME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW ORLEANS VOTES TODAY ON MAYORAL TERM LIMIT
description: Four years ago Mayor Ernest N. Dutch Morial, fighting for re-election, was also battling his own image of arrogance. Successful in that fight, he is now in another: to change the city charter so he can run for a third term.

title: New Eminent Domain Issues
description: WHEN New York City rezoned some land in midtown Manhattan recently, the owners of the land sued the city. They asserted that the rezoning reduced the value of their property and therefore was equivalent to condemning it. When a government takes private property, according to the Constitution, it must compensate the owner.

title: AIRCAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,509,000 for the quarter and $6,494,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,048,000 for the quarter and $2,823,000 for the 9 months.

title: CATALYST ENERGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KOCH FAULTS U.S. POLICY ON ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION
description: Mayor Koch assailed the Federal Government yesterday, saying it was at fault for allowing illegal immigrants into the city yet unwilling to share the cost of providing services for them.

title: HIGHER AND LOWER TELEPHONE CHARGES
description: TODAY, the average New York State home telephone bill will increase by 4.8 percent, the result of a New York Telephone Company rate increase.

title: DRUG DEALERS' BOULEVARD
description: My block is an open-air drug market. At any hour of night or day, a band of ''steerers'' will approach pedestrians on 92d Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan and offer to sell them cocaine. The daily goings-on at this corner are well known to all of my neighbors, the police, narcotics agents, local politicians, members of the community board and the Manhattan District Attorney. So why can't anyone do anything about it?

title: HOWARD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ZETA LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOVIET MILITARY CHIEF ACCUSES U.S. OF DISTORTING TERMS OF ABM PACT
description: The Chief of the Soviet General Staff, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, in an article to be published Saturday in Pravda, calls recent Reagan Administration interpretations of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty a ''deliberate deceit.''

title: NANCY AND MARY
description: The only time Mary Martin and Nancy Davis appeared on the New York stage together was in ''Lute Song,'' which was ''a love story with music'' and was staged by John Houseman at the Plymouth Theater in 1946.

title: Aramco Will Cut 7,000, Paper Says
description: Aramco, Saudi Arabia's giant oil production company, plans to reduce its work force by 7,000, or about 13 percent, by the end of 1986, according to a report that quoted company officials. The officials, whose names were not disclosed in the report by the English-language Saudi Gazette, said the cutbacks were necessary because declining oil production had reduced revenues.

title: SCIENTIFIC MICRO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $683,000 for the quarter and $1,461,000 for the nine months. c-Net income.

title: ROUTINE DEFENSE BY KARPOV BLOCKS ATTACK BY DASPAROV
description: Anatoly Karpov had only a routine defensive task in the 17th game of his world championship chess match and he carried it out without a hitch to make a draw with his challenger, Gary Kasparov, in Moscow on Thursday.

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company paid a 2 percent stock dividend on Dec. 5, 1984.

title: LED OLDER-WOMEN'S UNION
description: Tish Sommers, co-founder of the Older Women's League and a lifelong political activist who called for the recognition of economic and social problems facing older women, died of cancer today at her home in Oakland, Calif. She was 71 years old.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $900,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: REGAL-BELOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOME REACTOR WORKERS ENDING WILDCAT STRIKE
description: A spokesman for the nuclear reactor under construction here, where 2,000 workers are conducting a wildcat strike over work conditions and layoffs, said today that some of the 400 laborers on the second shift began reporting for work after a judge issued a contempt order against them.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Excludes extraordinary income of $13,007,000, or 83 cents per share.

title: CENTRAL HUDSON GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Patents;

Monitoring Display of TV Ads
description: BURTON L. GREENBERG of New York, who has been directing television commercials for 30 years, has invented a process called Telescan to help advertisers make sure they are getting what they pay for. He received a patent this week for equipment that detects whether a commercial is cut short, distorted or played at the wrong time.

title: SYNTHETIC GROWTH HORMONE CLEARED
description: A hormone manufactured through genetic engineering has been approved for crucial treatment of children with severe growth problems, at a time when use of the natural human hormone had been suspended because of suspicions that some batches might have been dangerously contaminated.

title: Nilan Suspended
description: Chris Nilan, the Montreal Canadien right wing who was involved in a fight with Rick Middleton of the Boston Bruins last Sunday, was suspended for eight games without pay yesterday after Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League's executive vice president, ruled that Nilan had deliberately tried to injure the Bruin forward by slashing him in the mouth with his stick. Middleton, the Bruin captain, suffered a cut that required stitches. ''The attack by Nilan was deliberate and foreceful enough to cause injury to his opponent,'' O'Neil said.

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $578,000 for the quarter and $830,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN PUT END TO TROOP STANDOFF
description: A confrontation between Italian soldiers and American Special Forces last week over who would take custody of the Achille Lauro hijackers ended only after President Reagan sent word for the Americans to back down, Administration officials said today.

title: PHILADELPHIS CHIEF SAYS HE WANTED FIRE TO BURN
description: The Police Commissioner acknowledged today that he had asked fire officials to allow flames to rage unimpeded on the roof of a house that he knew was occupied by members of the radical group Move and their children.

title: Deposit Relief In Maryland
description: More than 70,000 depositors in two ailing Maryland savings and loan institutions will be able to make withdrawals if they face extreme hardships, or can prove they need the money for ''necessities of life,'' under a plan approved today.

title: BRELAND WIRNS AGAIN
description: Mark Breland, the most celebrated of the American gold-medalist boxers at the 1984 Olympics, knocked out Donald Gwinn in the second round of a scheduled eight-rounder at the Felt Forum last night.

title: FINANCIAL SECURITY SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALLIS-CHALMERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $53,492,000 for the 9 months, losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $2,969,000 for the quarter and $78,108,000 for the 9 months and extraordinary income of $11,000,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $15,169,000 for the quarter and $2,819,000 for the 9 months.

title: Coach Is Barred
description: The University of Nebraska said it had barred the head basketball coach, Moe Iba, and his assistants from attending team practices for five days because Iba had broken an N.C.A.A. rule by conducting a preseason practice Oct. 7. N.C.A.A. rules prohibit coaches from running such practice sessions before Oct. 15. The illegal practice was disclosed last week by the student newspaper, The Daily Nebraskan, but Iba denied he had done anything wrong, saying that he had merely been putting his players through running drills, which are allowed.

title: MEDIPLEX GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: EQUITABLE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a debate on an abortion referendum in Bristol, Conn., misidentified a member of the audience. He was the Rev. Joseph Looney, not the Rev. Patrick Mahoney.

title: SUMMIT BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results include operations of the Breddo division which the company sold in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1984.

title: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split, effective Aug. 28, 1985.

title: White at Cleanup In Royals' Opener
description: Frank White, the second baseman known primarily for his glove work, is going to bat cleanup for the Kansas City Royals in the first game of the World Series.

title: U.S. Will Pay Part Of Gloria Cleanup
description: The Federal Government will help pay for the cleanup of Long Island made necessary by Hurricane Gloria, the White House announced today.

title: SENATE BELL TO CUT 1986 DEFICIT GETS A VETO THREAT
description: The Reagan Administration today threatened a veto of the Senate's deficit-reducing bill for 1986 because it includes a permanent extension of the cigarette tax at 16 cents a pack.

title: Youthful Helping Hands
description: O ne of the tasks performed by the youths in the City Volunteer Corps is helping elderly people to do some of the things they are no longer able to do for themselves. The idea is to allow the elderly to continue living in their own homes instead of being sent off to an institution.

title: AID SOUGHT IN ISLAND DISASTER
description: Efforts to raise millions of dollars in relief for the victims of the mud slide in Ponce, P.R., earlier this month were renewed yesterday by officials in the New York area who are Puerto Rican and a commonwealth official based in New York City.

title: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $12 million. Results for the third quarter of 1985 include a portion of the quarterly financial results of G. D. Searle & Co., following the completed acquisition during the quarter of that company's outstanding common stock.

title: MCI-I.B.M. Pact
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation for the previously announced purchase of I.B.M.'s Satellite Business Systems unit. Under the agreement, I.B.M. will sell the unit and make $400 million in investments in MCI between Sept. 1, 1986, and Dec. 31, 1988, in return for 46.7 million MCI shares, or 16.6 percent of the company's outstanding stock.

title: MARCOS REPORTED TO REJECT U.S. CALL TO CHANGE COURSE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines has rejected a plea by the Reagan Administration for major political, economic and military changes to avert further turmoil there, Administration officials said today.

title: SURVEYS FIND FOOD HABITS ERRATIC
description: Americans continue to be of two minds about their diets: they give up one bad habit and replace it with another. Surveys over the last few years have shown that even as sales of coffee, eggs and whole milk have dropped, Americans are consuming more soft drinks, sugar and fats.

title: SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LIBERTY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. COMPANIES GAIN IN JAPAN
description: American companies, after fighting their way into the market, now have growing hopes for their role in the $4 billion Japanese telecommunications field.

title: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EUROPEAN AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss
