The company paid dividends of 8 cents per share for the latest quarter, 16 cents per share for the latest six months, 7.2 cents per share for the year-ago quarter and 14.4 cents per share for the year-ago six months.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about telephone company earnings misstated the period in which MCI Communications recorded a $30 million gain. It was the second quarter.

title: SOFTWARE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Alcoa Declines 5%; Monsanto Off 60.3%
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that its earnings fell 5 percent in the third quarter from the 1984 period, as its business softened. The Pittsburgh company said it earned $57.1 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with $60.1 million, or 74 cents a share, in the 1984 third quarter.

title: Boeing Contract
description: The Boeing Aerosapce Company has been awarded a $221.9 million contract for work on the MX missile, the Air Force said. The contract is for 39 sets of operational support equipment for the missiles, the first of which are scheduled to be deployed next year.

title: ONE MAN'S GIFT: COLLEGE FOR 52 IN HARLEM
description: Sitting on the dais, Eugene Lang, multimillionaire industrialist, suddenly realized the commencement address he was about to deliver was complete balderdash, to put it nicely.

title: AUTOTROL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $14,000 for the quarter and $357,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $195,000 for the quarter and $905,000 for the 9 months.

description: The per share figures reflect a 3-for- 2 stock split in March.

description: b-After extraordinary gains of $1,378,000 for the quarter and $4,314,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary gains of $439,000 for the quarter and $2,181,000 for the 9 months. Society converted to a capital stock savings bank on Feb. 7, 1984. Per share earnings therefore are not comparable. Pro forma per share results represent earnings per share as if the conversion from mutual to stock form had occurred on Jan. 1, 1984.

description: To the Editor:

title: DECISIONS OF LIFE AND DEATH REQUIRE OUR JUDGES' GUIDANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MGM FILM DISPUTE IS SETTLED
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said yesterday that they had settled a dispute with the Rainbow Service Company over rights to MGM's film library.

title: MAYS, J. W. INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods include nonrecurring pretax income of $53,215 for the quarter and $322,185 for the year. Year-ago results include nonrecurring pretax income of $2,016,794 for the quarter and $4,182,515 for the year and an extraordinary tax credit of $390,000, or 18 cents a share, for the year. Sales figures include leased departments.

CALIFORNIA LEADING WAY IN HIGH-COST RACES FOR THE JUDICIARY

title: SHUTTLE COUNT REHEARSED
description: Three European scientists and five American astronauts finished a dress rehearsal today of the countdown for a West German science mission that begins Oct. 30 aboard the space shuttle Challenger. The mission will cost $180 million, of which the Germans are paying $64 million for the use of the Challenger laboratory. There are 70 experiments on board, three-quarters of them related to metallurgy.

description: Despite the opposition of its labor union representatives, a Democratic rules panel moved today to expand the role of elected officials and party leaders in the Presidential nominating process.

title: FOOD STAMPS CALLED LACKING
description: Poor Americans have to pay 26 percent to 54 percent more than what they receive under the food stamp program to assure a nutritious diet, an group fighting hunger said today.

Big Fines Said To Face Arco
description: The Energy Department is seeking $499 million from the Atlantic Richfield Company on allegations that the oil company violated Government price controls in a series of oil deals from March 1978 through 1980, officials said today.

title: Option to Keep Seaver
description: The Chicago White Sox exercised their option yesterday to keep Tom Seaver on the roster and off the free agent list, but club officials said that Ken Harrelson, the director of baseball operations, was still amenable to trading the 40-year-old right-hander to a New York team, most likely the Yankees, so he could finish his career close to his home in Conncecticut. At the same time, the White Sox said they had exercised their option to retain Britt Burns, a 26-year-old left-hander, who turned in the best season of his eight-year career this season, an 18-11 record with an e.r.a. of 3.96.

title: TROOPS MOVE INTO SUBURB
description: The South African authorities ordered hundreds of armed troops into Cape Town's mixed-race suburb of Athlone today after the police came under fire on six occasions in clashes Thursday night.

ACTOR FINED IN ATTACK ON 2
description: Sean Penn, the actor, was fined $100 and given a suspended 90-day jail term Thursday after pleading no contest to charges of assault and battery in connection with an attack on two British journalists who tried to photograph Madonna, the pop singer and actress who is now married to Mr. Penn. Mr. Penn arrived at the courthouse by a tunnel entrance and eluded a crowd of reporters. The incident occurred here in June. The couple were married Aug. 16 at Malibu, Calif.

title: After the Fall
description: The Toronto Blue Jays took a heavy enough fall of their own Wednesday night when they lost the American League pennant to the Kansas City Royals. And, as if that were not enough, one of their fans took a cue with a spectacular header that exposed him, like his Jays, to a North American television audience.

title: Dow Off, but Week Is Best in 9 Months
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday but ended their best weekly performance since January, as the market remained transfixed by potentially profitable takeovers.

title: Allis-Chalmers Loss Widens
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation today reported a third-quarter loss of $18.4 million, compared with a loss of $15.6 million in the period a year ago.

title: N.C.A.A.'s Ills
description: Athletic Director Bob Frailey of American University, whose basketball team was ordered to forfeit a week's practice because the coaching staff observed and participated in some offseason workouts last year, issues this diagnosis: ''The N.C.A.A. is confronted with the bubonic plague, and it spends time treating head colds.''

description: Despite international appeals for clemency, a black supporter of the outlawed African National Congress was hanged today in Pretoria for his role in the 1982 murder of a security policeman.

title: ROCK BY SUPERTRAMP IN RADIO CITY CONCERT
description: When the music in a rock show seems more like an accompaniment to the visual effects on the stage than vice versa, something is amiss. That is what happened on Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall, where the reconstituted British-American band Supertramp performed.

HURRICANE GLORIA'S LESSON
description: Memory for natural disasters is short. The terrifying Mexican earthquakes and murderous Puerto Rican mudslide soon will no longer occupy the nation's attention. The same is true for hurricane Gloria. That is too bad, for Gloria teaches us a valuable lesson that may save the millions of people who live on our coasts both lives and dollars.

title: COLEMAN STATUS STILL A QUESTION
description: Vince Coleman picked up a bat from his locker, limped toward the field and gave one man's answer to the burning question on the eve of the 82d World Series: ''I'm playing. And I'm 100 percent.''

description: So who ya like in the Series, the Boils or the Aardvarks?

title: AN AIDS DEATH DRAWS CONCERN OF L.I. PARENTS
description: A teacher here died of AIDS last summer, officials said Thursday. But far from prompting the panic that has often followed such a disclosure, parents here seemed more interested in discussing how a teacher who was seriously ill - perhaps too ill to teach effectively - had gone unnoticed by school officials.

title: AMR Profits Climb by 11.1%
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines Inc., said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 11.1 percent, to $87.3 million, or $1.45 a share, from $78.6 million, or $1.51 share, a year ago. Revenues for the third quarter totaled $1.56 billion, up 13.9 percent from $1.37 billion a year ago.

AS ELECTION DAY NEARS, NEW JERSEY VOTERS STIR
description: The electorate is beginning to stir. The dog days of the early campaign are gone, and even though the polls show one gubernatorial candidate furlongs ahead of the other, there is a sense here at least that a race is on.

title: MRS. MARCOS OFFERS VIEW OF SAD WORLD
description: Imelda R. Marcos told the General Assembly today that the problems that confront the world ''have their roots in injustice, intolerance, greed and dominance by the strong.''

title: Dollar Continues Down While Gold Is Mixed
description: The dollar fell yesterday in quiet trading, continuing the decline begun Thursday on a wave of intervention. Dealers said they were continuing to study Government reports that showed the American economy is far from robust.

title: POSSIBLE SIGNS OF BOMB FOUND IN AIR-INDIA DEBRIS
description: The first evidence that an Air-India jumbo jet may have been destroyed by a bomb has been detected on a fragment of the fuselage brought up by a salvage ship, an American official said yesterday.

TOTE THAT DUSTER
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese is causing a fuss with his excited view of the Constitution. He says the courts interpreting the Constitution ought to consider what its authors intended when they wrote it. He suggests the Supreme Court for at least the past 30 years has ignored the intent of those 18th-century lawyers, with the result that we now have a lot of cockeyed laws on the books.

The resulting product, a high-fructose syrup, is expected to compete with corn syrup as a sweetener for soft drinks.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. The picture is part of the wall of a collapsed lock that closed the St. Lawrence Seaway to traffic. 2. The Italian Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, resigned after Mr. Spadolini pulled his Republican Party out of the Government to protest its handling of the hijacking of the liner Achille Lauro and its decision to free Mohammed Abbas, a Palestinian guerilla sought by the United States. 3. To the consternation of the Russian Tea Room, which has been situated near Carnegie Hall since 1928, a new restaurant, the Chinese Tea Room, has opened in the vicinity. To avoid confusion, the Russian Tea Room is demanding that the new restaurant change its name. 4. Richard M. Nixon. 5. Paul A. Volcker refused an offer of the presidency of the World Bank. 6. The President sent Senator Paul Laxalt to the Philippines to ''express concern'' to President Ferdinand E. Marcos about the worsening military, political and economic situation there. 7. Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia, the former Managing Director, Leo A. Brooks, and the Police Commissioner, Gregore J. Sambor, testified on successive days before an inquiry into a confrontation last May with the radical group Move that ended in 11 deaths. The men disagreed on what the Mayor had been told about details of plans to attack Move's headquarters. 8. Wood pulp. 9. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum. 10. description: The Giants seemed likely today to activate Mark Haynes for Sunday's game here against the Washington Redskins. But it appeared that Ali Haji-Sheikh would remain on injured reserve for at least one more week.

title: No Progress Reported In Strike at Columbia
description: Pickets marched at Columbia University and hundreds of classes were held off campus yesterday as a strike by clerical employees went on for a second day with no report of progress on issues involving pay, health benefits and what the union says are inequities for women and minority workers.

SYRIA PRESSES TO SET RUSSIANS FREE
description: Syria and its allies in Lebanon have decided to step up their efforts to secure the release of three Soviet Embassy men who were kidnapped in West Beirut on Oct. 1. A fourth Russian who was abducted was found slain two days later.

title: JAIL ORDERED FOR 4 ORGANIZED-CRIME SUSPECTS
description: A Federal District Court judge here revoked the bail of four reputed leaders of a New Jersey organized-crime group today and ordered them jailed on the ground that they posed a potential threat to Government witnesses and to the public.

SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Royals vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Kansas City, Mo., opening game of the World Series. (Television -Channel 7, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Madison Square Garden, 8:30 P.M., second game of an N.B.A. preseason doubleheader that will be preceded by a game between the Detroit Pistons and the Atlanta Hawks starting at 6 P.M. The Pacers recently signed the 6-foot-9-inch Wayman Tisdale, the No. 2 pick in the draft behind Patrick Ewing of the Knicks. (Television - MSG Network, 8 P.M.) Nets vs. Phoenix Suns, exhibition at Anchorage. Boxing United States Soviet Union Heavyweight Invitational, at the Sands Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. Doors open at 1 P.M. First fight in the eight-bout card is at 2 P.M. Michael Bent of Cambria Heights, Queens, heads the United States heavyweights. Football Army at Notre Dame (Television - USA Network and Channel 11, noon.); North Carolina at North Carolina State (Television - MSG noon); Purdue at Ohio State (Television - Channel 2, noon); Rutgers vs. Pittsburgh at Giants Stadium, 12:30 P.M. TAKING LENIN'S DIRECTION
description: About 15 years ago, my wife and I were driving back to Moscow from the Black Sea when we turned onto the broad and, by Soviet standards, fairly good main road that runs from Pyatigorsk to Rostov-on-Don. At the point where we joined the road, there were no signposts; we turned in the direction we thought was the right one and drove on, reckoning that we would soon reach a road sign. Then, we thought, if we were lucky we would keep straight on, and if not we would only need to turn around.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. This was a traffic stopper of international proportions. Identify it and explain. 2. An action by Giovanni Spadolini, the Italian Defense Minister, had dramatic consequences. What did he do and what happened? 3. A new skirmish has broken out between the Russians and the Chinese, and the battle front is slightly to the left - and right - of Carnegie Hall. Explain. 4. A former President has agreed to arbitrate the pay dispute between baseball major league owners and umpires. Who is he? 5. ''I'm here; I'm staying,'' said the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Who is he and what were the circumstances? 6. President Reagan sent a Senator who is one of his closest friends on a diplomatic mission. Who is the Senator and what did the President ask him to do? 7. The Mayor said he had been misled, misinformed and disobeyed. But the city's former Managing Director and its Police Commissioner contradicted the Mayor on many details. Identify the Mayor and explain. 8. A nonnutritional ingredient used as a source of fiber in a number of high-fiber breads is (hemp/plastic/ wood pulp). 9. Soil and ashes from six European burial sites were mixed into the foundation of a building being erected near the Washington Monument. What building is it? 10. According to a widely accepted theory of Franco Modigliani, who won the Nobel Prize in Economics, the market value of a company's stock generally is a function of (the size and structure of a company's debt/a company's expected earnings/both a company's debt and its expected earnings). 11.

title: VAMPIRE FOR OUT TIMES
description: THE VAMPIRE LESTAT. By Anne Rice. 481 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95. Anne Rice has what might best be described as a Gothic imagination crossed with a campy taste for the decadent and the bizarre. Her last novel, ''Cry to Heaven,'' was about castrati; and her latest novel, ''The Vampire Lestat,'' is about - what else, vampires. It's not just the exotic subject matter that makes these books feel so baroque; it's Mrs. Rice's whole sensibility and use of prose. She loves to sling around phrases like ''Children of Darkness'' and ''the Devil's Road''; displays an equal fondness for such words as ''chaos,'' ''ecstasy'' and ''death'', and she likes to give her characters romantic names like Armand, Gabrielle and Marius. Reading ''The Vampire Lestat,'' in fact, is a lot like spending an entire day in a museum featuring only works by Henry Fuseli - all hung in heavy, gilt frames decorated with curlicues and malicious cherubs. By the end, you're reeling from both the strangeness and the surfeit of ornamentation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Champion International Corp., Stamford, Conn., a producer of paper and wood building material, said it had sold its distribution yards and industrial supply division to Michael R. Mastro of Seattle. Terms were not disclosed. * Coast Savings and Loan Association., Los Angeles, said it had filed its complete application for conversion to a public company with the Federal Home Loan Bank board. * First Union Corp., Charlotte, N.C., a bank holding company, said the Federal Reserve Board had approved its acquisition of Atlantic Bancorp. * Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., London, said it was discussing the sale of its bingo, entertainment and holiday interests in a management buyout with directors of Mecca Leisure Ltd. and Warner Holidays Ltd., a spokesman said. * Exxon Corp. received a $126.1 million contract for jet aircraft fuel, the Pentagon said. * LTV Corp., Dallas, said its Sierra research division had received a $34 million Air Force contract for two airborne platform/telemetry relay systems with related data and software systems. * LTX Corp., Westwood, Mass., said it would lay off 250 employees because of ''persistent weakness'' in the domestic semiconductor industry. * NCNB National Bank, a banking company based in Charlotte, N.C., said it plans a commercial and retail center on 237 acres near Cary, N.C., with an estimated construction cost of $300 million to $400 million. * NCR Corp., Dayton, Ohio, said its personal computer division had introduced a new version of its NCR PC4 personal computer. The new model, the PC4I, is compatible with I.B.M.'s PC and XT computers. * Nynex Corp., said that its wholly owned subsidiary, Nynex Development Co., had signed an agreement to acquire the Data Group Corp. Terms were not disclosed. * Orbit Instrument Corp., Hauppauge, L.I.. said it had agreed to acquire Comdial Corp's Comdial Technology Corp. subsidiary. * Scope Inc., Reston, Va., said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its bar code scanning business to Rockwell International Corp's Allen-Bradley Co. subsidiary. Terms were not disclosed. * Xerox Corp., Leesburg, Va., said it had introduced a computer-aided system for mechanical design and drafting applications.

title: IT'S STILL NOT SPYING

title: PEANUT SHACK OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
No Nukeport Jazz
description: Thirteen jazz groups and soloists will perform tomorrow, starting at 2 P.M., at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets, in a 10-hour No Nukeport Jazz Festival, presented by Mobilization for Survival.

title: INFOTRON SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A View From the Balcony
description: T he Republican candidate for Mayor, Diane McGrath, has been upstaged on many civic occasions by Mayor Koch. But never was the disparity in their positions as evident as Thursday night at that most political of nonpolitical affairs - the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: New Patent Office Chief
description: Donald J. Quigg took office today as Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks. The Senate had approved his nomination on Thursday. Mr. Quigg, who had been deputy commissioner, joined the staff in 1981. Before that, he had been patent counsel for the Phillips Petroleum Company.

title: Chamberlain Disputed
description: Wilt Chamberlain may have been paid $4,000 by a series of Jayhawk ''godfathers'' to play basketball at the University of Kansas 30 years ago, but four of his teammates say they had no such ''godfathers'' and got no such illicit payments. The four, Gene Elstun, John Parker, Maurice King and Bob Billings, told USA Today that they got no more than the $15-a-month ''laundry money'' that the National Collegiate Athletic Association allowed athletes to receive at the time. In disclosing that he had received illegal payments from ''two or three'' godfathers, Chamberlain said, ''Everyone was assigned at least one godfather when I was at Kansas.''

title: DENTAL WORLD CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title:
PATENTS;

Data on Devices To Replace Bone
description: Medical Biological Sciences Inc. of New York received two patents this week related to two issued last August for implantable devices useful as bone or hard tissue replacement anywhere in the body.

title: CHRYSLER AND UNION BREAK OFF TALKS FOR WEEDEND
description: Talks on a new contract between the sriking United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation broke off for the weekend late this afternoon.

title: CHANGE IN 'FALSTAFF' AT METROPOLITAN OPERA
description: The Metropolitan Opera's current production of Verdi's ''Falstaff,'' constructed around the central figure of Giuseppe Taddei's ''Fat Knight,'' has recently undergone several secondary cast changes.

title: ROYAL PALM SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WESTPORT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $588,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: NEW AIRLINE JOINS THE CROWDED SKIES
description: With the snipping of a ceremonial blue ribbon at Dulles International Airport and the in-flight popping of champagne corks, another new airline has joined the growing ranks of carriers hazarding the increasingly competitive skies.

title: SOUTHERN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRANSWORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $6,059,000 for the quarter and $11,797,000 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $6,067,000 for the quarter and $13,964,000 for the 9 months.

title: AN ISRAELI TOUR GUIDE STABBED ON WEST BANK
description: An Israeli tour guide was stabbed and wounded today while showing three Danish tourists around ancient ruins in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the Israeli Army spokesman announced.

title: LANE CO AND WOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FEDERAL SCREW WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comings and Goings
description: Don Garlits posted the fastest speed in drag racing history on Thursday when he reached 268.11 miles an hour in a qualifying run for the National Hot Rod Association's finals at the Los Angeles County Fairgrounds on Sunday. . . . Martina Navratilova, who turned 29 yesterday, has regained the top spot in the women's world tennis rankings after defeating Steffi Graf in a tournament on Monday. She had dropped to No. 2 last June after losing to Chris Evert Lloyd in the French Open.

title:
PATENTS;

Free-Flowing Solids
description: A method of producing free-flowing solids was patented this week for Arthur D. Little Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., by Chakra J. Santhanam, who is the manager of the company's chemical and metallurgical section.

title: POPE BIDS U.N. ACT ON THE DEBT CRISIS
description: Pope John Paul II today described the global debt crisis as an ''ethical and humanitarian'' issue and called on the United Nations to play a ''front line'' role in the effort to find solutions.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Sept 22
AMERICAN WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALASKA NATIONAL BANK OF THE NORTH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $222,000 for the quarter and $391,000 for the 9 months.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT TOLD TO LEAVE
description: Irina Grivnina, a political dissident who served several years in internal exile in the Soviet Union for publicizing accounts of what she said were Soviet abuses of psychiatry for political ends, has been told she must leave Russia before Oct. 30, according to executives of private human rights organizations.

title: MARIAN HAHN, PIANIST, AT CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL
description: Marian Hahn, a pianist who made her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall in 1974 as a Concert Artists Guild winner, returned on Wednesday night to open its new ''Debuts and Encores'' series sponsored by Carnegie Hall.

title: Randall Pence Is Wed To Robin Heidi Ehrlich
description: Robin Heidi Ehrlich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard G. Ehrlich of Bedford, N.Y., and Randall Pence, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Pence of Holmesville, Neb., were married yesterday. The Rev. John Olafson of the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., performed the Protestant ceremony at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y.

title: The Targets: 6 Diseases That Threaten Children
description: MEASLES: Without vaccination, virtually all young children in developing countries catch measles. About 3 percent of those, more than 2 million a year, die from the viral disease or its complications, which include pneumonia, blindness, deafness and malnutrition. Mortality rates from measles among children already malnourished can rise to 10 percent or higher.

title: CITY OPERA: 'FAUST' ON TOUR
description: The New York City Opera's traveling arm, its National Company, is taking Gounod's ''Faust'' to 25 cities this month and next. Thursday night it came momentarily to rest at the brightly refurbished Shubert Performing Arts Center here.

title: Medical Examiner to Modify Use of Brains of the Executed
description: The Alachua County Medical Examiner has said he will stop giving the brain tissue of executed killers to a university scientist for research.

title: WRIGHTT'S LEGACY
description: To the Editor: I read the article on ''Wright's Legacy in Wisconsin'' (Travel, Aug. 25) upon my return from a vacation in the Midwest; it was with a tinge of sadness. Just the week before, while visiting the old hometown, Kankakee, Ill., I had taken my son Ted, a Miami stained-glass artist, to see the town's ''sight'' - two Frank Lloyd Wright houses, side by side, at the southern end of Harrison Avenue overlooking the Kankakee River.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on June 9 under the headline ''Many-Faced, Contradictory, Ancient Sicily'' incorrectly named a Sicilian town that specializes in pottery making. The town is Santo Stefano di Camastra.

title: STAGE STARS TALK SHOP IN FREE PUBLIC SEMINARS
description: WHEN the American Theater Wing asked Barnard Hughes to participate in one of its fall seminars on the theater, he agreed for several reasons.

title: PENNSYLVANIA REACTOR NEARS FULL-SCALE OPERATION
description: Irene Kervier had lived for years near the site of the Limerick nuclear power plant, so it was natural that she was alarmed by the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island plant, near Harrisburg.

title: VERSATILE PIANIST CHANGES HIS MIND ABOUT THE CLASSICS
description: The 20's were just beginning to roar when jazz first made inroads on the ''serious'' side of American musical life. It was an uneasy mix from the start. The editor of The Etude, a music magazine, declared jazz responsible for an increase in the crime rate, and John Philip Sousa claimed that ''some of it makes you want to bite your grandmother.'' The attitude of concert artists toward the new phenomenon might best have been summed up, though, by Ossip Gabrilowitsch, then conductor of the Detroit Symphony. At a social gathering one evening at which the indefatigable George Gershwin was, typically, demonstrating his piano prowess for hours on end, Gabrilowitsch began to beat an early path for the door when someone asked him what he got out of jazz. ''I get out of it,'' he replied, ''as soon as I can.''

title: Corpocracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Steinberg Is Bride Of Marty Katz in Jersey
description: Linda Steinberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Steinberg of Clifton, N.J., was married yesterday to Marty Katz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Katz of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Dr. Leon Katz performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: HOW STRAIT THE JACKET
description: When candidate Ronald Reagan made a silly statement blaming some trees for causing environmental pollution, a sign was tied to the trunk of a large, innocent tree: ''Stop me before I kill again.''

title: NEW YORKERS, etc.
description: DAVID SUSSKIND was working late one night, and when he was ready to leave, he asked if anyone in his office was hungry. A 21-year-old production assistant said she was, and the two of them went across the street for something to eat.

title: TOUGHT TIMES FOR THE FI-FI NOVEL
description: IN an era when economic and business affairs dominate the news and appear to shape the nation's character, it is odd how small a percentage of successful fiction deals with the executive suite and the board room. These are the arenas in which the power of money and the workings of ego and ambition connect and from which the consequences of that connection reverberate into millions of lives and trillions of dollars. Yet it would seem to be the view of serious literary personages - whether novelists, critics, editors or inveterate readers -that only in everyday life can suitably serious material be found. Henry James's ''figure in the carpet,'' as he characterized the object of the novelist's search, is now the figure in the linoleum.

title: Worms and Law
description: FOR five years, State Senator Dale M. Volker, a Republican and sometime fisherman from the Village of Depew, had pressed the New York Legislature to rectify what he deemed a patent injustice in state law: denial of a child's right to gather earthworms for pay after 7 P.M.

title: Debra L. Motschwiller Married to a Physician
description: Debra Louise Motschwiller, a head nurse at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, and Dr. James Paul Hollenberg, an attending physician at the center, were married yesterday at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

title: FIGHTING FOR WHAT'S DUE
description: ALTHOUGH I am disabled with end-stage heart disease and able to do many ordinary things such as mow the lawn, take out the garbage or pick up the cat only with great care to avoid breathlessness and pain, I am grateful that there is still much I can do.

title: EWING IS EJECTED
description: The Knicks desperately need to replace Bernard King, at least until midseason. And if the team's management has its way, two prime candidates for the small forward's job -Louis Orr and Albert King - will be in Knick uniforms this season.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GOOD SOUTHERNER: The Life of Henry A. Wise of Virginia. By Craig M. Simpson. (University of North Carolina, $27.95.) As presented by Craig M. Simpson, Henry A. Wise (1806-1876) represents the conscience of the South, especially during the years immediately preceding the Civil War.

title: FORTUNE FAVORS REDSKIN
description: When they line up against the Redskins here on Sunday, the Giants will be facing a team whose recent revival has been spurred in part by Steve Cox, a strong and steady kicker who has kicked the second-longest field goal in National Football League history.

title: Business in Short
description: THE VITAL DIFFERENCE: Unleashing the Powers of Sustained Corporate Success. By Frederick G. Harmon and Garry Jacobs. (AMACOM/American Management Association, 135 West 50th Street, New York, N.Y. 10020, $18.95.)

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Continue bulb planting. . . . Transplant perennials and woody shrubs. . . . Start leaf raking. . . . Finish lawn renovation. . . . Stock up on pots, potting soil, drainage trays, lawn fertilizers and other garden supplies.

title: UNIVERSITY CHIEFS PLEDGE MUTUAL SUPPORT
description: THE new presidents at both of Connecticut's public university systems are pledging an end to the era of rivalry between the two schools.

title: No Big Deal
description: Women don't believe men are ''no big deal.'' Many women, myself included, believe men to be fun, interesting, brave, generous, loving, compassionate and, often, intelligent.

title: Massachusetts And Its Homeless
description: THE FIRST MAJOR report by Massachusetts on its response to the problems of the homeless shows that about 75 percent, 8,000 to 10,000 people, live in family groups.

title: AMERICA'S IMPERIAL BALLET SCHOOL
description: TWO BLOCKS north of Lincoln Center, at the end of a long, winding hall on the third floor of the Juilliard School, the School of American Ballet quietly goes about its work of the past half-century.

title: GENERAL MANAGERS PAYING FOR LOSSES
description: THE mortality rate for general managers has risen dramatically. Once a safe and secure job with the promise of lifetime employment, the general manager's position now challenges the manager's for high-risk living in baseball. In 1985 alone, seven clubs have changed general managers.

title: SHIFTS AND SLUMPS
description: THE FUTURE OF AMERICAN BUSINESS The U.S. in World Competition. By Marvin Cetron with Alicia Pagano and Otis Port. 239 pp.

title: A VISIT TO THE PUMPKIN PATCH
description: WHEN Terry Jones was in the sixth grade, his first farm project was to grow pumpkins to sell to wholesalers. The pumpkins grew fine, but Mr. Jones soon moved on to other agricultural pursuits.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A FATHER'S DIARY. By Fraser Harrison. (Pantheon, $16.95.) After several years as a book editor, Fraser Harrison moved from London to a farm in Suffolk and began a career as a writer, a career that gave him the opportunity ''to watch and take part in every moment of my children's lives.''

title: MYSTERY AND SURPRISE IMPEL 'GOLDEN WINDOWS'
description: At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Robert Wilson is watching a run-through of his new play. The set is up, the lights are ready, the actors are in costume. From the proscenium hangs a scrim embroidered in gold with the name of the play: ''The Golden Windows.'' On a raked stage, a dead man, noose around his neck, is suspended in space. Behind him stands a black house resembling a sentry box, with a shaft of light glaring through the slightly open door. Lying downstage and looking up at the corpse is a girl draped in white.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBAL '85;

ATTACK TURNS BACK BOTH THE CLOCK AND OTHER TEAMS
description: THE preference in this leafy little village is for things that are old.

title: SPORTS LIT, ETC.
description: THE SHOPPING MALL HIGH SCHOOL Winners and Losers in the Educational Marketplace. By Arthur G. Powell, Eleanor Farrar and David K. Cohen. 360 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: BRAZILIAN SOAP OPERAS APPEAL TO GLOBAL TASTES
description: Gone is the cliche of Brazil as a nation of irrepressible samba dancers and consummate soccer artists.

title: POLICE CHIEF FILES SUIT
description: THE Police Chief of the town of Mamaroneck charged in a $60 million lawsuit filed late last week that his civil rights have been violated and that he has been libeled, harassed and ridiculed by Mamaroneck's Town Supervisor, Town Administrator, Police Commissioner and Town Board.

title: A HALO FOR THE FRIDGE
description: ADVERTISING THE AMERICAN DREAM Making Way for Modernity, 1920-1940. By Roland Marchand. Illustrated. 448 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $27.50; $35 after Dec. 31.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Royals vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Kansas City. Game 2. (Television - Channel 7, 8:25 P.M. Radio -WCBS 880, 8:25 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Toledo, Ohio. This is the final exhibition game for the Knicks, who open the regular season next Saturday at home. Football Jets vs. New England Patriots, at Foxboro, Mass. Steve Grogan, a longtime nemesis of the Jets, will start at quarterback for New England. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 4 P.M.). Giants vs. Washington Redskins, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. With three touchdowns last Sunday, John Riggins of the Redskins joined Jim Brown as the only N.F.L. player with 100 touchdowns on the ground. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 1 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Vancouver Canucks, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Rangers won two of the three meetings last season. (Television - MSG 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) Black Hawks vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Chicago (Television -ESPN 8:30 P.M. live.) Running Ninth annual America's Marathon/Chicago. Steve Jones, the defending champion is back, and Joan Benoit and Ingrid Kristiansen are also competing. (Television -Channel 2, 4:30 P.M. same day tape). Thoroughbred Racing Belmont, 1 P.M. Cool is the 3-1 early favorite to win the $75,000- added Kelso Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at a mile and a quarter on the turf. (Television - SportsChannel 6:30 and 11 P.M. Other Events AUTO RACING: Nascar American 500 at Rockingham, N.C. (Television -WTBS 12:35 P.M.) GOLF: Ladies PGA J&B Gold Putter Award Playoff at Las Vegas, Nev.

title: LABELING OF GIFTED IS CALLED DESIRABLE
description: After reading Dr. Nancy Devlin's Sept. 1 Opinion Page article on why not to label children, it occurred to me that something ought to be said about why bright children should be identified promptly.

title: UNBEATEN AMHERST TROUNCES WESLEYAN
description: John Tucci caught six passes for 114 yards and two touchdowns today, and Amherst recorded its second straight shutout in the 26-0 Little Three victory over Wesleyan. Amherst (5-0) held Wesleyan (2-3) to only four first downs, all in the second half, and 98 yards total offense, allowing Jim Lukowski 31 yards passing and picking off four of his passes. Tucci scored on passes of 10 yards and 54 yards from Paul Foye, who threw for 225 yards.

title: Business in Short
description: KAISHA: The Japanese Corporation. By James C. Abegglen and George Stalk Jr. (Basic, $22.50.) Like most things created in Japan, this book is sturdy, well designed and a good buy.

title: CONCESSIONS AT ISSUE IN STRIKE OF FOOD PLANTS
description: Buffeted by competition from Texas and abroad, two of the country's largest frozen-food plants have demanded wage and benefit concessions from their workers, leading to a strike by 1,700 employees that has lasted six weeks.

title: RAISING CAPITAL FOR CO-OPS
description: FINANCING through bond issues is usually considered a governmental or business fund-raising technique. In certain instances, however, a small, private bond issue offered only to residents can be a practical way for cooperatives, condominiums and homeowner associations to raise money for capital improvements.

title: A NEW ATTACK ON ALCOHOLISM
description: ALCOHOLISM: A mysterious and incurable result of a personality disorder; at worst, a moral disease; at best, a pyschological one.

title: Business in Short
description: THE CORPORATE COUPLE: Living the Corporate Game. By Peggy J. Berry. (Franklin Watts, $16.95.) Psychologists have written at length about the pressures on the families of high-powered corporate executives.

title: REUSING A FACTORY
description: In a section of Jersey City that lies between the port city's booming commercial district on the waterfront and its brownstone neighborhoods to the west, a former chocolate plant is being converted to 27-unit condominium apartment building.

title: Wedding Planned By Lisa Williams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Williams of Pueblo, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elisabeth Trefz Williams to George Ring Ireland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Ireland of Cleveland, Ohio. The wedding is planned for Jan. 18.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Headliners column last Sunday on the play from which the movie ''Casablanca'' was made omitted the name of one of its co-authors. The play, ''Everybody Comes to Rick's,'' was written in 1940 by Murray Burnett and Joan Alison.

title: Going On in the Northeast;   CARVINGS IN CONNECTICUT
description: Another use for trees will be in evidence Nov. 2 and 3 at a New England Woodcarvers Festival in Wallingford, Conn.

title: WHAT CAN MAKE MARCOS LISTEN?
description: President Reagan chose a good time and the right messenger to convey his alarm about the drift of the Marcos dictatorship in the Philippines. Mr. Reagan tried to offer the urgent but private advice that corruption, incompetence and brutality were playing into the hands of a Communist insurgency. It fell on deaf ears. ''Another Meddler from the U.S.'' was the headline that greeted Senator Paul Laxalt, the President's closest associate in Congress. And he was sped on his way Thursday with ''Good Riddance.''

title: MURDER IN SUBURBIA
description: FOXPRINTS By Patrick McGinley. 282 pp. New York: A Joan Kahn Book/ St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

title: PEKING GIVES BUSH A BILL OF PARTICULARS
description: In a sense, George Bush's problems in China last week began with Margaret Thatcher. When Mrs. Thatcher was in Peking last year to sign the agreement under which Britain will return Hong Kong to China in 1997, Deng Xiaoping, China's pre-eminent leader, gave the British Prime Minister a message for President Reagan. It urged the United States to endorse the ''one country, two systems'' approach Mr. Deng had fashioned for Hong Kong as a solution to China's pursuit of reunification with Taiwan.

title: Esther Lynn Fortunoff To Wed Joshua Greene
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Fortunoff of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Esther Lynn Fortunoff to Joshua M. Greene, the son of Adele S. Greene of New York and Rhinebeck, N.Y., and Alan Greene of New York. The wedding is planned for Nov. 23.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Night and Day Starring Cary Grant, Alexis Smith, Monty Woolley; directed by Michael Curtiz, 1946 Key Video 127 minutes. $59.98 Never among Hollywood's top-notch musicals, this film has not aged particularly gracefully.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Oct. 20, 1985 Fiction

title: NOTRE DAME ENDS ARMY STREAK, 24-10
description: Notre Dame, suffering through a difficult and disappointing season, played better today than the best Army team in many years. The Irish scored two early touchdowns and went on to beat the Cadets, 24-10, handing Army its first loss of the season.

title: ADDDING OFFICE FRILLS TO THE BASIC HOME MODEL
description: A HARRIED bachelor is cooking an elaborate Italian dinner for guests, when the phone rings. He flips on a speaker and talks while he cooks.

title: THE BIG PAYOFF IN PAY PHONES
description: WITH visions of quarters jangling in their heads, corner delicatessens and corporate giants alike are buying pay telephones. The lure: Owners of pay phones need not pay commissions to telephone companies.

title: CONFINED SO FAR TO BACKYARDS
description: Agriculture inspectors have reported finding a new citrus pest never before seen in this country's trees.

title: U.N. IN BRONX: RECALLING EXCITING EARLY DAYS
description: Diplomats met in a gymnasium. Reporters worked out of a broom closet. Wooden classroom seats served as chairs. And the likes of Eleanor Roosevelt and Andrei A. Gromyko mingled freely with clerks, secretaries and junior officers.

title: Lisa Pawel Is Married To Eric S. Schlesinger
description: Elizabeth Thompson Pawel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ernst Pawel of San Antonio, was married yesterday to Eric Scott Schlesinger, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stewart Schlesinger of Santa Ana, Calif. The Rev. Ralph Henderson Shuffler performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in San Antonio.

title: Brown Tops Cornell on Kicks
description: Chris Ingerslev kicked five field goals today to lead Brown to a 22-0 victory over Cornell, tying the Brown record for field goals in a single game, set in 1972 by Tyler Chase.

title: AGING CLAY AND THE PRODIGAL SON
description: BACK IN THE WORLD By Tobias Wolff. 221 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95.

title: STEREO SOUND IS BECOMING THE NORM
description: >A slow but significant shift is under way in the sales pattern of video cassette recorders. Only a year ago, interest in VCR's with high-fidelity stereo sound was confined chiefly to the exceptional viewer intent upon the latest technical refinements. Today, such VCR's are heading for more general acceptance, claiming an increasing share of the market.

title: BLEAK REPORT ON BRITISH INDUSTRY DRAWS FIRE FROM CABINET
description: A gloomy assessment of Britain's industrial prospects by some prominent industrialists and bankers in the House of Lords has drawn an unusually defensive and caustic response from members of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet.

title: A Royal Tizzy Envelops the Capital
description: ''My birthday was a few days ago and I don't think I have ever before received so many birthday cards,'' said J. Carter Brown.

title: NATIONALISM IN MUSIC RECOGNIZES NO BOUNDARIES
description: Unlike George Washington in the political realm, Charles Ives has never been first in the hearts of his countrymen despite his now classic status as a quintessentially American composer. A new recording of the Symphony No. 3 and Orchestral Set No. 2 should help to repair the damage.

title: Onder John Olcay And Phebe Miller Exchange Vows
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Phebe Condict Miller, a daughter of Mrs. Albert Fullerton Miller of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Mr. Miller, was married to Onder John Olcay, the son of Nahide Olcay of Izmir, Turkey, and the late Sureyya Olcay. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony.

title: The Myth Maker
description: Twenty-five years after the publication of his first novel, ''Welcome to Hard Times,'' E. L. Doctorow is reminiscing about a letter from one of its readers. Set in the Dakota Territory in the latter half of the 19th century, the novel takes the form of journals written by the mayor of a tiny frontier town called Hard Times. It's a dark fable, a literary western by a serious young writer, that employs the town's tribulations - and the mayor's attempts to record them - to explore grand themes: the nature of American culture, the mortality of men and their civilization, the eternalness of art. ''The letter was from Texas,'' Doctorow says, ''and obviously from an elderly woman, written in a shaky hand. She wrote, 'Young man, when you said that Jenks enjoyed for his dinner the roasted haunch of a prairie dog, I knew you'd never been west of the Hudson. Because the haunch of a prairie dog wouldn't fill a teaspoon.' ''

title: MAKING GRAPHICS GLITTER
description: BUSINESS software can be divided into the ''Big Three,'' the ''Hopefuls'' and a pool of miscellaneous programs into which most people are hesitant to stick their toes. The ''Big Three'' - word processing, spreadsheets and data base management programs - are the cornerstones of personal computer use. These are the programs for which computers are bought in the first place. The ''Hopefuls'' are communications software and graphics packages.

title: PAISLEY, BIGGER THAN EVER, IS BACK ON THE SCENE
description: NO, those are not sunspots you see every time you turn a corner. They are merely fashion's latest comeback, the paisley boom.

title: WAGNER TRIUMPHS, 19-0
description: Jesse Foote, the quarterback, ran 8 yards for one touchdown and connected with Herb Bellamy on a 26-yard pass for another as Wagner strengthened its bid for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III playoffs by beating Fairleigh Dickinson-Madison, 19-0, yesterday. The game was played before a homecoming-day crowd of 4,214 at Fischer Field on Wagner's campus in Staten Island.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Handmade Dhurries $20 to $18,000 At an Oriental Rug Bazaar and Sale today at Larchmont Temple, hundreds of handmade rugs and dhurries - in Persian, Indian, Pakistani and Chinese styles - will be sold for prices of $20 to $18,000. Credit cards cannot be accepted, but checks with two forms of identification can be.

title: NEW CRITICISM FOR LILCO IN STORM'S WAKE
description: THREE weeks after the Long Island Lighting Company suffered millions of dollars in damage from Hurricane Gloria, the utility is being buffeted by new public dissatisfaction over the time it took the utility to restore power.

title: Canaday Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for John Canaday, former chief art critic of The New York Times, will be held Thursday in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. Mr. Canaday died July 19. He was 78 years old.

title: O'CONNOR NAMES BLACK WOMAN TO CHANCERY POST
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, who recently told a conference in Harlem that he intended to expand the influence of blacks in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, has selected a black woman for a key chancery position.

title: No Big Deal
description: I cannot see what is so new about Michael Blumenthal's experience. Had a middle-aged poet, in 1885, joined a group of matrons of that age, would he expect much more to happen than benevolent disinterestedness? It is simply a sign of aging, or maturing, or whatever you like to call it, that women of an age where they have seen it can't get so easily into the kind of erotic shiver he hopes for. So either he sheds his youthful fantasies or else he looks for female company that is less worn out than the matrons he is socializing with. THOMAS WALDE New York City

title:
THEATER REVIEW;

L.I. ACTOR IN COMEDY WITH SERIOUS SIDE
description: THE deadly disease AIDS hardly seems the stuff of humor. But an actor from Long Island who stars in a cable television comedy series that will feature a character with acquired immune deficiency syndrome says the effort is a way to reach and educate the public.

title: THE LONG LINES ARE WORTH IT
description: HOT TOMATO'S may be the best thing to happen in New Haven since the Yale Center for British Art opened its doors a few years ago.

title: STORMS BATTER ASIAN COUNTRIES FROM INDIA TO THE PHILIPPINES
description: Storms continued to batter countries in Asia today, with Typhoon Dot leaving 31 people dead and thousands homeless after hitting the Philippines' main island of Luzon with heavy rains and winds of up to 70 miles an hour.

title: MONITORING VITAL SIGNS IN NEWARK
description: After William Mikesell chose this city as the headquarters of his new architectural firm 10 years ago, he often took lonely walks downtown on Sunday afternoons to study the facades of the city's many 19th-century buildings. Given the deterioration of the rest of the city, he thought these symbols of Newark's more affluent past would soon disappear. But on weekend strolls in the last few months, he has encountered people eager to know if the buildings are for sale.

title: A PLAN FOR REVOLUTION AT THE PENTAGON
description: The Pentagon's defenses against those recurring drives - usually launched on the Congressional side of the Potomac - to reorganize and otherwise make more efficient the sprawling, expensive military establishment have become well-nigh impregnable; indeed, they have not been breached since the Eisenhower Administration.

title: U.S. Advances to Final Of Richest Golf Event
description: The top-seeded United States beat fourth-seeded Scotland, 2-1, today to advance to the final of golf's richest tournament, the $1.2 million Dunhill Cup.

title: Business in Short
description: THE HIGH COST OF HIGH TECH: The Dark Side of the Chip. By Lenny Siegel and John Markoff. (Bessie/Harper & Row, $16.50.)

title: SEOUL IS ACCUSED OF RIGHTS ABUSES
description: A London-based human rights organization and members of a South Korean opposition group accused South Korean Government officials last week of torturing political prisoners to obtain false confessions of espionage and antistate activities, crimes that carry the death penalty.

title: Wendy Bartlett Becomes a Bride
description: Wendy Norman Bartlett, a daughter of Mrs. Walter Comstock Bartlett Jr. of St. Joseph, Mo., and Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Mr. Bartlett, was married yesterday to Howard Paul Serrell Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Serrell of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Walter Wagoner, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich.

title: WARSAW THRONG MARKS PRIEST'S SLAYING
description: More than 20,000 Poles gathered at a church here tonight to mark the slaying last year of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a pro-Solidarity priest who was kidnapped and killed by four state security men.

title: The Pregnant Detective
description: As a fan from the start of ''Cagney & Lacey,'' I was disappointed to find that the show's writers consider being pro-choice to be synonymous with opting for an abortion -that Mary Beth Lacey's choice not to abort would mean coming out ''against a woman's right to make a choice.'' (''The Pregnant Detective,'' by Karen Stabiner, Sept. 22).

title: WINNING ISN'T EVERYTHING IN THE RACE FOR MAYOR
description: Mayor Koch stood on the steps of City Hall the other day, less than four weeks before Election Day, and delivered what sounded remarkably like an election night victory speech.

title: WRIGHT'S LEGACY
description: To the Editor: The article, ''Wright's Legacy in Wisconsin'' brought back memories of an interview I had with Frank Lloyd Wright 50 years ago; the writer of your article, John Welchman, truly captured the essence of Taliesin as I remember it.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: STRIKE UP THE BANDS One of the state's most spirited events, the Windjammers Invitational Marching Band Competition, will be held at the Cadet Memorial Field of the Coast Guard Academy in New London from 5:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. Saturday. Sixteen champion high school bands from about a dozen Northeastern states will compete for plaques. Some 3,200 musicians will be involved, among them members of bands from East Lyme, Trumbull, Cheshire, Waterford and Greenwich.

title: WHERE BIGGER ALSO MEANS BETTER
description: THE good reasons to recommend La Marmite in Williston Park have become more compelling lately. Although the restaurant remains in the two-star category, if it continues along its current course a third star would not be out of reach eventually.

title: THE TOLL RISES IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Another violent week in South Africa pushed the death toll still higher. Among the latest victims were a white soldier in the Eastern Cape, the first to die on riot patrol, and a 13-year-old black youth who, it was charged, was beaten by four white members of the security force near Pretoria. But despite the violence, which has claimed more than 750 lives in 13 months of township turmoil, the nation may have been as much caught up in past cases as in current ones.

title: Naidia Cascio Is a Bride
description: Naidia Cascio and Scott C. Borowsky were married yesterday in their home in Wynnewood, Pa., by Rabbi Max Hausen. The bride's parents are Sam Cascio of Lake Park, Fla., and Mrs. Oli Gulbramson of Cornwells Heights, Pa. Mr. Borowsky's parents are Irvin J. Borowsky and Beverly Borowsky, both of Philadelphia. The bridegroom, a lawyer, is the founder and owner of Kane Communications in Philadelphia, publisher of trade and professional magazines. Mrs. Borowsky is a food and cooking consultant.

title: ART ROCKERS BID FOR GLORY
description: If your taste runs toward slightly precious, calculated female art-rock with a folkish base, from Joni Mitchell to the Roches to Suzanne Vega, then two new records are worth your attention. They are Kate Bush's ''Hounds of Love'' (EMI America ST-17171) and Jane Siberry's ''No Borders Here'' (Open Air OA-0302, distributed by A & M). Since some tastes - like this one - do indeed run in that direction, at least occasionally, the generic description is not as condescending as it sounds.

title: Got a Second?
description: When Congress starts tampering with time, it takes a lot of, well, time.

title: SYMPHONY MARKS DEBUT WITH A SULLIVAN PREMIERE
description: THE birth of another ensemble, the Connecticut Sinfonia Society, has been announced. The proud, if unlikely, parents are the Connecticut Gilbert and Sullivan Society and the Xerox Foundation, with the first performance set to begin at 5 P.M. today at Middletown High School.

title: WASHINGTON 18-CENT COIL STAMP
description: The United States Postal Service has announced that the new 18-cent coil stamp will feature a portrait of George Washington with the Washington Monument in the background. The first day of issue is Nov. 6 in Washington, D.C. Stamps will go on sale across the country Nov. 7.

title: SIC TRANSIT GLORIA: A BLACKOUT DIARY
description: FRIDAY: It's over! The hurricane is now gone and we consider ourselves lucky. The house is in one piece and most of the trees survived. As a matter of fact, Mother Nature took care of the pruning I should have done a long time ago.

title: Elena de la Rosa, an Internal Auditor, Becomes Engaged to Tom S. Penney
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gustavo de la Rosa of Caracas, Venezuela, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elena de la Rosa, to Tom Smith Penney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Penney Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. The wedding is planned for Nov. 30. The future bride is a senior internal auditor for the Block Drug Company in Jersey City.

title: BYARS PACES OHIO ST. VICTORY
description: For the first time this year, Keith Byars was in the game. But he was not back - really back - until less than five minutes remained and Ohio State and Purdue were tied.

title: Holdout Is Over
description: Michel Goulet, the Quebec Nordiques' all star left wing, gave up his effort to force the club to renegotiate his $240,000 contract and ended his 25-day holdout after signing a one-year contract that will take effect at the end of the season. Details of the new pact were not disclosed, but both Goulet and the Nordiques said he would not get any extra money this season.

title: UCONN RESTORING 110 FLAGS OF HISTORY
description: THE flag of the Fifth Connecticut Regiment is tattered and faded, its fabric as delicate as butterfly wings.

title: BUILDINGS IN CITY TERMED ADEQUATE
description: Design and construction requirements in New York City and the surrounding region insure, by and large, that buildings are more than able to resist the type of tremors that shook the Northeast yesterday, according to building and engineering officials.

title: Gary Dotson to Be Married
description: Gary Dotson, who was released from prison in May after the woman he was convicted of raping recanted her accusation, is getting married in the spring to Camille Dardanes, who presented him with a rose in his clemency hearing. The hearing, held after Cathleen Crowell Webb recanted the rape accusation, led to Mr. Dotson's freedom, but his 1979 rape and kidnapping conviction was left standing.

title: HELMETS FIT FOR A WARLORD
description: Japanese helmets sprout antlers, giant mouselike ears and a sunburst. Others are crowned with a huge butterfly, yak hair and a fierce-faced killer whale.

title: Ray Charles's Airplane Slides Off Runway; 26 to Hospital
description: A 4-engine plane carrying the singer Ray Charles and his band ran off a runway while landing in heavy rain and slid down a hill into a cornfield, injuring the pilot, officials said.

title: THE PERMISSIVE DUTCH
description: MORE THAN 1,000 LOCAL COORDINATORS OF THE Interdenominational Peace Council of the Netherlands gathered early on a Sunday morning at a high school in Utrecht to begin planning their fall demonstrations. The high school was on a street called Amerikalaan, America Street. That seemed appropriate to the Dutch organizers, because their marches, meetings and petitions would be an attempt to stop the deployment of United States cruise missiles in their country.

title: ACCUSATIONS DELAY SAFETY OFFICIAL'S CONFIRMATION
description: The nomination of Terrence M. Scanlon as chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, which had been expected to win easy approval in the Senate, has been delayed so that a consumer group's allegations of impropriety can be investigated.

title: 3 ARE INDICTED IN JERSEY SHOOTOUT
description: Three New York City men have been indicted on charges stemming from a gun battle in a private park that killed two people, injured 19 others and sent hundreds running for cover.

title: OFFICER LOSES LICENSE MONTHS AFTER FATALITY
description: For seven months after he was accused of driving a New York City police car in a fatal hit-and-run accident, Sgt. Frederick G. Sherman had a valid driver's license.

title: Q AND A
description: The 10% Subtenant Question: I live in a rent-controlled apartment and recently allowed a student to move in with me on a month-to-month basis and pay me rent. I have agreed to pay my landlord a 10 percent rent increase; now, he tells me I am required to tell him how much my tenant pays me. Is this true? . . . D.K.B., Manhattan Answer: There is no requirement in the rent-control law for you to provide rent information about an additional occupant, says Thomas Viola, assistant commissioner for public information in the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. A Question of Stabilization Question: I've lived in my apartment since 1972. All my leases have followed the rent guidelines for stabilized apartments. My building, which has five units, and the building next door, which has three, and a third building, which has eight, all share a boiler that provides heat and hot water. The new owner says my building is not stabilized because it does not have six or more units and is offering a lease with a 50 percent increase. Could this be? . . . J.T., Manhattan Answer: If the heat and hot water are supplied to all three dwellings Redinger from one source then, based on past housing policy decisions and court cases, you probably reside in a rent-stabilized apartment, according to Mr. Viola. Your case would have to be determined by the state division or by a court should the landlord pursue it there.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

THE FOLKS DOWN UNDER GET THE WORD AT LAST
description: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN and John Sayles have made me proud to be a New Jerseyan again. It was not always thus.

title: GUILTY IN ALABAMA
description: In the 1960's, Spiver Gordon fought to insure that all the citizens of Alabama had the right to vote. Last week, Mr. Gordon, a director of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, was found guilty of abusing that right.

title: STORES' SALE IS BONANZA FOR ALTMAN FOUNDATION
description: At 72, the Altman Foundation has acquired new wealth, a new director and emerging plans to blend its traditional style of giving to local charities and cultural institutions with fresh initiatives to benefit New Yorkers.

title: Large Computer Costs In Welfare Checking
description: I would like to comment on an article entitled ''Audit Outlines Errors in Welfare Payments,'' printed in the Westchester Section of Sept. 29.

title: Miss Reed Wed To Paul Hough
description: Linda Reed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rex R. Reed of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Hallowell Hough, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Hough of Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. William L. Bearden performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Madison.

title: NEW YORK PLANS JOB REQUIREMENT FOR WELFARE AID
description: An estimated 220,000 welfare recipients in New York State will be required to take a job or enter a job-training program beginning next month or have their benefits reduced, state officials said yesterday.

title: CABLE TV
description: The prospect of three vintage movies on this cable this week - old friends - rekindles some treasured images. Take ''The Asphalt Jungle'' (1950), John Huston's brilliant study of a robbery and aftermath, as each thief pays the piper. Who could forget Louis Calhern's final, wry remark to his young mistress, Marilyn Monroe - or his unfinshed letter and brisk suicide? Or Sam Jaffe's prolonged stare at a gyrating girl near a cafe juke box? Or the fadeout - with the wounded Sterling Hayden in a pasture, nuzzled by curious horses. It will be shown Monday at 11 A.M. and 7 P.M. on WHT.

title: Kimberley Morse And Willem Roell Wed in Bay State
description: Kimberley Arland Morse, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Morse of Sarasota, Fla., and Marion, Mass., and Johan Willem Lodewyk Roell, the son of Anna Geertruida Roell Dietz of Zeist, the Netherlands, and the late Baron Jacob Alexander Roell, were married yesterday. The Rev. Charles P. Scott, the chaplain of Middlebury College, and the Rev. Ernest William Cockrell performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel's Episcopal Chapel in Marion.

title: William I. Greenbaum Wed to Elyse Gellman
description: Elyse Robin Gellman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome I. Gellman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last night to William I. Greenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Greenbaum of Albany. Rabbi Maurice Davis officiated at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale.

title: LIVING THE LIFE OF A TUSCAN VILLAGE
description: Gargonza, a tiny walled hamlet in the Tuscan hills between Arezzo and Siena, is moderately famous as the place to which Dante fled in about 1300 in the wake of all the trouble between the Guelphs and the Ghibellines. The traveler contemplating a visit may have visions of a Dante museum, manuscripts of ''The Divine Comedy,'' the cottage he called home - at the very least a lock of the poet's hair.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

PROVIDING FOR CAPE COD'S BIRDS
description: As autumn advances, serious and sometime birders prepare to observe the great annual migration down the East Coast that will carry birds as far as the tip of South America.

title: REAGAN LINKS SUMMIT SUCCESS TO SOVIET ACTIONS
description: President Reagan said today that the success of his meeting next month with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, hinges on Soviet willingness ''to address the real sources of tension in the world.''

title: THE YUPPIES OF YESTERYEAR
description: WE are driving from Manhattan in a rented Chevrolet, on the way to a modest little cabin we have rented in an unpretentious part of the East End. My husband is wearing his favorite polyester plaid slacks, which have a deplorable tendency to slip below his belly even when he is driving, and I am wearing a pair of jeans so old that the fabric at the knees is several shades lighter than the rest of it. I don't think these jeans ever had a label, but if they did, it fell off long ago.

title: KEEPING UP WITH CHANGING TIMES
description: Tightened security has become the focus of concern in the cruise industry following the hijacking earlier this month of the Achille Lauro.

title: THE UNUSUAL, THE INSTRUCTIVE AND THE MYSTERIOUS AT RUTGERS
description: THERE is much to be seen these days at Rutgers' Zimmerli Museum. Some of it is unusual and instructive, and some of it is mysterious. All of it can be seen through Nov. 3.

title: FUND FOR YOUTHS INJURED IN SPORTS
description: TO assure that financially disadvantaged young athletes will receive high-quality medical service, the sports medicine section of the Department of Orthopedic Surgery at the New York Medical College in Valhalla is establishing a fund that will underwrite the cost of health care for young people who are hurt while participating in sports or the arts. It will also support research and educational activities in the field of orthopedic sports medicine at the college.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BACK TO BACH The celebration of the 300th anniversary of Johann Sebastian Bach's birth is definitely not over. This week, for instance, the Long Island Baroque Ensemble plays two concerts dealing with Bach and Sons, and Hofstra University mounts a belated, but still major, three-day conference devoted to J. S. himself. The ensemble's programs will be performed today at 7:30 P.M. at Christ Episcopal Church, on East Main Street in Oyster Bay, and at 8 P.M. Saturday at St. Andrew's Lutheran Church, on Brooksite Drive in Smithtown. For ticket information call 757-0737.

title: THE CONGRESS THAT ROARED
description: At first, the goals were both brave and efficient. This was to be the year of fiscal responsibility in Congress. When it adjourned, on Oct. 15, it would have taken serious action to stop the run of $200 billion budget deficits. More. This would be the Congress that finally reformed a tax code that has become more loophole than law.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: At the Center of Emptiness In this vignette of a young American in a cafe in the medieval town of Autun in central France, James Salter captures the uncanny yet familiar feeling of foreignness. It is from his novel ''A Sport and a Pastime'' (North Point Press).

title: A PROFOUND THOREAU AT WALDEN
description: THE piercing sounds of a solitary flute in a tiny pitch-black theater mark the beginning of ''An Hour at Walden,'' the Victory Theater's latest offering.

title: Robin Sue Lesser Wed to Michael Gershon Resnick
description: Robin Sue Lesser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Lesser of Millwood, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Gershon Resnick, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel J. Resnick of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Melvin Sirner performed the ceremony at the Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: 2 Economists Assess Philadelphia Outlook
description: Two economists at the University of Pennsylvania say the Philadelphia area is on a brighter course after weathering economic storms.

title: Hagler-Hearns II
description: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter, said that he had made plans for a rematch between the middleweight champion, Marvelous Marvin Hagler, and Thomas Hearns if both fighters win scheduled bouts on Nov. 14. He said the bout would take place at Caesars Palace in April 1986, a year after Hagler knocked out Hearns in the third round of their first bout.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SOUL OF THE NIGHT: An Astronomical Pilgrimage. By Chet Raymo. (Prentice-Hall, $15.95.) People have long found answers to big questions in the night sky, whether by attributing divine properties to celestial bodies, discerning mythical figures in the stars or observing the structure of the universe and extrapolating to its past and future.

title: Monetary Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Banker Is Wed To Miss Bostwick
description: Catherine Kent Bostwick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bostwick Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Harrison Maireaux Wilson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry H. Wilson Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: BAKER HAS THE REINS AND IS PULLING
description: There are two views of James A. Baker 3d's apparent dominance over economic policy in the Reagan Administration. One is that he has captured control and that it is his for the duration. The other is that the White House and the other members of the Cabinet are letting the Treasury Secretary go it alone, an isolated target to be abandoned if his policies go awry.

title: JERSEY'S BID TO LIMIT OCEAN DUMPING GETS UNEXPECTED AID
description: A Massachusetts Congressman said this week that he was cosponsoring legislation that would block Boston from dumping sludge in the Atlantic Ocean off New Jersey because New Jersey is where the chairman of the House committee on public works lives.

title: The Most Wanted
description: BORROWING a tactic from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the New York City police began in March to publish lists and to post photos of its 100 most-wanted fugitives. A modest bounty of $100 apiece was offered for information leading to their capture.

title: BRUNSWICK ADVANCES
description: With a berth to the Fairchester League championship at stake, the ground games of Brunswick and Fieldston clashed head-on yesterday, each dragging a string of consecutive victories into battle behind them. But in a reversal of the expected, Brunswick surprised Fieldston with a powerful aerial attack and soared to a 30-12 victory, extending their own unbeaten streak to 22 games.

title: RESORT RAIL LINNE: PLANS GAIN
description: THE PACE of negotiations leading to possible restoration of passenger railroad service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City quickened last week after two politically significant barriers were apparently removed.

title: UNLIKELY CLEANUP HITTER
description: ASK a baseball manager to define his most important daily duty and invariably he will answer, ''Filling out the lineup card.'' Which not only means determining who will play but also where each player will hit in the batting order. And when Dick Howser sat down at his desk last night to fill out the Royals' lineup card for the World Series opener against the Cardinals, the manager chose a cleanup hitter who knew he didn't quite fit the mold.

title: MISS LIBERTY CREW GREETED BELATEDLY
description: FOR Grace Spinelli, a recent New York Times article reporting that American workers had not welcomed the 10-member team of French metalworkers recreating the Statue of Liberty's flame and torch of by inviting them to their homes was a clarion call for action.

title: N.A.A.C.P. to Boycott In U.S. on South Africa
description: The executive director for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Benjamin L. Hooks, said yesterday that a national boycott would be held in early 1986 against one to four American companies doing business in South Africa.

title: Miss Wright Wed To John W. Davis
description: Jo-Ann Wright, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Wright of Holyoke, Mass., was married yesterday to John Wagner Davis, a son of Mrs. Ralph A. Steiger of Wilbraham, Mass., and Dr. William Mabon Davis of Suffield, Conn. Msgr. Robert E. Foudy performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Cathedral in Springfield, Mass.

title: ARMY PLANNING TV DRIVE FOR QUALITY RECRUITS
description: The Army, concerned that a 26 percent nationwide dropout rate in high schools will make it more difficult to keep a quality force, has enlisted celebrities in a televised drive to keep students in school.

title: CASTER RETURNS TO FOOTBALL, AS A TEACHER
description: WHEN Richard Caster comes out of a huddle these days, it may be after explaining a pass pattern to one teen-ager or advising another about private school attendance.

title: COACHES STAY CLOSD TO HOME
description: Allan Liebowitz still remembers how his involvement in high school football at New Utrecht began in 1956.

title: AGENCY AIDING VETERANS STILL HAUNTED BY DAYS IN VIETNAM
description: THEY were buddies in basic training who were reunited in the jungles of Vietnam. In an ambush, a bullet struck one of the men, killing him. Now, more than 10 years later back home on Long Island, the memories of that incident remain vivid and haunting.

title: THE FACE OF AMERICA
description: For the last 16 years the face of Marianne, a symbol of the French Republic and fixture in every town hall, has been that of Brigitte Bardot. This month, however, Miss Bardot's luscious pout will be traded in for Catherine Deneuve's serene stare -as soon as the French decide which of the 24 statuettes of her now on view in a Paris subway station best evokes la patrie.

title: ISRAELI DANCERS AT HOME IN THE COUNTY
description: ON a recent Friday afternoon the Larchmont Temple was humming with more than usual pre-Sabbath activity. In the auditorium, the Kibbutz Dance Company, which had arrived in the county the day before, was going through its rigorous rehearsal paces. Next to the auditorium, a number of women in the congregation were setting out dishes and arranging chrysanthemum centerpieces for the Sabbath dinner that the dancers and the families that were their hosts would attend that evening.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

EXTRA EFFORT
description: At the State University of New York at Purchase, a new program is providing a structured tutorial experience for students who need academic help. The Student Supplemental Instruction Program, financed by the Xerox Corporation, brings in ''supplementary instructors'' to courses in which the failure rates have been high.

title: PRESIDENT SENDS CONCILIATORY NOTE TO ITALIAN LEADER
description: President Reagan sent a conciliatory letter to Prime Minister Bettino Craxi today, marking a significant improvement in relations between Italy and the United States.

title: Kathleen Delany Marries
description: Kathleen Delany, a daughter of Violet Delaney of Syracuse and the late Lewis Delany, was married in New York yesterday to Christopher David Foley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Foley of Demarest, N.J. The Rev. John Cleremont performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The bride and bridegroom are alumni of the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: No Sousa in the Suitcase
description: The trade crisis has finally struck home for one Washingtonian, who wanted to give some fundamentally American music to a friend who was departing for Yugoslavia.

title: ARMY SAID TO SKIRT DUMPING SAFEGUARDS
description: A COALITION of environmentalists, fishermen and civic groups has charged that the Army Corps of Engineers lets barges dump contaminated dredge spoils from New York Harbor into the Atlantic without using prescribed ecological safeguards.

title: SAVING HOMES FROM LIGHTNING
description: LIGHTNING is one of nature's most violent, frightening and destructive forces. A bolt of lightning can generate millions of watts.

title: Business in Short
description: GAME PLANS: Sports Strategies for Business. By Robert W. Keidel. (Dutton, $16.95.) Written by a senior fellow at the Wharton Applied Research Center of the University of Pennsylvania, this book raises one overriding question: Is the author serious? Robert W. Keidel clearly had fun dreaming up the schemes he outlines - schemes designed to show how the organizational structures of professional sports teams can be applied to help businesses improve their operations.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

TEACHING THE ART OF WRITING
description: IN Barrington, Ill., a neat, proud suburb of Chicago, students in kindergarten through the 12th grade are writing almost, if not always, daily. And they're sharing what they write. Their teachers are writing, too (and sharing).

title: Knowing Hob Broun
description: To the Editor:

title: U.A.W. RAISES MONEY GOALS IN STRIKE AT CHRYSLER
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers confirmed today that they have increased their monetary goals in contract talks at the Chrysler Corporation where they have been on strike since Wednesday.

title: CORPOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN A LAW FIRM FEELS OBLIGED TO 'FIRE' A CLIENT
description: To the Editor:

title: ORSON WELLES BEGAN AN ONGOING REVOLUTION
