description: Orson Welles, 70, the greatest, most influential American film maker of his generation, died just 10 days ago, but already it's apparent that it won't be easy to get a fixed image of the man, especially from his own words as preserved in the clippings of the reference library of this large metropolitan newspaper.

title: WITH TOLLS GONE, A CRACKDOWN ON SPEEDERS
description: AS work crews start building temporary bypasses this week around the shuttered tollbooths of the Connecticut Turnpike, the state police plan to continue their crackdown on speeding motorists, and state officials hope to firm up plans for five banks to buy unused tokens.

title: MIAMI BEATS SOONERS, 27-14
description: Vinny Testaverde passed for two touchdowns and ran for a third, and the tackle Jerome Brown demolished Oklahoma's wishbone offense with three decisive plays in the second quarter as Miami beat the Sooners, 27-14, today.

title: No Big Deal
description: Women may not need us as they once did, but we will not be entirely dispensable as long as there are heavy objects to be lifted.

title: CONCERT: THE DETROIT SYMPHONY
description: THE Detroit Symphony and its thoughtful new music director, Gunther Herbig, now beginning his second season at the helm, returned to Carnegie Hall Friday night for a concert that sustained their reputations admirably even if it did not brand itself on the memory as a special evening.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;

WHY BUSINESS HAS SO FEW LEADERS
description: WITH almost daily reports about terrorism in the Middle East, nuclear proliferation and economic protectionism, it is easy to see the crisis of political leadership in the world today. Much less appreciated is the leadership crisis that is closer to most of us and affects almost all of us directly and daily - the leadership crisis in the workplace.

title: NEW YORK AND ISRAEL SHARE JOB-TRAINING PROGRAM
description: A program sponsored by New York State and Israel is being developed to create educational and job opportunities for underprivileged youths in both countries.

title: Completion Mark Broken
description: Brian McClure of Bowling Green broke the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I career record for pass completions today as he brought his total to 825.

title: ROAD PLAN ANGERS RESIDENTS
description: A PLAN by Suffolk County to straighten and widen a road in the Town of Smithtown to ease traffic problems is raising concern among local residents who fear that their property will be confiscated.

title: Recent Sales
description: Avenel $80,000 *2* 482 Jansen Avenue *2* 4 bedroom, 1 bath, 30-year-old *2* Cape Cod; eat-in-kitchen, *2* 2-car garage; taxes $1,476. Butler $121,500 *2* 12 Bellview Terrace *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 27-year-old *2* Cape Cod; family room, aluminum siding, *2* 2-car garage; taxes $1,926. Fanwood $126,000 *2* 196 Second Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 48-year-old *2* colonial; wall-to-wall carpeting, *2* attic fan, bay window; taxes $2,146. Lincroft $216,450 *2* 73 Lehigh Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new Tudor; *2* central air-conditioning, deck, full basement, *2* 2-zone heat; taxes to be assessed. Long Valley $145,000 *2* 70 West Valley Brook Road *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2* mini-horse farm, 4-stall barn, riding ring, *2* small vineyard; taxes $1,822. Trenton $44,000 *2* 511 Home Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old duplex; *2* slate roof, aluminum siding, formal dining room; *2* taxes $962. OTHER AREAS Rye, N.Y. $187,000 *2* 11 Adelaide Street *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 16-year-old frame *2* ranch; eat-in kitchen, patio, full attic; *2* taxes $2,767. Richfield, Conn. $225,000 *2* 544 Ridgebury Road *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2* central courtyard, opposite golf course, *2* 3/4 acre; taxes $2,531. Mount Sinai, L.I. $235,000 *2* 12 Birch Hill Road *2* 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 12-year-old farm ranch; *2* dining room, family room with fireplace, *2* basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,800.

title: Miss Ufford Has Wedding
description: Eleanor Morris Ufford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Ufford Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and South Bristol, Me., was married yesterday to Albert Leger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Leger of Caraquet, New Brunswick. The Rev. Thomas Powers, Roman Catholic chaplain of Harvard College, from which the couple graduated, participated in the Quaker ceremony at the Stony Brook Friends Meeting House in Princeton.

title: ILLITERACY RESISTS TREATMENT IN BRAZIL
description: In 1970, with an economic ''miracle'' feeding national pride, Brazil's military regime decided to turn its attention to a glaring example of the country's continued backwardness: illiteracy, it proclaimed, would be eliminated within a decade.

title: Business in Short
description: THE NAKED MANAGER: Games Executives Play. By Robert Heller. (Truman Talley/Dutton, $22.50.) Management books are selling, a fact that seems at least mildly surprising to Robert Heller, a British financial journalist.

title: CRASH OF CONTINENTS TO BLAME?
description: The earthquake and foreshock that hit the New York area yesterday originated about two miles west of Cameron's Line, which marks an abrupt change in the earth's crust that resulted from a collision between North America and a European-African land mass 400 million years ago.

title: GETTING INTO THE HEART OF ITALY
description: Why go to Italy? There are, of course, all kinds of specialized motives: if one happens to be interested in the physical remains of the once overarching world authority of ancient Rome, for instance, or if, tired of taking in the great Renaissance painters through reproductions, one wants a really rich exposure to the originals; but most people who go there would answer the question as I would, with a simple, ''Just to be there, of course.''

title: Business in Short
description: THE WINNING PERFORMANCE: How America's High-Growth Midsize Companies Succeed. By Donald K. Clifford Jr. and Richard E. Cavanagh. (Bantam, $19.95.) Attempting to repeat the success of ''In Search of Excellence,'' the best seller that profiled large, successful United States companies, ''The Winning Performance'' tries to do the same for midsize companies, which Donald K. Clifford Jr. and Richard E. Cavanagh, both management consultants, describe as those with annual revenues of between $25 million and $1 billion.

title:
GARDENING;

PREPARING PLANTS TO SURVIVE THE WINTER
description: WHEN October's bright, crisp days beckon us outdoors, what better way to spend an afternoon than to look after one's garden chores.

title: FOR L.I., SURGE OF FOREIGN PUPILS
description: IN a corner room at Public School 4 in Inwood, 22 kindergarteners - half of whom primarily spoke Spanish and half of whom knew only English - recently drew pictures showing how they had spent their summer vacations. With much prodding, they also described their illustrations in words.

title: MARCOS BALKS AT U.S. PRODDING
description: The Reagan Administration, concerned about the strategic position of the United States in the Far East, has been watching the deteriorating political and economic situation in the Philippines with increasing worry. Last week President Reagan sent an old friend, Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, to prod President Ferdinand E. Marcos into action, but there was some question whether it did much good.

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;

Business in Short
description: BAD BUSINESS: The OPM Scandal and the Seduction of the Establishment. By Robert P. Gandossy. (Basic, $17.95.) In 1970, at age 23, Mordecai Weissman founded OPM Leasing Services Inc., and Myron Goodman, his boyhood friend from Brooklyn, soon joined the enterprise.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PRICE OF THE TICKET: Collected Nonfiction 1948-1985. By James Baldwin. (Marek/St. Martin's, $29.95.) James Baldwin's essays on race in America are enlightening, entertaining and, because of his remarkable prescience, a bit eerie.

title: POLICE REPORT 2 SUSPECTS IN BLAZE THAT CLOSED DOWN GRAND CENTRAL
description: Nearly two months after a fire at Grand Central Terminal caused a major disruption in commuter service and traffic jams investigators said the search had narrowed to ''a couple of suspects.'' No arrests have been made.

title: 'THE LAST PLACE ON EARTH' - NOT JUST ABOUT THE ANTARCTIC
description: Fifteen years ago this coming January, television launched one of its programming milestones.

title: SHORT SUBJECTS
description: THE STORY OF THE LOST REFLECTION The Alienation of the Image in Western and Polish Cinema. By Paul Coates. 167 pp. Verso/Schocken Books. Cloth, $25. Paper, $9.95. DESCRIBING ''The Story of the Lost Reflection'' as a collection of unrelated essays would be misleading - though things do occasionally jell to good effect, the book is more a collection of unrelated paragraphs. Paul Coates displays a wide acquaintance with European culture, and one is pleased to find apposite references to Holderlin and Schiller in a film book. He also knows a lot about movies.

title: IMMIGRATION HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH BRITAIN'S TROUBLES
description: To the Editor:

title: KICK BY IOWA STOPS MICHIGAN
description: The ball was in the air. Then the kicker was in the air. Then the ball passed between the goalposts, and time ran out, and Iowa had beaten Michigan, 12-10. Suddenly, Rob Houghtlin found himself on the bottom of a rapidly expanding swarm of black and gold that swallowed the goalpost that helped make him famous.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:We are retired and plan a winter vacation in the National Park in St. John, the United States Virgin Islands. Will the concessionaires of the campgrounds honor our Golden Age Passport, issued by the National Park Service, which provides 50 percent discounts on camping fees? - G. L., Oakdale, N.Y. Answer:The two campgrounds within the park on St. John, Cinnamon Bay and Maho Bay Camps, are under no obligation to honor the Golden Age Passport, which is issued by the Park Service and the Forest Service to citizens age 62 and over. Holders of the pass are given discounts on fees for camping and use of boat facilities operated by the two services. The Cinnamon Bay site is on National Park Service land but it is managed by RockResorts, the hotel corporation founded by the Rockefeller family. Maho Bay is on private land within the park, is owned by a private company and has no legal relationship with the Park Service. (Cinnamon Bay offers tent cottages, tents and tent sites: Maho has tent cottages.) According to Duncan Morrow, an official of the Park Service, a few campgrounds in national parks within the 48 states have been turned over to private concessionaires on condition that they honor the Golden Age Passport. However, private operators that had been running campgrounds for many years - including RockResorts at Cinnamon Bay - were not required to recognize the pass, he said.

title: TEXAS KICKS UPSET ARKANSAS
description: Jeff Ward made a school-record five field goals as his counterpart, Greg Horne, missed three to give Texas a 15-13 upset of Arkansas in a Southwest Conference game today. The safety John Hagy preserved the victory when he intercepted Mark Calcagni's pass at the Texas 22-yard line with only seconds remaining.

title: A NOBEL ECONCOMIST LOOKS BACK
description: Franco Modigliani, the M.I.T. professor who was awarded the 1985 Nobel Memorial Prize in Econommic Science, started to become a doctor but couldn't stand the sight of blood. A winnng entry in an Italian essay contest put him on the road to law and economics, and he wound up under the tutelage of Jacob Marschak at the New School for Social Research in New York, where he got his first training in macroeconomics and developed many of his neo-Keynesian views.

title: RUN, RUN, RUN, RUN, STOP: ENJOY LIFE
description: SOME weeks ago, instead of going to the office, I found it necessary to remain at home to attend to some personal matters. These responsibilities required numerous telephone calls. Within a half-hour I spoke with five individuals but none of the conversations was completed. One business discussion was interrupted because the other party received an overseas call and he breathlessly informed me he had been trying to make contact with the other individual for some days.

title: MUSEUMS DESIGNED FOR TIGHT QUARTERS
description: The conventional image of the museum is of a great, sprawling building, freestanding, perhaps in a park or some kind of garden setting. It became so in the early decades of this century, when such Beaux-Arts museums as the Metropolitan and the Art Institute of Chicago established the impression of the museum as a monumental civic structure. But this kind of museum has remained the rule in our own time, with such major museums as Edward Larrabee Barnes's Dallas Museum of Art and Richard Meier's High Museum of Art in Atlanta, which are relatively low, free-standing structures with grand civic scale.

title: TENNESSEE INTERCEPTS ALABAMA
description: Carlos Reveiz made three field goals and Dale Jones had a crucial interception after the quarterback Tony Robinson was sidelined by a knee injury as Tennessee edged Alabama, 16-14, in a Southeastern Conference game today. It was the fourth consecutive loss by Alabama (4-2 over all and 2-1 in the S.E.C.) to Tennessee (3-1-1 and 2-1).

title: A PLACE LIKE NO OTHER
description: JERUSALEM The Holy City in the Eyes of Chroniclers, Visitors, Pilgrims, and Prophets From the Days of Abraham to the Beginnings of Modern Times. By F. E. Peters. Illustrated. 640 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $35.

title: Liburd Is Ill
description: Because of the discovery of a rare medical condition, Robert Liburd, the 7-foot-2-inch former DeWitt Clinton High School star who had been one of Temple's top basketball recruits this year, will not play, according to his coach, John Chaney. Tests at Temple University Hospital showed that Liburd, who was born in Trinidad, suffers from Marfan syndrome, a connective tissue disorder that affects the heart valves and blood vessels. Gavin White Jr., the Temple athletic director, said that Liburd would retain his full athletic scholarship.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The writer of the Players column in yesterday's Sports Pages was incorrectly identified. He was Gerald Eskenazi.

title: SCENIC-ROAD AWARDS: 'A BEGINNING'
description: WHEN the Department of Environmental Conservation recently handed out its first Scenic Roads Awards, Bear Mountain Bridge Road in Cortlandt was singled out for its scenic beauty, but nearby Inspiration Point in Peekskill was never mentioned. While the Tappan Zee Bridge, Bear Mountain Bridge and an eight-mile stretch of Route 9D in the town of Philipstown were named as part of the state's 79 miles of ''scenic roads'' in the Hudson Valley, the roads nominated for that honor in the village of Cold Spring never made the list.

title: CBS FINDS AN ALLY
description: Another self-made man on the Forbes list is Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of the Loews Corporation. Last week CBS offered Mr. Tisch a seat on its board of directors and he has agreed to increase Loews' stock holdings in CBS from 11.3 percent to as much as 25 percent.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Oct. 20, 1985 Fiction

title: Evelyn Lifsey to Wed
description: Evelyn Perri Lifsey and Richard Ira Male plan to be married Nov. 23, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy A. Lifsey of Philadelphia, have announced. Mr. Male is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Male of Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: DUBBING DECKS: PRO AND CON
description: They've been called burglars' tools - abominable instruments of electronic larceny. But larceny has always held a broad appeal for some people, especially if unpunished or unpunishable. So it is hardly surprising that so-called dubbing decks are currently among the hottest items in audio.

title: Maine Will Not Appeal Ruling in Sears Case
description: Maine has ended its 19-month-old court fight with Sears, Roebuck & Company, with the state Attorney General saying he will not appeal an Aug. 29 ruling dismissing virtually all allegations that the company had violated consumer-protection laws.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN TELEPHONES
description: TELEPHONES shaped like milk cartons, footballs, and gumball machines. Telephones with two lines. Memories to program frequently used numbers. Buttons to switch from touchtone to pulse systems.

title: HARVARD WIDENS INQUIRY IN C.I.A. AID TO PROFESSOR
description: Officials of Harvard University have decided to broaden their inquiry into $150,000 in grants that the Central Intelligence Agency made to a Harvard professor of Middle Eastern studies.

title: Going On in the Northeast;   PHILADELPHIA HOUSE TOUR
description: Twenty buildings, mostly old homes that are unusually decorated or well restored, will be on view today from 1 to 5 P.M. in the 27th annual Philadelphia Center City Residents House Tour.

title: HANOI ASKS TO END AMERASIANS' ISSUE
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, Oct. 17 -

title: PROSPECTS
description: Auto Incentives: Part II?

title: HUMBERT HUMBERT-SAN
description: NAOMI By Junichiro Tanizaki. Translated by Anthony H. Chambers. 237 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: FRANCE'S NEW PHONE SYSTEM, SKIING IN AUSTRIA
description: Eight Digits (Two Areas) For the French It is not, to be sure, an undertaking on the order of the A.T.&T. breakup. But for some 54 million French citizens - and those elsewhere in the world who are trying to call them - the changes that will take place at 11 P.M. Oct. 25 are drastic enough: The entire telephone dialing system of France will be altered by the P.T.T. (French Post and Telephone).

title: TUSCANY'S TIMELESS LANDSCAPE
description: Imagine first a rose-colored city, sitting atop a small mountain. It is circular and bounded by a crenelated wall. Bunched within its confines are a multitude of palaces, fortresses, churches and towers. Each one has its own decoration of arched windows, tiled roofs, mosaiced walls, buttresses, domes, verandas and pillars. It is a child's picture of fairyland, an unforgettable image of order and design.

title: MODERN MANNERS
description: 'Table manners are part of the social structure of relationships and social forms, and they require us to accept the collectivity of the society.

title: WHY THE FUTURE NEVER HAPPENED
description: SOCIALISM AND AMERICA By Irving Howe. 225 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: HALFBACK LEADS BRONXVILLE
description: The halfback Jeff Shieh ran for 82 yards and two touchdowns to lead undefeated Bronxville to an 18-6 victory over division rival Tuckahoe yesterday. The defeat was the Tigers' first of the season and leaves Bronxville tied with Dobbs Ferry for first place in the division.

title: READING THEIR WAY TO THE TOP -- BOOKS THAT MADE A DIFFERENCE
description: Books offering all manner of inspiration for success in business have been proliferating during the last few years. To discover which books actually have helped to shape the careers of successful businessmen and women, Sandra Salmans, a reporter for the Business Day section of The New York Times, asked a dozen leaders in various fields which book most influenced their careers.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;

UNION CITY
description: FROM its first substantial settlement by Germans who moved from Manhattan in search of space to its latest wave of new residents - Cubans who fled Fidel Castro in search of political freedom - Union City has been a place to begin anew, prosper and move on to more affluent communities.

title: DETAILS AT ISSUE IN CHRYSLER STRIKE
description: More than 70,000 workers in the United States and 10,000 in Canada walked off their jobs last week in the first nationwide strike by the United Automobile Workers against the Chrysler Corporation since 1973. Talks broke off for the weekend as Owen F. Bieber, president of the union, headed for Huntsville, Ala., and a meeting yesterday of the U.A.W.'s Chrysler Council, previously scheduled in anticipation of a settlement. The message Mr. Bieber was taking the 170 local union officials was that both sides were ''still far apart.''

title: WHEN SECRETS ARE PASSED TO THE PRESS
description: In his quiet gray suit, with his professorial air and patrician background, Samuel Loring Morison seemed an unlikely defendant in an espionage trial as he sat in Federal district court in Baltimore over the last two weeks.

title: MARVELS AND NASTY SURPRISES
description: THE STORIES OF MURIEL SPARK By Muriel Spark. 314 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: REVERSING REAGANOMICS
description: THE ZERO-SUM SOLUTION Building a World-Class American Economy. By Lester C. Thurow. 416 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: AMERICANS FOUND 'MOST EDUCATED IN WORLD'
description: Significant advances in schooling since 1940 ''have made the American people the most educated in the world,'' a Census Bureau study said, but the study concluded that the quality of United States schools sagged in the 1970's.

title: THE CASE OF F.D.R.'S HEALTH
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt's death on April 12, 1945, just five months after he was elected to a fourth term, was attributed to a cerebral hemorrhage. No autopsy was performed, however, and the question of the President's physical condition before he decided to make his last race has never been laid to rest.

title: Janet Keyes, Broker, Wed
description: St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Philadelphia, was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Janet Bayard Keyes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fenton Keyes of Philadelphia, to John Ryan O'Connell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. O'Connell of Center Valley, Pa., and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Ralph W. Pitman Jr. performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Daniel G. Gambet, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CBS INVITES LOEWS INTO A NEW ALLIANCE
description: CBS may be taking a calculated risk in inviting Loews to buy up to 25 percent of its stock and giving a board seat to Laurence A. Tisch, Loews's chairman. Most analysts say the move is a smart one in that it concentrates a big block of stock in friendly hands, puts a savvy investor on the board, and thus discourages any raids such as the one by Ted Turner. But the deal does not prevent Mr. Tisch from trying a takeover of his own. Mr. Tisch, who built Loews into a multibillion-dollar company, is not saying why he agreed to the alliance. But his friends say he will bring a critical eye to the company, and will probably work well with Thomas H. Wyman, CBS's chairman.

title: 10 FOR SALE
description: With New York University occupying much of the property surrounding Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village, the opportunity for home ownership on the streets off the square - particularly to the south and east - has been limited.

title: MOGAMBO CAPTURES THE CHAMPAGNE STAKES BY 9 3/4 LENGTHS
description: Mogambo, entered in the Champagne Stakes for 2-year-olds only after Ogygian was declared out of the race earlier this week, posted an overwhelming 9 3/4-length victory yesterday at Belmont Park as heavily favored Ketoh faded to finish fourth.

title: A STREET PAVED WITH GLITTER
description: The Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore, its luster enhanced by a half-dozen new boutiques, has raised the curtain on the fall and winter season of one of the world's most celebrated luxury shopping streets.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GLASS MOUNTAIN. By S. L. Sparling. (Doubleday, $15.95.) This first novel by the Canadian writer S. L. Sparling is a psychological mystery story.

title: Barry J. Glickman Married To Jill Ellen Blumencranz
description: Jill Ellen Blumencranz, a lawyer for Time Equities Inc., a real-estate company in New York, and Barry J. Glickman, an associate with the New York law firm of Levy, Bivona & Cohen, were married yesterday at the Regency Hotel in New York. Rabbi Bernard Cohn officiated.

title: CAPE TOWN MOSLEMS ARE URGED TO FIGHT APARTHEID
description: About 10,000 South African Moslems, some of them holding banners calling for a holy war against apartheid, gathered here today to bury a fellow Moslem shot dead by the police on Thursday.

title: CALIFORNIA IS STEPPING UP ITS EARTHQUAKE PRECAUTIONS
description: Like a pincushion, the earth's crust near this rural central California town is punctured by scientific probes that measure the constant geological turbulence beneath Hollister as opposite sides of the San Andreas Fault crash and rub against one another.

title: 'NUPTIAL BIRDSEED' IN PLACE OF UNCOOKED RICE
description: THE expression, ''You eat like a bird,'' has taken on new meaning for a legislator's family - possibly a lethal one if the food is rice.

title: WHAT'S LOST IN THE BIG PICTURE
description: RELIVING THE PAST The Worlds of Social History. Edited by Olivier Zunz. 334 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $29. Paper, $9.95. IN 1973, Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie, exhilarated by the accomplishments of social history, proclaimed that ''tomorrow's historian will program computers or will cease to exist.'' It is reassuring to find, on reading ''Reliving the Past: The Worlds of Social History,'' that he was wrong.

title: SHOPPING AT MALLS IS FOR MASOCHISTS
description: ''PRICE CHECK, hardware.

title: ISLANDERS EDGE RANGERS, 5-4
description: The rivalry began again with all the energy of the past, with breakaways and flashy goaltending. And the night ended suddenly. Pat Lafontaine's shot with 24 seconds to play caromed off the blade of the stick of the Ranger defenseman James Patrick and between the legs of the goalie Terry Kleisinger to undo a tie and give the Islanders a 5-4 triumph.

title: ANTIOCH IN THREAT TO SHUT CAPITAL LAW SCHOOL
description: The Antioch Law School, an innovative institution designed to be a socially conscious alternative to traditional schools, has been given 60 days to raise at least $2.5 million or be ''phased out'' by Antioch University, the university's president said today.

title: FLASH AND THE DEVIL
description: DELOREAN By John Z. DeLorean with Ted Schwarz. Illustrated. 349 pp. Grand Rapids, Mich.: Zondervan Books. $17.95. HARD DRIVING My Years With John DeLorean. By William Haddad. 193 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: PLAN FORMED TO AID NORTHEAST TOWNS
description: OFFICIALS in northeast Connecticut said they were pleased by last week's announcement of a $2.1 million economic revitalization program for their corner of the state.

title: CARDINALS WIN, 3-1, IN WORLD SERIES OPENER
description: The three-game winning streak that catapulted the Kansas City Royals into the World Series ended abruptly tonight as the team from 250 miles across the state showed them why it was considered the favorite in the all-Missouri matchup.

title: Greece Freezes Wages In the Private Sector
description: Greece's Socialist Government announced today that it was freezing the wages of all private-sector workers for two years as part of an austerity program.

title: FLOUNDER FISHERMEN PROTEST RULE
description: COMMERCIAL fishermen say that New Jersey's flounder industry, which employs hundreds and brings in millions of dollars, may be wiped out if the state's Department of Environmental Protection continues to enforce a new regulation prohibiting catching or possessing any flounder or fluke (flatfish) under 14 inches long.

title: NEW GENERATION OF POOR YOUTHS EMERGES IN U.S.
description: Complex social, economic and political factors are creating a vast new class of poor Americans who are much younger, less educated and likely to give birth sooner than recent generations of the poor.

title: FOR HERZOG, IT WAS A MANAGER'S DREAM
description: When the Kansas City Royals tried a suicide squeeze in the second inning, Buddy Biancalana missed the bunt and the man on third base was trapped and run down by four Cardinals: the catcher, the third baseman, the pitcher and the shortstop.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

PARK, NOT PARKING
description: ONCE Mount Kisco Village officials had hoped to turn it into a parking lot. Now, it seems, they will turn the 1.25 acres of land once owned by Laura Flewellyn into a park instead.

title: THE ABSENT HERO WHO SPURS MCNEIL
description: FREEMAN McNEIL never played for his father. And that has been his spur as he continues on a rushing-and-receiving pace that could make him the National Football League's leading yardage-gainer from scrimmage in one season.

title:
ART;

AN UNUSUAL WORLD OF EDIFICES AT THE NEUBERGER MUSEUM
description: A PORTION of the Neuberger Museum on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase is appropriately darkened for ''Night Stops,'' an installation of eight building-like constructions that Donna Dennis has made over the last decade.

title: INFORMATION LACK CITED IN BOMBING
description: Approaching the Baltimore Tunnel on his way home after a weekend visit with his parents in Virginia, the city's Managing Director, Leo A. Brooks, heard a radio news report: The police were evacuating a middle-class neighborhood in Philadelphia.

title: Anne Rothwell Is Wed To John A. Forlines 3d
description: Anne Megan Rothwell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Rothwell of Glen Ridge, N.J., New Orleans and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and John A. Forlines 3d, the son of Mr. Forlines Jr. of Granite Falls, N.C., and the late Julia Dunn Forlines, were married yesterday. The Rev. Kenneth Swanson performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

NEW YORK SALE OF KOSOFF COINS
description: Ordinarily, a coin dealer's leftover stock would not provide the makings for a million-dollar auction.

title: THE SAD TALE OF PHONE STORES
description: IT seemed such a promising business just two years ago: setting up a store that sells only telephones. But with department stores, electronics stores, convenience stores and catalogues all offering phones these days, the mortality rate of telephone-only stores is soaring. And the survivors are scrambling to find new revenue sources.

title: Navy Officer Engaged To Hilary B. Famolare
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Famolare Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Hilary Burnham Famolare to Lieut. Comdr. David Kirk Meier, U.S.N., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Meier of Baltimore.

title: Diane C. Linen Is Wed To Kirk Lucas in Rye
description: Diane Carola Linen, a daughter of Camille Linen of Port Chester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kirk Stephen Lucas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Lucas of Clearwater, Fla., formerly of Hartford. The Rev. Roger Nicholson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: NEBRASKA WINS: 7 FIELD GOALS TIE N.C.A.A. MARK
description: Dale Klein, demoted to second team just two weeks ago, tied a National Collegiate Athletic Association record with seven field goals to allow Nebraska escape with a 28-20 triumph today over Missouri in the Big Eight Conference game.

title: IN THE SPIRIT OF '68
description: FOOTSTEPS Adventures of a Romantic Biographer. By Richard Holmes. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/ Viking. $18.95.

title: COURT TAMPERING DISCUSSED ON TAPE
description: A New York State Senate committee says it has obtained tape recordings of conversations in 1982 in which lawyers and a private investigator discussed payments to court officers and clerks, the doctoring of court records and other irregularities committed to help win civil cases in city courts.

title: FRENCH NOVELIST WINS A NOBEL
description: ONE rrItalian-born professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, two molecular geneticists, three other scientists and a novelist in the experimental tradition learned last week that they were winners of the Nobel Prize.

title: Arthur Charrington 3d Wed to Ardis Borden
description: Ardis Constable Borden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Wilson Borden Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday to Arthur M. R. Charrington 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. M. Randolph Charrington Jr.. The Revs. Rudolph Moore and Richard W. Hess performed the ceremony at the chapel of Old St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: SEEING SHELTER ISLAND WITH CALIFORNIA EYES
description: CROSSING on the ferry from Greenport to Shelter Island recently, I glanced at the familiar coastline and beaches and studied the faces of my children. This was their first visit to Shelter Island, a spot beloved to me for 30 years.

title: A MOVIE GIANT'S UNFINISHED SCRIPT
description: IT was a glamorous show business evening. Burt Reynolds was there. So were Frank Sinatra, Elizabeth Taylor and Charlton Heston. The guest of honor was Nancy Reagan, but the host and undisputed master of the event was a slender, white-haired, austere man whose invitations few people in Hollywood ever refuse: Lew R. Wasserman.

title: STORIES CONFLICT IN PHILADELPHIA
description: On May 13, after the Philadelphia police dropped a bomb on a house where members of the radical group Move lived, an entire neighborhood burned down. This much city officials can agree on. But beyond that, an investigative panel found out last week, the accounts of the disaster -and the opinions on whom to blame for it - conflict.

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;

Business in Short
description: THE MARKETING EDGE: Making Strategies Work. By Thomas V. Bonoma. (Free Press, $20.95.) Thomas V. Bonoma, who teaches at the Harvard Business School, confesses that he is offering '' 'driver education' for marketers and general managers,'' and he sets out to give managers some practical tips on how they can ''effectively translate strategies into market place results.''

title: Some Children Are Superior
description: In the matter of classes for gifted children, several of the responding letters [Opinion Page, Sept. 22] seem hostile to the very idea of intellectual superiority. Sylvia Zucker actually conceives of genius as mere possession of good memory and the ability to read quickly through textbooks.

title: SCULTPUTRAL EULOGY FOR A LAKE
description: OLD-TIMERS here remember when they could swim in Lake Surprise, a narrow, mile-long lake that parallels the northeast edge of the Watchung Reservation.

title: COACH OF CHINESE DISCOVERS BASKETBALL TRANSLATES EASILY
description: HOW does an American basketball coach communicate with a group of Chinese players, when the American speaks no Chinese and the Chinese speak no English?

title: PIANO: YIN CHENG-ZONG
description: YIN CHENG-ZONG, who offered a recital of music by Galuppi, Schubert, Schumann and Liszt at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, puts a smooth legato and singing tone at the top of his priorities; one rarely hears the piano played so lovingly, expressively and with such a sensitivity to the sheer physical beauty of its sound.

title: ELMONT GAINS SHUTOUT
description: In Nassau County, the Elmont Spartans, whose defense has allowed a mere 15 points this season, have proven themselves the cream of Conference III's crop.

title: Tigger Montague Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Cresap Montague, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Giles Montague Jr. of Granville, Ohio, was married yesterday to John J. Parziale, a son of Mrs. Charles Parziale and the late Colonel Parziale, U.S.A., of Fairfield Glade, Tenn. The Rev. Stephen Tischendorf performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Granville.

title: $1.3 Million Cow
description: A VERMONT show cow described as having a high pedigree and milk with a high butterfat content brought the highest price ever paid for a cow at auction: $1.3 million.

title: THE RIGHT COSELL, THE WRONG GOLDBERG
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: OASIS IN APPALACHIA
description: The spoonbread!

title: A HANDSOME LOOK IN FUNCTIONAL GUIDEBOOKS
description: The 1986 editions of many popular guidebooks are beginning to appear in bookstores across the land. The first to arrive each year are updated versions of the familiar meat-and-potatoes directories - the Fodors, the Frommers, the Let's Go's - that steer first-time visitors along well-beaten paths. Later, as the holiday season approaches, come the coffee-table books that stir memories or dreams of distant countries through lavish use of photography and lush color reproduction. These expensive books are hardly meant to be tucked inside a suitcase, and contain little if any day-to-day travel tips.

title: BOOKS FROM THE TIMES
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE'S NEW YORK TIMES FOOD ENCLOPEDIA. Illustrated. Compiled by Joan Whitman.

title: PACIFIC ATOLL LANDOWNERS TO IGNORE U.S. PACT
description: Landowners on the Kwajalein Atoll in the central Pacific, the site of a billion dollar United States missile testing and surveillance range, will refuse to recognize an arrangement with the United States to make the area independent except in military affairs, according to the landowners' legal representative here.

title: Woman, 69, Injured in Crash At Branford Toll Plaza on I-95
description: A 69-year-old woman was injured at the toll plaza on Interstate 95 here Friday when a van ran into the back of her car, the state police said.

title: VENICE OBSERVED
description: A SMALL TOWN By Shelby Hearon. 335 pp. New York: Atheneum. $15.95.

title: CASINO CHANGES PROPOSED
description: THE casino industry, as well as its regulators and legislators, are pondering a proposal that the state eliminate most regulation of hotel-casino facilities and concentrate instead on regulating the casinos themselves.

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;

Business in Short
description: TOWARD THE YEAR 2000: World Business Leaders Speak Out on the Future of Free Enterprise. Compiled, edited and with an introduction by Ruth Karen.

title: LET MEMORY SERVE AS THE STOREHOUSE OF SERIES PAST
description: IT was a generation ago - 25 years, to be exact - that the New York Yankees scored a record 55 runs in the World Series. In so doing, they managed to outscore their opposition by better than 2 to 1. They also managed to lose the Series: proof positive that there was humility before Steinbrenner.

title: POLICE ROUST DEMONSTRATORS ON EGYPTIAN CAMPUS
description: Riot policemen used tear gas and clubs here today to disperse hundreds of students protesting the American interception of the Egyptian plane carrying four Palestinian hijackers.

title: YOUNG MUSICIANS ON TOUR FOR ELDERLY
description: LAST year when Theodor Liebmann visited his grandmother at Tower One-Tower East in New Haven, he was struck by a feeling that something was missing from the lives of the elderly people living in the apartments for the elderly.

title:
ANTIQUES;

ROOSTERS AND HORSES: PORTENTS OF SHIFTING WINDS
description: WEATHER vanes, used in ancient Greece and by the Vikings in the Middle Ages, have always had a special importance to mariners and farmers - to everyone, in fact, who needs to know which way the wind blows.

title: Elizabeth Carbery Wick of Harvard Is Married to Charles A. Kaminski Jr.
description: Elizabeth Carbery Wick, a daughter of Mrs. Paul Raymond Locher of Washington and the late Lieut. John Glen Wick, U.S.N., of Trinidad, was married yesterday to Charles Anthony Kaminski Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kaminski of Norwich, Conn.

title: WHY HEBREW HAS NO HOMER
description: THE ART OF BIBLICAL POETRY By Robert Alter. 228 pp. New York: Basic Books. $17.95.

title: Lift Water Curbs, Delaware Asks
description: GOV. MICHAEL N. CASTLE of Delaware plans to ask the Delaware River Basin Commission to consider ending its drought emergency and lifting mandatory water restrictions in the three other member states, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New York.

title: Marathon Problems
description: She won the women's division in 1983 and 1984, but on the eve of the America's Marathon through the streets of Chicago this morning, Rosa Mota of Portugal conceded that to win the 1985 race she would have to overcome a couple of problems. Their names are Ingrid Kristiansen and Joan Benoit, both of whom have predicted that the race will produce the first sub 2-hour 20-minute marathon by a woman.

title: HIGH TECHNOLOGY BOOM BUILDING UP CAMBRIDGE
description: It was spawned in a Cambridge basement four years ago: a new high technology company with a handful of employees. Then it expanded into a series of renovated warehouses, and recently moved into a new nine-story brick and glass building overlooking Boston across the Charles River.

title: BOEING TO GET $2 BILLION ORDER
description: The head of Northwest Orient Airlines says the company will place an order worth about $2 billion with the Boeing Company for up to 20 of its planned 747-400 jumbo jets.

title: WHO'S IN CHARGE?
description: Like the managers of the baseball World Series in Missouri, the managers of world diplomacy here in Washington concentrate on one game at a time.

title: South Africa: Dream and Reality
description: I recently returned from South Africa, where I worked as an intern in a nonwhite law firm, and would like to add a legal footnote to Joseph Lelyveld's article, ''South Africa: Dream and Reality'' (Sept. 22). He discussed the sad and all-too-common case of Thabane Ntshiwa, the young mechanic who was sentenced to 18 months in prison for using a coffee mug on which were inscribed some political phrases, including ''Release Nelson Mandela.''

title: THE CITY OPENS ITS ARMS AND SHUTS ITS EYES TO ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: ACCUSING the Federal Government of failing to defend the borders of the United States against illegal immigrants, then refusing to provide financial assistance to cover the city's cost of providing health services and education for aliens who are here, Mayor Koch said last week that the city would not report illegal aliens to Federal authorities unless they appeared to be involved in criminal activity. He said as many as 750,000 illegal immigrants live in New York.

title: Detecting Cancer
description: SAYING that one in every seven people in the country had skin cancer, the American Cancer Society announced a weekend of free screenings in New York City in March in the hope of detecting and stemming the disease. Six hospitals cooperated in the effort.

title: Shere Hite Wed To Fred Horicke
description: Shere Hite, the sex researcher and author, and Fred Horicke, a pianist, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Nicholas R. Reid performed the ceremony.

title: TOPICS
description: WHEN I was a child, I told the neighbors my mother was trying to poison me. Why? She was trying to force me to eat vegetables - in particular, string beans.

title: DAY FOR AGED TO GET INFORMED
description: MORE than 35 state agencies will be offering information about programs that enhance the quality of life for the elderly Tuesday at the second Governor's Day on State Services for the Aging.

title: NEW SPORTS-FANTASY VENTURE
description: FOR more than a decade Bob Wirz of Norwalk lived out a personal fantasy, mingling with some of the best-known figures in baseball as the chief spokesman for the baseball commissioner's office in Manhattan.

title: IN FIRM PURSUIT OF CRAFTY GROUSE
description: THE sunken lane is overgrown enough that you can miss it from the road . . . which is fine by me. I drive past it without slowing and then, about a quarter of a mile further, pull over and park. When I get out of the truck, the dog is right behind me and she hits the ground running. She knows this place and she knows what we've come for.

title: SURGERY FOR METS' WILSON
description: Mookie Wilson, who missed two months of the season after arthroscopic surgery in July, underwent another operation on his right shoulder yesterday. The Mets said that the 29-year-old center fielder would begin therapy immediately and would be ready for spring training in February.

title: HE HID, SHE HOWLED
description: WATSON'S APOLOGY By Beryl Bainbridge. 222 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $14.95.

title: HOSPITAL MOVING
description: When it was establiished in 1869 the primary mission of New York Foundling Hospital was the rescue of abondoned infants and children.

title: WRIGHT'S LEGACY
description: To the Editor: The article on Frank Lloyd Wright brought back fond memories of visits to Taliesin in my youth. As a child, living in the town of Sauk City, 25 miles from Spring Green, I spent many a summer afternoon at Taliesin.

title: POLISH EXPERIMENTALIST EXAMINES MAN AND HISTORY
description: In his analysis of the performance art of Tadeusz Kantor, Jan Kott speaks of his Polish countryman as a creator of ''a theater of essence.'' With Kantor, he explains, ''essence is the aftermath . . . as final as the Last Judgment.'' It is ''a trace, like the still undissolved imprint of a crustacean on stone.'' Kantor's archeological imprint is transmitted through images, many of them, as Kott says, expressing the director's horror and fascination with ''the still life of the dead.'' Kantor transports us to a world in which the dead play restless roles.

title: CANDIDATES COMPOETE FOR 17 BOARD SEATS
description: ARMED with election brochures, petitions and even water restrictors, Westchester County Legislators are appearing at all the old familiar campaign places this fall - railroad platforms, shopping centers and front doors.

title: REAGAN'S LETTER TO CRAXI
description: Following is the letter sent today by President Reagan to Bettino Craxi, the caretaker Prime Minister, as made public by the Prime Minister's office: Dear Bettino:

title: A RISING TIDE OF FORECLOSURES
description: LIKE tens of thousands of others in the late 1970's and early 80's, James and Linda Low left Illinois and came to Houston in search of a bigger piece of the American dream.

title: The Pregnant Detective
description: As a 31-year-old, career-oriented woman of the baby-boom generation, I don't have time to watch a lot of television, and I usually don't want to.

title: ADRIFT IN THE DMZ
description: THE FENCE WALKER By William Holinger. 290 pp. Albany: State University of New York Press. $12.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: COPING IN MEDICAL SCHOOL. By Bernard Virshup. (Norton, Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95.) This book is intended as a self-help guide for medical students.

title: Another Gandhi Loyalist Is Shot Dead in Punjab
description: A local leader of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's party was shot dead today in the Punjab, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: AUCTION TO AID SPECIAL OLYMPICS
description: A CAMEO role on the television show ''Kate and Allie,''

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Princess Who Had Never Laughed Starring Ellen Barkin, Howard Hesseman, Howie Mandel; directed by Mark Cullingham CBS/Fox Home Video 60 minutes. $39.98 For this project, the people at Shelley Duvall's Faerie Tale Theater have recast the Grimm Brothers poignant story about a widowed king and his soberly raised daughter and set it in a never-never land located somewhere between the Borscht Belt and the Kingdom of Daytime Television.

title: SOUTH KOREA FEARS THE 'JAPAN TREATMENT'
description: Friction between the United States and South Korea over trade issues is not new, but the protectionist mood sweeping Washington has officials in both countries worrying about broader diplomatic and political consequences. Other American trading partners have similar concerns, but the relationship with South Korea is special, born of the Korean War and subsequent security arrangements. The United States, with 40,000 troops stationed here, is not just an ally, it is a participant in political life.

title: HOW REBELS CAN KEEP SALVADOR ON EDGE
description: Along with the personal anguish, the six weeks since the kidnapping of his eldest daughter has been a severe political test for Salvador's President, Jose Napoleon Duarte. Inez Guadalupe Duarte Duran was abducted last month, almost certainly by leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. New strains have now appeared in Mr. Duarte's relations with the army and his opponents on the right. The shift in rebel tactics exemplified by the kidnapping appears to have pushed the haggard-looking President virtually out of public view. It may even influence his management of the civil war now stretching into its seventh year.

title: CONTRACT FOR RAIL SERVICE TO ATLANTIC CITY IS SIGNED
description: The New Jersey Transit Corporation and Amtrak have signed a contract to provide rail passenger service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City, three years after Congress authorized $30 million for the line.

title: Las Vegas Hilton to Pay Out $22 Million in Accord on Fire
description: Victims of a 1981 fire that killed eight people and injured 198 at the Las Vegas Hilton have agreed to a $22.8 million settlement from more than 40 defendants.

title: KIPPERS: BEYOND THE BREAKFAST TABLE
description: WHENEVER I go back to England, I search out favorite foods from my childhood. Fruit pies with Devonshire cream, roast beef and Yorkshire pudding, smoked salmon and smoked haddock are among my favorites, and, of course, kippers for breakfast. I am always delighted when I find kippers still going strong.

title: THE FUTURE OF LONG-TERM FORECASTING LOOKS BRIGHT
description: In the global atmosphere, the weather of the tropics is the straw that stirs the drink. The regions near the Equator, with their warm oceans and steaming forests, infuse the atmosphere with most of the heat that keeps the world's weather moving. They provide most of the water vapor, and they spawn the great storm systems.

title: Hemingway's Unpublished Stories
description: John McCormick, who has written some excellent pages on Ernest Hemingway, including ''The Middle Distance'' (Free Press, 1971), disagrees with Matthew Bruccoli's assertion that ''Everything Ernest Hemingway wrote is of importance because he wrote it'' (Letters, Sept. 22, in response to ''The Young Hemingway, Three Unpublished Stories,'' Aug. 18). Professor McCormick then calls the three stories of Ernest Hemingway ''wretched early stuff'' that, published, can serve only to cut down the writer to ''a small man among small men.''

title: The Conservative Line
description: President Reagan has agreed to add conservative academicians to the various experts who are briefing him for his trip to Geneva next month to confer with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: SPOTLIGHT ON BRAZIL
description: The world team championship scheduled to begin today in Sao Paulo, Brazil, will surely be hard-fought, though it is unlikely to match the excitement of the last such Bermuda Bowl event. In Stockholm two years ago the results of the preliminaries, both semi-finals and the final, remained in doubt almost to the last card.

title: OPERA: 'LUCIA' CAST CHANGES
description: FOUR new singers stepped into the cast of Gaetano Donizetti's tearjerker ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' Friday night at the New York City Opera.

title: 'AN INTERESTING PHYSICS PROBLEM'
description: STAR WARRIORS A Penetrating Look Into the Lives of the Young Scientists Behind Our Space Age Weaponry. By William J. Broad. Illustrated. 245 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: BACK OFFICES IN MOUNTAIN LAKES
description: After 15 years of leasing space in three buildings in Livingston, N.J., for back office operations, Newsweek magazine will move its subscription processing and computer staffs to a building it is constructing in Mountain Lakes.

title: MORE AND MORE AIDS CASES FOUND AMONG DRUG ABUSERS
description: Freddy Lambert cannot escape the consequences of a five-year drug addiction that drove him to inject himself with heroin and cocaine, sometimes with dirty needles, in abandoned buildings and friends' apartments and that eventually landed him in prison.

title: NEW CANAAN SINGERS SEEK NEW AUDIENCE IN STAMFORD MOVE
description: THE cultural magnet of Stamford has attracted yet another performing-arts organization.

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;

URSUS MAJOR
description: THE WARNING The Coming Great Crash in the Stock Market. By Joseph Granville. 397 pp. New York: Freundlich Books. $18.95.

title: DANCE: HOUSTON BALLET PRESENTS 'PEER GYNT'
description: THERE are some highly touching moments in ''Peer Gynt,'' the two-act ballet by Ben Stevenson which the Houston Ballet presented for the first time in New York at the City Center Friday night.

title: STOP-AND-GO HOUSE
description: IT IS PERHAPS THE MOST TIMELY OF ARCHI-tectural dilemmas: to design a house that satisfies a client's desire to ''make people come to a screeching halt when they drive by'' and at the same time fulfill the architect's social responsibility to a place's existing building traditions.

title: The Kennedy Fellowships
description: President Kennedy had agreed to deliver the 1964 keynote address at the annual national dinner of the Weizmann Institute of Science.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in last Sunday's Travel Advisory column gave incorrect dates for activities at Old Sturbridge Village in Sturbridge, Mass. The village is open daily but closed Mondays from Dec. 2. The cider mill will be open through Nov. 3.

title: ADULTERY WITH DISCUSSIONS
description: A LITTLE DECORUM, FOR ONCE By W. M. Spackman. 128 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: THIS LIBERAL PARTY'S OVER
description: New York's Liberal Party was born of a split in the old American Labor Party in 1944. The split reflected irreconcilable differences between the liberal social democratic left and Moscow-controlled Communists. Now the Liberal Party has, de facto, split again, but its two leaders, Ray Harding and Donald Harrington, are divided not by principle but by personal desire for patronage and influence. Unable after two years to bury the hatchet, they ought to bury the party emblem instead.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PLANS FOR DEPARTURE. By Nayantara Sahgal. (Norton, $14.95.) ''Plans for Departure'' is a novel of ideas. Set in 1914 in Himapur, an isolated town in the Himalayas, it explores the impact of British rule in India and deals with the irony that the British, after winning India by force, expected gratitude from the conquered.

title: Right for the Role
description: WHEN PEOPLE criticize President Reagan I say, ''Name a movie actor you'd rather have in the White House than Ronald Reagan.'' That takes the steam out of them. Oh sure, somebody always says, ''Jimmy Stewart - I think Jimmy Stewart would be a lot better President than Reagan.'' And that is so irrelevant.

title: Literary Prizes
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE SEEKS TO CUT INFANT MORTALITY
description: AN AMBITIOUS campaign was begun in 10 of the state's largest cities this month to reduce the number of babies who are born too soon or too small or who die before their first birthdays.

title: Going On in the Northeast;   FREE TREES IN RYE
description: People with pickaxes will descend on a field in the Marshlands Conservancy in Rye, N.Y., on Saturday to dig up trees and shrubs and take them home.

title: BOSTON SUCCUMBS TO A CASE OF RENOIR FEVER
description: You would have to be blind and deaf to go to Boston these days and not realize that Renoir is in town. There is the word of mouth. There is the double-decker bus, painted white and with Renoir's signature writ large all over it, that plies to and from the Boston Museum of Fine Arts with a full load of enthusiasts. And then there are the Bostonians themselves. Gladly do they stand in a long line to buy tickets for the Renoir retrospective, and gladly do they stand in line all over again to get in at the appointed time.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HEAVEN AND EARTH. By Frederic Raphael. (Beaufort, $16.95.) Celebrated for his literary translations, Gideon Shand is unable to decode the tangled plot of his own life; it seems curiously immobile, as if the past and the future had conspired to hold it hostage.

title: DAVID MURDOCK BEATS THE UNION
description: THE life and fortunes of David H. Murdock, it was widely assumed, would change sharply after he bought controlling interest in the Cannon Mills Company from its founding family and turned his attention to this snoozing company town. When Mr. Murdock took over as chairman in May 1982, it was the first time the high-rolling Los Angeles financier had actually taken operational control at a large manufacturing company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1985
description: International

title: Janice Dooner Weds Thomas Lynch 3d
description: Janice Patricia Dooner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Dooner of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas F. Lynch 3d, a son of Joyce F. Lynch of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. Lynch. The Rev. Daniel Smilanic, the bridegroom's cousin, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Peace in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Business section last Sunday on ethical investing incorrectly stated the location of the New Alternatives Fund. It is in Great Neck, L.I.

title: RACIST ARYAN NATIONS GROUP INDUCTS NEW DISCIPLES
description: While some former members are standing trial on charges of armed robbery, arson and murder in what the authorities say was a racist plot to overthrow the Government, the white supremacist group Aryan Nations is attracting new disciples.

title: ICE SKATING AT POND DEBATED
description: TEEN-AGERS and their parents in the Village of Lawrence say they are determined to have ice skating legalized this winter at Dixon Pond, in a rural setting minutes from the Queens border.

title: TUNISIAN OFFICIALS LEAVING DOUBT WHETHER PALESTINIAN CAN RETURN
description: Remarks in recent days by Tunisian officials have caused confusion about whether a Palestine Liberation Front leader, Mohammed Abbas, will be allowed back into the country.

title: POLICE NAME 2D SUSPECT IN SALT LAKE BOMBINGS
description: The police today named a second suspect in the bombings that killed two people and wounded a third here this week.

title: LOWEST FOOD PRICE RISE SINCE '67 IS FORECAST
description: Retail food prices are rising at the slowest rate in 18 years as surpluses in major commodities and livestock continue to depress the financially strapped farm marketplace, according to a report from the Department of Agriculture.

title: COUNCIL ON FOREIGN RELATIONS: NEW LOOK
description: Changes have not always come easily to the Council on Foreign Relations, which after 64 years is probably still the pre-eminent American meeting place on international affairs.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE NOBLE TRAVELLER: O. V. de L. Milosz. Edited by Christopher Bamford. (Lindisfarne Press/Inner Traditions, $24.95.) Who was Oscar Vladislas de Lubicz Milosz (1877-1939)? Symbolist poet, ''French Goethe'' of Slavic origin, metaphysical dramatist and biblical exegete, Catholic visionary and member of esoteric circles, professional diplomat who lived in Paris but served the cause of Lithuanian independence - no one description seems appropriate.

title: EXPERTS PREDICT ALMOST EVERY CHILD ON EARTH WILL BE VACCINATED BY 1990
description: The campaign to vaccinate all the world's children against six deadly diseases by 1990 has made dramatic gains in recent months and, for the first time, many health officials say they believe the goal will be virtually accomplished.

title: PHILHARMONIC: SINOPOLI CONDUCTS ROMANTIC TRIO
description: THE second of Giuseppe Sinopoli's two subscription programs with the New York Philharmonic this season - heard Friday afternoon and to be repeated Tuesday evening - was purely Romantic. There was Wagner's ''Flying Dutchman'' Overture, Schumann's Cello Concerto and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 5. All this suited Mr. Sinopoli, who for all his roots in late-modernist composition seems most effective as an interpreter of overtly passionate music.

title:
GARDENING;

PREPARING PLANTS TO SURVIVE THE WINTER
description: WHEN October's bright, crisp days beckon us outdoors, what better way to spend an afternoon than to look after one's garden chores.

title: NO SURPRISE, KANSAS CITY IS SURPRISING
description: For the thousands of people who will ask the question in the days of the World Series, ''Is everything up to date in Kansas City?'' Mayor Richard L. Berkley would like to respond once and for all, as he did yesterday. ''The answer is yes,'' he said. He can point, as he did in an interview this week, to a building boom now under way, with several office towers rising higher, according to the precepts of the ''Oklahoma!'' song ''Everything's Up to Date in Kansas City,'' than ''a building ought to go.''

title: Cate Halsey, Former Secretary, Wed To Dr. Joyce P. Kilmer, an Engineer
description: Mary Catesby Halsey, a daughter of Mrs. S. MacRae Halsey of New York and Charles Day Halsey Jr. of New York and Carmel, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Joyce Prentice Kilmer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Joyce Kilmer of Palm Beach, Fla., Pittsburgh and Southampton, L.I. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: VIEWS ON ROOMS
description: BILLY BALDWIN An Autobiography. By Billy Baldwin, with Michael Gardine. Illustrated. 368 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: LEHMAN BLANKS CLINTON IN MARCH TOWARD PLAYOFFS
description: Lehman virtually guaranteed itself second place in the Bronx Public School Athletic League and the accompanying playoff berth by defeating Clinton, 26-0, yesterday at Kennedy.

title: QUEENS YOUTH WINS WORLD JUNIOR TITLE
description: For the second time this year, a United States player has won an individual world title.

title: THE TANGO WHIRLS WITH PASSION
description: The dazzling two-hour exploration of the tango as both music and dance at the Hellinger Theater, entitled ''Tango Argentino,'' carries a program note warning against overintellectualizing about the origins of the form and its significance: ''It is easy to get lost in a maze of theories that is as confusing and circuitous as the streets of Buenos Aires themselves.'' True. And one has only to observe that 36 books and articles devoted to the tango are listed as bibliography under the Groves' Musical Dictionary ''tango'' entry to see the point. Its origins never completely defined, the tango remains a mystery, a myth - a dance ''remembered'' even by those who have never seen it.

title: CHESS GAME POSTPONED
description: Gary Kasparov, who is challenging Anatoly Karpov for the world chess title, took his second timeout today in the championship match between the two Soviet grandmasters.

title: ILL-CONCEIVED U.S. CURB ON WORLD COURT CASES
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

PREPARING PLANTS TO SURVIVE THE WINTER
description: WHEN October's bright, crisp days beckon us outdoors, what better way to spend an afternoon than to look after one's garden chores.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ALTHOUGH 1985 has been dubbed the ''Year of the Environment'' by Governor Kean, both he and his Democratic opponent, Peter Shapiro, did not put special emphasis on pressing environmental issues during their televised debate earlier this month.

title: DIRECTORY OF FALL AND WINTER SAILINGS
description: The following directory of cruise ships is arranged by destination and focuses mainly on cruises that require booking a cabin and sailing at least overnight. Most of the trips listed take place between Oct. 21 and March 31; the next guide is scheduled to appear on Feb. 9, 1986.

title: CHINA REPORTS ITS TROOPS USE ELECTRONIC GUNS ON EXERCISE
description: Chinese troops are using laser-beam and electonic simulators in military exercises for the first tiwme, the official New China News Agency reported Friday.

title: Patricia Ochs to Marry Feb. 1
description: Patricia Stratford Ochs and Brian Gould Manning plan to be married Feb. 1 in Charlottesville, Va. Miss Ochs and Mr. Manning are members of the clerical news staff of The New York Times in New York.

title: About Men;    Young Rabbi
description: I AM 28 YEARS OLD AND a rabbi. Had I chosen to be a gymnast or tennis player, I would be considered past my prime. As a lawyer or computer engineer, I would be reaching the peak of yuppiedom. In my own eyes, I fret at how quickly the years pass while I helplessly watch my youthful vigor recede.

title:
IVESTING;

SPECULATING ON MIDWEST BANK MERGER
description: IN recent weeks, the stocks of several Indiana banks have surged, as takeover rumors -fanned by the local press - have swept Indianapolis and Fort Wayne, the state's banking centers.

title: AN EPIC FILM ABOUT THE GREATEST EVIL OF MODERN TIMES
description: For someone who has just finished a monumental labor of 11 years, a labor of relentless determination, loneliness and - it is not too much to say - obsessive moral commitment, Claude Lanzmann is not a particularly satisfied man. To be sure, his film ''Shoah,'' a nine-and-a-half-hour documentary on the Holocaust, due to open in New York on Wednesday at the Cinema Studio, has received extravagant praise in France; it has been called a ''masterpiece'' by critics; it has awakened a new consciousness about the greatest evil of modern times.

title: RACES FOR SUPERVISOR UNDER WAY
description: WILLIAM D. CARLEBACH of Bedford concedes that he is an avid poker player, and right now he is betting that he can unseat the town's incumbent Supervisor, Lawrence E. Dwyer Jr. of Katonah. ''I think the odds are pretty good,'' said Mr. Carlebach, a Democrat.

title: THE COLD ECONOMIST
description: THE FATAL EQUILIBRIUM By Marshall Jevons. 215 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $10.95.

title: 6 AT YALE ARE PENALIZED FOR PRANK IN MARCHING BAND
description: TO many members of the Yale Precision Marching Band, yesterday's break in their performance schedule was welcome, after two incidents at recent halftime shows.

title: HOMELESS PROJECT STIRS HASTINGS DISPUTE
description: A PLAN by a Hastings-on-Hudson landlord to provide two apartments to the county to house homeless families has angered neighborhood residents and led village officials to protest the move to County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: WILL VAPOR MAN STRIKE AGAIN?
description: DON'T look for Vapor Man in the comic-book racks, at least not yet. Vapor Man is the real thing, a frothy white apparition who stalks - or streaks -the clubhouse of the St. Louis Cardinals during victory celebrations.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: In most eyes, one of photography's essential virtues is its ability to describe the world with accuracy and precision. But many photographers of the current generation believe that the most interesting photographic images suggest much more than they describe.

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;

Business in Short
description: WILLIS R. WHITNEY, GENERAL ELECTRIC, AND THE ORIGINS OF U.S. INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH. By George Wise. (Columbia University, $29.) In the early years of this century, the General Electric Company struggled to perfect the lightbulb and pioneer electronics for the consumer.

title: A LEADING CHARACTER ACTOR
description: IN the theater world, ''the actor's actor'' refers to the consummate professional who evokes admiration and awe in his colleagues.

title: DRIVEN BY A RAGE TO ACCUMULATE
description: THE NATURE AND LOGIC OF CAPITALISM By Robert L. Heilbroner. 225 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SAN ANDREAS. By Alistair MacLean. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Alistair MacLean's latest novel begins with a factual prologue presenting, in almost textbook fashion, the ''pitiable'' state of the British Merchant Navy during World War II and the record of ruthlessness with which the Germans stalked and sunk the navy's ships.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''I HAVE often heard,'' a German writer said to me, ''that Americans don't read books, that they're too busy doing other things. How do you reconcile this with the fact that so many books are sold in this country?'' I didn't know the answer, so I referred his question to a friend of mine who is always buying books, who, whenever we take a walk together, invariably leads me to a bookshop. Before quoting him, however, I want to make it clear that these are his opinions, not mine.

title:
DINING OUT;

2 CATERER-RUN ESTABLISHMENTS
description: ALTHOUGH we try to avoid writing about restaurants we consider poor or fair, there are times when it is necessary. Usually, it is because a restaurant that was previously rated highly had deteriorated, sometimes it is because there is a new chef or owner and sometimes it is because the restaurant's advertising has been so extravagant that it seems only fair to set the record straight.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CAMPAIGNING FOR PIZZA CHRIS DOWNEY, wife of Representative Thomas J. Downey of Amityville, said recently that whenever she and her husband came home from Washington they visited ''my mother, his mother and Pizza Town in West Babylon - and not necessarily in that order.''

title: HARVARD DEFEATS DARTMOUTH BY 17-7
description: Harvard brushed aside a weak Dartmouth team today, and the victory over the Green, 17-7, moved the Crimson into a first-place tie with Penn in the Ivy League.

title: OF HUMAN BEHAVIOR DURING A HURRICANE
description: IT is said that we learn by experience. Hurricanes are not the expected fare for Connecticut residents. Some of the natives recall the 1938 disaster, but Hurricane Gloria was my first experience with a misplaced tropical storm. I offer 10 perceptions gained by living in Gloria's path. 1. Having remained glued to the television, then to a battery-operated radio before the storm arrived, I conclude that when anticipating a potential disaster, one will listen eagerly to the same information no matter how many times it is repeated. 2. Of the things one hopes to accomplish in the time off bestowed by a storm, all require electricity. 3. Abe Lincoln deserves more credit for his willingness to study by the light of a flickering fire. 4. The least romantic hardship of lack of electricity is living without the pump that assures us of running water. 5. The luxury most taken for granted in America is the flush toilet. 6. Ben Franklin advised us that after three days, guests, like fish, begin to smell. A refrigerator deprived of electricity can accomplish it in less than that. 7. Just as there is more than one way to skin a cat, there is more than one way to clean out a refrigerator, the most thorough and least satisfying of which is tossing out a freezerful of spoiled food. 8. Cheerfulness has a correlation to the length of time since the last shower. The longer it has been, the more disagreeable one becomes. 9.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE PATCHWORK QUILT By Valerie Flournoy. Illustrated by Jerry Pinkney. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers/ E. P. Dutton. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 8) THE QUILT STORY By Tony Johnston. Illustrated by Tomie dePaola. Unpaged. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: ELECTRONICS: A MAJOR PART OF SPY GAME
description: The intercepted radio conversations that purportedly took place between the hijackers of the Achille Lauro and an associate on shore have underscored the central role that electronic snooping now plays in the intelligence operations of the United States and other nations.

title: BECOMING A 'REGULAR' (GETTING INTO THE SWIM)
description: OVER the last few years my dedication to swim on a regular basis has been fulfilled at the Boys' Club in Mount Kisco. During the winter months, especially, opportunity to exercise and swim several times a week has been greatly appreciated. For one so accustomed to physical exercise in order to feel fit, the pool became a life-saver. Deprived of other outlets that release energy or insure vigor, my attempts to maintain a regimen of health revolved around the laps stroked away in the water.

title: EXPLORING THE RICHES OF MODERN WORKS FOR CELLO
description: Arnold Schonberg once wrote a celebrated essay entitled ''Brahms the Modernist.'' The cellist Joel Krosnick and the pianist Gilbert Kalish are going a step further in three concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall this year, actually integrating Brahms into a three-part series entitled ''The Cello: A 20th-Century American Retropspective.''

title: MUTTONTOWN EASES ZONING
description: WHILE many Long Island communities have been making their zoning rules stricter to combat development, officials of the Village of Muttontown recently eased a zoning regulation to give residents more flexibility in the use of their properties.

title: Partygoer Falls Into Hudson And Is Missing After 2 Hours
description: A man attending a costume party in a white wedding dress fell overboard from a Circle Line tour boat in the Hudson River late last night and was still missing after two hours of searching by Coast Guard and police vessels and scuba divers, the police said.

title: Sorting Through Pitching Records
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: INJURIES CRIMP JET BACKFIELD
description: When the quarterback was named Joe Namath and the running back was John Riggins, the Jets won six straight games. That was 1974, and they closed out their season on that note.

title: UNDERSTANDING MUSIC'S 'LANGUAGE'
description: I CAN'T remember Latin, and speak French only a little, but the language I really wish I knew is music. Responses to music may be universal, but the truth is, the language isn't.

title: FASHION DESIGNERS TO AID AFRICANS
description: Taking a leaf from the rock world's book, American designers are planning a fashion extravaganza in New York next month as a counterpart to the Fashion Aid benefit in London for African famine relief.

title: PASSAIC TRIUMPHS
description: Troy Giles, a senior tailback, ran for 125 yards and two touchdowns and passed for a third score while guiding Passaic (3-1) over Paterson Kennedy, 19-0, yesterday in Passaic.

title: IMMIGRANT ARTISTS OF PARIS AFTER 1905 ARE CELEBRATED AT JEWISH MUSEUM
description: SHORTLY after the turn of the century the Montparnasse district of Paris began to eclipse Montmartre as an area for artists. Beginning in about 1905, some of the artists who began to show up in the neighborhood were Jewish immigrants who hoped to establish themselves in the city of Monet, Picasso, Renoir and Cezanne. The names of some of the immigrants were Chagall, Modigliani, Lipchitz, Soutine, Zadkine and Delaunay.

title: PREMIER SAYS THE SUDAN WILL NOT BE A 'CLIENT'
description: The Prime Minister of the Sudan says that although his nation is strongly committed to close relations with the United States, it will not be a ''client'' of any superpower.

title: Janice Barefoot Is Affianced to Richard B. Sachs
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Kirk Barefoot of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Lynn Barefoot, to Richard Burton Sachs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton A. Sachs of Scarsdale, N.Y. A January wedding is planned.

title: ECONOMIC REALITIES AND POLITICAL DIVIDENDS
description: HOUSE and Senate negotiators started the arduous process last week of hammering out a compromise bill that would force Congress to balance the budget by 1991. Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat, called the measure a ''cop-out,'' because it increased the President's power at the expense of Congress. ''It may be a cop-out,'' said Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who is chairman of the conference. ''I'm afraid to think we've come to that. But we may have. I wish I had another answer, but after 17 years here, I don't have one.''

title: A BUSY CHARACTER ACTOR
description: IN the theater world, ''an actor's actor'' is a consummate professional who evokes admiration in his colleagues.

title: Lendl and Leconte In Australian Final
description: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia registered a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Paul Annacone of the United States in a semifinal of the $285,000 Australian indoor tennis championships tonight.

title: Business in Short
description: METAL MEN: Marc Rich and the 10-Billion-Dollar Scam. By A. Craig Copetas. (Putnam, $17.95.) A. Craig Copetas, a magazine writer who posed as a commodities trader in order to uncover Marc Rich's rags-to-riches story, reveals more about metals trading than he does about the $10 billion metals man. Mr. Rich, whose power to manipulate world markets helped precipitate the 1979 oil crisis, is now under self-imposed exile in Switzerland to avoid criminal prosecution for the largest known tax-evasion scheme in American history.

title: Sharon Kelly Marries
description: Sharon Marie Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kelly of Old Westbury, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Michael Patrick Reilly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Reilly of Merrick, L.I. The Rev. Terence Reilly, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Brigid Roman Catholic Church in Westbury, L.I. Mrs. Reilly is a regional computer analyst for the treasury management division of the Bank of America in New York. Mr. Reilly is a senior accountant with Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the accounting firm in New York.

title: CORNWALL
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed our recent stay at Grey Gables, Porthcurno, Cornwall very much, and we appreciated the article ''Along the Rugged Rim of Cornwall'' (Travel, May 26), which mentioned Grey Gables. It was reasonable in price, and our room was very comfortable, having the only firm mattress and decent shower we experienced on our bed-and-breakfast tour of Southwest England. Mrs. Thomas, the proprietor of Grey Gables, is an exceptionally energetic and enthusiastic lady, who cooked us a fine breakfast and dinner.

title: Alice Wheeler Becomes Bride Of Peter Morris
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Alice Owens Wheeler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Warren Wheeler of Bronxville, and Peter John Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert George Morris of Sydney, Australia. The Rev. Christopher L. Webber officiated.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE INSIDE-OUTSIDE BOOK OF NEW YORK CITY Written and illustrated by Roxie Munro. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $13.95. (Ages 3 and up) THERE are two sides to every window, of course. One side, inside, is comforting - the orderly border we impose on the tumbling scenes beyond. The other side, outside, is alluring - the mysterious frame that hides so many other lives from our view.

title: MARCOS DENIES REBUFFING U.S. ON HIS POLICIES
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos denied today that he had rejected an American plea for changes in his policies.

title: NEONATAL CARE UNIT TO MARK 10th YEAR
description: Thousands of children and their parents have been invited to a birthday party today at the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington, to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the neonatal intensive-care unit there.

title: THE U.S. MAY PAY A HIGH PRICE FOR ITS TRIUMPH
description: IN a matter of days, the mood of exultation in Washington over the handling of the Achille Lauro hijacking has been tempered by recognition that in the apprehension of some of the terrorists, vital American interests in the Mediterranean - and perhaps beyond -may have been eroded.

title: OILY OILIES
description: BELLY UP The Collapse of the Penn Square Bank. By Phillip L. Zweig. Illustrated. 500 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $17.95.

title: THE MYTH MAKER
description: TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AFTER THE PUBLICATION OF HIS FIRST NOVEL, ''Welcome to Hard Times,'' E. L. Doctorow is reminiscing about a letter from one of its readers.
