Set in the Dakota Territory in the latter half of the 19th century, the novel takes the form of journals written by the mayor of a tiny frontier town called Hard Times. It's a dark fable, a literary western by a serious young writer, that employs the town's tribulations - and the mayor's attempts to record them - to explore grand themes: the nature of American culture, the mortality of men and their civilization, the eternalness of art.

title: CORPORATE CATERING: A GROWTH BUSINESS
description: CALLED Mrs. Incredible by her clients, Janet Dresden of Incredible Edibles caters 15 to 20 parties a week for her corporate clients. It is a pace that separates her Stamford company from many smaller catering concerns, which average five parties a week. But then, Mrs. Dresden acknowledges that things come a lot easier when your work is fun.

title: 3 CONTENDERS VIE FOR SURROGATE POST
description: FOR the first time in many years, a Democrat is rated a strong contender for election to a major countywide office in traditionally Republican Suffolk County, both Republican and Democratic politicians agreed last week.

title: PRIMARY LEADS TO CALLS FOR SIMPLER ELECTION LAWS
description: The Democratic primary here last month, with its court challenges of nominating petitions and candidates on and off the ballot, was reprised last week in a hearing room at the Arthur J. Levitt State Office Building, across from City Hall.

title: Cathy Levine Is Married
description: Cathy Levine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Levine of Metuchen, N.J., and Ira Elliott Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Boris Cohen of Passaic, N.J., were married yesterday. Rabbi Gerald Zelizer, assisted by Rabbi Barry Friedman, performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J.

title: PERFECT LIFE SUPPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: WHO REIGNS IN OPERA?
description: There exists, I am told, a biography of Birgit Nilsson that includes a photograph of the Swedish diva as Salome, contemplating a platter on which rests the head of Herbert von Karajan. Someone, supposedly without Miss Nilsson's knowledge, dubbed in the face of the autocratic German conductor, with whom the formidable soprano engaged in many a lively argument during her career. It is a picture that, while no doubt playful in intent, fairly represents an age-old conflict between famous singers and famous conductors, whose differences are rooted not only in individual temperaments but in the history of music itself.

title: DISCOUNTS TO WOMEN VOIDED
description: ''Ladies night'' price discounts discriminate against men and must be banned, the California Supreme Court ruled Thursday in a suit brought against 11 car washes and seven bars in Orange County. The state's high court unanimously found that sex-based price discounts violated the state's civil rights law.

title: PAINTER AND THE MAID
description: DEPTHS OF GLORY A Biographical Novel of Camille Pissarro. By Irving Stone 653 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $19.95.

title:
DINING OUT;

FRENCH CUISINE AMID CHARM
description: BUFFET DE LA GARE comes loaded with charm, from the lace curtains behind its large storefront window, its high, pressed-tin ceilings and long antique bar to the earnest Gallic lilt of the gracious Annie Goulet. In the six years of Gwenael (the chef) and Annie Goulet's ownership of Buffet de la Gare, the decor and menu have changed little. While constancy is to be commended, a few appealing aspects of the scene have drifted.

title: On Language;   Name Your Poison
description: A ROSE BY ANY other name would smell as sweet, Shakespeare posited, founding a school of linguistics later led by Alfred H. S. Korzybski and popularized by Stuart Chase. Their point: the name is not the thing. A word is only a word, a label, a symbol, and we should not endow that symbol with the reverence we would pay the object, or referent, itself.

title: NEW LONNIE SMITH FACES HIS OLD CLUB
description: The man who used to hide cocaine in the pockets of his socks no longer has anything to hide. With the cocaine cloud no longer hovering over him and his adjustment to a new league complete, Lonnie Smith entered the World Series tonight pleased to be with his new team and pleased to be playing his old team.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: USA for Africa: 'We Are the World' RCA/Columbia Home Video 33 minutes. $15.95 Jane Fonda, strolling on the lot of A&M Studios in Hollywood, narrates the ''behind-the-scenes'' documentary of the all-star recording session that produced ''We Are the World.''

title: West German Unionists Protest Unemployment
description: More than 250,000 labor unionists held rallies throughout West Germany today to protest record unemployment and call for a huge job creation program.

title: KEAN, SHAPIRO CLASH ON ISSUES
description: GOVERNOR KEAN and Peter Shapiro, his Democratic opponent in the Nov. 5 election, have differing views on what has been done and what should be done in New Jersey about taxes, education and the state's water-supply system.

title: DOCTORS SAY NOBEL AIDS ANTIWAR EFFORT
description: ONE Hartford rheumatologist walked into his office to the sound of applause from his staff. Another Connecticut doctor arrived at her hospital to find medical residents volunteering to show up at meetings she had been organizing.

title: 'Egregious' Authors
description: To the Editor:

title: UTILITIES' RESPONSE TO STORM STUDIED
description: THREE weeks after the onslaught of Hurricane Gloria, Connecticut shifted its focus last week to providing Federal aid for the hardest-hit communities and evaluating how the state utilities could cope better with natural disasters in the future.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in some copies of the Sunday Sports section Oct. 6, accompanying an article on high school athletic injuries, incorrectly identified the pediatric specialist shown. He was Dr. Anthony Mansell, not Dr. David Roye.

title: LIONS LOSE AGAIN, THIS TIME TO YALE
description: Columbia's bright moments were outnumbered by the disappointing ones against Yale yesterday and the result was a familiar one for the Lions: a victory for the other team, this time, 28-12.

title: CLARK IS CARDS' MR. OCTOBER
description: Reggie Jackson, the Mr. October of baseball's past, considered the possibility that Jack Clark might become the Mr. October of baseball's present and future, and said:

title: BUENOS AIRES
description: South America explodes into spring in October, and Buenos Aires -above all, a walker's city - is one of the best cities in which to savor the approach of the Southern Hemisphere's summer. The Argentine capital is full of parks, cafes, streets of luxurious shopping, and a panoply of well-dressed Argentines who love nothing better than showing off themselves and their city to foreigners.

title: TAKING SIDES, NOT TRANSCENDING THEM, AT THE U.N.
description: The 40th session of the General Assembly is being billed as the largest gathering of world leaders in history, and more than 160 presidents and prime minsters, kings and generals, foreign ministers and special envoys have stepped to the podium in the last month to deliver close to a million words. Before the special commemorative session ends Thursday - the anniversary of the day in 1945 when the United Nations Charter became effective - they will have uttered hundreds of thousands more.

title: NYET IN BUDAPEST
description: Abruptly, Hungary's Communist regime canceled a meeting of writers that was to have coincided with a six-week review conference of the Helsinki accords on human rights. Such unofficial writer meetings were held at previous ''Helsinki'' conferences in Madrid, Stockholm and Ottawa.

title: BRODSKY DISKS ARE DUE
description: Musical Heritage Society is a split personality in more ways than two. For one thing, the operation reflects both the business and musical interests of the Nissim family, father (Albert) and sons (Jeffrey and Robert). For another, the record company both licenses recordings and produces its own. For a third, its enormous catalogue of some 3,000 recordings ranges the repertory from ancient to classical to modern, yet at the same time keeps a hand in such fields as jazz, folk music and other miscellaneous areas. Finally, while it is primarily a huge mail-order house, it also is the parent body of the relatively new Musicmasters label, a low-profile but growing presence in retail stores that is marking its fifth anniversary with a mixture of repertory that typifies the wide-ranging interests of the proprietors.

title: U.S. KEEPS OPTIONS FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: The Reagan Administration made clear this week that it intends to continue with a program to investigate the feasibility of a space-based antimissile defense as the program is ''currently structured,'' but to keep open the option of speeding development and testing of antimissile devices in the future.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We woke up and our house was shaking. We thought at first it must be the furnace.

title: GREAT LAKES SHIPPING STALLED
description: FOR the freighters tied up along the St. Lawrence Seaway last week, the sign erected by the Chamber of Commerce at the entrance to this town on the Welland Canal says it all: ''Where the ships climb the mountain.''

title: Jane Carpenter Becomes Bride
description: The wedding of Jane Louise Carpenter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John George Carpenter of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and Peter William Keegan, a son of Mrs. James Francis Keegan of Providence, R.I., and the late Mr. Keegan, took place yesterday. The Rev. Robert Collins performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: For Drivers In Philadelphia
description: THERE was good news and bad news for Philadelphia motorists last week.

title: LURES OFFERED TO HIGH TECH
description: HIGH-technology manufacturing and support companies that hope to offer new jobs tied to the Federal Aviation Administration's Technical Center here will find two ''welcome wagons'' waiting, and possibly a third if a bill to encourage such technology is approved by the State Senate.

title: JAZZ WILL BRIDGE A GENERATION GAP
description: Tomorrow night at the Public Theater, an ambitious new program of jazz commissions will show its first results. The concert will pair the Kansas City pianist Jay McShann, a contemporary of Count Basie, with a big band that mixes veteran jazz musicians and young firebrands. No matter which way the music swings, the concert symbolizes a new respect for the American jazz composer; it opens a series of three evening-length commissions by New Jazz at the Public Theater.

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES ARE SUSPENDED IN NICARAGUA
description: Nicaragua suspended most civil liberties last week after a partial relaxation that began before the country's 1984 election. President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced the crackdown on ''some political parties, news media outlets and religious institutions,'' which he denounced as Washington's ''internal allies.'' Mr. Ortega also attacked ''counter-revolutionary activities of the rightist and far-left sectors,'' apparently referring to strike calls by construction unions.

title: BOYS HARBOR OFFERS STUDY AND SPORT TO YOUTHS LIVING IN WELFARE HOTELS
description: Away from their crowded and temporary homes in the welfare hotels of New York City, hundreds of homeless children are exploring new worlds, in subjects as varied as African dance, acting and photography, at a handful of after-school centers.

title: Sarah L. Kinder Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Sarah Leslie Kinder, a daughter of Robert D. Kinder of West Simsbury, Conn., and Mrs. William E. Fortmann of Canton, Conn., to Ens. David W. Clark Jr., U.S.N.R., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of Berwyn, Pa., took place yesterday.

title: Debra Burnham Is Married in Rye
description: Congregation Emanu-El in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Debra Gail Burnham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jon M. Burnham of Scarsdale, N.Y., to William L. Hyman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Hyman of New Haven. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the ceremony.

title: DANCE: LAURIE BOOTH
description: IT took nerve to present ''Yip Yip Mix and the Twentieth Century'' on Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. But Laurie Booth and Philip Jeck had lots of nerve, and some imagination as well.

title: That Elusive Metric Mile
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nathan Milstein In Carnegie Series
description: The violinist Nathan Milstein, in his only New York recital of the season, will open a four-concert series of ''String Virtuosos'' at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, Oct. 30 at 8 P.M. The program will include his own transcriptions of Prokofiev segments from ''Tales of the Old Grandmother'' and Tchaikovsky's Lullaby from ''Mazeppa''; a Milstein composition, ''Paganiniana,'' for solo violin, and works by Bach, Handel, and Beethoven.

title: DANCE: DUNCAN RECALLED
description: PLANNING, research and care obviously went into the concert of music and dance presented on Friday at Marymount Manhattan Theater by Dancers for Isadora. Almost everything on the program touched upon the art of Isadora Duncan, and the devotion of the participants was evident.

title: POP/IN THE CLUBS
description: In the last days of the big bands, during the postwar years of the 40's, Kay Starr found a unique niche for herself as a singer with an approach that was based on two distinctively American musical forms - country music and jazz.

title: Novelist Reported Ill
description: Francoise Sagan, the French novelist, has suffered a heart attack and is in a coma in a Bogota hospital, official French sources said.

title: FROM THE GRIDIRON TO THE CLASSROOM
description: WHEN Richard Caster comes out of a huddle these days, it may be after explaining a pass pattern to one teen-ager or advising another about private school attendance.

title: KEEPING 'DOO-WOP' (AND JAZZ) ALIVE
description: In the 1950's black singers here got their start harmonizing on street corners. It was the fastest way to get an audience. None had back-up bands. While one sang the lyrics, the others backed him by singing ''doo-wop'' softly, over and over.

title: College President Named
description: Carol J. Guardo, provost and professor of psychology at the University of Hartford, has been named president of Rhode Island College, becoming the first woman chosen to head a public college in the state. Miss Guardo, who is 46 years old, will succeed the late David E. Sweet in January at Rhode Island College. The state's Board of Governors for Higher Education chose her Wednesday.

title: FOR SIMMS, PROOF IS PROGRESS
description: Once, Phil Simms wondered if anything would go right with his career. Injuries wiped out part or all of four of his first five seasons, and by then he had still not proved he was the Giants' No. 1 quarterback.

title: EXCERPTS FROM KEAN-SHAPIRO DEBATE
description: Following are excerpts from the debate last Monday at The New York Times between Governor Kean and Peter Shapiro.

title: Social Events;   Benefits for Many
description: Antiques Show Preview Oct. 23 - The seventh annual preview of the Fall Antiques Show will be held at the Passenger Terminal Pier, 48th Street and the Hudson River, from 6 P.M. to 10 P.M. The evening, a benefit for the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street, will include a buffet and cocktails, and will offer antiques hunters the first chance to buy items at one of the nation's foremost shows. About 100 dealers from around the nation will exhibit furniture, paintings and decorative accessories from the late 17th century to the 1950's. Hours for the show are noon to 10 P.M. Oct. 24, 25 and 26 and noon to 6 P.M. Oct. 27; admission is $6. Shuttle buses will operate between the museum and pier during the preview and show. Preview tickets, available at the pier or the museum, are $85, which includes two tickets good during regular show hours, or $175, which includes admission to the show on any day and the autographed book ''Windmill Weights.'' Information: 212-581-2474. Unusual Auction Oct. 23 - Probably one of the city's least known libraries is the 165-year-old Mercantile Library at 17 East 47th Street, a nonprofit organization that offers unpublished writers a place to work and to receive free research help. For its first fund-raising event, a Champagne reception at 6 P.M. will precede an auction at which bidders can compete for some unusual items. For example, one winning bidder, identified by name and occupation, will become a character in a short story by Isaac Asimov.

title: Britain's Mansell Wins South African Race
description: Nigel Mansell of Britain won the South African Grand Prix in a Williams-Honda today, just ahead of his teammate, Keke Rosberg of Finland.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: SIR GAWAIN AND THE LOATHLY LADY. By Selina Hastings. Illustrated by Juan Wijngaard. Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $13.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Lisa Goldstein's latest novel, THE DREAM YEARS (Bantam, $13.95) plays with the notion that reality is a kind of public dream. The situation that the author sets out in the opening chapters is enormously promising. The place is Paris, the year is 1924, the principal characters include Andre Breton, Louis Aragon and other writers, artists and hangers-on associated with the French Surrealist movement. It is the author's conceit that the Surrealists were not only devastating critics of the false and pretentious in the art of their day but reliable guides to effective political action and, quite literally, to the nature of the universe.

title: Oregon State Stuns Washington, 21-20
description: Andre Todd blocked a Thane Cleland punt and Lavance Northington fell on the ball in the end zone with 1 minute 46 seconds to go as Oregon State, a heavy underdog, beat the Washington Huskies, 21-20, in the Pac-10 game.

title: NOVEL GREENERY TO SPRUCE UP THE INDOOR PLANT COLLECTION
description: Why not pep up the indoor plant collection?

title: A BAND OF THE '50's REUNITES
description: PLENTY of notes get taken in classes every day at the University of Bridgeport.

title: INTREPID PHOTOGRPAHER: A TIRBUTE
description: AT THE turn of the century, Americans, hungry to learn about the rest of the world, flocked to lecture halls for a glimpse of exotic vistas or, at home, looked at three-dimensional images through a stereopticon.

title: HOW WELL PREPARED?
description: MILITARY INCOMPETENCE Why the American Military Doesn't Win. By Richard A. Gabriel. Illustrated. 208 pp. New York: Hill & Wang/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: New Orleans Rejecting Longer Mayoral Terms
description: The hopes of Ernest N. Dutch Morial for another four-year term as Mayor died today as voters rejected a proposed City Charter change that would have allowed him to run for a third consecutive term in 1986.

title: STEREO PHOTOGRAPHY, ALIVE AND WELL
description: FRED SPIRA, one of the nation's leading collectors of photography equipment, concluded a presentation on the stereoscopic camera at the Photographic Historical Society in Rochester last week with a slide that said: ''Stereo - Not the End.''

title: Gun Foes Enlist Brady's Wife
description: Sarah Brady, whose husband, James, President Reagan's press secretary, was shot in the head in the March 1981 assassination attempt on Mr. Reagan, has joined the board of Handgun Control Inc., the lobbying group has announced. Mrs. Brady will make her first public statement on the shooting later this month before a House subcommittee in New York City, it said. Mr. Brady is confined to a wheelchair.

title: TOPICS
description: THIS is the season for contemplation. I have noticed that it is quiet but not dull. There seems to be time for conscious speculation but not exhaustive activity.

title: REVITALIZED CUNY-TV REFLECTS THE CITY'S DIVERSITY
description: For more than a decade after New York City set aside a channel for the City University, CUNY had largely let it lie fallow, screening more-or-less random offerings at more-or-less random hours. But starting this academic year, the university is becoming a dynamic source of cable fare.

title: TRACKING AIDS IN THE MILITARY
description: Every man and woman in the armed forces, all 2.1 million of them, will be tested for infection by the virus that causes immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, a Pentagon official said last week. The decision reflects concern over the military implications of the virus, which can strip the body of its natural defenses against other diseases.

title: BUFFALO FOUNDATION ENJOYS NOBEL LIMELIGHT
description: As dozens of reporters and photographers began to pour into the Medical Foundation of Buffalo on Wednesday, someone asked Jane F. Griffin, a research scientist, if there had ever been a news conference there before.

title: F.B.I. Says It Has Joined Inquiry on Miami Police
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said Friday it had joined an investigation of police departments in the Miami area after charges that officers engaged in drug-related armed robberies, stole department money and sold police equipment to criminals.

title: Jane Wilton Is Married
description: Jane Louise Wilton, an associate with the New York law firm of Baer Marks & Upham, was married at the First Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday to Ronald Barry Risdon, an associate with the New York law firm of Slade & Pellman. The Rev. John Macnab performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Virgil A. Wilton of Huntington Woods, Mich., and Mr. and Mrs. John L. Risdon of Arlington, Va.

title: CIRCLE REPERTORY SEEKS TO REKINDLE PAST GLORY
description: Twenty years ago, Marshall W. Mason and Lanford Wilson inaugurated one of the American theater's most productive and enduring creative alliances when Mr. Mason staged Mr. Wilson's ''Balm in Gilead'' at Cafe La Mama Experimental Theater Club.

title: AN ARCHITECT OF CHANGE
description: ''I think the newest thing in housing construction is that most of the buildings that are going up are condominimums,'' said Samuel Paul, ''and I think developers are becoming more sensitive to design and the architects are designing housing which has much better design than we have ever had before. I think that people are willing to pay extra for a building they own partially, and they take pride in it.''

title: U.S. AGENCIES TOLD TO CUT '87 BUDGETS
description: The Office of Management and Budget has formally notified most Federal agencies that their budget requests for the fiscal year 1987 exceed ceilings set by President Reagan.

title: PENN STATE EDGES SYRACUSE
description: Penn State continued its habit of winning narrowly and preserved its undefeated record by rallying for a 24-20 victory today over Syracuse in the Carrier Dome. The Nittany Lions have now won six games this season by a total of 24 points.

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;

Business in Short
description: SERVICE AMERICA! Doing Business in the New Economy. By Karl Albrecht and Ron Zemke. (Dow Jones-Irwin, 1818 Ridge Road, Homewood, Ill. 60430, $19.95.)

title: PLAYING THE GAME CALLED REAL ESTATE
description: THE Real Estate Game has reached our town. Any number can play, but the minimum bid is $100,000. The playing pieces are suburban houses, and the owners need not move on the game board to enjoy playing.

title: The Pregnant Detective
description: I hope that ''Cagney & Lacey'' doesn't sensationalize the birth scene being planned, the way other shows have. Unfortunately, the inordinate attention being paid by the media to a biological function seems, in part, to be at blame for the precipitous rush back to the old feminine mystique - that a woman is fulfilled only when she becomes a wife and biological mother. MIRIAM GREENWALD Merion Station, Pa.

title: ROLE REVERSAL IN NEW BALLET POSES CHALLENGE TO DANCERS
description: WHEN Pamela Mitchell and Tomas Rahal take the stage Saturday at the Inter-Media Art Center in Huntington to perform ''Three of a Kind,'' something unusual in ballet will occur: A 100-pound ballerina will be supporting a 160-pound man on his toes.

title: PUTTING PEOPLE FIRST
description: RE-INVENTING THE CORPORATION Transforming Your Job and Your Company for the New Information Society. By John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene. 308 pp. New York: Warner Books. $17.50.

title:
ART;

WHERE POLITICS MEETS CREATIVITY
description: THE Fine Arts Center Gallery of the State University of New York at Stony Brook has established itself as a periodic forum for art with a political message.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, Samuel Beckett's ''Molloy'' was incorrectly described in a Sept. 29 review of Italo Calvino's ''Mr. Palomar.'' ''Molloy'' is a novel.

title:
GARDENING;

PREPARING PLANTS TO SURVIVE THE WINTER
description: WHEN October's bright, crisp days beckon us outdoors, what better way to spend an afternoon than to look after one's garden chores.

title: PENNSYLVANIA HEART RECIPIENT BEGINS RECOVERING
description: Anthony Mandia, the first recipient of the Pennsylvania State artificial heart, continued his recovery at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center here today, talking with family members and doctors.

title: 'THE FRONT PAGE' AS A MUSICAL
description: IS THERE anyone who has not seen ''The Front Page'' in one incarnation or another? If there is, now hear this:

title: CONSUMER RATES
HOPE RISES FROM LAB'S ASHES
description: IF SCIENTIFIC research is more a function of the mind's curiosity and the spirit's indomitability, then the laboratory of the National Marine Fisheries Service is still thriving here, though its walls and equipment lie in ruins.

title: A BETTER LIFE FOR EAST VILLAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: HUCK'S RIVER REVISITED
description: Interstate 80 west at the Illinois-Iowa border could have been laid out to play upon Mississippi River mystique. One by one, the roadside mile markers have been counting down the distance to the river through 150 scraggly miles of Illinois. The Mississippi is visible about a mile away, and no toll plazas, gas stations or cloverleafs distract from the view. The riverbank is mud with patches of sand; four or five Huckleberry Finns may be splashing in the shallows. As a driver starts across, a small sign on the right shoulder announces ''Mississippi River'' in the same understated type that heralds every muddy ditch from New Jersey to Oregon.

title: JAPAN TRIES MORE GROWTH AT HOME
description: The United States and other trading partners have been seeking for years ways to reduce Japan's huge trade surpluses. Among those who, like President Reagan, wish to keep world trade as free as possible, the preferred way is to sell more in an expanded Japanese market.

title: THE NEW NO. 1
description: Sam M. Walton has replaced Gordon Peter Getty, the oil heir, as the richest man in America, a special annual issue of Forbes magazine reported last week. But don't expect to see the chairman of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in a Rolls-Royce on Park Avenue or Rodeo Drive.

title: Iranian Gains Hearing On a Plea for Asylum
description: An immigration judge has ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to suspend its effort to deport an Iranian exile to his homeland.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CHRONIC CONFLICT Areas of the world dominated by chronic conflict are to be examined in a series of four lecture-luncheons by the Bronxville Adult School at 12:30 P.M. Wednesdays at the Bronxville Field Club on Locust Lane.

title: What Lombardi Really Meant
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE ISLAND CAST ADRIFT
description: FIRST, there was the cataclysm.

title: EUROPEANS ARE EAGERLY FILLING IN THEIR PROXIES FOR GENEVA
description: An unusual meeting in New York this week will provide an opportunity for the United States and its principal allies to display unity before President Reagan's encounter with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva next month. Yet, though Mr. Reagan is likely to hear in New York some advice on countering the Soviet leader's public diplomacy and on regaining the initiative in the contest for Western European opinion, strains in the alliance are apparent.

title: No Big Deal
description: Michael Blumenthal's essay, ''No Big Deal'' (About Men, Sept. 22), is a big deal indeed. Mr. Blumenthal has come a long way. It is heartening to know that men like him are beginning to hear the ''clicks'' so well described by Ms. magazine and women in the ''movement.'' Now we can begin to talk about equality between men and women.

title: STRATEGIES TO LOCK IN BENEFITS AS TAX OVERHAUL NEARS
description: PRACTITIONERS say that tax law is more art than science, and that in this year of tax-reform debate, the art is embracing fortune-telling.

title: OPERA COMPANY PREPARES OPENING
description: ''I'VE sung all my life, but never did I imagine I would head up an opera company - at least not until recently.''

title: AFTER A YEAR, DELAYS PLAGUE CITY'S HOMESTEAD LOTTERY
description: MORE than a year after 33 homesteaders won city-owned houses in a lottery, none of the houses are occupied nor do the owners have building permits to begin rehabilitation or the low-interest loans that were promised to finance it.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kellen Winslow, the San Diego Chargers' all-pro tight end who missed the second half of the 1984 season with a knee injury, was reacivated Friday and is expected to see limited action against the Minnesota Vikings today. . . . Bernie Kosar, the Cleveland Browns' rookie quarterback who led the team to a 21-6 victory against the Houston Oilers in his first start last week, will again be the starter when the team takes on the Los Angeles Raiders, according to Coach Marty Schottenheimer. He has been filling in for Gary Danielson, who injured his shoulder two weeks ago.

title: TAMING THE INSURANCE INDUSTRY'S BOOMS AND BUSTS
description: WITH premiums for business liability insurance soaring and coverage almost impossible to obtain for such high-risk areas as day-care centers, obstetrics and long-haul trucking, the commercial insurance industry is, by common agreement, in crisis. Insolvencies among state-regulated insurance companies are running at the highest rate since 1969, when the Insurance Services Office, a trade group, started keeping such records.

title: A HOARD AND A LEGACY
description: ''The Old Savoyard'' by Watteau, a red and black chalk drawing made on cream paper around 1715, is so uncharacteristic of him it startles one and so beautiful it cannot be forgotten. It is one of a great hoard of drawings acquired by the Art Institute of Chicago during the 25 years Harold Joachim was its curator of prints and drawings.

title: A NEW COMMERCIAL ROLE FOR OLD BRIDGE
description: WHEN the Garden State Parkway opened to traffic in the mid-1950's, it paved the way for intensive development of the southern New Jersey shore. The tree-lined, divided highway made it quick, easy and inexpensive for residents of Northern New Jersey to drive to the beach for the weekend, and it also allowed thousands who liked the shore to live there and work in Newark or New York.

title: COUNTY CELEBRATES UN ANNIVERSARY
description: THE county has been closely linked with the United Nations since the world organization's earliest days. Before the United Nations settled in Manhattan, Westchester was under strong consideration as its site. Forty years later, the links between Westchester and the United Nations remain strong and this month, in honor of the anniversary, a variety of exhibits and events is taking place in the county.

title: U.S. FUNDS FOR SOVIET STUDIES ARE IN JEOPARDY
description: Supporters of a $5 million State Department program for academic research on Soviet-bloc affairs are hoping to save the money, which they say was a casualty of the war on spending.

title: PEACE PRIZE WINNERS COULD BACK SAKHAROV
description: To the Editor:

title: ENGLISH MINERS: EMOTIONS STILL MIXED
description: Most coal miners in Nottinghamshire, a battleground of the yearlong national strike that ended in March, still argue that it all might have turned out differently, as a triumph rather than a debacle for their union, if only there had been a proper vote on whether to shut the mines.

title: Rutgers Drops Fifth Game in Row, 38-10
description: Rutgers, which only five weeks ago seemed destined for one of its finest seasons, today watched the 1985 campaign officially disintegrate into one of its worst.

title: EARTHQUAKE SHAKES PARTS OF 5 NORTHEASTERN STATES
description: A predawn earthquake centered just north of New York City shook parts of five states and southern Canada yesterday, rattling homes and furniture and rousing thousands of people from sleep with shocks and prolonged rumbling.

title: SHIFT IN INSPECTION OF SHIPS PROPOSED
description: A Federal health agency that inspects the sanitary conditions of cruise ships has proposed changing its inspection program, at the request of the cruise industry. Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York State said some changes would weaken the program, Many cruise liners have failed to meet the Federal Centers for Disease Control's sanitation standards in a 10-year-old program aimed at stemming outbreaks of gastrointestinal disease at sea. In the latest report, the agency failed 26 out of 64 ships inspected. Ships that fail may still operate in almost all cases, but the inspection results are made public.

title: WHEN A LAW FIRM FEELS OBLIGED TO 'FIRE' A CLIENT
description: To the Editor:

title: CLUB CONCEPT CAPTURES CONDO MARKET
description: IN the beginning was the apartment. It was a place to live, shelter pure and simple, and if it had amenities they, too, were simple, like elevators and doormen. Usually, it was in a building with an address instead of a romantic or exotic-sounding name.

title: THE NETWORKS AND ADVERTISERS TRY TO RECAPTURE OUR ATTENTION
description: Watching television is not as simple as it used to be.

title: AN AGREEMENT TO IMPORT ELECTRICITY
description: With appropriate flourishes about history but also with sighs of relief, American and Canadian power company officials and politicians last week celebrated the signing of a contract under which Quebec's electric company will export its oversupply of power to meet New England's demand in the 1990's.

title: THE U.N. 'SIMPLY MUST BE MADE TO SUCCEED'
description: Recent events have underlined the uncertain nature of the times in which we are living.

title: L.I. TREES GROW INTO CHAMPIONS
description: PEOPLE win awards for their dogs, their gardens, even their dancing. But now the State Department of Environmental Conservation plans to give awards to Long Islanders for their trees.

title: Outdoor Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT TO AVOID IN NEW-BUSINESS LOANS
description: SEVERAL years ago, Susan J. Goldstein and her husband, Robert, a veterinarian, used their own money to open Lick Your Chops, a store that sells their private label, all-natural pet foods in Yorktown, N.Y. But last year, the couple turned to outside investors for additional capital to franchise the business: They have just completed a prototype store in Westport, Conn. - a 2,200-square-foot department store for pets, complete with grocery and frozen food sections, an apothecary, a gift shop, a bookshop and a bakery that offers freshly baked herb dog biscuits and catnip crunchies.

title: GAUNTLET TO LIBERALS
description: THE COURAGE OF A CONSERVATIVE By James G. Watt with Doug Wead. 221 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: IDLED BY SHUT SEAWAY, SAILORS SET SIGHTS ON SHORE
description: ''We're not twiddling our thumbs - we're doing what we always do,'' Capt. Morgan W. McCutcheon insisted today as his ship, the Black Bay, sat stationary for the fourth day in the Welland Canal in front of a broken lock on the St. Lawrence Seaway.

title:
ANTIQUES;

INSIGHTS AT THE STATE MUSEUM
description: STRIKING insights into the role of the ceramic artist in 20th-century industrial design, as well as a glimpse into how museum exhibitions are assembled and presented, are provided by the current show at the State Museum here.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE LAND OF ULRO, by Czeslaw Milosz. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $9.95.) This is an extremely personal work of nonfiction by the winner of the 1981 Nobel Prize in Literature. The central theme is the steady decline of European civilization, because of the growth of scientific thought and the resultant divorce of spiritual and secular values. Our reviewer, Norman Davies, said last year that the book ''examines Milosz's state of mind and intellectual preoccupations,'' and it ''exudes the defiant stance, the freedom of spirit and the depth of cultural commitment of his homeland.'' Translated from the Polish by Louis Iribarne. THE CRAZY KILL, by Chester Himes. (Allison & Busby/Schocken, $5.95.) Chester Himes wrote close to 20 novels, and he is best known for his Harlem detective series. In ''The Crazy Kill'' - reportedly the author's favorite - a theft and a defenestration stir the intrepid detectives Grave Digger Jones and Coffin Ed Johnson to action. In 1959 our reviewer, Anthony Boucher, called this one of Himes's ''wild caprices of Harlem crime'' and ''a perverse blend of sordid realism and macabre fantasy-humor.''

title: Going On in the Northeast;   SCARLATTI ON BROADWAY
description: Bach and Handel have been getting most of the tricentennial attention this year. But Domenico Scarlatti, who was also born 300 years ago, will get his due on his actual birthday next Saturday in Manhattan.

title: Cloak 'n' Dagger Directions
description: A motorist looking for the Central Intelligence Agency headquarters in Langley, Va., gets some guidance when approaching from the west. A ''C.I.A.'' sign on an overpass above Route 123 clearly indicates the left turn to the well-guarded campus installation.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NOAH'S ARK. By Barbara Trapido. (Franklin Watts, $16.95.) In her second novel - following ''Brother of the More Famous Jack'' - the English author Barbara Trapido weaves a family tapestry rich in good humor, sensuality and comical human imperfection.

title: Church and Seminary: Changing Times
description: As one who spent six years at the Seminary of the Immaculate Conception in Huntington (1953-59), it was of special interest to read the recent article on the seminary's ''New Missions in a New Age.'' It is encouraging to know that the institution that we pre-Vatican II seminarians affectionately called ''The Rock'' has so much resiliency.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture and caption today with the Thursday television listings in some copies of The Guide, section 2A, appear erroneously. The picture shows an episode of ''Simon & Simon'' that was broadcast last week on CBS.

title: 16 AREAS RESTRICTED UNDER ANTARCTIC TREATY
description: Parties to the Antarctic Treaty have agreed to restrict human access to 16 areas of special scientific or environmental value in Antarctica.

title: TRAINING MANAGERS TO TAKE CHARGE
description: THE IDEA that the United States is failing to produce as many leaders as it needs seems to be accepted as gospel by numerous commentators on business. They may be right. The number of leaders may always lag behind the need for such people, and perhaps that has always been the case. But it all depends on how we define leadership - a notoriously slippery concept.

title: 13 Columbia Strikers Seized at Baker Field
description: Thirteen members of the union of clerical employees striking Columbia University were arrested yesterday on trespassing charges inside Baker Field, the school's football stadium, at the start of Columbia's homecoming game against Yale.

title: A NEW COMPANION, A NEW LIFE
description: TWO months after my husband died, I advertised in the local paper for a roommate. The advertisement, which I forced myself to compose coming home late one night on the train from New York, read as follows: ''Professional woman, aged 30, desires neat, quiet, cheerful professional woman to share one-half large country home in beautiful wooded setting.''

title: Pamela Whelihan Marries Dr. Scott Thomas Latimer
description: Pamela Whelihan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Stuart Whelihan of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to Dr. Scott Thomas Latimer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Henry Latimer of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Stephen Rourke performed the ceremony at St. Francis Episcopal Church in Potomac.

title: OPENING UP AMERICA'S TAX RETURNS
description: If the Reagan Administration has its way, Federal agencies will be given access to the tax data and information on the private insurance coverage of anyone who applies for a student loan, Medicare or other Government benefits. The White House plans to ask Congress for such authority later this month or early next year.

title: Debuts in Review;   Organist and 2 Singers
description: John Scott Musical debuts in New York ranged wildly in quality last week. Substance, indeed imposing talent, came from John Scott, a young British organist who is assistant director of music at London's St. Paul's Cathedral and winner of last year's International Bach Competition in Leipzig.

title: ADOLESCENTS SINGING, EACH TO EACH -- WHEN WE AND ELIOT WERE YOUNG
description: I AM trying to reach back to what it was in T. S. Eliot's poetry that so attracted me and my little gang of adolescent literati pals in the early 1930's. Although I don't like to think of myself as a hoary memory bank, facts must be faced. I speak of a time before ''Burnt Norton'' appeared, when Joyce's ''Ulysses'' had just been published in the United States - to the shocked fascination of Miss Hughes, my charming, encouraging English teacher in Cleveland, where in 1933-34 my stepfather had a job. The year before, we had lived in Boston, where my previous little gang and I had taken to Eliot over the dead bodies of our teachers. Free verse was still a topic of hot debate, especially on the part of people who hadn't a clue one way or another. As for me, at ages 15 and 16, I certainly thought well of the word ''free.''

title: CABARET: LARRY ADLER
description: THE renowned mouth organist Larry Adler has refined a cabaret act that blends a rhapsodic melodiousness and his own pithy reminiscences into a thoroughly satisfying evening of sophisticated entertainment. Technically, the 71-year-old instrumentalist, who is appearing at the Ballroom Theater (253 West 28th Street), Wednesdays through Saturdays through Oct. 26, is the equivalent of singers like Cleo Laine or Mel Torme, who have multioctave ranges.

title: MUSIC
description: There's more to New York musical life just Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center and, this week, some unusual programs await the adventuresome.

title: SPOTTING THE DEALS ALL OVER TOWN
description: ''SELLING is easy,'' says Arthur Shapolsky. ''The trick is to buy right.'' Spoken like a true trader, or operator, whose business it is to buy property and resell it fairly soon, sometimes even before taking title. But operators may also build their own portfolios of property, hoping for long-term appreciation. In that case the more dignified term ''investor'' might be more appropriate.

title: CINDY SHERMAN'S DARK FANTASIES EVOKE A PRIMITIVE PAST
description: Cindy Sherman's photographs - all of which portray the artist in various guises - have received an extraordinarily enthusiastic reception virtually from the time the artist arrived in New York in 1977. They apparently strike a cultural chord of widespread resonance. Her photographs are in one sense narcissistic, and in another, self-abnegating. They suggest that the decline of first-hand experience that is a consequence of today's media-saturated world is not without compensation. Look, they say, at the possibilities. Why not enjoy ourselves, trying on an endless chain of chameleonlike identities the way we try on clothes.

title: Managua Says It Broke 'Vast' Rebel Network
description: The official Sandinista newspaper Barricada reported today that security agents had broken ''a vast network'' of rebel sympathizers in the northern part of the country.

title: DEVILS RALLY FAILS IN 4-3 LOSS TO BLUES
description: Joe Mullen had a goal and an assist and Bernie Federko added two assists tonight to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 4-3 victory over the Devils.

title: Manchester United In Tie With Liverpool
description: Manchester United failed to win at home for the first time this season today but maintained its 10-point lead in the English League First Division soccer standings by salvaging a 1-1 tie with the runner-up, Liverpool.

title: A Passionate Metaphysic
description: To the Editor:

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;

Business in Short
description: TENDER OFFER: The Sneak Attack in Corporate Takeovers. By Dorman L. Commons. (University of California, $14.95.) Amid all the hoopla over the continuing wave of corporate takeovers, the feelings of the men actually doing the attacking and defending have pretty much been ignored.

title: On the Road Again
description: It's been more than a year since she revved up at a starting line and she's still recovering from five major operations, but Shirley Muldowney, who suffered a series of serious injuries in a 250-mile-an-hour crash in June 1984, says she will be back behind the wheel of a drag racer next January. ''I miss it something awful,'' said the 45-year-old hot-rod star, who is chafing at her role as spectator at the National Hot Road Association drag race finals in Pomona, Calif.

title: WHEN A LAW FIRM FEELS OBLIGED TO 'FIRE' A CLIENT
description: To the Editor:

title: PAST FORTY, AND BACK TO SQUARE ONE
description: THEY can be found poring over obscure trade magazines in the stacks of public libraries. They stare at the want ads in their newspapers. They scan career columns and books on job hunting. They do all the things that new college graduates, hankering for their first jobs, do. But their hair is gray, or even gone.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

LIFE AFTER RETIREMENT
description: ''The object of this Association shall be to get together for fellowship, diversion, and to assist each other and our community. Any man of good moral character and standing, resident of White Plains or its vicinity, who is retired from regular active business or profession, shall be eligible for membership. A prospective candidate for membership shall first be brought in as a guest of a member . . .'' - From the Constitution of the Old Guard

title: FOR RECRUITS, TRIAL BY FIRE
description: THE 31 police recruits walked into the small building hesitantly. The single room was empty except for a pile of debris in the center. The steel door made a hollow echo as it was slammed shut. The only light filtered down through a round vent in the roof.

title: A Window on Contemporary Cooking
description: TODAY'S GROANING-BOARD feasts are indebted to the great meals of the past. Through the centuries, feasts have not only celebrated cultural, religious and social events, they have mirrored changing customs and fashions.

title: CRIME CHIEFS' TIES TO CASINOS PRESSED AT TRIAL
description: Prosecutors at the conspiracy trial of nine men here say they will offer testimony next week showing that organized crime maintained hidden control of two Las Vegas gambling resorts that were reportedly purchased with loans from the teamster union's largest pension fund.

title: CATHOLICS AND JEWS: A NEW RAPPROCHEMENT
description: When the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was revising its guidelines this year on relations between Catholics and Jews, its officials spent eight months talking with Jewish leaders in an effort to make the document more sensitive to Jewish misgivings about interfaith marriage.

title: ANTECHAMBER OF DEATH
description: BOULEVARD DES MISERES The Story of Transit Camp Westerbork. By Jacob Boas. Illustrated. 169 pp. Hamden, Conn.: Archon Books/ The Shoe String Press. $22.50.

title: Blast at L.I. Abortion Clinic
description: Two gasoline bombs were thrown into an abortion clinic here, causing $8,000 in damage but no injuries, the Suffolk County arson squad said today. Detective Vincent Ciappetta, a spokesman, said the blast occurred at about 6:25 A.M. at the Coram Woman's Center at 356 Middle Country Road. No one was in the building at the time and no witnesses have been found, he said.

title: MENUHIN TO PERFORM IN NEWARK BENEFIT
description: TO RAISE money to repair the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart here, the Cathedral Symphony Orchestra, under Thomas Michalak, will give a benefit concert next Sunday at 3 P.M., with Yehudi Menuhin as violin soloist.

title: FOR U.N.'S BIG WEEK, LEADERS BY THE SCORE
description: The Nicaraguan leader, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, will answer questions on ''The Phil Donahue Show.''

title: ZONING RULES LIMIT HOME SATELLITE TELEVISION DISHES
description: LAST spring, when Dirk Francois of Windsor was considering the purchase of a home satellite television receiver, he decided to check with Town Hall to determine if there were zoning restrictions on the antennas.

title: A WEAKER DOLLAR WON'T SLOW IMPORTS
description: THE agreement between the United States and four other industrial nations to weaken the dollar through intervention in exchange markets was clearly related to the rising American trade deficit and mounting protectionist pressures in Congress. While the agreement marks a major shift in the Administration's economic policy, the intended result - to cut the deficit - is not likely to be achieved. The reason: The strong dollar was not the primary cause of the trade deficit. Thus, even a significant drop in the dollar's value will not substantially reduce the trade imbalance.

title: Iranian Warship Attacked
description: An Iraqi naval attack on an Iranian warship near Iran's Nowruz oilfield set off explosions and fed a fire at the installation, which was already ablaze, the official Iraqi press agency said today. There was no confirmation of the statement by other sources. Nowruz is 62 miles northwest of the damaged oil terminal at Kharg island, which has been attacked repeatedly since Aug. 4.

title: TOP PASSING GAME AGAIN AT MIAMI
description: Vinny Testaverde of Elmont, L.I., and Sewanhaka High School's Class of 1981 battled Bernie Kosar for the starting quarterback's job at Miami until the week before the 1983 season opener when Coach Howard Schnellenberger selected Kosar. Kosar then helped Miami upset Nebraska in the Orange Bowl to be voted No. 1 in the nation in both news-agency polls.

title: New Peace Talks on Uganda Are Pushed Back by 6 Days
description: A fourth round of peace talks in Kenya between the military Government of Uganda and the rebels has been rescheduled for Oct. 28, President Daniel arap Moi said today. The talks had been scheduled to start Tuesday.

title: KNICKS BETTER BY JUST A BIT
description: SO you waited in line, or pulled some strings, and got season tickets for the Knicks. Hottest ticket in town, you said to yourself. A return to the glory days. Madison Square Garden will be the place to be on those nights when Ewing & Company are blocking shots and slam-dunking their way into the playoffs, right? Maybe you'll sit next to Woody and Mia or Peter Falk.

title: 2 Jerseyans in Plane Missing On Flight From Pennsylvania
description: About 100 air and ground searchers combed northern New Jersey and northeastern Pennsylvania today for a missing single-engine plane with two men from Ridgefield Park, N.J., aboard.

title: NO SHORTAGE OF BREEDERS' CUP HOPEFULS
description: A year ago, as the first Breeders' Cup races approached, a cup official had carefully drawn and ruled a blank sheet of paper to write down the entries, leaving spaces for the maximum of 14 for each race. A selection committee and a complex point system were in place to decide which 14 horses to let into each rich race, some of which seemed sure to attract overflow fields that would have to be limited.

title: Conversion Rites
description: The Reagan White House, eager to continue demonstrating to the nation that a major political realignment is under way, has scheduled another group induction rite for state and local officials who are recent converts to the Republican Party. Later this month, two or three dozen former Democrats, a number of them from the South, are coming to Washington for a personal laying-on-of-hands by President Reagan and to pose for pictures. One senior White House aide said it would be ''a naturalization ceremony.''

title: TRIAL OPENING IN ARIZONA IN ALIEN SANCTUARY CASE
description: It started obscurely with a chance encounter on a hot, dusty day in July 1981 when a friend of Jim Corbett's picked up a hitchhiker on the outskirts of Nogales, just north of the border.

title: The Worst Enemy
description: Those Americans who consider it illicit and unwarranted for the U.S. to intervene militarily in the affairs of Central American nations have a heavy burden to bear in Nicaragua's Sandinista Government. Its heavy-handed suspension of civil liberties has made that burden much harder to bear.

title: Carl T. Gossett Jr., 61, Dies; Photographer for The Times
description: Carl T. Gossett Jr., a staff photographer for The New York Times for nearly 40 years, died yesterday of liver failure at his home in Leonia, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: World Bank Possibilities
description: The Clausen developments set rumor mills rolling. Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve's chairman and the object of much speculation, said last week that he had refused the Clausen job.

title: Mother, 33, Concedes Drowning 2 Children
description: Fumiko Kimura, who drowned her two children and attempted to drown herself, pleaded no contest Friday to a charge of voluntary manslaughter and faces a maximum of 13 years in prison.

title: The Ferry That Couldn't Help Being Adrift
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR DIVORCED COUPLES, FRIENDSHIP NOT A RARITY
description: A new and more complex portrait of the continuing relationships of divorced spouses has emerged from a meeting of the therapists who treat many of the nation's couples and families.

title: DAIMLER-BENZ SETS DIVERSIFICATION
description: Last week's announcement by Daimler-Benz A.G. that it had bought 24.9 percent of AEG and would seek control of the electronics company is the latest step in a diversification program to reduce its dependence on automotive products.

title: U.S. CANDY MAKERS STRUGGLING
description: Americans ate more sweets last year than they had in any year of the past decade, but domestic candy makers still have a slightly sour taste in their mouths these days.

title: Sutter to Be Out 2 Weeks
description: Brent Sutter, the high-scoring Islander center, will undergo another examination on his left shoulder tomorrow night before the Islanders' game. The full extent of his injury will not be known until then.

title: TAX-EXEMPT MARKET IS BUSY
description: In advance of possible changes in Federal tax laws, securities dealers have been selling record amounts of tax-exempt bonds and expect the supply to remain heavy through the end of the year.

title: MARATHON CHALLENGES DISABLED RUNNERS
description: Brian Froggett of Dagwood, New Zealand, arrived in New York early for Sunday's marathon. He wanted to compete in yesterday's tune-up race, the five-mile New York City Marathon Computer Run, and to meet his coach for the first time.

title: DEBUSSCHERE: STILL A STRAIGHT SHOOTER
description: WHEN the Knicks acquired Patrick Ewing last May through the first-ever lottery in the National Basketball Association, the team's executive vice president-director of basketball operations, Dave DeBusschere, reacted like a quiz-show contestant who had hit the jackpot. He shook his fist, grinned and carried on as if Monty Hall had told him there was good news behind door No. 2.

title: Vital Checks and Balances in Pretoria's Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: What Will Tomorrow's Literacy Require?
description: To the Editor:

title: Volcker to Talk With Bankers
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, will meet privately with leading bankers here Monday to discuss a plan to help debtor nations service their loans, bank industry officials said today.

title: Peru Rejects I.M.F. Visit
description: Peru's Government, which has criticized the International Monetary Fund for imposing what it terms colonial-style policies, has announced that it will not receive visits by I.M.F. missions.

title: Eagles Come Back To Beat Cowboys
description: Ron Jaworski's touchdown pass to Kenny Jackson in the fourth quarter today gave the Philadelphia Eagles a 16-14 victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

title: ERSKINE CALDWELL, AT 81, IS RECOGNIZED IN GEORGIA
description: Last month in rural Ben Hill County, there were teas and lectures and even a Sunday picnic in his honor. But Erskine Caldwell, author and native Georgian, said there was one woman at the county library who wanted nothing to do with him.

title: PAPANDREOU AUSTERITY PLAN ATTACKED
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou will be spending this week in Athens defending his economic austerity measures, which are causing political dissent and labor unrest, rather than celebrating the 40th anniversary of the United Nations in New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1985
description: Companies

title: MUSIC: ROBERT COHEN
description: ROBERT Cohen, a young British cellist with a burgeoning solo career, gave a recital Sunday at the 92d Street Y that was respectable throughout, but became something more than that in the serenade and finale of Debussy's magical cello sonata.

title: Meager Supply of Issues Expected
description: The credit markets continue to wait for Congress to raise the Federal debt ceiling and thereby unleash a torrent of new Treasury issues. But Congressional action is not expected until later this month, leaving a scanty supply of Treasury notes and bonds.

title: Comptroller Nominee Is Expert on Bank Law
description: Robert L. Clarke is a lawyer, but when he was growing up in Hobbs, N.M., he thought seriously about becoming a banker.

title: CONCERT: SHAKUHACHI
description: KATSUYA YOKOYAMA, one of Japan's most renowed practitioners of the shakuhachi, a 21-inch-long bamboo flute with five finger holes, made the instrument breathe and sigh like wind whistling through the eaves, in his concert at the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium at Asia Society on Friday evening. In addition to performing solo pieces Mr. Yokoyama played duets with the koto player, Susumu Miyashita, and with a second shakuhachi player, Bertil Chikudo Petersson.

title: Who Was That?
description: If, despite televised warnings, you leave home without your credit card, it helps if you have a familiar face.

title: JACK CLARK'S LUCKY HIT
description: WITH two out, Willie McGee on second and the Cardinals trailing, 2-0, in the ninth inning last night, Jack Clark strode toward the batter's box - a slugger who had a candy bar named for him even before he was born.

title: Six Gulf States To Meet Today
description: Oil ministers from the six states of the Gulf Cooperation Council will meet here Monday for talks aimed at increasing oil policy coordination, officials said today.

title: Quick-Ending Bouts
description: This week's wishful-thinking award goes to the promoters of a heavyweight bout between Robert Coley and Mike Tyson in Atlantic City on Friday night. The bout is scheduled for eight rounds, which appears to be six and a half too many.

title: Access to the Air
description: Do televised campaign debates limited to the Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates constitute unconstitutional discrimination against candidates of other parties? This persistent question will be argued before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today in a case that could have profound impact on national campaigns beginning in 1988.

title: MARYLAND EXTENDS STUDY OF CHASE DEAL
description: The Maryland Senate adjourned early today before it could vote on a plan to let the Chase Manhattan Bank buy three ailing thrift institutions, but both legislative chambers are scheduled to meet Monday, Chase's deadline for the transaction.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: UNITED NATIONS WEEK - The period officially proclaimed ''United Nations Week'' by Mayor Koch gets into full swing today as the General Assembly is scheduled to hear from no fewer than 20 speakers. President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua is to speak first. Others scheduled to speak are: President Abdou Diouf of Senegal, President Pal Losonczi of Hungary, President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon and King Moshoeshoe II of Lesotho, Prime Minister Steingrimur Hermannsson of Iceland, Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany and Foreign Minister Mochtar Kusumaatamadja of Indonesia.

title: Karen Lynn Friedman Weds Paul P. Stewart
description: Karen Lynn Friedman, a certified public accountant for Marks Shron & Company in Great Neck, L.I., and Paul Phillip Stewart, an associate in the law firm of Rivkin, Radler, Dunne & Bayh in Garden City, L.I., were married yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein performed the ceremony.

title: THE THEATER: 'TOMORROW'S MONDAY'
description: BROADWAY rediscovered Paul Osborn in 1980, when an all-star revival proved that his all-but-forgotten 1939 comedy of small-town life, ''Morning's at Seven,'' remained as vivid and anxiety-ridden as an Edward Hopper canvas. Now it's apparently Off Broadway's turn to champion this veteran American playwright.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Kansas City, Mo., Friday on Missourians' excitement over the ''I-70'' World Series misstated the period between the departure of the Browns from St. Louis and the arrival of the Athletics in Kansas City. It was one year. The dispatch also misstated the year the Royals succeeded the Athletics; it was 1969.

title: Topics;   Uncommon Carriers Railing at the Deficit
description: What Congress says it wants is to balance the budget by 1991. What does Congress do? Alerted by Representative Fred Eckert of Rochester, we note the case of Amtrak, the national passenger railroad.

title: WALTRIP IS FIRST
description: Darrell Waltrip slipped past Ron Bouchard to take the lead 31 laps from the end, then moved away to an easy today in the Nationwise 500 Grand National stock car race.

title: AN UNHAPPY LIST LENGTHENS
description: Near the end of his 13th season with the Kansas City Royals, Frank White has been here long enough to have all the major disappointments filed away in his mind.

title: Blue Bonnet Enlists Talking Cows for TV
description: In the wonderful land of margarine and butter, the only category that is showing growth is the one that combines the two. And that category was pioneered by a butter organization, Land O'Lakes.

title: SIZABLE ADDITIONS PROMISE A HIGHER LEVEL OF PLAY
description: BIG, bigger, biggest.

title: Plane Carrying Ray Charles Has an Accident on Landing
description: A 4-engine plane carrying the singer Ray Charles and his band ran off a runway while landing in heavy rain and slid down a hill into a cornfield, injuring the pilot, officials said Saturday.

title: A Welcome Reunion With a Respected Teacher
description: Joseph Fischer had anticipated the moment for two weeks. When it came yesterday, at the Marsha Stern Talmudical Academy-Yeshiva University High School for Boys in Washington Heights, Mr. Fischer said it was a thrill.

title: Iranian Oil Exports
description: President Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei of Iran said Friday that Iran could export more than four million barrels of oil a day after overcoming ''slight problems'' in loading at Kharg Island in the northern Persian Gulf. Iraqi air attacks since mid-August have damaged the terminal. But foreign diplomats in Teheran said exports have been around normal - 1.4 million to 1.5 million barrels a day - this month.

title: Workfare Programs Don't Shame the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: WORKING AT HOME: THE PITFALLS
description: HOME has always been where the heart is. Nowadays, it can be where the office is too -where walking a dog competes with running a computer program, and the item being ironed out can as easily be a contract as a shirt. ''Working at home means having to distinguish between work and home,'' said Richard Rutkin, a clinical psychologist in Manhattan who has addressed issues such as work morale. ''It also means balancing work life and home life.''

title: GROGAN AGAIN IN KEY ROLE
description: Steve Grogan, who two weeks ago was a forgotten athlete, came back to beat the Jets once more today, and it was his incisive play-calling as much as his passing and running that won the game for the New England Patriots.

title: Lendl Defeats Leconte in Final
description: Ivan Lendl won the $285,000 Australian Indoor tennis championship today, defeating fifth-seeded Henri Leconte in the final, 6-4, 6-4, 7-6.

title: Moving Together
description: Few members of Congress can resist the political urge to join as many organizations as possible, even at the cost of founding new ones, and the compulsion seems to be staff-infectious. In the House of Representatives, there are already associations of Administrative Assistants and of Press Secretaries at whose meetings tips on professional technique and a certain amount of gossip are exchanged.

title: PEN EVENT STARS BUCKLEY AND IRVING
description: William F. Buckley Jr. and John Irving offered pages from their novels and their lives, sprinkled with a few political musings, to an audience at the Royale Theater last night in the third PEN Celebration - two separate talks by the authors that illustrated the different ways in which their fiction evolves.

title: OLD LAW, BIG HERO, BAD SHAPE
description: The Legislature has refused to endorse Gov. Dick Thornburgh's plan to turn state liquor stores over to private enterprise, so Robert Weaver of Elkton, Md., will probably just go on checking the files at the sheriff's office for when Pennsylvania agents plan to stake out his place.

title: EWING IS CRYING FOUL
description: On the morning after, an ailing Patrick Ewing was still convinced that the incident that caused him to be ejected from the Knicks exhibition victory over Indiana Saturday night at Madison Square Garden was not his fault.

title: Q&A
description: QUESTION: I recall Don Larsen as such a good-hitting pitcher that he sometimes was called upon as a pinch-hitter. How did Larsen do at the plate for the Yankees during his perfect game in the 1956 World Series?

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HEMINGWAY: A Biography. By Jeffrey Meyers. 644 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $27.50.

title: Tax Amnesty Program Has Raised $2 Million
description: New York's tax amnesty program starts Nov. 1, but nearly $2 million is in the state's treasury already from those seeking a clean slate with the tax collector.

title: 4 KILLED NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: A white motorist was reported today to have shot dead a mixed-race man who stoned his car near here Saturday, and three other people were killed during the weekend in political violence around the Cape region.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

High Expectations
description: Sure, there has been enormous publicity leading up to his pro debut next Saturday against Philadelphia, but Patrick Ewing is far from the first wildly coveted center subjected to that kind of pressure. Here's how some of the others fared as they made their bow in the National Basketball Association:

title: GOVERNMENT AS A PATRON OF DESIGN
description: The Founding Fathers wanted to embody in the architecture of their capital city a classical simplicity, a concept that is reflected in the Capitol and the White House.

title: Pensacola Open Won by Edwards
description: Danny Edwards posted a 1-stroke victory in the $300,000 Pensacola Open today, while Don Pooley captured the 1985 Vardon Trophy as the golfer with the lowest average score on the PGA Tour.

title: CRAXI EXPECTED TO TRY TO FORM CABINET
description: Politically strengthened by a warm letter of conciliation from President Reagan, Italy's caretaker Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, today seemed virtually certain of being asked to form a new government.

title: BALL, IN A DRAMATIC ROLE, IS RETURNING TO TV
description: Lucille Ball is standing in the middle of her living room gazing into a mirror and complaining that her red hairdo has too much spray in it.

title: KOCH TO REQUEST MORE U.S. HELP ON AIDS COSTS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that treatment of AIDS patients was ''breaking the bank'' of municipal governments and charitable institutions, and he called on the Federal Government to pick up more of the costs.

title: RANGERS STOP CANUCKS, 4-3
description: On Saturday night the player rested, and last night the player excelled. Kelly Miller scored the first two goals of his National Hockey League career, one to help start the Rangers off well and the other to make up for an advantage that they had let slip away.

title: Plan to Balance Budget Assailed by Democrats
description: Representative David R. Obey, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said Saturday that the Senate plan to balance the budget by 1991 was a ''mindless threat'' to economic growth.

title: A MAYOR CONTRADICTED
description: When Mayor W. Wilson Goode appointed a commission to investigate the May 13 confrontation with the radical group Move, the panel's independence was immediately criticized.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Eugene P. Beard has been named executive vice president, finance and operations of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Miss Wilamowski Becomes a Bride
description: Doris Wilamowski, a psychotherapist in Manhattan, was married yesterday to J. David Dainow, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Yuter, Rosen & Dainow. Rabbi Lavy Becker, a cousin of the bridegroom, and Judge David B. Saxe of New York City Civil Court performed the ceremony at the New York home of Dr. and Mrs. Jonathan Korn, friends of the couple.

title: JOB RULE ON WELFARE AID TO BE APPLIED IN PHASES
description: A New York State program to require welfare recipients to take jobs or job training is to begin next month on a modest scale that will affect only new applicants for aid in New York City, state officials said yesterday.

title: REFERENDUM IS SOUGHT ON SHELTERING FAMILIES
description: The Coalition for the Homeless has begun a campaign for a referendum vote that would require the city to upgrade its shelters for homeless families.

title: Juvenile-Crime Data Lacking
description: More than half the states keep no record of juvenile offenses, even though many recent crime-fighting initiatives have been aimed at singling out potential career criminals, the Justice Department said today.

title: THE CITY'S TRAFFIC CHIEF RIDES HERD IN STREETS OF MIDTOWN
description: Oh, to be Sam Schwartz on a rainy Friday in midtown when trucks are doubled-parked, intersections are beginning to lock, horns are tearing at the nerves and drivers are using words no dictionary would ever list.

title: Baldrige's Antitrust Campaign
description: Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige has stepped out alone on a couple of issues, such as his proposal to merge the Commerce Department and the special trade representative's office, and they have gotten nowhere. But he may be making headway with his campaign to relax the antitrust laws.

title: AMERICANS, AT A FORUM IN FRANCE, PUT FORWARD CASE FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: Many Europeans, and especially the French, have been highly skeptical and even publicly opposed to the American antimissile program that President Reagan calls the Strategic Defense Initiative, and it was clearly with awareness of that skepticism that a team of American officials made the Administration's case in a two-day public debate here last week.

title: NBC'S 'LOVE ON THE RUN'
description: CAN a seemingly intelligent woman suddenly turn stupid and still remain sympathetic? Well, NBC has managed to get Stephanie Zimbalist, an always attractive actress, to play such a character in ''Love on the Run,'' a TV movie at 9 tonight, but the effort remains unconvincing.

title: Seagram Trims to 3 Agencies
description: THE House of Seagram, the American arm of the world's largest distiller and wine merchant, has just cut back to three ad agencies from a roster of seven. Still playing in the big ball game are Ogilvy & Mather and Doyle Dane Bernbach, both publicly held international agencies, and Mingo-Jones Advertising, specialists in promoting to the black community.

title: Ending An Illusion
description: The South African Government has performed a useful service that should be acknowledged. Over these last days and weeks it has finally disposed of the illusion that it is ready for serious change - political change - in the apartheid system.

title: Fire Damages Collection At California Library
description: Fire climbed through an elevator shaft at the Huntington Library Art Gallery and Botanical Gardens on Thursday, heavily damaging a 208-year-old painting and four pieces of antique furniture.

title: ARTIFICAL-HEART PATIENT SUFFERS SLOW SPEECH
description: Anthony Mandia, the first recipient of a new type of artificial heart, suffered a ''brief neurologic event'' today, 30 minutes of slowed speech, according to Dr. John W. Burnside, a spokesman for the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center.

title: LOBBYISTS LINE UP THE POWER ON ARMS FOR JORDAN
description: Dennis M. Neill, who once lobbied on Capitol Hill for the Agency for International Development, now represents the interests of Jordan. So when King Hussein came to Washington recently, Mr. Neill was ''all over the place,'' as one Congressional staff member put it, promoting an Administration plan to sell $1.9 billion in advanced arms to the kingdom on Israel's eastern flank.

title: Inquiry Is Planned on Jet Fire
description: Investigators will try to determine whether an engine fire that forced an Eastern Airlines DC-9 jetliner to make an emergency landing in Tampa, Fla., Saturday is related to two similar engine failures, an Eastern spokesman said today.

title: Canaday Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for John Canaday, former chief art critic of The New York Times, is to be held Thursday at 11 A.M. in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. Mr. Canaday died July 19. He was 78 years old.

title: A 'Jewel' in the Water
description: Sanitation workers have been called on to haul away a lot of things: broken-down machinery, dead animals, abandoned cars. But recently the department was stumped briefly by a call from Anthony LaBella of Queens.

title: CARDS RALLY IN 9TH TO BEAT ROYALS, 4-2
description: In a nightmarish repeat of the fourth game of the American League pennant playoff, Charlie Leibrandt lost first a shutout and then the game in the ninth inning tonight in the second game of the World Series.

title: At Harvard Law, Turmoil Is an Outward Sign of Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Colleges Should Divest
description: The Reagan Administration's limited sanctions against South Africa are beginning to take effect, but many American individuals want to exert still more pressure on the apartheid system. One of the most effective ways for them to do so is to encourage educational institutions to divest themselves of stock in corporations that do business in South Africa.

title: Maryland Retains Ban On Steep-Slope Mining
description: A coal industry effort to repeal Maryland's ban on steep-slope coal mining, the only such prohibition in the country, failed after an intense campaign in the General Assembly.

title: ZIA HOPES TO EASE FRICTION WITH INDIA
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan said today that he hoped his meeting with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India on Wednesday would ''pave the way for a better, friction-free relationship'' between the two countries.

title: Publisher's Net Is Up
description: Affiliated Publications Inc., a communications company that is the parent of The Boston Globe, said that its third-quarter earnings rose 14.3 percent, to $7.2 million, or 59 cents a share, from $6.3 million, or 52 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose 8.6 percent, to $88.6 million, from $81.6 million a year earlier. In reporting the results on Friday, the company cited a gain from the sale of two Springfield, Mass., radio stations.

title: A FIRE CAPTAIN WHO SAVED ONE OF HIS MEN DIES
description: A city fire captain died yesterday of severe burns that he suffered in a Bronx apartment after he pushed one of his men to safety.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 21, 1985: *2*MONDAY Burlington Northern LubrizolCorp Eastern Utils Assoc Mellon Bank Corp GAF Corp Wells Fargo Mtg & Eq Johnson & Johnson Whirlpool Corp Jorgensen (Earle M) *2*TUESDAY Allied Stores Pogo Producing Amoco Corp Public Service Co NM Ball Corp Rollins Inc Bearings Inc Rorer Group Brockway Inc Rubbermaid Inc Cilcorp Inc Santa Fe So Pacific Crompton & Knowles Southwest Airlines Fedders Corp Southwestern Pub Serv Gannett Co Tambrands Inc Kennametal Inc Thrifty Corp Norfolk Southern Corp Veeco Instruments Norwest Corp *2*WEDNESDAY AMP Inc North Amer Philips Alltel Corp Philips Indus Baker Intl SCANA Corp Belo (AH) Corp Smith Intl Inc Ceco Industries Inc SmithKline Beckman Eaton Corp Stanley Works Edison Bros Stores Sybron Corp Hughes Tool Todd Shipyards Inland Steel Transworld Corp (NY) Jostens Inc Union Carbide Minnesota Pwr &Lt Wisconsin Elec Pwr *2*THURSDAY Alcan Aluminum McNeil Corp Beverly Enterprises Morton-Thiokol Inc Central & SW Corp Nalco Chemical Coachmen Industries Natl Distillers & Chem Cross (AT) Co Niagara Mohawk Pwr Donnelley & Sons Nicolet Instrument Dravo Corp Norton Co Eastern Gas & Fuel Outboard Marine Corp Empire District Elec Parker Hannifin Ethyl Corp Potomac Elec Pwr Handy & Harman Questar Corp Iowa-Ill G & E RLC Corp Lawter Intl Sonat Inc Libbey-Owens-Ford Standard Oil Ohio Mark Controls Sun Chemical Corp Martin-Marietta Corp *2*FRIDAY Carter-Wallace Loctite Corp Central La Elec McDonnell Douglas Delta Air Lines (Del) Mobil Corp Dexter Corp Monsanto Co Dyco Petroleum Corp Rollins Environmental Federal Signal Rowan Cos Ferro Corp Scotty's Inc GATX Corp Snap-On Tools Harland(John H) & Co Stewart-Warner Corp Harris Corp (DEL) Tyler Corp Holly Sugar Corp Vulcan Materials Indiana Gas Co Warnaco Inc Kysor Industrial

title: Donna Sue Glickstern Wed To Albert W. Tanenbaum
description: Donna Sue Glickstern, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Glickstern of Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday to Albert Wise Tanenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Jerome Tanenbaum Jr. of Dumas, Ark. Rabbi Sanford E. Saperstein performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Am in Merrick, L.I.

title: A BATTLE FOR BREVITY IS WON, BUT THE BIG GUNS LIE AHEAD
