description: Time is on everyone's mind as the United Nations heads into its final week of 40th anniversary celebration. And no one is more concerned about time than Jaime de Pinies, the President of the General Assembly.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1985
description: International

title: Accounts
description: Brothers International Corporation to Al Paul Lefton Inc., for office typewriters.

title: Foreign Firms Vie for Tokyo Seats
description: With the way finally clear for foreign securities firms to become members of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, more than a dozen firms are expected to apply for seats on Monday.

title: Lester Wigler, Banker, Weds Susan Ambrose
description: Susan Faith Ambrose, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Ambrose of Pinehurst, N.C., was married yesterday to Lester Wigler, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Warren Wigler of New York. Rabbi Lawrence Siegel and the Rev. Walter Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Cobb's Mill Inn in Weston, Conn.

title: CORRECTION
description: A selection on Friday from the writings of Claude Simon, winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, omitted the names of the translator and the publisher of the excerpted works - ''The Flanders Road,'' ''The Palace,'' ''Histoire'' and ''The Battle of Pharsalus.'' The translator is Richard Howard; the books were published by George Braziller.

title: JETS' STREAK ENDS AT 5
description: With an injured Freeman McNeil wanting to play but merely a sideline cheerleader who was shaking teammates' hands as they came off the field, the Jets' five-game winning streak ended today where other bad memories remain for them.

title: 9 Wounded by Gunfire In New Caledonia
description: Nine people were taken to a hospital in Noumea today after outbreaks of gunfire in the French territory in the South Pacific, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Mitel Picks Leader And Shifts Officers
description: The Mitel Corporation, a major Canadian maker of telecommunications equipment that has been experiencing severe financial difficulties, has announced sweeping changes in its top management.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Friday misstated the amount of the BankAmerica Corporation's nonperforming loans as of June 30. It was $3.58 billion.

title: Elizabeth Schiff Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Eugenie Gordon Schiff, a daughter of Mrs. C. Leonard Gordon of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Herbert Schiff of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Stuart Kaufman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Kaufman of New York and East Hampton. Rabbi Hillel Friedman performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: ADAMS, AT LAST, HEARS CHEERS
description: Surrounded by celebration, George Adams, the Giants' rookie running back, sat in front of his locker, smiling the widest smile of his young career.

title: Tatham-Laird Hired By Butter Industry
description: Meanwhile the promoters of the high-priced spread have switched their agencies, and the winner is Tatham-Laird & Kudner in Chicago, which will be taking on generic butter promotion in behalf of the United Dairy Industry Association in Chicago and the National Dairy Board in Washington. The budget will be about $12 million.

title: RECITAL: SIBELIUS QUARTET
description: FROM the beginning of the Jean Sibelius Quartet's Saturday night recital at Merkin Concert Hall, it was obvious that this was a first-class ensemble. The four members - the violinists Yoshiko Arai and Jaakko Vuornos, the violist Jouko Mansnerus, and the cellist Seppo Kimanen - play with a cultivated musicality, rock-steady intonation and a sense of collegial give and take.

title: JAPAN PLAN IS CRITICIZED ON HOUSING AND CREDIT
description: Japan's steps to spur economic growth, announced with some fanfare early last week, are unlikely to produce as much growth as the Government hopes for, according to economists and industry specialists here.

title: NEW FORAY IN THE WAR ON TRAFFIC
description: Traffic in New York City is horrendous, according to city officials, transportation analysts, traffic engineers, taxi drivers and other fuming motorists. And the predictions are that it will get worse.

title: Topics;   Uncommon Carriers Care in the Air
description: With more than a dozen accidents and 1,400 deaths worldwide this year, the airline industry has had to work overtime reminding the public that commercial air travel nonetheless remains safe. Now that effort has been dealt a new setback.

title: COURSE RECORD SET IN CHICAGO
description: By the time Steve Jones rounded a corner near the finish line in America's Marathon/Chicago, the only indication he had of how fast he was running was the crowd's frantic urgings. So he kicked and pumped his arms, driving across the finish line 2 seconds short of a world record.

title: NEW ORLEANS VOTE REBUFFS MAYOR
description: The hopes of Ernest N. Dutch Morial for a chance at a third term as Mayor of this city were dashed Saturday by voters' rejection of a proposal to change the City Charter to allow a mayor to serve more than two consecutive terms.

title: FETE FOR U.N.: AN EXHIBITION OF DIPLOMACY
description: Olof Palme got lost among the Picassos and Monets.

title: FOR CARDINALS, IT WASN'T OVER
description: ''I guess we're from the school of Yogi Berra,'' Tito Landrum said afterward, placing the St. Louis Cardinals in time and history. ''It ain't over till it's over.''

title: A LIBERAL AND A SKEPTIC/David Robert Peterson
description: David Peterson is the first Premier of Ontario in nearly 42 years who has not been a member of the Progressive Conservative Party. Since being sworn in on June 26, he has made some sharp turns from the policies of his Tory predecessors, but has also demonstrated some strong continuities.

title: BankAmerica: Upbeat View
description: NEW YORK CITY'S major banks announced generally robust results last week for their third quarter, and a number of Wall Street analysts are recommending purchase of selected stocks in this group.

title: AFTER A LULL, THE GYPSY MOTH STRIKES HARD IN THE NORTHEAST
description: After three years of decline, the gypsy moth population of the Northeast rose sharply this year, causing almost twice as much damage to trees as in 1984, according to state and Federal forestry experts.

title: Bernice Feuer Is Wed To Kenneth Garbade
description: Bernice Feuer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Feuer of Bayside, Queens, and Kenneth Douglas Garbade, the son of Louise Garbade of New Hyde Park, L.I., and the late Arthur Garbade, were married yesterday. Rabbi Jonah Bender performed the ceremony at the Fox Hollow Inn in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Ownership in Turkey
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has become the first international agency to gain a majority position in a Turkish ad agency - Pars, Turkey's largest, with which it has been associated for 11 years. It has acquired 51 percent of the shop, which like itself is a Coca-Cola agency. The move was made possible by an easing of Turkish law.

title: Whale in River Appears To Show Distress Sign
description: A humpback whale that wandered into the Sacramento River almost a week ago was seen smacking its tail on the water's surface Saturday, apparently a sign of distress, a wildlife official said today.

title: Cheers for Paul Volcker
description: They cheered Paul Volcker the other day when he said he's not leaving the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve Board. Confirming the rumors that the White House wanted to shunt him off to the presidency of the World Bank, he told a Washington meeting of foreign financiers that, when asked, ''my answer was 'no.' '' It was the right answer for a mischievous question.

title: Bridge; India Orders a Withdrawal From World Team Contest
description: Political considerations had a last-minute impact on the 1985 World Team Championship, which began here this morning. Five hours before it was to depart, the Indian Open Team, which would have had to compete against Israel, was forced by the Indian Government to withdraw.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Bears vs. Green Bay Packers, at Chicago. The Bears (6-0) are looking like the old Monsters of the Midway. Last week Chicago beat the defending Super Bowl champions, the San Francisco 49ers, 26-10, avenging last year's defeat in the conference title game.

title: BEATRICE REJECTS BUYOUT BID
description: The board of directors of the Beatrice Companies unanimously rejected today a $4.9 billion acquisition bid from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout specialists.

title: COMMONWEALTH LEADERS AGREE ON SANCTIONS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA
description: Commonwealth leaders agreed tonight to impose limited economic sanctions against South Africa and to set up a group to try to persuade the Pretoria Government to negotiate with black leaders on ending apartheid.

title: LOTS MORE FUN FROM TOP TO BOTTOM
description: FOR one regretful moment, it seemed as if it had really happened. Nearly four decades after Ralph (Sky) Siewert became the first 7-footer to play professional basketball, it looked like the game had finally been overtaken by redwoods, giraffes and human high-wire acts. When the National Basketball Association season opens this Friday, there could be as many as 33 7-footers among the league's 276 players. One is as high as 7-6, for goodness sakes. Add another 22 guys who measure 6-11, and it means that one of every five players would be at least that tall.

title: Futures/Options;   3 New Vehicles Tied to O-T-C
description: MORE hoopla than business is expected this Friday when the alphabet soup of stock index products is thickened by the addition of three new contracts covering the over-the-counter market.

title: Brighter Shade of Dull
description: Professional economists, rarely known as light-footed entertainers, will be bringing a little excitement on at least two Washington fronts today.

title: Vietnam Crusades Against Markets
description: Vietnam is embarking on a series of substantial economic changes intended not only to relieve chronic shortages in goods and resources but also to speed up the collapse of the resilient free-enterprise sector in the South.

title: Mourjane Rallies For Kelso Victory
description: Fernwood Stable's Mourjane, a 5-year-old Irish-bred, finished fastest to pass favored Cool in the final strides and win the $95,100 Kelso Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: 'SUN CITY' GETS A RANGE OF AUTHORITY
description: ''SUN CITY,'' the benefit record by an all-star group called Artists United Against Apartheid, has met a positive reception at radio stations, although its lyrics openly denounce current United States policies on South Africa.

title: Untying the Mental Health Knot
description: In many states, the mentally ill remain victims of deadlocked politics. Legislation now offered by Senator Kennedy would use the Federal funding power to press such states - New York heads the list - to institute reforms and restore some hope.

title: Asian Investment Talks
description: The European Economic Community and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations agreed Friday to set up a joint working group to promote European investment in Southeast Asia, especially by small and medium-sized enterprises.

title: An Encyclopedic Look At New York City
description: Where is the geographical center of New York City? What was John Adams's Bronx address for two months during his Presidency? And where did Mary Pickford appear before the camera for the first time?

title: MARTIN SALUTED BY FRIENDS
description: She got her first standing ovation of the evening the moment she took her seat in the Shubert Theater. She got her second as she stepped on the stage. But if those were the easiest accolades Mary Martin ever earned, then everything else in last night's tribute showed that she deserves a few freebies.

title: 'Old House' Roots Of French Socialists
description: To the Editor:

title: Diana R. Marshak Weds
description: Diana R. Marshak, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Marshak of Atlantic Beach, L.I., and Dr. Evan Siegel, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Siegel of Merrick, L.I., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Sol Roth and Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. Mrs. Siegel, a teacher at the Westchester Day School, graduated from the State University of New York at Albany. Her husband, a resident in internal medicine at Montefiore Hospital, graduated from Boston University, where he was enrolled in its seven-year medical program.

title: GROSSINGER'S REGULARS GREET SALE PLANS SADLY
description: Jennie Grossinger, who would bid good night to each of her 1,200 guests as they left the dining hall each evening, is dead. Eddie Fisher, who was discovered at Grossinger's, married Debbie Reynolds there and later returned with Elizabeth Taylor, hasn't been back in several years. The women no longer come down to dinner on Saturday nights in evening gowns, their hair piled high.

title: Two of a Kind
description: Karen Sperling finally met Karen Sperling last week.

title: Canadian Eights Win in Regatta
description: The Canadian men's championship eight, which won the 1984 Olympic gold medal, reunited today to beat the United States crew by 17.7 seconds in Boston's Head-of-the-Charles Regatta, the world's largest one-day rowing event.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Savings Bank FSB has named Dennis G. Devere executive vice president.

title: Catching Up
description: The football team at Glenville (Minn.) High, the school that is on a seven-year losing streak (Scouting, Sept. 17), completed its season last Wednesday by absorbing a 43-0 shellacking from Waterville.

title: Promotions at White House
description: President Reagan has announced several White House promotions, naming Charles D. Hobbs as director of the Office of Policy Development and Deborah Steelman as director of the Office of Intergovernmental Affairs. Mr. Reagan, who acted Thursday, also named Cecilia Cole McInturff as special assistant for political and intergovernmental affairs and Donald A. Clarey as special assistant and deputy director of the Office of Cabinet Affairs.

title: Ads for Braun Shaver Ready to Show on TV
description: This week the Northeast will get to see the first American television advertising for the Braun electric shaver, one of the world's best sellers.

title: Dr. K.A. Freedberg Wed to Dr. Joyce Jen
description: Dr. Joyce Susan Jen and Dr. Kenneth Alan Freedberg were married yesterday at the Memorial Church at Harvard University. The Rev. Thomas Powers, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony.

title: FOR MARIA SHRIVER, A NEW SERIES OF ENGAGEMENTS
description: It was 1972, in the heat of the Presidential elections, and the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, Sargent Shriver, stopped in at a California television studio to do a question-and-answer program. When he emerged, he found his daughter, Maria, then 15 years old, speaking out, too. ''While I was on the inside, she was outside engaged in a debate with a crowd of 75 people, mostly students,'' Mr. Shriver recalled the other day. ''I was astonished and very impressed - she had actually read the campaign book, she was on her toes, and she answered every question. And when the news came on that night, I wasn't on it, she was.''

title: McNeil President Adds Chief Executive's Title
description: TheMcNeil Corporation, a maker of pump and lubrication equipment, has named Glenn H. Meadows its chief executive officer.

title: OUTDOORS: PREPARING BOATS FOR THE WINTER
description: MY childhood recollections of this time of year - a time that all my life has signaled the end of a boating season - are fairly concise. Our family's waterfront home along Lake Ontario made the ritual of winter storage quite easy. The sailing dinghy, with its spindly mast and tiny mainsail, required little effort to tuck away for the season. Once upside down on cinder blocks in the garage, there was nothing else to do except wash the sail and store it in a dry place.

title: CELESTE HOLM RECEIVES TOWN HALL ARTS AWARD
description: Celeste Holm became the fifth recipient of Town Hall's annual ''Friend of the Arts'' award last evening. The award, a handwritten scroll, was presented to the actress and singer at a dinner by Marvin Leffler, the president of the board of trustees of Town Hall. The presentation followed a performance by the New Amsterdam Theater Company of ''A Tribute to George White's Scandals,'' which included such stars as Peggy Cass, Patrice Munsel, Paula Laurence and Carleton Carpenter. The show consisted of material written for the 1920's editions by the songwriting team of DeSylva-Brown-Henderson.

title: Inequality in the Nobel Peace-Prize Organization
description: The awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War reminds one of the story of the American and the Russian arguing over whose political system is freer.

title: Alien Lineup
description: On being told that the best 2-year-olds in the country are named Ogygian and Ketoh, anyone who does not follow thoroughbred racing will understandably have a question: Which country?

title: MUSIC: JOSE FEGHALI AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: THE aptest of all commentary on the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition and its progeny came from a colleague a few years ago who, when asked to assess a recent Van Cliburn winner, answered, ''Andre-Michel Schub? Why, I knew him when he was Steven De Groote.''

title: SELLING OF FIREMAN'S FUND
description: Not since the Ford Motor Company went public in 1956 has Wall Street attempted to sell a new issue anywhere near the size of the Fireman's Fund Corporation. The sale, expected as early as this week, could fetch more than $850 million, making it the largest initial public offering in American history.

title: GIANTS DOWN REDSKINS
description: The Giants knew that if they could shut down the Washington Redskins' running game today, they would probably win. In addition, if they could put together a good running game of their own, they almost surely would win.

title: Deborah L. Lewis Is Wed in Queens
description: Deborah L. Lewis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Lewis of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Jay Damashek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Igor Damashek of Plantation, Fla., and Brooklyn. Rabbi Robert Widom officiated at the Terrace on the Park in Queens.

title: Dr. Paul Arthur Zahl, A Biologist and Writer
description: Dr. Paul Arthur Zahl, a biologist, explorer, photographer and writer on natural science, died Wednesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness.

title: Administration And Clausen
description: THE president of the World Bank, A. W. Clausen, was never brought in on the big plans for the bank that Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d disclosed in Seoul, South Korea. His staff got a whiff of them months ago, and he learned more of the details from newspaper reports leading up to Mr. Baker's speech.

title: Body Found, Girl Missing After Flooding in Texas
description: The body of a National Guardsman who drowned when his military ambulance was washed away by a flood was recovered today, but a teen-ager who was lost after her family's car washed into a lake was still missing.

title: CANOE ADVENTURE ON 'SUN KOSI, RIVER OF GOLD'
description: WHAT could be more visual than white-water canoeing in the Himalayas? Envision it: The trim young paddlers in their orange suits battling the crashing waves through channels of boulders. The photogenic Nepalese children watching in wonderment as the strangers risk their lives doing what there is no particular reason to do. The greenery descending precipitously into shadowy gorges. And, of course, the raging white water. To the Australian producers of ''Sun Kosi, River of Gold,'' which will be shown at 10 P.M. on Channel 13's ''Quest,'' the subject must have seemed made for television. But despite the excitement and beauty of individual scenes, by the end of these 50 minutes, you may find yourself longing for dry land.

title: NETS TO RUN, BUT WOHL WONDERS HOW FAR
description: THE Nets will make the playoffs. But how much further than last season's opening-round playoff elimination by the Detroit Pistons can this franchise go?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are witnessing a worldwide spread of violence among individuals and groups for political and other motives.

title: RAIDERS' LATE PASS TRIPS BROWNS, 21-20
description: So there they were, on the 8-yard line, with a fourth down and 34 seconds left in the game. The Los Angeles Raiders were trailing the Cleveland Browns, 20-14, and in the huddle Marc Wilson had just called something known to his teammates as ''94-option.''

title: Drive Against Anti-Semitism Announced in Bergen County
description: Responding to reports that Bergen County has the highest rate of anti-Semitic incidents in New Jersey, the County Prosecutor has begun a program to improve the investigation of such cases.

title: 1629 'GREAT HOUSE' STUDIED IN BOSTON
description: Archeologists working near Bunker Hill said today that they had uncovered hundreds of artifacts in the 350-year-old ruins of the first meetinghouse in the Massachusetts Bay Colony, where Gov. John Winthrop once lived and ruled.

title: WORDS, FRESH BAKED
description: So you think you know every Americanism ever devised? Maybe not. In remarks inserted into The Congressional Record, Representative Bill Green, Republican of Manhattan, noted that David B. Guralnik, editor in chief of Webster's New World Dictionary, came up with an astounding total of 14,000 words in the category.

title: OPERA: 'MAGIC FLUTE' PERFORMED IN ENGLISH
description: NEARLY two decades after it was introduced, the New York City Opera's enchanting production of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' still represents the company at or near its best.

title: SYRIA IS SAID TO ABANDON BID TO GAIN AMERICANS' RELEASE
description: Lebanese political leaders said today that Syria had abandoned its efforts to gain the release of Americans kidnapped in Lebanon in the last year and a half.

title: Locking Barn Door
description: FOR the past six and a half years, Dan Quisenberry has been the best relief pitcher in his league, saving 217 games and winning 44 others.

title: THE LIMITED ACQUIRES HENRI BENDEL
description: Henri Bendel, the prestigious West 57th Street specialty store, has been purchased by The Limited Inc., the large retail chain said yesterday. Neither party would disclose the purchase price, but officials close to the situation placed it at ''under $10 million.''

title: Sale of Phillips Unit
description: Freeport-McMoran Inc. said it had agreed to buy the Phillips Petroleum Company's Geysers Geothermal unit and other geothermal properties for $215 million. Freeport-McMoran said Friday that the acquisition strengthens its commitment to the natural resources industry. Geysers Geothermal produces geothermal steam air for electric power generation.

title: DANCE: FELD BALLET IN 'RETURN TO MARIA LA BAJA'
description: FILLED as it was with gimmicks and grotesquerie, the Feld Ballet's performance Saturday night at the Joyce Theater could easily have served as a reminder that Halloween is coming.

title: 17 Reported Killed In Sri Lanka Violence
description: At least 17 people, including 11 Tamil separatist guerrillas, were killed in ethnic violence in Sri Lanka's Northern and Eastern provinces over the weekend, security sources said today.

title: WORKERS SAY CHRYSLER OWES THEM
description: When the Chrysler Corporation called Kevin Cheshire back to a job on the assembly line last year, he had been unemployed four and a half years and was on the verge of divorce.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch last Monday from Toulouse, France, about a meeting of the governing Socialist Party, referred incorrectly to the organization's origins. It grew out of the Second International.

title: CATHOLICS SUFFERED, TOO, O'CONNOR SAYS TO JEWS
description: John Cardinal O'Connor appealed to a largely Jewish audience, gathered yesterday to mark a milestone in Roman Catholic-Jewish relations, to understand that Catholics, too, have suffered and have been the victims of oppression.

title: CONCERT: EBENEZER OBEY PLAYS AT JUJU AT TOWN HALL
description: CHIEF COMMANDER EBENEZER OBEY and his 17-man Inter-Reformers Band played a short concert Saturday at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street - short by the standards of their all-night performances at home in Nigeria. Here, they delivered just under three hours of juju music, a celebratory crossfire of percussion, guitars and voices.

title: OFFICIALS, CITING CAVE-IN THREAT, SEAL SITE OF PUERTO RICO MUD SLIDE
description: Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon decided late Saturday to end the search for bodies of landslide victims here and will have the site sealed as a memorial.

title: New York Through New Eyes
description: Tourists have a way of turning one's native soil into foreign ground. ''Look,'' they say about the building or park or newsstand one has passed twice a day for 20 years. ''Look at the way the third floor slants . . . the size of those mums . . . the color of that awning.'' Sure enough, the floor does slant, the mums are monsters, the awning is puce - and the native is seeing them all for the first time.

title: Wilson Picks President
description: James N. Harvey, 58, has become an ad agency president for the fourth time. The agency is the 69-year-old Edwin Bird Wilson, where the title has been unused since Richard G. Farrell left for Muir Cornelius Moore a couple of years ago. Delano W. Ladd Jr. is chairman and chief executive. Mr. Harvey, who first worked on the creative side for Young & Rubicam and then McCann-Erickson, was president of Richard K. Manoff, Harvey & Carlson and of his own place, James Neal Harvey Inc., which he sold to Creamer Inc.

title: Vivien Friedman Becomes a Bride
description: The Park Avenue Synagogue was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Adele Vivien Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lou Friedman of Forest Hills, Queens, to Robert M. Newman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Newman of Brooklyn and West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony.

title: AMDAHL'S ANSWER TO I.B.M. SET
description: The Amdahl Corporation this week will introduce a family of computers designed to compete with the mainframes known as Sierra introduced earlier this year by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: ALLEGATIONS OF BIAS IN CLASSROOM MARK NEW PUSH BY CONSERVATIVES
description: Criticizing an Arizona political science teacher for what it says is ''antinuclear propaganda,'' a new conservative group has opened a campaign for ''greater balance'' in college teaching that has already brought loud protests from academia.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE HAMPTON There are the Hamptons, which are seasonal, and there is the Hampton, Lionel Hampton, the master of the vibraphone, who is a perennial. Mr. Hampton has been a major figure in jazz for more than 50 years, when he joined the Benny Goodman Quartet, Mr. Goodman on clarinet, Teddy Wilson on piano, Gene Krupa on drums. Tonight he shows up in Greenwich Village for a date unusual for him and tomorrow he goes to Brooklyn to teach a class.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Saturday about the Guild Hall awards to Alan Alda, Willem de Kooning and Kurt Vonnegut for participation in the arts misstated the telephone number for information on the reception and dinner Dec. 3 at the St. Regis. It is (516) 324-0807.

title: Dow Declines 4.70; Macy Soars 16 1/8
description: The stock market succumbed to a bit of profit taking yesterday, except for the retail group, where R.H. Macy & Company, a takeover candidate, inspired a rally.

title: TV SPORTS;ABC IS HAVING A GOOD SERIES
description: The idea of the World Series going entirely prime-time is reason both to rejoice and be concerned. After all, the convenience of being able to watch all the games at night is nice, but do we want television to be able to muck around with an institution that seemed born for October afternoons?

title: P.L.O. AIDE LINKS ABBAS TO MISSION
description: A senior leader in the Palestine Liberation Organization, discussing the Achille Lauro hijacking, said today that the four hijackers had been acting under written orders from Mohammed Abbas to carry out a suicide attack as soon as the boat docked in Ashdod, Israel.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1985
description: Companies

title: ELDERS BIDS FOR BREWER IN BRITAIN
description: Elders IXL Ltd., Australia's biggest beer maker, began its long-awaited bid today for Allied-Lyons P.L.C., a leading British brewer and food producer. If successful, the takeover would be the largest in British history.

title: MUSIC: NOEL POINTER
description: NOEL POINTER is such a versatile, outgoing violinist, pianist and singer that he might give a good name to that usually bland blending identified as ''jazz fusion.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;FELINE SHELTER
description: Betsy Smulyan spends her days working in the section of the City Human Resources Administration that deals with sheltering homeless people.

title: Japanese Orchestra
description: The NHK Symphony Orchestra of Japan will make its only appearance in the United States this season, tomorrow night at Avery Fisher Hall. Under the direction of Yuzo Toyama, the NHK will play a Beethoven work, the Dvorak Cello Concerto - with Tsuyoshi Tsutsumi as soloist - and a work by the Japanese composer Hidemaro Konoye. Tickets, at $20, $15 and $10, are available at the box office. The concert is part of the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series.

title: Required Reading;Presidential Custody
description: President Reagan's reply, when asked what it was like to be President, at a question-and-answer session with students at Gordon Tech in Chicago, Oct. 10:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;THE LETTER OF THE LAW
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams's plan to move into handsome new headquarters was barred yesterday - by his own lawyers.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Seaway Work Goes On; Season to Be Extended
description: Officials said today that preliminary repairs on a lock on the St. Lawrence Seaway had progressed faster than expected and that once shipping was resumed, the waterway season would be extended to clear a backlog.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday with articles about the United Nations misidentified the wife of Jaime de Pinies, President of the General Assembly. Her name is Julia.

title: CANADIANS ON JOB
description: Negotiations resumed here Monday after a two-day recess and were continuing into the early morning hours today, with pressure growing to settle the six-day strike between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers.

title: STAGE: 2 SOLDIER POETS IN 'NOT ABOUT HEROES'
description: WORLD WAR I wasn't just the war that changed all wars. It was the trauma that changed all literature, demanding that writers find a new esthetic language for describing a civilization whose pieces could never be put back in coherent order again. In Stephen MacDonald's ''Not About Heroes,'' the new play at the Lucille Lortel, we are invited to spend an evening with two pioneers in the art of antiheroics, the English soldier poets Siegfried Sassoon (1886-1967) and Wilfred Owen (1893-1918). Yet, curiously enough, ''Not About Heroes'' is itself written as if the war didn't happen: the evening often seems more like a genteel Edwardian theatricale than a jagged modern excavation of the bloody waste land.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PERES'S SPEECH PROPOSING TALKS
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, as issued by the Israeli Mission:

title: The National Parks Are Indeed for People
description: To the Editor:

title: MET OPERA: SEASON'S FIRST 'TRAVIATA'
description: A PERSISTENT complaint against James Levine ever since he took charge of the Metropolitan Opera's musical fortunes has been that he lavishes great care on productions that he himself conducts but pays little attention to what happens in the house on other nights. The season's first performance of ''La Traviata'' last evening could easily be entered in evidence to support such a contention. It was not a disreputable performance by any means, merely one of provincial quality that lacked the kind of vocal and dramatic luster that should be expected of a first-cast evening at the Metropolitan.

title: WESTCHESTER IS STRUCK BY STRONG AFTERSHOCK
description: A strong aftershock of the predawn earthquake of two days ago, again centered in Westchester County, rumbled through parts of the metropolitan area this morning, prompting a new wave of phone calls but causing no injuries or damage.

title: HEADED SCHLUMBERGER COMPANY
description: Jean Riboud, the former chairman of Schlumberger Ltd., the international oilfield services company that under his leadership was often called one of the world's best corporations, died of cancer at his home in Paris late Sunday. He was 65 years old.

title: BALLET: IGAL PERRY'S PERIDANCE GROUP
description: A BRIGHT new company called Peridance appeared Sunday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The company, founded by Igal Perry, an Israeli choreographer and teacher who came to America in 1976, specializes in contemporary works in the balletic idiom.

title: McKesson Net And Sales Rise
description: The McKesson Corporation, a distributor of drugs, beverages and chemicals, said today that its latest quarterly profit rose 13.5 percent, to $19 million, or $1.01 a share, from $16.8 million, or 92 cents a share, a year ago. Meanwhile, sales in the second fiscal quarter, ended Sept. 30, rose 32.5 percent, to $1.6 billion, from $1.2 billion.

title: Norwegians Reject Decision To Protect the Minke Whale
description: The Norwegian Government today rejected a decision by the International Whaling Committee to protect the Minke whale, saying that there were doubts about the scientific reasons for the move.

title: STATE TO USE PRISONERS FOR INFORMATION LINES
description: The Department of Motor Vehicles will use prison inmates to handle telephone calls for information from people in the New York City area, the Motor Vehicles Commissioner, Patricia B. Adduci, said today.

title: STANDARD PARTS OF CAMPAIGN SPEECHES BY JERSEY GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATES
description: Governor Kean and his challenger, Peter Shapiro, have been making dozens of speeches in the New Jersey gubernatorial campaign. The content often varies, depending on where a speech is given and who is in the audience. But a body of material appears, with only slight variation, in nearly every such speech. Here are the standard sections of their speeches.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: TELEVISION GUEST SHOT -The most interesting words heard today will probably be those uttered behind closed doors or away from the premises of the United Nations headquarters. President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua and his wife, Rosario M. Murillo, will be the guests on the ''Donahue'' program this morning. At the United Nations, President Abdou Diouf of Senegal, who is the current president of the Organization of Africa Unity, will address the group of African nations in the Trusteeship Council Chamber. Leaders from many of those nations will convene in the afternoon at a special meeting of the 101 nations espousing nonalignment. The chairman for that gathering will be Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India.

title: CRAXI GIVEN MANDATE TO FORM NEW ROME CABINET
description: Italy's President today asked the caretaker Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, to form a new government.

title: EXCERPTS FROM NICARAGUAN'S SPEECH
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, as distributed in translation by the Nicaraguan Mission:

title: CRANSTON ASSAILS U.S.-CHINA ACCORD
description: A United States Senator asserted today that China was still exporting nuclear technology to five countries with ''the most dangerous nuclear programs'' despite Peking's pledge to not help others develop atomic weapons.

title: FOREIGN LOAN PLAN MET COOLLY
description: Representatives of small and medium-size banks gave a chilly reception today to a speech by Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve chairman, asking that they provide fresh loans to troubled debtor countries. Even some larger banks expressed reservations.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;Debt of 4 Utilities Given Higher Rating by S.&P.
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday raised the debt ratings of four electric utilities whose financial condition had been hurt by their investments in nuclear power plants during the last few years.

title: PLAYERS;TROUBLE IS HAUNTING BALBONE
description: The most powerful member of the Kansas City Royals stepped into the batting cage at Busch Stadium yesterday afternoon and tried to right some wrongs. Sometimes Steve Balboni would meet a batting-practice pitch squarely and hit line drives that even the Cardinal outfielders would find difficult to reach. Other times he would hit harmless popups, easy outs.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;SHIFFMAN IS SENTENCED
description: Dale M. Shiffman, an unemployed photographer characterized by his attorney as ''a minor league dealer among major league users,'' was sentenced yesterday in Pittsburgh to 12 years in Federal prison for selling cocaine, mainly to major league baseball players. Judge Barron McCune of the United States District Court imposed no fine or court costs against Shiffman, who pleaded guilty Aug. 19 to 20 counts of cocaine distribution from 1982 to 1984. The 33-year-old Shiffman will be eligible for parole at the discretion of the Federal parole board, the judge said, meaning it is likely that Shiffman will serve only a fraction of his sentence. The Government yesterday dropped 91 other cocaine distribution charges brought when Shiffman and six other Pennsylvania men were indicted May 31 on charges of dealing cocaine to major league players. The sentencing of Curtis Strong, a Philadelphia caterer convicted last month of dealing drugs to various major leaguers also had been was scheduled for yesterday, but it was delayed because of the illness of Strong's attorney, Adam O. Renfroe Jr.

title: ON 'COCAINE STRIP,' PROGRESS IS SLOW
description: To Lieut. Jay Kosack of the 24th Precinct, Amsterdam Avenue just below 96th Street is known as the ''cocaine strip,'' one of scores of retail markets that pockmark the city's streetscape, where $20 or more can buy you a small foil packet of cocaine.

title: Wayward Whale On Its Own
description: As Humphrey, the wayward humpback whale, meandered aimlessly today in a dead-end channel, scientists decided to take ''a hands-off approach'' to see if it would return on its own to the ocean 70 miles away.

title: THE CITY;SETWART JUDGE LIMITS TESTIMONY
description: The judge in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart yesterday barred from testimony references to city and state investigations of the city's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross.

title: The Bureaucracy;Giving New Meaning To Clock-Watchers
description: At 5:30 A.M. Tom Roadley leaves his two sleeping children with a baby sitter to leave for his job as an industrial relations specialist at the Department of Labor. Home by 3:30 in the afternoon, he is able to spend the rest of the day with them. In the summer, he works longer days and is able to take three days off each week to devote himself to the task of being a single parent.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Somalia Said to Repel 2 Ethiopian Attacks
description: Somalia says it has repulsed two attacks by Ethiopian troops, killing 64 soldiers and capturing tanks and weapons.

title: Ivan Boesky Has 5.7% of MGM/UA
description: The New York investor Ivan F. Boesky said that he had purchased the equivalent of 2.8 million shares of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, or 5.7 percent of the shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Boesky said the shares had been purchased ''in connection with merger arbitrage and other investment activities.''

title: ATKINSON, FOR NOW, IS GIANTS' KICKER
description: The report on the Giants' place-kicking game is good and bad. Coach Bill Parcells was happy today about Jess Atkinson's field-goal kicking, unhappy about the kickoff coverage.

title: Bridge: U.S. Women's Team Makes An Impressive Start in Brazil
description: The United States women's team made an impressive start in world championship play, leading the standings for the Venice Trophy after the first three rounds of qualifying play.

title: DAN WHITE, KILLER OF SAN FRANCISCO MAYOR, A SUICIDE
description: Dan White, the man convicted of shooting to death Mayor George Moscone of San Francisco and fellow Supervisor Harvey Milk in 1978, committed suicide today, the police said.

title: Not the World's Only Nuclear Supplier
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Uganda Troops Reported To Clash With Rebels
description: A Uganda newspaper reported today that both Government troops and rebels recently suffered heavy casualties when Uganda troops tried to break out of the Mbarara barracks, which is under siege by rebel forces.

title: STRONG EMOTIONAL RESPONSE TO DISEASE MAY BOLSTER PATIENT'S IMMUNESYSTEM
description: EVIDENCE appears to be mounting of specific links between people's emotions, the body's immune defenses and the course of serious diseases.

title: BEARS AND PERRY BARREL ON
description: William Perry, the 325-pound defensive lineman who carried on the final two plays of the Chicago Bears' victory last week in San Francisco, resumed his rushing career tonight by scoring a touchdown and throwing key blocks on two others, as the Bears won their seventh straight game without a loss.

title: Net Triples At Compaq
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, bucking the trend of poor industry earnings, said today that its third-quarter net income tripled over a year earlier on a 50 percent gain in revenues.

title: MCNEIL ONLY '50-50' TO PLAY ON SUNDAY
description: Freeman McNeil's season, already shortened by a game with a back injury, has been jeopardized further with the disclosure today that the Jet running back also damaged the tip of a rib, an injury that could slow his return.

title: NIXON HEARS ARGUMENTS
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, the arbitrator in the dispute over how much extra money umpires will receive for working the expanded league championship series this season, heard arguments from both sides yesterday but is not expected to render a verdict until later this week.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;QUEST IN NETWORKING: SOFTWARE
description: WORD processing is supposed to turn writing from a chore into a pleasure. Spreadsheets permit an almost infinite juggling of numerical data in a trial-and-error search for the best solution to quantifiable problems. The benefits of a database manager are a little more difficult to define.

title: UNION CARBIDE HAS $543 MILLION LOSS
description: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday reported a third-quarter loss of $543 million as the result of its previously announced restructuring plan.

title: Guards, in a Protest, Let Convicts Escape
description: All 149 convicts in Honiara's central jail, including six murderers, escaped today after guards opened the gates in a protest action.

title: SPELLS OF SLOW SPEECH PRECEDED IMPLANT
description: The latest artificial heart recipient, Anthony Mandia, has had over the last two years at least three episodes of slowed speech like the one that occurred Sunday, his hometown cardiologist said today.

title: Saudi Oil Flow Is Said to Surge
description: Saudi Arabia's oil production is believed to have doubled from the 20-year low of last summer and is expected to average 4 million barrels a day in October, the Middle East Economic Survey said today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics aggravated a lower back injury in practice yesterday and may miss Friday night's opener against the Nets. . . . The forward Greg Ballard of the Golden State Warriors underwent successful arthroscopic knee surgery but he was still expected to miss the first five games of the N.B.A. season. . . . A state district judge ordered the San Antonio Gunslingers' owner, Clinton Manges, to pay his players overdue amounts totaling $601,000. Phil Hardberger, the attorney for the United States Football League, said he would begin foreclosure proceedings today.

title: NUDE STATUE DRAWS A CROWD OF CRITICS
description: It is hard to ignore.

title: Abbas Called 'Surprised'
description: An Italian official said today that Mohammed Abbas, the P.L.O. official, had told him ''he was surprised when he learned of the ship's hijacking.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;BROADWAY FAVORITE
description: It's my life work,'' Jerry Herman said yesterday as he watched a line of chorus girls go through the first rehearsal of ''Jerry's Girls,'' a musical entertainment that draws on his scores over the last 25 years.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;Tax-Exempt Sale For Georgia Utility
description: Georgia's Burke County Development Authority is offering $100 million of 10 1/2 percent, tax-exempt pollution control revenue bonds due in 2015 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY TUESDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1985
description: International

title: WORD FROM PARIS: BODY-HUGGING DESIGNS
description: High fashion and funky clothes alternated on the runways of the tents in the Tuileries Gardens as the spring and summer ready-to-wear shows gained momentum over the weekend. What the sophisticated and the rebellious designers had in common was a penchant for skintight clothes that made last season's more generously cut styles seem completely out of date.

title: SENATOR FAULTS REAGAN'S HANDLING OF INTERCEPTION
description: The chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence criticized President Reagan tonight for failing to give Congress advance notice of United States plans to capture the hijackers of an Italian cruise ship.

title: POLICE KILL ANTI-U.S. PROTESTER IN MANILA
description: At least one person was killed and 27 reported wounded today when the police opened fire on a crowd of rock-throwing demonstrators who were on their way from the American Embassy to the Presidential Palace.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: A dollar has meaning for a lot of people and it could well be an economic barrier for a lot of people. But I'm not in the psychology business. I'm in the train business, so I'm the last person to ask about that.'' - Robert R. Kiley, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, on a possible fare increase. [B4:2.]

title: KNICKS ARE LOSERS IN ROBINSON RULING
description: The Knicks were right where they began - without a veteran small forward - yesterday morning after learning that they had lost an arbitration over how much money they can use to sign a free agent.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SINGING OUT The Westminster Cathedral Choir, 25 boys from England between ages 8 and 13, is making its first American tour, which brings it to New York for two days of intensive singing. Tonight at 8 o'clock, they and their voices do a formal concert at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and 84th Street, with a program of Bach, Tomas Luis de Victoria, Britten (''Missa Brevis'') and Howells (''Motet on the Death of President Kennedy'').

title: The National Parks Are Indeed for People
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: DETROIT ENSEMBLE
description: THE Detroit Chamber Winds, which made its New York debut Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is an ensemble of 15 instrumentalists drawn largely from the Michigan Opera Theater Orchestra and the Detroit Symphony. On Sunday, it proved a cohesive, well-trained unit with a full, bright, organlike sound. The soloists are fluent and expert; much rehearsal time must have gone into establishing the group's internal rapport. The only notable weakness was a rhythmic regularity that occasionally seemed four-square.

title: Surgeon General Predicts Isolation For U.S. Smokers
description: The smoker of 1995 likely will be segregated from society, forced to practice his habit alone or outdoors, as America rolls toward a smoke-free society by the year 2000, Surgeon General C. Everett Koop said today.

title: EXECUTIVES PLAN $3.6 BILLION BID FOR R.H. MACY
description: Top executives of R.H. Macy & Company said yesterday that they would offer to buy the department store concern from its shareholders for almost $3.6 billion.

title: RECITAL: RAMON SALVATORE
description: THE pianist Ramon Salvatore had the splendid audacity to devote his entire Sunday afternoon recital at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street) to music by contemporary American composers.

title: DEFECTS CURTAIL PROGRAMS
description: La Guardia High School's academic programs are mostly in place, but many of the specialized arts programs intended to be the school's hallmark have been curtailed or suspended because of what the city calls ''faulty design and faulty construction.''

title: UTAH SUSPECT AIDED ON LOAN
description: A man arrested in an investigation of three bombings last week in which two people died was arraigned today on charges of possessing weapons.

title: The Editorial Notebook;Some Sunshine in the Subway
description: It took but a minute or two on the E train one recent morning to recognize that we were in for no ordinary ride. The standees, holding onto the stainless steel bar, were smiling. Those who had found seats looked up as though expecting something pleasant, which in the subway would be as unusual as champagne. But an explanation was forthcoming before we left 42d Street.

title: LAND-USE, F.D.I.C. SUITS ACCEPTED BY HIGH COURT
description: The Supreme Court set the stage today for what could be a major ruling next year on whether governments must compensate property owners for land-use restrictions that drive down the value of their properties.

title: South Africans Open A Major Treason Trial
description: The largest treason trial in South Africa since the nationalist leader Nelson Mandela was jailed for life more than two decades ago opened in Pietermaritzburg today as 16 leaders of the United Democratic Front pleaded not guilty to treason.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;DISHARMONY AND HOUSING
description: A handful of hecklers sang protest songs yesterday, as Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mayor Koch and other officials put shovels to the earth and broke ground for a 20-story condominium project overlooking Central Park at Frederick Douglass Circle on the edge of Harlem.

title: David Bernstein Dies; Headed Budget Group
description: Dr. David Bernstein, former executive director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a civic oversight group, died of a heart attack last Thursday at his home in Bayside, Queens. He was 70 years old.

title: SCIENCE WATCH;TOXIC SHOCK AND THE FALL OF ATHENS
description: EXAMINING historical accounts with an epidemiological eye, American medical researchers have concluded that the mysterious plague that led to the downfall of ancient Athens was caused by a combination of influenza and toxic shock syndrome.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about the New York Knicks basketball team misstated the earnings of Gulf & Western's Entertainment and Communications Group. It produced $1 billion of the company's $3.1 billion total revenues for fiscal 1985.

title: U.S. Is to Meet With Soviet On Central American Region
description: Senior United States and Soviet officials will meet in Washington next week for talks on Central America and the Caribbean, the State Department said today.

title: ADVERTISING;New Yorker Magazine Appoints Ad Director
description: Wasting no time, The New Yorker magazine has replaced its departing 50-year-old advertising director with 34-year-old Michael Trainor, who since last year has been vice president and advertising director of Esquire magazine.

title: Playing Chicken With the Homeless
description: This winter the number of homeless people seeking shelter in New York City is expected to approach the peak levels of the Great Depression. Yet the city is taking a slow, some say grudging approach to preparing for the emergency.

title: WORLD SERIES EXPRESS CARRIES MISSOURIANS TO GLORY
description: On a train ''bound for glory,'' as the Governor put it, Missourians danced and sang, cheered and celebrated across their state today, hailing the fact that no one but a team from Missouri can win the World Series.

title: COX LEAVING JAYS FOR BRAVES' POST
description: Bobby Cox, who managed the Toronto Blue Jays to the American League East championship this year, has been named the general manager of the Atlanta Braves, sources close to Cox said tonight.

title: Burlington To Bid for Southland
description: Burlington Northern Inc., the giant railroad company, said yesterday that it intends to begin a tender offer for all the shares of the Southland Royalty Company, a major independent developer and producer of crude oil and natural gas, for $17 a share, or about $695 million.

title: SCIENCE WATCH;Origin of the Moon
description: An Indiana University astronomer has proposed a new explanation of how the Moon was formed, the National Science Foundation announced yesterday.

title: Making Fantasy From Scrap
description: The Capital Children's Museum is a ''hands on'' museum popular with Washington children and their parents.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FRINGES OF POWER. 10 Downing Street Diaries 1939-55. By John Colville. 796 pages. Illustrated. Norton. $25. SIR JOHN COLVILLE was only 24 when he was seconded from the British Foreign Office to 10 Downing Street in 1939. He was to serve as private secretary to three British Prime Ministers - to Neville Chamberlain from 1939 to 1940; to Winston Churchill for the remainder of World War II, apart from a period of two years (1941-43) when he was a fighter pilot in the R.A.F.; to Clement Attlee for a few weeks after the 1945 election, and to Churchill once again from 1951 to 1955. Before returning to Downing Street for the last time he also served as private secretary to Princess Elizabeth, the present Queen.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Man Aboard Jet Tries To Open Door in Midair
description: A man who tried to open the door of an Eastern Airlines jet today while the plane was 14,000 feet above ground was taken into custody after the plane landed here.

title: SPEAKERS FROM AFAR
description: GARRET FITZGERALD: PRIME MINISTER OF IRELAND Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland told the General Assembly yesterday that the countries that founded the United Nations and those, like his, who joined later, ''must not pretend that we have adequately lived up to this commitment.''

title: Careers;Negotiators in Demand
description: THE courts are crowded, but alternatives to litigation are emerging. Now arbitration and mediation are being taught in law schools.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Hospital Supply Corp., Evanston, Ill., said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its American Haemonetics division to a management team headed by the division's president. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;RATES ARE LITTLE CHANGED
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday as many potential traders and investors stayed on the sidelines until the more-than-three-week-old hiatus in Treasury bond sales is ended.

title: Iraqis Report Raid on Kharg
description: Iraq said today that its planes had raided Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal after a weekend lull. There was no independent confirmation. The air attack was the 29th reported against Kharg since mid-August.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;U.S.-SOVIET TALKS HALT ON RESUMING FLIGHTS
description: United States-Soviet talks on resuming airline service between the two countries have ended in disagreement and no further meetings have been set, the State Department said today.

title: Plea for EPIC Names Denied
description: A Federal bankruptcy court judge in Alexandria, Va., rejected a motion yesterday that he make public the names of about 100 savings and loans and other investors in Equity Programs Investment Corporation real estate partnerships, which filed for bankruptcy several weeks ago.

title: Cluett Rejects Bid; Makes Swap Offer
description: The board of Cluett, Peabody & Company, the nation's fifth-largest apparel company, yesterday rejected a $258.9 million tender offer from a group led by Paul A. Bilzerian, the California investor. The board instead invoked an anti-takeover measure, which it called a shareholders rights plan, that would exchange up to 2.2 million of Cluett's 8 million shares for a package of cash and notes valued at $45 a share.

title: Debt Problems Seen for Storer
description: Storer Communications Inc. disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it ''does not expect to be able to generate sufficient cash flow to make all of the principal payments'' on the $2.48 billion debt arising from a leveraged buyout of the company led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. Storer said that it ''intends to refinance a portion of the debt in the future.''

title: Top Positions Filled at Wilton
description: Wilton Enterprises Inc., a maker of baking and kitchenware supplies, yesterday named Douglas E. Pease, formerly a vice president of the Sara Lee Corporation, to be vice chairman and chief executive.

title: 73% OF AMERICANS SUFFER HEADACHES
description: ALMOST three-quarters of Americans suffer from occasional headaches and more than half suffer from aches of the back and muscles, according to a nationwide survey that also links the prevalence of pain in various ways to age, income, stress and family history.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Hunters Bag 260 Moose As Maine Season Opens
description: Hunters bagged 260 moose, including several weighing close to 900 pounds, as the six-day season opened today on Maine's official state animal, according to officials of the Inland Fisheries and Wildlife Department.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;The Oldest Art
description: It is a rare privilege to visit the prehistoric caves here. They are a rich and mysterious reminder of human capacities long before civilization.

title: Outburst at Hawaii Volcano
description: Lava fountains shot up to 1,000 feet today in the 38th phase of a Kilauea Volcano eruption that began Jan. 3, 1983. The latest outburst began at 3 A.M. at Pu'u O'o vent in the volcano's east rift zone, according to George Ulrich, a geologist with the United States Geological Survey here.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Strikers Back to Work At Seabrook Project
description: Construction returned to normal today at the Seabrook nuclear power plant as workers obeyed a back-to-work order issued by a Federal district judge.

title: SUPREME COURT LETS STAND A TAX ON NEW YORK REAL-ESTATE DEALS
description: The United States Supreme Court today let stand New York State's 10 percent tax on gains from real-estate deals of $1 million or more.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago

title: QUARTERBACK OUT
description: Tony Robinson, the University of Tennessee quarterback, underwent successful surgery on his right knee today but will miss the rest of the season.

title: Protectionism Is Criticized
description: Four leading economists, reacting to growing calls for trade protection bills, issued a joint statement today condemning laws to shield American industries from foreign imports.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Hijackers Can Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: MARCOS AIDE DISCOUNTS REBEL THREAT
description: The acting Philippine Foreign Minister said today that the United States Government and the American press were overestimating the strength of a Communist insurgency in the Philippines and underestimating the ability of the Government to bring it under control.

title: The Immigration Mess (Both of Them)
description: When it comes to aliens, Americans are making a mess of both law and decency, as has just been manifested in quick succession by front-page stories in The Times.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: Net Income Percent Change

title: CHINA'S SEARCH FOR NUTRIENT LINK TO CANCER PROVES ELUSIVE
description: MEDICAL suspicions have grown in recent years that diet deficiencies of certain nutrients in tiny amounts may lead to cancer, and, conversely, that adding such micronutrients would prevent cancer. Now from China comes what is believed to be the world's first rigidly controlled trial aimed at preventing cancer by adding these micronutrients to the diet - and the results are negative.

title: DEVELOPER BUYS 3D AVENUE SITE FROM HOSPITAL
description: The New York Foundling Hospital, which plans to move to new, smaller quarters in 1988, sold its 10-story building at Third Avenue and 68th Street on the Upper East Side yesterday to the real-estate developer Donald Trump, according to Mr. Trump.

title: REAGAN SAYS HE'LL USE VACANCIES TO DISCOURAGE JUDICIAL ACTIVISM
description: President Reagan promised today to use the rest of his second term to appoint Federal judges who seek ''judicial restraint,'' and he criticized those who view courts as ''vehicles for political action and social experimentation.''

title: BLACK LEGISLATOR IN CAROLINA
description: The Rev. I. DeQuincey Newman, a dominant figure in the civil rights movement in South Carolina and the state's first black State Senator since 1888, died Monday at Richmond Memorial Hospital of complications from cancer. He was 74 years old. Mr. Newman, the son of a minister and himself an ordained minister in the United Methodist Church, served as field director for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People from 1959 to 1969. The association dominated the rights drive in South Carolina, a state second only to Mississippi in percentage of black population.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;WILLIAMS WON'T PLAY
description: John (Hot Rod) Williams and the Cleveland Cavaliers have agreed that he will not play for the National Basketball Association team pending the outcome of the sports-bribery case against him. A court in Louisiana had dismissed the charges arising from the point-shaving scandal at Tulane University last season, but the prosecution is appealing that dismissal. No date has been set for a hearing on the appeal. If the dismissal of the charges is upheld, David Stern, the league's commissisoner, will decide whether Williams will be able to play. Meanwhile, Stern warned that the fights that marred the end of the exhibition season will not be tolerated in the regular season. ''We can't let it get out of hand,'' Stern said during a reception at the Basketball Hall of Fame Sunday night. Patrick Ewing, the Knicks' rookie center, suffered a hyperextended and bruised left elbow Saturday night following a fight with Steve Stipanovich of the Indiana Pacers that ended with Stipanovich grabbing Ewing and tossing him to the floor. Both players were ejected. In Los Angeles, the Boston Celtics' center, Robert Parish, and the Laker forward Maurice Lucas got into a pushing match that ended with Parish being shoved over a press table.

title: 39 Abortion Foes Arrested
description: Protesters against abortion stormed a line of police and security personnel at an abortion clinic over the weekend, leading to the arrests of 39 demonstrators and minor injuries to two police officers, the authorities said. The incident Saturday was the third time since December that protesters had tried to enter the clinic, the Northeast Women's Center, said Kate Strauser, a clinic spokesman.

title: A SPECIAL ON CBS: 'WAR BETWEEN CLASSES'
description: WHAT could be more visual than white-water canoeing in the Himalayas? Envision it: The trim young paddlers in their orange suits battling the crashing waves through channels of boulders. The photogenic Nepalese children watching in wonderment as the strangers risk their lives doing what there is no particular reason to do. The greenery descending precipitously into shadowy gorges. And, of course, the raging white water. To the Australian producers of ''Sun Kosi, River of Gold,'' which will be shown at 10 P.M. on Channel 13's ''Quest,'' the subject must have seemed made for television. But despite the excitement and beauty of individual scenes, by the end of these 50 minutes, you may find yourself longing for dry land.

title: MARGOT KIDDER PORTRAYS WIFE IN DIVORCE THROES
description: THE dramatic story of a newly separated wife with three children faced with the wrath of her vindictive husband - that is how CBS describes, in the requisite nutshell, the plot of ''Picking Up the Pieces,'' its television movie at 9 o'clock this evening. A tough look at this kind of not uncommon situation would indeed be welcome, but, like most television movies, this one comes with its predigested upbeat ending, narcotically assuring viewers that the beleaguered heroine is that much stronger and nearer to perfection after her ordeal. Once again, real issues get fudged in audience-research fantasies.

title: ASHE TO BE DROPPED AS DAVIS CAPTAIN
description: Arthur Ashe, the captain of the United States Davis Cup tennis team for the past five years, is about to be relieved of his job.

title: Loss Reported At Zellerbach
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said today that a previously announced restructuring had resulted in an $84.6 million loss in the third quarter, in contrast to earnings of $22.9 million, or 70 cents a share, a year ago. Sales for the quarter fell 2.6 percent, to $788.2 million, from $808.9 million last year.

title: AUTHOR AND TV PRODUCER HONORED
description: Architecture, to me, is the mother of all the arts - the inescapable art,'' Barbaralee Diamonstein, the writer and television producer, said last night. It is also the subject of her latest book, ''American Architecture Now,'' the 14th in her series on the visual arts, design and architecture in the United States.

title: 2 Guilty of Spanking Student
description: An eighth grade teacher has been convicted of reckless conduct for paddling of an 11-year-old student, and the junior high school principal who watched and approved the paddling was found guilty of battery. The teacher, Robert Gasoske, found guilty Friday, and the principal, Burdette Wehmeyer, found guilty Thursday, are to be sentenced Nov. 26. They each face up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Mr. Gasoske faces a second charge of reckless conduct in an unrelated incident in which he is accused of dangling a student out of a second-story window as punishment.

title: A FIGHT OVER UNEQUAL STOCK
description: In the 1960's a highly successful New York Stock Exchange advertising campaign convinced millions of investors to own shares of American business. These days, the Big Board is still promoting share ownership, but, to its chagrin, is having to acknowledge that not all shareholders of some corporations get the same rights for their money.

title: CLOSED-CIRCUIT POP CONCERT
description: Pop music will join sports events as closed-circuit, pay-per-view entertainment Dec. 27, when a concert by Duran Duran, Culture Club and a third band to be announced will be transmitted from Anaheim Stadium in Anaheim, Calif.

title: A Delighted Texan
description: ELTON M. HYDER Jr., a retired Fort Worth oil lawyer, was in town the other day, mostly because his wife, Martha, was chairman of a day-long celebration of Mstislav Rostropovich. He went to the award ceremonies and afternoon concert, the reception and even the dinner dance. Next day over lunch at the Jockey Club he said he'd had a wonderfully good time.

title: What to Say at the Summit;Focus On Warheads
description: The Soviet Union has proposed a 50 percent reduction of missiles and warheads to about 5,000 on each side. Such cuts would be a giant step toward nuclear sanity, and we should respond positively.

title: Philippines Storm Kills 63
description: The official death toll from a typhoon that struck the main Philippine island of Luzon on Saturday has risen to 63, the Philippine News Agency reported. The agency said the Governor of Nueva Ecija Province, 50 miles north of Manila, had asked President Ferdinand E. Marcos to declare the province a disaster area. Damage there was estimated at $5.3 million and 90 percent of the buildings were destroyed in the provincial capital at Cabanatuan.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: PARIS steals no thunder from New York City's fashion world, not even while Europe's spring collections rain down on the forecasters of fashion.

title: Greek Workers Strike
description: Greek workers ranging from doctors to taxi drivers joined a 24-hour general strike today to protest a two-year wage freeze and other austerity measures ordered by the Government. The strike, organized by a coalition of trade unions and business groups, affected Athens and 24 other cities and towns.

title: REAGAN TO SEE INDIAN AND PAKISTANI LEADERS
description: President Reagan will hold separate meetings at the United Nations with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India and President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan, White House officials said today.

title: EDUCATION;PLAN FOR CERTIFICATION GAINS
description: AS commissions, committees and task forces continue to discuss new ways to improve American public education, a 26-year-old proposal is attracting broad interest and support among education leaders. The plan is designed to raise both the status of the teaching profession and teachers' salaries by providing a workable approach to merit pay.

title: At the Guggenheim, the Collection Came Before the Building
description: To the Editor:

title: COLEMAN IS OUT OF WORLD SERIES
description: The Kansas City Royals arrived in St. Louis today to continue the World Series, speaking bravely on the morning after but remembering vividly the night before. Charlie Leibrandt especially remembered.

title: Kodak in Japan
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said that it plans to establish a research and development center in Japan, which would employ up to 150 scientists and technicians. ''Our intention is to draw on the valuable resources of this country - both in terms of people and in terms of high technology,'' Kay R. Whitmore, Kodak president, said in a prepared statement. A spokesman, Charles S. Smith, said that one task of the center would be to adapt Kodak products for Japanese use.

title: Cocaine Craving Eased by Drug
description: Researchers reported today that they have eased cocaine craving and withdrawal with a drug that triggers production of an important brain chemical partly depleted in chronic cocaine users.

title: BRIEFING;Your Honor, Dear
description: If the nomination of the new judge for the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., comes before the Senate for a roll-call vote, at least one Senator, William V. Roth Jr., will be recorded as present but not voting. That, Mr. Roth said, is ''to avoid any perception of conflict,'' because the new judge is to be his wife, Jane Richards Roth, the mother of their two teen-age children.

title: BROADCAST GROUPS PLAN FAIRNESS-RULE CHALLENGE
description: A group of broadcast industry organizations, including CBS Inc., plans to ask a Federal court of appeals to find the Fairness Doctrine unconstitutional.

title: BABY TAKEN AT GUNPOINT FROM THE MOTHER'S ARMS
description: A three-day-old baby was stolen from her mother's arms last night by a woman brandishing a pistol on a Brooklyn street corner, just minutes after the mother and child were released from Brookdale Hospital, the police said.

title: THE CITY;SUBWAY TRAINS STALLED IN BROOKLYN
description: A malfunctioning subway train, passengers who refused to leave it and a track fire, all in Brooklyn, combined to cause long delays during yesterday morning's rush hour.

title: MORAL RIGHT'FERVOR LAPS AT NEW ZEALAND SHORE
description: It was the biggest petition effort in the history of New Zealand, bigger even than the drive a decade ago to save the white birch trees of the South Island.

title: JETS HAVE TOP PAYROLL, SURVEY SHOWS
description: The Jets have the highest payroll in the league, with a scheduled dispersal of $14.38 million for the season, or an average of $217,823 per player under contract, according to a recent National Football League survey.

title: Midwest Energy
description: The Midwest Energy Company, an electric and gas company based in Sioux City, Iowa, said that it had agreed to acquire the Donovan Companies of St. Paul for $33 a share, or about $50 million. Donovan is the parent of the North Central Public Service Company, a gas utility serving about 60,000 customers in suburban Minneapolis and in Iowa, and the Southern Gas Company, a natural gas utility serving 4,900 customers on Florida's Gulf Coast.

title: SALVADOR GUERRILLAS ADMIT THEY SEIZED DAUGHTER OF DUARTE
description: Almost six weeks after the kidnapping of President Jose Napoleon Duarte's daughter, the Salvadoran guerrilla front has taken public responsibility for the action.

title: BRIEFING;Stockman on Deadline
description: David A. Stockman, who resigned as the White House budget director in July, is now working hard in his basement against two deadlines.

title: CHARRED STREETS STRUGGLE TO RECOVER
description: Richard Smith looked at his pride and joy, a black 1975 Buick Electra. ''Only 58,000 miles on her,'' he said outside his house at 6235 Pine Street in West Philadelphia.

title: Business TV Program
description: The Entertainment and Sports Programming Network said yesterday that it would begin televising a weekday morning business news program on Nov. 4. The program, ''Nation's Business Today,'' will be produced by the American Business Network, the broadcasting arm of the United States Chamber of Commerce. Initially, the program will appear on several cable networks and on 40 other stations, in addition to ESPN.

title: FIRST LADIES, AT MEETING ON DRUG ABUSE, GET AN IMPROMPTU APPEAL TOCONSIDER THIRD WORLD'S PLIGHT
description: After a carefully planned and presented program, it was a spontaneous moment that made the biggest impression today at the First Ladies' Conference on Drug Abuse.

title: Warner Net Rises 39.8%
description: Warner Communications Inc. said yesterday that its net income for the third quarter rose 39.8 percent, to $34.1 million, or 50 cents a share, from $24.4 million, or 36 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 3.6 percent, to $560.5 million, from $540.9 million.

title: Talking Business with Monfort of Monfort of Colorado;Meatpackers Try to Adapt
description: Meatpacking, a low-margin industry in the best of times, is having to deal with a steady decline in its market. Per capita consumption of red meat is about 5 percent below the level of a decade ago.

title: SIDE TRIPS ON AGENDA OF LEADERS
description: Mostly, there were great speeches. But there were a few great escapes. Like any group of conventioneers, the world leaders gathered here for the United Nations commemoration this week are snatching opportunities to see something of New York.

title: CLASH OVER KELLY ROLE AT BEATRICE
description: Top executives of the Beatrice Companies offered to support a $4.9 billion takeover if Donald P. Kelly, the Chicago businessman, was excluded from the deal, insiders said yesterday.

title: COMMONWEALTH IS EXPECTING LITTLE EFFECT FROM SANCTIONS
description: The limited economic sanctions against South Africa that were agreed upon by Commonwealth leaders late Sunday are expected to have little effect on the Pretoria Government, officials here said today.

title: 2 APPROACHES SHAPE CANDIDATES' ORATORY IN JERSEY CAMPAIGN FOR GOVERNOR
description: Oratory, as every politician knows, should match the moment. And the moment for Governor Kean arrived this summer.

title: PERES, AT THE U.N., PROPOSES TO VISIT JORDAN FOR TALKS
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, addressing the General Assembly as it began the second week of its 40th anniversary commemoration, offered today to travel to Jordan before the end of the year to participate in a Middle East peace conference.

title: INSURANCE EXECUTIVE LED PRINCETON BOARD
description: R. Manning Brown Jr., retired chairman of the New York Life Insurance Company and former chairman of the board of trustees of Princeton University, died of cancer Saturday at the Medical Center of Princeton. He was 70 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: U.S. AIDES REPORT 3M OFFICIAL IS REAGAN CHOICE FOR OSHA
description: The White House is expected to nominate John A. Pendergrass, an industrial hygienist with the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, as head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, according to Labor Department and union officials.

title: U.S. AIDE BIDS MUBARAK END DIVISIONS
description: A special American envoy sent to try to ease diplomatic strains growing out of the Achille Lauro hijacking told President Hosni Mubarak today that President Reagan hoped Egypt and the United States would ''put our recent differences behind us.''

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: EDWARD SIDNEY FINKELSTEIN;MACY'S MASTER MERCHANDISER
description: When Edward S. Finkelstein took charge of Macy's New York in 1974, the division - and particularly its Herald Square flagship - had been in decline for years. Many people favored retrenchment by closing off part of the world's largest store. Instead Mr. Finkelstein plunged into a five-year, $15 million renovation that turned Macy's into one of the nation's smartest stores and the company overall into a leading department store chain. All this earned Mr. Finkelstein a reputation as a master merchant.

title: Stockman on Tax Rise
description: A major tax increase is necessary to reduce the Federal deficit, preferably a value added tax, David A. Stockman, the former Federal budget director, said today. In the five years of the Reagan Presidency great strides have been made in reducing the growth of Federal spending, but the deficit remains a major threat to the nation, Mr. Stockman told the annual convention of the Food Marketing Institute.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Critic's Choices column in The Guide on Sunday gave an incorrect time for a benefit concert at Cami Hall this Saturday by the Museum of the American Piano. It will take place at 3 P.M.

title: ADVERTISING;Arnell Adds 3 Clients
description: Arnell/Bickford Associates of New York, founded this year and catering largely to accounts with a fashion orientation, has received three new pieces of business, bringing its billings to $8.6 million.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Thai Accord Is Reached On Rice for Refugees
description: A food crisis in two camps housing Laotian exiles has been averted by the intervention of Thailand's national security chief.

title: ENERGY RECESSION ENDS TEXAS POPULATION BOOM
description: The deepening energy recession, which has been depressing the Texas economy, has dramatically slowed the state's rollicking population growth.
