title: DR. AMELIA ASHE, 69, MEMBER OF CITY'S BOARD OF EDUCATION
description: Dr. Amelia H. Ashe, a member of the City Board of Education the last 11 years, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 69 years old.

title: AMOCO FALLS
description: The Mobil Corporation yesterday reported a $116 million loss for the third quarter, the result of a decision announced last May to set aside over $500 million to restructure its troubled retail subsidiary, Montgomery Ward & Company.

title: GOVERNMENT LISTS EVIDENCE IN SUSPECTED BOMBERS' TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they would present fingerprint, ballistic and other evidence to link seven accused as terrorists with the bombings of 10 corporate buildings and military installations.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ON COAST MOLESTATION CASE
description: Nearly two years after seven people were accused of molesting scores of children at a nursery school in nearby Manhattan Beach, the Los Angeles District Attorney has asked his aides to prepare a ''candid and complete evaluation'' of the evidence in the case.

title: STRIKING CLERICAL WORKERS REACH A TENTATIVE PACT WITH COLUMBIA
description: Negotiators for Columbia University and 1,050 clerical workers who have been on strike since Thursday reached a tentative contract agreement last night.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;I.B.M.'s Notes Yield 10.308%
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday offered $250 million of 10 1/4 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.65, to yield 10.308 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Aristar President Takes Posts at Parent and Unit
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, holding company for the nation's third-largest savings and loan association, announced yesterday that Robert B. Holmes had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: BRIEFING;The Great Celebrator
description: President Reagan plans to help the National Review celebrate its 30th anniversary at a dinner in New York Dec. 5.

title: SCOUTING;LOOKING FOR NO. 7
description: The real race in the women's division of the New York City Marathon figures to be the one for second place. Yes, Grete Waitz is running again next Sunday, and the only thing that seems to be bothering her is a week-old cold that she picked up in her native Norway two days before leaving for New York.

title: Offer May Require SCM Asset Sale
description: The SCM Corporation said that it might have to sell assets to meet payments on new preferred stock if it goes ahead with plans to swap $64 in preferred stock plus $10 cash for each SCM share. SCM is seeking almost 8.3 million shares, or two-thirds of its stock, under a plan to protect stockholders in case two bids for the company fail. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets has offered $74 a share, while Hanson Trust P.L.C. has bid $75.

title: Protest in West Germany
description: West German anti-nuclear activists today slashed the tires of a truck carrying nuclear waste, the police said. The protesters blocked the road to a waste dump at Gorleben, 80 miles northeast of here, for about an hour before the truck proceeded under escort, a police spokesman said.

title: 25/ FARE INCREASE CALLED POSSIBILITY IN TRANSIT BUDGET
description: The New York City Transit Authority made public its 1986 budget yesterday, showing a deficit of $225 million and presenting the possibility of an increase of up to 25 cents in bus and subway fares next year.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;Health Bond Issue From California
description: A $150 million financing by the California Health Facilities Financing Authority, on behalf of the Kaiser Permanente Medical Program, was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: SCOUTING;FOR THE RECORD
description: Joe Dudek, Plymouth (N.H.) State's elusive running back, continued his assault on the collegiate record books Saturday in a 20-14 victory at Maine Maritime. The senior tailback gained 236 yards on 24 carries to push his four-year total to 4,767 yards and break the Division III record - 4,631, set by Rich Kowalski of Hobart from 1972 to 1975.

title: ALLSTATE PLUNGE SENDS SEARS NET DOWN 18.5%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, said today that its third-quarter net income fell 18.5 percent from the 1984 quarter, principally because of lower earnings at its Allstate Insurance subsidiary.

title: Buyout Cash Is Borrowed
description: Leveraged buyouts are an increasingly popular way for a company's top management to take it private, assure a larger ownership position and remain in control. The buyout is leveraged because most of the cash that is used to buy out existing public shareholders is borrowed.

title: Smokers' Babies: Care Cost High
description: Intensive care for babies born too small because their mothers smoked during pregnancy costs Americans $152 million a year in medical expenses, a new study concludes.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;PLAYERS' INVESTMENT
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers' center, and six other players are investing heavily in real estate, primarily hotels. ''You only get so many chances to make good investments,'' said Abdul-Jabbar, who has invested about $7.5 million so far. The group headed by him bought the Balboa Inn in Los Angeles for $4.2 million and is buying the Inn of Laguna in Los Angeles for $4 million. They own a 13-story hotel in Birmingham, Ala., a $1.4 million Newport Beach restaurant and a $22 million Los Angeles health club. Abdul-Jabbar is in partnership with Ralph Sampson of the Houston Rockets, Terry Cummings of the Milwaukee Bucks, Alex English of the Denver Nuggets and Brad Davis of the Dallas Mavericks.

title: SOVIET BLOC MEETS IN BULGARIA TODAY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders left today for a Warsaw Pact meeting in Sofia, Bulgaria, the Government press agency Tass said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Angeles Corp., a Los Angeles-based investment management company, said its chairman and chief executive officer, William H. Elliott, had assumed the additional title of president.

title: REAGAN PRESSES JORDAN ARMS SALE TO AN UNWILLING CONGRESS
description: The Reagan Administration formally notified Congress today of a plan to provide Jordan with up to $2 billion in advanced planes and air defense systems despite overwhelming opposition in Congress.

title: DIANA, ON VISIT TO ULSTER, MINGLES WITH THE CROWDS
description: The Princess of Wales paid a surprise five-hour visit to Northern Ireland today, mingling with outdoor crowds four times as the police looked on nervously.

title: B.P. Plan Spurs Sohio's Stock
description: The British Petroleum Company said yesterday that it wanted to replace its old credit facility with a new $6.5 billion line by next month. The announcement gave rise to speculation that it may try to acquire the 45 percent of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) it does not already own, driving Sohio's stock up $3 a share, to $50.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CLUES EMERGE TO THE CREEPING MENACE OF GLACIERS
description: EVER since Louis Agassiz and other naturalists of the mid-19th century showed that glaciers sometimes swarm across the landscape, burying large regions in ice, scientists have sought to understand these flowing rivers of congealed snow.

title: What to Say at the Summit;Appeal for Refuseniks
description: When Ronald Reagan meets Mikhail S. Gorbachev, I hope he will speak to him, among others, of an innocent man who is now in danger of being sentenced to hard labor in the Soviet Union. His name is Leonid Volvovsky, a 45-year-old mathematician; his trial opened Friday in Gorky. His ''crime'': active involvement with the large ''refusenik'' community there. His friends are worried that the prosecution may use his case as a warning, handing down a severe condemnation.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION;MILESTONE FOR N.Y.U. MATH CENTER
description: FIFTY years ago, Richard Courant, who has been described by his peers as one of the greatest organizers of mathematical research and teaching, fled his native Germany and the University of Gottingen. Invited by New York University to develop its graduate mathematics program, he laid the foundation, in a vacant hat factory, of what was to become the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. This week, the institute, one of the great centers of mathematics, celebrates its 50th anniversary.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;Dealers in London May Form Group
description: Members of the Association of International Bond Dealers, facing new rules set up by British authorities for the London international securities market, are thinking of creating a self-regulatory organization.

title: CONCRETE CANOE RACE YIELDS LESSONS ABOUT BUOYANCY
description: UNDER the rules of the contest, any concrete canoe that sinks directly to the bottom of the Round Pond is not allowed to continue the race.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST OFF 26.7 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest declined 10.7 percent, or 26.7 million shares, in the month ended Oct. 15, to 222 million shares. The short interest for the period a year earlier was about 217 million shares.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOR ARTS: LONG HISTORY OF FLAWS
description: Board of Education and city officials went ahead with the construction of a showcase arts high school even though they knew its design was out of date and did not comply with city building codes, according to city documents and people involved in the project.

title: Advertising;Adjusting To Spots of 15 Seconds
description: The nation is teetering on the edge of the age of the 15-second TV commercial.

title: BRIEFING;Driven by Suspicion
description: Washingtonians are known to be frequently suspicious that top officials illegally allow their wives to use Government limousines for frivolous unofficial purposes involving hair-dryers, tennis courts or both.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Cardinals vs. Kansas City Royals, at St. Louis. After two games in Kansas City, the World Series moves about 250 miles east on Interstate 70 to the banks of the Mississippi River. Joaquin Andujar is the scheduled St. Louis pitcher and Bret Saberhagen is scheduled to go for the Royals, although Saberhagen's right hand was bruised by a line drive in the American League championship series last Wednesday. (Television - Channel 7, 8:25 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:20 P.M.) Boxing Carl Jones vs. Kevin Perry, at Atlantic City, the Tropicana Hotel and Casino, 10 rounds. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. Jones, from Los Angeles, is undefeated in 17 bouts since losing his only pro decision to Fred Hutchings. Perry, from Philadelphia, is a slight favorite, despite a record of 14-5-1, with 10 knockouts, because of the quality of his previous opposition. Hockey Islanders vs. Vancouver Canucks, at Uniondale, L.I., Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WOR, 710; 8 P.M.) Other Events HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. Garden State, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M.)

title: CONGRESS HEARS NOTES OF CAUTION ON PLAN TO BALANCE U.S. BUDGET
description: The director of the Congressional Budget Office today warned the House-Senate conferees who are discussing the plan for a balanced budget that even minor forecasting errors could put the proposal's automatic spending cuts into effect.

title: Tax Plan Penalizes Early Retirees
description: To the Editor:

title: STANLEY R. JACOBS
description: Stanley R. Jacobs, a retired member of the New York Stock Exchange, died at his home in Manhattan Saturday. He was 87 years old.

title: LIGHT MAY BE KEY TO NEW GENERATION OF FAST COMPUTERS
description: SINCE its start nearly half a century ago, the computer revolution has advanced by virtue of a simple physical phenomenon: that streams of speeding electrons can start or stop the flow of other streams of electrons. In short, electrons can act as a switch.

title: SUPREME COURT ROUNDUP;JUSTICES TO PONDER EXTENT OF RIGHTS OF THE DISABLED
description: In a case that could affect the reach of several civil rights laws, the Supreme Court agreed today to consider whether airlines may discriminate against handicapped people aboard airplanes.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Ex-Lehman Official Joins New Venture
description: Stephen A. Schwarzman, the former Lehman Brothers partner who initiated what turned into a controversial merger with Shearson/American Express by jogging over to see a neighbor, has joined his former mentor, Peter G. Peterson, in the formation of a new private investment banking firm, it was announced yesterday.

title: RUTH J. BERMAN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Ruth J. Berman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Berman of London, and Kenneth Robert Spiro, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald H. Spiro of New Rochelle, N.Y., were married Sunday by Rabbi Noah Weinberg at Moshav Ora in Jerusalem.

title: What to Say at the Summit;A 'Fifth Protocol'
description: Despite Moscow's dramatic arms control proposal last month, we are unlikely to see breakthroughs on the four Summit agenda items to which the United States is giving priority -arms control, regional political issues, trade and human rights. But the interests of both sides could be served by a ''fifth protocol'' that would provide for a new and more satisfactory channel of communication between American and Soviet leadership groups.

title: Todd Shipyards To Acquire Aro
description: The Todd Shipyards Corporation, the country's largest independent shipbuilder, said that it had agreed to acquire the Aro Corporation, based in Bryan, Ohio, for $35 a share, or about $84.1 million. Directors of both companies have approved the purchase.

title: RESURGENCE IN HARD-COVER PRINTINGS
description: In a striking example of the resurgence of hard-cover books, Crown Publishers has announced a first printing of more than one million copies of ''The Mammoth Hunters'' by Jean Auel, a novel set in prehistoric times that is scheduled for publication Dec. 6. The figure is widely thought by industry officials to be a record for a work of fiction.

title: Let Indians Have Their Big Bingo
description: It's ridiculous to hinge our status as sovereign entities on bingo, but people are forcing that issue upon us.'' So says the president of the National Congress of American Indians. He refers to the Indians' struggle to hang on to big-jackpot bingo games, a thriving tribal business.

title: Albert (Runt) Pullins Dead; Last Original Globetrotter
description: Albert (Runt) Pullins, the last surviving member of the original 1929 Harlem Globetrotters basketball team, has died at the age of 74.

title: Market Place;Macy Bid Lifts Retail Shares
description: RETAILING stocks posted gains yesterday following a proposal by the senior management of R. H. Macy & Company for a leveraged buyout at $70 a share. While Macy's own stock was the star performer, jumping 16 1/8 points, to 63 1/4, the announcement proved a boon to shares of other retailers.

title: Swift Receives Offer for a Buyout
description: The Swift Independent Corporation said that it had received a leveraged buyout offer totaling about $135 million in cash and preferred stock from a partnership led by Edwin L. Cox Jr. of Dallas.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;JUST FOLKS ALONG I-70
description: In the hush of the Cardinals' sudden 4-2 victory in the ninth inning at Kansas City on Sunday night, George Brett was asked if the Royals could forget such a damaging defeat before tonight's third game of the World Series.

title: PERIPHERALS;ASSESSING SOFTWARE, VERSION 2.0
description: ONE of the most informative and refreshing books to emerge from the great computer publishing glut of 1984 was the Whole Earth Software Catalog, Version 1.0. The 1986 edition, Version 2.0, is now in the stores ($17.50, paperback, from Quantum Press/ Doubleday). Just as the most successful software programs improve with age, adding new features and refining old ones, so too has this compendium of pithy software reviews and wise computer advice.

title: GUILTY IN HAWAII FRAUD CASE
description: Ronald Rewald, an investment counselor who said his firm was connected with the Central Intelligence Agency, was found guilty today on 94 felony counts of fraud, perjury and embezzlement.

title: SCOUTING;'MISTAKES'LL KILL YA'
description: The exact time and the exact place are uncertain now, obscured by the haze of a distant past. What is known is that on that long-ago day on a field of natural turf, a middle-aged sort whom everybody would learn to call ''Coach'' surrounded himself with a gaggle of youths and, having told them what a football was, delivered his first axiom. ''Gentlemen,'' he said, ''mistakes'll kill ya.''

title: KLINGHOFFER EULOGIZED AS PUBLIC AND PRIVATE HERO
description: The murder of Leon Klinghoffer was not God's will, Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum told the family members and friends who mourned yesterday at Mr. Klinghoffer's funeral. It was, he said, the act of an unjust and disordered world in which man's cruelty and stupidity are infinite.

title: BRIEFING;A Risque Joke, by Shultz
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the House Foreign Affairs Committee that he would like to use a joke to illustrate the Administration's problem with restarting Middle East peace talks.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: What to Say at the Summit;A Note To Gorbachev
description: Dear Mr. President:

title: NEWHALL INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $6.3 million for the quarter and $9.1 million for the 9 months from the sale of properties. c-Including a gain of $11.7 million from the sale of properties.

title: READING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $165,000. c-Net income.

title: JUDGE REJECTS PLEA TO STOP PATIENT'S FOOD
description: A probate judge today denied a family's request to withdraw food and water from a comatose patient but reinstated orders that no special measures be taken to keep him alive.

title: ROYALS END CARDS' SPELL AND CUT SERIES LEAD TO 2-1
description: After winning six straight postseason games, three of them with ninth-inning rallies, the St. Louis Cardinals finally took the tumble.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A New Kind of Veal Rambling Rose is the brand name of a new kind of veal that is just beginning to become available in a few New York City meat markets. Raised free from confinement, Rambling Rose veal calves are also free of the antibiotics, hormones and other growth regulators that are routinely used in veal farming.

title: LAM RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $70,000 for the latest first quarter and $198,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: COMFED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: BIG GUNS SPUTTER
description: For their home opener in the World Series last night, the Cardinals unleashed the most formidable show of power since the last May Day parade of weapons in Moscow.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FREEPORT-MCMORAN GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LAST April, Peter Filichia saw an announcement in his newspaper: daylight saving time was resuming the next day at 2 A.M.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Cardinals vs. Kansas City Royals, at St. Louis, Game 4 of the World Series. (Television - Channel 7, 8:15 P.M. P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:10 P.M.) Boxing Terrence Alli vs.

title: Policeman Is Indicted In a 2d Assault Case
description: A New York City police officer charged in July with assaulting a handcuffed prisoner was indicted in a separate case yesterday on charges of assaulting and improperly arresting a man after a traffic accident.

title: BULL & BEAR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: LUNCHEON POLITICS - The concept of the ''power meal'' will take on new dimensions today as the world leaders visiting New York for the 40th anniversary of the United Nations mix international affairs and fine dining. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will sponsor a luncheon in the Delegates' Dining Room of the United Nations. A more private affair, meanwhile, will take place at Lutece, where Prime Minister Lho Shin Yong of South Korea is scheduled to have lunch with former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: LOAN AMERICA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The per share figures reflect a 5-for- 4 stock split paid Aug. 30, 1985.

title: Pretoria Debt Action
description: The Government may try to extend a four-month freeze on foreign debt repayments to international banks at scheduled talks on Wednesday, bankers said today. South Africa imposed the moratorium unilaterally in September when foreign lenders refused more credit because of the political unrest over the policy of apartheid.

title: PITTSTON COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $312,000. c-Including a tax credit of $1,089,000 and income from discontinued operations of $1,012,000.

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sister Mary Aquinas Is Dead; Pilot Inspired TV 'Flying Nun'
description: Sister Mary Aquinas, who gained national fame as a pilot and teacher of aeronautics died here Sunday. She was 91 years old.

title: Meese's Thoughts on the Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: LEADERS OF SIX NATIONS TELL OF THEIR HOPES AND WORRIES
description: SURINAME Desire D. Bouterse Chief of State 'New' U.N. Wanted To Meet the Needs Of the Third World Suriname's Chief of State, Lieut. Col. Desire D. Bouterse, urged the General Assembly to restructure the United Nations in the interests of third world nations.

title: JWT GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $2,671,000 from a loss on divestiture of its European advertising agencies.

title: NUMERICA FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results have been restated to reflect the pooling of interest from the company's acquisition of Home Bank in October and adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid yesterday.

title: SOO LINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring charge of $546,000 from a discontinued newspaper edition. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $2,741,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: 'Aid' Name Abandoned
description: Officials of the Aid Insurance Company said today that they would change its name to avoid any association with the deadly disease called AIDS. Some employee who suggests the winning name will get $5,000. The property insurer adopted the old name (simply implying help) in 1968, long before the medical world discovered acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: Taiwan Textile Lobby
description: A five-member delegation from Taiwan's textile industry left for Washington today to lobby against a proposed American law that would restrict textile and garment shipments to the United States.

title: WEIRTON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN ENCYCLOPEDIA OF U.N., A MASS OF TREATY DETAILS
description: After a half-century of accumulating documents - beginning in the 1930's when he was a Polish correspondent covering the League of Nations in Geneva - Edmund Jan Osmanczyk has at last completed a monumental book: Encyclopedia of the United Nations and International Agreements. What makes the encyclopedia all the more remarkable is that it is the fruit of research and reporting, through war and peace, by one man, working alone.

title: Economic Scene;   The Struggle Over Deficits
description: IN the 1985 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, the deficits of the Reagan years crossed a bewildering threshold. The four-year, $685 billion accumulation of deficits now exceeds all previous deficits, less periodic surpluses, of the 20th century.

title: BORG-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN OREGON, PIONEER VINTNERS PRODUCE HOMEGROWN PINOT GRIS
description: PINOT GRIS has been produced as Tokay d'Alsace in France, rulander in Germany and pinot grigio in Italy. But until a few adventurous vintners in Oregon planted the vine, America did not have its own commercial version of this rich, flavorful, highly individualistic white wine.

title: GROWING U.S. TASTE FOR MUSHROOMS
description: MUSHROOM mania is the current epidemic sweeping through American produce markets.

title: Dow Edges Ahead 0.22, to 1,364.36
description: Wall Street remained preoccupied by takeover rumors yesterday, but a better-than-expected quarterly earnings report from the Digital Equipment Corporation rescued the market from a second consecutive decline.

title: PLASTOMEDICAL SCIENCES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary nonrecurring loss of $100,000.

title: Advertising;   D.D.B. Regains Piece Of Airline's Business
description: Jubilation time at 437 Madison Avenue. Doyle Dane Bernbach International, which lost the American Airlines account to Bozell & Jacobs in 1981 after 20 years of service and some brilliant advertising, just got its foot back in the hangar door.

title: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Modern Maturity magazine to Cadwell Davis Partners.

title: Suns Sign Bulgarian
description: Georgi Glouchkov, a member of the Bulgarian national basketball team, has signed a two-year guaranteed contract with the Phoenix Suns. In addition to guaranteeing his salary, which was not disclosed, to get the 6-foot-8-inch forward, the Suns paid Bulgaria a ''player transfer fee'' estimated at $100,000 and agreed to arrange coaching clinics in Bulgaria and an American tour for the national team. . . . Ron Brewer, a seven-year guard who joined the Nets last March and averaged 8.2 points in 11 regular season games and 12.0 in the playoffs, was waived late yesterday afternoon.

title: LEADERS OF SIX NATIONS TELL OF THEIR HOPES AND WORRIES
description: AUSTRIA Fred Sinowatz Chancellor A Four-Point Plan For Renewed Hope And a Stronger U.N. In his speech at the 40th General Assembly of the United Nations, the Chancellor of Austria, Fred Sinowatz, outlined four proposals that he suggested would strengthen the world organization and ''replace resignation with constructive'' hope.

title: MARYLAND ADOPTS CHASE PLAN
description: Maryland's General Assembly today approved a plan to let the Chase Manhattan Corporation enter the Maryland banking market by purchasing three ailing thrift institutions.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Including a nonrecurring DISC tax credit of $63,250,000.

title: Note and Bond Prices Climb
description: Note and bond prices rose steadily yesterday, and closed with gains of about 1/2 point for long-term issues in the Treasury, corporate and tax-exempt markets.

title: Commonwealth Nations End Weeklong Parley
description: The Commonwealth heads of government ended a weeklong meeting here today with a call for international cooperation in fighting drug trafficking and terrorism.

title: DISCOVERIES
INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary income of $315,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: MOSCOW VOWS TO MATCH SPACE ARMS
description: Soviet officials said today that the Kremlin was prepared to devote whatever resources were necessary to develop a space-based missile defense if the United States did not abandon its own efforts.

title: Hoover Cites Severance Plan
description: The Hoover Company disclosed today that its top executives were entitled to receive more than $7.1 million in severance agreements if the company was taken over and the executives lost their jobs.

title: PATIENT WITH MECHANICAL HEART DRIFTS IN AND OUT OF CONSCIOUSNESS
description: The condition of the first recipient of a new type of artificial heart worsened overnight, and the patient drifted in and out of consciousness, a spokesman at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center said today.

title: VLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. UNION CHIEFS GIVEN SUSPENSIONS
description: A Federal judge today ordered the heads of the three biggest unions for Federal workers suspended from Federal employment for 60 days on his finding that they had illegally engaged in partisan politics by supporting the Mondale Presidential campaign.

title: Knight Chain Net Falls 13%
description: Citing the adverse effects of the Philadelphia newspaper strike, Knight-Ridder Newspapers today announced a 13 percent drop in net income for the third quarter.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET VIOLATES TREATY WITH A MISSILE
description: The United States said today that the Soviet Union had begun deploying a new intercontinental nuclear missile in violation of the 1979 treaty limiting offensive strategic weapons.

title: CIGARETTE TAX RISE REJECTED
description: The Senate voted, 66 to 30, today against raising the cigarette tax to 24 cents a pack from 16 cents.

title: WHITE KEEPS SLUGGING
description: Frank White, the unlikely cleanup hitter for the Kansas City Royals in the World Series, admitted he was surprised by his performance in the second game of the Series, when he got three hits in three times at bat, a bunt single and a pair of doubles, one of which drove in one of the Royals' two runs.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE industry calls its product ''the incredible, edible egg.''

title: WORLD CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

description: b-Net income

title: Bridge;   Brazil and U.S. Are Ahead In World Team Title Play
description: Leading the qualifying race here this afternoon after five rounds of world team championship play were Brazil, in the open series, and the United States in the women's series.

title: Financial Corp. Reserves
description: The Financial Corporation of America, which is expected to report its earnings for the third quarter on Wednesday, will take major additions to its loan loss reserves that will reduce earnings by two-thirds, the company said today. It will take the additional reserves because of foreclosures in its single-family mortgage portfolio.

title: How to Save the Dollar Fare
description: New York City transit fares will have to go up. The only question is, can the increase be held to a dollar?

title: NEW PROGRAMS ON CAMPUSES TEACH STUDENTS ABOUT AIDS
description: Colleges in the New York area, faced with mounting student and parental concern over AIDS, have started programs to teach students and staff members about the disease.

title: Advertising;   New Pitch To Spur Phone Use
description: NEW YORK TELEPHONE COMPANY advertising is generally aimed at increasing telephone use.

title: MET OPERA: 'TRAVIATA' MAKES SEASON DEBUT
description: A PERSISTENT complaint against James Levine ever since he took charge of the Metropolitan Opera's musical fortunes has been that he lavishes great care on productions that he himself conducts but pays little attention to what happens in the house on other nights. The season's first performance of ''La Traviata'' Monday evening could easily be entered in evidence to support such a contention. It was not a disreputable performance by any means, merely one of provincial quality that lacked the kind of vocal and dramatic luster that should be expected of a first-cast evening at the Metropolitan.

title: POGO PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a loss of $3.8 million for the quarter and the 9 months from Turkish operations. c-Net income.

title: U.S. EXPECTED TO ACT TO LIMIT UNITARY TAXATION
description: Under pressure from Britain and other trading partners, the Reagan Administration plans to take steps shortly that could limit the way some states levy taxes on multinational corporations, according to Administration officials and Congressional staff members.

title: Leveraged Buyout Of Wieboldt Due
description: Wieboldt Stores Inc., which operates 13 department stores in the Chicago area, said it had agreed to be acquired in a leveraged buyout for $13.50 a share, or a total of about $37.3 million. If completed, the deal would take the 101-year-old retailer private.

title: WOMAN, 22, IS CRITICALLY INJURED WHEN PUSHED OFF BMT PLATFORM
description: A 22-year-old woman was critically injured yesterday when she was pushed in front of a subway train by another woman at the Times Square BMT station at the start of the evening rush hour.

title: PRESTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lebanese Christian Holds Talks With Syria
description: Lebanon's top Christian militia chief held talks in Damascus today to complete a draft agreement reached by his representatives with Moslem groups for ending Lebanon's 10-year-old civil war.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Stevenson Enters Race For Governor in Illinois
description: Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, who lost in 1982 to Gov. James R. Thompson in the closest gubernatorial race ever in Illinois, announced today that he would seek the 1986 Democratic nomination for governor.

title: GLUT OF FIELD GOALS THIS YEAR
description: Even though Tennessee beat Alabama last Saturday, 16-14, with the help of three field goals by Carlos Reveiz, the Vols' coach, Johnny Majors, had little to say in praise of the 3-pointers. ''Maybe it's time to do something about all these field goals,'' Majors said. ''I haven't had time to give it too much thought, but maybe we should take the tee away or narrow the goal posts.''

title: CRAXI AND SPADOLINI HOLD TALKS
description: Italy's caretaker Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, conferred today with former Defense Minister Giovanni Spadolini on forming a new Cabinet, but they apparently failed to resolve the foreign policy differences that brought down Mr. Craxi's administration last week.

title: 20 PLAYERS FINED FOR 2 N.B.A. FIGHTS
description: An edict against violence in the National Basketball Association was issued yesterday, three days before the start of the regular season, when 20 players were fined a total of $12,750 for incidents in two exhibition games. Patrick Ewing drew the stiffest penalty.

title: UNGARO'S LATEST: BRILLIANT COLORS, REVEALING SHAPES
description: Serenity usually returns when the couture houses take over the runways during the week of ready-to-wear openings. In these collections, couture designers are more concerned with making wearable clothes than with carving new design paths. Their presentations are consequently more soothing.

title: TRICO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
America Goes It Alone
description: ''We did this all by our little selves,'' said President Reagan as he announced proudly that United States Navy fighters had forced an Egyptian plane to land in Italy without prior consultation with either country. In the Administration's view, the widespread American applause for this use of military force against an ally and major aid recipient plainly outweighed the cost in injured relationships with Italy and Egypt. Indeed, the action was a classic example of the Administration's unilateral approach to world affairs.

title: Rail Merger Opposed
description: The Justice Department, citing ''serious anti-competitive effects,'' told the Interstate Commerce Commission that it opposes the merger of the Southern Pacific Railroad with the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway. The railroad merger application has been pending since March 1984, three months after the railroads' parent companies merged into the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation.

title: Advertising;   Palace Brands Assigned By Heublein to DYR
description: Heublein recently created Palace Brands in Farmington, Conn., to market Finlandia Vodka and Mouton Cadet Bordeaux and other wines. Now it has assigned Palace to the DYR agency, which already is serving several of its wine products.

Eastern Bloc's Harvest
description: Farmers in the Communist nations of Eastern Europe report mixed results in this year's grain harvest: bumper crops in the north and a production slump in the drought-stricken south.

description: Higher interest income and lower credit losses combined to produce a 10.3 percent increase in third-quarter earnings for the Mellon Bank Corporation.

title: HALF THE MEMBERS OF SCHOOL BOARDS FACING DISMISSAL
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that he would seek the immediate dismissal of nearly half the community school board members in New York City for failing to file financial-disclosure statements, as required by state law.

title: Zellerbach Layoffs
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said that its previously announced restructuring will have resulted in 1,000 layoffs between March 1 and the end of the year. A spokesman, Delos Knight, said the layoffs affected primarily salaried personnel in positions throughout the company, all of whom had been notified before Aug 1. He said severance pay and other costs associated with personnel reduction accounted for a large part of the restructuring charge of $106.2 million, after taxes, which resulted in the third-quarter loss of $84.6 million announced Monday.

title: Media General Names Officers
description: Media General Inc., a newspaper and broadcasting company based in Richmond, yesterday named J. Stewart Bryan and James A. Linen 4th executive vice presidents.

title: TO A PROTOCOL CHIEF, NO ONE IS UNIMPORTANT
description: ''Where is Sri Lanka?'' asked Aly Teymour, chief of protocol at the United Nations.

title: LEADERS OF SIX NATIONS TELL OF THEIR HOPES AND WORRIES
description: YUGOSLAVIA Radovan Vlajkovic President Detente for All, Not Just the Mighty President Radovan Vlajkovic of Yugoslavia, reaffirming his country's support for the United Nations, called on the General Assembly to ''oppose having key world problems resolved within the narrow circles of the big and mighty.''

title: ON ARMS CONTROL AND THE FUTURE OF THE U.N., STATESMEN SPEAK OUT <
description: uf1> AFGHANISTAN Shah Mohammad Dost Foreign Minister It is regrettable that we are celebrating the 40th anniversary of the establishment of this organization when, as a result of the policy of all-out confrontation and unbridled arms race pursued by imperialism, the world is precariously tottering on the edge of the abyss of a nuclear catastrophe, which threatens not only the entire civilization but also the very existence of any form of life on earth. Nothing could be more distant from the dreams and ideals of the authors and signatories of the United Nations Charter.

Lindbergh Papers Said to Back Trial
description: Newly unearthed documents on the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh's son show that the case was correctly solved, that the baby was killed and that the man electrocuted for the crime had been beaten by the police, state police investigators said at a news conference here today.

Mr. Rubin, 57 years old, replaces Finis F. Conner, 42, who resigned both posts ''for personal reasons'' on Oct. 10, after only about three weeks in the job.

title: FILM: 'SHOAH,' MEMORIES OF THE DEATH CAMPS
description: ABRAHAM BOMBA, a survivor of the Nazi death camp at Treblinka, stands in a busy Israeli barber shop, cutting a customer's hair and answering the questions of the off-screen interviewer. Mr. Bomba is a stocky man who seems to be in good health and is probably older than he looks. Initially his remarks about Treblinka have the manner of tales told so many times that they've lost their meaning.

description: U.S.A. for Africa, the charity that has been administering the proceeds from the record ''We Are the World,'' has planned an event, ''Hands Across America,'' to raise funds to combat hunger and homelessness in the United States.

His dashing good looks, she recalls now, coupled with his shy grin and friendly manner made him appear ''sweet, but not macho.'' They talked and danced for hours, and later that evening, he took her in his arms and they kissed.

description: SMILES wreathed every face in sight Sunday at Carnegie Hall when the pianist started ''Parlami d'amore, Mariu'': Yet another treat, in an evening full of enough to last a season. They will probably have to, as we aren't likely to hear tenor singing on the level of Carlo Bergonzi's concert again this year (unless possibly from Mr. Bergonzi himself in the upcoming concert performance of ''Giovanna d'Arco''), nor encounter a recitalist so unaffected and endearing.

description: The sharpies at AC&R Advertising have been named to do advertising in the United States for J. A. Henckels Zwillingswerk, marketer of quality cutlery from West Germany.

title: BIG BANKS BASKING IN PROFITS
description: Many corporate executives who have always considered themselves a breed apart from commercial bankers are probably wishing they were in the bankers' shoes these days. As one big bank after another has reported its earnings for the third quarter, it has become clear that, as a group, they are currently among the most prosperous businesses in the nation.

title: Advertising;   Gerrity Joins Subsidiary Of Needham Harper
description: Edward J. Gerrity, who has been one of the better known corporate communications directors, is joining Needham Porter Novelli/New York, the public relations subsidiary of Needham Harper Worldwide, as a senior counselor.

title: Retirement Considered
description: Steve Bartkowski, who lost his job as the Falcons' starting quarterback two weeks ago after five straight losses by Atlanta, is considering retiring now that his replacement, Dave Archer, has demonstrated that he can win. According to the Falcons, Bartkowski and the club's owner, Rankin Smith, met last week to discuss the 11-year veteran's future and they plan another meeting later this week.

title: Two New Seat Belt Laws
description: Massachusetts became the 16th state to require drivers and passengers to buckle up or face a fine when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a mandatory seat belt law today, which takes effect Jan. 1. Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington, D.C., also signed legislation requiring the use of seat belts, but it must undergo Congressional review before taking effect in 30 days.

title: WINE TALK
description: SOME interesting things are happening in Alsace. Not that it will make much difference to most American wine drinkers. No matter what happens in Alsace, it's almost impossible to interest more than a handful of Americans in it. Too bad, because the northwest corner of France, tucked between the Rhine and the Vosges Mountains, is one of the finest wine-producing regions in the world.

title: LAXALT REPORTS PLEDGES BY MARCOS ON POLITICAL AND MILITARY CHANGES
description: Senator Paul Laxalt said today that President Ferdinand E. Marcos had agreed to permit American observers at Philippine elections in 1986 and 1987, and to relax his control over the Philippine military.

description: President Raul Alfonsin invoked special executive powers early today and ordered the immediate arrest of six military officers and six civilians suspected of participating in a recent wave of right-wing violence.

description: Without taking sides between the Royalists of Kansas City and the Cardinals of St. Louis, it is clear that both are in violation of the spirit of compromise that brought the state of Missouri into the Federal Union on Aug. 10, 1821. Not being satisfied to join the club, they decided in 1985 to take the joint over.

High on the Hog
description: I had never eaten where the truck drivers eat. All my life I had meant to. ''Eat where the truck drivers eat'' is one of the first maxims every American learns when he first takes to the road, but I had never done it.

title: ARE BLOCS AT THE U.N. CRUMBLING OR AS MONOLITHIC AS EVER?
description: It is said that more brokering is done at the United Nations than on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, with various groups of nations trading votes on one issue for support on another.

title: Former Owens Officer Gets Distillers Ltd. Job
description: When he took early retirement in February 1984, the loser in a two-man race for the chairmanship of Owens-Illinois Inc., William F. Spengler did not think his life was over. But he did not see himself, at age 55, signing on with another giant corporation, either. Mr. Spengler was wrong. In a surprise announcement late last week, Distillers Ltd., the $2 billion British company that is the world's largest producer of Scotch whisky, announced that Mr. Spengler had agreed to become deputy chairman and deputy chief executive. The appointment is expected to strengthen the management team at Distillers, which is threatened by a possible takeover bid by Argyll , one of Britain's largest food retailing concerns.

title: TOLEDO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRAZIL'S TIME BOMB: POOR CHILDREN BY THE MILLIONS
description: Small, barefoot and about 12 years old, the boy reached swiftly through the car window and snatched a woman's necklace. Her scream alerted four passing men, who grabbed the youth and, amid curses, began beating his face and ribs.

description: International

title: Oak Industries
description: The Oak Industries company said it had reached agreement in principle with Allied-Signal Inc., which enables Oak to restructure its outstanding capitalization and to reorganize its operations. The plan includes the sale to Allied-Signal of 10 million newly isssued common shares and warrants to purchase about 4.2 million shares for $1.80 a share as well as an offer to exchange Oak's $230 million of outstanding publicly held debt securities for $160 million in cash and up to 11 million shares of its common stock.

title: A Record Bid
description: Ahmed Salah, the 29-year-old Djibouti soldier who holds the world's fifth fastest marathon time, said yesterday that he would be trying to lower the fastest world time on Sunday in the New York City Marathon, but not as a special honor to New York. ''I try every time to break the world record,'' said Salah, whose best time of 2 hours 8 minutes 9 seconds is less than a minute slower than Carlos Lopes's world best of 2:07:12.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BACARDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lights, Camera, Politics
description: The Republicans, too, are getting serious about the 1986 Congressional elections. They have hired a professional television consultant, Susan Peterson, to give 100 wives of Republican House members a cram course on dealing with cameras and reporters in political campaigns. Today, in a Capitol Hill office building, Miss Peterson will spend an hour and a half coaching the women on how to dress, sit, stand and speak before television cameras, how to field tough questions at news conferences and how to reinforce the candidate without ever overshadowing him.

title: 2 Concerns Move To Bar Takeovers
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the giant paper concern based in Tacoma, Wash., said today that its shareholders had approved antitakeover measures, including a provision that important transactions be approved by 80 percent of shareholders or a majority of continuing directors.

title: PERES TAKEN TO TASK BY RIVALS IN CABINET FOR OFFER TO JORDAN
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres's appeal at the United Nations for talks with Jordan was criticized today by his rivals in the Israeli Cabinet, but the dispute did not appear to pose an immediate threat to the coalition Government.

description: IN ''Crazy Arnold'' (at the Apple Corps Theater), there are three muses, live, on stage, and their names are Groucho, Chico and Harpo. One Bogart was enough for Woody Allen in ''Play It Again Sam,'' but even Gummo, Zeppo and Margaret Dumont could not have rescued ''Crazy Arnold.''

title: Cadet Is Suspended In Honor Code Case
description: The Air Force Academy has reduced its top junior cadet to enlisted rank and suspended him for one year for violating the cadet honor code in not immediately admitting he had broken a window.

Asian Americans

Today at the National Press Club, the Asian American Voters Coalition will announce a national conference on ''political awareness and participation'' to be held in Arlington, Va., Nov. 7-9.

As an electronic publisher of financial information, this company tracks the performance of a wide variety of equity managers tending a total of $339 billion.

description: Assistant Police Chief Gerard J. Kerins's wife had to wake him up Monday night. He was screaming uncontrollably. He is haunted, even in sleep, by the fear that a giant black limousine is about to swallow New York City.

description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it was putting its St. Louis station, KMOX-TV, up for sale, as part of its program to sell assets to finance its stock repurchase plan.

description: IT is curious how palates adapt to new seasonings and flavors. I recall that many years back, curry powder was little known in Burgundy and was used, if at all, in only a few Parisian restaurants. I believe that I first tasted curry in this country; I know that I found it to be quite pleasant, but that I considered it a ''spice'' to be used sparingly and for special occasions.

description: After a complicated debate last night that capped months of discussion, the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission voted to allow construction of a residential tower behind and above the facades of three brownstones on East 79th Street just off Park Avenue.

title: No Way to Balance the Budget
description: Here Congress goes again, playing Robin Hood in reverse. In the guise of solving Federal deficits now approaching $200 billion a year, Congress is on the threshold of enacting a regressive budget process that would leave the poor to be soaked while avoiding the root causes of the nation's fiscal ills.

title: Buckley Heard From
description: The other evening in Buffalo, William F. Buckley, the conservative commentator, was addressing a dinner of 300 of the more generous contributors to the political campaigns of Representative Jack F. Kemp, Republican of New York. In the question period, one member of the audience asked Mr. Buckley what White House position he would seek if Mr. Kemp should be elected President in 1988. Without a flicker, he replied: ''Ventriloquist.''

title: PERES PROPOSALS ON MIDEAST PEACE WELCOMED BY U.S.

title: Cox Family Member Leads Bid for Swift
description: His family has amassed a vast fortune in the oil and gas business, but Edwin L. Cox Jr., 38, has always been interested in animals.

description: The police issued a sketch yesterday of a woman being sought in the kidnapping at gunpoint of a 3-day-old baby outside Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn on Monday night.

title: GIRL WEATHERS DEBUT AS FOOTBALL GUARD
description: In the third quarter of the junior varsity football game here this afternoon, the coach of the North Hunterdon High School team sent No. 14 onto the field to play on the defensive line as nose guard.

description: Marion County Judge James W. Payne has declared a pregnant 13-year-old girl and her fetus temporary wards of the state in order to prevent her from having an abortion sought by her father.

description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, continuing its efforts to pare its debt, said yesterday that it had sold or agreed to sell properties worth $500 million.

description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode, who less than six months ago seemed to be running the country's fifth largest city with a golden touch, today faces a mounting range of criticism from both allies and adversaries.

title: EX-HOSTAGES TELL HOUSE PANEL OF HIJACKING
description: With two of the former hostages from the Achille Lauro seated at the witness table before them, members of a Congressional committee argued today over whether there was anything the United States could do to force foreign cruise lines to impose tighter security.

title: SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA ARE CALLED 'BETTER OF 2 EVILS'
description: African leaders told the General Assembly today that the world faced a choice between imposing economic sanctions on South Africa or watching a destructive explosion by the black majority there.

description: Baseball's club owners, intensifying their dispute with the players over drug testing, voted unanimously today to end the joint drug agreement, an act the head of the players' union called ''regrettable.''

title: YOUNG PROFESSIONALS JUGGLE RELIGION AND THEIR CAREERS
description: A MAJOR contract and a lot of money were at stake for Muhammad el-Refai. And so, the engineer decided, a lunch date with his prospective client was in order. The two met at a fine Italian restaurant, but Mr. Refai did not eat or drink a thing. A Moslem, he was observing Ramadan, a month in which Moslems must fast until sunset.

description: An increase in the tax on $1 million real-estate deals could raise the money to avert transit fare increases, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

Real Estate;   New Buyer For a 70's Failure
description: IT isn't often that a tenant company that wants to shrink the office space it has been leasing decides instead to buy it, but that is what has happened at 1166 Avenue of the Americas. The unusual transaction is the latest chapter in the troubled history of this 44-story building on the eastern side of the avenue between 45th and 46th Streets.

title: Polaroid Profit Up 77%
description: The Polaroid Corporation, which cut costs with second-quarter layoffs, has reported a third-quarter profit of $14.8 million, or 48 cents a share, up 77 percent from $1.7 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier. Meanwhile, sales fell to $299.9 million from $307.8 million, the company said Monday.

title: Topics;   Cars and Colas Coke Jokes
description: Everyone seems to be having fun at Coca-Cola's expense. The wisecracks proliferated when the company felt obliged to restore old (''Classic'') Coke to the market along with its new cola, introduced just last April.

description: b-Net income

title: DANCE: JOFFREY OFFERS KYLIAN 'FORGOTTEN LAND'
description: THE Joffrey Ballet, which skipped its autumn season in New York last year, returned happily to the City Center last night and opened with the first of the three new productions that can be seen through Nov. 10.

title: Dr. Joseph Cochin, Professor And Authority on Addiction
description: Dr. Joseph Cochin, a professor of pharmacology and psychiatry at Boston University School of Medicine and an authority on drug addiction, died Sunday. He was 69 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For his 85th birthday, Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, the philanthropist, received nothing less than the complete renovation of Buttenwieser Hall at the 92d Street Y. The 50-foot-square hall, which was built in 1929, serves as the Y's dance, lecture and film auditorium. It was named for Mr. Buttenwieser in honor of his and his family's support over the years.

title: COLUMBIA WORKERS HAIL UNION PACT
description: Today, 1,050 clerical workers will be back at their typewriters and computer terminals at Columbia University, but yesterday they celebrated their first union contract with a giddy parade through the crackling leaves of the Morningside Heights campus.

title: NET INCOME RISES 23.9% AT G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation today reported a 23.9 percent gain in profits, but a costly sales incentive program and ambitious capital spending left the No. 1 auto maker with an operating loss in the third quarter.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period.

title: MUSEUM HEAD CONSIDERED
description: A candidate to replace William B. Macomber Jr., who will retire next June as the first salaried president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will be considered by the museum's board at its next meeting on Nov. 13.

title: CHEF OFFERS LOW-CALORIE HAUTE CUISINE
description: GEORGES and Marianne Masraff first attracted patrons to their Paris restaurant, Au Quai des Ormes, with a low-priced, three-course, 900-calorie menu. ''No other restaurant in Paris does this,'' Mrs. Masraff said, ''and when we started, people made fun. We told them: 'Don't laugh. Come and see. Taste our food, then decide.' ''

title: FOR THE RUSSIANS, PRIZES OF THE HUNT
description: The joys of mushroom picking are difficult to transmit to the uninitiated. The glimmer of the golden cap and massive leg of the bely mushroom - Boletus edulis, the unparalleled lord of all edible fungi - deep in a forest of fir is a thrill akin to the flash of a trout streaking for a fly. It is a pleasure that combines the satisfaction of the hunt, the rich musty fragrance of the late-summer woods, the dark privacy of the deep forest, the anticipation of succulent mushrooms sizzling in butter and sour cream.

FILM: TALE OF A DIVORCE, 'TWICE IN A LIFETIME'
description: TWICE IN A LIFETIME'' is an enjoyable, second-rate family drama rich in the kind of folk wisdom that can ordinarily be found on daytime television. Played by actors so good they give even paper-thin characters some dimension, it leans heavily toward homilies like ''He kept me up on this pedestal and he never let me down,'' ''You can't have your cake and eat it,'' and ''Nothing can change the love of a family - those bonds just can't be broken.'' The small-town, sentimenal ethos of 1930's family movies is no longer with us, but this is the closest imaginable present-day equivalent: a small-town, sentimental family movie about a messy divorce.

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE RETURN OF A SAXOPHONE LEGEND
description: BIG JAY McNEELY must have played in every black theater in the South during the 40's and 50's. Ornette Coleman, the celebrated saxophonist and composer, remembers the first time he saw Mr. McNeely as if it were yesterday. ''It was in front of a theater, there in the black section of Fort Worth, Tex., where I grew up,'' Mr. Coleman said recently. ''I saw this big-looking guy, all dressed up in this fine-looking zoot suit, and he was honking one note, over and over, with one of the biggest saxophone sounds I'd ever heard.

title: THEATER: WILSON'S 'TALLEY & SON'
description: LANFORD WILSON, one of the most generous-spirited of American playwrights, has devoted more than four years to creating a play about mean-spirited rich people. It may well be that the author of such compassionate works as ''Balm in Gilead'' and ''The Hot l Baltimore'' is just too nice a fellow for the task. Mr. Wilson's revised and improved drama of familial greed and backstabbing, known as ''A Tale Told'' in its 1981 premiere but now titled ''Talley & Son,'' is, for much of its length, amusing entertainment - especially as performed by a crack Circle Repertory Company cast. But if Mr. Wilson has been, on other occasions, a persuasive heir to Tennessee Williams, in this play he remains an unconvincing stand-in for Lillian Hellman.

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'BISON FOREST,' A PBS DOCUMENTARY
description: ''BATTLE OF THE BISON FOREST'' has no battle, although there is a lot of forest - the Bialowieza, 200 square miles straddling the Polish-Soviet border, looking as if Dr. Zhivago were waiting to pop out. He does not, but bison, elk, beaver, raccoon dogs, boar, wolves and wild horses, called tarpan, do. They are seen in the pleasant documentary on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

description: A special American envoy, sent to help heal damaged relations with Tunisia, today criticized the Israeli bombing of the Palestine Liberation Organization headquarters near here, saying, ''We deplore it, as we deplore all acts of terrorism.''

title: College Official in Maine Is Wounded by Sniper
description: The dean of Bates College, James W. Carignan, was in critical but stable condition today after a sniper shot him in the back through a window at his house just off campus, the authorities said.

title: Sharp Tongue in Trouble
description: Representative Bob Dornan of California, a former Los Angeles talk show host and one-time film actor, has probably the sharpest tongue in Congress. His personal attacks over nearly 10 years have succeeded in angering a legion of House Democrats, from Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. on down, as well as a number of Mr. Dornan's fellow Republicans, not least among them Senator Barry Goldwater.

title: HOUSEHOLD TO SELL BIG SUBSIDIARY
description: Household International Inc. said today that it had reached an agreement in principle with a group of investors, including the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation and the Foxmeyer Corporation, to sell Household's merchandising unit in a leveraged buyout valued at about $690 million in cash and securities. Household will retain a 10 percent equity interest in the new company if the deal is completed.

title: Decision on Bartkowski
description: Steve Bartkowski, the Atlanta Falcon quarterback who had been given the choice of retiring or being placed on the injured reserve list because of his chronic knee problems, was placed on injured reserve yesterday, apparently marking the end of his National Football League career after 11 seasons. . . Mike Moroski, a former Falcon quarterback who was released by Atlanta last summer and later cut by the Houston Oilers, is joining the Los Angeles Raiders to give the team some much-needed depth at the position. . . Mike Pruitt, the running back who gained 6,540 yards in nine seasons with Cleveland before the Browns released him this summer, has been signed by the Kansas City Chiefs. Pruitt was released by Buffalo earlier in the week after signing with the Bills and appearing in five games for them.

title: U.N.'S GIFT TO TONGUES: A CORPS OF INTERPRETERS
description: If the United Nations, as its critics charge, is a Tower of Babel, then the teams of interpreters are the tour guides, the indispensable link helping diplomats from 159 nations to speak a common language.

title: GRASSES IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER
description: THE plantings seem natural enough - clumps of towering grasses that wave and rustle in the breeze. Yet this is no marshy seaside setting. Instead, these slender stems are the latest display at the Channel Garden in Rockefeller Center, where the wind that bends them sweeps between the Fifth Avenue skyscrapers.

Some business leaders took the bold step of going to Zambia to talk with the African National Congress.

title: 5 Hurt in Amtrak Train Fire
description: Five people were injured and some cars received smoke damage in a fire on the Amtrak train City of New Orleans as it pulled into Chicago, officials said. The fire began in electrical cables under the ninth car of the 11-car train Monday morning, an Amtrak spokesman said. The crew stopped the train, put out the fire with fire extinguishers and continued into Union Station.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOLY DAYS: The World of a Hasidic Family. By Lis Harris. 266 pages. Summit. $16.95. IT is immediately obvious to the reader what a wonderful subject Lis Harris has found for her first book, ''Holy Days: The World of a Hasidic Family,'' most of which appeared in The New Yorker recently. Her prospects did not look promising at the start. When she first approached the world of Hasidic Jews, not even the traditionally more gregarious Lubavitcher Hasidim of Brooklyn's Crown Heights neighborhood seemed willing to open up to her.

Books: Islam Inflamed
description: SACRED RAGE. By Robin Wright. 315 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $17.95. EARLY in her volume on the fundamentalist crusade of modern Islam, Robin Wright quotes approvingly from Marvin Zonis, a Middle East expert at the University of Chicago: ''The message from Iran - no matter how bizarre or trivial it sounds on first, second, fourth or thirty-ninth hearing - is in my opinion the single most impressive political ideology which has been proposed in the 20th century since the Bolshevik Revolution.'' If that seems too large a statement at the beginning of the book, it does not seem so by the end, for Miss Wright weaves a skillful, disturbing tapestry of warning from the religious history, doctrine, terrorism, politics and social upheaval that have created and sustained the movement.

title: FRILLS AND FLOWERY PATTERNS
description: FRILLS and flowers as well as a smattering of hearts seem to be the trademarks of most of the accessories and linens at the just-opened La Boutique de Marie Claire. The owners, Tania and Amine Naayem, decided to start the new venture while they were in New York on their honeymoon.

title: NL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Three Yesses for the U.N.
description: Do we need the United Nations? If it hadn't been around for 40 years, would the world now invent it? Can a case be made, without humbug, for an organization that thrives on humbug? The answer is three times yes.

title: THE FORD MUSEUM AUCTIONS OLD CARS
description: The world's largest indoor-outdoor museum held what its curators called a ''housecleaning'' last weekend, an auction at which buyers bid on 400 old cars, steam engines and other items that museum officials say they no longer need. The sale netted the museum $1.26 million.

title: BATHHOUSE CURBS CALLED HELP IN COAST AIDS FIGHT
description: Officials here say that a year-old legal effort to prohibit ''unsafe sex'' at public bathhouses appears to be having encouraging but limited success in curtailing the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: UNIVERSAL TELEVISION AT TOP OF PRIME TIME
description: The 12 series Universal Television has on the air this fall - including ''Miami Vice,'' ''Murder, She Wrote'' and Steven Spielberg's ''Amazing Stories'' - take up 10 1/2 hours of prime time each week, more than double the number of series and hours of its nearest competitor, Aaron Spelling Productions.

title: CARDINALS WON WITH 2 HOME RUNS TO TAKE 3-1 LEAD
description: John Tudor, the precise left-hander who pitched 10 shutouts this season, pitched another tonight. It was a five-hit, 3-0 beauty over the Kansas City Royals, and it moved the St. Louis Cardinals within one victory of winning their second World Series in four seasons.

description: Consumer prices in New York and northeastern New Jersey rose four-tenths of 1 percent in September, returning to the moderate inflationary pattern that has characterized the year so far, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

Bend in the Rules
description: After Bo Schembechler, the Michigan coach, charged onto the field during the Wolverines' 12-10 loss to Iowa last Saturday and didn't draw a 15-yard penalty, as the rules call for, Iowa's coach, Hayden Fry, suggested that officials were intimidated by Schembechler. Not so, according to the Big Ten's supervisor of officials, Gene Calhoun.

A SOVIET ARMS IDEA INTERESTS THE U.S.

description: Twenty-three years after American Presidents began flying in a Boeing 707, the Pentagon is asking Congress for permission to trade Air Force One in for a faster and bigger jet.

KARPOV CAUTIOUS AS WHITE
description: Anatoly Karpov put out some cautious feelers for attack in the 18th game of his world chess title defense match with Gary Kasparov on Tuesday in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall, but they came to nothing and the players agreed to a draw after four hours of play.

description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has accused the Democratic Party's Fairness Commission of ''stacking'' the party's Presidential nominating rules against blacks and other minority groups.

EX-EASTERN OFFICER IS T.W.A. PLANNER
description: Morton Ehrlich, who resigned in July as senior vice president at Eastern Airlines after losing out in a race for the carrier's No. 2 job, has been named executive vice president for planning and government affairs at Trans World Airlines, it was announced yesterday.

title: DECIPHERING THE BALANCED-BUDGET BILL
description: The names of Senators Phil Gramm, Warren B. Rudman and Ernest F. Hollings will be forever linked with their bill to balance the Federal budget by 1991. But the man who is telling Congress what the Senate-passed measure really means, or does not mean, is Stephen E. Bell, the staff director of the Senate Budget Committee.

title: GOTAAS-LARSEN SHIPPING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Trial Asked for Man Who Shot His Sick Wife
description: An attorney asked an appeals court today for a new trial for a 76-year-old retired engineer who was convicted in May of killing his ailing wife.

title: Telling It All
description: For the better part of a week, a somewhat embarrassed Dan Eddy held his peace. When countless television replays showed an unidentified fan taking a spectacular dive out of the right-field stands of Exhibition Stadium during the final game of the American League championship series Oct. 16, landing on his back in the adjacent bullpen and lying sufficiently still to have frightened a North American TV audience, he said nothing. When witnesses who had rushed to his aid speculated publicly later that he might have been intoxicated, he remained mute.

title: Colombian Army Chief Wounded in Ambush
description: Gunmen suspected of being leftist guerrillas ambushed and wounded the head of Colombia's Army this morning, a Bogota radio station reported.

title: U.S. Security Rates Up a Bit
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose modestly early yesterday, and then gradually declined until there were only slight increases by the close of trading.

title: Herman Ruhm Jr., 83, Dies; A Retired Textile Executive
description: Herman D. Ruhm Jr., a retired textile executive, died Monday at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 83 years old.

title: Catherine Hanneford; Led the Family Circus
description: Catherine Hanneford, matriarch of the Royal Hanneford Circus, died Tuesday after a stroke suffered while performing in the ring with the family's horse act. She was 97 years old.

title: It Looks Like McGee
description: It won't be official for several weeks, but the National League's most valuable player for the 1985 season will apparently be Willie McGee, the St. Louis Cardinal outfielder. That is the conclusion, anyway, of The Cincinnati Enquirer, which said it had polled 21 of the 24 members of the Baseball Writers Association of America who make the selection and determined that McGee is assured of winning. According to the paper, McGee got 12 first-place votes, twice as many as the putative runner-up, Dave Parker of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: WAVERLY PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: The headline yesterday on a Washington dispatch about the confirmation of Charles Fried as Solicitor General of the United States misstated his position on abortion. Like the Reagan Administration, Mr. Fried has asked that the Supreme Court return abortion law to its status before 1973, when each state legislature determined its legality or illegality; he has not advocated a Supreme Court ban.

description: One of four hijackers of the Italian cruise liner Achille Lauro was reported today to have told Italian investigators that a leading Palestinian figure, Mohammed Abbas, was the military leader of the hijacking operation.

title: MCRAE FAILS AS DESIGNATED PINCH-HITTER
description: As John Tudor cruised through the season of his career, leading the St. Louis Cardinals to the best record in baseball, Hal McRae of the Kansas City Royals was curious to see what was happening.

title: Celebrating the U.N.
description: The celebration of the 40th anniversary of the United Nations is not being overlooked in the capital. Today the World Bank and the 17 United Nations agencies represented in Washington will hold a reception. Before it begins, Phyllis Kaminsky, the United Nations information director in Washington, will give the United Nations Peace Medal to Ken Kragen, who organized production of the record album ''We Are the World.'' On Saturday celebrations in the capital will include the music of Mstislav Rostropovich and the National Symphony Orchestra and of Lester Lanin and his orchestra. Mr. Rostropovich will be at the Kennedy Center for a United Nations Day concert, and Mr. Lanin will be at a follow-up dinner at the Washington Hilton.

title: LONG A KEY MILITARY LEADER
description: Gen. Xu Shiyou, a veteran of the Long March who held top Chinese military posts for a quarter of a century, died Tuesday in the eastern city of Nanjing, the New China News Agency announced. He was 80 years old.

title: HUSSEIN WELCOMES 'SPIRIT' OF SPEECH ON PEACE BY PERES
description: King Hussein of Jordan today welcomed the ''spirit'' of a peace proposal made Monday by Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel.

title: DOCTORS UNIT URGES SCHOOLS TO ADMIT AIDS VICTIMS
description: The nation's major professional association of pediatricians recommended yesterday that most children with AIDS should be allowed to attend school in a normal manner.

title: SOTHEBY'S PICKS NEW CHAIRMAN
description: Lord Gowrie, a former London art dealer who resigned as British Minister of the Arts in September, has returned to the commercial art world as chairman of Sotheby's International, the auction house announced yesterday.

title: ANHEUSER UP BY 11.8%
description: The General Foods Corporation, with strong results in its important product lines, yesterday reported a 23.8 percent jump in earnings for the latest quarter.

title: JAZZ: JAY MCSHANN AND BAND
description: KAY STARR burst on the pop music scene 40 years ago, a gloriously vital young beauty belting out anything that came to hand - country songs, jazz, pop songs and what she now calls ''drunks' music'' - in a resonant, joyful Oklahoma twang. This week Miss Starr, four decades along the road but otherwise seemingly unchanged, opened a three-week engagement at Freddy's, 309 East 49th Street, the first time she has been in New York for anything more than a one-night engagement in so long that she says she can't remember the last time.

title: Weyerhaeuser Net Off 33.8%
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, a leading forest products producer, today reported third-quarter earnings of $38.6 million, or 24 cents a share, down 33.8 percent from $58.3 million, or 40 cents a share, for the comparable period a year ago.

title: Advertising;   Magazine On Black Culture
description: ''AMERICAN VISIONS: The Magazine of Afro-American Culture'' is the brainchild of a black historian that will make its official debut on a most historic occasion, Jan. 15, the first national holiday marking the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Through the good offices of the Washington-based Martin Luther King Federal Holiday Commission, which will pay for production, the magazine will be mailed free to at least 1.5 million people, mostly upscale blacks. And that is the group that Gary Puckrein, 31-year-old publisher and editor in chief, would like to see making up most of his permanent subscriber list. So, in effect, the January mailing will be a giant sampling.

title: STAGE: 'DUE SERGENTI' AT BEAUMONT ITALIAN FESTIVAL
description: HAVING been drawn to the American premiere of ''I Due Sergenti'' (''The Two Sergeants'') Monday evening by the promise of English subtitles, I stayed on after learning that the subtitle technology had proved faulty and those of us possessing only a menu acquaintance with Italian would have to make do with a synopsis. The question, then, was, do you have to know Italian to enjoy ''I Due Sergenti''?

title: Frontier Stake For First Boston

The training includes making videotapes of key members of Congress and then showing them to the recruits.

title: Peruvian Peasants Say Soldiers Killed 59
description: Andean peasants asserted today that soldiers in Ayacucho Province shot or stabbed to death 59 people in a massacre in two villages late in August. They said most of the victims were children and elderly people.

description: THE Vietnam veterans' parade, May 7, 1985: I saw my generation pass in review, a fair chunk of it anyway, wearing jungle fatigues in the canyon of Lower Manhattan. It didn't look so good. I look better. Younger, less lined about the face. Slimmer, though some I saw were very slim indeed. Less fright in the eye area. Fewer scars. There's a reason. I'm a woman. These are men. They look as if they've been through a war.
