title: Dome May Sell Stakes
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said today that it would be willing to sell its entire stake in Dome Mines Ltd. Dome Petroleum also said it will probably sell its 1 million shares of Texaco Inc.

title: Fireman's Fund Issue Elicits Strong Demand
description: The largest initial public offering of common stock in this country got underway yesterday, when Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. began selling 35.2 million shares of the Fireman's Fund Corporation at $25.75 a share. Strong investor demand for the stock was indicated by underwriters' exercising an option to sell more stock than they were originally allotted.

title: VIE DE FRANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOMOSEXUAL VETERANS SUE ON PARADE
description: An organization of homosexual veterans sued the American Legion, Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday, contending that its members had been improperly barred from marching in next month's Veterans Day parade.

title: For America's Poorest, Infant Mortality Is Up
description: To the Editor:

title: TO CLOSE SOME PLANTS
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, hurt by low aluminum prices and import competition, said yesterday that it would close some of its plants and take a $313.5 million charge against its third-quarter earnings.

title: Pipeline Gets Financing
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that financing has been completed for a 1,750-mile crude oil pipeline from the West Coast to the Texas gulf coast to be built by its Celeron Pipeline unit.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe his speech represents the beginning of movement in the right direction and reflects a personal concern for the fate of future generations and a determination to contribute towards the achievement of peace in our time.'' - King Hussein, on a peace proposal by Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel. [A1:6.]

title: CONCERT: A NEW ORATORIO
description: THE American Guild of Organists, New York City chapter, brought to Calvary Episcopal Church an impressive new oratorio Monday evening. William Albright's ''A Song to David'' had its premiere in Minneapolis, that progressive and lively musical city, in 1983. Progressive and lively choirs will want to take it up.

title: China Blizzard Strands 800
description: A blizzard has stranded 800 herdsmen and 90,000 head of livestock in the mountains of western China's Qinghai Province, a newspaper reported today. The state-run Peasant Daily said the storm on Thursday and Friday was the worst in the area since 1956 and had covered pastures with half a foot of snow.

title: MORMON AIDES TELL OF DEALINGS WITH A SUSPECT IN 3 BOMBINGS
description: In their first formal comment on the bombings that killed two people and injured a third here last week, leaders of the Mormon Church today disclosed that they had been discussing with one of the suspects the possible acquisition of some purported rare documents of Mormon history.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AT BAT Some of America's best baseball players never made the major leagues. They were black, and decades ago black ballplayers were relegated to the Negro Baseball League. A new baseball musical, ''Bingo,'' set in those times with jazz to match, opens today at Amas Repertory Theater, 1 East 104th Street (369-8000).

title: No Headline
description: Transactions

title: FARM CREDIT SYSTEM POSTS $522 MILLION LOSS
description: The Farm Credit System, the nation's largest agricultural lender, today reported a $522 million loss in the third quarter, making it all but certain that 1985 would be its first overall losing year since the Depression.

title: MUSIC: 25TH ANNIVERARY OF YOUNG CONERT ARTISTS
description: YOUNG CONCERT ARTISTS INC. has been searching out and promoting young concert artists for a quarter-century, choosing them through competitions and rewarding them with a few seasons of professional management. A glance over the list of 106 alumni (counting ensembles as though they were one person) printed in the program of Y.C.A.'s anniversary concert Tuesday at the 92d Street Y disclosed three indisputable superstars, 14 names that rank high in the business by any objective standard, and 18 more whose careers have been at least successful enough for me to be aware of or familiar with their work.

title: LAFARGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: REVLON LOSES A TAKEOVER RULING
description: In a court decision expected to have major repercussions in all takeover battles, the Delaware Chancery Court ruled yesterday that directors of Revlon Inc. had breached their fiduciary duty by giving a New York investment house the right to buy two key operations.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PACIFIC LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALCOA HEDGES ITS BETS, SLOWLY
description: It is not as if the Aluminum Company of America is going to turn its back on the metal that gave the company its name, Alcoa officials say. It is just that the aluminum business is not what it used to be, and the company wants to hedge its bets.

title: MUSTANG DRILLING & EXPLORAION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: B.P. ASIA PLANS
description: The British Petroleum Company plans to spend $1.3 billion to develop Southeast Asian operations in the next five years, according to Eddie Walshe, the company's regional planning manager.

title: AT THE HIGH POINT MARKET, A PATRIOTIC SPIRIT MARKS NEW FURNITURE COLLECTIONS
description: HIGH POINT, N.C., Oct. 18 - Reproductions and adaptations of furniture inspired by the American West, the Teddy Roosevelt era and the Victorian front porch highlighted the semiannual Southern Furniture Market, which will end Friday.

title: WARSAW PACT ENDS SUMMIT TALKS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and other Warsaw Pact leaders said today they would withdraw and destroy any weapon in their arsenals if the West would do the same.

title: GENERAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of Gaines Pet Food business of $59.8 million and after the cost of restructuring certain international operations of $20.7 million.

title: OFFICER REFUSES TO TESTIFY AT BOMBING INQUIRY
description: The police bomb squad commander refused today to testify before a commission investigating the confrontation between the police and the radical group Move.

title: WITCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $14,710,000 for the quarter and the nine months from the sale of the Witfield division and certain oil and gas interests, and after provisions of $13,618,000 primarily related to reserves for the disposition of plant facilities and for environmental projects. c-Including a tax credit of $3 million for the quarter and the nine months, and after charges of $2,600,000 for the quarter and the nine months principally from the writeoff of systems development costs.

title: NETWORK SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONFORT OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW-CAR SALES DECLINE 16.8%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles fell 16.8 percent in the Oct. 11-20 period, on a daily selling rate basis, from weak sales in the corresponding period a year ago, the manufacturers reported today.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS MINISTERS TELL OF THEIR HOPES FOR THE WORLD ORGANIZATION
description: MEXICO Bernardo Sepulveda Amor Foreign Minister Rather than a problem of efficiency, we face that of the efficacy of the U.N. system. Rather than questions regarding the organization and the administering of resources, we face vested interests and new problems that undermine the necessary decisions to prevent, solve and move forward.

title: Koch in AIDS Appeal To Cuomo and Reagan
description: Mayor Koch yesterday appealed for more Federal and state money to help New York City cope with the spread of AIDS.

title: Whither April 15?
description: If Representative George W. Gekas has his way, April 15 will no longer be the most dreaded day of the year for millions of Americans.

title: PIANO: ANDREI GAVRILOV
description: TALENTED young pianists usually go through a stage that is rather like first love.

title: BLACK RAISES STAKES IN VIRGINIA VOTE
description: Former United States Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. said recently it was something for Virginia voters to think about: The next Lieutenant Governor will be, as Mr. Byrd put it, only a ''heartbeat'' away from the Governor's office.

title: CBS News Executives Plan Early Retirement
description: Two top executives at CBS News announced yesterday they would take early retirement.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Automatix Inc., Billerica, Mass., said it had laid off about 15 percent of its work force in response to losses and diminishing revenue. The company now employs about 290 people.

title: PLACIDO DOMINGO PLANS CONCERTS FOR QUAKE AID
description: Placido Domingo, who lost four close relatives in the September Mexican earthquakes, has announced his desire to be released from all his commitments for a year in order to perform a series of large-scale concerts for the benefit of quake victims. Some 40 concerts are envisaged, with a target of $8 million to be raised.

title: VIEW-MASTER INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHILL IN BUCHAREST BRINGS A WHIFF OF HARDER TIMES
description: The first chestnuts have fallen from the trees in Europe's greenest capital, nights have become nippy and Rumanians' thoughts are turning fearfully to winter.

title: EPIC Plan Opposition
description: A committee of limited partners in real estate partnerships set up by the Equity Programs Investment Corporation said today that it intended to oppose any reorganization plan for the bankrupt partnerships that failed to preserve tax benefits they had enjoyed through their investments.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $16,933,000 from the company's equity interest in Warner Communications Inc.'s loss from discontinued operations.

title: TAX PANEL VOTES LIMIT ON A BIG-BANK SHELTER
description: Setting the stage for weekend meetings that could be decisive to the prospects of tax-revision legislation, the House Ways and Means Committee voted today to limit one of the main tax shelters enjoyed by large banks.

title: EVENTS: LEADERSHIP BY BLACK WOMEN
description: Black Women of Brooklyn and Brooklyn Heights Tour, Brooklyn Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street, at Clinton Street; 718-624-0890.

title: Koivisto Visits Mill in Maine Run by Finns and Times Co.
description: President Mauno Koivisto of Finland, who is in the United States this week for ceremonies marking the 40th anniversary of the United Nations, traveled here today to inspect a paper mill operated jointly by a Finnish company and The New York Times Company.

title: WISCONSIN ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Promises, Promises
description: First New Yorkers were tantalized by the prospect of a Subway Series, but the Mets and Yanks didn't deliver. Then they were promised the storm of the century, but nature didn't deliver.

title: TENNESSEE MUST BAR NEW INMATES
description: A Federal District judge today ordered Tennessee not to admit new inmates until the state complies with a 1982 court order limiting the number of prisoners that could be housed.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: WITNESS AT EDWARDS'S TRIAL BACKS GOVERNMENT CHARGES
description: A prosecution witness in the trial of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards on racketeering, wire and mail fraud charges today supported the Government's assertion that the Louisiana Governor had misrepresented his interest in two hospital projects from which he earned $844,000.

title: Bridge: U.S. Women Fall to Second In World Team Title Event
description: Brazil maintained its lead in the open series of the world team championships here this afternoon, but the United States women's team slipped out of first position in its series.

title: MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a two-for-one stock split paid Sept. 10, 1985.

title: 10 1/4% Redeemable Swedish Bonds
description: The Kingdom of Sweden is offering $300 million of 10 1/4 percent bonds due in 2015 with an unusual feature allowing investors to redeem the bonds at a price of 100 after 10 years.

title: ORDERS FOR DURABLE GOODS FALL 1.1%
description: Orders to factories for durable goods fell 1.1 percent in September, continuing their seesaw pattern, the Government reported today.

title: Seal the Deal in Brooklyn
description: The Board of Estimate is likely today to approve a pioneering computer and back-office center that's crucial to economic development in Brooklyn. Yet its fate still hangs in the balance because of a legal challenge from the Brooklyn Heights Association.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HCM Wins Contest For Jack in the Box
description: The HCM agency has won the multi-agency competition for the Jack in the Box fast-food account, which is expected to bill $23 million. That makes it the biggest new piece of business landed since the joint-venture agency was founded in January by the merger of Marsteller, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, and Havas Conseil, a French agency.

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes after-tax charges of $313.5 million for the quarter and special charge for the 9 months for the writedowns and other costs associated with uneconomic assets. c-Net income The 1984 net results included a $14.8 million after-tax special charge for facility writeoffs.

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,098,000 for the quarter and $2,963,000 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $12,423,000 for the quarter and $26,214,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago 9 months' net includes a gain of $9.2 million from the disposition of certain real estate and other investments.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Take It or Leave It

title: EQUIPMENT COMPANY OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $46,000 for the quarter and $185,000 for the nine months. c-Including a tax credit of $75,000.

title: REAGAN ASKS TO END RIVALRY WITH SOVIET IN THIRD WORLD
description: President Reagan said in an interview made public today that constructive relations with Moscow depended in large measure on the easing of Soviet-American rivalries in the third world.

title: Avalon Pulls Out Of Maynard Bid
description: The Avalon Corporation, an oil and gas company, said that it had withdrawn a $6-a-share, $43.2 million offer to buy the Maynard Oil Company, a gas and oil exploration and contract drilling concern based in Dallas.

title: GANDHI AND ZIA SET TALKS ON BORDER AND OTHER ISSUES
description: The leaders of India and Pakistan met here today and agreed to begin talks on how to improve security on their borders and increase economic cooperation, according to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India.

title: An Alternative to Bilingualism
description: It is not surprising that Secretary of Education William J. Bennett, in a speech on bilingual education, asked whether American schools should ''continue down the same failed path on which we have been traveling.'' No convincing evidence has emerged that the 17-year Federal experiment with bilingual education has worked.

title: JUSTICE BLOCKS A REFERENDUM ON BASE ON S.I.
description: A referendum intended to block a Navy base in New York City for ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice.

title: 'DOOR IS ALWAYS OPEN,' ON CHANNEL 5
description: NASHVILLE, the center of country music, grudgingly welcomed a new group of so-called outlaw songwriters and singers in the 1960's - among them Willie Nelson, Kris Kristofferson and Waylon Jennings.

title: How Trial of Achille Lauro Hijackers Is Like the Eichmann Case
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STAGE: 'ALICE AND FRED'
description: BEWARE of plays that begin with a bare chair on an empty stage. No matter how frivolous the characters may seem, one suspects that the frame of the play is a prison cell and that morbidity is on the horizon. If a straight razor is used for an oath of blood brotherhood, later, if not sooner, there will be an act of homicide. Such, sadly, is the case with ''Alice and Fred,'' which opened last night at the Cherry Lane Theater. Dan Ellentuck's play is about the terrible wages of adolescent lesbianism in upstate New York at the end of the 19th century.

title: SHELL OIL COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $616,000 from discontinued operations and including a gain of $10,558,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Including income of $468,000 for the quarter and $1,813,000 for the nine months from discontinued operations. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend distributed Feb. 28, 1985.

title: Boris Lassanevitch, 80; Russian of Katmandu
description: Boris Lassanevitch, a Russian emigrant who was a ballet dancer, big game hunter, distiller and hotelier, has died in this Himalayan kingdom that was his home for half a century. He was 80 years old.

title: TAFT BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WORKING PROFILE:William Brown;   A Career on the Stairways of Power
description: Working at the people's business does not make it any easier to hunker through a nasty morning rain to reach the office routine inside a grand marble building on Capitol Hill. The corridors are slick and echoey, and the first aromatic tatters of coffee on the brew do not make self-government seem any less wrenching a venture as staff members open the office doors of the members of Congress for another day.

title: PHIBRO-SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Editorial Notebook;   Frozen on the Gunks
description: Why would any sane person want to climb on fingers and toes up a near- vertical rock wall, clinging only to tiny imperfections in the stone?

title: Where Lottery Money Could Have Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Peru Assails Debt Plan
description: Peru has denounced the debt proposal of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d as a device to prevent third-world unity. Prime Minister Luis Alva Castro said in a speech Tuesday night that the American's plan for helping debtors case-by-case was intended to silence joint demands.

title: QUINONES CHOOSES RUDIN TO HEAD STUDY OF SCHOOL-BUILDING PROGRAM
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones yesterday announced the formation of a committee to review the Board of Education's $500 million building and maintenance program and recommend changes.

title: VALID LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $190,000.

title: WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TECUMSEH PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $7,000,000 for the quarter and the nine months.

title: Agreement Reported On Duarte's Daughter
description: A high official of the Salvadoran Government confirmed today that Government representatives and the leftist guerrilla front had met for three days in Panama and had worked out out a series of ''public'' and ''private'' agreements.

title: JWT Net Falls 8.3%
description: The JWT Group reported third-quarter revenues of $135.5 million, up 9.4 percent from the $123.8 million for the period in 1984. Income, however, was down 8.3 percent, to $4.4 million, from $4.8 million. That comes to $1.21 a share, compared with $1.61.

title: Marine to Buy Finance Unit
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Commercial Credit Business Loans Inc. The company is a unit of the Commercial Credit Company, which is the financial services subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation.

title: Interest in Schlichter
description: Art Schlichter, the former Indianapolis Colt quarterback who has been looking for another National Football League job since being cut by the Colts two weeks ago, has apparently widened his search to include the Canadian Football League. According to one of his business associates, Gilman Kirk, the Winnipeg Blue Bombers made an approach this week and Schlichter is interested.

title: RICHMOND SPINNING A WEB OF SUCCESS
description: The Rutgers football team, six games into a difficult schedule and without a victory this season, could do with an easy opponent.

title: Help for Washington
description: Claudell Washington, the Atlanta Braves' outfielder who was arrested in California last February and charged with possession of marijuana, was allowed yesterday to enter a drug-diversion program rather than stand trial on the misdemeanor charge, which carries a penalty for conviction of up to a year in prison and a $1,000 fine. Details of the diversion program were not immediately available, according to court authorities in Walnut Creek, Calif., where Washington was arrested on Feb. 19 after being stopped for a traffic check. Washington, who lives in the nearby town of Orinda, about 30 miles from San Francisco, was treated for drug dependecy after the 1983 season.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MEETS WITH ITS CREDITORS
description: South Africa, trying to reschedule its $24 billion in foreign debt, held its first meeting today with its creditors since the politically troubled nation announced a four-month freeze on its debt repayments last month.

title: NEW HOLOCAUST DOCUMENTARY DRAWS MOTIVATED AUDIENCE
description: They were young. They were old. Some were with friends. Some were alone. But just about everyone who stood in line yesterday on the opening day of ''Shoah'' - the new documentary by Claude Lanzmann about the Holocaust - had a reason.

title: EMERY AIR FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TERA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
How Trial of Achille Lauro Hijackers Is Like the Eichmann Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Earnings Decline 88% At BBDO International
description: Largely as the result of transferring ownership of its South African operation to its local management, BBDO International's third-quarter earnings dropped 88 percent from the quarter last year.

title: Market Place;   Hospital Corp., 'Fallen Angel'
description: THE stock of the Hospital Corporation of America, regarded by some security analysts as ''a fallen angel,'' is having a hard time regaining its lost luster in the investment community.

title: How Trial of Achille Lauro Hijackers Is Like the Eichmann Case
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: THE MUNICH
description: THE Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, which made its New York debut Monday night in Avery Fisher Hall, dates back to 1893, although it only received its current name in 1928. While well-known conductors did lead it, off and on, the orchestra labored for decades in the shadow of the Bavarian State (formerly Court) Orchestra, which was an opera orchestra in concert guise, and later the Bavarian Radio Symphony, which still counts as the city's No. 1 ensemble.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOLDER OF TOP 3 POSTS QUITS UNION ENTERPRISES
description: Union Enterprises Ltd., a Canadian gas utility that lost a fierce takeover battle last winter, said yesterday that its chairman, president and chief executive officer, W. Darcy McKeough, had resigned over ''fundamental'' policy differences with the new controlling shareholder.

title: PRESIDENT, IN NEW YORK, PLUNGES INTO A WHIRL OF DIPLOMATIC TALKS
description: President Reagan, arriving here under security so heavy that it brought East Side traffic to a standstill, began a round of high-level diplomatic activities today before a scheduled appearance Thursday at the General Assembly.

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $62 million in expenses from two early retirement programs, and a $63 million writedown from certain assets scheduled to be disposed of at a later date for the quarter and 9 months. The share earnings have been restated for a 3-for-1 stock split in the second quarter of 1985.

title: Thanks for the Scares
description: A sign held by a scary-looking stuffed doll in the F. A. O. Schwarz toy store on Fifth Avenue yesterday read: ''Welcome Home Maurice.''

title: WEYERHAEUSER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SYDNEY W. MORRELL
description: Sydney W. Morrell, a public-relations consultant, died Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 3 Hostages Held in Queens After an Attempted Robbery
description: Two women and a man were held hostage for more than three hours last night after a bungled robbery attempt at a Queens variety store, the police reported, then freed early this morning.

title: CLIPPERS' BARGAIN WILL COST THE LAKERS
description: Every two weeks, when the Los Angeles Clippers pay their players' salaries, they will prorate Jamaal Wilkes's $70,000 salary and send a check eight miles crosstown to the Los Angeles Lakers' offices. The Lakers, who waived Wilkes last August with three years and $2.4 million remaining on his guaranteed contract, are responsible for paying his salary - minus the $70,000 he earns from the Clippers.

title: EXXON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Saturn Plant Site Dispute
description: City annexation of the proposed Saturn Corporation auto plant site, which would place the $3.5 billion project in jeopardy, has been delayed two weeks while city and county officials decide how to divide revenue generated by the project.

title: RTC TRANSPORTATION CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the year-ago six months are for the 25 weeks ended June 17, 1984; results for the latest six months are for the six months ended June 30, 1985. The latest first quarter results are restated.

title: How Trial of Achille Lauro Hijackers Is Like the Eichmann Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Corp. Net Is $12.3 Million
description: The Financial Corporation of America today reported net income in the third quarter of $12.3 million, or 22 cents a share, on revenues of $781 million.

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
APOLLO COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $14,425,000 related to inventory writedowns, provisions for excess capacity costs and severance and outplacement costs. c-Net income

title: AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Loss at Bevill, Bresler Unit Is Put at $150 Million
description: The Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Asset Management Corporation, whose bankruptcy filing last April touched off one of the largest collapses in the government securities market, is now estimated to have lost a total of nearly $150 million, according to court documents filed yesterday.

title: GIANTS' KICKOFF COVERAGE NOT SO SPECIAL
description: The Giant special teams have not always been special this year.

title: U S TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOR MANES'S OPPONENT, RACE IS UPHILL BUT FUN
description: I awoke this morning as the Republican candidate for borough president of Queens. Just think. - Barbara Le Goff, a working mother, a single parent, getting ready to go against the Democratic machine. So the saga began. The chatty style has been continued in a series of newsletters that chronicle the course of her campaign.

title: Intelligence Screening At BBC to Continue
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation said today that certain staff members working for its external services would continue to be screened by British intelligence.

title: CENTENNIAL IS CELEBRATED BY SEEDBED OF INDUSTY
description: Six years after the close of the Civil War, Benjamin Hill, who had been both a United States and Confederate Senator from Georgia, made a speech at a University of Georgia Alumni Association meeting.

title: Floridian Dies of Snake Bite
description: A 65-year-old man died Tuesday in Shands Hospital here from a rattlesnake bite suffered Saturday at his home as he butchered snakes for meat. The victim, Wilford W. Jordan of Oak Grove, near Lake Bulter, was described by Capt. Vince Smallwood of the Florida Highway Patrol, a family friend, as ''an enthusiastic outdoorsman'' who ''did not believe in killing anything you don't eat.''

title: TERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $137,000 for the quarter and $7,053,000 for the nine months from the sale of a facility in Boston.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMPCO-PITTSBURGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,858,000, or 19 cents a share, from the sale of an investment in Portec Inc. for the quarter and 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $305,000 for the quarter and $795,000 for the 9 months.

title: 'METROLINE' EXAMINES NEW YORK CITY
description: ''METROLINE'' is an idea whose time has come, and if it's not fully realized in the opening segment tonight, that's O.K., too. Actually, the opening segment just asks the questions that the remaining l9 programs in the series will try to answer. The principal question seems to be, what's wrong with New York? ''Metroline'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock.

title: HERSHEY FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $694,000 for the quarter and $1,422,000 for the nine months from discontinued operations and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $7,000,000 for quarter and the nine months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $672,000 for the quarter and $1,095,000 for the nine months.

title: Technology;   The High-Tech Blackboards
description: FOR those who have discovered with dismay that the vital information they wrote on the blackboard was erased overnight by the janitor, the answer is at hand. New high-technology blackboards can make paper copies of what is written on them.

title: INTERGENERATIONAL FIBER ARTS SHOW
description: FOUR internationally recognized fiber artists, Lenore Tawney, Francoise Grossen, Neda Al-Hilali and Nancy Guay, considered their colleagues and chose four younger artists whose work is quite different from their own for the current show ''Artists Select Artists'' at Modern Master Tapestries.

title: JERSEY INQUIRY PLANNED ON NO-BID STATE CONTRACTS
description: A special panel will be created to explore possible links between Republican fund-raising and the Kean administration's awarding of no-bid contracts and its bond-sale procedures, the chief of the legislative budget committee said today.

title: DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CARDINALS FINDING NEW WAYS TO WIN
description: ''Amazing'' is the word Whitey Herzog used, as in, ''It's amazing we're up 3-1.'' No disrespect intended, but Andy Van Slyke, for one, did not think it was so amazing. The St. Louis manager and his outfielder were talking about the same circumstance - the Cardinals' ability to win in spite of their inability to produce hits and runs in mass quantities.

title: A SURGE OF INTEREST IN THE DECORATIVE ARTS
description: THE passion for collecting decorative arts -Louis XV furniture, Tiffany lamps, Ming vases, Georgian silver, Peruvian feather capes and Egyptian jewelry - is changing the look of the nation's living rooms and bringing broad revisions and expansions in American museums.

title: CHAMPION SPARK PLUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Johnson Products Drops Plan
description: The Johnson Products Company, concerned that a link with Louis Farrakhan could lead to accusations of anti-Semitism, has dropped plans to make household and beauty products for a black economic enterprise he helped create.

title: DUQUESNE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are pro-forma.

title: CANADA MAY CUT SOUTH AFRICA TIES
description: Canada may cut relations with South Africa if there is no progress in dismantling apartheid, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada told the General Assembly today.

title: Hoover Income Slides 25.4%
description: The Hoover Company, the object of an unfriendly $40-a-share tender offer by the Chicago Pacific Corporation, today reported a 25.4 percent drop in third-quarter net income, to $8.8 million, or 71 cents a share, from $11.8 million, or 95 cents a share, a year ago. Sales of $179.7 million almost matched the $180 million in sales reported in the 1984 quarter.

title: Article 102197 -- No Title
description: Apollo Computer Inc., posting its first deficit as a public company, said today that it lost $18.5 million in the third quarter, in contrast to net income of $6.3 million, or 20 cents a share, a year ago.

title: Soviet Fever
description: The exploitation of Soviet Communism by non-Communist institutions seems to be rising in Washington and elsewhere as the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting approaches. Nationally televised advertisements are using stereotyped Soviet characters to sell beer, soda and long-distance phone service.

title: Cigar Fever
description: The question was whether it was a violation of the trade embargo against Nicaragua for a member of the National Security Council staff to smoke a Nicaraguan cigar. Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the National Security aide who works with the anti-Sandinista rebels, did not agonize over legalities in accepting a Nicaraguan cigar at a private reception the other night. It was offered by Bruce Cameron, a human rights lobbyist who is close to leaders of the insurgent movement.

title: Railroad Merger Is Endorsed
description: The Transportation Department today endorsed the proposed merger of the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad and the Southern Pacific rail system, even though the Justice Department has concluded the deal would substantially reduce competition and should be rejected.

title: IN NICARAGUA, RIGHTS CURBS BRING UNCERTAINTY AND MORE CENSORSHIP
description: La Prensa, the acerbic and partisan daily newspaper that has irritated every Nicaraguan Government over the last half-century, was to have carried six articles on its front page on Monday.

title: U.S. Exports Getting Help
description: The Reagan Administration today accelerated its campaign against what it calls unfair trading practices, saying it would subsidize some American exports even before Congress acts on a $300 million trade ''war chest.''

title: NAKASONE URGES MORE FREE TRADE
description: The Prime Minister of Japan, Yasuhiro Nakasone, urged delegates to the General Assembly today to resist the lure of ''a powerful narcotic, protectionism.''

title: 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL JURORS PICKED
description: Nine men and three women were chosen yesterday as the jury for a major trial involving charges that an international Mafia ring smuggled huge amounts of heroin into the United States.

title: WHEN U.N. ENVOYS MEET NEW YORK
description: FOR the many diplomats, their wives and husbands, and the heads of government who are celebrating the United Nations' 40th birthday this week, the city is truly a smorgasbord to be savored and sampled. They flood the restaurants of their East Side neighborhood at lunch, drop in at many of its private clubs at night, shop at stores that provide interpreters and besiege the city's Commission for the United Nations and Consular Corps with requests to see small ethnic pockets of the larger New York.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RANGERS TRIUMPH
description: Call it the shot-in-the-dark style, the way the Rangers shoot until something happens. It isn't the best-looking style, but more and more it seems to be working. Last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers had their best offensive game this season and defeated the Devils, 5-1.

title: DIPLOMACY: 2 MINUETS AT WALDORF
description: Everyone was perfectly pleasant at the President's party, of course.

title: INEXCO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: 40 YEARS OLD - Today is United Nations Day, the official 40th birthday of the world organization. The anniversary will be marked by speeches by representatives of seven nations, and a ceremony in the General Assembly hall. The afternoon session is to include remarks by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and the President of the General Assembly, Jaime de Pinies. A 40th anniversary declaration is to be read, provided that member states have reached agreement on one, and 1986 will be officially declared the International Year of Peace.

title: BROOKLYN UNION GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JERSEY'S G.O.P. AIMS FOR GAINS IN COUNTY RACES
description: The races for governor and the State Assembly dominate the 1985 election campaign in New Jersey, but the results of a series of county elections could lead to the state's most significant political realignment at the local level in decades, according to party leaders.

title: ART: 49 FEININGER WORKS GET FIRST U.S. SHOWING
description: LYONEL FEININGER (1871-1956) died where he was born, in New York City. He was an American artist; he even contributed to that quintessentially American art form, the comic strip. Yet, the son of German musicians, he went to Germany at the age of 16 to study music and, becoming converted to art, did not return until 50 years later and under duress.

title: SPERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $10.6 million and a loss of $220 million on sale of discontinued operations in the latest quarter; and a loss of $13.2 million from discontinued operations and a loss of $220 million from disposal of discontinued operations in the latest 6 months. c-Net income, including net from discontinued operations of $2.2 million. Also includes credit of $64 million from reversal of DISC tax liabilities, and a charge of $2.3 million from the writedown of the company's investment in Trilogy Ltd. to market value. d-Net income, including $100,000 from discontinued operations. Also includes a charge of $24.1 million from the writedown of Trilogy, as well as the $64 million credit in the second quarter.

title: DATRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Last Chance for Tax Reform?
description: Some Congress watchers have been saying all year that President Reagan's tax reform plan doesn't stand a chance. It is too ambitious. It takes aim at too many special privileges; the targeted interests will pick it apart and kill it.

title: Hospital Stays Shorter, Medicare Report Says
description: The average length of a Medicare patient's hospital stay has declined since Congress ordered a new payment system in 1983, but it is too early to determine if quality of care has changed, a report by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment said today.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY OFFERS 'ARDEN COURT'
description: ROBERT JOFFREY has been collecting ballets for many years now, scanning the ranks of new choreographers and the international ballet repertory of this century with the keen eyes of a scholar and a miser's zest for gold. His latest acquisition was performed by the Joffrey Ballet on Wednesday at City Center, where the company performs through Nov. 10. And Paul Taylor's ''Arden Court,'' which joins Mr. Taylor's ''Cloven Kingdom'' in the Joffrey repertory, promises to be a fine addition to the company's stock of dances.

title: ARMS CUTS URGED BY SOVIET MINISTER
description: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, used his speech commemorating the 40th anniversary of the United Nations today to appeal for nuclear disarmament and to review recent Soviet arms control proposals.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The San Francisco 49ers re-signed Jim Stuckey, a defensive end who had been waived, and placed the linebacker Fulton Kuykendall on injured reserve. . . . Chris Keating, waived by the Redskins on Wednesday, was re-signed yesterday after his replacement at linebacker, Monte Coleman, aggravated a strained hamstring in practice before being reactivated. . . . Lee Davis, a rookie defensive back who was arrested earlier in the week and charged with carrying a concealed weapon, was waived by the Cincinnati Bengals. . . . Bill Laskey, the former Giant pitcher who lost all five of his decisions after being traded to the Montreal Expos Aug. 1, was traded back to the Giants in exchange for a left-handed pitcher, George Riley, and an outfielder, Alonzo Powell. . . . Willi Plett, a forward, suffered a shoulder separation and will be lost to the North Stars indefinitely. . . . Rod Langway, the Washington Capitals' defenseman, will be sidelined up to 10 days with a bruised right knee he sustained Wednesday night in Calgary.

title: CONVERGENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,544,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $8,465,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission failure, excerpts in Metropolitan Report yesterday from a judge's decision to block a referendum on a Navy base at Staten Island omitted several key sentences. An article including the omitted material appears today on page B14.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $42,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7,000, a tax credit of $264,000 and a gain of $785,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: VIACOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARTEL COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hit-Run Victim, a Physicist, Had Been Hired by Columbia
description: A woman killed Wednesday night by a hit-and-run driver on Riverside Drive was identified yesterday as a 28-year-old physicist who was to have started work next week as a fellow at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Plan Corp., Plano, Tex., said U.S. Assurance Corp. had terminated its Sept. 13 agreement under which U.S. Assurance had agreed to infuse $40 million into American Plan.

title: Interstate Bakeries Has New Chairman
description: The Interstate Bakeries Corporation, the nation's largest independent wholesale baker and the maker of Dolly Madison cakes and Butternut bread, yesterday named Howard P. Berkowitz, a New York investor, as its chairman.

title: BENNETT LEADS JETS BUT SACKS THE SACK
description: Barry Bennett calls it ''the stupid little sack.''

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LATIN: SONORA MATANCERA
description: SONORA MATANCERA, the Latin dance band founded in Cuba back in 1924, brought guarachas, mambos and rhumbas to Kamikaze, 531 West 19th Street, on Wednesday. Its elegantly propulsive set was completed by a reunion when the band was joined by the conga player Carlos (Patato) Valdez, who last played with Sonora Matancera in 1940.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a solemn moment. Leaders of all nations are assembled here and behind them is the single, collective constituency of the human race.''

title: Folger Consort
description: The Folger Consort will present a program titled ''Measure for Measure'' at the Corpus Christi Church Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

title: MOORE MCCORMACK REOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $42,000 for the quarter and $582,000 for the 9 months and a special gain of $13,325,000 for the 9 months on a debt buyout.

title: FRENCH FASHION SALUTES ITSELF WITH OSCARS
description: The French fashion industry celebrated itself at the Paris Opera on Wednesday night with a spectacular entertainment inspired by Hollywood's annual Academy Awards ceremony. Called ''The Oscars of Fashion,'' the event was seen live from 10 P.M. to midnight on French television and will be repeated later in Japan and the United States.

title: Photography Center To Open New Branch
description: The International Center for Photography announced yesterday that it will open a midtown branch in an effort to ''bring photography to a larger audience.''

title: Court Gives Revlon a Stay
description: The Delaware Supreme Court yesterday delayed a preliminary injunction that had been granted by a lower court to prevent Revlon Inc. from giving Forstmann Little & Company the right to buy two key businesses.

title: SERVISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Interest Rates Rise Slightly
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday, but were declining late in the day as traders took encouragement from fresh statistics suggesting that the Federal Reserve is not trying to push short-term rates higher.

title: LOUISIANA LAND AND EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.8 million for the quarter and $10.1 million for the 9 months.

title: CELANESE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THATCHER ON A TIGHT DIPLOMATIC SCHEDULE
description: With 50 heads of state and government converging on a skyscraper at the foot of East 43d Street today, many, including Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain. tried to compress a week's worth of diplomacy into a day.

title: BLACK HILLS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 Die, 7 Hurt as Copter Crashes Into Gulf Oil Rig
description: A helicopter crashed into an offshore oil platform today, killing the pilot and one passenger and critically burning the seven other passengers, the Coast Guard said.

title: ENRIQUE HANK LOPEZ
description: Enrique Hank Lopez, a writer and lawyer, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Los Angeles.

title: ROLLINS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Sept. 25.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Boston Celtics, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 8:05 P.M. Dave Wohl makes his regular-season and home debut as the Nets' coach against the defending Eastern Conference champion and Larry Bird. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WPAT-AM, 930; 8 P.M) Boxing Alexis Arguello vs. Pat Jefferson, 10 rounds, junior welterweights, at Anchorage. Arguello, the 33-year-old three-time champion from Nicaragua, returns to the ring after a two-year retirement. He is 78-6 with 63 knockouts. The 27-year-old Jefferson (25-5) is from Eugene, Ore. (Television - Channel 9, 9 P.M.; live.) Calvin Grove vs. Dana Roston, 12 rounds, U.S.B.A. featherweight title fight, Atlantis Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8 P.M. Grove, from Coatesville, Pa., is 23-0 with 12 knockouts. Roston, from Las Vegas, Nev., is 13-2-1 with six knockouts. (Television - MSG, 10:30 P.M., tape, after the Rangers' game.) Cross Country Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference Championships, at Van Cortlandt Park, 2:30 P.M. for men's 5-mile and 3 P.M. for women's 5-kilometer (3.1 miles). Despite a first-place finish last year by Iona's Brian Roche (25:02.26), who will be back this year, LaSalle won the men's team title. Holy Cross, which won the women's title, is a favorite again because of the return of Julie LeClair, who won last year in 18:20.5. Harness Racing Garden State, 8 P.M., Cherry Hill, N.J. The $1,357,500 Governor's Cup, richest race in North America so far this year, is the feature. Barberry Spur is the 5-to-2 early favorite.

title: SENATE IN A SNAG
description: The House of Representatives today approved a package of spending cuts that would reduce the Federal budget deficit by about $60 billion over three years.

title: A PASSENGER REVOLT LEADS TO SUBWAY DELAYS
description: Queens-bound subway service was disrupted in the rush hour last evening when several hundred passengers refused to get off two IND trains that were blocked at the Queens Plaza and 23d Street-Ely Avenue stations in Long Island City.

title: 39 Leaders Urge a Slowdown In Growth of the Population
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar was presented with a statement today signed by 39 heads of state or government calling for curbs in population growth.

title: Czechs Hold Hostage-Taker
description: The Czechoslovak press agency said today that the police in Brno had overpowered a gunman who took children and nurses hostage in a nursery and demanded to be allowed to emigrate to the West. No one was injured.

title: SEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,765,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Profit Up 45% At Genentech
description: Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company, reported today that its third-quarter net income rose 45 percent, to $1.6 million, or 10 cents a share, from $1.1 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: PLEA CONCEDES ILLEGAL SCHEMES OF $66 MILLION
description: A garment-industry executive pleaded guilty yesterday in Manhattan to Federal charges of wire- fraud and tax- evasion schemes that totaled $66 million.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SOME REMARKS BY U.N. HEAD
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Javier Perez de Cuellar, the United Nations Secretary General, to the commemorative session of the General Assembly:

title: SOHIO SLIPS
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, said yesterday that, pushed by the earnings growth of gasoline and other petroleum products, its third-quarter profits increased 28.1 percent over the corresponding period in 1984.

title: A 2-PART DOCUMENTARY ON LAURENCE OLIVIER
description: IF one were forced to choose the most prominent and influential actor of this century, surely the top candidate would be Laurence Olivier, a star for more than 50 years, his Archie Rice and Lord Marchmain as dazzling and memorable as his Henry V and Hamlet. His awesome career is splendidly reviewed in ''Laurence Olivier - A Life,'' a two-part documentary being broadcast as a ''Great Performances'' presentation on Channel 13 tonight and next Friday at 9 o'clock.

title: E G & G INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes about $2 million, or 7 cents a share, due to the forgiveness of taxes, net of other tax adjustments, that had been deferred on the company's domestic international sales corporation.

title: Advertising;   Fisher Award For Newhouse
description: S. I. Newhouse Jr., the second-generation publisher who this year added The New Yorker to his holdings, has been named ''publisher of the year'' by the Magazine Publishers Association.

title: Dining Out Guide: Madison Square Garden
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BISTRO-BORDEAUX, #407 Eighth Avenue, near 31st Street (594-6305) -

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain from the sale of Celebron Corp. of $98.1 million, or 92 cents a share, for the quarter and income from discontinued operations and the sale of Celeron Corp. of $110.2 million for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $8.2 million for the quarter and a gain of $37.4 million from the sale of discontinued operations for the 9 months.

title: CF & I STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of assets of $7,000 for the quarter and $2,615,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income includes gains on the sale of assets of $1,388,000 for the quarter and $2,994,000 for the 9 months.

title: REAGAN AND ALLIED LEADERS DISCUSS GORBACHEV MEETING
description: President Reagan met with leaders of five of the leading industrial democracies today in advance of his meeting next month with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $23,763,000 for the quarter and $24,289,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $102,000 for the quarter and $196,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest quarter results include a non-recurring charge of $70.1 million to write down certain assets of its coal and oil and gas exploration subsidiary due to unsatisfactory financial performance at those operations.

title: 100 Brooklyn Artists
description: The paintings, sculptures and assemblages of more than 100 Brooklyn artists can be seen this weekend at Loft Two, on 36th Street between Second and Third Avenues, in Brooklyn The exhibition, which runs through Nov. 17, is presented by the Park Slope Artists Council, a a not-for-profit organization that promotes the arts in Brooklyn. The gallery is open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission is free. Information: (718) 768-2401.

title: HUSSEIN CONFERS WITH MUBARAK
description: King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met here today for four hours to discuss the latest initiatives for peace negotiations in the Middle East.

title: TALKS ON SALE OF PAPER END
description: Daniel Sullivan, a spokesman for a group of investors considering purchase of the financially ailing St. Louis Globe-Democrat said today negotations had been ended. Mr. Sullivan said Jeffrey M. Gluck, publisher of the paper, and his wife, Debra, had rejected an offer from his group. The newspaper sought protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws on Sept. 26.

title: BID TO OUST LOCAL SCHOOL BOARD MEMBERS REFLECTS DEEPER SPLIT
description: When New York City's two top education officials moved this week to dismiss nearly half the members of the city's 32 community school boards, the immediate issue was the local officials' refusal to file financial disclosure statements as provided for by state law.

title: 'Winter's Tale'
description: ''The Winter's Tale,'' one of Shakespeare's last works, will be performed today at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 and 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and West 95th Street.

title: China Denies Atom Aid To Iran and South Africa
description: China denied today that it had offered nuclear help to Iran and South Africa and it stressed that its nuclear contacts with Pakistan were for peaceful purposes.

title: ACME UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
ENDO-LASE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: BIRD IS FOCUS AT NETS' OPENER
description: The Larry Bird watch starts tonight. With the Nets opening their season against the Boston Celtics at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, how Bird passes, shoots and runs will be scrutinized.

title: KASPAROV CHEERED AS HE TAKES EDGE IN CHESS
description: A crowd of more than 1,000 chess fans erupted in cheers and whoops this evening in Tchaikovsky Concert Hall after Gary Kasparov came to the edge of victory in a thrill-packed game and moved closer to seizing the world championship from Anatoly Karpov.

title: CARDINALS' BULLPEN ARRIVES TOO LATE
description: The sellout crowd that came to Busch Stadium tonight in hopes of becoming part of a World Series celebration knew that the fate of the St. Louis Cardinals could rest in the hands of ''The Committee.'' And sure enough, the members of the Cardinal bullpen shuttled successfully in and out.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter include Lawyers Title Insurance Co., which was acquired in the second quarter ended Dec. 31, 1984.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIA TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MSGR. JOHN ROMANIELLO
description: Msgr. John Romaniello, ''the noodle priest of Hong Kong,'' died Monday at the Maryknoll Fathers headquarters here. He was 85 years old.

title: Making the Grade
description: Marathon is a west Texas town of 800 people, and there is not much for the local ranchers to do on a fall Friday night except cheer on the high school football team. But no longer this year.

title: MUSIC: CATHEDRAL CHOIR
description: THE Westminster Cathedral Choir is a superbly trained ensemble of young musicians, and its Tuesday evening concert at St. Ignatius Loyola Church was deeply satisfying. Although one suspects the choristers, some still in early grade school, are disciplined with a firm hand - little boys are, after all, little boys -there's a sense of genuine musical conviction to their performances.

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Aches and Pains
description: It was too bad that Vince Coleman had to miss the World Series, but that's the way it went in major league baseball this year, which turned out to be not only a season for the record books but also a season for freakish injuries. In addition to Coleman's curious encounter with a tarpaulin, there were these other bizarre happenings:

title: 'I'm Sick, I'm Sick, and I Have No One'
description: Early Tuesday evening at the Times Square BMT station a young woman named Mary Ventura pushed another young woman, Catherine Costello, off the platform. Miss Costello, an accountant who recently started her first post-college job, fell in the path of a southbound D train and was critically injured. Before being led away by transit police, Miss Ventura said, ''I'm sick, I'm sick, and I have no one.''

title: REID-PROVIDENT LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $503,000 related to settlement of litigation and the sale of a building.

title: A Copland Premiere
description: The world premiere of Aaron Copland's early piano piece ''Sonnet II'' will be a highlight of a benefit concert for the MacDowell Colony and the Museum of the American Piano tomorrow at 3 P.M. at Cami Hall, 165 West 57th Street. The program will feature music by several MacDowell composers, including Ned Rorem, Phillip Ramey, William Mayer, George Walker and Nicolas Roussakis, and will be played by Stephen Mayer, Samuel Bartos, Julie Jordan and Bennett Lerner. Tickets are $10; for information: 841-9633.

title: SYSTEM INTEGRATORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1985
description: International

title: Citizens Cable
description: Citizens Cable Communications Inc. said it had reached a definitive agreement for its previously announced acquisition by the Comcast Corporation, but the price has been cut to $15.15 a share, from $16. The company said the lower price had been agreed upon ''to resolve an impasse that had arisen during negotiations involving the magnitude of an unanticipated potential Federal income tax recapture liability.'' Citizens said the revised price was still subject to pre-closing adjustment based on its total liabilities, and as matters currently stand a further downward adjustment to $14.80 a share would be made.

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $6,416,000 in the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $14,439,000 in the nine months.

title: P.&G. NET UP 12.1% IN QUARTER
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the Cincinnati-based giant, today reported a 12.1 percent gain in net income for the recently concluded quarter, leading the earnings performance of three other large food and consumer products companies also reporting today.

title: Two Reggae Bands
description: The British reggae band Steel Pulse and the Jamaican reggae ''toaster,'' or rapper, Yellowman will share a double bill today at 7:30 P.M. at Radio City Music Hall, 1260 Sixth Avenue, 246-4600. Tickets are $20.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander's Inc., the department store, has named Gordon L. Bluestone senior vice president and Robert Mullen general merchandise manager.

title: LODGE & SHIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A MISNAMED POST OFFICE AND A FIGHT FOR CHANGE
description: Dorothy Macfarland pointed at the sign leading into town. ''See that sign,'' she said. ''Mount Tabor.''

title: Dirty Dozen Band
description: The Dirty Dozen Brass Band from New Orleans will perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; and 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Sunday. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CIBA-GEIGY INDICTED IN JERSEY FOR ILLEGAL DUMPING
description: The Ciba-Geigy Corporation, one of the nation's largest chemical manufacturers, has been indicted for illegally dumping toxic wastes into a landfill and into the Atlantic Ocean during the last decade, the State Attorney General said today.

title: REAGAN-KLINGHOFFER VISIT
description: The White House announced today that the family of Leon Klinghoffer would visit President Reagan on Friday in his suite at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

title: SOUTH AFRICA EASES EMERGENCY DECREE
description: President P. W. Botha announced today that he was lifting a state of emergency decree in 6 of the 36 magisterial districts where it has been in effect since the Government proclaimed it three months ago.

title: AMERICAN FILTRONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $7,039,000.

title: PHARMAKINETIC LABORATOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHIEF AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
How to Get the Russians Out of Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Bevill Agent Is Sued
description: The trustee for the bankrupt Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Asset Management Corporation filed a $159 million lawsuit yesterday against the Security Pacific Clearing Services Corporation, charging that the clearing agent helped to defraud customers of Asset Management. The trustee said in the suit that Security Pacific had been in a position to know that the owners of Asset Management were defrauding its customers.

title: COHU INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said figures include a gain of $160,000 from the sale of land for the quarter and 9 month periods of both years.

title: How Now Brown Zschau
description: No candidate today can afford an identity crisis. Representative Ed Zschau of California, who is seeking the 1986 Republican Senate nomination from that state, is using campaign stationery that includes a handy pronunciation guide. In tiny print above Zschau on his letterhead, it reads: ''schow as in now.''

title: CLOROX CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONSOLIDATED-BATHHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a special gain of $7.1 million for the quarter and 9 months. The year-ago figures were restated.

FROZEN FOOD EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for 5-for- 4 stock splits paid Sept 18, 1985 and Sept. 12, 1984.

title: Subverting a Treaty
description: Just one month before President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev meet at the summit, the Administration has subverted the ABM treaty, alarmed the NATO allies and brought into question its own good faith as well as its unity of purpose.

title: YANKS AND WHITE SOX AGREE ON TRADE
description: The Yankees, seemingly more active off the field than either of the World Series teams are on the field, have reached agreement on a seven-player trade with the Chicago White Sox, sources familiar with the deal said today. The trade, however, is contingent on the Yankees signing Carlton Fisk to a new contract and getting Don Baylor to approve a move to the White Sox.

title: CONNECTICUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Police Detectives Hunt Bryant Park Gunman
description: An expanded force of police detectives searched yesterday for the gunman who fired onto a crowded sidewalk outside Bryant Park Wednesday night, killing a woman and wounding three other people, one critically. The police said all the victims were bystanders.

title: ACTMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May.

description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union to the General Assembly today, as translated by the Soviet Mission to the United Nations:

title: MILITARY CUTS SEEN UNDER BUDGET PLAN
description: A budget-balancing plan passed by the Senate would threaten the Pentagon with drastic, automatic reductions in military personnel and equipment, according to an analysis prepared by the staff of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: Beirut Search is Pressed For 3 Soviet Hostages
description: Shiite and Druse militiamen conducted house-to-house searches in West Beirut and its southern suburbs today looking for three Soviet Embassy officials who were kidnapped 25 days ago. A similar search was conducted in Sidon.

title: U.S. TRIES TO SPUR MIDEAST PEACE BID
description: The United States sent a high-level official to Jordan this week to encourage Israel and Jordan toward Middle East peace talks, the State Department said yesterday.

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FROM LIECHTENSTEIN, QUINTESSENCES
description: THERE has never been, in New York or elsewhere, an exhibition quite like ''Liechtenstein: The Princely Collections'' at the Metropolitan Museum. This is not to say that it is better or worse than this exhibition or that, but simply that it is different. It is about places, and about people, almost as much as it is about works of art. Neither a monographic exhibition nor an aimless ramble, it is a show in which quintessences fall from the air like meteorites.

Two Men, Bound by a Sheet, Die in Leap From 35th Floor
description: Two men tied together with a bed sheet jumped to their deaths from their 35th-story apartment on the Upper East Side yesterday, the police said.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: BACK TO NORMAL - Today, for the first working day in more than a month, not a single king, president, prime minister or foreign minister is scheduled to address the General Assembly. The assembly, which will meet in a basement conference room in order to allow the hall to be prepared for tonight's United Nations Day concert, will take up more mundane matters: the report of the International Court of Justice, and cooperation between the United Nations and regional groups.

description: CHINA Zhao Ziyang Prime Minister Arms Race Called Threat to World Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China described a world threatened by the nuclear arms race of the superpowers and yet witnessing the emergence of nations that have escaped the influence of those powers.

title: MOVE SEEN ON LOCAL TAX ISSUE
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, told several members of his panel this week that he would support legislation that would retain Federal income tax deductions for state and local tax payments, those committee members said today.

title: Chrysler Canada Layoff
description: Chrysler Canada Ltd. said today that it was temporarily laying off more than a third of its work force at its plant in Ajax, Ontario, because of an inventory buildup resulting from a strike of Chrysler plants by American workers. That strike was settled Wednesday. There are 2,000 employees at the Ajax plant, which makes trim parts.

title: VETO IS LIKELY IF FARM BILL IS TOO COSTLY, AIDE SAYS
description: President Reagan has given up hope of holding Federal farm spending within the limits that he and Congress set just two months ago, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

Pullman-Peabody
description: The Pullman Company said its merger with the Peabody International Corporation to form the Pullman-Peabody Comapny had been approved by shareholders of both companies and becomes effective tonight. The company said Pullman's president and chief executive, Thomas M. Begel, becomes chairman and chief executive of the combined company. Peabody's chairman and chief executive, John E. McConnaughy Jr., and Pullman's chairman, James R. Shepley, become vice chairmen.

title: The U.N. at 40
description: There are no grounds for argument against the widespread judgment that the United Nations falls far short of what it should be, but it is a lot better than nothing. It has aged 40 years. It has not matured.

title: HRUDEY HELPS STOP NORDIQUES' STREAK
description: Billy Smith, the Islander goalie, and his Quebec counterpart, Richard Sevigny, were baffled by a series of 50-foot shots, 30-foot shots and other assorted missiles tonight. But Kelley Hrudey was sharp enough as Smith's replacement to enable the Islanders to beat Quebec, 6-5, and prevent the Nordiques from tying a record for most victories at the start of a season.

title: ART AND ANTIQUE SHOWS, FROM FOLK TO FURNITURE
description: The increasing importance to collectors of the Fall Antiques Show and of decorative arts has spawned a variety of other art and antique exhibitions around town this weekend. Following are some of the shows that may be of interest to collectors:

title: Moscow Reported to Expand Naval Base at Cam Ranh Bay
description: The Soviet Union has expanded its installations at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, making the former United States base its biggest overseas naval installation, Thailand's leading security official said in an interview published today.

title: U.N., 40, FAILS TO WIN ACCORD ON ITS PURPOSE
description: The United Nations turned 40 today, but the historic birthday party was marred by the failure of member nations to agree on a universal declaration of purpose.

title: SENATE APPROVES COMPROMISE BILL PUTTING OFF ARMS SALE TO JORDAN
description: The Senate approved a bill today that would prohibit the sale of advanced arms to Jordan before March 1. There was one dissenting vote.

title: First, Let the Voters Vote
description: A trial judge says New York voters should not be allowed to pass on a referendum opposing a naval base on Staten Island for ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons. He has stricken it from the Nov. 5 ballot for constitutional reasons. The referendum is a bad idea, but so is the judge's ruling and it warrants quick reversal.

title: BILINGUAL AID IN SCHOOLS TOO LITTLE, REPORT FINDS
description: More than 44,000 of the 114,000 New York City public-school students with limited ability in English are getting none of the extra language instruction the law requires, according to a report released yesterday by an advocacy group.

title: 8TH ARREST IN NAVY THEFT CASE
description: Federal agents arrested a former Navy employee from Norfolk, Va., today on charges that he helped steal aircraft parts for a West Coast group accused of smuggling parts for the F-14 Tomcat fighter to Iran.

title: SENATE SIGNALS SUPPORT FOR CURB ON IMPORTS OF TEXTILES AND SHOES
description: The Senate today ignored threats of a Presidential veto and warnings of economic disaster and strongly signaled its approval of a severe limit on textile and footwear imports.

title: SHUTTLE TO ORBIT WITH JOURNALISTS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that a journalist would be chosen to fly into orbit aboard the space shuttle, probably on a flight next fall.

title: POLAND EXPECTS TO JOIN I.M.F. AND WORLD BANK
description: Poland, which has a crushing debt burden, shortly expects to become the 149th member of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank and to qualify for hundreds of millions of dollars of credits, according to Polish economists, including one member of the ruling Central Committee. All were interviewed today at Poland's Embassy here.

title: Angola Is No Place To Test U.S. Resolve
description: The Reagan Administration is seriously considering financial support for the Angolan guerrilla faction led by Jonas Savimbi and backed by South Africa. Because the Marxist Government of Angola is supported by Soviet military advisers and Cuban forces, such action is seen as a way of demonstrating the credibility of American resolve on the eve of the summit meeting. The argument is not a new one. When Henry A. Kissinger decided to intervene in the Angolan civil war in 1975, he was also preoccupied with demonstrating American credibility. Then as now, it was a seriously mistaken view.

title: Advertising;   Arnell Chief Corrects Fragrance Assignment
description: Peter Arnell, president of Arnell/ Bickford Associates, reported yesterday that when he announced Monday that his agency had picked up the Jean Patou Inc., fragrance business he thought it was a full-service assignment, including media buying. He has since learned from the client, he said, that media buying would continue to be the province of Al Paul Lefton Inc., which has served Jean Patou for 47 years.

title: Advertising;   Ziff-Davis to Close Creative Computing
description: Because the segmentation and heavy business orientation that has come to the microcomputer market has had an negative impact on the growth of Creative Computing magazine, Ziff-Davis Publishing is going to close down the magazine with its December issue.

title: MORE IMPORTS BY CHRYSLER EXPECTED
description: The tentative labor agreement at the Chrysler Corporation will be an added incentive to the company to buy more cars and parts from low-cost foreign sources, according to auto industry analysts.

title: Shares Rise On Texas Gas
description: The shares of the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation rose sharply yesterday and the stock was at the top of the New York Stock Exchange's most active list after rumors arose again that the company might become a target of the United States Steel Corporation.

title: What the President Left Out
description: To a world eager for progress toward peace at Geneva, President Reagan yesterday offered a combative sermon. He spoke of the innate goodness of Americans and the sanctity of freedom. He called on the Soviet Union to join with the United States in resolving regional conflicts - but only in those regions where Moscow stands to lose. Mr. Reagan seemed less interested in diplomacy than in scoring debating points off Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: TRAIL OF LOUISIANA'S GOVERNOR HEARS ABOUT ROLE OF BROTHER
description: A hospital company executive, testifying today in Gov. Edwin W. Edwards's trial on racketeering charges, linked the Governor to negotiations for the sale of a corporation that had a valuable state approval to build a hospital.

title: Cunard QE2 Plan
description: Cunard Line Ltd. said it would spend about $115 million to install a new diesel electric power plant in its flagship, the Queen Elizabeth 2. The ship will be taken out of service Nov. 1 for six months for the project, which will keep the liner the fastest passenger ship in the world.

title: Economic Scene;   Opposing Voice On Deficit Plan
description: WITH United States fiscal policy in disarray, some legislators are willing to say that neither the King nor the King's men have clothes. Senator Mark O. Hatfield, the Oregon Republican who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, took direct aim yesterday at President Reagan over the budget deficit.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: INDIAN cuisine, at least as represented in this country, is not known for innovation. The fare in most of New York's Indian restaurants is as predictable as scarlet curtains in the dining room, dim lighting and soft-spoken managers wearing tinted, black-framed glasses. The best you can hope for is well-made breads, succulent tandoor-roasted specialties, authentically hot and spicy stews and fresh vegetable-rice preparations. That, in short, is what you get at Tandoor, the spacious, low-key midtown restaurant that is marking its 10th anniversary Little seems to have changed since it opened. The hushed main dining room is still accommodating with its tufted red banquettes, ornate wall moldings and Indian paintings. Unfortunately, the phlegmatic waiters do not contribute to a welcoming atmosphere - they tend to be distant and slow - but if you are willing to endure that inconvenience, there is some exceptional food to be had.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE legendary Harry's Bar in Venice, celebrated by Hemingway and apotheosized by travel writers ever since, plans to open a branch in New York next month. The American incarnation, to be called ''Harry Cipriani'' after the family that founded the original in 1936, will be at the former site of Le Petit Cafe at the Sherry Netherland Hotel, 781 Fifth Avenue, at 59th Street.

title: FILM: 'KRUSH GROOVE,' BY MICHAEL SCHULTZ
description: CONSIDERING the kind of boisterous energy that goes into rap records, Michael Schultz's ''Krush Groove,'' which opens today at the RKO Warner Twin and other theaters, seems pretty tame. A group of rap performers is assembled here, including Run-D.M.C., the Fat Boys and Kurtis Blow, and given a chance to perform a virtually nonstop score. That's the better part of the film, although many of the concert scenes have been shot clumsily and edited in a way that cuts the numbers short.

title: Jean Gordon Stern, 81, Dance Magazine Head
description: Jean Gordon Stern, the owner and publisher of Dance Magazine, died at her home in Manhattan Tuesday. She was 81 years old.

title: The Selling Of a Schoolboy
description: Jim O'Keefe, a Boston University sophomore, is a big, fast and agile linebacker who could probably play at any number of Division I schools. But as much as he owes to his size, speed and agility, he owes his college scholarship to an acronym - AIDA.
