title: 'Sleepy Hollow' Tours
description: ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow,'' the 19th-century tale set near the Hudson River, will be remembered through film, storytelling and a puppet show this weekend during tours of the historic Sunnyside in Tarrytown, N.Y. - where the legend's author, Washington Irving, once lived - and the Philipsburg Manor in North Tarrytown.

title: STAGE: 'GOBLIN MARKET,' FROM POEM
description: WHETHER or not one regards Christina Rossetti's poem ''Goblin Market'' as a fairy tale for children or a psychosexual plunge into the repressed Victorian heart, there is no denying the forbidden-fruit fascination that it continues to have for the reader - of whatever age, or whichever sex.

title: How to Inflate The Trade Deficit
description: Congress seems increasingly seduced by the notion that protectionism will reduce our trade deficit. But the protectionist measures floating around Capitol Hill will have precisely the opposite effect. They will drive up the value of the dollar, place our exports at an even greater disadvantage and in time lead to demands for even more protection.

title: Honoring the Duke
description: The original design for a commemorative stamp honoring Duke Ellington will be unveiled by Postmaster General Paul N. Carlin today at a gala benefit for the Duke Ellington School of the Arts in Georgetown. The 22-cent stamp, which features a profile of the composer-orchestra leader, will be officially issued in 1986. Among the participants in the benefit at the school will be Lena Horne, who starred in the first Ellington gala five years ago and recently moved to Washington.

title: BRIGHT OUTLOOK IN SPRING FADES IN AUTUMN FOR CHALLENGER IN HOUSTON RACE
description: Louie Welch, who was Mayor of Houston for five consecutive terms and now seeks to get his old job back by defeating Mayor Kathy Whitmire in the Nov. 5 election, says the major issue is jobs and industry, but he also likes to talk about image.

title: NETS' KING GETS KNICK OFFER
description: After more than five months of virtual silence between Albert King and the Nets, the free-agent forward had a message for the team yesterday: an offer sheet from the Knicks worth close to $3 million over five seasons, including a $1 million signing bonus.

title: McDonnell Drops; Celanese Has Gain
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, citing losses in its information systems business, reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter fell 17.3 percent McDonnell Douglas, which said that earnings were also hurt by a higher tax rate and higher interest costs, said net income fell to $73.1 million, or $1.81 a share, from $88.4 million, or $2.19 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 17.1 percent, to $2.88 billion, from $2.46 billion.

title: MIXED REVIEWS FOR WYMAN
description: It has been a tough year for Thomas H. Wyman, the chairman of CBS Inc. No sooner had he fought off a takeover bid by Ted Turner, the Atlanta-based entrepreneur, than he felt compelled to ask another potential bidder, Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of the Loews Corporation, to join the CBS board.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE major studio that will be bringing you ''Superman IV,'' ''Death Wish 3,'' Robert Altman's ''Fool for Love,'' Franco Zeffirelli's ''Otello,'' Jean-Luc Godard's ''King Lear'' and new action films starring Chuck Norris and Sylvester Stallone, not to mention ''Spider-Man,'' ''Captain America'' and Tobe Hooper's ''Pinocchio the Robot,'' isn't major at all. It isn't even a studio. It's the Cannon Group, the Israeli-run independent production company that until now has been known chiefly for breakdance movies, teen-age comedies, Brooke Shields's ''Sahara,'' Bo Derek's ''Bolero,'' and assorted other schlock.

title: Hanson Trust Suit
description: After three days of hearings in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Judge Shirley Wohl Kram adjourned a lawsuit by Hanson Trust P.L.C. against the SCM Corporation until next Tuesday. Hanson, a British conglomerate trying to take over SCM, is seeking a preliminary injunction to prevent Merrill Lynch Capital Markets from buying two key SCM businesses as part of a plan to buy the company.

title: Bell Canada-Daon
description: Bell Canada Enterprises Inc. said its share exchange offer for the Daon Development Corporation was restrained by a court order obtained late Wednesday by the National Trust Company and the Central Trust Company in the British Columbia Supreme Court. The trust companies say that the proposed transaction would constitute a breach of the financial restructuring agreement with Daon, Bell Canada said. Bell's offer for Daon was announced last week.

title: After a Rough Start, Traffic Loosens a Bit
description: Traffic on the East Side was heavy yesterday morning because of the United Nations's 40th anniversary celebrations, but was fairly smooth during the rest of the day, traffic officials said, Between 8:30 and 10 A.M., on the morning of President Reagan's address, motorcades of diplomats compounded regular rush-hour traffic, according to Samuel I. Schwartz, chief of the city's Bureau of Traffic Operations.

(with the pianist Jon Jang and Fred Houn and the Asian-American Art Ensemble) and Sunday at 7:30 P.M. (with Mr. Hwang, the East of the Sun Orchestra and the dancer Genevieve Lam). WEEKENDER GUIDE: Friday
description: FIRST WOMAN FILM MAKER Women directors may still find it tough going in the movie industry, but there as in other fields their history includes long-forgotten pioneers. This weekend, the American Museum of the Moving Image in Queens is presenting a program of films by one such figure, Alice Guy-Blache, the first woman film maker. Miss Guy-Blache started making movies in 1896 in France, and later came to the United States to become the first woman to own and operate a movie studio. From 1910 to 1914, she supervised the production of more than 350 films - at least 35 of which she directed herself - under the auspices of her studio, the Solax Company, which began in Flushing, Queens. The current series of programs honors the 75th anniversary of the Solax Company. Being screened tonight at 7:30 will be ''Greater Love Hath No Man,'' ''The Detective's Dog,'' ''His Double,'' ''Canned Harmony,'' ''The Girl in the Armchair,'' and ''Beasts of the Jungle,'' an extravagant production that reportedly cost more than $18,000 and has the distinction of featuring the first scenes in which actors, lions and tigers appeared in the same shot. On Saturday at 7:30 P.M., the program is ''Officer Henderson,'' ''The Burstup Homes Murder Case,'' ''A House Divided,'' ''Matrimony's Speed Limit'' and ''Brennan of the Moor.'' The screenings will be in the Zukor Theater at 34-31 35th Street of the Kaufman Astoria Studio Complex. Tickets are $4. Information: (718) 784-4742.

title: CLEVELAND-CLIFFS IRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ART: JEWISH EMIGRES IN PARIS, 1905-45
description: JUST after the turn of the century, Marc Chagall, Jacques Lipchitz, Amedeo Modigliani, Chaim Soutine and many other Jewish artists from all over Europe migrated to Paris and formed what the art historian Kenneth E. Silver has described as the ''first generation of Jews to become professional visual artists in the West.'' Paris was so liberating and irresistible to them that it transported their work and became known in the places they left behind as the ''city from which artists would not return.'' ''The Circle of Montparnasse: Jewish Artists in Paris 1905-1945,'' at the Jewish Museum through Feb. 2, is the first major attempt to tell their story.

title: Johnson Net Up by 14.7%
description: Johnson & Johnson, the medical and institutional supplies company based in New Brunswick, N.J., said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 14.7 percent, to $158 million, or 87 cents a share, from $137.7 million, or 75 cents a share, a year ago.

description: Senator Alan K. Simpson calls it the ''Christmas crunch,'' that time of a Congressional session when frustrated lawmakers plaintively ask: ''When do we get out of here?''

title: Virgin Air in Bid For Standby Fare
description: Virgin Atlantic Airways, a closely held British company, has applied to the British Civil Aviation Authority to authorize a standby fare of $:99, or about $142, for London-to-New York flights. Virgin is also urging its potential passengers to take advantage of the new low-cost domestic fares on sale here from three American airlines at $:22, or about $31, per flight. A Virgin spokesman said the airline hoped customers would fly to New York on Virgin, then transfer to Pan American, Trans World Airlines or Northwest, which are offering the inexpensive local flights to any United States destination.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: PERT, smiling faces and cookie-cutter voices singing innocuous ditties. That's the picture that comes to many people's minds at the mention of early 1950's pop music. In fact, most of the stars from that era have proven more substantial than their packaging used to suggest. Ronnie Gilbert and Kay Starr, who both had No. 1 hits in the early 50's and who both are appearing in New York this weekend, share a quality that might be called true grit, for their careers have the vagaries of fashion and politics.

HOME OF ARGENTINE OFFICIAL LINKED TO ARRESTS IS BOMBED
description: A bomb exploded early today at the weekend home of an Argentine official closely identified with the Government's decision this week to jail 12 people suspected of taking part in right-wing violence.

title: Secret List
description: Many athletes refuse to compete in South Africa as a protest against apartheid, but according to the organizers of the Million Dollar Golf Challenge in Bophuthatswana, a full field of 10 men has been recruited for the 1985 tournament that begins Dec. 5, with only two of the five spots for women still open. Even so, in the face of unrest in South Africa, the organizers have been forced to make one concession to international opinion: They are keeping the entry list secret. But Seve Ballesteros of Spain, who won the last two tournaments, collecting about $300,000 each time, told a Madrid newspaper: ''It would become politicized if I did not attend the tournament.''

title: NICARAGUA AND ETHIOPIA REBUT REAGAN REMARKS
description: Nicaraguan and Ethiopian officials denounced President Reagan's speech at the United Nations today and took issue with his assertions on the number of Soviet-backed troops in their countries.

title: FOLK: ELECTRONIC ROCHES
description: ON the Roches' newest album, ''Another World,'' New York's City's finest folk-singing group has ventured confidently from acoustically based music into an electronically inflected folkpop that uses synthesizers and drum machines. And at the Bottom Line, where they performed on Tuesday and Wednesday, the trio, augmented by the keyboardist Libby McLaren, translated their newly adopted studio vocabulary into a dazzlingly accomplished opening-night show.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $550.3 million, to $208.7 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the second consecutive week that declines were registered in all categories, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The 73 institutional funds led the decline, falling $254.1 million, to $52.837 billion. Assets of the 192 general purpose funds were down $142.9 million, to $61.774 billion, and the 87 broker-dealer funds fell $153.3 million, to $94.093 billion.

Wayne Lukas-trained entry that will be heavily favored in the $1 million Distaff, and Proud Truth, an upset possibility in the $3 million Classic.

Miss Jenkins really does mix her media, and the effect is often astonishing.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LIVES OF LEE MILLER. By Antony Penrose. 216 pages. Illustrated. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $29.95. IN her heyday, Lee Miller was a legend - the beautiful Vogue model who was also an outstanding photographer, the muse of the Surrealists who went on to cover some of the most dramatic and devastating scenes of World War II as a photojournalist. In her later years, she faded from view, and by the time she died in 1977, she was pretty much a forgotten figure. But recently there have been renewed stirrings of interest in her, and the biographical study that her son has written, accompanied as it is by many examples of her work, now makes it possible for the first time to follow the full course of a remarkable career.

title: AUCTIONS
description: A COPY of the cartoon that started Paul Revere's career as a political propagandist will be auctioned Thursday at 10:15 A.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. The engraving, the only colored version of the five known copies, shows a dragon, representing the Stamp Act, attacked by a number of people, symbolizing the Colonies, while a New Hampshire tax collector is hung in effigy from the Liberty Tree.

title: THE SUDDEN DECLINE AT APOLLO
description: For much of its five-year history, Apollo Computer Inc. had been one of the computer industry's great success stories. When its stock went public, it sold for a dizzying 50 times earnings. And sales of the company's powerful desktop computers, known as engineering work stations and used by engineers and other product designers, doubled and doubled again in 1983 and 1984, to reach $215.9 million.

title: Honoring the Earl
description: Observance of the coming visit to Washington of the Prince and Princess of Wales may have gotten out of hand. Lady Wright, wife of the British Ambassador, will be hostess at a tea today at the Sheraton Carlton in honor of the Earl of Litchfield, a cousin of Prince Charles who was official photographer at his wedding.

title: TOP ROCKERS ARE IN TOWN, SWINGING BACK TO BASICS
description: THIS is the kind of weekend when first-rate rock-and-roll bands all over the United States - from Hoboken to Los Angeles - converge on the city's clubs and concert halls, some to prove themselves in the media capital, some to reclaim and expand their New York audiences.

title: BAM IS A MECCA OF THE NEW
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music will be a beehive of experimentalist dance and theater activity this weekend, when the modern dance companies of Margaret Jenkins and Carolyn Carlson perform in the Academy's Lepercq Space and Opera House, respectively, and Robert Wilson takes over the Academy's Carey Playhouse for the American premiere of his play ''The Golden Windows.''

title: WEST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOUNDER OF AVIS WANTS IT BACK
description: Warren E. Avis, who founded Avis Rent-a-Car in 1947 with a $10,000 investment and sold it in 1955 for $8 million, wants to buy the company back again. The price tag on the company now is several hundred million.

title: Army Contracts
description: The United Technologies Corporation's Sikorsky division has received a $341.5 million contract for 96 UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters, the Army said. It is the second increment of a multiyear procurement of the helicopters. Work will be performed at Stratford, Conn., and is expected to be completed by August 1987.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DICOMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,160,000 for the quarter and $1,250,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Including a tax credit of $75,000.

title: BIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1.65 million as a result of the devaluation of the Mexican peso which was offset by higher interest expense in Mexico.

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring tax credit of $4,002,000, or 29 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: CRAXI IS POSITIVE ON U.S. RELATIONS
description: Bettino Craxi, the caretaker Prime Minister of Italy, says he does not blame the Reagan Administration for the collapse of his Government in the aftermath of the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro.

title: Speculum Musicae
description: Speculum Musicae opens its 15th anniversary season Sunday night at 8 o'clock with music by Alban Berg and Karlheinz Stockhausen at the Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: S.E.C. May Propose New Rules on Tenders
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, John S. R. Shad, told Congress today that his agency would propose new rules concerning tender offers made in takeover situations.

title: Cogenic Energy Shifts To Replace Co-founder
description: Cogenic Energy Systems Inc., the nation's leading manufacturer of modular cogeneration systems, said yesterday that Richard H. Nelson, president and chief executive, had been named chairman.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ABOUT 25 years ago, ''there was only one important hairdresser'' in Palm Beach, Fla., Prince Johannes von Thurn und Taxis was saying. ''Now,'' he added, ''there are 10!''

title: PHILADELPHIA PRESS STRIKE: THE EFFECTS
description: When word came at 4:30 Tuesday afternoon that the 46-day Philadelphia newspaper strike was officially over, several hundred employees who had gathered expectantly in front of The Philadelphia Inquirer's building streamed inside. Wednesday's issue started coming off the presses just after midnight.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $450,000. The company said net income for the latest quarter was enhanced by an adjustment to its estimated annual tax rate and a reduction by $250,000 in accrued tax reserves. The year-ago results include $2.30 a share gain from the sale of property.

title: DIAGNOSTIC PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GRAHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: AMERICA WEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a profit sharing provision of $536,000 which will be paid to the company's employees in October. c-Net loss

title: ALL'S FAIR AT PIER FAIR: A DIVERSITY OF AMERICANA
description: The increasing importance to collectors of the Fall Antiques Show and of decorative arts has spawned a variety of other art and antique exhibitions around town this weekend. Following are some of the shows that may be of interest to collectors:

title: FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GILBERT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misstated the day of Senator Mark O. Hatfield's appearance before a conference of business executives in Washington. It was Thursday.

title: PURCHASE SIGNED BY BRISTOL-MYERS
description: The Bristol-Myers Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the Genetic Systems Corporation in a stock transaction valued at $10.50 a share, or a total of $294 million. The companies had announced a preliminary agreement earlier this week.

title: MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
M.D.C. HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE DANCE: MARIE CHOUINARD OF MONTREAL
description: Marie Chouinard, a hard-working enfant terrible from Montreal, tends to dance topless. In her newest solo, she even manages to have the paint on her breasts match the periwinkle blue that smears her face as she transforms herself into a wrathful pseudo-Asian deity.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. Accompanying the jogging President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, in New York for the United Nations commemoration, were Secret Service agents with holsters and Nicaraguan security guards holding aloft guns in white plastic bags. 2. Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India and President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan held a cordial meeting. In a concession to King Hussein of Jordan, Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel agreed that the Soviet Union could be invited, along with the United States and perhaps some other nations, to a Middle East peace conference. 3. Macy's. Henri Bendel. 4. Whether to make changes in the requirement that Federal contractors set numerical goals for hiring women and members or minority groups. 5. Americanism - a word, phrase, or usage originating in, or peculiar to American English. 6. Mr. Craxi's protests against American attacks on his handling of the Achille Lauro incident and the conciliatory message he received from President Reagan have apparently strengthened his popularity, and he has been asked to form a new government. 7. The United Nations was meeting in its first headquarters, Hunter College. 8. The Jets. 9. Denied. 10. Nancy Reagan. 11. Almost 500,000 Federal employees participate in flexitime, an alternative work schedule program that allows full-time workers to adjust their hours to suit their personal needs. The Federal program is scheduled to end Oct. 31. 12. The justice acted on a referendum to block a Navy base in New York City for ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons, ruling that it would infringe on the Federal Government's power to provide for the nation's defense. 13.

title: CORRETTA KING, IN JERSEY, BACKS KEAN AS HE SEEKS THE SUPPORT OF BLACKS
description: Coretta Scott King, a Democrat of long standing, came here today to endorse a Republican, Governor Kean, for re-election.

title: EQUIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $1,279,000 for the quarter and $2,019,000 for the 9 months. c-Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income, therefore no per earnings. d-Net loss The latest third quarter earnings include a gain of $11,937,000 on the sale of 11 of Equibank's branch officed in Western Pennsylvania. The gain was offset in part by reduced net interest income and an increased provision for possible loan losses.

title: VELO-BIND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPEN DATA BACKED IN BMT PUSHING
description: A judge yesterday ordered the unsealing of most of the transcript of a hearing that led to the release of a psychiatric patient accused of pushing a woman into the path of a BMT train this week.

title: U.S. Women's Team Loses To Last-Place Indian Squad
description: When the world team championships continued here today, Brazil and Israel seemed headed for qualification in the open series, but the women's division became a question mark.

title: ALLIED SIGNAL SALE
description: Allied-Signal Inc. said it had agreed to sell its North American Refractories Company to a management group and an investment firm in a leveraged buyout.

title: VERBATIM MOVING SOME OPERATIONS
description: The Verbatim Corporation, a major manufacturer of computer diskettes based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would move all diskette finishing, testing and packaging operations to its plants in North Carolina, Ireland and Mexico, resulting in about 400 layoffs at its Sunnyvale location.

title: EXCERPTS FROM STEVENS'S REBUTTAL OF MEESE
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Associate Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court that was delivered Wednesday in Chicago and made public today in Washington:

title: CORRECTION
description: A review on Thursday of a recital by the Soviet pianist Andrei Gavrilov misstated his age. He is 30.

title: FIRST WYOMING BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NETS DEFEAT CLETICS IN OVERTIME
description: Since the naming of Dave Wohl as the new Nets' coach, much has been said and written of the importance to the Nets' success of Micheal Ray Richardson and Darryl Dawkins. In the season opener tonight, Richardson, the playmaker, and the 6-foot-11-inch Dawkins, for whom coaches have waited 10 seasons to grow into a dominating pro center, played the key roles as the Nets raced back from a 19-point third-quarter deficit and defeated the the Boston Celtics, 113-109, in overtime at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1985
description: International

title: CORVUS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $4,097,000. The latest quarter's results include Onyx & Imi Inc., which was acquired July 30 on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: APPELLATE COURT UPHOLDS RULING ON VOTE ON BASE
description: A state appeals court upheld a lower-court ruling yesterday and blocked a New York City referendum on a proposed Navy base for ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons.

title: L-1011'S MAY FACE INSPECTIONS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board yesterday recommended that all Lockheed L-1011 jumbo jets be inspected immediately to check electrical and other systems that were involved in a brief fire aboard a Jordanian airliner last week.

title: VICTORY MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Aurora Chamber Group At Merkin Concert Hall
description: The baroque chamber ensemble Aurora plays with a warm conviviality, creating a sound that is dapper, delicate and spirited. On Monday night at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street), the four members of the group - Virginia Brewer and Lisa Sandow Lyons on baroque violin, Loretta O'Sullivan on baroque cello and Eric Milnes on harpsichord -were joined by Stephen Hammer on recorder for a program of music by Telemann, Handel, Couperin, Vivaldi and the lesser-known Johann Fasch, Marco Uccellini and Dario Castello.

title: 14-YEAR CONSERVATIVE WAR ENDS IN LIBEL JUDGMENT FOR MAGAZINE
description: A Federal jury tonight presented a mixed verdict in a bitter, drawn-out libel contest between two organs of the conservative movement, National Review and Liberty Lobby.

title: WISCONSIN POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCHOOL BOYCOTT GROWS OVER AIDS FEARS
description: More than half the pupils at an elementary school here were absent today in a growing boycott by parents protesting the attendance of a 9-year-old boy whose sister has an AIDS-related disorder, the Superintendent of Schools said.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Congressmen, at U.N., Urge Big Effort on Drugs
description: A delegation of American members of Congress urged the industrialized nations today to join with developing nations to combat ''an international epidemic'' of drug trafficking and vastly increase their contributions to the $20 million United Nations Fund for Drug Abuse Control.

title: Ex-Florida Legislator Acquitted by U.S. Jury
description: A Federal District Court jury today acquitted a former state legislator of charges that he helped a drug smuggler hide his illegal assets.

title: Lisa Grossman Becomes Bride
description: Elizabeth Ellen Grossman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Grossman of West Gilgo Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Donald Edmund Thomas, the son of Mrs. Edmund Thomas of Sun City, Ariz., and the late Mr. Thomas. The Rev. Dr. Warren Danskin, a Methodist minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the couple's home in Manhattan.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT AGREES TO BUYOUT
description: The Swift Independent Corporation, the nation's largest pork packer, said its board had approved a letter of intent for a $135 million leveraged buyout from a partnership led by a Texas investor, Edwin L. Cox Jr. The proposal calls for each share of Swift to be converted into $21 cash and $7 face value of a cumulative exchangeable preferred stock.

title: JAPANESE PROTECT OH'S RECORD
description: While Japan's political leaders were in New York today to assure President Reagan that their domestic markets were open, Japanese back home offered unique proof that the protectionist spirit was far from dead.

title: KARPOV CONCEDES 19TH GAME
description: An excellent performance of attacking/positional play by the 22-year-old challenger for the world chess championship, Gary Kasparov, forced the 34-year-old champion, Anatoly Karpov, to concede defeat in the 19th game of their title match in Moscow yesterday.

title: BOSTON EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GATX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net charge of $78 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income.

title: YOUTH VERSUS HISTORY IN THE SIXTH GAME
description: He does not have the precision or achievement rating of John Tudor. He does not have the senior status of Bob Forsch. And he certainly does not have the flair or air of mystery of Joaquin Andujar.

title: DANCE: KRISHNATTAM, A FORM OF SACRED DRAMA FROM INDIA
description: Since the 17th century, an unusual form of sacred dance-drama called Krishnattam has existed in southwestern India. It is performed by a single company, originally attached to the court of Calicut and now under the sponsorship of the temple of Guruvayurappan, and the entire repertory is limited to eight plays, all concerning the god Krishna. Until the group visited Paris in 1980, few Westerners had ever seen any of these plays, for only Hindus are allowed inside the temple.

title: MUSIC: NHK SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA OF JAPAN
description: One wishes the NHK Symphony Orchestra of Japan, which played Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, had chosen a more interesting program for its first New York concert in over a quarter-century. Only the first work, Hidemaro Konoye's ''Etenraku,'' was unfamiliar; the other two, much longer pieces - Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 and Dvorak's Cello Concerto - are genuine warhorses trotted out again and again by visiting orchestra after visiting orchestra.

title: KOHL MEETS WITH JEWISH LEADERS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany shared a kosher lunch yesterday with a group of American Jewish leaders and held what was described as a ''soul-baring'' discussion about lingering ill feelings from President Reagan's visit to a German military cemetery in May.

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 6.

title: BISHOP MUGAVERO GOES INTO HOSPITAL
description: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Brooklyn Roman Catholic Diocese has been hospitalized with pneumonia, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After restructuring charges of $31 million, principally relating to the polyester cotton apparel fabrics area and an 8 cents a share gain from reduction in retirement system expenses. c-Includes a gain of 9 cents a share from the sale of the company's office furniture business and a 6 cents a share gain from litigation. d-Includes a charge of $1.07 a share for the restructuring of various finished apparel fabric operations in the U.S. and the shutdown and conversion of a textured woven operation in Ireland. e-Includes restructuring charges of $1.20 a share, a 15 cents a share gain from litigation and an 8 cents a share gain from an in-substance defeasance of long-term debt. Foreign currency items resulted in a loss of 2 cents a share in 1985 and a 6 cents a share gain in 1984.

title: BUT WILL ANYONE SYA 'HI, MOM'?
description: The football team at Eastern Illinois University has made it all the way to regional television a couple of times, most notably in December 1978 when ABC picked up the Panthers' victory over Delaware in the Division II championship game. But national TV? Never.

title: BIG THREE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The results for the latest third quarter and 9 months reflect an after-tax writedown of certain oil and gas assets of $42.3 million.

title: PHILIPPINE GENERAL SAYS UP TO 12,500 REBELS HAVE JOINED THE FIGHT
description: The top military officer in the Philippines said today that the Communist insurgency had grown to a fighting strength of as many as 12,500 men, considerably higher than a recent estimate by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: COURT BACKS PLAN TO LIMIT ABORTION COUNSELING
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they wanted Congress to forbid abortion counseling by family planning clinics that receive Federal money.

title: LEADER IMPOSES A STATE OF SIEGE ON ARGENTINA
description: Argentina's civilian President, Raul Alfonsin, today imposed a 60-day state of siege on the country. The action was seen as a move to free the Government's hand to combat a sharp increase in violence widely attributed to right-wing terrorists.

title: ACCO WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ORTEGA FACES THE PEOPLE BUT MOST ARE FRIENDS
description: He entered to a standing ovation and shouts in Spanish of ''They shall not pass!''

title: Article 107842 -- No Title
description: Texas Instruments Inc., in its deepest financial crisis since a foray into home computers cost it hundreds of millions of dollars two years ago, said yesterday that it lost $82.8 million in the third quarter and would lay off 2,200 more employees.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARMCO'S CHAIRMAN PLANS TO STEP DOWN
description: Armco Inc., which is trying to climb back to profitability after three successive years of huge losses, said today that Harry Holiday Jr., its chairman since 1982, would retire next Jan. 31. Mr. Holiday, who is 62 years old, will be succeeded by Dr. Robert E. Boni, 57, who will remain president and chief executive.

title: COMPUGRAPHIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOCTORS AT GATHERING SHARPLY DISAGREE ON HOW THE DEVICES SHOULD BE USED
description: Four heart surgeons who have implanted artificial hearts disagreed sharply today on how to use the new mechanical devices in the wake of severe complications that have developed in previous patients.

title: CHANNEL 31 OFFERS SHAKESPEARE WORKSHOPS
description: In 1982, Britain's London Weekend Television recorded nine studio workshops of the Royal Shakespeare Company - its actors in sessions overseen by the associate director, John Barton. ''Playing Shakespeare'' is now being shown on Channel 31 on Mondays at 9 P.M., with repeats on Saturdays. The first installment can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: REAGAN SAID TO PROMISE A POST-GENEVA BRIEFING
description: President Reagan has agreed to meet with European leaders after his conference next month with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, according to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.

title: YANKEES WORKING ON BID TO GET FISK
description: George Steinbrenner and Jerry Kapstein, the agent for Carlton Fisk and Don Baylor, began negotiating today a contract that would make Fisk a Yankee and help complete a seven-player trade between the Yankees and the Chicago White Sox.

title: LAVELLE HAS A BOOK BUT NO PUBLISHER
description: Broke, angry, contending that she was ''lynched by politicians to further their own careers,'' Rita Lavelle, the former Environmental Protection Agency official jailed for perjury, has written a book about what really happened, she says, including how she was ''framed'' by her former bosses.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,186,000 for the quarter and $1,398,000 for the 9 months.

title: THE PARTY SEEMS TO BE OVER FOR LOWER MANHATTAN CLUBS
description: Fall is the season when new nightspots usually pop up like goldenrod. But this year is different. There is a blight on the Elysian fields of Lower Manhattan's clubland.

title: VERIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss, including a loss from discontinued operations of $78,000.

title: TEXTILE MILLS SQUEEZED IN MODERNIZATION DRIVE
description: In the employee parking lot of the Spartan Mills headquarters office, there is not a foreign car to be seen, and the bumper of the chairman's Cadillac bears a sticker that proclaims: ''Crafted With Pride in the U.S.A.''

title: ASTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONSANTO RESTURCTURE IS PLANNED
description: The Monsanto Company announced today that it would divest itself of certain assets, withdraw from several low-return businesses and cut its work force in a major restructuring that will result in an after-tax charge of $559 million in the fourth quarter.

title: MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. c-Including a gain of $1,404,000 from an accounting adjustment. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: CIRCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHICAGO IS ON HEELS OF N.Y. MARATHON
description: In a relatively short time the New York City Marathon has attained an ''event'' status that transcends the quality of the field in any given year. But the question arises whether this overnight tradition the marathon enjoys - making it the Kentucky Derby of long-distance running - can sustain itself in a period when many of the elite marathoners in the world are taking the money and running elsewhere.

title: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MELRIDGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CARTER LIBRARY NEEDS CONFLICT RESOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAFALGAR BID FOR MINEBEA
description: Trafalgar Holdings Ltd. and the Glen International Financial Service Company, a London-based securities and investment company, formally announced a bid today to acquire the Minebea Company, a Japanese manufacturer of miniature ball bearings and electronic parts.

title: CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net income

title: LEMONS MAKE SOVIET ARCTIC LIFE A LITTLE SWEETER
description: Nearly 200 miles above the Arctic Circle, thousands of miles from the nearest citrus orchard, Murmansk is swamped with bright yellow lemons these days.

title:
PATENTS;

COMPACT HEART PUMP
description: A patent was granted this week to Walter E. Strimling, a physicist in Weston, Mass., for a pump for a mechanical heart that takes up less space than previous heart pumps. According to patent 4,547,911, the pump runs at two or three times the speed of normal heartbeats.

title: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DESPITE CRACKDOWN BY CITY, BICYCLISTS STAY IN HIGH GEAR
description: Near Herald Square, where Broadway crosses the Avenue of the Americas in a tumult of screeching brakes and honking horns, bicyclists have a traffic signal all their own: a little illuminated bicycle that blinks red or green when it is time to stop or go.

title: PANEL IS EXPECTED TO DISCLOSE FINDING ON EX-C.I.A. OFFICER
description: The chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today that he expects the committee to make public its findings on the case of a former C.I.A. officer who is believed to have given damaging information to the Soviet Union.

title: PACIFIC GAS TO BUY TRANSMISSION UNIT
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, northern California's major utility, said it had agreed to acquire all of the Pacific Gas Transmission Company. P.G.&E. currently owns 50.2 percent of the shares outstanding of the transmission company.

title: SALVADORAN MAYORS, FREED BY REBELS, TELL OF LIFE AS CAPTIVES
description: The guerrillas knocked on the door at 3 A.M.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GLASS ACTION One of the most dramatic free spectacles of the artist at work is on the second floor of an aged building at 142 Mulberry Street - where Chinatown is creeping up on Little Italy - between Hester and Grand Streets, just north of Canal Street. This is the New York Experimental Glass Workshop where artists create beauty from sand and fire.

title: MICHAELS STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-After a loss of $115,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: NEW JAPAN STRATEGY ON YEN SEEN
description: The Bank of Japan, frustrated in its efforts to drive up the value of the yen further by selling dollars on the foreign exchange markets, now seems prepared to augment its approach by tightening credit conditions at home, foreign exchange and credit market analysts said yesterday.

title: KEYSTONE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
4 Journalists Are Held By South Africa Police
description: Four journalists, including a correspondent for The New York Times and two members of a CBS News television crew, were held by the police today for three and a half hours.

title: WHY WAS RECOMMENDED DIETARY ALLOWANCES REPORT REJECTED
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW LAYOFFS BY A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would lay off more than 1,000 additional workers at its plant in Shreveport. Employees were told that the giant telecommunications company, which has already announced 1,877 layoffs this year at Shreveport, was making the further cuts because of poor market conditions.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FORD'S PROFIT FALLS 17.5%, INCENTIVE PLAN IS CITED
description: The Ford Motor Company reported today that it earned $313.1 million, or $1.70 a share, in the third quarter, down 17.5 percent from the $379.7 million, or $2.05 a share, earned in the comparable period in 1984.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY NAVY SPY SUSPECT WILL PLEAD GUILTY
description: John A. Walker Jr. will plead guilty to espionage charges in exchange for a shorter prison sentence for his son, a seaman who has also been charged in the Navy spy case, law-enforcement and military officials said today.

title: NEW MATH
description: If the St. Louis Cardinals beat Kansas City tonight, they will have won the World Series as no team has ever won it before. Yes, there have been previous six-game Series, of course - 17 of them, in fact - but not one of them has ever been captured with victories in Games 1, 2, 4 and 6.

title: ACME ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: POETRY BY THE HOMELESS
description: Life on the streets can be bleak, degrading and lonely. But out of that experience some powerful voices have also emerged.

description: b-Net income

title: N.B.A. CHALLENGING KNICK OFFER TO KING
description: Charging the Knicks with attempting to circumvent the salary cap, the National Basketball Association yesterday challenged the offer sheet the Knicks presented Thursday to Albert King, the Nets' free-agent small forward.

GENERAL PHYSICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Court Blocks Alaska Drilling
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered a halt to exploratory drilling for oil in two huge tracts off the Alaska coast, saying the Federal Government had failed to consider the impact on hunting, fishing and other activities pursued by native Alaskans.

title: PUROLATOR COURIER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $6,608,000 in the latest quarter and $14,190,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: JAPANESE VIEW
description: The central bank's action to strengthen the yen will probably cause bond prices to stumble further, traders and economists said today.

title: OWENS & MINOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Aug. 30.

title: LODGISTIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $131,000. Year-ago revenues include a gain of $288,000 on the sale of interest in Lodgistix Systems Pte., formerly the company Singapore subsidiary.

title: ARGUELLO WINS IN FIFTH ROUND
description: Fighting for the first time in more than two years, Alexis Arguello stopped Pat Jefferson in the fifth round tonight to renew his bid to become the first man to win world boxing titles in four classes.

title: Cardinal, on U.N. Trip, Has Surgery After Fall
description: Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, the Vatican's Secretary of State, underwent emergency surgery Thursday night to remove his spleen, a spokesman for the Holy See's mission here said today.

title: IN JAIL MIXUP, WRONG MAN IS TRIED 2 DAYS FOR MURDER
description: Despite his cries of ''not me,'' a Vietnamese stood trial for murder for two days and two witnesses named him as the killer before officials realized the wrong man had been brought to court from jail, prosecutors said today.

title: A SNEAKING PROBLEM FOR MEN
description: There is a new and increasingly dangerous phenomenon afoot: women in sneakers.

title: 2 SLAIN NEAR SALVADORAN LEADER'S OFFICE
description: Two people were killed and at least seven were wounded today in shooting that broke out in front of the presidential palace here as President Jose Napoleon Duarte was preparing to leave for a speech in the National Assembly.

title: LONG TERM BOND PRICES FALL
description: A brief selling wave inundated the longer-term bond market yesterday, after Japanese bond prices posted their biggest one-day drop in 40 years.

title: CALPROP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said last year's results for the third quarter and 9 months included gains realized on the sale of its interests in various apartment complexes, while there have been no similar sales in the current year.

title: Israela Margalit, Piano, In 'Music and More'
description: Because standard concert formats are apparently losing their appeal for more and more music lovers, attempts to repackage familiar musical products are cropping up with increasing frequency. The violin is from the Smithsonian collection of antique instruments, which is in the National Museum of American History.

title: CORRECTION

The analysis, by Mark Gersh of the committee staff, says that the Democrats could turn the Republican majority of 53-47 into a Democratic majority of 51-49.

Kay Starr, at Freddy's, Opens 3-Week Stay
description: Kay Starr burst on the pop music scene 40 years ago, a gloriously vital young beauty belting out anything that came to hand - country songs, jazz, pop songs and what she now calls ''drunks' music'' - in a resonant, joyful Oklahoma twang. This week Miss Starr, four decades along the road but otherwise seemingly unchanged, opened a three-week engagement at Freddy's Supper Club, 309 East 49th Street, the first time she has been in New York for anything more than a one-night engagement in so long that she says she can't remember the last time.

title: GORCERY SURVEY: PLEASANT SURPRISE
description: THE Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York surprised itself last week. Staffers shopped for 500 advertised food items to determine how many were actually available and found that 95 percent of the advertised items were in fact on the shelves and being sold at the sale price.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1985 Companies U.S. Steel and Texas Oil and Gas are discussing a merger. An acquisition by U.S. Steel would increase its dependence on energy as a source of revenue; steelmaking would provide only 25 percent. At the top end of the price that analysts are estimating, U.S. Steel would pay about $5.2 billion. [Page 33.] Texas Instruments lost $82.8 million in the third quarter and said it would lay off 2,200 more employees. The loss, which included a $63.8 million writedown for plant closings and layoffs, put the company in its deepest financial crisis since a foray into home computers cost it hundreds of millions of dollars two years ago. [33.] Monsanto plans to take a $559 million after-tax charge in the fourth quarter for divesting itself of certain assets, withdrawing from several low-return businesses and cutting its work force. [35.] Ford earnings fell 17.5 percent, to $313.1 million, in the quarter, hurt by cut-rate financing programs. Analysts said the results were about what was expected. [45.] Delta Air Lines said profits dropped 51 percent, to $29.5 million. [45.] Aetna operating earnings soared 36.8 percent, to $111.5 million. [45.] Armco's 62-year-old chairman, Harry Holiday Jr., will retire on Jan. 31. His successor will be Robert E. Boni, who will remain president and chief executive. Armco said it earned $48.6 million in the latest quarter, its second quarterly profit in a row. [35.] Colonial Penn is to be bought by the FPL Group, the holding company for Florida Power and Light, for $565 million.

title: 'MYSTERY!' INTRODUCES P.D. JAMES DETECTIVE
description: ''Mystery!,'' the public-television series financed by Mobil, is beginning a new season on PBS, but Channel 13 is moving the presentation from Thursdays to Saturdays at 9 P.M. Tonight marks the premiere of the six-episode ''Death of an Expert Witness.'' It also marks the debut in the series of the writer P. D. James and her terribly urbane detective creation, Adam Dalgliesh, a chief superintendent from Scotland Yard.

title: NO HELP FOR MINORITY HEALTH

title: WADKINS GAINS HONOR
description: Lanny Wadkins became the PGA Player of the Year yesterday when Calvin Peete hit his ball into water. Peete was the only man with a chance to overtake Wadkins in the standings in the last official event on the 10-month PGA Tour, the Seiko Tucson Match Play Championship. And Peete needed to win the tournament to do it, but his bid ended when Peete hit his second shot into the water on the second extra hole and he conceded a 1-up upset loss to Phil Blackmar.

description: A former Prime Minister and 39 others accused of roles in a failed coup were charged in criminal court today with inciting rebellion against the Thai Government.

title: PUBLIC SCRUTINY SUFFERS A SETBACK
description: The Reagan Administration has scored a momentous victory in its quiet campaign to block public scrutiny of the workings of the Federal Government. On Oct. 17, Samuel Loring Morison, a naval intelligence analyst, was found guilty of espionage for giving three classified satellite photographs of a new Soviet aircraft carrier to Jane's Defense Weekly, the venerable British military magazine.

title: SOVIET CRITICIZES REAGAN'S ADDRESS
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass said today that President Reagan's speech to the United Nations ignored the ''burning'' problems of nuclear disarmament and served only to justify a United States policy of ''international banditry.''

title: Tweedless
description: Unseasonably mild and soggy weather has been keeping Washingtonians out of their baggy tweeds and into their shaggy weather stories. In the years before air-conditioning, one story goes, the British considered Washington a hardship post and paid their embassy staff an extra allowance, as if they were stationed East of Suez instead of North of the White House. Marianne Goff, an embassy spokesman, said she did not know when air-conditioning was installed but she still gets questions about extra pay.

title: THE REAL COST OF THE SLAVADOR EXCHANGE
description: As a matter of humane interest, the world could only welcome the great prisoner exchange in El Salvador. Ines Guadeloupe Duarte was an innocent victim, held captive for 44 days only for the crime of being daughter of the country's president. Her companion was innocent. So were the 23 mayors released by the rebels. Meanwhile, on the other side, of the 22 leftist political prisoners that the Government released, a high official acknowleged that 19 had been held on ''weak legal ground.''

title: PERES REPORTS FRENCH OFFER TO FLY SOVIET JEWS TO ISRAEL

title: NEW JUDGE IN TRIAL
description: The Louisiana judge who dismissed sports bribery charges against the former Tulane star, John (Hot Rod) Williams, was disqualified from presiding over the trials of four other suspects in the case after prosecutors testified that the judge, Alvin Oser, had cursed and threatened them during breaks in the Williams trial. In removing Oser from the case, Orleans Parish Judge Patrick Quinlan said, ''The appearance of justice would suffer if Judge Oser were to hear the motions and trials of the remaining defendants.'' Judge Oser had rejected a prosecution request that he disqualify himself.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK

Rafael Quinones, standing on a street corner nearby, broke into a smile at the sound of the laughter and said: ''Sounds good. Nice to know somebody's having some fun around here.''

title: COMMONWEALTH TELEPHONE ENTRPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GETTING LARA, 4, A BRIGHT GIRL, INTO SCHOOL
description: Discovery: Our pediatrician tells us that our daughter, Lara, who is 4 years and 4 months old, seems abnormally bright. ''Have her tested,'' he recommends. The test shows that her I.Q. is 154. The psychologist says this I.Q. occurs in two out of 10,000 people her age. He says she's about at second- or third-grade level. He also says she's mature, emotionally speaking. It is June 1985. Reverberations: At first, there is parental vanity. My child, the genius. Then wonderment, then humility why our child?), then the weary feeling of a trustee, not just of this child's fate but of creation's marvel. How to do right by her? And by it? As a first step, we decide to enroll her in kindergarten. It is July.

title: On Ezra Pound
description: There was a time in Washington when it seemed unlikely that Ezra Pound would ever be honored by a body of the United States Government. In 1946 Pound was committed to Saint Elizabeths, a mental hospital in the capital, after being found psychologically unfit to stand trial on charges of treason stemming from radio broadcasts he made from Mussolini's Italy in World War II.

title: Greek Orthodox to Rebuild
description: The spiritual leader of Greek Orthodox Christians in the Americas, Archbishop Iakovos, said yesterday that the central building of the Ecumenical Patriarchate in Istanbul, Turkey, ''will be rebuilt'' under a permit expected to be issued soon. The building was destroyed by fire in 1942. The archdiocese reported that Archbishop Iakovos said at a meeting of the Archdiocesan Council in Manhattan that he received assurances about the reconstruction when he met with Prime Minister Turgut Ozal of Turkey yesterday morning.

JEFFERSON SMURFIT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PASSING THROUGH
description: FOREIGN LAND. By Jonathan Raban. 352 pages. Viking. $16.95. George Grey, the hero of Jonathan Raban's new novel, has spent the better part of his life on the road - moving from city to city, country to country, one set of rented rooms to another. He believes that ''the safest way to live was to assume that your marching orders would arrive tomorrow,'' and having lived so many years ''a lodger in other people's houses,'' he's ''picked up the lodger's habit of passing through without leaving tracks. He'd been born in a rectory that belonged to the Church and gone on to Navy quarters and Company apartments; and he left each billet exactly as he'd found it.'' If such a restless life has freed him from responsibilities, however, George has also begun to realize that it's made him a stranger to his family and friends - he has become one of those unannounced, nervous-making guests who drop by in the night and then are gone the following morning. At the age of 60, he decides to leave Bom Porto, the small African nation where he's lived for the last couple years, and return home to England.

Unfree and Unfair in Liberia
description: Liberia, founded 138 years ago by freed American slaves, now receives more American assistance per capita than any other country in Africa. Aid levels have been quadrupled since Sgt. Samuel K. Doe seized power in 1980. Last year's $83 million covered fully a third of Liberia's budget. What did the United States wish in return? The first genuinely free multi-party elections in Liberian history. The elections were held last week and both Liberian voters and the American taxpayers have been defrauded.

description: New music's most formidable enemies are rarely critics or estranged listeners but the people who perform it. Schoenberg's half-plaintive, half-acid comment bears constant repeating: ''My music is not modern,'' he said. ''It's just played badly.''

description: From a windy ridgetop here, one can look out at 5,000 spinning wind turbines, where four years ago there were only cattle and rolling hills. But the rapid growth of wind-produced energy here and elsewhere has been as much a response to generous Federal and California tax credits as to any perceived energy crisis.

title: RACE FOR DISTRICT ATTORNEY SHARPENS
description: IN recent weeks as the race for Westchester District Attorney has neared its conclusion, the Democratic challenger, Paul W. Pickelle, has adopted an aggressive campaign style, repeatedly accusing his opponent, the Republican incumbent Carl A. Vergari, of having mishandled major cases and of questionable campaign financing tactics.

title: Miss Fauntleroy Weds J. E. Fuller
description: Barbara Lee Fauntleroy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence G. Fauntleroy of St. Louis, was married yesterday to James E. Fuller, a son of Irma Fuller of Lawrenceville, Ga., and the late Leland A. Fuller. The Rev. J. Douglas Ousley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation in New York.

title: Geologist Clarifies Prong Composition
description: In the Oct. 13 article about radon, the potential danger from naturally occurring radon was pointed out. The article stated that most of the radon in New Jersey emanates from the Reading Prong, a geologic foundation composed primarily of soft granite.

title: HOW JAPAN TEACHES ITS OWN HISTORY
description: THE REVISION OF HISTORY IS A NEVER-ending process. Each generation, it is said, rewrites history in the light of its own experience. But when the historical event is defeat in war, as Japan experienced in World War II and the United States experienced in Vietnam, the impulse to ignore or explain away or tidy up the defeat is particularly strong.

title: U.S. Jawboning In the Philippines
description: Senator Paul Laxalt reported to President Reagan last week on an uphill effort to persuade President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines to change his ways. Washington is worried about spreading Communist insurgency in the Philippines and the rise in anti-Marcos and anti-American sentiment, all of which are casting a shadow over United States security interests there.

title: RUNNING EXPERT GIVES VIEW
description: ALTHOUGH running is not the be-all-end-all for Dr. George Sheehan - he says he is ''tremendously interested in ideas'' - it is the big thing in his life.

title: BREAKFAST
description: AS A CHILD, I FOUND IT DIFFICULT to invest in the necessity of breakfast, involved as I was, at the appointed hour, with the inner life of the previous night. I like to look back to my disbelief in breakfast as an esthetic position, at a time when the first order of business upon awakening was to place the needle on my 78-rpm recording of Spike Jones's ''That Old Black Magic'' and spin around my room, spin back into the dreams so recently departed, spin myself into nausea - the state of my first formal encounters with breakfast proper.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AWAITING TRESPASS (A Pasion). By Linda Ty-Casper. (Readers International, Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95.) The wealthy family of Don Severino Gil has gathered in his Manila home for his wake and funeral.

title: Alleged Leader Of Spy Ring May Be Talking
description: The telling of the extraordinary Walker family saga began in May, after John A. Walker Jr. was arrested by Federal agents who said they had watched him drive down a deserted Maryland road and hide a bag of classified Navy documents near a tree. Prosecutors later said the stashing of the bag, which apparently was to have been collected by a Russian diplomat, was the least of Mr. Walker's many crimes. The retired Navy warrant officer, they said, was nothing less than the brains behind the most damaging Soviet espionage operation uncovered in the United States in 30 years.

title: UNIONS INVITE SALVADORANS
description: DESPITE opposition from the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Lane Kirkland, unions throughout the state sponsored a tour last week by a group of Central American unionists.

title: HARTFORD EXAMINES ITS RIVER'S BENEFITS
description: HARTFORD was a thriving port at its birth, but today denizens of the downtown area cannot even get to the banks of the Connecticut River because of superhighways and office towers.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A TRADITION OF TRADING IN SOUTHPORT
description: THE Southport Congregational Church on Pequot Avenue is just a block from the seaport that made the small village an important part of the early New England shipping trade. In the 18th century, Southport's chief export was bushels of small, white, sweet onions.

title: IN SHORT:FICTION
description: THEY SLEEP WITHOUT DREAMING. By Penelope Gilliatt. (Dodd, Mead, $14.95.) Not all the characters in this collection are as dotty as the bag lady talking to herself in ''Purse,'' but all of them are eccentric - the kind who recite Latin verses while doing backbends or still use lorgnettes with ivory handles.

title: ASSEMBLY CANDIDATES WALKING A FINE LINE
description: WHILE Governor Kean is planning to spend the last week of the election campaign on the stump with Republican Assembly candidates, Peter Shapiro, his Democratic challenger, is finding the trail becoming more lonely.

title: WATER RULES CALLED UNFAIR
description: TO SEVERAL Mayors in South Jersey, the emergency water restrictions are unfair.

title: THOSE PEOPLE WHO CREATE LIFE'S DAILY IRRITANTS
description: THERE are some people who were born to be hated. They aren't nasty or vicious; in fact, most of them are probably nice to children and dogs, support the police and fly the flag. They have just one problem. They are completely thoughtless. These people never do anything sufficiently serious to warrant a physical reaction, such as a sock in the jaw. They merely irritate and annoy, in various degrees, and they get away with it because an outburst of temper would be considered both bad manners and an overreaction.

title: 3 CONCERT TREATS AT HAND FOR THE HALLOWEEN SEASON
description: HALLOWEEN is a time for witches and pumpkins but it usually does not inspire concerts. This year, however, at least three programs take note of the occasion, beginning at 3 P.M. today at the State University of New York at Purchase, where the Philharmonia Virtuosi's program is entitled ''Halloween and Handel.''

title: THE BOOM IN DUTCH FICTION, WHERE VALUES ARE IN VOGUE
description: IF a nation's reading habits are in any way a measure of its frame of mind, then the Netherlands is in a state of ebullience. Reports that Europe is slumped in cultural fatigue appear not to have reached here. Poets, playwrights and essayists have always had an audience in the Netherlands, but of late people have responded strongly to fiction writers in search of a new social cohesion. Not since the Eightiers, the Dutch modernist literary movement of the 1880's, have the novel and novelists carried such authority.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: REPRODUCTION SEMINAR Arthur J. Goldberg, former United States Supreme Court Justice, will be the keynote speaker at a conference titled ''Who Governs Reproduction?'' to be held from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday at the Yale Law School in New Haven.

title: WILMINGTON POLICE CRACK DOWN ON GANG VIOLENCE
description: On North Market Street in the northeast part of Wilmington is a string of sandwich shops, liquor stores and corner groceries called the Strip. Under the street lights, hundreds of young men gather at night. They lounge on corners and lean in doorways and call themselves Yeayo boys.

title: SUNBATHER IS CLEARED IN PUBLIC NUDITY CASE
description: A jury says naked buttocks do not ''outrage the sense of public decency'' and that ruling sent Sheriff Jake Miller of Brevard County back to reconsider measures he had taken against nude sunbathing.

title: A MIDDLING MOLIERE AT THE HARTMAN
description: MOLIERE may be the acknowledged master of 17th-century French comedy, but how is a 20th-century audience to believe that? Certainly not on the evidence of Pat Patton's staging of ''The Imaginary Invalid'' at the Hartman Theater in Stamford.

title: Mary Wilkin Fiancee Of Thomas B. Winmill
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rodger A. Wilkin of Leawood, Kan., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Christine Wilkin, to Thomas Bassett Winmill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bassett S. Winmill of New York and Rumson, N.J. A Nov. 23 wedding is planned.

title: SAFETY SEATS
description: To the Editor: The decision to use a child safety seat on airplanes, (Practical Traveler, Aug. 18) is rightly left to the parents. The responsibility of the state and the airlines is to inform the parents of the risks of turbulence and rough or crash landings.

title: NEW CASSETTES: EVERGREEN MUSICAL, CLASSIC ANIMATION
description: All the President's Men Starring Robert Redford, Dustin Hoffman, Jason Robards, Jane Alexander; directed by Alan J. Pakula, 1976 Warner Home Video 137 minutes. $59.95 Few thrillers have ever made such a virtue out of being deskbound.

title: VOODOO POLITICS TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: AS a Representative in 1981, Phil Gramm played a major role in developing the economic program of tax cuts and enhanced military spending that President Reagan promised would automatically produce higher revenues and a balanced budget. We would ''grow our way'' out of the deficit, they said.

title: IN THE MEDIEVAL FUTURE
description: THE NEW WORLD An Epic Poem. By Frederick Turner. 182 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $26. Paper, $9.95.

title: TITLE TO AYERS ROCK GIVEN TO ABORIGINES
description: The Government today gave back Ayers Rock, the world's largest monolith and one of Australia's biggest tourist attractions, to aborigines, who consider caves at its base to be sacred.

title: 6 REBELS KILLED IN SRI LANKA
description: Security forces stopped a van carrying armed Tamil guerrillas and killed six of them in a gun battle, official sources said today. The officials said the clash occurred Friday at Moonemadu in the northern Vavuniya District.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

WEAK HEARING EXACTS A HIGH TOLL
description: A FRIEND of mine, at the age of 11, was convinced that he would die of shame and humiliation if he had to wear glasses. He did not care that glasses would help him at sports or that he could stop asking friends what the teacher had written on the blackboard. He gladly would have chosen to see nothing but fuzzy shapes and to withdraw from sports altogether rather than proclaim his nearsightedness for all the world to know.

title: 'ELENI' ENSHRINES ON FILM A MOTHER'S LEGACY OF LOVE
description: The small snapshot could be a tourist's memento. It shows several people sitting around a wooden picnic table in a Greek town. The sun is bright, and the vines and lush Mediterranean vegetation give the sense of an arbor in the garden behind. There are several older Greek women, their hair tied by scarves, peasant-style, their faces weathered and lined, and at least two apparent tourists, a man and a striking young woman with short blond hair.

title: Paula Quinn Is Bride Of George Scanlon Jr.
description: Paula Ann Quinn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Quinn of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to George J. Scanlon Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Scanlon of Ridgewood and Waldwick, N.J. Msgr. Eugene V. Clark performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Sacred Heart Church in Haworth, N.J.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE BIRTHDAY KING, by Gabriel Fielding. (Phoenix/University of Chicago, $8.95.) A novel about Germany from the invasion of Poland to the fall of Berlin and, more specifically, two industrialist brothers who survive World War II by following different paths. In 1962 our reviewer, the British journalist Richard Hughes, termed ''The Birthday King'' a ''haunting and terrible book.'' He continued, ''Gabriel Fielding has turned his brilliant and precise genius to a ruthless examination of 'Hitler-Time' in Germany, skillfully interweaving fiction with historical fact.'' THE BURN, by Vassily Aksyonov. (Aventura/Vintage, $9.95.) ''The Burn'' sheds light on everyday material life in the Soviet Union in the late 1960's and early 70's. Yet as the author sees it, Russians, like everyone else, must go beyond mundane existence to a saving vision of past and future. Last year our reviewer, Anatole Shub, wrote that ''The Burn'' is the novel ''of a unique writer, at the height of his powers. . . . It is in turn hilarious, tragic, evocative, mystical.'' Mr. Aksyonov, who now lives in Washington, was forced to emigrate from the Soviet Union when ''The Burn'' was published in Italy. Michael Glenny did the translation. OUT OF THE FORTIES, by Nicholas Lemann. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) In 1943 Standard Oil of New Jersey (now Exxon) commissioned outstanding photographers to record ordinary Americans in ordinary pursuits. The now-famous project produced 85,000 photographs, and scores of them are in this large-format paperback. Peter Davis wrote here in 1983 that the illustrations alone would make an excellent book.

title: NEW YORK BALLOT TO POSE 5 QUESTIONS
description: Should New York's highest court be able to give advisory opinions to out-of-state courts?

title: FLORIO AND RCA AT ODDS OVER SEMANTICS
description: A CURIOUS ''confrontation in semantics'' has arisen between the RCA Corporation and Representative James J. Florio in their interpretations of the nature of foreign competition that has resulted in a pending phase-out of the corporation's plant in this Camden County borough.

title: THE ARMS BUILDUP: FIRST SIGNS VISIBLE
description: The Strategic Air Command's force of bombers and nuclear missiles has begun to see the first visible effects of President Reagan's four-year-old plan to modernize the nation's nuclear deterrent.

title: FORUM SCORES WITH 'NINE'
description: WONDER of wonders.

title: A HISTORIC JERSEY TOWN LONGS FOR THE OLD DAYS
description: Ben Douglas wants this oceanfront community to secede from Neptune Township because he yearns for the time, not that long ago, when residents set aside Sundays for rest and reflection and police officers knew him by name.

title: Planting Plastic Gardens
description: Paula Deitz's article ''Planting Plastic,'' on landscape architect Martha Schwartz, provoked in me a variety of reactions, not the least of which was the fervent hope that her Stella Garden does not represent the future of the American back yard (Home Design Section, Sept. 22).

title: JUDGE CHALLENGES ARGENTINE CURBS
description: In a move that directly challenges President Raul Alfonsin's right to use the newly imposed state of siege to detain people suspected of being terrorists, a civilian judge ordered the release today of six men arrested under a presidential order.

title: FAIR LAWN TRIUMPHS
description: Carl Straw passed for 141 yards and two touchdowns and Marc Oler ran for three touchdowns to lead Fair Lawn (5-0) past Bergenfield, 33-19, in Fair Lawn. Straw competed passes of 28 yards to Brian Meerholz and 23 yards to Chris Davies for touchdowns while Oler scored touchdowns on runs of 3, 19 and 14 yards.

title: PROUD TRUTH TAKES DISCOVERY
description: Proud Truth had a harder time than anyone expected him to in winning the Discovery Handicap for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct Race Track yesterday. But he ran a better race and had an easier victory than his margin of only a neck over Important Business would suggest.

title: Melissa Hoefer Becomes Bride
description: Melissa Hoefer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Burns Hoefer of Bronxville, N.Y., and Charlestown, R.I., was married yesterday to William Lester Branch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Branch of Nashville. The Rev. Jerry Everley performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan.

title: NICARAGUA'S EDGE IN THE ARMS RACE
description: A wedge of helicopters flew over the plaza where several hundred thousand people were celebrating the Sandinista Front's sixth year in power. The planes included MI-24's, Soviet-made asssault craft, an announcer told the crowd. There was only mild applause, but foreigners charting Sandinista military strategy were startled.

title: Mason and Dixon, 2 Centuries Later
description: A boundary marker, set by Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon 217 years ago to fix the extreme southwest corner of Delaware at the Maryland border, was returned to its original location Thursday.

title: INDIAN POINT A-PLANTS BUILT TO WITHSTAND QUAKES
description: The Indian Point nuclear power plants here are designed to withstand earthquakes much more severe than the one that hit the New York area last Saturday, according to the plants' operators.

title: TOPICS
description: DURING Long Island winter nights of old, the women would sit by the open hearths spinning flax and wool into yarn that would be woven or knitted into garments.

title: THE COCKTAIL HOUR
description: WHEN I LIVED IN SALA-manca, Spain, several years ago, I never had to look far to find my friends. Every evening around 7 o'clock they could be encountered at a cramped, overheated little tavern in the Plaza Mayor called the Covachuela. Its popularity was attributable to two features. First was the friendly and forever clowning owner, who usually delighted newcomers by taking a coin and flipping it toward the ceiling, then catching it in his shirt pocket. Second were his tasty tapas, or Spanish finger foods - specifically, the spicy local sausages and cured ham and Spanish tortillas made with potatoes and eggs. They were consumed with a chato, a short glass of rough red wine, or a cana, draft beer.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE OFF-SEASON. By Michael Covino. (Persea, $14.95.) A collection can go for or against you. On the plus side there is the chance for the work to build, layer by layer, toward a fully realized fictional world.

title: Miss Taylor Wed To Charles Leedy
description: Barbara Ann Taylor and Charles Dean Leedy were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Peter G. Finn performed the ceremony.

title: Stephen Apple to Wed Miss Gordon in Winter
description: Dr. Ellen Gordon Adams of Hackensack, N.J., and Edward S. Gordon of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin L. Gordon to Stephen J. Apple, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Apple of Harrisburg, Pa. The wedding is planned for Feb. 1. The future bride and bridegroom are brokers for the Edward S. Gordon Company, a real estate brokerage concern in New York of which her father is the founder and president.

title: THEATER GROUP IN AN ENCORE
description: A COMMUNITY theater production of A. R. Gurney's ''Dining Room'' that won numerous awards in a statewide competition last spring will be recreated Friday by the shoreline theater group that originally presented it.

title: Katherine Probst Wed in Brooklyn
description: Katherine Nicole Probst, the daughter of Bethami Probst of Brooklyn Heights, N.Y., and the late Leonard Probst, and David Andrew Bussard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Arthur Bussard of Princeton, N.J., were married yesterday. Judge Richard J. Goldman of the Civil Court of the City of New York, Kings County Branch, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Chrysler, U.A.W. Reach Agreement
description: As he mulled over the pay-increase formula that the Chrysler Corporation had agreed to for its 70,000 union hands, Owen F. Bieber, president of the United Auto Workers, said last week that he hoped General Motors and Ford would ''look at it and see that it's proper and come through with it as well.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: Subduing the Dollar Will the attack on the dollar, mounted a month ago by the Group of Five industrial nations, bring down the currency's value enough to stimulate exports and ease the Congressional pressure for protectionism? So far, that achievement is not in sight. At best, the steps taken amount to a quick and temporary fix, says Edward Yardeni, chief economist for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

title: SCOTTICH DELICACIES
description: To the Editor: Your correspondent Kenneth I. E. MacLeod of Westborough, Mass.

title: When New York's Liberal Party Mattered
description: To the Editor:

title: JUST ANOTHER TRADE?
description: WORKING WOMEN The Subterranean World of Street Prostitution. By Arlene Carmen and Howard Moody. 208 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/Harper & Row. $16.50.

title: Facing Up To College
description: William Safire and his ''college-code slangbusters'' have successfully broken through much of the current slang (''Back to Tool,'' On Language, Sept. 22). Granted, there is much variation from semester to semester and from college to college, but I feel I would be neglecting a responsibility if I did not tell Mr. Safire that, at Cornell, ''doing face time'' is not a synonym for the passe term for necking - ''sucking face.''

title: CHANCE FOR GLORY INSTEAD GOES AWRY
description: Todd Worrell knew the figures. ''Eighty-four and oh,'' he said. That was the record the St. Louis Cardinals compiled in the regular season for games in which they took a lead into the ninth inning.

title: 20 ARE HURT IN CLASHES IN NEW CALEDONIA
description: Twenty people were hurt overnight in clashes between loyalists and separatists in Noumea, capital of this French territory in the Pacific, the police said today.

title: LAWMAKERS SEEK TO CURB SCOFFLAWS OF AIRPLANE TAX
description: SEVERAL decades ago, when tax assessors would show up at airports around the state, a lot of the planes they wanted to tax weren't there. Many plane owners, in what was known as the ''Oct. 1 Flyaway'' would take their planes out of the state to avoid paying the local property tax.

title: IN NEW YORK AREA, COLLEGES SUCCEED IN RECRUITING EFFORT
description: College recruiters and administrators at several private institutions in the New York area have found ways to increase the percentage of minority students at their schools, despite the national trend to the contrary.

title: IS THE WATER SHORTAGE AN ACT OF GOD OR MAN?
description: The dog days may be over, and with them the complaints of hundreds of thousands of office workers compelled to spend several hours a day without air conditioning, but New York City's drought goes on. The reservoirs were at 51.5 percent of capacity last week, a major improvment over the days before Hurricane Gloria dumped more than four inches of rain over them. The day before the hurricane struck on Sept. 27, the system was at only 44.4 percent of capacity. Ordinarily, however, the reservoirs are slighlty more than 70 percent full at this time of year.

title: JPACIFIC ISLANDERS OFFER TO SETTLE WITH THE U.S.
description: A majority of landowners on Kwajalein atoll, the site of a billion-dollar United States missile testing range in the Central Pacific, have offered to settle their longstanding political and financial differences with Washington for a payment of $6 million spread over six months. This would be in addition to their present cash remuneration of about $487,750 a month.

title: CONRAIL SALE STILL SIDETRACKED
description: THE eight-month-old effort of the Reagan Administration to sell a majority interest in Conrail to Norfolk Southern, a Virginia-based freight line, remains stalled on Capitol Hill, and signs are that it will stay there as long as the proposal remains in its present form.

title:
WINE;

HINTS ON SELECTING FOR MOST OCCASIONS
