description: SELECTING wine to accompany a restaurant meal -particularly when diners in a group each choose different appetizers and entrees - is often a confounding experience. Therefore an attempt was recently made to find a few basic rules that would fit most occasions rather than remand all who order wine to acquire an encylopedic knowledge of vineyards and vintages.

title: GETTING READY FOR THE BIG ONE
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov each had his own idea about how to practice before they began their world championship match in Moscow last month.

title: SCREEN: FROM JAPAN, 'ONIMASA,' BY GOSHA
description: HIDEO GOSHA'S ''Onimasa,'' which takes place mostly in the 1920's and 1930's, covers more than two decades in the hysterical home life of a Japanese gangster named Onimasa, his shrewish wife, his concubines and his two daughters - Matsue, adopted when she was an adolescent, and the younger Hanako, his child by a concubine. Onimasa has his hands so full with this household that one is allowed to wonder how he ever finds the time to run his profitable gambling and prostitution rackets and to fight his competition.

title: Donna Friedman Engaged
description: Donna Elise Friedman, a real estate broker for Whitbread Nolan Inc., and David Pelton, a vice president of investments at Drexel Burnham Lambert, plan to be married next summer, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Friedman of Oceanside, L.I., have announced. Mr. Pelton is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervin J. Pelton of Atlantic Beach, L.I.

title: Offices by the Hour
description: A new medical building in which doctors will be able to rent space by the hour is to open next month in Murray Hill a block and a half from the New York University Medical Center complex. Among the project's developers is Dr. Michael Reitano, a 27-year-old internist, who came up with the idea of renting space on a time-use basis after he was unable to find affordable midtown office space for himself.

title: AFRIKANER ASKS U.S. BANKS TO RESTRICT LOANS
description: The Rev. Beyers Naude, general secretary of the South African Council of Churches, has called on American banks to make future loans to South Africa conditional on a lessening by the Pretoria Government of its crackdown against opponents.

title: MODEST PROPOSALS
description: IT WAS A WINTER DAY JUST BEFORE Christmas a few years ago, and I had come down from Paris to talk to Georges Blanc, whose restaurant in Vonnas, north of Lyons, had just been awarded three Michelin stars.

title: AT HOME WITH RESTAURATEURS: WEST COAST
description: THE SECRET OF successful home entertaining is to invite good people,'' says Michael McCarty, the 32-year-old proprietor of the acclaimed Michael's restaurant in Santa Monica, Calif. ''Of course,'' he adds, as he lights a pile of charcoal briquettes in a weathered Weber barbecue behind his hilltop home in Malibu, ''simplicity, organization and setting are important, too.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: EVERGREEN MUSICAL, CLASSIC ANIMATION
description: Puccini's 'Turandot' An Arena di Verona production, featuring Ghena Dimitrova, Nicola Martinucci, Cecilia Gasdia and Ivo Vinco; conducted by Maurizio Arena. EMI/Thorn Video 116 minutes.

title: SAVORING WINTER
description: IT SEEMS VERY strange to try to remember the best meal of my whole life, especially one that I ate in the winter.

title: FOR FRENCH PHONES, SOME EXTRA DIALING
description: French phone service, once notorious for its inefficiency, was seized by a technological revolution Friday night. A flick of the switch and - voila! - all 24 million numbers had eight digits and no area codes.

title: No Headline
description: Schlumberger's operations were spread out around the world when Jean Riboud joined the oil services company in 1951.

title: DEVELOPER SUES TO VOID SALE OF CASINO
description: THE Walter Company of California, in a suit filed in Federal District Court here, seeks to regain its half interest in the highly profitable Harrah's Marina Hotel-Casino in Atlantic City.

title: ROYALS STUN CARDINALS IN 9th AND TIE SERIES
description: Stunningly, incredibly, the Kansas City Royals staged their comeback of comebacks tonight. The St. Louis Cardinals were two outs from winning the World Series, and the Royals snatched the game from their grasp. The teams will learn Sunday night if the Royals grabbed the Series as well.

title: SUDAN TRYING EX-AIDES IN AIRLIFT OF ETHIOPIA JEWS
description: Former Vice President Omar el-Tayeb of the Sudan and four officers of the dissolved State Security Service pleaded not guilty today to charges of helping smuggle Ethiopian Jews to Israel in a secret airlift.

title: 20TH GAME IN CHESS MATCH IS ADJOURNED IN 41ST MOVE
description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, and his challenger, Gary Kasparov, adjourned the 20th game of their title match today when Kasparov sealed his 41st move in a position experts decribed as likely to lead to a draw.

title:
ANTIQUES;

SEMINAR TO OFFER PRESERVATION TIPS
description: AT HER wedding next April, a young woman from Colts Neck is planning to wear an antique gown that is the equivalent of a modern size 4.

title: 'SINGLE VISION' GUIDES TROUPE
description: THE Chapel Street Players, a community troupe in Stratford that is now presenting ''Arsenic and Old Lace,'' has thrived for 13 years under one founder, producer and director -Jane Ciarcia.

title: WHERE HAVE ALL THE SITTERS GONE?
description: GOING out for an evening is no easy task for parents. It takes all the strategic planning skills I have learned as an executive to go out to dinner or a movie on a weekend. I can not even contemplate a weekday outing in the city. And we have had to educate our childless friends that a spur-of-the-moment date is out of the question. What's the problem? Baby sitters. If my friends and I do not arrange for baby sitters at least two weeks in advance, the only way we can get together is if they bring the kids over, and we order out for pizza and rent a video movie. No wonder video stores are springing up all over Fairfield County. Where are all the baby sitters? More importantly, where are the reliable baby sitters, the ones to whom you feel you can trust your precious baby?

title: The Navy Wins A Skirmish On Staten Island
description: What was shaping up as one of the most heated races in this year's election campaign - and perhaps one of the closest - involved not politicians but a port of call, the Staten Island site of a proposed Navy base. But less than two weeks before Election Day, the courts have struck down as unconstitutional a proposed referendum on the base, ruling that such a vote would infringe on the Federal Government's power to provide for the nation's defense.

title: PRINCETON BEATS HARVARD, 11-6
description: Tom Urquhart raced 75 yards with a free kick late in the fourth quarter to give Princeton a stunning and strange 11-6 upset victory over Harvard before 18,000 fans at Harvard Stadium today.

title: SEA DANGERS
description: The Affair of the Somers. By Philip McFarland. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $19.95.

title: MYTH INSPIRES OPERAS 250 YEARS APART
description: Greek mythology long served as the wellspring of opera plots, especially in the 17th and 18th centuries. For the Romantic era, librettists turned more often to history or drama or melodrama. And in our time, with the fragmentation of values that made Euro-American culture homogeneous, operatic sources have become as varied as musical theater itself.

title: EX-MARYLAND AIDE
description: Former Lieut. Gov. Blair Lee 3d, who served as Acting Governor of Maryland after Gov. Marvin Mandel was indicted on corruption charges in 1977, has died at his home in this suburb of Washington, his son said today. Mr. Lee was 69 years old.

title: EQUITABILITY OF CO-OP RULES
description: Question: After living in my co-op for two years I would like to rent it out and move. The board says I cannot, although it allowed another shareholder to sublet for a year. How can I fight this decision? . . . F. T., Manhattan Answer: While a legal challenge might be won if a board did not apply its rules uniformly to all shareholders, David Clurman, a lawyer who represents sponsors, tenant groups and co-ops, says it is very difficult to prove. You may want to find out more about your board's policy and discuss your situation with a lawyer.

title: Reagan Backs Abortion Limit
description: President Reagan has disappointed some supporters who say his Administration's efforts against abortion have not matched the determination of his speeches. But Federal officials vowed action last week, saying they would press Congress to forbid abortion counseling and referrals by federally financed family-planning clinics.

title:
GARDENING;

SOLVE SOIL DRAINAGE PROBLEMS IN THE FALL
description: THE adage, out of sight, out of mind, accurately sums up the average person's understanding of the importance of optimum soil conditions to successful gardening. And most soil problems are buried where they cannot be easily seen.

title: WOMEN AND THE ROMANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: EPIDEMIC KILLS 22 NIGERIANS
description: An epidemic of stomach inflammation in the northern state of Sokoto has killed 22 people, Nigerian television reported today.

title: A NEW CHIEF PUSHES TO KEEP HIS COMPANY INDEPENDENT
description: AS a Navy flier in the 1950's, Joseph J. Kroger's idea of fun was to fly up to Manhattan at night on practice runs from his base in Atlantic City, swoop in low along the Hudson River and make forbidden passes under the George Washington Bridge.

title: OSSO BUCO, THE CLASSIC ITALIAN 'STEW', IS ON THE SCENE AGAIN
description: AMONG the hearty stew-like preparations that are beginning to whet the appetite once again, the Italian osso buco ranks as a classic. Meaty veal shanks simmered with white wine and vegetables and served with risotto is to Milan what beef in red wine is to Burgandy.

title: NONLOSING BELIEF INSPIRES DISLIKE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PAPAL PLOT TRIAL HEARS TESTIMONY IN SWITZERLAND
description: The court trying seven men accused of conspiring to kill Pope John Paul II traveled to Switzerland this week on the first of several trips through Europe to question defendants and witnesses thought capable of testing the contentions of the court's chief witness, Mehmet Ali Agca.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SHORELINE TOUR Current and proposed development of the Long Island Sound shoreline at New Rochelle will be the subject for those taking an instructional two-hour boat ride today, leaving from Fort Slocum Dock at 4 P.M. Fifty passengers will be accommodated aboard the Shamrock, a 56-foot licensed excursion boat, for a fee of $5 a person.

title: 75 RUNNING IN THEMARATHON AIM TO FIGHT WORLD HUNGER
description: For 75 competitors in today's New York City Marathon, starving people around the world provide a compelling reason for running. The 75 are members of World Runners, and with every mile they complete, money is raised to feed the hungry.

title: WHO WILL REPLACE THE OLD GUARD OF SOVIET MUSIC?
description: The death the other day of Emil Gilels, a few days short of his 69th birthday, has further thinned the ranks of an elite group of Soviet virtuosos who broke onto the international scene after World War II. Of the three acknowledged leaders of that group, only his fellow pianist Sviatoslav Richter, still active at age 71, is left, the legendary violinist David Oistrakh having died in 1974. The old guard of Soviet music is passing and the new guard, if there is one, is slow in taking shape.

title: O'ROURKE, GOODMAN DEBATE ROLE OF COUNTY
description: THE candidates for County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican incumbent, and Arthur H. Goodman, the Democratic challenger, differed last week on their views of the role county government should play in development in Westchester, with Mr. Goodman calling for a more activist administration and Mr. O'Rourke defending the present system.

title: IN ASBURY PARK, A MOOD OF REBIRTH
description: AN AIR of festivity and a mood of rebirth swept through this Shore municipality last weekend.

title: COLLEGE PRIZE IS SET FOR COMMUNITY AID
description: STUDENTS will compete for an unusual prize on two Connecticut college campuses this academic year - a humanitarian award for ''socially valuable'' work outside the classroom.

title: LONG LIVE LINKAGE
description: In dealing seriously with the Soviet leadership, you have to provide them with a solid, unsurprising, unwavering statement of your own position. That is the only negotiating they consider ''serious.''

title: SURVIVING THE DEATH OF AN INFANT
description: GALE KALECHOFSKY of Massapequa remembers how quietly the nurse came into her hospital room, cradling the pink receiving blanket. ''Can I hold her?'' she asked. ''Sure,'' the nurse responded.

title: POLICE GROUPS REVERSE STAND AND BACK CONTROLS ON PISTOLS
description: In a sharp departure from the past, the nation's major police associations are fighting for controls on pistols, adding a new element to the long, bitter struggle over regulation of firearms.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

KEEPING THE PEACE
description: WHITE Plains Police Officer Ken Corsell has seen it all: burglary, robbery, murder, rape. This night, however, he isn't seeing any of it. This night, the 37-year-old, 16-year veteran of the force is doing the other side of police work - the side he calls ''not John Wayne.''

title: A MINNESTOTA INN FROM A GENTLER ERA
description: It is true that Stillwater, Minn., bears more than a passing resemblance to the mythical Lake Wobegon of Garrison Keillor's ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' that the good-natured little town sits similarly, snugly, in the St. Croix River Valley, in the shadow of the high-tech but eminently livable cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul, 30 minutes to the southwest.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the special Careers section on Oct. 13, under the headline ''Decade's Top Jobs,'' misstated the cost of a booklet titled ''Injection Molding,'' published by the Society of Plastics Industry Inc. It is $1 a copy.

title: TWIN THREATS TO DEMOCRACY IN NICARAGUA
description: In the last two weeks, the Sandinistas have shown their true stripes. Invoking the name of the ''people's revolution,'' they stripped the Nicaraguan people of all their civil rights. But what are the true stripes of the Reagan Administration? Invoking freedom and democracy, it opposes the increasingly totalitarian Sandinistas with unconditional backing for a rebel leadership that is disrespectful of human rights and reminiscent of the detested Somoza dynasty that ruled Nicaragua before the revolution.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: PLEA IN SPY CASE MAY HELP NAVY ASSESS DAMAGE
description: Military officials said today that the cooperation of John A. Walker Jr. in a Navy spy case will allow them to prepare a much more accurate assessment of the se= curity breach caused by what they say was nearly two decades of espionage.

title: Victoria T. Page Weds Executive
description: The wedding of Victoria Tilney Page, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norcross S. Tilney of Palm Beach, Fla. and Cedarhurst, L.I., to David Crumley Bevan Jr., a son of Mr. Bevan of Gladwyne, Pa., and the late Mrs. Bevan, took place yesterday. Judge Bruce M. Kaplan of New York City Family Court officiated at the River Club.

title: HERZOG INVEIGHS AGAINST UMPIRING
description: Whitey Herzog angrily denounced the umpiring in the World Series as ''a disgrace'' tonight and said that it had probably cost the St. Louis Cardinals the Series.

title: CONTROLLERS FIND ORGANIZING SNAGS
description: The effort to organize a union to represent the nation's air traffic controllers, already moving at a much slower pace than some advocates forecast earlier this year, has suffered two severe setbacks.

title: JAMES LEVINE AND THE MET
description: Many of the most passionate and faithful opera lovers have always been low- and middle-income people who scraped and saved to keep up their Met subscriptions but have now reached the point at which it is a totally unaffordable luxury. Is the Met so elitist that, despite its concern about the increasing failure to fill the house, it is not interested in attracting an audience for whom price is a problem? Is it not possible that by lowering prices a bit (say, to the level of Broadway shows), the increased amount of sold-out performances would more than make up the difference?

title: KODAK BOOSTS ELECTRONIC PICTURES
description: KODAK, the company that introduced roll film almost 100 years ago, has now embarked on an innovative program in electronic picture-taking that may significantly change the face of still and motion-picture photography. The company's new thinking is built around the home television set.

title: AFTERSHOCKS
description: EARTHQUAKE experts at Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory in Palisades, N.Y., installed eight portable seismographs at five sites in the Ardsley area last week in an effort to learn more about a ''previously unmapped fault line,'' as one scientist put it, that caused major concern last weekend.

title: 25 Food Outlets Cited By New York Officials
description: The New York City Department of Health has in the last two weeks released lists of 25 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: U.S. SEEKING TO TALK WITH A SOVIET SAILOR
description: State Department officials today negotiated with the captain of a Soviet grain ship anchored in the Mississippi River to interview a man who jumped from the vessel but was inadvertently returned to it, the officials said.

title: YONKERS RACE CENTERS ON FISCAL ISSUES
description: THE issue, the Yonkers vice mayor, Bernice Spreckman, told an east side taxpayers association recently, is ''10 years of fiscal mismanagement.''

title: MEN'S STYLE THE WINTER COVER-UP
description: THERE WAS A TIME WHEN BEING PROPERLY attired meant wearing a dress coat or chesterfield - in cashmere, melton and other fine wools - to the office. Period. Polo, steamer and other less formal coats - in tweeds, plaids and checks -were for the weekend.

title: WHERE HAVE ALL THE GOBLINS GONE?
description: THE neighborhood ghosts and goblins didn't come last year. In fact, I could count on the fingers of one hand the few who did.

title: Japan's Medicine For the Economy
description: What ails the world economy and the economies of the world? Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan offered delegates to the United Nations General Assembly his diagnosis last week, in suitably medical metaphors. Protectionism, he said, was ''a powerful narcotic.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CONSERVING A CONSERVATORY IT WAS the site of exotic parties during the early 1900's. A few orgies may even have taken place there, according to Doris Pike, a Dowling College trustee.

title: MORTGAGE ADVERTISEMENTS OFTEN BAFFLE CONSUMERS
description: ''ARM yourself against high mortgage payments,'' Eastern Savings Bank states in a recent newspaper advertisement for adjustable rate mortgages, or ARM's. The pun may be catchy, but that ARM - the bank's most prominently featured loan - is no weapon against high mortgage payments.

title: ARE BANK COMPUTERS TOO ABUSER-FRIENDLY?
description: The story trickling out of Chase Manhattan Bank's computer center near here in the last 10 days seemed all too familiar. Federal investigators said about two dozen teen-agers in San Diego, armed with a toll-free Chase telephone number and some inexpensive home computers, broke into a computer system housing financial records of some of the bank's largest corporate customers. They changed some passwords, briefly keeping Chase officials out of some of their own files. And depending on who you believe -the F.B.I. or Chase - they may have even gained access to one corporate account, though no money was transferred out of it.

title: U.S. MISSIONARY PILOT FLEES COLOMBIAN CAPTORS: 3 STILL HELD
description: A kidnapped American pilot for a missionary group escaped from rebels who had captured him by flying out of the jungle on a foggy, moonless night in a plane carrying an unknown amount of fuel, a spokesman for his missionary group said.

title: TV PLANS FOR AMERICA'S CUP
description: The 1987 America's Cup Races are more than a year away. But programmers at ESPN, the cable network that recently bought the rights for live American television coverage, are convinced that viewers want to know what syndicates are doing now to prepare for the races.

title: Elizabeth C. Orbe Wed To Vincent R. Fischer
description: Elizabeth Caroline Orbe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Octavius A. Orbe of Ridgewood, N.J., and Hyannis, Mass., was married yesterday to Vincent Robert Fischer, a son of Gloria Comerford Fischer of Ridgewood and the late Carl George Fischer. The Rev. Michael J. Moran performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J.

title: Miss Tannenbaum to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Tannenbaum of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Tannenbaum, to Alan Horvitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Horvitz of Fall River, Mass. A June wedding is planned by Miss Tannenbaum, a senior at Boston University, from which her fiance graduated last June.

title: OKLAHOMA NEWSPAPER SHUT
description: The Woodward Daily Press, a 62-year-old afternoon newspaper, has been sold to the competing morning paper, The Woodward News, and will go out of business. ''Sunday is my last day of publication,'' the publisher, Clark Lawrence Jr., said today. This town of 15,000 people has been among the smallest in the country with competing daily newspapers since The News started publishing a year ago. .

title: ARMY WINS AS IT FOILS 2-POINT ATTEMPT
description: All season, Army's defense has given up plenty of yards but few points as the Cadets rolled up an impressive record.

title: NICARAGUA REPORTS SOVIET BLOC IS STEPPING UP AID
description: A Nicaraguan official says Soviet-bloc countries are stepping up their aid to the Sandinista Government.

title: TRENTON ST. STOPS JERSEY CITY ST., 26-0
description: Bernie Liberati scored a pair of touchdowns in the fourth quarter on runs of 5 and 14 yards as Trenton State defeated Jersey City State yesterday for the 12th straight time, 26-0, in a New Jersey State Athletic Conference game in Jersey City.

title: FOR REAL GHOSTS, HALLOWEEN IS ALWAYS
description: GOBLINS, ghouls and ghosts will flit through countless neighborhoods Thursday, most of them under parents' watchful eyes.

title: PENN STIFLES YALE WITH STIFF DEFENSE
description: Penn rolled onward in the Ivy League today, using a strong defense to dominate Yale. The Quakers took command early and trounced the Elis, 23-7, before a crowd of 23,499 at Yale Bowl.

title: Home Sweet Home
description: Some Southerners have never forgiven Erskine Caldwell for ''Tobacco Road'' or ''God's Little Acre,'' his 1930's novels depicting depravity and deprivation in rural Georgia.

title: MONETARY POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: MADE IN INDIA FOR THE BRITISH MARKET
description: The shapes of chairs, tables and teapots look decidedly British - the materials and crafting anything but - in ''Anglo-India,'' an exhibition of 85 made-in-India 19th-century antiques and art works that opens Wednesday, and remains through Nov. 15, at Kentshire Galleries, 32 East 12th Street. The show covers material dating mostly from 1800 to 1870, a period during which, at first, part of the country was governed by the East India Company and, from 1858 on, was under the British Crown.

title: CONCERTS WITH A FRENCH ACCENT
description: THE next fortnight should be a Francophile's delight. Today at 4, for instance, when the Pro Arte Chamber Singers begin the season in their new home, St. John's Episcopal Church in Stamford, it will be with ''Musique de France.''The centerpiece of the program is the radiant Faure Requiem, and the conductor Arthur Sjogren has also chosen shorter works by Rameau, Ravel, Milhaud and Janequin. Tickets will be available at the door. When Opera New England begins its 12th season in Connecticut at 8 P.M. Saturday at Data General Cultural Center in Woodstock, the setting may be Sri Lanka but the music will still be pure French: ''The Pearl Fishers'' by Georges Bizet. A number of fine, young American singers are featured in the cast, including Joyce Guyer of the New York City Opera, Malcolm Arnold, resident baritone with the Dallas Opera, and Paul Spencer Adkins, the tenor who won the first Pavarotti International Competition. Call 928-2946 or 429-5813.

title: NEW ORLEANS
description: New Orleanians are deriving great satisfaction from the fact that the rest of the world has discovered blackened redfish. They have always known that their food was the best, along with their jazz and their Victorian architecture. Now news about Cajun cooking and its attempted cloning from Manhattan to Singapore has given the city an added lift.

title: MODELS FOR THEIR SEX
description: THE PRE-RAPHAELITE SISTERHOOD By Jan Marsh. Illustrated. 408 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $21.95.

title: TOOLS AS CONNECTIONS TO NATURE
description: OCCASIONALLY, one encounters a body of work that is remembered because it raises questions that will not settle down. That was this viewer's response to a selection of pieces in a group show at the Lee Sclar Gallery at 14 South Street here.

title: HURRICANE HEADING TOWARD HAWAII
description: Hurricane Nele, packing winds up to 110 miles per hour, accelerated toward the Hawaiian Islands today, producing 10-foot waves and prompting the authorities to post a hurricane watch.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HOLLYHOCKS, LAMBS AND OTHER PASSIONS. By Dee Hardie. (Atheneum, $15.95.) Dee Hardie has been chronicling her experiences on Thornhill Farm, in Maryland, in House Beautiful magazine for the last six years. Mrs. Hardie was inspired to write this memoir of life in the country as a legacy for her children and grandchildren.

title: ALL-YOU-CAN-EAT IN HIGGANUM
description: CUSTY'S latest stand is taking place in Higganum. In the early 1960's, when ''more was more'' gustatorily, Custy's of North Kingston, R.I., earned a reputation, that soon spread far beyond the state line, for its ''all you can eat for a fixed price'' buffets.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MASS. By Jack Fuller. (Morrow, $16.95.) The author of the acclaimed Vietnam War novel ''Fragments'' returns to the spy genre he explored so skillfully in his first novel, ''Convergence.''

title: LATCH-KEY CHILDREN ON THE INCREASE
description: SOME trudge home every day to an empty house. Others have to be the grown-up for younger brothers and sisters. Still others are locked out of their homes. These are ''latch-key'' children. The term dates to a time when children of working parents were sent to school wearing keys on strings around their necks. Though keys are not usually worn around necks these days, more and more children are believed to be alone at home after school.

title: A MONUMENTAL TREASURY OF 20TH-CENTURY ART
description: Not long after the end of World War II it became known that Peggy Guggenheim, a collector then widely regarded as a member of the lunatic fringe, had bought the Palazzo Venier dei Leoni on the Grand Canal in Venice and intended to fill it with her collection of 20th-century works of art. Feeling ran high among senior Venetians, many of whom saw it as an insult to Venice. Eager as they were to be invited to the house, and ready as they were to stay on to lunch or dinner if they could contrive to do so, they were amused, embarrassed, baffled or just plain disgusted by the art.

title: HUSSEIN REPORTED TO WEIGH LEAVING P.L.O. OUT OF PLAN
description: King Hussein, increasingly angry at Yasir Arafat, may threaten to drop the Palestinian leader from his peace efforts to force him to make an unequivocal declaration recognizing Israel and renouncing violence, according to Palestinian, Jordanian and Western diplomatic sources.

title: DRAMAS THAT SCORCH
description: MEMORY OF FIRE: I. GENESIS Part One of a Trilogy. By Eduardo Galeano. Translated by Cedric Belfrage. 293 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: ARIZONA IS UPSET
description: John Paye, the quarterback who suffered a separated shoulder last week, came off the bench in the second half today to rally Stanford to three touchdowns and a 28-17 upset that knocked Arizona out of the Pacific-10 Conference lead.

title: Mount Laurel Reshapes Moore Estate Plan
description: SHE was called Pippin, and in her day there was not a horse alive that could beat her. A bay with a white blaze on her face, she was considered the greatest hackney mare of all time and when she died in 1957, she was buried on the slope of Hollow Hill Farm in Morris Township.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: When the English painter Beryl Cook visited New York two years ago, she had lunch at the Russian Tea Room and tea at the Algonquin Hotel, but the Automat became her spiritual home. Although her droll impressions of each are among the 30 scenes reproduced in BERYL COOK'S NEW YORK (Knopf, $13.95), the artist seems to have the greatest affinity for the patrons of the Automat.

title: NO SIGN OF WEARINESS
description: For most tournament players a full day consists of 52 deals or perhaps 56. There has been a recent tendency to provide for the bridge-hungry by scheduling events beginning after breakfast or even at midnight. This makes a 10-hour playing day of about 80 deals a possibility, but most experts who attempt it would confess to some fatigue and consequent inefficiency at the end of it all.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

COINS FOR STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: After months of secrecy, the United States Mint has unveiled the designs of the three coins it will issue to honor the Statue of Liberty. The coins were introduced during first-strike ceremonies held Oct. 18 at two locations: the West Point Bullion Depository and the San Francisco Assay Office.

title:
GARDENING;

SOLVE SOIL DRAINAGE PROBLEMS IN THE FALL
description: THE adage, out of sight, out of mind, accurately sums up the average person's understanding of the importance of optimum soil conditions to successful gardening. And most soil problems are buried where they cannot be easily seen.

title: HEDGING YOUR BETS IN TAX PLANNING
description: ALTHOUGH it appears unlikely that Congress will enact a sweeping tax overhaul this year, there is a strong possibility that it may hammer out such legislation next year. Amid this uncertainty, tax specialists say that the traditional maxims of year-end tax planning have new urgency.

title: A FANTASY RESTORED
description: For 50 years it has jutted out from a point halfway up one of the peaks of Hong Kong's Happy Valley, a garishly colored, bizarre world of fantasy and mythology called Tiger Balm Gardens that has been perhaps Hong Kong's most visited attraction simply because of its longevity.

title: TWO ANCIENT MARATHONERS RETURN TO NEW YORK
description: THE gray stationwagon inched along in the midtown traffic at a considerably slower pace than Bill Rodgers and Frank Shorter are capable of running. The ancient marathoners were passengers, being briefed on the state of New York City politics by Fred Lebow, president of the New York Road Runners Club. They were behind schedule for an appearance at City Hall where they would endorse the re-election of Mayor Koch, who also knows a thing or two about running.

title: DIMLY VISIBLE IN THE MIDEAST FOG
description: King Hussein of Jordan has for 18 years cloaked his overtures for peace with Israel in fog. Is the fog finally breaking? Can there be substance to this season's peace scare?

title: PSYCHIATRIST, 33, HELD IN SLAYING
description: A 33-year-old psychiatrist was arrested yesterday in connection with the apparent strangulation of a man found nude in the psychiatrist's apartment in Manhattan, the police said.

title: The Gentler Time And the Fast Track
description: On the Opinion Page of Sept. 15, Joan Mass wrote of ''Finding Strength in a Gentler Time.'' Such strength poured from the frame of a self-sacrificing mother who gave more than it possessed her ever to ask in return. In the Magazine section there was a cover story, ''To the Edge of the Universe.'' I suggest that the granddaughter writhing on the floor from an overdose succumbed not to minor vexations but the decline of the humanities in an age of scientific breakthrough, with no less a prize than the stars.

title: HOT OVER 'THE BIG CHILL'
description: SHADOW DANCING IN THE U.S.A. By Michael Ventura. 232 pp. Los Angeles: Jeremy P. Tarcher/St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

title: PUBLIC ART GROUP IS ESTABLISHED
description: AN arts group whose goal is to place works of art in communities countywide has just been formed and has already obtained the use of a massive outdoor sculpture that will begin its tour in Valhalla in November.

title: MAO'S LONG MARCH
description: To the Editor:

title: FRANCE TO REVIEW ITS MIDEAST POLICY
description: France has decided to review its Middle East policy, particularly regarding the Palestine Liberation Organization, in light of recent events, French Government spokesmen said today.

title: MAIMI TOPS EX-COACH
description: Vinny Testaverde, playing against the coach who recruited him for Miami, passed for 295 yards and three touchdowns tonight to help the Hurricanes rout Louisville and their former coach, Coach Howard Schnellenberger, 45-7.

title: MEDDLING IN THE GROVES OF ACADEME
description: ''Our nation is deeply committed to safeguarding academic freedom, which is of transcendent value to all of us and not merely to the teachers concerned. That freedom is therefore a special concern of the First Amendment, which does not tolerate laws that cast a pall of orthodoxy over the classroom.''

title: CITY-CATHOLIC AGENCY ACCORD
description: The Board of Estimate has approved a foster-care contract with a Roman Catholic social-services agency in return for the agency's agreement that it will no longer require its employees to accept Catholic religious beliefs.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: VOYAGES OF THE STEAMBOAT YELLOW STONE. By Donald Jackson. (Ticknor & Fields, $16.95.) On April 16, 1831, the steamboat Yellow Stone set off from St. Louis up the Missouri, headed for Fort Union, in what is now Montana.

title: CONCERN OVER AIDS SPURRING CALLS TO BLOOD-TEST HOT LINES
description: WORRY over acquired immune deficiency syndrome has spurred dozens of Long Island residents to call local hot lines for information on the blood test that can indicate whether they are carrying the AIDS antibody.

title: THE EMPEROR OF HARTFORD
description: WALLACE STEVENS A Mythology of Self. By Milton J. Bates. Illustrated. 319 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $24.95.

title: A Gift in Boston For Old Ironsides
description: THE U.S.S. Constitution, now a naval museum on the Charles River in Boston, received a 58-foot piece of Douglas fir for her 188th birthday this week.

title: CAVIAR, GENERAL?
description: A COUPLE OF HEAVY-weight professors were sparring recently on the ''CBS Morning News'' about the wisdom of the nuclear shield called ''Star Wars.'' I was in bed in a hotel room, getting a second reprieve from a snooze alarm, when I heard the voice of Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., a Distinguished Professor of the City University of New York (who happens also to be a distinguished professor, uncapitalized, in real life). He was knocking the President's plan, which did not interrupt my reverie, but then he said something about ''not helping the sclerotic economy.''

title: VERBATIMk;   CRUMBLING COURTS
description: Too often, when our citizens seek a dignified place of deliberation in which to resolve their controversies, they find instead aesthetic revulsion. They bear witness - not to dignity, but to deterioration, not to actual justice delivered - but to the perception of justice denied or worse, justice degraded ' rrSol Wachtler Chief Judge of New York State, calling for the rebuilding of the state's deteriorated court buildings.

title: Dr. William F. Eckhardt 3d Marries Dr. Carolyn L. Kinney in Philadelphia
description: Dr. Carolyn Louise Kinney, a daughter of Dr. Joseph J. Kinney and Dr. Dorothy Kinney of Bridgewater, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. William Francis Eckhardt 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Eckhardt Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. William O'Brien performed the ceremony at Old St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: SALVATION ARMY OUSTS OFFICIAL ACCUSED OF GRAFT
description: The Salvation Army has forced the head of its Dallas thrift store operation to retire after concluding that he had violated its rules of conduct with respect to a donated boat.

title: Miss Warriner, Editor, Is Wed
description: Alexandra Mercer Warriner and George Burnet Lewis Jr. were married yesterday at the Ruxton, Md., home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Farnham Warriner. The Rev. William McKeachie, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: NEW CASSETTES: EVERGREEN MUSICAL, CLASSIC ANIMATION
description: Prince and the Revolution Live Warner Home Video 156 minutes. $29.98 Dimly lighted, overextended, sloppily directed and indifferently recorded, this March 1985 Prince concert is still a worthwhile sample of his calculated abandon.

title: THE CABINET SEARCHES FOR CONSENSUS ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: Rarely has an issue divided the Reagan Administration as deeply as a proposal to rewrite a 20-year-old executive order that requires affirmative action by Government contractors.

title: AT HOME WITH RESTAURATEURS: EAST COAST
description: MY WAY OF relaxing on a Sunday is to try to cook in the same kitchen with my wife, which is not always easy,'' said Sirio Maccioni, owner of one of the world's most celebrated restaurants, Le Cirque in Manhattan.

title: SCHNAPPS, THE CORDIAL SPIRIT
description: SCHNAPPS. THE NAME, IN this country at least, recalls a simpler time, when vaudeville comedians regaled German immigrant audiences with stories about happy schnapps drinkers.

title: REMODELING YOUR HOUSE: FIRST, GET IT IN WRITING
description: YEARS ago, it was common for a homeowner who needed another room or an updated kitchen or bathroom to sell his house and move to one that better suited his needs. But with today's high housing costs, more and more homeowners are remodeling or enlarging instead of moving.

title: BOMB HURTS STUDENT AT BRIGHAMN YOUNG U
description: A homemade bomb has exploded on the campus of Brigham Young University, the police said, injuring a student who was trying to stamp out the fuse.

title: DANCE
description: Dance directors tend to talk about the eclecticism of their companies. The Joffrey Ballet nearly defines the term in dance, as may be seen from the repertory the company will perform this week at City Center.

title: LEGAL MOVE UNDER WAY TO OUST RHODE ISLAND CHIEF JUSTICE
description: The Chief Justice of Rhode Island is expected to return to the bench Friday, four months after he took a leave of absence when a judicial commission censured him for his ties to organized crime figures.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: BUSINESSES have invested more than $125 million in New Jersey's five Urban Enterprise Zones since the start of the state's Urban Redevelopment Program less than a year ago, according to figures released earlier this month by the state's Department of Commerce and Economic Development.

title: PLAN FOR VISTA OUTSIDE NATIONAL PARKS IS REJECTED
description: The Interior Department has rejected a proposal to create a list of scenic views outside national parks that would be recommended for protection from development.

title: Of Things British
description: As the Washington visit of the Prince and Princess of Wales approaches, it seems that the sun never sets on plans to make good commerce out of it. The British Embassy is cooperating to the hilt with local merchants and has released a list of stores that will be promoting the sale of goods made in the United Kingdom while the royal couple is in town.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY COMPANY IN CRANKO 'JEU DE CARTES'
description: IGOR STRAVINSKY'S ''Jeu de Cartes,'' a ballet score created in 1936, contains fleeting parodies of such composers as Rossini, Tchaikovsky and Ravel. John Cranko's choreography to the music has its moments of parody of the original ballet, by George Balanchine. All three refer to poker deals and hands. If that all sounds impossibly intricate, the Joffrey Ballet's performance of the Cranko ''Jeu de Cartes,'' revived on Friday at City Center, can be enjoyed as sheer dance fun.

title: IT'S A BIRD, IT'S A...NO, IT'S JUST A BLIMP WITH A MESSAGE
description: SINCE late August, something new has been appearing in the skies above northern New Jersey and New York City: McDonald's airship, the Big Mac 1, which operates out of Teterboro Airport.

title: FOREIGN POLICY: WHERE CONSENSUS ENDS
description: FOR PRESIDENT RONALD REAGAN, THE UNITED STATES-SOVIET relationship is a constant preoccupation - the touchstone by which all other issues are judged. Even at the height of the Beirut hostage crisis last summer, the Russians were never far from his thoughts. Anxious to avoid comparisons with President Carter's self-imposed isolation during the Iran hostage crisis, Mr. Reagan went to a Lions Club convention in Dallas to sell his tax-reform plan. Characteristically, he departed from his prepared text to tell one of his favorite anti-Soviet stories.

title: PLETHO PAPPUS AND THE DOUGHBOY
description: MASTERS OF ATLANTIS By Charles Portis. 248 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: MILITARY CLARIFIES AIDS TEST POLICIES
description: The Defense Department, in guidelines for testing active military personnel for AIDS, has barred the automatic dismissal of individuals who, in the course of the testing, acknowledge that they are homosexuals or drug users.

title: JOHN JAY UNDEFEATED
description: Undefeated John Jay won its battle for first place in the Northwest B division by beating Brewster, 35-21, yesterday.

title: THE A.B.A.'S BREAK WITH TRADITION
description: WILLARD C. BUTCHER, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, did not show up. And John S. Reed, chairman of Citibank, flew in for the weekend, but left before the sessions.

title: SOULS IN THE GULAG
description: THE ZONE A Prison Camp Guard's Story. By Sergei Dovlatov. Translated by Anne Frydman. 178 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Black Sash wonders why the President thinks it's necessary to declare a state of emergency in Cape Town when he knows very well that existing legislation allows the police to detain without trial, to ban meetings, to prevent all legitimate protests and opposition to government policy.'' - Sheena Duncan, president of the Black Sash, a South African civil rights group. [23:4.]

title: EFFORTS OF PUPILS AID STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: WHEN the 400 students at the Mitchell School in Woodbury begin their costumed rounds on Halloween, they will be in search of both treats for them and money for the restoration of the Statue of Liberty.

title: THE PRIVATE PALACES OF BRITAIN
description: IF THERE IS ANY ONE THING ABOUT England on which everyone is agreed, it is that the English country house is one of the great human achievements. It is because of this that the National Gallery of Art in Washington has staked its time, space and a very large sum of its own and its supporters' money on an exhibition sponsored by the Ford Motor Company and called ''Treasure Houses of Britain: 500 Years of Private Patronage and Art Collecting'' that will open Nov. 3 and run through March 16.

title: POST-PUNK ROCK REBELS THRIVE IN MINNEAPOLIS
description: Something about Minneapolis breeds rock rebels. The city's best-known performer, Prince, bends genres and breaks taboos without batting a mascaraed eyelash. Less showmanlike, but no less rebellious, are Minneapolis's two leading post-punk bands, Husker Du and the Replacements. These two bands stand in open opposition to the upscale verities of 1980's rock - they defy the docile, well-groomed, reassuring, high-image and low-content rock mainstream. In fact, they have mapped out a new kind of American malaise; they see nothing ahead but dead ends, and they hurtle toward them with a black-humored rage.

title: FIRST ENCOURAGEMENTS
description: AT LEHIGH UNI-versity in the fall of 1968, Prof. David Greene called one of my freshman English papers ''Whitmanesque.''

title: WHEN RAIN IS A REASON TO SHINE
description: A LOT of New Yorkers greet rain with a grumble. To them, it's a nuisance manifested in wet shoes and socks, clothes that will get rumpled and need cleaning and puddles that become tidal waves when a passing cab drives through them. Perhaps that's why the standard color for umbrellas is black - for gloomy.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN ALPINE
description: IT will take no more than 10 minutes for a visitor to discover that the Borough of Alpine is not a typical suburban community. There is no downtown, no library, no mail delivery service, and to find one of the 1,550 residents within its eight square miles the visitor will probably have to knock on a few doors since the houses are not numbered.

title: HEART IMPLANT PATIENTS SAID TO MAKE PROGRESS
description: Thomas J. Gaidosh, a 47-year-old factory worker being kept alive by a Jarvik-7 artificial heart, continued improving today, and hospital officials said they were encouraged by his progress as the search for a human heart widened.

title: L.I. PLAYWRIGHT JOURNEYS INTO THE BIZARRE
description: A PAIR of parents ignore their child's obesity and catatonia. An earthquake occurs in the midst of a family squabble. A house is enveloped by an ominous fog, and a child is sent out to play in it. A ''30-year-old farm girl'' is watching television, while fantasizing about immolation, incest and patricide.

title: ST. PAUL'S WINS TITLE
description: St. Paul's of Garden City (6-0) handed Long Island Lutheran (4-1) its first loss of the season, 12-0, to take the Nassau County Island Football Conference title for the second year in a row.

title: APARTHEID FOES CONDEMN NEW CAPE TOWN DECREE
description: Opponents of the Government today condemned the extension of the state of emergency to Cape Town and seven surrounding districts on Friday.

title:
DINING OUT;

AN AIR OF INFORMALITY IN MIDDLESEX
description: RECOMMENDATIONS from readers led us to Middlesex, north of New Brunswick, to sample the fare at Boca. This two-year-old establishment in a nondescript little building next to the A. & P. is packed on weekends with locals watching television at the bar or dining on generous, if routine, Italian-American dishes in the two attractive rooms.

title: A PLAY OF IDEAS STIRS POLITICAL PASSIONS
description: Wallace Shawn's Toby-jug features, alternately amiable and harassed, have become a standard feature of American movies in the last eight years. Mr. Shawn made his stage-acting debut in his 1977 adaptation of ''The Mandrake.'' As he himself, some 20 films later, self-deprecatingly puts it, ''Once you're on the casting directors' list of the six short, bald, little people they find comical, you find that work tends to breed work.''

title: ENTERTAINERS ARE SHAMELESS
description: Something odd is going on.

title: EWING-MALONE: TO CONTINUE
description: THERE was aggression everywhere at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Outside, the pretzel man was telling the hot-dog man to move to another corner or he'd punch his face. Just another fine Saturday noon in the big city.

title: GETTING MIDEAST MOMENTUM GOING AGAIN
description: The various players in the Middle East took their turns stealing the limelight last week, but when all was said and done it was clear that the next -and perhaps climactic - move belonged to Jordan's King Hussein. The King seemed to hold the keys both to the start of direct negotiations with Israel and to the futures of Yasir Arafat and Israel's coalition Government.

title: A SKEPTICAL BELIEVER
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH ISAAC BASHEVIS SINGER By Isaac Bashevis Singer and Richard Burgin. 178 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $15.95. IS there a Jewish sensibility? Anyone reading these interviews of Isaac Bashevis Singer by Richard Burgin, a professor of English at Drexel University in Philadelphia, would have to say yes. For Mr. Singer, character is ''the very essence of literature'' and is established through ''the language of deeds,'' while Yiddish is rich in descriptive idioms for character and behavior. He also assumes life is richer than art, and he always begins with real people.

title: LANGUAGE PROJECT CITES GAINS
description: IN recent years, numerous studies have documented the declining interest in foreign-language study in American schools. To counteract that trend, many efforts have been made nationwide to encourage student interest in foreign languages and to help teachers improve their language-teaching skills.

title: MINORITY ENROLLMENT IN COLLEGES IS DECLINING
description: Five years ago one of every eight students in New Jersey's 56 public and private colleges was black. Last year the figure was down to one of every nine students.

title: Mary Jane Davis Weds Dr. Bernard Turchiano
description: Mary Jane Davis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood E. Davis of Kingston, N.Y., and Craigville, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Bernard M. Turchiano, a son of Antoinette Turchiano of Brooklyn and Hollywood, Fla., and the late Richard Turchiano. The Rev. William F. Guido performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ASK Janice Fitzsimmons to define a schoolteacher and she says: ''A teacher reaches into her students' hearts, encourages their enthusiasms, helps them keep their dreams and excitement about what life has to offer and teaches them to feel good about who they are.''

title: James Levine And the Met
description: Will Crutchfield does not sufficiently stress the importance of great conductors for a first-rate opera house (''James Levine: New Era at the Met,'' Sept. 22). While James Levine is certainly a very good conductor and has raised the orchestra to a high level of performance, none but mediocrities and routiniers have mounted the podium since maestro Levine's ascendancy.

title: GROW YOUR OWN APPLES AND HAVE THE PICK OF FLAVOR
description: I have an apple tree with the unwieldy name of Esopus Spitzenburg. It is known to bear only moderate crops and is especially susceptible to apple scab. Then why am I growing it? Because of the mouth-watering flavor of this aromatic, crisp apple!

title: SITUATION YOU DREAM ABOUT
description: AS the other Royals hurried through the tunnel into their clubhouse, Danny Jackson yelled, ''We're not dead yet.'' And in front of the Royals' dugout, Dane Iorg, Charlie Leibrandt and their manager, Dick Howser, were waving to all the Royals' rooters who had refused to leave, who were still staring at the scoreboard almost in disbelief.

title: Buffer Zone Concordat
description: When a Nassau County developer made known his plans to put up a complex of condominium apartments in town houses in an area of single family homes in Woodbury, neighboring homeowners vowed to fight the project.

title: CONSUMER RATES
PHILATELIC TIES WITH CHINA
description: Ties that bind the United States and Nationalist China are evidenced by two recent events. There was a visit to this country of a leading Taiwanese postal official and the imminent release by that nation of a stamp honoring Dr. Sun Yat-sen, a leader who has twice been featured on United States stamps.

title: JAZZ
description: The Manhattan Transfer, who are sharing the bill with the Count Basie Orchestra at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday, have long since transcended their original image of campy pop nostalgists to become the country's most popular jazz singing ensemble. The quartet's wonderfully refined blend of vocal personalities includes a hipster (Tim Hauser) and a smoothie (Tim Hauser).

title: Angela Campbell Becomes a Bride
description: Angela Julia Campbell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Campbell of Cincinnati, was married yesterday to Michael Deuel Sullivan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Deuel Sullivan of New York and Bayville, L.I. Associate Judge Patricia M. Wald of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Washington.

title: ROCK MUSIC
description: On Thursday, two of the odder manifestations of California funk will share a double bill at the Ritz, East 11th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues. The bands, both from Los Angeles, are Fishbone and the Red Hot Chili Peppers; they are raucous, irreverent and highly danceable.

title: AN ELEGANT EVENING
description: A SHORT WHILE AGO, A friend and neighbor, recently married, telephoned me to discuss preparations for the first ''seated'' dinner to be given in her new home.

title: WHAT'S WRONG AT NOTRE DAME?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FORMALLY AND PASSIONATELY YOURS
description: DARLINGHISSIMA Letters to a Friend. By Janet Flanner. Edited and with commentary by Natalia Danesi Murray. Illustrated. 507 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: Jean Willard Married To John Houston Foss
description: The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Jean Willard, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Tyler Darby Willard of Raymond, Me., to John Houston Foss, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Foss of Wooster, Ohio. The Rev. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony.

title: What Washington Said
description: To the Editor:

title: BAUSCH AS CHOREOGRAPHER OF SOCIAL TRAUMA
description: The Pina Bausch Tanztheater Wuppertal has come and gone again, leaving the usual controversy in its wake. It isn't true that you either love or hate Miss Bausch's work. She is one of the few choreographers who can magnetize a spectator's attention on a level that has nothing to do with the simplest of emotions. Those who claim to hate her work came to see it anyway. In her 1984 New York debut, most who said they despised her pieces, specifically the images of violence, stayed put in their seats. This year in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave festival, her recent ''On the Mountain a Cry Was Heard'' did succeed in driving some out of the theater.

title: HARD CURRENCY Imprudently Paranoid
description: Delta Press Ltd., an Arkansas mail-order house, takes a straightforward approach to marketing. It inflates the fears of the paranoid and then sells them books with ''the information you will need to survive the economic collapse, rioting and civil disorder that await us all.''

title: HOME ON THE RANGE, BUT AT WHAT PRICE?
description: In the vast and dry Western landscape, where 30 or 40 acres may be needed to support a single cow for a month, livestock operators turn at this season to one of their oldest rituals, moving stock from high summer pastures to winter grazing grounds.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

COUNTRY FRIENDS
description: A glimpse of the Quaker style of living - past and present - can be had today at the Purchase Meeting House, where ''300 Years of Westchester Quakers: A Friendly Celebration'' is being held from 1 to 4 P.M. Its organizers are inviting the public to ''explore the Friendly way of life: Quakerism. Enjoy refreshments, historical exhibits and friendly discussion.''

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: FOOLISH RABBIT'S BIG MISTAKE. By Rafe Martin. Illustrated by Ed Young. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $13.95. (Ages 3 to 5) In this handsome adaptation of an African variation on ''the sky is falling,'' foolish rabbit, dozing under an apple tree, wakes to a crash and becomes convinced that the earth is breaking up.

title: TRUTH IN TEACHING IS CRUCIAL
description: OUR nation's many fine schools and talented students rank among the best in the world. Unfortunately, our high schools also graduate functional illiterates who cannot read, write or use mathematics in a practical way.

title: INFLATION IS STAYING AT A 20-YEAR LOW
description: Inflation is at its lowest in almost 20 years. Consumer prices rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in September, for an annual rate of 2.3 percent. Some economists worry that the rate is too low for a vigorous expansion in the economy. Because of low inflation in the third quarter, Social Security recipients will get just a 3.1 percent increase in benefits come January, the smallest increase in 13 years. The third-quarter rate is also used to determine the new Federal income tax brackets and personal exemptions for indexing purposes: Assuming no dollar increase in salary, a family of four with adjusted gross income of $33,437 will save $81.

title: Pretoria Extends Emergency Rules To Cape Town
description: South Africa imposed emergency rules last week in Cape Town, its second-largest and historically most liberal city. At least 30 people have died in the city and surrounding settlements in the last two weeks.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE BENNINGTON STITCH By Sheila Solomon Klass. 133 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up) AMELIA BLOOMER HAMILTON, known as Amy, may be the world's worst test-taker, and her SAT scores are too low to get her into a good college. This doesn't particularly upset Amy because she doesn't really want to go to college yet. She would rather take some time off after high school to figure out what to do with her life. Opposition comes from her mother, who has her heart set on Amy's attending Bennington College, the school she once hoped to attend.

title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TRAVELER'S CHECKS
description: Responding to a knock on the door by a man dressed in what looked like a hotel uniform, a professor from Japan visiting New York with his wife was recently robbed at gunpoint of, among other things, $1,000 in traveler's checks.

title: No Headline
description: In the early 1800's, Bethesda, Md., just northwest of here, was a frontier crossing of Indian trails, the first hard day's overnight stop on the covered wagon trek to the West, eight uphill miles on a rutted dirt road from the starting point at the Potomac River tobacco port of Georgetown.

title: Rev. Roger T. Schellenberg Is Wed to Virginia Scherrer
description: Virginia Scherrer and the Rev. Roger Thomas Schellenberg were married yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., where the bridegroom is the assistant to the rector, the Rev. William C. Heffner, who performed the ceremony.

title: CAPPODOCIA'S LUNAR LANDSCAPE
description: In the days before Neil A. Armstrong gave real contours to the phantasmagoric image that the phrase ''lunar landscape'' used to evoke, Cappadocia could have served as its earthly counterfeit. Although firmly planted in the earth of Turkey's Anatolia (the ancient Asia Minor), a more extraterrestrial specter than Cappadocia's landscape can hardly be imagined -endless fields of bizarre castles, cones, spires and towers, crags dotted with mysterious apertures and phalanxes of gigantic mushrooms wearing caps that mock gravity.

title: PLUMBING THE SECRETS OF THE TALLEY CLAN
description: In Lanford Wilson's richly textured cycle of plays about the Talleys of Lebanon, Mo., generations of one family dominate a town and its inhabitants. The Talleys are the owners of both the bank and clothing factory, primary employers as well as local aristocracy of wealth. Almost to a man, they are acquisitive and retributive. The secret of Talley acumen, as represented by the domineering grandfather of the family, is decisive and impersonal maneuvering. In common with Lillian Hellman's Hubbard family (in ''The Little Foxes''), the Talleys know when to sell - and when to sell out.

title: John L. McDonald to Wed Elizabeth Verrochi in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Verrochi of Point Pleasant, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Verrochi, to John L. McDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. McDonald of Storrs, Conn. A May wedding is planned. Miss Verrochi is a special accounts manager and Mr. McDonald is a strategic planner for the Tufts Associate Health Plan in Waltham, Mass.

title: HOMELESSNESS: LOOKING FOR SOLUTIONS
description: WITH winter approaching, shelter operators throughout the state are worried they will not be able to accommodate the growing number of people who will need their help this year. But adding more beds, they say, is not the way to solve the problems of Connecticut's homeless.

title: SICILIANS SAID TO ISSUE WARRANT FOR A PALDSTINIAN IN HIJACKING
description: Prosecutors in Sicily have issued an arrest warrant for Mohammed Abbas, the Palestinian official accused by the United States of masterminding the hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise ship, the ANSA news agency reported tonight.

title: CABLE TV
description: Movie goose-pimples on cable this Halloween? You bet - choice ones, too, amidst some lurid horror fare that should have stayed under the rocks.

title: SUFFOLK JUDGE ACCUSES PROSECUTORS OF HARASSMENT
description: A Suffolk County Court judge who sharply criticized the conduct of the District Attorney's office in two murder trials has charged that county prosecutors harassed him Tuesday.

title: TOBIN VS. MUNDELL
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAY, NOT THE MESSAGE, IS THE THING
description: THE Hungarian playwright Ferenc Molnar is best known in America for his play ''Liliom,'' which Rodgers and Hammerstein turned into the long-running musical ''Carousel.'' He was a prolific writer and his more popular works, such as ''The Guardsman'' and ''The Play's the Thing,'' are still frequently produced in regional theaters.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: REQUIEM. By Shizuko Go. Translated by Geraldine Harcourt. (Kodansha, $14.95.) ''Requiem'' is a hymn for the dead offered by a dying girl.

title: Love Those Lobbyists
description: One widely accepted view of Congressional life and relationships is that the lobbyists spend most of their time buttering up the members, but sometimes it seems to work the other way about.

title: CHINA HITS ITS STRIDE
description: ''We are weeping from too many joys. We are rid of the shame of the past. Our forefathers can feel at ease in their graves.

title: BUFFETED BY CHANGE, TV GRASPS AT FORMULAS
description: A few weeks ago, CBS devoted an entire Sunday evening - before the start of the official ratings season - to a superb production of Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman,'' starring Dustin Hoffman. It was television for the history books.

title: TEEN-AGERS AND CARS: TIME TO GET TOUGH
description: A 17-YEAR-OLD friend, on a mile-long stretch of straight road, drove his car up to 115 miles an hour to see if his radio aerial could withstand the speed. Another new driver, also 17, after working on his car to give its engine as much power as possible, discovered he could hit 130 miles an hour.

title: Patient Must Be Fed, Judge Says
description: Does the medical profession have an ethical responsibility to provide food and water to hopelessly ill patients? It does in the case of a 48-year-old Massachusetts man who has been in a ''persistent vegetative state'' since March 1983, a probate judge ruled last week.

title: THE ENIVIRONMENT
description: ASSEMBLY subcommittee hearings on hazardous-waste dumping at the Lakehurst Naval Air Engineering Center so far have produced more questions than answers in determining, among other things, whether there is ground-water contamination.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Royals vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Kansas City. This would be Game 7 of the World Series only if the Royals won last night. (Television - Channel 7, 8:15 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:15 P.M.). Football Jets vs. Seattle Seahawks, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. The Jets have never beaten the Seahawks in seven meetings, and Seattle has won five games on Jets turf. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 1 P.M.). Giants vs. Saints, at New Orleans. The Giants have never won in New Orleans. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 4 P.M.). Golf Seiko-Tucson Match Play Championships, at Tucson Arizona, semifinals and final. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Boston Bruins, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Rangers close out a four-game home stand and don't play again until they meet the Devils next Saturday in New Jersey. (Television -MSG Network 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.). Sabres vs. Minnesota North Stars at Buffalo (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.). Running New York City Marathon, 26 miles 385 yards beginning at the toll plaza of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, Staten Island, to Tavern on the Green in Central Park, 10:30 A.M. Orlando Pizzolato and Grete Waitz are the defending men's and women's champions in the field of 19,000 going for $273,800 in prize money. First prize is $25,000, plus a Mercedes-Benz. In addition there is a $10,000 bonus for a course record and a $50,000 bonus for a world best.

title: WILLIAMS CENTER SEEKS FUNDS
description: THE William Carlos Williams Center for the Arts here will begin its fund-raising campaign Thursday evening with a ''Phantom of the Opera Ball.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Oct. 27, 1985 Fiction

title: 2D PRIMARY FOR LONG BEACH SUPERVISOR SET FOR TOMORROW
description: LONG BEACH Democrats will hold their second primary in two months tomorrow to choose a candidate for city supervisor, after the results of the September primary were thrown out by a judge.

title: RAM DEFENSE A GROUP EFFORT
description: THE left end is Doug Reed, the nose tackle, Charles DeJurnett, the right outside linebacker, Mike Wilcher. What's that? Never heard of them? How about Carl Ekern, the left inside linebacker, or Reggie Doss, the right end? Still nothing?

title: COURT BARS ALASKAN OFFSHORE OIL EXPLORATION
description: A Federal appeals court has issued a preliminary injunction prohibiting exploration for oil and gas on two tracts of federally owned land on Alaska's outer continental shelf.

title: Miss McMahon, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Melissa Ann McMahon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Franklin McMahon of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Jonathan Paul Cramer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving I. Cramer of Shaker Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Walter Wagoner, a Congregationalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: TRADITIONAL DUTCH TASTING HOUSES
description: When his drink arrives, the man puts his hands behind his back, bends over and takes the first sip. No, he hasn't committed a faux pas, he has executed the drinking ritual practiced in a Dutch proeflokaal (tasting house).

title: DANCE: CAROLYN CARLSON PERFORMS A SOLO WORK, 'BLUE LADY'
description: THE newest venture in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival is a series of various one-woman shows - launched Friday night with Carolyn Carlson's appearance as a dance soloist in the academy's opera house.

title: A.I.C. HANDS ITHACA FIRST LOSS
description: A reserve fullback, Rod Fontes, rushed for 104 yards and three touchdowns today as American International ended Ithaca's 15-game winning streak, 41-8. Fontes scored twice on 1-yard runs and added a 6-yard touchdown for the Yellow Jackets (6-2). Ithaca is 5-1. Canisius 33, Mercyhurst 15 BUFFALO (AP) - Mike Panepinto rushed for 232 yards and two touchdowns as Canisius ended a nine-game winning streak of Mercyhurst (6-1). Canisius (5-2-1) capitalized on nine turnovers.

title: David A. Nolletti Weds Jennifer Leigh Wallach
description: Jennifer Leigh Wallach, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brian Wallach of White Plains, was married yesterday to David A. Nolletti, a son of Albert A. Nolletti of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Rita C. Nolletti. The Rev. William D. Eddy performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WORKS OF MAN. By Ronald W. Clark. (Viking, $24.95; $29.95 after Dec. 31.) At a time lost in the mists of antiquity, someone looked at the two stone posts on either side of the doorway and wondered if and how the two might support a horizontal crosspiece.

title: JOURNEYS TO AFRICA AND THE AMAZON
description: African Tour For Gorilla Watchers At a height of more than 9,000 feet, on heavily forested African mountainsides scarred with deep gullies, live two families of the last of the world's 500 mountain gorillas. They are typical of their species - with one exception. Over the years, these animals have been habituated to visits by humans, initially by naturalists associated with the Mountain Gorilla Project, established to preserve the gorillas' habitat by staving off the encroachment of farmers.

title: Debra Campbell Weds Executive
description: St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Debra Lynn Campbell, the daughter of J. David Campbell of Phoenix and the late Mrs. Campbell, to J. Frederick Stillman 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. P. Gordon B. Stillman of New York and Wrightsville Beach, N.C. The Rev. Bruce W. Forbes performed the ceremony.

title: FOR FOUR NEW YORKERS KIFFICULT VIETNAM VISIT
description: It was in many ways a painful odyssey, marked now and then by tension and tears. Four New York veterans of Vietnam, the first state delegation to make such a trip, had returned to this country on public and personal quests.

title: BEARS FLOURISHING IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Despite continuing pressure from an extremely hearty species known as man, another creature has been making a comeback lately in the New York metropolitan area - the black bear.

title: NETS ARE ROUTED BY PACERS, 119-92
description: Vern Fleming scored 25 points and Clark Kellogg added 24 tonight as the Pacers trounced the Nets, 119-92, in Indiana's season-opener.

title: A LONG LINE IS FORMING TO FILL HECKLER'S SHOES
description: Nearly four weeks ago, at about the same time Margaret M. Heckler was agreeing to step aside as Secretary of Health and Human Services, a White House aide was drafting a lengthy memorandum for Donald T. Regan, the chief of staff.

title: JETS ARE HOPING FOR BETTER ENDING
description: Crazy things must be happening when one club loses to another seven straight times - especially when the loser has been favored virtually every game.

title: REAL ESTATE'S MATCHMAKER
description: ACROSS THE WATERS FROM THE Statue of Liberty, a pair of mighty monoliths is rapidly emerging to join lower Manhattan's tangle of skyscrapers. The towers are to be the world headquarters of Merrill Lynch & Company, and the deal behind them - the sale of Merrill's old headquarters and the 25-year lease for the new - was worth a staggering $3 billion, one of the largest transactions in the history of commercial real estate. The man who hammered out the deal was John C. Cushman 3d. John Who? In the remarkable office-building boom of the last decade that has transformed urban skylines across the nation, the public stars have been the architects, like Philip Johnson, and developers with names like Donald Trump of New York and Gerald Hines of Houston. But in recent years, an elite group of brokers has played an increasingly crucial, behind-the-scenes role in the remaking of America's cityscape. At the age of 44, John Cushman is a leader of the pack, a flamboyant, boastful broker with the negotiating skills of a diamond trader and a line into the most powerful corporate circles. And now, even as the building boom shows signs of slackening, he is preparing to take advantage of a downturn.

title: AN OPERA FULL OF COINCIDENCES
description: IT'S not that Joan Crowell is overly superstitious. The long arm of coincidence might just be getting shorter, she conceded. But strange things started happening as soon as she tried to get her opera, ''The Bell Witch of Tennessee,'' produced.

title: THE LONDON CONNECTION
description: London is the cheap-flight capital of Europe, and the traveler from the United States who wants to add another country to a trip to Britain will find that charter flights and discounted fares abound. Moreover, the special fares can often be booked up to the last minute.

title: FOR ARTHRITIS VICTIM, PIANO IS TREATMENT
description: THERE would seem to be nothing unusual about a 15-year-old playing the theme from the television show ''Hill Street Blues'' on the piano, but Jamie Birnbaum of Stamford has psoriatic arthritis.

title: INDIA AND PAKISTAN EDGE A BIT CLOSER
description: After three wars in less than four decades India and Pakistan remain deeply suspicious of each other. But as their leaders met at the United Nations 40th anniversary celebration last week, the reconcilation process took on fresh urgency.

title: TARRYTOWN AGENCY MARKS ANNIVERSARY
description: AS a matrimonial lawyer, Doris T. Friedman said, she was ''used to calamities.''

title: Pamela Kanner, Producer, Married to Edward Henry
description: Pamela Anne Kanner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kanner of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Wellfleet, Mass., was married yesterday to Edward John Henry, a son of Grace Henry of Chicago, Ill., and Daniel Henry of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. John B. Kauta performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: DARWIN AND GRACIE MANSION
description: POLITICAL CRISIS/FISCAL CRISIS The Collapse and Revival of New York City. By Martin Shefter. 270 pp. New York: Basic Books. $21.95. TEN years ago, in an informal meeting at Gracie Mansion, several journalists confronted Mayor Abraham Beame with evidence of what was fast becoming an open secret - that New York City was teetering on the brink of bankruptcy. Mr. Beame, who rarely betrayed emotion, fidgeted in his seat and sipped a scotch-on-the-rocks as he listened politely but stone-faced. Then, in exasperation, he delivered a warmed-over lecture about how New York was unique, and why, in spite of the proliferating warning signs, it couldn't happen here.

title: ICHABOD CRANE TURNS UP IN MANHATTAN
description: YESTERDAY the cast and crew of a new Off Off Broadway stage adaptation of ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow'' were to take a trip to Tarrytown -where its author, Washington Irving, lived - to pick up some local color and an extra on-the-spot rehearsal.

title: NEW BOOK TO LIST TALENT-FOR-HIRE
description: WHEN Dorothy and Ed Bryce were asked to help find 12 actors for a commercial and 50 actresses for a television production, the Westport couple discovered the difficulty of finding the talent in Connecticut. Now they are doing something about it.

title: BABENCO AND KENNEDY PREPARE TO FILM 'IRONWEED'
description: ALBANY, Oct. 23 - The night streets of Albany are dark and silent, and a cold wind has sprung up; it would slice through the tattered rags of a skid-row bum like Francis Phelan with chilling ease. The moon is rising, but it takes little imagination to conjure up the ghosts of Phelan and his luckless cronies in the shadows under the trees.

title: STRATEGY FOR THE SURPRISE VISIT
description: AMONG THE BEST-REGULATED households, unexpected visitors are offered a repast appropriate to the hour they arrive, whatever that hour may be. My mother had one of those households. There was always something to serve the drop-ins who ''just happened to be in the neighborhood.'' (Though heaven knows what they were doing in our neighborhood, other than visiting us. We didn't live near enough to anything of importance for people to be in the neighborhood. I suspect they just wanted to see what my mother, who was known for her cooking, could throw together on a moment's notice.) My household is hardly as well regulated as my mother's, but I've learned over the years that even though I won't have enough leftover anything to feed dinner to drop-ins, I can usually pull together something in the way of a between-meal snack. Now that everyone these days seems to have given up three squares in favor of ''grazing,'' so much the better.

title: 100,000 IN LONDON PROTEST ARMS RACE
description: More than 100,000 antinuclear protesters took part in a five-mile march through London to Hyde Park today in a demonstration that was designed to press the superpowers to end the arms race.

title: JOHN HAWKES'S ART
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Thanhauser 3d And Aimee Garn Wed
description: Laura Aimee Garn, a freelance writer, and Joseph Thanhauser 3d, a partner in the real estate development and consulting firm Pattison Partners in New York, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Judge Solomon H. Katz of the Bronx Supreme Court at the home of the bridegroom's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Thanhauser, in New York.

title: Ellyn G. Trautmann Engaged to Wed John Rueger Pflug Jr., a Candy Broker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Adam Trautmann Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellyn Garland Trautmann, to John Rueger Pflug Jr., the son of Jane Patterson Pflug of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Mr. Pflug of Manhasset. The wedding is planned for April.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES TO KEEP TAX PLAN THAT AIDS HOUSING
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, in a weekend of meetings that could be decisive to the prospects of revising the Federal tax system, voted today to retain most of the tax advantages now used to subsidize construction of low-income housing.

title: NIGHT OF OUR GHASTLY LONGINGS
description: ''Halloween is the carnival-time of disembodied spirits,'' said Nathaniel Hawthorne, whose fiction is evidence he knew what he was talking about. A proper carnival, after all, is a rite of disinhibition, a riot of release, a good time for letting go, for letting out what you normally keep in. That is what makes Halloween fun. What makes Halloween scary is the nature of the spirits we let out. They are re-embodiments of secret fears and desires, of monstrous hungers and frightful lusts. Ghosts, ghouls, witches, incubi, succubi, werewolves, possessing demons and demonic children are figures of fascination, repulsion and threat. Halloween threatens with what it promises, like a good-looking vampire puckering up for a kiss.

title: ANGELA LANSBURY'S UNLIKELY SLEUTH HAS STAYING POWER
description: At 8 P.M. on Sunday, Sept. 29, something amazing happened. To the surprise of almost everyone, ''Murder, She Wrote'' swept past the most talked about, most publicized, most eagerly awaited new television series of the year, Steven Spielberg's ''Amazing Stories.''

title: Gorbachev Also Consults Allies
description: It was warmup time both for President Reagan and for Mikhail S. Gorbachev last week as Mr. Reagan and the Soviet leader prepared for their first meeting in Geneva Nov. 19 and 20. Just before the President consulted with the heads of other industrial democracies in New York, the Soviet leader met in Sofia, Bulgaria, with his considerably more compliant allies in the seven-nation Warsaw Pact.

title: NEW LEADERS SEEK TO QUIET PUNJAB
description: Sporadic shooting incidents, apparently carried out by Sikh radicals, have returned to the Punjab and are creating problems for the newly elected state government of Sikh moderates.

title: 6 DISTRICTS LACK TEACHER CONTRACTS
