description: TEACHERS in six Long Island school districts were still working without contracts last week as efforts to negotiate issues of salary, benefits and duties failed.

title: MALL IN NEW HAVEN BRACES FOR BOYCOTT
description: A THREATENED boycott by a citizens group has at least some of the merchants in the refurbished Chapel Square Mall in New Haven worried about their sales for the Christmas season.

title: A MIDDLING 'INVALID'
description: MOLIERE may be the acknowledged master of 17th-century French comedy, but how is a 20th-century audience supposed to believe that?

title: IN LONDON, A MUSICAL 'MISERABLES'
description: Was the Royal Shakespeare Company about to astonish the world with another ''Nicholas Nickleby'' or, more exotically still, an amalgam of ''Nickleby'' and ''Cats''? That was the question the trend-spotters were asking of the pop opera ''Les Miserables'' before its English-language premiere at the Barbican a few days ago. London's new theatrical season is, as it happens, proving unusually lavish with offerings designed to soothe savage breasts, soften rocks, bend knotted oaks, and do those other things proverbially expected of music and musicals. A rather solemn salute to the memory of Elvis Presley, ''Are you Lonesome Tonight?,'' has won itself both admirers and audiences. A theatrical version of the movie ''Gigi,'' austerely staged by John Dexter, has had to content itself with good audiences, the critical admiration being somewhat uneven.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

THE GARDEN GAINS A VICTORY
description: IT is time again to assess the financial damage of our Victory Garden.

title: VERSAILLES
description: To The Editor: The articles concerning the enjoyment of Versailles (Travel, Sept. 15) were excellent -would that we had read them before our recent trip there.

title: UNIONISM STRUGGLES THROUGH MIDDLE AGE
description: ''Our obituary has been written at least once'' for every year of labor's history, says Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O, ''and at least that many causes of death have been diagnosed, gleefully or scornfully, depending on the diagnostician.''

title: Comet at an Exhibition
description: Across the upper border of a section of the 1083 Bayeux Tapestry is stitched ''Istimirant Stella'' (''They are in awe of the star''), and below the Latin caption, over a scene from the Battle of Hastings, flies a cartoon comet trailing flame. Thanks to calculations made nearly seven centuries later by Edmund Halley, the British astronomer, we now know that the fiery star over William the Conqueror and King Harold II was a comet that made periodic trips past the Earth.

title: A NATIVE AT THE TOP
description: MARVIN ASHNER, who at the age of 7 during World War II did housekeeping chores for his hotelier father and then went on to make millions in Monopoly-style hotel buying and selling, seems to be emerging as the only ''local'' person to become a partner in a hotel-casino here.

title: Keeping Pace
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrea H. Belkin To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene N. Belkin of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea H. Belkin, to David R. Epstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond H. Epstein of Cupertino, Calif. The wedding is planned for Dec. 28.

title: Profits in 'Flipping' A Condo
description: THE strong demand for condominiums in recent years has enticed a growing number of people to seek quick profits by ''flipping'' contracts to buy units in new buildings.

title: INVENTING WOMEN
description: THE MAGNIFICENT SPINSTER By May Sarton. 384 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: WHEN A DAUGHTER BECOMES AN ADULT
description: SOMETHING definitive happened that weekend last June when my oldest daughter, Ruth, graduated from college. I knew it when I watched her deep in collegial conversation with a professor at a graduating seniors' tea, and she pensively put her fingers in her mouth. It was a familiar, child-like gesture that I had seen her make a thousand times, and that day, as always, I wanted to reach over and pull her hand away.

title: BRANCH ACTIVATED
description: Cliff Branch, the 37-year-old Raider receiver who missed the first seven games of the National Football League season with a pulled hamstring, was taken off the injured reserve list and will be in uniform when Los Angeles meets the San Diego Chargers tomorrow night. To make room for Branch, a 14-year veteran with 501 career receptions, the Raiders waived Mike Moroski, the quarterback who had been signed just two days before.

title: FRENCH COMMUNISTS ARE HARDLY THEIR OLD SELVES
description: It usually does not take much to paralyze Paris using the traditional method, a general strike. The subways and buses can be stopped, the electricity turned off, the telephones silenced. That, however, is what did not occur in the French capital last week despite a widely publicized call by the Communist controlled General Confederation of Labor, France's largest union organization, for a day of action to protest Government austerity measures. True, there was a march attracting some 20,000 people and disrupting traffic. Some subway trains failed to run. But in general, life in Paris was very close to normal, indicating that the Communists, despite their greater stridency of late, have yet to find a formula to halt what many here are calling a historic decline.

title: MORE CHOICES FOR LOCAL COMMUTERS
description: HARRY P. HARRIS, who commutes by train from Fairfield to Stamford, likes to get to work before 9 A.M.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

2 GENERATIONS GONE FISHIN'
description: EVERY year I hear that the fishing in Long Island waters is over. We heard it 20 years ago when our children were young and we were catching pails full of fish.

title: PAYING COMPANIES TO OBEY THE LAW
description: THE technical and economic magnitude of the problem of disposal of toxic wastes has not yet been reliably estimated. It may, however, prove more serious than all other environmental problems combined. Yet we have made virtually no progress toward its resolution.

title: JAMES LEVINE AND THE MET
description: James Levine is determined to preserve all the traditions of grand opera, shunning such innovations as English supertitles on the ground that he wants ''the audience riveted on the performers at every moment.'' Thus, he limits the Met's patronage to true devotees and cognoscenti, while, at the same time, requiring sold-out houses for financial survival.

title: GEORGIAS'S RUSHERS BEAT KENTUCKY, 26-6
description: Georgia got three touchdowns against the nation's fourth-best defense against the run, and Greg Waters made key defensive plays to help provide a 26-6 victory over Kentucky in a Southeastern Conference game today. Kentucky, which had been limiting allowing only 74 yards a game on the ground, yielded 375 yards.

title: Jane Kathleen Weddington to Wed Paluel V. Flagg Jr.
description: Mrs. Robert Oliver Briggs of Newport Beach, Calif., and William Guy Weddington of Capistrano Beach, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Kathleen Weddington, to Paluel Venard Flagg Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Flagg of Darien, Conn. The wedding is to be March 1.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A CONDUCTOR FINDS KEY TO SUCCESS
description: I USED to live at 103d Street and West End Avenue in New York City (Klezmar Heights in music circles) and was a regular on the Broadway Local. So were a lot of other musicians. It was not unusual to see a swarm of well-worn tuxedos and black gowns carrying odd luggage buzzing out of the lead car at 62d Street, making a beeline for the subterranean depths of the Metropolitan Opera House, the State Theater and Avery Fisher Hall to respond to some esteemed maestro's downbeat. The same scene occurred in the morning but then the artists' mufti blended in with the other passengers'. Only the telltale cases gave them away. On the Local there was always someone with whom to discuss the performances of last evening: who was sounding particularly good in what orchestra, which conductor should be run out of town on a rail. It was a camaraderie possible only in a city where a few acres was home to several major orchestras and where a subway car became the musician's cafe-konditorei.

title: HOSPICE BENEFIT IS TARGET OF QUESTIONS
description: MANY employees in the state are now finding an additional medical benefit included in their insurance coverage. The benefit is hospice care, and although it has been received as a bonus by businesses and employees, it has also raised some questions.

title: Recent Sales
description: Edison $200,000 *2* 1320 Inman Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 37-year-old ranch; *2* central air-conditioning, recreation room, *2* 2.7 acres; taxes $3,553. Hackettstown $80,500 *2* 155 Riva Drive *2* 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1-year-old town-house *2* condominium; fenced yard, basement, $50 *2* monthly charges; taxes $1,227. Long Valley $178,500 *2* 105 Wherli Road *2* 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 6-year-old ranch; *2* family room with fireplace, foyer, *2* 2-car garage; taxes $3,152. Maplewood $120,000 *2* 7 Fleming Terrace *2* 3 bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 55-year-old colonial; *2* wine cellar, full attic, slate roof; *2* taxes $3,245. Westfield $248,000 *2* 632 East Broad Street *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 75-year-old colonial; *2* flagstone patio, leaded glass, screened porch; *2* taxes $3,327. West Orange $135,000 *2* 37 Hooper Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old split-level; *2* alarm system, new kitchen; taxes $3,006. OTHER AREAS Levittown, L.I. $108,000 *2* 105 Squirrel Lane *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; *2* eat-in kitchen, Florida room; taxes $2,200. Tuckahoe, N.Y. $231,000 *2* 71 Oakland Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 55-year-old red-brick *2* colonial; eat-in kitchen, dining room, family room, *2* 1-car garage; taxes $3,882. East Haven, Conn. $72,000 *2* 595 Laurel Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; *2* hardwood floor, prime condition; taxes $1,000.

title: FOR LAURA DEAN, A NEW DIRECTION
description: There was once a child named Laura Dean, who grew up to become a leading American choreographer of modern dance. Early on, she had her own way of looking at figures in space. ''I was in the first grade,'' Miss Dean said recently, recalling a telling incident in her childhood. ''The teacher had gone to the board and written down that one plus one equals two. I raised my little hand and said this could mean something else. She got kind of huffy. 'What do you mean?' she said. I went to the board and I wrote down that one plus one equaled two ones, because I saw it visually. The teacher got extremely angry and said that one plus one did not equal 11. I didn't even know what 11 was.''

title: MIDNIGHT SUPPER
description: LET IT BE SAID RIGHT FROM the start: the midnight supper is not your everyday sort of feast.

title: Peso Cheating
description: THE Mexican peso first gained notoriety as a favorite of cheaters when the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority reported in 1982 that the coin was turning up in its electronic toll baskets in New York City. Instead of dropping in an authority token, then worth $1.25, some motorists were depositing the peso, worth a fraction of a cent.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE MARE ON THE HILL Written and illustrated by Thomas Locker. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books. $15. (All Ages) THOMAS LOCKER'S first book for children, ''Where the River Begins,'' was the story of a grandfather and his two grandsons who follow the river that flows past their house, hike up the foothills of a mountain and come at last to a small, still pond where the river originates. The story was a simple one, told in a straightforward, unelaborate fashion, but one that would strike a chord for any reader, child or adult, who ever tossed a leaf in a gutter and then waited for it to come out the other end of a drainpipe. It conveyed, wonderfully, the suspense a person can feel at the bend of a river (or the turn of a page), waiting to see what's on the other side.

title: MOTHER TERESA IS HONORED AT U.N. CEREMONY
description: After a week of princes, presidents and prime ministers, the warmest ovation of the United Nations' 40th anniversary observances came tonight for a small woman in sandals and a sari.

title: JUILLIARD'S FUTURE TAKES SHAPE
description: Changes are in the making at the Juilliard School where Joseph W. Polisi has completed his first year as president.

title: COMPOSER WITH A BUILT-IN AUDIENCE
description: An eminent American composer lives in Minneapolis, writes frequently performed, accessible music, and is essentially unknown to New York audiences. This last situation may be changing. Dominick Argento's opera, ''Postcard from Morocco,'' was mounted by the Juilliard School last February, and Frederica von Stade, Neville Marriner and the Minnesota Orchestra had brought his song cycle, ''Casa Guidi,'' based on the letters of Elizabeth Barrett Browning, to Carnegie Hall just two weeks earlier. On Friday, the latest Argento opera, ''Casanova,'' will have its New York premiere at the New York City Opera.

title: Sharing the Problems Of Westbury
description: As the article ''Westbury Group Fights New Zoning'' [Sept. 15] indicated, some local business people condemned the proposed zoning laws within the Village of Westbury while some residents and representatives of civic associations expressed their strong approval.

title: New Manager Named For the Arena Stage
description: William Stewart, managing director of the Hartford Stage Company, has been named to a corresponding position at the Arena Stage, succeeding Thomas C. Fichandler, who will retire Jan. 1.

title: LAFAYETTE DEFEATS MADISON TO CAPTURE DIVISION TITLE
description: Lafayette won its first Public School Athletic League Brooklyn division title in 14 years, defeating Madison, 20-14, yesterday at home.

title: CARDINAL ROY OF CANADA DIES
description: Maurice Cardinal Roy, the former Archbishop of Quebec and Roman Catholic Primate of Canada from 1956 to 1981, died Thursday at a Montreal hospital after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: ENOUGH OF THE ACID RAIN
description: President Reagan has been winning acclaim since his decisive order to send United States fighter planes to intercept the hijackers of the Achille Lauro cruise ship. Why can't he use the same determination to quickly settle some languishing domestic problems, such as acid rain, which because of years of inaction by the United States is doing incalculable damage to relations with our neighbor Canada?

title: SALVADOR REPORTS PLEDGE BY REBELS
description: Senior Government and church officials said today that leftist rebelshad pledged they would no longer kidnap relatives of political or military leaders.

title: 2 BOOKS TO EASE CHILDREN'S FEARS
description: ''Discuss emergencies that have happened to people you know; your friends and relatives. Talk about how they handled the situation and what they might have done.''

title: BRIGHT JOB PICTURE FOR FAIRFIELD WOMEN
description: PROJECTIONS of job opportunities in Fairfield County through the next decade indicate that female workers will be very much in demand.

title:
DINING OUT;

A NEW HOME FOR FRITZ'S
description: LAST July, Ron (Fritz) and Pamela Lunge gave up their plain but popular Somers luncheonette (Mr. Lunge's culinary arena for the last 10 years) for roomier and somewhat classier digs in Granite Springs. There's no doubt about it: Fritz's has become a bona fide restaurant.

title:
GARDENING;

SOLVE SOIL DRAINAGE PROBLEMS IN THE FALL
description: THE adage, out of sight, out of mind, accurately sums up the average person's understanding of the importance of optimum soil conditions to successful gardening. And most soil problems are buried where they cannot be easily seen.

title: CASSETTE DECKS STRIVE FOR INCREASED PRECISION
description: The curious spell that recording devices cast upon their owners may have something to do with their seemingly predatory character. While all other components in a stereo system are essentially passive - merely reproducing the music - a recorder implies action and will: it captures the sound and holds it.

title: LONG TIES RECORD
description: The powerful passing game of Iowa, the nation's No. 1 team, overwhelmed Northwestern today, 49-10, in a Big Ten matchup.

title: DEFAULTS THREATEN STUDENT LOANS
description: FEDERAL student-loan programs have revolutionized our national system of higher education. Young, talented people who equate a quality education with success, but whose parents lack the financial means to send them to college, are now able to further their schooling with the help of federally quaranteed loans.

title: ROMANCE OF THE ROUND TABLE
description: EQUALITY, LEGEND HAS IT, was the reason King Arthur sat his knights at a round table. Since no one would be perceived as having a more desirable seat, none of the knights could feel slighted.

title: A GUITARIST, A PIANIST AND A SOPRANO
description: Vladimir Mikulka Vladimir Mikulka brought an admirably bold program to Carnegie Recital Hall for his New York debut Thursday night. Mr. Mikulka, a Czechoslovak-born guitarist now based in Paris and New York, has maintained close relations with several Eastern European composers not often heard here, in particular Stepan Rak of Prague and Nikita Koshkin of Moscow, both of whom he has recorded.

title: 'OLD PIRATE' TAKES A POLITICAL PLUNGE
description: In 1948, Tony Tarracino elected to go to Florida for his health. The risk to his health was the strong arm of some hoods in Elizabeth, N.J., who had decided that Mr. Tarracino's bets with them on horses were costing them too much money.

title: COMMON-SENSE PHILOSOPHY?
description: To the Editor:

title: HARD CURRENCY Gold Scare
description: Treasury Secretary James Baker says that if the national debt limit isn't raised by Nov. 15, the Government will have exhausted all bookkeeping gimmicks. The choice then would be to default or sell gold.

title: WORKING FOR LAUGHS IN THE HUMAN COMEDY
description: WHEN strangers asked Bob Melvin of Lawrence his profession, he used to say, ''I kid around.''

title: SAFETY FEARS PUT CLASS TRIPS ON HOLD
description: THE Hamden Board of Education, which earlier this month vetoed student trips to Germany and Canada in the spring, will be asked this week to also reconsider their approval of a student trip to Spain. Both actions are the result of concern over recent terrorist hijackings.

title: SOLO VOYAGERS
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column of Sept. 15: Discriminating visitors to London who happen to be voyaging alone can find charming and spacious accommodations at several first-rate smaller hotels where the decor, service and even the food are superior to larger and better known hostelries.

title: THE REWARDS IN LOSING
description: WINNING really isn't everything. Take it from me, a man who has lost to the worst, losing can be much more rewarding and can, in fact, improve the quality of your life. But, in the face of all the adverse propaganda, it takes some deep soul searching to reach this conclusion.

title: HWO HISTORY SURPRISED US
description: THE AMERICAN OCCUPATION OF JAPAN The Origins of the Cold War in Asia. By Michael Schaller. 351 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.50.

title: WHERE ASPIRING DRAMATISTS GET A START
description: For Myer (Mike) Gutwillig, a 60-year-old Montrealer, both the New York theater scene and his status as a playwright are turning out to be dazzling new experiences. In fact, his is something of a Cinderella story.

title: Fashion Preview;   SPRING'S SHAPE IN NEW YORK
description: OSCAR DE LA RENTA IS IN HIS OFfice, telephone crunched to one ear. He is simultaneously speaking staccato-style Spanish, pruning a bouquet of flowers on his desk and appraising a mannequin who faces him in a fairly fitted coatdress. After the dress has been adorned with the right buttons and the phone cardled, the designer explains, in English, that clothes for next season have to be ''wise.'' Which means they have to make sense. Spring, he says is not a season for risky experimentations. De le Renta's new designs, as a case in point, basically follow the same curvy shapes that he currently has in the stores for fall. Perhaps the shoulders are a little narrower, and a bit more rounded, but they are still padded. And hemlines continue to hover at the knee.

title: Hard Going On the Budget
description: As House and Senate negotiators continued to struggle last week over the theory of a plan its sponsors say would force the Federal budget into balance by 1991, their colleagues tried in other committees and on the floor to put into practice a more modest regime required by Congress's budget resolution for 1986. Through spending cuts and tax increases, a total of $276 billion would be saved by 1988 from previously projected spending - only a bit more than the deficit for 1985, which, the Government reported last week, came to $211.9 billion, the highest yet.

title: CITY SEEKS COOPERATION OF BATHHOUSES IN ENFORCING RULES ON AIDS
description: Voluntary cooperation by bathhouses catering to homosexuals will be vital to the enforcement of a new state rule that seeks to control the spread of AIDS by barring such establishments from allowing ''high-risk sexual activities,'' a city health official said yesterday.

title: TABLE DISPLAYS AID PROGRAMS AT Y
description: FAIRFIELD'S Burr Mansion will be the location this year for Festive Tables, a three-day event that will raise money for the rape-crisis and abused-women programs at the Y.W.C.A. of Greater Bridgeport.

title: Duarte Gets His Daughter Back
description: Ines Guadalupe Duarte, the daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, was released last week after 44 days as a captive of Salvadoran rebels. The release, part of ''a vast delicate operation'' that involved the exchange of 143 people, brought joy to the Duarte family, but the President's supporters were left wondering about the price he had paid.

title: Cynthia Ingraham Pigott to Marry Louis M. Bacon
description: James Stanley Glanville Pigott of New York and London has announced the engagement of his daughter, Cynthia Ingraham Pigott, to Louis Moore Bacon, a son of Zach Hampton Bacon Jr. of Raleigh and Figure Eight Island, N.C., and the late Ann Moore Bacon of Wilmington, N.C. Miss Pigott also is the daughter of the late Corinne Ingraham Pigott. A Feb. 15 wedding is planned.

title: A NEW LAY OF THE LAND IN WESTCHESTER
description: Twenty years ago, Westchester County represented the epitome of the suburban dream: spacious housing surrounded by acres of woods, respected public schools, no more than an easy commute from midtown Manhattan. In much of the county, of course, this picture still holds. But during the 1970's Westchester's tranquil atmosphere attracted major corporations eager to move out of New York City, and office parks rolled across the landscape. Behind them have come hotels and restaurants, traffic congestion and housing shortages.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Sept. 1 about buying wool sweaters in Mykonos incorrectly gave the name of a shop in the Venezia section. The shop is called Tony Pappas.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Miss Tydings Has Wedding
description: Mary Campbell Tydings and John Thomas Smith 2d were married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church on Lafayette Square in Washington by the bride's stepgrandfather, the Rev. Lowell R. Ditzen.

title: RACES IN SUFFOLK FOCUS ON SHOREHAM
description: BOTH Democratic and Republican candidates for seats in the Suffolk County Legislature are running hard against the Long Island Lighting Company and its Shoreham nuclear plant in the Nov. 5 election.

title: GLOOM ON THE RENTAL HOUSING FRONT
description: ''MY sole job is to liquidate the family's property,'' says David Paulsen. ''It's a sad commentary on an industry.''

title: Meg Millard Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E.F. Millard of Southport and Fenwick, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Millard, to William H. Stahley. Mr. Stahley is the son of Lawrence H. Stahley of Andover, Mass., and the late Mrs. Stahley. A September wedding is planned.

title: TO WRITE, TO FIGHT, TO DIE
description: THE OLD GRINGO By Carlos Fuentes. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden and the author. 199 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Oct. 27, 1985 Fiction

title: BLACKS ARE SEEKING A PATH TO THE STATEHOUSE
description: State Senator L. Douglas Wilder, the Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor in Virginia, supports the death penalty, laws barring union shops and a Constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget. In Michigan, William Lucas, a leading contender for the 1986 Republican nomination for governor, praises President Reagan's economic policies and has prescribed large tax cuts and tighter management of social programs for his state.

title: NO. 2 WITH A SILVER BULLET
description: THE VAMPIRE LESTAT By Anne Rice. 481 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Susan P. Rogers Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Pell Rogers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howland Pendleton Rogers of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Tuxedo Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Stephen Charles Williamson, a son of Mrs. David Archibald Forbes Williamson of San Francisco and St. Helena, Calif., and the late Mr. Williamson. The Rev. Edward H. Cromey performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Church.

title: HUNGER STILL HAUNTS APPALACHIA, PANEL TOLD
description: Hunger is still a serious problem in the most impoverished counties of central Appalachia, a group of Appalachian residents have told a House committee.

title: October 27, 1985
NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1985
description: International

title: STANDINGS IN BRIDGE TIGHTEN
description: The world contract bridge team championships continued here this afternoon in a ferment of uncertainty and excitement. With two rounds of qualifying play remaining, three teams were vying for the two top positions in the open series, and four women's teams were in contention in their series.

title: ARCHITECTURE BOASTS ITS OWN MUSEUM
description: When the movement to create a national architecture museum in the old Pension Building in Washington - which has what may be the capital city's most exhilarating interior space -picked up steam around 1980, the organizers and fund-raisers referred to the future museum as ''The Building Building.'' Clever, but for that very reason a bit off-putting. Was the first museum in the United States devoted solely to architecture going to be just so much fun and games, or would it be able to contribute something genuine to the body of scholarship on architecture? More to the point, perhaps, does a museum of architecture make sense at all, or is it merely a poor substitute, a vicarious experience taking the place of visits to real architecture?

title: ALONG THE CONNECTICUT RIVER
description: The Connecticut River is not the widest, swiftest or the deepest river in the world, and at 410 miles it is barely a ninth the length of the Mississippi-Missouri river system. Yet the Connecticut occupies a firm place in our consciousness with an imagery all its own -of white, clapboard villages, gentle green mountains, Yankee ingenuity and steady Puritan values. Wallace Stevens, a native of Hartford, once described the river as ''coming home to the American self.'' Discovered by a Dutch sea captain in 1614, the Connecticut has long been the life artery of New England, providing a major highway from the sea to the lush hardwood and pine forests of the Northeast.

title: THE MANY FACES OF THE WALL STREET ANALYST
description: IT was almost 8:30 and Frank J. Barkocy, joking and a little nervous, sidled down the hall to a small Merrill Lynch conference room to participate in the daily ritual known as the ''morning call.''

title: BERGEN TO VOTE ON EXECUTIVE
description: IN ADDITION to voting for a Governor and Assemblymen on Election Day, Bergen County residents will decide, in a binding referendum, whether they want to change to a new type of county government and administration.

title: A Job Instead Of a Grant
description: New York State officials, hoping to reduce the state's $2.5 billion annual welfare bill, announced last week a plan to steer recipients of welfare grants toward jobs in private industry. The project is to start next month with about 2,000 new welfare applicants in New York City, then be extended gradually to all of the state's employable grant recipients under the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program, about 220,000 people.

title: NORTHPORT DYNASTY FLOURISHES
description: Most of the players on the Northport High School girls' soccer team have never lost a game. Ranked first in the state in a recent poll of sportswriters, the varsity team (14-0 this season) has not lost in two years, since North Babylon took the Long Island championship in 1983.

title:
GARDENING;

SOLVE SOIL DRAINAGE PROBLEMS IN THE FALL
description: THE adage, out of sight, out of mind, accurately sums up the average person's understanding of the importance of optimum soil conditions to successful gardening. And most soil problems are buried where they cannot be easily seen.

title: BERKSHIRES SET LIMITS ON HUNTERS
description: A rack of Winchester rifles and a brace of deer antlers adorn the walls of Mary Hale's living room here.

title: PHILHARMONIC: CHAILLY
description: RICCARDO CHAILLY is one visiting conductor to the New York Philharmonic who seems embarrassed neither by the orchestra's capacity for deafening virtuosity nor by Avery Fisher Hall's ability to amplify it. Anyone who has stood in the Lincoln Center subway station and listened to express trains shriek past will have an idea of what went on much of the time when these principals met on Thursday evening.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the listing of worldwide cruises on Oct. 20, the heading for Regency Cruises appeared in a typeface different from other cruise lines, giving the incorrect impression that Caribbean sailings of the Regent Sea were offered by Princess Cruises.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: PREGNANT teen-agers are turning increasingly to the gray and black markets in adoptions because they have no money for food, rent or medical care, says Dr. Grace W. Sisto, executive director of the Children's Aid and Adoption Society of New Jersey. (In New Jersey, adoption is illegal if arranged by a third party, such as a lawyer or physician; only agency-sponsored or one-to-one agreements between the mother and adoptive parents are legal).

title: SCARY OLD ENGLAND - STILL
description: You might meet the Devil in Sussex. You would take A24 south out of london and follow it for a little more than 50 miles as far as the village of Washington, where you would turn off onto the South Downs Way. After a short distance you would be obliged byt he roughness of the terrain to alight from your motorcar and continue on foot up a steep and deeply rutted track that would lead you to the crest of the Downs. From there you would follow a comparatively level path to the grass-covered mound, surmounted by a coppice of beech trees, that is the highest point on the South Downs and is known as Chanctonbury Ring.

title: IN LOS ANGELES SCHOOLS, IT'S ALMOST STANDING ROOM ONLY
description: Like most such systems, the Los Angeles Unified School District found the 1970's a painful time of retrenchment. Schools were closed, teaching staffs were cut and enrollment plummeted because Americans had decided to have fewer children.

title: DEVILS WIN, 5-2, TO END SLIDE
description: The Devils wanted a stiffer defense and an end to a four-game losing streak. Tonight, they turned to four veteran defensemen who had not played in the previous game and got both in a 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: NEW HOMES ADDED TO SOLAR PLAN BOOK
description: FROM the outside, the house being built off Duncaster Lane in Bloomfield looks like an ordinary old Victorian, one of those huge drafty homes so prevalent in the older sections of Connecticut cities.

title: A DECK STACKED AGAINST SMALL INVESTORS
description: LAST week, the management at R. H. Macy & Company, the New York retailer, proposed to take the company private by purchasing each public share for $70 in cash. Though the deal had been quietly in the works for months, the executives disclosed their bid earlier than planned, after rumors of a buyout had suddenly lifted the stock $4 on heavy volume.

title: LIBRARY INITIATES SPANISH PROGRAM
description: SPANISH will be spoken at the Warner Library in Tarrytown at 2 P.M. Nov. 10 when a folk singer and storyteller from Puerto Rico will perform an all-Spanish program. ''It is a pilot program to provide cultural enrichment to members of a specific population group as part of the Outreach project,'' said Eva Taben of Greenburgh, the Outreach services coordinator for the Westchester Library system. ''We hope to get Spanish-speaking parents and their children into the libraries to acquaint them with our facilities. If this program is successful, there will be more Spanish programs in libraries throughout Westchester County.''

title: Social Events;   For Culture and Causes
description: New Museum in Town Oct. 29 - New York's newest museum is the stunning Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum in Long Island City. It contains some 500 works by the Japanese-American sculptor, who has been termed one of the most versatile and inventive artists of our time. The Municipal Art Society will offer thanks to the artist and will benefit from a black-tie dinner for which the co-chairmen are Jacqueline Onassis and Brendan Gill. The benefit will start at the museum with cocktails at 7 P.M. Charter buses will leave the Asia Society, Park Avenue at 70th Street, at 6:30 P.M., 6:45 P.M. and 7 P.M. for the museum. Tickets, $1,000, from 212-874-4098. Two-Continent Ties Oct. 29 - Founded in 1953 by a group of Americans, black and white, the African-American Institute seeks to strengthen cultural ties between Africa and the United States. The group's second annual awards dinner will be at the Grand Hyatt starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Tickets for black-tie or national dress benefit for the institute, $300, from 212-949-5711. Briefly: Oct. 30 - The Madison Square Boys and Girls Club's black-tie dinner-dance starts with cocktails at 7 P.M. at the Pierre. Tickets, $250, from 212-532-5751. Oct. 30 - American Ballet Theater Halloween party at Visage, 610 West 56th Street, starts at 8:30 P.M. Tickets, $50, from 212-477-3030, ext. 246 or 247. Oct. 30 - Cocktails at 7 P.M. open the Lenox Hill Hospital's fall dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: JERSEY TRIAL TO CONSIDER BRIEF LIFE OF A FOSTER CHILD
description: The short, tragic life of Rosa Swain began in a shabby, roach-infested apartment in Trenton, where her mother broke her legs and cracked her ribs. Rosa was then 2 months old.

title: A JERSEY PLANT RELEASES FOUL SMELLING FUMES
description: A cloud of foul-smelling fumes released by an Exxon oil refinery in Linden, N.J., passed over parts of New York City and New Jersey last night, prompting hundreds of people to call authorities complaining of the smell of spilled oil or rotten eggs.

title: Road to Cape Cod Takes Final Bow
description: IN Bourne, Mass., a 50-year-old concrete landmark tumbled to the ground in a cloud of dust last week as nearly 100 people stood by, cheering and clapping.

title: Dec. 21 Wedding For Chase Rogers
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Rogers of Greenwich, Conn., and Pinehurst, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Chase Theodora Rogers to Lieut. Edward Vincent O'Hanlan J.A.G.C., U.S.N.R. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Treacy O'Hanlan of Waynesboro, Va.

title: Dr. Cathy Buch Weds
description: Dr. Cathy Buch, chief resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia, and Richard S. Ross Jr., president of the Philadelphia School of Office Technologies, were married yesterday. Rabbi Jeffrey Wohlberg performed the ceremony at Beth El Temple in Harrisburg, Pa. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Buch of Harrisburg and Diana Ross Trachtman of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Ross.

title: CELEBRATING CONVERSATION
description: OH, TO BE IN NEW YORK, dressed to the nines, sharing pre-dinner quail eggs with the glamorous, sophisticated, powerful, bright, articulate, attractive, witty, successful and rich.

title:
ART;

AT YALE, WORKS OF A LEADER OF BRITISH POP ART
description: RICHARD HAMILTON is forever in art history books as the father of British pop art, which many contend preceded the American version. In America, not much is known of Mr. Hamilton's doings since. The current exhibition at the Yale Art Gallery, an exhilerating retrospective of his prints from 1952 to 1982 called ''Image and Process,'' brings us up to date.

title: PINIELLA ASKED TO MANAGE YANKEES
description: The Yankees, intent on relieving Billy Martin of his managerial duties once again, have offered Lou Piniella the manager's job, a source close to the team said today. Barring any unforeseen developments, Piniella was expected to accept the job and become the fourth person to replace Martin as the Yankees' manager in slightly more than seven years.

title: DAY CARE VS. BEING THERE
description: A MOTHER'S WORK By Deborah Fallows. 243 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95. I WON'T keep you in suspense: According to ''A Mother's Work,'' a mother's work is to stay home and raise her children. And if we are to believe Deborah Fallows's study of the world that working mothers have bought their children with their labors, the 50 percent of American mothers who think they can both work and raise happy kids are fooling themselves and harming their children.

title: A SPOOKY PLACE TO THRILL THE YOUNG
description: DURING most of the year, a little brown cottage in a yard in Bristol remains locked up. But as Halloween draws near, a pair of skulls pop up on the sign posts and a pointy-hatted witch directs the way with her green fingernail into a world inhabited by the likes of the Mummy, Frankenstein's monster and Count Dracula.

title: D.B. Kidd Weds Penley Toffolon
description: Penley Brewster Toffolon, the daughter of Mrs. John E. Toffolon of Riverton, Conn., and West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late John E. Toffolon, was married yesterday to Douglas Bradford Kidd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Alexander Kidd Jr., of Lavonia, Ga. The Rev. Thomas Joyce performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: NEW CASSETTES: EVERGREEN MUSICAL, CLASSIC ANIMATION
description: Bugs Bunny's Wacky Adventures Warner Home Video 59 minutes. $19.98 Er, um, what's up, Doc? A new collection of eight classic Bugs Bunny cartoons, that's what.

title: NORTHWEST'S STRUGGLE TO DEFEND ITS PRIZED PACIFIC ROUTES
description: NEXT year, Northwest Airlines Inc. will move its headquarters from the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport to a new building on 154 rural Minnesota acres. From its windows, the staff will look out on three lovely duck ponds dotting the vast property, and an almost limitless view of the surrounding countryside.

title: VONNEGUT AND DARWIN
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR MANY TROUT ANGLERS, AUTUMN IS A SECOND SEASON
description: BY late October, most trout fishermen are sure the season is near oblivion. Last year's license expired on Sept. 30, and most of us have long taken that to be a message of some kind.

title: Back to Basics
description: Warren E. Avis is not one to shy away from an investment opportunity, even if it means buying back the company that he sold 30 years ago and that still bears his name. Mr. Avis, a developer, has joined a group of investors who want to buy Avis Inc. from Beatrice Companies, which has put it up for sale. Mr. Avis sold the rental-car company for $8 million seven years after he founded it in 1947. He would not disclose the terms of his new offer, but estimates put it somewhere between $250 million and $400 million. Mr. Avis was an Air Force major in World War II when he thought of renting cars at airports. Today, he is also involved in projects from Manhattan (a condominium complex next to the ''21'' Club) to Michigan (an industrial park).

title: NOW, A YOUNG STEINBRENNER IS SOUNDING OFF FOR YANKEES
description: ANOTHER Steinbrenner has appeared on the Yankee scene, and it may not be long before Hank Steinbrenner wields more influence in the organization than anyone but his father.

title: MAKING THE BEST OF IT
description: SHARED DESTINY Fifty Years of Soviet-American Relations. Edited by Mark Garrison and Abbott Gleason. 167 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $16.95.

title: Tax Strategies
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS SEE NEW FLAW IN BALANCED BUDGET BILL
description: Several House Democrats say they are worried that President Reagan, citing constitutional duties to insure the security of the nation, might refuse to make the automatic reductions in military spending that could be required under a Senate-passed bill to balance the budget by 1991.

title: DISARRAY IN ISRAEL FOR PEACE GROUP
description: The cycle of violence in the Middle East in the last month has left many scars, some of them obvious, others less apparent. Among those whose outlooks seem to have been affected most are the members of the Israeli peace movement Peace Now.

title: FAUST CRITICISM
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I would not get involved in any way with this plan. I'd tell Volcker to tell the people who borrowed the money to bail themselves out.''

title: Dangers of Calling History to the Witness Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: SAFETY FOR THE SPEEDY
description: TERRY EARWOOD is at the wheel of a BMW sedan, circling the wet skid pad at exactly 32 miles an hour. Suddenly, he lifts his foot from the gas, then jams the pedal back to the floor, throwing the car into a violent slide.

title: January Wedding For Wendy Stein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Stein of Manhasset, L.I., and Copake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Alpern Stein of New York, to Bart Friedman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Friedman of Brooklyn, N.Y., and West Palm Beach, Fla. A January wedding is planned.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Trevor Kennerd of the Winnipeg Blue Bombers broke the Canadian Football League's single-season scoring record Friday night when his kicking brought his 1985 total to 198, three more than the previous record set by Dave Cutler of the Edmonton Eskimos in 1977. . . . William Tutt, vice president of the Broadmoor Hotel in Colorado Springs, has been named to succeed the late Jack Kelly Jr. as first vice president of the United States Olympic Committee. Kelly died last March. . . . The Detroit Lions have signed Vernon Maxwell, an outstanding linebacker with the Baltimore Colts as a rookie two years ago.

title: PARITY AND PREDICTABILITY MARKED CHRYSLER TALKS
description: For 42 consecutive hours this week the Chrysler bargainers trudged up and down the stairs between the first floor offices of the union and the second floor offices of the company in a white stucco building at Chrysler headquarters in Highland Park.

title: THE NAUMBURG COMPTITION AT 60
description: Music competitions are very much with us. Every year, hundreds of them are held throughout the world - competitions for every keyboard, stringed, wind, brass and percussion instrument, vocal competitions for opera or lieder, competitions for composers, competitions for the playing of Bach, of Chopin or of American compositions, concerto playing, conducting and chamber-music playing. There are competitions that offer prizes of honor, money, performances in recitals, appearances with orchestras, recordings, managerial contracts and national radio and television attention. Competitions are held in the names of great musicians, patrons of the arts, families, institutions and industries, as well as cities and countries.

title: TRAFFIC, TETE-A-TETES AND REAGAN'S TOUGH U.N. TALK
description: FOR three days last week, Ronald Reagan entered into a whirl of diplomatic and social activity with dozens of heads of state and of government who were in New York to mark the 40th anniversary of the United Nations Charter.

title: A Fall Wedding For Eta Gershen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alvin E. Gershen of Princeton, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eta Margolit Gershen, to Steven Bruce Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry L. Cohen of Tenafly, N.J. A November wedding is planned. Miss Gershen, a Deputy Attorney General in the Division of Criminal Justice of the New Jersey Department of Law and Public Safety, graduated from the Hun School of Princeton and Boston University.

title: A SETTLER'S OHIO, DAY BY DAY
description: THE TREE OF LIFE By Hugh Nissenson. Illustrated. 159 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: WHALE IN RIVER HEADS TOWARD SAN FRANCISCO
description: The 45-ton humpback whale that has wandered for two weeks in the byways of the Sacramento River returned to the main channel and headed back toward San Francisco Bay today.

title: Irregular Lots
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO BUY, AND SELL, A BANK
description: LIKE a preacher in shirt-sleeves, Stanley M. Huggins, a Memphis attorney, stood before a capacity crowd. The subject was ''When to Buy? When to Sell?'' And Mr. Huggins was not talking about apples or bananas, but banks.

title: LOOKING BACK: THE U.N. ANNIVERSARY
description: The police barricades are stacked on the side of the streets, and all the presidents and prime ministers have gone home. After more than a million words, hundreds of meetings, speeches, competing dinner parties and receptions, statesmen are sorting out what the 40th anniversary commemoration was all about.

title: JERSEY POPULATION SURPASSES 7.5 MILLION FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: New Jersey's population passed the 7.5 million mark last year as more people moved into the state than left it, officials have announced.

title: GREEK COLLEGE 'IS VERY GOOD' WHEN OPEN
description: The office of Prof. Athanasios N. Safacas bustles and hums more like that of a railroad stationmaster than of a university rector.

title: GREENPEACE AFFAIR: A QUICK FADE-OUT
description: The day after France's most recent nuclear test explosion on Mururoa Atoll in the South Pacific, television viewers in Paris saw images of a glassy lagoon that seemed to ripple just slightly at the very instant of the underground blast.

title: STEEL UNION RATIFIES WHEELING CONTRACT: 98-DAY STRIKE OVER
description: The United Steelworkers union said today that its members had overwhelmingly ratified a contract that cuts pay by 16 percent, ending a 98-day walkout against the financially crippled Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation.

title: KOREA WAR VETERANS RETURN FOR ANOTHER LOOK
description: Some things have not changed here after 32 years. Searchlights still play every night over the fingers, crags and ravines of midpeninsula mountains in the demilitarized zone.

title: CORPORCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: THE LILLO WAY COMPANY
description: LILLO WAY is an artist with taste and intelligence. That was clear from a performance by the Lillo Way Dance Company on Thursday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street. The evening offered a chance to hear several lilting and ironic piano ''portraits'' by Virgil Thomson, including a setting of a nonsense verse by Gertrude Stein. And they were performed with memorable lightness and sensitivity by Vinson Hammond, on the piano, and Dale Stine, the dashing singer. Tarrant Smith's lovely backdrop for ''Canterbury'' evoked the ''Shoures soote'' of Chaucer's ''Canterbury Tales.'' But Miss Way's three dances lacked the immediacy of those other contributions to the evening.

title: IN BROOKLYN HEIGHTS, A SPOTLIGHT ON 87 NEGLECTED ACRES
description: LET your imagination run riot and try to figure out uses for 87 acres of publicly owned land covering almost a mile of waterfront with one of the world's great maritime views.

title: Carolyn Ann Revelli Weds David M. Karp
description: Carolyn Ann Revelli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Revelli of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Mitchel Karp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Karp of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Al Sturmer at the Plaza Hotel.

title: SENATE PANEL RESTORES FUNDS FOR SOVIET STUDIES
description: The Senate agreed this week to restore $4.8 million for a State Department program that provides grants to American scholars for research on Soviet and Eastern European affairs.

title: Units On the Park
description: The first residential project to be developed on Gramercy Park in many years is taking shape in a former residence for religious on the southwestern corner of the park.

title: SUTTER LEADS ISLES PAST THE BLUES, 5-2
description: Duane Sutter scored one goal and assisted on another tonight to lead the Islanders to a 5-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: EDUCATION AIDE IS RESIGNING
description: Harry M. Singleton, the Assistant Secretary of Education for civil rights, announced this week that he was resigning as of the end of the year. Mr. Singleton, a 36-year-old lawyer, said he planned to work as a consultant in the Washington area.

title:
ART;

POLITICAL MESSAGES
description: NOT LONG ago, politics seemed simple. It meant Democrats against Republicans and communism against democracy. And now, it seems, just about everything has been touched by politics.

title: BRIDGING THE GAP IN NETWORKS
description: THE whole point of personal computing is independence. One person, one machine and the freedom to get the work done -when and in the manner required - are the PC's raison d'etre. There is no scheduling time on a mainframe, no waiting for programmers, no waiting for anyone or anything, in fact.

title: FRIENDS, FAMILY AND READERS CELEBRATE LIFE OF E.B. WHITE
description: The life and language of E. B. White, the revered American essayist and stylist who died in Maine at age 86 on Oct. 1, were celebrated here this afternoon by friends and family, readers and strangers who had been touched by his words.

title: EAVESDROPPING IS NOT TO BLAME
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WASHINGTONReagan at the U.N.
description: President Reagan has an odd habit of evading things he can do and concentrating on things he can't possibly do. His speech at the 40th anniversary of the United Nations is merely the latest evidence in point.

title: Leukemia Battle
description: IN need of a compatible bone-marrow donor to try to save his life, Steven Akin, a 24-year-old leukemia victim in Victoria, Tex., managed finally to track down a brother near Chicago and a sister in Green Bay, Wis., from whom he had been separated more than 20 years. But when they were tested as potential donors in March, their marrow proved unsuitable.

title: French Remain Tough on Testing
description: After once again neutralizing opposition by Greenpeace, France proceeded to test an atomic device in the South Pacific last week despite protests by the environmental organization and Australia, New Zealand and other countries in the area.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Is there regularly scheduled bus service along the length of the Alaska Highway? Where does it originate and what would be an approximate fare? - M. C., Queens Answer: Passengers can ride the length of the Alaska Highway, in summer, by using three buses. Greyhound covers the first leg, from Dawson Creek, in eastern British Columbia, to Whitehorse in the Yukon. The bus runs six days a week from June 20 to Sept. 1 and on three days the rest of the year. From Whitehorse, Norline Coaches operates service twice a week from June 1 to Sept. 17 through the Yukon to Beaver Creek, near the Alaska border. At Beaver Creek, that bus connects with Yukon Stage Lines (also twice a week), which follows the highway to Fairbanks.

title: LAST DEFENSE AGAINST SPECIAL INTERESTS
description: THE Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 - commonly referred to as the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings amendment - is a simple, straightforward plan to eliminate the Federal deficit over five years by forcing Congress and the President to do the job we were elected to do.

title: HEMPSTEAD ROLLS OVER FARMINGDALE
description: After five games, the Hempstead Tigers are unbeaten, untied and possibly unstoppable. Yesterday, they trounced second-place Farmingdale, 28-3.

title: Bowed but Unbloodied at the Department of Motor Vehicles
description: To the Editor:

title: CRIME
description: When Gregory Mcdonald's ''Fletch'' appeared 11 years ago, it all but started a minor industry. The book sold like iced clams at the seashore; it sparked a movie and, of course, many Fletch follow-ups. Most of them were issued in paperback. But now comes FLETCH WON in hard-cover (Warner, $14.95).

title: FROM FRANCE WITH LOVE
description: WHEN I WAS A BOY IN the village of St. Vinnemer, a farming community of about 300 inhabitants in northern Burgundy, the surest harbinger of the holiday season was when my father started talking about his upcoming trip to Paris. Every December he would close his blacksmith shop for a few days, don his heaviest wool sweater and hop in our trusty old 1928 Renault Mona 6 for the bumpy trip to an annual agricultural exhibition. It was such an exciting time because my father always returned with exotic gifts for me and my three brothers.

title: YANK TRADE FOR FISK OFF
description: Carlton Fisk informed the Yankees through his agent today that he plans to become a free agent and will not sign a contract with them at this time. Although the Yankees made no announcement, the catcher's decision effectively kills the seven-player trade they had worked out with the Chicago White Sox.

title: LENDL TOPS BECKER IN TOKYO
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl defeated Boris Becker, 6-3, 7-6, today and advanced to the championship match of the $375,000 Seiko Super Tennis Tournament at Yoyogi National Stadium.

title: JOB AGENCY'S LENDING LIMIT AT ISSUE
description: Governor Cuomo went to Syracuse the other day to present a $331,480 loan to a printing company and to warn that, if the state is to continue making such loans, voters must approve the first question on the ballot Nov. 5.

title: 'THANK YOU FOR MAKING ME READ TOLSTOY'S NOVEL' - THE LETTERS OF FLAUBERT AND TURGENEV
description: Gustave Flaubert met Ivan Turgenev in a Left Bank restaurant in Paris on Feb. 28, 1863, when Flaubert was 41 years old and Turgenev 44. The history of their friendship is part of the literary history of the age. But until now their complete 17-year correspondence has not been published. The 230-odd letters they exchanged, mostly after 1868, are filled with discussions of literature and politics, but the characters of the two come through clearly - especially that of Flaubert, as he turned himself into the hermit of Croisset, the community near Rouen where he had a country house. These excerpts from their letters are taken from the editor-translator Barbara Beaumont's ''Flaubert & Turgenev: A Friendship in Letters: The Complete Correspondence,'' which W. W. Norton will publish next month.

title: EDUCATION OF NATIVE ALASKANS GETS FAILING GRADE
description: In the last 10 years, Alaska has spent hundreds of millions of dollars to build an educational system for Alaska natives who live in remote villages.

title: Beware of the Fallout From a Farm Shakeout
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN COMPANIES ACT LIKE THE MOB
description: Congress is taking a hard look at RICO, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, at the urging of corporations that have felt its sting. This 1970 law gives prosecutors added tools to fight organized crime and authorizes private citizens to help; those injured by it may bring civil suits to recover triple damages and legal expenses.

title: Politicians And the Real World
description: The picture of Illinois Representative Dan Rostenkowski in a helicopter flying over his district in Chicago illustrates a mistake the President and members of Congress make in avoiding the real world (''A Most Important Man on Capitol Hill,'' by Steven V. Roberts, Sept. 22). They all jet from here to there, taking a helicopter or limousine to a scheduled event, and never experience the everyday problems familiar to all citizens: the limited services of Amtrak, the crowded conditions at Greyhound or Trailways bus stations and the breakdown of city transit systems. EDGAR C. KINTZER Des Moines

title: 2 More Justices Join Debate on The Constitution
description: The extraordinary public debate between the Administration and members of the Supreme Court has evolved since July, when Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said the Constitution's framers would find some High Court rulings ''somewhat bizarre.'' In calling Mr. Meese's account of history ''somewhat uncomplete,'' Justice John Paul Stevens last week took the debate further than such disputes have in memory gone, criticizing a sitting Attorney General by name.

title: LEBANESE PEACE TALKS IN SYRIA
description: Top Lebanese militia officials met in Syria today to finish drafting a peace agreement that would end Lebanon's 10-year-old civil war, while fighting continued in several Beirut areas, killing at least two people.

title: ALPHABET SOUP
description: OUR HOUSE CUR-rent is AC, not DC, but with the AC we can get both AM and FM on the radio. The radio also works without the AC if you put in D batteries. The TV is different.

title: REAGAN CITES REGIONAL CONFLICTS
description: President Reagan today reaffirmed his commitment to making his proposal for resolving regional conflicts a ''key part'' of the summit meeting next month with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: COLUMBIA LEADS, BUT BUCKNELL WINS
description: Facing reporters for the sixth straight week as a losing coach, Jim Garrett, the fiery first-year head football coach at Columbia, conceded yesterday that he had truly felt the sting from his team's latest setback.

title: DANCE: THE JOFFREY IN A KYLIAN WORK
description: ALL the energy for which the Joffrey Ballet is celebrated was evident Thursday night at the City Center. Yet, often, it was expended upon indifferent choreography.

title: BELIZE WARILY CONSIDERS MARIJUANA HERBICIDE
description: The leader of the Central American nation of Belize said today that he was ready to accede to United States wishes to resume aerial spraying of his tiny country's vast marijuana fields, but only if it posed no environmental hazard.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TO REQUIRE USE OF SEAT BELTS
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has signed a bill that will make Massachusetts the 16th state to require motorists to use seat belts, and its backers say the new law should result in fewer highway deaths and lower automobile insurance rates.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the film page of the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday misidentified a member of the rock group Run-D.M.C. who appears in ''Krush Groove.'' The performer shown was D.M.C.

title: NEW CASSETTES: EVERGREEN MUSICAL, CLASSIC ANIMATION
description: Maytime Starring Jeanette MacDonald, Nelson Eddy, John Barrymore, Rafaela Ottiano; directed by Robert Z. Leonard, 1937 MGM/UA Home Video 132 minutes. $24.95 Like a full-bloom peach tree, this lavish, melodious movie still stands as Hollywood's best operetta, even in black and white.

title: RACONTEURS OF THE RAILS
description: Through the loneliness of the Alleghenies, along the bottom lands of Missouri, over the Santa Fe Trail, the voices of a hidden America can occasionally be heard by fortunate Amtrak passengers.

title: Statue of Liberty Centennial Concert
description: The yearlong centennial celebration of the Statue of Liberty will begin here Monday - the statue's 99th birthday -with the world premiere of a symphonic suite by Richard Adler entitled ''The Lady Remembers.''

title: NOTRE DAME STUNS SOUTHERN CAL, 37-3
description: Allen Pinkett rushed for 110 yards and one touchdown, and John Carney made three field goals today as Notre Dame surprised Southern Cal with a a 37-3 trouncing.

title: Icelandic Rift
description: Though her office is largely ceremonial, Vigdis Finnbogadottir, the President of Iceland, found herself caught in a political paradox last week.

title: ONE DISTRICT'S SOLUTION
description: AT 4:30 P.M., when the door opens at Maurice Hawk School, the sounds of children at play ring through the halls.

title: GUNFIRE IS REPORTED IN UGANDA'S CAPITAL
description: Explosions and sporadic gunfire, apparently between rebels and Government troops, rocked the outskirts of the capital today, and military roadblocks were put up for the first time in two months, witnesses said.

title: BUSH CAMPAIGN COMMITTEE LISTS 470 OF ITS SUPPORTERS
description: Vice President Bush's political action committee has released the names of 470 Republican activists who have joined its national steering committee, the latest step in Mr. Bush's efforts to demonstrate broad-based party support for a bid for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: A STANDOFF WITH THE REGULATORS
description: YOU could feel the sense of frustrated revolt in the air from the moment that the bankers and the regulators filed into the standing-room-only meeting with top officials of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the agency that regulates federally chartered banks. The tally of bank failures hit an all time high of 76 last year, has reached 95 already this year, and everyone was smarting.

title:
ART;

PRIVATE WORLDS
description: TASTE and how it has changed is one of the most fascinating and revealing aspects of cultural history. This message is particularly strong in the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art's new offering, ''The House and Garden: 10th Anniversary Exhibition,'' which commemorates the museum's decade of public service.

title: BUONICONTI HURT
description: A Citadel linebacker, Marc Buoniconti, was hospitalized in critical condition after injuring his neck in a game against East Tennessee State yesterday. Aubrey Lee, a spokesman at Johnson City Medical Center Hospital in Tennessee, said Buoniconti, the youngest son of the former Notre Dame and Miami Dolphin linebacker Nick Buoniconti, was admitted after being injured in the first quarter.

title: EROSION CONTROL FROM THE PHARAOHS
description: MILLIONS of dollars are spent each year in Nassau and Suffolk Counties on public and private waterfront fortification projects, most typically, steel or timber bulkheads placed alongside beaches or marinas.

title: PAUL VOLCKER LOBBIES THE REGIONALS
description: THE band played ''You're a Grand Old Flag.'' The house lights went down, the spotlights went on. Applause rang through the vast, hangar-like convention center as Paul A. Volcker, the much-respected, 6-foot 7-inch chairman of the Fed, strode on stage. His charisma even overcame the effect of the football-field-sized screen above and behind him that simultaneously televised his talk. ''He's a great individual,'' said Jay J. Delay, president of Comerica Bank in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: WE MUST REBUILD ISLAND'S ROADS
description: THERE is no surer sign of economic decay than decline of a region's infrastructure, particularly its transportation system. This was as true in ancient times as it is today.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PHILADELPHIA COMET WATCH For a chance to see Halley's comet, try the roof of the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. Astronomers there can't promise a sighting, but they know where and when to look, and they will have their telescopes set Nov. 8, 13, 15 and 20 from 7 to 11 P.M. and Dec. 6, 11, 13 and 18 from 5:30 to 9 P.M.

title: Robert Dufour Weds Shelly Ann Cox in Rye
description: Shelly Ann Cox, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph Parker Cox of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Cox, was married yesterday to Robert Charles Dufour, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Dufour of Lakeville, Conn. The Rev. Howard Major performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: WATERS FOUND TAINTED
description: THE first statewide survey of nonpoint sources of water pollution - those not traceable to large pipelines of chemical and sewage-treatment plants - shows that 40 percent of the rivers and streams and 27 percent of the lakes and reservoirs surveyed are seriously tainted.

title: NEW IDEAS FOR WINTER CELEBRATIONS
description: THE HOSPITALITY OF WINTER can take as many forms as the imagination will allow. Sitting down with friends to savor the crisp snap of new harvest apples and some golden ripe cheddar can be an act of celebration; a quieter pleasure than the elaborate festivities that make up this season of many holidays, but one similarly touched with a quality of well-being. In fact, the meals served at home by those who know food best - professional restaurateurs - reflect a relaxed approach, in a grouping of family around the table or a luncheon for an exuberant, casual crowd.

title: Jennifer Dalton, Michael G. Carey To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Dalton Jr. of Saratoga, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Mari Dalton, to Michael Gerard Carey, a son of former Governor Hugh L. Carey and the late Helen Owen Carey. The wedding is planned for March 1.

title: ALL AMERICAN HITTER
description: He eats Japanese food and he plays the difficult Japanese chess game known as Shogi, but for all his assimilated ways, when Randy Bass comes to bat for the Hanshin Tigers there is no doubt about the nationality of the Oklahoma-born former major leaguer. His American-style batting power in the small-scale Japanese parks won Bass the triple crown of Japanese baseball this season and brought him to within one of tying Sadaharu Oh's record of 55 home runs.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

WHEN POETS WITH CAMERAS SOUGHT A SURREAL VISION OF LIFE
description: In a sense, all photography is surrealistic. The shadow of the photographer in a family snapshot, the ghost-like intruder in a double exposure, the pained grimaces and contorted gestures in a split-second action shot - such characteristic juxtapositions of incongruous elements distort reality, or present it to the viewer under an unfamiliar aspect that may suggest another, possibly superior, reality.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ONE OF MY VERY BEST FRIENDS. By Shirley Lord. (Crown, $16.95.) Readers will have their Perry Ellis socks knocked off by Shirley Lord's steamy new novel of sex and success. Beginning in 1950 London, it tells of two teen-age ''very best friends'' - beautiful Nell and sweet Sylvie. Both are hired by a Fleet Street newspaper and fall in love with the same man. That's where the similarity between the two ends. Nell, as loathsome as she is toothsome, begins her vertiginous climb up the ladder of success by abandoning an illegitimate child, escaping to Canada with the man Sylvie loves and involving herself with a Mafia boss while stealing cosmetic secrets from the chemist she lured from Sylvie's Aunt Gert. Her big break comes when she marries a much older millionaire who sets her up in the beauty business and enrolls her in a private course in the art of public manipulation taught by a lesbian Hungarian harpie. Nell, who has become known as ''the Godmother'' of beauty and independence to millions of women worldwide, has one stab of human feeling: she falls for her very married son-in-law. Sylvie, meanwhile, has married a top composer, but her happiness is shattered by Nell's compulsive evil. Sylvie survives and becomes a crack gossip columnist. Although the action takes place in some of the world's very best places, it winds down in Palm Beach, Fla., in 1975, with both women getting their just destinies, and the cast of characters from their pasts all present and accounted for.

title: POPULAR TENOR IN RADIO ERA
description: Morton Downey, whose soft and melodious Irish tenor enchanted radio listeners and night-club audiences in the 1930's and 40's, died Friday night at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and had been in ill health since suffering a stroke 18 months ago.

title: Facing Up To College
description: William Safire's column demonstrates how creative the fertile young mind can be, although describing ''the technicolor yawn'' as an example of ''the orginality and vividness of collegiate phrase-making'' may be too generous. It is neither new nor was it coined within the walls of academia.

title: LILCO TAKES CENTER STAGE IN ELECTIONS
description: WHILE arguments over the future of the Shoreham nuclear power plant have dominated public discourse in Suffolk County for years, until recently the $4.5 billion facility had raised far less concern in Nassau County.

title: CHINA'S SHOP WINDOW IN HONG KONG
description: There is a particular exhaustion that overcomes visitors to Hong Kong, and renders them incapable of setting foot in one more shop. It is a symptom of overdose: According to tourism officials, the 3.2 million people who visit Hong Kong each year spend almost 65 percent of their time shopping.

title: Simulating Town Houses Low-Rise Apartments in Kew Gardens
description: Although Kew Gardens remains an enclave of mostly single-family homes, cooperative and condominium residences are gaining favor among those who want to own homes in that Queens neighborhood.

title: VINTNERS ON L.I. DEBATE QUANTITY VS. QUALITY
description: FOR 13 years, Long Island's vintners have been carefully developing their crops and the image of the local wines.

title: TOUCHDOWN RECORD SET
description: Joe Dudek ran for five touchdowns today as he led Plymouth State to a 35-15 decision over Bridgewater and eclipsed Walter Payton's all-division National Collegiate Athletic Association record of 66 touchdowns in a career.

title: Dole and Friends
description: Senator Bob Dole refuses to take his undeclared campaign for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination seriously, at least in public. He told reporters the other day that he had a speaking engagement coming in Vermont and, while he was in the neighborhood, he planned to ''drop by and see my friends in New Hampshire,'' site of the earliest primary contest of the next national campaign.

title: State of Siege In Argentina
description: Argentina revived emergency restrictions known as the state of seige last week after a judge freed 12 suspects arrested in a Government crackdown on right-wing violence. The country had been under a state of seige for nine years, until Oct. 30, 1983, the day Raul Alfonsin was elected its first civilian president after years of military rule.

title: JUDICIAL CANDIDATES RUN UNOPPOSED
description: FOR the first time in the political history of the Ninth Judicial District, candidates for vacant seats on the State Supreme Court bench are running unopposed. Highly placed officials in the county's Democratic Party said this was the first time anyone could remember that their judicial nominating convention had failed to name one of its own candidates.

title: MICHIGAN TOUNCES INDIANA BY 42-15
description: The tailback Jamie Morris rushed for 179 yards and two touchdowns as Michigan overcame two early turnovers and a 15-15 halftime tie for a 42-15 victory over Indiana in a Big Ten Conference game today.

title: THE WORLD AHEAD
description: THE MEMORY OF the motel sign is still vivid despite the years. Neatly printed black letters on white spelled a puzzling message for a young black boy from suburban St. Louis traveling with his parents through sleepy Arkansas towns with the rural charm of Norman Rockwell paintings.

title: Transit Deficit May Raise Fares
description: To make ends meet in the coming year, transit officials said last week, the subway and bus fare in the city might have to be raised beyond what Robert R. Kiley, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, called ''the one-buck psychological barrier,'' and tolls on city bridges and tunnels might have to be increased unless more help is forthcoming from Albany and City Hall. As for those who ride the Long Island and Metro-North railroads, the officials said they might not be spared, either.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: PROPHETICALLY, these words appeared in ''Outlaws of the Ocean,'' a book written by G.O.W. Mueller and Freda Adler (William Morrow & Company, New York, $17.95) and published earlier this year:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: KLAUS BARBIE: The Untold Story. By Ladislas de Hoyos. Translated by Nicholas Courtin. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Klaus Barbie, the Nazi ''butcher of Lyons'' who fled to Bolivia in 1951, is in a French prison awaiting trial for war crimes. This well-researched book by the French journalist Ladislas de Hoyos is crammed with information from interviews and government records and focuses on the maneuvers that got Mr. Barbie expelled from Bolivia and sent back to France. In February 1983, after years of diplomatic wrangling, Mr. Barbie was led into Lyons, where as head of the Gestapo he tortured and murdered Jews, civilians and Resistance fighters. Mr. Barbie, twice condemned to death by French courts in absentia, felt safe in Bolivia when the 20-year statute of limitations on war crimes ran out. This book gives names, places and other information likely to be used by the prosecution as evidence of Mr. Barbie's crimes. But Mr. de Hoyos also tries to determine why it took France 40 years to get Mr. Barbie back. Mr. de Hoyos writes that the French Government was afraid of what Mr. Barbie might say in his defense if he were prosecuted. Mr. Barbie is notorious in France as the killer of the Resistance leader Jean Moulin, but has claimed since the Allies liberated Lyons that Moulin was betrayed by Rene Hardy, another member of the Resistance. In 1948 Mr. Barbie was interrogated by French investigators, but only in connection with the trial of Hardy, who was exonerated. Mr. Barbie's testimony, which is reprinted in the book's appendix, would, if proved accurate, be an intense embarrassment to the French.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BECOMING AMERICAN: The Early Arab Immigrant Experience. By Alixa Naff. (Southern Illinois University, $19.95.) This book deals with those Arabs - largely from the Syrian and Lebanese segments of the Ottoman Empire - who came to America from about 1870 to 1940 hoping to strike it rich and return home in a few years.

title: EXPERT CHOICES
description: FOR DEVOTEES OF THINGS gastronomical, whether proficient cooks or simply the armchair variety, an interesting culinary gift is always welcome for the holidays. Professional food experts, too, enjoy receiving an unusual addition to their batteries de cuisine; they are also decidedly clever in choosing items to give to friends who enjoy entertaining and the pleasures of fine food and wine.

title: ON THE TRACK OF THE MILITANT MULLAHS
description: SACRED RAGE The Crusade of Modern Islam. By Robin Wright. Illustrated. 315 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

HEALTH GUIDE
description: If you have ever wondered about the difference between an endodontist and a periodontist, pondered about the preparation needed to become a psychologist or a psychiatrist, or needed to know what services a local hospital provides, help has arrived.

title: JAMES LEVINE AND THE MET
description: In answer to the problems discussed in Will Crutchfield's article on James Levine: What is needed is another Strauss or Puccini, and there is about as much chance of that as there is of filling all the empty royal boxes in all the opera houses with their reigning monarchs. This is not to endorse a return of world monarchies, but to realize that the culture that fostered grand opera has long passed, leaving the opera houses as relics, not living theaters. JAMES CAMNER Hopewell, N.J.

title: MARSHALL SACKS WEIGHTY IMAGE
description: Two summers ago, Leonard Marshall, the Giants' second-round draft choice, reported to training camp overweight, flabby and obviously out of condition. He looked like a 300-pound mistake. On Sunday, when the Giants play the Saints here in the Superdome, the Saints must be concerned about the new Leonard Marshall. In the Giants' normal 3-4 defense, he will start at right defensive end. In passing situations, he will play right tackle in a four-man rush. He is effective either way because he leads the National Football League with 11 1/2 sacks.

title: EWING HAS A TOUGH TIME
description: In the fall of 1974, a high school phenom named Moses Malone made his debut as a professional by scoring 19 points for the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association. In the 11 seasons since, Malone's playing style - exemplified by a relentless work ethic - has made him one of basketball's unchallenged stars.

title: HEAVEN IS THE BACKYARD OF HELL
description: NOTHING HAPPENS IN CARMINCROSS By Benedict Kiely. 279 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $16.95.

title: O'Connor Recalls Catholic Suffering
description: In a speech to a Jewish audience gathered at New York City's largest synagogue last Sunday, John Cardinal O'Connor made remarks that he said were ''perhaps unwise, imprudent and risk great vulnerability.''

title: RISE IN LATIN STUDY OUTPACES TEACHERS
description: AN increased interest in Latin among the Island's public school students has led to the offering of more courses. But it has also led to a shortage of Latin teachers.

title: CLAP, CHEER, AND PEEL THE ORAGNES
description: I'VE always wanted to run a marathon -which is unfortunate, since my lousy knees long ago popped that pipe dream and relegated me to the spectator sidelines.

title: JERSEY IN AN ACCORD ON AID TO PAROCHIAL PUPILS
description: Public-school teachers will be allowed to resume remedial classes in mathematics and reading at Roman Catholic schools in six New Jersey communities under an agreement reached between state and Federal officials.

title: Now for El Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: DOMESTIC SCANDALS AND TRADE FEARS LEAVE TAIWAN UNCERTAIN
description: A series of scandals this year has provoked widespread dismay and uncertainty in Taiwan.

title: THE BREEDERS' CUP IS HERE: IS NEW YORK READY FOR IT?
description: DESPITE the undeniable quality of the sport, both from a standpoint of its high-grade administration and the champions it produced, thoroughbred racing in New York has suffered too long as a publicly accepted punching bag. The jokes and jabs started way back and never seem to end. After the flashy hoopla of the Kentucky Derby in May, June's Belmont Stakes, that dignified mile and a half over the East Coast's show-case track, whisperingly came to be known as the best-kept secret in town.

title: SNATA BARBARA TO VOTE ON STRENGTHENING PACTS ON OIL DRILLING
description: This scenic coastal town, the site of a disastrous oil spill in 1969 that helped inspire the environmental movement of the 1970's, is preparing for a huge new oil boom amid a debate over what it means for the community's future.

title: MICHIGAN APPLE CROP OVERTAKES NEW YORK'S
