description: With the 1985 harvest completed, New York fell to third place in the nation in the volume of apples picked, according to a report this week by the State Crop Reporting Service here.

title: No Headline
description: A picture caption last week incorrectly identified one of the New York Dance Theater dancers rehearsing; he was Tomas Rahal.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: From 35% to 70% Off At J. H. Harvey Sale J. H. Harvey is celebrating 30 years of retailing classic and contemporary furniture by renting the County Center Tuesday through Thursday for a ''quality saleathon'' of discontinued merchandise, inventory overstock and nondelivered items from the Yonkers warehouse, along with special purchases from North Carolina manufacturers - their opportunity to clear fabric overstock.

title: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE FOCUS OF TRAINING
description: POLICE departments around the state are reviewing their training procedures and policies on handling domestic-violence cases in the wake of a new state law and a landmark Connecticut court case.

title: MOGUL COOKING DONE WITH CARE
description: NEARLY all the Indian restaurants that have opened on Long Island in recent years are elegant affairs, and Ashoka, new to Glen Cove, is no exception. But for a couple of framed Indian prints and the tandoor oven area visible behind glass, the small, plush dining room could accommodate a restaurant of any ethnicity.

title: RUTGERS WINNER AT LAST <
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 26 (AP) -

title: THE NEW POP MOVIES: MADE FOR FIDGETY VIEWERS
description: In the opening sequence of ''Remo Williams: the Adventure Begins,'' a New York policeman, having a lonely, late-night snack in his patrol car underneath the Manhattan Bridge, goes to the aid of a mugging victim, only to have the victim and the two muggers turn on him. They beat him in ways that, in real life, would result in real death, then push the patrol car, containing his body, into the East River.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review Oct. 20 of Richard Holmes's book ''Footsteps: Adventures of a Romantic Biographer'' misstated the cause of Mary Wollstonecraft's death. She died of complications after the birth of her second daughter, Mary, in 1797.

title: $167,000 Question
description: ALADIER OSORIO was about to board a Delta Air Lines flight in Florida when an airport security guard at an X-ray machine asked him to open his suitcase. Inside was clothing and $167,430 in cash. Mr. Osorio reportedly seemed startled.

title: SAFETY SEATS
description: To the Editor: In the article on child safety seats it is mentioned that use of a safety seat generally means the parents will have to buy a ticket for a child under 2 who otherwise can travel free.

title: HONG KONG, MADE TO ORDER
description: Once or twice a year I have the same dream: I walk into Bloomingdale's to discover that everything in the store is on sale for $1, and I am the only customer. I get to indulge my chronic passion for acquisition at a level of gluttony and guiltlessness that waking life never permits. Or never did, until I went to Hong Kong.

title: JOHN MAUCERI AND THE AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: Since Leopold Stokowski left it in 1972, the American Symphony Orchestra has been something of a musical ship without a rudder - a self-governing organization drifting along without significant commitments to either a charted musical course or a permanent music director. Now, that era seems to have ended. At the suggestion of Gilbert Kaplan, the orchestra's chairman of the board and chief executive officer, the orchestra has decided to follow the implications of its name by emphasizing American music and American musicians.

title: UNBEATEN PENN ST. WINS, 27-0
description: For a change, there was nothing close about undefeated Penn State's victory today, its seventh of the season and 600th in the university's football history. The Nittany Lions soundly whipped West Virginia, 27-0, before 85,534 fans in Beaver Stadium.

title: MAKING A HERO TAKES A HEROIC EFFORT
description: IT is hot. We are in our bathing suits on the way back from the pool. Every leaf on every tree is a vibrant green. From the back seat of the car comes the question that strikes terror in my heart. ''What are you going to be for Halloween?,'' son No. 1 innocently asks son No. 2. The question seems to come earlier and earlier each year, giving me more and more time to try and solve this thorny predicament. Unfortunately, time is not what I need.

title: WHEN RELATIVES ROLL IN GERALD GOLD
description: ONCE, my Aunt Roz and her brood descended upon us unheralded, unnotified, unannounced. Now, she is a terrific aunt, and I love her. She is a lot of fun, outspoken and original, but there are limits to a welcome mat.

title: WHAT HAPPENED IN CRAFT CEMETERY?
description: IT SOUNDS like a Halloween scare story, but some local people say bodies may be missing from an old graveyard owned by the City of Glen Cove.

title: MOVIES OUT OF THE MAINSTREAM FIND A HOME ON BRAVO
description: For most viewers, cable primarily remains a source for feature films. Yet the movies that predominate on cable are what might be considered mainstream titles, produced by large American studios or high-profile independents, and typically preceded by wide theatrical distribution.

title: THAT FAMILIAR SHAMBLES, THE AMERICAN MALE
description: HAZZARD'S HEAD By Scott Sammer. 193 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $14.95.

title:
THE TALK OF SOMERS;

A TOWN PREPARES FOR CHANGE
description: MORNING has broken over this town of 4,500 households, although you couldn't easily tell it. Fog has obscured the rising sun and the only glimmers of outdoor brightness come from the headlights of the automobiles traveling along Route 100, past the 7-11 on one side of the road and Froggy's, a delicatessen, on the other. One of the few places open this early in the Somerstown Shopping Center, a large part of the small heart of the municipality, is the post office lobby, where the posters of wanted felons have been replaced by a hand-drawn rendering of ''Bagels,'' a ''white short-hair with rust markings.'' Appropriately, a reward has been offered.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CHILDREN'S HOURS What with Nassau Community College beginning its ''Classics for Kids'' series, and the East End Arts and Humanities Council bringing in the Paper Bag Players for a one-afternoon stand, this is a good week to be a child on Long Island. The action starts today in Garden City at the College Union, where at 1 and 3 P.M. Don Oliver retells ''Br'er Rabbit Tails,'' stories of African origin that he heard his grandfather tell in their charming, humorous original form. There will be four more entries in this series - from a ballet version of ''Cinderella'' to a performance of Mozart's opera ''The Magic Flute.'' For ticket information call 222-7153.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: In the High Pulpit of Criticism A fine social and literary critic, Dwight Macdonald was also a spirited and witty polemicist. In ''Discriminations: Essays and Afterthoughts'' (Da Capo), he replies to a thrust from Irving Howe.

title: ROOOM SERVICE, PLEASE: 3 COLLEGES IN MANHATTAN TURN TO HOTELS FOR HOUSING
description: Donald Sewall, a 20-year-old New York University student, has a room in a ''dorm'' that features an impressive marble sink and bathtub, not to mention a view of the Empire State Building.

title: 'MYSTERY COMMUTER' UNVEILED
description: AT first, Abby Montgomery of Yonkers thought she had won the lottery. Instead, she had won something she said was better than money: a place in Westchester history.

title: CITY OPERA: CORSARO STAGING OF 'BUTTERFLY' RETURNS
description: THE 1985 installment of the New York City Opera's Frank Corsaro production of ''Madama Butterfly,'' seen Friday evening, offers little that seems exemplary, though next to nothing that is deplorable, either. And yet this honorably ordinary performance made a powerful impression not just on the audience, but on this curmudgeon of a critic, too.

title: Epilogue To Brutality
description: To a senseless crime was added a troubling epilogue last week. A woman was pushed in front of a subway train at the Times Square BMT station; the stranger charged with the crime, it turned out, had recently been released, against the recommendation of her doctors, as a psychiatric patient from Kings County Hospital Center.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SATIRIST IN RED BANK Mark Russell, the resident political humorist at the Shoreham-Americana Hotel in Washington, is as irreverent as a political satirist should be.

title: PHILIPPINE COMMUNIST INSURGENTS ARE GAINING, U.S. OFFICIALS WARN
description: The Communist insurgency in the Philippines has grown steadily larger and more violent, despite assertions by the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos that the situation is being contained, according to officials familiar with the most recent reports of American intelligence agencies.

title: Susan Robertson, Psychologist, Weds
description: Dr. Susan Ruth Robertson, a daughter of Dr. David Allan Robertson Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and the late Dr. Beridge Ruth Robertson of Demarest, N.J., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Bartz, the son of Mariann Dwyer Bartz of Sun City Center, Fla., and the late Dr. Quentin R. Bartz of Detroit. The Rev. George M. Landes performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother.

title: CUMMINGS EXCELS IN KNICK DEFEAT
description: Patrick Aloysius Ewing's National Basketball Association debut helped fill Madison Square Garden to its 19,591 capacity. But another Patrick - Patrick Michael Cummings -wound up with a healthy share of the few bright spots the Knicks could find in losing their season opener to the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CHAMPION: Joe Louis, Black Hero in White America. By Chris Mead. (Scribner's, $17.95.) Joe Louis Barrow was heavyweight champion of the world from 1937 to 1949 and died in 1981, a legend of the ring and the first black American - athlete or otherwise - to become a national hero in a segregated society.

title:
ART;

ADVENTUROUS PRINTMAKING IN ACADEMIA
description: THE printmaking department of Indiana University in Bloomington, founded in 1942, is in many ways a model of what art education can achieve within an academic framework.

title: IN POUND RIDGE, 'RETURN TO CHILDHOOD'
description: SOME people outgrow toys.

title: B.Y.U. IS SHOCKED BY TEXAS-EL PASO
description: The defensive back Danny Taylor intercepted a Robbie Bosco pass in Texas-El Paso's end zone and raced 100 yards to score and put the Miners ahead to stay tonight in a stunning 23-16 upset of Brigham Young.

title: MEASURING THE SERVICE ECONOMY
description: ''WE'VE been looking at the economy with one eye; it's time to open the other eye,'' says Joan E. Spero, senior vice president of the American Express Company.

title: Sanctuary Case Comes to Court In Arizona
description: A courtroom in Tucson, Ariz., provided the setting last week for what may become the most impassioned conflict between state and religion since some churches harbored draft resisters during the Vietnam War.

title: New York Curbs Bathhouses
description: New York State last week took its most drastic step yet to slow the spread of AIDS. It promulgated measures designed to restrict places that provide a haven for ''dangerous'' sex, the kind that involves an exchange of bodily fluids and along with them the virus that destroys the body's immune system and leaves it vulnerable to fatal diseases.

title: Barbara Ruscick Weds
description: Barbara Ann Ruscick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. M. James Ruscick of Alpine, N.J., was married yesterday to William Peter Procida, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Procida, also of Alpine.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 28, 1985: *2*MONDAY Armstrong World Ind Georgia-Pacific Corp Associated Dry Goods Heck's Inc Atlantic Richfield Koppers Co Boeing Co Phila Elec Co Brown & Sharpe Mfg Sea-Land Corp Burndy Corp Storage Equities Consol Freightways Union Camp Corp Fort Dearborn Inc Wackenhut Corp Foster Wheeler *2*TUESDAY American Brands McDonald&Co Invest Amsted Indust NUI Corp Becor Western Inc North European Oil Rlty Black Hills P & L Overnite Transp Borden Inc Pulte Home Corp Duke Power Sargent-Welch Sci Enserch Corp Tenneco Inc Gulton Indus Inc Triangle Industries Harcourt Brace Jov U G I Corporation Kaiser Alum & Chem Warner-Lambert Co Koger Properties Wendy's Intl Lee Enterprises *2*WEDNESDAY Amer Business Prdts Houghton Mifflin Amer Genl Corp Kentucky Utilities Bethlehem Steel Lafarge Corp Butler International McGraw-Hill Inc Celanese Corp National Medical Entpr Chevron Corp Newell Companies Du Pont Pacific Lumber Equifax Inc Pope & Talbot Exxon Corp Public Serv Co Ind Freeport-McMoRan Squibb Corp Grainger (WW) Stride Rite Corp Heileman G.
