title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Have any Ivy League football teams ever played in a bowl game?

title: A Shimmering City
description: Not so long ago, George Forss was a poor man struggling to make a living by selling his photographs on the street.

title: UNION SUPPORTS ENDORSEMENT MADE EARLY IN 1984 CAMPAIGN
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council has adopted a resolution standing by its decision to issue an early endorsement for Walter F. Mondale as the 1984 Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: Three Heart Patients Showing Progress
description: Thomas Gaidosh was ''comfortable and relaxed'' here today while another artificial heart patient, Anthony Mandia, continued progressing in a hospital in Hershey, Pa.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: U.A.W. STRIKE ENDS AS MEMBERS BACK PACT FOR CHRYSLER
description: Rank-and-file members of the United Automobile Workers today ratified a new labor contract with the Chrysler Corporation, ending a 12-day strike by the company's 70,000 production workers in this country.

title: Worse Than Deficits
description: ''Something has to be done about the deficit,'' say those who support the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing bill already passed by the Senate. But some things are worse than the deficit, and Gramm-Rudman-Hollings is one of them.

title: Buying Back City Schools
description: New York City's new contract with school custodians all but ends the expensive user fees that have deterred community groups from running after-school programs. Doing that won't be cheap, but the money is well spent for the expanded day care, remedial, sports and other activities it will bring into the public schools.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture provided by Camera Press in some copies yesterday with an obituary of Maurice Cardinal Roy, former Archbishop of Quebec and Roman Catholic Primate of Canada, was incorrect. It showed Paul-Emile Cardinal Leger, former Archbishop of Montreal.

title: FATE OF SOVIET SEAMAN IS NEGOTIATED
description: A young Soviet seaman who had jumped into the Mississippi River twice to escape his ship remained on board the vessel today, his eventual fate uncertain.

title: Market Place;   Foreign Fund Leads the Pack
description: GEORGE L. NOBLE has been buying Spanish utility stocks lately and adding to holdings of railway issues in Japan. But he views the Japanese securities market - whose capitalization accounts for nearly half of all stock markets outside the United States - as less appealing than that of certain other countries.

title: ANTI-SEMITIC SENTIMENT ON RISE, CONFEREES SAY
description: Anti-Semitic acts and sentiments have increased recently in the United States and abroad, even as several studies have suggested that anti-Semitism is on the decline, Jewish leaders warned yesterday at a conference on anti-Semitism.

title: PIGEONS DEFY ODDS, RACE ON
description: The race would be long and fraught with danger. Along the way the competitors could fall victim to accident or enemy.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Raiders vs. Chargers, at Los Angeles. The Raiders are the kings of ''Monday Night Football'' with more victories than anyone.

title: Iran's Prime Minister Introduces Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi of Iran introduced his proposed Cabinet to Parliament today and emphasized the religious and revolutionary credentials of its 24 members.

title: KASPAROV GAINS DRAW AS THE GAMES DWINDLE
description: Anatoly Karpov dragged out the 20th game of his world chess title defense to 85 moves but his stubbornness could not stave off a lifeless draw with Gary Kasparov in the Tchaikovsky Concert Hall in Moscow yesterday.

title: THE RACE TO BRING FAST TRAINS TO U.S.
description: The vineyards of Burgundy flash past the window in a long green blur as France's high-speed Train a Grande Vitesse, traveling at 170 miles per hour, eats up the 270 miles between Paris and Lyon in a bare two hours.

title: 'A TIME FOR LOVE' - AN NBC MOVIE
description: THE mother in tonight's television movie - ''A Time to Live'' on NBC at 9 - is faced with the challenge of coping with her son's muscular dystrophy. It is the kind of unusual situation that has unfortunately become all too commonplace in television drama projects exploiting a ''disease of the week.'' Some efforts, however, are more successful than others, and this one scores its emotional points deftly, thanks largely to Liza Minnelli's performance as the mother.

title: PROPOSAL FOR NEW COUNTY GOVERNMENT SPLITS BERGEN VOTERS
description: Bergen County voters going to the polls Nov. 5 will face eight ballot questions, including a little-publicized provision that could change the shape of county government.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1985
description: International

title: Shevardnadze Visiting Cuba
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, left New York today on a visit to Cuba, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page caption yesterday with a picture of barge traffic in upstate New York incorrectly described the Erie Canal. It runs for about 350 miles from Albany on the Hudson River to Buffalo on Lake Erie; it is part of the 525-mile New York State Barge Canal System.

title: PERES PLANS TO 'CARRY-ON' WITH EFFORT
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel declared to American and Canadian supporters of Israel yesterday that despite disagreement within his Cabinet about his recent peace overture to Jordan, ''we shall have enough support to carry on.''

title: Julie Sara Hailparn Weds Daniel P. Ginns, Executive
description: Julie Sara Hailparn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Lee Hailparn of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married yesterday to Daniel Paul Ginns, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Haskell Ginns of Belmont and New Seabury, Mass. Rabbi Earl Grollman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Am in Merrick, L.I.

title: 2 YALE STUDENTS RUN IN A RACE FOR ALDERMAN
description: Two Yale students, Joel Ratner and Keith Ferrazzi, have been learning a lot about politics this fall - not in class but on the campaign trail. The two are running against each other for a seat on the New Haven Board of Aldermen.

title: 'Alternative Maximum Tax'
description: If President Reagan's effort to overhaul the income tax system runs aground in Congress, Senator William L. Armstrong, a member of the Finance Committee, plans to offer a plan that would satisfy both those yearning for a simpler tax system and those who like things just the way they are now.

title: HOORAY FOR HOWSER
description: And in the seventh game, Dick Howser rested.

title: PACERS' GUARDS OUTPLAY NETS
description: Micheal Richardson and Otis Birdsong of the Nets are regarded as one of the finest backcourt combinations in the National Basketball Association. The Indiana Pacers, who committed 1,622 turnovers, the most in the league last season, have missed the playoffs for four straight years, primarily because of their weakness at guard.

title: AQUEDUCT PLANS TO HELP FANS
description: Aqueduct Race Track, where the seven Breeders' Cup races will be run Saturday, has made numerous changes and improvements designed to accommodate an expected turnout of 40,000 fans.

title: Hamburg Offices Attacked
description: Windows were smashed at the Dutch Consulate and several company offices early today in attacks that the police said might have been related to the death of a protester in police custody in Amsterdam last week. ''Police murder'' was written on the building.

title: Plan on Brokered Deposits
description: The new chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, L. William Seidman, says the agency's latest proposal to regulate the flow of brokered deposits to banks ''obviously has some merit,'' but legislation may be needed.

title: Herald Tribune Post
description: Michael G. Conroy, 46 years old, has been appointed to the newly created post of president of International Herald Tribune U.S. Inc., the Paris-based newspaper announced Friday. Mr. Conroy, who had previously been an international publishing consultant, will be responsible for the newspaper's operations in North America, including advertising sales, circulation and distribution. The International Herald Tribune, which circulates in 164 countries, is jointly owned by The Whitney Communications Company, The New York Times Company and The Washington Post Company. The Herald Tribune plans to open a facsimile printing site in Miami early next year to serve readers in North and South America.

title: Home Resale Pace Eases
description: Sales of existing homes dropped 1.7 percent in September, but the annual rate of sales still remained close to the best pace set since late 1979, according to a real estate trade group.

title: Prescribing Limits For World Court
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: RUBEN BLADES'S SALSA
description: RUBEN BLADES, salsa's most literary songwriter, read considerable symbolism into his Carnegie Hall debut Saturday night.

title: Making It Too Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: Price of Gas Rises Slightly
description: Retail gasoline prices rose nearly a fifth of a cent in the last two weeks, showing that the cost of reducing lead content in gas has finally reached the pump, Dan Lundberg, an oil industry analyst, said today. The rise was the first in three and a half months.

title: DEVELOPMENT'S SHADOW OVER BOOKSHOP
description: When Stuart Brent first brought his passion for books to a little store on Michigan Avenue here in 1947, the street was a quiet thoroughfare with small shops and affluent customers from surrounding neighborhoods.

title: FROM THE SIDEWALKS, A 26-MILE STANDING OVATION
description: For almost the entire circuitous route of the 26-mile-385-yard New York City Marathon yesterday, it was standing room only along the sidewalks, with a healthy scattering of leaning-out-of-windows, propped-up-against-storefronts and entwined-around-lampposts.

title: Todd Rival in Aro Bid
description: The Todd Shipyards Corporation disclosed Friday, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, that the Aro Corporation had another corporate suitor when it agreed to be acquired by Todd. The rival, not identified, made a bid on Sept. 10 for less than the $35 a share offered by Todd, according to information Todd said it received from Aro. Todd said Aro considered the offer too low.

title: END OF TUBE FEEDING OF COMATOSE PATIENT ASKED IN JERSEY CASE
description: A New Jersey Supreme Court decision authorizing the withdrawal of feeding tubes from incompetent, terminally ill patients in ''right to die'' cases is being invoked for the first time, in an attempt to end the life of a 65-year-old woman in a nursing home here.

title: Private Hospitals' Dumping of Patients
description: A patient arrived in the emergency room at Cook County Hospital recently clutching a grocery sack full of bottles of outdated medicines and unfilled prescriptions. The patient, whom I will call Mrs. Smith, arrived, unannounced and unexpected, from a private hospital with a note from her physician that stated: ''Please assume medical care of Mrs. Smith. She is no longer eligible for medical assistance and cannot afford to see me.''

title: Advertising;   Accounts
description: Trintex, a joint venture of CBS, I.B.M. and Sears, to J. Walter Thompson/New York, for its developing videotex service.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Who Needs Reality?
description: He's 9 years old, and if he lives to be 100, Jesse Binger will never forget the 1985 World Series. It was, after all, his Series. After dreaming about it all summer, Jesse, a Met fan from Ronkonkoma, L.I., saw his dream come true. From a front-row seat, he watched the Mets take on the Yankees in a Subway Series.

title: STAKES ARE HIGH FOR LUKAS IN BREEDERS' CUP
description: D. WAYNE LUKAS has tried everything to win a Kentucky Derby, a Belmont Stakes or a Breeders' Cup race. He has tried running horses fresh from an airplane trip, and tried giving them a month on the ground. He has tried working them out long and hard and tried giving them no workouts at all. He has even gone beyond tricks of the horse-training trade: He scheduled his second marriage for Derby Week in the hopes it would be a good omen for his attempt to win the race with a filly. None of it has worked. This would not be surprising for any other trainer. There are a dozen or more horses in these races, the sport's most prestigious, and most horsemen wait a lifetime to get just one good enough to deserve a start. But D. Wayne Lukas has won just about everything else in thoroughbred racing - everything but the sport's very richest and toniest events.

title: President of Harris To Become Its Chief
description: The Harris Corporation, beset by many of the same problems that currently plague the computer and semiconductor-manufacturing industries, has announced that John T. Hartley will become its chief executive officer. Mr. Hartley, currently president and chief operating officer, will succeed Joseph A. Boyd.

title: CORPORATE GIFTS SAID TO JUMP
description: American companies gave $3.8 billion in gifts of cash, products and property to charities last year, a jump of 15 percent over the previous year, according to a national survey to be released today. But there are signs that the yearly increase in giving may be beginning to slacken.

title: Catching Up
description: * A couple of weeks ago, the Miller Brewing Company removed one of its Lite Beer commercials from network television because during the spot, Bobby Bonds grossly exaggerated his career stolen-base total. Now, a different kind of inaccuracy has bubbled to the surface, and with a different outcome.

title: ROYAL ROUT A BITTER ENDING FOR CARDS
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, the sprinting team that stole more bases and won more games than anybody else in baseball in 1985, took one of the historic tumbles in World Series history tonight and did it in an outbreak of anger, bitterness and violence.

title: Bridge: Brazilians and Israelis Lead Qualifying Play in Sao Paulo
description: Qualifying play in the world team championships concluded this afternoon with Brazil and Israel surviving in the open series for the Bermuda Bowl, and Britain and Taiwan leading the women's division.

title: POLICE IN SOUTH AFRICA REPORT 6 BLACKS KILLED
description: At least six blacks were killed in some of South Africa's segregated black townships during the weekend as confrontations continued between the police and black protesters.

title: FOR TEXAS-EL PASO, A MIRACLE
description: Anytime the University of Texas-El Paso wins a football game it is an upset. But when the Miners beat Brigham Young, 23-16, Saturday night for their first victory of the season it was more than an upset. It was a miracle, according to the Miners' coach, Bill Yung.

title: P.L.O. ASSERTS HUSSEIN WON'T CUT ARAFAT TIES
description: Palestine Liberation Organization officials say King Hussein would face such a host of political difficulties if he dropped Yasir Arafat from his peace initiative that they believe the uneasy alliance will survive.

title: Advertising;   Advertising to Women Quits Second Account
description: Advertising to Women, which announced last Thursday that it had resigned the Charles of the Ritz account, made a similar announcement Friday concerning the Wella Corporation. And the reason the agency gave was the same: It wanted to free itself for advertising assignments of an entrepreneurial nature that would let it share in the profits from sales.

title: Petersen Near Front Again
description: He is more than just a local hero now, one whose style suits a particular course and surroundings. Since he finished a surprising fourth in last year's New York City Marathon, Pat Petersen has developed into one of the better American distance runners. In just his fourth marathon, Petersen ran New York in 2 hours 12 minutes 59 seconds yesterday, good for a third-place finish.

title: WAITZ OVERCOMES HEAT AND MARTIN TO TRIUMPH AGAIN
description: In the days before the start of the 16th New York City Marathon, Lisa Martin was talking big. A former 400-meter hurdler for Australia who didn't begin running in marathons until 22 months ago, she spoke of her conditioning, which she noted was at a peak, and of how much she has improved every year. But her boldest statement concerned Grete Waitz.

title: Do We Just Take Terrorism Case by Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 28, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Up From Down Under
description: Players born abroad have often found their way to National Football League teams. Usually they are kickers, such as Raul Allegre of the Indianapolis Colts, who is from Mexico; Neil O'Donoghue of the St. Louis Cardinals (Ireland), and Jan Stenerud of the Minnesota Vikings (Norway).

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Axlon Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., a toy company, has named William F. X. Grubb executive vice president.

title: IN RIOT'S WAKE, BLACK LEADER'S WORDS ROIL BRITAIN
description: He has been called a black militant, a gutter demagogue, a loony, an apologist for murder. He has also been called a populist and an honest man.

title: Steven Joffe, a Lawyer, Is Wed to Joan H. Ball
description: Joan H. Ball, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ball of New York, was married yesterday to Steven J. Joffe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Joffe of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Morris S. Friedman and Cantor Richard Botton performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue, of which the bride's father is the past president.

title: WILLIAM CARR DIES IN TUCSON
description: William H. Carr, the co-founder and first director of the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum, died Friday at St. Josph's Hospital in Tucson. He was 83 years old and a resident of Arizona since he moved there from New York 40 years ago.

title: Texaco, Mobil Set Swap
description: Texaco U.S.A. said Friday that it had signed a letter of intent with the Mobil Oil Corporation for Mobil to acquire Texaco's 82 retail outlets in the Chicago area and its suburban terminal in exchange for 79 Mobil stations in the Southeast and Southwest.

title: How to Create a Crisis on Main St.
description: To the Editor:

title: Supercow, Supersurplus
description: According to researchers at Cornell, the Supercow is on the way. Within a few years it will be possible for farmers to feed their herds a cheap, apparently harmless natural hormone that increases milk production by as much as 40 percent.

title: Boo!; NOTABLE WALKS
description: The Greenwich Village Halloween Parade, a fantastic conjunction of all kinds of people in all kinds of costumes, has gotten too big for its britches - the narrow West Village streets that were its original venue. It is therefore moving to Sixth Avenue.

title: STAGE: WILSON'S 'GOLDEN WINDOWS'
description: IF the world were flat - and coming to an end - it might look something like the spectacle that serves as the midpoint climax for ''The Golden Windows,'' the first Robert Wilson theater piece to appear in New York since last year's revival of ''Einstein on the Beach.''

title: Darkness at 5
description: It is possible to date the melancholy passage of summer in a variety of ways: the first day of fall, according to the calendar; the first day of school, according to the Board of Education; the first rattle of heat in the pipes, according to the whim of the building superintendent.

title: Advertising;   Jordan, Case to Push Imports From Italy
description: Here comes a little high fashion for the people at Jordan, Case & McGrath, courtesy of Ti:me Distributors, which seems to have a fondness for colons as well as for Fiorucci, a manufacturer of fashion items in Milan, Italy.

title: ALASKA NATIVES BEGIN EFFORT TO RETAIN CONTROL OF LANDS
description: After resolving deep disputes that had threatened efforts to protect Alaska native control over land and resources, native leaders today began a campaign to persuade Congress to amend the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act.

title: Advertising;   Robins Picks Agency
description: Just in time for winter, the folks at Scali, McCabe, Sloves have been named to do the creative work for the A. H. Robins Company's Robitussin cough and cold products and Dimetapp cold and allergy medications.

title: WORLD BANK URGES CHINA POLICY SHIFTS
description: China's leaders have a ''good chance'' of fulfilling their ambitious economic goals for the next 15 years, but should consider a shift in emphasis away from crude output targets toward a strategy allowing for faster growth in personal income and services, a World Bank report has concluded.

title: TUNNEL RENOVATION FIRST OF ITS KIND
description: For nearly two years, an intriguing construction project has been under way beneath the Hudson River. A new ceiling is being built in the Holland Tunnel.

title: IMPRISONED TAIWAN GANG LEADER IS LINKED TO NEW YORK DRUGS DEAL
description: A Chinese gang leader who is serving a life term in Taiwan for killing a Chinese-American writer in San Francisco helped direct a New York drug deal from prison last month, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: For a Florida Area, Last Shot of a War
description: The last shot of the Revolutionary War may have been fired in an obscure sea skirmish off Cape Canaveral, a researcher here says.

title: The Cure Is Worse
description: For some time now, the Library of Congress has been developing a system of preserving books by taking the acid out of the paper in a controlled atmosphere. Construction is scheduled to begin soon on a $11.5 million facility in Frederick, Md., that in two years will provide this anti-brittleness treatment for 5,000 items at a time.

title: FRIENDSHIP IN PATIENTS' LAST DAYS
description: THEY paint together, sing together, talk about sports and literature; they reminisce about the good old days of the past and the not-so-good ones of the present, and sometimes they do not talk at all but simply take comfort from each other's presence. The friendships that spring up between terminally ill patients in hospice care, either at home or in a hospital setting, and the volunteers who visit them are unusual. These connections are forged at a time when the patient is otherwise paring down social contacts, and they inevitably end shortly after they take root.

title: TAX CHECKS DUPLICATED
description: Duplicate state income-tax refund checks totaling $236,000 have been sent to nearly 1,000 New Jersey residents, the result of ''our haste to get out the refunds,'' the state tax director said.

title: CONCERT: 8 HOURS OF SCARLATTI
description: THERE may be as many ways of looking at the music of Domenico Scarlatti as he himself found of working out the two-part sonata form into which he poured such amazing compositional energy for decades of his odd life. That life began 300 years ago Saturday, and the anniversary was marked at Symphony Space with a marathon concert in which 20 players, alternating between piano and harpsichords, presented something like a sixth of his output of 550 sonatas.

title: GREENS VOTE TO JOIN A COALITION IN HESSE
description: The Hesse state chapter of the antinuclear Green Party voted tonight in favor of entering a governing coalition with the Social Democratic Party, the first of its kind in West Germany.

title: Futures/Options;   ECU Confusion And Debate
description: THOSE who have had trouble figuring out what an ECU is now have company. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission seem to share the confusion and are currently locked in a debate on the issue.

title: Sudan Says Rebels Kill 14 Despite a Cease-Fire
description: Southern Sudanese rebels attacked a Nile steamer despite a cease-fire, killing 14 soldiers, Defense Minister Osman Abdallah Mohammed said today.

title: Thorpe Triumphs in Tucson, 4 and 3
description: Jim Thorpe took advantage of a bogey by Jack Renner on the par-4 13th hole today and cruised to the title in the Tucson Match Play championship with a 4-and-3 victory.

title: SATURN LABOR PACT ASSAILED BY A U.A.W. FOUNDER
description: Victor Reuther was invited here to talk about the past, but the unpredictable and outspoken labor leader, now 73 years old, ended up talking about the present. He said he opposed on several counts a labor agreement between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation for a Tennessee plant to make small cars.

title: RADIOACTIVE GAS ALTERS LIVES OF PENNSYLVANIANS
description: The network of white plastic pipes and whirring electric fans in Kay Jones's basement is supposed to cleanse her house of dangerously high levels of radioactive gas.

title: Gandhi Visits Moscow, Stresses Common Views
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi returned from a two-week overseas trip tonight after a stop in Moscow, scheduled at the last minute, that was widely interpreted as an effort to buttress India's ties with the Soviet Union.

title: American Ship Building Appoints a New Leader
description: The American Ship Building Company, whose chairman, George M. Steinbrenner Jr., also does business in the Bronx as the principal owner of the New York Yankees, has announced that H. Allen Fernstrom has been named president and chief executive officer.

title: Prerequisite for Workfare: Work
description: Give New York's Governor Cuomo half credit for deciding to enforce the requirement that employable welfare recipients work for their benefits. He'll deserve the other half if his administration can make a dent in the problem that has always been the fatal flaw in workfare: finding real work for the welfare clients to do.

title: PINIELLA ACCEPTS YANKS' OFFER
description: Lou Piniella, for years a hot-tempered hitter, stepped into the Yankees' managerial lava pit today by becoming the 14th manager in George Steinbrenner's 13 years as owner. Piniella replaced Billy Martin, who may or may not have been informed that he had been dismissed.

title: CONCERT: MAUCERI AND THE AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI begot the American Symphony Orchestra in 1962, but did not do as much as might have been hoped to forge a place for it in our musical life. Though it has had its impressive and laudable moments, the orchestra's history has largely been one of struggle to find an audience, an artistic identity and a consistent standard of performance .

title: Laura D. Parker Becomes a Bride
description: Laura Dianne Parker, the daughter of Walter W. Parker of Annandale, Va., and Dr. Beatrice G. Parker of Richmond, Va., and James B. Rosenwald 3d were married yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. Rosenwald of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Jean B. Rosenwald.

title: Buoniconti's Son Listed as 'Critical'
description: Marc Buoniconti, son of the former Miami Dolphin All-Pro linebacker Nick Buoniconti, has suffered a serious neck injury similar to one that paralyzed Darryl Stingley, the former New England Patriot receiver, officials said today.

title: WOLFF RETURNS TO VIETNAM IN FICTION
description: It was March 1968. ''I remember after Tet,'' Tobias Wolff recalls. ''I was driving down a road in the delta with a Vietnamese lieutenant after the worst of the offensive was over, and the road was lined on both sides with corpses, and most of them were children. They were wrapped in straw mats with just their feet sticking out - little feet. People were wearing surgical masks because of the stench. It was like being in hell. I thought this was a place I'd never leave. But I did.''

title: Miss Woldenberg Becomes a Bride
description: Merle Ray Woldenberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David H. Woldenberg of New York, was married yesterday to David Todd Wolff, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Wolff of West Nyack, N.Y. Rabbis Haskel Lookstein and Henry Sosland performed the ceremony at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Wretched Excess Dept.
description: The Political Chutzpah Award for October goes to Elliot Greenspan of Ridgefield Park, N.J. Two weeks ago he announced that he would challenge Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey's Ninth District in the Democratic primary next year. Last Wednesday he was sent to jail in Lawrence, Mass., for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating credit card fraud. Within hours, he asked a friend to call Washington and ask his Congressman, Mr. Torricelli, to intercede on his behalf.

title: DOTSON RELINQUISHES CLAIMS AGAINST WEBB AND GETS CHECK
description: In exchange for immediate cash, Gary Dotson has relinquished his rights to further royalties from a book written by Cathleen Crowell Webb, the woman who accused him of raping her in 1977 then recanted her story.

title: AT CENTRAL PARK FINISH LINE, JOY AND A SHORT CASUALTY LIST
description: They trudged across the finish line like troops coming home from a war. Their faces seemed full of despair and defeat, but it was only their weariness from the long afternoon of running. Hours after the winners had lifted their arms to the rousing cheers in Central Park, the thousands of other competitors in the New York City Marathon finally came in.

title: 2 ARE MISSING AFTER BOAT CAPSIZES
description: Hurricane Juan, with winds up to 85 miles per hour, moved north through the Gulf of Mexico today, swamping boats and oil rigs and stranding some 1,400 people in one Louisiana town as it lashed the shore and forced evacuations.

title: SONTAG AND VONNEGUT AT PEN CELEBRATION
description: Kurt Vonnegut and Susan Sontag alternately entertained and instructed a Broadway audience last night in appearances at the Royale Theater, where they touched upon a number of topics from anthropology to censorship. Their separate itineraries also included excursions into literary analysis and the right of artists to be political or apolitical, as they desired.

title: Advertising;   Cable Industry Drops Image Campaign Plans
description: The Council for Cable Information, whose board last August approved a $12 million McCann-Erickson image advertising campaign for the coming year, announced Friday that it was unable to raise the money from its industry and would be going out of business on Nov. 30.

title: SYRACUSE RACE BECOMES BITTER IN A TV DEBATE
description: The campaign for mayor turned bitter here the other night when the Republican, Roy Bernardi, opened a blistering attack on his Democratic opponent, Thomas Young, in their first televised debate.

title: Samuel J. Duboff, 70, A Retired Accountant
description: Samuel J. Duboff, a certified public accountant active in civic affairs, died of a heart attack Friday while attending a meeting in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Military AIDS Tests Can't Be Conclusive
description: To the Editor:

title: WITHOUT LEADERSHIP...
description: A white South African, a man who has not been at all involved in politics, spoke on the telephone from Cape Town the other day. ''Why can't we get past this?'' he asked in anguish. ''Why can't we do what we have to do?''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FAMOUS PEOPLE I HAVE KNOWN. By Ed McClanahan. 196 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95.

title: TAKE SERIES ON 3D VICTORY IN ROW
description: The Kansas City Royals, adding a previously well-hidden hitting attack to their season-long tenacity, made baseball history tonight by winning their first World Series in a game spiced by a wild scene that concluded with a St. Louis coach dragging a Cardinal pitcher away from an umpire.

title: 49ERS SURPRISE RAMS, 28-14
description: In recent seasons, the San Francisco 49ers have always found the Los Angeles Rams to be a therapeutic opponent, especially in games played here. And from the way the current season was unfolding for the 49ers, they were never in greater need of help.

title: Do We Just Take Terrorism Case by Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: Experts Back Safety of Navy Yard Waste-Disposal Project
description: To the Editor:

title: PROBLEMS INCREASING AT SEAWAY
description: The rumble of the heavy machinery goes on 24 hours a day here as engineers and construction workers try to repair a 150-foot concrete chunk of Lock No. 7 in the Welland Canal that slammed into the side of a ship on Oct. 14.

title: KENTUCKY PAID PLAYERS, REPORT SAYS
description: Some former Kentucky basketball players say they sold complimentary tickets at inflated prices to boosters and received cash and other improper gifts from supporters, according to a report published today.

title: Bear, Stearns Offering
description: Bear, Stearns & Company said Friday it would make its first public offering Tuesday. As previously reported, it will consist of 8 million shares. The final price has not been set.

title: Space-Repaired Satellite Is Sent to High Orbit
description: Two months after repair by spacewalking shuttle astronauts, an $85 million Navy communications satellite was launched toward high orbit today.

title: Missiles Said to Kill 14 In an Afghan Mosque
description: The official Afghan radio said today that rebel missiles had hit the main mosque in the western town of Herat, killing 14 people and wounding 78.

title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS
description: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column, appearing today for the first time, will periodically review some of those questions.

title: SICILIAN PROSECUTORS EXAMINE STANDOFF AT AIR BASE
description: Sicilian prosecutors let it be known today that they were looking into the United States interception of an Egyptian plane carrying four Palestinians charged with hijacking the cruise liner Achille Lauro.

title: It's Time to Put Heat on Marcos
description: There is a consensus here about what is wrong in the Philippines. But there seems to be a kind of paralysis about what to do.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SETTINGS Settings, in photography circles, are important to the business of making pictures that are presentable. The new setting of the new midtown branch of the International Center for Photography, which opens its doors to the public today, looks out on a pretty scene, the International Paper Plaza at 77 West 45th Street, one of the most attractive of those open spaces attached to overwhelming high rises.

title: FINANCIAL PLANNERS FACE OUTCRY FOR SUPERVISION
description: An Arizona financial planner wasted $1.1 million of his customers' money in a tax shelter for financing development of a genetically superior rabbit. Another planner in Georgia took $100,000 from the savings and investments of his clients and put it into worthless certificates of deposit. And two financial planners in Maryland promised investors returns of 30 percent in 90 days, but squandered the funds instead.

title: IT'S THE GREAT PUMPKIN
description: What do you call a 450-pound pumpkin? Most people would probably call it heavy; the farmers who grow these giants on their compost piles call them profitable. Whoppers like the one below, which was being loaded late last week at Fischer & Page, a wholesale flower and plant store on West 28th Street, go for $150 to $200.

title: POLITICS OF DEFICIT: ECONOMIC MOVE TIED TO ELECTION
description: This week, House and Senate negotiators will start crafting the details of a bill that would require a balanced Federal budget by 1991. But beneath the surface, the lawmakers will be arguing about politics as well as economics, and staking out positions for the 1986 elections, which are barely a year away.

title: PLEA AGREEMENT SAID TO IMPROVE CASE AGAINST SPY SUSPECT
description: The decision by John A. Walker Jr. to admit his involvement in what the authorities say is one of the most damaging spy rings in American history improves the prosecution's case against the retired Navy radioman described as his closest friend, Government officials say.

title: A Storing of Illusions
description: The magician Harry Blackstone Jr. will present two of the illusions made famous by his father, the Spirit Handkerchief and the Floating Light Bulb, to the National Museum of American History tomorrow after demonstrating them before Smithsonian Resident Associates at a special performance. The gift of these cultural artifacts is a delayed observance of the 100th anniversary of the birth of the performer's father, the Great Blackstone, on Sept. 27.

title: The Background;   Schiller's Tragedy a Source
description: ''Giovanna d'Arco,'' Verdi's seventh opera, roughly follows Schiller's tragedy ''Die Jungfrau von Orleans'' in recounting the Joan of Arc story. The premiere at Milan's La Scala in 1845 scored a success with the audience, but leading critics were less pleased.

title: ISRAEL SAYS IT HIT BASES IN LEBANON
description: Israeli Air Force jets attacked Palestinian guerrilla bases in the Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon today, the Israeli military reported.

title: Advertising;   Leber Katz Attracts New Clients, Quietly
description: Leber Katz Partners rarely sends out news releases and never sends out business solicitation letters, but it manages to get accounts nonetheless.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's unbelievable what's been happening. A week ago people were saying tax reform was dead.

title: AFTER 20 YEARS, TANZANIANS ELECT A NEW LEADER
description: Nearly seven million voters across Tanzania cast their ballots today for a President to succeed Julius K. Nyerere, the man who led his country to independence from Britain in 1961 and became one of the foremost spokesmen for newly independent Africa.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE SURE OF PRODUCING TAX BILL THIS YEAR
description: After an intense weekend of meetings that began amid talk that tax revision would be scuttled, members of the House Ways and Means Committee said today that they had broken the stalemate and would be able to produce a bill this year.

title: Dr. Lynne Quittell Wed To Dr. Eric T. Skolnick
description: Dr. Lynne Meredith Quittell, a pulmonary pediatric fellow at St. Christopher's Hospital in Philadelphia, and Dr. Eric Ted Skolnick, chief of pediatrics at the United States Naval Hospital in Philadelphia, were married yesterday at Estherwood, an historic estate in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Simckes officiated. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Quittell of New Rochelle, N.Y., is a graduate of Hampshire College and the Sackler School of Medicine at Tel Aviv University. Dr. Skolnick, a son of Dr. Louis Skolnick, a dentist, and Mrs. Skolnick of Bayside, Queens, graduated from Queens College and the Medical College of Pennsylvania.

title: PIZZOLATO WINS AGAIN IN MARATHON
description: This time, Orlando Pizzolato was going to enjoy the show. So the 27-year-old Italian raised his arms triumphantly, smiled for all to see, and ran the final yards savoring the applause on a course through Central Park that now was his victory route. Last year, on a warm and oppressively humid day, Pizzolato overcame severe stomach cramps and disorientation to win the New York City Marathon for the first time in what was more a survival test than a race. It also was an achievement he was not expected to duplicate.

title: RANGERS WIN ON BECK'S GOAL
description: Two teams, both stressing new offensive styles and both still in evolution, met last night at Madison Square Garden. The Rangers' new self won out over the Bruins' new self.

title: Briefcases
description: * The Optical Manufacturers Association has told President Reagan that 86 percent of eyeglass frames are now foreign-made, the highest import penetration for any American industry.

title: Thrift Ruling Appealed
description: A court order preventing the identification of thrift institutions that lent money to bankrupt real estate partnerships established by the Equity Programs Investment Corporation has been appealed by The New York Times and The Washington Post. Last week a bankruptcy judge in Alexandria, Va., refused to rescind his order sealing financial information submitted by the bankrupt partnerships, because attorneys representing them had said the disclosure could trigger runs among their depositors. Lawyers for the newspapers said the order violates provisions of the bankruptcy code permitting public access to court documents, and also violates First Amendment guarantees of freedom of the press.

title: AMTRAK HALTS TRAINS TO LET CLOCK CATCH UP
description: At 10:30 Saturday night, Train No. 66 left Union Station in Washington for what seemed to be a routine run to Boston. But at 2:12 A.M., the 108 passengers aboard the Night Owl entered another dimension of time and space. As Amtrak's R. Clifford Black put it, ''After Trenton - next stop, Twilight Zone.''

title: ISRAELI CABINET DEBATES PERE'S PEACE PROPOSAL
description: Israel's fragile national unity Cabinet held a long and often acrimonious debate today on Prime Minister Shimon Peres's peace overture to Jordan, but the Government appeared to be in no immediate danger of falling apart over the issue.

title: FOR FANS, ' IT'S LIKE A MIRACLE'
description: Pandemonium erupted across Kansas City tonight as happy throngs celebrated their hometown's first World Series championship.

title: BEARS, 8-0, OVERCOME VIKINGS
description: Jim McMahon threw two touchdown passes and Otis Wilson returned an interception 23 yards for a touchdown today as the Chicago Bears defeated the Minnesota Vikings, 27-9. It was the eighth consective victory for the undefeated Bears.

title: 'JENNY'S WAR' - A FOUR-HOUR PLAY
description: ''STRANGER things have happened,'' says one character to another in ''Jenny's War,'' and the other replies, ''Not many.'' That might be an epigraph to this four-hour television play, purportedly based on the adventures of an American woman who was slipped into Germany by British intelligence in 1941 so that she could try to find her son, an R.A.F. bomber pilot who had been shot down, and, while in the vicinity, spirit out some German military secrets in her shoe.

title: Erratum
description: The task of attempting to capture in print every word Congress says on the House and Senate floors and in dozens of daily committee sessions clearly approaches the Herculean.

title: SCHOOL OIL, LIVE PRINTS AND TUNES
description: At first you don't quite believe your eyes as you round a curve past blocks of pretty houses in Beverly Hills, but yes, it is an oil well. And it's pumping away on the grounds of Beverly Hills High School.

title: ALFONSIN WINS APPEAL IN COURT
description: An Argentine appeals court early today upheld President Raul Alfonsin's right to arrest terrorism suspects under the newly imposed state of siege, reversing an earlier court order.

title: Advertising;   Traveler Cuts Base
description: National Geographic Traveler, a quarterly introduced in March 1984, will cut its circulation rate base next year to 850,000 from 1 million, which it went to from 600,000 in September 1984. Although the publiction is cutting its base 15 percent, it will cut its rates only 8.6 percent.

title: AIR TRAVELERS, WARY OF LONG LINES AND LOST LUGGAGE, TOTE THEIR OWN
description: One passenger arrived with a Geiger counter on a long metal pole. A musician pushed a cello on wheels. A salesman toted a computer. Virtually every traveler getting on and off planes at La Guardia Airport on a recent afternoon was carrying at least a garment bag and a suitcase, briefcase or shopping bag.

title: SECURITIES DEALERS AWAIT TREASURY BORROWING
description: The Treasury will need to borrow money soon in order to pay its bills in early November, but government securities dealers are still waiting for an announcement.

title: NINE PAINTINGS STOLEN IN PARIS BY 5 GUNMEN
description: At least five gunmen entered the Marmottan Museum today and stole nine of its major Impressionist paintings, including Claude Monet's celebrated ''Impression, Sunrise'' and Pierre Auguste Renoir's ''Bathers.''

title: Nothing to It
description: Two weeks ago, Washington State's defense used a new tactic in trying to thwart John Lee. In autumns past and present, Lee had already heard all sorts of things shouted by opponents trying to rattle him, but the Cougars' twist was a real cute one: They yelled his Korean name, Min Jong Lee.

title: FLORENCE LUSCOMB
description: Florence Luscomb, an organizer for women's suffrage who went on to devote her life to Socialist causes, died yesterday at the Emerson Convalescent Home in Watertown, Mass. She was 98 years old.

title: Bought in the U.S.A.
description: The 12 members of the Chinese national basketball team, who had been playing against National Basketball Association teams during a monthlong visit to this country, wanted blue jeans, American blue jeans. But fitting a group of men whose average height is 6 feet, 6 inches turned out to be a challenge.

title: Mexico City Fire Injures 600
description: About 600 people were injured, some seriously, by a fire in the subway system here today, the Red Cross said.

title: Advertising;   Outsiders Catch On In the City
description: OUT-OF-TOWN ad agencies seem to have it tougher than most when they open offices and try to get accounts in Big Town. But Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopolus of Boston, which has been in our midst for a couple of years, seems to be thriving.

title: AIDS Center Run By Archdiocese
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has been operating a temporary shelter for AIDS patients at an undisclosed location for more than a month, church officials say.

title: MATCH ATTRACTS CROWDS OF DEVOTEES
description: Lately the crowds have been forming earlier on Mayakovsky Square here on the evenings when Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, and Gary Kasparov, his challenger, square off.

title: TEMPERS FLARE IN FRENCH TV DEBATE
description: Prime Minister Laurent Fabius accused the leader of the rightist opposition in France tonight of wanting to return to ''politics of the past,'' as a nationally televised debate opened a campaign for legislative elections that Mr. Fabius is widely expected to lose.

title: Janet Cohen Is Wed To a Fellow Lawyer
description: Janet E. Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Cohen of Rosyln Estates and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to John Winter, a son of Olga Igneri of Randall Manor, S.I., and the late John K. Winter. Rabbi Barton A. Shallat performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadows Country Club in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Theresa Elmore Wed To John T. Behrendt
description: Theresa Ann Elmore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Elmore of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to John Thomas Behrendt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Behrendt of Syracuse, Kan. The Very Rev. James R. Leo performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in Paris.

title: PAY-BACK TIME BEGINS
description: THERE are three hard things about the New York City Marathon. One is getting into it. The second is finishing. And the third is finding your family.

title: BANKERS 'TO ASSESS' BAKER PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration is hoping that a consensus in favor of its recent initiative to ease the global debt crisis will emerge here Monday at a closed-door meeting of commercial banks holding 85 percent of the third world's debt.

title: IN THE WESTERN PACIFIC, AN EVER-WARY WATCH
description: As they maneuver their navies in a widening competition for dominance in the Pacific, the Russians and Americans keep a constant wary eye on each other's movements.

title: KEEPING TABS ON COMPETITORS
description: After more than 20 years of analyzing weapons-related technological developments for the Central Intelligence Agency, Jan Herring is now working for Motorola Inc., helping the big electronics company analyze the technological advances of its competitors.

title: WILLIAM V. DZIERSON Sr.
description: William V. Dzierson Sr., chairman of the board of Elmer Little & Sons, a glove manufacturer, died Oct. 16 at Johnstown (N.Y.) Hospital after a long illness.

title: ROYALS' 'UNBELIEVABLE' TIME
description: So now there was a telephone call for the manager of the Kansas City Royals. Ronald Reagan calling. So now David Letterman would like to have a chat with Buddy Biancalana, at Rockefeller Center, on national television late at night. The request came Saturday, the day before Kansas City's 11-0 victory over St. Louis in the seventh game of the World Series. The shortstop has not been the object of quite so many jokes lately, although there was laughter in the Royals' clubhouse tonight.

title: Restructuring At Hurdman
description: KMG Main Hurdman, the nation's ninth-largest accounting firm, has announced a restructuring of its top management.

title: BUSINESS WOLVES STALK HIS NOVELS
description: AS Louis Auchincloss sees it, things have never been worse. ''We've fabricated a society of wolves and coyotes,'' he said. ''Why does anybody think we're better than we were in the robber baron days?''

title: F.D.A. Looking at Safety Of More Heart Valves
description: The Food and Drug Administration says it will look into the safety record of a heart valve made by a company that has already recalled larger sizes of the same model.

title: 'THE STATUE OF LIBERTY' MIXES OLD WITH NEW
description: What's new about the Statue of Liberty? Nothing much, really; it was officially unveiled 99 years ago today, and has stood in the Narrows ever since. Many New Yorkers take it for granted; it is visited mostly by tourists. It may not seem like a rich topic for a television documentary, but ''The Statue of Liberty,'' on Channel l3 at 9 P.M., is a terrific piece of work. It mixes history and ideas. The history, of course, is the history of the statue. It was conceived at a dinner party outside Paris in 1865, and nurtured toward birth for the next 20 years. The sculptor, Frederick Auguste Bartholdi, wasn't sure that he even liked Americans. ''What is lacking in the cities and most of the men,'' he wrote, ''is charm and taste.''

title: Japanese May Go to Sidelines
description: A new element of doubt was injected into the credit markets late last week, when a sharp rise in Japanese interest rates led to concerns that investors from that country would reduce their buying of Treasury securities.

title: Marathon Energy
description: About 10:30 yesterday morning a shiver of excitement seemed to encircle the Central Park Reservoir. On the 1.6-mile track, where joggers and world-class runners share the dirt path most mornings, those talented and strong enough for the Marathon were massed at the Staten Island starting line.

title: ADMINISTRATION TROLLING FOR CONSTITUTIONAL DEBATE
description: Recent history has seen nothing quite like the rhetorical crossfire between Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and two members of the Supreme Court.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS FELL 7% IN SEPTEMBER
description: Orders for American-made machine tools continued to fall in September, dropping 7 percent from their August level, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said in a report to be released today.

title: A $160,000 RIPOSTE WINS $1,001
description: Without benefit of clipboard or Bach, William F. Buckley Jr. pursued his forte, the clash of ideas, from the witness chair here in Federal District Court this month, thrusting and riposting even as his power of interrogation was thwarted. ''Am I allowed to ask a question, Your Honor?'' he asked blandly as he testified in his hard-fought countersuit for libel against Liberty Lobby, a conservative organization far less well known as an idea forum than his own National Review.

title: Plea on Writer's Exclusion
description: A group of noted writers is going into Federal District Court tomorrow to challenge the 1952 McCarran-Walter Act, which permits the Government to exclude from the United States anyone who advocates ''the economic, international and governmental doctrines of world Communism.'' Specifically, the lawsuit will seek to reverse a decision of the Immigration and Naturalization Service that denied permanent resident status to Margaret J. Randall, a 48-year-old writer who gave up her citizenship in Mexico in 1967.

title: Posts in Two Key Units Filled at Bankers Trust
description: The Bankers Trust Company, the nation's ninth-largest bank holding company, has announced two appointments in areas that are considered crucial to its continued drive into merchant banking fields.

title: WHITNEY HOUSTON IN CONCERT
description: Whitney Houston, the statuesque young belter who could become the queen of soul of the 80's, will graduate from clubs to Carnegie Hall tonight in a sold-out concert. The performance will be a homecoming for a singer who by birth and training is heir to the pop-gospel tradition of Aretha Franklin, Dionne Warwick and Valerie Simpson.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'GIOVANNA D' ARCO'
description: EVEN the stoutest partisans of Verdi's early operas do not claim much for ''Giovanna d'Arco,'' his dramatically naive and musically crude version of the Joan of Arc story. Most commentators blame the librettist, Temistocle Solera, for the work's faults, but that is a little unfair. The truth is that Verdi was far from being a sophisticated composer when he took up the subject of Joan. He was protectively fond of the work, probably because it was treated so rudely by critics of the day, though in the six years before it he had done better (''Nabucco'' and ''Ernani,'' for instance).

title: Topics;   Notable Walks; Oh Homers
description: In the world of baseball, ''homer'' usually is short for home run, but occasionally it refers to someone outrageously partisan on behalf of the home team. Events in Japan last week gave force to both meanings.

title: GUESTS 'FREE WORK KEEPS HOTEL OPEN'
description: During the season, the Chalfonte Hotel, a 109-year-old establishment, operates almost like the other Victorian hotels and guest houses lining the streets near the broad beach and promenade here.

title: Norton Off; Plans Layoffs
description: The Norton Company said Friday that it would take an after-tax fourth-quarter charge of $110 million to $120 million and would lay off 15 percent of its salaried work force in a companywide restructuring.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Washington Watch;   No Democrats Seen for F.T.C.
description: DANIEL OLIVER, general counsel at the Agriculture Department, has emerged as the top candidate to succeed James C. Miller 3d as head of the Federal Trade Commission. Mr. Oliver, 46 years old, is a native New Yorker and a graduate of Fordham Law School whose previous job was general counsel at the Department of Education. He once served as executive editor of the National Review and as a speechwriter for former Senator James L. Buckley.

title: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES
description: The scene was disturbingly familiar: United States marines in battle gear with camouflage blacking on their faces, moving along a jungle trail and carrying M-16 rifles.

title: Lendl Defeats Wilander, 6-0,6-4
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia overwhelmed second-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-0, 6-4, in less than an hour today and won the $375,000 Seiko super tennis championships.

title: GIANTS DEFEAT SAINTS
description: The panic was short-lived, and eventually the ghosts were chased and the memories erased. Finally, after seven straight losses over eight years, the Jets defeated the Seattle Seahawks today.

title: WOMEN AND AIDS: ASSESSING THE RISKS
description: As AIDS becomes more widely dispersed in the population, more women who may once have perceived the disease as largely confined to men are worrying about their own risks of infection. Almost half of the nation's women with AIDS live in New York City, and more than four-fifths of these are black or Hispanic women. According to city health officials, as many as 1 in 15 residents may now harbor the AIDS virus.

title: Coaches Fined
description: The coaches Stan Albeck of the Chicago Bulls and Chuck Daly of the Detroit Pistons have been suspended for one game apiece and fined because of a shoving incident during a game, the National Basketball Association announced.

title: FASHION IN 3 CITIES: MILAN SHOWS THE WAY
description: A funny thing happened as the Milan spring and summer showings faded into fashion history. As the London and then the Paris openings began, everyone began talking about the Italian clothes. In retrospect, they began looking better and better.

title: TEACHING SKILLS HE KNOWS BEST
description: The hockey coach assumed the coach's pose for the night, back erect, his head stiff as he peered over the helmets of his players. Play moved, the players tumbled over the wall, nudged each other along the bench to make room, and the coach hardly moved. He tapped players on the shoulder as hockey coaches do, to tell them to get on in there, but he said little, changed his expression not at all, and stayed put in the center of the team box where coaches are confined.

title: 'TENDER IS THE NIGHT' ON SHOWTIME
description: IF ''Tender Is the Night,'' a new six-hour mini-series version of the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel, seems to exude the kind of overall care and quality usually associated with British television, there is good reason. Although partly financed by Showtime, the pay-television outlet, the adaptation of the American novel was done by the British Broadcasting Corporation, with Jonathan Powell as executive producer, Robert Knights as director and Dennis Potter (''Pennies From Heaven'') as writer. The first two hours can be seen on Showtime tonight at 8 o'clock; the remaining episodes will be presented over the next four Tuesdays.

title: 4 IN NASSAU RACE DIFFER SHARPLY CONCERNING LILCO
description: The four candidates for Nassau County Executive clashed yesterday over the role of county government in the management of the Long Island Lighting Company, the future of the utility's nuclear power plant and political contributions by county employees.

title: GIFFORD-HILL & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,368,000 for the quarter and $10,981,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,025,000 for the quarter and $3,275,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago results have been reclassified to conform with the 1985 presentation.

title: BURRITT INTERFINANCIAL BANORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $57,200.

title: Bilingual Education Is a Form of Segregation
description: To the Editor:

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST MIDWEST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $169,000 for the quarter and $350,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $100,000 for the quarter and $393,000 for the 9 months.

title: JAMES F. LYNCH
description: James F. Lynch, a copy editor at The New York Times for 34 years, died yesterday at Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital after a heart attack two weeks ago.

title: ROCK: NAPPY BROWN AT LONE STAR CAFE
description: THE glorious excesses of 1950's rock singing are still thriving with Nappy Brown, the 56-year-old performer who appeared Sunday at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue.

title: NORTH FORK BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHITTENDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. INDICTS OREGON GURU AND SAYS HE TRIED TO FLEE COUNTRY
description: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, charged in a sealed indictment with conspiring to violate immigration laws, was taken off a private jet and arrested here early this morning by Federal agents who said he was trying to flee the country.

title: Afghan Seeks Inclusion of Pakistan in War Talks
description: The Foreign Minister of Afghanistan said today that his nation could not reach agreement on the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghan territory unless Pakistan enters into direct negotiations.

title: Banks Wary on Baker Plan
description: Commercial banks from around the world are shying away from commitments to lend to developing countries the extra billions of dollars proposed by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d.

title: REAGAN SEES CONGRESSIONAL DELAY ON DEBT CEILING AND BUDGET PLAN
description: President Reagan accused Congress today of ''inexcusable dithering and delay'' in its consideration of both an increase in the Government's debt ceiling and the Senate-approved plan to balance the budget by 1991.

title: Hutton Agrees to Pay New York Clients Quickly
description: E. F. Hutton signed a consent decree yesterday with the State of New York that will force the brokerage to remit funds more quickly to its customers in New York.

title: BOB SCHEFFING, METS OFFICIAL
description: Bob Scheffing, whose five-year tenure as general manager of the New York Mets included a pennant-winning team in 1973, died Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Phoenix. He was 70 years old.

title: TROPICAL ATMOSPHERE STUDIED FOR CLUES ON GLOBAL CHANGES
description: Using a new laser tool that is fired toward earth from an airplane, scientists here are measuring more precisely the levels of gases and particles above tropical oceans and rain forests in an effort to understand the complex exchange of chemical elements between the earth and the lowest layer of its atmosphere.

title: Gremlins and the Parade
description: The Greenwich Village Halloween Parade, an annual event for the 10 years, is threatened with cancellation this year.

title: GLENDALE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $5,780,000.

title: Governor Kean for New Jersey
description: New Jersey has long been able to boast of its resorts, truck farms, manufacturing industries and Bruce Springsteen. This year's gubernatorial election gives it two more objects of pride.

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,061,000 from the distribution of assets to shareholders.

title: REECE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POPE AND JEWS: STRAIN AMID CELEBRATION
description: Pope John Paul II met with a group of Jews today to celebrate the 20th anniversary of a Second Vatican Council document that revolutionized Roman Catholic teaching on Judaism. The meeting came amid signs of difficulty in Catholic-Jewish relations.

title: CHRYSLER'S NET UP 21% IN QUARTER
description: The Chrysler Corporation today reported record earnings for the third quarter of $316.2 million, or $2.75 a share, up 21 percent from $261.6 million, or $1.88 a share, in the comparable period last year. It was the eighth consecutive quarter of record earnings for the nation's third-largest auto maker.

title: GIANT YELLOWKNIFE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
$450 Million Bond Sale From a Power Agency
description: A $450 million issue of refunding revenue bonds for the Northern California Power Agency was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: CARTERET SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,569,000 from a preferred stock dividend from Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

title: NAVY'S BID TO TRY DOCTOR IS DELAYED
description: A military judge ruled today that the Navy made a major procedural error in pretrial hearings in the case of a heart surgeon accused of negligence that caused five deaths at Bethesda Naval Medical Center.

title: Computer Company Loss
description: The Computervision Corporation said today that it had lost $20.7 million in the third quarter, in contrast to a net income of $4.7 million, or 16 cents a share, in the 1984 period.

title: Mideast Deadlines
description: Virtually all the players in the endless Middle East drama are in motion again. Whether their myriad signals mean at last there is a real chance for peace negotiations or whether it is just another turn of the old merry-go-round remains to be seen.

title: Art for Travelers
description: People swirl in and out of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown in a seemingly endless waltz. But some have been waylaid, at least for a moment, by an unexpected encounter with art in this transient place.

title: REAGAN DELAYS MOVE ON ALTERING GUIDELINES ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to delay for at least the next several weeks a decision by President Reagan on whether to make changes in affirmative action rules on Federal contracts, White House officials said today.

title: SEACOAST BANKING CORP OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a one-time after-tax charge of about $411,000 for a security writedown.

title: Don't Bore the Elephants
description: So far, Halloween has been good for two of the elephants at the National Zoo. This is probably because Elizabeth Frank and the keepers of the elephant house try to keep both big beasts and small humans happy.

title: SUSPECT AND SON BOTH PLEAD GUILTY IN NAVY SPY CASE
description: John A. Walker Jr. pleaded guilty today to charges that he spied for the Soviet Union and that he recruited his son, friend and brother into an espionage operation that the authorities have called one of the most damaging in American history.

title: Minebea Acts To Thwart Bid
description: The Minebea Company moved today to frustrate an international takeover bid by agreeing to merge with an affiliate. The merger would increase the number of shares outstanding and increase the holdings of stockholders who could be relied upon not to sell their shares.

title: SOUTHDOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'HUMAN RIGHTS' ON PBS, BRITISH DOCUMENTARY
description: IN its way, ''Human Rights'' is a significant documentary. It has a point of view, and it is clear about its message: Communist governments may be heavy-handed, but real ferocity, systematized and calculated, is found only in the West or its dependents and in theocracies. We know whose side we should be on. The 90-minute documentary, part of Channel 13's ''Intercom'' series, will be seen at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: ALLEGHENY POWER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DALLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,889,000 for the quarter and $4,734,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $169,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $42.9 million for the quarter from the termination of the company's merger agreement with Texas Air Corp. before entering into its merger agreement with Carl C. Icahn, and a pre-tax nonrecurring charge of $61.7 million for the nine months and a pre-tax extraordinary gain of $14.8 million for the nine months. c-Net income, including nonrecurring gains of $20.8 million for the nine months.

title: KYSOR INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $333,000 for the quarter and $534,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $192,000 for the quarter and $158,000 for the 9 months.

title: NUVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUFACTURERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $3,790,000. c-Including a tax credit of $1,923,000. Results for the latest quarter includes the operations of Jonathan Logan, which was acquired in fiscal 1984; results for the year-ago quarter include Logan's operations for the month of September 1984 only.

title: White's Profit Plunges 48.6%
description: White Consolidated Industries reported today that its third-quarter earnings plunged 48.6 percent to $7.4 million, or 44 cents a share, from $14.4 million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: AN EVOCATION OF EZRA POUND
description: ''Ezra Pound?'' asked the wild-bearded man bearing a remarkable resemblance to Pound the poet. ''Wasn't he a screwball? And didn't he get locked up for treason?''

title: PLANS FOR RATING COLLEGES SOUGHT
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett said today that colleges and universities should develop ways to measure the quality of the education they offer, and that the Federal Government would help them do so.

title: Topics;   Upward Mobility Natural Law
description: A friend whose apartment is being remodeled thinks he has discovered a new natural law, on the order of Mr. Murphy's discovery that anything that can go wrong will.

title: WORTHEN BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $20 million from insurance claim related to collapse of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman, a $1.6 million gain on the sale of an affiliate bank and a $52 million writeoff related to the Bevill collapse. c-Net income

title: Wieboldt Cancels Buyout Agreement
description: Wieboldt Stores Inc. said that it was ending an agreement in principle, announced last week, for a leveraged buyout at $13.50 a share, or about $37.3 million. Wieboldt's, which operates 13 department stores in the Chicago area, cited an ''inability to obtain satisfactory assurance that financing is available'' for the deal.

title: Miles Davis to Record With Warner Brothers
description: Miles Davis has signed a new recording contract with Warner Brothers Records, ending a 30-year association with Columbia Records, the jazz trumpeter's manager said yesterday.

title: SOVIET REPORTEDLY LETTING SAKHAROV'S WIFE LEAVE
description: The son-in-law of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and Soviet rights activist, said today that ''it seems to be a likely possibility'' that Dr. Sakharov's wife has received permission to leave the Soviet Union for medical treatment abroad.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1985
description: Markets

title: ASARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an unusual pretax charge of $38 million to reflect the company's decision to close its Tacoma, Wash. copper smelter.

title: MERRILL'S EARNINGS PLUNGE 52%
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, parent of the giant financial services organization, yesterday reported a 52 percant drop in net income for the third quarter despite a 5.4 percent increase in revenues.

title: REOPENING OF INQUIRY INTO MARILYN MONROE'S DEATH RAISES IMBROGLIO IN LOS ANGELES
description: A new imbroglio has sprung up in Los Angeles over reopening the case of Marilyn Monroe's death 23 years ago.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $221.2 million, or $29 a share, on the sale of Investors Diversified . Results for the latest quarter include operating results of Chicago Title & Insurance Co. subsidiary, acquired in June.

title: SIR EDMUND HALLEY: ORBITING FOREVER IN NEWTON'S SHADOW
description: TOWARD the end of his long life, Edmond Halley was writing of his prediction that the comet he studied in 1682 would return in 1758 or 1759. He knew he would not live to see if his calculations proved to be correct. But he expressed the hope that ''candid posterity will not refuse to acknowledge that this was first discovered by an Englishman.''

title: SAVINGS RATE IN U.S. LOWEST SINCE 50'S, DESPITE INCENTIVES
description: Despite high interest rates, stable prices and Federal incentives to encourage thrift, Americans are saving a smaller portion of their incomes than at any time since the early 1950's.

title: KANSAS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN, AFTER GENEVA TALKS, PLANS AN ADDRESS TO CONGRESS
description: President Reagan plans to address a joint session of Congress on the night he returns from the Geneva meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, White House officials said today.

title: TIE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, after a pre-tax inventory writedown of $34 million for the nine months and including a gain of 11 cents per share for the nine months on the sale of stock of Nitsuko Ltd. c-After a pre-tax inventory writedown of $40 million and a pre-tax charge of $8 million from the restructuring of operations.

title: For Once, a Defensible State of Siege
description: ''The action was a little dramatic, but Argentine society is dramatic.'' So said an Argentine scholar, and he was right on both counts. Raul Alfonsin, whose presidency embodies Argentina's return to constitutional legality, has imposed a state of siege. That means suspending constitutional liberties, but the action needs to be seen in dramatic context. Many Latin American dictators have imposed cruel martial law. This is a state of siege with a difference.

title: CENTRONICS DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: TEXAS EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NELL VAN LEEUWEN BONI
description: Nell van Leeuwen Boni, widow of the book publisher Albert Boni, founder of Boni & Liverwright, died Oct. 22 in Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: STEWART-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $1,480,000 related to the sale of property. c-After a nonrecurring provision of $3,462,000 for the quarter and the nine months for the possible future restructuring of certain operations and including a tax credit of $1,662,000 for the quarter and the nine months and a gain of $1,800,000 on reversal of deferred tax liabilities related to the accumulated income of a unit.

title: MESABA AVIATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHO SPEAKS FOR THE PALESTINIANS?
description: Has terrorism killed the Arab-Israeli peace process? Or can new initiatives get it going again?

title: ROYAL INTERNATIONAL OPTICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Offer by Amphenol
description: Amphenol, a subsidiary of the Allied-Bendix Group, has made an offer totaling 340 million francs, or about $42 million, to buy a high-technology unit of the state-controlled Thomson-C.S.F., trade union sources at Thomson said. The offer includes 100 million francs, or $12.4 million, to acquire Socapex; 120 million francs, or $14,9 million, to buy its inventory, and 120 million francs in new investment in the company, which specializes in making electrical connectors. A Thomson spokesman said only that Thomson was interested in selling Socapex, whose specialty is not seen as strategic to the group's future.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF N C INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.N. GETS RESCUE PLAN FOR TROPICAL FORESTS
description: A new multibillion-dollar plan to save the world's rapidly disappearing tropical forests was presented today to governmental conservation leaders from around the world.

title: TRI-STATE MOTOR TRANSIT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $261,000 for the quarter and $784,000 for the nine months.

title: OKLAHOMA LOANS BEING INVESTIGATED
description: A report by the University of Oklahoma into reports that several of the school's athletes signed with sports agents while still eligible to play has been sent to the Big Eight Conference, Frank Horton, the university president, said.

title: Critical but Stable
description: The Citadel linebacker Marc Buoniconti, son of the former Miami Dolphins star Nick Buoniconti, is to be transferred to a Miami hospital for further treatment of a neck injury he suffered in a weekend game, a hospital official said. The younger Buoniconti was in critical but stable condition Sunday in Tennessee in the intensive care unit at the Johnson City Medical Center Hospital, said the spokesman Aubrey Lee.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for the 10 percent stock dividend declared in August.

title: New York City Requires Child-Abuse Reports
description: To the Editor:

title: JAL Officers Are Replaced
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone named a new Japan Air Lines president and two other executives today and linked a JAL crash that killed 520 people to poor management-labor relations and low staff morale.

title: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: NIAGARA MOHAWK POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Destination New Zealand
description: For the first time since the late 1950's, the United States is expected to send a career Foreign Service officer to be Ambassador to New Zealand. He is Paul Cleveland, who is now at the American Embassy in Seoul, South Korea, as deputy chief of mission, or second in charge.

title: How Andrea Doria Bank Notes Were Treated
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 CHILD-WELFARE GROUPS SUE CITY ON FOSTER CARE
description: Three child-welfare organizations filed suit against New York City yesterday, charging that it has failed to help tens of thousands of troubled families whose children may be forced to enter foster homes.

title: WHO SPEAKS FOR THE PALESTINIANS?
description: Jordan's equivocal and ambiguous reaction to the peace proposal put forward last week at the United Nations by Israel's Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, indicates that the Middle East peace process is still deadlocked. King Hussein has not yet been able to take Mr. Peres up on his offer of direct negotiations, largely because he does not feel that he is authorized to pursue peace on his own without the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: GLENMORE DISTILLERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. AIDES QUESTION SEAMAN WHO FLED
description: A crewman aboard a Soviet freighter south of New Orleans was removed from the ship tonight for an interview with State Department officials who are trying to determine whether he wants asylum in the United States, the department said.

title: MAYFLOWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: TRADE TALKS SEEN WITH CANADA IN '86
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that free trade negotiations between the United States and Canada could begin early next year.

title: COURT IN BRITISH ESPIONAGE TRIAL ACQUITS LAST OF SEVEN DEFENDANTS
description: The longest spy trial in British history ended today with the acquittal of the last of seven British servicemen charged with passing secrets to Soviet agents in Cyprus. A jury at Old Bailey acquitted all the defendants on all charges.

title: RENAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.
