Required Reading;   Missouri's Rankings
description: Excerpts from remarks by Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, in Senate debate over a bill to curb textile and footwear imports, Oct. 24:

title: MORE TALKS ARE SCHEDULED TODAY
description: King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met for two and a half hours here tonight to discuss strains in their already uneasy alliance.

title: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $178,000 for the quarter and $403,000 for the 9 months. The year-to-date earnings for 1985 included a $5.6 million gain on the sale of a small gas property and a $6.2 million favorable adjustment due to reassessment of taxes on foreign source income. The first three quarters of 1984 benefitted $12.7 million from favorable foreign tax adjustments.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The way we hit, we couldn't beat Molly Klutz.'' - Whitey Herzog, manager of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: CPT CORP(0) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATIONAL HORSE SHOW BEGINS
description: In 1883, the Brooklyn Bridge was opened, the Metropolitan Opera had its first performance and the National Horse Show started what has been one of the longest runs in sports.

title: Malone Out
description: Mark Malone, the Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback, suffered a dislocated big toe in Sunday's 26-21 loss to the Cincinnati Bengals and may be lost for four weeks, Coach Chuck Noll said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allegheny and Western Energy Corp., Charleston, W.Va., an oil and gas company, has named Anthony Altmann president and chief executive officer. * Amfac Inc. of San Francisco, which has interests in hotels and resorts, food processing, wholesale distribution and agriculture, has appointed Richard A. Naille 2d executive vice president. He was also named chairman and chief executive of Amfac Resorts Inc., a subsidiary. * Bankers Trust Company said Steven H. Reynolds and James A. Reavis have joined its Investment Management Group as managing directors. * Caldor Inc., Norwalk, Conn., the discount department store chain that is a division of the Associated Dry Goods Corp., has appointed Jean Frank senior vice president, personnel. * Cigna Corp., Bloomfield, Conn., an insurance and financial services company, has appointed Richard W. Maine chief investment officer and senior vice president. * Computerworks Inc., Westport, Conn., said Seymour Merrin has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer. * Dewey Electronics Corp. of Oakland, N.J., which makes military electronics and snow-making machinery, has appointed Mark L. Hyland executive vice president, responsible for operations and government procurement. * Great Southern Federal Savings Bank, Savannah, Ga., has elected Peter Knox 3d president and chief executive officer, succeeding M. Carson Branan, who continues as chairman. * Home Insurance Co. has promoted T. Bowring Woodbury 2d to executive vice president. * Imperial Corp. of America, San Diego, a savings and loan holding company, has appointed Kevin E. Villani executive vice president and chief financial officer and Stephen G. Haines executive vice president and chief administrative officer. * Mercantile and General Reinsurance Co. of America, Morristown, N.J., has elected John D. Dunn Jr. and John F. Cannon senior vice presidents. Paul D. Hawksworth has also been elected executive vice president. * New York League of Savings Institutions has elected as its chairman Franklin H. Ornstein, chairman and chief executive officer of Central Federal Savings of Long Beach, L.I. * RKO General Inc., a subsidiary of Gencorp, has appointed Joseph N. Fedoryk director of management information services. * Snap-on Tools Corp. of Kenosha, Wis., which makes hand tools and related equipment, has elected Marion F. Gregory president and chief operating officer. * Suburban Bank of Bethesda, Md., has elected to its board Dr. John Brooks Slaughter, chancellor of the University of Maryland. * Tishman Speyer Properties, a real estate developer, has named Sidney Unobskey a partner. * Warnaco Inc., an apparel company with headquarters in Bridgeport, Conn., has elected to its board Paul Britton Paine, retired chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Montreal Trust Co.

title: LIFELINE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After pretax charges of $170,000 for the quarter and $470,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: PERES WINS VOTE OF CONFIDENCE ON PEACE OVERTURE
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres won a vote of confidence from the Israeli Parliament today for his peace overture to Jordan, but only after a bitter struggle with his right-wing partners in the national unity Cabinet.

title: SALEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including after-tax gains of $116,000 for the quarter from the sale of real estate and $535,000 for the nine months attributable primarily to favorable settlement of contract termination reserves established in 1983. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the five percent stock dividend paid Jan. 31, 1985.

title: ANOTHER SHAKE-UP AT PHIBRO
description: Phibro-Salomon Inc. yesterday announced the second major shake-up in a year at its Philipp Brothers commodities trading subsidiary, cutting hundreds of staff and installing new management.

title: People to Begin Link With Denver
description: People Express Airlines said that next Monday it would begin five daily nonstop flights connecting its Newark hub with Frontier Airline's hub in Denver.

title: ABC Discontinues Movie Operations
description: The American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that it had decided to discontinue its theatrical motion picture operation, which has produced six films since it was formed four years ago.

title: G.O.P. HOPING TO GAIN 2 SEATS ON CITY COUNCIL
description: Republicans, hoping to gain a seat on the City Council for the first time since 1982, are seeking to defeat two freshmen Democrats in conservative, largely Italian-American neighborhoods in Brooklyn and on Staten Island.

title: GUARDIAN PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a credit of $505,000 for the quarter and 9 months from DISC tax cancellation.

title: MARILYN KLINGHOFFER'S STORY: GUN AT HER HEAD
description: Telling her story publicly for the first time, the widow of Leon Klinghoffer described yesterday how hijackers aboard the Achille Lauro put a machine gun to her head when she pleaded with them to let her stay at the side of her 69-year-old wheelchair-bound husband.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch on Friday about the United Nations' 40th anniversary misstated the American position on resolutions on the Middle East. The United States opposes references not to a ''just settlement'' but to Palestinian ''self-determination.''

title: SICILIANS WON'T PURSUE INQUIRY ON U.S. TROOPS
description: A Sicilian prosecutor said today that there were no grounds for a formal investigation of the behavior of United States soldiers after the interception of an Egyptian plane carrying the hijackers of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro.

title: TRANSCO ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $92.1 million from the writeoff of the company's investment in the Great Plains coal gasification project. c-Net income.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ROCKS OF CHINA In China, the rock has for thousands of years been an important element in the concept of beauty and philosophy, part of nature that particularly lends itself to the human imagination. ''Kernels of Energy, Bones of Earth: The Rock in Chinese Art'' is the new show filling the China House Gallery of the China Institute in America, 125 East 65th Street (744-8181).

title: LAND OF LINCOLN SAVINGS AND LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. SETS $17.75 BILLION SALE
description: A pent-up flood of Treasury notes and bonds will be unleased on the credit markets beginning today when the Treasury starts a three-part financing totaling $17.75 billion.

title: COUNTDOWN BEGINS FOR SHUTTLE FLIGHT CARRYING 8 ON A SCIENTIFIC MISSION
description: A huge laboratory crammed with experiments developed primarily by West German scientists will be carried on the space shuttle Challenger's next mission, scheduled to begin Wednesday.

title: Britannia Arrow Resists Offer
description: The board of Britannia Arrow Holdings P.L.C. today urged stockholders to reject a $302 million buyout offer made earlier in the day by Guinness Peat Group P.L.C. Officials of Britannia, a fund management, banking and insurance group, said the Guinness Peat offer of 15 of its common shares for each 8 Britannia common shares ''is wholly inadequate and not in the best interests of Britannia's shareholders or employees.''

title: ENGELHARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a DISC tax credit of $6.6 million for the quarter and 9 months and a gain of $1.2 million for the quarter from the liquidation of precious metal LIFO inventories.

title: GUILFORD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Lukens Price Rise
description: Lukens Inc., following the lead of the United States Steel Corporation, said that, effective with orders for shipment Dec. 30, it is cutting its carbon and high-strength low-alloy plate-steel base price by $150 per short ton, to $365 a ton, while eliminating discounts from published prices and revising selected price components for carbon plate. Lukens said the net effect is an average increase of $30 to $40 a ton.

description: b-Year-ago figures are not available because the company began operations in December 1984.

S. and international computer services businesses as well as writedowns of various investments. c-After a special charge of $130.2 million for the quarter and 9 months related to the phaseout of a business. d-Net income

title: Prices in Sweden Rise
description: Swedish producer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in September from August and were up 4.2 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today. Statistics Sweden said producer prices for engineering products, nonferrous metals and food products rose sharply in September, while prices for commercial steel and petroleum and coal products dropped.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The world middleweight champion Marvelous Marvin Hagler, saying his back felt ''much better'' arrived in Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday to open his training camp for his Nov. 14 title defense against unbeaten John Mugabe. Hagler suffered a lower back strain last week while training in Brockton, Mass., but received medical clearance Friday to go on with the fight. . . . Keith Byars, the Ohio State tailback, was given permission yesterday to play in the Buckeyes' Saturday showdown against No. 1-ranked Iowa.

title: Hearing Is Set for Knicks
description: The hearing on the National Basketball Association's charges that the Knicks attempted to circumvent the salary cap with their offer sheet to Albert King of the Nets will be held Saturday in London before Kingman Brewster.

title: Potomac Electric High Grade Bonds
description: The Potomac Electric Power Company is offering $75 million of 11 1/4 percent first mortgage bonds due 2015, at a price of 99 1/2, to yield 11.308 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: MARTIN'S LAWYER UNSURPRISED BY MOVE
description: Eddie Sapir, Billy Martin's lawyer, said yesterday that he was not surprised by Martin's dismissal as the Yankees' manager but that he was surprised by Martin's public demand, on the last day of the season, for more money to remain as the club's manager.

title: BALLET: CANADIAN TROUPE
description: THE Dance Canada Festival, sponsored by the Metropolitan Life Foundation and the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts, presented the third company in the five-group series this weekend.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CHAMPION: Joe Louis, Black Hero in White America. By Chris Mead. 330 pages. Illustrated. Scribner's. $18.95.

title: USING OMNIS 3: A WEALTH OF FEATURES TO LEARN
description: Database managers - important pieces of software for almost anyone having to organize such large quantities of information as student records, sales reports, transactions, mailing lists or any of the myriad other data collections characteristic of the technological world - are flooding the market.

title: Productivity Shows Gain
description: The productivity of American businesses rose at a 1.2 percent annual rate during the summer, the Labor Department said today. The increase matched the advance recorded from April through June.

description: b-Net income.

PENTAGON CITES SAFETY CONCERN IN CAMPAIGN FOR NERVE GAS FUNDS
description: The Pentagon said today that leaks had been detected in ''hundreds'' of poison gas weapons stored at military depots in eight states and that, although the leaks had caused no casualties, they constituted a ''safety concern.''

title: 3 MILE ISLAND SET FOR CLEANUP
description: Workers will soon begin fishing out radioactive fuel that has lain under 20 feet of water at Three Mile Island's Unit 2 nuclear power plant since the nation's worst nuclear accident at the unit more than six years ago, the plant's operator announced today.

title: JETS GLANCING DOWN THE ROAD
description: Some of the Jets peeked today.

title: EX-U.S. PROSECUTOR INDICTED
description: A former prosecutor with the New England Organized Crime Strike Force was indicted today on charges of selling information to drug dealers about investigative plans and pending indictments.

title: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in SportsMonday on Oct. 21 about the World's Masters Games rowing competition in Toronto last August stated the achievements of Dave Challinor and J. William Middendorf 2d. Challinor won a bronze medal in the double-scull event with William Killhour. Middendorf and an Australian teammate won a gold medal in the paired oars.

title: TUTU DENOUNCES REAGAN AS RACIST
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu accused President Reagan and the leaders of Britain and West Germany today of racism for their opposition to economic sanctions against South Africa.

description: b-Net loss after a loss of $670 million from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $535 million from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $766 million from discontinued operations.

title: Boeing Up 53.5%; UAL Falls
description: The Boeing Company reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter of 1985 rose 53.5 percent on a 40.5 percent rise in sales.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Ametek Inc. said it had completed its previously announced purchase of the Houston instrument division of Bausch & Lomb Inc. for $46 million.

title: DEBATE INTENSIFIES ON ATTITUDE AND HEALTH
description: IN an editorial in June, the influential New England Journal of Medicine concluded that ''our belief in disease as a direct reflection of mental state is largely folklore.'' That statement touched off a furor. The American Psychological Association responded with a resolution denouncing the editorial as ''inaccurate and unfortunate,'' asserting that it ignored a substantial body of research findings linking psychological factors and health.

title: EXPERT TESTIFIES CHOKING CAUSED STEWART'S DEATH
description: The Chief Medical Examiner of Massachusetts testified yesterday that his review of hospital records, the autopsy report and previous prosecution testimony indicated that Michael Stewart had died of asphyxia as a result of force applied to his neck.

title: Topics;   Upward Mobility Appearances
description: President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua did some family shopping while in New York for the United Nations session. For bulletproof eyeglass lenses, $300 a pair sounds like a bargain, and considering all the different suits and combat fatigues he wears, six pairs are understandable.

title: Texas and Steel Stocks Diverge
description: Shares in the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation, the subject of takeover talks with the United States Steel Corporation, fell $1, to $18, yesterday, while U.S. Steel shares rose 12.5 cents, to $28.125, both moving against typical takeover patterns.

Police in Wyoming Seek Clues to a Boy's Identity
description: The police searched today for clues to the identity of a teen-ager who can neither hear nor speak and who arrived at a bus station here with no identification. The youth carried a five-page letter apparently written by his mother urging him to seek a better life.

description: b-Includes a gain of about $3.3 million for condemnation of property located in Kansas.

Prudential Names Ball as Chairman
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said yesterday that James T. Barton would become its president on Jan. 1. George L. Ball, presently the securities firm's president, will become chairman. Mr. Ball will remain chief executive.

title: A to Z in Acronyms
description: The National Archives has just published the 1985-86 edition of the United States Government Manual, probably the most concise, efficient summary of official Washington. The price of the 927-page-volume has been raised by $3, to $15, but the difference seems well worth it.

32-BIT CHIP: POWERHOUSE IN THE WINGS
description: THE Intel Corporation, a major manufacturer of integrated circuits for computers, recently announced that it was about to begin delivery of a new chip, the 32-bit 80386. Many computer users care not a whit whether their machines are powered by 32-bit chips, two-bit chips or chipmunks on a treadmill, as long as the job gets done. However, the news is of great significance to the computer industry because Intel's chip signals the direction personal computers are likely to take over the next decade.

title: More Bank Disclosure Urged
description: The Comptroller of the Currency proposed a regulation today that would require national banks to make increased disclosures about their operations, including enforcement actions against them.

title: Control Data Has $255.6 Million Loss in Quarter
description: The Control Data Corporation, facing turmoil in virtually every one of its businesses, said yesterday it lost $255.6 million in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $54.5 million in the 1984 quarter. Quarterly revenues this year were $1.23 billion, compared with $1.24 billion.

title: BANK BOARD CHIEF SAID TO RESIST RESIGNATION
description: Angered by what he regards as an attempt by the White House to force him from office, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board is reassessing plans to leave voluntarily, a source close to him disclosed today.

title: MUSIC: FOLGER CONSORT
description: THE Folger Consort - resident ensemble at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington - came to Corpus Christi Church on West 121st Street Sunday afternoon, singing and playing music from 16th- and early 17th-century England and Italy. Music by Morley and Gibbons was there, as well as Robert Johnson, John Wilbye, Tobias Hume and Anthony Holborne.

description: Women undergoing operations for sterilization could be saved from unnecessary risk if doctors administered local anesthesia instead of general anesthesia, according to a study by scientists at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: ANDRES GRUENTZIG DIES IN AIR CRASH
description: Dr. Andres Gruentzig, who developed the treatment of heart disease in which a balloon is used to clear arteries of fatty deposits, died Sunday in a plane crash near here, the authorities said today. He was 46 years old.

title: DINOSAUR EXPERTS RESIST METEOR EXTINCTION IDEA
description: ONE of the most widely publicized scientific theories of recent years holds that the dinosaurs were wiped out 65 million years ago by the impact of a large meteorite. But an informal survey of vertebrate paleontologists, the leading dinosaur experts, suggests that very few have come to accept the theory.

description: The Exxon Corporation has closed its West Side Chemical Plant here following a second release of chemical vapors, and officials said today they would keep the plant closed until they were sure it could be operated without incident.

description: Hurricane Juan left at least three people dead and four missing, sank one offshore oil platform and damaged another in the Gulf of Mexico, and stranded hundreds of people today as it thrashed the Louisiana coast with winds of 85 miles per hour and waves up to 20 feet.

title: Yiddish Poetry Reading

title: IMMIGRATION BILL PITS UNIONS AGAINST WORKERS
description: To the Editor:

description: International

title: FIRST COLUMBIA FEDERAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Sensible Deficit Dithering
description: President Reagan accuses Congress of ''inexcusable dithering and delay'' over the bill to raise the national debt ceiling to $2.1 trillion. Yet now Defense Secretary Weinberger is dithering too, and with good reason.

title: UNIVERSAL FURNITURE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $369,000. c-Including tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $1,035,000 for the nine months.

title: Bear, Stearns Stock Offering
description: Bear, Stearns & Company, one of the largest private partnerships on Wall Street, today begins a previously announced public offering of its own shares at $21.50 a share.

title: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $397 million from a domestic international sales corporation adjustment.

title: SUMMCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,044,000 for the quarter and $3,058,000 for the nine months. c-Including tax credits of $621,000 for the quarter and $1,102,000 for the nine months.

title: GULF APPLIED TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Honest Finish
description: After finishing the New York City Marathon in 5 hours 24 minutes Sunday, Paddy Rossbach, who lost her left leg below the knee in a truck accident when she was 5 years old, received an award for outstanding performance from the Achilles Track Club, an organization for disabled runners. She might have also received a prize from the New York Road Runners Club, but instead she gets a tip of the cap for honesty and good sportsmanship.

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
MENGELE PAPERS GIVEN FOR NEW BOOK
description: More than 5,000 pages of letters, diaries and other writings of Dr. Josef Mengele and his protectors have been provided for a forthcoming biography of the Nazi war criminal, according to the book's authors and publisher.

title: DEL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Q&A
description: Q.

title: Business and Health;   Nursing Home Insurance
description: THE insurance industry has been studying the senior end of the actuarial tables to consider nursing home coverage for those in the fast-growing over-65 market. Prodded by Federal surveys showing overwhelming demand, Aetna, Metropolitan Life and the American Association of Retired People are experimenting with such insurance. Blue Cross and Blue Shield is also interested.

title: Simulated Microbursts
description: Researchers at Cambridge University in England have developed an ingenious laboratory simulation of the sudden wind shifts known as microbursts that often plague aircrafts in landings and takeoffs.

title: TECO ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEARNING OF HOMEWORK
description: New York City was the site of two special sporting events over the weekend - the marathon and Patrick Ewing's professional basketball debut - and television was there for both. But the gratitude one feels for being able to watch from home was tempered somewhat by the quality of the broadcasts, particulary with the Ewing game.

title: DeLorean Gets Cardiac Care
description: John Z. DeLorean was hospitalized today for an irregular heartbeat after complaining of palpitations while driving to his divorce trial here, Dr. Richard Berger of the Somerset Medical Center emergency room said. Mr. DeLorean was listed in stable condition.

title: Boston Studies Advice On Weapons at School
description: School officials who have seized four guns from students in three weeks met today to consider recommendations by a task force on school safety, including an anonymous tips program and routine locker searches.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Hawks, at Atlanta, 7:30 P.M. Neither club made the playoffs last season, but the Knicks figure to improve if they can get a quality guard to go with Patrick Ewing. The Hawks are experimenting with Dominique Wilkins at guard this year. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) Nets vs. Detroit Pistons, at Pontiac, Mich. This is the first meaningful meeting since the Nets lost to the Pistons in the first round of last season's playoffs. The Pistons got Rick Mahorn from last year's Washington Bullets and should make the playoffs again this year. They lost in the conference semifinals to Boston in six games last year, and the Celtics went on to the conference title. (Television - SportsChannel II, 7:30 P.M. SportsChannel, 11:30 P.M. tape delay. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) Mavericks vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Dallas. The Mavericks have the rookies Bill Wennington from St. John's and Uwe Blab from Indiana, but no established center. The Lakers are the defending N.B.A. champions and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is doing so well he is contemplating playing a few more years. (Television -WTBS 8 P.M.) Equestrian 102d annual National Horse Show, at Madison Square Garden, 9 A.M., 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. Opening Day. Among the highlights of the 1:30 show will be the N.Y. Police Mounted Musical Ride, and the first round of the International and Open Jumping. The Parade of International Teams Opening Ceremonies and Dressage Exhibition will be held at the evening performance.

title: NATIONAL PIZZA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Crucial Test On Gerrymandering
description: During the current Supreme Court term, a judicial earthquake may shake the foundations of American political practice more than any ruling since Baker v. Carr, which in 1962 heralded the end of rural over-representation in state legislatures and the House of Representatives.

title: BANKS OF IOWA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GERM-KILLING BLOOD AGENT IS IDENTIFIED
description: SCIENTISTS have discovered natural substances in human white blood cells that attack a wide range of germs, according to reports in the Journal of Clinical Investigation. The substances attack staphylococci and E. coli bacteria as well as some disease-causing fungi and viruses.

title: STEP-BY-STEP LEARNING RAISES SCHOOL SCORES IN JERSEY TOWN
description: Six years ago the test scores of eighth-grade public school students in this rejuvenated waterfront city were among the most dismal in the state. On the Metropolitan Achievement Test, the eighth graders were a year and a half behind in reading, a year behind in science, eight months behind in mathematics.

title: William Esty Wins Texaco Competition
description: The William Esty Company has won the competition to replace Benton & Bowles on the Texaco account for gasoline, motor oil and antifreeze advertising.

title: Witness Says He Aided Gang Because of Fear
description: A former Brinks Company security guard, testifying today at the racketeering trial of a neo-Nazi group, admitted being a racist, but he said he never would have helped the group steal $3.6 million if he had not feared for his life and the safety of his family.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: GREASE MONKEY HOLDING CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FLORENCE LUSCOMB
description: Florence Luscomb, an organizer for women's suffrage who went on to devote her life to Socialist causes, died Sunday at the Emerson Convalescent Home in Watertown, Mass. She was 98 years old.

title: Rise Forecast In Air Fares
description: World airlines, which posted their first collective profit in six years in 1984, still face a financial struggle and fares will probably go up, the International Air Transport Association said today.

title: DANCE: SALLY SILVERS AT FOLK ARTS CENTER
description: SALLY SILVERS is a wild and wacky law unto herself. And she presented a typical evening of her dance on Saturday at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. ''Extend the Wish for Entire'' started with an eight-minute solo, danced by the choreographer, that served almost as a statement of esthetics. The program then moved into a 15-part piece for Miss Silvers and her company, each dance performed to bursts of accompaniment that was for the most part as irresistibly anarchic as the dance.

title: KEYSTONE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $68,000 for the quarter and $54,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $381,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Clabir Buying All Of General Defense
description: The Clabir Corporation, a diversified holding company based in Old Greenwich, Conn., has offered to buy all shares of the General Defense Corporation it does not already own for a package of securities ''not to exceed $18 a share,'' or about $117 million. Clabir, which owns 23 percent of General Defense's 8.5 million shares, said exact terms had not been set.

title: OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Two Car Dealers to Join Yugo America's Board
description: Richard I. Loehr Jr. and Raymond Van Duren are car dealers. And, starting next month, they will also become pioneers, joining the board of Yugo America Inc.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS SETS 4.5% SHARE BUYBACK
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it would repurchase up to 10 million, or about 4.5 percent, of its common stock and make a $100 million capital contribution to Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., the company's investment banking subsidiary.

title: Sports of The Times;   Piniella Wants Yogi As Coach
description: As the Yankees' new manager, Lou Piniella intends to ask Yogi Berra to put on a pin-striped uniform again as his coach-de-camp.

title: HYDRAULIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People
description: Eli Schonberger has been named chairman and Milton Bagley president of the Pace Advertising Agency.

title: REACTIVATED HAYNES
description: One week after earning Coach Bill Parcells's praise, Jess Atkinson, the rookie place-kicker from Maryland, was waived by the Giants today. Atkinson was picked up on Sept. 17 to replace the injured Ali Haji-Sheikh, who is expected to be activated later in the week.

title: Immigration Bill Pits Unions Against Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ivory Coast's President Wins a 6th Term
description: President Felix Houphouet-Boigny has won 99 percent approval in a referendum for a sixth term, the Government announced today.

title: THEFT OF MAJOR ARTWORKS ON THE DECLINE
description: The theft of nine Impressionist paintings from the Marmottan Museum in Paris on Sunday runs counter to a trend of declining thefts of important works from major museums, art professionals and police experts said yesterday.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been adjusted to reflect acquisitions accounted for by a pooling of interests.

description: b-Net income, including net income of 31 cents per share for the cumulative effect of a change in accounting method.

title: THE MAORI RIGHTS FUROR: A QUESTION OF ANCESTRY
description: The angry words are still echoing around New Zealand's surprised and hurt white majority, a people that has prided itself on its policies of racial equality toward the indigenous Polynesian minority, the Maori.

BRITTON LEE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $177,000 for the quarter and $1,064,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $612,000 for the quarter and $1,156,000 for the 9 months.

title: BARTKOWSKI LOSES PLACE WITH FALCONS
description: One of the most celebrated careers in recent National Football League history was quietly interrupted last week, when the Atlanta Falcons put their most successful quarterback ever, Steve Bartkowski, on the injured reserve list with a bad knee.

title: SCHOOL WORKERS SHOWN AIDS FILM
description: All 946,000 of New York City's public school students were sent home early yesterday to give teachers, administrators and the other adults who serve them an opportunity to learn about AIDS.

title: Umpire Ruling by Nixon
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, acting as an arbitrator, yesterday settled a dispute between umpires and the major leagues with a decision providing a 40 percent increase in the pay umpires receive for working the two league playoff series.

title: WRECKAGE OF AIR-INDIA JET SHOWS SIGNS OF FIRE, PIERCING AND BULGES
description: The theory that an Air-India jumbo jet may have been destroyed by a bomb was strengthened over the weekend when a salvage ship retrieved additional wreckage showing signs of fire damage, investigators said yesterday.

title: FIREFIGHTERS GO ON TRIAL IN FOOD-RUN CRASH DEATH
description: A prosecutor charged yesterday that two of six New York City firefighters making a food run were criminally responsible for the death of a motorist in a collision between his car and their fire truck in Queens last year.

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROYALS INSPIRED AT RIGHT TIME
description: Somebody didn't necessarily turn the World Series around for the Kansas City Royals, but perhaps something did. Or some things - two, to be precise: ABC and Commissioner Peter Ueberroth.

DRANETZ TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: b-Including a tax credit of $622,000.

title: St. Luke's Orchestra
description: Alexander Schneider will conduct the Orchestra of St. Luke's, with the pianist Peter Serkin as guest soloist, on Thursday, Nov. 7, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. Tickets, at $17, are available at the museum box office or by mail.

title: FRENCH PRESSING HUNT FOR STOLEN ART
description: France began a worldwide search today for the nine Impressionist paintings stolen Sunday morning from the Marmottan Museum in Paris's elegant 16th Arrondissement.

title: POP: WHITNEY HOUSTON IN CARNEGIE HALL DEBUT
description: THE essence of Whitney Houston, the dazzlingly talented 22-year-old pop-soul singer whose first album has sold double platinum (two million copies), might be summed up in two lines from one of her signature songs, ''The Greatest Love of All'': ''No matter what they take from me, they can't take away my dignity.''

title: COLLEGE OPTION: BEST OF BOTH WORLDS
description: MINNEAPOLIS -

title: U.S. Envoy Arrives in Greece
description: A United States envoy arrived in Athens today for three days of talks with senior officials that are expected to concentrate on the future of American military bases in Greece. The official, Michael Armacost, arrived just hours after two cars belonging to United States military personnel were set on fire. No one asserted responsibility for the attacks but left-wing groups have made similar attacks and demanded that the American military bases be dismantled.

title: SAFECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains from security investments of $5,085,000 for the quarter and $24,255,000 for the nine months, gains on real estate in excess of current operating needs of $13,356,000 for the quarter and $14,022,000 for the nine months, a gain on real estate investments of $951,000 for the nine months, and after a loss on real estate investments of $33,000 for the quarter. c-Including gains on real estate investments of $1,205,000 for the quarter and $3,443,000 for the nine months, gains on real estate in excess of current operating needs of $2,294,000 for the quarter and $2,970,000 for the nine months, a gain on security investments of $4,194,000 for the nine months, and a nonrecurring tax credit of $14,180,000 for the quarter and the nine months, and after a loss on security investments of $7,261,000 for the quarter.

title: Raiders Win, 34-21
description: Marc Wilson picked apart a shaky San Diego secondary, and Marcus Allen ran for three touchdowns as the Los Angeles Raiders rolled to a 34-21 victory over the Chargers tonight.

title: AQUEDUCT GAINING A FOREIGN ACCENT
description: Angel Penna Sr. is running a horse named Bob Back in the $2 million Breeders' Cup Turf at Aqueduct Race Track Saturday. On paper, the horse looks good. The trainer is worried. Bob Back, who has made 20 of his 21 starts in England, France, Ireland and Italy, was flown here last month and ran an excellent second in the Man o' War Stakes on the grass, beaten just a length by Win. It all seems like a perfect setup for a foreign horse: A month here to acclimate, a prep race on American soil, and a strong effort to prove he made the transition successfully. But in the skewed world of international racing, these good portents add up to worries for Penna.

title: Low-Level Vs. Middle Salaries
description: AT a time when many middle managers are being laid off, there is a surplus of jobs at the entry level. In fact, the overabundance of middle managers and the shortage of beginners are emerging as a long-term economic problem.

title: AMERICAN HOME INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Mostly Mozart Festival Tours New York State
description: Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra yesterday started a tour of New York State that will take the group to nine cities by the end of March.

title: Bridge: Brazil and Austria Go Ahead In Opening of the Semifinals
description: Semifinal playoffs in the world team championships began here today with Brazil and Austria starting well in the open series.

title: WARNING OVER IGNORING PUPILS LIVING IN POVERTY
description: ENTHUSIASM over recent school reforms has diverted attention from the plight of students from poor and uneducated families who now make up one-third of all public school pupils. This neglect poses a threat not only to these children's lives but to the nation's future, according to a report by an educational economist.

title: MARATHON SCHEDULE CONFLICT IS POSSIBLE
description: The competition among the promoters of marathons is becoming as spirited as some of the races themselves. Big purses, incentive bonuses and a crowded schedule, said Grete Waitz - who won her seventh New York City Marathon Sunday - make it unlikely that all the top runners will face one another before the world championships, a quadrenniel event next scheduled for 1987, or the Olympic Games. That certainly will be true next fall when it appears that New York and its arch rival, the America's Marathon/Chicago, both will be held on Sunday, Nov. 2.

title: Immigration Bill Pits Unions Against Workers
description: To the Editor:

2 IMPLANT PATIENTS GIVEN HUMAN HEARTS
description: A human heart was transplanted today into a Pennsylvania man who received the Jarvik-7 artificial heart five days ago. The man, Thomas Gaidosh, 47 years old, of Sutersville, about 40 miles southeast of Pittsburgh, received the heart in a three-and-a-half hour operation that began at 2:15 A.M.

title: SOUTH AFRICA FORBIDS CAPE TOWN MEETINGS BY OPPOSITION FRONT
description: The authorities said today that the United Democratic Front and more than 100 other organizations had been banned from holding meetings in Cape Town and surrounding areas.

TAX RISK FOR PARENTS IN NEW TRUSTS
description: The tax-saving devices that countless parents have used to shift income to their children would be prohibited if legislation approved over the weekend by the House Ways and Means Committee becomes law.

title: Lowered Ratings For General Foods
description: The General Foods Corporation's debt rating and those of its subsidiaries was lowered to A-1, from Aa-2, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

description: A wayward humpback whale again outmaneuvered marine biologists early today, and efforts to coax the whale back to the Pacific Ocean were temporarily suspended.

description: Just when tax legislation seemed about to become unraveled, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, apparently managed to salvage it last weekend with old-fashioned political horse-trading.

title: No Latin Loan Change
description: Western bank lending to Latin America showed no change on balance in the second quarter, the Bank for International Settlements said today.

Off the Rack, For the Lighthouse
description: They clawed, some of them feverishly, yesterday at fancy gowns, sequined handbags, fur coats and even somber three-piece suits hanging conservatively on racks.

title: PROSPECTS APPEAR GRIM FOR U.S. CHIP MAKERS
description: In the wake of hundreds of millions of dollars of losses, many of the nation's leading semiconductor makers are now admitting - in words or actions - that they have ceded to Japan the largest single slice of the industry: the standard memory chips that store data in everything from computers to video cassette recorders.

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: End-of-Year Tax Strategies
description: IN the final two months of the year, many investors pore over their portfolios with an eye to easing the bite of income taxes. One time-honored strategy is tax-loss selling, whereby losses are taken either to offset gains in other holdings or to reduce ordinary income. This year, according to some experts, taking such losses could be a timely decision.

title: E.E.C. Production
description: Industrial production in the 10-nation European Economic Community fell four-tenths of 1 percent in August from a month earlier and was up 3.3 percent from the average for 1984, the trade bloc said today. The Common Market said the decline from July represented ''a slight pause'' after moderate growth in the first half of the year.

title: Diener Builds Ties To Movies
description: AFTER having had a leading role as a taste treat favored by E.T. in the movie of the same name, Reese's Pieces had a 70 percent sales increase, which Hershey Foods considered out of this world.

title: Pentagon;   The Navy, Saving Money, Toots Its Whistle
description: In the nearly five years since John Lehman became Secretary of the Navy, he has become known for never missing an opportunity to urge Congress to put up still more money to build a 600-ship Navy.

KANSAS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARGENTINE STATE OF SIEGE: A RISK FOR ALFONSIN
description: Hours after President Raul Alfonsin imposed a state of siege on Friday, a Government official tried to explain why such drastic action was taken to keep 12 terrorist suspects in jail.

title: Pacific Merger Raises Objection
description: Three grandchildren of a former chairman of the Pacific Lumber Company, who together own 3 percent of the company's shares, said they are ''adamantly opposed'' to the $869 million merger agreement reached between Pacific's board and the Maxxam Group last Wednesday. ''The long-term value of the company's assets is substantially higher'' than Maxxam's $40-a-share offer, said Stanwood Murphy, a grandson of the former chairman, Albert S. Murphy.

title: Uganda Offers Guerrillas A High Military Post
description: Uganda announced today that it was offering the country's main guerrilla group an equal say with the army on the governing military council and vice chairmanship of the body.

title: PACIFIC TELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Uphill Battle
description: Steve Ovett describes what it was like to run uphill for 1,200 meters - about three-quarters of the race - in San Francisco's business district during the California Mile: ''I went through a stage of feeling awful to a stage of feeling terrible. Once I started to feel terrible, I was O.K.''

title: The Champion Arguer
description: This is a lawyers' town, in the sense that there are more of them here than anywhere, per capita, in the country. The estimate of the American Bar Foundation is that there are 25,465 lawyers in Washington, or about one for every 25 inhabitants.

title: Topics;   Upward Mobility Truth in Taxes
description: Congress huffs and puffs over balancing the budget. It will probably reform the tax system some day. But one thing is certain.

title: CBS PRESENTS 'INTO THIN AIR,' WITH ELLEN BURSTYN
description: ''INTO THIN AIR,'' a television movie starring Ellen Burstyn on CBS at 9 o'clock this evening, is another ''based-on-a-true-story'' project, this one about a 19-year-old student who simply disappears one fine July day while driving a van from Ottawa, Canada, to Boulder, Colo. The same story has already been the subject of a Canadian Broadcasting Corporation documentary called ''Just Another Missing Kid.'' In this instance, the adaptation from one form to another has been done with intelligence and unusual sensitivity. The Tony Ganz production - made in association with Major H Productions, written by George Rubino and directed by Roger Young - carefully avoids manufactured uplift, staying tightly focused on the more unsettling aspects of the story.

title: HERZOG CITES COLLAPSE AT PLATE
description: The St. Louis Cardinals went home with their .185 batting average today for what John Tudor said would be ''a long winter.'' And Manager Whitey Herzog, astounded at the downfall of the best offense in baseball, concluded: ''The way we hit, we couldn't beat Molly Klutz.''

title: Officer, 39, Charged In Rape of a Girl, 15
description: A 39-year-old Bronx policeman was arrested yesterday and charged with statutory rape for having sex with a 15-year-old girl, according to the Bronx District Attorney.

description: Kirk Gibson, Carlton Fisk and Donnie Moore were among 13 players who filed for free agency yesterday, the first day eligible players could submit their names.

Addenda
description: Sports Illustrated is increasing its circulation to 2.8 million, from 2.75 million, and its ad rates by 7.9 percent with the Jan. 6 issue.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ONCE people watched hemlines.

title: IN SYRIA, A LONG-HUNTED NAZI TALKS
description: A West German magazine said today that it had interviewed and photographed a Nazi war criminal in Syria, where he has reportedly been living in exile for three decades.

title: VIKTOR P. MAKEYEV, TOP SOVIET DESIGNER OF STRATEGIC MISSILES
description: Viktor P. Makeyev, chief designer of Soviet strategic missiles, died Friday, according to Soviet press reports. He was 61 years old.

title: LAWRENCE X. CUSACK
description: Lawrence X. Cusack, founding partner of the Manhattan law firm of Cusack & Stiles, died yesterday after a brief illness at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: GIRL WINS RIGHT TO A FOOTBALL TRYOUT
description: A Federal judge ruled last night that a 16-year-old Yonkers girl could not be barred under a New York State law from trying out for her high school's junior varsity football team.

title: PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $961,000, or 30 cents per share. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain of $406,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. e-After a gain of $2,103,000 from a tax credit and a Federal Home Loan Bank dividend. f-After a gain of $1,489,000 from the early extinguishment of debt and from an accounting change. The latest year's per share figure is unavailable because the company went public in February 1985.

title: OAK HILL SPORTSWEAR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $479,000 for the quarter and $703,000 for the nine months and a gain of $435,000 for the quarter and the nine months on the sale of business and related assets. c-Net income.

title: A.T.&T. Unit Gets Union Complaint
description: The Communications Workers of America filed an unfair-labor-practice charge against AT&T Information Systems in an effort to stop the American Telephone and Telegraph Company subsidiary from laying off some 24,000 employees. The union's president, Morton Bahr, said the formal complaint, filed with the National Labor Relations Board regional office in Newark, sought an injunction blocking the layoffs.

title: Greyhound Net Declines 35.1%
description: The Greyhound Corporation today reported a 35.1 percent drop in its third-quarter profit to $27.4 million, or 56 cents a share, from $42.2 million, or 87 cents a share, a year before.

title: IT'S PALM BEACH IN NEW YORK - BRIEFLY
description: THE Palm Beach All-Stars brought their money and glitter to town the other night, and players from Newport, Saratoga, Southampton and the Upper East Side eagerly turned out to celebrate.

title: STAGE: 'EYES OF AMERICAN'
description: IN his play ''Home,'' Samm-Art Williams revealed a natural theatrical exuberance and an ability to treat a serious subject - in this case, the black revolution in America - in vivid, personal terms. As he chronicled the often comic travails of his hero, Cephus Miles, he set him within the background of his turbulent times.

title: Survivor of Titanic Backs Bill To Safeguard Historic Wreck
description: Louise Pope, who was 4 years old when she was rescued from the sinking Titanic in 1912, told a Congressional committee today that she did not want the liner's wreck used for commercial gain.

title: Topics;Flukes Oil Leak
description: President Reagan's decision to authorize limited exports of Alaskan oil opens a small but welcome crack in a self-defeating barrier. Export control legislation empowers him to release oil from the Cook Inlet pool, near Anchorage. That isn't much - 60,000 barrels a day, at most - when compared with the 1.6 million barrels pumped from Alaska's North Slope each day. Exports from the North Slope, however, require Congressional as well as executive approval.

title: F.C.C. Postpones Action on Murdoch's TV Deal
description: The Federal Communications Commission today postponed final action on the proposed acquisition by Rupert Murdoch of six of the seven television stations owned by Metromedia Radio and Television Inc.

title: CHARLES DOUGLAS-HOME, 48, EDITOR OF TIMES OF LONDON
description: Charles Douglas-Home, the editor of The Times of London, died yesterday of cancer. He was 48 years old.

title: A.T.&T. AND UNION BARGAIN ON JOB REDUCTION
description: Negotiators for the Communication Workers of America began talks here today with the Information Systems division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in an effort to avert a strike over the company's decision to eliminate 24,000 jobs.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY AT CITY CENTER
description: THE Joffrey Ballet was in a genial mood on Sunday afternoon at the City Center Theater. The program consisted of three carefree pieces and the company danced them with brio.

title: Velikovsky's Precursor In Comet Cataclysms
description: To the Editor:

title: POLLS COMPARE JOURNALISTS' AND PUBLIC VIEWS
description: Newspaper journalists consider themselves more accurate and unbiased than does the public, but they share many of the public's concerns about how newspapers do their job, according to a survey of newspaper reporters, editors and other newsroom employees released here today.

title: SEOUL ARRESTS 26 IN SECURITY CASE
description: The South Korean authorities, extending a crackdown on political dissidents, today announced the arrest of 26 people accused of inciting anti-Government protests by students and workers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;New York Stars
description: They didn't get to show their stuff in postseason play, but in the opinion of 117 baseball writers and broadcasters, Dwight Gooden, the pitcher who won 24 games for the Mets, and Don Mattingly, the first baseman who drove in 145 runs for the Yankees, were the top players during the 1985 season. In balloting conducted by The Associated Press for an all-star team, Gooden got 114 votes and Mattingly got 107 to lead all other players. In the balloting by position, the closest race was for manager, with Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals edging Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, 44-42.

title: TV REVIEW;'MAX HEADROOM SHOW'
description: THE zaniest and most inventive television character to pop up in many a season can be found on a pay-cable series called ''The Max Headroom Show,'' which can be sampled on Cinemax tonight at 7:30. Max Headroom is what somebody diplomatically refers to as a ''computer-generated geek'' who serves as the two-dimentional host of a music-video interview show. Among other things, he officiates over a game called ''Emotional Outburst,'' in which the winner can receive a country. ''Tonight'' Max promises maliciously, ''it's France.''

title: Japanese Bank Plans To Issue Bonds in U.S.
description: In another effort to raise the value of the yen, the Government-owned Japan Development Bank today announced that it would issue $200 million of seven-year bonds in New York next month.

title: About Real Estate;Jersey University Adding To Its Corporate Campus
description: The concept of a corporate campus seems to fit Fairleigh Dickinson University well. This large private institution in New Jersey has entrepreneurship built into its history. It was founded by a successful immigrant-scholar, sponsored by a wealthy local industrialist and is located, in part, on the estate of a turn-of-the-century capitalist.

title: Advertising; Needham Harper N.Y. Names Creative Head
description: Carleton E. Vanderwarker, known as Tony to the troops, is saying farewell to the Chicago office of Needham Harper Worldwide, and hello to the New York operation where he will be creative chieftain.

title: BRITAIN FAILS TO WIN SPACE-ARMS PLEDGE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and his British counterpart, Michael Heseltine, failed today to reach agreement on terms that would commit Britain to participation in the Reagan Administration's research program for a space-based missile defense.

title: 3 AIDS DOCTORS SEE SOME HOPE IN NEW THERAPY
description: Three French doctors said today that a new treatment might prevent the progression of the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. But their announcement, at a news conference here, was quickly criticized by other AIDS researchers in France and the United States, who called it premature and ''irresponsible.''

title: AROUND THE WORLD;General Doe Is Winner In Liberian Election
description: Maj. Gen. Samuel K. Doe won the presidency of Liberia and his party swept the legislature in this country's first multiparty election, the election commission announced today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Honors for a Jazzwoman
description: I once received the greatest compliment from a man,'' said Marian McPartland, the jazz pianist. ''He said, 'You must not be a respectable woman if you can play the piano like that.' ''

title: PHILADELPHIA FIRE AIDE TELLS OF ROLE AT CONFRONTATION SITE
description: The Fire Commissioner said today that he considered Police Commissioner Gregore J. Sambor to be in charge of operations at the May 13 confrontation with the radical group Move, which resulted in bombing of the headquarters and a fire.

title: KOHLBERG RAISES BEATRICE BID TO $47
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York investment house, said yesterday that it was raising its offer to buy the big Chicago food producer, Beatrice Companies, to $47 a share, or $5.8 billion.

title: Wynegar Tests Free-Agent Market
description: Butch Wynegar, one of three Yankees eligible for free agency, placed his name on the list yesterday along with eight other players, including Don Sutton, Al Oliver and three members of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: JEFFERSON'S? MAYBE
description: A CACHE of more than a dozen bottles of wine thought to have belonged to Thomas Jefferson, a connoisseur of fine Bordeaux, has been found in Paris. One, a Chateau Lafite vintage-dated 1787, is to be auctioned in London on Dec. 5. Two others, 1784 and 1787 Chateau d'Yquem, have been drunk.

title: Michigan Gets Top Ranking
description: Michigan and Florida exchanged last week's positions as the Wolverines took over the top spot in The New York Times's computer football ranking. Page B8.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: RAIL UNION AGREES TO JOB REDUCTION
description: Members of the United Transportation Union have ratified a contract covering 68,000 railroad employees that includes gradually eliminating 8,000 jobs, the union said today.

title: Market Place;Maytag Stock At New Highs
description: SHARES of the Maytag Company, whose dishwashers and major kitchen appliances are familiar to millions of households, sold at a record high of 65 yesterday and closed at 63 3/4, up 1/2, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TAMING OF CURRENCIES IS PICKING UP SUPPORT
description: Worldwide concern over the ups and downs of the American dollar and its impact on the livelihood of all countries has set in motion a multinational effort to reimpose some form of government control over currencies, according to international economists.

title: Texas Air Earnings Climb Sharply
description: The Texas Air Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter income more than doubled to $68.8 million, or $3.85 a share, from $30.2 million, or $1.94 a share, a year ago. Revenue totaled $541.2 million, up 40 percent from $386.5 million a year ago.

title: DEFENSE CHALLENGES WITNESS ON STEWART CHOKING THEORY
description: Defense attorneys in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart sought yesterday to discredit the testimony of the Chief Medical Examiner of Massachusetts, who said Mr. Stewart died of asphyxia from pressure on his neck.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VIOLINIST Not all great violinists hail from Odessa but sometimes it seems easier to name those who do than those who don't. Among the Odessans, the name of Nathan Milstein is one of the most luminous. The violinist turned 80 last year, and his 70 years of virtuosity lead him, once again, to Carnegie Hall, where tonight at 8 he will be giving his only New York recital this season.

title: MASSACHUSETTS CURB
description: The State of Massachusetts yesterday signed a consent order with E. F. Hutton that bars the brokerage house from selling any new public limited partnerships in the state through the rest of the year.

title: CARTWRIGHT'S FOOT FOUND TO BE FRACTURED AGAIN
description: Just hours before tonight's game against the Atlanta Hawks, the Knicks received some disheartening news. They learned that Bill Cartwright, the center who missed all of last season with a fractured left foot, would be sidelined for another four weeks - and possibly much longer - because X-rays taken Monday revealed that he refractured the foot in an exhibition game.

title: DEMOCRATS WOULD EXEMPT THE POOR FROM BUDGET AX
description: Democratic leaders in the House said today that they would propose to exempt programs for the poor from the automatic spending cuts in the Senate-passed plan to balance the budget by 1991.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Renewed agreement with Buffalo Bisons, Class AAA affiliate. Announced that Joe Nossek, first-base coach, will become a major-league scout.

title: TABLE MANNERS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT;INNOVATION FOR POTATOES
description: I USED to think that among all vegetables, potatoes were the most forgiving of careless cooks. If you left them in the oven 15 minutes too long, for example, no great harm would be done. And it really didn't matter whether you baked them in an electric, gas or microwave oven. A baked potato always comes out tasting the same, doesn't it?

title: $75 Million Issue Of Hawaii Bonds
description: A $75 million issue of Hawaii general obligation bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Mexico City Is Jarred By 25-Second Tremor
description: A strong tremor lasting about 25 seconds struck Mexico City today, shaking loose debris from the earthquake last month and prompting some people to run into the streets.

title: U.S. Metals Plant
description: The U.S. Metals Refining Company plant employing 700 people here will close by the end of next year, the company's parent corporation has announced. Operating losses and a depressed smelting and refining industry in the United States led to the closing of the plant, which had been in operation since 1902, according to a spokesman for Amax Inc., the parent. The Carteret plant is a secondary refiner of copper and precious metals. Howard Anastasi, a spokesman for U.S. Metals, said Monday that the company planned to begin layoffs in May but would continue operating a specialty metals unit employing 60 people at Carteret.

title: Bhutto Daughter to Be Freed
description: Pakistani police sources said today that Benazir Bhutto, an opposition leader, was expected to be freed from house arrest in a few days so that she can go to France to testify at an inquiry into the death of her brother, Shahnawaz, who died in July in Cannes.

title: ROCKWELL INDICTMENT IS SEEN
description: The Federal Government is about to announce criminal indictments for reported overcharges on military work at a Rockwell International Corporation factory in Texas, a source close to the investigation said today.

title: Robert E. Chambliss, Figure in '63 Bombing
description: Robert Edward Chambliss, the Alabama Ku Klux Klansman who was convicted of murder in the 1963 bombing of a Birmingham church that killed four black girls, died yesterday in a hospital in Birmingham. He was 81 years old and had a history of heart problems. The dynamite bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church on a Sunday morning, Sept. 15, 1963, was one of the most infamous incidents of racial violence in that era of the civil rights movement. Mr. Chambliss, a truck driver for an auto parts company, joined the Klan in 1924 at the age of 20 and was known as ''Dynamite Bob.'' In 1977 he was convicted of the murder of only one of the four girls. She was Denise McNair, the 11-year-old daughter of Christopher McNair, then a Birmingham photographer and today a member of the State Legislature. The other victims were Carole Robertson, Cynthia Wesley and Addie Mae Collins, all 14. At least four other Klansmen were identified as suspects in the bombing, but none were ever indicted for the crime. John Hale, a spokesman for the Alabama Department of Corrections, said Mr. Chambliss was taken Monday to the Lloyd Nolan Hospital and Health Center from the St. Clair Correctional Facility in Springville, Ala., where he was serving a life sentence. An autopsy will be performed, he said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Beverly Enterprises, Pasadena, Calif., said it had agreed to establish a joint venture in Japan with Shimizu Construction Co. to provide retirement living in Tokyo. Eventually, the companies plan to expand into long-term nursing care and home health services.

title: Topics;Flukes Landmark
description: A long time ago a New York woman lived for six months in the rear basement room of an old Greenwich Village house. There was little light and less heat, and much flooding when it rained. The kitchen sink was also the tub, and the toilet was in the hall.

title: Banks Wary of 3d-World Lending Plan
description: Commercial banks want the United States and other creditor governments to lend more money to developing countries before the banks commit themselves to making the additional loans proposed by Washington, a spokesman for the banks said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Institute * of Beneficial Certified National Public Bank of Accountant Wilmington s has , Del., a elected to subsidiary its board of the

title: RALLY BY BUINS SETS BACK DEVILS
description: Ken Linseman of the Boston Bruins made up more than enough for his momentary loss of temper and display of impoliteness to the referee tonight in the game against the Devils.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Looking to the Future
description: The television commercials seem to be promoting Queens, with their rosy, upbeat themes of ''something is happening in Queens'' and ''the future is Queens.''

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: Net Income Percent Change

title: ILLEGAL WORKERS AS DOMESTICS: UNEASY ALLIANCE
description: BY late morning the Pavillion Agency on East 40th Street is crowded with women seeking positions as nannies, housekeepers and live-in companions. Waiting, filling out forms, they confer quietly in the accents of such places as Jamaica, Guyana and Trinidad. Many of the women are in the United States on visitors' visas that explicitly forbid them to work. But the employment agency has no trouble placing them, for housekeepers are in short supply and, under Federal law, placing or employing an illegal worker carries no penalty.

title: NAVY SECRETARY, CRITICIZING PLEA, CONTRADICTS U.S. ON SPYING CASE
description: The Secretary of the Navy tonight sharply criticized the Justice Department's decision to arrange a plea bargain with John A. Walker Jr., saying the information Mr. Walker could provide about his spying for the Soviet Union would be of little value to the Government.

title: DUARTE AND DAUGHTER: HAS THE DRAMA JUST BEGUN?
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte's long struggle for the release of his kidnapped daughter ended last Thursday as she rushed from a helicopter to her parents and children, waiting on a lawn in pouring rain. It was a public occasion, recorded by a glut of cameras.

title: Coke Bottlers Pursue Suit
description: Forty bottlers suing the Coca-Cola Company because of a pricing dispute have asked a Federal judge to declare that the secret syrups used in Coke and Diet Coke are identical and should cost the same.

title: SCOUTING;A Legend Once, But Not Twice
description: Last April, Mickey Wright and Kathy Whitworth, two of the greatest players in the history of women's golf, became the first of their sex to compete on an equal footing against men in a sanctioned tour event. Hitting off the same tees as their rivals at the Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf in Austin, Tex., the pair of history-makers created an additional sensation by opening with a five-under-par 65, then faded a bit to 275 and a tie for 19th in the 28-team better-ball field. The publicity was bountiful, the response generally warm. ''I never heard a gallery pull for me like this before,'' Miss Wright said before leaving Austin.

title: CREDIT MARKET;PRICES SOAR IN SALE BY TREASURY
description: Note and bond prices rose sharply yesterday, as the long-awaited sale of new Treasury issues this week attracted many investors who had been on the sidelines since the previous major Treasury financing in early August.

title: The News Conference, Soviet Style
description: That great Washington institution, the news conference, has come of age here in Moscow, complete with many a free-wheeling Washington twist, but not too many.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN ZULU OFFICIAL SLAIN
description: Blacks set fire to the home of a black legislator from the Zulu homeland today and then shot him dead as he fled the blaze. Four other people were also reported killed in anti-apartheid rioting around the country.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IT wasn't so long ago that leukemia was an almost certain death sentence, often within a few months of its discovery. Little could be done for victims, about half of whom were children.

title: Travelers Reports Gain
description: The Travelers Corporation reported today that its net income rose 2.9 percent to $81.7 million in the third quarter of 1985, compared with $79.4 million in the same quarter of 1984. Revenue of $3.9 billion increased 8 percent from $3.6 billion in the same period a year ago. With more common shares outstanding this year, per-share earnings dropped to 89 cents, from 94 cents a year ago. Operating earnings rose 7 percent, to $86.1 million in the 1985 quarter, compared with $80.4 million in the third quarter of 1984. ''Catastrophe losses, due largely to hurricanes Elena and Gloria, had a major effect on the third quarter,'' Edward H. Budd, chairman of the insurance company, said.

title: BRIEFING;Destination St. Louis
description: The Reagan Administration's chief tax specialist and negotiator on tax legislation, Ronald A. Pearlman, plans to leave his job by the end of the year, so someone new will have to press the case for tax revision in Congress in 1986. Mr. Pearlman, whose title is Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy, said that when he first came to town in 1983 he made it clear he would stay no more than two years.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, one line was omitted from the fifth paragraph of an article in Science Times yesterday about the relation between emotions and health. The paragraph should have read: ''Opponents of the editorial's view also point to a major article that appeared the next month in an equally respected publication, The Lancet, the British medical journal. The article reviewed studies linking psychological factors and disease and concluded, in contrast to The New England Journal's editorial, that counseling and psychological support may be as important as many medical measures.''

title: COSBY' PRODUCERS PLAN 2 SIMILIAR TV SERIES
description: The producers of ''The Cosby Show,'' the prime-time situation comedy that more American families watch than any other, are attempting to cash in on their success with two new shows that use similar ingredients.

title: Advertising; Bulova Watch Decides To Use Only Radio Ads
description: The Bulova Watch Company, which used both spot television and magazines for last year's advertising program, will now be totally in radio, starting this week.

title: Chess Game Put Off At Kasparov's Request
description: Gary Kasparov, who is leading 11 to 9 in the world chess championship match, took a timeout today that postponed the 21st game against the current champion, Anatoly Karpov.

title: SENATE PANEL CONSIDERS BILL TO TAX AUDIO TAPES
description: A Senate subcommittee is scheduled to hold hearings today on a bill that would place a surcharge on audio tape cassettes and recorders. The legislation, known as the Home Audio Recording Act, could generate more than $100 million a year to compensate copyright holders for royalties lost when music is taped privately.

title: Thomson-CSF To Buy Mostek
description: The Mostek Corporation, the financially troubled subsidiary set to be closed by the United Technologies Corporation, said yesterday that a preliminary agreement had been reached under which Mostek would be bought by Thomson-CSF, the giant French electronic and electrical company. Terms were unavailable.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK;WINTER AT HAND, MIGRATION TO THE FURRIER BEGINS
description: The New York woman,'' said Beverly Stein, tossing off a raccoon coat and slipping into a silver fox in the showroom, ''is the queen of the fur-bearing kingdom.'' And when the weather turns cold, as it has the last few days, there is no ensuing dormancy in the species, no thought of retiring to a cave or of burying oneself in a muddy pond bottom for the winter.

title: 4-DAY GALA TO HONOR MISS LIBERTY AT 100
description: A four-day extravaganza of concerts, tall ships, ethnic festivals and fireworks will celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty the next Fourth of July weekend, the sponsors of the festivities announced yesterday.

title: NOW THAT THE CHILDREN ARE GONE
description: WELL, it is done. This year at last my two children are in college, enrolled, oriented, settled into freshman dormitories at opposite ends of the continent - he on a small, maple-shrouded quadrangle in Vermont, she on a bustling, urban California campus, where the eucalyptus-scented fog drifts into her window with the sounds of the city. I wonder if, like me, they have slept fitfully these last few weeks - if they, too, are weary from the long journey to where we three are now, a bit stunned at having - finally, it seems -arrived, and still wondering what happens next.

title: Advertising; Evolution Of a Firm On Coast
description: JUST because he's now an ad biggie in Los Angeles doesn't mean that Leonard Pearlstein has forgotten the glories of Gotham that he learned firsthand in the 1960's working for Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn and then Papert, Koenig, Lois, an agency now gone but not forgotten.

title: AIDS AND THE STATE
description: New York State's new policy on AIDS was as much a political decision as a scientific one, intended in part to create the impression that Governor Cuomo had taken a tough but medically sound approach to one of most delicate and least approachable issues of our time, in the view of many public officials and homosexual activists.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;The Parade Is On
description: Footnote: the Greenwich Village Halloween Parade, which faced cancellation for want of a $5,000 insurance premium, has been rescued by the Association for a Better New York, which paid for the policy.

title: Wien Chapter 11 Filing
description: New Wien Airlines has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Fedzation under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code, seeking protection from its creditors for the second time within a year. The low-cost carrier, which flies between Anchorage, Seattle and Reno, was grounded on Friday after its operating permit was revoked by the Transporation Department. In documents filed Monday in Federal Bankruptcy Court, the carrier listed assets of $3.5 million and debts of about $3 million.

title: P.S.C. Hearing Officer Backs Lilco Rate Rise
description: A State Public Service Commission hearing officer recommended today that the Long Island Lighting Company get the full 3.8 percent, or $68.7 million, electric rate increase it has requested.

title: ADMITTED MEMBER OF MAFIA TELLS OF OATH AND DEADLY PUNISHMENT
description: An admitted Mafia member who turned informer testified yesterday about the strict rules, sacred oath and deadly punishment imposed by the secretive organization.

title: SCOUTING;A Third Assist
description: When Barry Beck of the Rangers scored the winning goal Sunday night in a 2-1 victory over Boston, Reijo Ruotsalainen and Don Maloney got assists. Jerry Maloney (a distant cousin to Don) didn't get anything, but he should have.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Comings and Goings
description: Marion Barber, the Jet fullback, and Lance Mehl, the linebacker, who suffered rib injuries in the victory over the Seattle Seahawks, were listed as questionable for Sunday's game against the Colts after X-rays showed that Barber had sustained a slight rib fracture and that Mehl had suffered cartilage damage. . . . Tony Bruin, a former Syracuse basketball star, was being sought by the police in Syracuse after being accused of selling $110 worth of cocaine to an undercover agent last April. . . .

title: HOOVER ACCEPTS NEW OFFER
description: The Chicago Pacific Corporation signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire the Hoover Company, the 90-year-old concern whose name has become synonymous with vacuum cleaners, in a deal worth about $550 million.

title: JURISDICTION IN HIJACKING CASE IS EXPECTED TO GO TO GENOA
description: An Italian court is expected to give magistrates in the port city of Genoa jurisdiction to investigate the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro and the killing of an American passenger, court officials said today.

title: PARIS FASHION, BEYOND CHIC, IS ALSO A MAJOR MONEYMAKER
description: Claude Montana was hot. Elisabeth de Senneville was not.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Rebels in Colombia May Free 3 Americans
description: Left-wing guerrillas have agreed to free three United States missionaries kidnapped 24 days ago in Colombia's eastern jungles and turn them over to a Government peace commission, a commission source said today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HE was going to be unavoidably late for his luncheon appointment, so Dale Remington, a television producer, telephoned the Four Seasons to warn his companion.

title: Advertising; YR Unit Parts Ways With Pacific Southwest
description: Having only recently revived the ''Catch our smile'' advertising theme for its client Pacific Southwest Airlines, the Los Angeles office of DYR has unsmilingly resigned the account.

title: MUSIC: THE SINE NOMINE SINGERS
description: BAROQUE composers found in the purported Choice of Hercules - between pleasure and virtue - an appealing opportunity for contrasted characterization, and their listeners and patrons apparently found a wholesome instrument of edification. ''Hercules at the Crossroads'' was the text chosen for a cantata marking the 11th birthday of the Saxon prince Frederick Christian. In the libretto Bach set, the god Mercury advises the audience that young Frederick has already made a similar choice himself, but one cannot help suspecting that the piece was intended to set the lad an example.

title: THEATER: 'LITTLE EYOLF,' BY IBSEN, IN NEW HAVEN
description: For years, Alfred Allmers has been writing a book entitled ''The Responsibility of Man,'' a volume he is unable to complete. Allmers's title is itself a major theme of ''Little Eyolf.'' This late Ibsen drama poses essential questions, such as, does man owe his first debt to himself, his mate, his progeny or a higher moral calling?

title: Sallie Mae Reports 10 Billion Yen Loan
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association yesterday announced a 10 billion yen, seven-year loan from a 17-member syndicate led by the Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance Company.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Immune System Flaws Are Found at Bhopal
description: Many survivors of the Union Carbide pesticide gas leak in Bhopal suffered chromosomal changes and damage to their immune systems, the head of a Government study into the tragedy said today.

title: R. HART PHILLIPS, TIMES REPORTER WHO COVERED CASTRO'S REVOLUTION
description: Ruby Hart Phillips, a correspondent for The New York Times who covered the the rise of Fidel Castro, died Monday at Cape Canaveral Hospital in Cocoa Beach, Fla. She was a resident of Merritt Island and was 82 years old.

title: BRIEFING
description: In North Dakota, one out of 10 men is a member of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks. So when a North Dakotan, in this case John T. Traynor of Devils Lake, is elected Grand Exalted Ruler of the Elks, the entire Congressional delegation of two Senators and one Representative is impelled to hold a Capitol Hill reception in his honor. And tonight the hosts are Senators Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat, and Mark Andrews, Republican, and Representative Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat.

title: 6 MINOR PARTIES OFFER NOMINEES IN MAYOR'S RACE
description: Voting machines in New York City will not be that crowded with candidates next Tuesday, but there is a bit of a traffic jam on the upper right side of the machines.

title: WASHINGTON;Shultz to Moscow
description: President Reagan will celebrate the first anniversary of his re-election on Nov. 6.
