A couple of days earlier, Secretary of State Shultz will be in Moscow to set the agenda for the Reagan-Gorbachev Geneva summit meeting on Nov. 19 and 20, a meeting that could have an important bearing on the historical record of Mr. Reagan's Presidency.

title: BRIEFING;In Behalf of Peace
description: The State Department is strengthening its efforts to promote peace talks in the Middle East by naming Wat T. Cluverius 4th, now consul general in Jerusalem, as a senior adviser to Robert W. Murphy, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs who made a flying trip to Jordan last week as a special envoy.

title: RADAR MONITORING AT ISSUE IN CRASH
description: The meteorologist assigned to monitor weather radar for the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport was at dinner when Delta Flight 191 crashed in a heavy thunderstorm in August, killing 137 people, a Federal official testified today.

title: U.S. REVIEWS ABOUT GANDHI SEEM MIXED
description: It was his United Nations debut, and although Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi charmed his audiences with his open manner and witty one-liners, he also showed he still had much to learn.

title: Berkshire to Buy Scott & Fetzer
description: The Scott & Fetzer Company, which last month dropped a leveraged buyout attempt, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Berkshire Hathaway Inc. for $60 a share, or a total of about $400 million.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: WEALTHY JAPAN'S SPARTAN STYLE
description: Japan is a wealthy nation whose citizens do not enjoy many of the amenities of wealth.

title: David John Rose, 63, Is Dead; Nuclear Researcher at M.I.T.
description: Dr. David John Rose, a professor of nuclear engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died of emphysema Thursday at Mt. Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 63 years old and had lived in Honolulu since January. Professor Rose was internationally known as a researcher, teacher and consultant on fusion, plasma physics, energy and nuclear-waste disposal. He was also noted for his work on peace and disarmament issues and the ethical implications of scientific advances. Dr. Rose joined the nuclear engineering facultty at M.I.T. in 1958 and played a key role in organizing its research and teaching on controlled thermonuclear fusion science and technology. In a two-year leave of absence starting in 1969, Dr. Rose founded the office of long-range planning at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Dr. Rose also advised the governments of Brazil, Britain and West Germany on fusion technology. A native of Victoria, British Columbia, Dr. Rose served as a captain in the Canadian artillery in World War II. He is survived by his wife, the former Renate Papke, and three children by a previous marriage, Elizabeth, Hugh and Andrew.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. When the teams met Saturday in Indianapolis, the Nets suffered a loss that was doubly disappointing because it followed their opening game, overtime victory over the Boston Celtics. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.). Boxing James Pipps vs. Carmelo Negron, at Atlantic City, Harrah's Marina Hotel and Casino, superbantamweights, 10 rounds, and Evander Holyfield vs. Jeff Meachum, cruiserweights, 8 rounds. First preliminary 8 P.M. Pipps, from Vidor, Tex., has a 27-1 record, with 22 knockouts. Negron, from Brooklyn, is 19-5, with 19 knockouts. Holyfield, from Atlanta, who lost his chance at an Olympic gold medal on a technical disqualification, is 6-0 as a pro, with 3 knockouts. Meachum, from Clear Lake, Tex., is 10-2, with 6 knockouts. Jamey Ollenberger vs. Juan Ramon Santana, at Las Vegas, Nev., at the Showboat Hotel and Casino, for the ESPN junior-welterweight title, 12 rounds. Ollenberger, from Vancouver, British Columbia, is 16-1-1, with 8 knockouts. Santana, from Camden, N.J., is 15-3, with 11 knockouts. (Television -ESPN, 9 P.M.). Equestrian 102d Annual National Horse Show, at Madison Square Garden, 9 A.M., 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. Highlights of the second day of competition are the New York City Mounted Police musical ride, the Three-Gaited Horse and Five-Gaited Mare Stakes. The evening program features the $10,000 International Jumping Nations Cup, the polo competition and a dressage exhibition. Other Events HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. Garden State, Cherry Hill, N.J., 8 P.M. SOCCER: City College at York, 3 P.M. Long Island University at Marist, 2:30 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. The $60,000 added East View for 2-year-old, New York-bred fillies at a mile is the feature (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M.). The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Network, midnight). VOLLEYBALL: City University of New York women's championships at the Hunter College subterannean sportsplex, 68th Street and Lexington Avenue, 4 P.M. City College is the defending champion, but Hunter is 29-2 and ranked No. 9 in the state, and 5-0 in the conference.

title: STATE CREATES EQUINE HISTORY
description: Ten officials of New York state agencies and racing organizations appeared before three reporters at a news conference yesterday to reveal that Governor Cuomo has issued an executive order proclaiming Saturday as ''Breeders' Cup Day.''

title: TENTATIVE STAGE PACT REACHED
description: Agreement on a three-year contract for Broadway stagehands -with no salary increase in its first year - has been reached by negotiators for Local 1 of the International Association of Theatrical and Stage Employees and the League of American Theaters and Producers.

title: Extra $2 Million Set for PGA Tour
description: Golfers on the PGA Tour will compete all year for a share of $2 million in bonus money starting with the 44-tournament circuit of 1986. The top individual prize will be $500,000 in addition to what that golfer wins in purse money during the year.

title: HARALD INGHOLT
description: Harald Ingholt, professor emeritus of archeology at Yale University, died Monday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 89 years old. A member of the Yale faculty from 1942 until his retirement in 1964, Professor Ingholt was best known for his archeological work in Gandhara, in what is now Pakistan, and in ancient cities of Syria.

title: THEATER: A FIRST PLAY, 'YOU BELONG TO ME,'
description: ON an otherwise deserted railway station in France sits a middle-aged civil servant reading Le Figaro. A woman appears. She says she is bound for a nearby town but then shows no great urgency about getting there even as night draws on. She is childlike and rather exotic, possibly a bit dotty. The man is annoyed by her chatter but also uncomfortably attracted.

title: U.S. HAILS VISA FOR SAKHAROV'S WIFE
description: The United States said today that it welcomed the reported decision by the Soviet Union to allow the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov to go abroad for medical treatment. It also called on Moscow to end Dr. Sakharov's own exile in the city of Gorky.

title: Come On, Japan, Live Better!
description: America buys $40 billion more from Japan than it sells there, but that, Japanese policy makers say, has little to do with protectionism. The real cause is the torrent of foreign capital being sucked into the American economy.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Rio Algom Chairman Confident About Future
description: October began on a promising note for George R. Albino, chairman and chief executive of Rio Algom Ltd., the Canadian mining company that early this month started production at the only mine in North America whose main product is tin.

title: NETS OVERWHELMED BY PISTON SHOOTER
description: Several times after a Detroit Piston basket tonight, the announcer would say: ''Laimbeer from Tripucka'' or ''Tripucka from Laimbeer.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph yesterday with an article about the Maoris in New Zealand was published in error. It showed Peter Tapsell, a British politician, not the Peter Tapsell who is New Zealand's Internal Affairs Minister.

title: OPERA: 'PORGY' RETURNS
description: WHEN George Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess'' entered the Metropolitan Opera repertory for the first time last February, it provoked all manner of learned debates as to just what it was: opera? inflated musical? loving portrayal? racist caricature? all of the above?

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;Turning Point
description: The name of the reporter doesn't matter. We were sitting in the press box waiting for the other shoe to fall on the Kansas City Royals last Thursday night.

title: 9 Writers Nominated For 1985 Book Awards
description: Nine writers have been nominated for the 1985 American Book Awards in three categories:

title: INDIA A YEAR LATER: GANDHI LEAVING HIS MARK
description: The assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi a year ago Thursday stunned India and raised the question of what life would be like without the woman who dominated national politics for nearly two decades.

title: 63D ST. TUNNEL DECLARED SOUND BY A CONSULTANT
description: There are no major structural problems in the 63d Street subway tunnel, according to the final report from a consultant hired by the Transit Authority to evaluate the trouble-ridden project.

title: REAPING WILD RICE BY MACHINE OR HAND
description: UNTIL recently, the harvesting of wild rice presented a romantic picture: two Indians in a canoe on a Minnesota lake, the one poling the craft through the water, the other shaking the seeds off the tops of plants and into the canoe. Today, little of that picture obtains.

title: PEOPLE REST
description: As rescue money ran low and frustration ran high, a wayward humpback whale splashed in the Sacramento River today, eluding rescuers trying to attach a transmitter that would enable them to keep tabs on its movements.

title: XEROX AND MANVILLE REPORT LOSSES
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday a loss of $15 million in the third quarter after the inclusion of two charges taken in connection with its insurance operations.

title: LABOR RESOLUTION CRITICIZES U.S. ROLE IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Delegates to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention today passed a resolution saying that ''a negotiated settlement, rather than a military victory, holds the best hope'' for achieving peace and democracy in Nicaragua and El Salvador.

title: In New York at Least, Sentencing Process Is Not Always Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: POP/JAZZ;BRASS TACKS TO DEBUT
description: MORE and more women are becoming leaders of jazz ensembles. Toshiko Akiyoshi, who has been leading a big band since 1972 and, by virtue of this, has become the grande dame of the field, was leading her band at the Blue Note last Monday night; Kit McClure, who formed a big band four years ago, leads an octet drawn from her full ensemble every Monday night at Joanna, 18 East 18th Street, and next Monday Amy Duncan will introduce a basically brass group (seven brass, three rhythm) called Brass Tacks at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: The Meat We Eat Throughout most of this century, American consumers have been able to rely on what is one of the world's safest supplies of meat and poultry. The Federal Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service sets the standards for other nations. But is it safe enough?

title: Economic Scene;Japan's Effort To Bolster Yen
description: THE Japanese Government, seeking to parry the threat of protectionist measures against its exports to the United States, is pushing up the value of the yen to make Japanese goods dearer and American goods cheaper.

title: TEST VOTE SIGNALS SENATE TRUCE ON SHIPPING ISSUE
description: The Senate today signaled strong support for a compromise proposal that would resolve a bitter and long-standing dispute between the agricultural and shipping industries over how American farm products are transported abroad.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 30, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BRIEFING;In Behalf of Books
description: Books by and about members of Congress, their triumphs over political odds and their solutions for world problems drop off the presses every week or two and are baptized by friends of the author over drinks and soggy canapes in a House committee room in late afternoon.

title: Advertising; Agency for U.S. Work Tapped by Kosta Boda
description: Kosta Boda, the Swedish maker of quality crystal, has assigned its account for advertising in the United States and Sweden to Hall, Cederquist & Sundberg, a Swedish agency in New York.

title: THE TWO-TIER WAGE IMPACT
description: It's strictly no frills,'' said the tall young man of his problems living on a $784-a-month salary in New York as a new Pan Am flight attendant. Had he joined the airline before Sept. 1, when the current contract went into effect, he would have earned $1,120 a month, a healthy 30 percent more.

title: Of Course It Does
description: Dear Buck, Harry, Cal and Jimbo:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1985
description: International

title: DeWitt John Is Dead at 70; Ex-Christian Science Editor
description: DeWitt John, former editor of The Christian Science Monitor and a member of board of the Christian Science Church, died last Tuesday while vacationing with his wife in Evora, Portugal. He was 70 years old. He was editor of The Monitor from 1964 to 1970, when the newspaper won three Pulitzer Prizes. He joined the paper as a reporter in 1939 and later became a political reporter before being named editor. After stepping down as editor, he became a member of the church's board of directors. In 1974, Mr. John became chairman of the board, making him administrative director of the Mother Church, First Church of Christ Scientist in Boston and of the Christian Scientist denomination worldwide. Besides his wife, Morley, Mr. John is survived by two children, his mother, a brother and four grandchildren.

title: What Colorado Is Doing to Control AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: GENETIC TIE FOUND IN BACTERIA TYPES
description: Scientists have reported finding a surprisingly close genetic link between certain bacteria that cause disease in plants and others that cause illness in humans.

title: DeLorean Leaves Hospital
description: John Z. DeLorean, the automobile maker, left Somerset Medical Center in Somerville, N.J., last night where he had been in the coronary care unit. Mr. DeLorean entered the hospital Monday afternoon complaining of an irregular heartbeat. A hospital spokesman, Mrs. B. Whiteley, said Mr. DeLorean left the hospital against the advice of his cardiologist. Mr. DeLorean is in a child custody battle with his ex-wife, Christina Ferrare Thomopoulos, and will return to the hospital for further tests after a court hearing this morning.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE always been fascinated by the dishes in classic French cooking that novice cooks consider so challenging that they will not undertake their preparation without professional help. The list would include basic pates, even though a pate is nothing more than an elaborate meat loaf.

title: Chevron Net Declines 28.4%
description: The Chevron Corporation today reported a 28.4 percent drop in third-quarter earnings to $245 million, or 72 cents a share, from $342 million, or $1 a share, a year ago. Revenues dropped 28 percent, to $10.3 billion, from $14.3 billion a year ago.

title: Topics;Flukes; No Mystery
description: Every so often, for reasons unknown to humans, a group of whales beach themselves, apparently determined to die. Scientists usually try to drag them back to the ocean. It never seems to work, and even seems annoying, as if man is interfering with a mysterious ritual of nature better left alone.

title: WRITER AND SECRETARY TO TROTSKY IN MEXICO
description: Bernard Wolfe, a novelist who was a personal secretary to Leon Trotsky in Mexico for eight months in 1937, died of a heart attack Sunday in the hospital of the Motion Picture Home in Calabasas, Calif. He was 70 years old. Mr. Wolfe's best known work was ''The Great Prince Died,'' a novel published in 1959, based on the assassination of Trotsky in Mexico in 1940. The novel centers on Victor Rostov, a Russian revolutionary who was living in exile in Coyoacan, a suburb of Mexico City, and includes his feelings of guilt and the impending murder. Explaining the novel, Mr. Wolfe wrote: ''This work cannot be called history. It is, rather, a fiction based upon, derived from - dogged by, if you will - history.'' In 1955, Mr. Wolfe adapted his novel for an NBC Playhouse drama called ''Assassin.'' After ''The Great Prince Died'' went out of print, Mr. Wolfe revised the novel and retitled it ''Trotsky Dead.'' Among Mr. Wolfe's other books are ''The Late Risers,'' ''In Deep,'' ''Limbo,'' ''The Magic of Their Singing,'' ''Lies'' and ''Logan's Gone.'' With Mezz Mezzerow, he was co-author of ''Really the Blues,'' the life story of Mr. Mezzerow, the jazz musician who became a drug addict. Mr. Wolfe was born in New Haven and received a degree in psychology from Yale University in 1935. Two years later, he became Trotsky's secretary. He is survived by his wife, Dolores, and two daughters, Miranda and Jordan, of Bell Canyon, Calif.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;A $200,000 Rematch
description: Zola Budd earned $125,000 and Mary Decker Slaney $75,000 for their 3,000-meter race in London last July, according to the British Amateur Athletics Board. The race was billed as a rematch of their Olympic clash in which Mrs. Slaney fell after a tangle with Miss Budd. Mrs. Slaney won the rematch and Miss Budd finished third. Mike Turner, treasurer of the board, revealed the figures at the European Athletics Union Congress in Oslo. He said American television had provided the money, but ABC, which televised the race, denied such payments.

title: A.T. & T.'s Unix
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had signed an agreement with VMark Computer Inc. of Natick, Mass., to supply an on-line data base management system that will provide about 2,500 applications programs for A.T.&T.'s Unix-based computers. A.T.&T. has been heavily criticized because relatively few business programs run on Unix, the operating system used on A.T.&T. machines. The VMark programs are primarily for specific industries, such as accounting and hospital management, office automation and telemarketing.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Maine Governor to Run For Congress Next Year
description: Gov. Joseph E. Brennan, who is serving his second term and is ineligible for a third term, announced today that he would run for Congress in Maine's First Congressional District next year.

title: ARAFAT'S PALESTINIAN FOES SPLIT ON HOW TO CHALLENGE HIS LEADERSHIP
description: A conflict has broken out among Yasir Arafat's opponents in the guerrilla movement on ways to challenge his leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization and scuttle efforts to begin Middle East negotiations.

title: GORDON S. WHITE JR. ON COLLEGE FOOTBALL;PRESSURE MOUNTING ON FAZIO OF PITT
description: Pittsburgh's 21-7 loss at Navy last Saturday put Coach Foge Fazio of the Panthers back under more serious scrutiny by his superiors - the athletic director, Ed Bozik, and the chancellor of the university, Welsey W. Posvar. No one says Fazio is in jeopardy of being dismissed. But they say a review will be made at the end of the season.

title: Bridge: Austria and U.S. Leading In World Open Team Play
description: The likely finalists in the world open team championship beginning here Thursday are Austria and the United States. The United States women's team will face Britain in the final of their series, also to start Thursday.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy & Mather Picked For Sears Promotions
description: Sears, Roebuck in Chicago traditionally has done its own sales promotion work for its Sears Merchandising Group, made up of almost 800 stores and its catalogue operation, through its Retail Merchandising and Sales Planning Department. Now it is going to share the chores with the Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Promotions.

title: COUNTRY MUSIC: TERRY ALLEN
description: TERRY ALLEN, a songwriter and artist from Lubbock, Tex., brought his slightly skewed country songs to Dance Theater Workshop (219 West 19th Street) Monday. He is in town working on a piece for the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave series.

title: THE THEATER: 'NOWHERE' AT LA MAMA
description: ON an otherwise deserted railway station in France sits a middle-aged civil servant reading Le Figaro. A woman appears. She says she is bound for a nearby town but then shows no great urgency about getting there even as night draws on. She is childlike and rather exotic, possibly a bit dotty. The man is annoyed by her chatter but also uncomfortably attracted.

title: LED BOEING IN CRUCIAL TRANSITION
description: William M. Allen, who headed the Boeing Company in a critical transition period for the big aerospace concern, died today at his home here. He was 85 years old. Death was attributed to complications from Alzheimer's disease.

title: U.S.-E.E.C. Steel Talks
description: Willy de Clercq, the European Economic Community's External Relations Commissioner, hinted today that some progress had been made in steel talks between the United States and the 10-nation trading bloc.

title: CONCERT: TE KANAWA
description: THE news around town, in singing circles at least, is that Kiri Te Kanawa, the New Zealand soprano, has bought a house in nearby Oyster Bay and settled down among us. If so, then Sunday evening's gathering at Carnegie Hall was, if not a housewarming, at least an expression of welcome. Indeed, the audience for her recital with Martin Katz at the piano filled the seats of the hall and flowed up onto the stage around her.

title: Morris Merger Deal Expected
description: Morris Decision Systems and Computerworks Inc., two of the New York region's largest business computer retailers, are expected to announce a merger today, involving an exchange of stock and an infusion of an unspecified amount of venture capital.

title: ST. BART'S AND GROUP OF PARISHIONERS CLASH AT LANDMARK HEARING ON NEEDFOR TOWER
description: Invoking the name of God and reading from the Bible, the Episcopal Bishop of New York told the Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday that if it did not approve construction of an office tower on the Park Avenue grounds of St. Bartholomew's Church, the church would eventually be forced to close.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;MARTIN MULLS FUTURE
description: Eddie Sapir, Billy Martin's lawyer, said he spoke with Martin Monday night, and the two would talk again about what the four-time former Yankee manager wants to do in the future. ''Billy was pleased,'' Sapir said, ''that George Steinbrenner said he would like to have Billy stay with the Yankees if he didn't have any other opportunities that would make him happier.''

title: HARRY O'DONNELL, PRESS AIDE TO 4 GOVERNORS AND A MAYOR
description: Harry J. O'Donnell, a press aide and top political adviser for four New York Governors and Mayor John V. Lindsay, died of a heart attack Monday at Brookhaven (L.I.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Elmira, N.Y. Mr. O'Donnell, a former reporter, had been the most prominent government press aide in the state for nearly 30 years. He had been a top aide in 11 statewide campaigns for president, governor and senator and two New York City mayoral campaigns. Although he fervently believed that press secretaries should not upstage their political clients - ''a public-relations man should rarely be seen, and heard only indirectly,'' he said - he became as well known among politicians and reporters as many of his clients. Mr. O'Donnell, a student of history and government who knew the political history and geography of the state as few did, went considerably beyond the role of press spokesman to lay the groundwork for governmental decisions and political campaigns. He moved easily between the executive chamber in Albany and campaign headquarters in New York City. A Compiler of Statistics Every year, he compiled statistics on voter trends that were the forerunners of the data used in modern, scientific political campaigns. Mr. O'Donnell, who was born in Elmira on Oct, 9, 1914, started his 20-year newspaper career with The Elmira Advertiser in 1933 and later worked at The Elmira Star Gazette, where he rose to sports editor, The Buffalo Evening News and the Albany bureau of The Associated Press, where he eventually became bureau chief. In 1952, he was appointed press secretary to the State Comptroller, J. Raymond McGovern, but soon moved to the post of press secretary to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey. He later served as a special assistant to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and as press secretary to Gov. Malcolm Wilson. All were Republicans, but a Democrat, Gov. Hugh L. Carey, appointed Mr. O'Donnell as his communications director. Spokesman for Republicans Between governmental stints, he was the spokesman for the Republican state committee. He also served as first deputy commerce commissioner during part of the Rockefeller administration. He is survived by his wife, Alice Gaffey O'Donnell; two daughters, Ellen Williams of Brookhaven and Ann Prichard of Washington; a brother, Jerome, of Elmira, and eight grandchildren. A funeral mass will be offered Friday at 11:30 A.M. at Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Elmira.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Washington Watch column of Business Day on Oct. 21 misstated the expiration date of A.W. Clausen's five-year term as president of the World Bank. It is June 30, 1986.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Portuguese Is Asked To Form a Cabinet
description: Portugal's Social Democratic leader accepted an invitation today from President Antonio Ramalho Eanes to form the nation's 16th government since its return to democracy after the 1974 revolution.

title: DISCOVERIES;FROGS FOR WALKING, CHIC WINE COOLER, PILLOW FUN
To Reagan and Gorbachev
description: The world's highest expectations are focused on your meeting in Geneva next month. All peoples and governments hope that you will be able to stop the deepening of tensions of the last years, opening an era of peace and security for humanity.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1985
description: Companies

title: UNITED STATES RIDERS LEADING FOR TITLE
description: The United States Equestrian Team, which trailed Canada after the matinee session yesterday, came back last night to gain a 3-point lead for the international team championship of the National Horse Show, which opened its six-day run yesterday.

title: AUSTRIAN WINE CONTROLS
description: Austria's Parliament passed a strict new wine law recently as dozens of growers driving tractors tied up traffic protesting the new legislation.

title: Officer Shot to Death; Husband Being Sought
description: A Bronx police officer was shot and killed here today by her estranged husband, a New York City transit police officer, the Rockland County District Attorney said.

title: For the City Council
description: In Tuesday's election, voters will fill the 35 New York City Council seats, all now held by Democrats. Here are our recommendations in close contests, giving weight to able service by incumbents.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FERRARO: My Story. By Geraldine A. Ferraro with Linda Bird Francke. 340 pages. Bantam Books. $17.95.

title: WINE TALK
description: ANYONE who has been involved with wine for 20 years or so, making it, selling it, sounding off about it or just drinking it, remembers Dr. Salvatore Lucia. Dr. Lucia, who died in 1984 at the age of 83, had been professor of medicine and, for 26 years, chairman of the Department of Preventive Medicine at the University of California Medical Center here. An authority on diseases of the blood, he published more than 200 articles and papers on the subject. He was a linguist, a scholar and one of the first well-known authorities on the subject of health and wine.

title: REAGAN, HIS AIDES SPLIT, BACKS ATTACK ON DEFICIT
description: President Reagan today reaffirmed his formal endorsement of the Senate plan to balance the budget, despite private warnings by some key advisers that it would interrupt the Administration's military buildup.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Special Food and Throne Denied to Guru in Jail
description: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh today was refused special food and a throne that the 53-year-old guru sought to make jail comfortable while awaiting a hearing on charges of immigration fraud.

title: FAIRFIELD SINGLES LAMENT SOCIAL PLIGHT
description: Despite years of corporate growth, attracting thousands of young executives, the suburbs remain largely bereft of social opportunities for singles.

title: HURRICANE MAKES RETURN VISIT TO SHORE AND STALLS
description: Hurricane Juan made a return visit ashore today, then stalled again, knocking down a third oil rig as its heavy rains and winds of 85 miles an hour whipped waves 20 feet high and drove tides up to 10 feet above normal.

title: Toshiba Factory
description: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it would make telecommunications products and medical equipment in a California factory. Toshiba will invest $37.2 million for the plant and sales offices in Arvin, Calif. The plant, which should begin operations in the fall of 1986, is expected to employ 500 people and will make products such as X-ray diagnostic equipment.

title: AFTERNOON TEAS ARE STILL FLOURISHING
description: PERHAPS it's the wearisome pace of metropolitan life or the cooler weather, but the custom of afternoon tea, which has been enjoying a broad revival across America for the past few years, continues to be popular. There are tea shops now in the unlikeliest spots (a shopping center north of Houston, for instance), and in a dozen cities from Boston to San Francisco, hostelries are luring patrons with promises of tea and crumpets. Here in New York, one has only to walk into any of a dozen midtown hotels to find businessmen, shoppers and even punk rockers reviving themselves with a cup of hot tea and a plate of fruit tarts.

title: DON'T TOSS OUT THE HALLOWEEN PUMPKIN
description: AFTER tomorrow night, when Halloween is over and the jack-o'-lantern has finished its work of decorating the stoop and illuminating the night for trick-or-treaters, don't relegate it too quickly to the garbage can or compost heap. Pumpkin pleasures need not be over.

title: PUBLISHING: THE IMPACT OF GRONOWICZ
description: ANTONI GRONOWICZ, author of the controversial ''God's Broker,'' died Oct. 16, but the Authors League and the American Civil Liberties Union each have filed a brief in the Supreme Court asking it to review a United States Court of Appeals decision concerning him that they fear will have a pervasive and chilling effect on authors and publishers.

title: The Role of Food
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago

title: Wards to Accept Sears Credit Card
description: Montgomery Ward & Company said today that its 316 retail stores in 40 states would honor Sears, Roebuck & Company's Discover Card when the new credit card is started nationally next spring. Analysts have questioned whether Sears would be able to induce its retail competitors to accept the card, but recently the Dayton-Hudson Corporation signed up to accept the card.

title: CREDIT CARD RATES DEFENDED
description: Martha R. Seger, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that the credit card business was ''reasonably competitive'' and there was no need for a Federal ceiling on credit card interest rates.

title: NEW AMERICAN EATING PATTERN: DINE OUT, CARRY IN
description: DURING the last few years there has been a dramatic change in the eating habits of many Americans, especially working families in metropolitan areas. Increasingly, they are relying on restaurants, carryouts and caterers to provide their meals instead of cooking for themselves.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Final Rides
description: Lester Piggott, Britain's top jockey for more than 30 years, brought his British career to a close yesterday with a second-place finish aboard the favorite, Wind From the West, at a provincial meeting in Nottingham. Pigott, who had a first and two seconds in five races, all on favorites, brought his 37-year career record to 4,349 victories, 2,964 seconds and 2,390 thirds in 19,806 rides. He now plans six days of racing at Aqueduct in New York and perhaps an engagement in Australia before beginning his new career as a trainer.

title: Chain of Crashes Kills Man
description: A fire engine responding to an emergency call collided with an automobile today, sending both vehicles careening into two cars and a city bus. Michael Cherry, 28 years old, of Baltimore, was killed, and 22 people were injured. No charges were filed. The fire, in some furniture, was put out by members of another engine company.

title: SCOUTING;Gift From Tex
description: Randall (Tex) Cobb recalls in an interview with The Los Angeles Times that it was his lopsided loss to Larry Holmes three years ago that led Howard Cosell to give up boxing coverage: ''If I eliminate heart disease, if I walk on water, if I come up with a cure for crippled kids, I can't imagine a greater gift to mankind.''

title: HUTTON ORDERED BY S.E.C. TO REPAY FUNDS' INVESTORS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered the E. F. Hutton Group to reimburse investors in two of its mutual funds more than $1 million for money the agency said the investors lost because of mismanagement by Hutton.

title: THE SCREEN: 'FLANAGAN'
description: SOME excellent New York actors are marooned on a bleak desert island called ''Flanagan,'' which is technically a movie but more accurately just movie-making. It's the work of people possessing more nerve than talent, playing with a camera and with a budget that most independent film makers would kill for.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: COLUMBIA GIVES CABOT PRIZES FOR JOURNALISM IN AMERICAS
description: Columbia University yesterday named four recipients of the 47th annual Maria Moors Cabot Prizes in inter-American journalism, to be presented at a ceremony tomorrow.

title: U.S. SAYS SEAMAN WILL RETURN TO SOVIET
description: A Soviet seaman who was returned to his ship by American officials will go back to the Soviet Union, at his request, the State Department said today.

title: Why Mess Up a Good Thing Like Amtrak?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombings in Chile
description: Four people were wounded in bombings Monday night, including blasts that damaged the offices of a United States-owned mining company, an international communications company and a fruit export company, the police said today.

title: WARNING BY ARAFAT: PEACE WILL NOT EXIST WITHOUT THE P.L.O.
description: Yasir Arafat angrily rejected American conditions for his participation in Middle East peace negotiations today and warned that there would be no peace if the Palestine Liberation Organization was left out.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Mystery Youth Is Man With a Past, Police Say
description: A young man who had arrived at a bus station with a note signed ''Mommy,'' indicating he had been abandoned, and who convinced experts he could neither speak nor hear has been identified as a convict, the police said today.

title: Curtain Call Looms For 'Treasure Houses'
description: Last-minute lighting and makeup were being applied today to the latest multipart dramatic import from Britain, an entire masterpiece theater unto itself, the ''Treasure Houses of Britain'' exhibition that Americans will begin strolling through Sunday at the National Gallery of Art.

title: Dirty Money' Curbs Asked
description: Administration officials urged Congress today to make ''money laundering'' a Federal offense and to stiffen penalties against banks that do not report large cash transactions. Assistant Attorney General Stephen Trott told the Senate Judiciary Committee that organized crime uses banks and other businesses to make billions of dollars obtained from drug trafficking and other illegal activities look as though it came from legal sources. The law now requires banks to report cash transactions over $10,000 but ''contains no sanctions for washing dirty money,'' he said. David Queen, Acting Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, said the present law is not strong enough. The officials urged Congress to raise the minimum penalty for not reporting large cash transactions to $25,000, from $10,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Let me suggest that over the long haul, the Federal Government simply can't raise revenue any faster than by cutting tax rates and then cutting them again. So it doesn't make much sense to blame the deficit on tax cuts, and even less to ask for economy-busting tax hikes as a cure. The deficit is, quite clearly, caused by over-spending.'' - President Reagan, endorsing a bill to require a balanced budget in five years. [B6:3.]

title: ISLANDERS LOSE IN THIRD PERIOD
description: The Islanders lost tonight for the first time in five games, and they might have pulled it out were it not for some stalwart goalkeeping by the Los Angeles Kings. Yet, for the second time in a week, the Islanders were chastised by one of their bosses for a lack of effort.

title: Dow Surges on Volcker's Remarks
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday on Wall Street and the Dow Jones industrial average finished fractionally below its record levels. Traders said the improvement was due to a strong rally in the bond market and remarks by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, on monetary policy. His statements were interpreted favorably in the financial community.

title: Hartford National To Buy Provident
description: The Hartford National Corporation said that it would buy The Provident Institution for Savings for $78.8 million, adding the nation's oldest mutual savings bank to its list of recent acquisitions. Under terms of a definitive agreement approved by directors of both banks, the Connecticut-based holding company will pay $21 for each of the Boston-based thrift institution's 3.75 million outstanding shares of stock.

title: GROUP SAYS SHELTERS REFUSED MORE THAN 20 HOMELESS MEN
description: A group of advocates for the homeless charged yesterday that the city turned away more than 20 homeless men who sought shelter Monday night, the coldest night of the fall.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Colonial Penn Chief Welcomes Utility Tie
description: There is nothing unusual about the pairing of an insurance concern and an electric utility company to John J. MacWilliams, chairman and chief executive of the Colonial Penn Group.

title: 3 EUROPEANS AND 5 AMERICANS SET FOR LAUNCHING OF SHUTTLE TODAY
description: A space shuttle mission conducted primarily by West German scientists is set for launching here at noon Wednesday, and both American and German space officials emphasize the flight's importance as a step toward a major European role in the space station being planned for the 1990's.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Promising Signs
description: Specialists at a Miami hospital, saying it would be several days before they could determine the extent of the neck injuries suffered by Marc Buoniconti, said yesterday that the the Citadel linebacker had some sensation in his shoulders, an optimistic sign that he might escape full paralysis. Buoniconti, the 19-year-old son of the former Dolphin linebacker Nick Buoniconti, suffered the injury in a game against East Tennessee last Saturday. He was transferred early yesterday to Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;Georgia Bonds For 2 Projects
description: The Georgia Development Authority is offering $200 million of pollution control revenue bonds for the Oglethorpe Power Corporation's share of the Hatch and Vogtle nuclear power plants.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Shared Applause
description: The audience cheers many of Lily Tomlin's antics during her one-woman show, ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe.'' But during a recent performance, the applause was not all for Miss Tomlin.

title: Khan Pursues Title in Squash
description: Jahangir Khan of Pakistan, the world's top squash-racquets player, will be among the players seeking the title at the Chivas Regal Open this week at Hunter College.

title: MARATHON OIL UNIT GAINS
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its net income dropped 34.6 percent in the third quarter from the same period in 1984.

title: Indian Politician Is Slain
description: Yash Pal, a member of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, was shot to death today by two gunmen in the Punjab, the Press Trust of India reported. The slaying was the third of a Congress Party member in the Punjab in two weeks.

title: Of Budgets Known and Loved
description: After everyone had downed a drink or two and the $11 hot buffet lunch, Roy F. Gootenberg, seated at the head table, eased into his usual impish exercise in group nostalgia, a session not unlike the format of a Quaker meeting.

title: Civil Rights Commission, From Watchdog to Lap Dog
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVISER TO U.S. DESEGREGATION STUDY QUITS, SAYING IT'S BIASED
description: A University of Chicago professor monitoring a Federal study of school desegregation resigned today, charging that the study was technically flawed and biased against busing.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Economics by Phone
description: It's the middle of the night. You can't sleep. You toss in bed, wondering if the consumer price index is up 2.3 percent or 3.2 percent.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;Atkinson Claimed
description: The St. Louis Cardinals claimed Jess Atkinson, the place-kicker who was placed on waivers by the Giants on Monday, and waived the veteran Neil O'Donoghue, who missed field-goal attempts of 28, 42 and 33 yards during St. Louis's 20-10 loss Sunday to the Houston Oilers. In eight games this season, the Irish-born O'Donoghue had been successful on 10 of 18 field-goal attempts and was 19 for 19 on extra points. ''The thing that I'll always remember about Neil O'Donoghue was the unique attitude that he displayed. He was really a team man,'' said the Cardinals' coach, Jim Hanifan. Atkinson, who played for Maryland, succeeded on 10 of 15 field-goal attempts and ran 14 yards for a touchdown off a fake field-goal lateral while filling in for the injured Ali Haji-Sheikh.

title: 2 RIDE THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL SMOOTHLY
description: While Peter Shapiro, the Democratic candidate for governor, stalks him at toxic-waste sites around the state and plumbs for support in city streets, Governor Kean pursues his own re-election by skillfully juggling campaign appearances with events that highlight the fact he is the incumbent, including an appearance as a stand-in for Woodrow Wilson.

title: Put Susan B. Anthony to Work on the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Table Manners
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Chamber Players in Concert
description: Four members of the American Chamber Players, a nine-member repertory ensemble, will make their New York debut next Tuesday at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall, 57th Street east of Seventh Avenue. The musicians - Edmund Battersby, Alexis Galperine, Miles Hoffman and Peter Wiley - will play works by Beethoven, Debussy, Faure and George Rochberg. Tickets are $9. Information: 247-7800.

title: A POLITICIAN, DIPLOMAT AND ACTOR
description: John Davis Lodge, a former Governor of Connecticut, member of the House of Representatives and Ambassador to Spain, Argentina and Switzerland, died last night of an apparent heart attack as he was finishing a speech here to members of the Women's National Republican Club.

title: FEDERAL JURY GETS ISLANDS LIBEL CASE
description: A seven-year-old libel case, in which the President of the world's smallest and richest republic sued America's largest newspaper chain for $40 million, went to the jury in Federal District Court here today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Shift Seen as Signal At Philipp Brothers
description: By naming Martin N. Kaufman and Henry S. Schachar as chairman and president, respectively, of Philipp Brothers, its commodity trading subsidiary, Phibro-Salomon Inc. sent a signal to the financial world.

title: Atlantic Unity Is a Two-Way Street
description: President Reagan has gone to great pains, in the aftermath of the Achille Lauro incident, to reconcile the United States with Italy. We have, it seems, chosen to forget the Italians' questionable reaction to our intercept of the Egyptian plane and even their release of the Palestinian terrorist Mohammed Abbas. Why has the Administration so undermined its own triumph? It is apparently more concerned with ''Atlantic unity'' than with the pursuit of our own national security.

title: Reuters Raises Stake
description: Reuters, the news and information organization, has raised its holding in Visnews, the international television news agency, to 55 percent, from 33.3 percent, Visnews said today. Reuters Holdings P.L.C. increased its stake in the London-based company by purchasing shares held by the British Broadcasting Corporation for $3.7 million, Visnews said.

title: SUPERTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: LEADERS IN ITALY AGREE TO REVIVE CABINET THAT SPLIT ON HIJACKING
description: Prime Minister-designate Bettino Craxi announced today that Italian political leaders had agreed to revive the five-party coalition Government that collapsed two weeks ago over the Achille Lauro affair.

title: TACO VIVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 15
description: b-Net income.

title: ENDATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on sales of properties of $1,162,909 for the quarter and $1,280,929 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains on sales of properties of $1,257,605 for the quarter and $1,621,973 for the 9 months. The share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in September 1985.

title: MEDICARE-GLASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $118,000 relating to the closing of the company's Deep discount operation. c-Net income

title: CARDINAL DISTRIBUTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
RAYCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WAYNE-GOSSARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: RECORD INDUSTRY SEEKS SURCHARGES ON TAPING
description: The record industry, claiming losses of $1.5 billion a year to home taping, asked Congress today to increase the cost of many tape recorders and blank tapes.

title: A GALA FOR 'TREASURE HOUSES OF BRITAIN'
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -

title: GREAT LAKES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DU PONT DE NEMOURS, E I & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Trade Surplus Gains in Japan
description: Japan's trade surplus has jumped more than 25 percent, to nearly $30 billion in the first half of this financial year, as the yen continues to strengthen, according to official figures released today.

title: TENNECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $240 million for the quarter and the nine months to reflect the write-off of substantially all of the company's investment in the Great Plains coal gasification and Cathedral Bluff shale oil projects. c-Net income.

title: CYCLOPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,766,000 for the quarter and 9 months from an insurance settlement and a gain of $5,573,000 for the 9 months from an accounting change.

title: President to Undergo Postoperative Tests
description: President Reagan will stop at Bethesda Naval Hospital Friday for ''a routine postoperative visit'' to assess his recovery from colon cancer surgery in mid-July, the White House said today.

title: 'Shoah' Screening Change
description: The screening schedule of ''Shoah'' at Cinema Studio 1 and 2, Broadway at 66th Street, has been changed. Part 1 of the nine and a half-hour film on the Holocaust can be seen at Cinema Studio 1 daily at 1:30 and 7 P.M. Part 2 is being shown at Cinema Studio 2 daily at 12:45 and 6:30 P.M. Previously, Part 1 had been shown Wednesdays through Saturdays at both theaters, and Part 2 Sundays through Tuesdays.

title: Punjab State Orders 456 Detainees Freed
description: The Punjab state government today ordered the release of 456 people arrested under federal antiterrorist laws in the Sikh-dominated state.

title: UNICORP AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LaROY B. THOMPSON
description: LaRoy B. Thompson, senior vice president and treasurer of the University of Rochester since 1970. died Oct. 23 at Park Ridge Hospital in Rochester. He was 65 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: The Fox (and Camel and Centipede)
description: A friend who danced for two hours through Greenwich Village's streets in last year's Halloween parade as an orange-coated fox found that, peering through the eyeholes of his muzzly mask, he took a new view of other people and himself.

title: Chevron to Sell Gulf Headquarters
description: The Chevron Corporation said today that it has agreed to sell the former headquarters of its Gulf Corporation subsidiary to a group of New York investors for an undisclosed sum.

title: How Do You Say Amazin'?
description: President Reagan does not believe everything he hears, but he did seem to believe that there was no word in Russian for ''freedom.'' In an interview Tuesday with the BBC, the President said, ''I'm no linguist, but I have been told that in the Russian language there isn't even a word for freedom.'' Yesterday at the White House press briefing, Larry Speakes, the spokesman, was asked whether the President had become aware that there was such a word in Russian.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for Year to July 27
CLC OF AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extrainary gain of $933,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: E.E.C. Curbs Steel Subsidies
description: Industry ministers of the European Economic Community agreed today to reduce subsidies next year for their battered steel industry.

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including extraordinary tax credits of $13,000 for the quarter and $1,018,000 for the 9 months.

title: BUTLER, JOHN O CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Specter of Tax Revision Prompts Unusual Deals
description: The specter of changes in Federal tax laws that would severely limit the amount of tax-exempt bonds that could be sold after the end of the year is spurring businesses and governments into proposing several large, unusual financings.

title: U.S. SAYS IT FEARS PHILIPPINES FACES A WIDE CIVIL WAR
description: The United States said today that the Philippines was headed toward ''civil war on a massive scale'' within a few years unless the Government made drastic internal changes.

title: Peru Extends Freeze
description: The government announced an extension of a freeze on local dollar accounts until April 30, 1986, to protect the country's foreign reserves as the result of a reported decision by United States banking regulators that would lower Peru's credit rating.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $13,868,000 from the shutdown of a plant.

title: DRUG DEFENDANT TERMED EX-BOSS OF SICILY MAFIA
description: A key informer testified in a major narcotics trial in Manhattan yesterday that one of the defendants was the former ''boss of the commission'' of Mafia leaders in Sicily.

title: TRIMEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THEATER: 'TATTERDEMALION,' A MUSICAL
description: LET'S hear it for the chorus, the two women and two men who lift the spirits of ''Tatterdemalion'' every time they get a chance at stage center of the Douglas Fairbanks Theater. At their liveliest they seem like a cast of thousands.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Andrew J. Quinn, Stanley Rygor and Raymond E. Zipko have been elected senior vice presidents, financial advertising, at Doremus & Co.

title: Judge Refuses to Delay Arizona Sanctuary Trial
description: A judge today refused to delay the trial of 11 people charged with smuggling aliens into the United States and providing them sanctuary.

title: CARLING O'KEEFE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JOHN DAVIS LODGE, 82, EX-ENVOY AND CONNECTICUT GOVERNOR, DIES
description: John Davis Lodge, a former Governor of Connecticut, member of the House of Representatives and Ambassador to Spain, Argentina and Switzerland, died Tuesday night, apparently of a heart attack, while giving a speech to the Women's National Republican Club in Manhattan.

title: ARUNDEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $415,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $355,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: TITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $318,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operationd of $9,726,,000. d-Net income, after a loss of $155,000 from discontinued operations.

title: EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $523,000 for the quarter and $874,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary gain of $295,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the termination of a pension plan.

title: A COOLER GEORGE C. SCOTT STAYS BUSY
description: He has long been notorious for behavior that ranges from the merely curmudgeonly to the truly alarming, his rages having run to the destruction of entire hotel rooms, not to mention himself, as on one memorable night when he punched his fist into a mirror between acts, gouging his hand so badly he had to finish the play wearing a rubber glove to collect the blood.

title: Mutual Fund Sales Triple
description: While mutual fund sales have declined some from their summer highs, sales in September were still more than three times as high as a year ago, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Net sales for the month, minus redemptions, were $7.03 billion, compared with $2.26 billion a year ago.

title: 2 GIRLS MAKE HISTORY IN COURT, IF NOT ON GRIDIRON
description: For the handful of New York-area girls dreaming of playing high-school football, the names of Elizabeth Balsley and Jacqueline Lantz have become synonymous this fall with erosion of legal barriers to their participating in a sport historically open only to boys.

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Customers Get Checks From Volume Investors
description: The customers of the Volume Investors Corporation, a commodities brokerage company in receivership, received checks yesterday repaying them slightly more than 50 percent of the value of their accounts with Volume when it was closed last March. It was the first distribution of funds the customers have received since their accounts were frozen at that time.

title: CAMBRIAN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Poland May Release Political Prisoners
description: A Communist front organization has urged the Government to consider releasing political prisoners as a gesture of national reconciliation geared to a new parliamentary term.

title: Marching for Pretoria
description: South Africa's white minority Government may have its American critics these days, but it has just pulled off a remarkable public-relations coup in this country. A leading Republican, a potential candidate for President, has endorsed one of Pretoria's main policy objectives.

title: Bad Counseling for Poor Women
description: Since 1970, millions of poor women have turned to the 4,000 clinics receiving funds under the Federal family-planning program for advice about contraceptives, pregnancy tests and abortion counseling. The program has saved those women much pain, anguish and ignorance.

title: 2 KILLED IN SHOPPING MALL AS WOMAN FIRES ON CROWD
description: A woman dressed in combat fatigues drove to a suburban mall this afternoon and opened fire with a semiautomatic rifle, killing two people and wounding eight others, the police said.

title: DREYER'S GRAND ICE CREAM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
C.D. YIELDS RISE A BIT IN WEEK
description: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds showed slight increases for the week ended yesterday, while bank money market accounts held firm for the second consecutive week.

title: CHILDREN VIDEOTAPED IN ANTI-APDUCTION EFFORT
description: Thousands of elementary school students are expected to participate in a local video identification program in a campaign against child abduction.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a drop in earnings at Merrill Lynch & Company for the third quarter omitted necessary information about the corresponding quarter last year. The company had a large one-time gain then; if that gain were set aside, earnings in the 1985 period would show an increase of 54 percent, to $38.4 million.

title: BARON DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $143,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $761,000 and a tax credit of $648,000.

title: U.S. Reportedly Bars Testimony on Deficit
description: The White House told the head of the Veterans Administration not to testify on how the Senate's plan to eliminate the deficit would affect veterans, a Congressman said today.

title: SILICON VALLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEAN'S STRATEGY FOR FOR ANOTHER TERM: MAKING THE 'NICE GUY' FINISH FIRST
description: To begin, the word along the hustings seems true: Tom Kean really is ''a nice guy.'' Even his most ardent critics give him that.

title: ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $358,000 for the quarter and $876,000 for the 9 months.

title: 3D-QUARTER LOSS AT BETHLEHEM
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation today reported a loss of $76.8 million for the third quarter and said that it would omit its common stock dividend due for payment in December. It was the first quarterly dividend omission in 46 years.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Tuesday about the innovative curriculum of the Red Bank, N.J., elementary schools misstated the source of their workbooks and other educational materials. The materials are prepared by staff members, who draw on a variety of commercial sources. None of the material used is from Mastery Education Corporation.

title: CONFEREES REACH SNAG ON BUDGET-BALANCING PLAN
description: Splitting sharply in a political argument over who wants to cut the deficit the most, House and Senate negotiators bogged down tonight in their effort to reach a compromise on a bill mandating a balanced budget by 1991.

title: Cobb Knocked Out
description: The way the fight crowd had it figured out, all Randall (Tex) Cobb had to do to earn a title bout against the heavyweight champion, Michael Spinks, was to score a decisive victory over Dee Collier, an obscure Los Angeles heavyweight, in their 10-round bout in Reseda, Calif., Tuesday night. It didn't work out that way. Cobb, looking more like a punching bag than a heavyweight contender, was knocked out in the first round after a severe battering by Collier.

title: TOP ITALIAN COURT UPHOLDS ARREST WARRANT FOR ABBAS
description: Italy's highest court today upheld an arrest order issued by Sicilian magistrates for a Palestinian official who the United States says masterminded the hijacking of the Italian cruise liner Achille Lauro.

title: S.E.C. Upheld On Bank Rule
description: A Federal District Court today upheld the Securities and Exchange Commission's authority to require banks that offer brokerage services to register with the commission as securities brokers.

title: ASSOCIATED BANC-CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Sept. 17. Year-ago results have been restated for the acquisition of a bank in July.

title: AN ODYSSEY WITH AFGHAN REBELS: TRANSPORTING VITAL ARMS SUPPLY
description: Fluttering green pennants over the graves of men and the bones of camels and horses glistening in moonlight mark one of the most dangerous parts of an Afghan rebel trail used to bring military supplies to the country's northern provinces.

title: BEIRUT SAID TO ASK TALKS WITH ISRAEL
description: President Amin Gemayel is trying to reopen military negotiations about southern Lebanon with Israel under United Nations auspices, and has sent a senior aide to Damascus for consultations with Syrian officials, Arab diplomats say.

title: Doubleday and the Deficit
description: Members of Congress often seize on passing events of some note to extol the virtues of their states, cities or towns.

title: Lotus General Manager
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said that Mitchell Kapor, its founder and chairman, will assume the additional responsibility of general manager for Lotus's core software products - 1-2-3, Symphony and Jazz. Mr. Kapor replaces Charles Digate, who will move to the international division as vice president and general manager.

title: 9 INDICTED IN MASSACHUSETTS RACKETS
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted nine men from Springfield, Mass., on racketeering charges, accusing them of using threats of violence to expand the power of an underworld organization in western Massachusetts and the adjoining Albany area.

title: CINCINNATI MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1985.

title: DU PONT'S NET DECLINES 10.5%
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter of 1985 fell 10.5 percent as revenues slipped 1.7 percent.

title: WEIMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $70,000 for the quarter and $270,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $170,000.

title: UNITED PRESIDENTIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Montgomery Out
description: Wilbert Montgomery, the running back who was signed by the Detroit Lions to take the place of the injured Billy Sims, was placed on the injured reserve list yesterday. A. J. (Jam) Jones, the former Texas running back who was waived by the Los Angeles Rams last month, was signed by the Lions to take his place. Montgomery has been out of the lineup since suffering a knee injury against the San Francisco 49ers two weeks ago. He will be out at least four more weeks.

title: Debt Issues
description: Beverly Enterprises has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $400 million of zero coupon convertible notes, due 2003, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole underwriter.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Net income

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS
description: Haunted Greenhouse, New York Botanical Garden, 212-220-8700.

title: TELEVISION DRIVE TO GET OUT VOTE BEGUN BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday began a $150,000 television advertising campaign aimed at getting out the vote in next Tuesday's mayoral election.

title: FARM VOTE IN SENATE
description: The Senate today narrowly defeated and Administration-backed effort to add budget restraint to the farm bill.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Golden State Warriors, at Oakland, Calif., 10:30 P.M. Golden State hasn't been able to come to contract terms with two players who are listed on the all-star ballot: Purvis Short, the seasoned forward, and Chris Mullin, the rookie guard from St. John's.

title: Anheuser Danish Pact
description: United Breweries Group of Denmark has signed an agreement with the Anheuser-Busch Companies of the United States for the import and distribution of Carlsberg beer, United Breweries said in a statement. A United official said the agreement would take effect in November and replace an import arrangement with All Brand Importers. He declined to give financial details or say how much beer was involved.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $127,000 for the quarter and $202,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $615,000 for the quarter and $354,000 for the year. d-Net loss.

title: BRITAIN IN ACCORD WITH U.S. ON FULL ROLE IN 'STAR WARS'
description: Britain's Defense Secretary announced today that he and his American counterpart, Caspar W. Weinberger, had overcome the difficulties blocking Britain's full participation in the Reagan Administration's research program on an antiballistic missile shield.

title: ARTIST'S DESIGNS FOR PLASTIC DISHES
description: HER inspiration was Picasso's ceramic plates, so Janna W. Josephson, left, decided she would do her own versions, mainly because she needed everyday dishes for herself. Mrs. Josephson then arranged to have the 10-inch melamine dishes made in quantity. A selection of the plate patterns is now available, at $16 apiece, at Frank McIntosh at Henri Bendel; the Gracie Mansion Gallery Museum Store, 337 East 10th Street, and Budding Affair, 51 Hudson Street, at Duane Street.

title: REFAC TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT CORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Batting Like Billy
description: The St. Louis Cardinals hit only .185 in the World Series, but one of them -a pitcher, no less - broke out of the slump when he went to bat against a restroom during the seventh-game loss Sunday night.

title: Free the Helms Hostages
description: Two Americans have been held hostage for five months, harming U.S. foreign policy. The hostage-taker is Senator Jesse Helms; his captives are Winston Lord and James Spain, whom President Reagan wants to send as ambassadors to China and Sri Lanka. Yet as the months go by, Mr. Reagan seems hardly to have raised a finger to end their captivity. Perhaps a humanitarian plea from their families would be timely, before Mr. Helms hijacks the whole State Department.

title: PARLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $61,784.

title: OPERA: NEW MUSSORGSKY PRINCIPALS
description: ONE can pick at flaws in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Mussorgsky's ''Khovanshchina'' - big cuts, a sometimes too-plain production, an unfamiliar epic sung without supertitles in a language most Americans don't understand. But this is still a grand operatic experience, and the four new cast members introduced Tuesday evening hardly blunted its impact.

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ferment on K Street
description: It may be that there is no free lunch in Washington. But there was free yogurt for dozens of lunch-hour strollers downtown at 18th and K Streets yesterday when, for reasons passersby could only guess at, a man opened the back of a refrigerator truck and started giving away cartons of the stuff, tossing them into the crowd, which asked no questions, just took the curds and went away.

title: TOP STATE COURT BLOCKS REFERENDUM ON S.I. BASE
description: A yearlong effort by antinuclear groups to block a Navy base in New York City by bringing it to a referendum vote was halted today as the state's highest court ruled that the referendum would violate state law and could not appear on the ballot.

title: HERS
description: ''THAT one is a bum. That one is a drug addict.'' Isabelle, at 5, has a firm grip on verities that have eluded me these last few years. I am walking her and my daughter through the five blocks of sidewalk from kindergarten to ballet class. Isabelle is our guide. We've walked around three men lying asleep on the sidewalk, stepping over a streak of urine that has made its way from one man to the curb. (''Are they asleep? Are they sick? Are they dead? What's the matter with them?'' my daughter asks. ''They're bums,'' Isabelle explains.) We've declined to give money to a woman who has asked us for 25 cents. I excuse myself to myself by saying that my hands are full with the children's hands.

title: DEVELOPERS PAYING NEW FEES FOR PUBLIC SERVICES
description: Pinched by sharp cutbacks in state and Federal financing, local governments around the nation are demanding that private developers pay a larger share of the cost of expanding community road networks, sewer systems and other public services that are burdened as a result of the developers' projects.

title: OFFICIALS DISPUTE MOVE SIEGE ORDERS
description: The Fire Commissioner said today that he accepted ''full responsibility'' for delaying fighting the fire that destroyed a neighborhood after the May 13 confrontation between the police and the radical group Move.

description: Marilyn Klinghoffer, whose husband was slain in the hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise ship, delivered an impassioned plea here today for a worldwide commitment to combat terrorism, which she called ''the gravest danger confronting the civilized world.''

title: SOUTH AFRICAN RIGHTISTS GAIN IN VOTE

title: Fall in Oil Output Creating Troubles for Moscow
description: The Soviet Union's oil production, which began declining last year, has fallen to 1979 levels this year, creating major domestic and international complications for the Kremlin, according to Western diplomats and economists.

title: Heart Recipient Worsens
description: Anthony Mandia, who received a human heart Monday after living for 11 days with the Penn State artificial heart, has an inflamed pancreas, a potentially fatal condition, a spokesman for the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center said today. The patient was listed in critical condition and was downgraded from stable to unstable.

title: POP: EARTHA KIT AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: MADONNA'S hit record ''Material Girl'' may have brought the fortune-hunting siren back into pop fashion, but Eartha Kitt still remains American pop's archetypal golddigger. The singer, who made her first major New York concert appearance in many years at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday, is 57 years old and still very glamorous.

title: NETS TOP PACERS IN 3 OVERTIMES
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, in one of the finest games of his eight pro seasons, scored a career-high 38 points tonight as the Nets rallied for a 147-138 triple overtime victory over the Indiana Pacers. The 30-year-old playmaker, who overcame a drug problem to became the league's comeback player of the year last season, refused to let the Nets lose.

title: Before and After
description: DeLoss Dodds, the athletic director at Texas, cites the 55-17 drubbing by Iowa in the Freedom Bowl last year as a reason why the Longhorns will now take a long and hard look at any postseason invitations: ''There was some feeling before that bowl that we shouldn't go. There was overwhelming feeling after that bowl that we shouldn't have gone.''

title: U.S. Insisting On Steel Pact
description: The United States is ready to take trade measures against the Common Market if negotiations with the 10-nation European bloc fail to produce a steel import agreement by Thursday's deadline, officials said today.

title: ARGENTINE PRESIDENT SAYS TERRORIST AIM TO OUST DEMOCRACY
description: President Raul Alfonsin said tonight that ''professionals of violence who had been left without a function'' in a democratic Argentina were making an ''absurd'' attempt to destabilize his Government.

title: School Board Data Still Due From 49
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that all but 49 of the 284 members of the city's community school boards had now complied with requirements that they file financial disclosure statements.

title: 200 FOREIGN BARRIERS TO U.S. EXPORTS LISTED
description: The Reagan Administration catalogued for Congress today more than 200 foreign trade barriers that it said impede American exports, everything from soda ash to telecommunications equipment.

title: An Eerie Visitor To Biology Class
description: The rumor had circulated for days among horrified upper-school students at the Greenwich (Conn.) Country Day School: the ninth-grade biology class would be dissecting a human cadaver.

title: Senate Panel Supports Testing of TV Coverage
description: Radio and television coverage of action on the Senate floor, long resisted as a threat to the chamber's traditions, moved a step closer to approval Tuesday.

title: SOVIET ANNOUNCES FIRST CIVILIAN AGENCY FOR SPACE PROGRAM

title: 'CURRENTS' LOOKS AT WOMEN AND POWER
description: IN the first program of its second season, ''Currents,'' the public affairs series that returns to Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight, takes on the interesting question of whether today's women can enter the corridors of power that have traditionally been men's domains without losing the softer traits and more human values that the feminist movement has claimed for itself. The half hour, with Marty Goldensohn once again presiding and Jane Petroff doing the legwork, consists of a brief and familiar documentary on the history of women's rise to political eminence, a few interviews and a panel discussion.

title: Pacific-Maxxam Deal Challenged
description: Three grandchildren of a former chairman of the Pacific Lumber Company filed suit here today in Federal District Court against Pacific and the Maxxam Group, seeking to stop their proposed merger. The suit charges that the companies planned to allow Maxxam to acquire Pacific at a price below its true value by unlawfully avoiding a Pacific requirement that an 80 percent vote by shareholders must approve any transaction made with a shareholder who has 5 percent or more of the common stock.

description: Kirby Grant, who starred as a wealthy Western rancher in the 1950's television series ''Sky King,'' died in a traffic accident today while on his way to view a space shuttle launching in Cape Canaveral, state troopers said. He was 73 years old.

description: Despite some of the lowest mortgage rates in years, housing sales fell 2.6 percent in September, the Government reported today. It was the second consecutive monthly decline.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SCARE TIME Tonight, witching hours really conjure up visions of witches, not to mention goblins and ghosts and kids trick-or-treating. Grown-ups have taken up Halloween, in no less a fun-loving serious way, as may be verified by a trip tonight to the Theater for the New City, 162 Second Avenue, at 10th Street (254-1109).

title: Kentucky Inquiry
description: The University of Kentucky, which has already begun an internal investigation, said yesterday that the N.C.A.A. also would investigate allegations that former basketball players at the college had accepted cash and other gifts from boosters. The statement, issued by Ray Hornback, vice president for university relations, said David Berst, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's enforcement director, had informed Kentucky officials of the impending investigation.

title: I.M.F. and Mexico In Post-Quake Talk
description: International Monetary Fund officials are here this week to discuss Mexico's economic problems. The outcome could have a significant impact on how the country decides to finance reconstruction programs in the wake of the September earthquakes. It is estimated that more than 5,500 people were killed and that damages total $4 billion.

title: 6 Accused by U.S. Of Cocaine Selling
description: Six people were indicted yesterday on charges that they conspired to distribute $50 million worth of cocaine in the New York metropolitan area between 1980 and 1984.

title: TWIG FURNITURE: MAKING REPAIRS
description: THE fashion for furniture with a framework carved to resemble the natural growth of trees, used both indoors and in the garden, started in the mid-18th century in England. But it was left to the Arts and Crafts Movement there in the 19th century to develop this type of furniture, using unhewn timber and roots of fallen trees, leaving the natural growth pattern of the wood to dictate design.

title: How Do You Say Home?
description: Vice President Bush is leaving tomorrow for a four-day visit to Texas, which he counts as his home state, but where he has no home of his own. Mr. Bush was born in Massachussetts, grew up in Connecticut, then moved to Texas, where he owned an oil business and represented a Houston district in Congress before he became Vice President. He then sold his home, but bought a plot of land in the Tanglewood section of Houston.

description: Frank B. Hall, an insurance brokerage based in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., said yesterday that it would suspend its quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share beginning in the first quarter of 1986.

title: MARION TANNER, KNOWN AS MODEL FOR 'MAME'
description: Marion Tanner, self-described as ''the ultimate Greenwich Village eccentric'' and the apparent model for the madcap fictional character Auntie Mame, died here yesterday. She was 94 years old and had suffered a stroke two months ago.

title: CONTRACTING ACCORD AVERTS STRIKE AT A.T.&T.
description: Working against a midnight strike deadline, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today reached agreement with the Communication Workers of America on the practice of using outside nonunion employees.

title: Officer Is Promoted At Insurance Brokerage
description: Fred S. James, the insurance brokerage firm that over the summer was sold by the Transamerica Corporation to the Sedgwick Group P.L.C. in London, said yesterday that Richard C. Nevins had been named chief operating officer.

title: Tailoring Of Games Magazine
description: FIRST there was segmented marketing. Then came marketing to segmented segments.
