title: T.W.A. May Adopt An a la Carte Situation
description: Trans World Airlines, which will officially part with Ogilvy & Mather in three months, might very well go to an a la carte situation thereafter, Erwin D. Kaufman, staff vice president, advertising and marketing programs, confirmed yesterday.

title: 'Fire Retardant' Found Flammable in Subway
description: The Transit Authority spent more than $4.5 million on a fire retardant, used on subway track ties, that in fact readily burns and emits thick smoke, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1985
description: International

title: Amoco Purchase
description: The Amoco Corporation's Amoco Oil Company said it agreed to acquire 72 Chicago-area service stations from the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: Israeli, at U.N., Says Arabs Supply South Africa With Oil
description: Israel accused the Arab oil-producing countries today of providing South Africa with 95 percent of its oil.

title: Divestiture in South Africa May Become an Investment Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: General Public
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation said that rate changes expected to go into effect around Nov. 8 because of the return of Three Mile Island Unit One to operation would reduce electric rates to customers by about $78.9 million a year. It said that Three Mile Island One has met operating criteria by operating at 35 percent capacity for 100 consecutive hours, and its subsidiaries have given 10 days' notice of rate changes. General Public said that the changes are expected to increase base rates about $99.2 million a year but cut energy charges $178.1 million.

title: Progress Is Reported In Uganda Peace Talks
description: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya said today that ''tremendous progress'' had been made in peace talks here between Uganda's military Government and the country's main rebel group.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the United States Steel Corporation's earnings misstated the percentage drop for the third quarter. The drop was 34.6 percent.

title: SENATORS PRAISE NOMINATION OF BUCKLEY TO FEDERAL BENCH
description: President Reagan's nomination of former Senator James L. Buckley of New York to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia was warmly received by the Senate Judiciary Committee today and was expected to win committee approval tomorrow.

Monsanto Nylon
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it would gradually withdraw from the producton of nylon yarns for apparel and hosiery, saying the operations had not met profitability targets and little growth was expected. The action is part of a restructuring that will reduce the chemical company's work force by about 900 workers, mostly at two nylon plants, in Florida and South Carolina. The St. Louis-based company said it would continue to make nylon products for use in industry, carpeting and home furnishings.

title: 21 PEOPLE ARRESTED IN DRUG CRACKDOWN AT PLAZA ON 43D ST.
description: Twenty-one people were arrested yesterday during a police crackdown on drug sales and use in the outdoor plaza at the southeast corner of 43d Street and the Avenue of the Americas, a block from Bryant Park, the police said.

title: Stake in Triton
description: Claremont Petroleum N.L. of Australia said it has a 5.5 percent stake in Triton Energy Corporation and may seek partners to join ''in acquiring control of Triton.''

title: DEMAND SUSTAINS BOND RALLY
description: The bond market rally was sustained in active trading yesterday, as strong investor demand for new Treasury issues and hopes for an easing in Federal Reserve monetary policy lifted bond prices to the highest levels since early June.

description: The year-ago figures were restated for income tax benefits realized.

title: COMPARISIONS TO BO CAN'T HURT BOO BOO

description: Pierre Larouche sat on a concrete floor, stretching, when the players from the visiting team's bus entered from the far end of the corridor. Larouche's head went up. ''Are they here?'' he asked. ''Are they here?''

14,800 New Jeeps Recalled
description: The American Motors Corporation has announced that it is recalling 14,800 1986-model Jeeps to check for fuel line or brake fluid problems. About 14,600 Cherokee, Wagoneer and Comanche Jeeps may have improperly connected fuel line fittings, the company said Tuesday, and 200 Grand Wagoneers, J-10 and J-20 trucks may have contaminated brake fluid. No accidents or injuries have been reported as a result of either defect, the company said.

title: LABOR FEDERATION MEETING HEARS BROCK PLEDGE TO AID UNION CAUSES
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock told organized labor today that collective bargaining was essential in a democratic society and that cooperation between unions and management was necessary to meet international competition.

title: FOR THE ELDERLY, PRIVATE CARE INCREASING
description: A GROWING number of social workers, nurses, psychologists and gerontologists are leaving nonprofit agencies to set up private geriatric care practices. The market for their services has expanded as the number of elderly people living alone and at considerable distances from their children has increased.

title: Mexico Shifts On Oil Prices
description: Mexico, the biggest single supplier of oil to the United States, announced today that it was raising the price of light crude by an average of 60 cents a barrel. The price of heavy crude will fall an average of 40 cents.

They have built Liz Claiborne Inc. into one of Seventh Avenue's success stories by designing and marketing a quality line of medium-priced clothing for working women.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dane Iorg, the Kansas City pinch-hitter who paved the way for the Royals' World Series victory by hitting the two-run, ninth-inning single that won the sixth game, led the list of major leaguers who filed for free agency yesterday. Others were Al Holland, the California Angel reliever Richie Hebner, a Chicago Cubs' infielder; Steve McCatty, the Oakland A's pitcher, and Tony Bernazard, a Cleveland Indian infielder. . . . Gene Upshaw, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, was elected a vice president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and named to its Executive Council, making him the first sports unionist to hold such high positions in the labor organization.

2 MUSIC MEN OF THE 1970'S TEAM AGAIN

They are catching a breath of fresh air after a long work session in the nondescript, one-story brick building across the street, formerly a movie house, the Royal Theater.

title: New Theory Voiced On Reluctant Whale
description: A humpback whale that prefers warm inland waters over the cool Pacific may be pregnant, a member of the whale rescue project said today.

title: PIANO: ROBERT TAUB
description: THERE are not many pianists who would consider ending the first portion of a recital with a work by Milton Babbitt, America's staunchest proponent of Serialism, but Robert Taub did just that at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. His program ran as follows: Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 570), Bartok's Sonata (1926), Babbitt's ''Tableaux'' (1973) and Chopin's 24 Preludes (Op. 28).

title: MULTIPLE COPIES OF GENE TIED TO CANCER'S SPREAD
description: Cancers grow more rapidly when their cells contain multiple copies of a known cancer gene than they do when cells have only single copies, scientists reported yesterday. title: DATASOUTH COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ROOF gutters do several important things. They carry rain and melted snow harmlessly off the roof without causing streaks and stains on shingles or siding; they prevent flooding of basements; they eliminate severe washouts of foundation plantings and nearby lawn areas. As water pours off the roof it runs along the gutter until it flows into the downspouts. If the system is properly set up, the water is then carried through underground pipes to a dry well or empties onto splash pans or other devices that disperse it several feet from the foundation.
